title: DU BOIS YARD YIELDS CLUES TO LIVES OF BLACKS IN U.S.
description: Plates and shoelaces from the backyard of the home of the civil rights pioneer W. E. B. Du Bois may yield clues to the lives of blacks in the Berkshires before the Civil War, an archeologist says.

title: A Bungled Mission to Iran And a Middleman Who Lied
description: The Tower Commission report says an American delegation, on a secret mission to Teheran last year, had not properly prepared for the trip and trusted the promises of a middleman, who lied.

title: A Burning Question
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: SHOW BIZ FOR SUPERVISOR THE last time that Brookhaven Town Supervisor Henrietta Acampora was on the stage was ''about 45 years ago,'' she said, ''when I was in high school, New Utrecht High School in Bensonhurst. We did 'Cyrano de Bergerac.' In fact, Jack Carter played Cyrano. I didn't play Rosalind, though. I was just in the group.''

title: Erin Danielson-Haskell Plans to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Melville Hanna Haskell Jr. of Santa Barbara, Calif., have announced the engagement of her daughter Erin Danielson-Haskell to Andrew Martin Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin C. Ross of Greenwich, Conn., and Stowe, Vt. The wedding is to be April 25.

title: THE OWL AND THE PUSSYCATS' FRIEND
description: IT was magical, the way he materialized on my patio at dusk in late fall, crunching the cat-cookies so noisily that it sounded like pebbles being pelted on the brick path. But he wasn't just another neighborhood stray.

title: The Shanghai Quartet To Open Debut Series
description: A performance by the Shanghai Quartet will open the fifth season of the Select Debut series tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The quartet, which is in residence at Northern Illinois University, was formed in 1983 in Shanghai.

title: Somber Silhouettes Of Winter
description: THE tones of winter in the city are as cold as the air - dull grays and stark whites. While they can bring on a shudder, they also provide a most affecting contrast for the flowing black shapes and wasp waists currently in vogue among the more avant-garde followers of fashion.

title: LOCKING IN THE STOCK OF S.R.O.'S
description: CAN housing for lower-income people be saved by a law that forbids alterations or demolitions in the privately owned buildings they occupy?

title: Star Wars and New Solutions
description: ''A Way Out of Reykjavik'' is a sad and disturbing article that exposes the presumably well-meaning but dangerous thinking that underpins much of our strategic policy (by Brent Scowcroft, John Deutch and R. James Woolsey, Jan. 25). Three influential experts, possibly wounded that their advice was not heeded by President Reagan in early 1983, are terrified by the possibility of abandoning ballistic missiles! The Reykjavik meeting revealed that this potentially dramatic first step toward dismantling the world's nuclear arsenal was, in fact, attainable. The authors are preoccupied with posing enemies (e.g. ''the expansionist totalitarian states'' and the nuclear-freeze movement) and have lost sight of the fact that we are all inhabitants of one world, that we possess the weapons to destroy our planet many times over and that we must work cooperatively with the Russians to find new solutions to our predicament. BRUCE J. McAULEY, M.D. Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Staying Home In Style
description: Suddenly, going out isn't very in.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Rancho Palos Verdes; Harcourt Sinks Marineland
description: WHEN Harcourt Brace Jovanovich bought California's oldest aquatic park last December, admirers of Marineland hoped that its past glories might soon be restored. At the time of the purchase, the Florida-based conglomerate said it had no plans to close the 33-year-old oceanarium, even though it was run-down and barely breaking even.

title: Lining Up
description: IN the scramble to recruit Southern Methodist players in the wake of the suspension of the school's football program, other Southwest Conference schools may find themselves at the back of the pack.

title: HEADED MANILA PEACE PANEL
description: Jose W. Diokno, a former Senator who headed the Government's peace negotiating panel until his illness forced him to step down, died of cancer Friday, one day after his 65th birthday.

title: Maria Pabon to Wed in June
description: Maria Mercedes Pabon, a 1985 graduate of Princeton University who is a first-year law student st the University of Pennsylvania, and Frederick Russell Treyz, a Princeton senior, plan to be married June 13, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Luis A. Pabon of Guaynabo, P.R., have announced. Mr. Treyz is a son of George I. Treyz, a professor of economics at the University of Massachusetts, and Mrs. Treyz of Amherst, Mass. Miss Pabon's father is general manager for Latin America of Technicon Instruments Corporation in Carolina, P.R.

title: ISLANDERS SCRAMBLE TO TIE THE BLUES
description: By the third period, their offense, after a sprightly beginning, had all but trickled away, and the Islanders needed a full-fledged scramble in the game's final minute to circumvent the St. Louis Blues' defensive shell and achieve a 3-3 tie tonight.

title: ARMED SERVICES MEET RECRUITING GOALS FOR START OF NEW YEAR
description: The armed services have met or exceeded their recruitment goals for the first three months of the fiscal year 1987, the Pentagon says, and have slightly improved their success in attracting high school graduates.

title: STELLAR EXPLOSION PUZZLES SCIENTISTS
description: Twinkling high over the snowcapped Andes Mountains, an exploding star relatively close to earth has added new luster to the night sky of the Southern Hemisphere. But in the four days since astronomers here discovered this new supernova, its behavior has caused growing scientific perplexity.

title: Victoria P. Moskowitz Plans to Marry April 5
description: Victoria Paula Moskowitz, an associate editor and the director of subsidiary rights at G. K. Hall & Company, a book publisher in Boston, plans to be married April 5 to Lee Hadas Glickenhaus, an associate at the Boston law firm Gaston Snow & Ely Bartlett.

title: CONCERT: A TRIBUTE TO PAUL PRICE
description: OVER the course of a career that spanned four decades, Paul Price introduced more than 400 new percussion works and distinguished himself as performer, a conductor and a teacher. Wednesday night at the Manhattan School of Music, where Mr. Price taught for many years, the Manhattan Percussion Ensemble, under the direction of Claire Heldrich, presented an apt, loving tribute to the late Mr. Price.

title: WILL TO HOLD POWER CALLED REGAN'S FLAW
description: The same traits that carried Donald T. Regan to the pinnacle of power on Wall Street and in the White House were also responsible for his downfall this week, according to Administration officials and former officials.

title: TALINUM OUTDUELS FAVORED CRYPTOCLEARANCE IN THE FLAMINGO
description: The trainer with the favorite for the Kentucky Derby may now also have the second favorite as well. Talinum, the D. Wayne Lukas stable's second-string Derby prospect behind Capote, rallied powerfully on the far outside to beat Cryptoclearance by half a length in the $450,000 Flamingo Stakes today at Hialeah Park.

title: LAWYER NAMED TO HEAD NEW YORK COMMITTEE
description: Since his days as a graduate student, and later, a law school dean and author, Peter Swords has watched over the well-being of New York's nonprofit organizations - the thousands of educational and cultural institutions, welfare agencies and neighborhood groups that serve the city's population.

title: A NEW CACHET FOR OLD WRISTWATCHES
description: Some people want more from their wristwatch than just the time of day. ''It's a portable status symbol,'' said Daryn Schnipper, a watch specialist at Sotheby's auction house. ''It says something about your personality.''

title: Come the Weekend, It's Talk-Show City
description: About the time that most Washingtonians are easing toward a leisurely weekend, a small number of people here are approaching countdown time.

title: Disparate Views On Effective Solutions
description: FLOOD OF CONVICTS

title: MASTERY TEST GIVES IMPETUS TO IMPROVE
description: THE scores reported in January in mathematics, language arts, reading and writing on the statewide Mastery Test should cause concern in local school districts, and I hope that this concern will serve as an impetus to improve what is being taught and when it is being taught in school districts across the state.

title: POSTINGS: Circa 1821; The Vinyl Goes
description: The Condit House has a lot going for it. The three-story, Federal-style structure in West Orange, N.J., thought to be built in 1821, has four marble fireplaces, hand-carved woodwork, a fieldstone foundation and wavy window panes. ''But it has been bastardized,'' said Richard Polton, a developer specializing in historic restoration, referring to the white vinyl siding that now sheathes the original scallop-edged clapboards.

title: THE NIGHT CHAMBERLAIN SCORED 100
description: HE was so large and so strong and his feats were so outlandish that he wouldn't be nicknamed for anything so mundane as a mere world, or planet, or star. He was named for an entire constellation. He was the Big Dipper.

title: OCEAN CONTROLS FACE HURDLES
description: LEAD: THE first legislative hearing on Governor Kean's proposed Clean Ocean Authority elicited few new specifics and appeared to portend a lengthy debate that some environmentalists fear could divert attention from the very problems the agency is intended to solve.

title: RISING RENTS FROM STORES SUBSIDIZING APARTMENTS
description: FOR $161 a month, Ralph J. Calise has an apartment at 448 Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan as big as a $2,400-a-month storefront four floors below.

title: RELAX, IT'S ONLY A THEORY
description: ONE of the most instructive arguments in modern literary criticism was conducted, many years ago, by Rene Wellek and F. R. Leavis.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: MEMORY OF FIRE: Faces and Masks. Part Two of a Trilogy. By Eduardo Galeano. Translated by Cedric Belfrage. (Pantheon, $18.95.) This is the second installment of the Uruguayan writer and journalist Eduardo Galeano's trilogy, ''Memory of Fire,'' a fictionalized history of the New World. As in ''Genesis,'' the well-received first volume, ''Faces and Masks'' is made up of hundreds of short, highly colored reports and anecdotes, each given a date and a descriptive title: for example, ''1781: Cuzco: Sacramental Ceremony in the Torture Chamber.

title: THE POLLINI SOUND
description: MAURIZIO Pollini's public performances have been selective, and they almost invariably sell out. With his friend Claudio Abbado conducting the Vienna Philharmonic, Pollini is about to begin this Friday a five-concert cycle of all of the Beethoven concertos in Carnegie Hall, followed by solo recitals of Schubert, Chopin and Debussy in Boston, New York (Carnegie Hall again), Washington and Chicago, in that order.

title: Report on Iran-Contra Affair Depicts 'A Very Unprofessional Operation'
description: DONALD T. REGAN

title: William A. Kerr Weds Sarah Catherine Jolley
description: Sarah Catherine Jolley, an assistant vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, and William Abercrombie Kerr, a vice president at the Irving Trust Company, both in New York, were married yesterday in Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at Myers Park Presbyterian Church.

title: HOW BIG BUSINESS STACKS THE DECK
description: In a series of hostile takeover attempts in the 1980's, T. Boone Pickens, the founder and head of the Mesa Petroleum Company, based in Amarillo, Tex., learned a simple lesson. In each battle, as he describes it in the following excerpt from ''Boone,'' to be published soon by the Houghton-Mifflin Company, Mr. Pickens discovered that he was opposing not just the ''entrenched management'' of an individual company. Instead, he says, he was fighting an entire class of professional managers who hung together, pulling the strings of power to protect their jobs and their life styles.

title: AN EMIGRE, FROM RUSSIA WITH JAZZ
description: LEAD: FOURTEEN years ago, soon after he arrived in New York from Moscow, Valery Ponomarev had a cultural shock that went beyond the usual Soviet emigre experience.

title: Demetra Siriotis Weds
description: Demetra Siriotis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Theophilos G. Siriotis of Jericho, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Mailles, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ilias Mailles of Campbell, Ohio. The Rev. George Stavropoulos performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in Hicksville, L.I.

title: A PROGRAM TO MEET NEW JERSEY'S UNMET HEALTH-CARE NEEDS
description: IT HAS been said that, in many ways, New Jersey is a microcosm of the nation. This is certainly true in relation to the health-care issues and problems facing the state.

title: THE PRESIDENT AND THE TRUTH
description: Will Ronald Reagan's Presidency end in 22 months of floundering as his Administration runs down like a wind-up toy?

title: FREDERIC G. DONNER, 84, FORMER CHAIRMAN OF G.M.
description: Frederic Garrett Donner, chairman and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation from 1958 to 1967 and a company director for 32 years, died early yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 84 years old.

title: Jean Lewis Plans To Become Bride of a Biochemist
description: Jean Lewis, a doctoral candidate in biochemistry at the University of Pennsylvania, and Dr. Hans-Rudolf Boehringer, a postdoctoral research fellow in immunology at the Wistar Institute in Philadelphia, plan to be married April 25.

title: BRISTOL AWAITING BASEBALL TOURNEY
description: MORE than 150 young baseball players will converge on Bristol next summer for the Little League Baseball Eastern Regional Tournament, the first time the competition will be played in the state.

title: Changes in the Army
description: Major changes in the leadership of the Army will take place this summer when the current Chief of Staff, Gen. John A. Wickham Jr., retires after four years in that job. His replacement has not been named, but the odds-on favorite in the quadrennial Pentagon guessing game is Gen. Carl E. Vuono, who currently runs the Army's Training and Doctrine Command at Fort Monroe, Va.

title:
GARDENING;
KEEPING GERANIUMS HEALTHY IN WINTER
description: LEAD: NOT too many years ago, geraniums were both the No. 1 potted plant and bedding plant in the country. They slipped from the top as potted plants when chrysanthemums became available year-round and as bedding plants when petunias, impatiens and marigolds increased in popularity.

title: WINTER WEATHER REVIVES ROAD-SALT DEBATE
description: THIS winter's snow and ice have caused more than the sore muscles that come from sweeping walks and driveways: they also have rekindled the controversy over the use and storage of the salt used to de-ice roads in the county, particularly in the northern towns.

title: CHEEKING THE COLOSSUS OF THE NORTH
description: THE CLOSEST OF ENEMIES A Personal and Diplomatic Account of U. S.-Cuban Relations Since 1957. By Wayne S. Smith. Illustrated. 308 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 52 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 52 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: COLONIZE THE MOON
description: To the Editor:

title: PROSPECTS
description: LEAD: Of Debt and the Dollar

title: DESPARTION TACTIC FAILS AS KNICKS ARE ROUTED
description: These are desperate times for the Knicks. The team is suffering from a string of debilitating injuries and a noted lack of talent. The club needs help, desperately. So does Coach Bob Hill, who is groping to salvage his reputation, and his job.

title: In Big-Time College Athletics, The Real Score Is in Dollars
description: BASKETBALL star Len Bias's death from cocaine intoxication last year at the University of Maryland led to the disclosure that he and four other members of the school team were not attending class. At the University of Georgia, a lawsuit by a dismissed instructor showed that members of the football team who were failing in school received special permission to continue so they could play in an important game. And at both Texas Christian University and Southern Methodist University, football players were paid for their services.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LEAD: A WIDER WORLD: Portraits in an Adolescence, by Kate Simon. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) This memoir of her girlhood picks up where Kate Simon left off in her earlier picture of Jewish immigrant life, ''Bronx Primitive: Portraits in a Childhood.'' Taking the precocious Kate from the late 1920's into the 30's and the ''wider world'' of Hunter College, Greenwich Village, Harlem and the Lower East Side, the narrative reveals a ''shining intelligence'' and ''a tough, likable vitality,'' Robert Pinsky said here last year.

title: Some Need Help From Boards
description: WHEN condominium and co-op documents were drafted in the 50's and 60's, nobody thought of including policies designed to cover instances where residents become so old or disoriented that they can pose a danger to themselves or their neighbors.

title: INSURANCE POLICIES OFFERED TO HELP ELDERLY INFIRM TO REMAIN AT HOME
description: Some of the nation's largest insurance companies have begun to offer experimental policies that would help pay for services at home for people who might otherwise have to be admitted to nursing homes in their old age.

title: MAINE RESIDENTS PROTEST AIR FORCE BUILDING PLAN
description: For many of Stacyville's 550 residents, the view of Mount Katahdin at daybreak is taken for granted but never ignored.

title: VANUATU SEEKS AID AFTER HURRICANE
description: Vanuatu appealed for more overseas aid Friday to rebuild its economy and to help feed and house 10,000 people left homeless after a hurricane hit the small South Pacific nation on Feb. 7.

title: SHOREHAM DEBATE PUT ON NATIONAL STAGE
description: LEAD: AS Governor Cuomo led an assault last week on a proposed Nuclear Regulatory Commission rule change that could expedite licensing of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Plant, the Shoreham issue seemed finally to have attained clear status as a national issue.

title: 'Out of Egypt'
description: To the Editor:

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
COMMUTER WIVES: THEY SERVE, SIT AND WAIT -- AND WAIT
description: LEAD: ''DA-DA,'' my 12-month-old daughter said. Clever, precious and downright brilliant, I thought - except that she was saying it to the diaper man.

title: A NEW STRATEGY AGAINST AIDS
description: Homosexual rights groups and television crews streamed into Atlanta last week to eavesdrop on a meeting convened by the Federal Centers for Disease Control. What drew the crowds were suggestions that the agency was preparing to advocate mandatory testing for the AIDS virus, which homosexual groups intensely oppose.

title: A C.E.O. Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: CROWDED RACE TO LEAD A DIVIDED G.O.P.
description: FOUR years after Thomas J. D'Amore Jr. became leader of the Connecticut Republicans with the goal of shedding their minority status, the state party last week was back at the drawing board with a spirited debate about its future course and a heated contest for a new state chairman.

title: WASHINGTON AND IRVING
description: To the Editor:

title: A CHAMPION'S STYLE IS CONTAGIOUS
description: It is remarkable how a great player seems to impose his style on the competitions he plays in. When Anatoly Karpov was world champion, his dry, prudent, conservative, technical approach rubbed off to some extent on his major rivals. Of course, they weren't as good at it as he was, but their unconscious emulation of him made draws preponderant in elite events.

title: The Dollar
description: To the Editor:

title: MENTALY ILL FIND AID FOR DRUG ABUSE
description: LEAD: THE abuse of alcohol and illegal and prescription drugs has become epidemic in modern life. But health experts on Long Island are now moving to help a group that has been found to need special help for abuse problems - the mentally ill.

title: Rosalind Alpert Marries Lawyer
description: The marriage of Rosalind Alice Alpert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Alpert of Lewiston, N.Y., to Toby Salter Myerson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Myerson of Santa Barbara, Calif., took place last evening in Manhattan. Rabbi David Posner officiated at the Pierre.

title: RECYCLING IS VIABLE AND ECONOMICAL
description: The League of Women Voters of Connecticut would like to comment on statements made in two recent articles on resource recovery:

title: MASTER OF ALL HE EXPLAINS
description: IMPORTANT NONSENSE By Lionel Abel. 232 pp. Buffalo: Prometheus Books. $22.95.

title: STAGE: 'CROSS WAY CROSS,' A JOURNEY
description: LINDA MUSSMANN calls her company Time and Space Limited. Never was that name more apt than on Wednesday night, when she presented a new multimedia production at Marymount Manhattan Theater. Written and directed by Ms. Mussmann in collaboration with Claudia Bruce, ''Cross Way Cross'' made use of words, music and choreographic movement and was simultaneously a history lesson, a travelogue and a meditation on ways the imagination can wander.

title: STATE'S AGENT ORANGE AIDES JOIN OTHERS TO UNIFY EFFORTS
description: LEAD: MEMBERS of New Jersey's Agent Orange Commission have joined their counterparts in 10 other states to form a national association designed to coordinate efforts to provide medical, social and legal services to Vietnam veterans exposed to the herbicide.

title: THE MAILBOX BASHERS MUST BE PROSECUTED
description: Richard B. Elsberry had a fine article on mailbox bashing [ ''Mailbox Bashing: Mysterious Crime,'' Opinion, Jan. 18 ] . I had a similar experience. Our box was bashed in, uprooted and blown up so many times we gave up, and now I rent a post office box.

title: Garcia Bribery Implied, Denied
description: Investigtors looking into allegations that Representative Robert Garcia of the Bronx took bribes from the Wedtech Corporation seemed to think they had found corroboration last week. But the source of that alleged corroboration disagreed.

title: CHAPPAQUA MAN HEADS U.S. LIBRARIES PANEL
description: LEAD: AS former director of the Voice of America, Kenneth Y. Tomlinson sought to increase its visibility while maintaining its independence. Now, as chairman of the National Commission on Libraries and Information Science, he is hoping to do the same with public libraries.

title: CONFLICT OVER JAY SITE IN RYE ENTERS NEW STAGE
description: THE dispute between a Larchmont developer and a coalition of environmental groups over the future of a 22.4-acre property in Rye has entered a new phase since the City Council recently agreed to support condemnation proceedings. Condemnation would insure public ownership of the land, which borders Long Island Sound and the Marshlands Conservancy and includes the site of the boyhood home of John Jay, the first Chief Justice of the United States.

title: STRIKE ONE KEY AND HEAR A CHOIR
description: LITTLE has changed in the look and function of, say, the saxaphone or the piano in the last few decades. So computerized instruments represent the first new category of equipment that music stores have stocked in years. And store owners are promoting them to the hilt. ''People shop for what's hot,'' explained Rich Cutler, an employee at Manny's Musical Instruments and Accessories.

title: Opening Loss
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ORIGINS OF STYLE
description: Designers have long extracted silhouettes, colors and patterns from the canvases of painters, working the elements into fresh designs. Among the most notable examples is Yves Saint Laurent's use of Mondrian's motifs in 1965-66. In this season's collections, many of the designs of Jean-Paul Gaultier, known for his Russian Constructivist images, seem to have emerged from the paintings of Richard Lindner and Oskar Schlemmer, while Oscar de la Renta's pouf skirts bring Degas's ballerinas to mind. And David's portrait of the legendary Mme.

title: Freedoms, Great and Small; ALSO A LEGEND
description: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. won a Nobel Peace Prize and had a national holiday created in his memory. Rosa Parks became legendary as the woman who refused to give up her seat at the front of a Montgomery, Ala., bus. E. D. Nixon, who died last week at 87, remained relatively obscure. Yet his life demonstrated as clearly as Dr. King's and Mrs. Parks's that an individual has the power to make a difference.

title: THE POETRY AND GRANDEUR OF SHURA CHERKASSKY
description: Lucky man, Shura Cherkassky. Also a deserving man who established his credentials as a major pianist when he was a child prodigy studying with Josef Hofmann at the Curtis Institute. Nimbus Records in England has interested itself in this veteran, 76-year-old Russian-born pianist, now an American citizen who lives in London. The result: five compact disks, each containing one or more major works. Mr. Cherkassky himself will be in New York this week and next for a series of performances with the New York Philharmonic beginning Thursday, playing the Anton Rubinstein Concerto No. 4.

title: Marci D. Wasserman Weds Barry Mainzer
description: Marci Dee Wasserman and Barry Steven Mainzer were married last night at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J., by Rabbi Bruce Goldman.

title: PAGLIARULA IS CLOSE
description: The Yankees brought one of their key players into the fold today when they signed Dan Pasqua to a one-year contract, and they appeared close to signing another, Mike Pagliarulo.

title: ONCE MORE, SYRIA COMES ARMED TO 'SAVE' BEIRUT
description: WHEN thousands of Syrian troops moved into mainly Moslem West Beirut last week to try to curtail the increasing slaughter of the urban civil war, the daily pro-Damascus newspaper Al Sharq front-paged a portrait of Syrian President Hafez al-Assad, hailing him as ''The Savior.''

title: MAKE IT MODERN, MAKE IT PLASTIC
description: THE NEW ART - THE NEW LIFE The Collected Writings of Piet Mondrian. Edited and translated by Harry Holtzman and Martin S. James. Illustrated. 414 pp. Boston: G. K. Hall & Company. $60.

title: SUPPORT FOR JEFFERSON-SALLY HEMMINGS LIAISON
description: To the Editor:

title: FIESTA IN TEXAS, HOLY WEEK IN SPAIN
description: San Antonio Celebrates Independence

GARDENING;
KEEPING GERANIUMS HEALTHY IN WINTER
description: LEAD: NOT too many years ago, geraniums were both the No. 1 potted plant and bedding plant in the country. They slipped from the top as potted plants when chrysanthemums became available year-round and as bedding plants when petunias, impatiens and marigolds increased in popularity.

title: Evacuation at Chemical Fire
description: Fire erupted Friday in a warehouse holding farm chemicals, destroying the building and forcing scores of people from their homes overnight. The blaze at the Milam Grain Company was contained after about 10 hours.

title: ACROSS AMERICA, THE FISH ARE JUMPIN'
description: DURING Steve Connolly's early days in the seafood business back in the late 1940's, he was accustomed to getting the brush-off.

title: BLACKS MEET TO REVIVE 50-YEAR-OLD SEARCH FOR IDENTITY
description: Black intellectuals from three continents were meeting here today to renew acquaintance with an idea that is getting a second look, much like a favorite old suit that turns up in a closet, is brushed off and more or less still fits.

title: UNEASY IN ZION
description: ENEMY IN THE PROMISED LAND An Egyptian Woman's Journey Into Israel. By Sana Hasan. 335 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Bacardi rum on Feb. 15 misstated Edwin Nielsen's relationship to Lucia Schueg. Mr. Nielsen, chairman of Bacardi Imports, was Mrs. Schueg's son.

title: Poetry, Politics and Adrienne Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: Janice Goldfarb Weds
description: At the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., last evening Janice Ellen Goldfarb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Goldfarb of Great Neck, L.I., was married to Leslie Steven Kohn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Kohn of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman performed the ceremony. The bride is an associate at the Jarvis-Walker Group, an executive recruiter in New York. Mr. Kohn is a lawyer in New York.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: STEICHEN AND TICE Two of America's most famous photographers, Edward Steichen and George Tice, are represented by about 40 pictures on exhibition at the White Plains Public Library at 100 Martine Avenue today through April 26. Portraits by Steichen, who died in 1973, will be familiar to some viewers who saw the originals in Vanity Fair and Vogue magazines. Greta Garbo, Paul Robeson, Charlie Chaplin, J. P. Morgan, Gloria Swanson, Joan Crawford and Eugene O'Neill were just a few of the celebrities he photographed during his long career as chief photographer for Conde Nast and while he was director of photography at the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan.

title: TRASH WILL TELL
description: THE PASSION OF ESTELLE JORDAN By Ernest Hebert. 210 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: COPING WITH CURRENCY SWINGS
description: When Jay Levy, an assistant state attorney general in Maryland, is asked about how he decides where to vacation, his answer is simple: ''Weather and exchange rates.'' It was for those reasons that he and his wife, Elizabeth, chose to visit the west coast of Mexico last year. ''Sun was guaranteed and the prices were low,'' he said. ''A bottle of Coke cost about a dime, and a meal for the two of us was only $15.''

title: BLACK SHURCH CELEBRATES 221ST YEAR
description: ''We have had rough pastures to pass over, but we came, sometimes crying, sometimes moaning, to lay down at the altar to say: Thank you Jesus, we've come a long way.''

title: BOOKSELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Karen Sudikoff to Wed Jonathan Blass in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Sudikoff of Orange, Conn., have announced plans for the June wedding of their daughter, Karen Davida Sudikoff, to Jonathan Andrew Blass, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Blass of New York and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: In Washington, South Africa Recedes as an Issue
description: South Africa, which occupied the attention of Congress and the Administration for more than two years, has significantly receded as a priority issue, officials in both branches of government say.

title: NEW COMMEMORATIVE FOR BLACK HERITAGE SERIES
description: The 10th stamp in the Black Heritage series honors Jean Baptiste Pointe Du Sable, who is regarded as the first permanent settler in Chicago. It was released last week by the United States Postal Service in Chicago. The stamp was issued during Black History Month and helps to commemorate Chicago's 150th anniversary.

title: A SPENDING SPREE AT SECURITY PACIFIC
description: SPORTING a pink shirt and a black-and-pink tie, Richard J. Flamson 3d, chairman of the Security Pacific Corporation, emerged triumphant from a special meeting of the company's board of directors last Wednesday. He had reason to look jaunty. The directors had just approved his agreement to acquire the Rainier Bancorporation, the second-largest bank in the state of Washington.

title:
GARDENING;
KEEPING GERANIUMS HEALTHY IN WINTER
description: LEAD: NOT too many years ago, geraniums were both the No. 1 potted plant and bedding plant in the country. They slipped from the top as potted plants when chrysanthemums became available year-round and as bedding plants when petunias, impatiens and marigolds increased in popularity.

title:
ART;
LEHMAN GALLERY FEATURES CHRISTO, BLACK MIGRATION
description: LEAD: THERE is easy commerce between the two exhibition spaces at the Lehman College Art Gallery in the Bronx. This time each space is the host to a documentary show; one charts voluntary black migration to the United States, and the other relates in detail one of the artist Christo's celebrated projects.

title: NAME THAT AWARD: THE BIG SELL IN SPORTS
description: SPORTS fans know that corporate names have been popping up in peculiar places - we now have the Nabisco Masters in tennis, football's Sunkist Fiesta Bowl and the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic in golf. For all we know, XXII may be played next January as the Campbell's Souper Bowl. So why should we be shocked to learn that corporations have been horning in on baseball, inventing new awards and naming them after themselves?

title: POTINGS: 24 in Columbia; Rural Housing
description: For years, John P. Rooney, a real-estate lawyer in Manhattan, has owned 124 acres of untouched land in the Town of Greenport, N.Y. Partly because he had no other way to finance a development, but also because he says that he believes in decent housing for the elderly, Mr. Rooney turned for help to the Federal Rural Rental Housing Loan Program, which is sponsored by the Farmers Home Administration.

title: PIANO: ZOLTAN KOCSIS PLAYS LISTZ AT RECITAL
description: THE Hungarian pianist Zoltan Kocsis has made a considerable international career for himself over the last decade, in part through his concert appearances but in larger part, one suspects, through his many recordings. Thursday night he gave a recital at Carnegie Hall, and, although the stage wasn't crowded with extra seats, the rest of the hall seemed full.

title: A SCRAMBLE FOR SCHOOL-BUS DRIVERS
description: LAST fall, Jim Castelli Jr. sent out 2,500 fliers to parents of schoolchildren in the area served by his bus company in the hope of enticing at least one of them to climb into the driver's seat. The plan did not work. ''If we had got even a phone call, it would have been great,'' Mr. Castelli said. ''When we didn't, we realized how much trouble we were in.''

title: DURABLES DELIVER DISAPPOINTING NEWS
description: Durable goods orders plunged 7.5 percent in January - the biggest drop in almost seven years. Strong military orders could not offset a 9.9 percent drop in civilian orders. Analysts had been expecting a big drop, because the tax bill had made it more advantageous to place orders before Jan. 1, but the magnitude surprised some. And although most analysts say orders will pick up, they note that capital goods orders, an important category, were particularly disappointing. * * *

title: MACAO'S CUISINE IS A CURIOUS BLEND
description: On Taipa Island, down a dusty alley in Taipa Village, is Cozinha Pinocchio, a restaurant that has a cultish following among residents of Macao - Chinese, Portuguese and Macanese - and among the weekend gamblers and pleasure seekers who spill over to Macao from Hong Kong, like jackpot coins from a slot machine.

title: STATE TOPS DRUG LIST
description: NEW JERSEY pharmaceutical companies led the nation last year in new drugs, producing 6 of the 20 ''totally new'' ones approved by the Food and Drug Administration for marketing in the United States.

title: THE BIG GAME...THE MOMENT...THE MOMENT COME AND GONE
description: I AM a basketball coach. What I may lack in recruiting ability, I make up for in technical skills. I have studied Wooden, Knight, Holtzman and Auerbach. I am an expert in the game's fundamentals. I teach pressing man-to-man and trapping-zone defenses; my teams are equally adept at the fast-break run-and-gun and slow-down four corner offenses.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Westchester Bookcase column on Feb. 15 included incorrect information about the author Samuel Heilman. He grew up in Boston and his first book was ''Synagogue Life.''

title: ISRAEL ASKING U.S. TO BAR SOVIET JEWS
description: The Government of Israel, hoping that Jews will soon be allowed to leave the Soviet Union in greater numbers, has asked the State Department to help insure that more of them will settle in Israel rather than in the United States.

title: ST. JOHN'S THWARTS PITT
description: Pitt came to Alumni Hall last night hoping for a victory to win its first undisputed Big East Conference championship. The Panthers left with a heartbreaking loss that forced them to share the title as St. John's played the role of spoilers.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A NOTED COLLECTION TO BE AUCTIONED
description: LEAD: An impressive coin collection formed by the well-known screen and television actor Buddy Ebsen will be sold at two West Coast auctions in May and June. The auctions will be conducted by Superior Coin and Stamp Company Inc. of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: HIGH STYLE THAT WORKS
description: Some of it is brash; some, particularly beautiful. Some of it is comfortably familiar; some, intriguingly new. It is the kaleidoscope of shape and style that makes for this spring's great new fashions. It is, for instance, the silhouette that is all angles and flair, or the one that is silkily fluid. It is the hemline that sails saucily shorter, or the one that drops delicately downward. It is the shoulder that is squared, or the one that is bared. It is the waistline that is pronouncedly centered, or the one that is markedly raised. It is the silhouette that reveals the body, whether through carefully curved seams or soft folds that insinuate and cling. Nostalgia and avant-gardism abound, and both have validity. Deliciously decorative touches are employed with abandon, but there are also luxurious clothes lacking in overly rich details. For some women, just one wacky, witty accessory will be enough; others will immerse themselves in the new. And, as always, there will be those who will stick to the classics. Whatever the decision, there is enough high style this spring to delight any number of women.

title: IN PRAISE OF THE OLD-FASHIONED PERENNIALS
description: An emphasis to buy everything new stirs gardeners to neglect the old-fashioned favorites. This is especially true with perennials. I like to think of a child's song that contains some good advice: ''Make new friends, but keep the old. One is silver and the other is gold.''

title: VIDEO SERIES BLENDS ART AND POLITICS
description: THE six singers in the a cappella group Sweet Honey in the Rock are alternately shown performing their politically charged music and proclaiming their political beliefs. With its emphasis on the fusion of the creative and the political, Michelle Parkerson's ''Gotta Make This Journey,'' one of the videos featured in the latest installment of the Whitney Museum's New American Film Makers Series, is representative of the show's works.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Feb. 1 on discount outlets in Manchester, Vt., listed an incorrect telephone number for the Manchester and the Mountains Chamber of Commerce. The number is 802-362-2100.

title: The Abacos
description: To the Editor: In her very interesting article, Mrs. Wright places the Abacos in the Caribbean Sea.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
In Garden City, 800 Wait for Condos
description: LEAD: WHEN The Ladies Home Journal included Garden City among ''America's best suburbs'' in a 1975 article, it described the village as a ''tranquil suburban area in the midst of unimaginative, look-alike developments that mark much of Long Island.''

title: THE FINAL DAYS OF A FAMILY EMPIRE
description: UNTIL last fall, George P. Kroh could not walk into a crowded room in this city that his family has helped to reshape without spending 10 minutes greeting friends. Over three generations, the Krohs had built a reputation for integrity and diligence as they put up suburban homes, shopping centers and office buildings.

title: PAYING TRIBUTE TO THE DARING OF PEGGY GUGGENHEIM
description: When Peggy Guggenheim started her gallery, ''Art of This Century,'' in the wartime year of 1942, no one was standing on line to buy avant-garde art. But that didn't faze this flamboyant apostle of the new, who at the gallery's opening wore one earring by Calder and one by Tanguy to demonstrate her equal regard for abstraction and Surrealism.

title: POLK AWARDS ARE RECEIVED BY THE TIMES
description: Twelve George Polk Awards, including two to The New York Times, have been announced by Long Island University.

title: WITTGENSTEIN IS DEAD AND LIVING IN OHIO
description: THE BROOM OF THE SYSTEM By David Foster Wallace. 467 pp. New York: Viking. Cloth, $18.95. Penguin. Paper, $7.95.

title: Man Held in Triple Murder
description: The bodies of a man, woman and child were found in a house here today and a 27-year-old man who was released from jail last week in an assault case was arrested and charged with their murders, the police said. The suspect, Mark Chicano, was being held on $500,000 bond pending appearance in Enfield Superior Court Monday, said Lieut. Carl Weymouth of the East Windsor police. The victims, Ellen Babbitt, 29, Mark Babbitt Jr., 11, and an adult male whose name was being withheld until relatives were notified, were not shot, the police said.

title: A GUEST CONDUCTOR FOR THE PC
description: DEVELOPERS of computer software appear to labor under the illusion that users will amass whole libraries of programs. In truth, the book collection analogy never held. Most people use their computers for a single dominant purpose. Writers are quite happy not to go beyond word processing, analysts settle into a cozy relationship with their spreadsheets.

title: HAVE SOME PLANTS BECOME CHIC?
description: LEAD: It may not be an exclusively American failing, but it does seem more endemic here than anywhere.

title: TROLLING FOR THE BASS VIA SMALL SPEAKERS
description: The deepest notes in music have always cast a curious spell upon listeners, a kind of shuddering enchantment. At some level of consciousness, this reaction may be linked to our ancestors' primal fear of thunder. At any rate, composers have instinctively used the lower depths of the tonal range to evoke feelings of awe and apprehension, as well as the more pleasurable frissons of spookiness we normally associate with horror movies.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
RING-BILLED GULL
description: LEAD: Larus delawarensis Size: 17 1/2 to 21 inches.

title: Ms. Van Beber Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Edward Van Beber of Columbus, Kan., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dianne Jean Van Beber, to Jay R. Watkins, the son of Mr. and Mrs. J.Rex Watkins of Honolulu and Dallas. The wedding is to be April 11.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: A NEW DEPARTMENT is being created here.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: PATERSON will hold dedication ceremonies Wednesday to start a federally financed demonstration project that will give the city cable television and let it monitor traffic lights through one coaxial cable.

title: CRITICS CALL COOKLAND PLANA PRELUDE TO HEAVY DEVELOPMENT
description: LEAD: OPPONENTS of a proposal to exchange 1,800 acres of Cranbury Township farmland for 350 acres owned or used by Rutgers University on the east side of Route 1 here say it could be the tip of a development iceberg rivaling the Princeton corridor boom.

title: A TANGY 'PIRATE' AND PRICELESS DUKE
description: The Magician of Lublin HBO/Cannon Video. 106 minutes. $79.95. If, as it appears, the lighting in this 1979 movie was designed to obscure rather than illuminate, it succeeds entirely in the video cassette version.

title: CHORUS OF TOY DOGS TO BACK ORCHESTRA
description: THE Hartford Symphony will have a few Wrinkles in its next program. There will be a chorus of the computer-programmed toy dogs in the orchestra's inaugural Saturday Family Matinee concert, ''The Fastastic Toy Shop,'' on March 7 at 11 A.M. at the Bushnell Auditorium in Hartford.

title: IMPORTANCE OF SCHOOL FOR GIFTED CHILDREN
description: As a parent whose child has been attending the Long Island School for the Gifted for six years, I couldn't have been more pleased to read the recent article ''School for Gifted: Where the S.A.T. Is Just Another Test'' and more distressed at a letter to the editor on Jan. 25.

title: WHIMSICAL MUSICAL ON ATLANTIC CITY BILL
description: BROADWAY will have to get along without ''Anything Goes'' until the summer, for the Lincoln Center revival has been postponed until then.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: MARCH is a month of literary events in the state, many of them taking place at Seton Hall University in South Orange.

title: LOVE AMONG THE RUINS
description: APHRODISIAS City of Venus Aphrodite. By Kenan T. Erim. Introduction by John Julius Norwich. Illustrated. 200 pp. New York: Facts on File. $45.

title: WADSWORTH OFFERS A LOOK AT THE LIFE OF J. P. MORGAN
description: THE news from the Wadsworth Atheneum is all of John Pierpont Morgan, who, born and buried in Hartford, was one of its major benefactors. Without him, the museum would be half the size and its collection the poorer by 1,325 treasures.

title: GREAT LAKES ARE STILL BEING POLLUTED, GROUP SAYS
description: Despite an agreement to stop dumping toxic pollutants into the Great Lakes and restore the water quality, the United States and Canada continue to contaminate the world's largest body of fresh water, a study by a conservation group, Great Lakes United, has concluded.

title: Oil Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: DELAWARE PRISONERS FINDING CAREERS AT 50-C A DAY
description: The supervisor on the job is serving a life sentence for murder. His construction crew is a mixture of rapists, robbers, killers, drug dealers, burglars and check forgers. They work from dawn to dark for about 50 cents an hour. For some it is their first honest job.

title: A Weakened Presidency Troubles Europe
description: AN opinion poll in France last week found that 56 percent of those questioned felt Mikhail S. Gorbachev was ''getting the better'' of Ronald Reagan. Only 20 percent believed the American President was one up on the Soviet leader.

title: THE FIRST LADY WAS AN ADDICT
description: LEAD: BETTY A Glad Awakening. By Betty Ford with Chris Chase. Illustrated. 217 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $16.95.

title: Vagrant Killed With Machete As Metro Passengers Watch
description: A well-dressed man on a subway platform pulled a machete from his attache case Friday and killed a vagrant with one stroke to the neck as dozens of horrified passengers looked on, the police said today.

title: COMMUTERS' WORK BEFORE WORK: FINDING PARKING SPACE
description: JOHN TURTURRO of Stamford remembers how in the late 1940's he would drive to the Stamford railroad station at any hour of the day and find a parking space close to either the westbound or eastbound depots.

title: DEVELOPMENT ON 110 COULD INFLATE PRICES
description: ONE of Long Island's most barren but conspicuous commercial properties could be transformed soon into a corporate landmark.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WEST OF FIFTH: The Rise and Fall and Rise of Manhattan's West Side. By James Trager. (Atheneum, $20.95.) Conventional New York literature can frustrate a West Sider, whose neighborhood often gets brushed off in a few paragraphs about Lincoln Center, the Ansonia and the American Museum of Natural History. An entire book on the subject should be as welcome as it is overdue. And James Trager, who lives on the West Side and whose books include ''The Foodbook'' and ''Letters From Sachiko: A Japanese Woman's View of Life in the Land of the Economic Miracle,'' is an enthusiastic chronicler. He is witty enough to describe the archetypal West Sider as ''an overaged hippie in running shoes, topped by a muskrat coat, Vearing too much makeup, with the ashes of her cigarette falling on her sleeve as she waited in line at the health food store.'' He is thorough enough to compile a detailed appendix of more than 400 West Side apartment houses. He is knowledgeable enough to enliven what had seemed to be the nondescript past of Columbus Avenue with stories of prizefighters sparring at Sharkey's athletic club, as recorded in the paintings of George Bellows; as well as those of America's first indoor ice-skating rink; a shopkeeper named Richard Hellman who kept a jar of his wife's blue-ribbon mayonnaise on the counter and gave America one of its most enduring brands; Lauren Bacall growing up to the roaring punctuation of the Ninth Avenue el; a company called Horton's, whose ice cream was served on ocean liners and at inaugural balls. Unfortunately, Mr. Trager's enthusiasm also hurts the book. He has so many facts and anecdotes to share that he crams them into a text that forms an interesting scrapbook but is not cohesive enough or well enough written to make anyone but an avid West Sider care.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Sherburne, Vt.;
Trouble On the Slopes
description: LEAD: DEVELOPERS of a ski village high on the slopes of Sunrise Mountain like to point out that residents can step outside their doors and ski right onto the trails of Killington Ski Area.

title: CUTTING COSTS, COUNTRY BY COUNTRY
description: If you catch a train from the Gare d'Austerlitz in Paris to Bordeaux, the round trip in second class costs $64. But for $4 more you can buy a French National Railroads pass that is good for unlimited train travel for any 4 days within a 15-day period. In Stockholm, with a $27 city card you can take buses and trains in and out of the city for three days, and go into palaces and museums without ever juggling with kronor. Vacationers can roam Britain by bus for a month and get a third off every ticket for a one-time payment of $10.

title: The Focus on Israel
description: The fact that the Palestinian question was only brought up in the final portion of the article told me a great deal about Mr. Friedman's priorities and sensibilities. I wonder what ''language'' Mr. Friedman would prefer to ''Palestinian diaspora'' and ''exiles'' - ''vacationing defectors?'' ROBBY AMEEN New York City

title: View of 3 Mile Island Reactor Shows Interior Wall Melted
description: A section of a one-inch-thick steel support wall inside Three Mile Island's Unit 2 reactor melted in the 1979 accident there, a video inspection of the reactor shows.

title: FIXING HUMPTY DUMPTY
description: In picking Howard Baker of Tennessee to be his White House chief of staff, President Reagan may even have chosen his successor.

title: The Boys of Winter
description: WE HADN'T EXPECTED to freeze our marrow.

title:
DANCE;
GLIMPSES INTO THE REHEARSAL STUDIO OF A MASTER
description: LEAD: Merce Cunningham and his troupe of 14 dancers spent much of last month holed up in an attractive but windowless rehearsal studio in the basement of Northrop Auditorium, on the University of Minnesota campus in Minneapolis. They were there courtesy of the Walker Art Center and the Northrop Dance Season, which jointly commissioned Mr.

title: Recent Sales
description: Amityville $293,000 Meadow Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new waterfront contemporary; fireplace, cathedral ceilings, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $3,900. Coram $128,000 42 Walnut Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 7-year-old ranch; den, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $1,900. East Patchogue $179,900 299 Dunton Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath new contemporary; den, fireplace, laundry room, 2-car garage; taxes $2,800. Kings Park $177,000 4 Norma Lane 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old split level; den, study, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. Setauket $295,000 3 Van Horn Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath 2-year-old contemporary; basement, fireplace, cedar siding, 2-car garage; taxes $4,700. Stony Brook $206,000 2 Lynbrook Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath 5-year-old colonial; dining room, fireplace, 0.75 acre, 1-car garage; taxes $3,800. OTHER AREAS Wilton, Conn. $340,000 20 Valeview Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old raised ranch; pool, level lot, 2 acres; taxes $3,074. Millwood, N.Y. $390,000 35 Taconic Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, deck, intercom, 2-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $5,163. Westwood, N.J. $178,500 41 Mountain Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $1,746.

title: GRAMMY WINNER: 'A GREAT FEELING'
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH he has just become a vice president at a major record company, Russ Titelman doesn't think that much will change in his job. ''I'm always in the studio making records anyway,'' said Mr. Titelman, whose title at Warner Brothers had been producer before the promotion. ''But I suppose that since my promotion was announced, more people will be sending me stuff.

title: Drunken Driving Deaths Lead To a 77-Year Prison Sentence
description: A drunken driver convicted of murder in the June 1985 traffic deaths of a woman and her four children has been sentenced to 77 years to life in state prison.

title: Co-op Loans
description: To the Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
45 YEARS OF HELPING
description: LEAD: RHODA LUNDE was browsing through a thrift shop on Division Street here, sifting through racks of sweaters and skirts and shirts that are called, in lieu of second-hand, ''slightly used.'' She loves these stores, she said, and she loves this one in particular -not just because she gets a kick out of getting a bargain.

title: TRYING TIMES
description: CAT-NAPPING in the County Courthouse could reach epidemic proportions if the heat isn't turned down. That's one of the conclusions in a report on the county courts released recently by the Westchester Task Force of Court Monitors.

title: BOOK TELLS OF THE LIFE OF A TOWN
description: LEBANON is a small town that has played a big part in the history of Connecticut. In the northeastern corner of the state, the farming community of approximately 5,000 citizens was a hub of Revolutionary War activity and was home to five of Connecticut's governors.

title: Ready For Geneva
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that the Soviet Union was willing to sign ''without delay'' an agreement to eliminate Soviet and American medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe within five years.

title: NEW HEARINGS PLANNED ON DAVIDS ISLAND
description: AN overflow crowd filled the New Rochelle City Hall meeting room to the edge of the dais and even the City Councilmen had to perch on its steps. Because of the crowd and one just as large outside the chamber doors, the Coast Guard adjourned a hearing on a controversial project planned for Davids Island.

title: Mourning A Keen Rivalry
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Daughter's Defense Of 'Native Son'
description: In his article ''On Rereading 'Native Son' '' (Dec. 7), David Bradley has sadly missed the essence of my father's book. In writing ''Native Son,'' Richard Wright had the courage to sit down next to his own fear and mould his literary child and alter ego, Bigger Thomas.

title: Man Beats an Officer Then Is Shot Six Times
description: A man attacked a police officer with a 15-inch lead pipe for no apparent reason, then was shot six times in the head and chest during a wild chase in Harlem last night, the police said.

title: ORCHESTRAL CHOICES
description: IT is going to be a busy couple of weeks on the symphonic scene, and county residents can take pride in the remarkable depth and variety of the orchestral offerings.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: TALES FOR THE TELLING Irish Folk & Fairy Stories. By Edna O'Brien. Illustrated by Michael Foreman. 127 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95. (Ages 8 and up)

title: THE CATCH-22 OF CONSUMER CREDIT
description: IT SEEMS ironic. While some deeply indebted credit-card customers find their mailboxes stuffed with new loan offers, other solid citizens find themselves unable to borrow because they lack that all-important passkey to obtaining credit - a credit history. People who have never borrowed, or who have paid all their debts without a blemish or who have been living abroad sometimes discover they are ''nonpersons'' in the credit world.
