In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer list statistically reliable. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) FOE, by J. M. Coetzee. (Viking, $15.95.) By reconsidering the events of Defoe's ''Robinson Crusoe'' from the point of view of an Englishwoman, the South African novelist offers an impressive political parable of liberation and responsibility. ENEMIES OF THE PEOPLE, by Anne F. Thurston. (Knopf, $19.95.) A harrowing oral history of the ordeal of China's intellectuals during the Cultural Revolution of the 1960's. THE SEVEN AGES, by Eva Figes. (Pantheon, $14.95.) Men wage war while women give birth in this short, ambitious, poetic novel; women's voices from the past render a thousand years of history by intruding on the consciousness of a modern English midwife. LITTLE WILSON AND BIG GOD, by Anthony Burgess. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $22.50.) The first volume of Mr. Burgess's turbulent, overflowing autobiography brings him to the age of 42, when he is beginning to think of himself as a writer and has been told he is about to die of a brain tumor (he didn't). DVORAK IN LOVE, by Josef Skvorecky. (Knopf, $18.95.) A historical novel, dizzying in its diversity, about the Czechoslovak composer's life and his adventures in America in the 1890's. THE JAPANESE EDUCATIONAL CHALLENGE: A Commitment to Children, by Merry White. (Free Press, $18.95.) Cultural differences preclude directly borrowing Japanese techniques, the author argues, but their main priority - the improvement of children's lives - is something we might profitably try. A CLIENT CALLED NOAH: A Family Journey Continued, by Josh Greenfeld. (Holt, $18.95.) Mr. Greenfeld's third book about his brain-damaged son takes us through his 20th year; it's an eloquent report of struggle and final concession to a hopeless situation.

title: 'PROTECTING' DISPLACED NOW GOAL OF UNIONS
description: LEAD: LABOR leaders in New Jersey say that provisions for workers displaced when plants are closed or cut back are at the top of the list when contracts are negotiated today.

title: DONOVAN TRAIL IN BRONX CRAWLS INTO ITS 7TH MONTH
description: As United States Secretary of Labor, Raymond J. Donovan strode for four years among the nation's most influential officeholders. Now he spends four days a week in an almost deserted, dimly lighted Bronx courtroom sitting in a row of dilapidated wooden seats with eight co-defendants in a fraud trial.

title: PART-TIME LEGISLATURE FINDS LITTLE TIME TP PONDER ETHICS
description: GOVERNOR Cuomo took on a formidable task when he called recently for an end to letting New York's State Legislators dispense funds almost at will to institutions and groups in their home districts. These ''member items,'' which got their start during the Rockefeller era, have quadrupled in cost in the last four years to $168 million for 2,744 projects in the current fiscal year.

title: STAGE: BOB BERKY'S 'TRAVELING' AT ACTORS OUTLET
description: FLYING solo or in collaboration with other New Vaudevillians like Michael Moschen (in ''Foolsfire'' and ''The Alchemedians''), Bob Berky has proven himself to be an inspired clown. As a performance artist, he evidently has a desire to expand his range into writing and directing. One result of this ambition is ''Traveling,'' an evening of sketches at the Actors Outlet Theater. The show was conceived and directed by Mr. Berky and written by him in collaboration with the National Theater of Woodbee. While awarding Mr. Berky points for earnestness in pursuit of laughter, one must also acknowledge that ''Traveling,'' at least in part, is a jejune journey.

title: CONFERENCE TO EXPLORE JOB SAFETY
description: LEAD: THE Manhattan-based New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health estimates that about 5,000 workers die each year in the state from occupational hazards and that about 40,000 develop job-related diseases.

title: PRINCETON SONG GOES COED
description: Two decades after Princeton University admitted women, the school has decided to include them in its alma mater, ''Old Nassau.''

title: CHICKEN FARM SETS UTILITY REBATE RECORD
description: OFFICE towers in Hartford and huge hotels in Stamford are among the businesses that qualify for rebates under the Connecticut Light and Power Company's Energy Alliance Program. But the largest rebate went last week to a chicken farm in Lebanon.

title: CATALONIAN SHOES WITH A PAST
description: Sundays in Barcelona, if you're walking near the cathedral just before noon, you'll hear the sound of instruments being tuned. The music, which is coming from the square in front of the 15th-century building, is that of the cobla, an 11-piece band of wind instruments and double bass. People are hurrying down the side streets, converging on the square, not for a performance, but to participate in a dance that takes place in plazas all over Catalonia, a fiercely independent region in northeastern Spain. Some dancers arrive with a pair of espadrilles slung over their shoulders, and quickly bend down to change shoes before joining in.

title: Incident in the Park
description: David Galef sits on a rock in a secluded area of Central Park, oblivious to his immediate environment (''Incident in the Park,'' About Men, Feb. 8). Nearby is valuable merchandise - his bicycle. He is approached by a man who threatens him with what could be a concealed weapon. He foolishly refuses to give up the bike. He gets his face bashed, and the bike is taken anyway.

title: HEALTH OPTIONS OFF TO A SLOW START
description: SMITH FACED with a confusing array of health insurance options since New York State relaxed its regulations in late 1985, encouraging for-profit health maintenance organizations to operate, most Long Islanders decided to stick with the traditional health insurance they already had.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HARD TIMES COTTON MILL GIRLS. Personal Histories of Womanhood and Poverty in the South. By Victoria Byerly. (ILR Press, Cloth, $26; Paper, $9.95.) ''Hard Times Cotton Mill Girls'' provides just enough background about Southern cotton mills to place these stories of women who work in them in context. Some readers may be annoyed by the author's summary approach to such issues as the political and economic forces that led to the growth of the ''cotton mill village'' at the end of the Civil War and the racism and sexism that created the multitiered economy of mill communities (mill work was a step toward emancipation for white women, many of whom employed black women as domestics). But the book's value and beauty reside in the personal stories of North Carolina mill workers - from that of Crystal Lee Sutton, whose life was the basis for the film ''Norma Rae,'' to that of Annie Adams, who struggled to move from cleaning mill floors to inspecting cloth (typically, a white woman's job). Out of these women's lost dreams, small triumphs and perseverence, the author has pieced together a mosaic of American labor history that is moving as well as exasperating. The child of three generations of Southern cotton mill workers, Ms. Byerly narrowly escaped a life in the mills, thanks to a college scholarship. And it was her exposure to Northern textile workers (she now teaches adult literacy in Boston) that inspired her to gather data on their Southern counterparts and seek out the personal testimony of women still at work in the mills. These oral histories of 20 white and black women are the powerful result of that inspiration.

title: Getting the Most Out of Marginal Sites
description: JANET GAFFNEY said she thought it was ''ridiculous'' when she saw a developer starting to put up town houses on a 5.2-acre strip between a highway and the business district in Briarcliff Manor late in 1985.

title: STYLE AND SUBSTANCE IN NEW HAVEN
description: WHEN all the elements of restaurant dining coalesce successfully, the results for the diner can be like those of the perfect party: unforgettable.

title: Leslie M. Rubin Plans To Marry A. A. Sunkin
description: The engagement of Leslie Meg Rubin to Andrew Alan Sunkin has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Stanley Rubin of New Rochelle, N.Y. Her fiance is a son of Mrs. Irving Sunkin of New York and the late Mr. Sunkin.

title: DANCE: RIKA BURNHAM AT ST. MARK'S
description: THERE were four new and recent dances on a program presented by Rika Burnham/The Burnham Company on Thursday at the Danspace at St. Mark's Church. The number of performers in each dance varied, two dances had props and all had different titles and scores. But there was a terrible sameness to the works.

title: UNION DISPUTE REVISITS MILL IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: An aging textile mill, once the scene of a bloody strike that historians say helped frustrate labor organizing in the South, is again the target of a union campaign.

title: WE'LL DROWN IN GARBAGE UNLESS...
description: BY voting for environmental quality bonds, the people of New York State showed their willingness to pay for a clean environment. However, there is one serious, devastating omission in the Bond Act.

title: REAGAN IS ASKING BIPARTISAN IDEAS TO HELP IN CRISIS
description: A day after he stunned the capital by naming Howard H. Baker Jr. as his new chief of staff, President Reagan called on Congressional leaders and personal advisers today for suggestions on how he can regain his political and legislative momentum after three months of preoccupation with the Iran arms affair.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: EDDIE BLACK. By Walter F. Shapiro. (Arbor House, $15.95.) Walter F. Shapiro's first novel is a thriller of high order: fast, literate and plausible, with more psychological insight than gunplay. Eddie Black, an unemployed New York actor driving a meat truck, kills his boss when, in a violent argument over their pay, the hot-tempered butcher goes after Eddie's friend Vincent with a carving knife. Vincent, who has a criminal record and is terrified of returning to jail, convinces Eddie to leave the body, take his salary and let the police think it was a robbery. ''Ten minutes later I, Eddie Black, day laborer, sometime actor, and killer, was on the Lexington Avenue Local with my money in my pocket. Another working stiff going home for the weekend. Except I didn't feel like a stiff. I wasn't even tired anymore.'' As in nearly all exceptional crime novels, the moral implications of the act - not to mention its practical complications - expand like ripples in a pond, disturbing every aspect of the killer's life. Worst of all, things start going right for Eddie. That evening he falls for the beautiful Charlotte, and in the following week he lands a part in a soap opera. Even while lying to the police, Eddie keenly senses this perversion of justice, and his search for a means to confess leads him deeper into trouble. In language that is gritty and spare the author creates several colorful characters, among them the crooked detective investigating the case and Eddie's mobster uncle, Willie. ''Eddie Black'' satisfies the demands of its genre, but never loses sight of its underlying theme - one man's perilous journey toward redemption.

title: Bumpurs Trial Ends in Acquittal And Anger
description: In a verdict predicted with bitterness by the supporters of Eleanor Bumpurs, the police officer who shot her was acquitted last week of all charges connected with her death.

title: DROUGHT PROPOSAL ANGERS FISHERMEN
description: THE drought of 1985 may be over, but area fishermen have not forgotten it. The recent release of a draft environmental-impact statement on the ''Drought Operation of the Hudson River Pumping Plant'' at Chelsea in Dutchess County prompted an outcry from anglers who fish the chain of 12 New York City-owned reservoirs, four lakes and trout streams in Putnam and Westchester Counties.

title: I.R.S. Interested
description: NOW that the N.C.A.A. has completed its investigation of the S.M.U. football program's improper payments to players, the Internal Revenue Service may begin an investigation. Marlene Gaysek, a spokeswoman for the I.R.S. office in Dallas, told The Fort-Worth Star Telegram that such an investigation could focus on whether the $61,000 in player payments, which S.M.U. says came from a single booster, may have been improperly claimed as business deductions. There is also the question of whether the players reported the payments and the value of other benefits, such as rent-free apartments, on their income tax returns.

title: Pop/Jazz
description: Call it Mardi Gras, call it Carnaval - either way, the festivities that lead up to Ash Wednesday put a celebratory kick in all kinds of music with Caribbean connections. New Yorkers who haven't headed for points south, masks in hand, can enjoy echoes of Brazilian and New Orleans traditions this week at local clubs, with a rare appearance by the Brazilian guitarist Baden Powell Tuesday through Sunday at the Blue Note (131 West Fourth Street, 475-8592) and a New Orleans week at Tramps (125 East 15th Street, 777-5077).

title: TRYING TO COLLECT ON SOVIET LIBEL
description: AFTER suing the Soviet Union for libel and winning, Raphael Gregorian, a businessman in Palo Alto, Calif., set out to try to collect the $450,000 awarded for damages.

title: Nia Thomas Plans to Marry March 21
description: Nia Elizabeth Thomas, the daughter of Mrs. Hugh Thomas of Aberystwyth, Wales, and the late Mr. Thomas, plans to be married March 21 to Dr. Michael Kenrick Gallagher, a research associate in the department of materials science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He is a son of Kristin Wynne-Jones of New York and Montauk, L.I., and the late Dr. Charles J. Gallagher Jr. The future bride, who until recently taught at the Spandau First School, a school for British military dependents in West Berlin, graduated from the University College of Wales in Swansea. Her father was an area manager for Welsh Brewers. Her mother, Iris Thomas, is an administrative assistant in the zoology department at the University College of Wales in Aberystwyth.

title: THE BEST THERAPY: WORDS OF COMFORT
description: After reading ''Waiting-Room Literary Clues'' [ About Long Island, Jan. 25 ] , I felt compelled to reflect upon my own physician and his office.

title: FRANCE SENTENCES TERRORIST TO LIFE
description: A special criminal court sentenced a Lebanese terrorist leader to life imprisonment today after finding him guilty of complicity in the killings of an American and an Israeli diplomat in 1982.

title:
WAHT'S DOING IN;
MUNICH
description: LEAD: It is a city of superlatives to which testimonials abound. The most adulatory accolade was surely the American novelist Thomas Wolfe's in ''The Web and the Rock,'' where he described it as ''a kind of German heaven . . . a German dream translated into life. In other parts of Germany people will lift their eyes and sigh rapturously when you say you are going to Munich: Ach!

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Shoes and More Shoes In 250 Styles The Factory Outlet Store of Church's English Shoes in Goodwives Plaza in Darien, Conn., just celebrated the company's 114th anniversary and features various promotions monthly. Besides the older London and Paris branches, in the United States the locations are in Manhattan, Boston, Philadelphia, Washington, New Orleans, Atlanta, Houston, Dallas, Chicago, Seattle and four in California.

title: WHAT'S IN A NAME? HISTORY
description: SOMETIMES the question is not so much what's in a name as it is what's in a place?

title: ELEPHANT MAN' TESTS IDEALS
description: BERNARD POMERANCE'S play, ''The Elephant Man,'' now at Theater Three, peers through the dramatic keyhole at the imagined life of John Merrick, a 19th-century man horribly afflicted with a rare genetic disease. While examining the minutiae of Merrick's life, Mr. Pomerance takes a close look at the ideals of truth, beauty, justice and mercy.

title: Plaster Hits Maryland Seat
description: Several pounds of plaster molding dropped from a ceiling in Gov. William Donald Schaefer's office today, landing squarely on the chair where the Governor often works. Mr. Schaefer was in another office in the State House at the time. Mr. Schaefer's aides said the Governor could have been seriously injured if he had been at the desk. William Shipley, the building superintendent, said, ''We have a leak up there and it didn't help much.''

title: SCANNING THE CULTURAL HORIZON
description: State and Art Theater, and are performed in the Theater of Epidaurus, which dates from the third century B.C. Synopses of the plays are available in English.

title: 'I See Him'
description: 'There is Ivan the Terrible. I dream about him every night. I see him, I see him, I see him.

title: EUROPEAN STYLE
description: LEAD: Just when the eye has become accustomed to a certain look, Yves Saint Laurent startles with a different length, Christian Lacroix, who recently left Jean Patou to form his own couture house, provokes with a radical change in silhouette, or Giorgio Armani surprises with a departure from strict tailoring.

title: UNDERSTUDY BECOMES THE STAR IN DARIEN'S 'SUGAR BABIES'
description: TONIGHT, it's Rudy Tronto's turn to be top banana. The director and performer who staged the sketches for the revue ''Sugar Babies'' on Broadway and who understudied the star, Mickey Rooney, will be in the spotlight when the ''burlesque musical'' has its formal opening tonight at the Darien Dinner Theater. Previews began there Wednesday; the show runs through May.

title: A Supernova Brings News From Another Galaxy
description: About 163,000 years ago, a star exploded in the Greater Magellanic Cloud, a cluster of small galaxies near the Milky Way. Meanwhile, on Earth, civilization developed, and by the time the light of this supernova arrived, there were telescopes to record it and astronomers to appreciate a rare celestial find.

title: APARTMENTS SUBSIDIZED BUT NOT CHEAP
description: LEAD: NEWBURY COMMON in Stamford is not the usual subsidized housing complex.

title: CONCERT: JAPANESE MUSIC
description: TWO performing groups, Kodo from Japan and the New York-based Soh Daiko, shared a concert at Japan Society on Tuesday that fairly rumbled and roared. If most of the traditional Japanese music heard in the United States seems gravely ethereal, the music of the taiko, a large ceremonial drum featured by both groups, is certainly an antidote. The sound is robust, the rhythms ferociously kinetic; the playing involved both precise musicianship and a physical discipline relating to the martial arts.

title: DOES BOXING STILL HAVE APPEAL?
description: Boxing has had appeal for generations because it fulfilled the immigrant's dream. As waves of immigrants came to America, each period had its clique of boxing greats.

title: Crews Work to Clean Oil Off Florida Beaches
description: Crews worked today to clean up heavy marine fuel oil that leaked from a disabled freighter and washed up on 30 miles of beaches in northeastern Florida. Environmentalists worked to rescue sea birds from the oil.

title: AID TO CITIES SPLITS KEAN AND G.O.P. IN ASSEMBLY
description: WHATEVER the outcome of the current agonizing attempt by the Legislature to help cities weather their budget problems, the exercise has produced the first real rift between Governor Kean and the Assembly's Republican majority.

title: SAILING THE THAMES, SOMEHOW
description: The Thames in midsummer is a frenzied picnic afloat, a continuous waterborne garden party to which almost everyone is invited and almost no one sends regrets. On the river, in a flotilla of anything that can be made to move over water, are English, Scots, Welsh, Southerners, Northerners, Midlanders, U's and non-U's, young and old, rich and poor, suburban couples with kids, substantial old parties with vivacious young companions and skinny long-haired students who have obviously pooled their allowances to hire something that looks like a 30-foot wooden box with an attached outboard motor.

title: Payroll Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Dartmouth Cost Rises 6.8%
description: Dartmouth College trustees have approved a 6.8 percent tuition increase to $12,474 a year and called for a ''major restructuring'' of residential-life programs, saying fraternities and sororities play too great a role in the campus social structure. Room and board costs will rise 5 percent, bringing the total cost next year to $17,091.

title: Feast Before Fast
description: HEARTY BREAKFASTS BRING out the best memories, calling to mind images of golden sunlight streaming through unshaded windows and of satisfyingly fresh aromas from the stovetop and the oven. Whether nostalgia is the cause or not, there is no denying that brunch has become passe, and the big American breakfast is back in fashion. Time, perhaps, to celebrate the simple pancake.

title: Pirates Sign Drabek
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates signed two right-handed pitchers, Doug Drabek and Mike Bielecki, to one-year contracts today, leaving them with 11 unsigned players. Drabek, 24 years old, was obtained in a six-pitcher deal last November in which the Yankees acquired Rick Rhoden, a 15-game winner. Bielecki, 27, was 6-11 with a 4.66 e.r.a. in 31 games for Pittsburgh last season.

title: Elisa Dolores Garcia Marries J. J. Hasluck
description: Elisa Dolores Garcia Canedo, an associate in the New York law firm Willkie Farr & Gallagher, and John Jay Hasluck, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, were married yesterday in Hicksville, L.I. The Rev. John Fencik performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church.

title: RIGHT TIME FOR A REVIVAL
description: WHAT a grand opportunity for Southern Methodist University.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: BELOW the ridge, on the south slope, spring was a certainty. The season had progressed too far to be forced into retreat by a single cold front. After all, this wasn't February.

title: Helms and Carolina Governor Clash on Party Job
description: Senator Jesse Helms and Gov. James G. Martin have taken opposing sides in a contest that will determine control of the North Carolina Republican machinery in the selection of the party's 1988 Presidential nominee.

title: Artifical Heart Transplant
description: A 57-year-old bricklayer who suffered three recent heart attacks received an artificial heart Friday in a nine-hour operation at the Presbyterian-University Hospital. The Jarvik-70 heart implanted in the patient, H. Jack Landis, was meant to last until a human organ becomes available, a hospital official said.

title: HOW ONE PATIENT FARES
description: LEAD: ROGER entered the Apple-Kings Park Psychiatric Center project for treatment of manic-depression and marijuana and cocaine abuse.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: SPRINGFIELD'S 'ROARING 20'S'

title: Head of Wells College Named President of St. Lawrence U.
description: Dr. Patti McGill Peterson, the president of Wells College in Aurora, N.Y,, has been named president of St. Lawrence University in Canton, N.Y., it was announced yesterday.

title: DANCE: STEPHEN PETRONIO
description: STEPHEN PETRONIO'S dances seem ready to explode. Yet it is not simply their energy that makes them interesting. Indeed, if they were ceaselessly energetic they might grow monotonous. Mr. Petronio's choreography fascinates because of its contrasts between control and flamboyance.

title: AUTOMOBILES' BUMPERS RATED
description: The new Chevrolet Corsica performed best and the Honda Accord DX worst in a series of crash tests at 5 miles an hour to determine bumper strength, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety says.

title: LIQUOR INDUSTRY COPES WITH CHANGES
description: FIVE months ago, when credit-card stickers began appearing in the windows of New York State liquor stores for the first time, Don Zacharia recalled that ''it was something we in the industry had been fighting for for years; every business accepts credit cards, and they have been in use for retail sales of wine and spirits in most other states for years.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
A TEMPORARY LIFE AMONG THE DISABLED
description: LEAD: TWO days before the start of a well-earned sabbatical, I fell off a ladder and shattered both my wrist and my plans for writing and study. My fall brought, in succession, an ambulance, a small crowd of onlookers, X-rays, a cast, painkillers and six weeks to contemplate my carelessness on a ladder.

title: THE TOP BANANNA IN 'SUGAR BABIES'
description: TONIGHT, it is Rudy Tronto's turn to be top banana. The director and performer who staged the sketches for the revue ''Sugar Babies'' on Broadway and who understudied the star, Mickey Rooney, will himself be in the spotlight when the ''Burlesque Musical,'' as it is billed, has its formal opening tonight at the Darien Dinner Theater in Connecticut, where previews began on Wednesday. The show runs through May 31.

title: BATTLING WINTER'S BLEAKNESS
description: IT'S the grayness that gets to me. I look out the front window and everything I see is the same dull color.

title: JAZZ: AN EVENING WITH BENNY CARTER
description: BOTH Benny Carter's impending 80th birthday, which occurs in August, and his six decades in jazz as an outstanding arranger, composer, bandleader and instrumental soloist, were celebrated in a concert by the American Jazz Orchestra on Thursday evening at the Cooper Union at which Mr. Carter was present in all his notable facets.

title: Star Wars and New Solutions
description: If ''Star Wars'' is supposed to have a role, then I would define it as a ploy devised by the Soviet Union to cause us great harm. It does not really matter whether the Strategic Defense Initiative can be perfected and put in place. What matters is that untold resources of our nation will be wasted on Star Wars while the Soviet Union will have to spend only a small fraction on circumventing it.

title: NATIVE-AMERICAN BASKETRY AT THE MONTCLAIR MUSEUM
description: IN THE introduction to his now-classic ''Baskets as Textile Art,'' Ed Rossbach recalls his tour of duty in the Aleutian Islands during World War II.

title: Peres's Cairo Trip Causes a Row
description: Acting like a bold Prime Minister, Israel's Shimon Peres traveled to Egypt last week and won support for an international Middle East peace conference this year. The only problem is that Mr. Peres is no longer Prime Minister.

title: THE COUNTY'S UNPAID CONSULTANTS
description: LEAD: THEY are about 600 in number, and although most work without pay or real power, for the most part they take their jobs very seriously.

title: Hunter Brown Marries T. G. Bailey Jr.
description: Susan Hunter Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Edwin Brown Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Thomas Goodall Bailey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodall Bailey of Nashville. The Rev. T.Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: U.S. Tied to Demise of Bears in Yellowstone
description: The management of Federal lands in and around Yellowstone National Park is seriously flawed and may be leading to the demise of the grizzly bear, according to a report by the research arm of the Library of Congress.

title: IN CONNECTICUT, MORE STATE AID
description: MORE money for housing and increased state aid to help hold down the local property taxes of homeowners dominate the legislative agenda for Connecticut's General Assembly this year.

title: Aquino Offers Amnesty to Rebels in Next 6 Months
description: President Corazon C. Aquino, saying she wanted to ''heal the wounds of our nation,'' offered a formal amnesty today to rebels who surrender in the next six months.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a review Feb. 15 of William E. Burrows's ''Deep Black: Space Espionage and National Security'' attributed characteristics to the National Reconnaissance Office meant to describe the National Security Agency. The correct passage follows:

title: Was S.M.U. Penalty Appropriate?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Photography
description: In October 1957 the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the world's first satellite, sparking a frenetic effort in the United States to revitalize science education and regain technological leadership. Six months after Sputnik, Berenice Abbott joined the Physical Sciences Study Committee at M.I.T. as its staff photographer. Her mission: to illustrate the principles of physics for the committee's landmark physics textbook.

title: PURDUE WINS, IS TIED FOR BIG TEN LEAD
description: Troy Lewis scored 31 points today as Purdue beat Ohio State, 87-73, to move into a tie with Indiana for first place in the Big Ten.

title: A Blind Vendor Quits After Second Robbery
description: For the second time in two months, the blind vendor who runs the candy and newspaper stand in the Statehouse Annex said he was robbed and this time he is giving up the stand.

title: Terrorist Given Life Term by French Court
description: For a time last week, it looked as if the French might go easy on Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, a self-described ''Arab fighter'' being tried for complicity in the 1982 murders of two diplomats, an American and an Israeli. The prosecutor asked the court to give Mr. Abdallah, a Lebanese Christian, a ''moderate'' sentence, linking his punishment to the fate of French hostages in Lebanon and threats of terrorist reprisals in Paris. But yesterday, the seven-judge special court said it had found ''no extenuating circumstances'' and handed down the maximum penalty under French law.

title: Allergic Reactions to Peanuts Prompt Granola Bars' Recall
description: Peanuts mistakenly placed in some New Trail-brand granola bars topuched off allergic reactions in four people, prompting the Hershey Foods Corporation to recall 2.8 million bars nationwide, a spokesman said Friday.

title: Freedoms Great and Small; TOAD THOUGHTFUL
description: Spring will come soon enough to England, and the English are getting ready for it - including English toads.

title: PROGRAM ON AIDS PRESENTED TO STUDENTS
description: LEAD: CAN you get AIDS from kissing? a teen-age girl asked recently of two experts visiting her school. Another asked if mosquitoes carried the disease. Several students wanted to know if AIDS can be got from using public facilities. These questions and others were answered by a psychiatric social worker and a social-worker intern who visited the Irvington Middle School to offer several hourlong presentations on AI

title:
ABOUT CARS;
Warranty Wars Bring Mixed Reaction
description: LEAD: THERE he is, Lee Iacocca, out in front of the camera again, intoning praise for Chrysler quality. He seems to be everywhere, in newspaper ads and magazines, on the tube, simultaneously chairman and chief huckster of the corporation, and he has one-upped the competition with his latest salvo in the war of the warranties.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: VERSION AND DIVERSION. By Judith Terry. (Morrow, $17.95.) Jane Austen's modest description of her writing as a ''little bit (two inches wide) of Ivory on which I work with so fine a Brush,'' suggests an imagination that knows its limits and prudently dwells within them. In this neo-Regency novel modeled on ''Mansfield Park,'' the British writer Judith Terry shows clearly that she is a fan of Austen's imagination but not of her restraint. She has shoved off some of Austen's characters from their pristine bit of ivory into a sooty underworld populated by revolutionaries and roues. The result is an odd yet amusing compound of Austen, Thomas Paine and the Marquis de Sade. Austen, invoking her favorite word for the ridiculous, would have called it a ''quiz.'' The adventures of Jane Hartwell, the heroine of ''Version and Diversion,'' begin when she secures a post as lady's maid to Julia Bertram, the youngest daughter of Mansfield. Austen focused on the ritualized flirtations of the drawing room, averting her gaze from the teeming life ''below stairs.'' One now understands why. Within a few short chapters, Jane has been assaulted by Julia's brother Tom, cavorted in the boathouse with Henry Crawford, an object of Julia's affections, and - most remarkably - been radicalized by the working-class politics of the servants' quarters. (''I am not a stick of wood to be used or not used by anyone,'' she tells Tom Bertram in a fit of egalitarian pique.) When even this enlarged Mansfield manor can no longer contain Jane, she runs off to London where she falls into the groping hands of a murderer and his bisexual mistress; from thereon all polite connections with Austen's world view are severed. ''Version and Diversion'' will irritate devout Janeites, entertain other readers with its command of Regency slang and manners, and persuade everyone of Austen's wisdom in knowing that less is more.

title: A CORRECTION
description: In the Feb. 22 Business Notes column the assets of the First Fidelity Bancorporation of Newark (which was spelled wrong) were incorrectly reported. It has assets of $15.2 billion.

title: Africa Students Protest AIDS Testing in India
description: More than 100 African students marched and scuffled with the police on Friday to protest a new requirement that foreign students be tested for the AIDS virus.

title: COLOR-CODED GASOLINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Phone Service Restored To 28,000 in Brooklyn
description: Telephone service that was knocked out by a fire 11 days ago has been restored to 28,000 customers in the Bushwick and Bedford-Stuyvesant sections of Brooklyn, the New York Telephone Company said yesterday.

title: Hogan Unwelcome
description: THE United States Olympic Committee's executive board ended its two-day meeting in Chicago yesterday without endorsing an International Olympic Committee proposal to liberalize participation by professionals in future Games. ''Nobody wants Hulk Hogan wrestling for our teams,'' said George Steinbrenner, the owner of the Yankees, who is a member of the 94-member U.S.O.C. executive board. The board tabled the endorsement proposal.

title: DATA BANK: March 1, 1987
Airports
description: To the Editor:

title: TEACHER HAD A SECRET
description: ECHOES IN THE DARKNESS By Joseph Wambaugh. 415 pp. New York: Perigord Press/ William Morrow & Company. $18.95. ENGAGED TO MURDER The Inside Story of the Main Line Murders. By Loretta Schwartz-Nobel. Illustrated. 291 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: THE LIBERALS' GUIDE TO TOMORROW
description: LEAD: THE NEXT LEFT The History of a Future. By Michael Harrington. 197 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $17.95.

title: THE SENTIMENTAL REALISTS
description: Today, tomorrow and for some weeks to come, the story of the Tower report will be what was in it, the steps Ronald Reagan takes to try to save his Presidency and whether he is capable of doing so.

title: The Focus on Israel
description: Mr. Friedman explains the Palestinians' use of the language of Jewish suffering ''to attract the same interest and sympathy.'' A more accurate explanation is to point out the incredible double standard we Jews employ when comparing our historical suffering with that of the Palestinians. Do second-class rights, harsh military rule over civilians, refugee status and a scattered nation without a home apply only to the Jewish people? STEVEN R. GOLD Rockville Centre, L.I.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
WOMEN HISTORY
description: LEAD: In honor of Women's History Month, the sixth annual ''Celebrating Westchester Women'' will be held next Sunday at 2 P.M. The event is co-sponsored by Sarah Lawrence College, Women of Westchester Inc. and the White Plains Public Library.

title: NEW YORK TO GRAPPLE AGAIN WITH RENT REGULATION
description: LIKE prizefighters training for a return bout, New York State legislators are now bracing for their biennial confrontation over the state's rent-regulation and cooperative-conversion laws.

title: A TANGY 'PIRATE' AND PRICELESS DUKE
description: Duke Ellington and His Orchestra, 1929-1952 With Billie Holiday, Snake Hips Tucker, Fredi Washington, Whitey's Lindy Hoppers, the Hall Johnson Choir. Jazz Classics division of Videofidelity. 40 minutes. $19.95. Three-quarters of this cassette is devoted to two primitive but priceless jazz films. Both have photography that could be described as stark. The sound is also stark, and the story lines - when there are story lines - are, well, stark.

title: Shultz Congratulates Baker From Half a World Away
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz at an American exhibition in Hong Kong. On his way to China for a six-day visit he said: ''Howard Baker is a patriot who possesses just that combination of intellect, wisdom and savvy needed at this juncture. I welcome his appointment with enthusiasm.'' (AP)

title: LEGISLATURE IN CALIFORNIA IS UNNERVED BY SCANDAL
description: The California Legislature, once considered a model of integrity, is being shaken by its worst corruption scandal in decades. Beneath the ornate dome of the state capitol these days, the most frequently asked question is: Will more legislators be indicted and, if so, when?

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
RUTGERS MUST NOT TRADE LAND ON ROUTE 1 FOR LAND IN CRANBURY
description: LEAD: THE FACULTY and students of Cook College, as well as agricultural, agribusiness, business, labor and environmental groups, individuals and legislators, have all expressed dismay and outrage at Rutgers University's action in considering a developer's proposal to swap 350 acres of Cook College land in New Brunswick for 1,800 acres 15 miles away in Cranbury

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: WOMEN'S MONTH If one good month deserves another, right on the heels of February's Black History Month, National Women's History Month gets under way today. This week's opening activities offer the typical celebratory mixed bag of events.

title: SOCIAL EVENTS
description: Benefits for Varied Tastes

title: SOUNDS OF THE STADIUM FILL A JUILLIARD HALL
description: The conductor raised his hands and a hush fell over the young musicians warming up in the red-carpeted auditorium at the Juilliard School.

title: Arsenic Levels Near Two Schools Stir Concern
description: Jane Resutek is a registered nurse who fears that her four children may be risking their health by attending the public schools here, about 40 miles north of Buffalo. She is not alone.

title: Devils Lose To Canadiens
description: Guy Carbonneau scored his second goal of the game on a breakaway at 6 minutes 17 of the third period tonight, giving the Montreal Canadiens a 3-2 victory over the New Jersey Devils. That ended the Canadiens' four-game streak without a victory.

title: BOY SCOUTS FOCUS ON CAREERS
description: LEAD: THE Boy Scouts of America's Exploring Division is no longer just for boys, and the focus is on careers.

title: Louise Shortell to Marry Hal C. Rich 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Campion Shortell of Paris and Siphnos, Greece, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Louise Campion Shortell, to Hal Crawson Rich 3d, a son of Mrs. Rich Jr. of Danville, Va., and the late Mr. Rich. The wedding is to be May 30.

title: FASHION FRISK
description: Survival chic has replaced radical chic in fashionable Paris. No longer a fantasy of camouflage fabric and army surplus clothes, today's chic is a basic designer's suit that allows the wearer to be frisked with ease. When such searches were conducted at the spring ready-to-wear shows in October, they sometimes resembled a Luis Bunuel film or a French comedy. Imagine the confusion of the police - females searching women and males frisking men - when they encountered women sporting short hair and men's clothing, and one young man with cascading locks and a punk skirt worn over tights. And was that a secret code monogrammed on a top? Any American food junkie could have told them that the garment was a McDonald's uniform. At times, the searching ironically recalled the gestures made by women and their dressmakers during a fitting.

title: THE REAL LESSON OF 'AMERIKA'
description: LEAD: Behind the layers of soap opera cliche, turgid plotting and cold war demogoguery of the much debated but little watched television series ''Amerika'' lurks a pointed political moral: The domain of the citizen is vanishing in America, and in its absence democracy is becoming ever more vulnerable - not to wolves wearing red stars preying from without but to atrophy and petrification from within.

title: A Chance to Play Congress
description: People who watch Congress closely from the outside - reporters, lobbyists, political scientists and the like - sometimes wonder how successful they would be as lawmakers, whether they could serve a term in the House of Representatives and make enough politically correct decisions to assure their own re-election.

title: Guide to Estimated Daily Expenses in 30 Places Around the World
description: This is a sampling of per diem rates set by the State Department for governmental employees and their dependents traveling on official business overseas.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: IN THE SHADOW OF THE BUDGET DEFICIT
description: REPORTS that the Administration and the Congressional leadership are prepared to abandon the $108 billion budget-deficit ceiling should be unwelcome news to anyone concerned with closing our trade deficit. Despite all the talk today of flagging American competitiveness, no measure - be it protectionism or fair trade, devaluation, foreign expansion or competitiveness - will eliminate the trade imbalance unless we manage to reduce our fiscal deficit by about $150 billion. In fact, cutting the trade deficit without cutting the budget deficit poses a serious threat of inflation.

title: THE NATION: New Price Index Bows; Charting How We Spend Our Money
description: ECONOMISTS are never sure whether the periodic revisions in the ways the Government measures inflation will produce figures that are a little smaller, a little bigger, or about the same as before. That also does not worry them much. The statistically operative word is insignificant, though the adjustments, which reflect changes in the way Americans spend their money, affect almost every ''consumer unit,'' as the statisticians prefer to call households, through cost-of-living increases in labor contracts and Federal benefit programs. Last week, when the first ''new'' Consumer Price Index since 1978 was introduced, the increase in retail prices for January was recorded at seven-tenths of 1 percent; had the surge been measured the old way, it would have been eight-tenths of 1 percent. Nor, many specialists said, should the jump from December's rate - two-tenths of 1 percent whether measured the old way or the new - be considered too significant.

title: POSTING: Stamford Condos; Rising High
description: The first high-rise condominium project in downtown Stamford could help shake the city's image as a place to work but not to live.

title: A TREE NO LONGER GROWS IN LARCHMONT
description: IF you drive by my house on Weaver Street - State Highway 125 - you can pick up some free firewood. A 150-year-old 90-foot elm has just been cut down, and the tree-feller urged me to save $400 by leaving the wood at curbside for fireplace lovers. I did. So help yourself.

title: DEFENSE FAILS VANBIESBROUCK
description: The Detroit player took one jab at the puck. Nothing. He took another jab. Still nothing. And there was the puck still sitting out there, waiting for him to try once more. So he did and he scored, making the score 4-1 and the Red Wings' afternoon with the Rangers so much the simpler.

title: Musical Toys Are Recalled
description: Toys-R-Us is recalling its Animal Voices Musical Toys because they contain small parts that may pose a hazard of choking children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced Friday. The Federal agency said the toys were cardboard cylinders about 1 3/4 inches long and 1 5/8 inches wide. One end has metal holes in it and the other end is covered with green paper with ''Taiwan'' on it. The company said tests showed the parts could come off and might injure children.

title: STALKING AN ERRANT BALANCHINE PAS DE DEUX
description: Many dancegoers were amazed when a pas de deux from a ballet by George Balanchine that has never been presented in the United States turned up at a recent gala at Brooklyn College called Festival of Dance Stars 1987.

title: HOW TO OUST A DRUG DEALER: IDEAS FOR EMBATTLED TENANTS
description: A few proposals for battling drug dealers in New York City apartment buildings: Turn off a building's water supply before a police raid so the dealers cannot flush their wares down the toilet; have dealers evicted through the housing courts, and organize tenants to help the police stop the drug traffic in the building and gather evidence.

title: SURVEY IN SOUND TO SEEK ARTIFACTS
description: LEAD: A PLAN to build a natural gas pipeline from Ontario to Smithtown could lead to an increased effort toward protecting archeological artifacts in Long Island Sound.

title: Grand Jury Accuses 3 In Plot on Bomb Data
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted three men accused of plotting to smuggle the technology for cluster bombs to Saudi Arabia and Iraq.

title: HOYAS LOOK TOUGH
description: Coach John Thompson began to sense something special about this Georgetown team, one of his youngest ever, in late January, when the Hoyas stunned undefeated and highly ranked DePaul. From then on, he drove them with an unrelenting passion. As a result, the Hoyas are once again one of the most feared teams in the Big East Conference - and they own a share of the regular-season conference championship.

title: Karen Hoffman, A Caterer, Weds
description: Karen Mele Hoffman, a daughter of Marilyn Rhoades Hoffman of Menlo Park, Calif., and Ralph Hoffman of Austin, Tex., was married yesterday to Edward Arthur Gilhuly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thomas Gilhuly of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Bruno Gibson performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in San Francisco.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency is reviewing two applications by E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company for permits to continue dumping industrial wastes in the Atlantic Ocean at a point 106 miles off Cape May.

title: Brian Carter Engaged To Christina Nichols
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Nichols 3d of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christina Adams Nichols, to Brian Clinton Carter, a son of Craig Carter of Albany and the late Elizabeth Carter. An April wedding is planned.

title: GREEK TRAGEDY IN A NEW MASK SPEAKS TO TODAY'S AUDIENCES
description: After slumbering peacefully on library shelves, Greek tragedy has staged a comeback. As far back as 1960, Robert Brustein urged the theater to ''rescue these imprisoned masterpieces from the gray walls of Victorian dullness'' and turn them into the ''immediate, sensual experiences'' they were meant to be. Within the past year or two, some of the world's most imaginative directors have heeded Mr. Brustein's advice. New productions in America, Japan and Europe prove that the Greeks were master craftsmen of the stage, weaving together poetry, music, dance and visual effects in a seamless cloth of pure theatrical magic.

title: THREE OF POP'S BEST GO ROMPING IN THE COUNTRY
description: Harmony singing runs deep in American folk culture, primarily as something to do but also as something to listen to, to be moved by.

title: The Focus on Israel
description: Thomas L. Friedman's thesis that the destiny of Israel is to be at the center of international attention requires at least one wrinkle of counterargument (''The Focus on Israel,'' Feb. 1). From the famous Jewish saying, ''If only God could have chosen someone else!'' to the contemporary laments of Israelis seeking ''normalcy,'' as portrayed in recent books by writers like Amos Oz and Lesley Hazleton, there is an expressed, legitimate desire on the part of some Israelis to forfeit a portion of the international stage in exchange for a higher quality of life. And some peace and quiet, as well.

title: WHY MOTHER DID IT
description: THE HANKY OF PIPPIN'S DAUGHTER By Rosmarie Waldrop. 152 pp. Barrytown, N.Y.: Station Hill Press. $14.95.

title: A Portrait of North: Bravado, Tenacity, Deciet
description: For a year before he was dismissed from the National Security Council staff in November, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North sought to keep alive the program to trade arms to Iran in exchange for American hostages. At the same time, he was directing a private global network that was providing military supplies to the insurgents fighting in Nicaragua.

title: DETROIT WAGES A WARRANTY WAR
description: WHEN you're having trouble solving a problem, attacking the perception may be the next best thing.

title: STYLE WITH SPEED
description: It's 6:45 P.M. Women in offices all over are about to transform their faces and hair - mascara smudges, shiny noses, droopy bangs and all -into something suitable for cocktails or galas. The time allotted for this effort is 10 minutes, tops.

title: NEWARK REVIVING CLASSIC FOOT RACE
description: OFFICIALS involved with the Newark Distance Classic are trying to reclaim the race's lost prestige.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Machias, Me., last Sunday, about reports of a downed plane in the Maine woods from a 1927 flight, described the accomplishments of Charles A. Lindbergh incorrectly in some copies. He was the first to make a nonstop solo flight between New York and Paris. The first nonstop trans-Atlantic flight, from Newfoundland to Ireland, was achieved in 1919 by John William Alcock and Arthur Brown of Britain.

title: DUKAKIS SHIFT SEENON ENVIRONMENT
description: As Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts considers a run for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination, environmentalists say he may be taking steps to resolve longstanding differences with them over his environmental policies.

title: Janet Richmond Becomes a Bride
description: Janet Van Vranken Mays Richmond, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Thacher Richmond of Lake Wales, Fla., and Bridgewater, Vt., was married yesterday to Philippe Claude Jean Braekman, a son of Suzanne Berglas of Los Angeles and Pierre Braekman of Alicante, Spain. The Rev. Joan Culpepper, a United Church of Brotherhood minister, performed the ceremony at the bride's home in Los Angeles.

title: 9 AT SHELTER FACE DRUG CHARGES
description: Nine people, including three employees of the Men's Shelter at 8 East 3d Street in lower Manhattan, were arrested on drug charges after an investigation by an undercover narcotics officer who posed as a shelter worker, it was announced yesterday.

title: LEADING BALLERINA
description: Nora Kaye, a leading American ballerina whose exceptional power as a dramatic dancer made her an international star, died yesterday at her home in Los Angeles after a long illness. She was 67.

title: PINELANDS YIELDS A NEW ANTIBIOTIC
description: LEAD: AN ANTIBIOTIC that has the potential for saving thousands of lives has its roots in an unlikely place: the mud of the New Jersey Pine Barrens.

title: India Raises Spending For Military by 43%
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi announced a huge increase in military spending today but ordered a freeze on other expenditures.

title: C.W. POST TAKES BIG APPLE TITLE
description: Juan Griles scored a game-high 21 points tonight as C. W. Post rallied for a 66-63 victory over Queens to win its fifth consecutive Big Apple Conference championship at Conolly Gymnasium.

title: Paul S. Bird to Marry Amy Parsons in May
description: The engagement of Amelia O'Brien Parsons to Paul Stanley Bird has been announced by Patricia O'Brien Parsons of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and Burlington, Vt., and James Otis Parsons of Somers, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip S. Bird of Waterville, Me. A May wedding is planned.

title: Poetry, Politics and Adrienne Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: DECODING MYSTERY OF THE SCHOOL CALENDAR
description: THE school calendar is a complex and mysterious measure of time that begins neither at the beginning of the year nor at the start of a season. The first day of school never corresponds with the first day of the month. The first day of school traditionally is a Tuesday, the day after Labor Day, which is the first Monday in September. (More about Mondays later).

title: REAGAN FAREWELL TO REGAN
description: Following is the text of a letter President Reagan sent to Donald T. Regan, his departing chief of staff, dated Friday and made public today: Dear Don:

title: The Focus on Israel
description: Mr. Friedman omits the continuing impact of another ''super story'' - the epic of decolonization. During the last 40 years, the most prominent international story has been the rise of scores of new nations in Asia and Africa from the waning colonial empires of Britain, France and other nations in Western Europe.

title: Auction of Gutenberg Bible
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocse here said Friday that it would auction a Gutenberg Bible along with other rare books and works of art to raise $17 million to $24 million for its seminaries. The Bible is one of 42 known surviving copies printed in Mainz, Germany, in 1449 or 1450 by Johann Gutenberg.

title: Jane R. Coxe to Marry Bertram Lippincott 3d
description: Announcement has been made by Gertrude Morgan Coxe and Daniel Travis Coxe of Providence, R.I., of the engagement of their sister, Jane Redman Coxe, to Bertram Lippincott 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lippincott Jr. of New York and Jamestown, R.I. A September wedding is planned. Miss Coxe, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Travis Coxe of West Chester, Pa., and Jamestown, is a securities analyst with Slocum, Gordon & Company, an investment management concern in Newport, R.I. She graduated from the Shipley School and the University of Rhode Island. She is a descendant of Dr. John Redman Coxe, a physician and partner of Dr. Benjamin Rush of Philadelphia.

title: A HISTORIAN OF EINSTEIN REFLECTS ON THE PROGRESS OF SCIENCE
description: TALK to David Cassidy for a while and you'll learn that Albert Einstein used to summer at Nassau Point on the North Fork, take part in local chamber music performances and spend time with local astronomers.

title: SCENES FROM A GENOGRAM
description: INTIMATE PARTNERS Patterns in Love and Marriage. By Maggie Scarf. 428 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: INSIDE HISTORY'S KALEIDOSCOPE
description: THE RED WHITE AND BLUE By John Gregory Dunne. 475 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Q AND A
description: Spring Training Question:I plan to visit Fort Myers, Fla., this month. Where can I obtain the local spring training schedule and ticket information? -C. C. H., Fanwood, N.J. Answer:Terry Park in Fort Myers is the headquarters of the Kansas City Royals who start their Grapefruit League season on Friday against a local team, Edison Community College. There will be 16 home games through April 4, all starting at 1:30 P.M., with the Texas Rangers, Atlanta Braves and Pittsburgh Pirates among clubs on the schedule. The schedule can be had by sending a self-addressed, stamped envelope to Royals Ticket Office, Terry Park, Palm Beach Boulevard, Fort Myers, Fla. 33905; 813-334-6175). Box seats are $5; reserved seats, $4; general admission, $3.

title: BROADWAY TO AID YIDDISH ARCHIVES
description: At the archives of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research on Fifth Avenue, members of the staff are like living parts of the collection.

title: Common Thread Seen in Ski-Related Deaths
description: SO far this season, five people have died as a result of accidents on Eastern ski slopes. For all of last season, there were eight ski-related fatalities in the East.

title: SINGLE MOTHERS ARE FILLING SHELTERS
description: LEAD: IT was the first sun-splashed morning after several bitterly cold days, but Donna Thornton was oblivious to the late winter thaw.

title: BEFORE FIGHT CAMP BECAME A SUITE SCIENCE
description: SUGAR RAY LEONARD lives in a luxury suite at the Hotel Inter-Continental, Hilton Head, S.C. The daily rate for Leonard's suite is $425. Meals are extra.

title: A VIOLINIST, A PIANIST AND A SOPRANO
description: Maria Bachmann

title: Regan's Exit Was Inevitable; Baker's Entrance a Surprise
description: The way White House officials tell the story, Donald T. Regan's career at the White House was over after his final telephone call with Nancy Reagan about 10 days ago, and it was Mrs. Reagan who got him dismissed.

title: Cynthia Smith Weds
description: Cynthia Ann Smith, a daughter of Ruby Freeble Smith and Roger Lufkin Smith of Berea, Ohio, was married in New York yesterday to Drake Lowey Dubin, a son of Wilbert Bernard Dubin of Wynnewood, Pa., and the late Jacqueline Lowey Dubin. The Rev. Christopher Dunne performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Mrs. Dubin is an assistant secretary and Mr. Dubin is an assistant vice president of the Irving Trust Company in New York.

title: CONNECTICUT-LABEL COLA CHARTS EXPOSURE
description: CONNECTICUT COLA is planning to begin a television campaign to take on the big guys. And if the product is not exactly going national, it will at least be touted in the New Haven area.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BOBBY KENNEDY: The Making of a Folk Hero. By Lester David and Irene David. (Dodd, Mead, $19.95.) In ''Bobby Kennedy,'' a husband and wife team has written a straightforward if adulatory biography that traces their hero's political development from an acolyte of Senator Joseph McCarthy to the liberals' heir apparent. ''This century has not seen a more remarkable reversal made by a public figure,'' the Davids write. How explain the change? His ''exposure to the real world'' of racial injustice, beginning with the 1960 Presidential primaries. Notwithstanding their hero worship, the authors, both journalists, acknowledge that Kennedy was ''ruthless.'' His feud with Lyndon Johnson is correctly described as ''one of the most bitter in recent political history.'' On the other hand, this flesh-and-blood portrait captures the zest and zaniness of Kennedy's family life, and shows him at his best - with children and the poor. His relationship with Marilyn Monroe is explored, but the authors conclude that the facts about it ''will probably never be known.'' Although they cover familiar material, the Davids have done original research (including interviews), and they provide fresh insights. They dispute the popular belief that Kennedy decided to run for President only after Senator Eugene McCarthy's strong performance against President Johnson in the 1968 New Hampshire primary. Three days earlier, they report, Kennedy had made a commitment to run but was not then ready to declare his candidacy. Had he done so, the authors conclude, McCarthy supporters could not have likened him to ''a jackal coming to feast on the carcass after someone else had made the kill.'' Moments before his assassination, after learning he had won the 1968 California primary, he told a friend, ''I feel now for the first time that I've shaken off the shadow of my brother. I feel I made it on my own.''

title: Pipelines Dumped Toxic Wastes
description: Five major gas pipelines have dumped hazardous wastes in pits or lagoons near their pumping stations, the Environmental Protection Agency said last week. Some of the pits showed high levels of PCB's, chemicals that have been found to cause cancer and other illnesses.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Soviet Union suggests that the problem of medium-range missiles in Europe be singled out from the package of issues, and that a separate agreement on it be concluded, and without delay.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ 1:6. ]

title: AS HE NEARS 48, PHIL NIEKRO IS KEEPING 55 IN MIND
description: IN the sunny chill, the red wool collar of his Cleveland Indians windbreaker was turned up around the back of his neck below his gray-streaked black hair. Phil Niekro will be 48 years old on April 1 but he hopped up the steps of the dugout and loped toward the outfield as easily as any of the Indians' rookies. Another sprint across the outfield grass, another spring across time for this knuckleball right-hander with 311 victories who first went to training camp in 1959 before 17 of his Indian teammates were born.

title: MUSIC: CAYENNE JAZZ BAND
description: THE Cayenne Jazz Band, which on Thursday played one of the two free jazz concerts being given daily through Tuesday at the South Street Seaport's Jazz Festival, is a seven-piece band with an unusual mixture of 1920's traditional jazz and 1950's be-bop along with generous servings of Duke Ellington.

title: IN JERSEY, A STRESS ON URBAN HOUSING
description: BUILDING or rehabilitating housing in New Jersey's decaying urban neighborhoods is on everyone's mind as Governor Kean and the State Legislature try to design a housing program for the current legislative session.

title: LLAMAS BEING BRED FOR PETS AND PROFIT
description: JONI DAOUD loves to hug her llamas. She also loves to walk them and, occasionally, she'll even invite one of them, like Peachy Keen, to follow her inside the house.

title: GOING FAR BEYOND MIRANDA RULES IN FAIR TREATMENT OF SUSPECTS
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: BREAKING THE RULES. By Caroline Lassalle. (Viking, $16.95.) The British author Caroline Lassalle's fourth novel (the first three were thrillers written under a pseudonym) is a serious attempt at character study. We first meet Celia in a Greek island village, drinking red wine, smoking cigarettes and brooding on the lives of five women she has known.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RCA. By Robert Sobel. (Stein & Day. $19.95.) Learning what was and suspecting what might have been are at the heart of Robert Sobel's intriguing history of the RCA Corporation, its founder, David Sarnoff (who was 80 years old when he died in 1971), and the parade of executives that followed him. Mr. Sobel, the author of ''IBM'' and ''ITT,'' digs carefully into the history of RCA and Sarnoff's incredible career. The result is a fascinating study of an innovative thinker who foresaw the impact of radio in 1916 and of television in 1924, but who, the author writes, eventually ''led RCA into unchartered territories, which resulted in a string of missteps, errors in judgment, and outright blunders.'' Mr. Sobel's account begins with the evolution of early wireless technology and concludes with the sale of RCA to General Electric in 1985 for more than $6 billion. ''RCA'' has the stuff of a smash television mini-series: intrigue between Wall Street and Washington, corporate raids, market wars and hardball corporate power plays. Sprinkled throughout are some historical corrections, including a reconsideration of the contributions of the Russian-born Vladimir Zworykin to the invention of television. Though ''RCA'' is a catalogue of amazing stories, it is especially a tale of missed opportunities and flawed judgment. An example was RCA's indifference to the threat of Japanese competition in the early 1960's, when it unwittingly handed over state-of-the-art technology licenses to Japanese manufacturers.

title: Ellen B. Wahl to Wed Daniel Parker in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Wahl of Royal Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter Ellen B. Wahl to Daniel S. Parker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Parker of Port Washington, L.I. The wedding is to be June 6.

title: DATA UPDATE: March 1, 1987
NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MARCH 1, 1987
description: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS 12-15 The President sought suggestions from Congressional leaders and personal advisers on how he could can regain his political and legislative momentum after three months of preoccupation with the Iran-Nicaragua affair. Page 1 A Nancy Reagan-Donald Regan clash on the telephone about 10 days ago sealed Mr. Regan's fate, White House officials say, adding that Mrs. Reagan got him dismissed from his post as chief of staff. 1 A changing 1988 Presidential race now that both Howard H. Baker and Mario Cuomo are out of the running is expected to lead to intense competition for the newly uncommitted and to a clarification of the Republican field. 1 A picture of Lieut. Col. title: IN DEFENSE OF VOLUNTARY EUTHANASIA
description: LEAD: A few short years ago, I lay at the point of death. A congestive heart failure was treated for diagnostic purposes by an angiogram that triggered a stroke. Violent and painful hiccups, uninterrupted for several days and nights, prevented the ingestion of food. My left side and one of my vocal cords became paralyzed.

title: Nancy Rodimer and Henry W. Wagner Are Wed
description: At St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church in Rockaway, N.J., yesterday Nancy Marie Rodimer and Henry William Wagner were married by the bride's uncle, Bishop Frank J. Rodimer of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Paterson, N.J. He was assisted by Msgrs. Charles Powers and Denis Hayes and the Revs. Patrick Browne and Edward Kurtyka.

title: Alaska Halts Wolf-Shooting From Helicopters
description: Hard economic times have ended a state program long opposed by animal protection groups: the shooting of Alaskan wolves from helicopters.

title: Germans in Buckskin
description: To the Editor:

title: A DEATH KNELL SOUNDS FOR MUSICAL JOBS
description: PEOPLE looking for job security have rarely chosen the music industry. But these days, musicians say, competition from machines has removed what little stability there was. Modern machines can effectively duplicate string sections, drummers and even horn sections, so with the exception of concerts, the jobs available to live musicians are growing fewer by the day.

title: BEFORE REPAINTING, REPAIR THOSE CRACKS IN THE WALLS
description: REPAIRING walls and ceilings is always an important step before any room is repainted. Fortunately, unless the plaster is in bad shape over a large part of the wall or ceiling, most such jobs can be safely and easily handled by anyone.

title: FENCING STAR AND COACH AIM TO PARRY EUROPEANS
description: LEAD: THE points of their weapons are blunted by beads, their faces are protected by wire masks and what would have been a cavalier's mortal thrust now just flashes a light on a scoring machine.

title: JULE STYNE AT 81: NOTES ON A 2,000-SONG CAREER
description: Of all America's favorite songwriters, Jule Styne is probably the most underappreciated, at least partly because of his virtuosity.

title: Dance
description: The Feld Ballet will be presenting its first ballet by George Balanchine - the high-spirited ''Tarantella'' - during the company's two-week spring season, which begins Tuesday at the Joyce Theater. And there will be a new work by Carolyn Carlson, the former Alwin Nikolais dancer who currently directs her own dance company in Paris. But for Feld fans, the highlight of the season promises to be the revival of his ''Tzaddik,'' created in 1974 and last seen in New York 10 years ago. Performed to Aaron Copland's ''Vitebsk,'' the dance is one of Eliot Feld's richest works, drawing on the choreographer's memories of the rituals he watched as a child in synagogue.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
'PRAIRIE HOME COMPANION' EXITS BOLDLY
description: LEAD: If it comes from Lake Wobegon, no news is decidedly bad news. So, it was a cause for sadness recently when Garrison Keillor, host of ''A Prairie Home Companion,'' announced that this homespun variety show, probably the most popular on radio, would sign off forever on June 13. Thereafter, Mr. Keillor, chronicler of events in the mythical

title: WADKINS SHOOTS 66 IN WIND TO LEAD BY 2
description: Lanny Wadkins, a superb player in the wind, said, ''I don't just stand there and fight the wind. I try to either use it or hit a shot low. I don't hit straight into the wind and try to hit it up in the air. I just try to knock it down.''

title: The Murder Sweden Can't Forget -- Or Solve
description: EARLY ON THE MORNING OF Jan. 20, 200 Swedish policemen surrounded a number of houses in Stockholm and rounded up 20 men. ''Three of those arrested,'' the police announced, ''have been informed of the suspicion of being accessories to the murder of Olof Palme.''

title: City Shelters Really Not Safe
description: A report by the Inspector General's office of the New York City Human Resources Administration confirmed what some homeless people have been saying all along: the city's 26 shelters for homeless single adults are not safe.

title: SAND PRICE VEXES HEMPSTEAD
description: LEAD: THE Town of Hempstead has locked horns with the Army Corps of Engineers over sand.

title: NOTED WIHT PLEASURE
description: Horsing Around in Paris

title: SCHOOL'S GROWTH PLAN IRKS SOME ON EAST SIDE
description: As such things go in New York, the building project on East 79th Street would not go very far: 10 stories. But that is enough to have incited some prominent neighbors, who are fighting an addition planned atop the Hunter College School of Social Work.

title: TALK ABOUT A BUYOUT!
description: THE WORD IS OUT: ON or about this St. Patrick's Day, Jack Frosting Partners, in alliance with Morgan, Livingston Inc. and the DeWitt, Lumpen Company (assuming Sid DeWitt is not in jail in connection with the latest ''unpleasantness'' about ''insider trading''), will tender for all of Britain. With this first offer for an entire nation, leveraged buyouts have come of age.

title: UP FROM HYPHENATION
description: GROWING UP ITALIAN By Linda Brandi Cateura. Illustrated. 268 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: Gorbachev Runs Into Opposition
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave outsiders a rare glimpse of discord in the Kremlin last week. Defending his version of democracy as an energizing alternative to ''stagnation and dormancy,'' the Soviet leader conceded that winning the endorsement of the 307-member Communist Central Committee in January was ''a difficult matter.''

title: USING THE FRUITS OF WINTER ADDS COLOR AND ZEST TO THE MENU
description: IN winter the produce stands turn gold and orange with citrus fruits. Varieties of tangerines, oranges and grapefruits provide nutritious refreshment as snacks and desserts and become key elements in recipes. At a time of year when many fruits are out of season or imported from the Southern Hemisphere and high-priced, having citrus fruits on hand can inspire the menu planner and the cook. Furthermore, these fruits are relatively durable. They keep well in the market and, refrigerated, at home.

title: Gephardt Says He Is In For '88
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, last week became the first major contender of his party to announce his candidacy for President. The manner of his announcement, in both style and substance, showed where he centers his hopes for success.

title: Brian D. McBride Plans to Be We To Miss Hackney
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Morris Hackney to Brian Dannell McBride has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Hackney of Philadelphia. Mr. McBride is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick McBride of Bayside, Queens. The wedding will be June 20.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PAST CARING. By Robert Goddard. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) When a down-at-the-heels historian named Martin Radford agrees to untangle a historical riddle for a wealthy patron his luck finally seems to be turning. Radford's pursuit of the riddle - which involves the inexplicable ruin of an Edwardian politician, Edwin Strafford - soon draws him into an intricate tale of murder and multiple betrayal. Betrayal is at the heart of ''Past Caring,'' and in this first novel the English writer Robert Goddard has done an expert job of piling one betrayal on top of another. The book is a good read, but also more ambitious than that. It tries to connect the betrayals to a broader view of history: ''After the Enlightenment,'' says one character, ''one day, they'll call this the Disillusionment.''

title: U.S. Expresses Hope For Action On Accord Soon
description: The Administration today welcomed the Soviet decison to seek a separate agreement on medium-range forces and expressed hope that the two sides could move quickly to conclude an arms accord.

title: Q AND A
description: The Right To Buy Question: I have a question on the rights of a tenant who with senior citizen status remained as a tenant in a building that was converted to a cooperative under a noneviction plan in 1980. The tenant chose not to buy and recently was notified by the sponsor that the apartment had been sold to another party. Does the tenant have the right of first refusal at the price offered to the other party? Is the sponsor obliged to notify the tenant in advance of the sale? . . . S. F., Manhattan Answer: The answers to both questions is no. The regulations regarding co-op and condominium conversions, promulgated by the State Attorney General Office, give tenants a 90-day period during which they have the exclusive right to purchase their apartments at insider prices and terms. Once the exclusive purchasing period has ended the tenants then have first refusal rights to buy the apartment for the same price and under the same terms offered to outside buyers. This period lasts for six months.

title: RIPENING DESIRE AND THE MUSE OF MIDDLE AGE
description: LITERATURE misses out on most of the fun of art. We don't get colors or new materials or music, just a lot of ''he saids'' and ''she saids'' mingled with greed and passion and ambition and bounded by the death of the characters or the laziness of the author or both.

title: Privacy Called Vital to AIDS Screening
description: WHEN Dr. John Martin's team at the Columbia University School of Public Health began a federally financed study of AIDS among male homosexuals, 410 of the 745 who were asked to participate declined.

title: PHOTOJOURNALISM'S COLORFUL ERA
description: PHOTOJOURNALISM IS ALIVE AND WELL, despite television. There may even be more news photographers at work now than in the 1940's, the heyday of the big American picture magazine. Today's work is mostly in color and is marketed worldwide to hundreds of publications. The best of it gives news events the permanence and haunting quality of art. The pictures here are by photographers represented by Contact Press Images and are part of an exhibition opening March 6 at the Midtown Gallery of the International Center of Photography in Manhattan. PHOTOJOURNALISTS WERE SLOW TO ADAPT TO the technical advances of photography. For a long time, 35-millimeter black-and-white pictures by Henri Cartier-Bresson, W. Eugene Smith, Robert Capa and David Seymour were revered as the ideal. Color was considered frivolous, the tool of advertising. All that changed rapidly in the last decade as color film became ''faster,'' that is, able to record events quickly without special lighting or long exposure. New lenses could capture good color, even at low levels of light, and handier, more sophisticated cameras brought the photographer in close. Advances in reproduction and printing made it possible for weekly newsmagazines (and now daily papers) to use color on tight deadlines. Today, pictures can be rendered into a digital code and sent by satellite to markets anywhere. Fast color is the name of the game. THE TECHNICAL IMPROVEMENTS HAVE NOT changed the goals of serious photojournalism, which remain those of the ''golden age'' of the 40's and early 50's: to offer visual information that legitimizes, confirms and reinforces what is written, and to capture the beauty, the tragedy and the universality of the human experience. ''People say we're inundated with pictures of blood and gore, images of the unpleasant side of life,'' says Robert Pledge, president of Contact, an agency made up of seven regular photographers and six others who are contributors. ''It just isn't so. Most of the pictures we see every day are pure entertainment - Princess Di, Dolly Parton and so on. The fact is that many of the images of violence and suffering are so powerful that people rarely forget them.'' The photographers still complain that editors use the wrong pictures. But despite their concern, the evidence of pictures like these leaves no doubt that their art remains vibrant.

title: Dale M. Cendali, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Cendali of Hartsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dale Margaret Cendali to John Francis Fitzpatrick, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas Fitzpatrick of Charleston, W.Va. A September wedding is planned.

title: Sally Ann Stoller Plans To Wed Gary Eisenreich
description: The engagement of Sally Ann Stoller to Gary L. Eisenreich has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Herbert Stoller of New York and Shirl E. Stoller of San Diego. Mr. Eisenreich is the son of Mrs. William F. Eisenreich of Alton, Ill., and the late Mr. Eisenreich.

title: 'The Broom of the System'
description: STANLEY ELKIN, an author never accused of being a minimalist, once recalled his defense when an editor advised, ''Stanley, less is more.''
