title: S.I. COLLEGE TEAM TO REFUSE TOURNAMENT BID
description: The College of Staten Island basketball team has agreed to refuse a probable bid from a major invitational tournament, dropping opposition to a ban the college president had imposed on postseason play because of a brawl with racial overtones at a regular-season game.

title: A STEAKHOUSE OFFERS FAMILY FARE
description: FAMILIES have been dining at Werner Baer restaurant in Cedarhurst for more than two decades. It's a downtown institution where life's milestones are often celebrated. At a nearby table one evening, an elderly couple were being honored on their anniversary. At another table, a 1-year-old birthday baby sat contentedly on his mother's lap during dinner.

title:
DINING OUT;
ON THE WATERFRONT IN PERTH AMBOY
description: LEAD: SOMETHING grand is afoot in Perth Amboy.

title: BIBLE IS BEING TRANSLATED INTO A SOURTHERN COASTAL TONGUE BORN OF SLAVERY
description: When Ronald Daise was growing up on this coastal island, he heard Gullah everywhere but he was taught not to speak it. That lilting tongue, he recalled, was not considered a language but merely a substandard form of English that would keep young blacks from getting on in the world.

title: A.M.C. BREAKS OFF AUTO TALKS
description: The American Motors Corporation today broke off talks with union leaders on wage concessions that the company said were necessary to keep open its only automobile assembly plant in the United States, a company spokesman said.

title: Jane Hoover To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Hoover of North Canton, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Curtis Hoover to Warren Delano Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Delano of Kittery Point, Me. The wedding is to be in May.

title: FUJI'S 35-MILLIMETER THROWAWAY
description: NOT every new piece of photography hardware can make waves by incorporating the latest technology in user-friendly form. Sometimes a small splash from the undertow of the tide of progress has to suffice. Such is the case with the new Fuji Quick Snap camera, announced in conjunction with last week's Photo Marketing Association trade show.

title: POSTINGS: Needed: 1,000 Rentals; Housing the Navy
description: Now that protests have subsided over plans to base the Battleship Iowa and six other naval vessels at Staten Island, the Navy has another hurdle to surmount: finding affordable housing for the 2,400 service personnnel who will run the base and their families.

title: Metro-North Police Force to Grow
description: Faced with a rise in crime in Grand Central Terminal and the rest of its rail system, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad plans to increase its police force by nearly 10 percent, a spokesman for the railroad said yesterday.

title: A TANGY 'PIRATE' AND PRICELESS DUKE
description: L.A. Suggested by the Art of Edward Ruscha. A film by Gary Conklin. Mystic Fire Video. 28 minutes. $50. Unless one knows and enjoys the paintings of Edward Ruscha, this film might seem bland or esoteric -a dreamy meditation featuring pan shots of palm trees against sunsets, skyscraper skylines, towering road signs and such, with jazz and classical guitar in the background.

title: Anne Davis Plans to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard A. Davis of Villanova, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Mumford Davis, to Jon Milton Peterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton V. Peterson of Fairfax, Va., and York Harbor, Me. A summer wedding is planned.

title: Reason and the Writer
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIE BLOODLINES LEAD TO RAMBO'S CHILDREN
description: Films may not have the bloodlines that race horses do, but a hit has a way of leaving a trail. Its descendants are liable to be indirect, thanks to the singularity that makes it a hit in the first place, and to the riskiness of exact cloning (since the authorized clone is almost always a letdown, and the clone without the ''II'' in its title seldom stands a chance). So anyone who sets out deliberately to copy a hit will soon discover the elusive brilliance of the original, whether it's ''E.T.'' or ''Top Gun'' or a $100 million-grossing dance movie. But that doesn't mean that the hit isn't, in its own way, able to spawn.

title: THE INSTANT SEASONED TRAVELER
description: Following is a primer, offering suggestions to help the traveler smooth the way and get better value on a trip abroad. AIR TRAVEL is much more expensive in Europe than in the United States and on the Atlantic routes. European airlines belong to an organization that structures fares to what the expense-account traffic will bear. If you're not in a hurry, travel by rail. BREAKFASTS in hotels are often a treat in such countries as Britain, Ireland, the Netherlands and Israel and may tide you over for a good part of the day. Many of the better hotels in Austria, Switzerland and West Germany, and some in France, include buffet-type breakfasts in their rates. In Italy breakfasts are usually skimpy if included, and expensive if not. CABS are more expensive in many European cities than in New York, mainly because gasoline costs more throughout the Continent. Fleets of radio-dispatched taxis operate in most places, but they often have a hefty charge on the meter when they pick you up. Cab rides from the airport to your hotel may cost $40 and more in Paris and Rome. Take the airport bus or the train wherever possible, as in Zurich, where the train from Kloten International Airport to the railroad terminal is $2.60. DEALS. The relative dearth of American tourists in Europe has prompted several regions, cities, hotel owners' associations and travel industry groups to offer special deals. These include package arrangements for accommodations and meals for periods of from three days to three weeks, and vacation booklets with cost-reducing coupons. EATING SPOTS. Meals in Europe's best restaurants start at around $50 a person and may go far beyond $100, especially with a good wine. Lunch may cost a little less than dinner, but not everywhere. Don't just follow the guidebooks; seek out local advice as well. At Citta' di Castello, a walled town in Umbria, I recently accosted a portly gentleman in the main piazza and asked him where I could get a decent lunch. ''There are two smart places nearby,'' he said, ''but their food is just so-so, and they are expensive. Go to Didon's, out on the highway to Perugia one kilometer from here, and you'll be grateful to me.'' I did and I was. FAST FOOD. You presumably aren't visiting Europe to eat cheeseburgers and milkshakes, but once in a while you might yearn for fast food, not to mention the chance to save money. The international chains have outlets in many European cities, and they feature such regional dishes as North Sea fish fillets and apple strudel. GUIDED TOURS are scorned by sophisticates, but permit a useful preliminary survey of a city or region. Fees for bus tours are usually reasonable, but keep in mind that many tour guides will steer their clients to restaurants, snack bars and souvenir shops and receive a fee in return. That fee will almost certainly be reflected in the price you pay for any merchandise. HOTELS. Even if you can afford $400 a night for a double room in a five-star hotel, you will probably be better off in a good medium-priced, medium-sized hotel. Switzerland publishes a brochure recommending one-star hotels, many of them family-operated, at around $32 a person a night for a room with a shower or bath, less for a room with only hot and cold water. INFORMATION. Collect all the details you need before starting your trip. National tourist offices in major United States cities can help with material on transportation, hotels, sightseeing and special events. JEANS are the unisex travel attire throughout Europe; in Eastern Europe people will even offer to buy the ones you are wearing. But be sure to pack something a little more formal than jeans, too. KIDS are being charged half rate or even less by many hotels in Europe now; ask about special rates when you book. Save money and nervous energy by sparing your children culinary adventures; they'll feel much more at home in fast food outlets and pizzerias. LUGGAGE. Experienced travelers know that less is best. Porters are no longer available at many airports and railroad stations and lower-priced hotels have dispensed with bellmen. MONEY. Change your dollars or traveler's checks at a bank; it will almost always be more expensive at hotels, travel bureaus and stores. Outside banking hours and on weekends official rates will be paid at currency-exchange booths at airports and railroad terminals. With the dollar fluctuating in value it may be risky to use credit cards. NIGHTCLUBS, limousines, gambling casinos, and gondola rides in Venice should all be avoided if you're on a tight budget. The same goes for black-market currency deals in Eastern Europe, where you may get stuck with bogus money or be courting legal trouble. Don't carry your wallet in your back pocket. Don't buy icons from touts in Moscow or Leningrad. Don't travel without a ticket on rapid-transit services in European cities: If you get caught, it won't help to claim you don't know the rules, and you'll have to pay a fine on the spot of at least 10 times the fare. OVERTIPPING should be avoided. In most European countries a 10 to 15 percent tip is already included in restaurant bills, and an additional 5 percent is usual for very good service. If your cab doesn't carry a notice that the tip is included, give 10 to 15 percent. PHONES. If you want to call home, do it from the local post office or telecommunications center. Most if not all European countries have authorized hotels to put a sizable surcharge on long-distance or local calls. It may even be cheaper to call collect. To be connected to an A.T.&T. operator in the United States, dial 080-089-0011 in Britain, 19 00 11 in France, and 06-022-9111 in the Netherlands. In other countries, dial the local operator for collect or credit-card calls. QUEASY feelings are something to be avoided on vacation, so play safe when it comes to exotic foods or bizarre beverages. Pack your favorite remedy for settling an upset stomach, or experiment with the local product. RENT-A-CAR. The international car rental companies operate fleets and offices in almost all European countries, but in many places local companies undercut their rates. Most of the local companies do not ask for a deposit if you produce a major credit card and an American driver's license (an international license, obtainable through the American Automobile Association, is even better). SHOPPING. Unless you get better advice from knowledgeable local people, downtown department stores are good places for exploring before turning to specialty shops. Duty-free shops at airports are not always cheaper than downtown stores. TRAINS in Europe range from the splendid French T.G.V. to crowded crawlers in the Balkans that can be recommended to no one but the hardiest traveler. In Western and Central Europe train travel is generally much cheaper than flying. Important centers are linked by intercity day trains; many long-distance night trains have sleepers as well as special coaches with four or six bunks to each compartment, available at a small surcharge. UNEXPECTED expenses invariably crop up, so keep some cash aside for possible emergencies. V.A.T. stands for value-added tax, which in most European countries is added to bills for all goods and services, including hotel rooms and meals. It can go up to 30 percent and even more for such luxuries as jewelry. Make sure the price you are quoted includes all taxes. Some countries refund taxes to tourists who take purchases out of the country; practices vary, some paperwork may be involved, and you may not be able to pack your purchases in checked baggage. WALKING is a great money saver. Many European cities spread out around a historic core holding castles, churches, palaces and other monuments that can be best visited on foot. It helps if you are staying close to the center. Many international hotels are based on the outskirts of cities because real estate is cheaper there and expense-account travelers don't mind taking taxis to business conferences. X FOR EXTRAS. It is almost always cheaper to buy what you want and take it to your room yourself than to call room service. As hotel restaurants often can charge more because they are so handy, you may want to go to a nearby cafe for coffee. Many deluxe restaurants in Europe have an annoying habit of serving hors d'oeuvres, sherbets or pastry that you haven't ordered, telling you they are offered by the chef. They are then put on your bill. YOUTH is well served in many European countries. If you're under 26, for instance, a Eurailpass good for a month will cost you $310; for two months it's $400. But you must travel second class and pay a surcharge for express trains. Youth hostels are widely available, with prices ranging from $8 to $10 a night. In France a special Youth Card offering discounts on air and rail transportation, as well as admission to sporting and cultural events, is available to people 25 years old and under. Restaurant privileges include year-round access to university dining rooms (where a meal costs about $2.50) and discounts at fast-food chains. Cards, valid from June 1 to May 31, are available at Youth Information Services located in town halls, tourist offices and Credit Mutuel banks. ZERO EXPENSE. Not all the best things in life are free, but some still are. There is no extra charge for the view of the Alps from your train window. And once you are there it costs nothing to gaze on the beauty of St. Peter's in Rome, the Acropolis in Athens, the waterfronts of Nordic cities or the dramatic west coast of Ireland.

title: Mary P. Hickey Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Stark Hickey of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., and Willsboro, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Page Hickey, to Capt. David I. Klumpar of the Air Force Medical Corps, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan V. Klumpar of Lexington, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: Drawing Conclusions From the Tower Findings
description: THE report of the President's Special Review Board detailed how President Reagan and some of his Administration's highest officials were involved in the Iran-contra affair. Bernard Weinraub of The New York Times interviewed public figures in and out of Government on the meaning of the Tower commission's report, which was issued Thursday. Following are excerpts from the interviews and from public statements. ELLIOTT L. RICHARDSON Resigned as Attorney General during Watergate

title: With Syrian Aid, Life Returns to West Beirut
description: Portraits of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria have gone up in West Beirut quarters where those of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini used to hang.

title: HOW CLAUDIO ABBADO WINS OVATIONS IN VIENNA
description: When Claudio Abbado leads the Vienna Philharmonic in an all-Beethoven cycle at Carnegie Hall beginning Friday, an old-fashioned wristwatch may peep out from under his sleeve. It was given to him by Erich Kleiber, the late Vienna-born conductor who was a champion of modern music, but was admired also for his interpretations of the classical and romantic repertory. The good-luck charm is a symbol of the Italian maestro's closeness to the Central European music tradition.

title: Miss Deretchin Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allen N. Deretchin of Glen Cove, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kay Deretchin, to Lawrence A. Gussoff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Gussoff of Rye Brook, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

title: Cable TV
description: ''Return of the Jedi'' is all over cable this week - one of four plum premieres on the home screen. George Lucas's 1984 windup of his ''Star Wars'' trilogy leads the parade. It's showing on four channels and six days: Sunday at 7 P.M. on HBO; Monday at noon and 8 P.M. on Showtime; Tuesday at 8 P.M. and 3:35 A.M.; Thursday at 5 P.M. and midnight; and Saturday at 8:30 A.M. and 7:30 P.M. on Cinemax; and Wednesday at 9 A.M., 5:50 P.M. and 3:30 A.M. on WHT.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ON THE LEFT BANK 1929-1933. By Wambly Bald. Edited by Benjamin Franklin 5th. (Ohio University, $19.95.) Wambly Bald lived in Paris at almost the right time. He arrived there in 1929, just at the end of that magic decade, and began writing articles on bohemian life for the European edition of The Chicago Tribune. His column, much of which is reproduced in ''On the Left Bank 1929-1933,'' was an irreverent who's who of the avant-garde. It poked fun at all who haunted the Latin Quarter or who took themselves too seriously. He described Ford Maddox Ford as a ''huge, bland bulk'' whose jaw ''woggled'' when he danced, and wrote that Aldous Huxley, then 38, looked ''like a person who had been concentrating for 75 years.'' Much of Mr. Bald's commentary was tongue in cheek; he was a master of the one-liner and the telling anecdote. His columns consisted of reconstructed conversations, barroom banter and gossip, amid his reports on gallery openings, dance performances and parties. Most wicked were his comments on visits with artists and writers. He reported that Gertrude Stein told him that all of literature would come down to ''the big four'': Poe, Whitman, James and herself. ''The Blood of a Poet,'' a new film by Jean Cocteau, was, Mr. Bald wrote, ''as false as a gold tooth and just as obvious.'' Occasionally he was sentimental, especially toward the end of his stint in Paris. By 1933, as more and more of the old guard left for America, he lamented that ''nothing will remain but a legend and half a dozen crowded saloons.'' And, it could be added, this stylish commentary by a witty raconteur.

title: Sarah S. Jeffrey Is Bride Of James Dulin in Jersey
description: Sarah Stewart Jeffrey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Robert Jeffrey Jr. of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to James Garrettson Dulin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stimson Dulin of Bayfield, Colo. The Rev. William Strain performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: RAGTIME PIANO IN BERGEN Max Morath, ragtime pianist and singer, will be at John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood Friday with his ''Pop! Goes the Music.''

title: Revealing an Ordeal
description: David L. Wolper, the producer, sought for years to put ''The Betty Ford Story'' on film. But Betty Ford, who lived it and then wrote about it, resisted the notion of a televised account of her treatment for drug and alcohol abuse. ''It was still too much of an emotional issue for her,'' Mr. Wolper recalled recently. But in 1986, he said, five years after her treatment, the former First Lady relented because ''it would help other people.'' The result is to be aired tomorrow on ABC. Mr. Wolper said Mrs. Ford initially objected to some strong scenes depicting a family confrontation over her alcoholism and some arguments with her husband. But ''eventually she came around,'' Mr. Wolper said. ''She is not one to hide things.''

title: A NOBEL LAURATE PROBES HIS ROOTS
description: For more than half his 51 years, the Nigerian writer Wole Soyinka has been admired as poet, essayist, memoirist and untiring -and fiercely tested - social critic. But when, in December, he accepted the Nobel Prize in Literature, he addressed the Nobel Foundation as a playwright. For Mr. Soyinka, in the tradition of political dramatists from Sophocles to Bernard Shaw, has created a body of theatrical work that embraces poetry, social and political criticism and, of course, memory.

title: SYRACUSE TOPS BOSTON COLLEGE TO SHARE TITLE
description: Rony Seikaly scored 18 points tonight as Syracuse claimed a share of the Big East Conference regular-season title with an 87-63 victory over Boston College.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Cheyenne, Wyo.;
Homes On the Range
description: LEAD: AS Wyoming ranchers, suffering losses in income for the fifth consecutive year, cast about for alternative uses for their property beyond the raising of livestock and crops, one has come up with an imaginative idea to save his family's spread.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
AMERICA FROM UPTOWN
description: LEAD: While the Harlem Renaissance (1919-1929) produced writers, musicians and performers whose names are familiar today, visual artists of the era remain underrated and virtually unknown. HARLEM RENAISSANCE: Art of Black America (The Studio Museum in Harlem, New York/ Abrams, $35), published in connection with the opening last month of an exhibition through Aug.

title: DYBBUKS IN DIXIE
description: LAZAR MALKIN ENTERS HEAVEN By Steve Stern. 249 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: States Spend Billions but Lag Behind Rate of Imprisonment
description: THE numbers game goes on every day of every week. Under a Federal court order, Texas officials painstakingly monitor the population of the state's overloaded prison system, admitting more inmates only when at least 5 percent of its beds are empty. The system has closed its doors five times already this year; last month it was warehousing new inmates in local jails more days than it was admitting them. Gov. Bill Clements authorized emergency provisions Friday to permit sending some 185 inmates to halfway houses, but officials said their beds would be filled at once.

title: HOUSTON SCORES 53 AS ARMY BEATS FORDHAM
description: Kevin Houston, the nation's leading scorer, put on a record-shattering show, scoring 53 points today as Army erased a 17-point second-half deficit and defeated Fordham, 98-94, in overtime.

title: Linking a Gene To a Mental Illness
description: The Old Order Amish of Lancaster County, Pa., shun such modern inventions as electricity, telephones and cars. But the nature of the Protestant sect is so close knit that it has been contributing for years to some of the most advanced research in human genetics.

title: RUSSIANS IN VIETNAM: U.S. SEES A THREAT
description: The commander in chief of the United States Pacific Fleet says the Soviet Union has quadrupled the size of a former United States base in South Vietnam and is using Russian forces there to intimidate the Philippines and other Pacific nations.

title: FAMILY LIFE IS A CONTACT SPORT
description: A WRESTLING SEASON By Sharon Sheehe Stark. 359 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: Stung by Report, Reagan Is Trying To Set New Course
description: ''THE problem, at the heart, was one of people, not of process. It was not that the structure was faulty. It was that the structure was not used.'' Brent Scowcroft, a deceptively mild-mannered Mormon, a retired Air Force general who served as national security adviser to Gerald R. Ford, used those words last week to summarize the findings of the special Presidential board that had just issued a damning indictment of the Reagan Administration's policies in the Iran-contra affair.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of erroneous information provided by the British Tourist Authority, the Travel Advisory column of Feb. 22 gave an incorrect telephone number for information on vacations offered by the Youth Hostel Association of Great Britain. The number is 212-581-4700.

title: Condor Trapped for Breeding
description: One of the last two California condors known to live in the wild was captured Friday in an effort to save the giant birds from extinction by breeding them in captivity. Only 27 of the birds, the largest in North America, are known to exist. Thirteen are in the San Diego Wild Animal Park and 13 in the Los Angeles Zoo. The newly caught male weighs 19 1/2 pounds and appears healthy, a spokesman for the wild animal park said. The carrion-eating condors, with bare heads and necks and black plumage, have wingspans reaching 10 feet.

title: Villanova Equation Has a Key Factor
description: BY day she attempts, sometimes in vain, to convey the elements of algebra to students at Archbishop Carroll High School in Radnor, Pa. But at night, when Shelly Pennefather teaches lessons in winning basketball, she nearly always makes her points.

title: New Arena of Conflict?
description: To the Editor:

title: A BEATLES FAN MAKES DEVOTION HIS BUSINESS
description: WHEN Charles Rosenay was 5 years old, he now recalls, he stared mesmerized at the television set one night in 1964 while the Beatles performed on the Ed Sullivan Show.

title: A Global Treasure Trove
description: TRUE ANTIQUE dealers are collectors who cannot stop. Living on an eternal treasure hunt, they spend their days endlessly searching the world for art and objects with a special provenance and beauty. Their homes, then, are where many unusual pieces are hidden, at least temporarily, until they are relegated to their shops or are replaced by yet another object of even greater stature.

title:
INVESTING;
THE SURPRISING COMEBACK OF JUNK BONDS
description: LEAD: IN the weeks after the Ivan F. Boesky scandal broke, junk-bond prices dropped sharply as buyers all but disappeared. They were worried that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the dominant force in the market for these low-rated, high-yield bonds, would be dragged down by Government investigations into insider trading.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 1, 1987
description: Weeks This On Week List FICTION 1 5 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Bantam, $4.95.) A rich, beautiful young woman conquers the world of magazine publishing. 2 6 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. (Fawcett, $4.95.) In the Republic of Gilead, men and women perform the services assigned them. 3 5 SEASONS OF THE HEART, by Cynthia Freeman. (Berkley, $4.50.) A businesswoman is torn between devotion to her husband and her mentor. 4 13 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) An Englishwoman in Afghanistan, caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B. 5 5 THE IMMIGRANT'S DAUGHTER, by Howard Fast. (Dell, $4.50.) The last volume of the Lavette saga tells of a woman involved in today's politics. 6 50 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 7* 8 THE STORYTELLER, by Harold Robbins. (Pocket, $4.50.) A poor boy from Brooklyn sets out to make it big in the world of glamour as a writer. 8 14 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $4.95.) Ayla of ''The Valley of Horses'' resumes her adventures in the prehistoric world. 9 14 THE TWO MRS. GRENVILLES, by Dominick Dunne. (Bantam, $4.50.) Romance, scandal and murder in New York's high society. 10 3 CHAIN OF ATTACK, by Gene DeWeese. (Pocket, $3.50.) The Enterprise is surrounded by hostile aliens in the 32d ''Star Trek'' novel. 11 2 NERILKA'S STORY, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $3.95.) While fighting a plague on the planet Pern, Nerilka finds a true love. 12* 2 AMERIKA, by Brauna E. Pouns. (Pocket, $4.50.) The United States 10 years after a Soviet takeover; based on a mini-series written by Donald Wrye. 13 18 SECRETS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) Behind the scenes of a television production. 14 41 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $4.95.) Continuing the story begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 15 10 ANGELS OF SEPTEMBER, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Geis/Warner, $4.95.) Father Blackie Ryan investigates an art gallery explosion. Weeks This On Week List NONFICTION: General 1 48 OUT ON A LIMB, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $4.50.) The actress's midlife ''journey to find her true self.'' 2 14 DANCING IN THE LIGHT, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $4.50.) The entertainer wins an Oscar, survives a stormy romance and has new visions. 3 3 WISEGUY, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Pocket, $4.50.) Life in a Mafia family. 4 175 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 5 8 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) Strange neurological disabilities. 6 1 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. Weeks This On Week List NONFICTION: Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 39 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. (Pocket, $4.50.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 2 5 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $4.95.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 3 4 THE FRUGAL GOURMET, by Jeff Smith. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A television chef's inexpensive dishes. 4 23 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 5* 17 THE FAR SIDE GALLERY 2, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $9.95.) Cartoons. 6 6 THE ARTHUR YOUNG TAX GUIDE 1987. (Ballantine, $10.95.) Aid from an accounting firm. 7* 16 THE PRICE WATERHOUSE GUIDE TO THE NEW TAX LAW. (Bantam, $3.95.) A handbook. 8* 39 ADULT CHILDREN OF ALCOHOLICS, by Janet Geringer Woititz. (Health Communications, $6.95.) Advice about a family problem. 9* 16 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1987. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. The number of titles within the two subdivisions of nonfiction can change from week to week, reflecting changes in book buying. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Heeding a Call
description: An appeal from a man who shares his antipathy to abortion led to the surrender last week of Dennis J. Malvasi, a fireworks expert wanted in the bombings of several New York City abortion clinics. Mr. Malvasi gave himself up to Federal authorities the day after John Cardinal O'Connor urged him to do so in a television news interview. The Cardinal said the bombings were ''contradictory to the fundamental teachings of our Catholic faith.'' A spokesman for the Cardinal said the prelate was ''pleased that Mr. Malvasi has come in and pleased that he was able to play some small part in it.'' The Federal agents who arrested Mr. Malvasi quoted him as saying, ''It's hard to turn down the Cardinal.'' He entered no plea at his arraignment on charges of bombing three abortion clinics and attempting to bomb a fourth.

title: AID IN FILING TAX RETURN AVAILABLE
description: LEAD: MORE than 418 volunteer income tax-assistance services at sites in all 21 counties are available for the elderly, the handicapped and people who cannot afford professional tax help.

title: FOR MOST NEW YORKERS, CABLE TV IS A MIRAGE
description: THE cable television picture in New York City suddenly went blurry last week after a surprise move by Mayor Koch and the municipal franchise director, Morris Tarshis, to seek new bids for service throughout most of the city. Only American Cable of Queens and BQ Cable, in parts of Brooklyn and Queens, will be spared potential competition.

title: ITALY SIGNS ACCORD WITH COUNTRY'S JEWS
description: The Government and Jewish spokesmen signed an accord Friday that replaced legislation governing Jewish life in Italy that had been in force since Mussolini's regime.

title: Promotion Based On Race Is Upheld By Supreme Court
description: For the first time, the Supreme Court has made clear that judges may force employers to use strict and specific racial quotas to promote blacks as a way of remedying past discrimination.

title: TWO YEARS THAT SHOOK THE WORLD
description: LEAD: ARMED TRUCE The Beginnings of the Cold War, 1945-46. By Hugh Thomas. Maps. 667 pp. New York: Atheneum. $27.50.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: M. PAMPLEMOUSSE ON THE SPOT: A Gastronomic Mystery. By Michael Bond. (Beaufort, $14.95.) Monsieur Pamplemousse eats and drinks again in this diverting novel, the third in a series of mystery-farces featuring the French detective turned gastronome. The mystery begins with the disappearance of ''Souffle Surprise'' from the menu of a three-star establishment in the French Alps. To restore the missing dessert Pamplemousse must track down a kidnapped pastry chef; his search leads him into danger - at an exclusive girls' school with a suspicious record of skiing accidents - and deeply into farce, during an amorous encounter with Fraulein Brunnhilde, the school's mountain-size gym teacher. Michael Bond is well known as the writer of the Paddington Bear stories, as well as other books for children. In his first series aimed at adults, he has created a comic idea of a French detective -Pamplemousse philanders, knows wine labels like his ABC's and treats his canine sidekick, Pommes Frites, like a human being. No matter. Serious insight, except in matters of food and wine, is not the point here; nor is the mystery, which is easier to solve than the crossword puzzles Pamplemousse does to improve his English. Like a successful souffle, this is light, fluffy, skillfully made, with no aftertaste or afterthoughts to disturb the reader.

title: A TANGY 'PIRATE' AND PRICELESS DUKE
description: Robert Schumann's Davidsbundlertanze Members of New York City Ballet. Home Vision. 43 minutes. $39.95. Although it bears an unwieldy title, this George Balanchine work is an eloquent ballet, as this video version makes clear. Young people appear to be dancing happily in a ballroom. Then one discovers that their merriment is forced, their gaiety desperate. Emotional storms arise and the choreography alludes to madness and death. This fine production, featuring members of the New York City Ballet under Merrill Brockway's direction, makes artful use of closeups to emphasize both the intricacy and the dramatic power of the choreography. Equally fascinating to behold is Rouben Ter-Arutunian's set, which depicts a ballroom that looks out upon a forbidding body of water and a ghostly cathedral.

title: STAGE: DAVID CALE'S 'SMOOTH MUSIC'
description: LOVE confounds all in the performance artist David Cale's ''Smooch Music,'' which is playing through next Sunday at the Kitchen (512 West 19th Street). Mr. Cale has been working as a monologuist since 1982; with ''Smooch Music,'' he adds music -for saxophone, bass and percussion, written by the saxophonist Roy Nathanson - to 23 overlapping stories about love and lust. The selections are about as long as pop songs, and they sketch situations with the economy and resonance of pop lyrics, illuminated now and then by a telling, specific detail.

title: BUDGET CUTTING STALLS IN GRIDLOCK OF PRIORITIES
description: LAST July, the United States Supreme Court drew the teeth of the budget-balancing law known as Gramm-Rudman-Hollings. Now the law's other key feature - rigid limits to the deficit, bringing it down year by year to zero in 1991 - is threatened. The chairmen of the House and Senate budget committees suggested last week that the law could still work even if Congress raised the ceiling for 1988.

title: THE HONEYMOON IS A MEMORY
description: Just two years ago an overseas trip was financially irresistible: Americans almost couldn't afford not to go, since it was cheaper than staying at home.

title: CUOMO PLEDGE OF BETTER SCHOOLS
description: SAYING that public schools in New York State had abandoned an important responsibility - the teaching of ''values'' - Governor Cuomo promised proposals to restore this function.

title: OTB WOULD ADD AMENITIES
description: SEEKING to make its offtrack betting parlors more attractive - and more profitable -the state is considering adding closed-circuit television to some of the 14 OTB outlets for patrons to watch the races they are betting on.

title: WHO'S AHEAD NOW IN NUCLEAR ARMS?
description: THE Soviet Union ended an 18-month unilateral freeze on nuclear testing last week, prompting disagreement over what the resumption of explosive tests bodes for the future of Soviet weaponry. The Pentagon said that it means little and that the Russians already had surged ahead in nuclear arms development despite the moratorium. But many Western and Soviet scientists argued that the freeze had brought Soviet nuclear work to a halt and that the resumption of testing promised a new round of weapons development, including arms that are increasingly viewed as threatening to President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' antimissile plan.

title: The Abacos
description: To the Editor: I read with interest Sarah Bird Wright's article (Travel, Jan. 18) on the Abacos, as we spend the majority of our summers in that area. Her information was accurate with one exception. Pete's Pub burned to the ground last June 28. We were anchored in the harbor the night of the fire and tried to help the family and friends put out the fire - an impossible task on a little island. Fortunately, no one was hurt. MARY ANN BECKER Vero Beach, Fla. Mrs. Wright replies: I am indebted to Mrs. Becker for her letter and am saddened to learn of the fire at Little Harbor. It happened, of course, after our visit. Readers will be happy to know that Pete Johnston is planning to rebuild the pub.

title: 'STARLIGHT EXPRESS' ROLLS TO MARKET WITH A ROCK BEAT
description: If the $8 million Andrew Lloyd Webber musical ''Starlight Express'' becomes the commercial blockbuster that its producers envision, its advertising slogan, ''The race is on!'' could resound from coast to coast for years to come. Hit records, a rock-and-roll-styled road show, a movie and a blizzard of merchandise would rain profits on the most expensive musical ever mounted on Broadway.

title: SCIENCE WITH A HAPPY ENDING
description: VICTORIAN ANTHROPOLOGY By George W. Stocking Jr. Illustrated. 429 pp. New York: The Free Press. $27.50.

title:
TV VIEW;
FURTHER ESCAPISM FASHIONED IN THE KRANTZ FACTORY
description: LEAD: Following the turgid pretentiousness of ABC's ''Amerika,'' the trashy glitter of CBS's ''I'll Take Manhattan'' arrives as something of a blessed relief. We are back snugly in the arms of normal American commercial television - acting out fantasies of wealth and power, and wafted into an ether of pure, undemanding escapism.

title: Chicago Mayor Leads
description: For more than four decades it was the election for mayor, but the Chicago Democratic primary last Tuesday was only the first battle. Introducing the winner, Harold Washington, the incumbent, at a victory rally, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said, ''Tonight we won the playoffs, but the Super Bowl is April 7.''

title: SHOWING HAMPTONS ART IN WINTER
description: KAZUKO HILLYER says jokingly that when she was growing up in Kyoto, Japan, she was the black sheep of the family because she was always doing the unexpected. ''A Kyoto girl was supposed to be very traditional, and I'm the total opposite,'' she said.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: BY NO EXTRAORDINARY MEANS: The Choice to Forgo Life-Sustaining Food and Water. Edited by Joanne Lynn. (Indiana University, $25.) When can nutrition and hydration be withdrawn from a terminally ill patient? Here are 27 compelling essays by ethicists, theologians and medical and legal experts on this and related questions.

title:
FOCUS: Malls;
Casting A Hotel as An Anchor
description: LEAD: WHEN Central Coast Plaza, a new 270,000-square-foot shopping center, opens next month in San Luis Obispo, a city of about 100,000 people midway between San Francisco and Los Angeles, one of its anchors will be Gottschalk's department store. The other anchor, however, will not be the expected second department store, but rather the four-story Park Suite Hotel and Conference

title: JUNKYARD OR MARS, OPERA DESIGN IS A SMOKESCREEN
description: If you believe everything you read, you know that opera is undergoing a violent but ultimately healthy jolt, something akin to the shock treatment that therapists have sometimes used to rouse patients out of deep depression. The therapists in this case are the concept-mongers, stage directors whose whole object is to give a stunningly novel twist to a familiar score. In no other way, they and their propagandists assure us, can the 387-year-old extravagance known as opera hope to survive.

title: The Focus on Israel
description: Thomas Friedman's cogent summary of the varied causes for the world's consuming interest in Israel omitted the overriding reason.

title: WILL 'SOLUTION' HASTEN BEACH EROSION?
description: LEAD: IN an oceanfront sandlot in the Fire Island summer village of Fair Harbor, a Federal parks official recently pondered a $100,000 question of priorities.

title:
DANCE;
'DANCE CELEBRATION' TO FEATURE VILLELLA
description: LEAD: EDWARD VILLELLA, former New York City Ballet superstar and dance ambassador extraordinary, and a small group of dancers will comprise one of five evenings of ballet sponsored by the Arts Council of the Morris Area in a festival called Dance Celebration II.

title: STATE CHIDED ON WETLANDS AREA
description: LEAD: THE State Department of Environmental Conservation has failed to implement the 1973 Tidal Wetlands Act, demoralizing the department, infuriating developers and threatening one of the most vital areas of the environment, according to a technical advisory committee evaluation.

title:
DINING OUT;
SOME SEAFOOD VALUES IN NYACK
description: LEAD: EXCEPT for a modest price increase, little has changed at Hilltop in the last dozen years: the Donado family still owns and actively operates this restaurant and bar, and although on a popular weekend evening some diners who were crammed three deep at the convivial bar were heard to grumble at having to wait - despite reservations - up to an hour for a table, waiting seems to be as much a tradition as the copious portions and the somewhat ramshackle air and draftiness of the premises.

title: The Adjustable Lease
description: The lease a merchant signs today is rarely as sweet as those from a decade ago. Back then, many leases allowed landlords little or no opportunity to adjust their rents as operating expenses and taxes climbed skyward.

title: ATHLETES LOOKING TOWARD WORLD TITLES
description: Athletes aren't supposed to be looking ahead, but it seemed that some were thinking ''world'' and not ''American'' in the unusual USA/ Mobil indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden Friday.

title: LOOKING BEYOND THE 'AW-SHUCKS' ACT
description: T BOONE Pickens is a skillful corporate raider who has had a high old time flinging rocks at corporate management and painting himself as an aw-shucks, down-home fella who just wants to help out the little shareholders on the block. He rides around in his corporate jet taking pot shots at the ''bad guys'' for riding around in corporate jets. He is like a little kid who gets left out of a club meeting in the tree house and tries to kick the ladder down.

title: MAN HELD IN LOS ANGELES FIRE
description: A 28-year-old man was arrested here Friday in connection with a fire that destroyed 700,000 books in the Central Library last year, the authorities said.

title: Words, Words, Words
description: EVERY SO OFTEN, IT IS MEET and proper to once again examine a peculiar subgenre of the English language - and of the American language as well -that has flowered wildly in recent years, like some pulpy jungle plant. It's called winespeak.

title: STICKS AND STONES: THE NAME GAME
description: THE other children on the block called my son a chicken. I wasn't there when it happened. I was in the house, changing my younger son's diaper, when I heard the door slam.

title: A TANGY 'PIRATE' AND PRICELESS DUKE
description: Treemonisha By Scott Joplin. With Obba Babatunde, Carmen Balthrop, Curtis Rayam, Dorceal Duckens, Delores Ivory, Kenn Hicks, Cleveland Williams. Arranged and Orchestrated by Gunther Schuller. Conducted by John DeMain. Directed by Frank Corsaro. Produced by the Houston Grand Opera. SONY Video Software. 92 minutes. $79.95.

title: 2 UNIVERSITIES GET AIDS CARE GRANTS
description: Two universities will begin programs to help physicians and others meet the mental-health needs of AIDS patients in the New York metropolitan area.

title: The New Flirt
description: MY MOTHER HAS given me only three books in my life. The first, when I was 13, was called ''On Becoming a Woman.'' The second, when I was 21, was called ''365 Ways to Cook Hamburger.'' The third, when I was 25, was called ''How to Catch and Hold a Man.''

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Reincarnating a Hotel and a Theater
description: LEAD: WITH 556,972 residents in 46 square miles, Hudson County is the most densely populated county in New Jersey. In its 12 municipalities, most of them along the Hudson River, little land is left open to development.

title: One Day in a Rookie's Life: Hard Work, Lots of Hope
description: THE fans who gather early in the morning behind the closely guarded fences outside Fort Lauderdale Stadium do not seem to notice the arrival of Phil Lombardi. Their gazes belong to Don Mattingly and Dave Winfield, whose autographs become cherished items to the kids wearing Yankee baseball caps under the warm Florida sun.

title: LARNED BLATCHFORD FOWLER JR. IS WED TO JENNIFER LEE BRANSON IN CALIFORNIA
description: Jennifer Lee Branson was married yesterday to Larned Blatchford Fowler Jr., a son of Mrs. William R. Miller of New York and Lawrence, L.I., and the late Mr. Fowler. The Rev. Barbara C. Mudge, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Dr. and Mrs. William A. White of Laguna Beach, Calif.

title:
GARDENING;
KEEPING GERANIUMS HEALTHY IN WINTER
description: LEAD: NOT too many years ago, geraniums were both the No. 1 potted plant and bedding plant in the country. They slipped from the top as potted plants when chrysanthemums became available year-round and as bedding plants when petunias, impatiens and marigolds increased in popularity.

title: WASHINGTON TALK
description: Starting tomorrow, Washington Talk will appear in The Times Monday through Friday.

title: Mothers Get Partial Custody Of 5 Children Found in Park
description: Temporary custody has been awarded to the mothers of five of six children found in a park in the care of two men from a communal group in the Washington area.

title: Trevino Tees Off
description: THE Masters may seem to be the ultimate golf tournament, but not to Lee Trevino. He says he won't play this year and won't miss it much, either.

title: Black Settlement Is Unearthed
description: The oldest settlement of free blacks in America was so little noted for so long that it was up to archeologists to find it under the Florida mud. They have succeeded for the most part, and last week, in the marshes outside St. Augustine, they showed off a few remains of the old camp called Fort Mose.

title: MUSIC: CHELSEA ENSEMBLE
description: THE Chelsea Chamber Ensemble's program at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday tried to explain the new Romanticism by placing it alongside the old.

title: PRETORIA'S PRESS CURBS LIMITING COVERAGE OF STRIFE
description: The South African Government's 16-month campaign of steadily tightening restrictions on the flow of information has proved effective at limiting reports of apartheid-related violence and at shaping news coverage in both the United States and South Africa.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Lloyd Advances:Chris Evert Lloyd, the defending champion, routed Vicki Nelson-Dunbar, 6-0, 6-0, yesterday to advance to the fourth round of the $1.8 million International Players championships at Key Biscayne, Fla. Other top-seeded players who advanced were Hana Mandlikova and Yannick Noah. Mandlikova won the first two games of her match with Svetlana Parkhomenko of the Soviet Union, then lost the next five. Almost as quickly as she lost her touch, however, she regained it and won five straight games to take the opening set by 7-5. Parkhomenko, who double-faulted six times in the first set, led by 4-2 in the second. Mandlikova held serve for 4-3 and broke Parkhomenko in the eighth game to pull even. She broke her again two games later to win the set by 6-4 and the match. Noah played his second five-set match in three days and beat Sweden's Ulf Stenlund, 1-6, 6-0, 6-4, 2-6, 6-3. His first-round match against Italy's Claudio Panatta lasted four sets. (AP) Skiing Zurbriggen Nears Clinching: Although he failed to score a point yesterday, Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland apparently clinched his second World Cup overall title when the only man who could catch him, Markus Wasmeier of West Germany, was injured during the day's downhill ski race at Furano, Japan. Preliminary reports said that the 23-year-old Wasmeier suffered a back injury and would be sent home for medical treatment. Zurbriggen, who has 274 points to 174 for Wasmeier, could clinch the title by winning the supergiant slalom today. (AP) Schmidhauser Slalom Champion: Corinne Schmidhauser of Switzerland clinched the women's World Cup slalom title yesterday after posting the fastest times on both runs of a fog-shrouded course to take the event's last race of the season, at Zwiesel, West Germany. It was the 22-year-old Swiss standout's third World Cup victory of the season. Schmidhauser clinched the slalom title when her closest rival, Tamara McKinney of the United States, dropped out after making a mistake in the second run. (AP) Boxing Galaxy Keeps Title: Khaosai Galaxy of Thailand knocked out the Indonesian challenger, Ellyas Pical, and retained his World Boxing Association super flyweight title with a 14th-round knockout in their scheduled 15-round championship bout at Jakarta, Indonesia. Each weighed 114 1/2. Galaxy extended his record to 30 victories, including 26 knockouts, against a defeat. (AP) Speed Skating Soviet Protest Is Upheld: Sergei Fokichev of the Soviet Union was declared the winner of the men's 500-meter race at a World Cup speed-skating meet following a protest last night in the meet at Hamar, Norway. Fokichev had posted the fast time of 37.48 seconds but was disqualified for two irregular starts and Nick Thometz of the United States was declared the winner with a time of 37.64 seconds. The Soviet team protested and several hours after the meet ended the meet jury lifted the disqualification. Thometz dropped to second place and Jens-Uwe May of East Germany to third. Michael Hadschieff of Austria won the 1,500-meter race in 1 minute 58.66 seconds. (AP) Blair Takes Sprint: Bonnie Blair of United States won the women's 500-meter sprint in a World Cup speed skating meet at Helsinki, Finland. Blair has won all seven World Cup sprints this season and is certain to be crowned champion at the finals in Inzell, West Germany, March 12-15. Blair was timed in 41.31 seconds. Karin Kania was East Germany was second in 42.39 and Natalya Artamandova of the Soviet Union third. Katie Class of the United States was fifth in 42.86. Blair placed third in the 1,500 meters behind Yvonne van Gennip of the Netherlands and Andrea Ehrig of East Germany. (AP) N.B.A. Jordan Gets 37: Michael Jordan scored 17 of his 37 points in the fourth quarter to help Chicago rally to a 107-104 victory at Chicago over the Milwaukee Bucks, the Bulls' fourth straight victory. (AP) Hawks 123, Trail Blazers 102: Dominique Wilkins scored 8 of his 25 points in a 14-2 spurt at the start of the game, and added 6 in a 12-0 third-quarter run for the Hawks. Kevin Willis had 24 points, John Battle 21 and Randy Wittman 16 for the Hawks, who took their biggest lead at 108-75. (AP) N.H.L. Bruins 5, Sabres 1: Charlie Simmer scored two goals and assisted on two others as Boston defeated Buffalo at the Boston Garden. Keith Crowder also had two goals, his 16th and 17th, for the Bruins. (AP) North Stars 6, Kings 3: Craig Hartsburg scored with 41 seconds left in the second period to cap a four-goal surge that carried Minnesota to victory over Los Angeles. (AP) Black Hawks 2, Penguins 1: Bill Watson and Wayne Presley scored third-period goals to help the Blackhawks extend their unbeaten streak to 3-0-2. Blackhawks took over third place in the Norris Division, 1 point ahead of St. Louis. (AP) Whalers 2, Nordiques 1: Sylvain Turgeon and Paul MacDermid scored second-period goals and Mike Liut made 31 saves, including 16 in the first period barrage, for the Whalers. MacDermid scored the game-winner on a long slapshot from the right wing with 7:43 left in the second period. (AP) Bowling Chicagoan Bowls Perfect Game: Larry Carmack of Chicago bowled a perfect game at the 84th American Bowling Congress championships tournament at Niagara Falls, N.Y. With the 300 game, the 41-year-old right-hander bested his previous high of 297. The 300 was only the sixth in team competition and the 74th in American Bowling Congress tournament history. (AP) Jerseyan Loses: In Peoria, Ill., top-seeded John Gant beat Parker Bohn of New Jersey, 223-190, in the title game to capture the $150,000 True Value Open yesterday. It was the second Professional Bowlers Association victory for Gant, of Independence, Ky., and the first since the summer of 1984. (AP) Horse Racing Proud Debonair Wins: Despite racing widest throughout, Proud Debonair was up in the final strides to score a neck victory in the $116,200 Grey Lag Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. The 5-year-old son of Lyphard-Proud Delta carried Jean-Luc Samyn to the wire just ahead of King's Swan who was a neck in front of Lover's Cross. It was the second victory in three starts this year for Proud Debonair. Samyn was aboard for both. Proud Debonair went a mile and an eighth on the fast track in 1:49 2/5 to earn $69,720 for Sam F. Morrell. He paid $5.60 for $2 to win as the favorite in the field of six.

title: REALTY AND RUDE AWAKENINGS
description: AFTER three years of dealing with Roman banks, language difficulties, and the incomprehensible bureaucratic tangles in which Italy specializes, I looked forward to the move back to New York. At last, I thought, I would be transacting business on the basis of clear, sensible rules, understanding and making myself understood, dealing with people who put the same value I did on efficiency and economy. I hadn't reckoned on the real estate market in Westchester County.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: A PIONEER WHOSE IMAGES RANGE FROM THE GRIM TO THE GLITTERY
description: Gordon Parks, whose 200-print retrospective exhibition is now at the New York Public Library, was the first black photojournalist to win a wide public audience and the admiration of his peers, black and white. During a 23-year career with Life magazine he covered everything from the Black Muslims to Paris fashions, and he did so with professionalism and sophistication.

title: L.I. SCHOOLS STILL REACH FOR THE STARS
description: LEAD: DEIRDRE McCLOSKEY takes her seven-and-a-half-hour school day for granted. Into the day she crams classes in the gifted program, aide duty and a kindergarten class, band practice, after-school clubs, homework and home chores.

title: POW! ARRGH! U.S. COMICS TAKE ON MALAYSIA
description: In Singapore and Malaysia, where English is widely read and spoken, one American export has withstood the onslaught of Japanese consumer goods: comic books.

title: A Carolinian Outing
description: North Carolina Democrats held a fund-raiser at a Capitol Hill landmark, the Eastern Market, featuring what one of them called ''the three chief staples of North Carolina life,'' barbecue, blue grass music and basketball.

title: '88 RACE RESHAPED BY BAKER PULLOUT
description: For the second time in 10 days, the 1988 Presidential race has been scrambled by the withdrawal of a potential candidate with significant standing in the opinion polls and substantial support among party leaders.

title: Challenging The Rights Of Special Prosecutors
description: AN issue of constitutional law brought together two of the Reagan Administration's most prominent and embattled veterans last week. In lawsuits filed less than a day apart, Michael K. Deaver and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, both under investigation by special prosecutors, challenged the constitutionality of the law that permitted the prosecutors' appointments.

title: VOLUNTEERS IN LONG BEACH JOIN TOGETHER TO REBUILD THE DUNES
description: LEAD: AFTER the Guarini family of Long Beach had the porch ripped off their house in September 1985 by Hurricane Gloria, they decided to fight Mother Nature.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Athol, Mass., Awaits Atholl

title: April 5 Wedding For Dr. Germano
description: Dr. Isabelle Margherita Germano and Dr. Joshua Benjamin Bederson, residents in neurosurgery at the Medical Center at the University of California, San Francisco, are planning an April 5 wedding in New York.

title: HOTEL TAX FACES NEW OBSTACLE IN ALBANY
description: THE proposed county hotel tax, a 3 percent levy on hotel and motel rooms that would provide $3.5 million a year for Westchester's homeless, came a step closer to resolution in Albany last week, but remained well short of final approval.

title: SPACE STATION IS AMERICA'S LEG UP TO THE STARS
description: To the Editor:

title: MEMORIES OF A TIME WHEN 'THE WIND' BLEW HOT
description: ''The Wind'' was one of the grimmest experiences of my 105 movies over 75 years. It was also one of the most gratifying films I made at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

title: Magruder Marries Counselor
description: The Rev. Jeb Stuart Magruder, who became a minister after spending time in prison for his role in the Watergate scandal, was married today to Patricia Ann Newton, a high school guidance counselor. Mr. Magruder, 52 years old, held several White House positions from 1969 to 1973, including deputy director of communications at the time of the Watergate break-in in 1972. He spent seven months in prison after pleading guilty to perjury and conspiracy to obstruct justice. It was the second marriage for both.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
ARTS SUPPORT NOTED
description: LEAD: Mary Lou Dickinson, Superintendent of Schools in the Hastings-on-Hudson Union Free School District, is one of 13 school administrators nationwide who have been honored for outstanding support of arts-in-education. The award was given by the Alliance for Arts Education, part of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in

title: Guildford
description: THE classic 11-acre village green laid out in Guilford in the mid-1600's -crisscrossed with footpaths and surrounded by churches and old buildings housing art galleries, the Town Hall, banks and shops - makes for a blend of old New England charm and contemporary chic that has attracted 500 new residents a year over the last three decades to this historic community.

title: EUROPE DEPICTING A CRIPPLED REAGAN
description: Western European commentators and politicians have concluded that President Reagan has been crippled by the Tower Commission report on the White House's handling of the Iran-contra affair. They remain divided, however, on his chances for recovering his authority as the leader of the United States and the NATO alliance.

title: SONG OUT OF TUNE WITH THE TIMES
description: IT seemed inevitable that Dartmouth College, which started accepting women in 1974, would one day have to face the issue of the school anthem. Adopted in 1926, it begins: Men of Dartmouth, give a rouse For the College on the Hill! For the Lone Pine above her And the loyal sons who love her! Give a rouse! Give a rouse! For the sons of old Dartmouth, The sturdy sons of Dartmouth.

title: TEACHING COMPUTERS TO EMULATE BACH
description: CAN a personal computer be classified as a musical instrument?

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''OPEC has put itself in a box by setting established prices that are way out of line.'' Charles T. Maxwell, of Cyrus J. Lawrence, on the problem of $18-a-barrel oil.

title: METS AS BRASH AS EVER
description: ''They hate us,'' Keith Hernandez said, sizing up the Mets' relationship with the rest of the teams in the National League. ''If I was on another club, I'd hate us, too. But we'll be there at 7:30 every night, 162 times, and they know where they can find us.''

title: OWNER ADMITS ERROR ON LIFETIME PACTS
description: By MURRAY CHASS

title: GOOD-TIME BEACH TIME
description: IT is a wild time for inexpensive watches. Now Gottex, the popular Israeli swimsuit manufacturer, is entering the fashion watch fray with some very wild timepieces. The Gottex name has been licensed to a watch manufacturer, Bienne, which will shortly begin selling timepieces designed to coordinate with colorful Gottex swim wear.

title: SOVIET AIDE STARTING ASIAN-PACIFIC TOUR WITH THAILAND VISIT
description: The Soviet Union, capping more than a year of overtures to Southeast Asia and the Pacific, is sending Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on a tour of the region beginning Monday.

title:
MUSIC;
SOLO AND ENSEMBLE STRINGS IN SPOTLIGHT
description: LEAD: OSCAR RAVINA of Upper Montclair, a violinist with the New York Philharmonic and a member of the Montclair State College music faculty, will be the soloist with the Ridgewood Symphony Orchestra Friday night in Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto in E minor.

title: Lorraine Johnson, Banking Official, Becomes a Bride
description: Lorraine Johnson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Johnson Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Peter Donaldson Prentis, a son of Helen Donaldson Grant of West Palm Beach, Fla., and Edmund A. Prentis 3d of Delray Beach, Fla., and Westhampton Beach, L.I. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church.

title: South Bronx Hub
description: To the Editor:

title: PARKING LOTS FIGHT FUND RAISERS
description: LEAD: THEY have been fixtures at airports and have maintained a ubiquitous presence on the city's subways, soliciting money to support their religion or finance their cause of the moment. But in recent months, the fund-raising efforts of groups like the Hare Krishnas have widened to the suburbs, specifically the parking lots of Long

title:
INVESTING;
BANKS WITHOUT A BRAZIL TAINT
description: LEAD: Even before Brazil began talking tough about its debt to foreign creditors, most American bank stocks were dragging. One problem affecting even the healthy regionals - which have no direct exposure to third world debt - is the fear that interest rates will go higher. But that concern may be overdone, according to Nancy A.

title: John C. Carson Jr. Weds Suki Stone, Official at a Bank
description: Susan Jane Stone, a daughter of Lieut. Col. William Leete Stone 3d, United States Army, retired, and Mrs. Stone of Bel Air, Md., was married yesterday to John Congleton Carson Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Carson of La Jolla, Calif. The Rev. James F. Madison performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Churchville, Md.

title: Caray Plans Return
description: HIS speech is still a bit slurred, and he'll need someone to push his wheelchair up the ramps at Wrigley Field, but if all goes well Harry Caray, the 70-year-old announcer who suffered a stroke Feb. 17, should be in the booth for the Chicago Cubs' first game, April 7.

title:
ART;
LANGUAGE BECOMES THE MEDIUM OF THE MESSAGE
description: LEAD: IT seems logical in this age of communication that language itself would become a principal motif for artists.

title: NEWARK AIRPORT ADDS PARKING SPACES
description: LEAD: NEW conveniences for passengers have been added at Newark International Airport, which last year handled 29.5 million travelers.

title: Dropout Problem Is Worsening
description: WITH the release of troubling new dropout statistics last week, the New York City Board of Education learned yet again how intractable the problem has become.

title: SAMPLING FRENCH B&B'S
description: On a five-week visit to France last September we spent our nights on the road in chambres d'hotes, the French equivalent of bed and breakfast stops - private homes that take paying guests.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: THE SPLENDOR OF ORCHIDS All the delicate phalaenopsis, cattleyas, paphiopedilums, vandas, cymbidiums and dendrobiums will be at the peak of their bloom from Tuesday through March 8 at the Champion International Corporation's orchid exhibition in its greenhouse. The building is at the intersection of Tresser Boulevard and Atlantic Street in Stamford.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN MUSIC TECHNOLOGY
description: GUITARS, a few brass instruments, even a violin or two line the counters along the entrance to Alex Musical Instruments on Manhattan's 48th Street. But it is the equipment in the back of the store, which overflows with a dazzling array of electronic keyboards, drum machines, synthesizers and computer software, that provides most of the sales.

title: HOSPITALS OFFERING DAY CARE
description: LEAD: IN an effort to recruit and retain nurses, which are in short supply throughout the state, two hospitals in eastern Connecticut have decided to offer in-house day care to their employees.

title: Resisting an Arrest
description: Italian authorities last week issued a warrant for the arrest of Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus, but it did not appear that they would be confronting him any time soon.

title: ABUSE OF IMMIGRATION LAW FEARED BY SOME HISPANIC GROUPS
description: A FEAR that the immigration law passed by Congress late last year could worsen conditions - particularly working conditions - for members of the county's Hispanic population has put many of their community groups on guard.

title: INSPIRED BY THE PAST
description: A major component of fashion is nostalgia, reacting to the styles of the past,'' says the designer Bill Blass. ''But the role of the designer is to refresh and change that look for the present.'' Blass, whose New York office boasts bound volumes of Vogue and Harper's Bazaar dating from 1935 to 1952, points out an elegant long pink silk crepe dress with a black point d'esprit ruff in a videotape of his spring show. ''The minute I finished putting that dress together,'' he says, reflecting on the glamour of the old magazines' fashion pictures, ''I knew I had designed it primarily to be photographed.''

title: THE WILDCATS' GREAT HOPE
description: IT WAS 3:29 P.M. A BIT HESITANTLY, A dozen Northwestern University players took to the court on their first day of organized practice for the coming Big Ten college basketball season. It was also the first day they would work with a new head coach.

title: A QUARTET OF SILENT CLASSICS THAT ADVANCED THE ART
description: LEAD: In the 60 years since the talkies transformed the film medium for good and all, a small, stubborn band of enthusiasts has persisted in championing the special eloquence of silent movies. Among them are the distinguished film historian Kevin Brownlow and the indomitable Lillian Gish - who certainly ought to know, having spent the last 75 years gracing movies both mute and loquacious.

title: THE WILDCATTER'S TALE
description: ''FRED, I think we've got a sissy here,'' said Duke Rudman to his chauffeur, Fred Washington. At the time, Mr. Rudman, clad in peach-colored jogging pants and a gray hooded sweatshirt, was digging in his toes and traipsing across an interviewer's back to demonstrate the Oriental acupressure massage therapy he had learned in Japan.

title: Wendy Lea Brown and Dr. Jack Pressman Marry
description: The marriage of Wendy Lea Brown, a lawyer, and Dr. Jack David Pressman, a medical historian, took place yesterday in Philadelphia. Rabbi Brian Walt performed the ceremony at the Horticulture Center in Fairmount Park.

title: Waiting For Rain
description: LOOSE-FITTING BALMACAANS, trench coats, durable oil slickers -rainwear's classic repertory alters little from year to year. But while designs remain fairly constant, raincoats these days are simpler, more streamlined and elegant than they've been in many seasons.

title: Soviet Dissident Is Sent To Psychiatric Clinic
description: A former Soviet airline navigator whose nine-year battle to leave the Soviet Union received widespread attention in the West was seized by plainclothesmen tonight and sent to a Moscow psychiatric clinic, the man's daughter said.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
STRATEGIES, TECHNIQUES AND TACTICS FOR LANDING AN APARTMENT
description: LEAD: THE APARTMENT rental market is tight. It was tight five years ago, when you had to sell your soul for an apartment, and it's tighter now.

title: A YOUNG LAMB PLAYING WITH LIONS
description: There are only a handful of living men, and even fewer women, who can claim to have partnered Ely Culbertson, the dominant authority of the 1930's who introduced the new game of contract bridge to millions. One of the handful, and probably the senior chronologically, is Harold Fishbein of La Jolla, Calif. He is unrelated to the late Harry Fishbein, a colorful expert who managed the Mayfair Club in New York City.

title: Ann Walsh to Marry Robert W. Anthony
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Walsh of New London, Conn., and Fishers Island, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ann Mariah Walsh to Robert Weeks Anthony, a son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Reed Anthony of Glen Head, L.I. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Julie A. Kielty Is Bride Of Michael J. Connolly
description: At Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Ridgewood, N.J., yesterday Julie A. Kielty, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Kielty of Milwaukee, was married to Michael J. Connolly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Connolly of Ridgewood. The Rev. Eugene Heyndricks performed the ceremony.

title: SOMETIMES IT'S BETTER TO BE HEARD THAN SEEN
description: THE two women had been carrying on business conversations by telephone for about six months. When they finally met, one looked at the other and said, with great surprise, ''But you're not fat!''

title: SIGNAL APPAREL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The amounts for 1986 reflect a change in the method of accounting for certain pension costs. Share earnings are not adjusted for the class B common stock to be issued on April 10, 1987, to common stockholders of record on March 10, 1987. Share earnings reflect the provision for convertible preferred dividends. Signal Apparel Co. was formerly Wayne Gossard Corp.

description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

S.E.C. STUDIES TRE TRADING
description: As part of its broad investigation into the takeover practices of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and other firms, the Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into the circumstances surrounding the acquisition last year of the TRE Corporation, sources close to the investigation confirmed yesterday.

title: DYNAMICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,768,000 for the quarter and $2,377,000 for the year; and the year also includes a charge of $392,000 for anticipated refunds on customer contracts and a charge of $732,000 for special expenses related to the investment in CTS Corp. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $526,000 and $1,919,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and the year also includes a gain of $5,739,000 from a patent award and a gain of $3,095,000 from a settlement with Lionel Corp.

title: DANCE: ELIASBERG IN CHOREOGRAPHIC DEBUT
description: KRISTIN ELIASBERG, a fine, experienced performer who has been a member of several modern-dance groups, made her choreographic debut Friday when Kristin Eliasberg and the Everybody Company appeared at the Bessie Schonberg Theater as part of the theater's 11 P.M. series of dance events. The members of her recently organized company looked as capable as Ms. Eliasberg herself. Yet, choreographically, it was a program of disconnected bits and pieces.

title: JENSEN SEEKING A FINAL CHANCE
description: LIKE Mark Jackson and Reggie Williams, Harold Jensen, Villanova's 6-foot-5-inch senior guard, is one of the final links to the Big East's glory year of 1985, when three conference teams made the Final Four.

title: THE YARDSTICK OF CORRUPTION IS IMPRESSIONISTIC
description: A year has elapsed since the first formal charges were lodged in New York's corruption scandal, but anyone who had hoped that the scandal would have faded away by now is in for some rude reminders.

title: CONTINENTAL MATERIALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
FAMOUS RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $12,500,000 charge for the establishment of a reserve for underperforming restaurants for both the quarter and year, and the quarter also is after a $572,000 charge for reversal of net operating loss carryover benefits recognized in prior quarter. c-After a charge of $219,000 for reversal of tax credit. d-Net income

title: IN INDIA, ECONOMIC GAINS AND NEW PERILS
description: After two years of widely applauded liberalization measures, India's economy has achieved solid growth - but it has also run into problems that threaten to undercut the recent gains.

title: REDMEN SPAWN NEW RIVALRY
description: Before Saturday night's game, the St. John's-Pittsburgh series had essentially been a series of good, hard-nosed Big East games, but nothing on the order of St. John's rivalries with Georgetown and Syracuse.

title: CONTRAS' MILITARY LEADERS RESISTING A REORGANIZATION
description: Senior military officials in the Nicaraguan rebel movement say they are worried that continued political disputes will weaken their cause, but they warn that they will resist any effort by American and disgruntled civilian rebel officials to impose changes without their consent.

description: Leading tin producers began a new quota system to bolsterworld prices, which crashed two years ago, and asked the United States not to undermine their effort by selling from its large strategic stockpile.

description: b-Net income

title: APPLE'S 2 NEW MACINTOSHES
description: Apple Computer Inc. will introduce two Macintosh models on Monday that will usher in a new generation of technology for personal computers and serve as the basis for the company's growth for years to come.

title: ISRAELIS SAY ARMS LINK WON'T IMPERIL ADVISER
description: An Israeli Government adviser who dealt closely with White House officials in the Iran arms affair is not in danger of losing his job because of the disclosures in the United States, ranking officials said today.

FITCHBURG GAS & ELECTRIC LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a charge of $4.7 million for a writeoff of an investment.

title: MAN SHOT AND KILLED IN A QUEENS TAVERN
description: An unidentified assailant opened fire on two Queens men during a dispute in a bar yesterday morning, killing one of them and seriously injuring the other, the police said.
