title: CABLE SYSTEMS DROP OR SHIFT PBS STATIONS
description: Cable television systems across the country, wielding their new power to pick and choose the programs they carry, are dropping public television stations or switching them to less desirable positions on the cable dial.

title: AMERICAN PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Canucks 4, Sabres 2: Patrik Sundstrom and Barry Pederson scored 12 seconds apart late in the second period for Vancouver to break open a tight game last night. Sundstrom scored his 20th goal of the season 17 minutes 59 seconds into the second period and Pederson followed with his 20th at 18:11. The Canucks won despite being outshot by Buffalo, 37-19. Play in the defensive zone was a determining factor in the game, with Vancouver playing solidly in front of Frank Caprice and the Sabres playing loosely in front of Tom Barrasso.(AP) North Stars 5, Flyers 4: In Bloomington, Minn., Brian Lawton and Dino Ciccarelli scored the tying and go-ahead goals 3:31 apart in the second period. Kari Takko had 40 saves for Minnesota.(AP) Blues 5, Penguins 5: Greg Paslawski scored with 1:57 left in the third period to give St. Louis the tie in Pittsburgh. Paslawski fired a shot over Gilles Meloche's glove from the left face-off circle for his 20th goal of the season.(AP) Track Boileau Takes Marathon: Art Boileau of Canada led most of the way and won the second Los Angeles Marathon, which drew a field of almost 15,000. The 29-year-old Boileau completed the course in 2 hours 13 minutes 7 seconds. The defending champion, Ric Sayre, 33 years old, of Ashland, Ore., finished second at 2:13:37. Nancy Ditz of Woodside, Calif., won the women's division for the second year in a row, in 2:35:23. Sylvia Mosqueda of Los Angeles was second.(AP) Lynch Sisters Win: Shola Lynch won the 1,000-yard run in 2 minutes 31.86 seconds, and her sister, Nnenna, was the winner of the mile run in 4:52.55 in the Eastern States girls high school indoor track and field championships at Harvard University. Shola, a senior at Hunter College High School in Manhattan, set a New York State public high schools record with her time, which also is the fastest in the country this season. Nnenna, a sophomore at Hunter, had a personal-best time. Two other New York State records were set. Notre Dame of Staten Island ran 9:15.80 in winning the two-mile relay and Tilden of Brooklyn was first in the mile relay in 3:52.40. Notre Dame's time was 1 second off the national record, while Tilden's clocking was the best in the country this season. Speed Skating U.S. Finishes 1-2: Nick Thometz and Erik Henricksen of the United States finished 1-2 in the 1,000-meter race at the men's World Cup speed-skating meet in Hamar, Norway. Thometz was timed in 1 minute 17.51 seconds with Henricksen 13-hundredths of a second slower.(AP) Horse Racing Play the King Is First: Play the King, who shipped up from Florida expressly for the engagement, raced to a one-length victory in the $84,000 Toboggan Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Comic Blush, the early leader, was runner-up, finishing three-quarters of a length ahead of the favorite, Best by Test, who failed to lodge a threat. Play the King, a 4-year-old son of King of Spain-Whisper, carried 112 and was ridden by Ruben Hernandez. He went six furlongs on the sloppy track in 1:09 3/5 to earn $50,400 for Kinghaven Farm and returned $8.20 for $2 to win as the third choice in the field of six.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Suppose Don Mattingly has hit safely in 30 straight games, then goes 0 for 3 before his last turn at bat in the ninth inning of a game the Yankees are losing badly. On the first pitch to him in the ninth, he hits a catchable foul pop off third base that the third baseman drops for an error. If Mattingly lines the next pitch for a single, does he extend his hitting streak or is it over because of the error? Without the error that extended Mattingly's turn at bat, there could be no hit to extend his streak. But the streak stays alive because it was the hit, not the error, that enabled Mattingly to reach first base safely. The error merely prolonged Mattingly's time up, in effect, giving him another chance for a hit that he still had to make. Had the pop-up been dropped in fair territory for an error, then Mattingly would have made it to first, but his hitting streak would not have made it to 31. QUESTION: An answer last month involving Wilt Chamberlain's averaging 50.4 points a game in the same season (1961-62) that Elgin Baylor averaged 38.3 got me to wondering: has anyone else averaged better than 35 points a game for a season? Only Rick Barry, but that singularity might end this season if Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls maintains his 37.3-point average. In 78 games during the 1966-67 season, Barry averaged 35.6 points with the San Francisco Warriors and led the National Basketball Association with 2,775 points. No wonder: he attempted 2,240 field goals, which was 541 more than any other player that season. Barry, recently elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame, averaged 24.8 points for his 14-year pro career. Baylor never again averaged 35 points or better in a season, but Chamberlain did it four other times on his way to a career average of 30.1 points. QUESTION: During the slam-dunk competition held before this season's N.B.A. All-Star Game, Michael Jordan, using a running start, made a shot after taking off from behind the foul line. If Jordan wanted to do this during a game, perhaps in order to make sure he didn't miss a crucial free throw, why couldn't he, since the ball would pass through the basket and hit the floor before he came down? Although free throws have been shot one-handed, two-handed, underhanded and overhanded, a player trying to slam-dunk a foul shot would be caught red-handed by the rule book. There is nothing wrong with leaving your feet to attempt a free throw, as in a jump shot, a style Hal Greer used years ago on the foul line. But the jump-foul-shooter has to stay behind the foul line. The rules prevent a free-throw shooter from crossing the plane of the line before the ball hits the rim or backboard. Otherwise, a violation would be called, the point would be erased and the ball would be turned over to the opposing team on the sideline. However, there's nothing wrong with a free-throw shooter moving forward and upward for the ball after it strikes the rim or backboard and ramming it home before he hits the ground. That play, of course, would be scored as a field goal worth 2 points and not a free throw worth 1. QUESTION: Who are the five women with the best times in the 1,500-meter run? Are any Americans among them? The top 10 in this outdoor event includes nine Soviet women and one Rumanian, Doina Melinte. The world- record holder is Tatyana Kazankina of the Soviet Union, whose time of 3 minutes 52.47 seconds was established in 1980. Next are four other Soviet runners: Olga Dvirna (3:54.23 in 1982), Zamira Zaytseva (3:56.14 in 1982), Tatyana Pozdnyakova (3:56.50 in 1982), and Nadezhda Raldagina (3:56.63 in 1984). The 11th best woman in the event - and also the best American - is Mary Decker Slaney, whose time of 3:57.12 in 1983 is nearly 4 1/2 seconds off the world mark. QUESTION: In the National Hockey League, how many players can a team carry on its roster and how many are eligible to play in a game? Technically, there is no league limit on the number of players on a team's roster, but realistically each team imposes a ceiling because there is a league limit on how many roster members can play in a game. Only 18 players are allowed to suit up for a game, plus two goaltenders. So teams generally carry a roster of 22 or 23 players, scratching two or three from each game, perhaps those still nursing injuries or those who have been ineffective of late. To carry more than that number on the roster would not only be an expense for the club, but also would be at the expense of the extra players, who could put the time to better use skating with a minor league affiliate instead of sitting with the parent club. QUESTION: In the bout in which Muhammad Ali beat Joe Frazier in Manila in their third heavyweight match, was Ali ahead on points at the time Frazier's corner stopped the fight before the final round? When Eddie Futch, Frazier's trainer, called it quits before the bell for round 15 - it was scored a 14th-round knockout for Ali - the defending champion Ali was decisively in front on the scorecards of the referee and the two judges, all of whom were from the Philippines. Under the 5-point must scoring system in which the winner of a round automatically earns 5 points, Referee Carlos Padilla Jr. had Ali ahead, 66-60; Judge Alfredo Quiazon had it 67-62 for Ali, and Judge Larry Nadayag 66-62 for the champion. On a rounds basis, Quiazon gave Ali 8 rounds, Frazier 3, with 3 even, and the others each had it 8-4-2 for Ali. Question Box is a regular feature of SportsMonday. Readers are invited to submit questions concerning any aspect of sport - statistics or strategies, rules or records. The address is Question Box, SportsMonday, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Unfortunately, questions not published cannot be answered individually.

title: S.E.C. PONDERS 'INSIDER' LAW
description: THERE are times when even a bureaucracy such as the Securities and Exchange Commission changes it mind, and that appears to be the case on whether a definition of what is illegal insider trading is needed.

TRACK AND FIELD;
BROOKLYN TECH WINS 4TH STRAIGHT TITLE
description: LEAD: Three years ago, Len Malech took over the boy's track and field coaching duties at Brooklyn Tech, succeeding Ed Zarowin, who retired with 16 Public Schools Athletic League city titles to his credit at Tech.

title: GERMANIA FA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes provsions for losses on loans and real estate of $2 million for the quarter and $8.2 million for the year. c-Includes provisions for losses on loans and real estate of $412,000 and $1.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively; and the year also includes a charge of $442,000 due to the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principles.

title: CONCERT: FREDDIE JACKSON
description: FREDDIE JACKSON, the Harlem-born pop-soul singer, whose second solo album has held at No. 1 on Billboard's black album chart for the last 13 weeks, has triumphed by taking the rococo crooning style of his fellow New Yorker Luther Vandross and roughing it up a bit.

title: CALLING GERALDO RIVERA! A FORUM VIVIFIES CONSTITUTIONAL AMENDMENTS
description: Mary Jones, the Mayor of Metropolis, lies in a pool of blood, an 11-inch knife protruding from her chest. The killer, her husband, is on the phone to Geraldo Rivera asking him to put the whole grisly scene on television.

title: 'ESTHER' AS ORATORIO AT ALICE TULLY HALL
description: Handel's ''Esther'' is the embodiment of oratorio's kinship with opera, having in its earlier years served in both capacities. This English retelling of ancient Jewish history originates from 1720, and the first performances seemed to have been operatic - this before a pious ban of staged religious topics turned the piece into a drama for the ears alone.

title: STERN BRAZILIAN IDEALIST ON ECONOMIC MISSION
description: While tens of millions of Brazilians spent a long weekend in wild revelry at carnival, their Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro, was in Washington and European capitals for somber negotiations about Brazil's latest debt problems. For those who know the minister well, it seemed quite appropriate.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: FUND-RAISER LINKED TO IRAN DEALS SAID TO BE SEEKING AUDITS
description: Carl R. (Spitz) Channell, the conservative fund-raiser whose organizations are being investigated by Federal authorities for their involvement in the Iran arms affair, is making an effort to clear his name by hiring an accounting firm to audit his books, two of his associates say.

title: JOY MANUFACTURING IS 'HOME' TO CHIEF
description: Roy Wennerholm Jr. has been named chairman, president and chief executive of the Joy Manufacturing Company, a mining-equipment manufacturer, in a move that is something of a homecoming.

title: Villanova Women Win Big East Title
description: Shelly Pennefather scored 28 points and grabbed 10 rebounds to lead Villanova to a 60-45 victory over Boston College for its second consecutive Big East women's basketball title and a berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: THEATER: 'MONA ROGERS IN PERSON'
description: WHEN we first meet Mona Rogers (Helen Shumaker), the sole character in Philip-Dimitri Galas's ''avant-vaudeville'' theater piece ''Mona Rogers in Person,'' her brassy, cigarette-ravaged voice rings caustically from the nearly dark stage on which she poses perched atop a short flight of stairs leading nowhere. ''Who needs another woman with too much hair?'' she demands. ''Who needs another story about her?''

title: SURROGATE MOTHERS VENT FEELINGS OF DOUBT AND JOY
description: For many of the nearly 600 women in the United States who have acted as surrogate mothers, the experience of bearing children for others has been one of fulfillment, an opportunity to make a gift of life. For others, giving up a child born on contract has left a bitter residue of remorse.

title: METHODE ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PARALYZED OFFICER FORGIVES TEEN-AGE ASSAILANT
description: A New York City police officer, Steven McDonald, paralyzed from the neck down and breathing with the aid of a respirator, expressed pity and forgiveness yesterday for the teen-ager who shot him in Central Park nine months ago.

title: CLAROSTAT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Year to Jan 3
STAGE: SOYINKA'S 'DEATH AND THE KING'S HORSEMAN'
description: THERE'S a lot of reading material available to those unsuspecting theatergoers who stumble into Wole Soyinka's ''Death and the King's Horseman'' at the Vivian Beaumont. The Lincoln Center Theater management has seen fit to provide not only a plot synopsis in the Playbill but also a handbill containing a second synopsis (longer but still unilluminating), descriptions of the leading characters and historical background and, finally, an author's note in which the playwright gives his own work a rave review. Is somebody trying to tell us something? I'm afraid so. Even with the elaborate documentation, ''Death and the King's Horseman'' is frequently baffling in this production, and even when it's coherent, it's stupefying. During the first half, one hears the constant sound of Playbills rustling, as the audience tries to figure out what's going on. After intermission comes a kind of resigned hush, most of the survivors having given up.

title: Cuba Slides Downhill
description: Cuba's problems and sharp new austerity program are driving it toward more complete integration into Comecon, the Soviet economic bloc. Already, a staggering 85 percent of its total trade, and 89 percent of its exports, is with Communist countries, one of the highest proportions of any bloc member.

title: EXPERT ON VIETCONG STRENGTH
description: Col. Gains Hawkins of the Army, retired, who was an expert on enemy forces in the Vietnam War and served as a defense witness in Gen. William C. Westmoreland's unsuccessful libel suit against CBS, died Thursday of a gunshot wound that the Clay County authorities said was apparently self-inflicted. He was 67 years old.

title: BELGIUM'S LOST CHOCOLATE ICON
description: Around the corner from a busy train station, in the middle of this city's immigrant quarter, stands a nondescript factory shrouded in a deep, sweet aroma.

Sunday Final, 2:30 P.M. *If Providence beats Villanova tonight, it will be seeded fourth; if it loses, it will be seeded fifth, and St. John's will be fourth.

title: EX-CONVICT IS ARRESTED
description: A former convict who had been freed on bail after being held 10 weeks on charges of assaulting a man and threatening the man's girlfriend went to the woman's home in East Windsor, Conn., Friday night or Saturday morning and killed the couple and the woman's 11-year-old son, the police said yesterday.

title: Meese Answers Student On Dealings With Iran
description: Speaking here before an audience of high school students from across the country today, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d commented on the Iran-contra affair and denied that the United States was exchanging arms for hostages.

STEERING AN UNCHARTED COURSE
description: The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., has been caught in the middle of a tiff between Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: RECITAL: MONTSERRAT CABALLE
description: MONTSERRAT CABALLE'S peculiar recital format, of which the great soprano gave her annual specimen on Friday night in Carnegie Hall, asks a good deal of her public's patience, but rewards it with something they are not likely to get in any other way. The first half is a placid read-through of little-known bel canto arias, punctuated (as intermission approaches) by a moment or two of vocal exertion. The scores on her music stand this time around were by Vivaldi and Spontini. The second half brings songs, mostly Spanish, and a rising level of involvement, attaining, by the end, the level of whimsical charm.

title: COMPUTER ENTRY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its earnings for the latest quarter and year were reduced by 4 cents a share by the repeal of investment tax credits.

title: BIG IRAQ-IRAN CLASH REPORTED IN AREA OF OFFENSIVE AT BASRA
description: Iraqi and Iranian forces fought a fierce battle near the southern Iraqi city of Basra today, three days after Teheran said it was ending a major offensive in the area.

title: 5 Killed and 80 Injured In French Ski Accident
description: Five skiers were killed and nearly 80 were hurt today when a damaged chairlift pitched dozens of skiers as much as 130 feet onto rocks and snow in the French Pyrenees, officials said.

title: MAN WHO KILLED HIS SISTER IN '79 ESCAPES FROM CREEDMOOR CENTER
description: A 25-year-old prisoner who killed his sister in 1979 walked out of the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens yesterday and escaped, the police said.

title: PUBLISHING: MATHABLANE GETS CORNELL FELLOWSHIP
description: Mark Mathabane, who wrote a widely acclaimed memoir of growing up black in a South African shantytown, has won a writing and teaching fellowship in the graduate humanities program at Cornell University. ''I'll be there next fall and through the spring of '88, conducting a seminar once a week,'' Mr. Mathabane said. ''The rest of the time I'll be writing a sequal to 'Kaffir Boy.' ''

title: Quite an Exhibition
description: It's an oft-told tale, especially when Stan Saplin, the sports historian, is around to tell it. So Herb Russell, the former Olympic sprinter who founded the Jesse Owens International Trophy Award, was hardly surprised last week when Saplin told it again while serving as master of ceremonies at the midtown announcement of the award's 1987 winner, Greg Louganis. What Russell had to listen to once more was an account of one of the most unusual races that was almost never run, a race, Saplin insists, that remains unique in the annals of track and field.

title: GREY WINS COLOR TILE
description: Grey Advertising has been named to handle the broadcast advertising for Color Tile Inc., of Fort Worth, which operates a nationwide chain of home decorating retailer outlets. Billings could come to $10 million. There are 680 company-owned stores in the chain, which had been doing all of its advertising in-house. The company will continue to handle its print advertising.

description: The first pretrial legal skirmishes are about to begin in the Howard Beach, Queens, racial attack case, and the results could be crucial to how the case is eventually argued before a jury.

CITIZENS GROUP PRAISES KOCH BUDGET
description: Mayor Koch's proposed $22.5 billion city budget for the fiscal year 1988 shows admirable ''fiscal restraint,'' but it could be undermined by the upcoming contract talks with municipal unions, the chairman of a citizens group said yesterday.

description: New York State Senate Republican leaders yesterday rejected a modified $8.6 billion capital spending plan presented last week by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. In its place they offered to approve an interim $7.8 billion plan that would allow the M.T.A. to spend up to $1.75 billion by May 15 to avoid costly delays in its rebuilding program.

description: The latest first quarter's results reflect development costs for Municipal Development Corp., which was formed in February 1986 and went public in April 1986. The comparable prior year quarter includes only the operation of James J. Lowrey & Co., which subsequently became a subsidiary of Municipal Development.

description: The company said the decrease in net was due to soft market conditions for some products, a strike at a Montreal facility in the first quarter and higher corporate income taxes. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: STERN APPRAISALS IN OTHER NATIONS
description: Commentators in Asia, Africa and Latin America are tending to view the Tower Commission report on the Iran-contra affair through the prism of their own national concerns, especially the effect of a chastened United States Administration on their own economic stability and on their relations with their neighbors.

title: 3 USE A FIRE HOSE AND SHEETS TO FLEE 6TH FLOOR OF QUEENS JAIL
description: Two men convicted of murder and a third inmate pried open a steel hatch, crawled 80 feet through a duct and then shinned down fire hoses and bedsheets to escape from the sixth floor of a city jail in Queens early yesterday, officials said.

title: TOUGH TALKS ON MANILA DEBT LIKELY
description: Debt rescheduling talks begin this week between the Philippines and its bank creditors, in what is expected to be an extremely tough round of negotiations that are likely to influence the outcome of debt negotiations elsewhere.

description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $9,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $271,000 for the year. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $53,000 and $137,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Big-Chill Circuit
description: Geoff Brabham has done it, and so have Herm Johnson, Gary Bettenhausen and other prominent race-car drivers. With increasing wintertime regularity, they're taking to the ice -competing on frozen rivers and lakes, where they strain for vision among billowing clouds of snow and struggle for traction that is a sometime thing. ''We never go much faster than 90 miles per hour,'' said Brabham, ''which doesn't seem so fast on the straightaway. Then you come to the first turn and find you're completely out of control.''

title: The Deaver-North Challenge
description: On the day that Michael K. Deaver joined Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North in challenging the constitutionality of the independent counsels investigating them, Congress's ears were still ringing with Mr. Deaver's call for an independent counsel investigation to clear his name and Colonel North's declaration of his desire to explain everything to the American people.

title: WOMEN IN NAZI GERMANY: PARADOXES
description: Time and again during the decade she spent researching the history of the forgotten women of the Third Reich, Claudia Koonz was struck by a paradox: the very women who were so protective of their children, so warm, nurturing and giving to their families, could at the same time display extraordinary cruelty.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MARCH 2, 1987
description: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS A10-12

title: Don't Hoard Cheap Power
description: New York's two publicly owned hydropower projects yield enough electricity to meet the needs of a large city, and at just a tenth the cost of coal or oil-burning plants. Law or long-term contract reserve most of this cheap power for a tiny minority of the state's residents and businesses. But one big chunk, now committed to a handful of companies in the Buffalo area, will soon be up for grabs.

title: PRESIDENT TERMED UNREADY TO YIELD ON IRAN ARMS DEAL
description: One of President Reagan's most trusted advisers, former Senator Paul Laxalt, said today that he did not think Mr. Reagan was yet prepared to condemn the reasoning that led to the Iran arms deal.

title: Catching Up
description: * Eight months after the death of Don Rogers, the Cleveland Brown defensive back, it appears certain that no one will ever be charged with supplying the cocaine that killed him at age 23. The police of Sacramento, Calif., say that they believe they know the identity of the supplier but that the suspect, a friend of Rogers, has denied involvement. Since there are no known witnesses to the transaction, the case is all but closed.

title: BEIRUT MOSLEMS CLOSE RANKS FOR PEACE BID TO CHRISTIANS
description: Lebanon's main Moslem and Druse leaders, whose rival militias fought pitched battles on the streets of West Beirut only a week ago, announced today that they had closed ranks and had prepared a program that they would offer to the country's Christians in an effort to halt 12 years of civil war.

title: 'MISERABLES' ALREADY A FINANCIAL HIT
description: By 10 A.M. last Friday, there were already seven people waiting to buy tickets for ''Les Miserables.'' One man said that he had never bought tickets for a Broadway show in advance, but that he had a friend who had seen this one in London and had ''absolutely loved it'' and talked him into it. He was not alone. Others, too, fishing for their credit cards, were willing to pay for tickets to a show they might not see until August.

title: TOP SANDINISTA: ORTEGA'S GRASP BECOMES FIRMER
description: When President Daniel Ortega Saavedra opened the 1987 legislative session recently with a long address in the town of Niquinohomo, he spoke with the authority of a strong national leader secure in his political power.

description: ''Howard Baker gets to have many of the powers of the Presidency without having to slog around New Hampshire.'' - Senator Alan Cranston of California. [ A10:5. ]

description: A Fighting Yank

title: A MATTER OF CONFIDENCE
description: The State Department maintains a telephone hot line on which employees are encouraged to make confidential reports of fraud, abuse or waste of Government money that they observe. There is only one problem: Calls to the number are answered by a recording that tells the informer to announce his or her name and telephone number.

description: 3 Escape From Queens Jail

title: NO LONGER A BANKER'S DREAM, THE SAUDI SYSTEM STAGNATES
description: Saudi Arabia's banks, wildly profitable a few years ago, are ensnared in a cycle of decline brought on by the fall in oil prices of recent years and by religious laws that once worked in their favor, according to bankers and Government officials.

title: TALINUM SCRAMBLES OUTLOOK FOR DERBY
description: One morning last September, D. Wayne Lukas mentioned that he was running a 2-year-old son of Alydar at Aqueduct and thought the colt would win his debut. The colt finished sixth, then sixth again two weeks later, and Jose Santos, who had ridden him both times, turned down the call the next time the colt was entered.

title: Thais Transfer Refugees
description: The first group of about 230 Cambodian refugees, many of them weeping, left a refugee center here today for camps near the Cambodian border, the first step in a journey that might take them back to Cambodia. Refugees at the Khao-I-Dang camp have been classified by the Thai Government as eligible for resettlement abroad. They can be ordered to return to Cambodia when authorities say conditions permit.

title: LAWS TO CURB BIAS ATTACKS WEIGHED
description: In the wake of the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, city and state officials are proposing laws and procedures to try to deter such crimes, to better aid the victims and to keep a more accurate count of the number of incidents.

title: DAVID TAYLOR PERFORMS AT THE 92D STREET Y
description: The bass trombonist David Taylor presented a creative and unusual concert at the 92d Street Y Saturday night. Mr. Taylor's instrument is a relatively unfamiliar one; so, too, was most the music he played. But what was particularly striking about Saturday's concert was the way in which Mr. Taylor built his program, especially the two extended suites of his own making. The first combined the 17th-century music of Schutz with Ravel, Charles Ives, Duke Ellington and the contemporary composer Eric Ewazen; the second assembled songs by Ravel, Honegger and Milhaud, with just a hint of the latter composer's ''Creation du Monde'' thrown in for spice.

title: VYING TO ENHANCE THE MACINTOSH
description: A few years ago, three engineers took out second mortgages on their homes and formed a company to make circuit boards that plugged into an I.B.M. personal computer, increasing the machine's memory and capability. The company, AST Research Inc., now has annual revenues of $170 million.

description: b-Net loss

title: SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $1,424,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes an extraordinary credit of $1,378,000 from the termination of a pension plan. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $1,445,000 from the sale of securities for the quarter, and for the year includes a gain of $3,061,000 from the sale of securities.

title: WHEN TYCOONS TALK OF LEADERSHIP
description: H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire, gave a rousing speech to the nation's governors last week, and some of his listeners thought he sounded like a man running for President.

title: FOR CUOMO, A LOSS OF MOMENTUM ON HIS PLAN FOR CUT IN TAXES
description: With just four weeks until New York State must enact a budget, Governor Cuomo has failed not only to win any legislative support for his tax revision plan but even to establish it as the framework for debate, according to both Democratic and Republican legislators.

title: MANY LANDMARKS NOT FOUND IN AUDIT OF CITY COMPUTER FILE
description: About a third of New York City's landmarks might be missing from the Buildings Department computer. But whether this is a disaster in the making or a bookkeeping chore waiting to be finished depends on which government official is talking.

title: RUTH WHALEY MARRIES DAVID JONATHAN GRAIS
description: The marriage of Ruth Maria Sarah Whaley, an assistant vice president of Citibank in New York, to David Jonathan Grais, a partner in the New York law firm of Grais & Richards, took place yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony.

title: WILLIAMS IS GOING OUT IN STYLE
description: JUST as clearly as he recognizes a soft spot in the defense, Reggie Williams recognized that it was time for him to change. He slipped out of the shadows and into the light this season as easily, it seems, as he smothers a passing lane or sidesteps a defender.

title: ARMS NEGOTIATORS TO MEET IN GENEVA OVER MISSILE PLAN
description: American and Soviet negotiators have scheduled a special session in Geneva on Monday to discuss a Soviet proposal that the two nations reach a separate agreement on medium-range missiles in Europe.

title: SHULTZ GETS A RIVERBOAT INTRODUCTION TO CHINA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived in China this morning and spent most of his first day enveloped in the graceful tranquillity of the countryside before flying on to Beijing for a formal state banquet in the Great Hall of the People.

title: MCFARLANE SUICIDE ATTEMPT: 'WHAT DROVE ME TO DESPAIR'
description: Among the Belgian chocolate truffles and the Bibles, the flowers and cards, the call from President Reagan and the visit from Jihan Sadat, there was one especially welcome get-well greeting that Robert C. McFarlane received after his suicide attempt three weeks ago.

title: CELEBRITY BROKERS: A BUSY TIME
description: THE prices that celebrities are getting for endorsements are going through the roof, according to Lloyd Kolmer of New York and Marty Ingels of Los Angeles.

title: DAVILS TIE WHALERS
description: John Driver's goal with six seconds left in regulation capped a furious comeback by the Devils today as they posted a 5-5 tie with the Hartford Whalers.

title: Juvenal Delinquent
description: Someone with classical tastes adorned the Tower Commission report with the apt epigraph, ''Quis custodiet ipsos Custodes?'' Every third-year Latin student knows that's from Juvenal: ''Who will watch the watchmen?'' Juvenal wrote a lot of good lines, suitable for moralizers of every persuasion. Consider:

title: ANALYSTS SEE STABILITY IN DOLLAR AS TEMPORARY
description: The fall in the dollar, a decline that reached breakneck speed during the first six weeks of the year, is unlikely to resume for at least the next few weeks, according to several economists and currency traders.

title: Knicks Go Flat Late in Game and Lose
description: Herb Williams hit a jumper for the go-ahead basket and then came up with a key steal as the Indiana Pacers beat the Knicks, 122-115, in overtime tonight.

title: MEMOS RAISE QUESTIONS ON REAGAN'S KNOWLEDGE OF CONTRA AID OPERATIONS
description: Although the Tower Commission reported that it had found no evidence that President Reagan knew about the extensive involvement of his aides in support of the Nicaraguan rebels, members of the panel say they found a few documents suggesting otherwise.

title: ECONOMY SLOWING, PURCHASERS REPORT
description: The economy grew at a slower pace in February, as the growth rate of production and new orders declined from January's levels, according to the monthly survey of the National Association of Purchasing Managers.

title: Swearing Off PAC'S
description: When he officially announces his candidacy for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination next week, Bruce Babbitt, the former Arizona Governor, will promise not to accept any campaign contributions from political action committees, which represent corporations, labor unions and business and professional associations. Private donations from individuals or committees can be accepted by Presidential candidates only in their campaigns for party nomination.

title: CATHARINE HUNTINGTON, FORMER PRODUCER, 100
description: Catharine Sargent Huntington, an actress, director and producer and a manager of the Provincetown Playhouse on the Wharf on Cape Cod, Mass., died Friday at Sherrill House, a Boston nursing home where she had lived for several years. She was 100 years old.

title: CYBERMEDIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: VEGA BIOTECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BAD IDEA, BAD ART, BAD DOG
description: No one knows why the 20 or so bald eagles decided to roost this winter at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal northeast of here. But whatever the reason, they probably should have reconsidered.

title: ILLINOIS UPSETS INDIA
description: Ken Norman scored 24 points and a reserve center, Jens Kujawa, scored Illinois' final 4 points today as the Illini defeated Indiana, 69-67, to knock the Hoosiers from first place in the Big Ten standing.

title: Grandfather Clause
description: It received scant notice among other matters involved in the penalties imposed last week against Southern Methodist University, but there was evidence in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's report that wrongdoers within S.M.U.'s athletic department had been at once capable of the most extreme brazenness and yet perhaps, somewhat paradoxically, subject to a compelling dread.

title: PROXMIRE'S BANKING CHALLENGE
description: An aggressive banking bill introduced by the Senate Banking Committee chairman, William Proxmire, has suddenly bogged down so badly that the Wisconsin Democrat has had to weaken two divisive provisions just prior to a committee vote scheduled for this week. Those two titles would have closed the ''nonbank bank'' loophole and would have given banks broad new securities underwriting powers.

title: NANCY E. SCHWARZKOPF IS WED TO ZVI SCHECHNER
description: Nancy Evelyn Schwarzkopf, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Schwarzkopf of Carle Place, L.I., was married yesterday to Zvi Schechner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arie Schechner of Haifa, Israel. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony at the Woodcrest Club in Syosset, L.I.

title: BONECRUSHER SMITH: AN UNLIKELY ROUTE TO BOXING SUMMIT
description: THE life of James Smith, of Lillington, N.C., has had the variegated richness that used to be virtually mandatory for the biographical blurb describing any red-blooded novelist. You know the kind. ''This is Mr. Doe's third book. Before turning to prose, he was a stevedore, a lifeguard, an orderly in a psychiatric institution and a librarian.''

title: Davis and Astros Reach Agreement
description: The Houston Astros announced tonight that Glenn Davis had agreed to terms on a one-year contract with the club.

title: NAVRATILOVA BEATS SABATINI WITH EASE
description: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova defeated Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina in straight sets to reach the women's quarterfinals, and Ivan Lendl and Jimmy Connors crushed third-round opponents today to make the men's round of 16 at the $1.8 million International Players Championships.

title: U.S. AIDES TELL OF HOSTAGE PLAN THAT COLLAPSED
description: In early 1986, the Reagan Administration put together a complex operation to rescue a hostage in Lebanon by paying a multimillion-dollar ransom with chemically treated bills designed to disintegrate after several days, according to Administration officials.

title: PLAYOFF TO GEDDES
description: Jane Geddes bogeyed the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today, but that was good enough to win the Women's Kemper Open golf tournament.

title: ATLANTIC AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $33,000 for the quarter and $375,000 for the year. c-Includes capital gains of $1,137,000 and $3,230,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: JORDAN GETS JUST 30; NETS GET VICTORY
description: An extra 4,000 fans came to Byrne Meadowlands Arena today to see Michael Jordan score, and the crowd got a bonus when the Nets won the game.

title: ARGENTINA ACCORD SEEN
description: Argentina's chief debt negotiator said today that he was confident that a prompt accord could be reached with international creditor banks for rescheduling the country's foreign debt.

title: Topics: Backing and Filling; Nuclear Nonsense
description: Question: How can Defense Department experts change their estimates of a Soviet activity without much old information and without hard new information? Answer: Easy, by issuing a new report.

title: TORNADO SURVIVORS DIG OUT OF DEBRIS
description: Chain saws roared through a sea of downed pines here today as residents cleared debris from the wake of a tornado that raked a 20-mile strip of southeast Mississippi.

title: PRO-MED CAPITAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
PAQUITO D'RIVERA JOINS STYLES AT WEILL HALL
description: Since the piano is the most orchestral of instruments, keyboardists have traditionally been the jazz musicians most likely to explore the longstanding affinities between jazz and contemporary classical music. But at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, the Cuban-born clarinetist and saxophonist Paquito D'Rivera and the New York Strings, a young jazz string quartet augmented by bass and guitar, offered an effervescent program that mixed 20th-century Latin American compositions with arrangements of popular and jazz standards for clarinet and chamber ensemble.

title: HOUSTON HURT, ARMY LOSES
description: A self-inflicted leg injury to Kevin Houston, the nation's leading scorer, with 5 minutes 25 seconds remaining proved costly to Army tonight. Fairfield took advantage of Houston's ineffectiveness after his injury for a 65-60 triumph at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: MERCE CUNNINGHAM TO BE TOPIC OF FESTIVAL
description: The role of Merce Cunningham in introducing a new abstract esthetic to dance will be explored in ''Merce Cunningham and the New Dance: The Modernist Impulse in Dance,'' a four-day festival presented by the State University of New York at sites around the city, from Thursday through next Sunday.

title: RANDOLPH REFLECTS ON FAMILY CRISIS
description: The game was just 45 minutes away when the telephone rang in the visiting clubhouse at Exhibition Stadium in Toronto. Willie Randolph still recalls seeing the clubhouse attendant summon him, thinking that it was not an emergency at all, as he had been told, but something far less urgent.

title: SPAIN, IN REVERSAL, WILL SIGN ATOM-ARMS PACT
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, possibly reacting to street protests from various sectors of the country, has announced that the Government will repeal an anti-terrorism law and will sign an international treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Mr. Meese's End Run for Death
description: Congress keeps balking at reviving Federal death penalty laws rendered unenforceable by the Supreme Court, so Attorney General Edwin Meese has appealed to the Federal Sentencing Commission. The commission has no business even entertaining this inappropriate proposal.

title: FRAMINGHAM SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings are not available because the bank went public in October 1986.

title: BROTHER GIVES AC&R ITS CORPORATE ACCOUNT
description: AC&R Advertising has become the agency for a $1 million corporate advertising campaign of the Brother International Corporation, a marketer of Japanese-made equipment for homes and offices.

title: Owing to Fair Play
description: Representative Andrew Jacobs Jr., Democrat of Indiana, has become one of the more unpredictable lawmakers in his 11 terms in the House. Now he has drafted a bill that would treat members of Congress and other Federal employees just like other citizens if they are forced into bankruptcy. The bill would repeal a current provision that shields some of their income from debtors. In a letter inviting his colleagues to co-sponsor his proposal, Mr. Jacobs officially titles it ''The Goose, Gander and Sauce Act of 1987.''

title: CASE DIVIDES LEGISLATORS ON THE QUESTION OF ETHICS
description: At political functions, few legislators pause these days to talk to Assemblywoman Gerdi E. Lipschutz. But though most of her colleagues see her as an embarrassment to the Legislature, few are willing publicly to condemn her or to call for her resignation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, MARCH 2, 1987 The Economy

title: Outdoors; Ice Fishing for Smelt
description: ALTHOUGH I do not share their passion, there are millions of anglers in this nation's snow belt who delight in shuffling forth on ice-covered lakes, ponds and rivers in quest of the sluggish fish that are moseying about beneath their feet.

title: When Government and Religion Are Partners in Public Service
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDMASTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $17,169 for the quarter and $84,000 for the 9 months.

title: FIERY TESTIMONY HEARD IN DAILY NEWS BIAS TRIAL
description: In the three weeks since a Federal trial began in a suit charging racially based job bias against The Daily News, the four black employees who brought suit have given their accounts of the racial epithets and repeated discrimination they say they faced at the newspaper.

title: COMPUDYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $5,519,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. The company said the latest quarter loss includes a gain of $5,000 from the sale of businesses. Results for 1985 have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $305,000.

title: BRIDGE: TEAM FINAL WHERE WINNING WAS NOT PRIMARY OBJECTIVE
description: Few dedicated players believe in their hearts that winning is not the most important thing. But it was certainly true in the New York City final of the Grand National Teams championship Saturday at the Penta Hotel, at Seventh Avenue and 33d Street.

title: SHAREDATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
STEPPARENTS PRESSING FOR CUSTODY RIGHTS AS NEW LEGAL ISSUE
description: In an age when one out of five American children is living in a stepfamily, when more than 1,000 new stepfamilies form every day and less than half of those marriages survive, the rights of stepparents after divorce is emerging as a provocative new issue in family law.

title: GEN. WILLIAM MCKEE, EX-F.A.A. HEAD, DIES
description: Gen. William F. McKee, a retired Vice Chief of Staff of the Air Force who served as head of the Federal Aviation Administration in the Johnson Administration, died Saturday after a brief illness in San Antonio.

title: ENSTAR INDONESIA INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CAMPAIGN MANAGERS SPAR AT HARVARD ON THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: The 1988 Presidential campaign was played out here this weekend.

title: Phone-Industry Deregulation Must Be Balanced
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORT OF PAKISTANI A-BOMB CAUSES A STIR IN THE REGION
description: A report by an Indian journalist quoting the director of Pakistan's nuclear program as saying Pakistan possessed a nuclear bomb created a stir today in India and Pakistan.

title: AN ISRAELI LAWYER DARES DEFEND AN ACCUSED NAZI
description: With sighs of disrespect, a few of his countrymen call the lawyer simply ''Sheftel,'' as in: ''Sheftel, how can a Jew defend a Nazi?''

title: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an after-tax favorable adjustment of about $434,000 from LIFO valuations.

title: IBERIA AIR COMES OFF ROPES
description: Two years ago, Iberia Air Lines of Spain was in poor financial shape, having reported a $100 million loss the year before. Its union employees were so distrustful that some pilots were illegally disconnecting their cockpit recorders for fear management was listening in. Service was abominable.

title: GORBACHEV OFFER: 2 OTHER ARMS HINTS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's offer to sign an agreement eliminating Soviet and American medium-range missiles in Europe offers tantalizing hints of movement on two other arms-control fronts, according to Western diplomats here.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Blasius Industries, Erie, Pa., a maker of plastic, rubber and metal products, elected to its board Andrew R. Heyer, a managing director of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. He was also appointed a director of the board's acquisition committee.

title: IDB COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Not for the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTOSPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $139,000 for the quarter and $282,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Spending by Cities Outlined in Report
description: A new Census Bureau study on cities' expenditures said the average city spends $85.71 annually per resident for police protection, the largest continuing item in city budgets.

title: MEMORIES OF OCTOBER LINGER AS SPRING BEGINS FOR RED SOX
description: HAYWOOD SULLIVAN, the owner, and Lou Gorman, the general manager, inched forward to the edge of their seats. They were ready to bolt out of them, dart quickly into the aisle, rush through the gate onto the field, then scurry down the steps into the dugout and walk quickly, excitedly and triumphantly to the clubhouse.

title: WORKED IN CHINA AS A LAWYER
description: Norwood F. Allman, a lawyer and diplomat in China for more than 30 years, died Saturday in Carlisle, Pa. He was 93 years old.

title: GUIDING THE BARBICAN'S BUSY SUCCESS
description: Henry Wrong, director of London's vast cultural complex called Barbican Center, which tomorrow celebrates its fifth birthday, finds that everything lands at his door -sometimes, quite literally.

title: MAN WITH LEAD PIPE SHOT DEAD ON HARLEM STREET BY 3 POLICEMEN
description: A 27-year-old man who the police say attacked a rookie officer with a lead pipe was killed in a barrage of police gunfire on a busy Harlem thoroughfare Saturday night after being chased and surrounded by eight officers.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CRISIS: NEW REAGAN CHIEF JOINED BY EX-AIDES
description: When Howard H. Baker Jr. begins his duties Monday as President Reagan's chief of staff, he will be joined at the White House by two of his former Senate staff members, Thomas C. Griscom and James M. Cannon. Their likable personalities are expected to bring a collegial approach that was largely missing under Mr. Baker's ousted predecessor, Donald T. Regan.

title: PANCRETEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONDE NAST MAGAZINES GET NEW PUBLISHERS
description: Marianne Howatson, after less than a year as publisher of Travel & Leisure magazine, is leaving to become publisher of Self magazine, making her the first woman publisher at Conde Nast in the company's 75-year history.

title: BUSH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CULP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $119,000 for the quarter and $452,000 for the year.

title: TECHAMERICA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: The First Lady Stages a Coup
description: At a time he most needs to appear strong, President Reagan is being weakened and made to appear wimpish and helpless by the political interference of his wife.

title: DETROIT SYMPHONY RECLAIMS 'ACOUSTICAL MARVEL' AS ITS HOME
description: After nearly 50 years of enduring poor acoustics at bigger halls, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra is returning to the house that was built for it 68 years ago.

title: FOR CHEMLAWN'S HEAD, THIS SPRING IS DIFFERENT
description: Normally at this time of the year, Jack Van Fossen, chairman and chief executive of the Chemlawn Corporation, would be looking forward to spring, when the grass turns green and the lawns need cutting. As the head of the nation's largest lawn-care company, spring is the beginning of the busy season. This spring, however, his attention has been diverted.

title: COMPUTER BOOKS MERGE
description: Lebhar-Friedman, a trade press publisher, has acquired a majority interest in Micro Marketworld, a weekly tabloid, from CW Communications, and has merged it into its own weekly Computer+Software News tabloid. That will make the publication, with more than 50,000 circulation, the largest in its field and second to Computer Reseller News in advertising pages.

title: 10 UNSIGNED EMTS NO CONCERN
description: The Mets turned into March today with the extraordinary total of 10 players not yet signed to contracts, but with the extraordinary belief on both sides that no hard feelings would result, however the disputes were settled.

title: FINDING GEMS IN THE RUST BELT
description: Shares of the Chemlawn Corporation, which provides lawn care services, jumped $11.875, to $29.625, last Thursday, in response to a cash tender offer of $27 a share from Waste Management Inc., the world's largest waste disposal concern. In Cleveland, Elliott Schlang, a senior vice president with the brokerage firm of Prescott, Ball & Turben, found himself ''pleasantly shocked'' by the news.

title: THE QUIRKY BEHAVIOR OF BONDS
description: Rarely has the credit market behaved more perversely than it did late last week. On Thursday, bond prices fell when they should have benefited from a steep 7.5 percent decline in durable goods orders for January. Then on Friday, bond prices rose despite sharp rises in the trade deficit and Consumer Price Index figures for January.

title: SAGE DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nader vs. Harvard
description: Ralph Nader, the public interest activist, is returning to the university where he received his legal education 30 years ago to make a personal inspection as part of his six-month-old ''Harvard Watch'' project. He has scheduled a trip to Cambridge this month to sample student opinion and give a speech on academic freedom, which he says Harvard has been ''just mouthing while waiting for the next corporate caravan to arrive.''

title: MUSIC: SOMEI SATOH'S WORKS
description: The Minimalist movement returned to its Eastern origins Saturday night with a collection of Somei Satoh's music at the Asia Society. Western ideas of music as drama, adventure or moral statement seemed far away. In its place, Mr. Satoh's music from Japan attempts a kind of therapy in which the physical and the spiritual blend.

title: GRIFFITH CONSUMERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'THE BETTY FORD STORY,' ON ABC
description: ''The Betty Ford Story,'' on ABC tonight at 9, is one of those sui-generis television presentations that command attention more for their subject matter than their artistic merit. As a portrait of alcohol and prescription-drug addiction, the film is carefully subdued and, despite its messy subject, insistently tasteful. But as a glimpse into the private life of a former and very much admired First Lady of the United States, ''The Betty Ford Story'' is genuinely compelling and an unusual profile in courage. Holding it together, powerfully yet sensitively, is the performance of Gena Rowlands in the title role.

title: JACKSON MISSION IS NEAR COMPLETION
description: THE summer before his freshman year in college, Mark Jackson set out on a mission.

title: PALME SUCCESSOR ALTERS STYLE OF SWEDISH POLITICS
description: In the year since the assassination of Prime Minister Olof Palme, his successor, Ingvar Carlsson, has emerged as a popular leader who has fundamentally altered the style of Swedish politics.

title: MEXICO PUSHES BANKS FOR NEW LOAN
description: Although negotiations for a badly needed $6 billion commercial bank loan continue to drag on, Mexico has no immediate plans to suspend payment on any part of its huge foreign debt, according to Mexican officials and foreign bankers and diplomats here.

title: ACME UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DATUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TASS SAYS IRAN DEAL HURT THE U.S.
description: The Soviet Union said today that the secret American sale of arms to Iran had irreparably damaged President Reagan's Administration and exposed the danger of ''ultra-reactionary'' forces in Washington.

title: I.B.M. PLANS STANDARDS STEP
description: Officials of the International Business Machines Corporation confirmed yesterday that the company is developing standards that eventually will permit software to run on machines ranging from I.B.M.

title: Private Diplomacy, Exposed
description: It's no longer conjecture about the White House's ''privatized'' foreign policy. The details are as vivid as the unblushing memos in the Tower Commission report, as devastating as the flow charts showing how Lieut. Col. Oliver North squeezed secret donations from foreign clients for the contras. The documents portray a hidden, unaccountable group of individuals, knowing few limits, operating with arrogance and marching to folly.

title: WADKINS COASTS AFTER EAGLE
description: Lanny Wadkins holed out a 91-yard sand wedge for an eagle 2 on the fifth hole for a six-shot lead today. From there on, the 37-year-old Texan had a rather easy time, despite a bad head cold, in beating Seve Ballesteros, Tom Kite and Don Pooley by three shots in the $1 million Doral Ryder Open.

title: SBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $96,000 in the latest quarter and $69,000 in the year-ago quarter.

title: DELTA WOODSIDE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: The company went public Feb. 10. The latest period results include the company's finished woven fabrics and the major portion of the company's knit fabrics divisions, acquired from J.P. Stevens July 15, 1986.

title: SOVIET PROPOSAL ON MISSILES FINDS SUPPORT IN WESTERN EUROPE
description: Several Western European Governments and NATO's secretary general today welcomed Mikhail S. Gorbachev's offer to reach a separate agreement with the United States on eliminating medium-range missiles from Europe.

title: KOCH DENIES P.B.A. HAS EXCESSIVE POWER
description: Mayor Koch yesterday denied allegations by Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward that he had given the police officers union too much power because of its president's support of his administration.

title: RELIGIONS CONFRONT THE ISSUE OF HOMOSEXUALITY
description: Many members of the clergy and lay people are struggling with the conflicts between their homosexuality and their religious lives and are forcing their religions to engage in that struggle as never before.

title: BASIC AMERICAN MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The 1985 shares outstanding are restated to reflect the 10 percent stock dividend declared on April 25, 1986.

title: HISPANIC RIGHTS LEADER GETS POST OVER EX-GOVERNOR OF NEW MEXICO
description: The board of directors of the nation's largest Hispanic American civil rights organization has voted to withdraw the appointment of former Gov. Toney Anaya of New Mexico as the group's new president.

title: CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $5,000 from early retirement of debt for the quarter, and the year includes a pretax writedown of $14.6 million for oil and gas properties. c-Includes an extraordinary charge of $12,000.

title: GENE MAUCH'S 'HOT DADDER'
description: ON the three baseball fields at Gene Autry Park, the California Angels were playing the sweet symphony of spring training, a symphony for bats, not violins. Every few seconds, the silence was interrupted by the sound of a bat hitting a ball. Music to the ears of every baseball fan. Music that's an overture to the approaching season. Music that's supposed to drown out bad memories.

title: CENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said 1985 results are not comparable because it changed from a fiscal year ending March 31 to a calendar year.

title: On Job Security
description: Top White House positions rarely come with any guarantee of job security, and these days their occupants are even less inclined to boast tenure. Last week at a dinner for Brookings Institution trustees, Frank C. Carlucci, President Reagan's new national security adviser, heard a series of tributes to Bruce K. MacLaury, observing his 10th anniversary as president of Brookings. When Mr. Carlucci was introduced to speak, he said, ''I don't expect to be around to get my 10-year pin.''

title: U.S. Cruise Missile Tested
description: The United States successfully tested an unarmed cruise missile over northern Canada today in the second test within a week, the Canadian Defense Department said. There were no problems, and there were none in a flight last Tuesday that prompted renewed protests from groups opposed to the tests, a Department spokesman, Maj. Jan Martinsen, said. He said the missile, launched over the Beaufort Sea on a 1,500-mile flight along the Mackenzie River valley, ''performed very, very well.''

title: THE PERFECT BUSINESS PARTNER
description: A FANTASY of entrepreneurs is finding the perfect business partner. Doreen MacAdams, co-owner of the Southwind Health Resort in Cartersville, Ga., remembers her search well.

title: RANGERS PUMMELED, 7-3
description: At one point, the Ranger goalkeeper, Bob Froese, lay on his back, trapped in his goalie's armor, as a Capitals' player, Dave Christian, punched away. When another Ranger, Larry Melnyk intervened, he was ejected, Froese was penalized for fighting, and Christian got away free.

description: b-Includes realized gains on investments of $246,481 and $669,131 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes realized gains on investments of $228,305 and $373,123 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax credit of $17,750 and $286,386 for the same periods, respectively.

title: Large Corporate, Municipal Offerings
description: Government financings this week are confined to the bill market, as the Treasury conducts its regular Monday sale of new three- and six-month bills. The size of today's bill auction is $13.2 billion, unchanged from the previous two auctions.

title: COMDIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $507,000 for the quarter and $1,201,000 for the year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $841,000 and $2,833,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and the year also includes a gain of $4,537,000 from the sale of European operations.

title: PRINCETON OBJECTS TO CLUB BIAS RULING
description: Princeton University has told an administrative law judge that two eating clubs that refuse to admit women should not be allowed to sever ties to the university.

title: AMERICAN FIBER OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSIC: 2 GOSPEL GROUPS AND IZULU ENSEMBLE
description: THE power of homegrown singing linked to heartfelt messages was reaffirmed in a concert at the Washington Square Church on Friday night when the World Music Institute presented two gospel groups and a South African-style chorus in a triple bill of call-and-response singing, close harmonies and whisper-to-shout dynamics.

title: WALL STREET IS FACING REAPPRAISAL
description: Wall Street, struggling to clear itself of the taint spread by the insider trading scandal, is facing the most thorough re-examination and perhaps overhaul of its self-regulatory system since the Depression.

title: TELLTALE TOOTHPASTE: DOES ECONOMY FACE DECAY?
description: The bustling department stores and fast-food restaurants and the new office buildings that are being thrown up speak of prosperity and plenty.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said results for the first quarter include $3,032,000 of interest expense and $1,509,000 of discount amortization both relating to the 15 percent secured income notes issued as part of the company's Chapter 11 settlement. Results for the year-ago first quarter, which was before the Chapter 11 settlement, did not include any interest on obligations of the company which were subject to Chapter 11 proceedings.

title: ZYCAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes about $12 million of costs related to a merger. c-Net income

title: GUITARIST IN COUNT BASIE BAND
description: Freddie Green, a jazz guitarist who played with the Count Basie Orchestra for half a century, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MUSIC: A NEW 'SOUTH PACIFIC' BY THE CITY OPERA
description: TO the New York City Opera's credit, its new production of ''South Pacific,'' which opened Saturday night for a nine-week run, seems a successful, intelligently intended reproduction of the Broadway original. Yes, amplification is used, but it's subtly handled. Yes, the New York State Theater is bigger than a Broadway house, but Desmond Heeley's entirely traditional sets fill the stage comfortably, and the characters don't disappear in the clutter. Gerald Freedman's direction could certainly be more stylish, but it looks faithful to the Joshua Logan original in most of the ways that count.

title: LOBBYING THE OFFICE THAT HUNTS NAZI SUSPECTS
description: In nearly a decade of hunting suspects in Nazi war crimes, the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigtions has prosecuted dozens of Europeans who entered the United States after World War II as refugees, became naturalized Americans, and then were found to have lied about their Nazi pasts to immigration officials.

title: B.F. GOODRICH
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said it will stop making aircraft tires, missile and marine products, and molded rubber products here by the end of the year. About 790 salaried and hourly workers will be laid off as a result, Goodrich said.

title: NANCY REAGAN'S POWER IS CONSIDERED AT PEAK
description: Nancy Reagan is now far more powerful, more confident and more politically involved than at any point in the Reagan Presidency, and she intends to remain so for the rest of her husband's term.

title: US INTEC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Stars for Poindexter?
description: Vice Adm. John Poindexter, who resigned as the President's national security adviser in November because of his role in the Iran-contra affair, must decide Wednesday whether to retire from the military or stay in uniform and take a new assignment. If he stays in active service, he will report back to work with the Navy on Thursday as a two-star Admiral, down a notch from the temporary three-star rank he was given for his job with the National Security Council. If he retires, it will be up to Congress to determine his retirement rank. As an active officer, Navy officials say, he would probably be stationed in the Washington area, where he would be readily available for further investigations of his role in the affair.

title: JAPAN PLANS TO SIMPLIFY RULES OF BOND OFFERINGS
description: Japanese securities firms are moving to streamline the procedures for offering new issues in Japan's bond market. Their goal is to encourage Japanese corporations to do more domestic financing, which has slowed to a trickle because many issuers have turned to more flexible overseas markets.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Basketball Navy 53, North Carolina-Wilmington 50: David Robinson's 3-point play with 17 minutes 13 seconds left put Navy ahead last night and the Midshipmen went on to capture their third straight Colonial Athletic Association basketball tournament, in Hampton, Va. Navy held off a late rally by the Seahawks and won its 13th straight game. The Midshipmen (26-5) received an automatic berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. North Carolina-Wilmington dropped to 18-12. Robinson extended the Midshipmen's lead to 51-48 when he hit a free throw with 2:02 to play. Charles Cherry got the Seahawks to 51-50 on an 18-foot jumper with 1:19 to go, but Robinson closed the scoring on two free throws with 20 seconds to play. Robinson finished with a game-high 23 points.(AP) Notre Dame 76, Brooklyn 57: In South Bend, Ind., Donald Royal scored 20 points, making 8 of 9 free throws, to lead Notre Dame (20-7). Frank Gregov led Brooklyn (10-17) with 18 points. Keith Grady, the Kingsmen's leading scorer with an 18.2 average, failed to score in the first half and finished with 6 points. With six minutes left, Brooklyn pulled within 10 points, 61-51, on two free throws by Gregov. But Notre Dame scored 11 straight points, including 6 from Royal. (AP) Providence 97, Villanova 80: Dave Kipfer, a senior forward, scored 17 of his season-high 20 points in the first half to lead the Friars to the Big East victory. Kipfer was the inspirational leader of the Friar squad during a first-half spurt that put the game away. He twice had forceful dunks in the final seven minutes of the half as Providence reasserted itself and stretched its lead from 25-20 to 44-34 at the break. Providence finished 20-7 over all and 10-6 in the conference. Villanova fell to 15-14 and 6-10.(AP) Tulsa 61, Southern Illinois 56: Byron Boudreaux made a 3-point shot with 25 seconds left to break a 56-56 tie, and David Moss added two free throws as Tulsa, at home, won the semifinal game of the Missouri Valley Conference tournament. Tulsa (22-6) will meet Wichita State in the tournament final Wednesday at Tulsa. Wichita State beat Illinois State, 56-53.(AP) N.B.A. Hawks 121, Bullets 99: Kevin Willis scored 26 points and grabbed 17 rebounds for Atlanta. The visiting Bullets rallied from a 34-21 deficit after one quarter to tie the game at 50-50 with 3:37 left in the half. The Hawks, who were led by Dominique Wilkins's 33 points, pulled away again in the third quarter behind Randy Wittman's 12 points after breaking a 56-56 halftime tie on baskets by Willis and Doc Rivers. An 8-0 run late in the third period extended the margin to 84-66. The Hawks' biggest margin was 24 points in the closing moments.(AP) Rockets 105, Spurs 100: Akeem Olajuwon scored 32 points and Houston beat San Antonio for the fifth time in as many meetings. Houston's Robert Reid iced the game, at San Antonio, when he made two free throws with 12 seconds left to put the Rockets ahead, 102-98. Reid finished with 21 points while Alvin Robertson led San Antonio with 26 and Mitchell added 20. The Rockets won the game at the free-throw line, hitting on 32 of 43 while San Antonio was 13 of 15.(AP) Mavericks 135, Suns 112: Rolando Blackman scored 25 points to lead Dallas to an easy home victory. The Mavericks, who were coming off their second-worst defeat of the season - a 123-98 loss at San Antonio on Saturday night - never trailed against the Suns and led by 33 points late in the third quarter. The victory was Dallas's fifth straight at home, where they are 25-5, and it moved them five games ahead of second-place Utah in the Midwest Division. Phoenix lost its seventh consecutive game. James Donaldson had 22 points and Mark Aguirre 21 for Dallas. Larry Nance led the Suns with 25.(AP) Kings 117, Nuggets 114: In Denver, Mark Olberding hit all 13 of his free throws and scored a season-high 21 points for Sacramento. The Kings got 24 points each from Eddie Johnson and Otis Thorpe, who also had 15 rebounds, and 23 from Reggie Theus in handing Denver its 10th loss in the last 12 games.(AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 4, Bruins 3: In Boston, Petr Klima scored his third goal of the game with eight seconds left in overtime last night to lift Detroit. The victory was Detroit's third straight and fifth in the last seven games, while the loss snapped a two-game Boston winning streak. With 1:21 left, Coach Terry O'Reilly of Boston pulled the goalie, Bill Ranford, in favor of an extra skater. Ten seconds later, Boston's Ray Bourque fired from the left point toward a crowd in front of the Detroit net. The puck hit Boston's Keith Crowder and caromed past the Red Wings' goalie, Glen Hanlon, to tie the score at 3-3. Boston jumped to a quick 1-0 lead on Bourque's first goal of the night at 3:07 of the opening period. However, Detroit went in front on a pair of goals by Klima before the period ended. After a scoreless second period, Detroit's Gerard Gallant scored his 33d goal on a power play at 11:09 and Boston's Greg Johnston scored his 12th at 12:09, pulling Boston to 3-2.(AP) Horse Racing Alioth Wins on Stretch Drive at Aqueduct: Alioth rallied boldly nearing the stretch to enter contention and then went on to a two-length victory in the $35,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. The 4-year-old son of Vigors-Bright Reflection carried 112 pounds. Ridden by E. T. Baird over the mile-and-a-sixteenth course on a track labeled good, Alioth was timed in 1:42 4/5 to register his first victory in five starts this year. Alberta Clipper, the favorite was runner-up, three lengths ahead of Bordeaux Bob. Alioth earned $21,000 for Harp Angel Stable and paid $20.20 for $2 to win.

title: PEOPLE
description: Thomas Rost has joined Hal Riney & Partners, New York, as senior vice president, creative director.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BOWLING: BOOM SPORT FADING FAST
description: Since Dutch settlers brought bowling to Manhattan and the English played at Bowling Green, the sport has been part of the island's life. By 1840, nearly every block of Broadway from Fulton Street to 14th Street boasted an alley, according to historical accounts.

title: Rangers' Euphoria Replaced by Doubt
description: Another crazy day in the Rangers' crazy year was past. They had argued with the officials and brawled with the opponent. One player was ejected and ended up suspended; in between, they allowed seven goals and fell to fourth place.

title: Shots Fired in Soweto At Home of Mandelas
description: Shots were fired near the Soweto home of the black nationalist Winnie Mandela early today and the police reported they had come under fire from the garden.

title: MICRO BIO-MEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

description: b-Includes pre-tax gains of about $200,000 on dispositions of an investment and an office building.

title: Russia Offers to Aid Ferret-Breeding Effort
description: The director of a Soviet zoo has offered to lend six Siberian ferrets to wildlife officials trying to save North America's nearly extinct black-footed ferrets.

title: Kenyan to Visit Washington
description: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya will make an official working visit to the United States and meet with President Reagan at the White House on March 12, it was announced today.

title: M'S NEW PUBLISHER SEES 10% CLIMB IN AD PAGES
description: M magazine, Fairchild Publications' slick, handsome publication for upscale men, has had Susan Guggenheim Lodge at the publishing helm for a couple of months now.

title: MUSIC: A LOOK AT 3 VINTAGE SHOWS
description: WHAT do the Broadway musicals ''The King and I,'' ''A Tree Grows in Brooklyn,'' and ''The Pajama Game'' have in common? All three shows were based on novels and were first produced in the 1950's. That is the premise for lumping them together in this season's second program of the 92d Street Y's popular ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series, in which guest artists sing the highlights from vintage hit shows, while a host-narrator delivers plot synposes and chatty historical information about the original productions.

title: A EUROPE OF TWO MINDS
description: Although Western European leaders have publicly welcomed Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal for a freestanding agreement to eliminate medium-range missiles from Europe, privately they are known to harbor misgivings about the dangers of such an accord for the NATO alliance.

title: Investigation of Rep. Boner Is Dropped by Justice Dept.
description: The Justice Department has dropped a grand jury investigation of allegations that Representative Bill Boner used his office for financial gain, attorneys for the Tennessee Democrat said today.

title: 17 FOUND GUILTY IN 'PIZZA' TRIAL OF A DRUG RING
description: A former chief of the Sicilian Mafia and 16 other defendants in the ''pizza connection'' trial were convicted yesterday of running an international ring that distributed tons of drugs.

title: DESIGN ADVANCES POINT TO CHEAP SUPERSONIC FLIGHT
description: AIRCRAFT manufacturers and Government scientists have intensified efforts to reduce the air's drag on planes. Success, some experts say, could make supersonic travel as cheap as subsonic flight by the year 2000.

title: 3 CONVICTED IN FAILURE OF HOME STATE
description: Marvin L. Warner, former owner of the Home State Savings Bank, and two other officers of the defunct savings and loan institution were found guilty today of state charges relating to Home State's downfall. which touched off a statewide thrift crisis in 1985.

title: COMPROMISE EXPECTED ON CHIP CONSORTIUM
description: The nation's leading chip makers remain deeply divided over how to structure a last-ditch effort against Japan's electronics giants, but they expect a compromise to be reached tomorrow as they meet in Washington.

title: TOWN GLITCHED BY COMPUTER
description: At 4:55 A.M. today hundreds of radio and television stations received a report that Rockford, Ill., had been demolished by a tornado.

title: Galaxy's 'Missing Mass'
description: A scientist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, ruling out a host of exotic possibilities, has calculated that the ''missing mass'' in the Milky Way galaxy consists of billions of dim, huge planets.

title: MORGENTHAU VOWS TO CONDUCT FAIR INVESTIGATION IN HARLEM SLAYING
description: The Manhattan District Attorney yesterday promised a full, fair and sensitive investigation into the death a man killed by a barrage of police gunfire in Harlem Saturday night after what the police called his unprovoked attack on a rookie officer with a lead pipe.

title: WALTER IS IN MIDDLE OF THINGS
description: Who is Gene Walter? The new left-handed middle-relief pitcher on the Mets. What's a middle-relief pitcher? Somebody who doesn't start a game, end it or win it.

title: INSIDE TRADERS RECEIVE FINES
description: A Federal judge today fined two men $25,000 each for securities law violations after they pleaded guilty last June to reaping $160,000 in illegal profits from insider trading.

title: RURAL-URBAN GAP IS WIDENING AGAIN
description: Rural and small-town Americans, who were gaining economically on those in urban areas in the last decade, are falling behind again in the 1980's.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD APPROVES MALL FOR REGO PARK
description: The Board of Estimate last night voted 8 to 2 in favor of plans for an indoor shopping mall in Rego Park -four days later than originally planned and minutes before expiration of a city deadline for the vote.

title: Wildlife Strategies
description: Efforts to save endangered animals may fail unless they are accompanied by detailed scientific study, according to an anthropologist at Harvard University who said that the woolly spider monkey of Brazil is a case in point.

title: M-I SCHOTTENSTEIN HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are pro forma to include adjustments to reflect changes in taxation based on changes in the structure of partnerships and corporations within the company.

title: POLISH POLICE BREAK UP DISSIDENT NEWS PARLEY
description: Three policemen today entered the home of Jacek Kuron, a Solidarity adviser, just as he was telling Western reporters at a news conference that pressures against dissidents had been abating.

title: Conflicting Views
description: The Philadelphia Eagles insisted yesterday that Ron Jaworski was still under contract, contradicting the quarterback's agent, John Langel, who contended the failure to guarantee a $600,000 contract left him free to negotiate with any other team. The Eagles' general manager, Harry Gamble, said: ''Ron is still under contract with the Eagles. He is not a free agent. He must advise us that he wants to be placed on waivers.'' Gamble, sitting with Coach Buddy Ryan at a news conference, said it wasn't a question of meeting a March 1 deadline under which the club would have to guarantee the $600,000 a year agreed to in a five-year contract signed a year ago. ''We want him to come to training camp and compete for a position on the team,'' Gamble said. ''We want Ron Jaworski here. We did not want to trade him.'' Said Ryan: ''I told Ron I didn't want to make my decision in March. I want to wait until August.'' Jaworski will turn 36 in three weeks.

title: BRAZIL'S DEBT: A KEY JUNCTURE
description: In coming weeks, Brazil's top finance officials will arrive in New York to resolve the latest episode in a five-year-old debt crisis: Brazil's decision to suspend interest payments to its banks on most of its $108 billion in foreign borrowings.
