description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: QUEENS ESCAPE RAISES QUESTION ON A JAIL POLICY
description: A city correction official said yesterday that the escape of three inmates from a Queens jail Sunday morning raised the question of whether past conspirators in ''extremely serious'' crimes should be confined together.

title: 'POWER' BREAKFASTS IN LONDON HAVE EXECUTIVES UP AT DAWN
description: FIRST it was hamburgers.

title: FOR TOP DESIGNERS, FALL IN NEW YORK PRECEDES SPRING IN EUROPE
description: MORE than a month before the openings of their new collections abroad, some European designers introduced fall styles in New York. The clothes included the predictable topical design features, such as ruffles framing bare shoulders and gathered tiers at the hemline. But there were also practical fashions, like raincoats and tailored suits.

title: Shift at RJR Nabisco
description: F. Ross Johnson, the 55-year-old president and chief executive of RJR Nabisco Inc., will become the top officer of the company this spring, even sooner than he had expected. J. Tylee Wilson, 55, the current chairman, said yesterday that he would resign from his post in April, although he will remain with the company, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., until taking early retirement in January 1988. Mr. Wilson had previously said he would step down next January, leaving Mr. Johnson in charge of the giant consumer products company. Mr. Wilson chose to break the news in the company's annual report, which was released yesterday.

title: TOWN TAKES TOXIC WASTES IN STRIDE
description: For more than 35 years operators of the underground natural gas pipelines that skirt this small town have helped build the community, providing jobs in hard times and playgrounds in summertime.

title: PBS REVIVES SERIES BY BILL MOYERS
description: A Bill Moyers series on the Constitution, scrapped by the Public Broadcasting Service two weeks ago after a dispute over the program's time slot, has been revived and will be broadcast this spring, according to public television officials.

title: IN PORTUGAL, COOKING VIA MOLIERE
description: FOOD was not her first love (needlework was), or even her second (gardening was). So how did this small woman with snapping brown eyes land a weekly television cooking show, produce a string of best-selling cookbooks and emerge as her country's most trusted food authority? In short, how did Maria de Lourdes Modesto become Portugal's Julia Child?

title: Pennzoil Calls For Negotiation
description: The Pennzoil Company has repeated its willingness to negotiate an out-of-court settlement with Texaco Inc., calling it ''clearly in the best interests of both companies.'' In a letter to Pennzoil shareholders, mailed Monday, the chairman and chief executive of the Houston energy company, J. Hugh Liedtke, said that Texaco was attempting to ''win in the newspapers what it lost in the courts.'' A spokesman for Texaco said tonight that the company had not seen Mr. Liedtke's letter and would not comment.

title: In a Class by Himself
description: If Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics can continue the play that won him the Maurice Podoloff Trophy the last three seasons, he would become the first player to be named the National Basketball Association's most valuable player four consecutive seasons. The players who have won the award in at least twice consecutively: Player Seasons Larry Bird, Celtics (3) 1984-86 Wilt Chamberlain, 76ers (3) 1966-68 Bill Russell, Celtics (3) 1961-63 Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Bucks (2) 1971-72 Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Lakers (2) 1975-76 Moses Malone, Rockets-76ers (2) 1982-83

title: MAN KILLED BY OFFICERS HAD CITED HARASSMENT
description: A man who was shot and killed by the police after he attacked an officer with a pipe in Harlem Saturday night had complained earlier that day that officers had harrassed him for peddling on the street, the police said yesterday.

title: SUPRADUR COMPANIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain from discontinued operations of $451,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,310,000.

title: FILM: 'BROKEN MIRRORS'
description: BY coincidence, two films have just arrived here that were made by women who see brothels, and the lives of the women who work in them, as signifying the lot of women in a political world in which men have all the power, at least until now.

title: Hall of Fame Doors Open for Dandridge
description: Ray Dandridge, a star third baseman who sometimes played three games in one day in the old Negro Leagues but who never made the major leagues, was elected to baseball's Hall of Fame today by the Committee on Veterans, and said: ''I came out of the cornfields and got there.''

title: AVERY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $4.8 million in non-cash acquisition accounting charges related to the acquisition of Uniroyal Chemical. c-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $1,591,000. The company said the latest quarter includes the operations of Uniroyal Chemical Co. since Oct. 30, 1986, the date of the acquisition.

title: 'TOP GUN' CASSETTE BECOMES TOP SELLER
description: Surpassing all expectations, initial orders for the video cassette of the Paramount movie ''Top Gun'' have exceeded 1.9 million, making the film the largest seller in video history two weeks before it even reaches store shelves. The previous record holder was ''Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom'' at 1.4 million units.

title: MARK CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a provision of $1.1 million for restructuring and unusual items. c-Net income.

title: DOW RISES BY 6.05 LIGHT TRADING
description: Oil stocks and certain drug issues were the only signs of life yesterday in an otherwise dead stock market that rose, but not too much, on continued light volume.

title: FUNDS URGED FOR F.S.L.I.C.
description: The fund that insures savings and loan association deposits is technically insolvent and requires an infusion of at least $25 billion, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: VERMONT SOCIALIST RE-ELECTED
description: Bernard Sanders, a Socialist Party member, easily won a fourth two-year term today as Mayor of Vermont's largest city.

title: MAKELA CONTINUES HIS PATTERN FOR TIES
description: Once again, there was a certain measure of relief after the Islanders recovered from a deficit and at least matched the opposition's goals. But distress, said their coach, was his primary reaction to another evening of frenzied third-period activity from his team.

title: EARLY ELECTIONS LOOM
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, one of Italy's most durable postwar leaders, resigned today, ending an unusually long period of political stability and raising the possibility of early elections.

title: Tort Reform Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: THOSE WITH AIDS COULD BENEFIT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that recipients of Federal money may not discriminate against people who are physically or mentally impaired by contagious diseases. Although the decision involved a schoolteacher suffering from tuberculosis, it could benefit many victims of AIDS.

title: DANNY KAYE, LIMBER-LIMBED COMMEDIAN, DIES
description: Danny Kaye, the puckish Brooklyn-reared comedian who sang, danced, mimicked, pantomimed and joked his way to Broadway and Hollywood fame, died of heart failure yesterday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, where he was admitted Sunday suffering from internal bleeding and hepatitis, a spokesman for the center said. He was 74 years old and had lived for many years in Beverly Hills.

title: KAY JEWELERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said sales recorded by the J.B. Robinson Stores, acquired on Dec. 1, 1986, contributed $23,000,000 to the latest quarter revenue. The company said it declared a 5-for-4 stock split to be distributed March 20, 1987, to shareholders of record March 2, 1987.

title: S.M.U. GOVERNORS ALLOWED ILLICIT ATHLETE PAY
description: Gov. Bill Clements of Texas said yesterday that he and some other members of Southern Methodist University's board of governors decided in 1985 that illicit payments to S.M.U. football players would continue.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE most popular ''new'' food found in America's homes and restaurants was once available mostly in regional and country settings. I am speaking, of course, of quail, now a menu standard from one coast to the other.

title: Army Is Facing Pressure to Delay Plan to Burn Chemical Weapons
description: The Army is facing increasing pressure to delay plans for destroying obsolete chemical weapons by incinerating them near sites around the nation where they have been stored for decades.

title: LIFE IN THE 30's
description: I am on the telephone to the emergency room of the local hospital. My elder son is getting stitches in his palm, and I have called to make myself feel better, because I am at home, waiting, and my husband is there, holding him. I am 34 years old, and I am crying like a child, making a slippery mess of my face. ''Mrs. Krovatin?'' says the nurse, and for the first time in my life I answer ''Yes.''

title: TOLL BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago share earnings restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Feb. 26, 1987.

title: JAPAN JOBLESS RATE AT RECORD 3%, STIRRING WORRIES OF WORSE TO COME
description: Japan's unemployment rate rose in January to 3 percent of the labor force, the highest level since monthly reporting began in 1953, the Government announced today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY: During a recent Saturday morning jam-up at a checkout counter in the Stuyvesant Town D'Agostino's, I stood behind a little girl of about 5 who sat in the jump seat of her mother's shopping cart. The youngster began to fidget and complain loudly about the slowness of the line.

title: Our Hearts' Desires
description: To The Living Section:

title: BENIFICIAL WILL SELL SIX INSURANCE UNITS
description: The Beneficial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell six insurance operations, including the American Centennial Insurance Company, to the management of American Centennial.

title: EXTENSION OF ALL PHASES OF ARMS TALKS IS DISCUSSED
description: American and Soviet negotiators met throughout the day today to discuss extending the negotiations on long-range and space weapons beyond Wednesday, when they were scheduled to adjourn, officials said.

title: Donald MacBeth Dies at 37; A Leading New York Jockey
description: Donald MacBeth, a leading jockey who won the first Breeders' Cup race three years ago, died of cancer Sunday evening at his home in Ocala, Fla. He was 37 years old.

title: HARMONY OF ART AND SCIENCE LIFTS A MUSIC INDUSTRY BARRIER
description: STEVIE WONDER and Nile Rodgers are planning to get together this afternoon to make a record, even though they are 3,000 miles apart. Their studio will stretch from Queens to Staten Island, across 45,000 miles of space and back down to Los Angeles, but it could just as easily span New York and Tokyo, Maui or anywhere else that busy, or perhaps reclusive, recording stars are found.

title: Ham Radio
description: To The Living Section:

title: Wedtech Founder Sued by Company
description: The new management of the Wedtech Corporation has filed a lawsuit accusing the company's founder and former chairman, John Mariotta, of conspiring to steal more than $2 million from the company. The company said the money was used in part to bribe officials.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 4, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11, A14-15 A proposed arms treaty on medium-range arms will be presented by United States negotiators in Geneva today, President Reagan announced, apparently in an effort to show he is taking an active role in foreign affairs. Page A1

title: GULF RESOURCES & CHEMICALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $6,050,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income d-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $24,839,000 for the quarter and the year includes net from discontinued operations of $64,013,000. The company said the latest results include a nonrecurring gain of $5.3 million from termination of a pension plan. Results for all periods have been restated to reflect an accounting change, effective Jan. 1, 1987, to the successful efforts method. The company said share earnings are fully diluted.

title: STRICTER SAFETY RULES URGED ON SHIPMENTS OF MUNITIONS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board cited an increased danger of highway accidents involving shipments of munitions today and called on the departments of Transportation and Defense to impose rigid new safety procedures for such activities.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 19 about Freedom Newspapers Inc. incompletely described the competition in Orange County, Calif., between two newspapers. The Orange County Register, a Freedom paper based in Santa Ana, has long had a bigger circulation in Orange County than The Los Angeles Times, and has increased its lead there in recent years.

title: JAPANESE ACT ON CHIP FLOW
description: Japan is tightening restrictions on microchip exports to countries other than the United States in an attempt to preserve an American-Japanese agreement on semiconductor trade. But Japanese chip makers say they doubt the move will work. The Ministry of International

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in December 1986.

title: CASE OF COLOR BLIND AIRMAN MAY AFFECT RECRUITING
description: Andrew Jackson Woodrick, the son of a World War II bomber navigator, said when he enrolled in the Air Force Reserve Offficers Training Corps six years ago, he was assured he was qualified to train to become a pilot.

title: BEAUTIFUL L.A. RAIDS UGLY CITY TO FIND POLICE
description: This is all grossly unfair, and was carefully planned that way.

title: Color at Home
description: 1. For a Cheery Room

title: PEOPLE
description: G. Howard Clark has joined Noble Communications Co. as executive vice president, director of new business development and Southern operations.

title: Liposuction Surgery
description: To The Living Section:

title: UNITED HEALTHCARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $920,000. c-After a tax credit of $785,000 for the quarter and year. The latest periods' results include those of Peak Health Care Inc., from Nov. 7, 1986, through Dec. 31.

title: Canseco Ends Holdout
description: Jose Canseco, the American League Rookie of the Year last season, has agreed to end his holdout and will report to the Oakland A's training camp in Scottsdale, Ariz., today. Canseco, who hit 33 home runs last year with 117 runs batted in, had been seeking a contract of $200,000 and the A's had offered $150,000. Sandy Alderson, the A's vice president of baseball operations, expressed optimism that an agreement can be reached within a week.

title: Surprise Winner
description: As the world's premier diver and winner of the 1985 Sullivan Award as the nation's top amateur athlete, Greg Louganis should not have been all that surprised that he outpolled some stiff international competition to win the 1987 Jesse Owens trophy as the world's top amateur athlete.

title: GERALD R. COLEMAN
description: Gerald R. Coleman, a retired union official and a former member of the New York City Planning Commission, died Saturday at a nursing home in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Move to Heal Split in F.B.I. and C.I.A.
description: The appointment of William H. Webster to be Director of Central Intelligence could bring a definitive end to a long period of feuding between the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency and improve the Government's effort to curb foreign spying, experts in the field said tonight.

title: YUGOSLAV DEBT POSITION
description: Yugoslavia may face problems repaying its $20 billion foreign debt, but it does not plan to follow Brazil in suspending debt interest payments, according to a senior Government official. Deputy Prime Minister Janez Zemljaric, in comments reported today by the state-run Politika newspaper, said Yugoslavia ''did not accept the Brazilian model'' of dealing with creditors.

title: Home Shopping Sets Stock Options
description: Home Shopping Network Inc. said its board had approved plans to offer a stock option plan for its cable television operators. Home Shopping, the leader in the video shopping industry, will offer the options in exchange for a commitment to deliver its programs to a fixed number of subscribers for five years, with a five-year extension option.

title: AQUINO ANNOUNCES LAND-CHANGE PLAN
description: President Corazon C. Aquino announced the first steps today toward financing a long-awaited land program, but declined to say whether she would redistribute the land on her own sugar plantation.

title: KANSAS SENATOR FORMS EXPLORATORY COMMITTEE
description: Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader, who is the chief challenger to Vice President Bush as the front-runner for the Republican Presidential nomination, officially entered the political waters today by forming an exploratory committee.

title: BURLINGTON COAT FACTORY WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Other Catastrophic Cost
description: The doubters and critics still have a point. Boldly and sensibly, the Reagan Administration has endorsed a new insurance plan that would instantly deflate the fear millions have of being wiped out by catastrophic illness. But the Administration has not yet done anything to allay a fear felt by students of Medicare. They see a rapidly rising need for home care and treatment in nursing facilities and worry that Federal revenues will be wiped out.

title: RUSSIANS TRADING ON FILM MARKET
description: When a group of independent American movie producers and distributors started the American Film Market in 1981, they were underdogs challenging the high prices and bureaucracy of the huge Cannes Film Market in France. Last year, member companies sold $143.4 million worth of theatrical and video rights at the American Film Market, almost double the $74.8 million they sold at Cannes.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: DANCE: LESA MCLAUGHLIN
description: LESA McLAUGHLIN and Dancers, a company from Washington, appeared Sunday afternoon at the Theater of the Riverside Church in a program that suggested that Ms. McLaughlin was fascinated by violent or inarticulate people. Fortunately, at its best, her choreography, though violent, is quite articulate.

title: NEW-HOME SALES FELL IN JANUARY
description: Sales of new homes fell 6.8 percent in January, reflecting the end of a tax-related buying spree, while the median price of a new home topped $100,000 for the first time in history, the Government reported today.

title: Bullet Kills Driver At Busy Intersection
description: A 31-year-old woman was fatally shot while driving her car past a shopping center yesterday afternoon, the Nassau County police said.

title: FANNIE MAE ISSUE
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association is offering $1 billion of 7 percent, five-year debentures at a price of 100 through various securities dealers. The issue yields about three-tenths of a percentage point more than recently auctioned Treasury notes of similar maturity. Proceeds will be used to redeem in part $1.35 billion of maturing debentures.

title: DALLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,814,000 for the quarter and $7,976,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Brazil's Battle Aainst Banks
description: WHILE the Carnival festivities were going on in Rio, Brazil's Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro, and its central bank governor, Francisco Gros, flew to Washington last week to seek the help of American and international financial officials. They got tea and sympathy but no promises of more money unless they came up with a plan for bringing their country's raging inflation under control.

title: ALONG HONDURAN BORDER, PEASANTS RALLY TO THE CONTRAS
description: The Sandinista army unit gave no warning when it swept into the village of Siuna two years ago to seize peasants who supported the Nicaraguan guerrilla patrols that regularly moved through the area, according to several villagers who say they escaped the roundup.

title: DANCE: CUNNINGHAM'S 'FABRICATIONS'
description: THERE are times when everything goes right at an opening and last night's start of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company season was a prime example.

title: REGAN BACKS CUTTING TAXES IN STATE IN '87
description: The State Comptroller today supported the Legislature's call for an immediate cut in state taxes, rejecting Governor Cuomo's argument that New York cannot afford one until 1988.

title: MORRIS AND PARRISH GO SEPARATE WAYS
description: Jack Morris read today that Lance Parrish was on the verge of signing with the Philadelphia Phillies, and he had mixed feelings.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AS AIDS casts a pall over the nation's once-liberated sexual consciousness, more and more attention is being paid to how - short of chastity - to halt the further spread of this deadly scourge. Though the phrase ''safe sex'' is bandied about and people are warned euphemistically to ''avoid exchanges of body fluids,'' few sexually active American adults and soon-to-be-sexually-active teen-agers are properly informed about the most effective weapon currently available: the condom.

title: A Call to Arms
description: President Reagan has received a wide variety of advice from prominent Republicans about his speech planned tonight on the Iran arms affair, and some of the least compromising may have come from his Secretary of Education, William J. Bennett. At the White House earlier this week, associates say, Mr. Bennett strongly urged the President not to apologize to the American people for his role in sending arms to Iran and funds to the Nicaraguan rebels. The Secretary counseled Mr. Reagan to explain in his speech what he had done and why, assume responsibility for his own acts and then ''issue a call to arms to the American people'' to unite behind him.

title: HUGHES UNIT THINKS TAX PACT WILL EXPAND RESEARCH EFFORT
description: Under a new tax settlement with the Internal Revenue Service, the Howard Hughes Medical Institute expects to expand significantly its already commanding position as the nation's leading private source of funds for biomedical research.

title: DOWN EAST, THEY EAT ORGANICALLY GROWN FOOD AT ARBY'S
description: LEAD: THE pungent odor of fresh cabbage overwhelmed the interior of Jim Raffel's car. In the back seat were several large buckets of coleslaw, prepared at Hedgehog Hill organic farm and destined for one of the four Arby's fast-food restaurants that Mr. Raffel and his brother, Ken, own in southern Maine.

title: WALTER MONDALE ON NOT SAYING, 'I TOLD YOU SO'
description: Walter F. Mondale says he's vindicated.

title: BROOKLYN NEIGHBORHOOD HELPS REVIVE STOREFRONTS
description: A year ago not one of the 14 storefronts on Nostrand Avenue between Martense Street and Linden Boulevard in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn held a business. Some had stood empty as long as eight years.

title: Let's Skip the Courts-Martial
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, the former United States Supreme Court Justice, recently recommended that Adm. John Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North be court martialed and granted immunity by a military court. That way, according to Justice Goldberg, a painful, prolonged inquiry would be avoided, the public would be sure to get the information it wants and ought to have and a flawed Presidency would be restored.

title: 'Pizza' Conspirator Faces New Charge
description: A former Mafia chief convicted in the ''pizza connection'' case was charged yesterday with contempt of court for his testimony in the 17-month drug trial.

title: N.C.A.A. Clamp To Get Tighter
description: It might seem tough enough already to the 32 athletes who were disqualified from N.C.A.A. tournaments and bowl games last fall, but come September the National Collegiate Athletic Association's new drug-testing program is really going to sprout teeth.

title: WITNESS TESTIFIES HE ARRANGED LOW-INTEREST LOANS FOR TUROFF
description: The prosecution's chief witness against Jay L. Turoff, the former head of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, testified yesterday that he arranged low-interest loans for Mr. Turoff in exchange for an exclusive deal to finance meters for taxi owners.

title: OPINION BY SCALIA OPPOSES BROAD VIEW OF POLICE POWER
description: Associate Justice Antonin Scalia, confounding predictions that he would invariably side with Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and with the police against criminal defendants, wrote an opinion refusing to expand police search powers in a decision issued today.

title: UNSUNG KNICKS LEAD TEAM TO VICTORY
description: Louis Orr snatched an offensive rebound from the grasp of two defenders, then scored over the outstretched arm of 7-foot-4-inch Mark Eaton, the league's leading shot-blocker. Rory Sparrow pushed the ball up the floor and either found an open man or scored himself. And Trent Tucker, the designated shooter, was doing just that, with deadly accuracy.

title: Reagan's Last Chance
description: Ed Muskie summarized the critical cause of the Iran-contra scandal when he declared that it was a failure of responsibility; and the Tower commission left no doubt that this responsibility was the President's.

title: COMMUNIST PARTY IN LEBANON HURT
description: Lebanon's small but highly active Communist Party was disastrously hurt by the recent fighting in West Beirut, with many of its leaders and members killed or missing.

title: Mets' Aguilera Ailing
description: The Mets suffered their first ailment of the spring today when Rick Aguilera left the team's workout early with a stomach virus.

title: EXCELLENCE AND EQUALITY: A CONFLICT?
description: New York institutions that pride themselves on rewarding merit are nonetheless wrestling with ways to serve the cause of greater equality.

title: Whispering in the President's Ear
description: What's the proper role for First Ladies?

title: 'HARRY,' ABC COMEDY STARRING ALAN ARKIN
description: ABC's ''Harry,'' a new situation comedy starring Alan Arkin in the title role, tries hard to be delightfully wacky. Two available episodes, including tonight's premiere at 8:30 on Channel 7, turn out to be hopelessly silly. Created by Susan Kramer and developed by Gary Jacobs, who is also the supervising producer, ''Harry'' is set in the purchasing department of ''a major metropolitan hospital.'' With Harry Porschak in charge, the staff dabbles in such madcap activities as organizing an office pool to guess when a hospital patient might pass his kidney stones. The laugh track almost doubles over.

title: CAMPAIGN ON ABUSE OF DRUGS
description: THERE was a sneak preview yesterday of some of the television advertising spots that will be part of the gigantic onslaught against the nation's drug-abuse problems, and they proved to be really high-quality commercials.

title: Headed to Law School
description: The University of Michigan football team will lose last season's leading receiver to Harvard Law School. Ken Higgins was eligible to play football for Michigan for another year because he was out with injuries earlier in his career. ''It's always been my goal to go to the best law school possible, and Harvard is obviously the best,'' said the 6-foot-2-inch, 190-pound Higgins.

title: HAWAII OFFERING
description: Hawaii is offering $201.6 million of general obligation and refunding bonds through underwriters led by Bank of America, with yields ranging from 4.20 percent for an issue due in 1990 to 4.70 percent in 1992, 5.45 percent in 1997, 6 percent in 2002 and 6.25 percent in 2007. The offering is rated double-A by both Moody's and S.& P.; all but $80 million of the proceeds will be used to refund outstanding bonds sold in 1983.

title: MINSTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,915,000 for the quarter and $11,530,000 for the year, and extraordinary charges of $2,482,000 and $9,468,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The year net also includes a writedown of $12.4 million on the company's investment in Tidewater Inc. c-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $18,729,000. d-After income from discontinued operations of $19,342,000 and an extraordinary gain of $7,375,000. The results for 1985 have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: REAGAN ANNOUNCES NEW U.S. PROPOSAL ON MID-RANGE ARMS
description: President Reagan announced today that American negotiators would begin offering a treaty draft on medium-range weapons in Geneva on Wednesday.

title: Suspect Is Released in Arson At a Library in Los Angeles
description: A suspect in a $22 million fire last April at the historic Central Library was released on Monday for lack of evidence, officials said today.

title: New Taxi Bill Benefits All New York Boroughs
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSIT REFUNDING IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority is offering $116.3 million of general transportation system refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 6.578 percent for bonds due in 2015.

title: Bass Shoe Concern Is Put Up for Sale
description: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. said it wanted to sell its Maine-based Bass shoe division, best known for the popular Weejuns loafers. Chesebrough, whose products include Vaseline skin products, Ragu spaghetti sauce and Prince tennis racquets, said the footwear operation did not fit in with its long-term strategy.

title: Soviet Dissident Released
description: Serafim Yevsyukov, a dissident who was taken to a psychiatric hospital on Sunday after protesting against his son's confinement in a labor camp, was released today, his daughter said. The woman, Lyudmila Yevsyukov, said her father was in ''reasonably good health'' after receiving two forced injections of drugs.

title: KEY RATES
LSB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain from early retirement of debt of $270,000. c-Net loss

title: FARM FRESH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its effective tax rate increased to 44 percent in the latest year from 31 percent. The elimination of the investment tax credit increased taxes by about $590,000. The company also said it incurred about $1.4 million of non-recurring expenses relating to its merger with Open Air Markets Inc., most of which were recorded in the latest fourth quarter.

title: Oilers Acquire Nilsson
description: ''He's a great player. He's the purest most talented player in the league.'' Is that somebody in the National Hockey League talking about Wayne Gretzky again? No, that's what Gretzky said yesterday about Kent Nilsson, the North Stars' right wing, when he heard that Minnesota sent Nilsson to Edmonton in exchange for a 1988 draft choice. In 44 games this season, Nilsson has 13 goals and 33 assists, but Lou Nanne, the North Stars' general manager, has expressed unhappiness wih his defensive play.

title: Marian Greenberg, 89; Active in Jewish Issues
description: Marian Gerber Greenberg, who worked closely with Henrietta Szold, the founder of the Hadassah, the Woman's Zionist Organization of America, and its Youth Aliyah to help rescue thousands of Jewish children from Nazi Germany, died of congestive heart failure Feb. 24 at the Cooley-Dickenson Hospital, Northhampton, Mass. She was 89 years old and lived in Amherst, Mass.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Oil Prices Surge on OPEC Reports
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products jumped yesterday, in some cases chalking up their biggest one-day advance so far this year. The increases came on reports that OPEC may be much closer than previously thought to the output levels it set last year.

title: 5 Libyans, Including Senior Officer, Flee to Egypt
description: Five Libyan airmen, including a high-ranking officer, sought asylum here today after fleeing the Chad battlefront for a remote tourist airport.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: OVERHEAD IN A BALLOON. Twelve Stories of Paris. By Mavis Gallant. 196 pages. Random House. $16.95.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Barry Parkhill was dismissed as basketball coach at William & Mary, three days after the team finished its season with a record of 5-22. . . . A student judicial board at the University of Maryland has suspended David Gregg, a forward, from the school's basketball team for a year, retroactive to the start of the season, for purportedly possessing cocaine in his dormitory suite, The Washington Post reported. Gregg did not play this season.

title: PRODUCER OFFERS REPAYMENT
description: John A. McQuiggan, the producer of ''The Common Pursuit'' and other Off Broadway hits, agreed yesterday to offer repayment within one year to investors in two shows, an assistant New York State Attorney General, Elizabeth Block, said yesterday.

title: DEVILS IN NO-WIN SITUATION
description: The Devils accomplished on two consecutive shots what they had failed to do on their first 30 tonight, but lost again to the Capitals, this time by 3-2.

title: A FOOTNOTE ON FERRARO
description: The following is an excerpt from the interview with Mr. Mondale, in which he discusses two crucial issues in his unsuccessful 1984 campaign: his controversial proposal to impose new taxes to reduce the budget deficit and the problems that resulted when his running mate, Geraldine A. Ferraro, resisted making a full disclosure of her family's tax and other financial records:

title: VINEYARDS ACROSS AMERICA ENHANCE THE STATUS OF PREMIUM U.S. WINES
description: SINCE the early 1970's, and especially in the 80's, the quality of the best wines in the United States has risen like bubbles in Champagne. The result is that today this country, a nation of beer drinkers, is a full-blown producer of premium wines. The United States is still not in the same league as France as a producer of first-quality wines, but it has achieved a new status.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN STATEMENT ON ARMS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's statement today on intermediate-range nuclear forces:

title: Navratilova, Lloyd Gain Quarterfinals
description: Women's tennis often mimics the changeable weather in southern Florida on a humid afternoon when the sky darkens, the wind freshens and there are sinister rumblings in the air. Sometimes it rains, sometimes it doesn't. The results thus far in the Lipton International Players Championships indicate that the storm that was brewing early in the year on the women's tour may be passing.

title: FUNARO MEETS FRENCH
description: Brazil's Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro, today took his nation's quest for concessions from its creditors to France's Finance Minister, Edouard Balladur, and the governor of the Bank of France, Jacques de Larosiere. It was the second stop on a European mission to explain Brazil's debt crisis.

title: A CAKE THAT JOINS THE MARDI GRAS PARTY
description: LEAD: MARDI GRAS has it all - glittering parades, fancy-dress balls, kings and queens for a day and a special cake named for the occasion - king cake.

title: MISSING THE IRAN ARMS STORY: DID THE PRESS FAIL?
description: It is now clear that dozens of people - officials at the White House, the State Department, the Defense Department and the Central Intelligence Agency, as well as private arms dealers, businessmen and financiers in Israel and other countries - knew early on about the delivery of American arms to Iran that began in August 1985.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Maturity Stories ''Celebration of the Short Story,'' a series of Wednesday evening short-story readings by actors at Symphony Space, presents a nonsubscription program tonight. This means that there are more than the usual small number of tickets available.

title: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $8,308,000 and $7,774,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, in equity in the earnings of the company's former Kay Jewelers Inc. unit. c-Includes $6,806,000 and $5,779,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, in equity in the earnings of Kay Jewelers, the year also includes a $472,000 gain from asset sales and a $2,778,000 gain from an accounting change. The company said the 1985 results has been restated in connection with the distribution of Kay's investment in Kay Jewelers. The company reported earnings figures on Feb. 18 that excluded Kay Corp.'s equity in the earnings of Kay Jewelers in 1986 and 1985 and non- recurring items.

title: UNEASY ARGENTINE NAVY PLEDGES ITS LOYALTY
description: The head of the Argentine Navy publicly pledged its loyalty to the Government of President Raul Alfonsin today after a week of tension over whether navy officers on active duty are to be tried for human rights abuses.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 4, 1987
description: Companies

title: David Bird, 61, Dies; Reporter for The Times
description: David Bird, a reporter for the metropolitan staff of The New York Times, died of cancer yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 61 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Children and TV
description: To The Living Section:

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for 13wks to Jan 3
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $3,164,600 and $3,630,800 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Incudes net from discontinued operations of $69,100 for the quarter and $462,400 for the year. The 1985 share earnings are restated to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split paid June 2, 1986.

title: BUILD-NOW-FINISH-PLAN-LATER PLAN
description: The political and technical travails of the Air Force's B-1B strategic bomber, which has entered service without all its parts in working order, have reopened a perennial debate over how the military should design and build its weapons.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges. The bank said its provision for loan losses rose to $223 million in the latest quarter from $187 million in year-ago period. The results are in Canadian funds.

title: Crisis in Liability Insurance Is Not Over Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: TOWER REPORT TARNISHES THE LUSTER OF ABRAMS, POINT MAN ON CONTRA AID
description: The Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Elliott Abrams, who has been the Administration's point man on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels for the last two years, now finds his standing with Congress threatened as a result of the Iran-contra affair, according to foes and supporters alike.

title: 'Starlight Express' Delayed
description: ''Starlight Express,'' the Andrew Lloyd Webber rock musical in previews at the Gershwin Theater, has postponed its official opening to March 15 from March 5, a spokesman for the show, Bill Evans, said yesterday.

title: A HEAVY WEIGHT LOOKS AT BOXING
description: Joyce Carol Oates does not like tennis ''or any other game that is one-on-one.'' She attributes that lack of interest not to any possible lack of physical ability as to an absence of aggression.

title: Mutual Genocide
description: To the Editor:

title: PANTASOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges of $320,000 for the quarter and year representing costs related to the sale of the printing- laminating division, and tax credits of $62,000 and $127,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The year also includes a charge of $4 million from a provision established for potential warranty claims related to the discontinued roofing products business. c-After charges of $10,276,000 for the quarter and $12,708,000 for the year from costs and asset writedowns associated with restructuring moves, and tax credits of $41,000 and $88,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: TEXAN IS EXECUTED FOR KILLING OF SIX
description: A man who killed a state trooper and five other people in a kidnapping and murder spree four years ago was executed early today after spurning efforts by others to save his life.

title: President Urging Congress To Approve Latin Aid Package
description: President Reagan called on Congress today to approve a $300 million Central American aid package that the lawmakers failed to pass last year because of budgetary restraints.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, likes to tell a self-effacing story about a yet-to-be-issued commemorative postage stamp, honoring sponsors of the budget-balancing law, himself and Senators Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, and Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina. The stamp, he says, has one big problem: It keeps sliding off envelopes. The Postal Service calls in a high-priced consultant to check the glue, which is all right. Finally, the reason is discovered. Government wor

title: PROFITS DECLINE 45.9% AT OMNICOM GROUP
description: The Omnicom Group, parent company of BBDO International and DDB Needham Worldwide, yesterday released its fourth-quarter financial statement, which showed a decline in net income that was directly related to last year's mega-merger.

title: TOWER REFUSES JOB
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate William H. Webster as the Director of Central Intelligence, apparently seeking to restore agency morale and move his Administration beyond the Iran-contra scandal.

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for 12mo Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $21,680,000 from the sale of Service Territory unit.

title: PROTESTERS IN SEOUL ROUTED BY TEAR GAS
description: Tens of thousands of riot police officers blocked an anti-Government march today before it could start, scattering protesters and passers-by with volleys of tear gas.

title: Bertrand de Jouvenel Dies; Economic Forecast Pioneer
description: Bertrand de Jouvenel, a political economist and pioneer in economic forecasting, died Sunday, his family announced. He was 83 years old.

title: U.S. MEDIATOR TO JOIN WRITERS GUILD TALKS
description: The striking Writers Guild of America and representatives of the ABC and CBS networks have agreed to meet with a Federal mediator later this week.

title: THE ART OF DEVISING AIR FARES
description: In the airline business, it is sometimes called the dark science.

title: U.S. BOND PRICES DECLINE A BIT
description: Treasury bond prices fell modestly yesterday in response to rising oil prices and concerns that higher energy prices will lead to more inflation in coming months.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: 1978 CULT FIGURE GETS LIFE TERM IN CONGRESSMAN'S JUNGLE SLAYING
description: Larry Layton, a former member of the People's Temple cult, was sentenced today to life in prison for aiding and abetting in the murder of Representative Leo J. Ryan at a jungle airstrip in Guyana in November 1978.

title: The Need to Yearn
description: To The Living Section:

title: 1 MILLION VICTIMS OF AIDS PREDICTED BY YEAR 2000
description: Barring some dramatic advance in AIDS treatment or prevention, more than a million Americans will have developed the disease by the year 2000, according to a group of experts surveyed by Louis Harris & Associates.

title: Setting Limits for '88
description: The 1988 Presidential campaign now getting under way could cost the participants and the Government as much as $400 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He was truly a champion for children in every continent.'' - Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, describing Danny Kaye. [ A1:2. ]

title: GATES ISSUES A DEFENSE OF RECORD WITH C.I.A.
description: Robert M. Gates, the Acting Director of Central Intelligence, has issued a wide-ranging defense of his record in the Iran-contra affair, denying suggestions that he ignored or covered up evidence of improprieties.

title: WRIGHT PROPOSES A TAX ON SALES OF SECURITIES
description: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, said today that he was proposing a transfer tax on securities sales to remind people that reducing the deficit will require a tax increase.

title: YANKEES CALLED '2d CLASS'; STEINBRENNER IN A TIRADE
description: The reaction was angry and immediate. When George Steinbrenner learned today that Donald Fehr, the executive director of the players' union, had said the Yankees were ''a second-class citizen'' for their refusal to pursue free agents, the Yankee owner flew into a tirade as hot as the Florida sun.

title: PSYCHIATRIST RECOMMENDS JOINT CUSTODY OF BABY M
description: A child psychiatrist urged today that the custody of Baby M be equally shared by her father, William Stern, and her mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, and their spouses.

title: WITH DENG, SHULTZ LOOKS ON LIGHT SIDE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, engaged today in some lighthearted bantering about the political ''troubles and difficulties'' in both Beijing and Washington these days.

title: Afghanistan to Permit Visit By Human Rights Observer
description: The Afghan Foreign Minister said today that a special United Nations representative would be allowed into the country for the first time to examine charges of human rights violations.

title: Strict Priestly Celibacy Is a Catholic Tenet
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSIMONT COMPO NV reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company converted results from Italian lira to U.S. dollars at the Dec. 31, 1986 rate of $1 equaling 1.339 lira.

title: DAYS INNS' FEISTY CHIEF TAKES ON MOTEL GIANT
description: When he's not overseeing his small empire of moderately priced hotels and motels, Henry R. Silverman, 46, peruses his competitors' financial statements. Just the other day, he was sifting through the latest proxy statement from the Holiday Corporation, the industry giant, when he noticed that the company's planned restructuring would leave it with a negative net worth close to $1 billion.

title: RUNWAY COLLISION RENEWS EXPERTS' CONCERNS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board has established that a Boeing 727 airliner that was lifting into the air on a takeoff from Los Angeles last week struck a twin-engine private airplane taxiing across the runway, according to the investigator in charge.

title: UPSTARTS AND UPSETS MEAN UPHEAVAL IN BIG EAST
description: This season was heralded as the year of parity in the Big East, and it did result in one of the tightest races the league has had in three seasons, but it may have been less a season of parity than a season of displacement.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Monterey, Calif., on Feb. 18 about plans to auction television rights there for coverage of a visit by Pope John Paul II later this year misidentified another city on his United States route. It is Columbia, S.C., not Columbus.

title: REAGAN'S STAFF DEPICTED AS FAILING HIM
description: The Reagan Administration is in disarray because the White House staff in the President's second term is not as well-suited to him as the staff he entered office with six years ago, according to men who served under Mr. Reagan and Presidents Nixon and Carter.

title: JUDGE-SHOPPING IN FEDERAL COURT: LAWYERS' QUEST FOR LENIENCY
description: There are days in the Federal courthouse in Manhattan when defendants line up to plead guilty in unusually large numbers.

title: Midcon's President Quits Gas Concern
description: The Midcon Corporation, a natural gas pipeline company owned by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, announced yesterday that its president, William C. Terpstra, had resigned.

title: Firestone Plans To Shut 3 Units
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, the second-largest American tire maker after the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said that it would close three plants after the United Rubber Workers rejected a cost-cutting agreement for a second time. The plants, employing about 2,900 people, are in Des Moines, Bloomington, Ill., and Oklahoma City. The company notified the union that the plants would be closed by Sept. 15. A Firestone spokesman, Bob Troyer, said the cost of the shutdowns would be covered by the $65 million restructuring charge taken last quarter.

title: ABC Names an Anchor
description: ABC News has appointed Jed Duvall as news anchor of its early-morning ''World News This Morning'' newscast and the ''Good Morning America'' program. Mr. Duvall, 49 years old, has been a correspondent on the ABC program ''Nightline'' since 1983. In his new job he succeeds Steve Bell, who recently left ABC to join a station in Philadelphia.

title: Jaworski Hopes to Shift
description: Ron Jaworski, the Philadelphia Eagles' veteran quarterback, said he hoped to join another team next season, saying, ''I'd like to get with a winning team and get with a team that can go to the Super Bowl.'' Jaworski's agent, John Langel, said the 14-year veteran is the equivalent of a free agent. The Eagles say Jaworski is still under contract with the team even though they failed to guarantee his $600,000 salary by a March 1 deadline. The Eagles' general manager, Harry Gamble, said Jaworksi would have to clear waivers before he could sign with another team.

title: CHIP MAKERS IN ACCORD ON PLAN FOR CONSORTIUM
description: The nation's semiconductor makers agreed today to form a consortium in an effort to revive American manufacturing technology in the production of computer chips. They appealed to the Reagan Administration for financial support.

title: RECITAL: DAVID ZINN PIANO WORKS
description: MERKIN CONCERT HALL was the site of an unusual piano recital Tuesday evening when Nicholas Underhill played a program devoted entirely to the works of David Zinn, a composer who (the program note advised) is ''now being cited in the music field as the 'Einstein of music.' '' The first and most substantial piece on the bill was ''Metacosmos,'' a five-movement tale of nuclear suicide by ''the most cognitively advanced species on planet X'' and some quick evolutionary work by lower species to take up the slack, culminating in a ''March of the Mutant Insects'' and then a ''Galactic Pilgrimage'' in which the bugs, at the peak of their cognitive upward mobility, seek out other life forms in the universe.

title: Newark Priest Pleads Guilty To Sexual Assaults on Youths
description: A 56-year-old Roman Catholic priest pleaded guilty today to sexually assaulting three youths while assigned to a Newark church.

title: IDEAL SCHOOL SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $72,000 from early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and year. The company, which went public in December 1986, said its 1986 results include the total year's net sales of Luxor Corp. and Institutional Fair Inc. which were acquired in September 1985.

title: MERCHANTS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized gains of $279,000 for the quarter and $1,013,000 for the year, and tax credits of $606,000 and $2,323,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and includes realized gains of $439,000 for the quarter and $666,000 for the year.

title: SOVIET CROP HANDICAP
description: Soviet winter grains may be off to a poor start this spring after enduring an usually dry autumn and cold winter, according to crop analysts here.

title: METRO DATELINES;
description: Three masked men wielding shotguns fled yesterday with $1 million taken from an armored truck as it delivered money to a bank, the police said.

title: DOW WILL SELL SOUTH AFRICA UNITS
description: The Dow Chemical Company will complete its withdrawal from South Africa with the sale of its chemicals and plastics marketing operations to a consortium of investors, the company said. Dow declined to release details of its sale of the marketing offices, which employ about 70 people. A Dow spokesman said the offices do $45 million to $50 million in business annually, through sales of imported chemical and plastic products in South Africa.

title: HAITIAN ASSEMBLY WORKS TO DRAFT A DEMOCRACY
description: When elections were held last fall to create an assembly to write a new constitution for Haiti, the prevailing sentiments were indifference and skepticism, and very few people voted.

title: ANGRY REAGAN CALLS REPORTS OF WIFE'S POWER 'A FICTION'
description: President Reagan today denounced as ''despicable fiction'' published reports that his wife, Nancy, had played a major role in the dismissal of his chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, and was involved in key Government decisions.

title: WHERE CAPITALIST ROADERS CLING TO THE FAST LANE
description: South of the Yangtze River here, the frigid political gale from Beijing seems little more than a faint breeze, dissipated in a climate of brazen money making, spirited discussion and fashions that shout Hong Kong chic.

title: Jaworski on Waivers
description: The Philadelphia Eagles, who refused to guarantee Ron Jaworski his contracted $600,000 salary for the 1987 season, placed the veteran quarterback on waivers yesterday. Under National Football League rules, clubs have 10 days to claim him, which means they must also guarantee the salary, or he becomes a free agent and can negotiate an entirely new contract. In being released by Philadelphia, Jaworski will receive $144,000 in incentive money from his contract for the past season.

title: GROSSMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,437,000 and $75,566,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and an extraordinary loss of $294,000 for the quarter and the year includes an extraordinary credit of $224,778,000 related to the settlement of liabilities pursuant to a plan of reorganization. c-Net loss and after a losses of $189,979,000 and $227,733,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes an extraordinary charge of $1,750,000. The company said the latest quarter results include an after-tax provision of $2.3 million for losses to be incurred in future store closings, offset by a reduction in pension liabilities related to the ongoing restructuring of the pension plan pursuant to the plan of reorganization. The company noted that its results in the latest year reflect $26,644,000 in interest expense, dating from Jan. 1, 1986, on debentures issued pursuant to a plan of reorganization. Evans Products Co., the predecessor of Grossman's filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code in March 1985. In November 1986, when that company's reorganization plan became effective, Evan's subsidiary, Grossman's Inc., was merged into Evans, which changed its name to Grossman's Inc.

title: RAIDERS SIGN FERNANDEZ
description: Mervyn Fernandez, a wide receiver who was the 1985 Most Valuable Player in the Canadian Football League, signed a four-year deal yesterday with the Los Angeles Raiders of the National Football League after five seasons in the Canadian league.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Texas Tech Can't Compete
description: Texas Tech and Southern Methodist both play in the Southwest Conference, but when it comes to illicit recruiting, Tech, it seems, is simply not in S.M.U.'s league.

title: Marquette Picks Cords
description: Marquette University has named Bill Cords to succeed Hank Raymonds as athletic director. Cords, 45, has served as athletic director at the University of Texas-El Paso for the last five years. Raymonds plans to retire Aug. 31, concluding a 26-year career with Marquette in which he also served as head basketball coach.

title: A BIG TURNOUT FOR SMALL PUBLISHERS
description: Broadway, the thoroughfare synonymous with theater, resonated for three days this week with talk about books and magazines. The occasion was the Small Press Expo '87, which wound up yesterday at the Marriott Marquis hotel. It was the first such working meeting for small publishers.

title: A.M.C. OFFERS TO RESUME TALKS
description: The American Motors Corporation said it was willing to resume negotiations with the United Automobile Workers, as requested by Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin. Labor talks, which began Jan. 21, broke off Friday after the union rejected contract concessions. About 6,500 Wisconsin jobs are at stake.

title: Professional Police
description: When big cities set up police departments in the 19th century, hiring had more to do with ward politics than competence or physical ability. Given the right party loyalty, men who were too fat, too short - even amputees - might get hired. Corruption and brutality brought civil service hiring and other reforms. In the 20th century, departments became more ''professional.''

title: VOTERS IN ALAMOGORDO TO CAST THREE BALLOTS
description: Residents of Alamogordo will be able to cast up to three votes for one candidate for the City Commission under a settlement of a lawsuit approved here this week by a Federal judge.

title: TEXAN WHO KILLED 6 IN 1983 IS EXECUTED BY LETHAL INJECTION
description: Eliseo Moreno, convicted of killing six people in a 50-hour rampage, one of them a state trooper, was executed early today after he rejected all appeals.

title: REDISCOVERING A PIONEER DANCE CRITIC
description: MARY WATKINS, America's first full-time dance critic on a daily newspaper, led a fairly public life. A young ambulance driver in France in 1918, she also served as secretary to Olive Fremstad, the opera star who served as a model for the heroine of Willa Cather's ''Song of the Lark.'' Miss Watkins combined a career as wife and mother with writing on music and theater in national magazines. She was the author of three books on opera, among them ''The Rainbow Bridge,'' an account of her days with Fremstad that is an American classic.

title: LAURENTIAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital losses of $1,878,000 for the quarter and capital gains of $1,291,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Includes capital gains of $751,000 and $3,547,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the results for the year-ago periods are restated for the combination of previously separate entities under common control.

title: New York's Finest
description: If Steven McDonald doesn't have reason to be bitter, who does? Shot last summer by a 15-year-old boy he was arresting in Central Park, the young police officer is paralyzed from the neck down. When his newborn son was christened Sunday, his wife had to take her husband's hand and guide it in tracing a cross on the child's forehead.

title: PACKAGING SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $768,000 for the quarter and $700,000 for the year. c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $40,000. d-After a gain from discontinued operations of $307,000 and a gain from an accounting change for investment tax credits of $482,000. The company said the results have been restated to reflect the sale of its packaging business in February 1986 and its plastics business last week.

title: TFC TELESERVICES reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-After a $114,887 loss from the company's discontinued robotics operations. TFC said its prior year results reflect the operations of telephone services only.

title: BOOKS: MONEY WARS
description: JOHNSON v. JOHNSON. By Barbara Goldsmith. Illustrated. 285 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Beverly Hills Bans Smoking
description: This Los Angeles suburb became the nation's second city to ban smoking in restaurants and retail stores Tuesday with the City Council's approval of an antismoking law. The ordinance, approved unanimously despite complaints from resaurateurs, takes effect April 3. The only other city with such a law is Aspen, Colo.

title: Clemens Makes Threat
description: Roger Clemens, unsigned and faced with the possibility of having his contract renewed automatically by the Red Sox, threatened yesterday to boycott the start of the exhibition season Saturday.

title: SEX ATTACKER STABS WOMAN AND MAN WHO RESCUED HER
description: A man who raced up a flight of stairs to aid a neighbor being attacked in her Manhattan apartment early yesterday was stabbed and critically injured by the assailant, the police said.

title: Another La-Z-Boy Unit To Ross Roy
description: The La-Z-Boy Chair Company of Monroe, Mich., has awarded Ross Roy Inc., in Detroit, the account for its contract division, which is in the $1 million range.

title: CONCERT: PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA
description: ERICH LEINSDORF led the Philadelphia Orchestra in a stylish, professional and not terribly exciting concert at Carnegie Hall Monday night. One never doubted Mr. Leinsdorf's expertise - few conductors could lead a complex new piece such as Stanley Walden's ''Invisible Cities'' with such command and clarity - and the many excellent qualities of the Philadelphia Orchestra are no secret. Still, Schumann's Symphony No. 1 in B flat received what seemed to this listener a stolid, earthbound rendition, its dance rhythms earnest and heavy, its lyricism rather cautious.

title: WHEN BUSINESS ASKS THE GOVERNMENT TO MEDDLE
description: Given their natural propensity to insist that the best government is the one that governs least, several captains of American industry seemed to be swallowing hard today as they paraded before Congress to seek help in turning away takeover bids.

title: PREFERRED ISSUE BY PAINE WEBBER
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. is offering four million shares of exchangeable preferred stock at a price of $25 a share, with an annual dividend of $1.375. The size of the financing was increased from 3.6 million shares.

title: ANITEC IMAGE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
RAYTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $534,000 for the quarter and $1,662,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Anheuser-Busch Co., St. Louis, said its Metal Container Corp. would build a beverage-can manufacturing plant at Chester, N.Y.

title: ACCEPTANCE INSURANCE HOLDNGS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

title: ISRAELI ECONOMIC VIEW
description: Bank Hapoalim said today that the Israeli economy was sliding out of control after a stable period resulting from the Government's austerity program and lower oil prices. The bank predicted that inflation would rise to 30 percent, from last year's 19.7 percent, and that the gross domestic product would grow between 2 and 3 percent, following 1 percent in 1986.

title: 3,500 G.M. LAYOFFS
description: About 3,500 General Motors workers will be laid off from plants in the Lansing area for a week this month because of high car inventories, the company said. The company told employees who build bodies and assemble the Oldsmobile Calais and the Buick Somerset and Skylark that they would be laid off March 23-27. They are scheduled to return to work for their regular shifts March 30, a GM spokeswoman, Linda Cook, said.

title: PAN AM TO LAY OFF 464, FREEZE MANAGERS' PAY
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it would lay off 20 percent of its nonunion employees on April 1 and that the salaries of the remaining managers would be frozen.

title: WHITEHALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Czechoslovak Officers Flee
description: Two Czechoslovak military officers escaped to West Germany today by flying across the border in an army helicopter, the police said. The two asked for political asylum in West Germany.

title: WHAT THE PRESIDENT HAS SAID
description: Nov. 24: ''I am not going to lie about that. I did not make a mistake.'' Nov. 25: ''I believe our foreign policy goals toward Iran were well founded. However, the information brought to my attention yesterday convinced me that in one aspect, implementation of that policy was seriously flawed.'' Nov. 29: ''So, while we've been occupied with the Iranian issue over the past two weeks, let's not forget that there are many other issues that concern us.'' Dec. 1: ''If actions in implementing my policy were taken without my authorization, knowledge or concurrence, this will be exposed and appropriate corrective steps will be taken.'' Dec. 6: ''While we are still seeking all the facts, it's obvious that the execution of these policies was flawed and mistakes were made.'' Dec. 16: ''It is my desire to have the full story about Iran come out now - the alleged transfer of funds, the Swiss bank accounts, who was involved - everything.'' Jan. 27: ''But though we have made much progress, I have one major regret. I took a risk with regard to our action in Iran. It did not work, and for that I assume full responsibility. . . . We did not achieve what we wished, and serious mistakes were made in trying to do so. We will get to the bottom of this, and I will take whatever action is called for.'' Feb. 20: ''Try as I might, I cannot recall anything whatsoever about whether I approved an Israeli sale in advance or whether I approved replenishment of Israeli stocks around August of 1985. My answer therefore, and the simple truth is, I don't remember -period.'' Feb. 26: ''But I pledge to the American people today that I will do whatever is necessary to enact the proper reforms and to meet the challenges ahead.'' March 4: ''First, let me say I take full responsibility for my own actions and for those of my Administration. As angry as I may be about activities undertaken without my knowledge, I am still accountable for those activities. As disappointed as I may be in some who served me, I am still the one who must answer to the American people for this behavior. And as personally distasteful as I find secret bank accounts and diverted funds, as the Navy would say, this happened on my watch.''

title: ASHTON-TATE PROFIT UP
description: The Ashton-Tate Corporation, a software maker, said earnings in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Jan. 31, grew 77 percent, to $10.6 million, or 43 cents a share, from $6 million, or 30 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose to $62.9 million from $41.5 million.

title: G.M. PLAN SPURS DOW TO A 30.93 RISE
description: With Wall Street receiving a psychological lift from the General Motors Corporation's plans for a huge buyback of its own shares, the stock market rallied to record-breaking levels yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My home has a large old porcelain sink with drain boards on each side. The porcelain is chipped in several places - some chips are about the size of a dime. Can an amateur refinish it? A.You can try touching up the chips with one of the porcelain touch-up kits sold by many hardware stores and dealers that carry appliance parts. The problem is how prominent the chips are, and whether the color will match the old porcelain. A two-part epoxy paint could also be used to repaint the entire sink. This requires very careful cleaning and preparation beforehand, especially around the drain fittings. Remember, once you paint, periodic repainting will be required. Q.The arm on my easy chair, which is covered with a vinyl upholstery, has a six-inch crack. Is there a preparation I can use to weld this crack? A.Several brands of vinyl cement, sold in most hardware stores and home centers, contain special solvents that weld breaks by partly dissolving the vinyl and then fusing the cracked vinyl together. However, for sizable jobs like yours the manufacturers usually recommend applying a patch of similar material behind the crack before cementing it. This may be difficult on a chair arm, but it is worth a try. Q.We just bought a five-year-old house with wood paneling on all the walls. Some paneling is light, which we prefer, but in several rooms it is very dark. We want to brighten it with whitewash or even paint, but we have never seen this done to paneling. What's possible? A.You can paint over the paneling just as you can over any other wall surface. However, make certain that all wax or polish is removed first. Wiping down with a rag dipped in paint thinner should do this, but change rags often. Apply an undercoat or sealer first, then a finish coat.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: POOR Baby M. As a mother who can remember not too long ago holding buttery little babies of my own, I too want only the best for her. Yet what seems sadly apparent during the battle for her custody in Hackensack, N.J., is that neither of her biological parents may deserve her.

L.I. Concern in PCB's Settlement
description: A Long Island-based manufacturer of electrical equipment has agreed to pay $2 million in state and Federal damages for the release of toxic PCB's into New Bedford Harbor and other waterways in southern Massachusetts over 25 years, according to a settlement reached today.

title: Kodak Campaign Set On Nonconsumer Items
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company has designed an umbrella campaign for Eastman Kodak to use to promote most of its nonconsumer products. The theme is ''The new vision of Kodak'' and it is the first effort of its kind in the history of the company.

title: U.N. COUNCIL BARS ARAB RIGHTS GROUP
description: In a rare show of unity, representatives of traditionally hostile Arab nations have joined to fight the recognition of an Arab human-rights group.

title: SOVIET, IN GENEVA, SAID TO BACK IDEA OF SITE INSPECTION
description: The Soviet Union has agreed to the principle of on-site inspection in the proposed removal of medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe, diplomats close to the negotiations here said today.

title: Back to the Future in Italy
description: With Prime Minister Bettino Craxi's resignation, it's back to a familiar future in Italian politics. Can the Christian Democrats, Italy's biggest party, cobble together a new coalition under five-time former Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti? Or will Mr. Craxi's Socialists demand too many cabinet seats, dissolve a five-party coalition and force early elections in June? And will all this revive traditional deadlock in Italian politics - or can Italy now institutionalize modern Craxi-style leadership?

title: In Defense of Mrs. Reagan
description: Not much has changed since 1914 when Woodrow Wilson's first wife, Ellen Axson Wilson, was taken to task in editorials for involving herself in men's concerns. Her crime was to publicly decry the condition of the slums in the capital.

title: UNICORP REDUCES STAKE IN PUROLATOR
description: The Unicorp Canada Corporation has lowered its stake in the Purolator Courier Corporation to 3.4 percent, from 12.6 percent, ending its attempt to influence the air-freight concern. When Unicorp acquired its Purolator stake last fall, the Toronto-based diversified gas utility said that it did not intend to be a ''passive investor.''

description: Strong demand yesterday for a $1.1 billion bond offering by the Grand River Dam Authority of Oklahoma enabled underwriters at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company to reduce yields of the long-term bonds by about a tenth of a percentage point from levels proposed earlier in the week.

So persistent was a story that Camacho had been murdered in a drug dispute in Los Angeles that reporters were obliged to investigate what turned out to be a strictly unfounded tale.

description: Mexico's governing Institutional Revolutionary Party ended a three-day party congress today. The meeting was dominated by calls for internal ''democratization,'' ''modernization'' and ''renovation,'' but in the end the party chose a continuation of current policies and organization.

description: Representative Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, told Democrats on the Budget Committee today that he was ready to fight for a tax increase this year to reduce the Federal deficit even though President Reagan was expected to oppose higher taxes.

Surmounting Politics at the C.I.A.
description: By choosing William Webster as Director of Central Intelligence, President Reagan for the third time improves on officeholders most damaged by the Iran-contra affair. First Frank Carlucci replaced John Poindexter as national security adviser. Then Howard Baker took over as chief of staff from Donald Regan. And now, the Senate willing, Judge Webster will succeed the disabled William Casey. The quality of all three appointments bespeaks a serious desire to govern.

description: Prices were stable to modestly higher in all sectors of the bond markets yesterday, with good investor demand for new tax-exempt and corporate issues and strengthening speculative demand for long-term Treasury issues.

description: In 1986 when his contract was renewed automatically at $150,000 by the St. Louis Cardinals, Vince Coleman vowed, ''I'll be eating caviar next spring.'' On Tuesday Coleman, who has stolen 217 bases in two major-league seasons, signed for a base salary of $160,000 and bonuses that could lift him to $215,000 if he wins a Gold Glove, makes the All-Star team and finishes first or second in the Most Valuable Player balloting. Less optimistic than a year ago, the outfielder said, ''If I have to base my life style on making m.v.p., I'll be starving.

description: Many in the tournament world are mourning a quiet young man who was regularly among the contenders for Player of the Year honors in New York City. The player, Michael Rosmarin of Jamaica, Queens, disappeared in January, and two men have since been indicted for his presumed murder.

The series is called ''Talk 'n Cheap'' and features Asian-American writers and artists dealing with a variety of social, political and esthetic issues.

(Sparky) Sparks headed the team that developed a dealer distribution strategy for the International Business Machines Corporation's original personal computer. It's already becoming a recognizable genre. Unfortunately, it's already producing purely generic works. A program Monday night by the keyboardist Linda Hudes and Power and Glory, to be repeated Tuesday and March 9 and 10, chugged along pleasantly, but usually it was less than the sum of its parts.

description: Sixty-four mushers have signed up for Alaska's grueling Iditarod sled dog race, which starts Saturday in Anchorage and ends more than 1,000 miles away in Nome. For the second time since the Iditarod's inception in 1973, the defending champion will be a woman. Last year's winner was 31-year-old Susan Butcher of Manley, Alaska.

description: A member of Texas's Railroad Commission, Jim Nugent, called today for changes in Federal energy policy. He also urged state lawmakers to offer tax breaks to ''excite the risk-takers'' who can help to lead the oil and gas industry out of its slump.

description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d seemed to rule himself out today for nomination as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and said he believed the nominee would not be a close political ally of President Reagan.

description: The National Black Nurses Association said Monday that it would hold its annual convention in Los Angeles instead of Phoenix this year because Gov. Evan Mecham of Arizona had rescinded the state holiday honoring Martin Luther King.

title: Ruling Finds Teamsters Got Illegal Help by Army in Vote
description: The Army illegally helped the teamsters' union try to oust a rival union at an Oklahoma military base by taking part in a White House meeting arranged by the teamsters' president, Jackie Presser, and President Reagan's top political operatives, according to an administrative law judge.

title: TEXAN WILL HEAD RESEARCH ALLIANCE
description: In East Texas, where Grant A. Dove sometimes goes on hunting trips, hunters often come back to camp with tall tales. But not Mr. Dove, even though he ''tends to go off where no one can verify what he claims to have seen or shot at,'' said a longtime friend, Ed Vetter, recently nominated to be chairman of the Texas Economic Development Commission.

description: New York City jail officials, responding to an elaborate breakout by three prisoners in Queens on Sunday, yesterday strengthened procedures for handling inmates serving life terms and moved to discipline two correction officers.

description: Rafael M. Salas, executive director of the United Nations Fund for Population Activities and a senior member of the Philippine Government in the 1960's, died tonight in his hotel room in Washington, where he was visiting. He was 58 years old.

title: CASTLE & COOKE SELLING UNIT
description: Castle & Cooke Inc. said it had agreed to sell its container-leasing business to the Itel Corporation, a truck and rail leasing company, for about $215 million in cash, notes and stock.

title: DIGITAL UPGRADES
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation has upgraded three of its midrange computer systems and announced an improved warranty and service policy. The new midrange computers -the VAX 8250, the VAX 8350 and the VAX 8530, which range in price from $65,000 to almost $300,000 - replace older and less powerful models. Bruce R. Watts, first vice president of Morgan, Keegan & Company in Boston, said Digital's extension of warranties on all computers and peripherals to one year was intended to reassure buyers that the company was not overburdened by its recent sales successes. Digital's stock closed yesterday at $166.25, up $9.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Black & Decker Move

title: CBS NEWS CHIEF GIVES PLAN FOR CUTS
description: The president of CBS News yesterday gave the company's chief executive a plan to restructure CBS News drastically, imposing budget cuts of more than $30 million and eliminating as many as 200 jobs in the news division, officials at the network said.

title: VAN DORN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CAREGIVERS FINDING SUPPORT IN GROUPS
description: LEAD: THE women arrive at the Northern Westchester Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in Bedford Hills, N.Y., accompanied by young children, who scramble toward the indoor playground equipment. The women gather into a circle, catching up on the week's events and sharing tips on petting zoos, toilet training and coping with tantrums.

title: GRANDE DAME OF PALM BEACH DECORATORS
description: THE scene: A complex of low-lying buildings on an unfashionable street in West Palm Beach. Over the main entrance is a sign that reads simply ''Jessup Inc.''

title: Leaving the Ivies
description: Citing the advantage of being able to offer scholarships, Wayne Szoke made a change in his basketball coaching career yesterday, leaving Columbia of the Ivy League for Monmouth College, a school that has not posted a winning record in its four years of Division I play.

title: OCCIDENTAL OFFERS 33 MILLION SHARES
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation yesterday began a public offering of more than $1 billion of common stock to raise cash and retire outstanding debt.
