description: b-Includes a tax credit of $83,000. c-Net income d-Includes a tax credit of $533,000.

title: CARACAS DEBT DEAL SEEN
description: Venezuela and its major commercial bank creditors have agreed to allow the conversion of outstanding bank debt into shares of enterprises covered by the loans, according to a report published today. A clause paving the way toward the capitalization of debt was included in a $20.45 billion refinancing accord reached last week between Venezuela and the banks, Venezuela's chief debt negotiator, Jorge Marcano, said in a newspaper interview.

title: PERIOD HARDWARE
description: WHEN homes are restored in period styles, whether as spare as Shaker or as ornate as high Victorian, authentic hardware is hard to find. A couple of dealers have been collecting handsome examples recently and have a small supply of hard-to-find authentic pieces. Edith Siegel, owner of Edith's Nostalgia, has a cache of more than 100 sets of doorknobs and matching door plates from the 1880's through the 1920's, culled mainly from buildings on the Upper West Side. They are brass, bronze or pewter. Edith's Nostalgia is at 469 Amsterdam Avenue, near 82d Street. Francoise Nunnalle, a Manhattan dealer in antique linens, has 60 pairs of drapery tiebacks, dating from 1815 through the 1920's, which she has collected for 10 years on annual forays to Europe. She has examples in porcelain, Battersea enamel, Wedgwood, brass, bronze and glass. She can be reached for an appointment at 212-246-4281.

title: GATES WELCOMES WEBSTER TO C.I.A. BUT ADMITS HIS OWN DISAPPOINTMENT
description: Robert M. Gates, who might have become Director of Central Intelligence except for the Iran arms affair, said today that he had no regrets about withdrawing his name from consideration even though he thought he would have won Senate confirmation.

title: K-TRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $400,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss

title: AMERICAN GETS LIFE FOR GIVING SECRETS TO ISRAEL
description: Jonathan Jay Pollard, the former civilian intelligence analyst for the Navy who pleaded guilty to spying for Israel, was sentenced to life in prison today in a highly emotional session in Federal District Court here.

title: Third World Debt (Cont'd.)
description: LEAD: Here we go again. Third world debt is back in the headlines following Brazil's decision to suspend all interest payments on its foreign bank loans. And once more, leading American bankers are hastening to assure us that there is nothing, really, to worry about. Overall, the third world debt situation is getting better, we are told, not worse.

title: DEADLINE FOR DEAL ON G.M. BUSES PASSES AS TRANSIT PLAN TALKS STALL
description: A midnight deadline for the purchase of 300 new city buses expired tonight as negotiations between state lawmakers and transit officials over $8.6 billion in transit improvements broke down in acrimony and recriminations.

title: More Care in Speaking Of AIDS Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: DEBATE ON SHOW GETS TONE FROM RADIO
description: Sports television shows, like television shows of all kinds, come and go with increasing rapidity these days, but for all the change, there is little that is new. Sure, there are plenty of gimmicks and occasional gadgets that make things feel new, but the ideas driving the shows hardly vary from year to year, station to station.

title: NORTH AMERICAN BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $299,000 for the quarter and $809,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $29,000 for the quarter and $71,000 for the year.

title: Bernard Barnes, 77, Dies; Retired Time Inc. Executive
description: Bernard Barnes, a retired vice president and secretary of Time Inc., died Sunday of a stroke while vacationing in Isla Verde in Puerto Rico. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan and Bethlehem, Conn.

title: MARGAUX CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Includes a charge of $7,507,000 to discontinue operations of the company's building management system operation which it sold to Cetek Systems Inc. on Jan. 30.

title: DANAHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $3,804,000 and a loss of $642,000 from early retirement of debt for the quarter, and the year includes a tax credit of $7,379,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $2,885,000 for the quarter, and the year includes a tax credit of $7,964,000. The company said the latest periods' record results are primarily because of the recent acquisitions of Chicago Pneumatic Tool Co. and Western Pacific Industries and improved performance of operations.

title: STANLINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 5 percent common stock dividend paid in December.

title: A MASKED BALL SET FOR PURIM
description: Purim - the Jewish festival celebrating Queen Esther's rescue of the Jewish people from an evil plot by Persia's chief minister, Haman - will be observed on March 17 at 7 P.M. with a masked ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Park Avenue at 50th Street. The event is to be sponsored by the Jewish Museum. And the masks will be something special.

title: AN AUTO GIANT COMES AWAKE
description: IN late January, when shares of the General Motors Corporation were languishing at $70, Jack V. Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Company described G.M. as ''a sleeping giant about to awaken'' and recommended that clients buy the stock.

title: Louis P. Hammett, 92, Dies; Retired Chemistry Professor
description: Louis P. Hammett, a retired Columbia University chemistry professor whose contributions to modern physical organic chemistry brought national recognition, died Feb. 23 at the Medford Leas retirement community in Medford, N.J. He was 92 years old.

title: SALES OF U.S. CARS UP BY 6.7%
description: Sales of new American-made cars increased 6.7 percent in the last 10 days of February, despite a decline in sales by the General Motors Corporation, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: BIOTECHNICA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1986 and 1985 full year figures are restated to reflect the retroactive consolidation of Biotechnica Diagnostics as of Dec. 31, 1985.

title: BP CANADA INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $3,483,000 for the latest year and $5,096,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: YIELDS UNCHANGED
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were virtually unchanged in the week ended yesterday.

title: HUGHES SETS CONDITIONS FOR MERGER WITH BAKER
description: The board of the Hughes Tool Company said tonight that it would not go through with its merger with the Baker International Corporation unless Baker and the Justice Department changed the conditions of the merger.

title: REAGAN AND PANEL DIFFER ON SOME POINTS
description: President Reagan's latest account of the Iran-contra affair, in an address to the nation tonight, closely resembles the accounts pieced together by the Tower commission and other investigators. But Mr. Reagan's version of events still differs from the others in several important respects.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $179,000 for the quarter and $226,000 for the 6 months.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Virginia Housing Development Authority is offering $160 million of fixed- and floating-rate collateralized mortgage obligations through First Boston Corporation as sole underwriter.

title: REPUBLIC AUTOMOTIVE PARTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects a charge of $790,000 due to additional restructuring costs.

title: W.H.O. CASTS DOUBT ON AIDS TESTS FOR TRAVELERS
description: The World Health Organization has concluded that blood testing of people traveling from one country to another would have minimal benefit in combating the spread of the AIDS virus and could be counterproductive, according to a statement released here today.

title: Plus the Tips
description: The Inside Track. a restaurant on Second Avenue near 53d Street, has been operating for the last 11 months as a New York City Offtrack Betting teletheater facility, with its decor featuring six betting windows and television viewing equipment that includes two large-sized wall screens and 19 carefully placed monitors.

title: EDBERG STUMBLES AT WRONG TIME
description: It is as if Stefan Edberg has been playing Off Broadway these last few years, getting rave reviews in Europe and Australia, perhaps, but still greeted by skepticism when he appears in this country.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: NO matter how high the quality of an enamel nor how carefully it is brushed on, painted cabinets, doors or wood trim will be no smoother than the surface on which paint was applied. If you paint over a surface that is rough and chipped, that's how the new coat will look. For a blemish-free finish, the old surface must be as smooth as possible before the first brushful of paint is applied.

title: DOUGLAS FILLS BIG GAP AT SYRACUSE
description: As Sherman Douglas's sophomore season nears its completion and his coming-out party approaches its climax, he remains fortunate that his basketball reputation will continue to be made at Madison Square Garden this week rather than the asphalt places where Dwayne Washington became cultured.

title: TS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch on Tuesday about the withdrawal of Robert M. Gates's nomination as Director of Central Intelligence misstated Bobby Ray Inman's view of the action. Mr. Inman said that he felt the nomination should not have been withdrawn and that Mr. Gates ''was exactly the right man'' for the job.

title: Penn Case Recalled
description: To the Editor:

title: TO ATTAIN A SATIN ANTIQUE FINISH
description: LEAD: FURNITURE that has been refinished - no matter the material used or how applied - usually calls for one final touch to produce an impeccable surface. That touch is ''rubbing down,'' which will eliminate that too-new look by reducing a hard gloss to the softer luster usually associated with antiques or fine old furniture.

title: WARWICK INSURANCE MANGERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net realized investment gains of $20,000 for the quarter and $586,000 for the year. c-Includes net realized investment gains of $86,000 for the quarter and $195,000 for the year; the year also includes a tax credit of $304,000.

title: ON DOLE AND SOUTH AFRICA
description: Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, had no more than made his campaign for the Presidency more or less official Tuesday than TransAfrica, the Washington-based black American lobby for Africa and the Caribbean, singled him out as a ''friend of apartheid.''

title: EUROBOND PLAN RAISES HACKLES
description: In a move reflecting concern that banks may be assuming too much risk in Eurobond activity, the Bank of England has proposed a role for itself in regulating that market.

title: KASLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: DASH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $311,174. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $42,621.

title: INSIDE
description: Chip Makers Join Forces

title: UNICORP AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1986 net included net gains of about $12,857,000 on the sale of eight real estate properties.

title: THE DANCE: ELLINGTON CELEBRATION
description: IT is a good thing that Bobby Short and the DancEllington company don't celebrate ''the Duke'' more often, given the vibrations that rocked Town Hall and had the audience cheering Tuesday at a gala benefit for the Duke Ellington Memorial Fund. New York might not survive the experience.

title: CCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $467,000.

title: TOP PHILIPPINE CONCERN SAID TO ATTRACT SUITORS
description: A New York investment bank is trying to form an investor group to acquire the San Miguel Corporation, by far the largest company in the Philippines, a Government official said today.

title: THE THEATER: 'DUCK HUNTING,' AT THE COURTYARD
description: IT'S a long Russian night at the Courtyard Theater, where a young cast is flapping around in ''Duck Hunting,'' by the Soviet writer Aleksandr Vampilov. Mr. Vampilov, who died in 1972 at the age of 34, is described in the company's press release as ''the most important postwar writer to emerge in the dramatic tradition of Chekhov and Gogol'' - which, to judge by this joyless New York premiere, is blatant capitalist disinformation.

title: DESPITE ALL THE PRUNING, YEWS REMAIN POPULAR
description: EARLY every spring, when it is time to trim back the yews that a previous owner planted to corset the foundation of my house, I rejoice that years ago I ripped many of them out and lament not having exterminated more of them. A basic but neglected principle of gardening is that no garden should have more than one yew, and that it should be placed at a distance from the house and allowed to grow into a handsome tree.

title: CLUB WANTS ETHICS RULES TO APPLY TO KOCH ADVISER
description: Officers of the City Club said yesterday that Mayor Koch's new unpaid adviser on public construction should be subject to the same ethical and legal restrictions imposed on salaried public officials.

title: HAITIANS ASK FRENCH COURT FOR DUVALIER MILLIONS
description: In court proceedings beginning Thursday, the Haitian Government is to make its first judicial attempt to recover public funds said to have been stolen by Jean-Claude Duvalier while he was President of Haiti.

title: EQUITEC FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
VIACOM BATTLE APPEARS OVER
description: After five weeks of battling that culminated in an all-night session of its special committee of outside directors, Viacom International Inc.'s future has apparently been decided.

title: COST WOES IN HOUSING
description: The question, raised initially by Mayor Koch in December 1985, has acquired a sense of urgency in recent months at City Hall: Can new, unsubsidized housing be built by private developers for middle-income New Yorkers?

title: 'NOAH,' A BIBLICAL OPERA, IS SET FOR PERFORMANCES
description: ''Noah,'' an opera about the biblical ark-builder by Michael Sahl and Eric Salzman, is to be presented by the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged on March 11 and 15 at 2 P.M. and March 12 at 8 in the Evelyn and Louis A. Green Auditorium, 40 West 68th Street. The production is directed by Paul Zimet; Constantine Kitsopoulos is to conduct. Suggested admission is $5, or $1 for the elderly.

title: METS PREOCCUPIED WITH SCOTT
description: The Mets admitted today that, for all their success, they had one haunting memory and one piece of unfinished business from their championship season of 1986: Mike Scott of the Houston Astros and his split-fingered fastball.

title: EXPANDED EXPLANATION OF PRICE-INDEX CHANGES
description: Two tables in Business Day last Thursday with an article on a revision of the Consumer Price Index compared the old and the new numbers but gave no explanation for apparent inconsistencies and anomalies in the figures.

title: COURT RULING AIDS PROSECUTION IN FILM DEATHS
description: Prosecutors do not have to prove the precise cause of the fatal helicopter crash on the set of ''Twilight Zone - The Movie'' to obtain a conviction against the film's director, John Landis, and four other defendants, the judge in the involuntary manslaughter trial has ruled.

title: IN A SPIRIT OF CONTRITION  Reagan's Concession on Iran Affair Evokes Memories of Kennedy's Bay of Pigs Speech
description: President Reagan spoke to the American people tonight in a spirit of contrition that has not been heard from the White House in a quarter century.

title: Mitchell 'Ain't Over It Yet'
description: Driving up to his San Diego home that night nearly three months ago, Kevin Mitchell saw what he believed to be ambulances.

title: TURKEY SAYS ITS PLANES RAIDED KURDISH GUERRILLA BASES IN IRAQ
description: Turkish warplanes raided bases of Kurdish separatist guerrillas in Iraqi territory today, the Minister of Defense announced.

title: DRESS BARN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-2 stock split paid May 2, 1986.

title: Saatchi Purchases Cleveland Consulting
description: Saatchi & Saatchi announced in London that it planned to raise around $100 million through the sale of 9.74 million shares of stock to European investors.

title: REGULATORS PENALIZE FIRST EXECUTIVE
description: The New York State Insurance Department said today that it had fined a unit of the First Executive Corporation $250,000 and forced the parent company to inject an additional $151.5 million in capital into its New York insurance operation.

title: WITNESS IN TUROFF TRIAL RECALLS TAXI METER DEAL
description: A former executive of a Brooklyn credit union testified yesterday that he illegally funneled $2.3 million from depositors' accounts to a taxi meter company formed by the head of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, Jay L. Turoff, and the three co-defendants in the Turoff trial.

title: LEBANESE ARMY DEPLOYS ON COAST ROAD
description: In an extension of the Syrian-sponsored security plan in West Beirut, units of the Lebanese Army deployed today along the coastal highway south of here as far as the port city of Sidon, 18 miles from the capital.

title: SCHOOLS REAFFIRM CITY DROPOUT DATA
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones and the Board of Education said yesterday that they stood by their report of three weeks ago showing a dropout rate of 30.7 percent in the 1985-86 school year, an improvement of 4.6 percentage points from the year before.

title: COOLIDGE OF LEGEND
description: To the Editor:

title: Knox Trying to Repeat
description: Last year at this time, Ken Knox had only $2,500 in the bank - but then he won the Honda Classic. ''This year I have the money to pay the locker room attendant and my caddie,'' he said today. He also has a new home that he will move into with his wife, Karen, and daughter, Michelle, later this month. And no longer does Karen Knox have to caddie for her husband - something she did for a year and a half before he struck it rich with his $90,000 first prize here last March.

title: ADC TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ICAHN BIDS $1.4 BILLION FOR USAIR
description: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines, offered yesterday to buy USAir Group Inc. for $1.4 billion, but some analysts suggested that he really wanted to force the opposite: the sale of T.W.A. to USAir.

title: KAPOK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW INVESTIGATIONS SOUGHT AT S.M.U.
description: In the aftermath of the disclosure Tuesday by Gov. Bill Clements that he and other members of the board of governors allowed illicit payments to football players to continue in 1985, three governing councils at Southern Methodist University have agreed that further investigations are necessary.

title: WEATHER SERVICE HALTS TESTS
description: The National Weather Service ordered a halt to all test warnings on its national weather wire today until corrections could be made in new computer programs that have led to several false warnings in recent days.

description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $231,000 and $1,212,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and the year also includes a loss from a change in accounting principles of $67,000. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $441,000 for the quarter and $1,196,000 for the year.

title: Geneva Convention No Prop to Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: 9 KILLED IN CRASH OF COMMUTER PLANE
description: A commuter airplane crashed while landing at Detroit Metropolitan Airport today, killing nine passengers and injuring at least 14, including eight on the ground, the Wayne County Sheriff's Department said.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago losses include a gain of $900,000 from reductions in LIFO inventory quantities.

title: RETRAINING AND HOUSING CALLED KEYS TO GROWTH
description: The strongest expansion of the New York metropolitan region's economy since World War II will stop without significant improvements in job training and housing, according to two government reports released this week.

title: RB&W CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $60,000 from tax loss carryforwards. c-After a charge of $130,000 from tax loss carryforwards for the quarter and a gain of $1,158,000 from tax loss carryforwards plus a gain of $3,283,000 from termination of pension plan for the year.

description: Embeti, about 3 years old, stopped chattering with her rag doll and looked up curiously at two visitors hovering overhead.

title: WISER OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reports of Child Abuse Rise 55%, Study Says
description: Reports of child abuse and neglect increased nearly 55 percent from 1981 to 1985 while resources to help such children increased only a fraction of that amount, according to a state-by-state survey by a House committee.

title: NATIONAL FSI INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: RUTGERS GETS $15 MILLION GIFT
description: The Campbell Soup Company will donate $1 million to the Camden campus of Rutgers University, the largest gift ever given to the school, officials said today. The money, to be distributed over six years, will be used to establish scholarships and for faculty development, Provost Walter K. Gordon said. The donation is part of a $100 million ''Campaign for Rutgers,'' which has already raised about $62 million.

title: American Exchange Starts TV Campaign
description: The American Stock Exchange began its first television advertising campaign yesterday, using the theme ''We Extend Your Reach.''

title: GREECE PROTESTING DEMOLITION OF UNION OFFICE AT U.S. BASE
description: Greece lodged what it termed a strong protest with the United States today over the partial demolition of offices used by a Greek labor union at an American military base here.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame has selected as its Gold Medal and and Distinguished American Award winners Charles (Monk) Meyer, a brilliant triple-threat halfback with Army 50 years ago, and I. M. (Ike) Sewell, an outstanding guard with the University of Texas 60 years ago. . . . Gordon D. Jorgensen of Phoenix has been elected to a two-year term as president of the United States Tennis Association. He previously served as chairman of the United States Davis Cup and United States Open committees. . . . Nate Blackwell, the guard who has averaged 19.9 points a game in Temple's 30-3 season, has been named Atlantic-10 Conference player of the year. . . . With each citing an injury, Jill Haworth-Jones (1,500 meters) of Beaverton, Ore., and Lesley Welch (3,000 meters) of Brookline, Mass., have withdrawn from the United States team for the world indoor track and field championships this weekend at Indianapolis. Diane Richburg (800 meters) of Troy, N.Y., was added to the team.

title: ASTRONOMERS SAY EXPLODING STAR IS REDDENING BUT REMAINS BRIGHT
description: The exploding star that blazed into view over the Southern Hemisphere last week is rapidly reddening, astronomers reported today, but despite the change in its color the supernova is as bright as it was when it first appeared.

title: CLANCYS PROFILED ON CHANNEL 13
description: IF these are the Clancy Brothers and Tommy Makem, St. Patrick's Day must be just around the corner. That's the rule of thumb Irish-Americans have been using for some 30 years now, and Public Television has finally picked up the cue. Tonight at 9 o'clock, Channel 13 is broadcasting ''It's a Long Way From Tipperary and Armagh,'' a profile of the four evergreen lads in a 1984 documentary made in association with Irish television's RTE organization. The Irish motif continues at 10 o'clock with a half-hour essay called ''McSorley's New York,'' a loving portrait of the city's most famous ale house.

title: RELAXED ROSE MAKES A BIG HIT WITH AN OLD ACQUAINTANCE
description: Pete Rose has been answering questions for 25 years as a major league player and manager, but today he asked some.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Notes on Fashion column of the Style page on Tuesday misstated the reason for a $10,000 fine paid by the fashion designer Norma Kamali to the New York State Labor Department. She was fined for having allowed workers to produce garments in their homes without permits, not for having employed sweatshop workers.

title: GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 123, Jazz 105: Kevin McHale scored 33 points and Larry Bird added 27 as the Celtics kept the Utah without a victory in all 17 of its visits to Boston Garden. McHale, Bird and Robert Parish, who had 21 points, combined for 81 of Boston's 101 points through three periods. Then the trio watched the fourth quarter from the bench. The Celtics, who lost to the Jazz in Utah last month, stretched their home-court winning streak against Midwest Division teams to 36 games. Led by Karl Malone's 20 points, Utah trailed by 5 points with 3:35 remaining in the second quarter. But the Celtics went on a 17-2 burst to lead, 70-50, at halftime. Boston stretched the lead to 97-64 with two minutes remaining in the third period after outscoring the Jazz, 44-18, over a span of 13 minutes. McHale, held to 15 points in the Celtics' loss in Utah, hit 12 of 15 shots from the field and 9 of 10 from the free-throw line. Bird added 13 assists and 8 rebounds. (AP) Speed Skating American Triumphs: Nick Thometz of the United States won the 500-meter event in World Cup speed skating competition yesterday in Oestersund, Sweden, and Rolf Falk-Larsen, of Norway, took the 1,500 meters. Thometz clocked 38.26 seconds to win a race in weather 20 degrees below zero. Frode Roenning of Norway was second in 38.26 seconds, and Dan Jansen of the United States was third in 38.54. In the 1,500-meter race, Falk-Larsen posted a winning time of 1 minute 59.32 seconds. (AP) World Cup Titles Clinched: Bonnie Blair of the United States and Yvonne van Gennip of the Netherlands clinched the season's World Cup titles in 500-and 1,500-meter speed skating for women by winning their races at Skien, Norway. Blair won the 500-meter race in 41.52 seconds. She has won all the 500-meter races she has entered this winter. Van Gennip won the 1,500 in 2 minutes, 11.17 seconds - more than three seconds ahead of Natalie Grenier of Canada, who was second in 2:14.66. Leslie Baader of the United States, who was leading the 1,500-meter World Cup standings before yesterday's race, only finished sixth in 2:16.55.(AP) Horse Racing Winner by Disqualification: Embrace's Sybling, the longest price in the field of six New York-bred 3-year-olds, was placed first by disqualification in the $67,500 Catskill Stakes at Aqueduct. Omar Khayyam finished first, 1 3/4 lengths ahead of Embrace's Sybling, but was disqualified and placed last for impeding Lone Quadrant nearing the stretch. In the revised order of finish, Sweet Envoy, the favorite, was placed second with Record Flight moved into third position. The victory was the first in four starts this year for Embrace's Sybling, a son of Regal Embrace and Sybiline, who went six furlongs on the fast track in 1:11 under Richard Migliore. He returned $60.20 for $2 to win. Boxing Marsh Wins Title: Terry Marsh of Britain knocked out Joe Louis Manley of Detroit last night in Basildon, England, to win the International Boxing Federation junior welterweight title. The unbeaten 29-year-old fighter dethroned the champion when the referee stopped the fight 20 seconds into the 10th round of the scheduled 15-rounder. Marsh improved his record to 25-0-1, while Manley slipped to 26-4-1.(AP) Yachting Matador Wins Second Event: Matador, an 81-foot maxi-yacht, won the International Offshore Rule Division of the St. Petersburg to Fort Lauderdale race off the coast of Florida in the second event of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference series. Matador, owned and skippered by Bill Koch of Boston, was the first boat across the finish line and had a corrected time of 46 hours 37 minutes and 36 seconds. That was more than seven minutes faster than the 80-foot Boomerang. Obsession, a 70-foot maxi skippered by Steve Nichols, was third. Class 3 was captured by Sprint, a 42-foot Joubert-Nivelt-designed yacht, which had a corrected time of 49 hours 39 seconds.(AP College Basketball Wagner 82, Robert Morris 72: Terrance Bailey scored 29 points and Omar Johnson got 13 last night as Wagner advanced in the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro tournament. The Seahawks gained a semifinal match tonight against Marist in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Bailey scored 18 of his game-high total in the first half as Wagner built a 38-32 advantage. Robert Morris, which finished 13-14, got 22 points from Ron Winoush and 10 from Willie Molson. Wagner (16-12), also received 10 points from Largest Agbejemisian and 17 fom Dean Borges.(AP) Illinois 89, Michigan 75: Ken Norman scored 19 points to lead five Illinois players in double figures in a Big Ten Conference game. Illinois' third consecutive victory improved its record to 22-7 over all and 12-5 in the Big Ten. Michigan fell to 18-11 and 9-8. Illinois converted 11 of its first 14 field-goal attempts while the Wolverines hit only 3 of their first 15. The Illini opened a 14-2 lead 4:17 into the contest and used a balance scoring attack to stretch the lead to 36-13 with 4:41 left in the first half. Michigan, which had been averaging 87.4 points a game, was stifled as Illinois led, 46-27, at intermission.(AP)

title: NWA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter earnings were reduced by about $12 million from the change in tax laws that limited investment tax credits. The latest year results include a non-operating expense of $17.2 million in the third quarter for non-recurring costs associated with the combination of Northwest and Republic Airlines.

title: FED ACTS ON BANKS' SWAP RISK
description: In another move aimed at strengthening the world banking system, the Federal Reserve and the Bank of England yesterday announced a new proposal that would require increased capital levels at banks.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Jerusalem last Thursday about an action by the Israeli Parliament against Rabbi Meir Kahane misidentified his political organization. It is the Kach movement.

title: A FAMILY GOES FROM RUGS TO RICHES
description: PRESTON McADOO, who designs many of the hand-hooked rugs turned out by his family business, had been trying to draw the right kind of cow. He did not like the ones he drew, and he did not like the ones offered by his employees.

title: BONUSES AT A.T.&T. UNIT DESPITE LAYOFFS, LOSSES
description: After losing hundreds of millions of dollars last year, the Information Systems division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company plans to give its managers more than $12 million in bonuses.

title: GRANDPARENTS OF BABY M APPEAL TO COURT FOR PERMISSION FOR VISITS
description: The parents of Mary Beth Whitehead appealed today for court permission to visit Baby M as her grandparents, after the custody of the infant has been decided.

title: COEUR D'ALENE MINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said a large part of its latest year loss was attributable to a one-time non-cash writeoff of $3,624,000 in the third quarter of its interest in consolidated silver joint venture in Idaho and its oil and gas investment in certain Oklahoma properties.

title: CABLE CONCERNS FIGHT 'PIRATE' CHIP
description: Cable broadcasters and equipment companies have filed a $5 million suit against a company and four individuals who reportedly promoted a ''pirate'' computer chip that descrambles satellite signals. The defendants are Network Productions Inc., of New Jersey, along with Bob Cooper Jr., Shaun Kenny, Karen J.P. Howes and Stephen Bepko. The suit did not provide hometowns for the four people or the company.

title: Kansas Mayor Wins Primary
description: Mayor Jack Reardon, recuperating from heart transplant surgery, has won a primary election in his bid for a fourth term, but by a smaller margin than in the past.

title: SCHOOLBOOKS RULED BIASED ON RELIGION
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that Alabama schoolbooks had been promoting a humanistic ''religion'' and neglecting the role of traditional religion in American history and culture. He ordered more than 40 textbooks removed from Alabama's public schools.

title: DANCE: FELD BALLET OPENS SEASON
description: THE Feld Ballet got its season at the Joyce Theater under way last night with a choreographic sweetmeat by George Balanchine and three serious works by Eliot Feld.

title: WILLIAMS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Fruit of Spring
description: As an indication of how seriously fans should take baseball's preseason games, which begin tomorrow, as a guide to how teams will fare during the season, here are the Grapefuit League records for 1986 along with where the teams eventually finished within their divisions: American League EASTERN DIVISION Season W L Pct. Finish Detroit 18 11 .621 3 Yankees 17 11 .607 2 Milwaukee 16 12 .571 6 Toronto 15 12 .556 4 Baltimore 14 15 .483 7 Cleveland 14 46 .467 5 Boston 12 16 .429 1 WESTERN DIVISION Oakland 17 12 .586 4 Texas 15 13 .536 2 California 15 14 .517 1 Chicago 15 15 .500 5

title: PHOENIX MEDICAL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year loss includes a charge of $466,000 for loss on facility closedown and writedown of inventory.

title: INTERFACE FLOORING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KNICKS FINDING WINNING KNACK
description: The Knicks are becoming quite cunning these days. It's as if they have discovered a new way of playing basketball.

title: GULF APPLIED TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $216,000 and $527,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and an extraordinary tax credit of $143,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $99,000 and $296,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: HOME ECONOMICS: NOT JUST STITCH AND STIR
description: LEAD: IN the White Plains Middle School classroom where Phyllis Zuber teaches home economics, the stoves are spotless and the pots and pans are stowed underneath the counters. Her seventh and eighth graders aren't busy beating batters. Instead, they are learning how to read labels in supermarkets, spotting sexual stereotypes and planning for their careers.

title: TOSHIAKI KUNII
description: Toshiaki Kunii, a Japanese-born bass-baritone, died of complications resulting from acquired immune deficiency syndrome Saturday at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: IRAN 'MONEY TRAIL' IS FOCUS OF HOUSE INQUIRY
description: The chairman of the special House committee investigating the Iran-contra affair said today that his panel's inquiry would focus on what happened to the proceeds from the sale of arms to Iran.

title: POWER CORP OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special gains of $23,799,000 for the quarter and $101,367,000 for the year. c-After a charge of $9,443,000 for the quarter and a special gain of $41,218,000 for the year. The results are in Canadian funds.

title: METRO AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend in January.

title: BUEHLER INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $63,000 and $1,365,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the 1985 results are reclassified to conform with 1986 presentation. The company also said pro forma net income share earnings for the 1985 fourth quarter and year was calculated based on net income reduced by pro forma additional interest expense of $224,000 and $736,000, respectively, and pro forma additional tax of $355,000 and $1,937,000, respectively.

title: CML GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
VOTERS TO QUERY BUSH ON IRAN ROLE
description: Vice President Bush begins a two-day campaign swing Thursday through Iowa, where he will answer questions from voters as part of his effort to recover politically from the controversy over the sale of arms to Iran.

title: KANEB ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After writedowns of $124,779,000 in the carrying value of oil and gas properties. The year represents only 11 months operations and the partnership commenced operations in February 1986.

title: DEFENSE DEPT. IS REBUFFED ON SOVIET ABM THREAT
description: The White House has rebuffed a Pentagon suggestion that the United States formally assert that the Soviet Union is preparing a nationwide ABM defense, Administration officials said today.

title: MOLECULAR GENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year's results include $1,044,000 on non-recurring charges. This figure includes a $888,000 charge relating to a change in patent accounting policy and severance obligations recorded in the fourth quarter and a $156,000 third quarter writeoff relating to seed commitments that the company assumed.

title: BUCKHORN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $293,000 and an extraordinary charge of $256,000. c-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $229,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $651,000, or 18 cents a share, for the year.

title: Debating a Mideast Mirage
description: Even for the Middle East, home of paradox and complexity, the subject bubbles with contradictions. Israel's Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, eagerly promotes a Middle East peace conference that he doesn't expect to materialize. Prime Minister Shamir strongly disavows his Foreign Minister's effort. And the Reagan Administration, though it also has reservations about such a conference, says the idea should be explored.

title: No Headline
description: ''What began as a strategic opening to Iran deteriorated in its implementation into trading arms for hostages. This runs counter to my own beliefs, to Administration policy, and to the original strategy we had in mind. There are reasons why it happened, but no excuses. It was a mistake.'' - President Reagan. [ A1:6. ]

title: For Contras in the Field, the Bonds Are Close
description: As his troops prepared to patrol the jungle valley below their base camp inside Nicaragua, a top guerrilla field commander spoke of the seven years of war and revolution that he and many of his men had shared.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE ENIGMA OF ARRIVAL: A Novel.

title: FLOW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DETREK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $127,000 due to the elimination of investment tax credits and a charge of $1.2 million to reflect cost overruns, development costs relating to new products, and costs associated with product warranties and related reliabilities. c-Net income

title: A LOVE-IN FOR BAKER AT CAPITOL
description: Perhaps the most symbolic moment came when the President's chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., stood in front of an oil portrait of the former Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., in the Capitol suite named the ''Howard H. Baker Jr. Rooms.''

title: ALLIS PROPOSES DRASTIC RESTRUCTURING
description: LEAD: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation, trying to avoid bankruptcy proceedings, proposed today to liquidate all but one of its subsidiaries, drastically reduce employee health benefits and postpone debt repayment.

title: MERRIMAC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
FOUR ARE HELD HOSTAGE BY DISTRAUGHT GUNMAN
description: A distraught gunman pushed his way into an East Harlem apartment yesterday afternoon, took four of its occupants hostage and fired at least seven shots in a standoff with the police.

title: AMERICAN BILTRITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $166,000 for the quarter and $1,865,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $130,000 and $1,452,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest year results include sales and earnings from Ideal Tape Co. from date of acquisition, July 25, 1986.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * A.T.&T. promoted John R. Smart to senior vice president of nationwide business market sales.

title: U.S. EXPERTS TO MANAGE AILING LIBERIA ECONOMY
description: The United States is going to send 17 financial experts to Liberia with authority to manage that country's debt-ridden economy, State Department officials said today.

title: CHRYSLER PLANT
description: The Chrysler Motors Corporation said it would spend $367 million to modernize its Belvidere, Ill., assembly plant, the company's sixth factory to undergo extensive modernization in recent years. Chrysler said the plant would be closed starting Thursday for a model change-over. About 2,800 of the plant's 3,300 hourly employees will be temporarily laid off for 18 weeks through mid-July. The 500 other workers will remain at the plant in maintenance, retooling and material-handling jobs.

title: Maytag Heir, 30, Is Drug Victim
description: Christopher Maytag, the 30-year-old great-grandson of the founder of the Maytag home appliance company, died of a drug overdose on Tuesday, the Medical Examiner's office ruled yesterday.

title: Navy Curbs Use of A-6E Jets Out of Fear of Wing Fatigue
description: The Navy said today that it had grounded or placed flight restrictions on more than half its A-6E Intruder attack jets last month because of concern about fatigue cracks in the wings.

title: The Polygraph Lied
description: While poking into the motivations of former national security adviser Robert (Bud) McFarlane, I tripped over a story that took place in 1982 in which The New York Times played a part. Because I was not privy to The Times's role, and because recent leads came from people outside the newspaper who share my outrage at ''lie detectors,'' I feel free to tell it now.

title: LaRouche Groups to Appeal
description: Four organizations linked to the conspiracy theorist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. will challenge a judge's order allowing the Justice Department to begin collecting $21.4 million in contempt fines, a defense lawyer, Matthew Feinberg, said Monday. In March 1985, Federal District Judge A. David Mazzone found the four groups - Caucus Distributors Inc., the Fusion Energy Foundation, the National Democratic Policy Committee and Campaigner Publications Inc. - in contempt of court for refusing to comply with subpoenas in connection with allegations of credit card fraud to finance Mr. LaRouche's 1984 Presidential campaign.

title: Corrections
description: Two tables in Business Day last Thursday, with an article about a revision of the Consumer Price Index, omitted some explanations.

title: AIDS IN PRISON: HARD QUESTIONS FOR JUSTICE SYSTEM
description: A sharp rise of signs of AIDS at Rikers Island reflects an impending crisis in city and state prisons in New York, justice officials said.

title: GROUPS URGE BETTER TAX-CUT PLANNING IN ALBANY
description: A coalition of 28 groups representing poor people, the elderly, environmental protectionists and others called on Governor Cuomo and the Legislature today to slow what they called ''a mad rush'' to cut taxes.

title: SYNTECH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $146,062 for the quarter and $310,206 for the year. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $655,284 for the quarter and $5,933,855 for the year.

title: Another Magazine By Architectural Digest
description: Knapp Communications is going to publish another piggyback publication for its popular, upscale Architectural Digest magazine. It will be called AD Architecture, will appear twice a year and will be packaged in a plastic wrapping with the parent magazine. The first copy will be out in September.

title: ORDER SLOWLY RETURNS TO WEST BEIRUT
description: The alumni club of the American University of Beirut was overflowing Sunday with members, their spouses and children at a buffet lunch.

title: QED EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AMERICAN VANGUARD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF THE ROCKIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: THUNANDER CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The latest year's results include the operations of BMD of New England Inc., acquired Sept. 1, 1986.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 5, 1987
description: Companies

title: AN APPEAL TO PRESERVE OLD BOOKS
description: A national campaign must be mobilized to microfilm millions of books in American libraries that are rapidly crumbling into dust because they were printed on paper containing self-destructive acids, a House subcommittee was told yesterday.

title: TRW ACTIONS SCRUTINIZED
description: TRW Inc., a military contractor, kept two sets of books for jet engine parts, listing the markup at 12.5 percent but actually making a profit of more than 60 percent, a former company controller said today.

title: DEMOCRATS WARY ABOUT THE FUTURE
description: Republicans, eager to put the Iran arms affair behind them, said President Reagan's speech tonight was a turning point in the crisis. But Democrats, while praising Mr. Reagan's performance, said a single speech was not sufficient to resolve the doubts he has raised about his leadership.

title: Sherwood & Schneider Wins Donlevy Account
description: Sherwood & Schneider won a four-way agency competition for Donlevy Inc. and is now producing advertising for its chain of 53 Donlevy's Back Room ''off-price'' shops.

title: COOPER-HEWITT LOOKS BACK, THEN AHEAD
description: TEN years ago, when the design esthetic of undecorated surfaces on everything from household objects to buildings was the rule, a museum devoted to the decorative arts promised to hold little relevance for many people. But in October 1976, the first exhibition held at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum in Manhattan, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, demonstrated that decoration and design were as pervasive and relevant as daily bread.

title: LITTLE PRINCE PRODUCTIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: HARD QUESTIONS FOR MEESE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d appears today before the House Judiciary Committee to talk about his budget request, but he is likely to undergo a grilling from Representative Charles E. Schumer on his stance regarding former Nazis.

title: Engineer in Amtrak Collision Enters Psychiatric Hospital
description: The Conrail engineer whose locomotive caused the fatal crash with an Amtrak passenger train Jan, 4 has been admitted to a psychiatric hospital.

title: George Schoepfer, Engineer
description: George Schoepfer, executive officer and chief engineer of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, died yesterday at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J., after a heart attack at the home of one of his children. Mr. Schoepfer, who had been released last week from Beth Israel Hospital in Newark after four weeks of treatment for a heart ailment, was 57 years old and lived in New Springville, Staten Island.

title: CASTLE & COOKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and year both include a $33.9 million after-tax loss related to the company's flexi-van container business disposition. Prior year earnings and revenue are pro forma and reflect a restatement to exclude the discontinued container leasing business.

title: KEY RATES
STARTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NOVELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest quarter includes 14 weeks, compared to 13 weeks for the year-ago first quarter.

title: WARD, THE 60'S, AND THE NEW SEEDS OF RACIAL UNREST
description: It is unusual, some would say imprudent or even self-fulfilling, for a law-enforcement official to publicly predict the kind of large-scale street demonstrations unseen here since the 1960's, but Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward did so Sunday, twice.

title: AMVESTORS FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $6,134 and $720,500 for the quarter and year, respectively; and tax credits of $102,300 for the quarter and $257,300 for the year. c-Net loss and after realized investment gains of $449,920 and $897,646 for the quarter and year, respectively; and the quarter also includes reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $42,820.

title: A GRIMY ATTIC BECOMES AN OFFICE WITH A SLIGHT TILT TOWARD FRIVOLITY
description: TUCKED under the steep roof of the Virginia Theater on West 52d Street, the attic sloped from 14 feet to 4.

title: OIL PRICES RISE AGAIN, BUT TRADERS EXPECT FALL
description: Petroleum futures prices rose today, continuing Tuesday's rally, but traders said the market would soon reverse course and push prices lower.

title: OPERA: CAST CHANGES IN 'MANON'
description: THE new production of Massenet's ''Manon'' has not been a great success for the Metropolitan Opera. At Tuesday evening's performance, the eighth of 12 this season, the house looked half-empty - and another 12 are scheduled for next season.

title: CARS, PAVEMENT AND PEOPLE ARE NEW VISTA OF RURAL CALIFORNIA
description: Gordon Garrett, who has spent most of his 73 years roaming California's High Sierras, remembers when all he saw on the horizon were mountains, pine trees, lakes and streams. Now he looks out at asphalt, automobiles and new housing developments and wonders what the future holds.

title: Toyota Distributor To DFSD
description: DFS DORLAND WORLDWIDE, a Saatchi & Saatchi company that is already the agency for Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. and a number of its dealer associations, has now picked up Mid-Atlantic Toyota Distributors, based in Glen Burnie, Md. Billings are expected to be around $10 million, and the agency will open an office in Baltimore to service the business.

title: EQUITABLE OF IOWA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,180,000 for the quarter and net from discontinued operations of $9,214,000 for the year. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $778,000 and $3,504,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: GUILIANI AIDE NAMED TO STATE CORRUPTION UNIT
description: The top assistant to Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, was named yesterday to a major post on the state commission formed to investigate corruption at all levels of government in New York.

title: JONES MEDICAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEEPING TRACK OF CALLS
description: JOEL C. GUSKIN, a telephone products buyer for the Tandy Corporation in Fort Worth, asked to go off the record. Asked what could be sensitive about a new attachment for the telephone, Mr. Guskin whispered, ''It involves the Government.''

title: NORTH ATLANTIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The prior year results have been restated to reflect the company's change to FIFO from LIFO in its method of valuing inventories. This change resulted in a decrease in net income for 1985 of $192,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: CHILLY NIGHT ON A SIDEWALK GRATE TEACHES LESSON ABOUT HOMELESS
description: The Congressman, the movie actor and the investment banker learned something from spending a night on the street.

title: MOZAMBIQUE SAYS IT BLOCKED PRETORIA AID TO REBELS
description: President Joaquim A. Chissano of Mozambique asserted here today that his forces had blocked a recent attempt by rebels to obtain supplies from South Africa by sea.

title: Man Is Convicted In Fire That Killed 14
description: A State Superior Court jury yesterday convicted a 34-year-old Waterbury man of arson murder in connection with a tenement fire that killed 14 people on July 5, 1982.

title: FOR CARRIAGE TRADE, PRAMS JUST LIKE NEW
description: Her first grandchild is due this month. So a few weeks back, Gay Brown dug through her attic and found the big baby carriage used by her three little boys in the early 1960's. ''I'd forgotten all about it,'' she said.

title: Alfred de Liagre Dead at 82; Stage Producer and Director
description: Alfred de Liagre, a producer and director for the Broadway theater whose career spanned half a century and included comedy (John van Druten's ''Voice of the Turtle'' in 1943), drama (Archibald MacLeish's play in verse, ''J. B.,'' in 1958) and musical comedy (the 1983 revival of ''On Your Toes''), died of lung cancer yesterday at his Manhattan home. He was 82 years old.

title: HALT URGED IN WORK ON SISTINE AND 'LAST SUPPER'
description: As debate intensifies over restoration of Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel in the Vatican, 15 well-known American artists have petitioned Pope John Paul II, urging ''a pause'' in the project.

title: U.S. SAID TO SUBPOENA MAJOR CLIENTS OF DREXEL
description: The Government has subpoenaed or requested information from more than a dozen financial institutions that were among the largest ''junk bond'' clients of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a number of sources with knowledge of the investigation said yesterday.

title: Lute Olson Sounds Off
description: Lute Olson is balking at signing the five-year, $85,000-a-year contract offered to him by the University of Arizona because one clause would force him to disclose in writing his other earnings. ''If it's in writing, it becomes public, and I personally don't think it's anybody's business but my own,'' said Olson. Olson said he doesn't oppose reporting his outside income verbally to the Arizona director of athletics, Cedric Dempsey, or the university president, Henry Koffler. The National Collegiate Athletic Association this year began requiring coaches to report income from outside sources, such as from radio and television appearances, but Olson and other coaches intend to challenge the demand, in court if necessary.

title: Roman Wolves Not Part of Valentine's Day
description: To the Editor:

title: S.M.U. AFFAIR POSES NEW HAZARD FOR HARD-PRESSED TEXAS GOVERNOR
description: An aging Republican head of government, vowing to veto new taxes, battles Democratic lawmakers over a huge budget deficit. Then the press smells a scandal, and soon he is forced to admit secret payments. His credibility is questioned. Can he finish his term successfully, the analysts ask.

title: WILSON J. GIBNEY
description: Wilson J. Gibney, senior partner of the Manhattan law firm of Gibney, Anthony & Flaherty, died of cancer Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: Catastrophic-Illness Questions Need Answers
description: To the Editor:

title: Witness in Turoff Trial Describes How Investigators Were Deceived
description: A key Government witness described yesterday how he and four defendants in the trial of Jay L. Turoff, the former head of the New York City agency that regulates taxis, devised a scheme to deceive state investigators.

title: Woody Shaw, Trumpet
description: The trumpeter Woody Shaw will lead a group tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M., midnight and 1:30 A.M.; no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: FIRST WORLD MEET FOR INDOOR TRACK
description: For most of its first century, indoor track and field was strictly an American pastime. Europeans were bemused by the tiny tracks in American basketball and hockey arenas, and they insisted that indoor track bore no relation to what they considered the true sport, outdoor track.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNIMATION TO MOVE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it would close the Danbury, Conn., operations of Unimation Inc., the robotics company it acquired for $107 million in 1983, and move Unimation's engineering, product integration, administration and assembly functions to Pittsburgh, where 50 of Unimation's 210 workers will be offered jobs. Unimation was a pioneer in high-technology manufacturing in the 1960's and 1970's, but fell on hard times. Westinghouse said the move would help it develop its venture in automation with the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company.

title: Premiere at the Y
description: The New York Chamber Symphony, under the direction of Gerard Schwarz, will play the premiere performances of a work by Paul Alan Levi, ''Transformations of the Heart,'' tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 3 at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue. The program will also include Debussy's ''Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun,'' Kodaly's ''Dances of Galanta'' and - with the pianist Emanuel Ax as soloist - Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 22 in E flat (K. 482). Tickets are $15 and $17.50; information: 996-1100.

title: A Free Concert
description: The cellist Frederick Zlotkin and the pianist Peter Basquin will present a free concert of works by Bach, Brahms and Shostakovich, tomorrow night at 8 at the Hunter Playhouse, 68th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues. Information: 772-5020.

title: MORE G.M. CARS TO GET AIR BAGS
description: The General Motors Corporation, the nation's biggest auto maker, plans to put driver's-side airbags on 500,000 cars in 1990 and on nearly three million cars during 1992 production, G.M.'s chairman, Roger B. Smith, said. The announcement followed a similar one by the Ford Motor Company a month ago. Ford, the nation's second-largest auto maker, plans to put the safety devices on 500,000 to one million 1990-model cars.

title: Shiites Now Keeping Low Profile in Lebanon
description: Pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem fundamentalists, until two weeks ago a main force in West Beirut, are keeping a low profile for fear of a confrontation with thousands of Syrian troops now patrolling the city's streets.

title: Research Aide Hurt in Blast
description: Katherine S. Crowley suffered first- and second-degree burns Wednesday when she opened a package in the Hewlett-Packard Company's parking lot and the package exploded. The Federal authorities said the blast apparently was not linked to 11 other such attacks on people whose work involved computers, electrical engineering or airlines and aircraft production. Ms. Crowley, 24 years old, a research engineer at Hewlett-Packard, said she had had harassing telephone calls.

title: The Wife's Boss
description: When President Reagan's nomination of William H. Webster as Director of Central Intelligence comes up before the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence for confirmation, Neal Manne is going to find himself in what might be described as a pivotal position.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Wednesday's stock trading characterized the prospect of a stock buyback at the ITT Corporation erroneously. The company has said it was considering such a move, but it has not committed itself.

title: The U.N. Today: March 6, 1987
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: BRITAIN APPROVES SALE OF AID DRUG
description: The British Government has approved the experimental drug azidothymidine for the treatment of AIDS in Britain, saying it appears to prolong the lives of people suffering from the disease, although it is not a cure.

title: DOW JUMPS ANOTHER 18.98, TO 2,276.43
description: The stock market advanced further into uncharted territory yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average scoring another big gain that moved it closer to the 2,300 level.

title: NO PLANS TO PUBLISH SOLZHENITSYN WORK, SOVIET OFFICIAL SAYS
description: A Soviet spokesman said today that there were no plans to publish ''Cancer Ward,'' Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's novel about the stagnation and moral deterioration of Soviet life in the 1950's.

title: 'ABDUCTION,' NBC FILM
description: MADE-FOR-TELEVISION movies are popping up all over the schedule these days and a disquieting number of them are being described as ''fact based.'' For the most part, these are productions that have been whipped up from passing stories in the news. There are people in the business who do nothing but scour newspapers and magazines for possible script ideas. Perhaps if the project can claim to have some roots in fact, the theory seems to go, audiences will hesitate before dismissing it as ridiculous.

title: TWO MINUTES FOR HONESTY
description: Ordinarily, Bryan Trottier is an athlete who can stare right at you with his chilling point-man eyes and say, ''Actually, I wouldn't have any opinion on that.'' Or, he might say, ''I never thought about it.''

title: Changing Spending Habits
description: The Federal Election Commission is urging Congress to change the campaign law so that candidates seeking the 1988 Presidential nominations could spend as much as they wanted in any state primary or caucus contest as long as they kept within the national ceiling for the period before the national conventions.

title: BROADWAY
description: IT'S not that there haven't been American musicals on Broadway in the last few years, but with all the spectacles and shows coming in from London, they've often been overshadowed. Now there's a new American show due in late summer or early fall and, if names and records mean anything, well . . .

title: JAGUAR'S PROFITS DIP
description: Jaguar P.L.C., the British luxury car maker, said today that its profits last year declined mainly because of the cost of redesigning its XJ-6 line of cars, which will be introduced in North America this month. Jaguar's 1986 pretax profits were $189.6 million, down slightly from $190.4 million in 1985. A company spokesman said the decline was mainly the result of the $17 million cost of developing the more fuel-efficient XJ-6 cars, Jaguar's first new models in more than a decade.

title: FRANCE WARMS UP TO MISSILE OFFER
description: In an important policy shift, France's conservative Government today retreated from the negative reaction it had expressed earlier this week toward the Soviet Union's proposal for the removal of all Soviet and American medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe.

title: RETIREMENT WON'T STILL OIL ANALYST'S CRITICISM
description: Kurt H. Wulff, a top-ranked oil analyst, has always been a critic of the big domestic oil companies. Now he plans to retire from the brokerage firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and step up his gadfly activities at oil company annual meetings, as well as pursue other endeavors.

title: QUIET WORLD FOR TYSON OUTSIDE RING
description: Not long ago, Mike Tyson, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, was seated before a television screen in a midtown Manhattan office answering a reporter's questions while watching old boxing films.

title: PCB HIGH IN WELLS NEAR JERSEY TOWN
description: The Environmental Protection Agency disclosed today that it had found high levels of toxic PCB's in wells for drinking water near a pipeline company dump near Lambertville, N.J.

title: NORD RESSOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for two 3-for-2 stock splits paid July 11, 1986 and Feb. 6, 1987.

title: RELENTLESS HOYAS ROLL INTO GARDEN
description: A wave begins innocently enough. But it changes, swelling until the roar and the forces behind it reach a sometimes frightening crescendo. Then, its damage done, it subsides and waits to rise again.

title: BANKERS TRUST NOTE OFFERING
description: The Bankers Trust Company is offering $200 million of 8 percent subordinated equity commitment notes due in 1997 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: Rights Activists Begin a Fast
description: Two veteran civil rights activists have begun a 40-day fast to protest drug abuse. The Rev. Hosea Williams and Dick Gregory, the comedian, camped out at the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s grave here Wednesday and said they planned to spend two days each outside the White House, the United States Capitol and the New York Stock Exchange. The two men said they would send a telegram to President Reagan asking him to commit more Federal money to the fight against drug abuse.

title: Feast Fireworks: Yuppies Take On The Old-Timers
description: For 50 years during Labor Day week, the Italian community here has paraded through the streets, celebrating the Feast of Madonna dei Martiri. Fireworks explode on feast week from morning to night.

title: NOW, MAINSTREAM PAWNSHOPS
description: Pawnshops, the latest business to discover the benefits of upscale marketing, are shedding their dingy image for a place on Wall Street and a hold on the middle class.

title: HARD ROCK CAFE
description: Hard Rock Cafe P.L.C., a London-based nightclub and restaurant concern with cafes in New York and Dallas, plans to make an initial public stock offering in the United States through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The offering consists of 2.24 million American depository shares, representing 11.2 million common shares.

title: NOSTALGIA SWAYS DECISION OF CONNECTICUT LAND USE
description: With the scarcity of land acting as a major restraint on construction of suburban homes in the metropolitan area, developers have had to become far more resourceful in using the few available sites.

title: THAIS SAID TO BAR LAOTIAN REFUGEES
description: With refugees arriving at nearly all of Thailand's borders, the Thai authorities appear to be toughening policies on Laotians, now the largest refugee group in the country.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Benjamin S. Tully has joined Fitzgerald & Company, Atlanta, as senior vice president, media and marketing director.

title: THE BIG TIME
description: Brian Cooper is a 21-year-old McNeese State junior from Lake Charles, La. Last Friday in Madison Square Garden, he made the lengthiest long jump of his career - 26 feet 11 3/4 inches - and won the USA/ Mobil National Indoor Championship.

title: GENERAL REFRACTORIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $600,000 and $1,750,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $1,000,000 for the quarter and $1,350,000 for the year. The company said the 1985 results benefitted from liquidation of LIFO inventories in the amount of $1,950,000, compared with $150,000 of income from that source in 1986.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE grimy and cheerless arcade running just off the Bowery north of Elizabeth Street has seen better days. Those who venture within, however, will find a compact and cacophonous little restaurant, the 16-year-old Phoenix Garden, that runs perpetually on overdrive, spinning out some splendid Cantonese dishes.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: IN Barry Levinson's ''Tin Men,'' which opens today (review on page C3), Danny DeVito and Richard Dreyfuss play fast-talking Baltimore aluminum-siding salesmen at war with each other -part of a breed of Americans who, sharply dressed and driving the latest-model Cadillacs, make their living by their wits and charm. ''They're almost like the gunslingers of the sales world,'' said Mr. Levinson, whose father worked as a contractor in the aluminum-siding business. Mr. Levinson, who also wrote and directed ''Diner,'' about a group of young Baltimore buddies, hails from Baltimore. One of the locations in the film is actually the house he grew up in, which his parents sold furnished in 1964 and which has been kept intact.

title: McCaskill Leaves Camp
description: ''I really had no intentions of this happening,'' said Kirk McCaskill, a California Angels pitcher, before walking out of training camp in Mesa, Ariz., yesterday after negotiations on his 1987 contract collapsed. ''I had no idea it would come to this.'' The 25-year-old Angels right-hander decided on the action after being advised by Mike Port, the California general manager, that he would either have to sign his contract or it would be renewed by the club at a figure below the club's final offer. McCaskill, 17-10 with a 3.36 earned run average and 202 strikeouts in 246 innings last season, had been asking for about $325,000 while the club had made only slight improvements in its standing offer of about $215,000. McCaskill's teammate Wally Joyner, who hit .290 with 22 home runs as a rookie first baseman, signed his contract for what is believed to be $160,000 plus performance incentives.

title: FARR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a provision of $815,000 for plant relocation and a capital gain of $1,162,000, or 14 cents a share, after taxes, on sale of the El Segundo property for both the quarter and year.

title: Villa-Lobos in Brooklyn
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonic will play Heitor Villa-Lobos's Sinfonietta No. 2 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 2. The academy is at 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place. Tickets are $10 to $20; information: (718) 636-4100.

title: No Progress Reported In TV Writers' Strike
description: Both sides in the four-day-old television writers' strike against the ABC and CBS networks met with a Federal mediator yesterday, but no progress was reported toward settling the walkout.

title: Frequent Influential Fliers
description: Members of Congress, who travel a lot, have always been partial to National Airport because it is as little as 10 minutes from Capitol Hill with luck and a speedy driver.

title: FOR SOME TEXAS REAGANITES, APPLAUSE, RELIEF, AND DOUBTS
description: President Reagan's speech Wednesday night elicited sedate applause at the elite River Oaks Country Club, conflicting views from the younger white-collar crowd at the Texas Club and a sense of quiet relief from half a dozen people watching television at Carol Standish's house in an affluent neighborhood.

title: Cuomo Calls for Tougher Penalties to Combat Crack
description: Declaring that ''crack has reached into every corner of the state,'' Governor Cuomo today proposed substantially stiffer penalties for its possession and sale, including a maximum sentence of life imprisonment for some dealers.

title: GLENN CITES FEAR OF A PAKISTANI A-BOMB
description: Senator John Glenn asked President Reagan today to suspend military aid to Pakistan until it offers convincing proof that it is not seeking to make nuclear weapons.

title: FEWER REDUCTIONS SEEN IN DEBT RATINGS IN 1987
description: Analysts at the Standard & Poor's Corporation expect reductions in corporate debt ratings this year to be less widespread than in 1986 and 1985.

title: OPEC OUTPUT MAY BE DOWN
description: The crude oil output of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in the first few days of March was running below February levels, supporting the market view that producers have succeeded in staying below the 15.8 million barrel-a-day ceiling imposed in December, market sources said. Output has slowed to about 14.7 million barrels daily, sources said.

title: William T. Farr Dies; Reporter Jailed in '72
description: William T. Farr, a newspaper reporter who chose to serve 46 days in jail rather than disclose a confidential source, died today at U.C.L.A. Medical Center of complications from pancreatic cancer. He was 52 years old.

title: BIG B INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FILM: 'LETHAL WEAPON,' A THRILLER WITH GIBSON
description: BEFORE the opening credits are over, a beautiful, half-naked blonde has snorted cocaine and jumped out the window of a high-rise building, landing on the roof of a parked car. Clearly, the makers of ''Lethal Weapon,'' which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, are not interested in the soft sell. Their concern is that the largest possible number of people, props and vehicles be made to crash and burn. That objective, while not the noblest, has been achieved quite handily in this hard-boiled, high-voltage, hotheaded police thriller.

title: CONFERENCE ASSESSES THE ROLE OF CALCIUM IN BLOOD PRESSURE
description: A new study has found that calcium supplements can reverse the effects of salt on hypertensive black adults, while another study found that black children at a high risk of having the disease can be identified earlier than had been thought, researchers said today.

title: WESTERN AUTO SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $400,000 on repurchase of debentures for the quarter and year. The company went public in January 1987; figures for both years are on a pro-forma basis.

title: WOOLF COLVIN
description: Woolf Colvin, a retired New York City high school principal, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 90 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: WHEN 'HOME' IS A MISNOMER
description: Talent was in short supply this season on the basketball team at Polytechnic Institute of New York in Brooklyn, losers in 17 of 23 games against Division III opponents. But for dedication under truly adverse circumstances, the dozen engineering students - who from a deep desire to play basketball stuck to the end despite a closing losing streak of seven games - received high marks from Coach George Barbezat.

title: BLACK DRAMATISTS OFFER NEW VISIONS OF OLD ICONS
description: WESLEY BROWN'S biting historical drama ''Boogie Woogie and Booker T.'' - one of several new plays by black playwrights currently running in New York - imagines a 1904 summit conference of black American leaders that will determine the direction of black politics in the country for the next half century.

title: MOVES TO CURB THE VOLATILITY
description: THE sharp run-up in stock prices over the last few days has been accomplished without much of a computer-driven push from program traders - institutions that seek to lock in profits by trading on price discrepancies between stock index futures and the underlying stocks.

title: Dispute on N.B.A. Draft
description: The National Basketball Association announced yesterday that it would hold its annual college draft on June 22, and the announcement immediately started a dispute with the players association.

title: B.C. Eliminates UConn
description: When Jamie Benton hit a jumper in the lane with 10 seconds left last night at Madison Square Garden, it gave Boston College the lead for the first time against Connecticut, 61-59. When Tate George followed by missing a desperation 3-point attempt for Connecticut, it gave the Eagles the victory in the qualifying game of the Big East tournament, which matched the eighth- and ninth-place teams in the conference.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Ken Gerhart, outfielder; Mark Williamson, Eric Bell, John Habyan, Tony Arnold, and Mike Kinnunen, pitchers; Ricky Jones, shortstop, Rene Gonzales, Rex Hudler, and Jim Traber, infielders, to one-year contracts. Renewed the contracts of Ken Dixon, pitcher, and Larry Sheets, outfielder. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Signed Wally Joyner, first baseman, to a one-year contract. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Signed Charlie Eisenreich, outfielder, to a minor-league contract. METS (NL) - Signed John Mitchell, pitcher, to a one-year contract. BASKETBALL PHOENIX (NBA) - Activated Bernard Thompson, guard; placed Grant Gondrezick, guard, on the injured list. FOOTBALL CHICAGO (NFC) - Promoted Bill Tobin to vice president of player personnel. Named Bill McGrane director of administration and Ted Phillips director of finance. DETROIT (NFC) - Signed Eric Truvillion, wide receiver, Frank Mattiace, nose tackle, and Bob Sebring, linebacker. HOCKEY HARTFORD (NHL) - Acquired Pat Hughes, right wing, from the St. Louis Blues for a 10th-round draft choice. MONTREAL (NHL) - Demoted Gilles Thibaudeau, center, to their minor-league affiliate in Sherbrooke, Quebec. RANGERS (NHL) - Traded Mark Osborne, left wing, to the Toronto Maple Leafs for Jeff Jackson, left wing. Traded Lane Lambert, right wing, to the Quebec Nordiques for Pat Price, defenseman. SOCCER CLEVELAND (MISL) - Traded Chris Chueden, midfielder, to the Los Angeles Lazers for Paul Kitson, forward. LOS ANGELES (MISL) - Placed David Brcic, goaltender, on the injured list. Signed Hubert Birkenmeier, goaltender, to a 10-day contract.

title: Koch Seeks to Foreclose On 730 Properties in City
description: The city will seek to foreclose on more than 700 properties in Manhattan whose owners are behind on tax payments, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Did the Reagan Style of Management Fail Him?
description: Was the Iran arms affair an ''aberration'' in the history of the Reagan Administration?

title: CASEY'S GENERAL STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PERFUMER'S WORKSHOP GOES TO EMMERLING
description: Perfumer's Workshop International, a smell factory of sorts that previously did all of its advertising in-house, has decided to go to John Emmerling Inc., which has been scentless since Halston left last year after a four-year stay.

title: JAPAN PLAN ON 3d WORLD DEBT
description: At a time when large banks all over the world are worried about a deepening of the Latin American debt crisis, Japan's leading banks are ready to try a novel approach to ease their share of the burden.

title: ELECTRONIC TAX FILINGS
description: Almost 32 million taxpayers have already filed Federal tax returns this year, and for more than 42,000 of them the chore probably has never been easier. Those taxpayers filed their returns electronically - by computer - and most can look forward to getting a refund within three weeks or less. Those who file the conventional way, mailing a paper return, will have to wait four or five weeks and, as the April 15 deadline draws nearer, maybe even longer. ''We already have received 42,383 electronic returns this year, compared to 26,000 for all last year,'' Larry Batdorf, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service, said Wednesday.

title: THE CONFIDENT STOCK MARKET
description: THE American economy continues to slog along, but the stock market moved to record highs this week, driven by the General Motors Corporation's announcement that it planned to buy back 20 percent of its common stock for more than $5 billion by the end of 1990.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ROBERT GRAVES: The Assault Heroic 1895-1926. By Richard Perceval Graves. 387 pages. Illustrated. Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $24.95.
