IN recent years Robert Graves has enjoyed renewed popularity as a novelist (thanks largely, no doubt, to the television adaptation of ''I, Claudius''), but his poetry, if its absence from the bookshops is any guide, has fallen out of fashion. No matter - his time will come again. The best of his poems are magnificent, and almost all of them are alive and kicking.

title: Letter: On Latin Justice; Speedy Trials for Argentina's Military?
description: To the Editor:

title: PRICE RISE BY PAPER COMPANY
description: The International Paper Company said yesterday that it was raising prices of linerboard, used in cardboard boxes, by as much as 11 percent next month because of very strong demand.

title: Toward a Broader View of the Arts
description: Representative Bob Carr, Democrat of Michigan, was recently elected chairman of the Congressional Arts Caucus, becoming the first non-New Yorker to head it.

title: FILM: 'NO END,' A POLITICAL DRAMA
description: ''No End'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times Sept. 30, 1986. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: AID FOR HOMELESS PASSED BY HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives today approved a bill on new aid for the homeless that could cost up to $725 million. The vote was 264 to 121. But by the time the program for this year can be finally approved - if the Senate agrees to it and the President does not veto it - the fiscal year will be almost over and some of the money will never become available. Separate appropriation legislation would have to be approved before the money could be spent.

title: GRASS STARS MEET IN HIALEAH FINALE
description: Hialeah closes its 50-day meeting Friday with the rubber match of the winter's best racing rivalry: Lotka against Bonne Ile, probably for the last time, in the $175,000 Black Helen Handicap.

title: DEVILS' DEFENSE ARRIVES TOO LATE IN LOSS
description: The first clear sign that the Devils were not going to be adequate on defense tonight came when Buffalo scored its third goal, 15 minutes into the game. Three more goals followed before the the Devils straightened out their defense early in the second period. By then it was too late for New Jersey, and Buffalo had all the goals it would need for a 6-4 victory that ended a a three-game losing streak.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $200,000 and $573,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said that as a result of translation into U.S. dollars, net income of Canadian subsidiaries for the latest third quarter and 9 months, was reduced by $35,000 and $650,000, respectively; net income for the comparable periods of fiscal 1986 was reduced by $108,000 and $656,000, respectively. The results of operations for the first 9 months of fiscal 1987 include a gain of $1,036,000 on the sale of property located in Ft. Lauderdale and Ft. Myers, Fla., and the expropriation of a small portion of property located in Montreal. The operating results in the fiscal 1986 third quarter and 9 months included a gain of $1,095,000 resulting from the termination of an overfunded pension plan.

title: NATURAL GAS PAYMENT PLAN
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission proposed today that natural gas pipelines and the retail distributors that they serve share equally in absorbing the costs of so-called take-or-pay obligations to gas producers.

title: Bridge: Spring National Tournament Drawing Players to St. Louis
description: As bridge tournament enthusiasts swarmed into this city today, looking forward to 10 days of play in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, some players were already hard at work in the North American Pair Championships.

title: BLOCKER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $68,507,000 from the extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss and includes a writedown of $72 million on the value of drilling rigs.

title: Archbishop Makes New Appeal to Find Waite By FRANCIS X. CLINES
description: At a time of relative calm in Beirut, the Archbishop of Canterbury has sent messages to officials in the Middle East in the hope of finding fresh traces of Terry Waite, the Anglican Church's hostage negotiator feared kidnapped six weeks ago.

title: George Coleman, Sax
description: The tenor saxophonist George Coleman will lead his quartet tonight and tomorrow at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street, at East Fourth Street (505-5660). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. Tickets are $10.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Whalers 10, Bruins 2: Kevin Dineen and Sylvain Turgeon each scored twice during a five-goal outburst in the opening period last night in Hartford and Paul Lawless also scored two goals for the Whalers coasted. (AP) Flyers 4, Capitals 2: In Philadelphia, Peter Zezel's third-period goal for the Flyers broke open a tight contest. The victory was the Flyers' second straight and stretched their unbeaten string against the Capitals to 5-0-1. The Capitals, second in the Patrick Division, have not beaten the Flyers at the Spectrum since April 1, 1984. (AP) Red Wings 9, North Stars 3: Bob Probert scored on a penalty shot and Petr Klima added two goals during a six-goal first period for the Red Wings. The nine goals were the most scored by the Red Wings since a 9-3 victory at Toronto on March 30, 1985. (AP) N.B.A. Nuggets 121, Spurs 104: Alex English hit 18 of 22 field-goal attempts in scoring 43 points to lead the Nuggets. English connected on 12 of 13 shots while scoring 26 points in providing Denver with a 64-58 halftime advantage. Lafayette Lever posted his 14th triple-double of the season with 20 points, 15 assists and 10 rebounds. (AP) Suns 126, Cavaliers 102: Alvan Adams scored 23 points and Larry Nance added 22 as the Suns gave their interim coach, Dick Van Arsdale, his first victory and snapped a seven-game game losing streak. Van Arsdale replaced John MacLeod. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Temple Wins Atlantic 10 Title: Mike Vreeswyk scored 21 points and Howard Evans added 20 points and 7 steals as Temple (31-3) defeated West Virginia (23-7), 70-57, to win the Atlantic 10 conference championship and a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. The Owls, who have won 18 of their last 19 games, connected on their first 5 shots and 7 of their first 8 as they raced to a 17-6 lead with 15 minutes 43 seconds left in the half. Nate Blackwell scored 19 points for Temple and was named the tournament's most valuable player. (AP) Notre Dame 65, Miami 49: David Rivers scored 22 points and Donald Royal added 20 for Notre Dame (21-6). Miami (14-16) pulled within 5 points late in the second half before Notre Dame, playing at home, scored 14 straight points for a 61-42 lead. Tito Horford scored 14 points in the first half for Miami but had only 3 in the second. (AP) Boston U., Siena Gain Final: In Niagara Falls, N.Y., Drederick Irving sank a 3-point jump shot with 9 seconds left to give Boston University (18-11) an 84-82 victory over Niagara (20-9) in the semifinals of the Eastern College Athletic Conference-North Atlantic Conference tournament. The Terriers will play at Northeastern in tomorrow's championship game. Northeastern (26-6) defeated Siena, 89-79, in the other semifinal as its point guard, Andre LaFleur had a game-high 9 assists to move within 2 of Jim Les of Bradley, the N.C.A.A.'s career leader with 884. Siena fell to 17-12. (AP) L.S.U., Tennessee Advance: In Atlanta, Anthony Wilson and Oliver Brown scored 16 points each as Louisiana State (19-13) took command early and defeated Mississippi State, 68-54, in the opening game of the Southeastern Conference tournament. L.S.U. advanced to a quarterfinal game tonight against Florida. In another opener, Tony White scored 30 points, including 12 in a row during one stretch, as Tennessee (14-14) used a strong second half to defeat Vanderbilt, 74-57. The Vols advanced to tonight's quarterfinal against Alabama. (AP) Big Upset in Big Sky Tournament: Harry Willis scored 23 points and Walt Tyler added 22 as eighth-seeded Weber State shocked top-seeded Montana State, 106-101, in a first-round game of the Big Sky Conference tournament in Flagstaff, Ariz. Weber State (7-21), which had finished last in the eight-team league during the regular season and lost by 108-78 at Montana State (21-7) on Feb. 12, led by 19 at six different stages of the second half. Montana State closed to 104-101 but Robert Maxwell insured the victory with two free throws with one second to go. (AP) New Mexico Wins: In Albuquerque, N.M., Hunter Greene pumped in 32 points as New Mexico (24-8) breezed to a 92-77 victory over Colorado State (13-16) in the opening round of the Western Athletic Conference tournament. The Lobos will face Brigham Young, an 82-79 winner over Air Force, tonight. (AP) San Jose State 71, New Mexico State 54: Ricky Berry, who didn't start because he hadn't been feeling well, came off the bench to score 25 points as San Jose State (15-13) won a first-round game in the Pacific Coast Athletic Association tournament. New Mexico State finished at 15-15. (AP) Iowa 103, Northwestern 76: Kevin Gamble scored 21 points and Jeff Moe made five 3-point field goals for Iowa in the Big Ten game. The victory was the 300th for Tom Davis, the first-year Iowa coach. Iowa improved to 26-4 over all and 13-4 in the conference. Northwestern fell to 6-21 and 1-16. (AP) GOLF Tale of Two Golfers: Mike Sullivan, the first player to tee off yesterday in the Honda Classic at Coral Springs, Fla., had the lowest round of the day, a seven-under-par 65. He led Bruce Lietzke, Brad Faxon and Mark Calcavecchia by four strokes. King Leads by 2: Betsy King, mastering the toughest course on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour with seven birdies and two bogeys despite driving rains, shot a five-under-par 67 to take the first-round lead in the $250,000 G.N.A.-Glendale Federal tournament at Glendale, Calif. Her round equaled the women's record at Oakmont County Club for a two-stroke lead over Sally Little and Alice Ritzman. (AP)

title: THE GOSPEL, ACORDING TO SAXOPHONES
description: THE saxophone is a resolutely secular icon in our culture, its gleaming curves and often voice-like sound firmly associated with both sultry, sophisticated jazz and bumptious rock-and-roll, with high-flying fancies and the red-dirt realities of the blues. But the saxophone has also been a vehicle of imagination and spirit. And although it isn't widely known, the spirituality of storefront churches and ecstatic religion has shaped the work of some of American music's most indelible saxophone stylists, including King Curtis, Ornette Coleman and Albert Ayler.

title: The 26 Now on Death Row
description: Twenty-five men and one woman have been sentenced to death here since New Jersey reinstituted capital punishment in 1982.

title: HUGHES, IN CHANGE, TO TALK TO BAKER
description: The outside directors of the Hughes Tool Company, facing a lawsuit for more than $1 billion, reversed their position this morning and voted not to terminate a proposed merger with the Baker International Corporation.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Sonny Jurgensen, who retired in 1974 as quarterback of the Washington Redskins, faces a license suspension hearing following his arrest earlier this week on suspicion of driving while intoxicated, according to Maryland state police. Jurgensen, 52 years old, failed a field sobriety test, according to the police, who added that he refused to undergo breath analysis, which could result in license suspension. . . . The Los Angeles Lazers placed a goalkeeper, David Brcic, on the disabled list with a broken nose and signed Hubert Birkenmeier, a former New York Express goalie, to a 10-day contract. Birkenmeier had a 1-9 record in 13 games this season with the Express before that Major Indoor Soccer League club folded.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMSON ORANISATION LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company reports its results in pounds sterling but the U.S. dollar amounts given are translated at the year-end rate of exchange (1 pound sterling equals U.S.$1.48).

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized capital gains of $1,103,406 and $3,477,300 for the quarter and year, respectively, and tax credits of $1,236,453 and $3,444,901 for the same periods, respectively. c-Includes realized capital gains of $23,299,777 and $24,024,031 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax credit of $3,866,763 for both periods. The company said its year-ago capital gains included a significant gain on the sale of Richardson-Vicks Inc. common stock.

title: ART: CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY AND PAINTINGS AT THE MET
description: OF all the shows of Chinese art organized in the last few years by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, ''Masterpieces of Sung and Yuan Calligraphy and Painting'' may be the least accessible. Many of the silk paintings have been darkened by time. Few works have the kind of spark that immediately brings a period and artist to life. For scholars, the complexity of the material will be clear. For the general art public, however, it will be a struggle.

title: INSIDE
description: Rent Law System Assailed

title: Jazz at the Vanguard
description: The saxophonist George Adams and the pianist Don Pullen will lead their quartet (with Dannie Richmond on drums and Cameron Brown on bass) tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Barbara Lea, Jan Wallman's, 49 West 44th Street (764-8930). Barbara Lea, one of the most knowledgeable collectors and interpreters of popular songs, is currently focusing on songs from films that are highlighted in Roy Hemming's recent survey of film scores, ''The Melody Lingers On.'' During a series of Friday appearances at Jan Wallman's restaurant-cabaret that starts tonight, she will sing film songs by Jimmy McHugh, Harry Warren, Richard Whiting, Ralph Rainger, Hoagy Carmichael and Jimmy Van Heusen. With Wes McAfee as her piano accompanist, she will go on tonight at 9 and 11 for a $7 cover charge and an $8 minimum.

title: Spreading Ivy
description: When the Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey playoffs begin today, the league's leading scorer, Joe Nieuwendyk of Cornell, will be conspicuous by his absence. The Big Red was eliminated in playoff action last weekend, so Nieuwendyk has set off to join the National Hockey League -the second player to jump from Cornell to the Calgary Flames in less than a year.

title: Roman Catholic Mass for Homosexuals Is Banned
description: The Archdiocese of New York has ordered a Jesuit-run church in lower Manhattan to discontinue a special mass it has offered since 1979 for members of Dignity, a group of Roman Catholic homosexuals that condones homosexual sex.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 6, 1987
description: Companies

title: CONAGRA DEAL FOR MONFORT
description: Conagra Inc., the food products and grain company based in Omaha, agreed yesterday to acquire Monfort of Colorado Inc., a meat processing and distributing company, in a stock swap valued at about $365.5 million.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS HE IS MOVING AWAY FROM IRAN AFFAIR
description: President Reagan said today that enough time had been spent on ''inside Washington politics'' and that he would not allow the rest of his Presidency to be hindered by the Iran arms affair.

title: Thompson Medical CONSOLIDATES ACCOUNTS
description: The Thompson Medical Company has consolidated its advertising at Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson, and Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey, which were already their agencies.

title: UNITIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Police Team Gains a Success As Long Siege Ends Calmly
description: It took nearly 30 hours, but in the end, members of the police hostage negotiating team were successful. Four hostages walked free from their East Harlem apartment, and the 25-year-old gunman who had held them captive peacefully surrendered.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company's fiscal year-end has been changed from Oct. 31 to Jan. 31., and results reflect the transition period. The company said the latest year results have been restated to reflect the transition in the fiscal year.

title: HAWLEY GROUP LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $40,918,000. c-After extraordinary losses of $12,061,000.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Segovia Master Classes
description: Andres Segovia will begin a series of three master classes in guitar, Sunday at 3 P.M. at Borden Hall of the Manhattan School of Music, Broadway and 122d Street. He will give a class on Monday at 2 P.M. in Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall, and on Tuesday at 8 P.M. again at Manhattan School. All three are open to the public. Weill tickets are $10 (247-7800); Manhattan School tickets are $15 (749-2802).

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a reversal of a tax credit of $409,000 for the quarter; and the year includes a tax credit of $224,000 and gains of $4,175,000 from sale of Marco Island Country Club and $3,549,000 from sale of property near Tampa, Fla. c-Includes a reversal of a tax credit of $1,510,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $3,988,000 for the year.

title: ON INDIA'S BORDER, A HUGE MOCK WAR
description: With more than a thousand armored vehicles spread across its western desert, India launched the final stage today of a huge military exercise that has stirred new tensions with Pakistan.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized gains of $93,957,000 and $139,224,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes realized gains of $11,624,000 for the quarter and $46,816,000 for the year. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect the 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a dividend paid Nov. 17, 1986.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ST. LOUIS;
A Castle Downtown
description: LEAD: TWO years ago, Mark Conner had a problem that confronts many residential developers in metropolitan downtowns: how to build safe quiet homes in an economically depressed big city neighborhood.

title: Top Jersey Court Upholds Death Penalty
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court, in a 6-to-1 opinion, upheld today the state's capital punishment law but threw out the death sentences of the two murderers whose cases formed the basis for testing the law.

title: The Case for Police Merger
description: The recent resignation of New York City's Transit Police Chief, James Meehan, appropriately followed a report showing the department's inattention to serious violations of procedure in the fatal case of Michael Stewart. Now the city needs to find a successor of high quality, a task made harder by indecision over who runs the department.

title: The President and the Quagmire
description: President Reagan still cannot pronounce the word ''I'' in the same sentence as the word ''mistake.'' If his speech about the Iran-contra scandal Wednesday was intended as a confession of error, his heart wasn't in it. He sounded at times like a man who's sure he hasn't done anything wrong -and promises never to do it again.

title: Double Bill at Ritz
description: The songwriter Garland Jeffreys and the Reckless Sleepers, featuring the songwriter Jules Shear, will perform tomorrow at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800); the double bill begins at 11 P.M. Tickets are $12.50 in advance, $13.50 tomorrow.

title: Lions Sign Three
description: The Detroit Lions have signed three free agents, including two who played in the United States Football League: Eric Truvillion, a wide receiver who had two 1,000-yard receiving seasons with the Tampa Bay Bandits, and Frank Mattiace, a 270-pound nose tackle from Holy Cross, who played in the 1984 and 1985 seasons for the Generals. The Lions also signed Bob Sebring, an inside linebacker from the University of Illinois, who was released by Houston before the 1986 season.

title: FILM: 'TIN MEN,' COMEDY FROM BARRY LEVINSON
description: TOE to toe, eyeball to eyeball, fin to fin - when the two feuding aluminum siding salesmen in ''Tin Men'' square off, they use every means available, Cadillacs included. Their battle alone would be enough to sustain an ordinary comedy, but Barry Levinson's richly textured new film also has a rueful nostalgia, a fine-tuned streak of con artistry, and the same hilarious, nit-picking small talk that colored ''Diner,'' his first and best film - which is recalled, rivaled and in a few ways even outdone by this one.

title: SENATORS PROPOSE 5 ELECTION LAWS
description: Many senators say the system under which they were elected is much too costly and unduly influenced by special interests and are calling for changes in laws regulating campaign financing.

title: CHRYSLER SETS SPLIT, PAYOUT
description: The Chrysler Corporation declared a 3-for-2 stock split today and raised its cash dividend by 7 percent.

title: HARTFORD INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOW THE NEWARD SUBWAY CAME TO LIE IN THE MORRIS CANAL'S BED
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro-North Train Engineer Dismissed in Bronx Accident
description: The engineer of a Metro-North Commuter Railroad train that struck another of the line's trains in the Bronx two weeks ago has been dismissed, the railroad said yesterday.

title: HOMER BY SCHMIDT NO HELP TO CARLTON
description: Steve Carlton is released by three teams but clings desperately, at the age of 42, to a chance of adding to his career total of 323 victories. Mike Schmidt wins his third most valuable player award but talks, at the age of 37, of retiring after this season.

title: ELRON ELECTRONIC INDUSRIES LTD (ISRAEL)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges of $2,987,000 and $7,778,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from equity in the loss of related companies, including a provisiion of $2.2 million for the quarter and $6 million for the year on an additional investment in Elscint Ltd., and losses from minority interests of $1,375,000 for the quarter and $2,698,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After a gain of $125,000 in the net income of related companies for the quarter and a charge of $5,120,000 for the year from equity in in the loss of related companies; losses of $1,375,000 and $4,125,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from minority interests, and the year also includes the writeoff of investment in and loans to Elscint Ltd. of $24,386,000.

title: BankAmerica Sale of German Units
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said it had agreed to sell its German consumer banking subsidiary, Bankhaus Centrale Credit A.G., and its German credit card operations to the Banco de Santander of Spain. Terms of the sale were not disclosed, but a BankAmerica spokesman said the bank expected a pretax gain of $45 million.

title: THOMPSON HONORED BY HIS COLLEAGUES
description: John Thompson, who molded a relatively young and inexperienced team into a potential conference champion, was named the Big East coach of the year yesterday.

title: ACQUISITION BY RYDER
description: Ryder Systems Inc. has purchased Caledonian Airmotive Ltd., an aircraft-engine repair company based in Scotland. Ryder refused to disclose the terms of the deal today, but it said Caledonian Airmotive is Europe's largest independent engine repair shop and is Ryder's largest international purchase to date. The Scottish company was a subsidiary of British Caledonian Group and had fiscal year 1986 revenues in excess of $50 million. The company employs more than 300 people.

title: Not With Open Arms
description: The European Community, which has had an office in Washington for nearly 20 years, is seeking State Department authorization to open a small mission of two or three people in San Francisco, but the proposal is not arousing a lot of support or action.

title: Figure in Palme Inquiry Leaves Stockholm Job
description: Hans Holmer, the man who for a year led the unsuccessful hunt for the killer of Prime Minister Olof Palme, has resigned as Stockholm's police chief, saying that the investigation had turned into a shambles.

title: PARADYNE PLEADS GUILTY, SETTLING FRAUD CHARGES
description: The Paradyne Corporation pleaded guilty today and was fined $1 million for scheming to defraud the Social Security Administration to obtain a $115 million computer contract.

title: The Wages of Espionage
description: America has several reasons to be dismayed at Israel's vexatious behavior. True, it was America's fault to have fallen into the Iranian arms sales quagmire, though Israelis helped lead Washington there. What Israel cannot escape blame for is its behavior in the Pollard spy case.

title: HONG KONG STOCKS FALL
description: Hong Kong stock prices tumbled today, absorbing their worst losses since August 1982 as traders took profits. The Hang Seng Index, the main market indicator, slid 92 points,

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,885,000 for retirement of debt for the quarter and year.

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2.6 million on sale of real estate for the quarter and for the year includes a loss of $3,432,000 from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Presidency And Governing
description: President Reagan said, ''You take your knocks, you learn your lessons and then you move on.''

title: Two Weekend Events For Women's Month
description: A concert by the Women of the Calabash is part of the events planned this weekend in observance of Women's History Month. The concert begins at 7:30 P.M. tomorrow at Public School 41, 116 West 11th Street. Tickets are $10 and $12. Information: (914) 682-0488.

title: THE DANCE: 'SHARDS,' CUNNINGHAM PREMIERE
description: MERCE CUNNINGHAM'S new season is on a choreographic roll.

title: FEDERATED STORES FILLS NO. 2 POSITION
description: Federated Department Stores filled a gap in its top management yesterday by electing Norman S. Matthews president and chief operating officer, its No. 2 position.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about appointments to the New York State Commission on Government Integrity misstated the salaries of Benito Romano, its staff director, and Gerard E. Lynch, its counsel. Each will be paid $80,000 a year.

title: Coming to Terms With Nicaragua
description: LEAD: If the Sandinistas really presented a serious threat to United States security, the Administration would already have invaded Nicaragua. The fact that no such invasion has occurred implies that even the Administration believes that the Sandinistas constitute an irritant, not a threat.

title: DAVID MASSENGILL
description: The songwriter David Massengill will perform tonight and tomorrow at Speakeasy, 107 Macdougal Street, at Bleecker Street (598-9670), with Jane Gillman opening tonight and Gail Rundlett opening tomorrow. Shows are at 8:30 and 11 P.M.; there is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: WILLIAMS, W W CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Can the President Still Lead?
description: In talking to his staff, Lyndon B. Johnson always announced the onset of catastrophe with the statement: ''The ox is in the ditch!'' Those words are very much in my mind these days. In the first place, they form one of the few of his pithier sayings that can be cited verbatim in mixed company without bowdlerization. In the second place, I know of no better description for the state of our Government in the aftermath of the Tower Commission report on President Reagan and the Iran-contra scandal, as well as the President's own speech on the subject.

title: Editors' Note
description: A Washington dispatch on Oct. 24, 1985, reported a Pentagon announcement that more than half of the new Army and Marine Corps helmets made by the Gentex Corporation of Carbondale, Pa., were defective.

title: TRW ADMITS OVERCHARGES
description: The chairman of TRW Inc. said today that his company had overcharged the Government on military contracts but promised steps would be taken to prevent the improper conduct from happening again.

title: GEMCRAFT INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes non-cash pre-tax charges of $4.7 million related to land which reflect current market values and for abandonment of land inventory, and pre-tax charges of $5.8 million relating to the company's recession offer and settlements with federal agencies, among other things.

title: CONTRA LEADER DISCLOSES BANK RECORDS
description: A Nicaraguan rebel leader, Adolfo Calero, made public the financial records of his army, the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, for the first time today.

title: Diner's Journal
description: AT the rate spiffy new eating spots are opening along Eighth and Ninth Avenues in what used to be Hell's Kitchen, the neighborhood might soon be redesignated Hell's Cafe. One of the newcomers is called Caffe Cielo, a bright and airy spot with a soft sky mural on the ceiling, peach-tone walls and white tables sprouting pink carnations. The food is not always as luminous, and service is bumbling at best, but several recent lunches turned up a few pleasing pastas, such as penne with a vodka-doused tomato sauce with peas ($11.25), bright little pizzas ($7 to $10) and satisfying grilled chicken with herb butter ($12.50). Such lunch prices are stiff for this neighborhood, and the wine list is even more out of line. If you are willing to pay for an uplifting setting, though, it's worth noting. Caffe Cielo, 881 Eighth Avenue, between 52d and 53d Streets, serves lunch from noon to 4 P.M., dinner 6 P.M. to midnight daily. Telephone: 246-9555. * * *

title: HARCOURT BRACE JOVANOVICH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods include earnings of 7 cents a share for the fourth quarter and 8 cents a share for the year from the acquisitions of Holt, Rinehart & Winston, W.B. Saunders and The Dryden Press in December. The 1986 Tax Reform Act's elimination of investment tax credit, a non- recurring event, decreased the company's earnings by$2.9 million for the fourth quarter and, in consequence, for the year.

title: Bromley K. Smith Dies; Longtime N.S.C. Aide
description: Bromley K. Smith, a consultant to the National Security Council, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Washington. He was 75 years old.

title: U.S. AFFIRMS CURB ON SOVIET TRADE
description: A high State Department official said today that Soviet actions on human rights, while promising, did not yet go far enough for an easing of American restrictions on trade.

title: FILM: MICKEY ROURKE STARS IN 'ANGEL HEART'
description: ALAN PARKER'S ''Angel Heart'' is set in 1955 in the very particular Manhattan of cheap walk-ups, unwashed windows and perpetual twilight inhabited by Harry Angel (Mickey Rourke), a private eye who specializes in gathering information for use in sleazy divorce cases. He talks tough but he's no Sam Spade. Harry exists in a self-imposed limbo, without a past or a future, which is all right with him.

title: FILM: 'LILY TOMLIN'
description: ''LILY TOMLIN'' is an unusual, extremely patient, backstage record of how Lily Tomlin, Jane Wagner and their associates put together ''The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe,'' Miss Tomlin's smash-hit, one-woman Broadway play of the 1985-86 season.

title: New Jazz
description: The New York Composers Orchestra will present new music for jazz orchestra by Lenny Pickett, Robin Holcomb, Elliott Sharp and Butch Morris tonight at 8 at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street. Admission is $6; information: 219-8242.

title: GAMES TO BEGIN AT LAST FOR YANKS
description: The day drifted by lazily, like so many others this spring. Beyond the left-field fence, palm trees bent slightly as a warm wind moved across the stadium. On the infield grass near third base, several players sat with Clete Boyer, a former Yankee and now a coach, and listened attentively as he spoke about glovework. Behind the dugout, fans pleaded for autographs.

title: Icahn Offer Is Rejected By USAir
description: USAir Group Inc. rejected a $1.65 billion takeover offer from Carl C. Icahn yesterday, saying that the $52-a-share cash bid from the chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc. was ''grossly inadequate.''

title: Queensboro Bus Lane
description: To the Editor:

title: Track View on Pros
description: Primo Nebiolo of Italy, the leading official of international track and field, indicated yesterday that American pro football players would not be allowed to compete in track and field as long as they were playing football. Nebiolo is the president of the International Amateur Athletic Federation, track and field's world governing body. Last year, the federation council reinstated Renaldo Nehemiah, the world-record holder in the 110-meter hurdles, after he said he would no longer play pro football. Later this month, the council will consider reinstatement requests from Willie Gault, Michael Carter, Herschel Walker and Ron Brown, all of whom play in the National Football League; Stanley Floyd, who has tried out for several pro football teams, and Brian Oldfield, the shot-putter who took part in a professional track circuit between 1974 and 1976.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings reflects a 3-for-2 stock split paid Dec. 1, 1986.

title: CARMEL CONTAINER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $73,000 for the latest year and $290,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said results were translated on the basis of a Dec. 31, 1986 exchange rate of U.S. $1 to new Israeli shekels 1.488.

title: AIDS WORKERS PLAN ANONYMOUS TESTING AT VARIETY OF CLINICS
description: Federal health researchers say they plan anonymous nationwide tests of blood samples collected at methadone and venereal disease clinics to track the spread of the AIDS virus.

title: Musical Improvisations
description: The pianist John Bayless will play a program of improvisations on the music of Bernstein, Bach and the standard operatic repertory at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night at 8:30. Tickets are $10; information: 247-7800.

title: TREASURY RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates rose slightly in the Treasury market yesterday in very light trading activity, while tax-exempt and corporate bond yields were little changed.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS PLAN VOTE ON A CONTRA-AID MORATORIUM
description: The House Democratic leadership, settling on its strategy to fight continued aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, said today that the House would vote next week on a six-month moratorium on the release of $40 million in military aid that President Reagan formally requested today.

title: WYSE WINS SEALY
description: The Ohio Mattress Company has assigned its $5 million Sealy Mattress account to the Cleveland office of Wyse Advertising, which already had $2 million in billings from the company. The former agency was Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, Chicago, which did not lie down on the job.

title: Dining Out Guide; 3-Star French, Part I
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AURORA, 60 East 49th Street (692-9292) - (Jan. 31, 1986) Joseph Baum's provocative creation combines a cor porate ambiance of burnished wood wainscotting and plush leather chairs with a playful bubble theme carried out on plates, the waiters' jackets and elsewhere. The food can soar as high as bubbles on a windy day, and the menu changes frequently. First-rate starters napoleon of layered vegeta bles and mousse of zucchini with mari nated shrimp and lobster. For a main dish, game fanciers may enjoy the me dallions of venison with apricot, pear and chestnut sauce, and fresh pasta. Other options are lobster, poached with ginger, lime and Sauterne, and baked salmon with tomato butter, diced apple and vegetables. Main courses $28.50 to $34.50. Fridays, noon to 2:30 and 5:30 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 5:30 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. LA COTE BASQUE, #5 East 55th Street (688-6525) - (Aug. 22, 1986) The wrap around dining room of this bastion of classic French cuisine exudes a time less glamour with its murals of coastal France and splendid flower arrange ments. The cooking style is character ized by intensely reduced sauces, lav ish presentation and prodigious por tions. Starter choices include the sea food casserole, which changes daily, and cold poached salmon. Entrees fol low classic French cooking, from stuffed quail in pastry crust with truf fle sauce to sweetbreads of staggering size in a veal-stock sauce tinged with Madeira and garnished with pearl onions. Or you might choose grilled seafood, which is always good - sole, salmon and red snapper. Dinner prix fixe $48. Fridays, noon to 2:30 and 6 to 10:30 P.M.; Saturdays, noon to 2:30 and 6 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. LA RESERVE, #4 West 49th Street (247- 2993) - (June 28, 1985) While the cook ing orientation here is classical, the touch is light and the two dining rooms with their beige- and peach-colored banquettes provide an enchanting backdrop for an excellent meal. You might begin with cream of lobster soup with basil; duck terrine with cumin and pistachio nuts, or a casserole of snails and wild mushrooms with garlic. For a main course, fish preparations are well focused, such as the grilled red snapper with tomato and herbs or poached Dover sole stuffed with arti choke mousse. Or choose roast duck with guava and rosemary, and sweet bread scallops with mustard seeds and red peppers. Dinner prix fixe $42. Fri days, noon to 3 and 5:30 to 11 P.M.; Sat urdays, 5:30 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. LA TULIPE, #104 West 13th Street (691- 8860) - (March 1, 1985) This charm ing and intimate Greenwich Village restaurant with its Parisian-style bar up front, chocolate colored walls and graceful tulip sconces has maintained its high standards over the years. The chef stresses flavor over flashiness, and appetizer selections include ce viche of salmon with fresh tomato sauce and wild mushroom soup. En trees are nearly always well con ceived: Slices of grilled squab with chartreuse of vegetables and braised cabbage; confit of duck with lentils; red snapper in parchment with herbs and vegetables, and lobster on a bed of pasta and brunoise of vegetables. Din ner prix fixe $57. Fridays through Sun days, 6:30 to 10 P.M. LE CIRQUE, #58 East 65th Street (794-9292) - (Sept. 19, 1986) There is indeed something magical about dining at this classically elegant East Side restau rant - certainly the food and service is of the highest quality rich and fa mous sit elbow-to-elbow on banquettes, but the experience is grander than the sum of its parts. The extensive menu is all in French, and starters are ceviche of red-snapper fillet in vinaigrette with red and yellow peppers or one of the changing daily pastas. You can't go wrong with the meticulously prepared grilled and sauteed selections, Dover sole with mustard sauce or paillard of beef or veal. Game birds are a spe cialty and the roast pigeon surrounded with shredded cabbage is a delight. Dinner entrees $20.25 to $27.75. Fri days and Saturdays, noon to 2:30 and 6 to 10:30 P.M.; closed Sundays. What the stars mean, page COO.

title: ISRAELIS REACT WITH NEW DISMAY TO THE LIFE SENTENCE FOR POLLARD
description: The sentencing of Jonathan Jay Pollard by a Washington court on Wednesday to life imprisonment for spying for Israel appears to have awakened the Israeli public and the Government to the full human and diplomatic implications of the affair.

title: How the Newark Subway Came to Lie in the Morris Canal's Bed
description: To the Editor:

title: HECK'S FILES FOR PROTECTION
description: Heck's Inc., a large regional discount store chain that has been struggling with losses, said today that it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Korean Film Series At the Asia Society
description: A series of films that highlight the social and cultural problems of South Korea since the early 1950's will begin today and run for the next five Fridays at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 71st Street. The films, which have English subtitles, have never been shown here.

title: Crafts Show
description: More than 100 contemporary artisans trained in the traditional crafts of weaving, ceramics, jewelry-making and glass-blowing will take part in an annual spring crafts market at Columbia University's Ferris Booth Hall, Broadway and 115th Street. The event, held over the next two weekends, is sponsored by the American Arts and Crafts Alliance. Hours today are 2 to 8 P.M., tomorrow 11 A.M. to 7 P.M., and Sunday 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is $3 (free for children). Information: 866-2239.

title: Texan Acts for Impeachment
description: Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, who asked the House to impeach President Reagan after the Grenada invasion in 1983, today introduced new articles of impeachment against Mr. Reagan regarding the Iran arms affair. They were given virtually no chance of approval. The six articles accuse Mr. Reagan of misconduct in secretly selling arms to Iran, of allegedly diverting the arms sale payments to the Nicaraguan rebels and of failing to inform Congressional intelligence committees of his activities.

title: Turning 40
description: Gerald Wilkins, a little known second-round choice from the University of Tennessee-Chattanooga in the 1985 college draft, used two explosive efforts in the last two weeks to join a group of nine more-heralded Knick offensive stars of the last 40 years. The 23-year-old guard scored 43 points on Feb. 21 against the Nets and on Wednesday totaled 41 against the 76ers in Philadelphia to become the 10th Knick to score 40 or more points at least two times. The other nine: $ Times Player Games 40+ Bernard King 540 21 Richie Guerin 518 11 Bob McAdoo 171 9 Willis Reed 650 6 Walt Frazier 759 5 Willie Naulls 430 4 Cazzie Russell 344 3 Walt Bellamy 268 2 Carl Braun 740 2

title: RANGERS' OSBORNE IS TRADED TO LEAFS
description: They have only 15 games left and their position in the playoffs is not yet secure. Yet, Phil Esposito said the first trade he made yesterday was ''not for right now.'' The second trade he said would help them during the playoffs.

title: KEY RATES
ARTISTS ARE CREATING A WONDERLAND OF VIDEO IN MUSEUMS AND GALLERIES
description: THE video art to be seen around New York City this weekend might make one wonder why television was ever called a vast wasteland. On video screens in museums, galleries and performance spaces, verve and imagination are in flower.

title: HORIZON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $168,000 for the quarter and year. Horizon said that essentially all of the net income realized as a result of the sale in December of most of its remaining interest in its Paradise Hills, N.M., development which resulted in pre-tax income of about $21,823,000 in the latest quarter.

title: MONEY FUND ASSETS UP
description: Assets of the nation's 381 money market mutual funds increased $552.5 million, to $237.46 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were down $386.9 million, to $65.8 billion. Assets of the 198 general-purpose funds were down $247.7 million, to $62.7 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds rose $1.19 billion, to $108.96 billion.

title: A New Regime?
description: If President Reagan does as he says, we are going to see an extraordinary kind of palace revolution in Washington. The king will still be there, but he will preside over a radically different Government.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE initial draw of the benefit for the Irvington House Institute for Medical Research this week was the chance to have a peek at the new decor of the Grill Room of the Four Seasons. But as luck and the vagaries of redecorating would have it, the only changes up to then were the new hand-rubbed finish on the French walnut paneling and some refurbishing on the sculpture by Richard Lippold. The carpeting, as Anna Murdoch, a co-chairman of the evening, put it, was ''somewhere between the moon and New York.'' That meant that the new blue chairs could not be used because they did not match the old carpet. The linens ordered last June were also delayed.

title: Add Long-Term Care
description: To the Editor:

title: State Oversight Of Rent Laws Called Chaotic
description: Almost three years after the state took over administration of New York City's rent laws, landlords and tenants say that the system is in disarray and that state officials have tried to disguise their inefficiency by resolving thousands of rent disputes arbitrarily.

title: G.M. MAY FILL M.T.A. BUS ORDERS
description: A day after the deadline passed for the purchase of 300 new General Motors buses for New York City, a spokesman for the company said yesterday it might still be able to fill the order.

title: CONCERT: MUSIC TODAY
description: GERARD SCHWARZ had put together an especially enterprising quartet of contemporary works for his Music Today program at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night: three world premieres and a backward look at a piece that established its composer's reputation in new-music circles a little more than a quarter of a century ago. As it turned out, one of the premieres fell through owing to a singer's throat ailment, but that still left a fairly hearty meal to be digested in one sitting.

title: DECISION DELAYED ON WHEELING MILL
description: The fate of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation's Monessen rail mill, one of three rail mills operating in the country, remains uncertain following a judge's decision to delay foreclosure of the five-year-old facility. Federal Bankruptcy Judge Warren Bentz issued a restraining order delaying foreclosure in order to hear arguments from unsecured creditors and scheduled a hearing for April 3.

title: BY SCAASI, BRIOCHES AND OTHER SPRING CONFECTIONS
description: Arnold Scaasi calls it his brioche skirt, and it turns up in many guises in his spring and summer made-to-order collection. It's a big, rounded pouf, and silk flowers are sometimes nestled in the fold where it joins an underskirt that flares to the floor.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MARCH 6, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12, 18-19 Israel appears to have realized the human and diplomatic implications of a 1985 arrest with the sentencing of Jonathan Jay Pollard by a Washington court to life imprisonment for spying for Israel. Page A1

title: What the Elderly Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Graf Sails By Navratilova to Final
description: Used as a growth chart, the Lipton International Players Championships is a most accurate measure of how Steffi Graf has grown on the women's tennis tour in three years. She has progressed from the fourth round in 1985 to the final last year, relying almost exclusively on a ripping topspin forehand, to her convincing victory against Martina Navratilova in today's semifinal, where she emerged as the favorite to win this tournament on Saturday.

title: Gunman Surrenders After Holding 4 for a 2d Day on 101st St.
description: A 25-year-old parolee who the police said was heavily armed and possibly crazed by cocaine peacefully ended a 30-hour hostage drama at a public housing project in East Harlem last night by releasing a 4-year-old girl and three others unharmed.

title: ART: PEIRRE ALECHINSKY AT THE GUGGENHEIM
description: WITH its current show, ''Pierre Alechinsky:

title: STERLING LORD AGENCY TO MERGE WITH LITERISTIC
description: In a move inspired in part by recent mergers and consolidations in the book-publishing industry, two of the better-known literary agencies - the Sterling Lord Agency and Literistic - announced yesterday that they would merge.

title: CANADA REJECTS ISRAELI ENVOY FAULTED IN '82 BEIRUT KILLINGS
description: The Canadian Government has refused diplomatic accreditation to a general who is currently Israel's defense attache in Washington, apparently because of the reprimand the general received in an official Israeli report on the massacre of Palestinians in refugee districts in Beirut in 1982.

title: CANADIANS TO REPEAT THEIR TOURISM THEME
description: Tourism Canada had so much success with its ''The World Next Door'' advertising campaign last year that it will repeat it this year while increasing the budget to $9 million from $7.9 million. Camp Associates, Toronto, is the agency.

title: WASHINGTON TALK
description: Washington Talk will now appear in The Times Mondays through Fridays only.

title: SHULTZ DISMISSES TOWER CRITICISM OF HIS IRAN ROLE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz denied today that he had distanced himself from President Reagan's secret Iran arms sales to protect his own record.

title: 3 REAGAN AIDES TRIED TO TEMPER TOWER FINDINGS
description: The White House general counsel and two other senior officials urged the Tower Commission, in its report, to minimize what the panel found to be conflicting statements by President Reagan on when he first approved Israel's shipment of American arms to Iran in 1985, the general counsel said tonight.

title: SOVIET OFFICIALS END A VISIT TO NICARAGUA
description: A Soviet delegation led by Boris N. Yeltsin, the Moscow city leader, left here today after a four-day visit.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE staff of the Bank Lambert in Brussels had departed for the weekend on a recent Friday when Christopher Burge, Christie's president in the United States, arrived with a team of six men and women carrying cameras, catalogues and briefcases. The art experts, cataloguers and photography crew were there to document Baron Lambert's collection of 209 Impressionist, modern and postwar paintings, prints and sculptures -holdings Christie's is to auction in 15 sales in New York, London and Amsterdam between May 5 and July 14.

title: Meese Gives Nazi Suspect Time to Find a Country
description: Karl Linnas, who is facing possible deportation to the Soviet Union, where he has been condemned to death as a Nazi war criminal, has been given 30 days to find another country that will grant him refuge, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today.

title: Cello-Piano Concert
description: The cellist Carlos Prieto and the pianist Doris Stevenson will play a free concert of works by Martinu, Bach, Boccherini and Shostakovich at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, Sunday afternoon at 3:30. Information: 662-2133.

title: GIANTS DUO GUAGES PUBLIC OPINION, BY THE DIAL
description: CONCERTS, radio spots, albums, cassettes, singles, EP's, video clips, flexi-disks - up-and-coming rock bands have tried every format imaginable to get new songs heard. But it took They Might Be Giants, the two-man band that performs tomorrow at the Village Gate, to build a reputation on what may be the ultimate in low-fi, low-budget music distribution -Dial-a-Song (718-387-6962), which dispenses the latest They Might Be Giants songs via answering machine.

title: City Faces Penalty For Child Care Plans
description: The Koch administration said yesterday that it was facing a $14 million state penalty because it was slow in developing plans for abused and neglected children placed in foster homes.

title: BUSH SAYS HE RUES IRAN ARMS POLICY
description: In a day of gentle questioning by political supporters, Vice President Bush said today that he wished he had been ''more help'' and had ''seen signals'' in the conduct of United States policy toward Iran.

title: TOWER PANEL CRITICISMS REJECTED BY WEINBERGER
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today rejected criticism of himself in the Tower Commmission report as ''totally unsupported by any evidence.''

title: Social Worker Urges Father Be Given Custody of Baby M
description: A mental-health expert retained by Baby M's legal guardian urged today that the baby's father, William Stern, receive custody of the baby, but that Mr. Stern's wife, Elizabeth, not be permitted to adopt the child legally.

title: TRADE WAR COUNTERATTACK: NEW THEMES BY LABOR
description: The music that comes up on the television screen is an instrumental version of ''America the Beautiful,'' and the first shots are of crystal coastlines, spacious skies and amber waves of grain.

title: TO HAPLESS MILLIONS, 'NEW' BRAZIL IS A SEALED BOOK
description: Past the gates of the explosives factory, in the shade of cashew and coconut trees, a sign says: ''Think. An accident can change your life.''

title: NATIONAL GYPSUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net earnings for the four months ended April 30, 1986, of $49,561,000. c-National Gypsum was acquired by Aancor Holdings Inc., effective April 29, 1986, and as a result of this transaction, which included new interest charges, and non-cash charges to earnings, net earnings for 1985 are not comparable and, therefore, have not been included.

title: A SHOW EXPLORES ANCIENT HIGH-RISES OF CHACO
description: THEIR civilization clearly lacked the wealth and splendor of the Inca and Maya far to the south, but the Anasazi had a distinctive quality: an unusual penchant for urban living and an impressive talent for building apartment complexes larger and taller than anything that existed in North America prior to the Industrial Revolution. This Anasazi culture reached full flower 1,000 years ago at Chaco Canyon in northwestern New Mexico.

title: POWER STRUGGLE ON SAVANNAH SCHOOLS
description: What started out five years ago as a drive to improve the public school system in this quiet coastal city and its surrounding county has erupted into a confrontation between white economic power and black political power.

title: POP-JAZZ GUIDE
description: ''Second Species,'' R.A.P.P. Theater, 220 East Fourth Street (254-1109). This experimental ''opera,'' conceived and directed by Keith King with new music and musical adaptation by Skip LaPlante, is set a millennium from today. The piece imagines a desolate world whose inhabitants have turned scraps of librettos, tapes, programs and photographs of opera into sacred cultural icons. It depicts the annual rites of this future world in which the people reconstruct what they think opera looked and sounded like. ''Second Species'' is hilarious as it portrays operatic customs solemnly misinterpreted and satirizes the fetishism that already surrounds the world of opera. Shows are at 8 P.M. Thursday through Sunday; tickets are $8.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday ALL-WORLD ANTIQUES

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about automobile sales gave incorrect results for three producers. Honda sold 27,851 cars in the United States in February, up 90.3 percent from February 1986; Volkswagen sold 3,808 cars, down 35.1 percent, and American Motors was down 61 percent, to 2,501 cars.

title: JUSTIN S. DUNN
description: Justin S. Dunn, former president and chief executive officer of E. W. Axe & Company, now Axe Houghton Management, an investment company in Tarrytown, N.Y., died Tuesday at his home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., after a brief illness. He was 92 years old.

title: CANDIDATE'S ONE VOTE COSTS CHICAGO DEARLY
description: The Board of Election Commissioners' final canvass of the Chicago mayoral election, released Tuesday, revealed that a third-party candidate, John R. Bilski, received just one vote in the Illinois Solidarity Party's primary. Mr. Bilski lost to Alderman Edward R. Vrdolyak, who got 3,911 votes.

title: WALSH STATUS CHANGED TO UNDERCUT CHALLENGE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d announced today that he had appointed Lawrence E. Walsh, the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, as an independent officer of the Justice Department.

title: SCITEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FILM: 'WAITING FOR MOON'
description: ''WAITING FOR THE MOON'' plays touch and go with the relationship of Gertrude Stein and Alice B. Toklas, the famous pair who knew everybody who was anybody or likely to become somebody in avant-garde Paris in the 1920's and 30's. The script by Mark Magill offers snatches of a few days in 1936, out of order in an attempt perhaps to suggest the spirit of Stein's own ''Cubist'' writings. But whenever the movie, which opens today at Cinema Studio 1, threatens to touch on anything serious, it goes off to something else.

title: Pedestrian Traffic Deaths Show Sharp Decline in New York City
description: The number of pedestrians killed in traffic accidents in New York City dropped last year to its lowest level since 1912, in part the result of changes in road engineering and increased enforcement programs, the City Department of Transportation said yesterday.

title: PLASTER MODEL CALLED A LOST MICHELANGELO
description: An eight-inch plaster model believed to have been used by Michelangelo to make his sculpture of David, the monumental statue in Florence that is among the world's most famous works of art, has been discovered after having been lost for nearly 300 years, a leading Renaissance scholar said yesterday.

title: CONCERT: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC
description: THERE have always been pieces of music in which nothing significant happens because an inept composer is unable to make anything happen. Of late, some composers have been making successful careers by purposely writing pieces in which little or nothing happens. For the sake of categorical tidiness, composers of the latter type have been known as Minimalists, though not all of them accept the title. Some, perhaps recognizing a dead end when they hear one, have tried to move beyond the numbingly simple repetitiveness that characterized many early Minimalist scores. Mr. Adams, whose ''Harmonielehre'' was performed last evening by the New York Philharmonic under Leonard Slatkin's direction, is reputed to be one of the movers, even though at times one would have been hard pressed to notice movement of any sort in this 40-minute, three-movement work.

title: ROSTENKOWSKI BACKS TAX RISE IDEA
description: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said today that he and his panel would support tax increases to reduce the budget deficit.

title: KODAK BUYS 18.7% OF ENZON'S SHARES
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it had acquired an 18.7 percent stake in Enzon Inc., a pharmaceutical company specializing in protein therapy, for $13 million. As part of the deal, Kodak said it provided Enzon with a $2 million loan. Kodak also bought worldwide marketing rights for three PEG-enzymes used to treat various illnesses. These drugs are in the initial stages of approval by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: SARAH CONNELL
description: Sarah Connell, a social worker and former New York City regional director for the State Office of Mental Health, died of cancer Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 56 years old.

title: Pole, in U.S., Looking To Exchange of Envoys
description: A visiting high Polish official said today that he was confident the United States and Poland would soon exchange ambassadors as part of a continuing normalization of relations.

title: FRENCH, FINDING ARMS, ARREST 7
description: The security police have arrested seven people after the discovery of more than 30 pounds of explosives, two machine guns and a pistol in the cellar of a building in the 16th Arrondissement of Paris, the Interior Ministry announced today.

title: FOR BLACK-RULED COUNTRIES, SOUTH AFRICA IS BOTH LIFELINE AND MORTAL THREAT
description: The gunfire and the burning tires may be out of sight and hearing, but the upheavals in South Africa send menacing shock waves far beyond its northern borders.

title: CHEMLAWN REJECTS TAKEOVER OFFER
description: The Chemlawn Corporation rejected today a $27-a-share unsolicted offer, valued at $270 million, from Waste Management Inc. and urged shareholders not to tender shares. But Jack Van Fossen, Chemlawn's chairman and chief executive, said the company's board instructed its financial advisers to seek other buyers. Officials at Chemlawn, the nation's largest lawn-care company, would not elaborate.

title: DEMOCRATS' ECONOMIC DOUBT
description: The nation's economy has been growing on borrowed money for five years and is in a precarious position, with few options for the Government in case of a downturn, the Democratic majority of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress said today.

title: To Deny the Humanity of the Fetus Is Also a Lie
description: To the Editor:

title: Bystander Wounded On Park Avenue
description: A bystander was shot and wounded outside a Park Avenue office building yesterday afternoon by an unidentifed gunman who the police said was aiming at another man with whom he had argued for no apparent reason.

title: WHAT IS THE VALUE OF AN OLD TOKEN? STILL $1, JUDGE SAYS
description: Somewhere out there, in pants pockets, purses and bureau drawers, are as many as 10 million brass subway tokens that were never redeemed when the New York City Transit Authority introduced new tokens last year. The new magnetized turnstile system that was installed then does not accept the old tokens, and the Transit Authority will no longer exchange them.

title: PRUDENTIAL-BACHE SECURIIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $25 million to expand its investment banking and capital markets activities.

title: ACCOUNTS
description: * Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company to Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis, for a new personal care product.

title: THE WAR ON DRUGS BEGINS
description: THE nation's advertising and media communities and many of their suppliers have been working for months on a gigantic, unprecedented advertising campaign to unsell illegal drugs. Yesterday, they disclosed their plans as the campaign was about to break in donated time and space on TV, radio, billboards, newspapers and magazines.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It didn't take me more than a minute before I realized what this had to be. I started to tremble, the discovery was so great.

title: Eager to Return
description: Chris Washburn, the Golden State Warrior forward whose rookie season has been interrupted by drug treatment, is eager to return to the National Basketball Association, according to Coach George Karl, who visited Washburn in a drug treatment center recently. No date has been set, however, for Washburn's release from the center in Van Nuys, Calif., which he entered Jan. 28 after seeking the team's help to treat his cocaine abuse problem.

title: Gotti's Attorney Attacks Actions Of Prosecutors
description: John Gotti's attorney told a Federal jury yesterday that prosecutors had resorted to ''dirt'' and perjured testimony because they could not offer ''a scintilla of evidence'' to support racketeering charges against his client.

title: NEW MCI STRATEGY: DEREGULATE A.T.&T.
description: The MCI Communications Corporation yesterday called for full deregulation of its chief long-distance competitor, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which has been forced by the Government to cut its rates drastically.

title: A $17.3 Million Bally Charge Is Set
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation disclosed that it would take a $17.3 million charge against its first-quarter earnings because of its recent agreement to repurchase, at a premium, Donald J. Trump's 9.9 percent stake in the Chicago-based hotel-casino chain. The repurchase ended a three-month standoff between Mr. Trump and Bally, and earned the New York real estate developer a reported $34 million profit.

title: DEFENSE REBUTTAL BARRED
description: Six and a half months after the trial began, the case against John Gotti and six other reputed mob figures went to the jury yesterday with prosecutors charging that the defendants had substituted ''the rule of force and violence'' for the rule of law.

title: Pitt 96 Seton Hall 88
description: At the cruelest point of the basketball year, when teams are defined as winners or losers, Pat Cavanaugh said he had not heard his teammates talk of the recent basketball disappointments at Pitt.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The President accepts the report. And Mr. Shultz and Mr. Weinberger can speak for themselves in terms of their view of the report. They're grown men. They can say whatever they want.'' - Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. [ 8:1. ]

title: SYRACUSE AND PITT STRUGGLE TO ADVANCE
description: Syracuse and Pittsburgh will meet, as expected, in one of two semifinal games in the Big East tournament tonight, but the Orange nearly missed the party.

title: Drug Ambush in Peru Jungle
description: A policeman was killed and 20 people, including a general, were wounded in an attack by drug traffickers Thursday at an airport in the Peruvian jungle, police sources said today. The smugglers reportedly attacked as the police were boarding a helicopter at Tocache, in the cocaine-producing area of Huallaga, 280 miles northeast of Lima.

title: IN SEARCH OF VERSATILE MUSEUM LEADERS
description: Eighteen of the country's leading art museums are seeking new directors, a fact that reflects tremendous growth, mounting financial pressures and other fundamental changes in the art-museum field.

title: U.S. REJECTS ICAHN'S BID FOR USAIR
description: The Government dealt a significant setback yesterday to Carl C. Icahn's attempt to gain control of USAir Group Inc.

title: CHRISTIAN MILITIAS IN BEIRUT URGED TO CEDE ROLE TO ARMY
description: The deployment of Syrian troops in the Moslem part of Beirut has increased pressure in the Christian sector for militiamen to turn their positions over to the Lebanese Army.

title: DANCE JUDITH GARAY
description: Some dances seem to have been driven into being by the press of ideas about music or movement. Occasionally, dances look as if they have been created to satisfy their creators' desire to get out on a stage. Neither of those urges seemed behind the new and recent dances by Judith Garay that were presented on Thursday at Theater of the Riverside Church. Indeed, it was hard to imagine why the dances had come into being.

title: Study Urges That the Elderly Be Allowed to Donate Blood
description: It is safe for people over 65 years of age to donate blood, and more and more may be asked to donate blood as the United States population ages, a study has found.

title: More Prizes Would Improve New York's Lotto
description: To the Editor:

title: ELXSI LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Report on Drug Tests
description: One player reportedly tested positive for cocaine and six others for marijuana during the National Football League's annual examination of prospective rookies in January. Players this year were tested for the first time for steroids, and 20 reportedly showed traces of the body-building substances in their systems. Last year, 54 former college players showed traces of marijuana and three showed traces of cocaine. An N.F.L. spokesman, Joe Browne, said the league would have no comment on a story in The Dallas Morning News on the results of the testing, which took place in Indianapolis the week following the Super Bowl. The post-Super Bowl testing session has become an important predraft yardstick for coaches and scouts. This year, tests for steroids were added and will also be conducted for all players at the physical before training camp. Under the agreement with the N.F.L. Players Association, that is the only drug testing allowed, although teams are permitted to test a player if they have reason to believe he may be using drugs. The N.F.L. frowns on use of steroids, though it has no official sanctions against those who use them.

title: A Credit to the Nursery School
description: It is a well-documented fact that winning a place in Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum is only slightly more difficult than winning one in a top New York nursery school.

title: It's Not a Simple Matter To Be a Blood Donor
description: To the Editor:

title: Assembly Seat Vote Ordered
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday ordered a special election April 7 to fill the Assembly seat vacated when Armand P. D'Amato, Republican of Island Park, L.I., resigned last month. Mr. D'Amato, 42 years old, is the brother of United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. He resigned Feb. 23 after 15 years as an Assemblyman from Nassau County, saying he wanted to devote more time to his law practice in Mineola and to his family. The former Assemblyman was re-elected for a seventh time last November, defeating Jonathan Farber, a Democrat, 18,662 to 11,190.

title: FILIPINO REBELS, 'OUT TO WIN,' ARE ON OFFENSIVE, LEADER SAYS
description: Communist rebels do not plan to return to the negotiating table in the near future and have begun a program of increasing violence, one of their leaders says.

title: ARUNDEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,517,000 and $3,011,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $1,644,000 for the quarter and $2,059,000 for the year.

title: METEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
YANKEES BEAT THE RAIN AND THE BRAVES
description: Chuck Tanner looked into the darkened skies today, pushed his hands into the pockets of an Atlanta Braves jacket for warmth, then offered a typical smile.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Pretoria Says Its Police Killed 716 Last Year
description: Police officers shot to death 716 people, including 92 juveniles, last year, the Minister of Law and Order, Adriaan Vlok, said today.

title: Offer Opposed By San Miguel
description: The San Miguel Corporation, the giant beer and food distributor in the Philippines, opposes any acquisition attempt by the New York investment bank Allen & Company Inc., a San Miguel executive said today.

title: HEART ILLS HIGHER IN BLACK DOCTORS
description: A study of heart disease in black and white physicians has found that the rate of heart attacks among the black doctors was 10 times that of the whites.

title: ROTECH MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Sabres Obtain Napier
description: Trailing Quebec by 2 points for the final playoff spot in the Adams Division on the eve of a home-and-home series, the Buffalo Sabres reached out for experience yesterday by obtaining Mark Napier, a 30-year-old right wing, and Lee Fogolin, a 32-year-old defenseman from the Edmonton Oilers. In return, the Sabres sent a pair of young right wings, Norm Lacombe, and Wayne Van Dorp, a minor leaguer with the American Hockey League's Rochester Americans, to Edmonton. Napier was one of only three Oilers to play all 80 regular-season games in 1985-86. He also played 6 seasons with Montreal and 2 with Minnesota, and had 8 goals and 13 assists in 62 games this season.

title: A No-Lose Hedging Strategy
description: LEAD: As a small investor, I often listen with glazing eyes to the sell-righteous market strategies of other small investors.

title: Cubs Get Dawson For $650,000
description: Andre Dawson, one of eight premier free agents who have gone without jobs and virtually without offers, told the Chicago Cubs earlier this week he would sign a contract for any salary they named. Dawson's lawyer, Richard Moss, said today that the Cubs had accepted that offer and named a salary of $650,000, with $500,000 of it guaranteed.

title: Dow Adds 3.80 Points, To 2,280.23
description: Stock prices were mixed in a slower session yesterday, but the Dow Jones industrial average still managed to inch ahead to another record.

title: MINISERIES REDEEMED BY RAT
description: By Wednesday night I was in agonies of suspense about the fate of Cutter Amberville. Would his worthless family drive a stake through his heart in that night's installment of ''I'll Take Manhattan'' or would he survive to sneer again?

title: FAIRMOUNT CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Brown Says He Doubts 'Star Wars' Schedule
description: The United States could not deploy a simple, ground-based ''Star Wars'' antimissile system until at least 1996 and a space-based system was unlikely this century, former Defense Secretary Harold Brown said today.

title: STATE MIGHT REDUCE CHARGES ON HOWARD BEACH WITNESS
description: The special prosecutor in the racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens, indicated yesterday that he was considering allowing Robert D. Riley, who is charged with murder in the attack, to plead guilty to a lesser charge in exchange for his testimony.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Fate of 15,000 Unwanted Cambodians Who Can't Go Home
description: To the Editor:

title: WARRANTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: MUSIC: LI'L QUEENIE SINGS
description: WHEN she made a first foray into New York in 1980, the New Orleans rock singer Leigh Harris, better known as Li'l Queenie, was compared to Janis Joplin. At Tramps on Tuesday, she had earned the comparison, punching out phrases with Joplin's timing and making notes rasp and slide with Joplin's gutsy tone. She has also laid claim to the New Orleans heritage of rhythm-and-blues with a Mardi Gras beat - and since Tuesday was Mardi Gras, she performed in a glittery costume with a feathered headdress.

title: TRENWICK GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $1,541,000 and $1,865,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a tax credit of $728,000 and a charge of $8.5 million related to an increase in reserves and a GAAP underwriting loss of $8,735,000. c-Includes realized investment gains of $301,000 and $1,424,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a tax credit of $378,000.

title: CETEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $384,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,936,000 and $2,361,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Metro-North Worker Testifies at Hearing
description: The engineer of a Metro-North Commuter Railroad train that struck another of the line's trains in the Bronx last month told a state safety board yesterday that he could not recall passing a red signal before the crash.

title: FILES FROM CONTRAS' BANKS SHOW PAYMENTS DURING BAN
description: An official of the Nicaraguan rebels allowed several reporters to examine detailed bank records today that showed payments by his group of more than $16 million to American brokers for weapons during a Congressional ban on direct American military aid.

title: The Fate of 15,000 Unwanted Cambodians Who Can't Go Home; Humane Relocation
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Hold Transit Hostage
description: Democrats and Republicans in Albany vie for the honor of proposing the bigger income tax cut, while Governor Cuomo and Comptroller Regan peddle moderation. The deadlock claims an inadvertent hostage: the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. As long as funding for the M.T.A.'s five-year modernization plan remains linked to the overall tax debate, the program, vital to the metropolitan area's future, sits on a sidetrack.

title: U.S.JOBLESS RATE IS STEADY AT 6.6%
description: The economy continued to create large numbers of new jobs last month, although not enough to push the unemployment rate below the 6.6 percent that has prevailed since December, the Labor Department reported today.

title: ABRAMS UNDER FIRE AT SENATE HEARING
description: Elliott Abrams came to testify before a Senate committee today on a new peace plan for Central America but became embroiled in questions about his role in the Iran-contra affair and charges that he hounded a respected diplomat out of the Foreign Service.

title: In Judge Hand's Own Words
description: Following are excerpts from the textbook ruling:

title: American Can Picks a Name
description: The American Can Company said yesterday that it plans to change its name to the Primerica Corporation.

title: ROCKY MOUNTAIN MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company has been publicly traded since April 1986.

title: WHITE HOUSE BACKS PANEL'S CRITICISM
description: The White House today reaffirmed President Reagan's support of a Presidential review board's report, including its criticism of how Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger handled the Iran arms affair.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. 76ers 123, Bullets 113: In Philadelphia, Cliff Robinson, playing in his first game since Feb. 23, scored 26 points last night to lead the 76ers. Robinson, who has been troubled by an eye infection, had missed 13 of the last 14 games, but led Philadelphia to its first victory over Washington in three meetings this season. (AP) Celtics 132, Clippers 111: Kevin McHale scored 35 points as the Celtics, playing without Larry Bird, rolled to a victory in Boston. Bird didn't report to the Boston Garden after suffering a lower back sprain a few hours before the game at home. But a reserve forward, Fred Roberts, filled in with a 17-point effort. (AP) Pistons 125, Mavericks 115: Vinnie Johnson scored a season-high 28 points and Bill Laimbeer added 24 as Detroit overcame an 11-point halftime deficit for the victory in Pontiac, Mich. The Pistons, ending a three-game losing streak, took control during the final 7:25 of the third quarter. They outscored the Mavericks, 20-4, over that stretch to turn a 77-66 deficit into an 86-81 lead after three quarters. (AP) GOLF Langer Takes 2-Shot Lead: Bernhard Langer, who double-hit his ball with one stroke on a wedge shot in his round Thursday, hit his ball only once on each of his 67 strokes yesterday as he finished with a five-under-par round that gave him a two-shot lead after 36 holes of the $600,000 Honda Classic in Coral Springs, Fla. The 29-year-old West German's score of 137 was seven shots under par on the Tournament Players Club course at Eagle Trace. HORSE RACING Northern Maiden Wins: Northern Maiden took command midway on the far turn and went on to a one-length victory yesterday in the allowance feature for fillies and mares at Aqueduct. The rider of the runner-up, Flantasia, filed a claim of interference by Northern Maiden in midstretch but the claim was disallowed by the stewards. Northern Maiden covered a mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in 1:45 under Robbie Davis to score her second victory in three starts this year. Hialeah Meeting Ends: Hialeah ended its 50-day meeting with a record parimutuel handle of just over $100 million.
