Woody Stephens took down the final stakes race of the meeting when he sent out Lotka to a dramatic victory over Fama and Bonne Ile in the $175,000-added Black Helen Handicap. Lotka, a 4-year-old daughter of Danzig and Kennelot, was avenging a narrow loss to Bonne Ile in the Hialeah Breeders' Cup Feb. 22. Lotka rallied furiously through the stretch to run down Fama, a 23-1 shot who had led from the start, while carrying top weight of 121 pounds and covered the mile and a half on the grass in 1:46 4/5 under Eddie Maple. TENNIS Lendl-Connors Postponed: Winds gusting to gale force and a late afternoon rain shower yesterday forced the suspension of the men's semifinal match between Ivan Lendl and Jimmy Connors in the Lipton International Players Championships at Key Biscayne, Fla. The evening semifinal between Yannick Noah of France and Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia was also postponed until today, when the women's final between Chris Evert Lloyd and Steffi Graf of West Germany will be played.

title: ON LONG ISLAND, SOME BEGIN TO FEEL THE FIGHT HAS BEEN LOST
description: Surrounded by fallen utility cables, Steven Meger recently leaned over a fence that blocked a section of Dune Road devastated by erosion.

title: Hialeah to Appeal Dates
description: John J. Brunetti, president of Hialeah Park, announced today that he would appeal through the courts and seek statewide legislation in an attempt to reverse the allotment of unfavorable racing dates for next season that has threatened the track's future.

title: SKI LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
TANGLEWOOD AT 50, PLANS 4-YEAR PARTY
description: The Tanglewood Music Festival began 50 years ago this summer, when Serge Koussevitzky led the Boston Symphony Orchestra in a program of music on the grounds of a magnificent estate in Lenox, Mass.

title: TPA OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said results are not comparable with 1985 periods because the company was formed in June 1985 and did not have meaningful operations until the acquisition of American Benefit Plan Administrators in August 1985; the company also said it changed its fiscal year to end Dec. 31 instead of Nov. 30.

title: British Bid in Japan
description: The British Government is worried that Cable and Wireless P.L.C. could be barred from participating in Japan's lucrative telecommunications business, a British official said today. Cable and Wireless owns 20 percent of International Digital Communications Planning, which along with International Telecom Japan seeks to compete against the former monopoly, Kokushin Denshin Denwa.

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the results include charges relating to litigation of $113,000 and $691,000 for the latest quarter and year, respectively, and $228,000 for the prior quarter and $498,000 for the prior year.

title: DOLE CAMP IS PRESSING EFFOR TO OUTFLANK BUSH
description: In the face of Vice President Bush's political difficulties as a result of the Iran arms affair, Senator Bob Dole is moving aggressively and rapidly to build a Presidential campaign organization and gather Republican support across the nation.

title: SMALL JERSEY TOWN WORRIES ABOUT THE PCB'S IN ITS WELLS
description: To Bill Kiriluk, the news that his well was contaminated with PCB's made him wonder if that was why his cows had been drinking from a muddy spring rather than from clear - but possibly tainted - Axelauken Creek.

title: High Post for Tampa Black
description: A major who already was Tampa's highest-ranked black policeman has been promoted to colonel of police operations, in charge of all uniformed officers in the racially tense city. Curtis Lane, 43 years old, was placed in charge of 469 uniformed officers as part of a restructuring plan announced Thursday. The changes follow racial disturbances set off by the death of a young black man after a white police officer used a choke-hold to arrest him.

title: Bid to Increase Fairchild Stake
description: A Fairchild Industries Inc. shareholder group said today that it was considering buying up just under half of the company's stock because management had been unsuccessful in enhancing shareholder values.

title: TV: 'LOUIS RUKEYSER'S 1987 INVESTMENT GUIDE'
description: Louis Rukeyser, who usually appears as the genial host of ''Wall Street Week,'' hedges today. In ''Louis Rukeyser's 1987 Investment Guide,'' on Channel 13 at 1 P.M., he says he'll put us on our ''personal road to riches.'' He doesn't really do that, however; he's only wishing us a pleasant trip. Exactly how one gets rich, or goes broke, is still cloudy.

title: Contras Claim to Down A Government Copter
description: A spokesman for the Nicaraguan rebels said here tonight that his comrades in Nicaragua had shot down the second Soviet-made helicopter in 10 days manned by the Government forces.

title: SOVIET AIDE SEES ARMS PACT BY SUMMER
description: The chief Soviet arms negotiator said today that he believed that the United States and the Soviet Union would agree by the summer to eliminate their medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe.

title: Foreign Flowers Are Clipping the U.S. Market
description: To the Editor:

title: HYPONEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PEGASUS GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are reported in U.S. funds, and company is also listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: THE ORDEAL CONTINUES
description: Despite the Tower commission report, the popular appointment of Howard Baker to be White House chief of staff and Ronald Reagan's artfully crafted and delivered speech, the President's ordeal by investigation is by no means over.

title: Test College Athletes for Drugs, Later
description: Simone LeVant is someone to admire. Rather than submit to a rule she believed unjust, she nearly forfeited her last season on the Stanford women's diving team. Her resistance was the more admirable because she was the only one among 15,000 college athletes in the country to fight the rule. Despite all that, Ms. LeVant is only half right.

title: PANEL NAMED IN CAPTIAL TO SEEK WAYS TO END AMTRAK SUBSIDY
description: The Reagan Administration today renewed its efforts to get rid of Amtrak.

title: COGHLAN FALLS, FAILS TO QUALIFY
description: The impossible happened today. Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland, the world's fastest, best and most celebrated indoor miler, fell in his 1,500-meter heat on the first day of the first world indoor track and field championships. As a result, he failed to qualify for the final by an inch or so.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for 13wks to Jan 31
description: b-Includes pretax LIFO charges of $6,484,000 and $13,516,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes pretax LIFO charges of $3,538,000 for the quarter and $15,962,000 for the year. The company said the elimination of investment tax credits reduced its earnings by 26 cents a share in the latest year; and the net for the latest year was also hurt by the establishment of reserves for certain reorganization expenses of 15 cents a share.

title: TV: BABY VANISHES IN 'DEADLY DECEPTION'
description: ''Deadly Deception'' is melodrama, occasionally unpleasant, vaguely depressing, only fitfully interesting. The two-hour CBS movie, at 9 P.M. Sunday, is about the disappearance of a baby. First, however, the baby's mother is hanged. This is cheerless stuff.

title: U.S. TRUCK LINES INC OF DELAWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $1,200,000 for the settlement of certain litigation. c-Net income

title: Freshman Nominee
description: In the seven-year history of the Hobey Baker Award for the outstanding collegiate hockey player, Brian Leetch, a Boston College defenseman, is the first freshman ever nominated among the 10 finalists yesterday. Leetch, a native of Cheshire, Conn., scored 8 goals and had 32 assists in 32 games this season. Boston College also had one of the two sophomores nominated, the forward Craig Janney. The other sophomore was Tony Hrkac, a center for North Dakota. Others nominated were Lane McDonald, Harvard forward: Joe Nieuwendyk, Cornell center; Tom Sasso, Babson center; John Cullen, Boston University center; Gary Emmons, Northern Michigan center; Tony Granato, Wisconsin center; and Wayne Gagne, Western Michigan defenseman. The winner will be named at the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey championships March 27.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption last Saturday on an Associated Press picture of a memorial service for Henry John Heinz 2d misstated Drue Heinz's relationship to Senator John Heinz of Pennsylvania.

title: INSIDE
description: Tower Report Reaffirmed The White House reaffirmed President Reagan's support of the report on the Iran affair, including criticism of two Cabinet officers. Page 8.

title: Bridge; Pairs Champions Crowned In North American Events
description: When the Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began here this afternoon, two events had already been concluded.

title:
PATENTS;
Viewer Reaction to Ads On TV Is Monitored
description: LEAD: A method of testing television commercials by monitoring the reactions of viewers was patented this week by Lee S. Weinblatt, president of the Pretesting Company of Englewood, N.J. He reports that the procedure is being used by the company in 20 locations in the United States and 7 abroad.

title: Smith Hits Tyson Image
description: On the billboards and in the print advertisements for his fight Saturday night against James (Bonecrusher) Smith, Mike Tyson is depicted as a man forged in iron. And lest the graphics fail a viewer's grasp, there's a caption: ''Your grandfather wished he'd seen Dempsey. Your father wished he'd seen Marciano. Don't you miss Iron Mike Tyson, March 7, at the Las Vegas Hilton.'' If Tyson, the 20-year-old World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, is as mythic as the trumpeted words say, then you could surely fool Smith.

title: 14 REPORTERS AMONG 215 CUT BY CBS
description: More than 215 people, including 14 on-air reporters, were dismissed from their jobs by CBS News yesterday in the most severe cutback ever sustained by the news organization.

title: SILVER STATE MINING CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on Feb. 27 with the text of the Tower Commission report carried an erroneous description issued by the commission for a diagram sketched on the bottom of a letter from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's secretary, Fawn Hall. A spokesman for the commission now says it may have been mistaken in attributing the diagram to Colonel North. The spokesman said the commission does not know who sketched the diagram.

title: SHULTZ PLANS TRIP TO SOVIET IN APRIL, WHITE HOUSE SAYS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will go to Moscow in mid-April to hold talks with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union, the White House announced today.

title: BUSH, IN IOWA, CALLS CONTROVERSY ON IRAN JUST AN 'ABERRATION'
description: On the second day of a campaign swing in Iowa, Vice President Bush fielded 14 questions this morning from 300 Republicans at a town hall style of meeting in Mason City.

title: HMO AMERICA INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,467,572 from a tax benefit. c-Net income

title: Dome Pressed To Sell Encor
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., burdened with debt of more than $6.1 billion, or $4.6 billion (United States), is being pressed by a large creditor to sell a 42 percent stake in the Encor Energy Corporation in order to repay some loans, energy industry analysts said. Dome has pledged its 42.5 million Encor shares as security for part of its debt to the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, estimated last year at $947 million, or $710 million in United States currency. The bank wants Dome to sell the stock to pay down debt, analysts said.

title: STATE DEPARTMENT REVIEW PANEL IS GIVEN PHOTOS IN SECURITY BREACH
description: The State Department's Bureau of Diplomatic Security has taken into custody the color slides of photographs reproduced in The Foreign Service Journal showing an open copy of one of the Government's most sensitive intelligence documents.

title: WASHINGTON REAL ESTATE INESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized gains on real estate of $1,438,988 and $3,771,479 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: SELECTERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the fourth-quarter loss was due to federal income taxes resulting from elimination of the investment tax credit.

title: CENTRAL SPRINKLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NEW VIOLENCE SEEN IN USERS OF COCAINE
description: In New York and other cities where crack use has become widespread, the police and drug treatment experts say they are being confronted by an increasing number of cases of violent, erratic and paranoid behavior among heavy cocaine users, and the growing appearance of a condition known as cocaine psychosis.

title: EDDIE DURHAM, TROMBONIST
description: Eddie Durham, a jazz trombonist and electric guitarist who played and composed for the Jimmie Lunceford and Count Basie Orchestras in the 1930's, died yesterday as a result of a fall at his daughter's house in Brooklyn. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Taking Action on Radioactive-Waste Trenches
description: To the Editor:

title: Rudolf Hess Is Hospitalized, Reportedly With Pneumonia
description: Rudolf Hess, the 92-year-old former Hitler deputy who occupies Spandau Prison alone, has been taken to a British military hospital with pneumonia, the family lawyer said today.

title: THE BOOM IN ALL-SUITE HOTELS
description: After 25 years in the apartment hotel business, the Denihan family decided in 1985 to shed that dowdy image by becoming Manhattan East Suite Hotels. In doing so, they repositioned themselves into what has become a hot trend in hotel circles - the all-suite hotel.

title: CALPROP CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1985 share earnings for both quarter and the year have been restated to reflect the payment of a 10 percent stock dividend.

title: BATTLE TO SAVE JERSEY SHORE PITS NATURE AGAINST THE STATE
description: The inexorable erosion of New Jersey beaches is permanently changing the state's coastline and forcing local officials, environmental experts and legislators into a quandary.

title: GENTEX CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
DEL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shares earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid March 26, 1986.

title: WILKINS PACES KNICKS
description: Just before the Knicks faced the Chicago Bulls tonight, Gerald Wilkins thanked his teammates for the support they have shown him during his recent torrid scoring run. Then he thanked them in a manner they won't likely forget.

title: HADSON CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a writedown of oil and gas properties of $12,515,000 for the quarter and year; the year also includes a net gain of $15,523,000 on the sale of foreign properties.

title: KEY RATES
CENCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $583,000 from extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and year. c-Net income The company said that during the latest quarter, it incurred additional after-tax expenses and losses of about $900,000 caused by one of its fitness center chains experiencing financial difficulties that subsequently led to it filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code.

title: NEW GARDEN: CORNUCOPIA OF THE PAST
description: News of the Promised Land seems best rooted in something old, such as the disclosure this week that this land of milk and honey is running short of honey and has begun importing it.

title: Chip Index Shows a Gain
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator improved for the fifth consecutive month, a trade group reported today, as chip makers in the United States, Europe and Japan reported modest increases in orders and shipments.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Lucky Stores Sees End to Edelman Bid
description: LEAD: Lucky Stores Inc. said today that it had reached a standstill agreement with Asher B. Edelman, apparently ending the New York investor's protracted bid for control of the supermarket company.

title: NEW DATA SHOW EVEREST MAY TAKE SECOND PLACE
description: New calculations based on American satellite measurements indicate that the Himalayan peak K-2 may be the highest mountain in the world, a few feet higher than Mount Everest.

title: WAKE FOREST UPSETS CLEMSON
description: ATLANTIC COAST

title: IN BLACK NEIGHBORHOODS, WORRISOME 'GENDER GAP'
description: Poor black neighborhoods in New York City house considerably fewer men than women, a new report says, and, along with quantifying the gap, it points up an alarming demographic trend - the disappearance of working-aged black men from the census roles.

title: Contact Lenses and Makeup
description: IT'S fine to have stars in your eyes, but not mascara, especially if you wear contact lenses. Even a mere flake of mascara is enough to ruin a contact lens. It can also be highly uncomfortable, causing the eyes to turn red and teary. But eye makeup is not the only potential troublemaker. Any cosmetic, soap, perfume or hair spray that gets into the eye will be even more irritating to a contact lens wearer than to anyone else.

title: METRO DATELINES;
description: Liberty Weekend, the four-day extravaganza over the July 4 weekend, produced a deficit of $9.4 million that will have to be made up from money raised by the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, the foundation announced yesterday.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK & TRUST PALM BEACH reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed the decline in earnings primarily to a $12.7 million provision for loan losses in 1986, compared with a $2.4 million provision in 1985.

title: Exxon Euronote Forgeries Found
description: The Exxon Corporation said that forgeries of zero coupon Euronotes due in 2004 had been discovered in London. The original notes were part of a $1.8 billion issue sold in 1984 by the Exxon Capital Corporation through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: ISSUE OF CONSENT UNDER SCRUTINY IN BABY M TRIAL
description: No woman, including Mary Beth Whitehead, can give her ''informed consent'' before birth to surrendering her baby, a psychiatrist testified today in the Baby M custody hearing.

title: Witherspoon Files Suit
description: Although Tim Witherspoon lost his share of the world heavyweight title to James (Bonecrusher) Smith in a knockout last Dec. 12, the former World Boxing Association champion is still battling outside the ring to get it back. Witherspoon has filed a $9 million suit against Don King, the promoter, Jose Torres, the New York State Athletic Commission chairman, and the W.B.A., charging he was forced to accept Smith as a replacement after Tony Tubbs, the original opponent withdrew several days before the fight. The suit makes allegations of conspiracy, breach of contract, and violations of racketeering and civil rights laws, and contends that Witherspoon should have been allowed to advance in a heavyweight tournament to a fight with the World Boxing Council champion, Mike Tyson, who is fighting Smith in Las Vegas tonight.

title: New Liver for Linda Lovelace
description: Linda Lovelace, who starred in the 1972 X-rated movie ''Deep Throat'' and then went on to campaign against pornography, underwent a liver transplant today, a hospital spokeswoman said. The operation at Pittsburgh's Presbyterian University Hospital began late Thursday night and lasted almost 14 hours. Ms. Lovelace, registered as Linda Marchiano, her real name, was listed in critical condition, which is normal for such surgery.

title: MEESE OVERRULED ON NIXON PAPERS
description: A Federal district judge today struck down a Justice Department ruling that would have virtually allowed former President Richard M. Nixon to block publication of documents from the Watergate era that are planned for release in May.

title: HAWKS ROUT BUMBLING NETS
description: The Nets turned the ball over 29 times against Atlanta tonight, with Ray Williams committing as many turnovers, eight, as the entire Hawk team. Those figures were reason enough for the Nets' embarrassing 111-83 loss, but they weren't the only reasons.

title: JUDGE WHO BANNED TEXTBOOKS: HERO OF THE RIGHT
description: Federal District Judge W. Brevard Hand of Mobile, Ala., had already become a hero to the religious right and a source of amazement in legal circles before his decision Wednesday to ban more than 40 textbooks from Alabama's public schools.

title:
PATENTS;
Cell Culture May Aid In Cancer Detection
description: LEAD: New agents for detecting and treating cancer and other diseases may result from a cell culture patented this week by Roy E. Ritts Jr., an immunologist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. Mr. Ritts received patent 4,647,535 for a special cell line that can produce antibodies against disease.

title: Funds Given for Refugee Aid
description: Clinton County received $177,000 today from Governor Cuomo for emergency care for Central American refugees awaiting sanctuary in Canada. About 150 refugees are stranded in Plattsburgh, 30 miles south of the Canadian border, because of new immigration laws in both countries. The United States immigration law provides tougher penalties for employers who hire illegal aliens, and Canadian officials now require a hearing for entry. The money, from the State Department of Social Services, would be used for food, shelter and other services, the county officials said.

title: BUSH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the share net results do not reflect the 3-for-2 stock split paid Feb. 5.

title: JAZZ: RODITI AND GILBERTO
description: Baden Powell, the Brazilian guitarist who was to make his New York club debut this week at the Blue Note, was not able to appear, but the Brazilian atmosphere was maintained by Claudio Roditi and the Brazilian Express and Astrud Gilberto.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-6 A British ferry rolled on its side after leaving a Belgian port on the North Sea. About 300 of the more than 500 people on board were reported rescued, and an undetermined number were trapped inside. Page 1 In Zeebrugge, signs of a catastrophe were everywhere, as policemen and emergency workers scrambled to cope with the British ferry disaster in the Belgian port. 1 George Shultz will go to Moscow in April to discuss a proposed treaty on medium-range arms, a possible summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev and other Soviet-American issues. 1 The chief Soviet arms negotiator said he believed the United States and the Soviet Union would agree by the summer to eliminate their medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe. 5 Body-builders in a Moscow suburb have become a sensation since a weekly magazine asserted that a fearsome gang of teen-age vigilantes had arisen from the suburb's underground weight-lifting rooms. 1 A pledge to democratize South Korea was reaffirmed by President Chun Doo Hwan after being pressed by Secretary of State George Shultz. He pledged to hold free elections and leave office next February. 3 Philippine rebels will not negotiate soon and have begun to increase the level of violence, one of the leaders said. She said she thought the President had for now lost a chance for a peaceful breakthrough. 2 Bank records of Nicaraguan rebels indicate payments of $16 million to U.S. brokers for weapons during a ban on direct military aid and deposits from a Swiss bank account controlled by Oliver North. 8 News analysis: Israel's image in the U.S. has been tarnished by the sentencing of an American for spying for Israel, the indictment of an Israeli Air Force officer on espionage charges and the Iran-contra affair. 4 The deployment of Syrian troops in mainly Moslem West Beirut has increased pressure in the Christian part of the city for militiamen to step aside and turn their positions over to the Lebanese army. 2 A new voice of Peronism is filling Argentine airwaves with a passionate defense of workers' rights. Labor leader Saul Ubaldini is the most visible adversary of President Raul Alfonsin's economic proposals. 3 Jerusalem Journal 4 Israelis press leaders on spy case 4 Security inquiry in Washington 6 NATIONAL 7-10, 28 Changes in economic priorities of the Administration may result from Donald T. Regan's departure as chief of staff, according to Administration and Congressional officials. 1 The President's support of the report by the Tower commission, including its criticism of George P. Shultz and Caspar W. Weinberger, was reaffirmed by the White House. 8 Oliver North filed a second lawsuit against Edwin Meese 3d and the special prosecutor in the Iran-arms affair, charging that the Attorney General could not grant Justice Department powers to the prosecutor. 8 Robert McFarlane's home telephone may have been tapped by a Government intelligence agency after he resigned as President Reagan's national security advisor, intelligence sources said. 8 The judge who banned 35 textbooks in Alabama because he said they unconstitutionally promoted the ''religion of secular humanism'' was already a hero to the religious right for earlier decisions. 7 A Detroit plane crash inquiry is handicapped by the lack of crash recorders on smaller airliners, the National Transportation Safety Board chairman said. The plane, carrying 16 passengers, crashed Wednesday. 7 Bob Dole is building a campaign organization rapidly for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination to take advantage of Vice President Bush's political troubles stemming from the Iran arms affair. 7 George Bush fielded questions at a Republican gathering on the second day of a campaign swing through Iowa. Not one touched on the Iran controversy and the Vice President did little to volunteer anything. 7 Many new jobs were created last month but not enough to push the unemployment rate below 6.6 percent, the Labor Department reported. The figures were stronger than generally expected. 10 Efforts to end Amtrak's subsidies were renewed by the Reagan Administration, as a panel was named to study the matter. Members of Congress and others praised the move but faulted its objectives. 9 A pledge that S.M.U. would obey N.C.A.A. rules was broken by Bill Clements, now the Governor of Texas, when he authorized the continuation of payments to football players, the director of enforcement for the N.C.A.A. charged. 1 A.T.&T. asked Federal authorities to remove earning limits on its long-distance service. It also proposed that it no longer have to prove that changes in long-distance rates are necessary or reasonable. 35 Meese overruled on Nixon papers 7 Everest may take second place 9 REGIONAL 29-32 50 New York prisoners with AIDS have been paroled early because of their disease, according to parole officials. The policy pits the inmates' rights to privacy against the need to protect public health. 1 Violence among cocaine users and a condition known as cocaine psychosis is increasing in New York and other cities where crack use has become widespread, police and drug treatment experts say. 29 New York's housing chief denied that his state agency improperly reduced a backlog of 100,000 tenant-landlord disputes, and discounted allegations that the state's administration of rent laws was in chaos. 31 The PCB-contaminated wells of West Amwell, N.J., have the local residents worried about their health, livestock and property values. Health officials continued to test wells there. 30 Beach erosion in New Jersey is permanently changing the state's coastline, forcing government officials and environmental experts into a quandary and threatening the tourist industry and private investment. 29 Big East tickets scarce 29 Consent at issue in Baby M trial 30 Gotti case goes to jury 31 Deal on charges in racial attack 31 Study cites decline in black men 31

title: About New York; Support Soaring For President In Plywood Poll
description: The plywood President's popularity soared yesterday on the sidewalks of New York.

title: Clemens Leaves Camp
description: Roger Clemens, the American League most valuable player and Cy Young Award winner, cleaned out his locker and left the Boston Red Sox training camp today when the team said it was unilaterally renewing his contract. The Red Sox said the pitcher had rejected a contract offer that could make him ''the highest-paid third-year player in baseball this year.''

title: NEW YORK CITY'S JOBLESS RATE DROPS TO LOWEST IN 12 YEARS
description: A record number of New York and New Jersey residents was employed in 1986, and New York City enjoyed its lowest unemployment rate in 12 years, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: UNITED INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reserves were provided in the latest quarter which resulted in an after- tax charge of about $19.1 million; the reserves were taken to cover future losses from several major projects in the company's defense contractor subsidiary. c-Net income and for the year includes a loss of $616,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $10,558,000 on disposal of discontinued operations. Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend distributed last month.

title: OLD AMERICAN GAME
description: The man was disgruntled, and maybe even very much gruntled. ''College football today is one of the last great strongholds of genuine old-fashioned American hypocrisy,'' he said.

title: 350 ARE SAFE, MANY TRAPPED; 48 REPORTED DEAD
description: A British ferry with more than 500 people aboard capsized Friday night shortly after leaving the Belgian port of Zeebrugge, and the vessel's owners said 48 people were dead and more than 200 missing.

title: 3d Officer Is Charged In Queens Escape
description: The Correction Department charged a third officer yesterday in the escape of three prisoners from a Queens jail last Sunday.

title: Vatican and Hungary Appoint New Primate
description: The Vatican and the Hungarian Government announced today that Archbishop Laszlo Paskai of Kalocsa had been named the new Primate of Hungary.

title: CHARTWELL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes loss on discontinued operations for the quarter, and the year includes a loss from discontinued operations of $243,000 and a tax credit of $600,000. c-Includes loss on discontinued operations for the quarter, and the year includes a loss from discontinued operations of $14,000 and a gain of $611,000 on early extinguishment of debt. The 1985 results are restated to reflect discontinued operations. Share earnings are adjusted for a 100 percent stock dividend to be paid in March 1987.

title: STATE HOUSING CHIEF DENIES CHARGES OF RENT-LAW CHAOS
description: New York State's Housing Commissioner vigorously denied yesterday that his agency improperly reduced a backlog of more than 100,000 tenant-landlord disputes, and discounted allegations that the state's administration of rent laws was in chaos.

title: IN NEW YORK, A PIER IS IN BLOOM
description: Daffodils, primroses, tulips, azaleas, dogwood and forsythia are making it spring at Pier 90 at the foot of 50th Street.

title: Fred Friendly Suggests Pay Cuts at CBS News
description: Fred W. Friendly, the former president of CBS News, said today that the highest-paid CBS employees should volunteer to cut their salaries by a third to avoid making drastic cuts in the network's news budget.

title: KEANE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SECOND NORTH SUIT ASSAILS ADMINISTRATION ROLE FOR PROSECUTOR
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North filed a second lawsuit today against Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the special prosecutor in the Iran arms affair, charging that Mr. Meese had no authority to grant Justice Department powers to the prosecutor.

title: BROWN TRANSPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

PATENTS;
Device to Melt Snow
description: LEAD: A device for melting snow and ice from driveways and sidewalks, patented this week by Essie Erwin Jr. of St. Louis, consists of mats with tubes that carry a warmed mixture of water and antifreeze. The mats, covered by patent 4,646,818, are designed to fit various surfaces and are equipped with valves to regulate the flow.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Poll Finds Civil Court System Fair but Flawed
description: Most Americans believe their civil justice system is fair, but they also think it is too slow and too costly, according to a poll released yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Commencement

title: Interest Rates Rise Broadly
description: Interest rates rose and prices fell across a broad front in the credit markets yesterday, as eagerly awaited unemployment figures proved disappointing to dealers and traders.

title: Bishops Allow Women To Participate in a Rite
description: A ruling by the National Conference of Catholic Bishops permitting women to take part in Holy Thursday foot-washing has won praise from lay women, nuns and priests who last year defied an order banning women from the ritual.

title: A.T.&T. SEEKS TO LIFT CURB ON PROFIT
description: Seeking to eliminate one of the last vestiges of telephone regulation, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company asked Federal authorities yesterday to remove limits on what it can earn from long-distance service.

title: NCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Further Spy Incidents Could Erode Support
description: The sentencing of an American Jew to life imprisonment for spying for Israel, the indictment of an Israeli Air Force officer this week on charges of espionage and the Iran-contra affair have tarnished Israel's image in the United States, in the view of some American officials, Middle East experts and the leaders of American Jewish groups.

title: VIVIGEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $77,264 and $134,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $26,808 and $44,096 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: NEW YORK STATE PAROLES 50 MEN SICK WITH AIDS
description: About 50 New York State prison inmates have been paroled early within the last two years because they have AIDS, parole officials said yesterday.

title: GEORGETOWN GAINS
description: Billy Donovan and his Providence teammates may be past the point of having to prove themselves. But last night, in front of a sellout crowd in Madison Square Garden, Donovan and the Friars played with the relentless tenacity of a team and a player with a serious point to make.

title: PHYSICIANS INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHORTAGE OF DATA IS SAID TO HINDER REVIEW OF CRASH
description: The head of the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday that the investigation into the fatal crash of a regional airliner in Detroit on Wednesday was severely handicapped by the absence of data-recording devices on smaller airliners.

title: BIOTECH RESEARCH LABORATORIESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Tonka Is Buying A Kidde Division
description: The Tonka Corporation said it was buying the Ertl toy manufacturing division of Kidde Inc. for $89.5 million in cash and notes. Stephen G. Shank, Tonka president and chief executive, said in a news release that the agreement was contingent upon a definitive purchase agreement, required board approvals and government filings and waiting periods.

title: SEOUL GIVES SHULTZ A DEMOCRACY VOW
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz was reported today to have won assurances from President Chun Doo Hwan that he would seek a compromise with the opposition on what form an elected government would take.

title: AUTO FERRIES VULNERABLE TO FLOODING
description: The British ferry that capsized off Zeebrugge, Belgium, yesterday must have taken on water far faster than other types of vessels because, like most other car ferries, it lacks bulkheads that would have contained the inrushing sea, a naval engineer from the United States Coast Guard said last night.

title: CLEVITE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $16,869,000 and $16,464,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and an extraordinary credit of $49,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $1,171,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $2,221,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $1,033,000 for the year; and the year also includes an extraordinary gain of $1,195,000. The company said share earnings results for the latest year net from continuing operations are pro forma because the company made an initial public offering in June 1986. For the same reason, there are no share earnings figures for the prior fourth quarter and year.

title: Fraternity Jokers Arrested
description: Twenty police cars on Thursday halted a city bus in which uniformed, apparently armed men were making obscene gestures and apparently pushing passengers. The 32 occupants of the chartered bus were members of Sigma Phi Epsilon at Huntingdon College on their way to a party whose theme was combat. The weapons were plastic. ''It was all a practical joke,'' said Lieut. Tommi Hord. Four students and the bus driver were charged with disorderly conduct.

title: ISRAELIS PRESS LEADERSHIP ON SPY CASE
description: Abba Eban, chairman of the Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee of Parliament, asked Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin today to appear next week to explain why an Israeli Air Force officer indicted in Washington for his part in the Jonathan Jay Pollard espionage case had recently been promoted.

title: A BUYOUT OF REVLON IS STUDIED
description: After insisting for months that he planned to keep the Revlon Corporation publicly owned, Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of the cosmetics concern, said yesterday that he was considering taking it private.

title: THREATS BY HOSTAGE-TAKER RECOUNTED
description: The heavily armed man who held four hostages for 30 hours in an East Harlem apartment threatened repeatedly to shoot them, the authorities said yesterday, and at one point gave the police a five-minute warning before firing and saying he had shot an 18-year-old captive.

title: INTER-CITY GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of $9,344,000 of U.S. oil and gas properties for the quarter and year, and special charges of $793,000 for the quarter and special gains of $1,213,000 for the year. c-After special charges of $4,648,000 for the quarter and special gains of $892,000 for the year.

title: IN PHILADELPHIA, THE PAST IS IN FLOWER
description: The Philadelphia Flower Show opens an eight-day run Sunday at the Civic Center, and while the sight of azaleas and viburnums in full bloom is sure to lift the spirits of the winter-weary, the variations on the show's theme, ''The Way We Were,'' seems certain to engage and inform them as well.

title: Student Sentenced In Racial Slurs Case
description: A 21-year-old college student was sentenced yesterday to a year in jail for spray-painting racial slurs on the home of a black family near his home in Maplewood, N.J., in 1983.

title: No Rest for Lincoln
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLDING STOCK: YOU OR BROKER
description: THE growth of central asset accounts - those all-in-one accounts combining checking, credit and securities - has encouraged more and more investors to leave their stocks and bonds at a brokerage firm. When stockholders do not take delivery of the securities they buy, the issues are registered in a broker's name, referred to as a ''street name'' account.

title: FREMONT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $40,462,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss on disposal of a subsidiary of $7,993,000, income from discontinued insurance operations of $61,000 and an extraordinary charge of $1,028,000. d-Net income and includes a gain on the sale of a subsidiary of $116,717,000, a loss from discontinued insurance operations of $13,415,000, income from discontinued health-care operations of $1,042,000 and an extraordinary charge of $1,028,000.

title: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Fed Governor Seeks Overhaul
description: Robert Heller, a Federal Reserve Board governor, said today that the regulatory framework of the American financial system must be revamped if the United States is to remain the world's leading financial power.

title: GOTHIC REVERIE
description: FAMILY SKELETONS. By Henrietta Garnett. 213 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title:
PATENTS;
VIRUS MADE FOR STUDY IF AIDS
description: LEAD: TWO staff members of the National Cancer Institute were granted a patent this week for a method of producing a virus that causes AIDS - acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The process creates large quantities of the virus for use in research.

title: MICHAEL SHIRMAN, SOVIET EMIGRE, DIES
description: Michael Shirman, the leukemia patient whose potentially life-saving operation was delayed by the Soviet Union's refusal to let his sister emigrate and donate bone marrow for him, died Thursday night. He was 32 years old. Dr. Alain Berrebi, professor of hematology at Kaplan Hospital in Rehovot, where Mr. Shirman died, said today that his patient's chances of recovery were much greater last spring, when his sister was first refused an exit visa, than early this year, when the operation was finally done.

title: SANTANA, DYKSTRA, FERNANDEZ SIGN
description: The Mets neared a full house in signed contracts today on the eve of their first exhibition game when they signed three of their young stars and pursued settlements with the two others still unsigned.

title: ALFIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Arthur O. Wellman, 92, Dies; Ex-Head of Textile Concerns
description: Arthur O. Wellman, former president and chairman of the board of Wellman Inc. of Boston, and Wellman Industries Inc. of Johnsonville, S.C., textile concerns, died of leukemia Wednesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 92 years old.

title: STAGE: 'PERICLES' OFFERED BY LAMOS AT HARTFORD
description: The impressive design for Mark Lamos's production of ''Pericles'' at Hartford Stage is by John Conklin, by way of Rene Magritte. The stage surface is painted to resemble a cloud-filled sky. Floating in the air is a rocking chair - and soon the landscape is lined with Magritte men in tails and bowler hats.

title: STEWART-WARNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a provision for restructuring costs of $23,675,000 for both periods; the effect of a change in accounting which reduced the company's pension expense by $617,000 and $1,817,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and for the year also includes a non-recurring gain of $1,811,000 from the sale of the company's minority interest in Plexus Corp. c-Net income and includes for the year a non-recurring gain of $1,480,000 related to the sale of excess property.

title: FOXBORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,149,000 and $2,200,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and after a one-time restructuring charge of $43.6 million for both the quarter and year.

title: DANCE: 'TIME EXPOSURE'
description: The Feld Ballet has taken the usual step of inviting a guest choreographer who works in Europe to create a premiere for its new season. The result is a visually stunning piece by Carolyn Carlson that deliberately raises more questions than it answers.

title: INLAND VACUUM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said increased sales reflect the acquisitions of Beaulieu Chemical Co. on Oct. 31, and Chemmark Inc. and Trident Products Corp. on Dec. 19.

title: FAMILY MEMBER IN OFFER FOR TAFT BROADCASTING
description: Dudley S. Taft, vice chairman of the Taft Broadcasting Company, emerged with a surprising $1.3 billion takeover bid yesterday that would restore control of the diversified media concern to the Taft family.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 33.

title: Unemployment Creep
description: After having been stuck around 7 percent for nearly two years, the unemployment rate has dropped to 6.6 percent for the last three months. At last, that's lower than when President Reagan took office. Yet even that is deceptive. Unemployment remains more serious than six years ago. Remedies remain elusive, but six years of neglect by the Administration makes things more difficult.

title: MONITERM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said year-ago results are restated to reflect the merger on March 12, 1986, with Amtron Corp.

title: CORRECTION
description: A ticket-information listing in Weekend yesterday with an article about black theater gave an incorrect closing date for ''Boogie Woogie and Booker T.'' at the New Federal Theater, 466 Grand Street. It runs through March 15, not through tomorrow.

title: THE FIERCEST BIG EAST GAME? GETTING IN
description: This was a contest that separated the haves from the have-nots in the Big East Conference, and it was not really about basketball. It was about tickets.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 1987
description: Companies

title: Canada Stand On U.S. Corn
description: The Canadian Import Tribunal upheld a countervailing duty on American corn imports today.

title: SHONEY'S SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net loss c-Includes an after-tax non-recurring charge of $1,966,000 relating to the company's termination of its obligations under a franchise agreement for the quarter and year. The latest quarter and year results were adversely affected by an adjustment to increase the effective tax rate for 1986 as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 which retroactively eliminated investment tax credits.

title: CORRECTION
description: A map caption yesterday with a Washington dispatch about a Federal report on health hazards along a pipeline route misidentified a community where high levels of PCB's were found in wells. It is West Amwell Township, N.J., not West Amway.

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $423,000. c-Net loss and includes a tax credit of $110,000.

title: Another Cover-up (18th-Century Style)
description: LEAD: Members of the National Security Council should have read French history before they established ''Project Democracy'' as their secret diplomatic service. King Louis XV (who reigned from 1715 to 1774) established a similar corps, now known as the ''Secret du Roi'' or ''King's Secret.''

title: LEASEWAY TRANSPORTATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $32,572,000 for the quarter and $37,629,000 for the year. c-After net from discontinued operations of $34,339,000 for the quarter and $40,264,000 for the year.

title: MOSCOW'S EAST SIDE STORY: TEEN-AGE TOUGHS
description: In a jerry-built gymnasium hidden beneath an apartment building in this eastside Moscow suburb, a half-dozen teen-agers are pumping iron. White, well-muscled young bodies strain at the homemade squat bars and leg weights, to the beat of pop music from a boom box.

title: REGAN DEPARTURE SPURRING CHANGES IN ECONOMIC POLICY
description: The departure of Donald T. Regan as President Reagan's chief of staff is likely to lead to significant changes in the Administration's economic objectives, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: BIG TRADES CITED AT GOLDMAN
description: Robert M. Freeman, the Goldman, Sachs & Company partner arrested three weeks ago on insider-trading charges, bought or sold large amounts of a number of stocks that later became takeover targets, sources with knowledge of the Government's investigation said yesterday.

title: NATIONAL SECURITY & INSURNCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital losses of $19,000 for the quarter and capital gains of $1,646,000 for the year, and a tax credit of $1,288,000 for both periods. c-After capital gains of $896,000 for the quarter and $1,331,000 for the year.

title: McFARLANE MAY HAVE HAD TAP
description: A Government intelligence agency may have monitored and recorded parts of some conversations on Robert C. McFarlane's home telephone after he resigned as President Reagan's national security adviser 15 months ago, intelligence sources said today. This confirmed elements of a report in the current issue of Progressive magazine.

title: QUARTZ ENGINEERING & MAERIALS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A.&P. AT THE TOP IN NEW YORK
description: After swallowing two of its big local competitors, the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company is digging in as the New York area's biggest supermarket operator.

title: MARKET FACTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Genentech Suit Against F.D.A.
description: Genentech Inc. said today that it had filed suit against the Food and Drug Administration seeking to clarify what constitutes a drug under the Orphan Drug Act, which grants F.D.A. approval for new drugs to one company for seven years.

title: MARIA JOLAS, 94, A TRANSLATOR AND PARIS MAGAZINE FOUNDER
description: Maria Jolas, an American-born translator who was one of the last survivors of James Joyce's Paris circle, died Wednesday at her home in Paris, where she had lived for almost 60 years. Mrs. Jolas, who was 94 years old, remained an American citizen.

title: New Salomon Financial Chief
description: Gerald Rosenfeld has been named executive vice president and chief financial officer of Salomon Inc., the firm said.

title: SENATOR EDWARD ZORINSKY, 58, OF NEBRASKA, DIES IN OMAHA
description: Senator Edward Zorinsky, a former Republican who switched parties in 1976 to be elected to the Senate, died late tonight after suffering a heart attack at the annual Omaha Press Club ball. He was 58 years old.

title: When Racial Quotas Are Reasonable
description: For six years the Reagan Administration has insisted that courts cannot order race-conscious remedies even where efforts to correct discrimination have met with steady resistance. Once again, the Supreme Court has rightly rebuffed that narrow-minded view.

title: N.C.A.A. OFFICIAL SAYS CLEMENTS MISLED HIM
description: By allowing the continuation of illicit payments to S.M.U. football players in 1985 and 1986, Bill Clements, now the Governor of Texas, broke a personal promise that the school would no longer violate regulations covering athletes, an N.C.A.A. official charged yesterday.

title: JAGUAR PLC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Shares earnings represent American Depositary Receipts. The results are translated into U.S. dollars at the exchange rate of one pound sterling equals U.S.$1.48, effective Dec. 31, 1986.

title: PENN-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraorindary gain of $830,281 from the early retirement of debt. c-Net loss

title: A NEW VOICE IS PREACHING PERON'S CREED
description: Juan Domingo Peron and his wives are gone, but a new voice of Peronism is filling the plazas and the airwaves of Argentina with a passionate defense of workers' rights that keeps political tempers blazing.

title: WRITER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $1,173,000 and $1,389,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and for the quarter also includes a charge of $1.7 million from a commercial lease writedown. c-Net income and includes income tax provisions of $297,000 and $964,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Putting Exotica to the Taste Test
description: Every culture has at least one food that is an acquired taste for anyone not brought up on it: lutefisk in Norway, fish maw in China, haggis in Scotland, Vegemite in Australia. As such these foods present a challenge to those who have a professional interest in food. We want to know what it is that people who have eaten them from birth find so appealing. We are also curious whether this appeal bridges cultural barriers.

title: Nets Appoint Weltman
description: The Nets, who have been operating without a general manager since Lewis Schaffel left last August to become part of the ownership group seeking to put a National Basketball Association expansion franchise in Miami, yesterday named Harry Weltman to fill Schaffel's job. Before his appointment, Weltman had been working as a consultant for a group that is seeking an expansion franchise for the Tampa-St. Petersburg, Fla. area. The 53-year-old Weltman was the executive vice president and general manager of the Cleveland Cavaliers from 1982 until his dismissal during the closing days of last season. He was president and general manager of the Spirits of St. Louis of the American Basketball Association in the days before the merger with the N.B.A. Weltman said that he expected to begin his new job around the end of the month, and his early observation of the Nets' plight was a logical one: ''It's very obvious that they're heading in the wrong direction; we'll try to stop that decline.''

title: KNICKS' STREAK AT 4 IN ROUT OF CLIPPERS
description: The Los Angeles Clippers will always hold a special place in the heart of Bob Hill. Three months ago he achieved his first victory as a head coach against the team, and last night at Madison Square Garden they provided him with one of his easiest.

title: 51 Dead and 84 Missing
description: The Belgian authorities said today that 408 of 543 aboard a British ferryboat had been rescued after she capsized outside this harbor on Friday.

title: FREE-WHEELING DEBATE ON FIRST AMENDMENT
description: Freedom of speech, the principle embodied in the First Amendment to the Constitution, was the subject of fierce debate at a forum last week at the New York Public Library.

title: MARLBORO IS FACING INQUIRY
description: A STATE Senator who assumed a false identity drawn from a convicted rapist and an armed robber, but was hired nonetheless to work with mentally ill patients at a state hospital, says he got more than he bargained for.

title:
GARDENING;
FLOWER SHOWS OFFER A HINT OF SPRING
description: LEAD: WITHOUT a doubt, the thought of gardens filled with spring flowers is about the best possible spring tonic.

title: COMPOSER'S MUSIC REACHES A CLEARING
description: ONCE a mathematics student, Joel-Francois Durand needs few lessons on how to keep a score.

title: Report Calls Mistrust a Threat to Atom Power
description: Although the world now relies on nuclear power plants for 15 percent of its electricity, popular mistrust could bring a virtual end to the nuclear age early in the next century, according to a report published today by the Worldwatch Institute, a research organization.

title: DARIEN DINNER THEATER STAGES MUSICAL 'SUGAR BABIES'
description: ''AN oldie but a goodie,'' comments one of the burlesque comics after his routine somewhere in the second act of the Darien Dinner Theater's ''Sugar Babies'' production.

title: WAS S.M.U. PENALTY APPROPRIATE?
description: I don't think there's any doubt that S.M.U.'s penalty was appropriate, and I say that as an S.M.U. alumnus and an avid follower of Mustang football. Nonetheless, when one looks at the litany of problems that has continued to surface in the S.M.U. football program during the past 30 years, somebody clearly had to do something and it had to be drastic. I'm just embarrassed that the N.C.A.A. had to bring the situation under control, and that it couldn't be done by members of the S.M.U. community - including alumni.

title: Key Provisions of the New Tax Law Compared With Provisions for 1986
description: The law as it affects individual taxes and personal finances. INDIVIDUAL TAX RATES* LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: 14 brackets from 11% to 50% indexed NEW LAW: Five rates in 1987, from 11% to 38.5%; 2 rates in 1988:, indexed, 15%, 28%, with 5% surcharge for some** EXEMPTIONS LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: $1,080, indexed NEW LAW: 1987: $1,900; 1988: $1,950; 1989: $2,000, indexed STANDARD DEDUCTIONS Single returns LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: $2,480, indexed NEW LAW: 1987: $2,540; 1988: $3,000, indexed Joint returns LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: $3,670, indexed NEW LAW: 1987: $3,760; 1988: $5,000, indexed Heads of households LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: $2,480, indexed NEW LAW: 1987: $2,540; 1988: $4,400, indexed Two-earner deduction LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Yes ($3,000 maximum) NEW LAW: No ITEMIZED DEDUCTIONS Mortgage interest LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Fully deductible NEW LAW: Deductible for principal and second residence; limited to original cost of home plus improvements plus medical and educational expenses. Other personal interest LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Deductible NEW LAW: Consumer interest not deductible; investment interest generally deductible to extent of investment income; 4-year phase-out. Real and personal property taxes; state and local income taxes LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Deductible NEW LAW: Retain present law Sales taxes LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Deductible NEW LAW: No longer deductible Medical expenses LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Deductible above 5% of A.G.I. NEW LAW: Deductible above 7.5% of A.G.I. Charitable contributions and moving expenses LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Deductible for itemizers and nonitemizers NEW LAW: Deductible for itemizers; no deduction for nonitemizers after 1986. Miscellaneous expenses LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Deductible NEW LAW: Limited as an itemized deduction, with employee business expenses, to amount above 2% of A.G.I. (exception for reimbursed expenses) INCOME AVERAGING LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Yes NEW LAW: No ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX ON INDIVIDUALS LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Yes, 20% rate NEW LAW: 21% rate; new preference items include appreciation on contributed property and tax-exempt interest on certain newly issued private activity bonds. BUSINESS DEDUCTIONS Entertainment Expenses LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Deductible NEW LAW: 80% of actual expense deductible Business meals and expenses LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Deductible NEW LAW: Deduction denied for 20% of meal expense except for convention meals in 1987 and 1988 INCOME SHIFTING TO DEPENDENTS LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Permitted NEW LAW: Curtailed RETIREMENT SAVINGS Individual Retirement Accounts LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: $2,000 deduction; $250 spousal; tax deferred accumulation NEW LAW: I.R.A. deduction phased out for middle- and high-earning plan participants; continued tax deferred accumulation on non-deductible I.R.A.'s 401(k) Plans LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Tax deferred under qualified plans; subject to $30,000 limitation NEW LAW: Elective deferral limited to $7,000 annually Vesting LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Full vesting required after 10 years or graded vesting schedule NEW LAW: Full vesting after 5 years or 7 years under accelerated graded vesting schedule 403(b) Tax-sheltered Annuity LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: No nondiscrimination requirement or withdrawal restrictions NEW LAW: Impose $9,500 limit on elective deferrals, nondiscrimnation and withdrawal requirements. Retirement Distributions LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: 10% penalty on distributions before reaching age 59 1/2 to 5% owners of businesses and I.R.A. participants NEW LAW: 10% penalty on distributions before 59 1/2 with certain exceptions TRUSTS AND ESTATES Nongrantor trusts LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Taxed separately at rates given to those ''married but filing separate'' NEW LAW: Taxed at new rates; both would be required to make estimated payments Reversionary Trusts LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: Greater than 10 years not taxed to grantor NEW LAW: Taxable to grantor INVESTMENTS Long-Term Capital Gains LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: 60% deduction; 20% maximum rate NEW LAW: Deduction repealed; 28% maximum rate in 1987 and 28% or 33% thereafter Dividends LAW AFFECTING 1986 RETURNS: $100/$200 exclusion NEW LAW: Exclusion repealed * Exemptions and the 15% bracket phase out; results in taxable income over $71,900 joint, $43,150 single being taxed at 33% until the benefits of the 15% bracket and the exemptions are eliminated. ** Rates, exemptions and standard deductions will be indexed for inflation. (Source: Coopers & Lybrand)

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: THE IRISH ARE COMING St. Patrick's Day fever will reach the contagious stage this week as the Chieftains, the Cassidy Family, Des Keogh, the Boys of the Lough and an Irish tenor take the stage.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Antonio;
New Co-Ops For Veterans
description: LEAD: A AN ANTONIO insurance company is seeking a niche in the growing military retirement market by developing a residence here for affluent former military officers.

title: THE LAST OF MRS. LINCOLN
description: By Tom Prideaux. Starring Julie Harris. USA Home Video. 118 minutes. $39.95.

title: BASEBALL'S RULING SERVANT
description: HARDBALL The Education of a Baseball Commissioner. By Bowie Kuhn. Illustrated. 453 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95.

title: Ms. Bluh Fiancee Of Dr. Lee Frost
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Bluh of Wayne and Deal, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alison Robin Bluh to Dr. Lee Thomas Frost, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William Frost of Wayne. A September wedding is planned.

title: 'SUGAR BABIES'
description: ''AN oldie but a goodie,'' comments one of the burlesque comics after his routine somewhere in the second act of the Darien Dinner Theater's ''Sugar Babies'' production in Connecticut.

title: SAVIORS OF SOUND LOOK SOUTH, TO LESSONS OF CHESAPEAKE BAY
description: PRESERVATIONISTS who hope to restore Long Island Sound are looking south, to the murky waters of the great Chesapeake Bay, for guidance.

title: VANDERBILT MUSEUM TAKES A NEW PATH
description: LEAD: DURING the last decade, the Suffolk County Vanderbilt Museum has seemingly earned more notoriety for political, fiscal and legal controversy than respect for its value as an educational resource. However, in recent months a new director, a new board of trustees and renewed enthusiasm on the part of the museum's professional staff indicate a brighter future for the facility.

title: DEMOCRATS ON BOARD OUTLINE THEIR PRIORITIES
description: DEMOCRATS on the Board of Legislators criticized County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke last week for what they said was his failure to deal adequately with the major problems facing Westchester: a rising county budget, declining garbage-disposal capacity and the plight of the homeless.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
SCOUT DINNER
description: LEAD: ''Everybody has them, so we thought we would, too,'' said Jean Havens, who is manager of public relations and oversees cookie sales for the Girl Scouts of Westchester-Putnam. Miss Havens was referring to fund-raising dinners, the fancy kind held at hotels: Thursday evening, the Girl Scouts of Westchester-Putnam will hold their first such event at The Stouffer Westchester

title: FASHION PREVIEW: MILAN
description: LEAD: IN THE FALL AND WINTER shows that begin in Italy this weekend, Milanese designers are going to extremes: very short or very long, very tight or very loose.

title: RECRIMINATIONS IN SWEDEN
description: Who killed Olof Palme? In the year since the Swedish Prime Minister was gunned down on a Stockholm street, the police have interrogated hundreds of people, including Kurdish extremists and a member of a right-wing group. But the investigation has produced no motive and no criminal charges. The intensity of the frustration over the mystery was visible again last week in the resignation of Hans Holmer as Stockholm's police chief. The Government removed Mr. Holmer a month ago as head of the murder inquiry because, it was said, it wanted to end the bickering between him and the prosecutors in the case. The prosecutors accused him of concentrating his investigation on the Kurdish Workers' Party and ignoring other leads. In a newspaper article published Friday, Mr. Holmer said his successors were incompetent and disorganized.

title:
ABOUT BOOKS;
WHERE ORPHANS CAN STILL BECOME HEIRESSES
description: LEAD: The family of D---- had been long settled in Sussex. Their estate was large, and their residence was at Norland Park, in the center of their property, where for many generations they had lived in so respectable a manner as to engage the general good opinion of their surrounding acquaintance.#1 The B----s of Hampshire lived, at the turn of the eighteenth century, in a place called Gavelacre on the banks of the River Test, some eleven miles from Winchester along the old Roman road to the east of Salisbury plain.

title: MARINE BAN ON STRIPED BASS LOOMS IN NEW JERSEY
description: ABAN against fishing for striped bass in New Jersey's marine waters will begin April 1 unless the state comes up with more restrictive length limits for the species before that date.

title: State Links To Federal Tax Code
description: Although there are variations on the theme, the majority of states link their state income taxes to the Federal income tax code. Therefore, most Americans will see their state tax bills rise when the elimination of Federal tax breaks broadens the base of taxable income. The links are as follows: TO FEDERAL ADJUSTED GROSS INCOME: Arizona, Colorado, Delaware, the District of Columbia, Georgia, California, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Montana, New Mexico, New York, Ohio, Virginia, West Virginia and Wisconsin. TO FEDERAL TAXABLE INCOME: Hawaii, Idaho, Oklahoma, Oregon, South Carolina and Utah. TO FEDERAL TAX LIABILITY: Nebraska, North Dakota, Rhode Island and Vermont.

title: 'Yankee' Police Chief Upsetting Shreveport
description: Charles Gruber has ruffled a few feathers since he arrived here in December.

title: BLAST YIELDS CLUES ON COSMIC EVOLUTION
description: Blazing with the light of nearly a billion suns, the exploding star that burst into view over the Southern Hemisphere Feb. 24 is yielding a trove of clues expected to help decipher the evolution of the universe. But this supernova has also produced a crop of puzzles that have brought into rare focus the collective efforts of observatories ordinarily as competitive as rival department stores.

title: Montreal
description: The people of Montreal are steeled for snow from October to May. They can't beat their long Canadian winter, so they do the only sensible thing: They adapt to it - outdoors or in.

title: Lorna Kent Is Wed to Dale Tahtinen
description: Lorna Dyer Kent, the daughter of Mrs. Richard Graff Denzer of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Dennis Edwin Kent of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dale Rudolph Tahtinen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Tahtinen of Baraga, Mich. The Rev. Eugene O. Krug performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Boca Raton.

title: MAESTRO FOR THE MASSES
description: UNDERSTANDING TOSCANINI How He Became an American Culture-God and Helped Create a New Audience for Old Music. By Joseph Horowitz. Illustrated. 492 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: A PRIEST GOES TO COURT
description: The Rev. Charles E. Curran, on the losing end of a seven-year struggle with the Vatican over his liberal views on sexual ethics, has gone to court to try to overturn his suspension as a teacher in the theology department of Catholic University of America in Washington. It is the only Catholic college in the United States that receives Vatican accreditation, and Father Curran has been a tenured full professor there since 1971. In his suit, filed in Superior Court of the District of Columbia and made public last week, Father Curran contends that most of the students in his classes were civil-degree candidates, not enrolled in Vatican-accredited programs, and that therefore his role as a teacher should not be subject to Vatican regulation. One purpose of tenure, he said, is ''to grant to the recipient academic freedom, freedom of thought and expression, and freedom of inquiry in his academic pursuits, without fear of reprisal.''

title: ANATOMY OF AN 'R' RATING
description: SOME FILMS ARE CONCEIVED IN notoriety. Twenty years ago Edward Albee's ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' was a notorious play they said could never be made into a movie because of the old Production Code's prohibition against vulgar language. George and Martha, Mr. Albee's domestic contenders, not only slapped and humiliated each other, but they also said ''damn'' (and worse) with some frequency. After a bit of fiddling with the text, the play was made in into a movie.

title: A FASCINATING COLLECTION OF CHURCH CHANTS
description: Four of my favorite disks of the past year range over 1,300 years and, while all are technically within the realm of Western high-art culture, they cover a stylistic spectrum almost as wide as human music itself.

title: U.S. FERRY STANDARDS CALLED TOUGHER
description: A ferry of the type that capsized off Belgium on Friday night would probably be prevented from operating in United States waters because the design would not meet standards here, a Coast Guard inspector said yesterday.

title: YANKEES: PUZZLES AT SHORTSTOP
description: The two players who are most deeply involved in the competition insist there are no battle lines drawn at shortstop this spring. Wayne Tolleson and Bobby Meacham only address the issue as it affects them - without much reference to the other person but with an understanding that if they falter, someone will gladly take their place.

title: High Speeds Shorten the Life of Auto Engines
description: To the Editor:

title: Searching for Mr. Bonoprop
description: William Safire does his usual excellent job in ''Mr. Bonaprop.'' The following are a few more Bonaprops he might have included:

title: SELLING GOODS AND SERVICES TO THE STATE
description: SUPPOSE one of your company's marketing representatives has an inexpensive lunch with an employee of the State Department of Administrative Services as part of your firm's effort to become a paper clip supplier to the State of Connecticut. If your representative makes the mistake of picking up the tab after lunch, the state employee will have violated his department's code of ethics.

title: Redmen Try to Rebound
description: As St. John's limped through the last agonizing minutes of a brutal 80-51 loss to Providence Friday night, the question was, ''Are the Redmen finished?'' Perhaps not yet. Despite the embarrassing loss and their earliest exit from the Big East tournament since 1981, St. John's (20-8) is likely to receive a bid today to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: DATA UPDATE: March 8, 1987
FUND STARTED FOR MRS. WHITEHEAD
description: BECAUSE she believes that a child should never be separated from its natural mother, regardless of legal contracts, 32-year-old Kathleen Rutler of this Bergen County community has set up a fund for Mary Beth Whitehead, the Brick Township woman fighting to keep Baby M, the child she bore as a surrogate.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Jewish Center Replacing Surplus Schools
description: LEAD: IT has been six-and-a-half years since the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Suffolk entered into a $4.5 million lease-purchase option agreement with the Commack school district for the surplus 47.5-acre Green Meadows Junior High School complex in Commack.

title: Meredith Hughes to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. John David Hughes of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Meredith Hughes, to Midshipman Bartlett Harwood 3d, a first classman at the United States Naval Academy. He is a son of Mrs. Raymond H. Carter of Princeton and North Haven, Me., and the late Mr. Harwood Jr. Miss Hughes, a development associate at the American Farm School's office of trustees in New York, graduated from Bates College. Her fiance is an alumnus of the Groton School.

title: Are They More Than Contras?
description: Six months, not much more. The political men here who represent Nicaraguan rebel troops in the field disagree about a lot of things. But they do say, quite separately, that they have about six months to show whether they can change from a collection of competing groups into a unified movement capable of challenging Sandinista control of their country.

title: RESIDENTIAL UNITS FOR THE RETARDED
description: After reading the Jan. 25 article ''Fears on Mental Center Proposal'' and the letter to the editor about the article on Feb. 8, I felt there was a need to speak for the mentally retarded children and adults who live at the Long Island Developmental Center.

title: BLUE JAYS BAFFLE FERNANDEZ
description: Adding aggravation to anger, Tony Fernandez could not find his car keys. ''I don't want to go back in,'' he said, patting the pockets in his warm-up jacket and uniform pants looking for the errant keys.

title: IN HOTELL BOOM, ROOMS GO BEGGING
description: BY the end of this year, the number of hotel rooms in the state will have increased by more than 30 percent over 1985, with most of the new units in the Hartford and Stamford markets.

title: SNOWS BRING ON BATTLE FOR PHILADELPHIA POWER
description: When back-to-back snowstorms hit the East Coast in January, many city streets here remained buried for several days, even though cleaning crews were on the job round the clock, racking up hundreds of hours of overtime pay.

title: Taiwanese to Be Tried in West in Murder of Writer
description: A Taiwanese member of an international gang has been extradited from New York to California to stand trial for the 1984 murder of a Chinese-American journalist.

title: BELGIAN PORT AMONG THE BUSIEST IN EUROPE
description: Zeebrugge, the Belgian port that the ferry Herald of Free Enterprise was leaving when she capsized, is the fourth busiest passenger port on the European continent.

title: A CLOTHESMAKER GROWS IN BROOKLYN
description: THE scene at the executive offices of Private Brands Inc. in Brooklyn had the warmth, the informality and the rowdiness of a family gathering.

title: BUSH'S 'HUMPHREY' FACTOR
description: It was in a television studio here, more than seven years ago, that George Bush invented ''Big Mo'' as his way of describing the morning after political momentum he got from catapulting over Ronald Reagan in the 1980 Iowa Presidential caucuses in his bid for the Republican nomination.

title: CRIME
description: Simon Brett first attracted an enthusiastic following with his Charles Paris mysteries. Paris - he is still with us - is a so-so British actor always getting involved with murder. But what has made the Paris mysteries so entertaining are the show business asides, told with wry humor. In some of his recent mysteries without Paris, Mr. Brett has not found a very interesting formula, and often the results have been rather dull. In A NICE CLASS OF CORPSE (Scribners, $13.95), however, some authentic touches of the old Brett are present.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: With THE TIME WANDERERS (Richardson & Steirman, $16.95), Arkady and Boris Strugatsky confirm their standing in the first rank of contemporary science fiction writers. They often deal with the theme of the incomprehensible alien, as in their masterful short novel ''Roadside Picnic.'' Their new novel seems to be about aliens as well, but nothing is as it seems in this slippery introduction to what might be called the science of paranoia.

title: ...AND WHAT WE TELL THE HOUSE TO DO
description: MY mother-in-law has this recurring nightmare.

title: TWYLA THARP AND BALLET - AN UNEASY MATCH
description: TWYLA THARP'S NEW WORKS -to be seen on a national tour following her company's season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music -have made that season the most successful ever in terms of popular appeal and packed houses. Still, this has been a hollow success - a case of an important talent less confident about an artistic imperative than about her ability to widen an audience.

title: THE GENIOUS OF GERSHWIN STILL INSPIRES COMPOSERS
description: FIFTY YEARS AGO, George Gershwin died of a brain tumor at the age of 38, shocking the musical world.

title: TALKING: Brokers; Breaking A Listing Agreement
description: SELLERS who market their homes through a broker must normally sign a listing agreement that gives the broker and the community's multiple-listing service the exclusive right to sell the property for three to six months.

title: INVENTOR OF THE PRECISION CLUB
description: If an established expert devises a new bidding system, the chance that he will attract a wide following is negligible. If an unknown does so his chance is zero.

title: PLAN IS OFFERED TO HEAD OFF AIR DELAYS
description: WITH airport use expected to increase significantly over the next 20 years, officials should begin making major improvements at 10 of Connecticut's airports if they want to avoid air travel delays, the draft of a new report says.

title:
INVESTING;
THE ADRENALIN BEHIND DRUG STOCKS
description: LEAD: THE talk about the drug stocks these days sounds remarkably similar to the debate over the prospects of the stock market in general. Those who own the drug stocks cite the falling dollar and the companies' growth prospects as evidence that share prices will rise, while those who are avoiding the group consider the stocks overpriced and mere beneficiaries of the flood of cash that has helped to drive up the market in general.

title: REPORTER ASSAILED IN RACE-BIAS TRIAL
description: In three days of cross-examination in a Federal discrimination trial last week, The Daily News mounted a blistering assault on the honesty and competence of one of its black reporters who has accused the newspaper of racial bias.

title: The Indian Ordeal
description: WHEN I WAS 12, MY PARENTS sent me to summer camp in California, in the eastern foothills of the Sierra Nevada mountains. I had grown up playing cowboys and Indians, whooping among the schist outcroppings of Manhattan. Now I was eager to explore the real American wilderness, unhampered by the presence of girls. When I saw the corral and the rifle range at camp, I thought I had landed in paradise. The West, I knew, was alive with thundering posses, bucking broncos and the echo of gunshot. I was prepared to act out the exploits of the Lone Ranger, the Rifleman and other valiant gunslingers.

title: A TOKEN BATTLE
description: As things stand in New York City now, one old brass subway token and one new steel-centered ''bulls-eye'' token will buy you one ride on the subway. But wait. A Queens subway rider, Samuel Tobet, had 56 old tokens that the New York City Transit Authority was refusing to accept because its exchange periods had passed. The agency, introducing new tokens last year for its new magnetized turnstile system, had set two exchange periods of a few weeks each.
