More than 21 million tokens were exchanged, but as many as 10 million were not returned. Acting as his own lawyer, Mr. Tobet challenged the Transit Authority in Small Claims Court and won the right to cash in the old tokens. The authority warned that it would continue to reject the old tokens pending an appeal; Mr. Tobet, a 65-year-old garment industry executive, said he, too, ''may just take it further.''

title: 3 TO GET LITERARY AWARDS
description: THE New Jersey Literary Hall of Fame, dedicated, in its founder's words, to proving that the state ''is not a literary wasteland,'' will add three writers to its ranks Saturday as the culmination of a day-long celebration of the written word.

title: TIMIDITY VS. SPIRIT AT THE OPERA
description: THE MOST IMMEDIATELY STRIKING FEA-ture of the Metropolitan Opera's 1987-88 repertory, announced the other day, is its timidity: just three new productions are planned, two of them segments of a ''Ring'' that will not fully materialize for two more seasons, the other a ''Trovatore'' perilously built around a great singer in decline, Joan Sutherland. This constriction of repertory should not really come as a surprise. For box-office reasons, the company has been pulling in its horns ever since James Levine and Bruce Crawford took charge as artistic director and general manager, in that order.

title: Suzanne Simons Weds Donald A. Laidlaw Jr.
description: At the Marvin United Methodist Church in Tyler, Tex., yesterday Suzanne DeLoach Simons and Donald Arthur Laidlaw Jr. were married by the Rev. Dr. James Garrett.

title: Pan Am's People
description: To the Editor:

title: SPIRIT OF STAGE, BLAZING TRAILS
description: IN Arthur Miller's new one-act drama, ''I Can't Remember Anything,'' which ends its run at Lincoln Center today, Geraldine Fitzgerald plays the role of a wealthy New England widow who meets nightly with a close family friend, Leo, trying to dilute the losses of the past by bantering and gently arguing with him about the absurdity and pain of old age.

title: Jo Klingenstein, a Teacher, Engaged To Marry Peter R. Ziesing in August
description: The engagement of Joanne Lee Klingenstein and Peter Raymond Ziesing, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert August Ziesing of St. Davids, Pa., and Center Sandwich, N.H., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Lee Paul Klingenstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., parents of the future bride. An August wedding is planned.

title: SYRIA AND IRAN IN A DISPUTE OVER SHIITES
description: A dispute has broken out between Syria and Iran over Iran's support for militant Shiites who have clashed with Syrian troops enforcing security measures in West Beirut.

title: THE ART BEHIND THE DOTS
description: SLIGHT, TRIM, GRAY-HAIRED, ROY LICHTENSTEIN is a diffident man who immerses himself in his work and keeps the world at a distance. The few who are permitted to visit his Manhattan studio are invariably struck by the discrepancy between this extremely reserved man and the brash, irrev-erent world of his paintings, in which a brunette leaps to catch a beach ball or a teen-ager coos to her boyfriend on the phone, ''Oh, Jeff . . . I love you, too . . . but . . .''

title: TAKING ACCOUNT OF OTHERS TAKES A TOLL
description: TAX season follows on the heels of the retailers' Christmas. It is the accountants' unjolly holiday period. It is prime billing time and thus the bellwether of the financial year. Is there life after work? Not at tax season. Annually it makes its relentless winter/ spring imprint on our lives.

title: Malawi's Leader Inspects Crop and Finds It Good
description: Ignoring the tropical rains, President Hastings Kamuzu Banda waded into a muddy field of tobacco plants five feet tall.

title: Bridgeport's $700 Million Waterfront Plan
description: THOUGH Fairfield County has become one of the most expensive and prestigious areas of the country in which to live and work, the city of Bridgeport -strategically placed along its shoreline - has never quite been able to capitalize on the county's strong drawing power.

title: SETON HALL EXPANDING TIES TO JAPAN
description: REPRESENTATIVES of about 100 American universities, including Seton Hall, are spending two weeks in Japan to examine the possibility of expanding their exchange programs or setting up branch campuses there.

title:
GARDENING;
FLOWER SHOWS OFFER A HINT OF SPRING
description: LEAD: WITHOUT a doubt, the thought of gardens filled with spring flowers is about the best possible spring tonic.

title: PATIENT: JOHN HUSTON. RX: FILM
description: THE RANCH HOUSE INN IS separated from the freeway by a low wire fence and a narrow strip of dirt. When John Huston wakes in the night, struggling to breathe, he can almost reach out and touch the herd of Colts and Mustangs that is inexorably plunging past.

title: THIS GUARD CAN BE OUTFOXED
description: LAST week, I began exploring a utility program that combines the features of a desk organizer, a menu builder, a DOS shell and a usage log. The software, called Maestro ($89.95 for the I.B.M. PC and compatibles from Spectre Software, Greensboro, N.C., 27404, (919) 272-9984), also supplies a password security system capable of handling up to 10 users. That feature explains why this week's column barely escaped being a dissertation on the pleasures of ice fishing - which is rather good this winter - instead of a continuation of the review.

title: Stapley Wonham Planning to Wed David Emberling
description: The engagement of Stapley Wonham to David Merton Emberling has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Wonham of Stamford, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Emberling of San Mateo, Calif. A May wedding is planned. Miss Wonham, an assistant to the general counsel at Sotheby's in New York, attended the Brearley School and graduated from the Greenwich Academy and Trinity College in Hartford. She is a granddaughter of the late Henry C. Brunie, president of the Empire Trust Company, and the late Mrs. Brunie of New York, and of the late Mr. and Mrs. W.Stapley Wonham of Greenwich, Conn. Her father is an executive vice president of the United States Trust Company of New York.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: THERE I WAS, LYING on my back, bubble gum wadded in my cheek, a copy of ''Sheena, Queen of the Jungle'' held before my deliciously shocked eyes, ready to yell the fa-vorite comic-book sound, ''Aieeeee!'' as the muscular maiden pounced on some unsuspecting leopard, when my mother appeared at the doorway like a Neil Simon heroine to pronounce the awful imprecation: ''Lounge lizard!''

title: FOOL FOR LOVE
description: Starring Sam Shepard, Kim Basinger and Harry Dean Stanton. Directed by Robert Altman and written by Sam Shepard. 1985. MGM/UA Home Video. 108 minutes. $79.95.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Another two weeks of data like this week and last week, and everyone will be talking about the '87 recession.'' James F. Smith, University of Texas, on the economy's performance.

title:
DINING OUT;
FRENCH FARE IN LOWER PUTNAM
description: LEAD: THOSE who look with misgiving on today's fast-paced, fast-changing world will be pleased to learn that within the last quarter of a century little has changed at The Arch. Moules mariniere, escargots, onion soup, creme caramel and coupe aux marrons - stanchions of popular French cuisine of the past - remain tamper-proof.

title: A TASTE OF THAILAND IN DANBURY
description: RUN, don't walk, to Bangkok, the new and only Thai restaurant in Connecticut.

title: A Florida Shore Where Solitude Rules
description: The advertisement is inviting but vague - ''Escape to the island that time forgot - a pristine barrier island off the northwest coast of Florida.'' The only clue to the island's whereabouts is the name of a town, Carabelle, which the map shows is on the coast, west of the big bend on the Gulf of Mexico.

title:
ART;
THE MANY IMAGES THAT SYMBOLIZE AMERICA
description: LEAD: IF you had to chose one image that symbolizes America, which would it be?The Statue of Liberty towering above

title: THEATER: BILATERAL TALKS IN 'WALK IN THE WOODS'
description: In Lee Blessing's play ''A Walk in the Woods,'' two arms negotiators - one from the United States and the other from the Soviet Union - meet in Geneva and edge toward common ground. Neither man ever claims a breakthrough or settles for a stalemate. It might be said that their success lies largely in their avoidance of failure. Similarly, Mr. Blessing's play (at the Yale Repertory Theater) is distinguished, first of all, by the pitfalls it avoids. The play, inspired by the real ''walk in the woods'' taken in 1982 by Paul H. Nitze and Yuli A. Kvitsinsky, is neither a polemic nor a cartoon, but an engrossing attempt to humanize a situation of awesome portentousness.

title: THE SONS OF COMMUNISM
description: ONE IS A 52-YEAR-OLD Czechoslovak engineer; the other, a 38-year-old Hungarian architect.

title: A Daughter's Father
description: I was most alarmed to hear that, since Richard Sandza's daughter, Annie, ''will never be an N.F.L. quarterback,'' she will ''have to settle for cheerleader.'' I would have thought that, given an interest in athletics, she might ''settle'' for being Grete Waitz or Martina Navratilova. GAIL B. GRIFFIN Coordinator of Women's Studies Kalamazoo College Kalamazoo, Mich.

title: CHILDREN'S FASHION
description: THE CHILDREN'S LOOK FOR spring is a far distance from ragtag street fashion; it tends toward a refreshing romanticism in pastel colors and loose silhouettes, combining elegance and sophistication without merely parroting adult styles.

title: 12% Rise Reported in New York City Tax Revenue
description: New York City's tax revenues from last July through January were 12.3 percent higher than for the comparable period a year ago, and city and state officials are debating whether the increase represents a long-term trend.

title: U.S. DEMANDS ON TRADE NO LONGER RATTLE JAPAN
description: AMERICAN and Japanese trade negotiators held another round of discussions last week, sessions that have become a familiar ritual. As it had done countless times, the United States reported mild progress after the talks but no breakthrough that might make it easier for American companies to sell things like car telephones, pharmaceutical drugs, medical equipment or microchips in Japan. Those products form the core of the present American trade offensive.

title: Elizabeth Donovan Is Wed to Edward Nolan Jr.
description: Elizabeth Anne Donovan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Collins Donovan of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Edward A. Nolan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nolan of Wantagh, L.I., and Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. Walter Modrys performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: THE POLLUTION ON BLUEBELL LANE
description: Regarding the Feb. 1 article ''Pollution Aftermath Splits Residents of Bluebell Lane,'' there is another viewpoint that was not mentioned.

title: THREE WEEKS IN MANAGUA
description: THE JAGUAR SMILE A Nicaraguan Journey. By Salman Rushdie. 171 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $12.95.

title: 'THE GIRL FROM FARGO': A PLAY
description: The editors of Arts and Leisure asked the playwrights Terrence McNally and Wendy Wasserstein to explain how a play gets from an Off Broadway producer's office to the stage. They responded in the medium in which they felt most comfortable. The result, ''Wendy Wasserstein's and Terrence McNally's 'The Girl From Fargo, North Dakota,' '' a one-act play in four scenes, is their first collaboration. THE PLAYERS JONATHAN SHARPE, Off Broadway's youngest leading artistic director/producer VERA-ELLEN ALLEN, a young playwright from Fargo, North Dakota MICHAEL TRUCK, an angry young playwright A. ROB ''BECKETT'' STERN, a promising young dramaturg MUFFIE CRAIN, a lonely young casting director TREVIS HAMMOND-STRUT, a hot young British director. Has eight plays running on Off and Off Off Broadway CARDINALE DI BENEDETTO, the brilliant young conceptual designer LUCY BALLOT, a promising young National Endowment for the Arts consultant BOBBIE POWELL, a young, no-nonsense stage manager CUBBY DUMOND, a promising youngish lady chairperson of JONATHAN SHARPE'S board NORTH, a cute intern. Also a senior at Phillips Exeter Academy SCENE ONE The time is now. JONATHAN SHARPE'S crowded office in the West 40's between 10th and 11th Avenues. The walls are covered with theatrical posters. Desks are piled high with play scripts. Photographs of now-famous Academy Award winners when they were young, eager and waiters are everywhere. MICHAEL TRUCK, the angry young playwright, has JONATHAN SHARPE, Off Broadway's youngest leading artistic director/ producer, in a hammerlock. MUFFIE CRAIN, the lonely young casting director, continues to cast at her Macintosh computer, oblivious to their struggle. MICHAEL TRUCK: You promised to produce my next play! Well, ''Drop Dead'' is my next play! JONATHAN SHARPE:: Michael, I can't produce a five-hour, 80-character Purim play on my budget. MUFFIE CRAIN: (working at her computer) Molly Ringwald is available! MICHAEL TRUCK: Sigourney Weaver is committed to ''Drop Dead''! JONATHAN: I'll be committed if I produce it. I'm sorry, Michael, but I have to worry about the future of the American Theater. MICHAEL: Wait till I tell the National Endowment for the Arts about this, Judas. Good thing my mother-in-law is lunching with Kitty Carlisle Hart. I'll have your funding on a platter! (NORTH, a cute young intern, enters with a bucket and mop. MUFFIE looks up from her Macintosh.) NORTH: I finished the men's room. Now what? JONATHAN: The women's room. (NORTH exits.) MUFFIE: That North kid is adorable! JONATHAN: He's a senior at Exeter, Muffie! MUFFIE: Well, you don't meet that many real men around here. I wonder if he has a trust fund. I wouldn't mind getting out of this business. (VERA-ELLEN ALLEN, the young playwright from Fargo, North Dakota, enters. She carries two suitcases and a large Teddy bear.) VERA-ELLEN ALLEN: Hi, I'm Vera-Ellen Allen, the young playwright from Fargo, North Dakota. Am I interrupting? JONATHAN: Mr. Truck is just leaving. VERA-ELLEN: You're Michael Truck? I loved ''Go to Hell.'' MICHAEL: You see, Jonathan? (To VERA-ELLEN) Let me give you a tip, honey. Don't let these people produce your play. Go right to the top, take it to Circle Rep! (He storms out) VERA-ELLEN: He seems nice. (She looks around the room.) So this is the theater! JONATHAN: (He puts his hand over a leak.) Did you have a nice trip? VERA-ELLEN: The bus broke down in Harrisburg so I hitched the rest of the way on a Diesel truck. The driver was real nice and handsome and wanted to marry me. MUFFIE: Maybe I should start hitchhiking. We love your play, Miss Allen. VERA-ELLEN: Call me Vera-Ellen. MUFFIE: It's just wonderful. VERA-ELLEN: You are really nice. JONATHAN: Usually we develop a script. You know, readings, staged readings, semi-staged readings, semi-seated readings, semi-seated standing readings . . . VERA-ELLEN: That sounds really nice. JONATHAN: However, when your play ''Isn't It Nice?'' came in through the Young Playwrights Festival sponsored by the Dramatists Guild, Peter Stone, president; David E. LeVine, executive director, I recognized a freshness and an urgency that I don't want to tamper with. Our promising young dramaturg, A. Rob ''Beckett'' Stern, has a few thoughts for rewrites he'd like to share with you. (A. ROB enters with a copy of VERA-ELLEN'S script.) A. ROB ''BECKETT'' STERN: Here's your play. The red markings are what you should cut, the pink markings are what doesn't work, and the blue markings need a total rewrite. And by the way, there's a big problem in your second act. I don't know what it is, but I'm not a playwright. Excuse me, I've got to get back to my translation of ''Woyzeck Tonight!'' (He exits.) VERA-ELLEN: He seems nice. JONATHAN: He isn't. About a director: we've sent it to Mike Nichols, Tommy Tune, Mr. Abbott, Susan Sontag - she's looking for a comedy - Sean Penn . . . it's a wild card . . . and Pina Bausch . . . that one's out of the ballpark. VERA-ELLEN: They all sound very nice, I'm sure. (TREVIS HAMMOND-STRUT, the hot young British director, flies into the office.) TREVIS HAMMOND-STRUT: Hello, darlings! I'm directing your play. Mike, Tommy, Susan and Pina all turned it down. But I love it. Now here's my schedule: I'm opening ''Mother Courage'' at the Public and then I'm off to L.A. for ''When We Dead Awaken.'' I can squeeze you in between the Mamet and the Miller. We'll talk. (He flies out of the office.) VERA-ELLEN: He seems very nice. MUFFIE: About casting: your play has wonderful parts for four women. I think we could even interest someone like Meryl to return to the stage. VERA-ELLEN: Meryl Streep! MUFFIE: (at her computer) Well, if not Meryl, Kathleen Turner is available. Or Swoosie Kurtz. Or Stockard Channing. Or Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio . . . or . . . you're in luck! They're all available. Every actress in America. VERA-ELLEN: And they'd all be willing to work Off Broadway? MUFFIE: That's what they tell us. JONATHAN: Whether stars do it or not, Vera-Ellen, I'm committed to your play. At my theater the playwright is the star. Your work is very exciting and it's hard to get excited in the theater these days. (Gunshots are heard offstage. NORTH rushes in.) NORTH: Michael Truck just shot himself. (He points at VERA-ELLEN.) He blames you and the American theater. VERA-ELLEN: I just got here! (Blackout.) SCENE TWO The same. Six weeks later. JONATHAN is with CARDINALE DI BENEDETTO, the brilliant young conceptual designer, and CUBBY DUMOND, a promising youngish lady chairperson on his board. JONATHAN: I'm sorry, Card, but I just can't afford to build a real bridge over water. This isn't the Yale Drama School. CARDINALE: My art isn't cheap! JONATHAN: Well, it has to be if you're going to work at my theater. (Enter BOBBIE POWELL, a young, no-nonsense stage manager.) BOBBIE: Jonathan, we have only $10.87 left in our production budget. We can't continue. (She exits. Plaster falls from the ceiling.) CUBBY DUMOND: If you'd do more musicals, the board could raise more money. All our friends like musicals. And why can't the theater be on the East Side near McMullen's? They serve such nice grilled fish. You drag us to the West Side and make us sit through dreadful Michael Truck plays. Why can't you do a nice play? JONATHAN: I am doing a nice play. It's called ''Isn't It Nice?'' CUBBY: Who's in it? JONATHAN: The four Christines: Lahti, Baranski, Ebersole and Estabrook. CUBBY: You promised us Meryl Streep this season. CARDINALE: He promised me a bridge! I'm going to the Manhattan Theater Club. (He exits as NORTH enters with a bucket and mop.) NORTH: I finished the ladies' room. Now what? JONATHAN: The men's room. NORTH: (to CUBBY) Hi, Mom. CUBBY: I thought you were at Exeter this semester. (VERA-ELLEN, TRAVIS, MUFFIE and A. ROB enter in high dudgeon.) TREVIS: The show is off! The Christines quit. All four of them. They all got TV pilots. JONATHAN: Relax, Trevis, we'll recast it. Muffie, check on the availability of Whoopi Goldberg. MUFFIE: She's doing ''Mother Courage'' for Joe Papp. TREVIS: Who's directing it? Oh, my God, I am. A. ROB: I've got it! Cut the four women out of your play. VERA-ELLEN: They're the only four characters in my play. (MICHAEL TRUCK enters. His head is bandaged. With him is LUCY BALLOT, a promising young National Endowment for the Arts consultant.) MICHAEL: There they are! Cut their funding! LUCY: Mr. Truck says you're not committed to new American plays. JONATHAN: I'm a reasonable, intelligent man. Why would I be working in this dump for no money dealing with people like Michael Truck and actresses who quit to be in TV pilots and board members who want me to put on musicals if I weren't committed to new American plays? I live, breathe, eat and sleep new American plays. (More plaster falls.) CUBBY: Bravo, Jonathan! VERA-ELLEN: Hello, I'm Vera-Ellen Allen, the playwright. I'm having a wonderful experience at this theater. I'm learning so much about my play, its structure, its language, its dramatic arc. Please don't cut their funding. Please support them. LUCY: We'd love to give you more but we're running out of money ourselves. CUBBY: Then once again it's up to the private sector. (She stuffs money into JONATHAN'S pockets. MICHAEL TRUCK shoots himself again. No one cares. NORTH rushes in.) NORTH: There's a riot down there. Four hundred waitresses from Curtain Up are demanding to audition for ''Isn't It Nice?'' VERA-ELLEN: Then the show will go on! TREVIS: Darlings, I can only give you four days. A. ROB: I still say this play should have been workshopped. (Blackout.) SCENE THREE The same. Four days later. Opening night. JONATHAN, VERA-ELLEN, MUFFIE, A. ROB and TREVIS are pacing nervously. JONATHAN: Sshh! I thought I heard a laugh from the theater. (NORTH enters breathlessly with binoculars.) NORTH: I found him in the audience. He's in the fourth-row aisle seat. He still hasn't laughed but he's writing a lot. JONATHAN: Don't take your eyes off him. (NORTH rushes out.) JONATHAN: Why are we so victimized by the critics? I'm not inviting them after this. VERA-ELLEN: Then how will my play get to Broadway? JONATHAN: I don't care if your play gets to Broadway. I'm committed to new American voices. VERA-ELLEN: Well, I care. Shoot, we had a nicer theater than this in Fargo. (A light fixture falls down. NORTH rushes back into the room.) NORTH: Edith Oliver went out for a cigarette. (He rushes back to the theater.) TREVIS: Maybe the critics know something we don't know. VERA-ELLEN: You mean, you don't like my play? TREVIS: Well, do you think it's a good play? I'm off, luvs. Good luck with it, darling. Ta ta. VERA-ELLEN: This play has to be a success. They've already taken my picture for Vanity Fair. (NORTH enters breathlessly.) NORTH: His wife is smiling. Or maybe she was yawning. (He rushes out.) VERA-ELLEN: (starting to cry) I just don't know what I'm going to do if they don't like it! I'll be so humiliated. That's me up there. My life. My feelings. My parents. JONATHAN: It's a wonderful play, Vera-Ellen. VERA-ELLEN: I know that! I'm talking about having a hit. JONATHAN: If it's a hit you want, you're in the wrong business. It's not who likes it, it's how it touches people. VERA-ELLEN: Will you lighten up? Hits touch people. They made a movie of ''Crimes of the Heart.'' Who is Beth Henley's agent? (NORTH rushes in.) NORTH: Listen to this! (He throws open the door. Shouts of ''Bravo.'' A great ovation is coming from the theater.) Even the critics are giving it a standing ovation. Everybody's saying what a terrific movie it will make. I'd like to buy the rights. (MICHAEL TRUCK enters.) MICHAEL: They loved it! They loved it! (He opens fire. Blackout.) SCENE FOUR Epilogue. One year later. NORTH'S office in Hollywood. NORTH is dictating to his secretary, BOBBIE POWELL, who has gone Hollywood in a big way. NORTH: Michael Truck won the Pulitzer Prize for ''Drop Dead.'' Get the film rights. I'll give Vera-Ellen first crack at a first draft. Have we fired Trevis Hammond-Strut off the Marsha Norman project yet? Well, do it now. Tell Meryl it's a go on ''Three Sisters'' with her, Barbra and Goldie. How were the ratings on ''The Four Christines''? Who said America wasn't ready for a sitcom about four struggling young actresses? (MUFFIE and CUBBY enter. They have been shopping.) Hi, Mom. Hi, honey. MUFFIE: Darling, your mother and I both think you should finish high school. NORTH: Why? I'm getting an honorary degree from Harvard. CUBBY: This is all that horrible little theater's fault! (A. ROB enters with a script.) A. ROB: I've got it! Bruce Willis in ''Woyzek Tonight!'' It's a natural mini-series! NORTH: You're fired! (A bedraggled VERA-ELLEN enters.) VERA-ELLEN: Here's my 11th draft of ''Isn't It Nice?'' Screenwriting is real hard. (JONATHAN enters with great enthusiasm.) JONATHAN: I just saw a great new play at a storefront theater in Hollywood. I think it will be terrific for us in New York. NORTH: I flew you out here to develop movie projects for me. JONATHAN: I'm sorry, North, but I'm going back. I belong in the theater. NORTH: You're walking away from a fortune. JONATHAN: I know and I don't look forward to begging for money, sweating out opening nights, the angry subscribers, the disappointments, the feeling sometimes that nobody cares anymore. But when I go into a theater I still get goosebumps. When the lights go down, my pulse races. I always expect the miracle to happen. I know: lighten up! But I just want to put on plays, I always have, since I had a puppet theater in the basement. NORTH: You had a puppet theater in the basement? So did I! VERA-ELLEN: Me, too. MUFFIE, CUBBY, BOBBIE & A. ROB: So did we! VERA-ELLEN: Jonathan, I'd like to go back to the theater with you, if you'll have me. JONATHAN: Come on, Vera-Ellen, let's go to New York, clean out those bathrooms and put on a new show. (They start walking off.) VERA-ELLEN: I want to write my ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' my ''Harvey,'' my ''Little Foxes.'' MUFFIE: And I want to cast my ''Glass Menagerie,'' my ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' Wait for me! CUBBY: I want to nurture my ''Barefoot in the Park,'' my ''Front Page.'' Oh, God, I'm coming, too! A. ROB: I want to dramaturg my ''Hurlyburly.'' Wait! BOBBIE: What about me? I want to stage manage my ''Chorus Line''! NORTH: Why are you doing this to me? I'm too young to be idealistic. (He breaks down and cries.) ''Oh Dad, Poor Dad, Mama's Hung You in the Closet and I'm Feeling So Sad.'' Don't leave me! (He rushes after the others.) JONATHAN: (from offstage) I want to find my ''Crucible,'' my ''Fifth of July,'' my ''Sister Mary Ignatius Explains it All for You,' my ''Oklahoma'' . . . ! (His voice fades away. The stage is empty. (In NORTH'S now-deserted office all the Bells Are Ringing.) THE END

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ALL THAT JAZZ
description: LEAD: BACK when his restaurant was just a restaurant, Al Defemio chopped parsley to a drumbeat in his head. ''I'd do all sorts of drum exercises,'' he recalled. ''Paradiddles, you name it.'' When the chef asked what he was up to, he would answer, ''I've got to keep my hands loose.''

title: BLOSSOMING OF THE LECTURE SEASON BEGINS
description: LEAD: WITH the spring-lecture season in the county moving into high gear, Westchester residents will have the opportunity to hear outstanding speakers cover a wide range of subjects in the coming months.

title: No Headline
description: DUE EAST By Valerie Sayers. 257 pp. New York: A Dolphin Book/Doubleday & Company. $15.95.

title: Court Defines Tenant Right as 'Property'
description: WHEN prosecutors in New York City began bringing the first cases several years ago, it was a novel legal theory: A tenant's right to occupy an apartment, while intangible, was nonetheless ''property,'' under the law in the same sense as the apartment building itself.

title: YEARNING FOR THE DAYS OF SPRING
description: MARCH: No month seems longer, 31 days without a break. Unless Easter arrives early - which this year it doesn't - no holiday gives transitory relief. The best March can muster is St. Patrick's Day; no wonder everyone turns Irish on the 17th. But you don't get a day off from work to celebrate or recover from it.

title: SURVIVORS, SOBBING WITH RELIEF, REACH BRITISH AIRPORT
description: About 200 survivors of the North Sea ferry sinking arrived back in England tonight, as relatives and officials of the Townsend Thoresen Company continued their vigil for the missing.

title: APARTMENT LIFE, WITHLOTS OF EXTRAS
description: Some elderly people are too healthy for nursing homes, yet wary of the fen-for-yourself living of a standard apartment complex. In an effort to create something in between, Paul T. Liistro is developing a retirement center in his hometown of Manchester, Conn., that will provide individual apartments as well as an exhaustive, perhaps an exhausting array of services.

title: FAST-TRACK FRAGRANCE
description: It seems that hardly a week goes by without some celebrity or another announcing plans to market a ''signature'' fragrance. But fragrance makers are not seeking only to sell to the fans of the famous.

title: TEACHING THE CONTRAS LEFTIST REBELS' METHODS
description: WITH new battle plans, weapons and American training the contra guerrillas appear to be on the offensive again in Nicaragua. Infiltrating from Honduras through jungle passes like the ones that crease this mountain zone, the rebels say they are making a final effort to become a guerrilla force able to challenge the Sandinistas for control of the country.

title: Seeking the Spirits of Bali
description: Down on Sanur Beach, where we used to watch the great sea turtles wade ashore in the moonlight to lay their eggs, female tourists from Europe now affront the Balinese by their casual immodesty. A small distance away lies Kuta, not so long ago one of the loveliest villages of the coast - and now two miles of close-packed bars, pubs, restaurants, money-changers, supermarkets, boutiques and rooming houses largely populated by young Australians.

title: NEVADA-LAS VEGAS WINS EASILY IN FINAL
description: Freddie Banks scored 12 of his 20 points in the first 10 1/2 minutes today as Nevada-Las Vegas, ranked No. 1 by The A.P., routed San Jose State, 94-69, in the championship game of the Pacific Coast Athletic Association tournament.

title: ALVARADO ASKED TO LEAD SCHOOL STUDY
description: Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan said yesterday that he would appoint former City Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado to head a panel to review the city's system of school decentralization and other education issues.

title: THE A.M. STATIONS GO FOR A FACELIFT
description: THE AM band has been the ugly member of the radio family since FM sprouted in the 1950's. FM sounded better; it had better programming; and its signal was clear enough to remain stable on most radios.

title: I.R.S. Offers Help
description: FOR taxpayers seeking help filling out their forms, the place to start is the 1040 booklet. It not only includes instructions for filing the 1040 return but also information on where to get additional, more detailed publications free from the I.R.S. By far the most comprehensive of these is Publication 17, entitled ''Your Federal Income Tax.''

title: IN COUNTY RACES, THEY'RE OFF
description: FACED with elections this year, the interim County Executives of Nassau and Suffolk are attempting to establish records they can run on.

title: OPERA: A PASTICHE, 'CHRISTOPHER COLUMBUS'
description: THE question boils down to this:

title: DEMOCRATS URGED NOT TO PIN HOPES ON IRAN ARMS CASE
description: Democratic leaders, saying that economic issues, not the Iran arms affair, will be the key to their party's resurgence, have begun warning the party not to depend on the scandal for victory at the polls in 1988.

title: Holly Phillips Married To Ernest Peter Wiehl
description: At the Episcopal Church of Our Saviour in San Gabriel, Calif., yesterday Holly Hamilton Phillips, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Albert Phillips 3d of San Marino, Calif., was married to Ernest Peter Wiehl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Alfred Wiehl Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., and Stuart, Fla. The Rev. Percy Jerkins performed the ceremony.

title: Lassitudes Of Working For Oneself
description: THE legions of the self-employed are growing, fueled by forces as disparate as waves of corporate mergers that prompt many managers to strike out on their own, to growing numbers of Americans choosing early retirement and becoming consultants. The new tax law will have a dramatic effect on these people. Many attractive tax options have been foreclosed, and complying with more stringent rules will bring on a blizzard of paperwork.

title: SUPPORTING THE CALL FOR AFFORDABLE HOUSING
description: It is indeed significant and heartwarming that Bishop John R. McGann of the Diocese of Rockville Centre is sounding the tocsin for affordable housing as a basic human right on the 50th anniversary of the Housing Act of 1937 [ Opinion Page, Jan. 25 ] . This act was the first national recognition that providing shelter for those unable to acquire it in the market was a public responsibility.

title: CAPE ACTS AGAINST HOUSING SHORTAGE
description: Cape Cod has an abundance of many things, like job openings, beaches, sea gulls, tourists and traffic jams, even in the winter. Two things, however, are now in very short supply - workers to fill those jobs, and housing that those workers can afford.

title: ICON OF MODERNISM POISED FOR EXTINCTION
description: THERE IS NOTHING, AT FIRST glance, particularly appealing about the Aluminaire House, a two-story box of glass and aluminum that sits on the grounds of an estate in Huntington, L.I. The house is surely not lyrical in its detailing, and it is somewhat graceless in its proportions. Moreover, bad alterations and years of neglect have put it in a condition that can most charitably be described as rundown. Yet this house, which was designed by Albert Frey - a disciple of Le Corbusier - along with Lawrence Kocher, and was owned for many years by the modernist architect Wallace K. Harrison, is among the pivotal works of modern architecture in America. Constructed in 1931 for a special exhibition sponsored by the Architectural League of New York, it may well have been the first prefabricated house in the country, and it is unquestionably one of the very first buildings in the United States designed in the modernist International Style.

title: DRIVER TRAINING AND CRASHES
description: ''A 'Skid School' for Drivers'' [ Feb. 15 ] suggests that drivers with skid training in particular and driver education in general are better drivers. Research evidence suggests otherwise.

title: ON INTRUDERS PARKING IN HANDICAPPED SPOTS
description: I read with interest your article of Feb. 8 on parking for the disabled [ ''Allocating Parking for the Disabled'' ] . Richard Manley [ director of the Office for the Disabled in White Plains ] can only be speaking from the perspective of one who need not use handicapped parking when he says he believes that few able-bodied people routinely abuse the privilege of using the parking spots for the disabled. My experience has not borne out his wishful thinking. As the parent of a handicapped child, I seem frequently to find myself circling around parking lots, looking at parking spots set aside for the disabled that appear to be illegally filled.

title: WRITING ABOUT THE MAGIC OF CHILDHOOD
description: ''YOU have to be some kind of peculiar person in that you straddle the line between childhood and adulthood, drawn to the world of magic.''

title: CONTRASTS IN MENU AND IN LOOKS
description: MARBLES in Locust Valley is a restaurant of contrasts. A huge 80-year-old bar with carved oak and mirrored backing, embellished by marble columns and marble railing, dominates the room. Ceiling fans, bentwood chairs, brass railings and wall sconces echo the turn-of-the-century feeling. One's eye then darts to the bright pink walls, the posters of modern art and a pink neon sign on the back wall spelling out Marbles, and we're back in the 1980's.

title: GRAF ROUTS LLODY, 6-2,6-2, FOR TITLE; LENDL AND MECIR IN FINAL
description: Her career is proceeding in fast forward, a dizzying climb that makes even Steffi Graf wonder whether it is all happening too quickly. A year ago, she had yet to win her first tournament, and now she is playing the best of any woman on the tennis tour. It does not appear to be a matter of if Graf will be No. 1, but when.

title: Cinema Verite
description: YEARS AGO, WHEN I was rooted in London, I was a regular contributor to The Spectator. Monday was a day of dread for the editors. Monday was the day Evelyn Waugh's postcard arrived listing the grammatical errors, misplaced commas and ill-advised semicolons in the most recent issue. I know exactly how the editors felt because my father, also a punctilious man, ruined not Mondays but the movies for me with his nit-picking.

title: Amelia Jones Wed To a Film Editor
description: Amelia Jones, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Edward E. Jones of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Anthony Sherin, a son of Edwin Sherin of New York and Los Angeles and Pamela Sherin of Princeton. The Rev. Carl Wartenburg, a Unitarian minister, officiated at Prospect House on the campus of Princeton University.

title:
GARDENING;
FLOWER SHOWS OFFER A HINT OF SPRING
description: LEAD: WITHOUT a doubt, the thought of gardens filled with spring flowers is about the best possible spring tonic.

title: MAKING VIRTUES OF HIS VICES
description: PAST TENSE Diaries: Volume I. By Jean Cocteau. Introduction by Ned Rorem. Translated by Richard Howard. 376 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: State Taxes, an Uneven Load: New Jersey
description: For taxpayers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the Tax Reform Act of 1986 is riddled with reductions and eliminations of long-cherished tax breaks, and for many in the three-state region unforeseen consequences await.

title: The Men Who Hold Colombia Hostage
description: CARLOS LEHDER RIVAS THOUGHT HE WAS safe from arrest. In fact, in all of Colombia, there were probably only a handful of officials who believed that he or any of a half-dozen other billionaire cocaine traffickers could be reached by the law. After all, the ''mafiosos,'' as they are known locally, had repeatedly defied the Government, murdering anyone, from Cabinet Ministers to Supreme Court justices, who stood in their way. Through terror and corruption, they had become in many ways more powerful than the state.

title: Marcia S. Ross Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Ross of Mount Vernon, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marcia S. Ross, to Todd A. Allen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherwin E. Allen of Baldwin, L.I. The future bride is a partner in Holstra/Ross Casting in Hollywood. Her father is a lawyer in Mount Vernon and a former New York State Assemblyman. Mr. Allen is a senior engineer for Citicorp T.T.I., a computer subsidiary of Citicorp in Santa Monica, Calif. His father and his mother, Rita Allen, are lawyers in Baldwin.

title: TOPIC
description: THE problem was that when a friend asked me if I could remember some ''first things'' that were important to me, I realized that I had blocked off a lot of those memories. Last things are better.

title: STATE'S BUREAU OF CARTOGRPAHY ENTERS THE COMPUTER AGE
description: DID YOU know there is a Miami Beach in New Jersey#1? And not one, but three Jacksonvilles#2? And even a Ukrainian Village#3?

title: 'The Second Oldest Profession'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW SEX MORES ARE CHILLING TV ARDOR
description: CHRISTINE CAGNEY, THE tough, glamorous, single cop on television's ''Cagney & Lacey,'' has not been shy about sex: Her lovers have included David, the civil-liberties lawyer who has been her steady boyfriend; Lars, a ski bum with whom she had a recent weekend fling; Ted, a paraplegic; Dory, a fellow police officer, and Ross, a journalist.

title: TRYING TO REGAIN THE MARKET IN CHIPS
description: SEVEN years ago, the suggestion that the American computer chip industry would have to band together for survival would have seemed absurd.

title:
FOCUS: Growth;
Coping in A Chicago Suburb
description: LEAD: THE difficulties of striking a balance between longstanding guidelines regulating growth and the growth itself are playing themselves out in this suburban Chicago village.

title: IN SHORT: NON-FICTION
description: THE INSANITY FILE: The Case of Mary Todd Lincoln. By Mark E. Neely Jr. and R. Gerald McMurtry. (Southern Illinois University, $19.95.) One of the saddest stories in the Lincoln family saga unfolds in detail for the first time in ''The Insanity File'' - the 1875 jury trial to declare Mary Todd Lincoln insane and the role played in it by Robert Todd Lincoln, her firstborn and only surviving son. To Robert fell the unhappy task of having his mother declared insane to protect her from harming herself and to conserve her estate. Documents pertaining to the case had been secreted in his country house in Vermont. A few years ago, they were turned over to two respected Lincoln scholars, Mark E. Neely Jr. and R. Gerald McMurtry, by Robert Todd Lincoln Beckwith, President Lincoln's last direct descendant. In a foreword, written before his death in 1985, Mr. Beckwith explains why he decided to let the details emerge: ''I believe that because of this file history will treat my great-grandmother Mary Todd Lincoln more kindly in regard to this very disturbing period of her life and most of all recognize that my grandfather acted in the best possible way towards his mother.'' The authors help answer the question: Should Robert have subjected his mother to humiliation and himself to heartache? They also discuss Illinois's liberal insanity laws, which required a jury trial to declare a person insane, and its property laws, which were harsher on women than on men. The story's sad conclusion: after spending several months in a sanitarium, Mary Todd Lincoln lived out her final years with a beloved sister in Springfield, Ill.

title: Aug. 8, 1985 Recalled
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PUBLIC'S FEELINGS ABOUT ITS FIRST LADIES ARE DECIDEDLY MIXED
description: ''DESPICABLE fiction'' were the words a visibly angry President Reagan used last week to denounce reports that his wife Nancy was an aggressive manipulator of the affairs of state, who, after three months of acrimonious trying, had succeeded in ousting Donald T. Regan as White House chief of staff.

title: MATERNAL MYSTIQUE AND TENDING PLANTS
description: FOR some time now, I have harbored a secret guilt regarding my adamant aversion to the growing of house plants. It is not the plants themselves that I object to; I love nothing more than a home overabundant in the lush greenery of nature. It is, rather, the actual caring and tending process that I dislike, the nurturing of sprouts, the trimming of overgrown foliage, the watering and transplanting, the threat of all manner of pests.

title: IN SHORT: NON-FICTION
description: THE DAVID LETTERMAN STORY. By Caroline Latham. (Franklin Watts, $15.95.) ''The David Letterman Story'' is just the kind of disposable product that the television talk-show host gives away to members of his audience in return for their contributions to, say, a ''Brush With Greatness'' segment of ''Late Night With David Letterman.'' The book's ridiculous quality is not entirely the fault of Caroline Latham, the co-author of ''Rose Kennedy.'' When she conscientiously narrates the events of Mr. Letterman's life and analyzes his success, she sounds like the sort of person the star makes fun of on television. When she tries to mimic the cheeky, wiseacre tone of the show, there is an edge of desperation in her voice. Her view of Mr. Letterman's humor - his rude, self-conscious but oddly cheerful deprecation of television's follies - is just accurate enough to explain why the book has no discernible audience: if Mr. Letterman's fans are as hip as she says they are, they are not likely to be in the market for quickie biographies. And her conclusion - that Mr. Letterman's television persona is a perfect reflection of the real David Letterman - is believable: he is as unmysterious a figure as television has to offer. But, then, why do we need a star biography? The interesting thing about ''The David Letterman Story'' is that in a way its subject would probably appreciate, it blurts out what it is: a Brush With Exploitation, publishing-style.

title: Are There Too Many Teams in the N.C.A.A. Tourney?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: CONCERT: ROSTROPOVICH AND OZAWA
description: MSTISLAV ROSTROPOVICH is celebrating his 60th birthday this year, and on Wednesday night he participated in a sort of jubilee concert at Carnegie Hall with the Boston Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Seiji Ozawa. Participated is probably too neutral a word, for Mr. Rostropovich was the center of attention the entire evening, playing his magnificent cello in three familiar and demanding works: Boccherini's Concerto No. 2 in D (G. 479), Strauss's ''Don Quixote'' and Prokofiev's Symphony-Concerto for Cello and Orchestra (Op. 125).

title: THATCHER IS GUARDED ON ARMS TALKS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has been guarded in her public response to the renewed push for a Soviet-American agreement on medium-range nuclear missiles, provoking her political opponents to portray her as bent on thwarting arms control.

title: PILOT AND AIRLINE IN DETROIT CRASH HAD A HISTORY OF VIOLATIONS
description: The pilot of a regional airliner that crashed and killed nine people Wednesday in Detroit was cited twice by the the Federal Aviation Administration for unsafe flying.

title: POSTINGS: V.A. Loans; Milestone
description: The Veterans Administration issued its 12 millionth home-loan guarantee on Friday, representing $275 billion in guaranteed loans since President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed the G.I. Bill during World War II. As of last year, 808,061 of those loans had gone to veterans in the New York metropolitan area.

title: CUENOD, AT 84, MAKES PEACE WITH PUCCINI
description: HUGUES CUENOD HAS been listening to ''Turandot,'' on and off, since 1928, and finds himself at last able to express a measure of qualified approval for the opera. ''Oh no, I didn't like the music,'' he hastened to explain over lunch last week. For anyone with French or German musical training - and Mr. Cuenod, who is Swiss, had both - the Italian composer's lush, sentimental operas were beneath contempt. ''People would compete with each other to say 'Puccini, bah.' ''

title: To Collectors, Sanibel Is a King's Crown
description: On the flight into Fort Myers, Sanibel and Captiva Islands look like nothing special, perhaps two of the more pleasant barrier islands along the Gulf Coast of Florida, forming a graceful crescent of green edged in white, a slice of nature less overbuilt than much of the surrounding suburban sprawl.

title: TWO BARITONES FOR THE AGES
description: Many of the best new records over the past year or so have been old. Two outstanding ones are Seraphim's boxed reissue of all the surviving recordings of the baritone Mattia Battistini (1856-1928; IG 6153) and the Metropolitan Opera's release of its own broadcast politan Opera's release of its own broadcast of ''Simon Boccanegra'' from 1939, starring The ''Boccanegra'' provides the rare experience of hearing one of Verdi's great baritone roles performed by a singer whose voice is capable of encompassing the demands of the score with beauty and confidence, and who sings with what is obviously a deep love for the character and the music. Tibbett's portrayal is something out of the ordinary; Ezio Pinza is a magnificent opponent for him as Fiesco. Giovanni Martinelli and Elisabeth Rethberg were somewhat past their best years by 1939, but the tenor is eloquent and the soprano is at least able to negotiate the role with security and authority.

title: Verbatim; Balancing Interests
description: ...the Constitution sometimes insulates the criminality of a few in order to protect the privacy of us all.' Associate Justice Antonin Scalia in a Supreme Court ruling refusing to expand police powers to search or seize objects they see that they suspect may be stolen.

title: NAVY CLEARS HURDLE ON PUGET SOUND BASE
description: Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington has given the state's approval for the Navy to build a home port here for the aircraft carrier U.S.S. Nimitz, a project that some see as the dawn of a new day for this economically depressed town and that others see as Doomsday.

title: No Headline
description: ONE ISN'T often treated to the development of full-scale new musicals in the state's regional theaters. With ''Little Ham,'' the George Street Playhouse here is offering such a treat - a modest one, but a treat is a treat.

title: HELP ON HOUSING SOUGHT IN CONGRESS
description: NEW YORK STATE and Westchester County officials are seeking help from Congress to remedy the lack of affordable housing in the county, a problem that has grown more severe as Federal assistance has been reduced during the Reagan Administration.

title: LIBRARY ELECTIONS: CONSOLIDATE THEM
description: SIX amendments to the United States Constitution have broadened the right to vote.

title: Lower Rates, Fewer Breaks
description: WELCOME to a new era in American tax policy. Tax rates are at their lowest level in more than half a century, and many long-cherished tax breaks have been sharply curtailed, if not banished outright. For individuals, the impact of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 extends well beyond the annual April 15 filing ritual. This new system of lower rates and fewer deductions holds important implications for the way people spend their money, save it and invest it.

title: BILLS ON GROUND WATER BEFORE CONGRESS AGAIN
description: AS Connecticut strives to locate new sources of ground water, state environmental officials are hopeful that Congress will expand Federal technical assistance.

title: THE DANCE: 'CHANNELS/INSERTS'
description: MERCE CUNNINGHAM is a generous choreographer, for he always gives one lots to look at. On Thursday night at the City Center Theater, when the Merce Cunningham Dance Company's program included ''Duets'' and ''Channels/Inserts,'' one could admire Mr. Cunningham's handling of large and small groups.

title: HELPING DISPLACED WORKERS IS COMPLEX
description: LEAD: SINCE its beginning in October 1983, the Title III program of the Federal Job Training Partnership Act (J.T.P.A.) has provided $17 million to retrain and give re-employment assistance to thousands of New Jersey workers who lost jobs at more than 450 plants that closed or cut back in that time.

title: Hudson Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: Uninspired Judging
description: Four years ago Brevard Hand, a Federal district judge in Mobile, Ala., held that the First Amendment's protections for religious liberty did not apply to the states. So Alabama, if it chose, could establish a state religion. Predictably, the Supreme Court reversed him on that point, unanimously, and struck down a school prayer composed by the governor and a ''moment of silence'' law intended as prayer. Judge Hand threatened at the time that if reversed, he might outlaw textbooks he deemed hostile to religion. Now he's done just that. His verbose, 111-page opinion makes no more constitutional sense than his earlier judgments but its effect is, at least temporarily, more serious. Alabama authorities have already started to remove schoolbooks the judge found inspired by ''secular humanism.'' The judge is right when he says a textbook that fails to make clear that the Pilgrims were religious is a deficient textbook. He's remarkably misguided when he says such a textbook amounts to an unconstitutional promotion of the secular humanist ''religion.''

title: Financial Markets Favored
description: IN the broadest sense investors should benefit from the Tax Reform Act of 1986 because the lower rates are aimed both at stimulating the economy and at letting individuals keep more of what they earn, thereby increasing the funds available for investment. Also, with tax incentives removed from real estate and other shelters, the financial markets are more attractive.

title: BETTER TO GIVE THAN RECIEVE, DEFINITELY
description: ARE you one of those people who receive a gift and, since they can't use it, can't resist the temptation of passing it on?

title: Patricia Yeh Plans to Wed Lawrence Lue in Autumn
description: Patricia Teresa Yeh and Lawrence Livingston Lue, who graduated from Cornell University in 1981 and received M.B.A. degrees in 1983 from New York University, plan to be married in the fall, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Yeh of Williamsville, N.Y., father and stepmother of the bride-to-be, have announced.

title: IRAN SAYS FORCES GAIN IN ATTACKS IN NORTHERN IRAQ
description: Iran said its forces, fighting in freezing weather, wiped out two Iraqi brigades in the snow-covered mountains of Kurdistan today.

title: INSIDE
description: Smoking and Philanthropy Many health and antismoking groups say the sponsorship of cultural activities by tobacco companies raises ethical questions. Page 34.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 8, 1987
description: Weeks This On Week List FICTION 1 6 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Bantam, $4.95.) A rich, beautiful young woman conquers the world of magazine publishing. 2 1 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.95.) A plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 3 7 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. (Fawcett, $4.95.) In the Republic of Gilead, men and women perform the services assigned them. 4 1 JOANNA'S HUSBAND AND DAVID'S WIFE, by Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey. (Dell, $4.50.) Two sides of a marriage revealed in diary entries. 5 51 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 6* 6 SEASONS OF THE HEART, by Cynthia Freeman. (Berkley, $4.50.) A businesswoman is torn between devotion to her husband and her mentor. 7 6 THE IMMIGRANT'S DAUGHTER, by Howard Fast. (Dell, $4.50.) The last volume of the Lavette saga tells of a woman involved in today's politics. 8 14 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) An Englishwoman in Afghanistan, caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B. 9 3 AMERIKA, by Brauna E. Pouns. (Pocket, $4.50.) The United States 10 years after a Soviet takeover. 10 9 THE STORYTELLER, by Harold Robbins. (Pocket, $4.50.) A poor boy from Brooklyn sets out to make it big in the world of glamour as a writer. 11 15 THE TWO MRS. GRENVILLES, by Dominick Dunne. (Bantam, $4.50.) Romance, scandal and murder in New York's high society. 12* 1 PRIVATE AFFAIRS, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $4.95.) A couple's marriage is seriously strained when they strike it rich in journalism. 13 1 THE LEBARON SECRET, by Stephen Birmingham. (Berkley, $4.50.) Love and conflict among a wealthy family of California vintners. 14 15 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $4.95.) Ayla of ''The Valley of Horses'' resumes her adventures in the prehistoric world. 15 1 TO TASTE THE WINE, by Fern Michaels. (Ballantine, $4.50.) An English beauty's passionate affair with a handsome Australian. Weeks This On Week List NONFICTION: General 1 4 WISEGUY, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Pocket, $4.50.) Life in a Mafia family. 2 49 OUT ON A LIMB, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $4.50.) The actress's midlife ''journey to find her true self.'' 3 2 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 4 176 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 5 15 DANCING IN THE LIGHT, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $4.50.) The entertainer wins an Oscar, survives a stormy romance and has new visions. 6 9 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) Strange neurological disabilities. Weeks This On Week List NONFICITION: Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 40 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. (Pocket, $4.50.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 2 6 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $4.95.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 3 5 THE FRUGAL GOURMET, by Jeff Smith. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A television chef's inexpensive dishes. 4 17 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1987. 5 24 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 6* 7 THE ARTHUR YOUNG TAX GUIDE 1987. (Ballantine, $10.95.) Aid from an accounting firm. 7 40 ADULT CHILDREN OF ALCOHOLICS, by Janet Geringer Woititz. (Health Communications, $6.95.) Advice about a family problem. 8 18 THE FAR SIDE GALLERY 2, by Gary Larson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $9.95.) Cartoons. 9 7 J. K. LASSER'S YOUR INCOME TAX. (Prentice Hall, $8.95.) The 1987 edition. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. The number of titles within the two subdivisions of nonfiction can change from week to week, reflecting changes in book buying. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: By Contrast to Carter
description: To the Editor:

title: MANDOLINIST, VIOLINIST AND TWO CLARINETISTS
description: Neil Gladd

title: Dina Cathey Plans To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sterling Eugene Cathey of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Diane Cathey, to Michael Nettleton Millard, a son of Mrs. Donald Henry Millard of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Dr. Millard. A June wedding is planned.

title: REBOUNDING NETS DOMINATE 76ERS
description: After a game last month, Coach Dave Wohl fined his Nets' players for an overall lack of effort. Last night, after his injury-riddled team's 114-102 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers, Wohl was generous in giving credit.

title: Death Penalty Is Upheld, in Theory, By New Jersey Court
description: After two years of deliberation, the New Jersey Supreme Court last week upheld the state's 1982 death penalty statute in a decision that may, at the same time, have made it easier for defendants to avoid execution.

title: REBELS WORK HARD FOR A BIG PAYOFF
description: FOR the nation's No. 1-ranked college basketball team, the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, practice had ended.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: BEHIND DONALD REGAN'S DOWNFALL;
WHY BUSINESSMEN FAIL IN GOVERNMENT
description: LEAD: BLAME the current turmoil in the White House on Franklin D. Roosevelt. He appointed Louis Brownlow in 1936 to head a committee on management of the executive branch. It was the Brownlow Committee that recommended creating the Executive Office of the President, which would be patterned after the modern corporation.

title: Drew Knowlton Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carlisle Knowlton of Haddam, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Andrews Knowlton to William L. Schaeffer, a son of Mrs. J.Peter Schaeffer of New York and the late Mr. Schaeffer. The wedding is to be May 30.

title: ANTI-SMOKING GROUPS QUESTION ETHICS OF TOBACCO CONCERNS' GIFTS TO THE ARTS
description: When the Joffrey Ballet begins its national tour in Denver next week, the name of the largest cigarette manufacturer in the United States - Philip Morris Companies Inc. - will appear on thousands of the dance group's program guides and promotional posters.

title: A TASTE OF THE WILDS OF MICHIGAN
description: In the small resort town of Petoskey, Mich., there's a northwester blowing off Lake Michigan, swirling snarls and gusts of snow up and down the streets. If residents of the town, on Little Traverse Bay, wonder how they will survive another northern Michigan winter, they have only to walk into the modest showroom of American Spoon Foods. There, the proprietor, Justin Rashid, is supervising the mixing of a batch of plum ketchup in one kettle and in another, a vinaigrette dressing made with red raspberry vinegar lightly sweetened with wild flower honey. The aromatic fragrance is both reminder and affirmation of the northern Michigan spring and summer to come. American Spoon Foods, which began as a small one-man operation five years ago, now markets its products by catalogue and in 400 stores across the country. For her book ''The Best Tastings: From Ketchup to Caviar,'' Jennifer Harvey Lange had a panel of experts rate more than 60 international brands of strawberry preserves. American Spoon Foods was No. 1, which resulted in a sellout of this year's supply.

title: Rewards of a Literary Marriage
description: At a time when mediocrity comes from even some of our best writers, Joan Didion and John Gregory Dunne are special people who have chosen, correctly, the novel as the necessary medium to deliver their experiential insights to us (''Didion & Dunne: The Rewards of a Literary Marriage,'' by Leslie Garis, Feb. 8).

title: Rome Flea Market
description: To the Editor: Grazie molto for Louis Inturrisi's wonderful article on Porta Portese (''Roman Flea Market,'' Jan. 4). As a student who lived in Rome for five months, I spent many Sundays wandering the stalls of this exciting market - certainly one of most entertaining ways to spend a Sunday morning (especially on a student's budget).

title: Allison B. Conway Is a Bride
description: Allison Brandes Conway and Richard Brian Carey, vice presidents in the investment banking sector of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York and London respectively, were married yesterday at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn Heights. The Rev. Frank A. Goodwin, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Harry Kreuner, retired minister of the church and also a Baptist, and Msgr. Charles E. Diviney, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
GARDENING;
FLOWER SHOWS OFFER A HINT OF SPRING
description: LEAD: WITHOUT a doubt, the thought of gardens filled with spring flowers is about the best possible spring tonic.

title: Bolshoi Boy in a Romp
description: Morning thunderstorms turned the $133,810 Gulfstream Breeders' Cup today from a 15-horse grass race to a five-horse dirt race, but the loss turned out to be more quantity than quality. Bolshoi Boy, a prominent 3-year-old last year, showed he may be a major force this season by scoring a four-length victory over Arctic Honeymoon, Little Bold John, Smile and Come Summer on opening day at Gulfstream Park's winter meeting.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Boonton Picking Itself Up After a Slide
description: LEAD: AFTER 15 years of a sinking economy, Boonton is beginning to show clear signs of recovery. A 50-acre light industrial/warehouse complex with more than 300,000 square feet of space is now under consideration and two residential projects with a total of 73 units are soon to be developed.

title: A Daughter's Father
description: One hopes Richard Sandza will come to understand that growing up ''big and strong'' doesn't mean being an N.F.L. quarterback (''A Daughter's Father,'' About Men, Feb. 1). It means being big enough and strong enough not to worry about a tiny scar over an eyebrow any more than Golda Meir worried about the wart on her face or Senator Barbara Mikulski of Maryland worries that she isn't as tall as George Bush.

title: FIRST, SET HIGHER ETHICAL STANDARDS...BUT NEW RULES ARE NEEDED, TOO
description: THE insider trading scandals have left the investment community shell-shocked, reeling in an atmosphere of betrayal, anger, and self-doubt. Stronger enforcement and some new regulations will deter future violators, yet those of us on Wall Street have already been galvanized into taking steps that, I am confident, will further reduce these abuses. To see why, we must understand the problem.

title:
ART;
SARAH LAWRENCE GALLERY ACTS TO STRENGTHEN ITS EXHIBITIONS
description: LEAD: THE story out of the Sarah Lawrence Art Gallery in Yonkers is twofold. The far-reaching part is a new dedication on the gallery's part to prestigious gallery exhibitions. This will be overseen by a newly named gallery board whose members have strong ties to the New York art world.

title: Pamela Wilds, a Business Consultant, Becomes Bride of Todd Godwin Cole
description: Pamela Wilds, a corporate consultant in New York, was married yesterday to Todd Godwin Cole, who recently retired as chairman of the C.I.T. Financial Corporation. The Rev. John G.B. Andrew performed the ceremony at St. Thomas's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about the Jay property in Rye incorrectly described a boundary line of the site. It is adjacent to the Marshlands Conservancy, which borders Long Island Sound. Because of an editing error, the name Alansten was used incorrectly. It is the name by which the Peter Jay House was once known.

title: WAS S.M.U. PENALTY APPROPRIATE?
description: The penalty imposed on S.M.U. for repeated infractions of the N.C.A.A. code was one the representatives of the member schools of the N.C.A.A. imposed upon themselves. It is not as if S.M.U. had no representation in the N.C.A.A. Any school that might have had reservations about the N.C.A.A. position was free to withdraw from the N.C.A.A. Since S.M.U. did not do so, it therefore subscribed to the penalties. So in good conscience (assuming that the heirs of the Wesleyan tradition do indeed have such item in their life style) no complaints about the penalties are in order.

title: A TALE OF MYSTERY AND SUSPENSION
description: The engineers who mastered the North American continent with railroads, dams, canals and bridges, last century and this, are among the great unsung national heroes. For the 50th anniversary of the Golden Gate Bridge, John van der Zee tells the story of the structure's creation, and while its realization was a complicated act of finance, politics and architecture, it was, above all, a masterpiece of engineering. Until THE GATE: The True Story of the Design and Construction of the Golden Gate Bridge (Simon & Schuster, $19.95), however, the authorship of its structural design was obscured by the practice - still common among many design firms - of attributing credit to the head of the firm responsible for the project. Joseph Strauss, of the J. B. Strauss Company of Chicago, indeed was the bridge's great promoter. But the book - organized like a whodunit - reveals that neither Strauss nor the famous New York engineers who worked as consultants really engineered the bridge. It was a professor from the University of Illinois who came to work on the bridge for the Strauss firm, and was dismissed after it was designed. This is a story of passions and the slide rule - of the exquisitely fragile moments when an engineer plumbs the subtle, not completely understood nature of a structure, and of credit for the results. The author of works of fiction and nonfiction, Mr. van der Zee shows us how the professor, Charles Alton Ellis, expanded knowledge of suspension bridges by his work on the Golden Gate and even discovered, after being pulled off the job, a flaw lurking in the concepts on which the calculations were based. The book is not only a tribute to what the author calls ''a democratic masterpiece.'' It also sets the record straight: it was Ellis who did it.

title: BEIJING PARTY DIRECTIVES CRITICIZE OUSTED LEADER
description: In the two months since student protests led to the dismissal of Hu Yaobang as the party leader, a series of Central Committee documents have attacked the protesters, criticized Mr. Hu and outlined the limits of the campaign against Western ideas.

title: CHANGE IN THE LAW ON PRESCHOOLERS
description: The accurate report ''New Rules Affect Preschoolers'' [ Feb. 8 ] provided a great deal of complex information of value to all those concerned with the needs of these children. The article will be very useful for parents, agencies and legislators who are not yet familiar with the Federal Amendments of 1986 to the Education of the Handicapped Act.

title: HOW THE ISRAELIS FELL INTO STRAINS WITH WASHINGTON
description: IN the history of Israeli-American relations, the last two weeks probably marked one of the lowest points. First, the Tower Commission report singled out Israel for encouraging and facilitating - for its own interests - the American arms-for-hostages deal with Iran. The ink on that report had barely dried last week when a Federal District Court in Washington sentenced Jonathan J. Pollard, the former Navy intelligence analyst, to life imprisonment, and his wife, Anne Henderson Pollard, to five years, for espionage on behalf of Israel.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WEITZ TO SPEAK ''I am normally not a novelist,'' said John Weitz, the celebrated fashion designer, who added that he would talk about ''what it is like to decide to write a book when writing is not your profession.'' The talk begins at 4 P.M. today in the Hackley School Chapel, Tarrytown.

title: WHAT DOES HE WANT WITH THE TRUTH?
description: CHARADE By John Mortimer. 188 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: A TREASURE GOES PUBLIC
description: ERNEST ERICKSON - A Finnish-born New York collector, described as obsessive and an intensely private man - would probably have been distressed to see his name on two exhibitions from his collection of ancient Asian and American artifacts on view this month at New York museums.

title: OUR CLOCK RUNNETH OVER
description: WINSTON CHURCHILL'S AFTERNOON NAP A Wide-Awake Inquiry Into the Human Nature of Time. By Jeremy Campbell. 432 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: 4 PUNJAB POLICEMEN WOUNDED IN SIKH TEMPLE
description: Four Punjab policemen were wounded by gunfire today after entering the interior of the Golden Temple at Amritsar, the Sikh religion's holiest shrine, according to news agency reports.

title: LIFE, DEATH AND THE AUDIENCE
description: IN THE VIOLENT SHIFT OF EMO-tional key that occurs toward the end of Woody Allen's film ''Radio Days,'' a fractious Brooklyn household suddenly halts its squabbles to listen to an urgent radio news bulletin. Somewhere in the rural American heartland, a somber announcer informs his nocturnal audience, a young girl has tumbled into a well and is in grave danger of losing her life. Up to this point ''Radio Days'' has lovingly re-created the fizzy kiddies' serials, game shows and pop music entertainments of radio's halcyon era before World War II. But in this sequence Mr. Allen obliquely prefigures a darker modern world, of unspeakable national tragedies and increasingly proficient electronic media, that would follow in the war's wake.

title: Recent Sales
description: Farmingdale $165,000 17 Baldwin Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, attached 1-car garage, aluminum siding; taxes $2,700. Holtsville $150,000 137 Abner Drive 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 23-year-old high ranch; eat-in kitchen, deck; taxes $2,600. Massapequa $283,000 39 Jackson Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; den with fireplace, waterfront property, 1-car garage; taxes $3,600. Nesconset $225,000 4 Meryl Lane 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; den, finished basement, office, in-ground sprinklers, 1-car garage; taxes $5,000. Selden $116,000 9 Larry Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; family room, patio, above-ground pool, 1-car garage; taxes $1,800. Smithtown $184,000 64 River Heights Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 21-year-old ranch; dining room, den, cedar siding, 0.5 acre, 1-car garage; taxes $3,800. OTHER AREAS Avon, Conn. $362,500 37 Brookridge Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old contemporary; built around courtyard, marble fireplace, 1 acre; taxes $6,364. New Rochelle, N.Y. $194,800 201 Mayflower Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 29-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, family room, walk to schools and stores; taxes $2,551. West Orange, N.J. $231,000 7 Knollwood Drive 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; deck, 2-car garage, full basement; taxes $5,000.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Inventories and Inflation A stronger economy and growing exports will encourage businessmen to slowly build up inventories, says Morris Cohen, president of Morris Cohen & Associates, a Hackensack, N.J., consulting firm. He expects the increase in non-farm inventories to be $12 billion higher this year than in 1986.

title: WHAT DOES SPEED SAY OF A PLAYER?
description: The length of the games a player wins tells more about his style than about his strength.

title: WHAT'S SHORTER, MORE COLORFUL -- AND MAYBE EASIER TO READ?
description: FIRST there was the Tax Reform Act of 1986, promoted on its promise of simplification. And indeed, it lowered the rates most people pay. Then there was the Internal Revenue Service, directed to create a new W-4 form for taxpayers to compute how much should now be withheld from their paychecks. And then came the howls of confusion, anxiety and frustration from taxpayers, their accountants and the politicians who represent them all.

title: ISLANDERS LOSE MOMENTUM AND GAME
description: From the start tonight, their plans went awry, and as too often occurs when the Islanders don't receive immediate gratification for their effort, they ceased to make the effort.

title: MCKAY'S SPURT TAKES 400 IN 45.98
description: The first world indoor track and field championships were truly international today.

title: EVEN MATHEMATICIANS CAN GET CARRIED AWAY
description: CARRYING exactitude to a staggering extreme, a Japanese computer scientist has calculated the value of pi to more than 134 million decimal places.

title: Tanzanian Treasures, New Wing in Boston
description: Rock Art From The Stone Age

title: Filling Out The Forms
description: A walk through Form 1040 with top professionals can help taxpayers both in organizing their records for the preparation of this year's return and - particularly important in this transition year -planning tax strategies for future years. S. Theodore Reiner, Marc D. Levy and Nicholas Giordano, tax specialists for Ernst & Whinney in Washington, prepared a sample return for a two-income New York couple. Key points of the return are explained in the accompanying commentary, and particular attention is given to areas where the new tax law will call for changes in planning or treatment. FILLING OUT THE 1040

title: NORTH'S AIDES LINKED TO AUSTRALIA STUDY
description: Several former military and intelligence officers who helped Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North ship weapons to Iran and Central America were closely associated with the co-founder of an Australian financial concern that collapsed in 1980, according to an Australian Government investigation.

title: A Promise of Legal Relief For AIDS Victims
description: AIDS came up only in a footnote, but a Supreme Court decision last week in an employment discrimination case seemed to dispatch an Administration argument that had worried homosexual-rights advocates for months.

title: A TOP PLAYER NEARS A TITLE IN BRIDGE PLAY
description: One of the leading players in the world women's rankings was in a commanding position going into the final session of the National Women's Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here tonight.

title: Deborah Glick Weds
description: Deborah Karen Glick, a group product manager for Pfizer Laboratories in New York, and Richard Dale Kirschner, a lawyer in New York, were married last evening in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Alan Greenspan performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club. The couple's parents are Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Glick of Liberty, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Kirschner of Clifton, N.J.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A GENTLEMEN'S GAME THESE are not your typical athletes. But then the Gentlemen's Hockey League of Long Island is not your typical athletic league.

title: THATCHER VISITS FERRY SURVIVORS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, during a short visit today with hospitalized British survivors of the ferry accident, repeatedly praised Belgium's rescue efforts.

title: INTERPEX WILL OPEN ON THURSDAY
description: The premier event of the season, Interpex '87, will open Thursday through Sunday at Madison Square Garden, 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Hours are Thursday noon to 6 P.M., Friday 11 A.M. to 7 P.M., Saturday 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Sunday 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Michigan Shocks Purdue, 104-68
description: Antoine Joubert scored 20 of his 30 points in the first half today as Michigan crushed Purdue, 104-68, dashing the Boilermakers' hopes for an outright Big Ten championship.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THAT BOWLING ALLEY ON THE TIBER: Tales of a Director, by Michelangelo Antonioni. Translated by William Arrowsmith. (Oxford University, $7.95.) The film director offers a collection of 33 mood pieces that our reviewer, Stephen Schiff, described in 1985 as ''literary doodles for films he never made.'' The sketches ''are sometimes mere fripperies, but at their best they are something more - plangent, haunting and refreshingly tough-minded.'' They can also be seen as ''a record of the fiction-making impulse'' and an attempt to claw toward the truth beneath the filmic appearance. MONKEYS, by Susan Minot. (Washington Square/ Pocket Books, $5.95.) Susan Minot's chronicle of an upper-middle-class New England family with seven children is ''a rare book - a subtle, funny and often extremely moving first novel,'' A. R. Gurney Jr. said in The Book Review last year. Set between 1966 and 1979, the book consists of nine sections, each devoted to an important incident in the Vincents' lives and seen mostly through the eyes of Sophie, one of the daughters. The author ''conveys the special texture of life in a large family,'' the reviewer said. DANCE: A Short History of Classic Theatrical Dancing, by Lincoln Kirstein. (Dance Horizons/Princeton Book Company, $15.95.) This history of classic theatrical dancing traces the art from its primitive ritual origins to modern times. Reviewers in 1936 found it a work of ''intelligence, scholarship and taste,'' and particularly eloquent in discussing the Renaissance beginnings of ballet. While Mr. Kirstein places the dance works themselves at the center of his analysis, another approach can be found in Walter Sorell's DANCE IN ITS TIME (Morningside/Columbia University, $14.50), a history of dance in its literary, artistic and sociopolitical context. Anna Kisselgoff, writing in The Times in 1981, said ''Mr. Sorell has researched an enormous amount and this is the first dance-related book to bring so many threads together.'' COUNTRY COUSINS, by Michael Brownstein. (Sun & Moon Press, $11.95.) Martin Kilbanky, the lunatic, sex-crazed hero of this novel set in 1959, has come into a fortune and sets about satisfying his two obsessions - his dream of building a house, and the body of his best friend's wife. In 1974 our reviewer, Karyl Roosevelt, noted the book's ''manic vitality'' and called it an example of ''fiction that is well crafted and yet experimental enough'' to be seen as ''completely original.'' BATTLES OF LIFE AND DEATH, by David Hellerstein. (Warner, $6.95.) A young doctor's casebook, ''Battles of Life and Death'' consists of 13 true stories -about a burn victim, cancer and stroke patients, a kidney-transplant recipient and others - from the author's medical school and residency experiences.
