Last year our reviewer, Mike Oppenheim, said most of the cases ''make stomach-churning, horrific reading,'' but admired two of the entries, particularly one about trying to reform an incompetent second-year resident, written ''with genuine insight and compassion.'' A PUZZLE FOR FOOLS, by Patrick Quentin. (Penguin, $5.95.) Patrick Quentin was the pen name of Hugh Callingham Wheeler, who switched to playwriting later in life and, under his own name, wrote the books for such Broadway productions as ''A Little Night Music,'' ''Candide'' and ''Sweeney Todd.'' ''A Puzzle for Fools'' (written in collaboration with Richard Wilson Webb, as were all the ''Quentin'' murder mysteries until 1952) introduces Peter Duluth, an alcoholic who gets involved in sleuthing after a series of murders at the expensive sanitarium where he is drying out. In 1936 our reviewer, Isaac Anderson, said the hospital, ''with its slightly mad patients and its coldly scientific medical staff, makes an excellent setting . . . and the author has used it to the best advantage.'' The same publisher has reissued two more Peter Duluth mysteries, PUZZLE FOR FIENDS and PUZZLE FOR PILGRIMS ($5.95 each). In the first, the amnesiac Duluth finds himself in a household of calculating women who insist he is their son, brother and husband. ''The sultry beauties and cushy California setting make this diablerie good warm weather diversion,'' Mr. Anderson said here in 1946. In ''Pilgrims,'' Duluth's unfaithful spouse is among the suspects when her lover's wife dies in a fall. ''What a predicament for an amateur detective!'' Mr. Anderson said here in 1947. BREAKING THE SILENCE, by Walter Laqueur and Richard Breitman. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) The authors reconstruct the life of Eduard Schulte (1891-1966), the German industrialist who tried in the early 1940's - vainly - to alert the Allies that the Nazis intended to exterminate Europe's Jews. The tale is told resourcefully, Henry Ashby Turner said here last year, but despite the authors' efforts, ''the man himself remains elusive.'' VILLAGE SCHOOL, by ''Miss Read.'' (Academy Chicago, $6.95.) Dora Jessie Saint, under the pen name Miss Read, has written some two dozen novels of the bygone days of English country life. The first, ''Village School,'' describes a year in the life of the headmistress of a school in a remote hamlet. A work of ''charm and grace,'' the book ''lingers in one's mind as something true, rare and lovely,'' Mary Ellen Chase said in The Book Review in 1956. The same publisher has reissued VILLAGE DIARY ($6.95), which continues the headmistress' chronicle of life at the school and in the village of Fairacre. The same reviewer in 1957 said the ''author has many wise things to say about the changing face of English village life.'' LIBERTY, A BETTER HUSBAND. Single Women in America: The Generations of 1780-1840, by Lee Virginia Chambers-Schiller. (Yale University, $11.95.) This history of the lives and works of more than 100 single women in antebellum America focuses on middle- and upper-class Northeasterners. In 1984 one reviewer found it ''well written, masterfully organized, skillfully researched, and highly original.''

title: Second Act
description: In his notes for ''The Last Tycoon,'' F. Scott Fitzgerald made a singularly chilling statement: ''There are no second acts in American lives.'' Anyone reading it, facing it - and needing a bracer - has only to look to the career of Millicent Fenwick, who is leaving her job as the United States ambassador to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.

title: Fields in Fettle
description: NEVER GIVE A SUCKER AN EVEN BREAK With W.C. Fields, Margaret Dumont, Franklin Pangborn, Leon Errol. 1941. Kartes Video Communications. 71 minutes. $19.95.

title:
WINE;
CHOOSING ROBUST BARGAINS
description: LEAD: A NUMBER of local shops and restaurants stock some excellent bargains in robust wines. When sipped alone, these products may not please every palate, but most make perfect accompaniment to the hearty fare commonly served this time of year.

title: Research Rocket Explodes
description: A small suborbital rocket carrying an experiment for the University of California at Berkeley exploded about 20 seconds after lifting off Friday night from a launch site in Poker Flats, Alaska, space agency officials said today. The Black Brandt X rocket, 17 inches in diameter and 30 to 40 feet tall, blew up about 10 seconds after ignition of the second stage, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said. A NASA representative said 40 to 45 of these research rockets are launched annually, with a success rate of 95 percent.

title: Fitzgeralds and Kennedys
description: To the Editor:

title: STUBBORN MEMORIES OF CHILDHOOD HOME
description: I GO from room to room remembering. I stop at my sister Pattie's old room and remember how pretty she looked as she stepped into her bridal dress 25 years ago. ''I'm feeling happy but nervous,'' I can hear her saying. And that's how I'm feeling about moving from my childhood home in Scarsdale to a condominum in Northern Westchester. Happy but nervous.

title: THE CORRESPONENT
description: I HAD WAITED FOR THIS FILM A very long time.

title: 28 Injured in Trolley Crash
description: A commuter trolley jumped its tracks while crossing a bridge over the Schuylkill and hit a car Friday evening, injuring 28 people, the authorities said. One passenger was hospitalized and 26 other passengers and the trolley operator were treated for minor injuries, the police said. The driver of the car was not injured.

title:
DINING OUT;
A DEARTH OF SEAFOOD RESTAURANTS
description: LEAD: THERE'S a certain uneveness in New Jersey when it comes to the type of restaurants available in most areas. For instance, no one would deny that there's a surfeit of Italian restaurants. There are also plenty of Chinese and Continental restaurants and steak houses, if those chains are included. Even

title: FASHION PREVIEW: LONDON
description: LEAD: BRITISH DESIGNERS DISPLAY A growing confidence about their place in international fashion - without sacrificing the freshness and individuality for which they are so justly known - in the fall and winter collections to be shown in London next weekend, From the tailored but flirtatious mood of Rifat Ozbek to Betty Jackson's restrained softness, from the dramatic flare and fit of Alistair Blair to the jaunty ease of Workers for Freedom, the

title: UNCERTAIN DAYS FOR CATCHERS-EMPLOYED AND UNEMPLOYED
description: THE Unsigned Eight have become the Unsigned Seven, but Andre Dawson's name-the-salary deal with the Chicago Cubs will not necessarily make any impact on a collection of catchers unemployed and employed.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
LIFE IN RETIREMENT: SENSIBLE QUESTIONS
description: LEAD: THE OTHER day, I was helping Mrs. B., an active, healthy, 74-year-old retired college professor, make a major decision: Should she enter a Continuing Care Retirement Community, also called a Life Care Community?

title:
NATURE WATCH;
KNOBBED WHELK
description: LEAD: Busycon carica Size: To nine inches.

title: THE EXUBERANCE AND DIGNITY OF LEONARD BERNSTEIN
description: The preponderance of new records I come across repeat the obvious, so it is nice to find the occasional item that actually enriches the known or else opens a door to the less familiar. Leonard Bernstein and the forces of the Bavarian Radio, for example, bring to Haydn's much-loved choral piece ''Paukenmesse'' the exuberance we have long associated with Mr. Bernstein, but here accompanied by a patient, measured dignity. This is a Philips compact disk (412 734-2) and worth the attention of all Haydn lovers.

title: WAS S.M.U. PENALTY APPROPRIATE?
description: The penalty was not appropriate because it will have no impact in the long run. As long as bigtime college athletics are million-dollar enterprises, and newspapers run the point spreads next to the schedules, we need only wait for the next scandal to hit. Given the atmosphere in intercollegiate Division I sports and the control exercised by alumni and athletic directors, until the presidents and the faculties assume the responsibility for their athletic programs, we will continue to have periodic scandals, outrages and deaths.

title: Deborah Ironson Marries a Writer
description: The marriage of Deborah Ann Ironson, a vice president in the North American department of Chemical Bank in New York, to Jordan Irving Katz, a writer, took place last evening at the home of Judge and Mrs. Burton J. Ironson, parents of the bride, in Springfield, N.J. Rabbi Israel S. Dresner performed the ceremony.

title:
PATENTS;
A New Cable Device To Lift Aircraft Cargoes
description: LEAD: Edwin Z. Gabriel, an engineering consultant in Ocean Grove, N.J., believes the hoist cable coupling device he patented this week will facilitate the loading and unloading of cargoes in helicopters and other aircraft.

title: WHERE'S THE GAME TONIGHT? ALL OVER THE COUNTY
description: In Atlantic City it's the Golden Nugget or Caesars. In Baltimore County it's the St. Charles Borromeo School or the Pikesville Volunteer Fire Department or other unlikely institutions and groups that have been swept up by gambling fever.

title: Diocese v. Parish Over Prayer Book
description: OF all the Episcopal churches in Connecticut, only Trinity-St. Michaels in Fairfield refused to use the denomination's revised ''Book of Common Prayer'' or to recognize the ordination of women as priests. The vestry said the prayer book, revised in 1979, was tainted by feminism and secular humanism.

title: A PEEK AT I.B.M.'S TRUMP CARD
description: LUIS ARZUBI leaned over a microscope here the other day, focused on a small part of a silicon wafer jammed with hundreds of memory chips, and said with a broad smile: ''Here, look at this.'' Etched into the silicon, alongside the expected line of densely packed memory cells and razor-straight circuitry, was an unexpected image: a leaping gazelle.

title: Ms. Hawthorne Wed To Edward D. Agne
description: At the Unitarian Universalist Church in Marblehead, Mass., yesterday Nancy Hawthorne, the daughter of Mary Elizabeth Hawthorne of Swampscott, Mass., and Francis J. Hawthorne of Richmond, was married to Edward D. Agne, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl O. Agne of Dayton, Ohio. The Rev. Elizabeth Leavitt performed the ceremony.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
FINLAND IS HONORED WITH 'COIN OF THE YEAR'
description: LEAD: An unusual silver commemorative from Finland has been named ''Coin of the Year'' in a competition sponsored by a major hobby publisher. The winner is a 50-markkaa coin issued as a tribute to the Kalevala, Finland's national epic poem. Presentation of this year's ''Coin of the Year'' award will take place April 8th in Washington at the residence of the

title: WHERE LIFE ALWAYS WINS
description: PLAYBOYS AND KILLJOYS An Essay on the Theory and Practice of Comedy. By Harry Levin. 214 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $18.95.

title: THE BATTLE OF BLUFF POINT: RECREATION VS. CONSERVATION
description: GROTON has 26 miles of coastline and no public bathing beach. One member of the community has gathered the signatures of 3,500 people who say the state-owned preserve at Bluff Point should be modified to fill the need.

title: U.S. SENATOR FROM NEBRASKA
description: Senator Edward Zorinsky of Nebraska, a maverick politician who switched from Republican to Democrat and then threatened to switch back again, died of a heart attack Friday after performing a song-and-dance routine that made fun of his threats to switch allegiance. He was 58 years old.

title: Dana DuGan Is Wed
description: Dana Fanshaw DuGan, the daughter of Capt. John Ross DuGan, U.S.N., retired, of West Palm Beach, Fla., and Mrs. William Bruce Cary of Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard Snowden Andrews 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrews Jr. of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Kenneth Gorsuch performed the ceremony at the West End Collegiate Church in Manhattan.

title: Fighters Fined $2,500
description: ALTHOUGH Donald Curry won his junior middleweight fight against Tony Montgomery after Montgomery was disqualified for repeatedly butting Curry last month, both fighters have been fined $2,500 apiece by the Nevada Athletic Commission. Curry was fined for going over and punching Montgomery behind the head after the bell had rung ending the bout, and even though he had already written a letter of apology to the commission he was further instructed to write a letter of apology to James Molinell, the referee who was grazed by the punch of rage thrown at Montgomery.

title: NEW FOCUS OF FEMINISTS: THE FAMILY
description: LEAD: CHANGES in the once-traditional family and increasingly vocal cries for help by modern households have spurred the General Assembly and feminists to make family and day-care issues a priority this year.

title: Icahn and USAir Go Head to Head
description: USAir scoffed at Carl C. Icahn's bid to buy it for $1.65 billion, saying it was a ploy to prevent it from taking over Piedmont for the same amount. USAir's merger talks with Piedmont were complicated by Mr. Icahn's offer, USAir said it was determined to go ahead with its plans, but it apparently is worried enough by Mr. Icahn's bid to be looking elsewhere for a suitor. Mr. Icahn appeared determined, too, and took USAir to court to block the airline from adopting any poison pill defenses. Analysts said he appeared to be using the same approach he used to buy T.W.A. -slowly gain control of the company through stock purchases while using diversionary tactics such as the highly visible cash offer. Other analysts think Mr. Icahn, who already owns 15 percent of USAir, may have another goal in mind: goading USAir into offering to buy T.W.A. $ ? * * *

title: In Queens, Blockbusting to Build Apartment Houses
description: LEAD: GLORIA FRANCHINO has opened her door four times in the last year to solicitors who have offered to buy her two-bedroom bungalow on Kneeland Avenue in Elmhurst, Queens, for all cash.

title: CUOMO INTENSIFIES CALL FOR SCHOOLS TO TEACH VALUES
description: Governor Cuomo this week intensified his call for the teaching of values in the public schools, saying that American youth is adrift with little guidance on the difference between right and wrong.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
ANALYZING PREJUDICE
description: LEAD: Prejudice - its causes, manifestations and remedies - will be the topic when a conference on ''Appreciating Differences'' gets under way Wednesday, from 8:30 A.M. to 2:45 P.M. at the Natural Sciences Building on the Purchase campus of the State University of New York.

title: NEEDY AGED GET MEDICAL PLAN
description: LEAD: WHEN William Volz of Elizabeth learned last September that he had bladder cancer, he wondered how he could pay for the surgery and follow-up care needed to save his life.

title: TAKING A RISK: 'DANGEROUS GROUND'
description: THE Arena Players Repertory Theater produces a wide variety of work, from classics to light British comedies to new American plays. It is in this last capacity that the Arena, as well as other theaters on Long Island that take a risk with new work, fulfills its function as a regional theater.

title: ANN ALLEN BRIDE OF JOHN KAUCHAK
description: At St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic church in Short Hills, N.J., yesterday Ann Elizabeth Allen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Allen of Short Hills, was married to John Joseph Kauchak, the son of Joan Kauchak of Colonia N.J. and John F. Kauchak of Linden, N.J.

title: Why No Women in Recent Public Scandals
description: To the Editor:

title: Celtics Undermanned
description: WHEN the Boston Celtics step on the Silverdome floor for their nationally televised game against the Detroit Pistons in Pontiac Mich. today, they'll be doing it with just nine men. Most conspicuous among the missing will be Larry Bird, who continues to struggle with a strained lower back that kept him out of Friday night's 132-111 romp over the Los Angeles Clippers in Boston Garden. Also missing will be Sam Vincent, with a sprained knee and Rick Carlisle, at home with an intestinal virus.

title: PRETORIA OPENS INQUIRY ON DETAINEE TORTURE
description: South Africa's police commissioner ordered an investigation today into accusations of ''horrendous'' brutality against detained black youths.

title: THOSE TRICKY MUTUAL FUND COSTS
description: UNTIL recently, mutual fund investors faced a simple choice: They could buy no-load funds directly, or they could purchase load funds and pay a broker's commission of up to 8.5 percent. But now it requires a heavy dose of new math to compare the costs of different funds. Apart from the customary operating expenses and management fees, fund managers have devised a farrago of other charges - high or low loads imposed when you buy, exit fees when you sell and some hard-to-find fees levied while you hold the fund.

title:
MUSIC;
SYMPHONY EXPANDING ITS SEASON
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, with a $4.2 million budget, will go from 46 concerts in the current 1986-87 series to 52 next season.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ON THE CONSTITUTION Dr. Christopher Collier, Connecticut State Historian and professor of history at the University of Connecticut, is to offer the first in a series of three lectures on the United States Constitution with a talk on ''Connecticut and the Constitution,'' 7:30 P.M. Tuesday at the Connecticut Historical Society, 1 Elizabeth Street, Hartford.

title: A HAUNTING WORK FOR ORCHESTRA AND SOPRANO
description: The record I have listened to most often this past year is the Symphony No. 3 by Henryk Mikolaj Gorecki (Erato ERA 9275, no cassette or compact disk), featuring the Symphony Orchestra of the Southwestern Radio, Baden Baden, conducted by Ernest Bour. It is a grave, melancholy work for orchestra and soprano, ineptly packaged with a cover that makes it look like punk rock, with no information about the composer, the artists or the origins of the symphony, no texts or translations. But the music -consonant, slow-moving, prayerful, both minimalist and Wagnerian - is haunting. I find the Gorecki symphony has its seasons: sometimes I will become impatient with its sequences and repetitions; at other times, it will move me like few other recent works. The performance seems authoritative, although Stefania Woytowicz's soprano is sometimes hooty.

title: A Daughter's Father
description: As not-so-new parents, we were alarmed to discover that Richard Sandza imagines his daughter has no need to grow up big and strong.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Kansas City, Mo.; Failed Project Is Demolished
description: LESS than 30 years after it was built, the Wayne Miner Court housing project had become so rundown that Kansas City officials considered letting the state use it as a prison.

title: TRANSIT BRIEFS
description: LEAD: PEOPLE using NJ Transit buses will not have to fumble for change for fares when a high-tech collection system goes on line next year.

title: OUTLOOK FOR SHELTERING THE POOR GROWING EVEN BLEAKER
description: WHEN the Supreme Court ruled this year that people living in public housing could sue for lower rents in Federal court, lawyers for the plaintiffs proclaimed a victory for 3 million low-income tenants across the nation. But as is usual in the case of public housing, any good news tends to be overshadowed by persistent troubles.

title: Comatose Woman's Fetus Is Focus of Dispute
description: For nearly three months, Colleen V. Fuller has been comatose in a hospital here with brain injury caused, the authorities said, when she tried to hang herself in the city jail after being arrested on an assault charge.

title: FOR JAPANESE, ANTI-SPY BILL RAISES FEARS
description: Osamu Watanabe, who makes his living by dispensing legal counsel, gets an unhappy look when he talks about a proposed new law to protect Japan's military secrets. It reminds him, he says, of his schoolboy days during World War II, when his parents did not want even to mention the military for fear of possible arrest.

title: REAGAN INSURANCE PLAN APPEARS HELPFUL TO FEW
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal to protect the elderly against catastrophic medical costs would offer significant help to relatively few people, mainly those with incomes just above the poverty line, according to Government figures and other analyses.

title: SOLUTIONS SUGGESTED FOR REPAIR PROBLEMS
description: TO catch up on mail, the Home Clinic column is again devoted to answering questions about frequently encountered repair and maintenance problems.

title: Thomas Wolfe
description: To the Editor:

title: The A.M.T., Alleviating The Anxiety
description: ITS name is a mouthful and its potential for increasing the tax bill of many individuals this year is enormous. So as millions of taxpayers prepare for April 15, there is increasing anxiety about the alternative minimum tax, or A.M.T.

title: PANEL URGES HOUSING EMPHASIS IN URBAN ZONES
description: CONNECTICUT, which pioneered the creation of enterprise zones to create more jobs in its blighted inner-city neighborhoods, is embarking on a major expansion of its five-year-old program.

title: JAZZ CONCERT: COMPOSERS ORCHESTRA
description: A BIG band doesn't have to sound like the big bands of yesteryear. It can also deploy trumpets, trombones, saxophones and a rhythm section for noise or neo-classicism, as the 16-member New York Composers Orchestra did in its concert Friday at Greenwich House Music School. The concert was the second of two programs of premieres by orchestra members (the pianist-conductor Robin Holcomb and the pianist Wayne Horvitz) and other composers. The group's skill, enthusiasm and discipline ought to encourage others - in and out of jazz - to write for it.

title: Oliver North's Strange Recruits
description: Edwin P. Wilson, the now-jailed, former Central Intelligence Agency operative, used his C.I.A. and military connections to establish a flourishing business as an international arms dealer (''Oliver North's Strange Recruits,'' by Peter Maas, Jan. 18).

title: OVERNIGHT SENSATION UPSTAGED
description: THE Big East tournament record lasted nearly 16 hours; the euphoria lasted only a few hours longer.

title: THE DEEPER CHALLENGES OF STRIKING A MISSILES DEAL IN EUROPE
description: THE nature of an imaginable war in Europe suddenly looked different last week. The restless Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, had boldly moved on the arms-negotiation chessboard, offering to give up a mighty arsenal of SS-20 missiles in exchange for a lesser one of American Pershing 2 and cruise missiles. With its European allies nervously kibitzing, the United States seemed ready to accept the Russian gambit on medium-range missiles in Europe.

title: Lori Mendelsohn Weds B. J. Meek
description: The marriage of Lori Fran Mendelsohn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Mendelsohn of Tampa, Fla., to Brian Joseph Meek, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Meek of Greenwich, Conn., took place yesterday. The Rev. Richard D. Bingham, a minister of the United Methodist Church, and Rabbi Samuel Silver performed the ceremony in the Dome Room of the Main Building at the University of Tampa, where the bride's father is a professor of English.

title: The Co-op Index: How It Works
description: To the Editor Your article regarding a new cooperative-apartment value survey [ ''Forecasting Prices in Manhattan,'' Feb. 8 ] did not fully explain how the Douglas Elliman Index works.

title: FISH AND CLAMS BEING DUMPED
description: MILLIONS of pounds of whole fish and clam meat, which scientists say are valuable sources of protein for both animal and human consumption, are being thrown overboard along the coast or dumped at southern New Jersey landfills.

title: DIRECTOR OF ALL HE SURVEYED
description: SECRECY AND POWER The Life of J. Edgar Hoover. By Richard Gid Powers. Illustrated. 624 pp. New York: The Free Press. $27.95.

title: Dance
description: Merce Cunningham has long been fascinated by indeterminacy and change, and he knows that the same movements can often be used in different ways. Take those in ''Points in Space.'' The work, with music by John Cage, was commissioned as a videodance by the BBC last May, and that version will be shown in England later this year. Yet a stage version of the piece will receive its premiere by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Tuesday night at the City Center. For Mr. Cunningham, choreography is subject to change.

title: Panel Criticizes Ward At Racial-Strife Forum
description: Speakers at a forum on racial violence held in a Harlem public junior high school yesterday condemned Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward for saying the Police Department was anticipating mass demonstrations this summer, and called for the removal of the Policeman's Benevolent Association president, Phil Caruso.

title: Do We Want a New Reagan but the Old Policies?
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN ANXIETY COMES TO BAT
description: WHEN JIM EISENREICH takes the field for the Kansas City Royals this afternoon, during spring training in Fort Myers, Fla., he will say a prayer that his dreams do not come true. In his dreams -recurring nightmares, really - he is playing outfield. The air in his lungs begins to feel like wet ashes, and he can't expel it. He bends at the waist to force it out, but it doesn't help. He worries that the fans or, worse, his teammates will notice his peculiar movements. He kicks at the weeds around his feet, trying to conceal his distress. In another moment, he tells himself, he will have to call ''time.'' He looks in to the pitcher, but the pitcher is staring out at him. Eisenreich is no longer able to control his body's cries for air. He gasps, and bolts awake.

title: Seeds, Like Hope, Spring Eternal
description: LEAD: Once again, the W. Atlee Burpee Company has worked its subtle persuasion on my will and imagination, to say nothing of my checkbook. My order for this summer's garden is being borne to the firm's headquarters as if on the wings of Mercury. And, yes, I am excited. For there is something uplifting in this seasonal ritual.

title: LEARN TO SKI BETTER
description: Warren Miller Sports Films. Karl Lorimar Home Video. 83 minutes. $24.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Feb. 8 on ''red-bag'' waste incorrectly identified the incineration site visited by Diane Carr, chief of staff for Assemblyman Patrick G. Halpin, Democrat of Lindenhurst, in June 1986. The facility she visited was the Energy Combustion Corporation plant in Old Bethpage, which has been closed, and not Medi-Waste Inc. of West Babylon.

title: ETERNALLY EVIL AND NEVER OUT OF WORK
description: LEAD: MEPHISTOPHELES The Devil in the Modern World. By Jeffrey Burton Russell. Illustrated. 333 pp. Ithaca: Cornell University Press. $24.95.

title: THE JOY OF SKIING
description: As a couple who enjoy skiing with our children and grandchildren, we feel compelled to comment on Barbara Klaus's ''Long Island Sound'' article on Feb. 1 [ ''Skiing: Are We Having Fun Yet?'' ] .

title: SHOREHAM DEBATE SPREADS TO NEW FRONTS
description: LEAD: THE Federal suit filed against the Long Island Lighting Company last week was only one of a number of current developments weighing on the fate of the plant and its owner.

title: A Verdict Eludes Gotti Jurors In First Day of Deliberations
description: The jury in the John Gotti trial met for eight hours on its first day of deliberations yesterday without reaching a verdict. Deliberations will resume today.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: AGRICULTURE MUSEUM ALTHOUGH it has no building to call home, the Agricultural Museum of the State of New Jersey does not exist on paper only.

title: BUILDERS PUSH TO CANCEL LIMIT ON APPRENTICES
description: BUILDERS are trying to get the State Department of Consumer Protection to rescind a rarely enforced regulation that requires most construction workers at a company have at least four years' experience.

title: Charles Clement 3d Is Wed To Barbara Koltes Sadtler
description: Barbara Koltes Sadtler, executive director of public relations for Estee Lauder International, and Charles F. Clement 3d, a managing director of Prudential-Bache Capital Funding, both in New York, were married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church. The Rev. H.Hays Rockwell performed the ceremony.

title: A Comeback For Prison Boat
description: Not since the Revolutionary War has there been a prison boat in New York Harbor, but the city, its jails bulging with inmates, announced plans last year for such a boat.

title: Cuba's Presence In Angola
description: There's nothing so ''strange'' about Cuba's presence in Angola; James Brooke's study of the history of the region is just incomplete (''Cuba's Strange Mission in Angola,'' Feb. 1). For starters, John Stockwell, the Central Intelligence Agency chief in Angola in 1974-75, writes in his book, ''In Search of Enemies,'' that the United States had opposed the Movement of the Popular Liberation of Angola (M.P.L.A.) in the 1960's and titilylyrerevented Angola's different political factions from negotiating a settlement. The United States promoted the military solution, via the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) and South Africa, and it was in response to their attacks that Cuba sent its troops.

title: FOR TALL EXECUTIVES: TWO BUMPS A DAY, $600 AN INCH
description: EVERYONE wants to be a person of ''towering accomplishments.'' It's always a compliment when someone refers to you as a ''corporate giant.'' But what if you are literally a corporate giant? In group photographs of the top brass at Chemical Bank, for instance, Walter Shipley always stands out. Not because he's the chairman. It's where his head is. Mr. Shipley is 6-foot 8. You look at his face and then you glance down quite a ways to the others.

title: Ms. Spanbauer To Wed in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Spanbauer of Brevard, N.C., of the engagement of their daughter Jo Ann Spanbauer to David Bruce Hardison, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Hardison of Falls Church, Va. The wedding is to be June 13.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption Feb. 15 misidentified a building in the Belem district of Lisbon. The photograph shows the Tower of Belem.

title: HEAVEN AND THE MODERN WORLD
description: LEAD: THE COLLECTED POEMS OF CARL RAKOSI 498 pp. Orono, Me.: The National Poetry Foundation. Cloth, $35. Paper, $12.95. COLLECTED POEMS By Samuel Menashe. 220 pp. Orono, Me.: The National Poetry Foundation. Cloth, $18. Paper, $12.95.

title: THE MESSAGE IN THE MORASS AT S.M.U.
description: THE not-so-sudden death of football at Southern Methodist University finally occurred last week. For the many men and women of integrity associated with S.M.U., and for its bright young students, it is a modern American tragedy that has come full circle.

title: WHY FEDERAL ATTORNEYS ARE THE GANG-BUSTERS NOWADAYS
description: TOMORROW in Federal Court in Brooklyn, a jury is to hear more disclosures about an alleged $30,000 payoff to former Taxi and Limousine Commissioner Jay L. Turoff and a million-dollar scheme to monopolize the city's taxi-meter business. On Wednesday, across the East River in Manhattan, Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic party leader, and three associates are scheduled to be sentenced in Federal Court for their roles in the corruption scandal at the city's Parking Violations Bureau. The two cases, both involving graft at high echelons of city government, illustrate a growing tendency on the part of Federal authorities to snare major municipal corruption inquiries from the city's five district attorneys.

title: U.S. AND CHINA UNITED BY ANTIPATHY TO THE SOVIET UNION
description: NOBODY who knew Ronald Reagan's devout anti-Communism could have imagined that as President he would be helping ''Red China'' manufacture its own ammunition for 105 millimeter howitzers, training elite Chinese industrial managers and coordinating American and Chinese military aid to an Asian guerrilla force. But just as Americans' stereotypes of Chinese have oscillated through the decades between negative and positive images, between the Chinese as sinister hordes and the Chinese as industrious toilers, so have formal relations.

title: MATERNITY WITH LUXURY
description: THE spacious pastel-colored rooms have rocking chairs, double beds, ample bureau space, color televisions and private bathrooms. You can dial room service and waiters bring gourmet dinners served on chinaware and crystal. Meals that include chicken cordon bleu, prime rib, or even champagne and candlelight, are typical fare. And for the ultimate in luxury, a jacuzzi is down the hall.

title: Real Estate Loses Much Of Its Glory
description: AS a result of last year's tax act, the real estate industry may no longer be the most favored child of the Internal Revenue Code, but it is still part of the royal family of investments.

title: AN OPPORTUNITY TO BE SILENT AND THINK ABOUT NEW GOALS
description: WHEN I was a boy, I recall my grandfather's sitting quietly in his armchair, smoking his pipe and being very silent. When he did venture a remark about world affairs or the weather, my grandmother would snarl at him:

title: AGUKLERA PITCHES IMPRESSIVELY BUT METS DROP SPRING OPENER
description: Four and a half months after they won the World Series in a swirl of last-gasp rallies, the Mets took the field again today and opened their 30-game exhibition season with cheers and memories but not enough runs to beat the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: BEATLES ON CD: YEAH, YEAH, NAH
description: TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGO TOday, the BBC broadcast an innocuous pop variety show called ''Teen-ager's Turn'' - a program that would probably have slipped through the cracks of pop-music history but for the fact that one of the bands making its radio debut that afternoon was a quartet called the Beatles. At the time, the Beatles were a dance-hall rock group with a growing following in northern England and in certain racier districts of Hamburg. But broader success was eluding them. Two months earlier, they had auditioned for Decca Records, which turned them down on the ground that guitar groups were passe. And they would collect record label rejection slips for several more months before George Martin, a producer at EMI's moribund Parlophone subsidiary, decided to give them a chance.

title: Powerful Verdi
description: DON CARLO By Verdi. With Luis Lima, Ileana Cotrubas, Giorgio Zancanaro, Robert Lloyd, Bruna Baglioni. The Royal Opera Chorus and Orchestra of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. Conducted by Bernard Haitink. Stage production, scenery and costumes by Luchino Visconti. Directed for television by Brian Large. Home Vision. 207 minutes (2 cassettes). $59.95.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: HOUSE

title: CANTON IDEA: CERTIFY ALUMNI
description: IF the Canton Superintendent of Schools has his way, when an employer finds a Canton High graduate to be educationally defective, the school system will fix the student free. His idea likens students to consumer products, a comparison some people approve of and some do not.

title: MCCRACKEN TO SING IN CENTENNIAL 'OTELLO'
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey State Opera will celebrate the 100th anniversary of Verdi's ''Otello'' this evening with a production starring the tenor James McCracken in the title role and, in her first major operatic appearance, the young American soprano Rebecca Copley as Desdemona.

title: Karen Ann Sharkey Wed to Alan Sheriff
description: Karen Ann Sharkey, a daughter of Mrs. Peter Salzone of Dongan Hills, S.I., and Alan R. Sheriff, a son of Nancy Sheriff of Manhattan and the late Saul H. Sheriff of Portland, Me., were married yesterday. The Rev. William J. Bradley, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: WAS S.M.U. PENALTY APPROPRIATE?
description: Woeful irony: John Wesley's great-grandchildren called to repentance by the prophetic moralists of the N.C.A.A.!

title: Explosion Damages School
description: A private elementary school was damaged early today by a fire and explosion that fire officials have labeled suspicious. No injuries were reported. Five nuns living at the school, St. Raphael's Elementary School, had to leave an adjoining building, said Officer Paul Kunz, a spokesman for the Nassau County police. Gasoline had been poured throughout the school building, he said.

title: Results Plus
description: SKIING Zurbriggen Wins Title: Pirmin Zurbriggen, leading a Swiss sweep of the top three places, won ''America's Downhill'' on Aspen Mountain in Aspen, Colo, yesterday and added the World Cup downhill title to the overall crown he captured a week earlier. Zurbriggen edged a teammate, Daniel Mahrer, by 5-hundredths of a second. Zurbriggen was timed in 1 minute 47.29 seconds down the icy, bumpy course, and Mahrer had a 1:47.34. Karl Alpiger, was third in 1:48.04.(AP) First Canadian Winner: Pierre Harvey of Quebec became the first Canadian to win a World Cup cross-country race, overwhelming the rest of the field by more than one minute in a 30-kilometer, freestyle-technique event at Falun, Sweden. The 29-year-old Harvey, whose best previous high in a World Cup race had been a fourth-place finish, was timed in 1 hour 17 minutes 46.5 seconds. Aleksei Prokurorov of the Soviet Union was second in 1:18:58.4.(AP) HIGH SCHOOLS Stevenson and Lincoln Advance: Stevenson of the Bronx and Lincoln of Brooklyn advanced to the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship tournament. Stevenson (24-1) beat Taft, 66-61, and will play Lincoln (21-4), which topped Grady, 71-67. The other semifinal Saturday at St. John's will match Far Rockaway (19-3), a winner over Martin last Thursday, against Springfield Gardens (22-2), which beat Newtown Friday. The winners will meet for the P.S.A.L. championship March 21 at St. John's. The Catholic High Schools Athletic Association semifinals, which will be Tuesday at St. John's, will pit Molloy (22-2) against Tolentine (22-4) and Cardinal Hayes (19-7) against Monsignor McClancy (17-8). Lynch and Galeano Impressive: Nnenna Lynch and Joe Galeano were among the impressive winning performers at the New York State Interscholastic Boys and Girls indoor track and field championships in Cornell's Barton Hall at Ithaca, N.Y. Nnenna, a 15-year-old sophomore at Manhattan's Hunter College High School, won the girls' 1,000- and 1,500-meter runs in the space of a little over two hours. She was timed in 2 minutes 51.96 seconds for the 1,000 and at 4:39.46 in the 1,500 as she led in both races from start to finish. Nnenna duplicated the double victory of her sister, Shola, in last year's title meet. Shola, a senior at Hunter who won the 600 and 1,000 in 1986, was ineligible for the meet because she did not participate in any of four qualifying meets. Galeano, a senior a Long Island's Centereach High School, won the 55-meter high hurdles in the meet and state record time of 7.22 seconds and the high jump at 6 feet 10 inches. Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn registered a meet record of 7:53.66 in the boys' 3,200-meter relay. Sonya Henry of Freeport set a state record with a long jump of 19 feet 9 inches. HORSE RACING Why Not Try Is Winner: Angel Cordero Jr. rode his fourth winner of the afternoon when he guided Why Not Try to a one-length score in the $87,600 Swift Stakes for 3-year-olds at Aqueduct. The Swift, at six furlongs, is the first of four New York prep races for the Triple Crown series, followed by the seven-furlong Bay Shore, the Gotham Mile and the mile-and-an-eighth Wood Memorial. Battle Man, the runner-up, finished five lengths ahead of the favorite, Z. Plasty. Why Not Try, a son of Cutlass and the Peace Corps mare Soon I Hope, was timed 1:10 3/5 for his fourth consecutive victory.(AP) Demons Begone Wins: Demons Begone, one of the top 2-year-olds in the country last year, stamped himself as a stong Kentucky Derby contender with an easy victory in the $59,900-added Southwest Stakes at Oaklawn Park in Hot Springs, Ark. Demons Begone, who had not raced in four months, circled the leaders on the turn and coasted home eight lengths in front of Wayne's Crane. The time for the mile was 1:34 3/5, one fifth off the track record, and jockey Pat Day never whipped the winner. (AP) LUGE Masley Takes National Title: Frank Masley of Newark, Del., won the national championship at Lake Placid, N.Y., his fourth national title since 1979. Masley, with a time of 1:27.857 seconds, beat two other former titleholders. Miro Zajonc of Annapolis, Md., the 1983 world champion, finished second. Tim Nardiello of Lake Placid, the 1984 national champion, finished third. In the women's division, Bonny Warner of Mount Baldy, Calif. captured her third national championship in 1:19.810.(AP) GOLF Langer Leads by 2: The $600,000 Honda Classic may come down to a battle between the two most prominent cross-handed putters on the PGA Tour: Bernhard Langer of West Germany vs. Bruce Lietzke of Oklahoma. Through the third round, Langer had the edge because he dropped a 12-foot birdie putt with a cross-hand stroke on the 15th green to break a tie for the lead. Then he parred the 18th where Lietzke took a bogey. That sent Langer into today's final round with a two-shot lead over Lietzke and Mark Calcavecchia, a standard-grip putter, who birdied No. 17 to move up with Lietzke. Langer, who led Lietzke by two shots when the rain-delayed third round began on the 7,037-yard Tournament Players Club at Eagle Trace in Coral Springs, Fla., shot two-under 70 for a 54-hole score of nine-under 207. Lietzke had 70 for 208 and Calcavecchia, who caddied for Ken Green in the Honda a year ago, had 68-209.

title: A HOUSE THAT SPREAD ITS WINGS
description: LEAD: THE old Kline house at a country crossroad outside Flemington was built when Hunterdon County was still woodland but being cleared for farms.

title: IN SHORT: NON-FICTION
description: LEAD: THE PRIVATE POLAND. By Janine Wedel. (Facts on File, $17.95.) After two stays in Poland (in 1982-84 and in 1985-86) doing research in social anthropology, Janine Wedel tells us that she began to understand the country. ''The Private Poland,'' written in a light style, is a general reader's guide to everyday life there.

title: NURSING PROFESSION AND POWER
description: As the leader of special seminars designed to assist women in finding fulfillment in their work, including many involving nursing professionals, I would like to comment on the Feb. 8 article ''Nursing Shortage Has Become Acute.''

title: Commercial Radio Arrives in Southern China
description: ''Good morning. It's 5 o'clock, and this is Zhou Yu on the Pearl River Economic Radio Station.''

description: International 3-23

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: SIX CHILDREN IN SEARCH OF A FORTUNE
description: LEAD: JOHNSON V. JOHNSON By Barbara Goldsmith. Illustrated. 285 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Duluth, Minn.; Lakefront Revival
description: THE second phase of a downtown and lakefront redevelopment project is beginning to take shape here in Minnesota's third-largest city, helping to restore and revive a long-neglected area plagued by retail vacancies.

title: L.I. OFFICIALS SEEK CHANGES IN LANDFILL LAW
description: LEAD: A THREE-PRONGED attack was begun last week by Long Island officials to change what is widely regarded as one of the most controversial environmental laws ever mandated by the state.

title: FODOR'S MEXICO VIDEO GUIDE
description: J. Mitchell Johnson, executive producer. HBO/Cannon Video. 75 minutes. $29.95.

title: PHILANTHROPY IN A TIME OF TIGHTER GIVING
description: THE young social activists of the 1960's are not expected to become the big givers of the 80's, even though many nonprofit organizations are counting on them now that Federal budget cuts have made the groups more dependent on private funds.

title: Julie Meyjes Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. C.Robert P. Meyjes of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Julie Elizabeth Meyjes to Gregory Langdon Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan C. Smith of Greenwich, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: Investor Profiles: Changing Strategies Under the New Law
description: Now that revisions in the nation's tax code have become law, taxpayers are being forced to examine new and varied investment strategies. Here, three groups of investors discuss how their planning has been affected, and what changes they will make as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. DIVERSIFYING INVESTMENTS

title: THE MARINE OFFICER
description: GOING TO A SUNDAY AFTER-noon movie is usually a good tonic for a retired Marine general suffering from midwinter blues. I did just that a couple of weeks ago with three of my adult daughters. Fortified with popcorn, we settled down in a suburban theater to see the much heralded ''Platoon.''

title: Jonestown Epilogue
description: In a flashback to a horror tale, Larry Layton, a onetime follower of the Rev. Jim Jones, a California cult leader, was sentenced to life in prison last week in San Francisco. Mr. Layton had been found guilty in Federal district court of conspiring in and aiding and abetting the 1978 murder in Guyana of United States Representative Leo J. Ryan of California, who was there to look into reports that cult members were being prevented from leaving the settlement known as Jonestown. Three journalists and a would-be cult defector were also shot down, and Mr. Jones and more than 900 members of his People's Temple killed themselves by swallowing a soft drink spiked with cyanide. Chief Judge Robert F. Peckham, who held Mr. Jones ''primarily responsible'' for the carnage, said Mr. Layton would be eligible for parole after five years instead of the customary 10. The trial, his second in Federal court, had been delayed during years of appeals over rulings on the admissibility of evidence.

title: Gibbs's Task: Rebuilding The I.R.S.
description: THE ghost of 1985 still haunts the Internal Revenue Service. Talk to tax lawyers, agency employees, even some taxpayers, and they say that 1985 remains fresh in their minds - the year when the agency's computers suddenly went beserk. The machines lost countless returns, sent thousands of erroneous letters to taxpayers demanding payments, and, in general, created the greatest collection of woes the service has ever seen. New hardware and software were installed, and all seemed to go smoothly last year.

title: TV AND TRAFFIC SYSTEM SHARE CABLE UNDER PATERSON STREETS
description: With the flick of a switch this week, Mayor Frank X. Graves turned on a computer-controlled system that will monitor traffic on the city's streets and quickly change traffic signals to reroute vehicles around jams or accident sites.

title: POT AU FEU FOR A LARGE MEAL-IN-ONE
description: POT AU FEU is an excellent soothing dish to serve guests in cold weather. All the ingredients are simmered together in one pot in an aromatic broth. These include a beef brisket, larded with pieces of garlic and fresh tarragon, a chicken, marinated in lemon juice and thyme and stuffed with herbs, breadcrumbs and prosciutto, a whole calf's tongue and garlic sausage. Winter vegetables such as potatoes, carrots, celery, parsnips and leeks are also cooked in the broth.

title: Take-Home Pay On the Rise
description: As a result of the new, lower Federal withholding tables, wage earners realized a year-over-year increase in take-home pay, effective with their first paycheck in January. The biweekly benefits for various income classes are shown below. The percent column is after withholding for both Federal income tax and F.I.C.A. tax.

title: TOWN REGULATES TANNING SALONS
description: THIS quiet Somerset County commuter town may not be at the forefront on many issues, but it is breaking ground on tanning salons.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN RADIO BROADCASTIN
description: THIRTY years after it lost the battle for the living room to television, the radio industry is facing an all-out war. Faced with music videos, compact disk players, portable cassette decks and digital record players, it is up against an ever-increasing number of competitors that are either distracting its audience, attracting its advertisers, or both.

title: REAGAN STRIVES TO DISPEL IMAGE OF HANDS-OFF LEADER WHO LOST TOUCH
description: THE stakes were high as President Reagan, the old master of television oratory, addressed the nation from the Oval Office last week. The Tower Commission report on the Iran-contra affair had not dealt with him kindly; he was a ''President who didn't do his job,'' as one member, Edmund S. Muskie, put it. The President's approval rating had dwindled to its lowest point in four years, and two-thirds of those questioned by a New York Times/CBS News poll said others, not the 76-year-old President, were in charge.

title: MAKING THE TENANT THE 'RENTER'
description: WHAT is a ''renter''? Someone who rents an apartment, the layman is tempted to venture.

title: Cuba's Presence in Angola
description: In referring to the 30,000 Cubans protecting his Administration and the Chevron oil facilities at Cabinda, Jose Eduardo Dos Santos, Angola's M.P.L.A. chief, claims that ''these forces are not paid.'' In a sense, he is correct.

title: GRUMMAN MAKES PLANS FOR A 'PRESSURE-COOKER YEAR'
description: AS 1986 came to a close, John F. O'Brien, president of the Grumman Corporation, one of the nation's largest defense contractors, looked ahead, forecast a ''pressure-cooker year'' in 1987 but said he did not foresee ''any need for layoffs.''

title: AUCTIONEERS AS RARE AS THEIR WARES
description: IT was four years ago last October that D. Wayne (Dick) Johnson was preparing for his 27th auction of rare medals and coins. A printer made an error in addressing labels and half of his customers did not receive the catalogue. Mr. Johnson lost $40,000 on the sale, and his auction house promptly went out of business.

title: COMPUTERS THAT DOUBLE AS TURNTABLES
description: TO a computer, a radio show is only so many hundreds of thousands of bits of data. And a growing number of studios are introducing computers that transmit that data, in the form of sound. The result is that some disk jockeys who gave up records for tape are spinning disks again - floppy ones.

title: Christine Bergin Becomes a Bride
description: Christine Bergin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Bergin Jr. of Washington, was married there yesterday to Edward W. Whittemore Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Whittemore of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. David Mudd performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church.

title: IN SHORT: NON-FICTION
description: LEAD: IN HITLER'S GERMANY: Daily Life in the Third Reich. By Bernt Engelmann. Translated by Krishna Winston. (Pantheon, $21.95.) When asked why she was risking her life to save a stranger from the Gestapo, Annie Ney, the proprietor of a cafe in Dusseldorf, said simply, ''Because I don't want to be ashamed of myself when I come to stand before my God.

title: CONCERT: ABBADO LEADS VIENNA PHILHARMONIC
description: THERE are those who question our late-20th-century culture's seeming fixation on Beethoven, on Beethoven concert cycles, on Beethoven recorded cycles. Right now, starting last night, New York is being favored with another such series - this time of the complete symphonies and concertos plus three overtures in six concerts through Friday night, with the first two installments of Deutsche Grammophon's recorded cycle of the symphonies already in the stores. But if we are to have yet another onslaught of Beethoven, then where better than Carnegie Hall, and who better by than the Vienna Philharmonic?

title: REPRODUCING FINE ART IN PHOTO
description: A VIRGINIA artist has asked me to reveal the secret technique of photographing works of art, since the slides she has made of her own watercolors fail to convey them accurately. This is not an uncommon lament. And having once aspired to copy artworks as a means of making a living, I know too well the problems involved. In copying paintings - as in all its other functions - photography is not always the honest witness it is cracked up to be.

title: ASLEEP AT THE REMOTE CONTROL
description: TALKING TOMBSTONES And Other Tales of the Media Age. By Gary Gumpert. Illustrated. 206 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $17.95.

title: Coghlan: 'Let It Die'
description: After 12 hours of trying on Friday - with running, appeals and pleas - Eamonn Coghlan, the world's most celebrated indoor miler, abandoned his attempt to get into yesterday's 1,500-meter final at the world indoor track and field championships in Indianapolis.

title: Officials Cite 32 Food Outlets
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 32 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: WHEN TWO COLLEAGUES CHOREOGRAPH IN TANDEM
description: FROM BEAUMONT AND Fletcher to Kaufman and Hart, there have been many collaborations between playwrights. Less common are collaborations between choreographers. The fruits of one of these rare tandem efforts will be offered during the season by Dance Theater of Harlem that gets underway Tuesday night at Davis Hall of the City College of New York.

title: TEACHERS URGE END TO APARTHEID
description: Twenty-seven academics from the university that is the intellectual cradle of South Africa's ruling National Party rebelled today against President P. W. Botha, urging his Government to abandon apartheid and commit itself to sharing power with blacks.

title: MUSEUMS, IN SHIFT, AIM AT ILLITERACY IN SCIENCE
description: The life-sized tyrannosaurus can stay, but the 7-year-old computer exhibit and the energy and communications displays, all considered outmoded, have to go, say curators at the Boston Museum of Science who are trying to bring their exhibits up to date.

title: U.S. TO RESTRICT BASS FISHING IF STATE DOESN'T
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY fishermen will face a federally imposed moratorium on taking striped bass next month unless the Legislature adopts catch restrictions already in place along the rest of the Eastern Seaboard.

title: ROLL-ON, ROLL-OFF DESIGN QUESTIONED
description: The ferry tragedy outside the Belgian port of Zeebrugge on Friday has raised questions about the design of the roll-on, roll-off type of vehicle-carrying ship involved in the accident, according to marine experts.

title: AFRICAN SEEKING U.S. HEARING ON BURUNDI KILLINGS
description: For the last 15 years, an African woman has sought to focus public attention on the mass killings in Burundi in 1972, win compensation for the families of victims and rehabilitate the name of her husband, a former Cabinet minister who was executed after he was accused of being an author of an uprising that preceded the killings.

title: U.S.-Saudi Military Talks
description: Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, conferred today with the Saudi Arabian Defense Minister, Prince Sultan. The official Saudi press agency said the discussions, attended by the kingdom's Chief of Staff, Gen. Mohammed al-Hammad, and commanders of the armed forces, centered on improving military ties between Saudi Arabia and the United States. Admiral Crowe arrived Friday night for a three-day visit.

title: Cassettes, Software And Books for Taxes
description: WANT to slash your tax bill?

title: COPING WITH ADOPTION'S AFTERMATH
description: LEAD: SHE could be your teacher, your aunt, your boss or even your mother. For years, perhaps even for decades, her well-guarded secret was known only to her parents, and usually her husband. The relentless psychological pain was hardest to bear on Mother's Day, holidays and one other occasion - the birthday of the child she gave up for adoption many years before.

title: ACTORS' GROUP THRIVING AT HARTFORD'S COMPANY ONE
description: LEAD: STEPHEN RUST still talks about the day he stood backstage of the Thomaston Opera House dreaming about operating his own theater company. ''I kept thinking how nice it would be to have a say in how things are done,'' he said.

title: From Con Ed, a Rare Announcement
description: Since the Consolidated Edison Company had never made such a pronouncement in the lifetimes of most New Yorkers, it held a news conference last week to announce a reduction in electricity rates.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Everything Under Sun At Rainbow Shoppe The Rainbow Shoppe in the Goodwives Plaza in Darien, Conn., encompasses a dizzying array of merchandise, much of it discounted by half to clear Valentine, New Year and Christmas paper goods - and wrapping paper, calendars and pottery, housewares and gadgets and selected doll-house miniatures and furniture are among the markdowns.

title: A FOND LOOK AT AN ENGLISH ORCHESTRA
description: LEAD: FIRST CAME THE ROMANS, then the Flemish, then the cotton tycoons, and then the Halle Orchestra, the first professional orchestra in Britain, and maybe the only one (anywhere?) to be named not after the city of its birth but after its founder. In Carnegie Hall today, at 3 P.M., at a scandalously late date, it will make its first appearance in the United

title: Seattle
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Seattle'' (Travel, Feb. 8) appeared only days after my first visit to the beautiful Pacific Northwest (home of Boeing, Dungeness crab, Pacific Northwest Ballet, etc.).

title: The Use of Libraries
description: To the Editor:

title: Lapchick Lauded
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FEDERAL SALTWATER FISHING LICENSE SOUGHT
description: For the second year, the Reagan Administration has sought to defray rising budget costs by requiring saltwater fishermen to pay at least $6 for a license.

title: Productivity
description: To the Editor:

title: FATS WALLER AND FRIENDS, 1941-1946
description: Jazz Classics, a division of Videofidelity. 29 minutes. $19.95.

title: ART ON THE MOVE BRIGHTENS WINTER
description: TO coatmakers with an artistic flair, a plain cloth coat is like an empty canvas, waiting to be filled. So fill these canvases they do, with all manner of decoration, from collages or silk-screened portraits to personal messages in applique. In the process, these artisans have turned an otherwise utilitarian garment into an eye-catching delight, making the transition from autumn to spring much smoother.

title: RETURN THE BOTTLES? NEXT WEEK, DEAR
description: THE question is, has concern for the ecology of our fair country - including Long Island - gone too far?

title: Jane Thea, a Lawyer Weds T. H. Shandell
description: Jane Gretchen Thea, the daughter of Carolee Thea and Michael C. Thea, both of New York, was married last night to Thomas Hicken Shandell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Shandell, also of New York. Rabbi Stephen Klein performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel.

title: CONCERT: FOSS AND SZERYNG
description: HEITOR VILLA-LOBOS, born 100 years ago this month, is best known to us for his chamber and vocal works; though the list of his orchestral compositions is long, it is largely unexplored. The Brooklyn Philharmonic's announcement of his Sinfonietta No. 2 (1947) for Friday night's concert at the Academy of Music promised a chance to hear an intriguing specimen in performance, but in the event, the more simply scored Sinfonietta No. 1 - composed in 1916, before Villa-Lobos had formed his mature style - was substituted. It proved an intermittently likable but fairly thin essay in Latin color; the performance was lively, and the ''trick'' ending of the first movement (a sudden cadence after slower music seemed to be in the offing) got its laughs.

title: Partnerships: New Focus On Income
description: DON'T write off limited partnerships as an investment vehicle yet. The right partnership investment can offer individual investors considerable advantages - professional management; a relatively high rate of return with the potential for capital appreciation; direct ownership of underlying assets so that profits are passed through directly to the investor, and, the Tax Reform Act of 1986 notwithstanding, some tax advantages.

title: POSTINGs: Developer Shifts; The Suburbs Call
description: After developing some 700 New York City apartments in the last decade, Jerome Kretchmer, a former city Environmental Protection Administrator, has discovered fresh air and lower land costs in upper Westchester County. His first suburban development, a 142-unit condominium complex, is now under way on 97 sylvan acres in Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

title: Counting the Centos
description: To the Editor:

title: V.A.T.
description: To the Editor: After reading about all the tactics for recovering V.A.T. refunds, I thought some of your readers might be interested in my own policy.

title: SYMPHONY IN D WORKSHOP
description: The Nederlands Dans Theater. Choreography by Jiri Kylian. Produced and directed by Jack Bond. Home Vision. 55 minutes. $39.95.

title: A STEADY DIET OF CRTICISM FRAZZLES NERVES IN RUSSIA
description: A TEACHER of comfortable income and orthodox views was startled the other day reading Mikhail S. Gorbachev's latest assault on shortcomings in Soviet society.

title: Fran Hoffinger Plans to Marry Harvey Fishbein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Hoffinger of New York and Cold Spring, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Fran Hoffinger to Harvey Fishbein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Fishbein of New York and Miami Beach. A June wedding is planned.

title: EXPLORING L.I. SOUND -- AND ITS FATE
description: S Long Island Sound dying? A few alarmists say it is, pointing as evidence to the low levels of dissolved oxygen in the waters of western Long Island Sound during the summer. Others fail to see the problem. ''I don't know if the Sound is dying,'' said one conservationist, ''but it isn't living well.''

title: ARTWORK ASKS, 'IS IT PAINTING OR PHOTO?'
description: LEAD: FOR years, Linda Lindroth has moved back and forth between painting and photography as a means of artistic expression, unable to choose between the two. It was not until the summer of 1982, when she moved to New Haven, that she decided there was no reason to concentrate on one to the exclusion of the other, and could, in fact, combine both media to make an even stronger statement than she felt she could with one alone.

title: Searching for Mr. Bonaprop
description: In his article ''Mr. Bonaprop,'' (On Language, Feb. 15), William Safire writes that he has ''long been searching for the origin of 'The opera ain't over till the fat lady sings.' '' His most probative finding is a 1978 reference from The Washington Post that attributes the ''fat lady'' to a San Antonio sportswriter.

title: IN SHORT: NON-FICTION
description: LEAD: AFTER PHILOSOPHY: End or Transformation? Edited by Kenneth Baynes, James Bohman and Thomas McCarthy. (MIT Press, Cloth, $35. Paper, $14.95.) In this excellent anthology, 14 leading philosophers from the United States, Great Britain, France and Germany discuss the fate of their discipline. The editors divide them into three groups.
