description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Gardner Wed To John F. Rand
description: Penn Gardner, a daughter of Mrs. Robert Livingston Gerry Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Fellowes Davis Gardner, was married yesterday to John Franklin Rand, the son of Mrs. J.Douglas Fairchild of Glen Head, L.I., and the late William Blanchard Rand. The Rev. C.Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Taos
description: To the Editor: The article on Taos Ski Valley in New Mexico (Travel, Feb. 8) was interesting and informative, but I'd like to add to it.

title: Pryor Out on Bond
description: THE saga of Aaron Pryor continued to take some bizarre twists Friday when a Dade County Circuit Judge in Miami released on $50,000 bond the former junior welterweight champion, who had been jailed on charges of sexual battery and aggravated battery. The judge, Arthur Snyder, said the ''credibility of the witnesses in this case leaves a lot to be desired, and I don't think proof is evident or presumption is great that the defendent committed these crimes.''

title: VERMONT PRISONS GIVE IMMATES CONDOMS ON REQUEST
description: Vermont prison officials say inmates can now get condoms on request to prevent the spread of AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases in homosexual encounters.

title: Hearns Wins Title
description: Thomas Hearns knocked down the light-heavyweight champion, Dennis Andries six times and stopped him at 1:26 of the 10th round today to capture the World Boxing Council championship.

title: Windows of Opportunity This Year
description: AS the nation's income tax system is restructured over the next few years, individuals will find special opportunities for tax savings - as well as new pitfalls to avoid.

title: TREASON AMONG THE CULTURATI
description: LEAD: THE RED AND THE BLUE Cambridge, Treason and Intelligence. By Andrew Sinclair. 179 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $17.95.

title: CONCERT: ILLINOIS ENSEMBLE
description: THE Illinois Chamber Orchestra, formed two years ago using members of the Springfield Symphony, made its first trip to New York on Friday night. Their program at Alice Tully Hall was cushioned by some interesting music and excellent soloists.

title: ALONE AT LAST IN A DESERTED FRENCH HOTEL
description: LEAD: I had accompanied my husband on a business trip to London around the date of our wedding anniversary. He proposed, instead of giving each other presents, taking me out to dinner. It wasn't that romance had flown out of the window, more over the English Channel. Dinner would be surrounded by a day and night in France.

title: MEDIATING SOLUTINS FOR TROUBLED FAMILIES
description: LEAD: DESPITE the best efforts of their parents, some children resist the guidance of the home and school to become truant, incorrigible and habitually disobedient. According to Jari Rapaport, the director of advocacy at the Westchester Family Service, ''These problems should be a family issue, not a court issue, as they frequently become.

title: IS THE MAFIA LIVING ON BORROWED TIME? A New York City Police Department expert on organized crime.    All of the recent trials showed that law enforcement could infiltrate the top leadership with informers and bugs. The new bosses probably will try to insulate themselves from us by having less contact with the capos (captains). There will be less reporting for instructions about routine business.  WILLIAM H. WEBSTER  Director of the F.B.I., who was chosen by President Reagan last week to be Director of Central Intelligence.    We don't claim to have finished the job. However, we have made a significant impact and they will never be able to operate again in the same manner.
description: THE 17-month ''pizza-connection'' trial in Manhattan ended last week with the convictions of 17 members of what Federal prosecutors described as an international Mafia ring that used pizzerias as a cover for heroin trafficking. Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, hailed the verdicts as evidence that the American Mafia is dying. Mr. Giuliani also cited vigorous prosecutions of Mafia bosses and said that changing social conditions have made it more difficult for Mafia leaders to recruit new members. Within a decade, he predicted, the American Mafia will cease to be a major threat.

title:
GARDENING;
ONE MAN'S FAVORITE HAND TOOLS
description: LEAD: MY wife and I keep the garden weed-free and looking good without hired help. Of course, we are grateful when our grown children, their spouses and friends assist us some weekends. But what helps most are the tools, and I am always looking for those that could be potential timesavers.

title: THE JET BENNY SHOW
description: Produced and directed by Roger D. Evans. Story by Mark Feltch. Music written and performed by Marianne Pendino. United Home Video. 77 minutes. $69.95.

title: EX-MARCOS ASSOCIATE TURNS OVER PROPERTIES IN U.S. TO MANILA
description: A close associate of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos has agreed to turn over to the Government his title to properties in New York and Hawaii, the head of a Government commission investigating Mr. Marcos's wealth announced today.

title: GOVERNOR NAMED IN S.M.U. SCANDAL
description: Southern Methodist University's problems with the National Collegiate Athletic Association grew worse last week when Gov. Bill Clements of Texas conceded that he and some other members of the S.M.U. board of governors had approved continued illicit payments to football players in 1985.

title: In Support of Owners
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ON CHANGING THE WELFARE SYSTEM
description: SINCE the 1960's, liberals and conservatives have been at an impasse over what to do about poverty in America.

title: IN SHORT: NON-FICTION
description: AMERICAN INDIANS, TIME, AND THE LAW: Native Societies in a Modern Constitutional Democracy. By Charles F. Wilkinson. (Yale University, $18.50.) Indian law may be the most arcane area of constitutional law. Subject to Federal control but technically separate nations, Indian tribes are political and legal anomalies. As analyzed by Charles F. Wilkinson, a professor of law at the University of Oregon, the basic question of modern Indian law has been how to honor half-forgotten treaty promises. During the last century, as many Indians blended with white society, tribes seemed to fade into near oblivion. Since 1959, however, the Supreme Court has made new law - and revived Indian culture - by reshaping treaty rights to fit modern realities. The Court has reiterated the view that tribes are sovereign entities; their powers existed before white settlement and have not lapsed with the passage of time. Decisions on land, water and fishing rights have given Indians a financial base; other rulings have swept state law from the reservations, so that tribal councils can levy taxes and set up their own courts. Thanks to the Court and to Indian activists, tribes have become ''a third level of government,'' building ''traditional and viable homelands for their people.'' ''American Indians, Time, and the Law'' is a scholarly book, but it is also persuasive, readable and fascinating. Seldom have legal abstractions been so ably distilled as here.

title: NEW EFFORT'S GOAL: KEEP FAMILY INTACT
description: LEAD: IN AN effort designed to keep children out of foster care, some New Jersey families can expect to have access to a therapist at any hour for crisis intervention.

title: Lynn M. Ashby, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Lynn Marion Ashby, an associate in the merger and acquisition group of the First Boston Corporation in New York, and John Ford Savarese, an assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, plan to be married in June.

title: WHY CAN'T THEY SHOOT JUST TO WOUND?
description: THE snarling man with the wavy pompadour, squinting down the barrel of his pointed revolver, is a familiar figure to New York City police officers who for years have practiced firing at the life-size paper target that depicts him.

title: SHULTZ SEES HOPE FOR ACCORD TO CUT LONG-RANGE ARMS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that progress in the Geneva arms talks offered some hope that his discussions in Moscow next month can make headway on reducing long-range nuclear weapons by half as well as on eliminating medium-range missiles in Europe.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: CURES FOR THE INSIDER PROBLEM;
FIRST, SET HIGHTER ETHICAL STANDARDS...
description: LEAD: ''QUIS custodiet ipsos custodes?'' The Roman satirist Juvenal's question, ''Who will watch the watchers?'' arises frequently these days. The Tower commission posed Juvenal's question at the beginning of its report, and with increasing frequency it echoes through the canyons of Wall Street as new scandals unfold.

title: IN THE 80'S, MONEY CAN BUY LOVE
description: LOVE IS UBIQUITOUS. SO ARE lust, rebelliousness and the urge to party. As long as pop songs ride the airwaves, there will be come-ons and put-downs, promises of ecstasy and howls of frustration. But while domestic affairs occupy the foreground, pop also picks up other cultural stirrings, and in the 1980's, songwriters have seized two new subjects: money and information. From Talking Heads' ''Love for Sale'' to Dire Straits' ''Money for Nothing'' to the Pet Shop Boys' ''Opportunities'' (''Let's make lots of money''), we now have pop for the age of arbitrage.

title:
INVESTING;
THE SHORTS BET AGAINST COPYTELE
description: LEAD: Copytele Inc., a four-year-old Long Island company with no sales and a $90 million market value, has shown up for several months as the over-the-counter stock with the highest short interest ratio. More than one million of the technology development company's 8.8 million common shares had been sold short as of mid

title: New White House Aide May Be Leaving Post
description: John O. Koehler, President Reagan's White House communications director for one week, has reportedly been asked to resign.

title: IN ART, AS IN LIFE, HIGH AND LOW SHOULD BE MINGLED BUT NOT MUDDLED
description: THE MUSEUM OF MOD-ern art is currently planning a ''High-Low'' show for 1990, in which modern art is to be displayed side by side with its popular sources. And the low shall be raised high, and the high shall be brought low. And it may well be, as I recently saw suggested in an article, not altogether playfully, that McDonald's golden arches will end up in the new 20th-century wing of the Metropolitan Museum. And it may be that the Museum of Modern Art will get hold of them first. Oh, well, given everything else that goes on, why not?

title: ART: 'SIR DAVID WILKIE OF SCOTLAND' LIMNS BRITISH HISTORY, AT YALE CENTER
description: AS I tucked into the beef Wellington at the inaugural dinner for the Yale Center for British Art almost exactly 10 years ago, it crossed my mind that the dish in question - long the standby of the American banqueteer - is named after one of the greatest of all Englishmen.

title: NEW YORK PROJECT SEEKS TO CUT COYOTE DAMAGE
description: The mournful howl of the coyote is being heard more frequently in upstate New York. The population of the wild canines has grown so much that they have become a menace to sheep farmers throughout the state, according to agricultural officials here.

title: 'TIME FOR THE NEW TRAINERS'
description: FOR a boxing trainer, older is always supposed to be better.

title: Carlton's Good Start
description: THE comeback bid by Steve Carlton took a positive turn yesterday when the Philadelphia left-hander pitched two innings in the Phillies' exhibition game opener against the Toronto Blue Jays. Unlike his two inning stint in an intra-squad game Thursday in which he gave up six earned runs, including three home runs, Carlton didn't allow a hit or run yesterday. The 323-game winner retired six of the eight batters he faced. He walked one and another reached base on an error in the game that ended scoreless. Carlton, who at 42 is being given a chance to make the team as a non-roster player, threw 24 pitches, six of them balls. ''He had a better slider and good split-finger fastball, said Manager John Felske.

title: NURSING PROFESSION AND POWER
description: I read with great interest the article on the nursing shortage, for I, too, am a nurse who has recently left the hospital environment. After 10 years of a continual love-hate relationship with my profession, I began to realize that the good did not outweigh the bad. All those virtuous plans I'd made in nursing school to help mankind through illness blew away in a storm of short staffing, double shifts, low pay and, most intolerably, disrespect.

title: America Takes The Fifth
description: Everything has been examined now about what happened to the U.S. Government except the role of the American people. We have blamed everybody but ourselves. It's almost as if the American people had taken the Fifth Amendment or been granted immunity from explaining why they elected Ronald Reagan in the first place.

title: NEW ROCHELLE FESTIVAL CELEBRATES THE FUNNY SIDE OF LIFE
description: SUBURBIA - especially in Westchester County - has been a key ingredient in the mix of comedy that has entertained millions of Americans for almost a century, bringing them gags and chuckles, laughter and guffaws.

title: Unusual Causes and Parties
description: Cole Porter Oldie March 9 - The Bandwagon of Vintage Musicals has the nostalgic function of producing elderly musicals that probably would not fill a contemporary Broadway house night after night, like its productions of ''Bittersweet'' by Noel Coward and Vincent Youman's ''Rainbow.'' In the same category is Cole Porter's ''Star Dust,'' written in 1931 but never produced, although some of its songs, including ''I Get a Kick Out of You,'' went on to shine in later Porter musicals. To benefit Bandwagon, the musical score of ''Star Dust'' will be sung by Patrice Munsel, Ann Reinking and others at Sardi's, starting with refreshments at 5 P.M. Tickets $30 at the door for seats or $20 for standing room. Information: 212-947-9023. A Benefit for Research March 11 - Scleroderma, a disease of the body's connective tissue that can disfigure, cripple and kill, affects 300,000 Americans, according to the Scleroderma Society, which raises funds to aid patients and families and for research. A black-tie benefit for the society will be held at the Pierre starting with 6 P.M. cocktails and followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment by Sergio Franchi and Dana Valery. Tickets $250, from 212-684-5025. Breaking a Barrier March 12 - With a philosophy of partnership between student and teacher, Literacy Volunteers of New York City teaches illiterate adults to read and write. This year illiteracy, one of the greatest handicaps, will be alleviated for more than 600 adults through reading and writing classes in eight locations around the city. Some masters of the printed word -Norman Mailer, Alex Haley, Maya Angelou, Isaac Asimov, John Gregory Dunne and Spalding Gray, as well as the television personality Carol Burnett - will read from their works at a benefit for the literacy group at 7:45 P.M. at St. Peter's Church at the Citicorp Center. A reception will follow. Tickets $125, from 212-475-5757. South Seas Evening March 12 - The evening starts at 6:30 with Polynesian-style (and Western) cocktails, followed by the 8 P.M. performance of the New York City Opera production of ''South Pacific,'' after which come dinner (Polynesian) and dancing (conventional), all at the New York State Theater. The evening, for which dress is described as ''bali ha'i black tie,'' will benefit the New York City Opera Guild and is sponsored by its junior committee. Tickets $125, from 212-870-5640. For Parent and Child March 12 - Adoption Circle is an organization founded last summer to improve and clarify the rights of adopted people and their biological and adoptive parents. The group also helps adopted people 18 or older find their original parents and aids parents in seeking out children over 18 whom they gave up for adoption. The new group is holding a benefit at the Circle Gallery, on West Broadway between Houston and Prince Streets, from 7:30 to 9:30 P.M. Refreshments will be served and artworks by Erte, Frank Gallo, Victor Vasarely and others will be sold; prices will range from about $15 to $20,000, with a portion benefiting Adoption Circle. No admission charge. Information: 212-988-0110. Briefly Noted: March 15 - A Champagne brunch at 1 P.M. followed by the 3 P.M. premiere of ''The Four Seasons/Jazz Version'' starring Charles (Honi) Coles will be held at and will benefit the Hudson Guild Theater, 441 West 26th Street. Tickets $100, from 212-760-9836. March 16 - A preview of more than 70 antique gold boxes prior to a public exhibition will be held at a black-tie cocktail reception at A La Vieille Russie, 781 Fifth Avenue at 59th Street from 6 to 9 P.M. Tickets for the benefit for the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, $125, from 212-752-1727. March 16 - A 7 P.M. black-tie Brazilian Ball at the Grand Hyatt will benefit the International Rehabilitation Development Foundation. Tickets $250 for dinner and ball or $100 for ball alone starting at 9 P.M., from 212-563-5350. March 16 - Arnold (Red) Auerbach, president of the Boston Celtics, and Ella Fitzgerald will be honored at a benefit dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria for the Jackie Robinson Foundation, which provides college scholarships. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Bill Cosby will be master of ceremonies. Tickets $300, from 212-889-2244. March 18 - Bayard Rustin, the civil rights activist and president of the A.Philip Randolph Educational Fund, will be honored on his 75th birthday at a benefit dinner-dance for the fund at the New York Hilton starting with 6:45 P.M. cocktails. Tickets $175, from 212-533-8000.

title: WAS S.M.U. PENALTY APPROPRIATE?
description: One of the major goals of a university is to provide young men and women with the tools for life after ''rah-rah.'' They should also lend guidance toward the straight and narrow path. S.M.U. (and many other major centers of higher learning) did just the opposite: corrupting young men with a variety of illicit inducements with little regard to their scholastic advancement. Let the punishment fit the crime.

title: Output Up as 'Africanization' Grows in Zaire
description: A decade after the ''events,'' the whites have not come back here.

title: Television
description: ''The Spencer Tracy Legacy: A Tribute by Katharine Hepburn,'' a 1986 program that will be rebroadcast as a Film on Film special on Channel 13, Saturday night at 10:05, is another of those movie-clip compilations that celebrate the talent and glamour of film stars. This one, however, is unusually rewarding. Written by John L. Miller, the two-hour documentary offers a lively review of the Tracy career. Miss Hepburn is on hand as narrator, host and tour guide. Hair piled high, and wearing her standard uniform of slacks, black turtleneck sweater and lumpy jacket, she doesn't romanticize Tracy's image. For those unfamiliar with his style, she explains, seeing him is ''like eating a baked potato for the first time'' -he is pure, of the earth, dependable.

title: WHO WOULD DARE SAY SUCH THINGS OF OUR MOTHERLAND?
description: LETTERS rrxhto the editor in the Soviet press are, to no one's surprise, overwhelminging supportive of the Communist Party line. But a significant minority reflect popular misgivings about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's demands for more candid criticism of Soviet society and for the ''restructuring'' of the economy. Excerpts from several letters in various publications follow. ----

title: A Ceremonial Leader
description: To the Editor:

title: SCULPTURE THAT SPRINGS FROM SURREALISM
description: WHILE THE EAST VILLAGE is not known as a sculpture center, there are an unusually high number of sculpture exhibitions there now, and they provide one more indication of the strength of the current sculpture situation. The best of these shows are not going to satisfy addicts of the new. They are likely to reward a search for independence and imagination. Their common ground is Surrealism.

title:
FILING THE RETURN: ADVICE FROM EXPERTS;
Choosing A Preparer: The Options
description: LEAD: REGARDLESS of how familiar 1986's tax forms may seem, especially in light of what next year has in store, many taxpayers will not view the preparation of their returns as a simple exercise. They will seek the help of a professional.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Hard-Bitten Speech

title: DANCE: MERCE CUNNINGHAM'S 'SEPTET'
description: THE Merce Cunningham Dance Company's season received another rich addition Friday night at the City Center when the company revived one of Mr. Cunningham's very early pieces, the 1953 ''Septet.'' Set to music by Erik Satie, the work has not been performed since 1964: the performance had the effect of a virtual premiere and was received as such.

title: Maura A. Del Gaudio Plans To Marry Peter Marcon Jr.
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Del Gaudio of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maura Anne Del Gaudio, to Peter J. Marcon Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcon of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: PROPER PLANNING A KEY TO L.I.'S FUTURE
description: James Larocca's comments on the Long Island Opinion Page on Feb. 8 [ ''Cautionary Note on L.I. Economy'' ] hit the target insofar as the concerns he expresses. There are, of course, more issues that must be addressed if Long Island is to enjoy continued prosperity.

title: DIGITAL TAPES: DEBUT INTO DEBATE
description: DEFYING LEGAL AND POLITI-cal maneuvers to block its way, Digital Audio Tape - DAT for short - stands poised for its American debut. Reports from Japan predict that the new audio format -using tiny cassettes capable of digital sound - will go on sale in Tokyo before the end of this month. Chances are that Americans will get their first earful of DAT at the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago in June.

title: BOSTON, WITH EYE TO THE PAST, PLANS BIG EFFORT TO INTEGRATE PUBLIC HOUSING
description: The city, which was torn by violence when it integrated its public schools in the 1970's, will make a concerted effort this spring to integrate its public housing when it begins to rent out more than 1,700 renovated apartments.

title: Congress To Tackle Taxes, Again
description: WHEN President Reagan, in an elaborate ceremony last October on the south lawn of the White House, finished signing the most sweeping tax legislation in a generation, he stood up and, with a flourish, held the book to his chest and slammed it shut.

title: SUSAN ZOX IS MARRIED TO HEDRICK SMITH
description: Susan Zox Eidenberg, the acting director of public relations at the Children's Hospital National Medical Center in Washington, was married last night to Hedrick Smith, a correspondent for The New York Times. Superior Court Judge Bruce S. Mencher performed the ceremony at the 1925 S Street Club in Washington.

title: Army Morale And Lottery Plan
description: IN need of funds for overseas morale and recreation programs, the Army was reported considering last year whether to start a lottery.

title: ALL ABOUT YVES
description: COUSTEAU An Unauthorized Biography. By Axel Madsen. Illustrated. 270 pp. New York: Beaufort Books. $17.95.

title: NEW YORK LAW: SURVEYING CENTURIES OF LEGAL LORE
description: A trade war with the province of New Jersey. Killer pigs loose on the streets. And a public savaging by the Mayor. Such has been the lot of the New York City Corporation Counsel over the last 304 years.

title: Berst Weighs New Information on S.M.U.
description: Improper payments to football players at Southern Methodist University were probably more widespread than the National Collegiate Athletic Association realized, the N.C.A.A's director of enforcement said yesterday.

title: Where Young People Choose to Live
description: FOR Dillon Remler, it was a process of elimination that began with the boroughs.

title: RYE RESIDENTS DROP EVERYTHING AND PICK UP THEIR BOOKS
description: AFTER reading aloud ''The Beast in Ms. Rooney's Room'' by Patricia Riley Giff, Jeremiah Lewin and his 9-year-old son, Daniel, got out their sleeping bags and prepared to spend the night on the floor of the Rye Free Reading Room.

title: PUBLIC-SECTOR UNIONS ARE LABOR'S DARLINGS
description: THE decline of the labor movement has been much chronicled in recent years, as have the protestations of its leaders that the decline has been greatly exaggerated. But the numbers show only one area in which organized labor is enjoying robust health. Public-sector workers - from firefighters to sanitation workers to teachers - are doing far better than their private-sector brothers and sisters.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Perhaps they'd like to see some movement in reducing the levels of nuclear arms.

title: GETTING DOWN TO THE FINE PRINT
description: THE United States and the Soviet Union have already worked out the main elements of an agreement on medium-range missiles - those capable of traveling between 1,120 to 3,100 miles. But they must still resolve complicated issues of treaty verification and limits on shorter-range missiles.

title: Ann Allen Bride Of John Kauchak (A. C. Sulick)
description: At St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J., yesterday Ann Elizabeth Allen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Allen of Short Hills, was married to John Joseph Kauchak, the son of Joan Kauchak of Colonia, N.J, and John F. Kauchak of Linden, N.J.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency is investigating the waste-disposal practices of natural-gas transmission companies after learning of numerous PCB dumps, including two in New Jersey, along one pipeline.

title: Mr. Reagan's Third Term
description: Now what should happen when you make a mistake is this: You take your knocks, you learn your lessons and then you move on . . . You put things in perspective. You pull your energies together. You change. You go forward.

title: Egypt Is Reported to Grant Asylum to 2 Libyan Officers
description: Egypt has granted political asylum to two Libyan Air Force officers who flew their C-130 military transport plane to southern Egypt, a former Libyan prime minister who is in exile in this country said today.

title: The Black Pottery of Oaxaca
description: In Oaxaca, as in other cities and towns in Mexico, pottery is familiar as decoration and is widely used for practical purposes. But the pottery best known in Oaxaca, a colonial-style city about 325 miles south of Mexico City, is unusual in that it is black.

title: How to Choose Future President
description: Today's starkest irony is the gap between reporting the President-we've-got and the Presidents-to-be.

title: ERNIE KOVACS: A COMIC TO THE MEDIUM BORN
description: ERNIE KOVACS JUST REFUSES to fade away. Killed 25 years ago in an automobile accident, the comedian who looked like a friendly but possibly demented insurance salesman had a television career that spanned little more than a decade, beginning 1n 1951. He never had a long-running series. Some of his more successful competitors on prime time, in terms of ratings, were people like George Gobel, Stu Erwin, Morey Amsterdam and Tennessee Ernie Ford. Yet, while they have decidedly faded, Kovacs remains as fresh as ever in his old black-and-white formats. His influence on subsequent TV comedy is detectable in styles ranging from Johnny Carson, ''Laugh-In'' and ''Saturday Night Live'' to David Letterman, ''Monty Python'' and ''Max Headroom.'' He has been impersonated by Jeff Goldblum in a TV-movie biography, and he has been saluted in a special exhibition at New York's Museum of Broadcasting. Ernie Kovacs is to television what Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton are to the movies.

title: 35 FOR DOUGLAS AS ORANGE WIN
description: Sherman Douglas was aware that the college basketball world had not been buzzing at his decision to enroll at Syracuse University. He was a skinny 6-foot guard who had not handled the ball enough in high school to satisfy the experts. His arrival at Syracuse came only after another recruit failed to produce the grades to qualify academically.

title: No Headline
description: THE SCENE WAS MACABRE: on the stage of the Broadway Theater, two massive towers made of junk moved on tracks toward and then away from each other, a hulking, oddly graceful dance. In the pit, the orchestra was rehearsing the storming of the barricade scene - a firing of muskets and thunderous explosions and music that had the unmistakable chill of an accompaniment to catastrophe.

title: EXPLORING A CHARACTER'S SEXUALITY
description: WHEN THE PLAYWRIGHT and director David Hare approached Mandy Patinkin to do a reading of his latest theater piece, the actor had no idea that he was being asked to play the most unusual role of his career. In Mr. Hare's ''Knife,'' Mr. Patinkin plays a man who transforms himself into a woman - and not by putting a little more mascara on, as in ''La Cage aux Folles.''

title: Ohio Businesses Ask Curb on Prison Products
description: Ohio businesses are pressing the Legislature to restrict the marketing and manufacturing of products made in the state's prisons.

title: PLAYOFF ENCOURAGES YOUNG MUSICIANS
description: LEAD: CHRISTOPHER KEENE does not like musical competitions. ''They go against the whole idea of art and individual expression,'' said the conductor and music director of the Long Island Philharmonic.

title: THE NEW BATTLEGROUND: RELIGION IN SCHOOLS TEXTBOOKS
description: EVANGELICALS have long contended that the nation's Christian heritage has been omitted from school textbooks and replaced by the influence of a philosophy they call ''secular humanism,'' which is said to put humans not God at the center of life. That argument attained the force of law in Alabama last week when Federal District Judge W. Brevard Hand ruled that secular humanism is a religion and therefore cannot be taught in schools. He wrote that the doctrine is not ''a mere scientific methodology'' but ''a religious belief system'' entitled to both the protections - and prohibitions - of the First Amendment. Although many experts expect the ruling to be reversed on appeal, more than 40 books that were challenged by a group of parents were ordered removed from Alabama's public schools.

title: MONTESSORI SCHOOL ENROLLMENT RISING
description: LEAD: IN THE last few years, say officials at some of the more than 30 Montessori schools in New Jersey, enrollments have doubled or tripled.

title: Editors' Note
description: ''Your Taxes,'' the Financial Planning Guide appearing today as section 12, discusses the need for taxpayers to file the complex new W-4 withholding form by Oct 1. (The form is mentioned on page 19 in a roundtable and on page 21 in the article about preparing returns.) The W-4 requirement still applies to taxpayers with complex financial situtions. But after the section went to press, the Internal Revenue Service announced that it had designed a simpler alternative form, the two-page W-4A, for those with income primarily from wages and salaries.

title: State Taxes, an Uneven Load: New York
description: For taxpayers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the Tax Reform Act of 1986 is riddled with reductions and eliminations of long-cherished tax breaks, and for many in the three-state region unforeseen consequences await.

title: Comparing State Taxes in the Tristate Area
description: The examples below show a couple with wages of $50,000, long-term capital gains of $10,000 (which under Federal rules are reduced to $4,000 for 1986 because of the 60 percent exclusion rule) and a spousal I.R.A. of $2,250. The examples compare the tax treatment in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, assuming the couple live and work in the same state. NEW YORK STATE AND CITY New York state and city income tax rules are based on Federal rules.

title: Cissy Wade Is Engaged To H. T. Van Ingen 3d
description: Announcement has been made by Gertrude Crockett Wade of Atlanta and George E. Wade Jr. of Columbus, Ga., of the engagement of their daughter, Trudy Wade, to Herbert Terrell Van Ingen 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Ingen Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: SOMEBODY TO TALK ABOUT
description: AS THE MOVIE opens, a middle-aged man in an unimpressive coat walks through New York traffic, hands jammed in his pockets. He enters a street-level door below a small sign that says ''The Performing Garage.'' Inside, at one end of a large room, an old wooden table holds a pitcher and glass of water. The man, now in a plaid shirt, minus the coat, sits down, places a Ronald McDonald spiral notebook on the table, takes a sip of water, faces the camera and begins to speak:

title: Adjusting Retirement Plans
description: PHOEBE FOX, a freelance designer-stylist in New York, is spending a lot of time reevaluating her retirement plan these days in light of the new tax law.

title: Britain Blocks Export Of a Painting by Manet
description: Britain has barred the export of one of the most expensive paintings in the world, a work by Edouard Manet, after a Government ruling that it was a national asset.

title: Recipe for Guesswork
description: At 2 A.M. a week ago Friday, New York City's Board of Estimate succumbed to its dream, a world in which it will never be blamed for rent increases because they won't happen.

title: Don't Count Cuomo Out
description: LEAD: Mario Cuomo's decision not to become a Presidential candidate has given the press a field day for articles that ask, ''Why?'' The press should be grateful to the New York Governor. He has provided an opportunity for column after column containing speculative analysis and ''psychoanalysis'' of his motives.

title: Study Urges New Measures to Combat Drugs
description: Citing what it called a crisis in confidence in governmental integrity and an epidemic in drug-related crime in New York City, a citizens group has urged that both problems be dealt with quickly.

title: ARDSLEY
description: WHEN Thomas and Patricia Basini bought a house at the end of a secluded road in Ardsley, they declined to buy the property next door - a bedrock ledge. They felt overextended already. Besides, their privacy seemed as immutable as the rock.

title: Q AND A
description: Railings for Handicapped Question: My mother is 85 years old and needs a walker or a cane to get about. She lives in an apartment building where there are other elderly people. While there is an elevator in the building there are three steps at the entrance that do not have a handrail of any kind.

title: WESTPORT SEEKS TO EASE GROWING PAINS
description: LEAD: WESTPORT, which is suffering growth pains as a result of its rapid commercial growth, is updating its town development plan for the first time in 27 years.

title: Waldo Salt, 72, Dies; Oscar-Winning Writer
description: Waldo Salt, a two-time winner of the Academy Award for screenwriting, died of lung cancer yesterday at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 72 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: FOR THE CANDIDATES, 1988 IS JUST AROUND THE CORNER
description: With the day that could decide the 1988 contests for the Republican and Democratic nominations for President a year away this week, both declared and prospective candidates are stepping up their schedules. But before March 8, 1988, when all Southern, most border and a growing number of other states will hold their primaries and caucuses, comes voting in Iowa. That was where the parties' putative front-runners found themselves last week.

title: DATA BANK: March 8, 1987
BASKETBALL BRINGS JOY TO FAIRFIELD
description: SINCE last Tuesday, some switchboard operators and secretaries at Fairfield University have been answering incoming telephone calls with ''N.C.A.A.-bound Stags'' or ''All the way to the N.C.A.A.''

title: Iran Reports Gains in North; Iraq Says It Counters in South
description: Iran said today that its forces, fighting in freezing weather, had wiped out two Iraqi brigades in the mountains of Kurdistan northeast of Kirkuk in a four-day-old offensive on the northern front.

title: Let Soviet Jews Decide
description: Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir wants the United States to stop giving special refugee status to Jews emigrating from the Soviet Union. At first glance, his reasons seem sensible. It would be politically easier for Soviet authorities to open the gates if Soviet Jews were headed for their presumed homeland. But past Soviet behavior belies this need for fig leaves. If the Kremlin wants to let Jews out, it knows how to open the doors without any fuss over their eventual destination.

title: Dr. Michele Berger Married to Dr. Marc Simmons
description: Dr. Michele Lisa Berger, a daughter of Mrs. Milton Berger of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Berger, was married yesterday to Dr. Marc Zachary Simmons, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Simmons of Huntington, L.I., and West Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi David Feldman officiated at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: JERSEY MONK WINS TEMPLETON AWARD
description: The Rev. Stanley L.Jaki, a Hungarian-born Benedictine monk and physics scholar in New Jersey, has won the 1987 Templeton Prize, which carries an award of $330,000.

title: CONCERTS FOR YOUNGSTERS
description: IT may not be fair to date the decline of children's concerts from the time Leonard Bernstein stopped conducting them, but certainly this once popular form of introducing youngsters to the wonders of music has become an increasing endangered educational species.

title: DEVILS BEATEN ON LATE GOAL
description: The Chicago Blackhawks came into Byrne Meadowlands Arena as the hottest team in the National Hockey League and left with a 4-3 victory this evening over the Devils.

title: FOOD
description: THOSE WHO ASPIRE TO THE American version of beurre blanc and puff pastry don't want to hear about cheese fries and Coca-Cola cake. That is why Jane and Michael Stern, chroniclers of ''real American food,'' are persona non grata in some food circles. What they have discovered on this country's back roads and byways over the last decade is often at odds with the cognoscenti's idealized picture of an elegant and classically pure culinary heritage. But to cultural anthropologists, the Sterns have no peer.

title: KOCH AIDES SEEK RULES ON DEVELOPERS' PLEDGES
description: The confusion surrounding city approval for a new Queens shopping mall last week has prompted the Koch administration to begin drafting rules about what developers may offer to communities where they want to build their projects.

title: LEGISLATURES IN REGION DEBATE WINDFALL PLANS
description: NEW York's tax-windfall debate was noisy enough last week to all but drown out Connecticut's quieter deliberations. In New Jersey, what shouting there had been was over.

title: Sail Technology
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tar Heels, Wolfpack Thrive in Overtime
description: Through regulation play and two overtimes, top-seeded North Carolina led Virginia only twice today in their semifinal of the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament.

title: 2 STATES AGREE TO $1 TOLL RISE ACROSS HUDSON
description: Governor Cuomo and Governor Kean announced agreement yesterday on a five-year, $5.8 billion transportation plan for the New York City area that would raise tolls on the George Washington Bridge and the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels to $3 from $2 to help pay for the rebuilding of the region's three major airports and other projects.

title: PLAN FOR ARMY COPTER STARTS A BATTLE FOR BIDS
description: The Pentagon is preparing to decide what kind of combat helicopter will serve the Army for the next two decades, making choices that will affect billions of dollars in military spending and thousands of jobs in the helicopter industry.

title: U.S. Officers in Panama Study Guerrilla War
description: A new research team at the United States military headquarters here is seeking ways for United States and Latin American forces to win small wars against leftist insurgents in this region.

title: Jazz
description: Charli Persip is one of the definitive modern jazz drummers, a graduate of Dizzy Gillespie's big bands and countless recording sessions, from some classic Blue Note albums of the late 50's to the present. For a number of years now he has been leading his Superband, a big band that always benefited from his keen dynamics and deeply grounded rhythmic feel but suffered somewhat from a lack of stable personnel.

title: DANCE: MARIA ALBA AND IBRAHIM FARRAH
description: AVERY FISHER HALL is just about the least congenial showplace imaginable for folk dance, but the companies of Maria Alba and Ibrahim Farrah managed to make that large, bleak stage seem a good deal warmer in a shared bill Friday.

title: Mets Need Time
description: Regarding Joseph Durso's article (''Mets Given Off-Field Pointer,'' The New York Times, Feb. 22), I fail to believe the only off-field pointer given for the regrettable incidents was ''I cautioned them not to discuss it.'' In my opinion this is not facing the off-field problems but simply sweeping them under the carpet and hoping they will go away. The coaches and owners should realize that the core of these problems starts with the team's overall discipline.

title: BUYERS BEWARE OF INVASIVE PLANTS
description: Usually mail offerings for plants are printed in lively colors. The copy is written in enticing language to make them sound like ''must haves.'' Caution. Plants that are easy to propagate or in excess supply are often offered at very low prices by mail order houses. Rather than joys to behold, these plants too often turn out to be nuisances or takeovers, the invasive species that gardeners would rather not have.

title: WHAT THE HOUSE TELLS US TO DO...
description: JUST as we accepted the crinkle of crow's feet in the face in the bathroom mirror, we presumed it was natural that the house would also begin to groan and creak with age. But slowly, the house began to disintegrate around us.

title: 4 CHARGED IN WEAPONS SCHEME
description: Four New York State men have been charged with trying to illegally export enough arms, ammunition and equipment to equip an 80-man army, Federal authorities said.

title: 20,000 LEAGUES UNDER THE SEA
description: Produced by Tim Brooke-Hunt. Animation directed by Warwick Gilbert. Music by John Stuart. 1985. Lightning Video. 60 minutes. $19.95.

title: PAN AM'S PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheila Murphy Planning to Wed J. F. W. Buckley
description: Mr. and Mrs. James E. Murphy of Warren, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheila Mary Murphy, to James F. W. Buckley, a son of Judge and Mrs. James L. Buckley of Sharon, Conn., and Washington. The wedding is to be July 11.

title: A ROSE FOR THE STUDENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CONFINEMENT
description: ONE spring, I took a bouquet of daffodils to school. To get it there, I had to carry it through a metal detector, past a sign-in desk, down a long, plain corridor intersected by several heavy, clanging metal gates and into the classroom area. Pleasant to look at in these most austere of surroundings, the flowers stayed on my desk throughout class. Then, one student after another approached to ask for one. The student who took the last daffodil also asked for the vase.

title: Memories of Sudden Terror
description: In the aftermath of the British ferry disaster, dozens of survivors wandered the halls of the Novotel here this morning, drying their clothes on the balcony rails, weeping into the arms of newly arrived loved ones, fearing for missing family.

title: ONE VOICE, HEARD 'ROUND THE COUNTRY
description: SOME readers were perplexed last fall when a Pensacola, Fla., newspaper asked them to choose their favorite radio disk jockey. Doc Bailey was nominated for best disk jockey by both WWAV in Ft. Walton Beach, Fla. and WBLT-FM in Mobile, Ala., towns that are more than 150 miles apart.

title: On the Trail Of the Buddha
description: Tracking the path of the peripatetic Buddha over the plains and mountains of Nepal can be an enlightening journey, but it can also be a bewildering maze for those trying to distinguish history from legend.

title: HOW AMERICAN CAN BECAME PRIMERICA
description: ON Friday morning, just after the stock market opened, the American Can Company unveiled its new name. The multi-billion dollar entity will now be known as the Primerica Corporation, pending approval of the stockholders.

title: A Hurled Stone Causes Injuries to Jersey Driver
description: A New Jersey man was injured yesterday when a cobblestone was thrown through the windshield of his car as he drove on the Henry Hudson Parkway in Manhattan, the police said.

title: POSTINGS: East Village Condos; The Legacy
description: A new condominium project in the East Village actually has its roots in the 17th-century New York of Peter Stuyvesant, who planted a pear tree at the corner of East 13th Street and Third Avenue. It bore fruit for 200 years before being killed in a carriage accident in 1867.

title: Home Refinancing: Advantages, Even Today
description: A LITTLE over two years ago, about 75 families purchased newly constructed houses in one central New Jersey community for $170,000 to $200,000. The builder arranged 13 percent mortgages for them.

title: Use 1986 To Prepare For 1987
description: THERE'S one big difference between 1986 and all previous years for taxpayers - that is 1987. Little has changed for the 1986 returns that are due next month. The forms look very much as they did a year ago, and most of the familiar deductions are there to be taken. It's the calm before the storm. The big differences, the changes wrought by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, will begin to be felt a year from now. But prudent taxpayers will look ahead.

title: THE CIVILIZED BARBARIAN READER
description: AS a Middle Westerner, the son of immigrant parents, I recognized at an early age that I was called upon to decide for myself to what extent my Jewish origins, my surroundings (the accidental circumstances of Chicago), my schooling, were to be allowed to determine the course of my life. I did not intend to be wholly dependent on history and culture. Full dependency must mean that I was done for. The commonest teaching of the civilized world in our time can be stated simply: ''Tell me where you come from and I will tell you what you are.'' There was not a chance in the world that Chicago, with the agreement of my eagerly Americanizing extended family, would make me in its own image. Before I was capable of thinking clearly, my resistance to its material weight took the form of obstinacy. I couldn't say why I would not allow myself to become the product of an environment. But gainfulness, utility, prudence, business had no hold on me.

title: Livia Brilliant to Wed Thomas G. Thompson
description: Profs. Richard and Eleanor L. Brilliant of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Livia Daniella Brilliant to Thomas Glenn Thompson, the son of Mary Edlo Thompson of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and the late John Lee Thompson. A June wedding is planned.

title: DEBATE OVER HOLOCAUST STIRS PASSIONS IN POLAND
description: A passionate controversy over whether Poles bear any special responsibility for the deaths of millions of Jews in World War II has flared in Poland's most influential Roman Catholic newspaper.

title: USE OF COTTAGES FOR HOMELESS STIRS CORTLANDT ZONING DISPUTE
description: THIRTY homeless families have moved into a cluster of old white bungalows in a former summer colony at Mohegan Lake, but because of a zoning dispute their stoves have been removed and their future there is uncertain.

title:
MUSIC;
BRAHMS VIOLIN CONCERTO
description: LEAD: Yehudi Menuhin, violin. Gewandhaus Orchestra conducted by Kurt Masur. Kultur. 60 minutes. $29.95.

title: HOPE SPRING'S PATERNAL
description: THE NURTURING FATHER Journey Toward the Complete Man. By Kyle D. Pruett. 322 pp. New York: Warner Books. $18.95.

title: Disaster Planning
description: To the Editor:

title: CONDOM AD POLICY DEVISED
description: LEAD: CONDOM commercials may soon be commonplace if Long Island's media outlets follow in the footsteps of New York City and accept the ads in an attempt to prevent the spread of AIDS.

title: PAINTING WITH FANCIFUL STROKES
description: HE HAS A LOOK OF THE NORTH-ern Renaissance. Alert, bald, trim-bearded and rufous, he could have been a reluctant halberdier, somewhere in the Low Countries. A predestined word-man - printer, lexicographer, calligrapher, master of verbal jiujitsu - he could have been on the staff of the Imprimerie Plantin in Antwerp in the second half of the 16th century, when the great printer-publisher was at his apogee. There is also something about him that comes from quite another cultural source - somewhere far to the south and the east, where indignity and misadventure and relocation were inbuilt and recurrent.

title: JUDGE CITES NEED TO HELP THE POOR
description: Francis T. Murphy, the presiding state appellate justice for Manhattan and the Bronx, said yesterday that American society had in many respects failed to uphold the promises of the United States Constitution.

title: FRESHMAN O FTHE WORLD, UNITE!
description: COLLEGE The Undergraduate Experience in America. By Ernest L. Boyer. 328 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: Thomas Wolfe
description: To the Editor:

title: Relearning Old Strokes At School for Sculling
description: It was 7:30 A.M. at the Florida Rowing Center. Twenty-eight gleaming new fiberglass shells were stacked on racks under a large Australian pine.

title: State Taxes, an Uneven Load: Connecticut
description: For taxpayers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the Tax Reform Act of 1986 is riddled with reductions and eliminations of long-cherished tax breaks, and for many in the three-state region unforeseen consequences await.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: BRONWEN, THE TRAW, AND THE SHAPE-SHIFTER A Poem in Four Parts. By James Dickey. Illustrated by Richard Jesse Watson. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Butcher Off First
description: THE person who was first across the finish line in the 1986 Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race was first across the starting line yesterday in Anchorage, Alaska, bound for Nome on a 1,100-mile trip.

title: A MOTHER'S STRUGGLE WITH THE KLAN
description: Beulah Mae Donald's youngest child went out for cigarettes one night in 1981 and did not come back. The badly beaten body of her son, Michael Donald, 19 years old, was found the next morning, hanging from a camphor tree along a street in Mobile.

title: BRAZIL, ALARMED, WARS AGAINST AIDS
description: After a pre-dawn blitz last weekend, the police in Sao Paulo claimed success for their first contribution to Brazil's new AIDS prevention campaign: 56 transvestite prostitutes were arrested and, in the words of one officer, ''lots of clients were frightened away.''

title: OFFICIALS EXPRESS DOUBTS ON CASEY
description: Reagan Administration officials familiar with William J. Casey's recovery from a malignant brain tumor said today that he appeared unlikely to recuperate to the point that he could help investigators resolve some questions about the Iran arms affair.

title: POSTWRITUM DEPRESSION, FALSE STAGNANCY AND OTHER ILLS CAUSED BY WRITING BOOKS
description: ONE day in the spring of 1951 Robert Giroux, then an editor at Harcourt, Brace, received a phone call from Jack Kerouac, who had been hard at work on his novel ''On the Road.'' ''He was very high,'' recalled Mr. Giroux, ''and he said, 'Bob, I've just finished my book and I have to come in and show it to you.' I could tell from his voice he was elated, which is very common among authors who have just completed their work.'' The next day Kerouac arrived at Mr. Giroux's office with something that resembled a large roll of paper towels tucked under his arm. ''What's that?'' asked Mr. Giroux, and Kerouac responded by yelling ''Whee!'' and unfurling the roll of pasted-together Teletype paper across the office floor.

title: SOVIET MOVES TO PAY MORE TO BETTER WORKERS
description: The Soviet Union has began a basic overhaul of its wage system aimed at halting a trend toward egalitarianism.

title: Q&A
description: Gibraltar Question:Does Spain allow access to Gibraltar? Is it possible to visit the fortifications there? What accommodations are available and is there a tourist office in the United States? -T. M. M., Staten Island, N.Y. Answer:A ban on vehicles crossing the Spanish frontier was lifted by Spain in 1985. Two years earlier pedestrian traffic had been allowed to resume following restrictions that began in 1969. Today, tourists cross freely into Gibraltar from La Linea, which is a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Malaga. They also reach the British colony by air from London and by air, ferry and hydrofoil across the Strait of Gibraltar from Tangier, Morocco.

title: Cave-In Kills 3 at Foundry
description: Sand stored in a silo at a foundry fell on three workers today, burying them alive, the authorities said. The men were pronounced dead at the scene, said Reedsburg Fire Chief Don Lichte of Reedsburg, which is 40 miles northwest of Madison. The three men apparently were clearing away sand that was clinging to the sides of the silo, Chief Lichte said.

title: TYSON UNIFIES W.B.C.-W.B.A. TITLES
description: James (Bonecrusher) Smith's chin was good, but his grip was even better. He held and held Mike Tyson and turned the advertised bout between heavyweight champion sluggers into a dreary charade of a fight.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: PURIM PARTIES If there's one holiday in the Jewish calendar that's observed joyously, it's Purim, the festival that marks the triumph of Queen Esther over Haman, her generation's persecutor of the Jews. And with the holiday coming up Saturday, by way of previewing what happens when synagogue-goers throughout Long Island read the Megillah, or Book of

title:
ART;
'CULTURAL AND SPIRITUAL ABSTRACTIONS IN VIDEO' AT THE ROBESON
description: LEAD: A VIDEO screening room is a stripped-down place, consisting only of a video monitor and a couple of rows of chairs. And video art requires that the viewer stay put for often considerable periods of time, whereas visual art usually has meant free circulation about an exhibition space.

title: Classical Music
description: It's a good week for cellists and master classes in New York.

title: Practical Traveler; Setting Sail Aboard a Windjammer
description: Sailing under canvas is a specialized type of travel.

title: THE ZOROASTRIAN OF AMSTERDAM AVENUE
description: THE RUG MERCHANT By Phillip Lopate. 218 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: Thomas Wolfe
description: To the Editor:

title: Rewards of a Literary Marriage
description: I am mystified that, despite her obvious and earnest footwork, Leslie Garis omits to mention Joan Didion's last and, arguably, best novel ''Democracy'' (1984), a particularly striking omission as it features an authorial and authoritative alter ego, one Inez Chistian Victor, and the elemental forces - vividly captured by Ms. Didion - that counterpoint her cool and ironic exterior: ''Colors, moisture, heat, enough blue in the air.'' ROBERT MIKLITSCH West Newton, Mass.

title: Saving Funds For Children
description: SAY goodby to Clifford trusts, the popular maneuver under which income was shifted to children and taxed at their lower tax rate. These trusts, primarily used by parents or grandparents, were often structured to provide the return of principal to the donor after 10 years.

title: BEST SELLERS: March 8, 1987
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List FICTION 1 1 5 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania. 2 2 6 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, two princes, an evil wizard and a mouse. 3 3 32 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 3 4 3 THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) How to cope with overbearing men. 3 3 38 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 4 4 78 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.)
