The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. In Advice and How-to, five titles are listed because, beyond that point, sales in this category are not generally large enough to make a longer lists statistically relialbe. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) ARMED TRUCE: The Beginnings of the Cold War, 1945-46, by Hugh Thomas. (Atheneum, $27.50.) The first volume of a series on the cold war, Lord Thomas's postrevisionist study finds the origins of the conflict in Soviet ideology and fear of the Germans. THE RED WHITE AND BLUE, by John Gregory Dunne. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Left-wing politics, big business, Hollywood, the Roman Catholic Church, Vietnam, Central America and much, much more are entangled in a pungent, violent, distinctly unsympathetic fictional treatment of America's last 20 years. ENEMY IN THE PROMISED LAND: An Egyptian Woman's Journey Into Israel, by Sana Hasan. (Pantheon, $18.95.) The stereotypes of two nations fall in this account of a brave and rebellious woman's 1974 migration to the enemy's heartland. BETTY: A Glad Awakening, by Betty Ford with Chris Chase. (Doubleday, $16.95.) A modest book about recovery from alcohol and drugs that should help others who haven't recovered yet. LAZAR MALKIN ENTERS HEAVEN, by Steve Stern. (Viking, $16.95.) Sharply plotted, sometimes horrific stories about Jewish life in the South by a prodigiously talented writer from Memphis. A WRESTLING SEASON, by Sharon Sheehe Stark. (Morrow, $17.95.) The title - a reference to a son's high school athletics - is the governing metaphor in this wise novel of domestic combat, of the tensions that separate families and the ties that bind them. THE BROOM OF THE SYSTEM, by David Foster Wallace. (Viking, Cloth, $18.95. Penguin, Paper, $7.95.) Exuberant, cartoonish, playful, preposterous and unrestrained, this first novel plays language games with a heroine who lives near a black sand desert in Ohio in 1990 and owns a cockateel named Vlad the Impaler.

title: ARCHAEOLOGISTS SEEK STATE POST
description: THE state needs a central office to look after its 10,000-year archeological heritage, which includes sites from prehistoric refuse heaps to 19th-century mill foundations, according to members of the Coalition on Connecticut Archeology.

title: FALSE ALARMS
description: DESPITE a low incidence of burglaries in the town of Pound Ridge, local and state police are extremely busy there. But 99 percent of the alarms they answer are false.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: PHILADELPHIA FLOWER SHOW

title: Roundtable: How the Tax Act Will Affect Individuals
description: What does the Tax Reform Act of 1986 mean to individuals, both in paying taxes and in structuring finances? How will investments be affected? How should people plan ahead for retirement or financing the children's education? Two members of The New York Times staff, David E. Rosenbaum and Jan M. Rosen, discussed these and other questions with three leading experts: Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, a principal architect of the movement toward lower rates and a broader tax base; Lawrence B. Gibbs, commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, and Warren E. Shine, partner in the accounting firm of Ernst & Whinney.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Mapping Wrecks On Ocean's Floor

title: HOW SCHOOLS ARE COPING WITH LAW ON SEAT BELTS
description: LEAD: FOUR months before a New York State law mandating seat belts on new school buses takes effect, half of the school districts in Westchester have gone even further in the name of safety: installing belts in at least some of their existing buses.

title: Miss Wyman Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hunt Wyman of Southport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Baldwin Wyman, to Donald Leighton Baron, a son of Mrs. Robert Quarterman of Dorchester, England, and Stanley C. Baron of Whitehouse, N.J. The wedding is to be in August.

title: OPERA: 'CARMEN' GETS A LAST-MINUTE DON JOSE
description: GARY LAKES, a young American tenor whose career has been much advanced by the current vacuum in Wagnerian singing talent, sang his first leading role at the Metropolitan Opera on short notice Thursday night, stepping in for the ailing Jose Carreras as Don Jose in ''Carmen.''

title: BEYOND GYM CLASS: TEACHING CIRCUS SKILLS ON L.I.
description: For nearly 15 years, starting when he was only 4 years old, JeanPaul Jenack was a circus performer. Then, in 1974, he broke his neck in an accident outside the circus, partly paralyzing the right side of his body and apparently ending his career under the big top.

title: MUSIC: CONCERTS HONOR VILLA-LOBOS
description: OUTSIDE of the United States, perhaps no modern culture has produced a popular music so potent as Brazil's. Its conglomeration of Iberian dance, the languorous Portuguese fado, the intricate rhythmic life brought by African slaves and the folk songs of Brazil's rural world has formed a music that - given the overwhelming richness and energy - is amazing for its subtlety and restraint. Indeed, the qualities of the modern samba and its offshoots possess a delicate inspiration that New World ''classical'' composers, for all their technique, only rarely understand.

title: CAROLINA IS MADE A NO. 1 IN SEEDINGS
description: North Carolina, upset in the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament final yesterday, still came away as the top-seeded team in the East Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: College Tuition Is Not-So-Simple Arithmetic
description: To the Editor:

title: VOTING AND TAX REFORMS IRELAND MIGHT TRY
description: To the Editor:

title: SMALLER FIRMS ARE VANISHING
description: SAGE Gray Todd & Sims, one of the oldest Wall Street law firms, is breaking up this month, with 30 of its 78 lawyers - the banking group and the Miami office - going off to Hughes Hubbard & Reed, and another dozen lawyers from the real estate department joining Chadbourne & Parke.

title: FOR NEWLY MARRIED COUPLES
description: RUTH and Steven Hanson of Manhattan spent their three-week honeymoon in 1975 touring Scandinavia. They visited the Louisiana Museum near Copenhagen, met Mr. Hanson's second cousin in Uppsala, Sweden, and went camping in Norway.

title: AN EXOTIC LUXURY
description: FEW pleasures are so satisfying as one that is anticipated.

title: 'STAR WARS' PUSH DIMMING PROSPECT FOR EXOTIC ARMS
description: The push for early deployment of a rudimentary defense against nuclear missiles is speeding up some areas of weapons research but hurting others, threatening to delay progress toward the long-term goal of protecting the nation from enemy attack, according to leading scientists in the Reagan Administration's anti-missile program.

title: JAPANESE REACT TO CHIP PLAN
description: Major Japanese semiconductor makers have apparently taken in their stride a move by the American chip industry to challenge them in the world semiconductor market. The Semiconductor Industry

title: KEAN SEEKS A KEY ROLE IN G.O.P.
description: When Thomas H. Kean addressed a meeting of A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders in Florida last month, like several potential candidates for President who also attended, he was asked to submit a videotape of himself.

title: AN S.M.U. BOOSTER'S STORY
description: He said he had first heard of it in 1971. A classmate asked him if he would contribute to a fund that had been set up to help recruit football players. Nothing big. No more than $100 would be paid out at a time, he was told. It was only to be used to help fix the players' cars or buy them clothes when needed.

title: GRETA COHEN, A BANKER WED TO M. S. GOLDSTEIN
description: The marriage of Greta Cohen to Michael Steven Goldstein took place yesterday at the Estherwood Mansion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Rabbi Robert Toren officiated. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Norman Cohen of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Goldstein of Brooklyn.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE AMERICAN AMBASSADOR. By Ward Just. 326 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $17.95.

title: BBDO LONDON OFFICE TO HANDLE BRITISH PEPSI
description: The London office of BBDO Worldwide has won all of the British Pepsi-Cola business from the local J. Walter Thompson Company. Just last year, Team/BBDO in Dusseldorf, West Germany, got the German version of Diet Pepsi - called Pepsi Light over there - from J.W.T.

title: CHAIRMAN ON THE SPOT AT G.M.
description: Can Roger B. Smith, the besieged chairman of the General Motors Corporation, turn the company around?

title: The U.N. Today: March 9, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: UNDER MARXISM, ETHIOPIA'S CHRISTIANS ABIDE
description: Holy Cross Square has been renamed Revolution Square and is now graced with a billboard hailing Communism's trinity: Marx, Engels and Lenin.

title: MISSOURI EDGES KANSAS BY 67-65
description: Lee Coward, a freshman guard, hit a jump shot from the top of the key with 4 seconds left to give Missouri a 67-65 victory over Kansas today in the Big Eight tournament championship game.

title: Uncaring Medicare
description: LEAD: One of the many terrible consequences brought on by the Reagan Administration's efforts to reduce health care costs is the new Medicare patient care policies.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MARCH 9, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11

title: HOMOSEXUAL GROUP HOLDS ITS FINAL MASS
description: Forbidden by the Archdiocese of New York from continuing to hold masses as an organization, a group of 1,000 Roman Catholic homosexuals and their supporters gathered Saturday night for a final service at a Manhattan church and then marched peacefully into the streets chanting, ''We are the church.''

title: CHAIRMAN OF USAIR IS STUDY IN CAUTION
description: About a year after airline deregulation had gone into effect, Edwin I. Colodny, the chairman of the USAir Group, was asked whether he thought the airline should rush into new markets as other carriers were doing. ''We had an itch to expand - but we put a lot of anti-itch powder on it,'' was his response.

title: COLLISION MARS HURDLES FINAL
description: The first world indoor track and field championships ended today with a violent crash involving two outstanding athletes. It left Greg Foster of Chino Hills, Calif., and Mark McKoy of Canada, the favorites in the men's 60-meter hurdles, stretched out on the track, bloody and bruised. Meanwhile, Tonie Campbell of Torrance, Calif., won the gold medal in 7.51 seconds.

title: MAGAZINE ADS OFF
description: In January, the Publishers Information Bureau reports, its member magazines carried 9,000 pages of advertising, a drop of 5.4 percent from the same month last year. Revenues were off 3.6 percent, to $297.2 million.

title: A NOVEL TO BE
description: For months rumors have circulated that Richard N. Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense for international security policy, who is one of the hard-line voices on arms control, is about to quit his job to write a Washington novel.

title: PATENTS DISPUTED IN BIOTECHNOLOGY
description: The remarkable successes by scientists in developing new means of combating some types of cancer and treating heart attack victims have led to a fight over the legal rights to market advances in biotechnology.

title: TRANSIT AID CALLED NO HELP FOR POOR
description: The law that set up Federal subsidies for local transit systems was intended to benefit those who have little choice but to rely on public transportation, but some critics complain that those are not the people being helped.

title: POLAND SEEKS CURE FOR BURDEN OF LONG-TERM DEBT
description: The Polish Government gave a nod of sympathy last week to Brazil, but choked back any impulse to follow suit and suspend its own debt-service payments. Instead, the Poles are pinning their hopes for economic relief and rescue on discussions with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

title: AMY S. GREEN BECOMES BRIDE OF STEVEN GORELICK
description: At the Park Slope Jewish Center in Brooklyn yesterday Amy S. Green, the assistant director of public affairs and a doctoral candidate in theater at the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York, was married to Steven M. Gorelick, the director of enrollment services and a doctoral candidate in sociology at the Graduate School and University Center. Rabbi Julie Gordon performed the ceremony.

title: POLITICIANS LAUGH AT LAMPOON BUT GUSTO IS MUFFLED
description: The prominent of New York's political establishment showed up, as always, and they laughed, as always. There were even outbreaks of sustained applause and one audience request, granted in full, for an encore.

title: Pry Letelier's Killers Out of Chile
description: If Ronald Reagan still is seeking a chance to prove to a justifiably skeptical world that his promise of ''swift and effective retribution'' against terrorism is more than empty words, he has a golden opportunity. The Administration should attempt to extradite a couple of cold-blooded killers in my country, Chile, and bring them to trial for murder in the United States.

title: INSIDE
description: Anger Over CBS Cutbacks

title: DIRECTORS GUILD HONORS STONE FOR 'PLATOON'
description: Oliver Stone won the 1986 Directors Guild of America award Saturday night for ''Platoon,'' a movie partially based on his own experiences as an infantryman in Vietnam.

title: Inside Softball
description: Jim Perrone would seem to be a quixotic sort, one who might be found peddling ice cubes in Fairbanks or furnaces in Fort Myers. Next month, when most athletes will begin heeding the springtime call to the great outdoors, he plans to open an indoor softball complex on Long Island. ''It's not an ideal time,'' Perrone conceded the other day, ''but it was one I was stuck with.''

title: ALONG FLANDERS COAST, PRAYERS FOR VICTIMS
description: Along the coast of Roman CatholicFlanders, where the church spires stand like staffs against the sky, prayers were offered today on this first Sunday of Lent for the dead and missing in the ferry disaster on Friday.

title: 'TIME AFTER TIME,' WITH SIR JOHN GIELGUD
description: WELCOME to the peculiar little world of Molly Keane. That should be the preface, or perhaps warning, attached to ''Time After Time,'' the BBC movie on cable's Arts & Entertainment Network tonight at 8 o'clock. Mrs. Keane, for those of you who haven't had the pleasure, is an Irish writer who was born some time ago - the exact year is rumored to be 1904. She was born in County Kildare into what she has described as a ''rather serious Hunting and Fishing and Church-going family.'' Turning to writing in order, she says, to supplement her dress allowance, she for years used the pseudonym M. J. Farrell ''to hide my literary side from my sporting friends.''

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt American Brands Inc. is issuing $:50 million of 9 1/2 percent Eurobonds due 1994 at 99 3/4, through Morgan Grenfell & Co. Ltd.

title: ST. PETER'S GETS BID, BUT THE WRONG ONE
description: Nowhere were yesterday's N.C.A.A. tournament pairings more closely followed than at St. Peter's College.

title: SYRIANS, SEEKING ORDER, WIPE OFF GRAFFITI LEFT BY MILITIAS IN BEIRUT
description: City workers, aided by teen-agers and supervised by Syrian soldiers, wiped political slogans off walls today and took down street signs and photographs that rival militias had put up throughout West Beirut.

title: GOLDIN CRITICIZES CONTRACT PAYMENTS
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, in a statement to be released today, has asserted that slow payments by the New York City Board of Education has added as much as $476,000 in unnecessary costs to major school contracting projects, such as building construction and repair work.

title: WELL SELECTED, 8-1, WINS AT GULFSTREAM
description: Well Selected, a speedball who made his debut just five weeks ago and scored a maiden victory just two weeks ago, led every step of the way to beat Gone West and Faster Than Sound in the $88,960 Hutcheson Stakes today at Gulfstream Park.

title: NEW YORK CITY SEEKS PARENTS FOR 20 ORPHANED MONUMENTS
description: Almost abandoned by the public treasury that was supposed to care for them, 20 monuments in New York City have been put up for private adoption so they can survive an increasingly hostile environment.

title: The Pollard Consequences
description: Jonathan Pollard, the traitor rightly sentenced to life imprisonment for selling secrets to Israel, is an American Jew.

title: NEW MINSTAR PRESIDENT A 'NUTS-AND-BOLTS MAN'
description: Kenneth J. Severinson has been named president and chief operating officer of Minstar Inc., the Minneapolis-based diversified energy and leisure products company. Currently, he is president of Minstar Energy Services.

title: NEW CHAIRMAN NAMED AT GREY'S WESTERN UNIT
description: Miles J. Turpin, who is 55 years old, has become chairman and chief executive of Grey Advertising's Western division, replacing Robert L. Humphrey, 62, who has had the job for the full 25 years of the division's existence. He moves to chairman of the executive committee-Western division.

title: AGING CONNECTICUT VETERANS' HOME IS FAULTED FOR BEING BEHIND THE TIMES
description: The Connecticut Veterans Home and Hospital, whose tradition of caring for the state's war veterans began in the Civil War, is surrounded these days by questions about its role in the post-Vietnam era.

title: BATTLE ON MEDFLY IS RENEWED
description: State and Federal agricultural agents have mounted new efforts to eliminate the Mediterranean fruit fly after five were found last Monday in suburban Hialeah.

title: Some Nations Giving Addicts Clean Needles
description: Parked next to a canal not far from the famed Rijksmuseum here is a burgundy bus equipped with a condom dispensing machine as well as trays of small plastic vials containing Methadone, the heroin substitute used in the treatment of drug addiction, and hundreds of syringes intended for people who have not overcome the habit.

title: AQUINO STEPS INTO STOCK CASE
description: President Corazon Aquino met with directors of the San Miguel Corporation, the Philippines' biggest manufacturing concern, to discuss a controversy over company shares that were seized by the Government, the Presidential Palace said today.

title: 2D BUFFALO PRIEST IN 13 DAYS IS MURDERED IN HIS RECTORY
description: A Roman Catholic priest was found slain in the rectory of his Buffalo parish yesterday, and the police are investigating similarities to the murder 13 days ago of another priest less than a mile away.

title: SETON HALL LANDS A SPOT
description: Tom Penders and Pat Kennedy, who were rivals when they coached at Fordham and Iona, respectively, will be rivals again this week. They will face each other in the National Invitation Tournament, which begins Wednesday.

title: Manhattan Faces Duke
description: The women's basketball teams from Rutgers and Manhattan College were among 40 teams selected to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament yesterday. Both were placed in the East bracket, where the defending champion, Texas, is the region's top-seeded team.

title: 1,200 ATTEND SERVICES FOR SENATOR ZORINSKY
description: Senator Edward Zorinsky was remembered today for his ''legacy of honesty'' and support for farmers at funeral services attended by about 1,200 people, including 18 United States senators.

title: PLANE LANDS SAFELY AFTER BLOWING TIRES
description: AN Air Jamaica flight carrying 348 passengers and a crew of 12 to Montego Bay, Jamaica, from Baltimore made an unscheduled landing at Kennedy International Airport yesterday when two of the airplane's tires blew out shortly after takeoff.

title: Soviet Reforms, American Interests
description: There's an argument uncoiling now among students of foreign affairs about how much to help the Russians. Sure, Mikhail Gorbachev's changes in the Soviet Union appeal to Americans: more openness, more freedom, more popular participation in decisions. But think of the reason he seeks those changes. He hopes they will make the Soviet Union stronger. Can the United States, indulging its idealism, afford to back him, at the risk of strengthening its adversary?

title: CHARLOTTE STREET: TORTURED REBIRTH OF A WASTELAND
description: The white picket fence needs painting, the front gate sticks, the three fruit saplings have long since died, and, several times, David and Irma Rivera have missed their monthly mortgage payments.

title: RATINGS BY EX-IM BANK
description: The Government's Export-Import Bank has decided to resume its risk-based rating system for borrowing countries, the bank's president, John A. Bohn Jr., said. The system, which will go into effect May 1, will mean that loan fees for lower-rated countries will be higher than those for nations with higher ratings. The Ex-Im Bank's main job is to aid sales of United States manufacturers by offering taxpayer-subsidized loans to prospective buyers on easy terms. Mr. Bohn said the Ex-Im bank formerly used country-risk ratings but gave up the practice in the late 1970's. ''We believe the current economic situation again justifies a country-differentiated approach,'' he said.

title: GULF CANADA TAPS THE BEAUFORT
description: Canada's petroleum industry, weathering its gloomiest period since the first major Alberta oil strike in 1947, perked up a little in January when the Gulf Canada Corporation announced that it was preparing to inaugurate the country's first commercial oil well in the icy waters of the Beaufort Sea.

title: ORANGE LOSE EDGE ON THE REBOUNDS
description: Rony Seikaly, the 6-foot-10-inch center of the Syracuse University basketball team, was an unfortunate witness. ''I would see the shot go up and I would think I had position,'' Seikaly said. ''And all of a sudden it was like a hurricane came up and took the ball and went away.''

title: PEOPLE
description: John Noble named executive creative director and to the board of DDB Needham Worldwide. He is replaced by Robert Mackall and Jack Mariucci as executive creative directors of the New York division.

title: Marcos Allies and Foes Unite Against Aquino
description: Former associates and opponents of associates and opponents of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos joined forces today to challenge the candidates of President Corazon C. Aquino in the Philippine congressional elections in May.

title: A DISPUTE OVER POLITICAL PROTOCOL LEAVES A COMMISSION IN DISARRAY
description: A political dispute over nominations to the State Public Service Commission has cast doubts over a recent rate increase and created confusion among commission members about how many of them there still are.

title: BUSH CRITICIZED FOR SOUVENIRS
description: Senator William Proxmire has discovered that the Air Force paid $59,000 over the last six years for the playing cards Vice President Bush has given as souvenirs to guests traveling with him on Air Force Two.

title: COSTA RICA WEIGHS PROTEST TO U.S. ON USE OF AIRSTRIP TO AID CONTRAS
description: The Tower Commission report on the Iran-contra affair has provoked controversy in Costa Rica, where the Government is considering a protest against the United States for violating an explicit prohibition on the secret use of an airstrip here by Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Catching Up
description: * Sister Maria Pares, the nun appointed coach of the women's basketball team at Marquette less than a year ago with the mandate to build a competitive Division I program, finished 9-18 last week as her first season with the Warriors came to a close. Rarely has a losing record brought so much encouragement. First, it was an improvement over the 5-20 mark of the previous season, when the squad debuted in Division I; second, the team will be losing only three players to graduation, and third, Sister Maria, hired too late to do any effective recruiting for 1986-87, is heartened by the look of next season's young prospects. If feistiness is contagious, the Warriors will also continue profiting from the demeanor of their coach, a pluckish 45-year-old who in one game this season called a timeout and then told the referees her purpose was to give them a breather.

title: A CHECK FROM 'JAMIE'
description: When a Nicaraguan rebel leader, Adolfo Calero, gave reporters a peek at the bank records of his band of insurgents, on the top of the pile was a check for $30 form a Chicagoan identified only as Jamie. In August 1985, Jamie made out the check for Alpha Services, a front for the rebels and sent it to the Swiss Bank Corporation in Panama with a notation that it was for the ''Nicaraguan Freedom Fighters.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, MARCH 9, 1987 The Economy The U.S. and Japan are headed for a trade confrontation more serious than any of the postwar period, Government officials and private analysts believe. Attitudes have stiffened on both sides, making compromises less likely. [ Page A1. ] A growing number of biotechnology patent lawsuits could determine the fate of dozens of companies, reshape major portions of patent law and affect the prices paid by patients seeking relief from afflictions once thought incurable, experts say. [ A1. ] Steel prices have remained firm despite the re-entry of USX into the market, and some steel executives predict prices could even increase slightly this year. [ D1. ] International Report The Philippines and its bank creditors are expected to consider a new approach to debt payments that would obscure the interest rate paid, allowing both sides to save face. The approach coulBurnham hopes applied in other countries. [ D1. ] Poland is pinning its hopes for economic relief on talks with the I.M.F. and the World Bank. [ D6. ] Dragonair's two-plane fleet is battling Cathay Pacific Airways for a future in Hong Kong. [ D10. ] Canada's oil industry is counting on discoveries in the Beaufort Sea to sustain it. [ D10. ] Companies Carl C. Icahn may withdraw his offer for USAir if the carrier agrees to take over Piedmont in such a way as to make USAir financially unattractive, industry sources said. [ D1. ] Roger B. Smith may succeed in turning G.M. around, analysts say, but his strategy faces many potential obstacles. [ D1. ] Bell Laboratories is still churning out new ideas, allaying fears about the impact of deregulation. But it still has to come to terms with competing in the marketplace. [ D1. ] By publishing a list of satisfied clients, Drexel Burnham hopes to dispel perceptions that its business has weakened. [ D4. ] Today's Columns The future is cloudy for medium-size law firms trying to compete with giant national firms. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Mutual funds that invest overseas are placing greater stress on investments in Britain. Market Place. [ D6. ] Speculative activity has shifted to the British Government bond market, where yields are off sharply. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

title: THE MONTHS OF SCANDAL: A BUREAUCRACY MOVES, BUT IN FITS AND STARTS
description: For more than three months now, as the Iran-contra affair snarled the gears of government, the decision-making process throughout the vast Federal bureaucracy has been sometimes distracted, sometimes stymied, and sometimes it moves ahead in fits and starts.

title: 'ELEANOR: IN HER OWN WORDS' ON 13
description: ''MY recommendation to First Ladies is quite simple - don't take yourself too seriously.'' That is one of the tantalizing lines that echo down to the present in the American Playhouse production, ''Eleanor: In Her Own Words,'' a one-hour, dramatized reading about Eleanor Roosevelt that will be broadcast tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13.

title: X-Burgers of Brazil
description: To the Editor:

title: DEBT PLAN FOR MANILA REPORTED
description: Negotiators representing the Philippines and its bank creditors are expected to consider on Monday a new approach to foreign debt payments that, if successful, could be applied in other countries.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Sports World Specials column in SportsMonday last week misidentified the founder of the Jesse Owens International Trophy Award. He is Herbert P. Douglas Jr.

title: STAGE: 'WOMEN BEWARE,' UPDATE OF JACOBEAN PLAY
description: IN ''Women Beware Women,''

title: A TWO-PAGE HUG BY DREXEL CLIENTS
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has helped to turn many of its clients into powerful corporate kingpins. Now Drexel is calling in its favors - 238 of them, to be exact.

title: Pakistan Says Its Work On Atom Will Not Stop
description: Pakistan declared today that it would continue peaceful development of nuclear energy and would not bow to pressure from foreigners who fear it may be building atomic bombs.

title: SPECIAL PROSECUTOR LAW FACING WIDER SCRUTINY
description: While the constitutionality of the special prosecutor law is being challenged in the well-publicized lawsuits by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Michael K. Deaver, the workings of the statute have come under quiet scrutiny by the special court responsible for the law's operation, and by a Senate subcommittee.

title: DRAGONAIR, A GNAT THAT ROARS
description: Dragonair, a 22-month-old airline that owns one plane and leases another, has a burning ambition. It wants to become a major international carrier.

title: CAMPUS RACE INCIDENTS DISQUIET U. OF MICHIGAN
description: As college officials around the country try to stem what they perceive as worsening racial tensions, racial incidents at the University of Michigan are creating a furor among students and administrators on a campus long known for social tolerance.

title: A Ruling for Railbirds
description: He may not look like the typical businessman, but the fellow who spends his time studying parimutuel boards at the track and poring over racing forms at home may well be one - his gambling a legitimate trade or business, with all the tax entitlements that implies.

title: EUROPEAN JOBLESSNESS
description: Unemployment in the European Community rose to record levels in January, according to the statistics office for the 12-nation group. The biggest increases were in West Germany and Denmark, while only Belgium showed a decline, Eurostat reported today. The number of registered unemployed in the member countries jumped by more than 500,000, to 17.1 million, topping the 17 million mark for the first time, Eurostat said in its monthly job market report.

title: Insurance Squeeze
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Battle Mountain Gold Co., Houston, named Karl E. Elers to the newly created position of executive vice president, and a director.

title: HANDLING OF WAR DEAD STUDIED
description: The Army is trying to modernize its procedures for handling the remains of fallen soldiers because the recovery of bodies from battlefields of the future may expose personnel to deadly chemicals or radiation.

title: KETCHUM OF PITTSBURGH GETS RUST-OLEUM
description: The bosoms of the management of Ketchum Advertising, Pittsburgh, swelled with pride Friday when they learned they had whipped the big boys in Chicago and had brought home the $5 million Rust-oleum Corporation account.

title: OF VOTERS, POLLUTION, MEMORIES
description: Like the groundhog of Punxsutawney, Pa., the voters of Dixville Notch, N.H., rouse themselves faithfully for a rite that the whole nation watches for a clue to the future. Just after midnight on the day of each Presidential election, the 20 or so registered voters line up to cast their ballots, and the results are announced immediately.

title: DANCE: 'QUARTET,' BY CUNNINGHAM
description: DANCEGOERS have come to understand that there is an inherent drama to movement, and much of this understanding has come from watching the work of Merce Cunningham. But the drama is overt in some of Mr. Cunningham's dances, ''plotless'' though they all may be. And one of the most dramatic and plotted seeming is ''Quartet,'' which the Merce Cunningham Dance Company presented on Saturday night at City Center, 131 West 55th Street, where the company is performing through Sunday.

title: A CITY WEEKEND, BATHED IN SPRINGTIME
description: The willows in Central Park were dressed in a pale green fuzz this weekend, softening the contours of winter and lifting the hearts of New Yorkers.

title: TRADERS BUYING BRITISH BONDS
description: While conflicting economic indicators and interest rate forecasts stifle trading and hold Treasury bond yields to a narrow range, speculative activity has shifted to the British Government bond market, where yields have been falling sharply.

title: AIDS AND TV: WHAT TO TELL A YOUNG CHILD
description: The television advertisement lasts just 15 seconds. ''I'm 24, single and worried,'' says the all-American fellow in the red Shetland sweater. ''I'm a nice guy who goes out with nice girls. But these days some pretty terrible things are happening to some pretty nice people.'' Then a picture of a Trojan condom box appears, along with the words ''For all the right reasons.''

title: TROUBLES AT S.M.U. REFLECT 'ETHOS' OF DALLAS
description: Southern Methodist University sits with sedate Georgian grace on Mockingbird Lane in the heart of ''The Bubble,'' the local term for the communities of Highland Park and University Park that provide Dallas with its most prestigious addresses.

title: MEDIA CHAIN'S FEUD IN COURT
description: After years of bitter quarreling and the collapse of last-minute negotiations, the families controlling Freedom Newspapers Inc. are scheduled to begin trial Monday in Orange County Superior Court to decide the fate of the closely held media company.

title: FUGITIVE MOUNTAIN MAN CAUGHT: KILLER WAS SUBJECT OF TV MOVIE
description: Claude Dallas, a self-styled mountain man who escaped last year from the Idaho State Penitentiary where he was imprisoned for killing two state Fish and Game wardens, was captured today, the authorities said.

title: 17-STORY PLUNGE KILLS LAWYER, 42, AT COLLEGE
description: A 42-year-old New York lawyer plunged to her death yesterday morning from a 17th-story window at Hunter College on Lexington Avenue, where she had been teaching a course on ''Women and the Law'' since last month, the police reported.

title: TYSON ATOP A TANGLED SCENE
description: In the Byzantine world of boxing, a statement that may ring true one moment is subject to speedy revision the next.

title: OVERNIGHT FLIGHT: BARGAIN FOR SPONTANEOUS TRAVELERS
description: Mary Carrico was on an overnight flight in a glorified cargo plane to Newark from St. Louis on Friday, and loving every minute of it.

title: HISTORIAN SEARCHES FOR KIN OF IRONCLADS' CREWMEN
description: After nine years, Irwin M. Berent has found about 300 of an estimated 10,000 descendants of crewmen of the Monitor and the Merrimack, or Virginia, who fought in the world's first battle of ironclads.

title: Corrections
description: A book review last Thursday of ''Johnson v. Johnson'' by Barbara Goldsmith misstated the means by which Nina Zagat became an heir to J. Seward Johnson. As Ms. Goldsmith's book says, Mrs. Zagat was included in Mr. Johnson's will before he became ill.

title: PROMOTION AT G.M. UNIT
description: The General Motors Corporation has named A. Grant Warner to replace Peter K. Hoglund as general manager of the Electro-Motive division in La Grange, Ill., on April 1. The appointment of Mr. Warner, a 59-year-old Canadian, has spurred speculation that G.M. may follow a consultant's advice and move the locomotive operations to Canada. A move to Canada could displace more than 4,000 workers, according to an Electro-Motive spokeswoman, Nancy Calvert. But, she said, G.M. has not decided whether to move the operation.

title: By Any Measure, Too Many Dropouts
description: Just a month ago, New York City education officials were bragging about a drop in the high school dropout rate - from 38 to 30 percent - that seemed to represent genuine progress. Then two weeks ago the Educational Priorities Panel, a private watchdog body, reported that the rate had indeed fallen, but only from 56 to 54 percent. Now, in response to the panel, the Board of Education recalculates the rate at 37 percent.

title: JAMES E. O'NEILL
description: James E. O'Neill, Assistant Archivist for Presidential Libraries at the National Archives, died Friday of a heart attack. He was 58 years old. Dr. O'Neill joined the National Archives in 1969 as director of the first Presidential Library, the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library in Hyde Park, N.Y., As Assistant Archivist for Presidential Libraries, he administered the eight existing Presidential libraries, oversaw the opening of the Ford and Carter libraries, and served as liaison between the National Archives and the Presidents.

title: FELONY CHARGES MAY BE SOUGHT IN THE IRAN CASE
description: Investigators working for the special prosecutor in the Iran arms affair expect to bring indictments and are studying a broad range of criminal charges against current and former Government officials, according to law-enforcement officials with knowledge of the investigation.

title: MOTORIST HURT AS POLICE NOTE NINE CASES OF ROCK THROWING
description: Nine motorists, one of whom was slightly injured, reported that their automobiles were hit by rocks as they drove on Manhattan highways yesterday, the police said.

title: A Team of Good Soldiers
description: WATCH Georgetown move. Mike Riley, the assistant coach, holds a trophy in one hand and raises his other hand and gives a shrill little whistle.

title: NEW CHAIRMAN OF I.C.I. PRAISES PLANNED AGENDA
description: On April 1, Denys H. Henderson, 54, will take over from the charismatic Sir John Harvey-Jones as chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries, Britain's largest chemical company.

title: Snowslide
description: When it comes to descending a snow-covered mountain, a pair of skis is still the predominant method of choice. But as a growing number of enthusiasts can attest, there's more than one way to get to the bottom of a slope. Their way is to take a ride on a snowboard, a sort of modified surfboard with foot straps, on which the snowboarder, standing sideway, skids down the slope, bending at the hips to negotiate turns.

title: GOODEN: 9 RUNS, 8 HITS 1 INNING
description: ''I'm not worried,'' said Dave Johnson, the manager of the Mets.

title: ISLANDERS RALLY FOR A 6-5 VICTORY
description: On Saturday night, in the desolation of a losers' dressing room, Mike Bossy had declared his hope, and his intention, of restoring his dignity with a hat trick tonight. ''It's what I would very much like to do,'' he had said, ''and not only for my personal well-being.''

title: RIGHTS GROUPS IN LOSING BATTLE FOR U.N. ROLE
description: A 19-country committee that met recently to consider applications of groups seeking ''consultative status'' at the United Nations granted the designation to such groups as the Mediterranean Women's Studies Institute, the International Society of Postmasters and the Malaysian-based National Consciousness Movement.

title: Blacks March in Mississippi To Condemn Bias in Schools
description: About 700 black marchers chanting ''we shall overcome'' accused the school system of discrimination Saturday and called for the superintendent to resign.

title: BRIDGES ARE THEME TO PROMOTE INSURER
description: On the theory that a good insurance company is frequently a bridge between a problem and its solution, Geer, DuBois Advertising has created a stunning print advertising campaign featuring eyecatching photographs of some of the world's more exciting bridges. The client is Fred. S. James & Company, insurance brokers.

title: FERRY INVESTIGATION FOCUSES ON THE OPEN LOADING DOORS
description: The North Sea ferry that capsized Friday probably departed from its dock here with the main bow loading doors open, company officials said today, but they insisted that this was a standard acceptable procedure to ventilate the lower decks.

title: STEEL PRICES HOLD FIRM, DESPITE RETURN OF USX
description: The nation's leading steel producers say that steel prices have remained firm despite the re-entry of the USX Corporation into the market. Some steel executives also predicted that prices would increase slightly this year, after years of going down.

title: EARLY SLUGGISHNESS IS DEVILS' DOWNFALL
description: Someone forgot to tell the Devils that the early stages of a game are just as crucial as the rest. Today they fell behind by 3-0 by the time the game was 3 minutes 10 seconds old, and ended up losing, 7-3, to the Philadelphia Flyers at the Spectrum.

title: A DIFFERENT CAMPAIGN FOR HOTELS
description: FOR the agencies competing last fall for the account of the Leading Hotels of the World, the challenge was to build an international campaign around 210 establishments in 48 countries that had few common qualities - except, perhaps, that they were leading.

title: GREEK LEADER ASSERTS THE U.S. SHOWS FAVORITISM TO TURKEY
description: In his sharpest criticism of the United States in months, Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou accused Washington this weekend of favoring Turkey over his country, and he threatened to close a Voice of America relay station unless what he called an imbalance was redressed.

title: SO MUCH FOR THE GRADUATE
description: JAMES (BONECRUSHER) SMITH climbed into the ring as the only college graduate ever to earn at least the World Boxing Association share of the heavyweight championship. But when he left in his red satin robe Saturday night, the business administration graduate of Shaw College in Raleigh, N.C., had dropped higher education to a new low or elevated it to a new high, depending on your sense of savagery.

title: IN A WARM CORNER OF SOVIET, A NON-RUSSIAN FLAIR
description: Moments before the airliner started to taxi toward the runway, the terminal door flew open and half a dozen passengers dashed out, their luggage swinging wildly from their shoulders as they ran toward the plane.

title: SADNESS TURNS TO ANGER OVER CBS DISMISSALS
description: For many of those remaining after the most severe cutback ever at CBS News, in which more than 215 people, including 14 on-air reporters, were dismissed from their jobs Friday, melancholy has turned to anger and a sense of betrayal aimed at Laurence A. Tisch, the chief executive officer of CBS.

title: REPUTED MOB LEADER GUILTY IN BOSTON RACKETEERING CASE
description: A reputed mob leader was convicted here Friday of gambling and loan-sharking.

title: Imminence of Chaos In Pakistan Discounted
description: To the Editor:

title: Voting and Tax Reforms Ireland Might Try
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSPECT IN KILLING ON FIRE I. IS HELD IN CANADIAN SLAYING
description: A 24-year-old Long Island man who early yesterday fatally shot a Canadian highway patrolman was arrested several hours later at Logan International Airport in Boston, according to authorities.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS LOOK TO BRITAIN
description: MUTUAL FUNDS that invest overseas find it virtually impossible to ignore Japan, since that nation accounts for 51 percent of the total equity capitalization of foreign markets. Moreover, Japan has provided handsome profits. On a relative basis, however, some funds have been placing greater stress lately on investments in Britain, where market capitalization is only one-fourth that of Japan.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Weren't there an unusually large number of players with 20 or more home runs in the American League last season?

title: SPEEDY RESCUE EFFORT SAVED MANY ABROAD CAPSIZED FERRY
description: When the British ferry Herald of Free Enterprise suddenly rolled on its side and partially sank two days ago, the captain did not have enough time to send out a distress signal, but the crew of a nearby Belgian dredging barge immediately sent out an alarm.

title: 4-MONTH DISRUPTION OF ECUADOR OIL
description: Ecuador's suspension of crude oil shipments will last at least four months because of the earthquake Thursday that ruptured the country's main oil pipeline, a senior Energy Ministry official said tonight.

title: LAWMAKERS TURN MUSIC CRITIC, ESSAY THE ESTHETIC
description: Representative Andrew Jacobs Jr. wants ''America the Beautiful'' to be declared the national anthem. Representative E. (Kika) de la Garza also admires the tune, but he would be content with its designation as the national song.

title: NEW CIGARETTE BRAND
description: The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company said it would begin test-marketing this month a new low-priced cigarette intended to appeal to image-conscious smokers. The Magna brand is Reynolds's third brand that is priced to compete with generic brands, the fastest-growing segment of the largely stagnant cigarette market. Reynolds also produces Doral, which competes directly with generics, and Century, which offers 25 cigarettes a pack at a price comparable to 20-cigarette packs.

title: FIREFIGHTERS FIND 2 MURDER VICTIMS
description: A 31-year-old man and a 16-year-old girl were found stabbed to death Saturday night when firefighters responded to a blaze in an Upper West Side apartment, authorities said.

title: AIDS HITS WESTERN EUROPE, MIMICKING VIRAL PATH IN U.S.
description: A story, not all that unusual in Europe these days, is told by Jean-Paul Escande, a doctor who heads the AIDS clinic at Tarnier Hospital in Paris.

title: QUESTIONS FOR A PRESIDENT ON THE RUN
description: They are analyzed, interpreted and instantly reported, these cryptic statements such as ''No'' and ''Yes'' or ''Well, this is up to him.''

title: JERSEY OFFICIALS WEIGH OFFER TO RESTORE STATUE
description: The bronze statue of Abraham Lincoln outside the Essex County Hall of Records here is showing the signs of its 75 years. It is pitted and stained from exposure to the elements, pollution and, of course, pigeons.

title: New York Zoning Plan for Tower Developers Needs Adjustment
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pistons 122, Celtics 119: Bill Laimbeer scored 6 of his 18 points in overtime yesterday to lift the Pistons to a victory in Pontiac, Mich. Adrian Dantley scored 28 points for Detroit, which had lost three of its previous four games. Isiah Thomas added 22.(AP) Bulls 115, Mavericks 105: Charles Oakley scored on two dunks and two free throws in overtime and Michael Jordan scored 33 points for Chicago, playing at home. (AP) Skiing Downhill to Figini: Michela Figini of Switzerland, skiing her best race of the season, won the women's World Cup downhill ski race yesterday on Mount Allan in Canmore, Alberta, edging Laurie Graham of Canada and Regine Moesenlechner of West Germany with a time of 1 minute 21.15 seconds. Zurbriggen Takes Supergiant Slalom: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland won for the second straight day capturing a supergiant slalom by nearly a full second on Aspen Mountain in Aspen, Colo. with an unofficial time of 1 minute 37.38 seconds.(AP) Gymnastics Phillips and Ginsberg Triumph: Kristie Phillips, the 14-year-old gymnast from Houston, compiled her highest point total ever in a competition, 39.275, yesterday to win the McDonald's American Cup for the second consecutive year. Brian Ginsberg, a 20-year-old from Scottsdale, Ariz., won the men's competition in Fairfax, Va., with 58.15 points. Auto Racing Earnhardt Wins 2d Straight Race: Dale Earnhardt won his second straight Nascar stock car victory by taking the Miller High Life 400 yesterday at Richmond Fairgrounds Raceway in Virginia. He beat Geoff Bodine to the finish line by about three car-lengths.(AP Horse Racing Landing Plot Wins by a Neck: After angling off the rail to find room in deep stretch, Landing Plot was up in the final strides to post a neck victory yesterday in the $71,900 Kings Point Handicap for New York-breds 3 years old and up at Aqueduct. Mr. Tatt was second in the tight finish a half-length ahead of Doctor Inglis. Landing Plot went a mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in 1:44. Track and Field Record Set in Bagel Run: Marty Ludwikowski of the New York Athletic Club set a meet record of 30 minutes 8 seconds in winning the New York Road Runners Club 10-kilometer Bagel Run yesterday in Central Park. Ludwikowski, in beating Dan Dickenson by 225 yards, erased the old record of 30:27 set by Frank McConville of Team Kangaroo Track Club last year. Gillian Beschloss of the Warren Street Athletic Club of Jersey City, defended the women's title in 35:48.(AP)

title: ROBB ON CAPITALISM
description: Although Gov. Charles S. Robb of Virginia says he's not running for President, he is seeking to move Democrats away from the protectionist bent evident in recent speeches by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, both contending for the party's 1988 Presidential nomination. Mr. Gephardt has warned that American workers must not be ''sacrificed on the altar of a false and rigid free-trade ideology.'' Mr. Biden has said, ''The Japanese and the Germans are trying to beat our brains out.''

title: CALCAVECCHIA WINS WITH 9-UNDER 279
description: Mark Calcavecchia went from the caddie shack at the 1986 Honda Classic to the winner's circle of this year's tournament, beating Bernhard Langer and Payne Stewart by three shots.

title: REAGAN BECOMING COMICS' DELIGHT
description: All across Manhattan, from Broadway stages to smoky comedy dives, the Iran-contra arms scandal has brought White House politics to the forefront of stand-up humor.

title: End the Arms Games
description: Both Moscow and Washington are suddenly waxing optimistic about a breakthrough on arms control, to start with eliminating all medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe.

title: THE ELDERLY ENJOY THE RESPITE OF SUMMER CAMPS
description: Evelyn Virgo has gone to Camp Green Acres in Dover Plains, N.Y., every summer for nine years. Like many a camper, her daily regimen usually includes basketball and swimming, field trips and outdoor sing-alongs. But unlike most campgoers, Ms. Virgo is a great-grandmother, and her fellow campers are mostly over 70.

title: Bridge: Seattle Couple Win Honors In Spring National Tourney
description: A married couple from Seattle were in the limelight here Saturday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, with the husband winning one major title and his wife placing second in another.

title: Nothing Surrogate About the Pain
description: The word mother has many definitions, several of which apply to Mary Beth Whitehead. Among them is the first: ''a woman who has borne a child.'' The person for whom she has been a surrogate - ''a deputy or substitute'' - is Elizabeth Stern. Because Dr. Stern feared that pregnancy might aggravate her mild multiple sclerosis, she and her husband deputized Mrs. Whitehead, by contract, to do what Dr. Stern chose not to do: have his baby. It's that simple.

title: CYNTHIA SALTZMAN WED TO YALE LAW PROFESSOR
description: Cynthia Saltzman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Saltzman of North Woodmere, L.I., was married in New Haven yesterday to Perry Dane, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arry Dane of Hackensack, N.J. Rabbi James Ponet, the Jewish chaplain and director of the Hillel Foundation at Yale University, performed the ceremony at Byers Hall of Silliman College on the Yale campus.

title: Unicef Names Belafonte Good-Will Ambassador
description: Harry Belafonte has been named to succeed Danny Kaye as a good-will ambassador for the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Classics in Church

title: Broad Brush Wins
description: Broad Brush, a 7-1 outsider, beat favored Ferdinand by a nose after a stirring stretch duel today to win the $1 million Santa Anita Handicap.

title: BRISK CORPORATE PACE MAY CONTINUE
description: Treasury auctions this week are confined to the bill market, starting with today's regular weekly sale of three- and six-month issues and concluding Thursday with a new issue of bills due in one-year.

title: RANGERS CRUMPLE AS FLAMES WIN, 7-4
description: The Rangers, making so many mistakes that they might all be in jeopardy of being traded, allowed the Calgary Flames six straight goals last night at Madison Square Garden and lost, 7-4.

title: HIS 3-POINTERS HELP TOP SYRACUSE, 69-59
description: It is not unusual for a highly touted freshman to take three or even four seasons to live up to his high school clippings. Sometimes, it never happens.

title: BRAZILIANS DIVIDED ON LEADER'S TERM
description: Trapped in a swirling economic and political crisis, President Jose Sarney has decided to press Brazil's newly inaugurated Constitutional Assembly to define the length of his mandate, according to pro-Government politicians.

title: ICAHN OFFER MAY HINGE ON USAIR TAKEOVER BID
description: Carl C. Icahn may withdraw his offer of $52 a share for the USAir Group if the carrier completes an agreement to take over Piedmont Airlines in such a way as to make USAir financially unattractive, industry sources said yesterday.

title: JOHN GETTING OFF TO GOOD START
description: There were a couple of walks in the first inning and there was a home run in the second, but the ball still dipped when Tommy John commanded. It usually does, even now in the spring when the games don't count for much and the players seem only concerned about getting themselves into shape.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This may be the year in which the string runs out on Capitol Hill. The level of frustration with Japan is higher than I have ever seen it.'' - Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, on trade imbalance. [ A1:4. ]

title: MECIR UPSETS LENDL WITH SPEED, WILES
description: It would be appropriate to raise a yellow caution flag above the stadium court at the International Tennis Center here, a warning that the strong winds that blew across South Florida last week may signify a change in the status quo of professional tennis. Ivan Lendl, who has been ranked first for the past two years, is still looking for his first tournament victory in 1987, and the frustration is beginning to show.

title: UNION BOYCOTT OF COORS EXTENDED TO NEW YORK
description: The long-running battle between the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Adolph Coors Company, the Colorado brewery, has moved into the New York metropolitan area.

title: ISRAEL DEFERS CABINET QUERIES ABOUT SPY SENTENCED IN U.S.
description: The Israeli Cabinet today referred questions on the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy affair to the 10-member inner Cabinet, which is expected to convene Wednesday, a statement about the meeting of the full Cabinet said.

title: MOUNTING CONFLICT OVER TRADE LOOMS FOR U.S. AND JAPAN
description: The United States and Japan are headed for their most serious trade confrontation of the postwar period, Government officials and many private analysts believe.

title: A 'HOT' WEEK FOR GOVERNOR OF ARIZONA
description: For Gov. Evan Mecham, this has been a typical week: He banned a local newspaper columnist from his news conferences, a citizen committee in Tucson announced a petition drive to remove him from office and a national organization of black nurses became the latest group to cancel a planned convention here because of him.

title: Wolfpack Upsets Tar Heels in Final
description: Afterward, as well-wishers crowded the floor and a beaming Jim Valvano was hoisted aloft to take a turn at cutting down the net, Andy Kennedy, a North Carolina State reserve guard, turned to a teammate and uttered a single word that summed up the Wolfpack's 68-67 victory over North Carolina today for the Atlantic Coast Conference championship: ''Unbelievable.''

title: TIGHTENED RULES SEEN FOR FERRIES
description: A Government minister said today that Britain was considering moves to tighten operating procedures on its ferries.

title: 2 FIRES SET BY VANDALS AT YESHIVA IN BROOKLYN
description: Vandals ransacked classrooms and lighted two small fires in a Brooklyn yeshiva this weekend, but the police said yesterday that the incident did not appear to be a deliberately anti-Semitic gesture.

title: BELL LABS: ADAPTING TO MONOPOLY'S END
description: In the last three years alone, Bell Laboratories Inc., the research and development arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has come up with a stream of new technologies that would be a credit to any major university.

title: 83% TO BE VICTIMS OF CRIME VIOLENCE
description: Eighty-three percent of 12-year-old children in the United States will be victims or intended victims of violent crimes at least once in their lifetimes, the Justice Department reported today. Fifty-two percent will be victims of such crimes more than once.

title: TARIFFS SEEN LOSING SUPPORT
description: The public's support for tariffs and other trade barriers has measurably declined, a nationwide poll has found.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $315,000 from the sale of real estate and an extraordinary gain of $590,000 from prepayment of long-term debt at discount. c-Net income and includes a gain of $2,080,000 from the sale of real estate. The company said the gain on sale in the latest quarter includes a valuation loss of $2,226,000 on the writedown of the carrying value of the Northridge apartments located in the Houston area. The company also said the loss in the latest year is due primarily to an investment loss provision totaling $6,298,000 relating to the trust's properties in Texas. As a result of a review of its Texas properties, the trust established an investment loss provision totaling $4,072,200 for its investments located in the Dallas area.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes gains of $387,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter on the sale and land; and the year includes $2,790,000, or 69 cents a share, relating principally to the sale of stores and land.

title: AUTHORITIES RELEASE 2 COWBOYS ACCUSED OF HARBORING KILLER
description: Two cowboys arrested on charges of harboring Claude Dallas Jr., the fugitive killer of two game wardens who was recaptured Sunday after roaming from Oregon to Mexico for nearly a year, were freed today for lack of evidence.

title: TOP CONTRA QUITS, SAYING CHANGES WERE BLOCKED
description: The leading Nicaraguan rebel leader, Arturo Jose Cruz, resigned today after months of bitter infighting that has fractured the American-backed rebel movement perhaps beyond repair.

title: 3 DIE AND ONE HURT AS STOLEN BUS AND AUTO COLLIDE IN WESTCHESTER
description: Three people were killed and a fourth person was injured when a bus - the third to be stolen from the same New Jersey company since December - collided early Sunday with an out-of-control car on Interstate 95 in Westchester County, officials said today.

title: INTEREST RATES CUT IN BRITAIN
description: The Bank of England, apparently concerned about a recent surge in the price of the pound, cut the interest rate it charges banks by half a point today, thus allowing Britain's major banks to cut their interest rates.

title: The Right Place for the Police Academy
description: Mayor Koch's commission on police personnel management called for replacing the police academy on East 20th Street in Manhattan and suggested a new facility ''in an under-utilized section of the city.'' The commission is right on both counts. Why not build a modern academy in the South Bronx?

title: OIL-RIG COUNT DECLINES
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped this week to 766, down 35 from a week ago, according to the Hughes Tool Company rig count. Last year at this time, the count was 1,212. The count, the yardstick of drilling activity, reached a low of 663 in July - the lowest since the Houston-based oil toolmaker began tracking the rigs in 1940 - as oil prices plunged. The rig count reached a peak in December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, when 4,500 rigs were active.

title: SOUTHERN CO.
description: The Southern Company said it would take an after-tax charge of $226 million against earnings no later than January 1988 because the projected cost of the Vogtle nuclear power plant had risen above the amount that retail customers in Georgia would be asked to pay. The company's largest subsidiary, the Georgia Power Company, said the budget for the plant had increased by 6.3 percent, or $522 million, to $8.87 billion. However, because of a pledge the company made to state regulators last year, the increased cost will not be included in the utility's retail electric rates.

title: HAFTS SEEK PARENT OF PATHMARK
description: The Haft family of Washington, which made nearly $160 million last year in an unsuccessful attempt to take over Safeway Stores, yesterday offered to buy the Supermarkets General Corporation for $1.6 billion in cash.

title: QADDAFI AND ARAFAT MEND FENCES
description: Libya, joining efforts to heal a four-year-old breach in the Palestine Liberation Organization, has reconciled with the wing of the guerrilla movement that is led by Yasir Arafat.

title: ADVANCED SUPERCOMPUTER BEGINS OPERATION
description: FULL operation began yesterday for a new supercomputer system, described as the world's most advanced, which will simulate for the first time extremely complex phenomena of flight, weather and galactic evolution.

title: ILLUMINATING 'COSMIC CONSCIOUSNESS'
description: THE exploding star that burst into view two weeks ago has given astronomers something more than a unique research opportunity; for the men and women studying it, the supernova has renewed a philosophical perspective that transcends career competition, family problems, economic hardships and even political persecution.

title: BAMBERGER POLYMERS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company went public in February 1987.

title: EX-JUDGE IS GIVEN IMMUNITY TO BE A GRAND JURY WITNESS
description: A former State Supreme Court justice convicted of bribery has been granted immunity to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating judicial corruption in Queens, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: GOVERNMENT ISSUING REGULATIONS ON FARM TOILETS
description: Operating under a court order issued last month that condemned past Government inaction, the Reagan Administration acted today to require farms to provide toilets, drinking water and other sanitation facilities to field workers.

title: DESPITE MEMBERSHIP DISPUTE, UTILITY PANEL GRANTS RATE RISE
description: In a special meeting today, the state's Public Service Commission averted a confrontation over how many members it still has by reaching a unanimous vote on a rate increase for the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation.

title: MCDONNELL REPORTS TALKS WITH AIRBUS
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said its officials had held informal talks with its European competitor, Airbus Industrie, about joint development and production of a new passenger airliner. ''McDonnell and Airbus have had a series of discussions of possible cooperation over the past several years,'' a McDonnell Douglas spokesman, Jack Cooke, said. ''So far none of the possibilities discussed have come to fruition, but we always remain open to further talks.''

title: GANDALF TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
COST IS $1.5 BILLION
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the American Motors Corporation for about $1.5 billion.

title: U.S. ALLOWS WIDER NORTH KOREAN TALKS
description: The State Department has authorized American diplomats to conduct substantive conversations with North Korean officials at receptions and parties and in other ''neutral'' locations.

title: A Profound Test
description: Mikhail Gorbachev understands that the Soviet Union pays a price in the world for its abuses of human rights. The end of Andrei Sakharov's exile and the release of some important political prisoners were, at a minimum, gestures to the opinions of mankind. Incomplete as we may think them, we have to understand that they were bold steps for a Soviet leader.

title: Litigation Over a Chart
description: F. Andrew Messing Jr., cited in the Tower Commission report as a link in the supply line to Nicaraguan insurgents, says he is planning to sue the commission for associating him with the weapon and fund transfers.

title: Right He Is
description: Andy Russo, basketball coach at the University of Washington, on U.C.L.A.'s first-round opponent in the national tournament: ''I don't know too much about Central Michigan. I think it's in the center of the state.''

title: RESEARCHER REPORTS PROGRESS AGAINST AUTISM
description: USING an intensive behavior modification program and training parents to continue treatment at home, U.C.L.A. psychologists say they have been able to transform a large proportion of autistic children into apparently normal children.

title: IN MILAN, IT'S SHORT OR LONG, SEXY OR SEDATE, FOR FALL
description: Sparks are flying in all directions at the opening here of the Italian fashion shows for fall and winter. Instead of the sameness that usually marks the Milan presentations, there is a wide range of shapes and styles, and the daytime clothes are the most successful.

title: Improperly Cast Votes Cited in Chicago Race
description: As many as 100,000 votes may have been improperly cast Feb. 24 in the Democratic mayoral primary, but they are not likely to affect Mayor Harold Washington's victory, The Chicago Tribune reported Sunday.

title: CUOMO, IN A SHIFT, AGREES A TAX CUT SHOULD BEGIN IN '87
description: Governor Cuomo, faced with growing political opposition on fiscal issues, agreed with legislative leaders today that a new cut in state taxes should begin this year.

title: BRIDGE: A CALIFORNIAN PARTNERSHIP LEADS IN OPEN-PAIR EVENT
description: A partnership of Californians led the field into the final session of the American Contract Bridge League's Open Pairs Championship at the Spring Nationals here tonight. Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif., and Ed Davis of Santa Ana, Calif., scored 63 percent in the first final session to take a lead of three-quarters of a board over their nearest rivals. These were the standings: First, Meyers and Davis, 730.7 match points; second, Jack Kennedy of Shreveport, La., and George Dawkins of Austin, Tex., 701.6; third, Alex Ornstein, Roslyn Heights, L.I., and Bruce Rogoff, Bayside, Queens, 669.9; fourth, Peter Nagy, Chicago, and George Mittelman, Toronto, 666.8; fifth, Curtis Cheek, Huntsville, Ala., and Bryan Howard, Nashville, 656.8, technically tied with Tom Trachuk, Oakland, Calif., and Mark Singer, Sausalito, Calif., 656.6.

title: Officers Fear a Backlash From Iran Affair
description: Midshipmen at the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, down the road from here, learn the fundamentals of seamanship and navigation in a Gothic building known as Luce Hall. Years ago its corridors were emblazoned with the sayings of naval heroes. One was ''Where principle is involved, be deaf to expediency'' (from an oceanographer of the Navy, Mathew Fontaine Maury, 1806-1873). That inscription, along with all the others, is no longer there, victims of an interior designer's paint job a few years ago.

title: MORTGAGE RATES FALL TO 9-YEAR LOW
description: Interest rates on mortgage loans continued to drop in February, reaching the lowest levels in almost nine years, according to two surveys.

title: We Can't Run Cars on Fuel Efficiency Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: BENCHES COULD DECIDE FATE OF BIG EAST
description: St. John's is going to Chicago, Providence is headed for Birmingham, Pittsburgh is Tuscon-bound and Syracuse is staying home. Georgetown is going to Atlanta, but the Hoyas could be headed to New Orleans.

title: CITIZENS SAVINGS ITHACA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,824,000 on sale of Mortgage Banking Co. The company said it went public in January, so it did not give any year- ago comparable figures.

title: MCDERMOTT STAKE
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas-based investor, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that companies he owns or controls have acquired a 5.4 percent stake in McDermott International Inc., a maker of offshore oil rigs and power generating plants. Mr. Simmons said he paid an average price of $22 a share, or about $44 million. Mr. Simmons said in an interview that he was undecided whether he would attempt to gain control of the company. ''The stock probably isfully priced at $30a share,'' he said. McDermott closed uncahnged, at $29,75 a share, with 2.8 million shares traded to day on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: ROHR DEBENTURES OF $150 MILLION
description: Rohr Industries of Chula Vista, Calif., a manufacturer of jet engine pod assemblies, is offering $150 million of 9 1/4 percent subordinated debentures due in 2017 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company. The debentures yield about 1.6 percentage points more than the 30-year Treasury bond due in 2016.

title: BRITISH CITE 'OPEN DOORS' ON THE FERRY
description: The British Government today cited an ''inrush of water through the open bow doors'' as the probable cause of the capsizing Friday night of the North Sea ferry in which 134 people were killed.

title: MACINTOSH SE: THE APPLE EVOLVES
description: OF the two new Macintosh computers introduced by Apple last week, the flashy, powerful Mac II attracted the most attention. Yet it is the other model, the Mac SE, that is expected to attract the most buyers.

title: CONSTITUTION AND EFFECT ON YOUTHS
description: ''MAIN STREET'' addresses the Constitution today: How does it apply to young people? Does it apply to them at all? In this, the Constitution's 200th year, these are solemn questions, although ''Main Street'' avoids solemnity in its discussion. The NBC News program for teen-agers, on Channel 4 at 4 P.M. today, is a lively but thoughtful hour.

title: A Question of Intelligence
description: One of the issues raised by the Tower Commission in its report on the Iran arms affair was that the Central Intelligence Agency, in updating a Special National Intelligence Estimate on Iran in May of 1985, went beyond its legitimate role of providing intelligence to the President and other high Government officials. The report said that Howard Teicher and Donald Fortier, then of the White House National Security Council staff, had asked the C.I.A. for the update to see whether there was some way military support of some kind could blunt Soviet influence in Iran, and suggested that the intelligence agency came closer than it should have to giving the N.S.C. operators the policy answers they were looking for. The C.I.A. vigorously disputes the suggestion. Following are excerpts from the report and from a letter from Robert M. Gates on this subject:

title: AFTER HOWARD BEACH: SEEKING RACIAL PEACE
description: Out of the tragedy and bitterness of the Howard Beach racial attack, George Russo, a white lawyer who grew up in the Queens neighborhood, and the Rev. Irvine A. Bryer Jr., a black minister in Queens Village, have become friends.

title: RANGE OF EMOTIONS IN TENNESSEE: SYMPATHY TO A SENSE OF BETRAYAL
description: Leo Crane says he thinks it is time for the country to move beyond the arms-for-hostages controversy, now that President Reagan has admitted the policy was a mistake. ''This is history now,'' said Mr. Crane, who owns the Inglewood hardware store in Nashville. ''Let's go forward.''

title: Serious Economic Damage
description: The Ecuadorean earthquake has caused serious economic damage to a country that was already suffering from the effects of the drop in the world price of oil.

title: Article 023687 -- No Title
description: In a move that took the book publishing industry by surprise, Theodore L. Cross, a lawyer and editor, has offered to buy Harper & Row Publishers Inc. in a $190 million deal.

title: STAGE: 'CARRYING SCHOOL CHILDREN,' A SPACE DRAMA
description: IN his plays, Thomas Babe has dealt with a broad diversity of subjects - boxing, crime, journalism - but through all his work there has been a folkloric streak. Mr. Babe is evidently interested in legends from the past, the present and, in the case of his new play, ''Carrying School Children,'' the future. However, as an attempted flight into outer space, ''Carrying School Children'' (at Theater for the New City) suffers from dramatic weightlessness.

title: AMERICAN PIONEER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,220,000 for the quarter and $4,460,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $119,000 for the quarter and $2,031,000 for the year, and the year also includes an extraordinay litigation loss of $2,400,000. The company said preferred dividend requirements for the 1985 periods exceeded net income.

title: Philippine Ferry Catches Fire
description: All 300 passengers and crew members of an inter-island ferry were rescued by fishermen after they jumped overboard to escape a fire, the Philippine News Agency said today. The passengers and crew abandoned the Geopeter, on her way to Negros Island from the Zamboanga archipelago, before the blaze sank her Sunday off Silinog Island. The agency said the fire was apparently caused by an electrical fault.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report yesterday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misidentified Charles S. Robb of Virginia. He is a former Governor, not the Governor.

title: Earl Montgomery, 65, Stage and Screen Actor
description: Earl Montgomery, a supporting actor who made his Broadway debut in 1947 and appeared in many plays as well as in movies and on television, died last Wednesday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 65 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Q&A
description: Q.What are cuds and why do cows chew them? A.Cows and other ruminants like goats, deer, antelope and similar hoofed mammals have stomachs divided into four compartments, designed to handle large amounts of forage. Ruminants do not chew their food completely at first. Instead, they chew the food only enough to moisten it with saliva for swallowing. The swallowed food goes into the paunch and the reticulum, the first two sections of the stomach. There the food is mixed with several kinds of bacteria and protozoa that start the process of digestion. After the animal has satisfied its appetite, it regurgitates or coughs up balls of the partially digested food from the paunch and reticulum. These balls are the cuds, and ruminants chew them thoroughly, swallow them and cough up more of them. The balls are eventually passed on to the other two stomach compartments, the omasum and abomasum, where digestion is completed. Q.Why does wax form in the ear canal and should it be removed? A.Ear wax is a fatty lubricant secreted by specialized glands in the skin of the ear canal to prevent bacterial growth. Because of its slightly acidic content, the secretion kills the bacteria that tend to form in the ear cavity, according to Dr. Derald Brackmann of the American Academy of Otolaryngology. Dr. Brackmann said a person should never clean the ear with cotton swabs or other pointed objects because such action only pushes the wax deeper into the ear and could lead to hearing loss or perforation of the ear drum. ''In general, the rule of thumb is: Don't put anything smaller than your elbow in the ear,'' Dr. Brackmann said. The ear is normally self cleaning; the wax migrates to the outer surface where it can be removed with a tissue. Occasionally, however, ear wax can build up and block the ear canal. In such cases, a physician should be consulted.

title: NEW YORK SUES FRANK B. HALL
description: The New York State Superintendent of Insurance has filed a $140 million lawsuit against Frank B. Hall & Company, one of the nation's largest insurance brokers, in connection with the insolvency of a subsidiary, the Union Indemnity Insurance Company of New York.

title: PROSECUTOR TERMS DEAVER'S STATEMENTS 'GROSSLY INACCURATE'
description: Whitney North Seymour Jr., the independent counsel investigating Michael K. Deaver, today told a Federal court that the former Presidential aide had made ''grossly inaccurate and deceptive'' statements in seeking to block a pending indictment.

title: 2,000 CATHOLICS LOBBY OFFICIALS IN ALBANY VISIT
description: Two thousand Roman Catholics - led by all eight bishops of New York State, including John Cardinal O'Connor - swept through the halls of state government today. They lobbied for the Catholic view on legislation, calling for greater aid for the poor and protesting that the government was pressuring the church to compromise some of its basic beliefs.

title: Bypassing 'Recruits'
description: The University of Texas has decided against recruiting any of the S.M.U. football players who are now eligible to play elsewhere following cancellation of the Mustangs' 1987 season because of N.C.A.A. violations. ''This is nothing personal against any of the student athletes,'' said the Texas athletic director, DeLoss Dodds. ''We just feel that it is in the best interest of our program to bypass the recruiting of S.M.U. players.'' Texas was one of the five Southwest Conference schools that voted on Feb. 27 in favor of allowing S.M.U. players to transfer within the conference without losing a year of eligibility. There was another vote Saturday morning ''and we voted in favor of it once again,'' Dodds said. He said a decision was made not to recruit any S.M.U. players after last week's stories about the extent of irregularities at S.M.U.

title: TEXACO LAWSUIT IS SAID TO HELP PENNZOIL BONDS
description: The Pennzoil Company's latest bond offering was helped by the possibility that the company will collect a sizable sum from its lawsuit with Texaco, market sources said yesterday.

title: ROCK STARS DELIVER ANTI-DRUG MESSAGES
description: In addition to the enormous flow of anti-drug advertising starting to come from the Media-Advertising Partnership for a Drug Free America, there are also all the messages being supplied to the various media by the Advertising Council and by a group called Rock Against Drugs. The latter organization introduced its first campaign last November and tonight is beginning Phase 2.

title: HOOPER HOLMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MANAGER IS NAMED AT LEFTON
description: THERE are probably very few advertising people moving into top positions who started out in the business, as James W. North did, ''riding the boards.''

title: Star Wars Stumbles on Itself
description: Something looks very wrong with the management of the President's Star Wars missile defense program. Instead of clear and steady progress toward establishing its technological feasibility, the program's managers seem to shift emphasis every few months from one vaunted breakthrough to another. Last year the free-electron laser was hot stuff; now attention veers to crash development of space-based rockets. The primary goal seems political: getting production lines running before President Reagan leaves office. That goal collides with any kind of orderly technical progress.

title: CLARY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.
