ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes securities gains of $59.5 million and $100,000 for the latest year and year-ago period, respectively. The company noted that stock was distributed publicly on Dec. 31, 1986, upon liquidation of the Maryland Corporation of the same name. The 1986 results include after-tax gains on the sale of American Express common shares, amounting to $38.8 million, of $6.04 a share. The results include the accounts of Alleghany and its subsidiaries, as well as of MSL Industries, which was merged into Alleghany in December 1986, and are computed on the basis of the number of shares of the old Alleghany common stock outstanding during the respective periods.

title: 2 BUFFALO YOUTHS ARRESTED IN MURDERS OF 2 PRIESTS
description: The police charged two teen-agers today in the slaying of two Roman Catholic priests within the last 13 days. They said that robbery appeared to be the motive and that one of the youths knew both priests and had been counseled by one.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FUJITSU, GTE IN VENTURE
description: Fujitsu America Inc., based in San Jose, Calif., said today that it had reached an agreement with the GTE Communication Systems Corporation to establish a joint venture that would develop and market voice and data business communications systems for the North American market.

title: MATTINGLY HITS EARLY GROOVE
description: It seemed like September again. Don Mattingly stepped into the batter's box, bent into his peculiar crouch at the plate and stroked a single sharply to right. He rounded the bag, stopped abruptly as the relay came back to the infield, then returned to first base and clapped his hands.

title: TOO MANY LEGS
description: Frogs in a California pond that have grown as many as eight legs may have done so in response to stimulation or injury by parasites, researchers have reported.

title: KENYAN KILLS A COUNTRYMAN AND WOUNDS 2, POLICE SAY
description: A 29-year-old Kenyan went on a rampage early yesterday in the apartment in Edgewater, N.J., where he lived with three other Kenyans, beating one of his roommates to death with a tire wrench, the authorities reported.

title: LEGAL AID SUES ON ALLOWANCES FOR APARTMENTS
description: Asserting that many families on welfare are being forced into homelessness by inadequate allowances for shelter, the Legal Aid Society filed a class-action suit yesterday in Manhattan demanding that state and city officials raise the payments.

description: Allegheny International Inc., the troubled Pittsburgh-based maker of Sunbeam appliances and other products, announced yesterday that it had agreed to a $500 million leveraged buyout by an affiliate of the First Boston Corporation.

description: The Lower Colorado River Authority of Texas is offering $510.9 million of refunding bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 7.18 percent for bonds due in 2009.

description: b-Net loss c-After a gain of $2,071,000 on retirement of debt.

title: MICHELIN'S CHANGES FOR 1987
description: The 1987 Guide Michelin for France, published today, demoted La Pyramide, one of the nation's longtime temples of gastronomy, from the top three-star rating to two stars. La Pyramide in Vienne, 17 miles south of Lyons, was first awarded Michelin's three-star rating in 1933.

title: PROGRESS IN AIDS DISPUTE
description: A BITTER dispute over scientific credit in the research on AIDS appears to be nearing a resolution that will recognize both French and American claims.

title: CBS'S TISCH RESPONDS
description: Passions ran high at CBS News yesterday in the aftermath of Friday's dismissal of 215 news division employees, and Laurence A. Tisch, the network's chief executive officer, tried to clarify some inconsistencies regarding the cutbacks.

title: 'TIMESTALKERS,' SCIENCE-FICTION FILM
description: MONEY - or at least a gigantic production budget - isn't everything. Dipping into science fiction, television cannot compete with the spectacular effects of a movie studio's ''Star Wars.'' But on its own chintzy level, television can come up with a ''Star Trek,'' no slouch in the popularity sweepstakes. Small may not always be beautiful, but it can be effective. Consider tonight's ''Timestalkers'' on CBS at 9 o'clock.

title: Zaire Is Striving to Emerge From the Yoke of Underdevelopment
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT'S POST FILLED AT WERTHEIM SCHRODER
description: Wertheim Schroder & Company, an investment banking and securities firm, said yesterday that Steven Kotler had been named president and chief operating officer.

title: HOWARD FAST IN A NEW MODE WITH LATEST NOVEL
description: ''It's been said,'' Howard Fast remarked, ''that I am the most widely read writer of the 20th century. The number of books I've sold runs into untold millions. 'Freedom Road' alone we calculated at one point years ago had sold over 20 million copies. The only complete bibliography of my work was done by a Russian scholar who came up with 82 languages and something in the neighborhood of 30 million books, but that was in 1952, so it's more than 30 years ago. I always tell myself that someday I'm going to try and add this up, but there's really no way I can do it.''

title: How Much Is Enough?
description: The difference between salaries in Government and the private professions never seemed quite so dramatic. At a Congressional hearing on the Securities and Exchange Commission the other day, Representative Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts asked John S. R. Shad, the agency chairman, whether the discrepancy between S.E.C. salaries and those paid outside was making it harder for the agency to fill jobs. Mr. Shad paused a moment, then observed, ''Well, my daughter, one year out of law school, is making more money than I am.'' The S.E.C. chairman receives $82,500 a year, having recently been increased from $75,800. An S.E.C. spokesman said the chairman's daughter, Leslie Anne, was working for a New York City law firm but declined to say which one.

title: A MATTER OF CENSORSHIP
description: A Federal judge's decision last week to ban more than 40 textbooks from Alabama's public schools is part of an emerging pattern in which fundamentalists and conservatives are trying to make public education conform to their religious and societal beliefs.

title: PANELS IN SENATE AND HOUSE DIFFER ON IMMUNITY TACTIC
description: The special Congressional committees investigating the Iran arms affair disagree with one another about how soon key witnesses should be granted immunity from prosecution to compel their testimony.

title: SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for 12mo Jan 31
MANATRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HAMILTON JORDAN IS NOW IN DIFFERENT CENTER COURT
description: He has the purposeful walk of a man in a hurry, a candidate's smile and handshake, and a knack for making small talk. Amid the brightly colored, casual designer outfits found on the grounds of a tennis tournament, Hamilton Jordan's dark blue business suit set him apart from the crowd, drawing curious glances from passers-by. But then, he is accustomed to making an impression.

title: TENDER BEGINS FOR CAESARS
description: Martin T. Sosnoff, a New York investor and money manager, has just published his second book, ''Silent Investors, Silent Losers,'' about how Wall Street has disenfranchised the small investor.

description: b-Net income and after extraordinary items, reduction of income tax arising from deduction of prior year's accounting losses, of $175,000 and $310,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: RENAULT TO FOCUS ON EUROPE
description: Renault is selling its stake in American Motors as part of a recovery strategy based on redeploying its assets in Europe, Raymond Levy, the French auto maker's new president, said today.

title: HOMETOWN CROWDS ARE HARD TO AVOID
description: College basketball's championship will take place before more than 61,000 seats in the Louisiana Superdome at the end of the month, and even that many are not enough. The four schools to emerge from regional competition will receive the first million-dollar congratulations. But the dramatic growth of the 64-team tournament has also contributed to inequities that could affect as many as one-quarter of the first- and second-round games to be played Thursday through Sunday.

title: BURSON-MARSTELLER ARGUES OVER RANKING
description: Jack O'Dwyer, editor and publisher of O'Dwyer's Directory of Public Relations Firms, has got a little flap going for himself with Burson-Marsteller, which says it is the world's largest but is being carried in the new directory as second to Hill & Knowlton.

title: FUND-RAISER ISSUES AUDIT TO SHOW HE GOT NO MONEY IN IRAN DEALINGS
description: Carl R. (Spitz) Channell, a conservative fund-raiser, today released audits of nine of his tax-exempt foundations and political action committees to show that they had not received money from the sale of weapons to Iran.

title: RAVES FOR WORLD INDOOR MEET
description: Antonio McKay said the first world indoor track and field championships was a great meet. He might be prejudiced because he won a gold medal, but many losers liked the meet, too.

title: Our Towns; A Consultant With a Cause: Helping Twins
description: There are some who say there's nothing to do in the suburbs, but you couldn't prove this by Dr. Jane Greer. Seems like she always has something twin-related perking.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Metropolitan Wildlife

title: SURROGATE-BIRTH LAW NOT LIKELY
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he did not think legislation on surrogate mothers would be approved this year.

description: b-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $162,000.

description: The Supreme Court today ruled that the Government must relax its standard for deciding whether aliens who contend they would be persecuted in their home countries are eligible for political asylum.

description: * Conde Nast to David Deutsch Associates for trade advertising for its Conde Nast Traveler magazine.

The results do not reflect the acquisition of Windowvision Inc., which was completed Dec. 31, 1986. The share earnings for its latest fourth quarter and year as well as year-ago figures were adjusted to reflect payment of a 10 percent stock dividend on Feb. 16, 1987.

title: HUGHES INSTITUTE PICKS HEAD OF ITS NEW EFFORT ON GRANTS
description: An expert on the public policy and ethical implications of science was named today to head a new program at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute that will make the organization's first grants to outsiders.

title: TYROL ISN'T UTOPIA YET, JUST THE LITTLE FATHERLAND
description: ''Don't think I wouldn't be delighted,'' the silvery haired politician said, thrusting a finger for emphasis. ''After all, I'd probably be Prime Minister. But I refuse to awaken hopes that have no chance of fulfillment.''

title: BRAZIL, JAPAN DISCUSS DEBT
description: Brazil's Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro, appealed today for Japanese help in sorting out his country's $109 billion debt problem and received sympathy and advice to seek the help of the International Monetary Fund.

title: A LEGISLATOR QUITS AS PANEL URGES PENALTY
description: A Queens Assemblywoman who admitted adding two ''no show'' jobs to her state payroll resigned today after the Assembly Ethics Committee recommended that she receive what it called the heaviest penalties possible under the State Constitution.

title: THUROW WILL HEAD M.I.T. SLOAN SCHOOL
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced yesterday that Lester C. Thurow, a professor and writer on economics, had been named dean of M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management.

title: RUBBER TALKS BEGIN
description: Representatives of 40 countries that produce and consume rubber met today to try to adopt a price stabilization agreement to replace the one that expires next October.

title: CITY OPERA: 'BUTTERFLY' IN THE BRONX ON TOUR
description: WHILE ''South Pacific'' rolls along at Lincoln Center, another arm of the New York City Opera has taken to the road. The company is taking Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' across New England, New York, the Middle West and the South for five and a half weeks. The tour began in Brooklyn Saturday night and moved to the Lehman Center in the Bronx on Sunday. Judging from Sunday's compact, decently sung and musically honest performance, both Puccini and the City Opera will be honorably represented.

title: CHOLESTEROL: DRUG HAILED AS TREATMENT BREAKTHROUGH
description: A NEW type of cholesterol-lowering drug, expected to be approved for marketing later this year, promises to revolutionize treatment of high levels of blood cholesterol, the main underlying cause of atherosclerotic heart disease, the artery-hardening condition that kills a million Americans each year.

title: SAUDI BUSINESSMAN IN IRAN AFFAIR TELLS OF 'PLAYING GAMES' WITH U.S. AIDES
description: The Saudi businessman who helped finance the sale of arms to Iran, Adnan Khashoggi, says he played ''games within games'' with William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, and with other American officials involved in the Iran-contra affair.

title: TESTIMONY ENDS AT HEARING ON BABY M
description: Testimony in the Baby M custody trial ended today with a nun describing a ''confrontation'' when Mary Beth Whitehead withdrew her two children from a parochial school five years ago.

description: Carl H. Lindner, the chairman of the American Financial Corporation, said today that he was considering seeking control of the Taft Broadcasting Company.

title: Banning Books Isn't the Answer
description: LEAD: On March 4, Judge Brevard Hand banned 40 textbooks from Alabama's public schools because they promoted a religion, ''secular humanism.'' The case arose from a systemic problem - the growing omission of discussion of religion in the textbooks and classes of public schools. Yet both the plaintiffs' account of the source of the problem and the judge's bizarre remedy miss the point.

title: CONCERT: HOIBY-BABIN DUO
description: LEE HOIBY and Stanley Babin, pianists and composers both, joined forces for an amiable program at Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall Saturday afternoon.

title: FRANCO ZEFFIRELLI READIES MET'S NEW 'TURANDOT'
description: Franco Zeffirelli, maker of glamorous operatic events, is back at the Metropolitan Opera, working, as usual, to anticipate our visual fantasies and then do them one better. Late last week, preparations for Puccini's ''Turandot'' were not going to his expectations, but Mr. Zeffirelli's imposing new sets were already more or less in place. When ''Turandot'' opens Thursday night with Placido Domingo, Eva Marton, Leona Mitchell and Paul Plishka in the principal roles, some may condemn its grandeur; others will wallow in it, but everyone - friend or foe - is going to gasp.

title: FOR NONPROFIT THEATERS, A VICTORY OVER RED INK
description: For the first time in five years, income at the nation's resident nonprofit theaters rose faster than operating costs - despite continued overall deficits and a reduction in Federal support to a majority of the theaters, according to a survey conducted by the Theater Communications Group.

Emergency Rescue Teams for Freighters

title: MAYOR'S RESPONSE TO REPORT ON HISPANIC CONCERNS CRITICIZED
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that in most cases his administration had fully adopted the recommendations made last December by his Commission on Hispanic Concerns. But commission members differed sharply with that assessment yesterday.

title: ARKANSAS SETS PRIMARY ON '88 SUPER TUESDAY
description: Gov. Bill Clinton signed legislation today to hold the 1988 Arkansas primaries on the same day as the primaries of 14 other states.

title: BROADWAY SONG TROVE TOPS ORIGINAL HOPES
description: Hundreds of unpublished songs, some previously unknown, by George Gershwin, Jerome Kern, Victor Herbert, Richard Rodgers and other composers have been identified in a treasure-trove of musical manuscripts stored in a Warner Brothers warehouse in Manhattan.

title: DISNEY TO ACQUIRE LOS ANGELES STATION
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire KHJ-TV, the independent television station in Los Angeles owned by RKO General Inc., a subsidiary of Gencorp Inc.

title: Sri Lankan Offensive
description: Eight rebels were killed in an offensive in the Tamil stronghold of Jaffna today, the Government said. A Government statement said security forces cleared the area around a military camp so that helicopters could land without coming under fire from the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the dominant guerrilla group fighting for an independent Tamil homeland in the north and east.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The First Woman President
description: To whom do the following labels apply: ''Presidentress,'' ''first woman President'' and ''the most influential and powerful First Lady in American history''? Contrary to the impression conveyed in recent news, the references are not to Nancy Reagan but to Edith Bolling Galt Wilson, the second wife of America's 28th President.

title: EQUITABLE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOW THE PRESIDENT ADDRESSED PUBLIC IS AN ISSUE IN OHIO
description: David Bersnak, a 37-year-old unemployed rubber company worker, did not vote for Ronald Reagan in 1980 or 1984, but he said he had developed ''some respect for the man'' and thought the President was doing a ''fair job'' in managing the economy.

description: The Adsteam-Lidums International Tournament in Adelaide, Australia, was won by Gyula Sax. The 35-year-old Hungarian grandmaster scored 10-1 to capture the first prize of $5,000 Australian (about $3,333).

Commuter Plane Hits Jetliner
description: A twin-engine Comair commuter plane taxiing at Greater Cincinnati International Airport rammed a parked Delta airliner today, but no passengers were injured, officials said.

title: ORDER FOR VON BULOW BOOK DRAFT RAISES FIRST AMENDMENT ISSUE
description: The companion of Claus von Bulow, the Danish-born aristocrat who was acquitted two years ago of charges that he had tried to murder his wife to inherit her fortune, is embroiled in a legal battle over the manuscript of a book about the trial and her affair with Mr. von Bulow.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $1,756,000. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The results include 53 weeks for the latest year, compared with 52 weeks for 1985.

title: JUDGE REJECTS BID TO DISMISS PRESCHOOL MOLESTATION CASE
description: A state judge today refused to dismiss a case of molestation at a preschool facility, saying that while prosecutors had made mistakes, they had not intentionally concealed relevant evidence from the defense team.

title: CONTRAS RAID CIVILIAN TARGETS
description: When gunfire erupted Wednesday night around the Quisilala cattle cooperative, Dominga Solana, 26 years old and quick, dived for cover.

title: Professor Backed as Judge
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has recommended a Columbia law professor for appointment to Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York. The professor, Peter L. Strauss, the Betts Professor of Law at Columbia University, has served as general counsel to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and in the office of the Solicitor General of the Justice Department. There are currently 27 judgeships in the Southern District. Senatorial recommendations are submitted to the Justice Department for approval before being passed on to the President.

title: HIGH COURT BOLSTERS STATES' CONTROL OVER MINING
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5-to-4 today that states have broad authority to restrict underground mining to protect the land above the mines.

title: NORTH MENTIONED AT BAIL HEARING
description: A New York arms dealer told Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, through an intermediary, of his plan to sell airplane parts to Iran last summer, his lawyer told a Federal judge yesterday.

description: b-Includes extraordinary tax benefits of $309,000 and $458,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and includes net from discontinued operations of $76,000 and $378,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and includes an extraordinary charge of $72,000 for the quarter, and an extraordinary credit of $23,000 for the year.

title: CATHOLIC BROTHER HELD IN VEHICULAR HOMICIDE
description: A Roman Catholic brother has been arrested and charged with vehicular homicide after the car he was driving struck and killed a tow-truck operator about to remove a disabled car on the Queensboro Bridge, the police said yesterday.

title: Ball-Park Study Finds No Big Hit
description: It won't likely stop the clamor for the construction of municipally financed stadiums, or halt the competition among localities to attract pro teams. But a study undertaken by Robert Baade, a professor of economics at Lake Forest (Ill.) College, suggests that the economic benefits that a city is widely assumed to gain from new teams and new arenas can be largely a chimera.

title: DRINKING AGE IS FIERY ISSUE IN WEST
description: Like rebellious colonies, Western states are resisting Federal efforts to raise the minimum drinking age to 21, just as the region has resisted other Government initiatives like the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit and mandatory seat belts.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $586,826 for the latest quarter and $183,850 for the year-earlier period.

title: KEY RATES
Eban Plans Pollard Inquiry
description: Abba Eban, chairman of the Security and Foreign Affairs Committee in the Israeli Parliament, today promised an inquiry into the Jonathan Jay Pollard espionage case after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir refused to answer questions before the committee. Mr. Pollard, a 32-year-old American, was sentenced to life in prison last week in the United States for spying for Israel.

title: From Murrow To CBS Mediocrity?
description: LEAD: More than 200 CBS News people will not be coming to work this week. Or next week. Or whenever the grace period ends and the new lean, mean CBS News officially begins. Two hundred and fifteen people to be exact.

title: A.M.C.'S LONG, HARD STRUGGLE
description: ''Nobody calls us just American Motors,'' W. Paul Tippett, the former chairman of the American Motors Corporation, was reported to have said. ''It's 'Struggling American Motors,' 'Ailing American Motors' or 'Moribund American Motors.'''

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PITT-DES MOINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ENERGY PRICES DECLINE; PROFIT TAKING IS CITED
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products sagged a bit yesterday, after having climbed nearly $2 in a week. Oil analysts attributed the decline to profit taking and said the market might be running out of steam after its upward swing.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss is after a provision of $2,500,000 related to anticipated relocation costs in the consolidation of the Whitelock manufacturing subsidiary into the company's facility in Wood Dales, Ill.

title: CURRAN'S ACCENT POSITIVELY NEGATIVE
description: Their friends may have praised them, the news media had glorified them, but on Sunday morning the members of the Archbishop Molloy High School basketball team were having their deficiencies exposed in a Queens gym.

title: NORANDA IN SPINOFF OF FORESTRY UNIT
description: The Canadian resource conglomerate Noranda Inc. said it planned to spin off its profitable forest products unit into a separate publicly owned company within three months. A Noranda spokesman said that the company had not yet determined the size of the offering but that it planned to retain a majority interest.

title: BIRD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $580,000 from reduction in utilization of tax loss carryforwards. c-Includes an extraordinary charge of $417,000 from reduction in utilization of tax loss carryforwards for the quarter; and the year includes a tax credit of $287,000 and a gain of $4.3 million from real estate sales. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income for both periods.

title: PACER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Robinson Top Choice
description: David Robinson, the 7-foot-1-inch center who has been responsible for Navy's sudden success over the last three seasons, was selected unanimously to the Associated Press college all-America basketball team. Also picked for the first team were Steve Alford of Indiana, the only repeater; Kenny Smith of North Carolina, Reggie Williams of Georgetown and Danny Manning of Kansas, a junior and the only underclassman. Robinson averaged 27.5 points and 11.8 rebounds and blocked 142 shots - best in the nation - this season. Mark Jackson, the St. John's guard, was named to the second team.

title: SL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $145,000. Share earnings reflect a 6 percent stock dividend paid in November.

title: TELEVISION PACTS: NO RERUN FOR N.F.L.
description: Contract negotiations between the National Football League and television networks interested in broadcasting its games will probably generate less money for the league this year than the league received in 1986, according to two television sports executives.

title: DONALD J. GROUT
description: Donald J. Grout, professor emeritus of musicology at Cornell University, died yesterday at his home in Skaneateles, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: The U.N. Today: March 10, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Non-Use of Force -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NEW HEADQUARTERS FOR BEAR STEARNS
description: The Bear Stearns Companies has leased more than 500,000 square feet in a 20-year-old tower on Park Avenue at 46th Street and will move its headquarters there from the financial district later this year. The move involves nearly 3,000 employees, half of the company's work force, Bear Stearns said.

title: MUSIC: BRITAIN'S HALLE ORCHESTRA AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: THE Halle Orchestra and spring made their New York debuts on Sunday. The latter might have been a little premature; but as Britain's oldest professional orchestra (founded in 1858), the first seemed overdue.

title: Coach's Son Dies
description: Daniel Paul Pitino, the 6-month-old son of Rick Pitino, the Providence College basketball coach, died Sunday at Kent County Hospital in Warwick, R.I. The child had suffered from a congenital ailment. Providence school officials said Pitino planned to coach in the N.C.A.A. first-round game Thursday against Alabama-Birmingham in Birmingham.

title: EAGLE TELEPHONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinay tax credit of $678,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: 'BLITHE SPIRIT' OPENING IS POSTPONED
description: A revival of Noel Coward's ''Blithe Spirit,' which begins preview performances tonight at the Neil Simon Theater, has postponed its official opening night, previously scheduled for March 19, in order to allow a new director more time to work with the company.

title: IRAN ARMS TALE TAKES A NEW TWIST
description: A man who says he is the son of the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament said yesterday that he planned to give the American Government $6 million, which he said he earned as an intermediary in the Iran arms sales.

title: RICHARD KNEIP
description: Richard Kneip, who was South Dakota's Governor for most of the 1970's, died today at McKennan Hospital of stomach cancer. He was 54 years old.

title: SCAR TISSUE REMOVED
description: Frank Sinatra was hospitalized for a routine checkup, and scar tissue from previous intestinal surgery was removed, the entertainer's spokesman said today.

title: Louisville Spurns N.I.T.
description: The University of Louisville, denied a chance to defend its title in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, today rejected a National Invitation Tournament bid.

title: BAKER ENDEAVORS TO TIGHTEN REINS
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., President Reagan's new chief of staff, moved on two fronts today to reverse the policies of his predecessor, Donald T. Regan, and tighten his control over the White House machinery.

title: FERNANDEZ TRIES GOODEN'S STYLE
description: They weren't running for the hills yet in the Mets' training camp. But, one day after Dwight Gooden made his 1987 debut and was ripped for nine runs in the first inning, Sid Fernandez made his debut today and was ripped for five home runs in three innings.

title: PROSPECT GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $857,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes a tax credit of $378,000. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,123,000 and $1,076,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net loss

title: RICHARD KAWAKAMI
description: Richard Kawakami, the Speaker of the state's House of Representatives, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: Laos Blast Is Reported On Shevardnadze Trip
description: A bomb killed one person and seriously wounded another outside the Soviet information center in Vientiane, Laos, on Monday during Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's visit, diplomatic sources said here today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MEMOIRS OF A FORTUNATE JEW. An Italian Story. By Dan Vittorio Segre.

title: CSS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $806,000 for the quarter and $2,763,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $264,000 and $4,158,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Prior year-ago quarter and year consist of 2 months and 11 months, respectively; the company changed its fiscal year from Nov. 30 to Dec. 31.

title: Not Good, But Good Enough
description: Penn, Fairfield and Idaho State are each headed to the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament after a .500 season. In the tourney's 48-year history, these 12 other squads have gained entrance despite their failure to post a winning record.

title: ELECTRICITY RUSHES INTO A NEW ERA OF DISCOVERY
description: PLUNGING toward the impossible, scientists on three continents are racing to achieve one of the great dreams of science - an everyday material that carries electricity without the slightest loss of energy.

title: DANCE: DANIEL MCCUSKER AND MAINE TROUPE
description: IN 1985, Daniel McCusker, a promising young New York dancer and choreographer, went to Maine to direct the Ram Island Dance Company of Portland. On Saturday night, the company came to St. Mark's Church in two works by Mr. McCusker that were notable for their graciousness and courtesy.

title: REPORT FINDS BMT BRIDGES ARE DETERIORATED
description: Many of the bridges that carry the Brighton BMT line through Brooklyn are in poor condition and getting worse, in part because of track repairs by the Transit Authority, according to a draft of a report to the agency made public yesterday.

title: CABOT ADVERTISING WINS HEALTH PLAN ACCOUNT
description: The Harvard Community Health Plan of Brookline, Mass., had Rizzo, Simons, Cohn of Boston as its ad agency. Then it merged with the Multi Group Health Plan, which also had an agency, Mintz & Hoke of Avon, Conn.

title: OPEC PANEL SESSION IS OFF
description: OPEC has postponed a meeting of one of its committees because some oil ministers feared that colleagues not on the panel might attend anyway and effectively make it a full session of the organization, OPEC sources said today. A full meeting now could unsettle the jittery oil market.

title: Miller-Gonzalez Letters
description: The appointment of former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. as President Reagan's chief of staff may improve relations between the White House and Congress, as advertised. But it is clear that in some sectors Mr. Baker will have a long way to go.

title: EX-DEFENSE SECRETARIES BACK STRICT VIEW OF '72 ABM PACT
description: Six former Defense Secretaries have written a statement urging the Reagan Administration to continue observing the traditional, restrictive interpretation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972.

title: DR. PAUL MORTON
description: Dr. Paul Colhoun Morton, former co-chief of surgery at St. Luke's Hospital-Roosevelt Medical Center, died yesterday at Sharon Hospital in Connecticut. He was 89 years old and lived in Washington, Conn.

title: ACTMEDIA CAMPAIGN BY LOIS PITTS GERSHON
description: Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK, the first agency for Actmedia, which rents 647,000 advertising display units in 13,000 supermarkets, has come up with a new campaign and a new theme line: ''The War Is In The Store.''

title: WEBB, DEL E INVESTMENT PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that results of operations in 1985 and 1986 are not comparable; that the company began operations Aug. 1, 1985; that nearly half of its 1985 revenues were derived from interest on temporary investments; that in 1986, revenue was primarily from rents from its real estate properties; and that the company is a closed-end, finite-life equity REIT.

title: ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $13,705,000 and an extraordinary charge of $1,112,000 from reversal of a tax loss carryforward for the quarter; and the year includes earnings from discontinued operations of $34,144,000. c-Includes loss from discontinued operations of $14,985,000 and $26,907,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company also said accounting rules require that it recognize a 1986 loss on these anticipated transactions amounting to $80 million, due primarily to the writeoff of associated foreign currency translation adjustments and good will. All 1985 results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Immigration Service Plays Thought-Police Role
description: To the Editor:

title: DAXOR CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes unrealized capital gains of $563,739.

title: PRICE STABILITY IS ANTICIPATED
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's third-largest steelmaker, recently reported fourth-quarter profits of $34.2 million. Despite its third profitable quarter in the last five years, Bethlehem remains a deeply troubled company that faces the continued pressure of worldwide steel overcapacity, price weakness and intense foreign competition. Analysts have questioned whether the company will survive beyond the next few years.

title: INSIDE
description: Contacts With North Korea American diplomats have been authorized to conduct substantive conversations with North Korean officials at social gatherings. Page A3.

title: AMERICAN LAND CRUISERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VATICAN PANEL PRESSES SEATTLE INQUIRY
description: A special commission appointed by the Vatican to assess criticism of the Archbishop of Seattle interviewed 8 bishops, 10 priests and 2 archdiocesan lay officials Friday and Saturday in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Co., a subsidiary of the Boston Company, named Timothy L. Vaill president.

title: RECHARGING EX-YANK BATTERY
description: Over the weekend, Butch Wynegar and Ed Whitson drifted together again when the California Angels played the San Diego Padres, a battery hoping to be recharged by the ''fun'' of playing major-league baseball elsewhere, the fun they didn't have while wearing Yankee pinstripes.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: The Boston Red Sox have threatened to fine Roger Clemens $1,000 a day unless he returns to training camp by tomorrow. Clemens, who had a 24-4 won-lost record last year and was the American League's Cy Young Award winner and Most Valuable Player, walked out of the Winter Haven, Fla., camp last Friday when the Red Sox rejected his demand for a $2.4 million, two-year contract. He turned down the club's proposal of $500,000 plus $350,000 in incentive bonus money for the 1987 season. The Red Sox then exercised their right to renew Clemens's contract, setting a salary of $400,000 while hoping to resume negotiations for an agreement. Clemens is not yet eligible for arbitration. Lou Gorman, general manager of the Red Sox, said he had not had any contact with Clemens or his agents, Alan and Randy Hendricks, since the walkout. Clemens's whereabouts were unknown yesterday. Gorman said that the Red Sox are now permitted to fine Clemens ''any amount we want.'' One day's salary - based on the new contract now in effect - would be about $2,200 under a player's 182-day work year. Don Baylor, the Red Sox player representive, said, ''It's Roger's contract and he feels he has to do what's good for Roger. But if he stays away 10 days to two weeks, it could be disruptive to the team.''

title: Maternal Instincts
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are those who ask us as members of the Catholic church what right we have to address the forum of public policy. I ask, 'What right do we not have to address it?' We cannot afford the luxury of silence.'' - John Cardinal O'Connor, speaking in Albany. [ A1:2. ]

title: IVERSON TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid Feb. 27.

title: IGOR KROPOTKIN, FORMER HEAD OF THE SCRIBNERS BOOKSTORES
description: Igor Kropotkin, the longtime head of Scribners Bookstores and a former president of the American Booksellers Association, died last Wednesday at New York University Hospital, following complications from a stroke. He was 68 years old and lived in Fair Lawn, N.J.

title: CHANNEL 13 REVERTS TO PLEDGE WEEK
description: Just when you thought it was safe to tune in again to Channel 13, PBS pledge week is back.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Louis A. Severine, director of sales for the ABC Radio Network, has been promoted to senior vice president.

title: PARK-OHIO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes non-recurring charges of about $5,506,000. c-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $4,974,000.

title: REFUND POLICY ON G.E. GOODS
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it would offer an unconditional return or refund for any major G.E. appliance the customer wishes to return within 90 days after purchase, becoming the first appliance producer to make such an offer.

title: Atkins to Be Questioned
description: Investigators are hoping to talk with Jeff Atkins, a former Southern Methodist University running back, concerning the shooting death of a man who was driving a car registered to Atkins. The dead man, 31-year-old David Simpson, was shot Friday night when a gunman opened fire on him as he was driving Atkins's auto into the parking lot of a Dallas apartment complex, according to the police. They said Atkins had ''made arrangements'' through a third party to talk to them. Simpson lived at the complex where the shooting occurred, worked there as a maintenance man and security guard, and also had two of his own cars parked there, according to the police. A bystander was wounded in the leg. Atkins recently revealed that he had undergone treatment after becoming addicted to cocaine last fall during his final season at S.M.U. He is No. 9 among career rushing leaders in the Southwest Conference.

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said first quarter share earnings will be adjusted to 30 cents a share versus 16 cents a share, as a result of the 3-for-2 stock split which becomes effective March 12.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK AND TRUST reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been retroactivley adjusted for the 10 percent stock dividend paid May 5, 1986. The company attributed the earnings decline principally to the $12.7 million provision for the loan losses during 1986, compared to $2.4 million in 1985.

title: PIEDMONT ACCEPTS USAIR BID
description: The USAir Group announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Piedmont Aviation Inc. for $1.59 billion, ending a three-week-old contest for control of one of the fastest-growing and most profitable carriers in the deregulated airline industry.

title: IFEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOUGHT SEGREGATED SCHOOL SYSTEMS
description: Paul B. Zuber, a lawyer who was a leading figure in court battles to desegregate several school systems in Northern cities in the early 1960's, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Troy, N.Y. He was 60 years old.

title: RATES STABLE IN QUIET TRADING
description: The credit markets remain unconvinced by forecasts calling for higher or lower interest rates, resulting in an atmosphere of ennui that yesterday left interest rates little changed in short- and long-term maturities.

title: INFOTRON SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes charges of $1,219,000 for writeoffs and equity losses in connection with investments in related technology companies; a $558,000 writeoff for a discontinued product line that had been purchased for resale; and a $935,000 provision for the implementation of a cost reduction program, including severance costs associated with the termination of about 100 employees, for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $294,000. The company said the recent period includes an after-tax gain of $2,519,000 from the sale of Sea-Land Corp. securities.

title: 'ENTERTAINMENT' ON THIN ICE
description: At Madison Square Garden Sunday night there had just been a fight on the ice between the Flames' Tim Hunter and the Rangers' Jay Caufield. The fans were on their feet, cheering, some in the crowd chanting, as the skaters headed to the penalty box, tugging at the sleeves of their jerseys, readjusting their equipment, both of them still panting.

title: Violent and Murderous
description: To the Editor:

title: Gipper, Come On Down!
description: Television news is being wiped out by game shows. It doesn't mean We the Audience of the United States are getting dumber. It just means we don't look to TV for the serious stuff anymore, just for light entertainment.

title: Yevtushenko and Army
description: The Pentagon has ordered the United States Military Academy to withdraw a speaking invitation to Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Soviet poet, according to John Macrae, editor in chief of Henry Holt & Company, which is about to publish Mr. Yevtushenko's latest book in this country. Mr. Yevtushenko had been asked to come to West Point on April 2 to read his poems and talk with the cadets, and the appearance had been cleared by the Army, Mr. Macrae said. But he said the decision was reversed by higher authority in the Department of Defense, although, he said, he had been unable to discover which official had rescinded the invitation or the rationale of the move.

title: 8 IN SEDITION CASE OBJECT TO COURT NAMING COUNSEL
description: Eight people charged with trying to overthrow the United States Government through a series of bombings and bank robberies raised repeated objections today to a judge's refusal to let them pick their own attorneys.

title: TAKEOVER ISSUES SOAR
description: After being dormant for the first two months of 1987, takeover stocks soared in wild trading yesterday, helping to offset somewhat a broad decline in the overall stock market.

title: DYNASCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SNYDER OIL PARTNERS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Shares outstanding are in units.

title: FRANCE WARY ON JAPAN
description: France's Foreign Minister, Jean-Bernard Raimond, expressed concern today that Japan and the United States were bypassing the European Community by reaching trade and currency agreements. His remarks came at a news conference ending a three-day visit to Japan.

title: REAGAN TO REVOKE FINDING ON SALE OF ARMS TO IRAN
description: President Reagan is preparing to revoke the intelligence finding that authorizes the arms sales to Iran amid a White House review of all findings authorizing covert actions, officials said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: GALOOB, LEWIS TOYS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MOODY'S STUDY OF FORD RATING
description: The rating of nearly $23 billion of outstanding long-term debt issued by the Ford Motor Company and the Ford Motor Credit Company is under review for possible upgrading, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: PHILHARMONIC SETS ITS 1987-88 SEASON
description: The English conductor Colin Davis will make his first New York Philharmonic appearance since the 1968-69 season when he leads the orchestra in its gala opening program of the 1987-88 season on Sept. 15 in Avery Fisher Hall, with the pianist Murray Perahia as soloist.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mark Pavelich, the former Ranger, signed a contract with the Minnesota North Stars for the remainder of the season. . . . Aurelio Lopez, the Houston Astros' reliever, was charged with driving while intoxicated. He was involved in a minor traffic accident in Kissimmee, Fla., the police said.

title: STAGE: 'WHORES OF HEAVEN'
description: MICHAEL WRIGHT'S chaotic musical farce ''Whores of Heaven'' is an extreme example of the Off Off Broadway musical as a frantic, eclectic junk heap of styles thrown together under the scattershot philosophy that if the last joke didn't knock 'em dead, the next one will.

title: Foreman, 39, Wins at 267
description: After a decade out of boxing, a portly George Foreman, the former heavyweight champion, stopped Steve Zouski at 2:47 of the fourth round of a scheduled 10-round bout at the Arco Arena tonight. Foreman, who last fought in

title: OFFSHORE PROJECT FOR PETRO-CANADA
description: Canada's state-owned oil company, Petro-Canada, has announced plans for a major development of the Terra Nova oilfield off the coast of Newfoundland. The project is expected to cost $1 billion (Canadian), or about $750 million (United States).

title: Citizen Karolyi
description: His credentials certainly make him worthy of being the 1988 women's Olympic gymnastics coach: Bela Karolyi guided both Nadia Comaneci (1976) and Mary Lou Retton (1984) to Olympic gold, and these days he runs a Houston training center where he oversees the development of Kristie Phillips and Phoebe Mills, now America's top female gymnasts.

title: PRESSER LAWYER CALLING FOR DATA
description: The lawyer representing Jackie Presser, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, argued in court today that the Justice Department had denied access to documents confirming that Mr. Presser was authorized to create a payroll scheme involving ''ghost'' employees at teamsters Local 507.

title: Smokers in Cambridge Can Light Up No More
description: As the no-smoking signs went up all over town today, a grudging acceptance seemed to have taken hold among nicotine addicts here.

title: TRUMP BUYS 73% STAKE IN RESORTS FOR $79 MILLION
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, has agreed to acquire a 73 percent voting stake in Resorts International Inc. for $79 million, the casino and real estate company announced yesterday.

title: AT 15, RUSSIAN YOUTH BEGINS A NEW LIFE ALONE IN U.S.
description: Fifteen-year-old Alexander Altman watched his grandparents leave Brooklyn in December and move back to the Soviet Union. Two weeks ago his parents and 4-year-old brother followed. Alexander chose to stay.

title: ANDREOTTI TO TRY TO FORM CABINET
description: President Francesco Cossiga asked Giulio Andreotti, the veteran Christian Democrat, today to try to form a new Government.

title: CHLORINE LEVELS REPORTED HIGH OVER ANTARCTICA
description: A scientist who recently returned from studying the mysterious ''hole'' in the ozone layer over Antarctica reported today that strikingly high levels of chlorine, almost certainly from industrial chemicals, were found in the polar atmosphere.

title: PENALTIES ON S.M.U. MAY BE CHALLENGED
description: Lawyers hired by more than 30 Southern Methodist University employees, alumni and other supporters are scheduled to meet with members of the football team Wednesday to tell the players of a lawsuit that may be filed challenging the recent penalties imposed on the school by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: SPIELVOGEL ADVERTISING PRAISE FROM HYUNDAI
description: Carl Spielvogel, whose agency, Backer & Spielvogel, serves the record-breaking Korean-made Hyundai Excel automobile, got an extremely complimentary letter from Hyundai that he is going to share with the world.

title: COLONEL NORTH DRAWS A CROWD AT HEARING OVER HIS LAWSUIT
description: Wearing his dark green marine uniform with a chestful of decorations, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North made a courtroom appearance today, causing a commotion that even judges and prosecutors could not ignore.

title: CONSUMER BORROWING UP SLIGHTLY
description: Americans took out $536 million more in consumer debt than they paid off in January, up only slightly from an extremely small December increase, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: I.R.A.'s LEAN TOWARD STOCKS
description: ''THE I.R.A. money is rolling in,'' said Don Underwood, manager of Merrill Lynch's retirement plans department. ''The volume of I.R.A. business is building up,'' Mitchell Glazier, marketing manager for retirement products at Fidelity Investments, added.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 10, 1987 Companies

title: BMC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $5 million from discontinued operations for both the quarter and year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $13,939,000 and $72,169,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and an extraordinary gain of $2,620,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Israelis Who Met With P.L.O. Deny Aid-to-Terrorists Charge
description: Four Israeli leftists who met with members of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Rumania in November pleaded not guilty today to breaking a law banning unauthorized contacts with ''terrorist organizations.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MARCH 10, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12, A16-17 Ecuador will suspend oil exports indefinitely, the authorities said, because of a series of earthquakes in the remote eastern jungles that, by some reports, has killed more than 300 people. Page A1 A Nicaraguan rebel leader resigned after months of bitter infighting that has fractured the American-backed movement. ''I have given all that I have to give,'' Arturo Cruz said in his letter of resignation. A1

title: A NEW SWEETENER
description: Researchers at The Hebrew University in Jerusalem have identified a natural sweetener that actually deters dental cavities from forming. The substance is glycyrrhizin, a natural sweetener 50 times sweeter than sucrose. Although it is derived from the licorice plant, it does not have the taste of licorice. The researchers say it could lead to more effective toothpaste and to a new sugar substitute.

title: APPLIED DATA COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $670,000 writeoff for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: A.T.&T. BONUSES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which is offering bonuses to managers at its debt-ridden Information Systems division, has revised the scope of the bonuses. It said that 32,000 managers would receive bonuses totaling at least $16 million. The company had said last week that 24,000 managers would get bonuses totaling more than $12 million. Analysts have estimated that Information Systems, which markets computer and telephone equipment, lost at least $800 million last year.

title: ITT BUSINESS GOES TO W.R.G.
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it was switching its corporate advertising account to Wells, Rich, Greene. The billings, according to J. Paul Jannuzzo, director of advertising and sales promotion, should be $9 million to $11 million.

title: HARVARD VS. R.P.I. TOP SEMIFINAL TEST
description: Harvard, Rensselaer, St. Lawrence and Yale won quarterfinal series in the Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey tournament and will make up the field for the league's semifinals in Boston on Friday and Saturday.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $5,736,000 from the secondary public offering of Sizzler Restaurants International common stock.

title: NICARAGUA ARRESTS 10 AT RALLY
description: Ten people, including two prominent opposition leaders, were arrested when they tried to hold a rally Sunday, but were released today.

title: WHY EXPERTS DIFFER IN CUSTODY CASES
description: The now-concluded testimony by expert witnesses in the Baby M trial points to the difficulty of predicting which of two parents would be the better guardian for a child when neither is clearly unfit.

title: New York's Housing Division: Lost
description: Sixty years ago, Gov. Al Smith of New York set up an agency that would come to be known as the Division of Housing and Community Renewal. Its purpose was to assist private efforts to build homes for low-income families.

title: 14 YOUTHS ARRESTED IN REGION FOR THROWING DEBRIS AT VEHICLES
description: At least 14 youths were arrested in the New York region over the weekend for throwing rocks and other debris at cars.

title: VETERINARY FIELD SEEN EXPANDING
description: ''DO you realize that the number of cats and dogs in this country is larger than the population of any Western European nation?'' asked Dr. Franklin M. Loew, dean of the School of Veterinary Medicine at Tufts University, near Boston.

title: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $1,000,000. c-Includes tax benefits of $693,000 and $3,400,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the latest quarter reflects the February 1986 acquisition of Vis Kase Corp., the film packaging division of Union Carbide Corp.

title: RESULTS
description: Figure Skating Fadeev Leads in Compulsory Figures: Brian Boitano of Sunnyvale, Calif., the defending champion, placed second to Aleksandr Fadeev of the Soviet Union yesterday as the favorites performed well in the compulsory figures at the world championships in Cincinnati. The surprise of the first day of skating came at night, when the United States pairs champions, Jill Watson and Peter Oppegard, placed third in the short program. Watson, of Bloomington, Ind., and Oppegard, from Knoxville, Tenn., were rated only sixth in the world. (AP) N.B.A. Hawks 108, Bulls 103: Kevin Willis scored 30 points and Dominique Wilkins 27, and they combined with Glenn Rivers for all of Atlanta's points in a 10-2 streak that lifted the Hawks to their seventh straight victory. Michael Jordan, who had 31 points, gave the Bulls a 94-91 lead on a 3-point play with 4:20 left, but a 3-point play by Rivers tied the score for the 18th time in the game.(AP) Horse Racing Majestic Empire Wins: Majestic Empire went into the air at the start and broke last in the field of eight, then rallied strongly under Nick Santagata to score a 1 1/4-length victory in the $40,000 J. O. Tobin Handicap for 4-year-olds and upward at Aqueduct. Basket Weave, who raced on or near the lead throughout in a stong effort, was the runner-up. Majestic Empire paid $9.80 for $2 to win. Dog Sledding Alaskans Jostle for Lead: Two Alaskans, Duane Halverson of Ambler and Joe Garnie of Teller, were jostling for the lead in the Iditarod Trail sled dog race from Anchorage to Nome. The two, with Halverson leading, were making their way toward the checkpoint at Finger Lake on Sunday. Garnie was first to reach the Skwentna checkpoint, 148 miles from the race's start in Anchorage, with Susan Butcher, the 1986 champion, in second place and Halverson third. Halverson left first for Finger Lake, 45 miles farther up the trail toward the Alaska Range, with Garnie following three hours later as Butcher remained behind. Squash Racquets Edwards and Nimick Advance: Top-seeded Ned Edwards of New York defeated Eric Christianson, a qualifier, also of New York, 18-15, 15-7, 15-9, yesterday in first-round play in the $13,500 Mutual Benefit United States pro squash racquets championship here. John Nimick of Philadelphia, seeded second, beat Neil Vohr of New York, 15-11, 15-11, 15-11.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE notion that various foods and nutrients can boost resistance to disease is one of the main tenets of popular but pseudoscientific nutritional theories. It is hardly surprising that desperate people are drawn to dietary advice purporting to cure such stubborn disorders as yeast infections or obesity or such devastating illnesses as cancer and AIDS.

description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2.5 million. The company commenced operation July 13, 1985.

title: South Korea Backs U.S. Talks With Envoys of North Korea
description: President Chun Doo Hwan chief's spokesman today welcomed a State Department decision to allow American diplomats to hold substantive talks with representatives of North Korea.

title: CHIEF WITNESS AGAINST TUROFF RECALLS CONVERSATION ON DEAL
description: The chief witness against Jay L. Turoff, the former head of the New York City agency that regulates taxis, said under cross-examination yesterday that Mr. Turoff did not directly ask him for a bribe but that a request for money was implied in a conversation they had.

title: McEnroe on Cup Team
description: Partly in appreciation for the sportsmanship and harmony he displayed in the event two years ago, John McEnroe was added yesterday to the United States team for the World Team Cup tournament in Duesseldorf, West Germany, which the United States has won three times since it started in 1978. The usually irascible McEnroe joins Jimmy Connors and Brad Gilbert in the competition scheduled for May 18-24. In 1985, the United States team consisting of Connors, McEnroe, Robert Seguso and Ken Flach, won in a dramatic final against Czechoslovakia. ''I think an essential factor for the team was the joint success of Connors and McEnroe,'' said the tournament director, Horst Klosterkemper. ''The cordiality they showed to each other after the two won in the final against Czechoslovakia was quite remarkable.''

title: BELDING HEMINWAY CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1986 earnings include net equity in earnings of real estate investments of $429,000, or 17 cents a share, and for 1985 a total of $1,031,000, or 37 cents a share. The latest periods also include a gain of $105,000, or 4 cents a share, on the sale of a portion of cellular telephone investments, compared with a similar gain of $775,000, or 28 cents a share, for the year-ago periods.

title: Orange Forecast Falls
description: The nation's orange harvest for the 1986-87 crop season is estimated at 190.9 million boxes, down 3 percent from the February forecast but still 8 percent more than last season, the Agriculture Department said. The Florida crop, based on March 1 indications, was estimated at 124 million boxes, down 4 percent from February but still 4 percent more than last season, the report said. California production was forecast at 63.5 million boxes, down 2 percent from the February forecast but 168 percent more than the 1985-86 crop.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IF I were to list my dozen or so favorite foods, I would include almost all of the ''variety meats'' - that is to say, the inner organs of calves and other animals. I dote on liver and kidneys and, perhaps best of all, sweetbreads, the tender thymus glands of calves, which most serious gastronomes and professional chefs consider suitable for the most stately banquets.

title: AUTOMOBILE TAX IS DROPPED FROM NEW M.T.A. PROPOSAL By ELIZABETH KOLBERT
description: Seeking to break a deadlock over mass transit aid, Assembly Democrats offered today a revised plan that dropped a proposed new tax on automobiles. The plan also offered some concessions to Senate Republicans, who have demanded a that a larger share of Federal transit aid go to commuter rail lines.

description: There are no comparable figures because the company went public in November 1986.

The latest year gains of $98.5 million are from the use of a portion of Inspiration's net operating loss carryforward, a gain from the sale of a mining royalty interest and credits resulting from the capitalization of previously expensed exploration costs. The prior year results include $160.5 million in restructuring charges.

description: From freshets to downpours, spring rains have soaked deep into the black soil around here, gradually washing away fears of a return of the drought and famine that ravaged Ethiopia from 1984 to 1986.

description: Prices of notes and bonds fell slightly yesterday as trading activity remained light.

title: MELVIN BOOZER
description: Melvin Boozer, who led groups seeking rights for homosexuals, died Friday at Washington Hospital Center. He was 41 years old.

description: The company said it elected to reinsure over $2 million dollars of annuity insurance, and this reinsurance transaction was primarily responsible for the 20 percent decline in fourth-quarter revenues.

title: Filipino Debt Talks Continue
description: Bankers plan to meet again today in New York with a delegation from the Philippines in an atmosphere described as hopeful. On Monday the bankers rejected Finance Minister Jaime V. Ongpin's initial proposal for rescheduling payments of the Phillipines' foreign debt.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BAKER AIDES PLAN SHIFT IN WHITE HOUSE SETUP
description: Members of the transition team assembled by Howard H. Baker Jr., surprised by what they see as weaknesses in the White House operational structure, have drafted a detailed plan to correct deficiencies, a senior White House official said today.

title: Lawrence Skrobacs, Pianist; Accompanied Major Singers
description: Lawrence Skrobacs, an accompanist and repertory coach who worked with many leading artists, including Kathleen Battle, Montserrat Caballe, James McCracken and Samuel Ramey, died yesterday morning. He was 38 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 'Lethal Weapon' Is No. 1 At Box Office for Week
description: ''Lethal Weapon,'' starring Mel Gibson and Danny Glover, was the No. 1 box-office attraction last week, earning $6.8 million in its debut week.

title: PANEL SAYS NEW AIDS DRUG MAY COST TOO MUCH
description: Members of Congress were told today that by the end of the year numerous AIDS patients would be eligible to receive a new drug that could extend their lives but that a substantial number might not be able to afford it.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SOUTH AFRICAN DISPATCHES: Letters to My Countrymen. By Donald Woods. Foreword by Alan Paton. 190 pages. Henry Holt. $16.95.

title: ALLAN JAFFE, NEW ORLEANS JAZZ REVIVALIST, DIES By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS
description: Allan Jaffe, the owner and manager of the New Orleans jazz mecca Preservation Hall, died of cancer Monday at East Jefferson General Hospital in New Orleans. He was 51 years old. Mr. Jaffe's name had become synonymous with traditional New Orleans music, and he was widely credited with a revival of the music at a time when the old musicians were out of work and out of favor.

title: SOCIAL SHORTFALLS: TO BE UNTITLED OR (GASP) UNTAN
description: ''Where are the princesses?'' yelled a frantic Bruce Lynn, a publicity man who had maintained his cool all evening but was suddenly seized by the awful fear that there could be a serious titled-nobility shortfall at this gala 10th anniversary celebration of a tanning salon.

title: BRADLEY OFFERS BILL TO RETURN LAND TO SIOUX
description: In the mid-70's, when Bill Bradley was a star forward for the New York Knicks, he went with his teammates Phil Jackson and Willis Reed to run a basketball clinic at the Oglala Sioux Indian reservation at Pine Ridge, S. D. There he learned the bitter history of the millions of acres of Sioux lands in South Dakota, stolen a century earlier, where now the faces of Presidents are carved into the granite of Mount Rushmore. He said then that if he was ever in a position to do it, he would get the land back for them.

title: Mudslides Kill 12 in Peru
description: At least 12 people were killed by mudslides on the outskirts of Lima that burst the banks of the River Rimac and flooded shantytowns close to the city center Monday night, fire officials said today. They said the worst damage was in Chosica, 20 miles from central Lima, where two mudslides crashed through straw and adobe houses and cut off the main central highway to the interior.

title: DOW REBOUNDS BY 19.97, TO 2,280.09
description: The stock market recovered yesterday what it gave away on Monday, as I.B.M. and a handful of other blue-chip issues set the pace in a more subdued session.

title: DIM OUTLOOK SEEN FOR U.S.-IRAN TIES
description: As details of the secret American arms-for-hostages initiative continue to become known, the positions of both the United States and Iran have hardened, and there is little likelihood of substantial improvement soon in relations between the two countries, according to American officials and experts on Iran.

description: Delays at the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear project, near Oswego, N.Y., have prompted the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Duff & Phelps, a Chicago rating firm, to lower debt ratings of several New York-based utilities involved in the project.

title: GAINS SEEN ON SALVADOR RIGHTS
description: Abuses by El Salvador's security forces have decreased, but torturers remain unpunished and the torment of detainees continues, an American human-rights group said in a report issued here today.

title: Caesars World Bidder Is Investor and Author
description: When Martin T. Sosnoff and his family went skiing at Lake Tahoe over the Washington's Birthday holiday, they stayed at Harrah's rather than Caesars, although he holds a 13.6 percent stake in its owner, Caesars World Inc.

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS DRUG TESTS FOR TRANSPORTATION WORKERS
description: A bill requiring random drug tests for thousands of airline and railroad workers and several million truck and bus drivers was approved by a Senate committee today despite concern about its constitutionality and potential for abuse.

title: Higgins Off the Hook
description: Sean Higgins, the basketball star from Fairfax High School in Los Angeles who claimed he signed a letter of intent to attend U.C.L.A. under duress, has been allowed to back out of the commitment after a ruling by the Collegiate Commissioners Association. In a Sports Illustrated article, Higgins had claimed his stepfather threatened him with a baseball bat and slapped him when Higgins said he wanted to go to Michigan to be near his natural father. Now he plans to commit himself to Michigan next month. ''Michigan was always my first choice,'' he said. ''U.C.L.A. was never my decision. I hope there aren't any hard feelings there because I had to do this for me.''

VW FRAUD MAY TOTAL $259 MILLION
description: Volkswagen A.G. said today that it had uncovered a case of foreign-exchange fraud that had forced it to provide for potential losses of $259 million.

title: WINE TALK
description: SUDDENLY, kosher wines have become chic. Now that sweet is out, they are not for Jews alone. The wines are so dernier cri that one store on Manhattan's East Side will offer futures in a Rothschild kosher Bordeaux. Even Carmel, that goliath of an Israeli winery, has awakened from its torpor.

title: John Van Ryzin, Chairman Of Columbia Statistics Dept.
description: John Van Ryzin, chairman of the department of statistics at Columbia University and a senior mathematician at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, L.I., died Friday of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, at the Presbyterian Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Gencorp to Sell RKO Pictures
description: Gencorp Inc., the tire and aerospace company based in Akron, Ohio, has agreed to sell what is left of RKO Pictures, a company once owned by Howard Hughes, to a group of RKO executives and investors. The RKO Pictures Holding Company is lead by former Hollywood studio chief Alan Hirschfield. Terms of the sale, expected to be completed in May, were not disclosed. Discussions began last year, when Mark E. Seiler, RKO's president and one of the executives involved in the buyout, approached Gencorp.

title: Ford to Close Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said it will close the coke ovens at its Rouge Steel subsidiary here next month after 68 years of operations, forcing 390 employees out of work. The company said the aged plant cost too much to run.

title: FOREIGNERS WILL BE ABLE TO OWN FRENCH BROKERS
description: Foreign banks and brokerages will be allowed to buy equity in French stockbrokers for the first time next year, Finance Minister Edouard Balladur said today.

title: RIGS WEIGH ANCHOR
description: OFFSHORE drillers are planning to go deeper than they have ever gone before in pursuit of untapped oil and gas reserves, using an ambitious new technology to float a 12,000-ton steel production platform a third of a mile over the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico.

title: OFFICER ADMITS GUILT IN SALE OF COCAINE
description: The New York City police officer who faced the most serious charges in the 77th Precinct corruption case pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of selling cocaine and agreed to testify against other officers who have been indicted in the case.

title: FANCY BARRETTES AND TEAPOTS
description: 1.Beautiful Bows The hair bow is making fashion news again. This delicate white lace bow is attached to a sturdy barrette. It costs $10 and is part of a flattering new collection by Honey in accessories on the main floor at Bloomingdale's. Also available at branch stores. 2.An Elegant Teapot Afternoon tea will be an elegant interlude with this decorative teapot from London. Glazed with pears and wild strawberries against a background of the palest pinks, lavenders and greens, the ironstone pot is $50 at Crabtree & Evelyn, 2768 Broadway, between 106th and 107th Streets. 3.Crate in Miniature A novel addition to a shelf or desk, this ceramic container is a copy of a packing crate, complete with staples and tape. The crate comes in three sizes, for $22.50, $29.50 and $125, at Jenny B. Goode, 1194 Lexington Avenue, between 81st and 82d Streets, and 11 East 10th Street. 4.Storing in Style Here is a solution for your storage problems - a box beautifully covered with fine French cotton. The fabric is printed with cherries on an off-white background. Three sizes are available. This one, for sweaters, costs $38. There are also boxes for shirts and shoes. At La Boutique de Marie Claire, 831 Madison Avenue, near 69th Street.

description: St. John's and Wichita State have never met in a basketball game, but when they meet on Friday in the first round of the Midwest Regionals, it will be a homecoming of a sort. How friendly a homecoming is something else.

description: Share earnings and shares outstanding for the 1986 periods are adjusted to reflect the 4-for-3 stock split effective on Dec. 8, 1986.

title: ISLANDERS RECOVER FROM A SLOW START By ROBIN FINN
description: There's a good chance the Islanders won't be meeting the Penguins in the playoffs. But if they do end up in a confrontation this spring, the Islanders will boast the security of having swept Pittsburgh (5-0-2) in the season series, capped by a 6-3 victory tonight.

title: DESSERTS ARE FOOD FOR PSYCHOANALYSIS
description: IT was St. Patrick's Day, and my mother had made a green cake.

title: 2 SIDES CLOSER ON SOVIET AFGHAN PULLOUT
description: The Afghan Government has proposed in negotiations with Pakistan on the seven-year-old Afghan conflict that some 120,000 Soviet troops be withdrawn from the country within 18 months of an agreement, diplomatic sources close to the talks said today.

title: A Tearful Farewell For an Ex-Legislator
description: Tearful and gloomy, Gerdi E. Lipschutz left Albany alone yesterday.

title: Choral Concert
description: A concert of choral works by Bach, Mendelssohn and Max Reger will be presented at the Central Presbyterian Church Sunday at 7 P.M. Soloists will be Charlotte Philley, soprano; Alexandra Hughes, mezzo-soprano; Darrell Lauer, tenor, and Richard Christopher, baritone. Charles Pilling will conduct a program of Bach's Cantata 106, ''Gottes Zeit Ist die Allerbeste Zeit;'' Mendelssohn's motet on ''Aus Tiefer Not,'' and Reger's Cantata on ''O Haupt voll Blut und Wunden.'' Suggested donation, $5. Information: 838-0808.

title: BIRDSONG CASE TO ARBITRATOR
description: Under pressure from both the National Basketball Association and the players' union, the Nets have agreed to drop their lawsuit against Otis Birdsong. Instead, their charge that Birdsong failed to disclose a leg injury before signing a three-year, $1.53 million contract last fall will be heard before an arbitrator at a hearing that will probably be scheduled for later this month.

title: Medical Unit Bid Rejected
description: American Medical International Inc. today rejected Dr. Leroy Pesch's sweetened acquisition offer of $1.91 billion, or $22 a share. In a strongly worded letter, American Medical called Dr. Pesch's offer ''seriously inadequate and not in the best interest of American Medical or its shareholders.'' The letter, which was signed by the company's entire board, called Dr. Pesch's proposal little more than a plan to initiate a recapitalization of American Medical, a hospital and health-care company based in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: CLEMENTS OFFERS AN APOLOGY OVER PAYMENTS TO ATHLETES
description: In an effort to end the politically damaging scandal over illicit payments to football players at Southern Methodist University, Gov. Bill Clements issued an apology today for his role in approving them.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some copies yesterday about reaction to the recent cutbacks at CBS News quoted a passage incorrectly from an article written by Dan Rather for the Op-Ed page of The New York Times. Mr. Rather, the CBS anchor, wrote: ''Anyone who says network news cannot be profitable doesn't know what he is talking about. But anyone who says it must always make money is misguided and irresponsible.''

title: Rainier Stock Rise Prompts Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating a surge in the Rainier Bancorporation's stock price before the Security Pacific Corporation announced on Feb. 24 that it would acquire Rainier, according to a lawyer for a law firm involved in the deal. Edward Lange, a partner in Davis Wright & Jones, said his firm had agreed to give the names and addresses of its lawyers and employees to the S.E.C. The firm represented Los Angeles-based Security Pacific.

He's highly motivated, but in the wrong direction. When first seen in Joel and Ethan Coen's new comedy, ''Raising Arizona,'' he is one of the state's most faithful recidivists.

If so, his pace would make him the shortest rebounding champion in N.B.A. history, a notch or so to the squat side of these former titleholders.

description: Roman Catholic medical experts said yesterday that many of the Vatican's new teachings on human reproduction had already been incorporated into the medical practices of hospitals affiliated with the church.

description: The State of Washington is offering $103.4 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Citibank.

title: David Deutsch Makes Point for the Homeless
description: With dramatic effect, David Deutsch Associates has juxtaposed a classified ad for a Sutton Place condo with the photograph of a ragged man asleep on a plank, to create a poster aimed at raising funds for a shelter for the homeless.

title: MILITARY SEEKS REPEAL OF ANTI-SATELLITE LIMITS
description: The Pentagon called on Congress today to repeal a law preventing the testing of a weapon to destroy space satellites, but members of Congress responded by introducing legislation that would extend the prohibition for another year.

title: THE MAFIA OF THE 1980's: DIVIDED AND UNDER SEIGE
description: The old images seem like a caricature now: the shadowy world of secret rituals, the aging dons behind high-walled estates, the passion for vengeance and power over other men. For years, the Mafia was the stuff of novels and movies and whispers on Mulberry Street.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday about a Supreme Court decision on political asylum for aliens misstated the position of two lawyers who commented.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Automobile Breakdowns: Urban Cowboys
description: For motorists, a collision on a New York City street means filing police reports and insurance claims and repair work, if not injury or death. For the city's special breed of tow-truck cowboys, however, it means a reckless race for business.

title: Amoco Oil in China Sea
description: An Amoco Oil Company subsidiary has struck oil in its first exploratory well in the South China Sea and plans a second well in the area later this year, company officials announced.

title: U.S. PANEL, BOWING TO CONGRESS, VOTES AGAINST THE DEATH PENALTY
description: A Federal commission, bowing to Congressional opposition, voted today not to issue guidelines recommending that the death penalty be restored for certain Federal crimes.

title: STATESMAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $3,112,000 and $8,139,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and losses of $1,313,000 and $1,879,000 for the same periods, respectively, from writedown of investments and other amounts relating to discontinued operations. c-Includes realized investment gains of $3,581,000 and $4,417,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; losses of $751,000 and $1,443,000 for the same periods, respectively, from writedown of investments and other amounts relating to discontinued operations; and an extraordinary credit of $1,727,000 for both periods.

title: WOMAN ARRESTED
description: A 66-year-old retired worker at the Brooklyn Navy Yard was found murdered yesterday in his apartment near the yard. He had been stabbed and put into a closet, and a neighbor whom he had befriended was charged with the slaying and with looting the man's belongings to obtain money to buy drugs, the police said.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: IN A VERY COLD CLIMATE, A DISPUTE GENERATES HEAT
description: Outside the Hudson's Bay fur trading center here, creaking in a sub-Arctic gale, is a painted sign attesting to the establishment of the company on May 2, 1670.

title: Gulf Air Grounded
description: Gull Air Inc., a commuter airline based in Hyannis, Mass., suspended operations indefinitely and filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code. On Monday, the airline sued the Texas Air Corporation and its chairman, Frank Lorenzo.
