Gull charged in the suit that Texas Air subsidiary Continental Airlines has violated agreements to establish Gull as Continental's local commuter carrier. Texas Air owns Gull's competitor, Provincetown-Boston Airline.

title: FRENCH NUCLEAR POWER, AN ''NBC NEWS SPECIAL'
description: NUCLEAR energy has fallen short in the United States; the promise of clean, cheap power has not been met. France, however, has had a success story. ''Nuclear Power: In France It Works,'' an ''NBC News Special'' at 10 o'clock tonight, judiciously examines what happened. It is a first-rate piece of television journalism.

title: 'HOUSTON KNIGHTS,' A SERIES ON CBS
description: ''HOUSTON KNIGHTS,'' a new CBS series, is having its premiere at 9 o'clock this evening. Unfortunately, the two-hour pilot is so confused and confusing that it is impossible to tell whether this latest police-detective romp can pull itself together long enough to have a shot at surviving. The show, starring Michael Beck (''Celebrity'') and Michael Pare (''Eddie and the Cruisers''), has television's requisite quota of young and attractive leading men. Now it's just a matter of giving them something believable to do.

title: NEVER ENDING WAR: CITY VERSUS POTHOLES
description: Melvin T. Brown and Felix Lubo know the streets of New York. Intimately.

title: CRUZ RESIGNATION: EFFECT IS DISPUTED
description: The Reagan Administration sought today to play down the effect of the resignation of Arturo Cruz from the leadership of the Nicaraguan rebel movement.

title: BOBBY LOCKE
description: Bobby Locke, a top international golfer in the late 1940's and 1950's and a member of the World Golf Hall of Fame, died in a nursing home Monday night. He was 69 years old.

title: HASTINGS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRESIDENT MOVES TO SOOTHE 2 CABINET MEMBERS ON IRAN
description: President Reagan moved today to soothe the wounds of Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, who were criticized in the report by the special review board on the Iran arms affair.

title: CONSIDER STEPPING DOWN
description: Like Uncle Don talking to the kiddies, Ronald Reagan tells the American people in his most disarming way that he is so very sorry that the arms-for-hostages fiasco occurred on his watch, and he promises it won't happen again. So what?

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Asian Neighborhoods

title: Council Planning Brief On Board of Estimate
description: The City Council majority leader, a sharp critic of the Board of Estimate, said yesterday that the Council planned to file a legal brief against the board in a pending court appeal.

title: Japanese Bank in Talks With Greenwich Capital
description: The Long Term Credit Bank of Japan has been talking with Greenwich Capital Markets Inc. about the possiblity of acquiring the American firm, bank officals here said.

title: MILAN: FERRE, FENDI AND BIAGIOTTI REFINE THEIR VIEWPOINTS
description: Some designers like Romeo Gigli are experimenting with different looks for fall and winter as they sense the beginnings of a major change in Italian fashion.

title: Specter's Desserts
description: Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania has been urging his guests in the Senate dining room to try the apple pie, and his full motivation has now become clear. His wife, Joan, a member of the Philadelphia City Council, also owns a bakery in that city called Joan Specter's Desserts, and the Senate, which can spot a poli-tic move, buys $100 worth of large pies from her each week. Some weeks they are carried to Washington by aides of the Senator, who occasionally presents them as gifts to colleagues or journalists.

title: Group Urges More Minority News Managers
description: Leaders of a minority journalist institute today called for a new strategy to put more nonwhites in top management positions in newspapers, magazines and broadcasting.

title: LAW FIRMS ADD SECOND TIER
description: Elizabeth Hyatt Goss was not one of the stars of her law school class at Case Western Reserve University. ''I had a B average, smack dab in the middle of the class,'' she said.

title: GRACE, W R & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $157,515,000 and $96,875,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the quarter also includes a pretax charge of $368,767,000 for asset writedowns and reserves. c-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $22,788,000 for the quarter and $59,302,000 for the year. The latest year loss includes a $221 million charge for the loss anticipated on divestment of the company's agricultural chemicals business and operating losses expected until the divestment is completed; a pre-tax charge of $275 million for the writedown of certain assets of Grace's natural resource business and a pre-tax charge of $57.2 million for the writedown of various assets of Grace's specialty chemical business. The latest year also includes a pre- tax gain of $41 million from a restaurant group management-led leveraged buyout of substantially all of Grace's full-service restaurant business; a pre-tax gain of $171.4 million from the sale of units in Grace's retail group; and a pre-tax charge of $36.6 million for the reduction of corporate overhead and other items, including costs related to severance pay and outplacement services. The company said its adoption of a pension accounting change reduced pension expense by $27.4 million in the latest year.

title: New 'Star Wars' Office
description: ''Star Wars'' is going underground.

title: ASK SHULTZ TO RESIGN
description: In claiming complete responsibility for his foreign policy failures, Ronald Reagan has said all that a fair and impartial judge could ask for. Now he must take command of his own foreign policy. The most crucial step is to ask for Secretary of State George P. Shultz's resignation.

title: Threat by Clemens
description: If necessary, Roger Clemens is prepared to sit out the 1987 season, and his agent has countered the Boston Red Sox threat to fine the pitcher $1,000 a day for each day he is absent from camp with a threat of his own. ''Starting tomorrow, our offer to the Red Sox will increase by $1,500 a day,'' said Randy Hendricks, who claims Clemens ''feels insulted'' by Boston's proposal of $500,000 a year plus incentives which the club claims are worth $350,000 more. Clemens walked out last Friday when the Red Sox rejected his demand for a $2.4 million, two-year contract. . . . Kirk McCaskill, the California pitcher, walked back into the Angels' camp yesterday, ending his six-day holdout over a contract dispute and saying he would sign a contract today. No details were disclosed.

title: PART II: INTERVENTIONS UPON HUMAN PROCREATION
description: Following is the text a Vatican doctrinal statement, ''Instruction on Respect for Human Life in Its Origin and on the Dignity of Procreation: Replies to Certain Questions of the Day,'' issued yesterday:

title: PICO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a gain of $43,185 from the discount on early long-term debt retirement for the quarter and 6 months.

title: SHOREHAM PLAN ATTACKED AT N.R.C. HEARING
description: Lawyers for Suffolk County and New York State told a Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission panel today that the emergency plan used in a federally supervised drill at the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station last year was fundamentally flawed.

title: New York and Soviet Police Reform, an Unflattering Comparison
description: To the Editor:

title: Shamir Says Pollard's Fate Is No Concern of Israel
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that the fate of Jonathan Jay Pollard, the former American naval intelligence analyst convicted of spying for Israel, was not something with which the Israeli Government has to concern itself.

title: SRYIAN ASSURANCE TO IRAN REPORTED
description: A senior Iranian official has reported receiving assurances from Syria that its troops in Lebanon have no intention of disarming Moslem militants loyal to Teheran, the official Iranian press agency reported today.

title: New York State Offers Securities
description: New York State is offering $78 million of securities with yields ranging from 3.50 percent for an issue due in six months to 4.70 percent in 1992 and 5.50 percent in 1997, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: Gates in Dispute Over Learjet Sale
description: The Gates Corporation said that it had agreed to sell its 64.8 percent stake in the Gates Learjet Corporation for $50.9 million cash to a partnership of the Cobey Corporation investment firm of Boston and a subsidiary of the Bear, Stearns Companies. The partnership would also buy a $23 million Learjet promissory note from Gates.

title: Conception and Birth: A Glossary
description: ARTIFICIAL INSEMINATION: The mechanical insertion of sperm into a woman for the purpose of conception. The sperm may come from an unknown donor. EMBRYO: The human organism in its period of most rapid development in the uterus. This period is described by various sources as lasting through the second or third month of pregnancy, when the fetal stage begins. EMBRYO TRANSFER: The transfer of an embryo from a laboratory container into the body of the woman who provided the egg or to another woman. FETUS: The human organism in later stages of growth in the uterus. GAMETES: Reproductive cells - eggs and sperm - produced by men and women, which can combine to form a new organism. GERM CELLS: Gametes. HOMOLOGOUS FERTILIZATION: In the Vatican document, the term refers to the union of gametes from a husband and wife. HETEROLOGOUS FERTILIZATION: In the Vatican document, the term refers to the union of gametes when one is provided by a donor. HYPEROVULATION: The production of more than the normal number of eggs per ovulatory cycle. It is often induced with hormone injections to obtain eggs for in vitro fertilization. Eggs fertilized in vitro can be frozen for later implantation. IN VITRO FERTILIZATION: Fertilization in a laboratory container, using eggs removed from a woman's body and sperm from her husband or a donor. It is sometimes referred to as ''test tube'' fertilization. IN VIVO FERTILIZATION: Fertilization inside the mother's body. OVUM: The female germ cell. PRENATAL DIAGNOSIS: Techniques to test the fetus or its amniotic fluid to detect malformations, illness or genetic abnormalities. SPERM: The male germ cell. SURROGATE MOTHER: A woman who bears a child for others, often under contract. The child may be conceived from her own ovum or may grow from an implanted embryo. TWIN FISSION: A method of splitting an embryo into two parts to produce identical twins. The technique, used in animals, apparently has not been applied to humans. ZYGOTE: The union of egg and sperm, before development begins.

title: The Wright Stuff
description: Jim Wright, the new Speaker of the House, has made it as official as one man can: he wants to commit the Democratic Party to a tax increase to reduce the Federal deficit. If that's courage, Mr. Wright needs a little less of it.

title: Wide Appeal Made
description: The Vatican condemned test-tube fertilization today and called on all governments to put strict limits on medical interference in human procreation. The church called for laws prohibiting such common practices as the use of surrogate mothers and experimentation on living embryos.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A DIFFERENT TUNE
description: ''We Shall Overcome'' and ''Blowin' in the Wind'' used to be favored anthems of campus protest, but when some 300 students at Southern Methodist University rallied Monday against the school's undying football scandal, they settled on a ballad that best fit the issue. The daylong demonstration was highlighted by their singing the Billy Joel number ''Honesty.''

title: Advertising; THE RISE OF LIFE'S PUBLISHER
description: IN 1972, the year that the old weekly Life magazine sank from sight with Gary Valk at the helm as publisher, an unrelated namesake, Elizabeth P. Valk, was graduating from Hollins College, a proper women's college in Virginia. Her degree was a Bachelor of Arts in political science, and, of course, that didn't prepare her for much in the business world.

title: SIMPLY RED'S 2D ALBUM BLENDS FUNK WITH BALLADS
description: WHEN Mick Hucknall, the soulful lead singer and chief songwriter of the British pop group Simply Red, flew to Los Angeles last month to appear on the Grammy telecast, he set about getting autographs feeling, he said, ''like a little kid in a candy store.''

title: House to Vote on Speed Limit
description: House leaders agreed today to allow a floor vote next week on whether to let states raise speed limits to 65 miles an hour, a concession to Western lawmakers that helped improve the prospects of the stalled bill on highways and mass transit.

title: CLEAR CHANNEL COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PART III: MORAL AND CIVIL LAW
description: Following is the text a Vatican doctrinal statement, ''Instruction on Respect for Human Life in Its Origin and on the Dignity of Procreation: Replies to Certain Questions of the Day,'' issued yesterday: THE VALUES AND MORAL OBLIGATIONS THAT CIVIL LEGISLATION MUST RESPECT AND SANCTION IN THIS MATTER

title: SELF-DENIAL FADES AS AMERICANS RETURN TO THE SWEET LIFE
description: SAY goodbye to the days of no pain, no gain. Americans are trying to exercise without sweating, diet without giving up cake and eat without cooking. If this keeps up, it may become stylish to be a little bit fatter, some trend watchers say.

title: 13.5% AMERICAN EXPRESS RATE
description: In a move that banking experts said could cause upheaval in the credit card business, the American Express Company said yesterday that it would offer its first card that would routinely allow customers to pay their bills in installments.

title: UNICORP CANADA CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $10,178,000 charge from sale of Unicorp Resources. Figures are in Canadian funds. Preferred dividends exceeded net income in the year-ago period. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: I.B.M. COMPATIBILITY IS AT A CROSSROADS  BIG BLUE VS. THE BULGARIAN MEGABITE
description: EVER since I.B.M. introduced the PC six years ago, people who use personal computers have needed to know only one thing about I.B.M. compatibility: Either they had it or they didn't. Those who did could share software with other compatibles in the office or at home; those who didn't, couldn't.

title: MELRIDGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MEYER, FRED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,530,000 from early extinguishment of debt.

title: MAXICARE HEALTH PLANS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter results reflect pre-tax operating losses of about $5.3 million at HealthAmerica and HealthCare USA. In addition, goodwill amortization expense and net interest expense related to the acquisitions totaled $3.7 million for the latest quarter and $8.5 million for the year. Other charges recorded in the quarter include a $4.8 million reserve for the discontinuance of hospital operations at Maxicare medical centers, and an increase of $11.8 million in medical expense reserves. Maxicare in 1986 acquired two HMO companies, HealthCare USA for about $67 million, and HealthAmerica Corp. for about $386 million.

title:
THE VATICAN ON BIRTH SCIENCE;
REPRODUCTIVE HELP: WIDESPREAD AND UNREGULATED
description: LEAD: The reproductive technologies condemned by the Roman Catholic Church yesterday have spread widely as accepted medical practice in the United States, approved by many ethics committees and largely unregulated by the Government.

title: Preparing for Nakasone
description: Administration officials are trying to decide what one describes as ''the level of extravaganza'' to be accorded Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan when he visits the capital in late April or early May. Foreign Minister Tadashi Kuranari is due in Washington Thursday to discuss the visit with, among others, Selwa Roosevelt, the State Department chief of protocol.

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $598,000 and includes a pre-tax gain on the sale of properties of $24,541,000. c-Net loss

title: Seasons' Greetings
description: The four seasons came and went last weekend. Very fast. Spring drifted in on Saturday morning, hung around long enough to make a few hearts beat faster and at about dawn on Sunday yielded to summer. By noon, people had looked for, found and put on their bikinis. By evening, people who hadn't thought of gin and tonic for seven months suddenly thought of gin and tonic.

title: Results Plus
description: Sled-Dog Racing Two Hardy Souls: Only two of the leaders in the Iditarod Trail sled-dog race in Alaska had ventured into the tough Farewell Burn between the checkpoints at Rohn and Nikolai early yesterday. Thirty-two of the 61 mushers remaining in the 1,157-mile race from Anchorage to Nome had reached the Rohn Roadhouse checkpoint, a remote cabin on the western edge of the Alaska Range, 270 miles into the race. Nineteen of them said they would take their mandatory 24-hour rest stop at Rohn. But Guy Blankenship of Fairbanks pulled into Rohn on Monday at 2:50 P.M., local time, in 13th place. He checked out 50 minutes later, heading to Nikolai, some 90 miles farther up the trail. David J. Olesen of Ely, Minn., reached Rohn at 9:29 P.M. and followed Blankenship onto the trail at 4:38 A.M. Tuesday. The Farewell Burn is a vast area that was burned in a forest fire years ago. Left behind were tundra charred to rock, stumps and fallen trees. (AP) N.H.L. Flames 6, Capitals 3: Joe Nieuwendyk and Gary Roberts, both rookies, scored second-period goals to lead visiting Calgary. Nieuwendyk, a 21-year-old center who signed with the Flames Monday after playing three seasons at Cornell, scored at 10:03 of the second period to tie at 2-2. Roberts, playing in only his 23d N.H.L. game, put the Flames ahead at 13:54.(AP) Nordiques 6, Whalers 4: In Quebec, Randy Moller put the Nordiques ahead for good in the second period, and Michel Goulet added two goals in the third. The Nordiques ended a five-game streak without a victory. Moller gave the Nordiques a 4-3 lead at 16:55 of the second with a slap shot from the right point.(AP) N.B.A. 76ers 100, Cavaliers 91: In Richfield, Ohio, Charles Barkley had 23 points and 15 rebounds, and David Wingate, making his first pro start, scored a career-high 22 points for Philadelphia.(AP) Hawks 113, Spurs 106: Guard Glenn Rivers scored 7 unanswered points in overtime as the Hawks took their eighth straight victory. Dominique Wilkins had 37 points for Atlanta. Walter Berry led the Spurs with 27 points. (AP) High School Basketball Molloy and Hayes Gain Final: Kenny Anderson scored24 points and rally Archibishop Molloy of Queens to a 65-55 victory over Tolentine of the Bronx last night in a Catholic High Schools Athletic Association semifinal. In Friday's city final, Molloy (23-2) will face Cardinal Hayes (20-7) of the Bronx, which eliminated McClancy of Queens, 65-53.

title: The U.N. Today: March 11, 19871
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Icahn Setback on USAir Bid Is Seen
description: Carl C. Icahn may have overreached in his effort to acquire the USAir Group and may find it difficult to end it without paying a price financially and legally, some analysts and sources close to the takeover effort said yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Compromise on ABM Pact

title: DO WINE DRINKERS DIFFER? YES, SAY THOSE WHO POP THE CORK
description: LEAD: MOST wine drinkers will never exhaust a single brain cell debating whether the '82 Bordeaux will age gracefully. And for good reason: the world is already too cluttered with complex questions to go around agonizing over wine. That is, of course, the purview of enologists. Who else cares which clone of sangiovese is used in Brunello?

title: Corrections
description: A report on March 3 in the Science Watch column of Science Times, about people with babyish faces, misidentified Leslie Zebrowitz McArthur. She is a professor of psychology at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass.

title: 22 Arrested in Sweep Against a Heroin Ring
description: Law-enforcement officers arrested 22 people in pre-dawn raids today, breaking up a drug ring that used New York Mafia connections to buy millions of dollars worth of heroin, a Federal prosecutor said.

title: Westinghouse Picks Broadcasting Chief
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday that Burton B. Staniar had been named chairman and chief executive of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company, succeeding Daniel L. Ritchie, who plans to step down May 1.

title: SEAGRAM SELLS WINE HOLDINGS
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc., the giant wine and spirits producer, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell most of its wine holdings for about $200 million in cash.

title: Yale and Harvard: In Forgiving Moods
description: Dean Burton Malkiel of the Yale School of Management is troubled. He talked the other day about a recent graduate who felt compelled to take a $50,000 position with an investment banking house though he was more interested in a $22,500 city manager's job. The young man had borrowed heavily to get through graduate school, and felt constrained to begin paying off the debt upon graduation.

title: Particles From Stellar Explosion Are Detected
description: Laboratories in Japan and the United States have independently detected a strong pulse of neutrino particles apparently coming from the exploding star that burst into view over the Southern Hemisphere two weeks ago, astronomers reported yesterday. The detection of neutrinos strongly reinforces a widely held theory of how such massive stars explode into supernovas.

title: LEO BERTISCH
description: Leo Bertisch, retired president of the United Whalen Corporation, a drug and discount store chain, died Sunday at Memorial Hospital in Hollywood, Fla. He was 79 years old and lived in Cedarhurst, L.I., and North Miami Beach, Fla.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $362,000 and $431,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Yanks Lose 2d in Row
description: The Yankees, who won their first three games of the exhibition season, lost their second straight today when the Texas Rangers scored an 11-5 victory. Al Leiter, a rookie left-hander starting in place of Charles Hudson, who was scratched last week because of a sore right shoulder, pitched two innings and retired all six Texas batters he faced. But the pitching collapsed after that. Brad Arnsberg gave up one run in two innings, Pete Filson allowed two in two innings and Cecilio Guante surrendered eight runs on seven hits in one and two-thirds innings.

title: CONCERT: ROBERT CRAFT IN STRAVINSKY PROGRAM
description: ROBERT CRAFT remains Igor Stravinsky's indefatiguable champion - the constant flow of what might called scholarly scrapbooks of Stravinskyana edited by him attest to that. But as a performer of Stravinsky's music, Mr. Craft has rather faded from the scene. It was interesting, then, to encounter him at the helm of a Composers' Showcase concert Monday night at Alice Tully Hall, devoted to two mid-period Stravinsky masterpieces, ''Oedipus Rex'' (1927) and the ''Symphony of Psalms'' (1930).

title: COLORADO SKI RESORTS OFFER DISCOUNTS AS BUSINESS TAKES DOWNHILL TURN
description: When Ann Swerdloff arrived in Colorado, she planned to spend most of her week's vacation skiing the powdery slopes of the Breckenridge Ski Area.

title: Lehman Packs His Bag, Abrasiveness Intact But No Resentments
description: When he departs in April as Secretary of the Navy, John F. Lehman Jr. will leave many bruised egos behind him.

title: Japan Accuses 2 of Fraud
description: An Indian exporter and his Chinese associate were arrested today and accused of using false documents to ship textiles worth 2.2 billion yen, or about $14.4 million, to the United States and Canada, the police said. The shipments accounted for about 10 percent of Japan's textile exports to the United States last year, according to a spokesman for the Ministry of International Trade and Industry.

title: MALRITE COMMUNICATIONS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $9.8 million associated with a reduction in the valuation of film contracts. c-After an extraordinary charge of $1,818,000 related to prepayment of notes. d-Net income and includes for the year a gain of $8,651,000 from the disposal of assets.

title: MONDAVI WILL OFFER A FUTURES PROGRAM
description: PAY now, drink later. That is the message Michael Mondavi delivered in New York Monday when he announced a new futures program for the Robert Mondavi Winery. Between mid-March and the end of April, the winery will offer some of the best red wine from 1985 and 1986 for advance purchase.

title: F.S.L.I.C. AID GAINS IN SENATE
description: The Senate Banking Committee, as part of a wide-ranging banking measure, voted this evening to provide $7.5 billion for the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation over the next two years.

title: A STEP FOR FOREMAN DESPITE THE FLAB By PHIL BERGER
description: The piece of yellow-lined paper taped to the door of the dressing room said: ''GEORGE FOREMAN, BOUT 4.''

title: HONDURAS DOWNS C-47 CARGO PLANE
description: Honduran Air Force jets shot down a cargo plane that flew from neighboring Nicaragua into Honduran airspace on Monday night.

title: Revised Tower Plans Approved by Panel
description: Revised plans for a 49-story skyscraper behind the former Rizzoli and Coty Buildings on Fifth Avenue were approved yesterday by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission. Work on the project is to begin immediately, the president of the development company said.

title: FOR STATE POET, ART MUST MELD LIFE AND DEATH
description: WHEN Stanley Kunitz was informed that he would receive the Walt Whitman Citation of Merit for Poetry from Governor Cuomo - who today is to name him the official New York State Poet for the next two years - he wondered to himself:

title: U.S. TAKES PASSPORT OF HEAD OF AN ARAB-AMERICAN GROUP
description: Last week, M. T. Mehdi, the leader of an Arab-American organization who has traveled to Lebanon twice in the last four months seeking to negotiate the release of American hostages there, returned from his brother's funeral in London.

title: STOCKS RISE SHARPLY BEFORE TENDER BIDS, S.E.C. STUDY FINALS
description: A study of 172 successful tender offers from 1981 to 1985 disclosed that in every case the price of the target company's stock rose abnormally more than three weeks before the bid was announced.

title: Crum Is Criticized
description: The Louisville coach, Denny Crum, must look no farther than the play of his team to discover why it was rejected by the N.C.A.A. tournament, a selection committee member, Jim Delany, said yesterday. ''For two days I've listened to Coach Crum's scapegoating Jim Delany and, by inference, the Ohio Valley Conference, the N.C.A.A. selection committee and the Metro Conference, for Louisville's failure to be selected,'' Delany said. Crum, seething because his 18-14 Cardinals were not invited to the 64-team tournament they won a year ago, has termed Middle Tennessee State as ''the most exaggerated case.'' Middle Tennessee, 22-6, the Ohio Valley champion, did receive one of the 35 at-large invitations. Delany is the Ohio Valley commissioner. Delany, 39, said he followed committee procedures and left the room when Middle Tennessee State's case was deliberated. He said Crum was wrong if he believed Middle Tennessee was the last at-large team selected. ''The fact is, Louisville wasn't in competition with Middle Tennessee.'' Louisville's poor record against good teams was its downfall, Delany said.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THEY say that politics makes strange bedfellows, which may explain why I find myself defending Nancy Reagan. My impression has always been that Mrs. Reagan and I have what her daughter, Patti, might once have called ''bad karma.'' She strikes me as someone who was born wearing color-coordinated lipstick and nail polish, which is not my style.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A Fortunate Twosome Will Be Cannes-Bound
description: This year the lucky Americans who get to go to Cannes, France, and judge advertising during the beautiful month of June are Jerry Della Femina, chairman of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, and Sean Kevin Fitzpatrick, the well-bearded executive vice president/director of creative services for Campbell-Ewald, Detroit.

title: IN MILAN, CELEBRANTS PARADE COSTUMES BOTH ON THE FASHION RUNWAYS AND OFF
description: There were two carnivals here last weekend, both featuring huge crowds and extravagant costumes. Celebrants of each sometimes passed on the streets, and the costumes they wore were often surprisingly similar. But there the comparisons end. One celebration, the Carnevale Ambrosiano, named for the patron saint of Milan, St. Ambrogio, resembled Halloween or Mardi Gras. On Friday and Saturday afternoons, the streets of central Milan were closed to traffic and filled with costumed, confetti-chucking children, jugglers, mimes, musicians and actors.

title: BALLET: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM
description: DANCE Theater of Harlem has followed up the very successful season it had last year at Aaron Davis Hall of City College with a second engagement, now called ''Harlem Homecoming 2.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Monday about the trade policies of the United States and Japan misstated Senator John C. Danforth's role on the Senate Finance Committee. He is the ranking Republican on its international trade subcommittee.

title: KOCH GETS TV SHOW OF HIS OWN By JEFFREY SCHMALZ
description: Sometimes it's just not enough being Mayor of New York. So this Sunday, Edward I. Koch will turn television star as well, beginning a weekly talk show to be called ''Koch on Call.''

title: Continental Departure A Shock for Ted Bates
description: After a 45-year association, the Continental Baking Company is leaving Ted Bates Advertising/New York, and the agency is shocked.

title: AMERICAN BARRICK REOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after special charges, mainly from writedown of oil and gas investments of $27,092,000 for the quarter and $26,392,000 for the year. Results are in Canandian dollars.

title: Bridge: A Top Partnership Picks Up National Open Pairs Crown
description: One of the world's best partnerships added to a large collection of titles at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here Monday night.

title: U.S. IS PROPOSING TO RELABEL LEAN BEEF
description: The Agricultural Department has taken the first step toward changing the designation of one of the leanest grades of beef from ''good'' to ''select.'' The action is in response to a request from a consumer organization, Public Voice, which said the leaner beef is more healthful but that consumers shy away from it because the designation ''good'' connotes something ''less than desirable.''

title: Court Rejects Appeal In Boston Globe Suit
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by a former Republican gubernatorial aspirant, John R. Lakian, who received no money in a 1985 libel suit against The Boston Globe.

title: Bank Ouster In Oklahoma
description: Gov. Henry Bellmon removed the state bank commissioner from office today, accusing him of using insider information to sell stock in state-regulated banking institutions.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Ohio Mattress Company is offering about $166 million of debt and equity through underwriters led by Lazard Freres & Company.

title: EMPLOYEES OF 3 AIRLINES CHARGED IN COCAINE SMUGGLING AT KENNEDY
description: Federal agents and the Port Authority police said yesterday that they had broken a sophisticated ring of airline workers that had smuggled almost $1.5 billion worth of cocaine into Kennedy International Airport aboard Pan American World Airways flights from Brazil.

title: KNICK STREAK ENDS AS PISTONS ROMP
description: Bob Hill has learned to tolerate a lot of things. He has learned to tolerate poor rebounding. He has learned to tolerate poor passing, poor shooting and an inconsistent production from his reserves. He has even learned that losing is an inevitability when a coach tries to achieve change in the midst of a season.

title: TRIAL IN PRAGUE: FIVE JAZZ FANS VS. STATE POWER
description: Five jazz enthusiasts who are advocates of cultural freedom were brought to court today, two of them in handcuffs, for directing a club of 5,000 jazz fans that the Government had ordered disbanded.

title: TW Services Inc.
description: TW Services Inc. said that it plans to invest $700 million in its core businesses over the next five years and could spend another $600 million on acquisitions. Frank A. Salizzoni, TW's vice chairman, also said the company should meet its target of 15 percent annual earnings growth over the next five years. TW Services, a food-services and health-care concern, is the successor company to the Transworld Corporation.

title: NATIONAL GAS & OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods' results include the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for revenue which increased net income by $334,274. The share earnings reflect a 7 percent stock dividend paid in December.

title: Trade Surplus Of Japan Rises
description: Japan reported today that it had another increase in its trade surplus, and economists said there was little prospect of a sharp decrease for some time. The surplus in February, the

title: ROPAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Don't Wallow in the Iran Scandal
description: The investigations into the Iran-contra scandal are starting to cross. Congress wants information to guide public policy about how the United States went astray in ransoming hostages and diverting weapons profits to the Nicaraguan rebels. Lawrence Walsh, the court-appointed independent counsel, wants to know whether criminal laws were broken and by whom.

title: DELAY ON IMMUNITY FOR NORTH IS SEEN
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, principal figures in the Iran arms deals, will not be compelled to testify before Congressional investigative committees until at least the end of May, Congressional leaders said tonight.

title: MISSOURI TEAM CHASES DREAM
description: The big-timers stumbled upon Springfield, Mo., this time last year. To be precise, they stumbled out of Springfield. Until five years ago, the Bears of Southwest Missouri State University played Division II basketball in a league that included Southeast Missouri, Northeast Missouri, Northwest Missouri and, of course, Central Missouri.

title: METS DEFEAT ASTROS ON MAZZILI'S HOMER By JOSEPH DURSO
description: It wasn't exactly the seventh game of the playoff for the National League pennant, which the Mets won in six last October. But it was the first time since then that they had met, the return match, and nothing was on the line except that the two winners of 1986 were still looking for their first victory of 1987.

title: RAYONIER TIMBERLANDS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that comparable year-ago periods are not available as the company began operations on Nov. 20, 1985. The company also said that the results are audited and that the partnership reported unaudited results for the fourth quarter and year on Jan. 28. The net income represents partnership income and the share earnings represent income per class A unit.

title: PROSECUTOR IN IRAN ARMS CASE GATHERS HEAPS OF DOCUMENTS
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-Nicaragua affair has been provided with mountains of documents from companies linked to the case and is creating a voluminous archive designed to assist his grand jury, according to lawyers and other sources.

title: Pay Should Be Suitable
description: To the Editor:

title: Dynamics Ranked No.1
description: The General Dynamics Corporation vaulted into first place last year as the nation's largest military contractor, winning contracts valued at $8 billion, the Pentagon said today.

title: MERCURY ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
ITALY REKINDLES CHEF'S PASSION
description: ON Sept. 19, 1983, Alice Huberman sublet her Greenwich Village apartment and purchased a one-way ticket to Milan, Italy, to see if she could rekindle her passion for cooking. After 12 years as a chef in New York, working at Laughing Mountain, at the former Delices la Cote Basque and at Arnold's Turtle, she felt burned out. ''Even though I knew I had a sense about food, I wanted to learn about it again with the passion of a novice,'' said Miss Huberman, a native of San Francisco.

title: BASKETBALL PROFESSOR
description: Several years ago, Bobby Knight, the basketball professor, dictated to his secretary a letter to the sports editor of a daily newspaper with whom he had a beef.

title: THE WHITNEY UNVEILS SMALLER EXPANSION PLAN
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art, responding to protests by neighborhood and civic groups over a plan to expand its building at Madison Avenue and 75th Street, announced a revised plan yesterday that calls for reducing the proposed addition by nearly a quarter.

title: In Search of Watergate in the Textbooks
description: To the Editor:

title: Ryun Seeking Partner
description: Jim Ryun, who held the American record in the mile for 16 years and the world record for nine, is looking for a partner to run with him in the Trevira Twosome Race April 25, but this year he is stepping down. Last year Ryun was in the 10-mile couples race as a partner with Jan Merrill, but he dropped out after completing about four miles. This year he is planning to run in the two-mile mini-Twosome. The race will be four days before his 40th birthday.

title: UNUSUAL SUBURBAN OFFICE GLUT
description: FOR more than two decades mid-Westchester County has been fertile ground for office space developers who have found eager tenants in such companies as I.B.M., Merrill Lynch, Seagram & Sons and Pepsico.

title: U.S. FIGURE SKATING IS IN GOOD SHAPE By FRANK LITSKY
description: A year before the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary, figure skating in the United States is good and getting better.

title: ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PROSECUTORS CITE A ZACCARO LINK TO MANES DEAL
description: Queens prosecutors yesterday cited a series of events that they said showed that John A. Zaccaro ''acted in concert'' with Donald R. Manes in trying to extort a bribe from a cable television company seeking a Queens franchise.

title: GAP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,591,000 and $6,730,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company's Pottery Barn Inc. operation was discontinued as of Feb. 1, 1986.

title: E. H. (PAT) BURGESS
description: E. H. (Pat) Burgess, a World War II British bomber pilot who served for three years as director of sales for the Concorde supersonic airliner, died yesterday at his home in Cornwall, England. He was 63 years old.

title: MAN ACCUSED OF TRYING TO SELL GIRL, 4, TO UNCLE
description: A hospital maintenance worker was arrested today on charges of selling a 4-year-old girl in his care to her uncle for $100,000, the authorities said.

title: Israel Is Placing the Wrong Bet
description: LEAD: Israel's policy of shipping arms to Iran while treating Iraq as an intractable foe raises serious questions about the judgments being made in Jerusalem.

title: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $84,000 for the quarter and $134,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $17,000 for the quarter and $23,000 for the 9 months. d-Net loss All figures have been restated to reflect the sale of assets of Hofmann's material handling equipment operation in November.

title: GERSHWIN DOUBLE BILL IS SET
description: Music lovers will have their first opportunity to hear some recently recovered scores by George Gershwin - part of a treasure-trove of manuscripts found in a Secaucus, N.J., warehouse - during the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Gershwin celebration.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 11, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17, A19

title: ECI TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. STUDIES COMPROMISE ON ABM'S
description: The Reagan Administration and several key senators are exploring a proposed compromise on the issue of how to interpret the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972, according to Administration and Congressional sources.

title: CADE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $2,844,000. c-Includes a gain of $2,271,159 from the sale of common stock in a subsidiary.

title: MARGIN OF VICTORY TIES NETS' RECORD By SAM GOLDAPER
description: Kevin Loughery, the Washingon Bullets' coach, has been around pro basketball long enough as a player and coach to know that games are rarely lost in the first quarter. But that's what happened to his injury-riddled team tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Awards for Books With Jewish Themes
description: Five authors of books with Jewish themes, published in 1986, were honored yesterday at the Eighth Annual Present Tense/Joel H. Cavior Book Awards luncheon, sponsored by Present Tense magazine and the American Jewish Committee, and held at the committee's headquarters.

title: CRUZ, CONTRA CHIEF WHO QUIT, SAYS AIM IS TO FORCE CHANGES
description: Arturo Cruz, the senior Nicaraguan rebel leader who resigned Monday, said today that he hoped his departure would ''shake up'' American and rebel officials and force them to face the necessity of fundamentally reorganizing the guerrilla movement.

title: TONED-DOWN BILL TO WIDEN EXPORTS OFFERED IN HOUSE
description: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee introduced a trade bill today that aims to open foreign markets but backs off from tough retaliatory proposals.

title: TRADE PROPOSAL FROM CHRYSLER
description: CHRYSLER'S decision to acquire American Motors shows its determination to forge ahead in the face of tough price and quality competition and growing auto overcapacity. The company's economists estimate that overcapacity in North America could reach 7.6 million units by 1990, causing the loss of 400,000 direct auto jobs.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $700,000 and a gain of $24.1 million, or 30 cents a share, from sale of stock of St. Joe Gold Corp.

title: REEBOK TO BUY AVIA FOR $180 MILLION
description: Reebok International Ltd., a maker of athletic and casual shoes, said today that it had agreed to acquire Avia Group International Inc. for about $180 million in cash, or $16.35 a share.

title: STOCK OUTLOOK BY TECHNICIANS
description: MOST technical analysts believe the Dow Jones industrial average - after climbing past 2,000, 2,100 and 2,200 so far this year - is poised to scale the next century mark of 2,300. But others sniff a possible correction in the air. After weathering a 20-point drop on Monday, the Dow caught its second wind yesterday and advanced 19.97 points, to 2,280.09, only a whisker below last Friday's record closing at 2,280.23.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Prime Exports
description: Shaw University's greatest claim to athletic renown is that it is the alma mater of James (Bonecrusher) Smith, the only college graduate -business administration, class of '78 - who ever held a heavyweight title. Smith, of course, was shorn of his crown last Saturday night by Brooklyn-born Mike Tyson, which is not to say that Shaw, a Division II school in Raleigh, N.C., has anything against Brooklyn.

title: A CLUB WHERE THE DRINKS ARE SPIRITED BUT SPIRITLESS
description: It's a Friday night at Top Brass, one of this city's new clubs.

title: SBARRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that the elimination of the investment tax credit due to the Tax Reform Act of 1986 affected earnings by about 10 cents a share in 1986.

title: BOLAR PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Delay in 'Blithe Spirit'
description: The opening night of ''Blithe Spirit,'' which began preview performances last night at the Eugene O'Neill Theater, has been changed from March 19 to March 31.

title: Tragic Ending To a Comeback
description: For someone born with spina bifida, a severe spinal defect, Harry Jakobson did pretty well for himself. After laboriously training to become an elite athlete, he won a gold medal in the 400-meter race and a silver in the 100 at the 1971 Pan American Wheelchair Games. He later became a full-time volunteer for the handicapped and worked to raise money for disabled athletes.

title: ADVANCE ROSS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RITZY'S, G D INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Political Obsolescence
description: To the Editor:

title: Shultz, His Tiger and His Tail By DAVID K. SHIPLER
description: Troubles that brew in Washington have a way of following Secretary of State George P. Shultz all over the world. And reporters who travel with Mr. Shultz often receive the impression, not very subtly, that he would prefer they not ask him about those Washington-based clouds that hang over his head.

title: NEW OVERSEER OF THE COURTS: ALBERT MARTIN ROSENBLATT
description: ''The Rosenblatts have done very, very well in the last few days,'' said Albert M. Rosenblatt, his right arm around his 13-year-old daughter, Betsy, as cameras flashed in his face and reporters crowded round yesterday.

title: THEATER: 'THE KNIFE,' WITH MANDY PATINKIN
description: WITH the possible exception of the Public Theater audience that's watching him, there's no one gloomier in town right now than Mandy Patinkin in ''The Knife.'' From the opening number of this new, all-sung English musical, the actor is in a funk so thick one could cut it with a hacksaw. As a lyric has it, Mr. Patinkin is ''lost at sea,'' and the question is why. Perhaps he is down because the lighting is. Or maybe he's defeated by the phalanxes of performers that keep marching to and fro with a solemnity that makes a Greek chorus seem as frivolous as a conga line. Or is it the confusion of locale? While the program states that ''The Knife'' is set in Winchester, England, no one on stage speaks with an English accent. It can't be easy pretending to be ''lost at sea'' when you're not sure which hemisphere the sea is in.

title: Back To the Summit?
description: This city is sick of the scandals now. It gave up when Colonel North didn't even have the decency to take off his uniform but took the Government into court for violating the Constitution! And the President's daughter turned everybody off with a few vulgar and ill-chosen words.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (KALAMAOO)(O) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
WESTERN AUTO SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $400,000 on repurchase of debentures. The company went public in January 1987. Corrected from Friday, March 6, editions.

title: INTRODUCTION
description: Following is the text a Vatican doctrinal statement, ''Instruction on Respect for Human Life in Its Origin and on the Dignity of Procreation: Replies to Certain Questions of the Day,'' issued yesterday: 1. Biomedical Research and The Teaching of the Church

title: PUSHES HIGH-RISK IDEAS
description: Bruce Babbitt, the former Governor of Arizona, formally declared his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination here today, offering a set of policy proposals that promise to enliven the political debate and stir controversy within his party.

title: ZENTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $513,000 and $1,607,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss Results for both latest periods include the business and certain assets of the data products division of Lear Siegler Inc., which were acquired July 1, 1986.

title: ARES-SERONO INTERNATIONAL HOLDING SA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Plane Carrying Gold Makes Belly Landing
description: A twin-engine plane carrying gold bricks made an emergency belly landing early yesterday at Kennedy International Airport, the Port Authority police said.

title: CARVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
N.F.L. Studies Rule Shift
description: The National Football League's competition committee, which is meeting this week on the Hawaiian island of Maui, is considering two rule changes for overtime games. One would eliminate tie games. The other would guarantee that each team had at least one chance to run an offensive series.

title: VATICAN'S MORAL MISSION  Reproduction Report Seen as Opportunity To Influence Government in Making Laws
description: The Vatican's document on human reproduction exploits what some church officials consider an unparalleled opportunity to influence governments before they enact laws on controversial medical innovations.

title: More Figures on Trade Gap
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit, calculated on a balance-of-payments basis, set a record of $38.4 billion in the three months ended Dec. 31, the Government said today. The report indicated that higher-priced imports swamped gains in exports.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 12, 1987
description: Markets

title: POLAR BEAR SMUGGLING ALLEGED
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a man and wife on charges of smuggling into the United States the skin and skull of a polar bear, an endangered species.

title: Boy's Life Distributes Anti-Drug Kits
description: Boy's Life magazine, the official publication of the Boy Scouts of America, has, with a financial assist from Coca-Cola and Champion International, printed and distributed 5.2 million kits to help in the war on drugs. They have gone to the scouts and adults connected with scouting.

title: Want to Run a Budget?
description: The House and the Senate Budget Committees have formally begun their search for a new director of the Congrsssional Budget Office - a little late. The last director, Rudolph G. Penner, left a week and a half ago.

title: Taxing Washington's Credibility
description: Give credit to House Speaker Jim Wright at least for boldness. He's making a brave effort to steer the Government toward responsible reduction of the budget deficit without last year's fakery -even if that means higher taxes as well as spending cuts. While he still hasn't found the formula, he's on a good path. Across a mine field.

title: FINANACE/NEW ISSUES;
description: In only its second venture into the United States debt market in 20 years, the City of Tokyo is offering $100 million of 10-year bonds, yielding 7.57 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: SERVICE RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $712,000 for the quarter and $1,972,000 for the year; an extraordinary charge of $1,167,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $628,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,843,000 for the quarter and $10,557,000 for the year. d-Net loss

title: AMID GRIEF, CLASSMATES FAULT EARLIER RESPONSE
description: Bergenfield High School was a tumult of contradictory emotions today as students learned of the joint suicide of four friends who died months after the deaths of four other troubled youths.

title: Apartments Planned Near Faulkner Home
description: A tentative agreement has been reached that would allow developers to build condominiums near the home of William Faulkner but would preserve part of the wooded area on a 3.5-acre site, according to a University of Mississippi official.

title: In Praise of Civil Servants
description: Excerpts from ''The Government's Managers,'' a new report on Federal civil servants by the Twentieth Century Fund, a New York-based nonprofit foundation that analyzes economic, political and social issues:

title: 3 Top Executives Quit Lorimar Unit
description: The Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation said yesterday that three top executives of its Karl-Lorimar Home Video unit had resigned after the parent company discovered that the executives had a financial interest in one of the unit's subcontractors.

title: Witco Increases Debenture Issue
description: The Witco Corporation is offering $140 million of 5 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2012 at a price of par through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. Because of strong investor demand, the size of the offering was increased from the initial $100 million.

title: REPAIRING FURNITURE IF THE JOINTS ARE LOOSE
description: LEAD: FOR those with more than passing interest in furniture, the professional dismantling or cannibalizing of old pieces - whether for spare parts or for the creation of a new antique - can be an impressive spectacle. This is particularly so when observing a demonstration of how to lift veneer by using a putty knife and blowtorch.

title: ADAMS SCORES 2 IN 6-4 LOSS TO FLYERS
description: Greg Adams, the Devils' leading scorer last season, scored for the first time in two months tonight. In fact, Adams scored twice and the Devils had two goals 13 seconds apart, but it wasn't enough.

title: HARCOURT IN BID FOR HARPER & ROW
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., one of the nation's leading textbook publishers, entered the bidding for Harper & Row Publishers yesterday by proposing to buy all of Harper's stock for $50 a share, or about $220 million in cash.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Carol Evans, 34 years old, will be taking over the publisher's job at Working Mother magazine when Raymond Eyes retires at the end of the month.

title: Tensions and Dole
description: Senator Bob Dole's nascent campaign for the Presidency is organizing its senior-level staff, but ideological and personal tensions remain evident.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $20 million to cover the disposition of 21 under-performing company-owned restaurants for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: Corrections
description: The headline of a Washington dispatch yesterday about a cargo plane that was shot down over Honduras misstated the origin of the flight.

title: NETWORK VIDEO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
REA SHORT-STORY PRIZE GOES TO ROBERT COOVER
description: Robert Coover has been awarded the $25,000 Rea Award for the short story. The prize is given annually by the Dungannon Foundation for a writer who has made a significant contribution to the short story as an art form.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $78,852,000. c-Net loss

title: Contract Backed At Food Plant
description: Members of the teamsters' union approved a contract today with the new owners of one of the world's largest food processing plants, ending a 19-month strike that was marked by violence.

title: ALBANY BASKS IN LIMELIGHT AS 'IRONWEED' IS FILMED
description: For decades, Albany residents have had to make do with watching movie stars in movies.

title: REDMEN THINK THEY CAN SILENCE CRITICS
description: St. John's season is winding down. The Redmen arrived in Chicago yesterday with a 20-8 record and some bruised bodies for tomorrow's game with Wichita State in the first round of the Midwest Regional.

title: Brown U. Disciplines Amy Carter on Protest
description: Amy Carter, the daughter of former President Jimmy Carter, was put on limited probation Tuesday by a Brown University disciplinary board for her participation in a campus protest on South African racial separatism last month.

title: Ferruzi Stake In Montedison
description: Raul Gardini, the head of the agricultural conglomerate Ferruzzi, took Italy's financial community by surprise today with his announcement that he had purchased a big slice of Montedison, the Swiss chemicals giant.

title: Taft Rejects Takeover Bid
description: The Taft Broadcasting Company said today that its board had unanimously rejected a proposed $145 a share takeover offer from an investor group led by its vice chairman, Dudley S. Taft.

title: JAPANESE WRITERS CRITICAL OF JEWS
description: One of Japan's more popular authors of the last few months is an Osaka man who argues that the country's recent economic problems are a result of a conspiracy by ''international Jewish capital.''

title: Hudson Says He's Ready
description: Charles Hudson threw several minutes of batting practice today, worked out a bit more in the bullpen, then turned to the Yankee manager, Lou Piniella, and said, ''I'm ready to go.''

title: VIEWS OF THE VATICAN DOCUMENT VARY FROM APPROVAL TO VOWED RESISTANCE
description: The Vatican's new document on human reproduction prompted reactions around the world yesterday that ranged from approval from the hierarchy in Brazil, the world's largest Catholic country, to at least one vow of resistance in Ireland and consternation in the Catholic hospital that performed France's first artificial fertilization.

title: 2 IN CABINET FIGHT SALE TO JAPANESE
description: In what would be a significant escalation of the nation's trade dispute with Japan, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige have asked the Administration to consider blocking a major Japanese investment in American industry, Administration officials said today.

title: Vandals Attack Cars Of Two Witnesses
description: Vandals punctured tires on seven cars parked at the homes of two witnesses who had testified against a 21-year-old Maplewood man convicted of racial vandalism, the authorities said yesterday.

title: EXPERTS DEBATE MEDICAL TECHNIQUES
description: In its condemnation of scientific intervention in human reproduction, the Roman Catholic Church would restrict couples to medical procedures that are riskier and more difficult than the more common practices that the Church wants outlawed, medical and religious experts said yesterday.

title: NEWPORT PHARMACEUTICALS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: DANCE: 'POINTS IN SPACE,' BY MERCE CUNNINGHAM
description: THE Merce Cunningham Dance Company offered the first performance of Mr. Cunningham's ''Points in Space'' on Tuesday night at the City Center Theater on a program that also included ''Signals'' and ''Pictures.'' Those three titles are significant, for they indicate much about Mr. Cunningham's approach to choreography.

title: DEB SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Implications Of a Stock Split
description: AS stock prices have surged to record levels with virtually each passing day, stock splits have proliferated, especially in the shares of many blue-chip issues.

title: Alpine Associates
description: Alpine Associates, a brokerage based in Cresskill, N.J., said that it had acquired a 5.87 percent stake in the Leaseway Transportation Corporation, the car-hauling and truck-leasing concern based in Beachwood, Ohio. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Alpine said that between Dec. 24 and March 6, it bought 529,100 Leaseway shares at prices ranging from $47.75 to $50.50 a share for investment purposes only. The board of Leaseway has accepted a $51-a-share, or $602 million, tender offer from an investment group led by Citicorp Capital Investors Inc.

title: ECUADOR MAY HALT INTEREST PAYMENTS
description: As it attempts to recover from an earthquake, Ecuador appeared close yesterday to suspending all interest payments on its $8.2 billion foreign debt.

title: BONNEVILLE PACIFIC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
DIAL LITERARY COLLECTION TO BE SOLD
description: To the dismay of scholars and teachers, one of the richest collections of letters, drafts and manuscripts relating to modernist literature has been removed from the Beinecke Library at Yale University after reposing there for almost 40 years, and will be put on the auction block.

title: PARTY CHIEF IS SAID TO REBUKE MAUREEN REAGAN
description: Vowing that ''she's never going to do that again,'' Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr, chairman of the Republican National Committee, harshly rebuked the co-chairwoman, Maureen Reagan, in private this week for her comments at a White House news conference, party officials said today.

title: THREE IN SECT CONVICTED OF BEATING TWO CHILDREN WHO REFUSED TO BEG
description: The leader of a religious sect and two of its followers were convicted yesterday in Queens on charges of beating two small children because they refused to beg for money.

title: Fyodor T. Gusev Dies; Wartime Soviet Envoy
description: Fyodor T. Gusev, a wartime Soviet envoy to Britain and Canada who also attended the Allied conferences at Yalta and Potsdam, has died, according to the Soviet press agency Tass.

title: HOUSE IN VOTE TO BLOCK FUNDS FOR THE CONTRAS
description: The House of Representatives voted today to suspend further aid to the Nicaraguan rebels until President Reagan accounts for the money provided so far by Congress and others.

title: CONGRESS PREPARING TO BLOCK A 2D STRIKE AGAINST THE L.I.R.R.
description: Legislation is being prepared in the House and Senate to prohibit or quickly halt a second strike against the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Q&A
description: Q.My rosewood table has white stains from water seeping from a plant saucer and a coffee mug. The stains look semitransparent. How can I remove them? A.This type of stain usually means that the water did not penetrate all the way through the finish. You may be able to rub it out with a rag moistened with denatured alcohol or a rag dipped in camphorated oil. If the stains persist, you can probably rub them out with a toothpaste containing ''extra brighteners'' (a mild abrasive).

title: U.S. Concern Seeks Japanese Contract
description: The Austin Company, an engineering and construction corporationn based in Cleveland, said it had reached an agreement on a joint effort with Kawasaki Heavy Industries of Japan to compete for contracts on the new $10 billion Kansai International Airport near Osaka. Lack of foreign participation in the island-airport project, billed as the most advanced airport in the world, has been a major trade problem between the United States and Japan.

title: MYERS, L E COMPANY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $25,337,000 from the extinguishment of debt for the quarter and year.

title: Injunction Granted In Drug Testing
description: Mandatory drug tests required by the National Collegiate Athletic Association are an unconstitutional invasion of privacy, a county judge in California ruled today in granting a preliminary injunction sought by a member of the Stanford University women's diving team.

title: EMIGRES APPRAISE GORBACHEV POLICY
description: When a Soviet journalist, Vladimir Morozov, defected to the West in October, he was asked about changes occurring under Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of openness.

title: VW Stock Off Sharply Again
description: The stock of Volkswagen A.G., the giant West German auto maker, plunged for the second consecutive day in the wake of the company's disclosure that fraudulent foreign exchange deals could cost it up to $259 million.

title: 'BLUE LEAVES' TO CLOSE
description: ''The House of Blue Leaves'' will close after the Sunday matinee at the Plymouth Theater, 236 West 45th Street. The revival of the play by John Guare opened at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater last March; it moved in April to the Vivian Beaumont Theater and then, in October, to the Plymouth. It was directed by Jerry Zaks and will have given 420 performances.

title: AFRICAN MUSEUMS FIGHT TO SAVE ART
description: Yaya Savane unlocked a door at the National Museum here and entered a musty storeroom filled from floor to ceiling with African masks.

title: KETCHUM & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $403,000 and $564,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; and a gain on the sale of a disposed segment of $1,300,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income d-Includes net from discontinued operations of $36,000 for the quarter and $70,000 for the 9 months; and tax credits of $138,000 and $368,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: JUDGE MAY LIFT TEXTBOOK BAN
description: A Federal district judge indicated today that he would temporarily halt his order banning 45 textbooks from Alabama's public schools.

title: COMPUTER SALE TO IRAN IS DEBATED
description: The Commerce Department expects to approve export licenses for the sale of computers to Iran, a move that has touched off a major conflict with the Pentagon, officials of both departments acknowledged today.

title: WHALE FOSSILS HIGH IN ANDES SHOW HOW MOUNTAINS ROSE FROM SEA
description: Scientists have found fossils of whales and other marine animals in mountain sediments in the Andes, indicating that the South American mountain chain rose very rapidly from the sea.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AS the cost of new housing climbs, more people become interested in doing their own building or remodeling. In response, publishers are turning out many new books on the subject. Here are some recent ones: Carpentry and Building Construction, by John L. Feirer and Gilbert R. Hutchings (Macmillan; $50; hard cover).

title: HUDSON BAY MINING & SMELTNG CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $18.6 million and $12.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively; and tax credits of $4.6 million for the quarter and $8.5 million for the year. c-Includes an extraordinary charge of $73.4 million for both the quarter and year; tax credits of $27.5 million and $32 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary gain of $500,000 for both the quarter and year. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is a unit of Inspiration Resources Corp.

title: THE BREWERS' TOM WHO?
description: Shortly after the Milwaukee Brewers opened spring training, a 39-year-old man wearing No. 42 on the back of his uniform walked toward the little Compadre Stadium clubhouse where several fans were waiting. To those fans, the face was friendly, but not familiar. And at 5 feet 11 inches and 178 pounds, he was smaller than most of the others in a Brewer uniform. ''What do you do here?'' one of the fans asked. ''I try to manage this club,'' Tom Trebelhorn said.

title: U.N. UNIT REJECTS FAULTING CUBA
description: An attempt by the United States to focus attention on what it says are human-rights violations in Cuba was rejected in a vote at the United Nations Commission on Human Rights today by a narrow majority of Soviet-bloc and third-world countries.

title: STUDENT DESIGNS BRIGHTEN LIBRARY
description: FOR the next two months, brightly colored elephants and exotic birds will hang from the rafters and cover the tabletops at the Jefferson Market branch of the New York Public Library in Greenwich Village.

title: WITH SEVERAL INQUIRIES UNDER WAY, SCANDAL IS FAR FROM OVER
description: The New York City corruption scandal that erupted a year ago, leading yesterday to the sentencing of former Deputy Mayor Stanley M. Friedman and, in a separate matter, the resignation of Bronx Borough President Stanley Simon, is anything but over.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $26,000 tax credit. c-Net income and after an $88,000 tax credit.

title: CATHOLICS SAY THOSE WHO WANT CHILDREN WILL INGORE EDICT
description: Heidi Plummer is a 40-year-old Roman Catholic who has been trying in vain to conceive a child with her husband, John, for more than a decade. Catholic or not, she said today, they will use whatever means it takes for them to produce a child, despite the Vatican's condemnation of virtually all technological methods of achieving conception.

title: POP: PAUL YOUNG PERFORMS
description: A YEAR and a half ago, the English ''blue-eyed soul'' singer Paul Young stood on the verge of major stardom in this country. Mr. Young, who had enjoyed a No. 1 hit with the Daryl Hall ballad, ''Everytime You Go Away,'' seemed to have it all -the baby-faced good looks of a teen-agers' idol, an excitingly acrobatic act in which he leapt from the rafters and twirled his stand-up microphone like a baton, and the technical command to sing with a nonstop vocal urgency.

title: MUSIC: GILLOCK IN NEW MESSIAEN WORK
description: THE organist Jon Gillock continued his services on behalf of Olivier Messiaen Tuesday night with the New York premiere, authorized by the composer, of Mr. Messaien's latest organ work, ''The Book of the Holy Sacrament.'' The performance took place on the ideally appropriate, massively Romantic organ at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Hughes-Baker Deal Close to Completion
description: The turbulent merger between the Hughes Tool Company and the Baker International Corporation neared completion today as Hughes said that its board voted Tuesday night to approve a modified Justice Department consent decree.

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''Do we stand with the forces of freedom or cave in to the forces of Communism?'' - Representative William S. Broomfield of Michigan. [ A10:6. ]

title: FRIEDMAN IS SENTENCED TO 12 YEARS IN CORRUPTION CASE
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader and once one of the most powerful political figures in New York City, was sentenced yesterday to 12 years in prison and effectively barred from politics for life for his role in the municipal corruption scandal.

title: Disciplined Over Disruption, Boy Hangs Himself in School
description: A 12-year-old boy who was disciplined for disruptive behavior at school hanged himself in a restroom later in the day, the police said.

title: SEAMAN FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are before a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid April 10 to shareholders of record March 20. The prior-year 9 months results are pro forma. Seaman went public in July 1985.

title: Man Found Hanged In Central Park
description: The body of an unidentified man, bound hand and foot, was found hanging by the neck from a tree in Central Park early this morning, the police said.

title: EVENTS: ANTIQUES, EASTER EGGS
description: Meadowlands Antique Show, Giants Stadium Club, Gate C, parking lots 15 and 16, Meadowlands Sports Complex, Route 3, East Rutherford, N.J.; 914-634-9663.

title: HOME SHOPPING NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
PULITZER PUBLISHING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
I.B.M. ENFOLDS MUCH OF ROLM
description: When I.B.M. bought the fiercely independent Rolm Corporation two and a half years ago, its top executives raced to Santa Clara, Calif., to assure the telecommunications company's employees that, despite rumors, they would not all be forced to wear starched white shirts.

title: AS NICKNAME FOR SCHOOL ON TV, 'ZOO' FAILS, TEACHERS ASSERT
description: The Bronx Zoo as the name of a New York City high school?

title: PATRICK PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $9.4 million. c-Net income

title: Icahn May End Bid for USAir
description: Carl C. Icahn is expected to drop his unsolicited bid for USAir, an industry source said yesterday, because he believes USAir has offered too much to buy Piedmont Aviation Inc.

title: DEAR ANN: ABOUT YOUR MOVE TO THE TRIB
description: Our next letter comes from Chicago:

title: HUNGARY'S PASSION: KEEPING UP WITH THE LASZLOS
description: When the Rev. Antal Kuklay came here 14 years ago, his house, part of a former monastery, was the only two-story building in the village. The fine, yellow 18th-century mansion in the rounded and curled Central European baroque style looked down on the peasant homes that stretch in neat rows along the straight main street and behind.

title: SIMON'S POLITICAL CAREER HAD A TRADITIONAL START
description: Stanley Simon's resignation yesterday in effect ended a political career whose rise - and fall - was tied closely to the old-style Bronx political machine.

title: DANCE: SUSAN FOSTER
description: ''GESTUARY'' was what Susan Foster called the work that Susan Foster and Dancers presented Sunday night at the Cunningham Dance Studio. Since Ms. Foster is a choreographer interested in semiotics, the theory of signs and symbols, her title is worth pondering.

title: INADEQUATE DESIGN AND TESTS FEARED IN U.S. COPTER CRASHES
description: A Navy helicopter may have been poorly designed and inadequately tested, leading to several major accidents in recent years, a member of the House Armed Services Committee said today.

title: OF CHAUVINISM AND CHIC IN THE WORLD OF DANCE
description: STAYING up late the other night, I started reading the classifieds in a recent issue of a dance publication. There I came upon an ad that nearly gave me insomnia for the rest of the night. A Middle Western company was seeking what it termed an ''artistic director/ choreographer.'' According to the ad, applicants had to have ''experience as principal in European company.'' What a requirement! Although not all successful directors or choreographers have also been star performers, I can understand the publicity value of hiring a former principal dancer. But why from a European company? Think of the people that specification rules out.

title: ANTITRUST RULES WAIVED TO ALLOW TALKS ON CUTTING AIRLINE DELAYS
description: In a move to reduce persistent airline delays, the Transportation Department yesterday gave air carriers immunity from antitrust regulations so that they could negotiate agreements to avoid peak-hour bunching of flights at seven major airports.

title: G.E. Manager Leaves To Run Taiwan Concern
description: James E. Dykes, the one-time director of the General Electric Company's semiconductor operations, is heading to Taiwan tomorrow to become president and chief executive of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturng Company.

title: INSIDE
description: Trade Issues Heat Up

title: As Landfill Runs Out, Composting Becomes a Better Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Visa Card in China
description: Officials of Visa International said the Bank of China would soon offer Visa charge cards to its clients in China. The company is designing a Visa card to be issued by the bank for use in China and abroad. Currently, no international credit cards are issued in China, officials said. Visa has been accepted in China since 1981 and is honored by about 1,000 merchants there.

title: LIONEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $5,799,000 reorganization costs while in Chapter 11. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $13,069,000 for the quarter and a gain of $17,387,000 from discontinued operations for the year; and an extraordinary gain of $19,186,000 for the quarter and the year includes a gain of $20,295,000 from tax loss carryforwards and other reorganization items.

title: 4 JERSEY TEEN-AGERS KILL THEMSELVES IN DEATH PACT
description: Four teen-agers - two sisters and two young men - killed themselves together today in a suicide pact, the authorities said.

title: SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Official's Daughter Cleared
description: A circuit judge has ordered the dropping of drug charges against the 34-year-old daughter of United States Representative Dan Rostenkowski because prosecutors failed to produce timely laboratory results on foil packets found in her purse. The Cook County associate judge, Mary Jane Theis, dismissed the charges against Dawn Rosten of Chicago on Tuesday.

title: POLITICAL NOVICE GETS ZORINSKY JOB
description: David Karnes, a 38-year-old Republican businessman, was appointed by Gov. Kay Orr today to fill the remaining 22 months of the United States Senate term of Edward Zorinsky.

title: YOUTH SUICIDE: A COMMON PATTERN
description: The four suicides yesterday by teen-age friends in Bergenfield, N.J., are in one respect a rare phenomenon, but in others part of a pattern increasingly found in communities throughout the country.

title: PAINTED PINE'S APPEAL
description: PAINTED pine furniture is warm, romantic and charming, in the opinion of Don Black, fashion administrator for home furnishings at Macy's. ''It goes with the country look, and it adds a note of color to a room,'' he added. Mr. Black traveled through England looking for the mid-19th-century furniture and, mostly through London antiques dealers, he found presses (the English word for storage cabinets), bureaus, night stands, beds, side chairs and mirrors. The painted designs range from small patterns to elaborate trompe l'oeil still lifes. An 1850 four-door pine press, left, has been painted with scenes depicting shelves holding a pheasant, fruit, dishes and wooden boxes. It is 88 inches high by 61 inches wide, and is $10,000. The 1850 bureau, below at right, embellished with a flower motif, is 40 inches high by 37 1/2 inches wide, and is $1,350. The 1860 bureau, below left, has its original paint, a brown-and-cream-colored striated pattern. It is 30 inches high by 42 inches wide, and is $3,200. At Macy's Herald Square.

title: Notes, Bonds Little Changed
description: Note and bond prices were little changed yesterday and remain entrenched in their narrow trading range that has prevailed during the last five weeks of quiet trading.

title: CLEANER TACTICS IN POLITICS URGED
description: Mindful that voter participation in elections is steadily declining, political leaders and lawmakers are trying to stop political campaigning that takes a negative tone, which they say is driving people away from the polls.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, MARCH 12, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Trash Fire on Museum Roof
description: A small rubbish fire broke out on the lower roof of the south wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night but caused no injuries and very little damage, fire officials said. The Fire Department received a report of the blaze at 7:56 P.M. and declared it under control less than an hour later. Fire officials said the rubbish had apparently been thrown from windows that overlooked the south wing roof. They said it was not clear how the blaze began, but that damage was confined to the surface of the roof.

title: IN ALBANY, TAX CUT IS GUESSWORK
