description: The problem in Albany is vexing: how to change the state tax code when nobody knows - whether they claim to or not -how much money the state will take in.

title: STAGE: 'NOAH,' A FLOOD STORY
description: ''NOAH,'' an opera by Michael Sahl and Eric Salzman now playing at the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged, 40 West 68th Street, is an agreeable entertainment built around the biblical story of the Flood.

title: The Future of Test-Tube Life
description: On the day in 1978 that a little girl named Louise Brown was conceived in a Petri dish in a British laboratory, humankind took an enormous step into the future. Nine years later, there is still no body of law to govern our residence there - nor are we really sure where to look for one.

title: CHILDREN TO PARENTS: YOU'RE DOING JUST FINE
description: American children believe that parents are doing a much better job of raising them than adults themselves do, a survey shows.

title: Constitution Was a Symbol to Douglass
description: To the Editor:

title: Goodyear-Loral
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it would receive a reduced sum of $588 million from the Loral Corporation for its aerospace unit. When Loral announced the transaction Jan. 12, it said it was paying $640 million for the Goodyear unit. Goodyear said the new price reflects adjustments for such items as pension and benefits provision, allocation of liabilities and asset valuations.

title: BANKERS GROUP TO FIGHT CURBS IN A SENATE BILL
description: Reeling from one of its worst legislative defeats in recent years, the commercial banking industry vowed today to seek the elimination of a key part of the wide-ranging bank bill passed by a Senate panel late Tuesday.

title: EX-LEGISLATOR DESCRIBES HER PAIN AND BITTERNESS
description: Until the end, Gerdi E. Lipschutz said yesterday, she expected to remain a New York State Assemblywoman, though deprived of a key committee post as punishment for her role in a fraudulent job scheme.

title: MUSIC: GERSHWIN GALA IN BROOKLYN
description: GALA celebrations are inherently problematic, especially when they're being taped for television. The quality of the star turns must be variable, and pacing is difficult to sustain. Given those built-in limitations, the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Gershwin Gala last night, which was taped for future telecast on the Public Television Service's Great Performances series, worked nicely enough for the audience - itself a fairly gala assemblage that had paid premium prices to honor George and Ira Gerswhin and, in the bargain, the academy's own 125th anniversary.

title: Sosnoff Says He Rebuffed Caesars
description: Martin T. Sosnoff, the New York investor, disclosed that on ''several occasions'' he refused offers from Caesars World Inc. executives to repurchase his 4.21 million shares in the hotel and casino company based in Los Angeles. Mr. Sosnoff has offered $28 a share in cash, or $375 million, for Caesars.

title: God and Ethic in Midtown
description: It was one of those meetings that are very much part of New York - a half-dozen people collected to talk to a hundred others in the middle of the day about something very important, but to which there were no real answers. This time it was ethics and although nobody really expected clear solutions, still a group of busy people had decided to spend a couple of hours talking about American ethical standards and what to do about them instead of going for a walk in the winter sun.

title: JACOB OLE JACOBSON
description: Jacob Ole Jacobsen, father of David P. Jacobsen, a former hostage in Beirut, died of natural causes Saturday. He was 92 years old.

title: HOURLONG 'FAMILY TIES'
description: OVER the years since it was created in 1980 by Gary David Goldberg, NBC's ''Family Ties'' has evolved from a series about a once ultra-liberal couple coping with the demands of a middle-class marriage to a show about their brash yuppie son celebrating the joys of making money. It helps enormously, of course, that young Alex P. Keaton is played by Michael J. Fox, an ingratiating 25-year-old actor who, between TV seasons, has won deserved attention in films like ''Back to the Future.''

title: The U.N. Today: March 12, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ITALY'S NEW WAVE OF FASHION CRESTS IN NATURAL CONTOURS
description: A major change in fashion is in the air here. It involves styles that are more supple and less complicated than they have been. Designers are experimenting with different forms in their attempt to hit upon just what will catch on, and those experiments are creating excitement as well as confusion.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: THE beginning of each year is the season of Academy Awards in more fields than film. In design and architecture, several publications single out the best projects done over the previous year. It is a time to acknowledge individual designs and to assess how they add up to larger trends.

title: Chemlawn Sale Talks Widen
description: The Chemlawn Corporation, the target of a unsolicited tender offer by Waste Management Inc., said today that it was discussing the sale of its business with other parties. The disclosure was made in a

title: METS SEE PHILLIES AS THE BIGGEST THREAT
description: If you ask the Mets which team in the National League East has the best chance of threatening them this year, they say the Philadelphia Phillies, the only team that had a winning record against the Mets last year.

title: Metro Matters; Friedman Points to a Need For Real Reform
description: The door to the Citisource Inc. office on Lexington Avenue was locked yesterday. The sign was partly taped over, but the brass showed even as the company's biggest stockholder, Stanley Friedman, was being sentenced to prison. Mr. Friedman may be going out of business, but the business of politics goes on.

title: THEATER: 'MIRACLE WORKER' WITH KAREN ALLEN
description: ''THE MIRACLE WORKER'' leads inexorably to that moment when Helen Keller discovers the relationship between words, sounds and images. The word ''water,'' in William Gibson's version of this inspirational story, is the key that unlocks the young blind girl's imagination. As the revival of the 1959 Broadway play begins at the Roundabout Theater, our attention is drawn to the water pump, sitting prominently on the apron of the stage and waiting to be used as the centerpiece in the climactic scene.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: NOT long ago, a friend told me that her husband's condition had been diagnosed, after months of doctoring, as Alzheimer's disease. He was brilliant, a walking dictionary. Now 53, he tries to say ''wife,'' utters ''life'' and it isn't a Freudian slip. She coaches him through telephone calls, signaling him - with big, propellerlike hand motions - when he should stop talking.

title: SHAKER SPIRIT
description: THE simplicity and grace of the Shaker philosophy is exemplified in many of the sect's accessories and furniture. Shaker pegboard and pegs, clothes hangers, towel racks, sconces, shelves, baskets, candlesticks and other accessories can be found in a catalogue from Shaker Workshops.

title: THE TONIC EFFECTS OF WATER, WHETHER IN A POND OR A FOUNTAIN
description: THERE are two kinds of water in gardens: the kind that looks easy (it runs or lies in a natural or apparently natural hollow in the ground), and the kind that is clearly making an effort. Ponds, streams, rills, lakes and cascades all belong in category one. Category two applies to pools, to hard-edged containers, to any water in a situation where it is obviously constrained by art, or, most emphatically, to fountains. Fountains are the antithesis of water's natural behavior. Versailles is full of them for that very reason. They are the hydraulic equivalent of fireworks.

title: Put a Percentage Premium on New Health Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY OPERA TO PERFORM IN TAIWAN IN DECEMBER
description: The New York City Opera announced yesterday that it would perform in Taipei, Taiwan, from Dec. 3 to 13. The company will participate in the opening of the National Theater and Concert Hall complex in Taipei, and will travel to Taiwan under the aegis of the Taiwanese Ministry of Education.

title: 5 JAZZ FANS ARE CONVICTED IN PRAGUE
description: Five advocates of cultural freedom on trial for refusing to disband their organization of jazz enthusiasts were convicted and sentenced today.

title: SOYINKA PLAY'S RUN IS CUT
description: Lincoln Center Theater has shortened the run of Wole Soyinka's ''Death and the King's Horseman'' at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, the theater's general manager, Steven Callahan, said yesterday. The play, which opened March 1 and was scheduled to run through April 5, will close after the evening performance on March 29. Lincoln Center Theater also announced that it would present Bill Irwin in his 1982 show ''The Regard of Flight'' at the Beaumont beginning April 7 for a three-week run.

title: AFGHANS DOUBTFUL ON SOVIET MOTIVE
description: The Afghan guerrilla movement says it is deeply concerned that the West may be deceived by the Soviet Union's recent statements in support of a negotiated peace in Afghanistan and withdraw support from the insurgency.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: IROQUOIS BRANDS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,167,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter; and the year also includes net from discontinued operations of $5,331,000 and a one-time charge of $1 million related to realignment of certain operations. c-Net loss d-After a gain of $366,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and net from discontinued operations of $2,164,000 for the year. The company said the year-ago figures are restated for comparative purposes due to the sale of its specialty food and alcoholic beverage segment.

title: Want to Run the Draft?
description: It is now a year since the Selective Service System has had a director, and no one seems to know when the Reagan Administration will find one.

title: Clemens's Fine Begins
description: The Boston Red Sox began fining Roger Clemens $1,000 a day yesterday and said the fine would continue until the pitcher returned to camp. ''He is in violation of his contract and the fine is in effect,'' said Lou Gorman, the Red Sox general manager. Clemens, the 1986 American League most valuable player and Cy Young Award winner, walked out during practice last Friday after negotiations for a new contract broke down. The Red Sox then renewed his contract for 1987, setting his salary at $400,000, or $100,000 less than they offered during negotiations. Clemens was seeking a two-year deal for $2.4 million. Randy Hendricks, one of Clemens's agents, reacted to the club's fine by announcing that Clemens's proposal would be increased $1,500 daily, starting yesterday, until an agreement was reached. Clemens earned $220,000 plus $120,000 in incentive money last year, his second full season with Boston.

title: BRONX CHIEF QUITS AND FRIEDMAN GETS 12-YEAR SENTENCE
description: The New York City corruption scandal deepened and dealt another traumatic blow to the Bronx Democratic organization yesterday as Borough President Stanley Simon resigned in the face of an impending indictment.

title: Anti-Rebel
description: Not everyone in Nevada is rooting for Nevada-Las Vegas to win the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, or so much as advance beyond the first round. For the state's sports bookmakers, every game the Runnin' Rebels win is money down the drain. That's because of a state law barring bets on Nevada's amateur teams, as well as a recent ruling by the State Gaming Control Board that extends the ban. Although wagers on the outcome of individual tournament games not involving U.N.L.V. are allowed, the bookies are prohibited from taking bets on any team to win the championship as long as the Rebels are in the tourney. Because pretourney bets on the eventual champion are especially popular, particularly with out-of-state visitors, the estimates are that U.N.L.V.'s participation could cut the usual $100 million tournament handle by from $5 million to $7.5 million.

title: DOCTRINE FOLLOWS YEARS OF DEBATE ON PROCEDURES
description: The Vatican's condemnation of test-tube fertilization on Tuesday follows a decade of rising concern around the world over the ethical implications of new medical technologies for assisting human reproduction.

title: Give Service Credits a Try
description: Americans have bartered ever since the Pilgrims and Indians traded tools, guns and beads for corn and furs. Now several communities are experimenting with the barter of services to help the elderly and disabled. Representative Ronald Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, would nurture the idea with modest Federal support. It deserves that and more.

title: McLain's Drug Story
description: Gary McLain, a starting guard on Villanova's 1985 national collegiate championship team, said he used cocaine during the Final Four tournament in Lexington, Ky., that season and was high when the team visited the White House for a reception. McLain, 23 years old, from Hempstead, L.I., told of his drug dependency and subsequent rehabilitation in a first-person story for the March 16 issue of Sports Illustrated magazine. McLain wrote the story with Jeffrey Marx, a reporter with The Lexington Herald-Leader. ''I had played well on coke, I had played bad on it,'' McLain said. ''It didn't seem to matter. So I did about a quarter gram of blow before the national semifinal in the bathroom of room 135 of the Ramada Inn, about three miles from Rupp Arena. In the locker room I was all quiet and subdued. Everybody was saying, 'You all right? You all right?' I said, 'Yeah, I'm with it.' But in the meantime, I'd gotten it in my head that if we lost it didn't matter. I just wanted the season to be over.'' McLain scored 9 points and had 2 assists as Villanova defeated Memphis State, 52-45. The Wildcats then upset Georgetown, 66-64, to win the national title, with McLain getting 8 points and 2 assists. McLain began the article by recalling the team's subsequent visit to the White House: ''I was standing in the Rose Garden, wired on cocaine. . . . President Reagan was welcoming my teammates and me at the White House and giving his little speech about how inspirational our victory was. And the cocaine had me floating in my own private world.'' McLain said he was treated for drug abuse at the White Deer Treatment Center in Allenwood, Pa., last summer after he had been dismissed from his job as a broker trainee on Wall Street. McLain, who admitted he smoked marijuana in high school, said he was not the only basketball player at Villanova who got high but did not identify the other players in his article.

title: Boxing Notebook; BIGGS'S TITLE SHOT IS LOST IN BEY BOUT
description: What has happened to Tyrell Biggs, the World Boxing Association's No. 1-ranked heavyweight?

title: Killer Gets 75 Years In '79 Purolator Case
description: A defendant in the $1.8 million robbery of a Purolator armored-truck depot in which three guards were killed was sentenced yesterday to from 75 years to life in prison.

title: POLITICAL CRISIS DEEPENING FOR NAKASONE
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone struggled today with a deepening political crisis that forced his Foreign Minister into a last-minute cancellation of a scheduled trip to the United States.

title: FITZGERALD LEAVES IRISH PARTY POST
description: Garret FitzGerald, architect of the British-Irish accord on Northern Ireland, resigned today as leader of the Fine Gael Party, a day after leaving the post of Prime Minister because his party was defeated in the general election last month.

title: FAIRFIELD PEAKING AFTER FRUSTRATING YEAR
description: The season started with their most productive player missing the first seven games with a broken right hand. When he returned, their biggest man missed the next five games with an ankle injury. But the most dramatic experience was still to come for Fairfield's basketball team.

title: STRIKES AND LOCKOUTS IN U.S. NOW ON THE RISE
description: For the first time this decade, strikes and lockouts are on the increase in the United States as unions are showing a renewed willingness to undertake work stoppages and employers are more willing to fight them.

title: JEWS AND EVANGELICALS TAKE DIFFERING STANDS
description: No other major religious group in the United States, including Protestant evangelicals and Orthodox Jews, has adopted an absolute theological stand against intervention in human procreation as outlined in the new Roman Catholic document, leading religious thinkers said yesterday.

title: HEINZ, H J CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
MERRILL LYNCH OFFICIAL NAMED IN $4 MILLION INSIDER SCHEME
description: The Government yesterday accused the head of international mergers and acquisitions at Merrill Lynch & Company and a foreign investor of insider trading. It said they made more than $4 million in illegal profits over two years.

title: TELEPHONE & DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,637,000 for the quarter and $4,679,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $720,000 for the quarter and the year.

title: Public Policy And the Ponies
description: Southern Methodist University's football scandal has so far been a private matter between S.M.U. and the National Collegiate Athletic Association, but it may not stay that way.

title: DANCE: THE FELD BALLET IN 'THEATER'
description: JAMES SEWELL is a young dancer but he knows how to command the stage. And he does that in Eliot Feld's ''Theater,'' performed by the Feld Ballet on Sunday afternoon at the Joyce Theater. In Mr. Sewell's moments alone onstage at the start of the ballet, his portrait of the pathetic Pierrot takes on a grandeur that is perfectly in keeping with the more modest role and ballet. Simian and heroic, muscular and frail, he is different yet the same as the character he plays in the ballet within a ballet in Mr. Feld's look at the lonely anguish of the artist. Pierrot's pain is narcissistic, but it is also so convincing in its simplicity that one almost cannot bear to watch.

title: ALARM RAISED ON GROWTH OF PHOENIX
description: Complaining of foul air and mounting traffic congestion, residents of this city in the Arizona desert, the nation's purest example of rapid urban growth in the past decade, are demanding limits on its heady pace of expansion for the first time.

title: EMPLOYERS FACE UP TO AIDS
description: Despite the soaring number of AIDS cases around the nation, most big companies have yet to confront the disease and the problems it brings to the workplace, health industry consultants and other experts say.

title: QUADRUPLE JUMP STILL A SKATER'S DREAM
description: To quad or not to quad. Brian Boitano says he will. Brian Orser says he will not.

title: M.A.C. Offers Refund Bonds
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York is offering $683 million of refunding bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 6.968 percent for an issue due in 2007, underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. said yesterday.

title: TRANSTECH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes loss from discontinued operations of $3,027,714.

title: VAL BJORNSON
description: Val Bjornson, who served for 22 years as Minnesota State Treasurer, died Tuesday of congestive heart failure in his home here. He was 80 years old.

title: KATY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued consolidated operations of $460,000 for the quarter and $11,344,000 for the year; and losses from the sale of discontinued consolidated operations of $200,000 and $4,960,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued consolidated operations of $5,364,000 and $11,637,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; a loss from discontinued unconsolidated operations of $5,488,000 for both the quarter and year; extraordinary gains of $490,000 for the quarter and $1,438,000 for the year, and the year also includes a gain on the sale of discontinued consolidated operations of $4,404,000. The company said year-ago results are restated.

title: MERGER MOTIVE FOR CHRYSLER
description: THE term ''good fit'' often crops up when one company explains why it decided to acquire another. In the case of the Chrysler Corporation's announcement this week that it planned to take over the American Motors Corporation, the phrase is particularly apt because Chrysler lacks the product that A.M.C. makes most successfully.

title: POSTAL SERVICE TO SEEK FIRST-CLASS RATE RISE IN '88
description: The United States Postal Service will seek an increase in the 22-cent price of a stamp for first-class mail sometime in 1988, a postal official said yesterday.

title: Nippon and Inland Discuss Plant Site
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation and the Inland Steel Company are negotiating to set up a previously announced joint venture in Indiana, a Nippon Steel spokesman said. Further details were not given.

title: PUTTING A HIGH GLOSS ON NEW YORK STYLE
description: ''DEAR SIR,'' a young student in Tokyo wrote to the restaurant designer Sam Lopata recently. ''I'd like to come study from you in America. I'm very serious.'' Mr. Lopata's work appears regularly in Japanese design magazines, not to mention American ones. Both Mr. Lopata and his New York colleague, the architect Peter Marino, have (quite separately) become part of the New York design Zeitgeist. They are hot. Both have developed international followings and tend to generate coverage - Mr. Marino for his lush interiors and stellar clients (including the designers Yves Saint Laurent and Mario Valentino); Mr. Lopata for his sometimes whimsical, sometimes serious restaurant interiors. Mr. Lopata has designed nearly two dozen restaurants in the past 10 years, including Joanna, Cafe Seiyoken, Prunelle, La Gauloise, Cafe Marimba, Pig Heaven, Batons, Safari Grill and Lox Around the Clock, as well as ''face lifts'' for Lutece and Chez Pascal. Though their specialties and styles are quite different, the designers reflect New York style circa 1987: Mr. Marino creates opulent fantasy worlds for prestigious clients, and Mr. Lopata, restaurants - fantasy environments for the rest of us. FOR SAM LOPATA, RESTAURANT AS THEATE

title: DETECTIVE DIES AND OFFICER IS WOUNDED IN BROOKLYN SHOOTOUT
description: A 60-year-old New York City police detective was shot and killed and another officer was seriously wounded in a gunfight with two burglary suspects they confronted in a Brooklyn apartment house yesterday, the police said.

title: N.F.L.-TV Pact Is Near
description: The National Football League may be close enough to agreement on a new three-year television package that the terms could be completed by the end of the week and announced early next week in Maui, the Hawaiian island where the club owners will be meeting.

title: CONCERT: THE GREGG SMITH SINGERS AT ST. PETER'S
description: THE Gregg Smith Singers sang music of living composers for the final concert in their annual series at St. Peter's Lutheran Church on Saturday evening - most of it difficult, unaccompanied and in English, much of it based on texts from the Psalms.

title: Wunderman to Handle New Optima Card
description: Now that American Express has revealed the existence of its new Optima card, it is possible to reveal that its agency for the introduction is Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, the Young & Rubicam direct-marketing specialty agency.

title: EXHIBITION OF 3 WYETHS OPENS IN LENINGRAD
description: An exhibit of three generations of Wyeth family artists opened here today minus one work - a James Wyeth study of the emigre dancer Rudolf Nureyev - that the Soviet authorities barred.

title: REGENCY CRUISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company did not begin operations until Nov. 17, 1985.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: AMERICA'S HEALTH IN THE BALANCE: Choice or Change? By Howard H. Hiatt, M.D. 252 pages. Cornelia & Michael Bessie/Harper & Row. $18.95.

title: LAMSON & SESSIONS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $8,326,000 and $9,494,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and the year also includes a gain of $4,726,000 from a change in accounting for a pension plan termination. c-Net income d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $639,000 for the quarter and $922,000 for the year; and a tax charge of $406,000 for the quarter and the year includes a tax credit of $296,000 and a gain on debt buyout of $13,325,000. The company said sales figures are adjusted to exclude discontinued operations.

title: Thick and Thin
description: Here are the current N.H.L. season's 10 best plus-minus ratings, calculated by determining the number of goals scored by a player's team when he is on the ice with his club at even strength or short-handed, and then subtracting the goals scored against when he is on the ice with his club at even strength or on a power play.

title: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $665,000 and $745,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes tax credits of $45,000 for the quarter and $88,000 for the 6 months. The company said the year-ago 6-month loss is after an increase in the provision for doubtful accounts of $1,500,000.

title: Mississippi Mayor Reverses Police Policy Based on Race
description: The mayor of this city of 200,000 people has ordered the rescinding of a policy announced three weeks ago by the police chief that officers could use race as a reason for stopping people in city neighborhoods.

title: South Africa Sanctions Shouldn't Include Arts
description: To the Editor:

title: 'STEPPING OUT' TO CLOSE
description: ''Stepping Out,'' the play by Richard Harris about nine women and a man who meet weekly for a tap-dance class, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Golden Theater. Directed by Tommy Tune, the play will have given 29 previews and 72 regular performances.

title: MUSIC: 'SECOND SPECIES' AT R.A.P.P.
description: THERE are some wonderful moments in ''Second Species,'' a work of music theater by Keith King and Skip LaPlante being presented at the R.A.P.P. Theater, 220 East Fourth Street. To quote Mr. King's extensive program notes: ''A great catastrophe has destroyed earth's electrical generating capacity and all the technicians who might have been able to re-create it. The inhabitants of this future society have found fragments of opera (tapes, scraps of libretti, programs, photographs, but no written music), which they attempt to understand by performing them.'' Since opera is already a world of myth and mystification for most spectators, in which music by dead composers from other lands is sung with hyperintensity by characters in funny costumes, ''Second Species'' just takes the confusion a little bit further.

title: TINY DIAMONDS IN SPACE SEEN AS CLUE TO EVOLUTION OF STARS
description: Microscopic diamonds, older than the Sun and the Earth and perhaps the oldest minerals ever examined, have been found imbedded in meteorites, scientists reported yesterday.

title: AEQUITRON MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: SHULTZ 'DISTRESSED' BY ISRAEL SPY CASE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today called the Israeli spy case ''very disheartening'' and said a decision by the Israeli Government to investigate would have ''a cleansing effect.''

title: Man Slain in Subway Brawl
description: Two men were fighting over a bottle of wine in the Spring Street station of the East Side IRT subway last night when one pushed the other onto the tracks causing him to be electrocuted when he struck the third rail, the police said. The incident occurred at 8:25 P.M., and shortly afterward, Jack White, 39 years old of 101 Bowery, was arrested and charged with second-degree murder in the death. The victim's identity was withheld pending notification of his family.

title: REAGAN FEIGNS LARYNGITIS TO AVOID QUERY
description: For the second day in a row, President Reagan pretended to have laryngitis today to avoid answering questions from reporters.

title: Yield Trend Is Mixed
description: With new clues to the economy's direction awaited, yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: THE STAGE: MICHAEL FRAYN'S 'DONKEYS' YEARS'
description: IN Michael Frayn's farce ''Donkeys' Years,'' the college chums who gather for a riotous 20th reunion in their old rooms at an illustrious English university represent a cross-section of upper-middle-class manhood viewed through a very jaundiced eye.

title: Night Trading Delayed
description: The Chicago Board of Trade said yesterday that it had postponed the inauguration of evening trading to April 30, from April 2. The board said the delay would give brokerage firms more time to prepare for evening trading. The session is scheduled to run from 6 P.M. to 9 P.M., central time. Initially, trading would be limited to Treasury bond and Treasury note futures and options.

title: Child Awarded British Couple Who Paid Surrogate Mother
description: A British couple who paid a surrogate mother to have a baby for them gained High Court approval today to adopt the child.

title: Student Admits Racist Act
description: A University of Michigan student who has admitted distributing a flier declaring ''open season'' on blacks will be evicted from his dormitory and banned him from campus housing, according to a university spokesman. The 19-year-old student, who was not identified, admitted Monday that he distributed the flier in January. The incident was one of several that prompted a legislative panel to hold hearings last week on charges of racism at the Ann Arbor campus.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $275,000 from costs associated with the closing of a store. c-After a pre-tax charge of $453,000 from costs associated with the grand re-opening of eight stores.

title: SALINITY LINKED TO FISH DEATHS
description: High salt levels caused by evaporation are believed to be responsible for the deaths of seven million small fish in a wildlife area 60 miles east of Reno, Federal scientists said Tuesday.

title: SLOW RISE FOUND IN PRISON AIDS CASE
description: The number of AIDS cases is rising more slowly among prison inmates than in the population at large, and indications thus far are that AIDS is rarely transmitted in prison, according to prison officials and medical experts around the country.

title: S.M.U. PLAYERS ARE ON THE MOVE
description: ''Hello, this is the home of Ricky Roden and Ken Grant. Ricky is 6-1, 215, linebacker, 4.6 speed and Ken is 6-6, 250-pound defensive tackle. We're ex-S.M.U. football players. We're looking for a school to go to, so if you're a coach or recruiter, leave your name, a number and the school you're with and we'll get back in touch with you. Thanks a lot. Beep.''

title: NOVO INDUSTRI A/S reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and have been computed at the Dec. 31 official Danish exchange rate of 7.3425 Danish kroner equals U.S.$1.00.

title: REPORT FEARS OVER-EXPLOITATION OF ANTARCTIC MARINE RESOURCES
description: Despite an international effort to avert over-exploitation of Antarctic marine resources, heavy commercial fishing, particularly by Soviet vessels, appears to have radically depleted some species, according to a newly completed American-Polish survey.

title: KOHL IS RE-ELECTED TO A SECOND TERM
description: Helmut Kohl was formally re-elected Chancellor of West Germany today as his center-right coalition concluded negotiations for a Cabinet and policies to guide the country for the next four years.

title: City Scandal: 4 Who Were Convicted
description: Stanley M. Friedman: The former Bronx Democratic leader was convicted of racketeering. The charges stemmed from his holdings in Citisource Inc., whose $22.7 million contract to design and produce hand-held computers for city traffic agents was canceled in January 1986.

title: U.S. SKIERS SEEK UPHILL TREND
description: This season, the performance of the United States Alpine Ski Team can be described only as dismal. When Tamara McKinney dropped out of the second run of the slalom at Zwiesel, West Germany, on Feb. 28, the last American chance for a World Cup title went with her.

title: CONTRAST TO ABORTION ISSUE IS DISCERNED
description: The Vatican's major doctrinal statement condemning a number of reproductive procedures and technologies seems unlikely to provoke as broad a political reaction as its stand against the Supreme Court's 1973 decision legalizing abortion, according to several political analysts and specialists.

title: RALPH HORNBLOWER Jr. DIES; LEADER IN BROKERAGE CONCERN
description: Ralph Hornblower Jr., former executive vice president of Hornblower & Weeks, which later merged with what is now Shearson-American Express to become the country's second largest brokerage firm, died Tuesday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Brookline, Mass. He was 68 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Not Only in Our Stars, but in Us
description: LEAD: Now that the Iran-contra scandal has added Ronald Reagan to the long list of recent Presidents who have met disaster, isn't it about time we finally got a grip on this Presidential problem?

title: Daiwa, With 7 Others, Wins Rockwell Notes
description: In an underwriting that piqued the interest of some securities dealers, Daiwa Securities America submitted the best bid for $200 million of the Rockwell International Corporation's 10-year notes, and offered the 7 1/2 percent issue at a price of 98 3/4 to yield 7.682 percent.

title: KEY RATES
Quarantine Modern Offices
description: LEAD: Ashtrays have been disappearing from offices at a startling rate, and perhaps next to disappear are the smokers. Before we're all shipped off to Siberia (surely the next step after New York State's antismoking laws take effect in May), it might be wise to ask a question lost amid the arguments between active and passive smokers:

title: 300 REPORTED DEAD AND 4,000 MISSING IN ECUADOR QUAKES
description: The International Red Cross said today that 300 people were killed and 4,000 missing in the two earthquakes and the floods that devastated the remote northeastern region last week.

title: 2 More P.&G. Products To Slater, Hanft, Martin
description: Slater, Hanft, Martin, already a Procter & Gamble agency, has picked up two more products, Dramamine and Icy Hot. The former is a motion sickness product, the latter a pain-relieving ointment. Already at the agency is Percogesic, an aspirin-free pain reliever. Billings for the products were not disclosed.

title: Stieb Starts Well
description: During the season, Dave Stieb would have been thrilled with the brevity of his pitching effort. But this was spring training. ''It would've been nice to throw a few more pitches,'' the Toronto pitcher said. ''But I at least got to throw one of everything.'' Stieb, in his first spring outing, worked three innings against Cincinnati yesterday in Tampa, Fla., and needed only 22 pitches to get nine outs. He threw one other pitch that Kurt Stillwell hit over the right-field fence. Stieb, who had a career-worst 7-12 record last season, played down the significance of his performance, but it heartened the Blue Jays because they need an effective and a healthy Stieb if they are to have a real chance to win the American League East title. ''At this point in spring training last year, my elbow didn't bother me,'' said Stieb, who was plagued all last season by a sore elbow. ''It didn't bother me until the end of spring training. I'll have to wait and see what happens.''

title: Safety's Price
description: The Straits of Dover were not stormy last week and winds reached no more than 20 miles an hour when the Herald of Free Enterprise tipped over and foundered with the loss of 134 lives. The tragedy at Zeebrugge, in other words, was no act of God. Barring some as yet undetected outside force, it is likely that the ferry's designers did not anticipate catastrophe from human error.

title: Among Democrats, the Trade War Has Begun
description: Trade policy has produced the first sharp exchange among Democratic Presidential hopefuls, and some party leaders are concerned that the issue could overshadow their efforts to put the Republicans on the defensive for their management of the nation's economy.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A music review on March 1, of the Chelsea Chamber Ensemble's program at Weill Recital Hall omitted the composer's name for one piece.

title: Britain Sentences 4 in Mafia
description: A Sicilian accused of heading the Mafia's London operations and three of his associates were given jail terms of from 22 to 25 years today after being convicted of importing heroin. The leader, Francesco Di Carlo, and the three others were arrested after customs officials found 132 pounds of the drug in May 1985.

title: SUBTRACTING ADDITIONS AND THEN BUILDING ANEW
description: LEAD: ANYONE who has bought a home knows that the house that seemed at the closing to need no work at all - not even decorating - shows unsuspected flaws after the move. The eye is more critical, and the urge to change things, to stamp the house as one's own, takes over.

title: Snag on Cutting Budget Confronts Democrats
description: Democrats on the House Budget Committee said today that they were having serious difficulty in assembling a package to reduce the projected Federal deficit by $36 billion, as sought by the Democratic leadership.

title: 113 Days Is Enough
description: My criticism of Nancy Reagan's successful media ambush of the White House chief of staff (Don Regan had the temerity to suggest that her husband hold a news conference) drew some attention.

title: HOW LAITY WILL BE TAUGHT
description: The teachings of the Vatican document on human reproduction will be disseminated among the nation's 52 million Roman Catholics through sermons, seminars, church bulletins and pastoral letters.

title: BROOKLYN FUEL DISTRIBUTOR PLEADS GUILTY IN TAX PLOT
description: A gasoline distributor pleaded guilty today to evading millions of dollars in state fuel taxes in what state officials called one of the largest gasoline bootlegging operations in the nation.

title: Youth Guilty of Murder In Newark Jacket Case
description: A 13-year-old boy was convicted today in juvenile court of murder in the January shooting death of a 15-year-old who was one of dozens of victims robbed recently of expensive bomber jackets.

title: AT CONTINENTAL AIRLINES, LEGACY OF WOES
description: People Express is gone, but its haunting legacy of lost luggage, lengthy delays and canceled flights lives on - at Continental.

title: DANCE: TAP OF 30'S AND 40'S
description: THE Gershwin era was the era of tap and it was the tap-dancers who really got it all down pat at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Gershwin gala. Along the way, the evening's dance component treated us to everything from Drew Barrymore playing Shirley Temple to Tommy Tune's Bill Robinson (both mouthing the words to ''Fascinating Rhythm'') to Mikhail Baryshnikov's fantasy-wandering among the ghosts of musicals past. Even Christopher Walken, with hair this shade of purple, did a ballroom number.

title: Mine Safety Agency Accused of Lax Enforcement
description: The Labor Department's coal mine agency was accused before the Senate Labor Committee today of sacrificing miners' lives through weakened enforcement of safety laws.

title: UNIFORCE TEMPORARY PERONNEL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding figures are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective June 30, 1986.

title: PIC 'N' SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
North and Poindexter Can Be Court-Martialed
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''It is wrong in our democratic country for our President to begin his war for democracy by keeping it secret from the American people.'' - Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, in the debate on contra aid. [ A10:4. ]

title: Photo of Michael K. Deaver (AP); JUDGE IN THE DEAVER CASE RULES LAW ON PROSECUTOR 'LIKELY' TO BE UPHELD
description: A Federal district judge held today that the law authorizing appointment of special prosecutors was probably constitutional, and he rejected Michael K. Deaver's effort to block an indictment.

title: PETROLEUM HEAT & POWER reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Remains of Condor Are Found Upstate
description: The fossil remains of a California condor have been uncovered from a site in western New York, the first such discovery in northeastern North America, officials of the State Museum announced yesterday.

title: 2 PANELS APPROVE IMMUNITY FOR KEY FIGURE IN IRAN CASE
description: The Senate and House committees investigating the Iran arms affair voted today to grant immunity from prosecution to a key figure in the scandal but withheld judgment about giving immunity to Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter.

title: Bible No Precedent
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE AIRWAVES, CONTRAS GAIN CONTROL
description: In rural Nicaragua, where radio is what ties people to the outside world, a new station at the far right of the AM dial is causing a quiet sensation.

title: FRENCH PRESS PLAN FOR CHEMICAL ARMS 881>
description: The Government of Prime Minister Jacques Chirac is proceeding with plans to develop new chemical weapons despite international efforts to ban them.

title: ABC'S '20/20' EXAMINES LOAN FRAUD
description: ABC's ''20/20'' is fascinated by scam, fraud and swindle; the predator preying on the gullible is a staple of its weekly report. Tonight at 10 o'clock, ''20/20'' looks at loan companies that don't make loans but that take money from borrowers instead. The process seems wonderfully simple.

title: Bus Crash Kills 12 in India
description: A bus carrying a wedding party collided with a van in western Rajasthan state today, killing 12 people, the United News of India reported. At least 20 others were injured, 7 seriously.

title: Qaddafi Said to Fault Shiite Group in Beirut
description: The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, was quoted today as criticizing the Shiite militant faction known as the Party of God, saying it posed a threat to the Arabs.

title: ITALY INDICTS 3 FOR AIRPORT ATTACK
description: The terrorist known as Abu Nidal and two other Palestinians have been indicted in the 1985 attack that killed 16 people at Rome's international airport, according to reports by Italian news organizations.

title: Pasqua's Career Is Now Booming
description: The day after Dan Pasqua launched his home run at Memorial Stadium in Miami, the Baltimore Orioles sent a public relations man to walk off the distance from the fence in right field to the sidewalk across the street, where the ball landed.

title: HISTORIC DELHI LOSING RACE WITH DECAY
description: Devastated by misuse, neglect, lack of money and unchecked urban sprawl, hundreds of ancient monuments here, one of Asia's richest centers of history and heritage, have decayed and crumbled, threatening to wipe out important strands of the region's turbulent past.

title: SOME SEEK TO TOUGHEN HOUSE'S NEW TRADE BILL
description: Supporters of a tougher trade bill said today that they would push for an amendment to tighten the provision in the proposed law dealing with nations that have large surpluses in trade with the United States.

title: Stock Prices Fall in Heavy Trading
description: Profit taking and programmed selling sent stock prices lower yesterday in heavy trading, but the decline came only after the Dow Jones industrial average made a valiant attempt to cross the 2,300 line for the first time.

title: Judge Picked in Zaccaro Case
description: Justice John S. Thorp Jr., an acting State Supreme Court Justice of Nassau County, has been assigned to the State Supreme Court in Queens. He will preside over the criminal cases against that borough's administrative judge, Francis X. Smith, and John A. Zaccaro, the husband of former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro. Judge Thorp replaces Justice Albert M. Rosenblatt of Dutchess County, who, as the new chief administrative judge, will oversee the New York State court system.

title: NUNN SAYS RECORD ON THE ABM PACT IS BEING DISTORTED
description: Senator Sam Nunn, a key Democrat on military and arms-control issues, charged today that the Reagan Administration had misrepresented the 1972 Senate deliberations on the Antiballistic Missile Treaty so as to support its new broad interpretation of the treaty.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 118, Suns 109: The Celtics erased a 6-point deficit by scoring 20 straight points in the fourth quarter, 10 by Kevin McHale, in Boston last night. Boston led for most of the game until late in the third quarter and gained its 65th victory in its last 66 games at Boston Garden. McHale led all scorers with 36 points. Bill Walton, sidelined all season with a painful right ankle, made his first appearance with 2:30 left in the first quarter. He had one rebound and no points before leaving early in the second period.(AP) Bucks 115, Bullets 107: Sidney Moncrief scored 18 of his 25 points in the second half to lead Milwaukee to its eighth straight victory. The defeat was the third straight for the Bullets, who played without their center, Moses Malone.(AP) 76ers 117, Bulls 108: Charles Barkley scored 31 points and David Wingate added a career-high 28 as Philadelphia withstood Michael Jordan's 49 points and defeated Chicago. The 76ers led, 103-92, with 3:48 to play but a 3-point shot by John Paxson sparked a 7-2 Chicago run that cut it to 105-99.(AP) N.I.T. Nebraska 78, Marquette 76: Brian Carr hit a 10-foot jumper with one second left to give Nebraska the victory in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament. Marquette's Kevin Johnson and Tony Smith each made a 3-point field goal in the final 53 seconds to tie. Bernard Day scored 18 points without missing a shot for Nebraska (18-11). (AP) Boise St. 62, Utah 61: Mike Sanor's rebound basket with 25 seconds left gave Boise State (22-7) the victory in an N.I.T opener. Utah ended the season 17-13.(AP) Washington 98, Montana St. 90: Greg Hill scored 11 of his 26 points in overtime to lead Washington (19-14) in an N.I.T. opener. Motnana State finished 21-8.(AP) N.H.L. Flames 6, Whalers 1: Colin Patterson scored twice and Mike Bullard added a goal and two assists for Calgary. (AP) Horse Racing Mo Hula Returns Mo Hula carried 117 pounds under David Nuesch to a front-running 3 1/4-length victory in the $40,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares at Aqueduct. Donut's Pride rallied late to be runner-up, a length ahead of What a Flip. The victory was the first in four starts this year for Mo Hula, who went six furlongs on the fast track in 1:11 1/5. Mo Hula, a Texas-bred 4-year-old daughter of Hula Chief and Slo Mo, earned $24,000 for her owner, Robert J. Bauer, and returned $9.00 for $2 as the second choice in the field of seven. The favorite, Dont Worry Bout Me, tired after chasing Mo Hula into the stretch and finished sixth.

title: VHC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $378,000 for the quarter and $715,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $75,809 for the quarter and $146,061 for the year. The results for 1985 periods include a reclassification of sales and expenses to account for the disposition of the company's remaining health food stores that were sold in June 1985; based on the reclassification, the company had no sales in 1985. VHC's results include the operations of its Maul Technology subsidiary from the acquisition date of Feb. 21, 1986.

title: BRIDGE: TWO TOP TEAMS ELIMINATED IN VANDERBILT KNOCKOUT PLAY
description: The second round of Vanderbilt Knockout Team play began here this afternoon with 32 teams in contention from an original entry of 60.

title: Victoria Sellers Gets Suspended Jail Term
description: Victoria Sellers, daughter of the late British actor Peter Sellers and the Swedish actress Britt Eklund was placed on three years' probation in Federal District Court here yesterday for her part in a cocaine smuggling ring.

title: NEW PRODUCTS FOR THE HOME GARDENER
description: Gardeners are usually eager to get busy outdoors (or in). Here are some new products to look for at garden suppliers, discount centers and hardware stores.

title: ISRAEL SETTING UP SPY CASE INQUIRY
description: After an eight-hour debate, the Israeli Cabinet announced today that it was setting up a two-member ''investigation commission'' on the Israeli espionage operation in Washington.

title: Turnstile Injustice
description: A few days ago, a friend met with a minor accident. He was starting a new job and in his anxiety to get to work on time he hurled himself against the subway turnstile before his token had released the steel bar. His thigh muscles and his amour propre were severely bruised.

title: Advice for Foreman
description: If George Foreman wants to fight again professionally in California, he will have to lose weight and find a better opponent. Ken Gray, the head of California's state Athletic Commission, said he does not want a repetition of Foreman's easy but sloppy victory over Steve Zouski Monday night in Sacramento. Foreman, the former heavyweight champion, was making a comeback after a 10-year retirement from the ring. Foreman, weighing 267 pounds, stopped Zouski, in the fourth round of a scheduled 10-rounder. ''We approved George on the basis of him being in a good physical state,'' said Gray. ''But before he fights again, I think I would have to talk to him about his weight first and also about facing a stronger opponent.''

title: RANGERS WIN IN DIONNE'S DEBUT
description: In the morning the Ranger players waited for his arrival, asking ''Where's Marcel?'' In the late afternoon they gathered at the Garden, asking, ''Is he here yet?'' And when he walked into the locker room at about 6 P.M., Don Maloney said, ''You could feel his presence.''

title: Air-Sole Introduced By Nike
description: THE first team from Nike was in town yesterday from Beaverton, Ore., bringing word of revolution and making plans to spread it.

title: HUNTER HARRIS Jr.
description: Gen. Hunter Harris Jr., former commander of Pacific Air Forces, died last Thursday. He was 77 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: History Lesson ''In Their Own Words: A Vietnam Chronicle'' is just that, a stage work that describes the war in the words of those who died in it and those who lived through it - at home and abroad. Betsy Lifton and Mindy Schanback wrote and adapted the work based largely on the oral history ''Nam,'' by Mark Baker, and ''Dear America,'' a collection of letters written by soldiers in Vietnam to friends and relatives. Ms. Schanback said the 75-minute show was produced with the cooperation of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Commission and was especially designed for high school and college students.

title: KEAN SIGNS BILL FOR $62 MILLION TO AVERT LAYOFFS
description: Governor Kean tonight signed a bill providing $62 million in additional urban aid to help cities offset the loss of Federal revenue sharing funds and avert the layoffs of hundreds of municipal employees, within minutes of its final passage.

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
William Lerner Dies; Record-Store Founder
description: William Lerner, the founder and president of Music Masters, a midtown Manhattan record store that has been a source of rare recordings for New York's music lovers, died of an immune system disorder Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. AND NICARAGUA ARE AT ODDS ON DOWNED PLANE'S MISSION
description: Drug Enforcement Agency officials said today that the cargo plane shot down over Honduras late Monday night had almost certainly been operated by drug smugglers.

title: ART: AT TWO GALLERIES, GERHARD RICHTER WORKS
description: IN a month that promises many outstanding gallery exhibitions, Gerhard Richter's double-header - at Marion Goodman (24 West 57th Street) and Sperone Westwater (142 Greene Street) - is already one of the best. It provides an excellent follow-up to his show of early work at the Barbara Gladstone Gallery in January.

title: A SHOW OF LICHTENSTEIN'S GENTLE DRAWINGS
description: THE first thing to be said about the retrospective exhibition of drawings by Roy Lichtenstein at the Museum of Modern Art is that very few people had a clear idea either of how large it might be or of what might be in it.

title: MEASURES OFFERED IN CONGRESS ON DETECTION AND CLEANUP OF RADON
description: Members of Congress today introduced legislation for a Federal program to help detect and deal with radon, a dangerous, naturally occurring radioactive gas.

title: DAYTON HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes earnings from discontinued operations of $9,000,000 and $2,100,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; a gain of $85,200,000 from the sale of the B. Dalton unit for both the quarter and year, and charges of $12,600,000 for the quarter and $32,300,000 for the year from the purchase and redemption of debt. c-Includes earnings from discontinued operations of $3,200,000 for the quarter and $3,100,000 for the year.

title: Luis Sanjurjo Is Dead; Agent to Many Writers
description: Luis Sanjurjo, literary agent for Arthur Miller, Tennessee Williams and Arthur Kopit, among other well-known American writers, died of cancer yesterday morning at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 45 years old.

title: Our Towns; Trash From L.I. Sits Uneasily In Upstate Dump
description: There is lots of money to be made hauling trash, if you can just find a cheap place to dump it. Landfills around New York City are piled high, and as they fill, dumping prices go up.

title: COURT REJECTS BID BY NORTH TO UPSET PROSECUTOR LAW
description: A Federal district judge today dismissed two lawsuits brought by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and authorized the special prosecutor in the Iran arms case to continue his investigation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 13, 1987
description: The Economy

title: REAGAN COUNSEL RECOUNTS CHAOS OVER IRAN AFFAIR
description: President Reagan's chief legal adviser today depicted scenes of chaos in the White House in recent months and said he had been prevented from looking into the Iran affair for several weeks after its disclosure last November.

title: US HEALTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said that results do not include $2.3 million in pre-opening membership sales from two new health facilities under construction.

title: Idle G.M. Plants
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would shut down a plant in Arlington, Tex., March 16-30 for inventory adjustment, affecting about 2,000 workers. Two other G.M. plants on temporary layoff are the Lakewood, Ga., assembly plant, which will be closed in early May for model change-over, and a Norwood, Ohio, plant, shut down March 9-23 because of material shortages. Separately, the Chrysler Corporation said it would put four assembly plants on overtime next week.

title: EMPIRE OF CAROLINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Beau Benny
description: Coach Benny Dees of the University of New Orleans, who learned much of his basketball as an Alabama assistant to bright-plaid-favoring Wimp Sanderson: ''I even have a jacket like his, only the batteries are getting a little weak.''

title: SUICIDES PUT 'BURNOUTS' IN SPOTLIGHT
description: On their last night alive, Lisa and Cheryl Burress turned to their closest friends.

title: METS' BAT-BRATS REMAIN FEISTY
description: Will success spoil ''the brats'' who trigger the Mets' offense?

title: FOSTERING WOMEN'S CAREERS
description: Now that women are entering the work force in record numbers, what can corporations do to make sure that they have the same opportunities for career advancement that traditionally have been available to men?

title: PARRISH AGREES TO JOIN PHILLIES
description: The Philadelphia Phillies and the Major League Baseball Players Assocation reached an agreement today that allows Lance Parrish, the free-agent catcher, to join the team in spring training Friday.

title: CANADIAN INQUIRY CRITICIZES TIMES REPORT ON JOSEF MENGELE
description: The Government inquiry into the presence of Nazi war criminals in Canada today criticized a report in The New York Times in January 1985 that said that Josef Mengele, accused of complicity in 400,000 deaths at the Auschwitz concentration camp, was reported to have made an application in Buenos Aires in 1962 for a visa to enter Canada.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday misstated the effect on the Dow Jones industrial average when one of its 30 components splits its stock. The denominator used in calculating the average is adjusted.

title: Critics of 'Amerika' and of 'The Day After'
description: To the Editor: There is a disturbing similarity in the complaints made against two politically provocative ABC television productions, ''The Day After'' (1983) and ''Amerika'' (1987). Both the right-wing critics of ''The Day After'' and the left-wing critics of ''Amerika'' tried, through publicity campaigns, to intimidate ABC into reversing its decision to produce and broadcast these shows.

title: Stop Pakistan's Nuclear Bomb
description: For years, Pakistan has lied to the United States about not having a nuclear weapons program, and for years the United States has bought the fiction. It has continued to provide military and economic aid to retain influence on Karachi. Now, intelligence reports show that Pakistan stands at the threshold of nuclear capability, and Washington can no longer escape a hard choice.

title: DEBATE IS SHARPENING OVER ALTERNATIVES TO PRISON
description: A combination of factors - led by the sharp increase in drug cases in New York in the last year - has renewed and sharpened debate over how society punishes its criminals.

title: FILM: AUSTRALIAN POLITICS IN LAWRENCE'S 'KANGAROO'
description: D.H. LAWRENCE spent only two days in Sydney, Australia, when he arrived there in May of 1922. Yet he wrote several chapters about Sydney in ''Kangaroo,'' the novel about Australia that he composed at a breakneck pace. Though Lawrence had no plans to document his Australian sojourn, he wound up writing 150,000 words in five weeks' time, giving his book an undeniable urgency. But the film version of ''Kangaroo'' is more staid, a calm and decorous work with a plot of no overwhelming interest. The one fiery thing about it is Judy Davis's performance, as a character modeled on Frieda Lawrence, the author's wife.

title: BROADWAY
description: IF it's living in the past to have a spectacular production on Broadway with beautiful girls, tuneful songs and natural homespun humor, then so be it. For they will very likely be some of the ingredients of a musical being whipped up by Peter Stone (book) and Cy Coleman, Betty Comden and Adolph Green (score). It's called, at this point, ''Ziegfeld Presents Will Rogers,'' and it's not actually being whipped up - it's being slowly simmered and has already entailed many, many months of work. Even under the best of circumstances, it probably won't go into rehearsal until early next year.

title: ROBINSON SCORES 50 BUT IT'S NOT ENOUGH FOR NAVY
description: At one end of the court workmen struggled to fix a rim bent by the dunk that provided the final points in Michigan's convincing 97-82 victory over Navy in the first round of the East Regionals tonight. At the other end the star of the game, indeed of the college season, took his final bows after scoring 50 points in a losing effort.

title: DOW SLIPS 1.64 AS OTHER INDEXES RISE
description: Stock prices closed mixed yesterday on Wall Street after the small gain in blue-chip stocks that had survived until very late in the session evaporated when Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, expressed new concerns about the economy and inflation.

title: Invited Observers From NATO Watch a Polish Army Exercise
description: Observers from NATO watched today as the Polish Army conducted war games, the first time in 11 years that Westerners were allowed to attend.

title: DATAMETRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes income of $123,500 and $179,000 for the latest quarter and year-ago period, respectively, from the reduction of federal income taxes arising from carryforward of prior year's operating loss.

title: A View of a Law
description: William French Smith, the Attorney General who has had the most experience with the special prosecutor law since it was passed in 1978, does not mince words when asked how it has been working. Replying to questions from a Senate subcommittee that plans to hold hearings next week, he said in a recent letter that the law was ''probably unconstitutional.''

title: NEVADA-LAS VEGAS AND U.C.L.A. GAIN
description: Freddie Banks scored 23 points, including seven 3-point field goals, and Gary Graham had 18 points as top-ranked Nevada-Las Vegas routed Idaho State, 95-70, today in a first-round West Regional game.

title: HUNGARIANS MOVE TO LIMIT DISSENT
description: Hungary is taking a tougher stand against leading figures of a small but vocal group of critics of the Communist regime who have ''gone too far'' and become ''insolent,'' according to an official with close ties to the Communist Party Central Committee.

title: Witching Hour Curbs
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today asked for tighter procedures for next week's experiment in smoothing out stock price swings on ''triple-witching-hour'' sessions.

title: Bail Is Denied Suspect In Killing of Detective
description: The man accused of killing a detective and wounding a police officer in a shootout Wednesday was arraigned last night and ordered held without bail.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Two days after he played a key role in Seattle's double-overtime 136-127 victory over the Houston Rockets, the SuperSonics have signed Eddie Johnson, a guard, to a second 10-day contract to replace the injured Terence Stansbury. . . . Following four straight losing seasons, including a 7-16 record this season, St. Francis College of Loretto, Pa., has released Kevin Porter, who played 11 years in the N.B.A., as its basketball coach. Porter, who played at St. Francis from 1968 through 1972, had coached his alma mater to a 42-68 record.

title: Ex-Justice in Israel Bars Role In Forum on the Pollard Case
description: A former Supreme Court president refused to take part today in a two-member forum being formed to examine the Jonathan Jay Pollard spying case, and a prominent lawyer later accepted an appointment to replace him.

title: BRITISH TELECOM PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results reported in pounds sterling have been expressed in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $1.48 to the pound, the rate prevailing on Dec. 31, 1986, the last date of the reporting period. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR) and each ADR represents 10 shares of British Telecom ordinary stock.

title: Ford Incentives For Popular Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would offer sales incentives on its popular Taurus and Sable models for the first time. ''Sales are still strong, but we have to meet the competition,'' a Ford spokesman, Bill Carroll, said. The costly incentive programs, largely abandoned last fall, have become more widespread than ever, and are now being offered by Japanese and West German auto makers.

title: PROVIDENCE ROLLS; ILLINOIS FALLS
description: Tony Raye hit two free throws with two seconds to play to give Austin Peay a 68-67 upset of 11th-ranked Illinois in a Southeast Regional opening-round game tonight.

title: Stores in Area Report Gains
description: After several lackluster months, New York City's retail sales surged in February, averaging a 10.3 percent rise from February 1986, according to a monthly spot-check. Sales in the metropolitan area, including the suburbs, rose an average of 11.4 percent, the highest monthly gain in years.

title: COPLEY PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company began operations after its initial public offering July 29, 1985. Therefore, its annual data are not directly comparable.

title: CHIEF AT NL RESIGNS; SIMMONS TAKES POSTS
description: Theodore C. Rogers resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of NL Industries, an oilfield services company that has been reporting losses in the oil economy slump.

title: DISTANT GALAXY FOUND TO BE LARGEST KNOWN
description: Astronomers say they have discovered that a galaxy observed by astronomers for two decades is 13 times as big as the Milky Way and others of average size. This would make the galaxy, Markarian 348, the largest known.

title: SPRING BREAK BRINGS BLUES TO FORT LAUDERDALE... AS WARY PALM SPRINGS BRACES FOR ONSLAUGHT
description: Recalling the rampage by hundreds of unruly students at the spring break last year, officials of rich and conservative Palm Springs are offering a handshake to visiting students this year, one with a viselike grip.

title: HOUSES UNIT APPROVES TRADE BILL
description: A House Ways and Means subcommittee today unanimously approved a toned-down trade bill that would require the President to retaliate against unfair trade practices.

title: DOLLAR GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Courts Rejected Claim in 'Ivan' Trial
description: To the Editor: Both your report on the defense at the trial in Israel of John Demjanjuk, accused of being the guard called Ivan the Terrible at the Nazi death camp at Treblinka, Poland (Feb. 18), and the Washington Talk page article on Patrick J. Buchanan (Feb. 19), who says Mr. Demjanjuk is a victim of mistaken identity, repeat defense claims, including one that the Russians forged an identification card to implicate Mr. Demjanjuk.

title: Give Her a Break
description: To the Editor: As a Walter Mondale-Geraldine Ferraro Democrat who considers the Reagan Administration corrupt and undemocratic, I make no brief for Nancy Reagan. However, I think she is taking a bum rap (front page, March 4).

title: Fieldcrest Cannon Offering 6% Issue
description: Fieldcrest Cannon Inc. is offering $110 million of 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2012, at par through Kidder, Peabody & Company as the sole underwriter.

title: MISTRIAL DECLARED IN A SUIT AGAINST 10 OFFICERS
description: A mistrial was declared today in a $605 million lawsuit that accuses city police officers of supressing evidence in the 1976 killing of a reporter, Don Bolles, and the judge ordered the 10 defendants to hire new lawyers.

title: A DAY AFTER SUICIDES, BERGENFIELD FOCUSES ON PREVENTING MORE
description: The day after four youths committed suicide together here, the Police Department today set up a suicide hot line telephone number, the Volunteer Ambulance Corps opened a 24-hour walk-in crisis center and high-school officials established counseling centers and support groups for students.

title: A QUEENS SHRINE TO TANGO'S PARAGON?
description: With its framed news clippings and memorabilia, Abel Malvestiti's basement is a virtual shrine to tango, his living room a side altar.

title: TWO FIFTHS
description: Mstislav Rostropovich will conduct the New York Philharmonic in two ambitious symphonies by Russian composers - the Symphony No.5 by Tchaikovsky and the Symphony No 5 by Prokofiev - tonight and tomorrow night at 8 in Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets are $7.50 to $35; information: 874-2424.

title: A JERSEY CITY WAREHOUSE NOW WATERFRONT HOUSING
description: The explosive development going on in Jersey City is perhaps best symbolized by Newport, a 250-acre complex spawning some 1,500 apartments in four towers, plus a sprawling shopping mall. But smaller developers are also active there, to capitalize with more modest projects on the potential of the waterfront and the view of Manhattan.

title: These Priorities Hold Water
description: Mounting suspicions to the contrary, there are still some collegiate athletic programs where academics aren't considered merely a time-consuming annoyance. One is the swimming program at Hendrix College in Conway, Ark.

title: RESTAURANT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $99,000 from operating loss carryforwards.

title: Why Do All Those Homeless Families Have to Be in Manhattan?
description: To the Editor: Mayor Koch's Task Force on the Homeless has recommended that New York City reduce the concentration of homeless people in Manhattan. But the city continues to fight in court for the right to house homeless families in squalor and despair in the midtown south area of Manhattan.

title: EASING OF CURBS ON BELL UNITS FOUGHT
description: A coalition of major communications trade groups said today that they would oppose Reagan Administration efforts to let the regional Bell Telephone companies offer long-distance and electronic information services and manufacture telephone equipment.

title: RAUCH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
G.A.O. SAYS 4 GOVERNMENT REACTORS OPERATED AT UNSAFE POWER LEVEL
description: Four Government nuclear reactors that produce plutonium for bombs have been operated for most of the last seven years at a power level substantially higher than what the emergency cooling system could handle in an accident, the General Accounting Office told a Senate committee today.

title: FILM: 'EVERYTHING FOR SALE'
description: THOUGH Andrzej Wajda's career has had its ups and downs, his position as Poland's premier film maker remains secure. He stunned the international film world with his early movies, including ''A Generation'' (1954), ''Kanal'' (1956) and ''Ashes and Diamonds'' (1958), and then, in the mid- to late-60's, went through a lean period in which he seemed to be making movies about everybody's concerns except his own. With ''Landscape After Battle'' (1970), Mr. Wajda rediscovered his own voice and sense of direction, and has gone on to make the more recent, mature masterworks ''Man of Marble,'' ''Danton'' and ''A Love in Germany.'' All this is said by way of warning about ''Everything for Sale,'' the 1968 Wajda film that opens today at the Public Theater.

title: IMPLANTED DEVICE FOUND TO CUT HEART DEATHS
description: Permanently implanted electrical devices that jolt the heart back to normal rhythm can dramatically reduce the death rate in people who are known to be at high risk of heart seizure, new studies have shown.

title: ART: AL HELD'S TAXIS, A WATERSHED FROM '59
description: IN 1959, in the spaciousness and light of the studio of Sam Francis, Al Held attached photographic paper to the walls and painted four works that would signal his break with Abstract Expressionism. The paint was acrylic. The color was not mixed, as it tended to be in Abstract Expressionism, but black and white and the three primaries. Form was not ambiguous but geometric. Taxicabs were the metaphor used to describe the color, energy and down-to-earth content the artist was after.

title: MICHIGAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $4,600,000 and $14,429,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,870,000 and $13,083,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Cannon Group Sells Film Archive
description: The Cannon Group said today that it had agreed to sell its Screen Entertainment film library to the new studio venture headed by Jerry Weintraub, the former chairman of the United Artists Corporation.

title: FLIGHT INTERNATIONAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss and includes operations of Intercredit Corp., which were presented on a consolidated basis prior to its sale. The revenues for the year-ago quarter and 9 months included $400,000 and $2,227,000, respectively, from operations of Intercredit, a subsidiary that was sold in April 1986.

title: AT MARIST, 7 FEET IS NOT TALL ENOUGH
description: Rudy Bourgarel had made a decision on where he was going to play college basketball. He had been leaning toward Villanova, which had just won the national championship, but decided that a 7-footer from a foreign country would be expected to do too much too soon.

title: U.S. Ambassador Tells Of Talks With North
description: Faith Ryan Whittlesey, the United States Ambassador to Switzerland, has told investigators that she had telephone conversations with Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, a key figure in the Iran arms affair, but she has denied any role in the affair.

title: SIMON INDICTMENT IS EXPECTED NEXT WEEK
description: A Federal grand jury is scheduled to take up the indictment of former Borough President Stanley Simon of the Bronx when it reconvenes Monday but is not expected to consider charges against two other Bronx politicians for at least another week, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Disney in Europe
description: The Walt Disney Company has named Robert J. Fitzpatrick president of Euro Disneyland, a theme park and development project Disney plans to build near Paris. Mr. Fitzpatrick's appointment will be effective when a definitive agreement is signed by Disney and the French Government. Mr. Fitzpatrick is president of the California Institute of the Arts and is director of the Los Angeles Festival. Before joining the institute in 1975, he was dean of students at Johns Hopkins University, and he served for four years on the Baltimore City Council.

title: Goldhirsh Plans to Sell High Technology
description: The Goldhirsh Group of Boston, the publishing company whose output includes the highly successful Inc. magazine, plans to sell its High Technology magazine to the Biotech Capital Corporation of New York, whose holdings including a majority interest in the Financial News Network on cable television. Details of the purchase agreement are being withheld.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN CHURCHMAN URGES MORE PRESSURE ON PRETORIA
description: A South African church leader has called for continued international pressure on the South African Government to negotiate with opponents of apartheid in his country.

title: Board Approves Zoning In Guggenheim Plan
description: Community Board 8 voted on Wednesday night in favor of the Guggenheim Museum's revised plan for an addition to its building at Fifth Avenue and 89th Street in Manhattan, by a count of 21 to 8.

title: TONY LAMA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Critics of 'Amerika' and of 'The Day After' Lincoln on Invasion
description: To the Editor: In ''The Real Lesson of 'Amerika' '' (Op-Ed, March 1), Benjamin R. Barber updates a theme Abraham Lincoln advanced in 1838. Lincoln said: ''From whence shall we expect the approach of danger? Shall some trans-Atlantic military giant step the earth and crush us at a blow? Never. All the armies of Europe and Asia . . . could not by force take a drink from the Ohio River or make a track on the Blue Ridge in the trial of a thousand years. No, if destruction be our lot we must ourselves be its author and finisher. As a nation of free men we will live forever or die by suicide.''

title: APPEALS COURT RULES AGINST DR. GROSS ON ISSUE OF AUTOPSIES
description: A state appellate court said today that autopsies are medical procedures and may therefore be the subject of medical misconduct charges, overruling an appeal on behalf of the Chief Medical Examiner for New York City, Dr. Elliot Gross.

title: IN GERMANY, BIER MAY BE BEER OR BIERE
description: It was a black day for tradition-minded German beer drinkers, and in the high-vaulted back room of the 200-year-old Fruh Tavern the waiters huddled in a taut cluster discussing the decision handed down this morning by the European Court.

title: Cole Porter Tribute
description: ''Night and Day - A Salute to Cole Porter,'' a free series of performances and films, continues this weekend in the atrium at the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue and 53d Street. Jon Hendricks and Company are the featured performers. Also scheduled to appear are the singers Barbara Lea, Daryl Sherman and Judy Niemack; the pianists Jane Jarvis, Arthur Siegel and Ronny Whyte, and Richard Sudhalter and his group. Performances are today at 12:30 P.M. and tomorrow and Sunday at 5:30 P.M. In addition, tonight at 7, the film ''Can Can'' will be shown. The series will run through March 29.

title: CB&T FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Irish Culture Is Focus Of All-Day Celebration
description: A daylong celebration of Irish culture, featuring videos, lectures, music and discussions, will be held tomorrow at the Loeb Student Center of New York University, 566 La Guardia Place, at Washington Square South. The event is to run from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. and is a benefit for the Gaelic Society at the university.

title: FILM: CONTI IN 'GOSPEL,' A COMEDY
description: THE Blessed Edith Semple is causing a commotion at a parochial school in Glasgow named for her. One group, led by the school's baby-faced chaplain, is campaigning for her canonization, but discovers that the Vatican is not in the market for miracles just now. A church official expresses admiration for the Blessed Edith because she performed her solitary wonder around World War I and hasn't bothered anybody since: ''One nice little miracle - and then off.''

title: M.T.A. PANEL URGES CHARGE AGAINST OFFICER IN STEWART DEATH
description: A Metropolitan Transportation Authority committee recommended yesterday in a majority report that a transit police officer face departmental perjury charges in connection with the 1983 death of Michael Stewart. The panel also suggested changes in procedures for investigating charges of police misconduct.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: Congress had hardly passed sanctions legislation last year, over President Reagan's veto, when opponents began pronouncing it a failure. White South Africans were withdrawing into the lagger, the critics said; sanctions were stiffening resistance to change.

title: Diner's Journal
description: BROADWAY theatergoers in search of a stylish spot to have a light meal and a drink before or after the show might stop by the dramatic bar at Palio, the Italian restaurant on the ground floor of the Equitable Assurance Tower at 151 West 51st Street. The lofty room with a spacious square bar surrounded by cafe tables is dominated by a bold and animated mural by Sandro Chia depicting a traditional horse race called the Palio, in the plaza of Siena, Italy.
