A small menu of appetizer-size plates is served from 5 P.M. until midnight Monday to Saturday, including a soothing polenta with sausage ($8.50), beef carpaccio with mushrooms ($7.50), herb-stuffed mussels ($6.50) and artichoke lasagna ($9.50). There is also an interesting selection of about 20 wines, mostly Italian, by the glass, in the $4 to $7 range.

title: Tokyo Stocks Surge
description: The Tokyo stock market vaulted to record heights for the third consecutive day today as investors poured in funds, convinced that the bull market would continue. The 225-share market average shot up 157.24 points, to a closing record of 21,470.20, after earlier rising to 21,474.68.

title: REALTOR'S ADS AIMED AT SELLERS
description: WEICHERT Realtors of Morristown, N.J., which considers itself the largest independent residential real estate company in the nation, used plenty of advertising to get there. But it has always advertised to reach buyers.

title: A Letter to William H. Webster
description: LEAD: Dear Bill, Thanks for being willing to take the job at the Central Intelligence Agency. The nation needs you there badly. There will likely be months of difficult investigations ahead, but I would like to suggest that there can be opportunity in the adversity.

title: Perle Is Bowing Out, His Goals and Acerbity Intact
description: Richard N. Perle, a staunch opponent of past arms control agreements with the Soviet Union and one of this city's most accomplished bureaucratic infighters, will leave office this spring, having accomplished his two main policy objectives: He has helped keep the Reagan Administration from concluding new agreements he deemed unsound and he has helped keep it from observing the old ones he was against from the start.

title: INTELLIGENT SYSTEMS MASTER LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains of $3,525,000 for the quarter and $3,784,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations; the quarter also includes a pre-tax charge of $2,403,000 for reorganization expense. c-After gains of $271,000 for the quarter and $731,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations. d-Net loss The year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations. Intelligent Systems changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from March 31 coincident with its conversion to a master limited partnership.

title: James Stewart, Natural for a Tribute
description: HAVING produced fond tributes to Judy Garland, Fred Astaire and Spencer Tracy, David Heeley and Joan Kramer of Channel 13 have now turned their attention to James Stewart. Made in association with MGM/ UA Television Productions, ''James Stewart: A Wonderful Life'' - a ''Great Performances'' presentation at 9 this evening - is yet another celebratory album, crammed with fascinating photographs and clips from the past, bursting with compliments from friends and colleagues, including Ronald and Nancy Reagan. It must also be added that no other movie star quite so easily elicits the genuine sincerity required for a heartwarming salute as Mr. Stewart does.

title: The Good Project Democracy
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver North borrowed the name of an overt, Congressionally mandated project to bless his own covert activities and thus created a good deal of confusion. In messages about his Iran-contra operations, he repeatedly boasted of their connection to ''Project Democracy'' or ''Prodem,'' his grandiose term for the privatized war games in Central America. That is also the term used to describe the National Endowment for Democracy, a constructive public initiative to help democratic institutions abroad through private, non-governmental efforts.

title: PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $887,000 and $304,000 from the sale of investments for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Killer Returned to Idaho
description: Claude Dallas Jr., the convicted killer of two game wardens, was returned to Idaho in shackles and handcuffs today and arraigned on a felony escape charge. Mr. Dallas, who was on the most-wanted list of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was captured Sunday in Riverside, Calif., a year after escaping from the Idaho State Penitentiary where he was serving a 30-year term.

title: RICHARD LEVINSON, 52, WRITER OF TEVELSION MYSTERY SERIES
description: Richard Levinson, one of television's most prolific and respected writers, died of a heart attack yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 52 years old.

title: Marlowe Play
description: Christopher Marlowe's ''Jew of Malta'' will be presented by the Classic Theater through April 5 at the Shakespeare Center, 165 West 86th Street. The play, written in the mid-1500's, has rarely been produced professionally because of objections that it is anti-Semitic. Owen S. Rackleff will star in the production; the artistic director of the theater company, Maurice Edwards, is the director. Performances are today and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 7 P.M. Tickets are $8; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Information: 877-6810. Reservations: 242-3900.

title: LANDS' END INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: The 1987 and 1986 net income and share earnings are on a pro forma basis.

title: BOOTHE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said results for 1985 have been restated to reflect the recognition of tax benefits attributable to the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.

title: 'BLACK AND WHITE,' BY CLAIRE DEVERS
description: CLAIRE DEVERS'S ''Black and White,'' which opens this year's New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art, is most notable for its cool and businesslike approach to the bizarre. It concerns a nondescript accountant named Antoine (Francis Frappat) who is hired at a less-than-fashionable health club. Along with the job comes free use of some of the facilities, and Antoine, who is white, attracts the interest of an extremely taciturn black masseur.

title: CONTINENTAL GENERAL INSURNCE COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $155,410 and $192,896 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes gains of $12,879 for the quarter and a loss of $315,763 for the year. The company said 1985 share earnings results are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid April 1986.

title: AN EXCITED CROWD ANTICIPATES A THEATER EVENT
description: Mayor Koch, who said it was the first Broadway opening he'd been to in years, already knew the words to all the songs from listening to the tape in his car. ''I expect it to be the best show I've ever seen,'' he said.

title: Four Wheeler Magazine Tries Out 5 New Titles
description: Penthouse's Four Wheeler magazine, with a circulation exceeding 220,000, will publish five additional one-shot titles for newsstand sale this year. If the books prove popular, they will have their publishing frequency increased. They are the 4x4 Answer Book, Trucksports USA, Monster Trucks IV, All W/D Car Guide and Light Truck Buyer's Guide.

title: Valves to Be Replaced At Costly Power Plant
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation will replace the problem-plagued safety valves at the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant with an older kind of valve used in all but a handful of the nation's nuclear reactors, company officials said today.

title: INDIANA TROUNCES FAIRFIELD
description: Playing before a partisan crowd that it obviously didn't need, top-seeded Indiana built a 25-point halftime lead and rolled to a 92-58 victory against Fairfield tonight in a first-round game of the Midwest Regionals.

title: EATON VANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A FESTIVAL OF NEW FILMS WITH GLOBAL OBSESSIONS
description: THE theme of obsession - of individuals struggling to transcend psychic, political and esthetic cul-de-sacs - runs like a dark, charging current through many of the 20 feature films in the 16th annual New Directors/New Films series that begins this evening at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Why Do All Those Homeless Families Have to Be in Manhattan?; A  [ check ]  for Compassion
description: To the Editor: Leaving Lincoln Center the other night, I saw a man lying under the steps near Alice Tully Hall, wrapped only in a thin coat to protect him from the freezing temperature. I am sure many New Yorkers who witness the plight of such homeless people feel the same frustrating helplessness I did.

title: LA SALLE BEATS VILLANOVA AT THE BUZZER
description: Lionel Simmons scored 21 points, including a running jumper at the buzzer to give La Salle an 86-84 victory over Villanova tonight in a first-round game of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: A Limit to Aquino's Honeymoon
description: LEAD: Corazon C. Aquino's bloodless revolution in the Philippines last year captured the imagination of the world. Main Street America was agog, Congress gave her more aid than the Reagan Administration had requested and the media virtually canonized her.

title: An $8,000 Golfing Bill
description: How much does it cost the Government when Secretary of State George P. Shultz goes golfing for a weekend? More than $8,000 is the answer, but the bill is not always paid on time.

title: BEL FUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SYSTEM SOFTWARE ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NEW LINE CINEMA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Massimino Speaks Out
description: The Villanova basketball coach, Rollie Massimino, expressed disappointment and sorrow yesterday over his former guard's ''personal tragedy,'' saying ''I never knew about Gary McLain's drug problem and if I had known there was no way he would have kept playing for me.''

title: WILTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest quarter includes tax credits, but amounts were not reported.

title: PRECISION AEROTECH reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary item of $176,000 which represents the unamortized discount on notes payable to former stockholders of a subsidiary of the company which were retired from the proceeds of the company's initial public offering on Nov. 7, 1986; the extraordinary item, which is both non- cash and non-recurring, caused an 8 cent decrease in earnings per share for the 9 months ended Jan. 31, 1987.

title: GROUNDWATER TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
U.S. IS DEMANDING WIDE VERIFICATION FOR A MISSILE PACT
description: The United States proposed in Geneva today elaborate verification measures that the Reagan Administration will insist the Soviet Union agree to before signing any treaty removing American and Soviet intermediate-range nuclear missiles from Europe.

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,360,000 from discontinued operations. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared in December 1986.

title: KODAK LAB FOR ROCHESTER
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the giant photographic and chemical concern that has expanded into pharmaceuticals and information processing, said today that it would invest $200 million in a large color film lab.

title: TELEPHONE SUPPORT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Golden Parachutes and Other Board Room Flimflam; Cowboys of Capital
description: To the Editor: Your report on the major impact insider trading scandals will have on the financial community (front page, Feb. 15) fails to address the root questions: What has caused this outbreak of potentially destructive fraud and greed, and what, if anything, should our lawmakers do about it?

title: Taft Broadcasting
description: The Narragansett Capital Corporation and Dudley S. Taft, vice chairman of the Taft Broadcasting Company, said they planned to continue efforts to acquire the Cincinnati-based company. Taft rejected their $145-a-share offer on Wednesday, and also directed Goldman, Sachs & Company, its investment banker, to explore alternatives including a possible restructuring. In response, Dudley Taft and Narragansett said they were confident that Taft's board would act to resolve current ''unstable situations'' as quickly as possible.

title: YALE'S KUDELSKI A ONE-MAN SHOW
description: A one-man hockey team might be a fantasy but Bob Kudelski is reality. He is almost the entire team for Yale, which meets St. Lawrence in the semifinals of the Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey tournament Friday night at Boston Garden.

title: Children Return to Mothers
description: Three children found in a park here last month have been returned to their mothers, members of a commune in the Washington, D.C., area. But a judge said three other children might need some form of state supervision and scheduled a hearing for March 23 to determine their fate. The four boys and two girls were taken into state custody after they were found, dirty and insect-bitten, in the park.

title: SURE SIGN OF PURIM: HAMANTASCHEN
description: For days, bakers have been wrestling with mounds of sticky dough, spooning out poppy seeds and dipping into pots of prune filling. These are the standard ingredients of hamantaschen, the three-cornered pastries that will be served during the Jewish festival of Purim, which begins at sundown tomorrow.

title: FOLK MUSIC OF ISLANDS IN A CHURCH
description: THE stuff of journalism -news and opinions, human-interest stories and gossip, memoirs and satire - has also been, from time immemorial, the makings of songs, a way for communities to transmit and reflect what's happened to them. From European troubadours to West African griots to New York rappers, rhymes and rhythms have turned communiques into grassroots art -and around the Caribbean, into dance music.

title: FILM: SPALDING GRAY'S 'SWIMMING TO CAMBODIA'
description: IT would be wrong to think of ''Swimming to Cambodia'' as a one-man show, even though it captures the performance of a single artist, Spalding Gray, as he sits alone on an almost empty stage. For one thing, Mr. Gray's feature-length monologue brings people, places and things so vibrantly to life that they're very nearly visible on the screen. For another, this is a two-man undertaking, one that shows off both Mr. Gray's storytelling talents and Jonathan Demme's ability to frame them. This film's arrival in the wake of Mr. Demme's pioneering concert film ''Stop Making Sense'' and his jubilant, anarchic comedy ''Something Wild'' completes quite an amazing triple play.

title: ART: WORKS BY BROTHER OF GRIMMS
description: TO the tens of millions reared on their fairy tales, the Brothers Grimm were two, Jakob and Wilhelm. Grammarian and literary scholar respectively, they were born in the German kingdom of Hanover (1785-1786), and achieved their joint immortality while still in their 20's. Jakob was 36 years old when he made a separate reputation by formulating the law, named for him, that elevated linguistics to a science.

title: WOODY HAYES, FIERY COACH, IS DEAD
description: Woody Hayes, the hot-tempered football coach who built Ohio State into a perennial national power and then saw his career end in disgrace after he struck a Clemson player during the 1978 Gator Bowl game, died in his sleep Wednesday night at his home in the Columbus suburb of Upper Arlington, Ohio.

title: Canada Trade Surplus
description: Canada's trade surplus was cut sharply in January by a steep fall in auto exports, official figures from the Government agency Statistics Canada showed today.

title: Lehrman to Join Morgan Stanley
description: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. said yesterday that Lewis E. Lehrman was joining the firm as a senior adviser and a director of Morgan Stanley Asset Management.

title: Cyclops Bidder Makes New Offer
description: A group that lost a bidding war for the Cyclops Corporation last month said it was proposing a higher offer aimed at foiling a $365 million purchase agreement by Britain's Dixons Group P.L.C. The Cyacq Corporation, a group including Audio/ Video Affiliates, Citicorp Capital Investors and others, said it would pay about $9 million more than Dixons for Cyclops, a diversified Pittsburgh-based company. But it said the higher offer was conditioned on the rejection of key parts of Cyclops's agreement to merge with Dixons.

title: HIGH BOSTON LEADER OF ORGANIZED CRIME GETS 30 YEARS IN JAIL
description: Ilario M. A. Zannino, said to be the second-highest-ranking figure in organized crime in New England, was sentenced in Federal District Court today to 30 years in prison.

title: T CELL SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BURST AGRITECH INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $49,700 for a contingency for bad debt expense and a one-time charge of $53,320 for an inventory obsolenscence expense.

title: AUCTIONS
description: CARRIE ESTELLE DOHENY'S collection of rarities -a Gutenberg Bible Old Testament, a Button Gwinnett autograph, a first edition of ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' inscribed by Samuel Clemens to his wife, Livy - will be auctioned by Christie's in a series of sales over the next two years. Mrs. Doheny's holdings of 15,000 rare books, manuscripts and autographs, described by Christie's as one of the largest and most valuable offered at auction in recent years, are expected to bring a total of $20 million. These works will be dispersed in eight sessions in New York, London and Los Angeles.

title: PUBLIC-INTEREST PERMITS URGED FOR TV
description: United States Representative from Ohio, speaking outside the offices of CBS here with a newswriters' picket line as a backdrop, suggested today that television networks be licensed ''for a commitment to the public interest.''

title: The Bigger Bore
description: Mayor Koch, a natural performer, will host and star in a weekly television talk show entitled ''Koch on Call.'' He should do well, since he is never at a loss for words. But sometimes his words deserve to be lost. In discussing his forthcoming show, the Mayor could not resist taking another swipe at John Lindsay, who also hosted a television show when he was Mayor. ''I hope I do it better than Lindsay did his,'' the Mayor said. ''He was boring.''

title: SWEDEN PLANS BAN ON PRETORIA TRADE
description: Sweden announced today that it would ban all trade with South Africa and criticized the United Nations for not imposing mandatory international sanctions to force Pretoria to end apartheid.

title: BIAS BY CLUBS ATTACKED BY CAROLINA LEGISLATORS
description: Discrimination by private country and social clubs, for years a quietly accepted sore point among Jews and blacks, is now a matter of public debate in the state capital, and some state officials are seeking ways to force integration.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Host Leads Guest by a Shot: Brad Faxon, who lives only a mile from the Bay Hill Club course in Orlando, Fla., had five birdies over the 7,103-yard course yesterday as he shot a five-under-par 66 and took the first-round lead by a stroke in the Hertz Bay Hill Classic. Steve Pate, who is staying at Faxon's house this week, came in at 67. That tied him with David Frost of South Africa. SLED-DOG RACING On a Record Pace: Duane Halverson and Jerry Austin were fighting for the lead in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race in Alaska and setting a record-breaking pace yesterday as the race neared the halfway point. Halverson, and Austin left McGrath 15 hours earlier than the lead musher left last year. By Wednesday evening, 16 of the 60 mushers remaining as the race reached McGrath, a town 409 miles from the start. (AP) SPEED SKATING American Clinches Title: In Inzell, West Germany, Bonnie Blair of the United States clinched the 500-meter speed skating World Cup title by winning the last race of the season yesterday in 39.85 seconds. (AP) HORSE RACING Last Laugh: Comedy Tonight slipped through between horses after entering the stretch and then outfinished favored Curtin in posting a 2 3/4-length victory in the $27,000 allowance feature at Aqueduct yesterday. Comedy Tonight carried 117 pounds seven furlongs on the fast track in 1:24 3/5 under Robert Thibeau Jr. to record his first victory of the year in five starts. Curtin finished three lengths ahead of Placid Waters. Comedy Tonight earned $16,200 for his owner-trainer, Robert Ewalt. The California-bred 5-year-old returned $28 for $2 to win. N.H.L. Bruins 6, Blues 4: In Boston, Ray Bourque scored twice in the first 10 minutes and assisted on another first-period goal as Boston stopped the Blues' seven-game unbeaten streak last night.(AP) Penguins 6, Nordiques 3: Dan Frawley scored early in the third period and Mario Lemieux set a career high for goals with a hat trick that raised his season total to 51. (AP) N.B.A. Cavaliers 116, Suns 109: In Richfield, Ohio, Ron Harper scored 32 points, including two free throws that capped an 11-point run late in the fourth quarter last night as Cleveland snapped a five-game losing streak.(AP) TENNIS Navratilova and Temesvari Lose -The defending champions, Martina Navratilova and Andrea Temesvari, were upset yesterday in the opening round of the Women's Team Championship in Marco Island, Fla. Lori McNeil and Bettina Bunge of Monte Carlo defeated Navratilova and Temesvari, seeded first, 1-6, 6-0, 6-3, after losing the first set and falling behind, 0-30, in the second.(AP)

title: Depaul's Guards Are Ailing
description: At a time of the season when talent and timing are all important, DePaul, the Midwest Regional's third-seeded team, is concerned that one of its star players will not be at full strength when the Blue Demons play Louisiana Tech Friday night.

title: Texas Prisons Closed Again
description: The nation's third-largest state prison system, deluged by more than 700 new inmates over two days, was closed today for the sixth time in as many weeks because the population had again exceeded the legal limit. The 26-unit Texas Department of Corrections had 38,420 inmates Wednesday, 10 inmates over the cap established by state law, said a spokesman, David Nunnelee.

title: VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pretax credit of $718,423 representing the excess of the assets in a terminated pension plan over the cost of paid-up annuities covering benefits earned by employees.

title: BAN ON TEXTBOOKS APPEALED
description: The State Board of Education voted 5 to 4 today to appeal the decision of a Federal district judge who banned 44 textbooks from Alabama's public schools on the ground that they were promoting ''secular humanism'' as a religion.

title: BATTLE IN OKLAHOMA OVER BANKING POST
description: Robert Y. Empie, who was suspended Tuesday from his post as Oklahoma's bank commissioner, plans to fight in the state courts to regain his job.

title: PACIFIC NUCLEAR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: FILM: 'EVIL DEAD 2: DEAD BY DAWN'
description: TALES of demonic possession are common, but the clever creators of ''Evil Dead 2:

title: SOUTHERNNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Day-Care Center Worker Gets 165 Years in Child Sex Abuse
description: A Mount Vernon day-care center employee was sentenced today to a total of 165 years in prison on 17 charges stemming from sexually abusing seven young girls in his care.

title: KURZWEIL MUSIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter results include about $200,000 of special engineering expenses to develop components for new products.

title: Suit Challenges Tests In Pentagon Research
description: An environmental group has filed suit against the Defense Department in an effort to block Pentagon research into the effects of high-power electromagnetic pulse, a wave of electrical energy that is released by a nuclear explosion.

title: CARS PUSH RETAIL SALES UP BY 4.1%
description: Auto dealers saw buyers return in strength in February, and other retailers posted modest gains that month as retail sales over all rose by a healthy 4.1 percent, the Government reported today.

title: SENATE BACKS COSTA RICAN PEACE PLAN 881>
description: As the Democratic leadership tried today to set the tone for the debate next week over continued aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, the Senate put itself on record as supporting the Central American peace plan of President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica.

title: BIDS FOR HARPER & ROW SPUR PUBLISHING STOCKS
description: Publishing stocks came to life yesterday.

title: SCHOLAR SAYS HIS VIEWS ON JEWS COST HIM A POST AT STANFORD
description: A lawsuit by a British scholar who contends he was denied a professorship because Jewish faculty members considered his work ''insensitive'' toward Jews and ''unacceptably defensive'' of Polish gentiles in World War II has raised unusual issues of academic freedom at Stanford University.

title: Manley Leaves Hospital
description: Dexter Manley, the Pro Bowl defensive end from the Washington Redskins who was second last season in the National Football Conference with 18 1/2 quarterback sacks, was released from Georgetown University Hospital yesterday. He was admitted Wednesday night for what his wife said was an alcohol-related problem.

title: Hanged Man Called Suicide
description: An unidentified man whose body was found hanging from a tree in Central Park early Wednesday, bound hand and foot, is believed to be a suicide, the police said yesterday. A wallet containing $7 was found in the victim's pocket, but it held no identification papers. The man was described as black, 30 or 32 years of age, wearing a black and white sweater, a blue jacket with hood, tan pants, a white and green plaid shirt and grey leather shoes. His body was discovered near The Lake off Transverse Road and West 72d Street. No note was found.

title: BIDS TO FILL SIMON SEAT ARE STARTED
description: Candidates for borough president of the Bronx began seeking support among political leaders and City Council members yesterday in a contest that reflects the political power of the black and Hispanic voting majority in the borough.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MARCH 13, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Scandinavian Airline Bid
description: Denmark, Norway and Sweden have offered to let United States airlines set their own fares between the three countries and the United States if Scandinavia's S.A.S. airline is allowed greater access in America, a Danish transport ministry official said today. Talks are now under way in Washington after a United States request for the freedom to set fares, which now must be approved by the governments involved.

title: Mitchell in Treatment
description: There was shock in San Antonio yesterday over the news that Mike Mitchell, the Spurs' leading scorer the last two seasons, had voluntarily checked himself into the N.B.A.-sanctioned substance abuse center in Van Nuys Calif. By turning himself in, Mitchell, a nine-year pro, avoided the league's mandatory career banishment for players found guilty of substance abuse without seeking treatment.

title: EASTPARK REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains on sales of real estate investments of $933,000 and $970,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After a loss of $137,000 and a gain of $1,257,000, for the quarter and year, respectively, on sales of real estate investments.

title: SOUTHWEST REALTY LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Interest Rates Hold Steady
description: The Treasury securities market strengthened yesterday, although bill rates and prices of coupon issues finished virtually unchanged. Dealers attributed the market's improved tone to its expectations, later proved correct, that the weekly and monthly money supply figures would not rise.

title: INERTIA IS UNUSUAL FOR HASSEY
description: The Yankees played the Chicago White Sox at Payne Park today, which meant that Ron Hassey was in uniform. But which one?

title: 'Sometimes I Say Things Differently'
description: In an interview, Richard N. Perle reflected on his 25 years in Government. Following are excerpts:

title: HERE'S TO NELSON AND HIS BRIDE AND TO NEVIS, TOO
description: Two hundred years ago, on a flawless, sunny afternoon, Adm. Horatio Nelson, one of Britain's greatest naval commanders, married the daughter of a colonial judge on this speck of a Caribbean island.

title: HEALTHSOUTH REHABILITATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company had its initial public offering in September 1986.

title: ANN C. MERSEREAU
description: Ann C. Mersereau, a Manhattan school district superintendent in the 1970's, died of cancer Tuesday at her home in Teaneck, N.J. She was 65 years old.

title: M.T.A. PICKS NEW SUBWAY CARS FROM JAPAN OVER A CONSORTIUM
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority decided yesterday to switch to another manufacturer, Kawasaki of Japan, for the final order of 200 R-68 New York City subway cars.

title: Prudential Plans Real Estate Unit
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America plans to set up a nationwide network of more than 1,000 franchised real estate offices that may eventually provide financial services, a company official said. The move follows the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's acquisition of the Century 21 Real Estate Corporation in 1985. In addition, Sears, Roebuck & Company bought the nation's largest real estate brokerage company, Coldwell Banker, in 1981.

title: O.M.B. Backs W-4A Form
description: The Internal Revenue Service said today that it had been given the green light by the Office of Management and Budget to begin printing and distributing its new W-4A form, a simplified version of the four-page W-4 employee tax withholding form introduced last November.

title: AC&R's New TV Spot For Beautiful Fragrance
description: The attractive woman is first seen entering an airline terminal, then aboard a commercial jet, then in a convertible auto zipping along a highway in the Western desert. Suddenly, the picture in this television commercial goes from vibrant color to sepia and the woman is out of the car and transformed into a bride of a century ago. A young man in western garb appears, dismounts from a surrey and, drawing close, kisses her gently. The bridegroom, obviously.

title: ENSECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $342,000 for the quarter and $1,175,000 for the year. c-Net income The 1986 figures are after charges of $209,472 in the quarter and $2,542,472 in the year for nonrecurring merger costs relating to the company's merger with California Analytical Laboratory Inc.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: Something is beginning to stir among ruling whites in South Africa. It is just a crack in the oppressive structure, but it matters because time is the critical dimension. Change will come, the question is only whether or not it awaits explosive disaster.

title: NORTHWEST ILLINOIS BANCORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Anheuser-Busch Sets 8.593% Debenture Yield
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies is offering $150 million of 8 1/2 percent sinking fund debentures, due in 2017, at a price of 99 to yield 8.593 percent. The underwriters are led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: Bid Solicitor For Purolator
description: The Purolator Courier Corporation said today that a member of its board had resigned in order to solicit competing bids for the air-freight concern. The director, Dorsey R. Gardner, is president of the Boston-based Kelso Management Company. The Purolator board has already accepted a $268 million leveraged buyout proposal from a group of Purolator executives led by E.F. Hutton LBO Inc. As part of the buyout agreement, Purolator agreed not to authorize directors or officers to seek other offers.

title: NOBEL INSURANCE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $799,000 and $1,526,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $317,000. d-Net income

title: NETS PLAY SPOILERS IN DOWNING BUCKS
description: The Nets are headed for the National Basketball Association lottery as one of the seven nonplayoff teams. But before that happens, the Nets are likely to have something to say about the positioning of the playoff-bound teams.

title: HEALTHDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes for the year an extraordinary tax credit of $235,000.

title: EVERYTHING MESHES AS RANGERS ROLL
description: Phil Esposito, who has schemed and dreamed and redone his team with all his trading, was smiling tonight at his new version - make that his newest version - of the Rangers.

title: Golden Parachutes and Other Board Room Flimflam
description: To the Editor: Richard R. West's defense (letters, Feb. 22) of golden parachutes, leveraged buyouts and, by inference, greenmail hardly qualifies as the serious thought about these activities he urges on others, including columnist A. M. Rosenthal.

title: ROSE'S STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in October. The company said that results for the year-ago fourth quarter are restated, but results for the full year remain as reported last year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Chicago dispatch yesterday about the advice columnist Ann Landers gave her name incorrectly. In high school she was known as Eppie Friedman; she married Jules Lederer, from whom she is now divorced.

title: Duos at the Big Dance
description: Fourteen schools sent teams to both the men's and the women's N.C.A.A. Division I basketball tournaments this year. Here's the list, with the schools ranked according to their combined winning percentage.

title: HERLEY MICROWAVE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PETRUCCIANI QUARTET
description: The pianist Michel Petrucciani will lead a quartet - Jim Hall on guitar, Ron Carter on bass and Al Foster on drums - Tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $21 cover and a $7 minimum tonight and tmorrow, a $10 cover and a $6 minimum Sunday.

title: 'Juno and the Paycock'
description: Sean O'Casey's ''Juno and the Paycock'' will be presented by the Thomas Davis Irish Players for the next five weekends at the Mazur Theater, Murphy Center, 555 East 90th Street. The play, set in the 1920's, tells of the fight for Irish independence. The theater company was founded in 1933 to produce works by Irish and Irish-American playwrights. Performances are Fridays and Saturdays at 8 P.M. and Sundays at 3 P.M. Tickets are $10. Information: (718) 767-4048.

title: Article 897687 -- No Title
description: The Houston Chronicle, the dominant newspaper in a fiercely competitive market and Texas's largest daily, will be acquired by the Hearst Corporation, a Hearst spokesman announced yesterday.

title: CANADA TO TRY NAZI SUSPECTS
description: The Canadian Government decided today to amend the criminal code to allow for the prosecution in Canadian courts of people charged with Nazi war crimes.

title: SOUTHLIFE HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $925,576 and $1,776,341 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $577,389 and $797,932 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE images in ''Man Facing Southeast'' are disturbing.

title: GENETIC ABNORMALITY SEEN AS LINK WITH ALZHEIMER'S
description: An abnormal duplication of a minute piece of genetic material may contribute importantly to the cause of Alzheimer's disease, destroyer of the minds of more than a million Americans, scientists in the United States and France reported yesterday.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS PLAN TO REQUIRE DATA DEVICES ON COMMUTER PLANES
description: Contending that the Government ''has failed to act responsibly'' on flight recorders for commuter airliners, a House Appropriations subcommittee has approved legislation directing the Federal Aviation Administration to require the devices immediately on all such planes.

title: Forbes Magazine Quits Publishers Association
description: Forbes magazine resigned from the Magazine Publishers Association last month, according to a source close to that publication.

title: FILM: FROM ARGENTINA, 'MAN FACING SOUTHEAST'
description: DR. JULIO DENIS, a member of the psychiatric staff of a large Buenos Aires hospital, works too hard, which has begun to take its toll on his career and private life. His wife and children have left him. At the end of the day, Julio returns to his lonely apartment, looks at movies of a home life he no longer has, drinks too much Scotch and plays the saxophone.

title: A CHEMICAL SECTOR RUNS INTO TROUBLE
description: Concentrates that prevent pipes from becoming clogged. Fluids that help cool steel slabs being rolled into sheets. Acids that prevent contamination of semiconductor parts. These have been the substances that traditionally brought huge profits and stunning growth to specialty chemical companies.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on March 4 about a jailbreak in Queens erroneously described the chairman of New York City's Board of Correction. The chairman, Robert Kasanof, heads a group that is independent of the Department of Correction and intended to oversee its operation. He is not an official of the Correction Department.

title: FILM: 'HEAT,' A DRAMA WITH BURT REYNOLDS
description: SO you think Charles Bronson is the most lethal object on two feet? That's because you haven't seen ''Heat,'' which opens today at the Ziegfeld and other theaters. William Goldman has patched together a scenario based on his own novel to demonstrate that it's Burt Reynolds all the way. He plays Nick Escalante, a guy so tough that hunks twice his size turn to jelly at his frown, yet so lovable that little girls blow kisses at him.

title: 3 Detroit Firefighters Killed And 6 Injured in Arson Fire
description: Three firefighters were killed and at least six others were injured today as a five-alarm arson fire swept through an abandoned warehouse and part of a paper products company.

title: Group Cites Toxic Emissions
description: An environmental interest group, citing tests conducted by the Environmental Protection Agency and private laboratories, said today that hazardous levels of toxic metals had been found in ash from solid waste incinerators in 23 cities.

title: SURGEON WON'T OPERATE ON VICTIMS OF AIDS
description: A prominent heart surgeon has refused to operate on patients infected with the AIDS virus and says he finds it disturbing that all hospitals do not insist on virus tests before surgery.

title: BOOK OF THE TIMES
description: AN UNFINISHED JOURNEY. By Shiva Naipaul. 136 pages. Viking. $15.95.

title: COMPARISONS WITH 1929-39
description: AS the stock market continues to climb, some eminent economists and financiers are dogged by the feeling that they are living under a volcano, which could erupt at any moment - or lie dormant for years.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday SARTI OPERA AT VINEYARD

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Ornette Coleman Chamber Music Festival, Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall (247-7800). Most fazz fans know that Ornette Coleman shook up jazz composition - writing tunes that ignore conventional melody, harmony and rhythm while sounding utterly natural - and remade the jazz group as an ensemble of equals. Since the 1960's, however, he has also been writing larger works for non-jazz performers that also reflect his own ideas about structure and musical space. This weekend offers a rare chance to hear that music - for soloists, augmented string quartets and chamber ensemble - in concerts tomorrow and Sunday. Both programs feature ''Time Design'' for amplified string quartet and Mr. Coleman's son, Denardo, on electronic drums. Tomorrow's program also includes ''Notes Talking'' for solo mandolin (Andy Statman) and ''The Sacred Mind of Johnny Dolphin'' for chamber ensemble; Sunday's program also features ''Trinity'' for solo violin (Malcolm Goldstein) and ''For NASA and Planetary Soloists,'' played by the Kronos String Quartet with Joseph Celli on oboe. Both concerts begin at 8:30 P.M.; tickets are $10. $ ? * * *

title: DOCKMASTER IS ACCUSED IN LIBERTY WEEKEND BRIBES
description: With thousands of boats in the harbor and dock space at a premium during last year's Liberty Weekend celebrations, New York City's chief dockmaster accepted more than $6,000 in bribes to provide anchorage for a vessel at a city-owned wharf, Federal prosecutors charged yesterday.

title: Advertising Comes To Prescription Books
description: Five years ago, Robert L. Curry and William F. Martin started Medical Publishing Enterprises in Fort Lee, N.J., with a single magazine. Now there are 19 titles and the twosome are diversifying, but always within the health-care field and always related to advertising.

title: Dining Out Guide; 3-Star French, Part II
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. LAFAYETTE, #65 East 56th Street (832-1565) - (Oct. 24, 1986) The dining room of this fine hotel restaurant is soft-edged and contemporary, done in shades of beiges and cream. In addition to a la carte, you can order from two tasting menus - and all the dishes are sunny and Mediterranean and highly inventive. You might start with shirred eggs in the shell crowned with vodka-laced whipped cream and beluga caviar; brioche of foie gras, or paprika-marinated shrimp with a salad of cucumber and aquavit. A winning seafood entree is fillet of halibut in a cardamom sauce; and among the meat entrees you might enjoy the saddle of rabbit with a tart of rabbit cibet; or Barbary duck steak with sesame seeds and mango crepes. Tasting menus from $55; entrees $26 to $36. Fridays, noon to 2:30 and 6 to 10:30

title: U.S. HAS ACQUIRED SOVIET T-72 TANKS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has obtained several Soviet T-72 tanks, which are the mainstay of the extensive Soviet armored force, Government officials said today.

title: BALTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $35,000 and $79,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After a loss of $40,000 from a tax loss carryforward for the quarter and a gain of $72,000 from a tax loss carryforward for the year.

title: Waiting for Lefty
description: In the classic Czech story, ''The Good Soldier Schweik,'' the hero confounds an authoritarian regime by taking its absurd rules seriously. That also has been the method of Karel Srp and his four codefendants from the Jazz Section. For more than a decade, they have seized on loopholes to put out, legally, an independent cultural newsletter. Their trial this week left the Communist regime tied up in knots of its own illogic. But it also left two of the defendants imprisoned. That's a repugnant outcome.

title: 'PLAYING AWAY, A COMEDY
description: ''PLAYING AWAY,'' directed by the Trinidad-born Horace Ove, is a movie about the comic pretensions of social and political organisms - the kind of community-comedy at which British movie makers have excelled from ''Tight Little Island'' and ''I'm All Right, Jack'' through ''A Private Function.''

title: CAPOTE LIKELY FOR THE GOTHAM
description: The New York route to the Kentucky Derby, scorned in recent years by the handlers of many top 3-year-olds, may take center stage again this year. Capote, the champion 2-year-old last year and early favorite for the Derby, is likely to be flown in from California to make his first start of the year in the Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct April 4.

title: Taiwan Import Controls
description: Taiwan is to relax import controls on more foreign goods, a Government spokesman said today. The move would allow greater access to Taiwan markets by overseas trading partners, especially the United States, an official of the Council for Economic Planning and Development said. Import curbs on about 400 foreign goods, including stationery and books, would soon be relaxed, he said. Taiwan announced last month that it would ease curbs on about 600 farming and industrial products.

title: INSIDE
description: Woody Hayes Dies

For the Omaha Lancers, a first-year entry in the 10-team amateur United States Hockey League, the season that ended last Sunday could well be called the Lower 48. Omaha played 48 games and was beaten in every one of them, scoring just 105 goals, yielding 453 and trying the spirit of three different head coaches.

title: CHICAGO MILWAUKEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $593,000 for the quarter and income of $17,598,000 from discontinued operations for the year; and gains from tax loss carryforwards of $6,574,000 and $28,210,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $300,000 for the quarter and $2,125,000 for the year; gains of $118,229,000 and $120,185,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from return of control of a real estate subsidiary, and extraordinary tax credits of $99,315,000 for the quarter and $101,179,000 for the year. The 1985 figures include operating results of CMC Real Estate Corp., formerly Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul, and Pacific Railroad Co. from Nov. 25 to Dec. 31, 1985.

title: COMPUTER MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes charges of $118,000 and $476,000 for the latest quarter and year-ago period, respectively, from the reversal of a tax loss carryforward.

title: LYNDEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $736,000, or 63 cents a share, from contingency adjustments.

title: GREECE PROTESTS U.S. POLICY SEEING A TILT TOWARD TURKEY
description: The Greek authorities summoned the United States Ambassador here today to protest Washington's policy toward neighboring Turkey in what seemed a worsening of relations.

title: F.C.C. BOARD URGES $1.50-A-MONTH RISE IN TELEPHONE CHARGE
description: In a careful compromise, a Federal Communications Commission board today recommended a $1.50 increase in monthly telephone charges and proposed a subsidy to help five million households get telephone service.

title: RARE PERSIAN MUSIC
description: Dr. Mojtaba Khoshzamir will present a program entitled ''Classical Music of Persia'' Sunday after noon at 2:30 in the Uris Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Dr. Khoshzamir will sing tasnifs - Persian ballads - and play the kamancheh, a popular MiddleEastern instrument that is commonly referred to as the ''spike fiddle.'' Admission is $8; $6 for students and the elderly. Information: 206-1050.

title: FOR BETTER LIVING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After net from disposed operations of $76,000 for the quarter and a gain of $79,000 from discontinued operations for the year.

title: OPERA: NEW PRODUCTION OF 'TURADOT' AT THE MET
description: TWO decades have elapsed since the Metropolitan Opera opened its new house at Lincoln Center with a production of Samuel Barber's ''Antony and Cleopatra'' so ornately designed and overbearingly directed by Franco Zeffirelli that the night went down as an unforgettable fiasco. Since then, Mr. Zeffirelli has gone from excess to excess, most recently giving the Met such glittering shows as his inflated ''Boheme'' and his elephantine ''Tosca,'' both of which seem to delight Met audiences with their extravagance. In fact, Mr. Zeffirelli's is one of the great excess stories of our time.

title: U.S. Denounces Trial of Czech Jazz Section
description: The Reagan Administration today denounced a Czechoslovak court's conviction of five advocates of cultural freedom as a contrived and unjust effort to stifle freedoms that Czechoslovakia agreed to uphold in a 1975 human rights agreement.

title: Merrill Dismisses Accused Official
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had dismissed Nahum Vaskevitch, the investment banker who was charged with insider trading by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday.

title: REAGAN FILLS STAFF POST OF KEY DEPUTY TO BAKER
description: President Reagan continued his overhaul of the White House staff today, naming Kenneth M. Duberstein as the principal deputy to Howard H. Baker Jr., his new chief of staff.

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $30.8 million for the quarter and $28.4 million for the year, and a charge of $16.4 million for both periods in connection with the redemption of a debenture issue. c-After a charge of $238.9 million in connection with discontinued operations for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $250.8 million for the year.

title: A COPTER LIFELINE ON ECUADOR'S RIVER OF DEATH
description: When a series of earthquakes struck this northeastern region last week, ''it felt like everything was going to end,'' said Aviola Atiz, one of the survivors.

title: Overthrow Trial to Be Moved
description: A Federal district judge ordered today that the trial of eight people accused of seeking the overthrow of the Government be moved out of Boston because the two jails they are in are too far from the courthouse and each other.

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENTS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $40,519 for the quarter, and a loss from discontinued operations of $9,666 for the 9 months.

title: ASAMERA INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $1,050,000 tax credit. c-Net income and includes a $5,550,000 tax credit. Results are in Canadian currency. The company said the loss reported for 1986 includes an unusual non- recurring, non-cash charge of $15 million, Canadian dollars, relating to a reduction in the carrying value of its refinery and related assets as of Dec. 31. The 1985 results include a gain of $10.8 million on the sale of a natural gas property in Canada.

title: STAGE: 'MISERABLES,' MUSICAL VERSION OPENS ON BROADWAY
description: IF anyone doubts that the contemporary musical theater can flex its atrophied muscles and yank an audience right out of its seats, he need look no further than the Act I finale of ''Les Miserables.''

title: COURT SAYS HOMELESS LOITERING IN STATIONS CANNOT BE ARRESTED
description: The police can no longer arrest people for loitering in public areas of the Port Authority Bus Terminal, Grand Central Terminal and other transportation centers, an appeals court in Manhattan has ruled. Numerous homeless people seek shelter at the centers, especially at night.

title: Borg-Warner To Sell Division
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its Industrial Products business for about $240 million to a group led by the division's senior management.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: WHILE French bistros - and their newly cultivated hybrid, the American bistro - are budding all over town, Serge Raoul, owner of the neighborly Raoul's in SoHo, has defied the trend and aimed his sights higher with a new venture called Rakel. Along with his chef and partner, Thomas Keller, a former chef at Raphael and La Reserve, he has created one of the handsomest and most provocative restaurants in the SoHo area, featuring an inventive menu full of surprises.

title: U.S. MINE SAFETY OFFICIAL CALLS FOR IMPROVEMENTS IN AGENCY
description: The acting director of the Labor Department's Mine Safety and Health Administration said today that a new agency was not needed to investigate accidents and law-breaking in the coal mines, but he acknowledged that ''additional improvements must be made'' in his agency.

title: LVI GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $492,000 for the quarter and $1,241,000 for the year, and losses of $135,000 and $533,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, on early extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss LVI's results for 1985 include two months of the operating results of NICO Inc., the company's interior consulting/construction business which was acquired on Oct. 31, 1985.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Eighteenth Annual Pee Wee Russell Memorial Stomp, Brower Commons, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N.J. (201-658-3515). The Pee Wee Russell Memorial Stomp, which was originated by the New Jersey Jazz Society in 1970 to commemorate the death a year earlier of the celebrated jazz clarinetist Pee Wee Russell, will move on Sunday from the Martinsville Inn, where all previous stomping has been done, to the Rutgers University campus. For the past 17 years, the Stomp has had a close relationship with Rutgers, providing money for music scholarships, matching grants and the university's Institute of Jazz Studies, as well as underwriting a Jazz Hall of Fame that is to be built on the Rutgers campus. The veteran tenor saxophonist Bud Freeman will be honored ''for outstanding service to jazz as a musician'' and the record producer Bob Thiele will be honored for his service as a nonmusician. The cornetist Jimmy McPartland, who frequently played with Mr. Freeman in Chicago in the 1920's, will celebrate his 80th birthday on Sunday by having a reunion with him, and will perform with Warren Vache Sr.'s Syncopatin' Eight, one of six bands that will play at the Stomp. The bands will include John Bucher's Speakeasy Jazz Babies, which plays every Monday with Woody Allen at Michael's Pub, and the Rutgers Jazz Band, which will have the pianist Mulgrew Miller as a guest. Tickets for the Stomp, which will run from 1 to 6 P.M., are $8 for members of the New Jersey Jazz Society, $10 for nonmembers and $2 for students. $ ? * * *

title: Isaac Asimov to Speak At West Side Y.M.C.A.
description: The writer Isaac Asimov is to open the West Side Y.M.C.A. 1987 ''Writer's Voice'' season with a reading tonight at 8, at the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street.

title: U.S. CLERICS WILL MEET AT VATICAN ON TENSION
description: A delegation of American Roman Catholic bishops will hold talks in Rome next week aimed at easing tension caused by a Vatican crackdown on dissent from orthodox views, church officials said today.

title: NEW FROM ARMANI, A SOFT AND GENTLE AIR
description: The big change at Giorgio Armani is that his famous wide-shouldered oversize jacket is giving way, after more than a decade, to a more gentle style. Oh, the shoulder pads aren't gone - not yet anyway. But they are softer and rounded.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The nation demands an expeditious and complete disclosure of our Government's involvement in the Iran-contra affair.

title: BEN & JERRY'S HOMEMADE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 25 about the former United States Immigration Station on Ellis Island misidentified the architectural team in charge of restoration. It is Beyer Blinder Belle/ Notter Finegold & Alexander Inc.

title: EX-BROKER INDICTED IN CASH SCHEME
description: Gary D. Eder, a former vice president and a top stockbroker at the Paine Webber Group Inc., was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges that he helped clients move more than $700,000 in cash into their accounts in a way that avoided reporting the transactions to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: No Headline
description: The court-appointed legal guardian of Baby M urged in her trial summation today that the parental rights of Mary Beth Whitehead be retained and custody of the 11-month-old girl be awarded to her father, William Stern, and his wife.

title: MOSLEM MOBS IN NIGERIA SAID TO KILL 11 IN NORTH
description: Moslem mobs attacking Christians have reportedly killed 11 people and burned 14 churches in northern Nigeria in the worst religious violence there in recent years.

title: Beirut Group Threatens to Kill French Captive
description: A clandestine organization warned today that it would kill a French captive within 48 hours unless France explained recent statements by President Francois Mitterrand about the hostages in Lebanon and French policy on selling military supplies to Iraq.

title: Kenyan Meets Reagan; Urges Apartheid Fight
description: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya met with President Reagan today and called upon the United States to make ''a deeper commitment'' toward ending apartheid in South Africa.

title: BRIDGE: A TEAM IN VANDERBILT EVENT WINS MATCH BY SINGLE POINT
description: All the favored teams survived second-round Vanderbilt Knockout Team play here Wednesday at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, but one did so by the narrowest possible margin.

title: Stern Justice for The Bronx
description: The 12-year prison sentence for Stanley Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic chairman, is one of the stiffest in the annals of municipal corruption. It properly measures this once-powerful politician's betrayal of public trust. Such is Mr. Friedman's continuing aura of influence that Judge Whitman Knapp saw fit to guard against his eventual return to power, especially over judge selection. Judge Knapp ordered that ''from this day forward, you will take no part, directly or indirectly, in any political activity.''

title: EX-VW OFFICIAL TO BE QUERIED
description: Officials at Volkswagen A.G. said today that the former chief of the company's foreign exchange division had agreed to be questioned by prosecutors looking into allegations of foreign exchange fraud that cost the company $259 million.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: HIGH on everybody's house tour list nowadays is Saul and Gayfryd Steinberg's 34-room Park Avenue triplex. And this week 100 friends of the New York City Opera Guild entered the great hall of the self-made demibillionaire, there to marvel at a Francis Bacon triptych on a trompe l'oeil marble wall and to circle a towering Rodin. Janice Levin, an art collector, was struck by what she took to be ''a wad of gum'' on the statue's left shoulder blade.

title: TREBLINKA TRIAL BECOMES AN ISRAELI OBSESSION
description: Before the trial of John Demjanjuk began here, many Israelis predicted that it would be an anticlimactic replay of the Adolf Eichmann war-crimes trial in 1961 and would arouse little public attention or press coverage.

title: SOME SURGING HOME BUILDERS
description: STOCK prices are surging for home building companies that tap strong regional markets. Shares of Toll Brothers Inc., which caters to the luxury, ''move-up'' market in the New Jersey and Philadelphia areas, have climbed 400 percent since last summer. Calton Inc., which constructs housing units in New Jersey and Florida, has seen its stock triple since late 1986.

title: SPECIALTY COMPOSITES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PROSECUTOR MAKING INQUIRY ON TICKET-FIXING IN QUEENS
description: A special prosecutor is investigating allegations of a ''system'' of ticket-fixing in the Queens traffic court that led to the arrest of a New York City police officer and another man on perjury charges late Wednesday, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: NASA PANEL URGING REDUCED CARGO ROLE FOR THE SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The space agency's Advisory Council said today that the agency should stop regarding the space shuttle as its principal cargo hauler and quickly buy a fleet of disposable rockets, including some that could lift heavier payloads into orbit.

title: The U.N. Today: March 13, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said in the latest quarter, earnings were affected by prepayment of 11 percent notes, which reduced net by $727,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: JERSEY'S ASSEMBLY VOTES TO PERMIT STATE TAKEOVERS OF WEAK SCHOOLS
description: The New Jersey Assembly passed bills today empowering the state to take over local school districts that fail to meet state standards.

title: American Academy Prize Winners
description: The American Academy in Rome announced yesterday the winners of the 93d annual Rome Prize Fellowship Competition, a leading cultural award presented to young and emerging artists and scholars in the United States in fields ranging from literature, musical composition, architecture, classical studies, painting and sculpture.

title: Ice Tank
description: For all of the Lancers' miserable play, there are ample grounds to hold them in higher esteem than the Hamilton (Ontario) Kiltys of the Golden Horseshoe Junior B Hockey League. A month ago, the Kiltys played their regular-season finale against the Thorold Black Hawks, with playoff positioning at stake. The team that won would finish fifth and meet second-place Welland in the postseason; the loser would be sixth and face No. 1 Niagara Falls.

title: DOCTORS SUBMIT TO DRUG TESTS AS ALTERNATIVE TO PENALTIES
description: Under a program that began two years ago to help doctors overcome drug abuse, about 100 doctors in New York are submitting to random urine tests for drugs and alcohol.

title: Ferry Safety Inquiry Sought After Accident at Zeebrugge
description: The European Parliament called today for a safety review of vehicle ferries after the capsizing off Zeebrugge, Belgium, in which 134 people died.

title: ST JOE GOLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $500,000 from computing the tax provision on a stand-alone basis; year-ago quarter results include a tax benefit of $700,000.

title: ROBINSON ENDS ON A HIGH NOTE
description: He came from the basketball equivalent of nowhere, from the moon, from Mars. He came to Annapolis as a 6-foot-7-inch ''Navy brat'' with more capacity for engineering and playing the piano and speaking in complex sentences than for a sport he had played only as a senior in high school.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 379 money market mutual funds decreased $35.3 million, to $237.43 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were down $204.8 million, to $65.60 billion. Assets of the 196 general purpose funds were up $42.7 million, to $62.74 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds rose $126.8 million, to $109.09 billion.

title: ORSER WINS AS BOITANO FALTERS
description: The United States started the day holding the two world singles championships in figure skating. Tonight, it lost the men's title, and on Saturday night it will face an uphill battle to keep the women's.

title: KEY RATES
Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific Corporation said the Federal Reserve Board had approved its $47 million acquisition of the Orbanco Financial Services Corporation of Portland, Ore. Security Pacific, the nation's seventh-largest bank holding concern, announced its intention to buy Orbanco in November, two months after the collapse of an agreement by the BankAmerica Corporation to pay $57 million for Orbanco's main subsidiary, the Oregon Bank. Orbanco, with about $1 billion in assets, has been operating under a liquidation plan.

title: Singapore Believes Freedom of Press Must Be a Two-Way Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Defining Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: General Mills Net Up 22.6%
description: General Mills Inc. said today that its third-quarter earnings increased 22.6 percent, to $56.9 million, or 64 cents a share, from $46.4 million, or 52 cents a share, in its 1986 third quarter.

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP A SCANT 0.1%
description: Producer prices rose a scant one-tenth of 1 percent last month, with lower prices for food and automobiles largely offsetting fresh rises in energy costs, the Labor Department reported today.

title: ELECTRO-SENSORS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $29,532. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $81,358.

title: ECUADOR SUSPENDS PAYMENT ON DEBT FOLLOWING QUAKES
description: President Leon Febres Cordero said today that ''without shame'' his country had suspended payments on its $8.3 billion foreign debt for the rest of the year and possibly longer.

title: Manley Gets Treatment
description: Dexter Manley, a Washington Redskins defensive end, checked in to a Minnesota drug and alcohol rehabilitation center yesterday, his agent said.

title: Singapore Believes Freedom of Press Must Be a Two-Way Street; Protecting Untruth
description: To the Editor:

title: GREAT AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SCEPTRE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: CONSUMERS FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
State Commerce Chief Quits Amid Plans to Modify Agency
description: Ronald J. Moss resigned yesterday as State Commerce Commissioner, and Governor Cuomo indicated that he might name Vincent Tese, the State Director of Economic Development, to take over the job in addition to his other duties.

title: Gates Learjet Gets New Offer
description: The Gates Learjet Corporation, which earlier this week disclosed that a large stake in the company would be sold to an investment partnership, said it had received an offer to buy the entire company for $7.07 a share, or $85.6 million. The new bid was from Interconnect Capital, a closely held investment company based in Stamford, Conn.

title: SCHOOL STAR PONDERS HIS PROSPECTS
description: For as long as he can remember, Oliver Taylor has worked on perfecting his jump shot in the city's playgrounds and gymnasiums. It was simple: If he perfected that shot, he would surely be able to play college basketball on the Division I level.

title: REAGAN SEEN AS FIRM ON IRAN
description: Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said today that President Reagan has not retreated from his view that his Iran policy initiative deteriorated into a trade of arms for hostages, which he has called a mistake.

title: HEMACARE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 14, 1987
description: Companies

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 22
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $8.5 million. c-After net from discontinued operations of $1.5 million for the quarter and $3 million for the 9 months.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Baseball on Television
