COMPRESSION LABS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $450,000 bad debt expense for the quarter and the year includes an extraordinary credit of $132,000, or 2 cents a share. c-Net income d-Includes an extraordinary credit of $163,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: THE TUNNEL OF LOVE, JUST FOR ENGLISH TOADS
description: The British opened the nation's first toad tunnel under the lethal Henley roadway here today just in time for the mating season.

title: INSIDE
description: Chernobyl Prosecutions Those reponsible for the Chernobyl nuclear power plant disaster will go on trial soon in Kiev, a Soviet official said. Page 6.

title: 2,500 TO LOSE JOBS IN L.I. PLANT AS U.S. ENDS JET CONTRACT
description: The Air Force and Fairchild Industries announced today that they had canceled their contract for the T-46A training plane. The decision will result in the closing of the Fairchild Republic Company's plant in Farmingdale, L.I., by the end of the year, the company said, eliminating more than 2,500 jobs.

title: C.I.A. Said to Have Obtained An Advanced Soviet Copter
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has obtained a sophisticated Soviet MI-24 helicopter gunship, Government officials said today.

title: CAMBRIDGE BIOSCIENCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MOLLOY TAKES CATHOLIC TITLE
description: Kenny Anderson, the star sophomore for Archbishop Molloy of Queens, scored 10 of his 23 points in the final quarter Friday night to lead the Stanners to a 62-44 victory over Cardinal Hayes of the Bronx. The victory gave Molloy its second straight Catholic High Schools Athletic Association city championship.

title: Article 152987 -- No Title
description: The Utah Power and Light Company and the families of 27 coal miners killed in a 1984 fire have settled a lawsuit alleging wrongful death, reportedly for $22 million.

title: Stage Set for Goetz Trial
description: The conclusion of John Gotti's trial yesterday cleared the way for the opening of another major criminal case - the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz.

title: ST. PETER'S DEFEATED BY ST. LOUIS, 76-60
description: St. Louis, led by 23 points from Monroe Douglass, eliminated Peter's, 76-60, in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: FALCON OIL & GAS CO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
KAPLAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $108,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes a loss of $30,000 for the quarter and $135,000 for the year from discontinued operations. d-Net loss The results for all periods include writeoff of fixed assets from discontinued retail meat market operations.

title: PINCH OR POUND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 Scoreless Innings by Gooden
description: Don't sell the farm yet; Dwight Gooden's alive and well.

title: Japan Rebuts Foes of Sale
description: A Foreign Ministry official today rejected as groundless arguments made by senior American officials who are trying to block the sale of an American microchip maker to a Japanese company.

title: MOURNERS OF YOUNG SUICIDES EXPRESS ANGUISH AND ANGER
description: Rick Steel was standing near the rear door of the Riewerts Memorial Home today as somber teen-agers came to mourn his 18-year-old nephew Thomas Olton, who two days before died with three friends in a suicide pact.

title: 24 ARRESTS AT GRAND CENTRAL CRITICIZED
description: The Metro-North police arrested 24 people at Grand Central Terminal Thursday in what a railroad official said yesterday was an effort to protect those using or working in the terminal. Others called the arrests an attempt to drive out the homeless.

title: HEMOTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NUCLEAR PLANT TO BE AT FULL POWER
description: The Georgia Power Company is being allowed to proceed with full-power operation of the Unit 1 reactor at the Vogtle Nuclear Power plant in east Georgia.

title: HUEY NEWTON TO BEGIN TERM
description: A judge has ordered Huey Newton, the former Black Panther Party leader, to begin serving a prison term for possessing firearms..

title: Polish Newspaper Is Printing A Serialized 'Doctor Zhivago'
description: A leading Polish newspaper has begun printing Boris Pasternak's novel ''Doctor Zhivago,'' a year before the book is to appear for the first time in the Soviet Union.

title: SPIRE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
WEIGH-TRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
What Man Has Wrought in the Galapagos
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSTON LOSES PIECE OF HERITAGE WITH SALE OF THE CHRONICLE
description: They sit opposite each other on Texas Street: The Houston Chronicle's building with its sparkling white marble facade and the pentagonal Texas Commerce Tower, a 75-story building that is the tallest in Texas.

title: PATENTS
description: LEAD: An automatic control system for twin-engine aircraft was patented for NASA. If one engine fails, the other is enabled to compensate for the loss of power. Patent 4,648,569 was awarded to Eric C. Stewart, an aerospace engineer at the Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va. Both patents are available for licensing.

title: IN CELEBRATION OF AN OPENING
description: Question: How many people are in a mood to party after seeing a somber musical in which the hero dies, half the characters bite the dust during the Paris insurrection of 1832 and the most striking set is a sewer?

title: Reagan Sees No Tax Rises
description: President Reagan took aim today at suggestions in Congress for tax rises, saying such proposals ''have about as much chance of flying as a dead duck.'' Speaking to a group of conservative business supporters, Mr. Reagan appeared to direct his comments at remarks by House Speaker Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, who has argued that the budget cannot be balanced by spending cuts alone.

title: 5 Are Held Hostage At Trenton Prison
description: An inmate at Trenton State Prison held five people hostage in a classroom section for almost three hours yesterday before surrendering to the authorities.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about lovastatin, a drug to reduce cholesterol in the blood, referred incorrectly to another cholesterol-lowering drug, Mer-29. That drug, no longer on the market, was manufactured by Richardson-Merrell, Inc.

title: DAMAGE TO FERRY DEBATED IN BRITAIN
description: The Times of London said today that the propellers of the Herald of Free Enterprise were damaged when the ferry hit the harbor wall off Zeebrugge, Belgium, forcing the vessel into an uncontrolled 180-degree turn that caused the vessel to capsize.

title: Jumper Still Missing
description: The whereabouts of Jan Cado, a triple jumper from Czechoslovakia who competed last weekend in the world indoor track championships at Indianapolis, remained unknown yesterday. Rude Pravo, the Czechoslovak Communist Party daily newspaper, reported that Cado ''failed to show up for departure in the United States,'' but made no reference to his seeking asylum in this country.

title: Beneficial Sells Insurance Unit
description: The Beneficial Corporation has agreed to sell its Western National Life Insurance Company to an Indiana insurance holding concern for $275 million in cash, debt and equity.

title: NO-HOLE BAGEL AND OTHER KOSHER TREATS
description: Enthusiasm ran so high at the first Kosher Foods and Jewish Life Expo this week that it was possible to be run down by the over-65 set. One slightly trampled visitor wondered aloud whether anyone was left in the local centers for the elderly.

title: INTERNATIONAL BANKNOTE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a reversal of tax loss carryforward of $115,000 for the quarter, and a tax credit of $8,096,000 for the year. c-Includes a reversal of tax loss carryforward of $995,000 and a tax credit of $1,480,000 for the quarter; and the year includes a tax loss carryforward of $1,173,000. The prior year revenue and pre-tax income includes $7.4 million from the termination of a domestic pension plan and a $1.4 million gain from restructuring and consolidation. Restructuring and consolidation expense in the year-ago quarter totaled about $1.2 million. The prior year revenue also includes $69.1 million in revenue and $500,000 in pre-tax income from a foreign subsidiary sold in March 1986. The 1985 fourth quarter includes $21 million in revenue and $300,000 in pre- tax income from such subsidiary. Revenue for 1986 includes a pre-tax gain on the sale of the subsidiary of $17.2 million.

title: AFTER 20 YEARS, BOOK ON STALIN REACHES PRINT IN SOVIET UNION
description: A novel chronicling Stalin's terror, ''Children of the Arbat,'' has been excerpted in a Soviet weekly magazine 20 years after its author first tried to bring his painful subject to a Soviet audience.

title: MANUFACTURED HOMES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $3,300,000 as a provision for losses on credit sales for the latest year, and for the year- ago period includes a charge of $504,571 for an accounting change.

title: EX-OFFICER REBUILDS FROM DRUG'S ASHES
description: Shortly after the two men entered the drug treatment center seven months ago, they met at the top of a stairwell, lit cigarettes and began to exchange secrets about their past.

title: FLOOD RISK THREATENS BARGAIN HOMES
description: To the people who live in the low-lying area along the Housatonic River here known as the Maples, the river's floods are a hazard they have been willing to accept.

title: CITICORP MAY ACT ON BRAZIL DEBT
description: Reacting to Brazil's decision last month to suspend interest payments to foreign lenders, Citicorp said yesterday that it might soon reclassify most of its $4.6 billion in Brazilian loans as nonperforming.

title: PROS AND CONS OF LIVING TRUST
description: EUGENE SCHWARTZ, a retired teacher in Scarsdale, N.Y., has been thinking recently about establishing a revocable living trust.

title: SALES FALL AS INVENTORIES JUMP
description: Business sales plunged a record 4.5 percent in January while inventories shot up by nine-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest rise in more than seven years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: ISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Plant Closings: Warnings, Not Laws
description: Congressional Democrats propose requiring employers to give workers substantial notice of layoffs and to consult with them or local authorities before the door is shut. The objective is noble, but the means are excessive.

title: JAPAN FOCUSES ON TRADE USES
description: Japan's Ministry of Trade and Industry, which organized that country's remarkably successful push into microelectronics, said yesterday that it would begin a government-coordinated effort to find commercial applications for superconducting materials, which offer no resistance to electricity.

title: OLD DOMINION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: PATENTS
description: LEAD: Television transmission from space vehicles is coded to compress the material accurately into fewer electronic bits. A decoder, to be used at ground stations for returning information to ordinary form and to correct errors, was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: GOTTI IS AQUITTED IN CONSPIRACY CASE INVOLVING THE MOB
description: John Gotti was acquitted of Federal racketeering and conspiracy charges yesterday in the Government's first major setback in its recent assault on organized crime.

title: Trevino Joins Masters
description: Lee Trevino, who said on Feb. 28 that he would not play in the Masters golf tournament in Augusta, Ga., April 9-12, has decided to participate after learning that a rule he had objected to has been changed at his request. Last year he was angered because he had to buy a $90 ticket for his son, but Hord Hardin, the Masters chairman, said players had been notified before invitations were sent out this year that sons and daughters over 21 years of age would be admitted free of charge.

title: LANDMARK TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
WOMEN'S HEALTH CENTERS OF AMERICA, INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
PARIS VOWS TO FIGHT TERROR TENACIOUSLY DESPITE NEW THREAT
description: France pledged itself to fight terrorism ''with tenacity and firmness'' today, a day after a Lebanese terrorist organization threatened to kill a French hostage it is holding within 48 hours.

title: A.T.&T. Partly Backs Plan Aiding Regionals
description: In a surprise move, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today conditionally endorsed parts of a Reagan Administration proposal that would allow the seven regional Bell telephone companies to provide some services such as message answering and storage, burglar alarm services and electronic publishing.

title: BIG BROTHER AT THE REGIONAL
description: ''Testing, testing, 1, 2,'' someone said into the microphone. This took place in the interview room of the Horizon following Temple's victory yesterday over Southern University in the first round of the N.C.A.A. Midwest Regional.

title: A KEY SOUTH AFRICA VOTE PITS EX-ALLY AGAINST RULING PARTY
description: Jan Christiaan Heunis did not seem quite at ease in his makeshift election office on the main street here, far from his spacious offices in the Union Buildings, Pretoria's administrative seat of Government.

title: HURCO COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Sosnoff's $28 Offer Rejected by Caesarsm
description: Caesars World Inc. yesterday rejected a $28-a-share tender offer from Martin T. Sosnoff, a New York investor who already owns 13 percent of the company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MARCH 14, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-6 Ecuador has suspended payments on its foreign debt for the remainder of the year and possibly longer because last week's earthquake has halted oil exports, President Leon Febres Cordero said. Page 1 A church-state conflict in Chile was made less intense when the Roman Catholic hierarchy backed away from a bishop's charge that the regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet was ''marked by an immense immorality.'' 3 A novel chronicling Stalin's terror, ''Children of the Arbat,'' has been excerpted in a Soviet weekly magazine, drawing to the attention of Soviet readers one of the most painful periods in the country's history. 1 An election contest in South Africa has focused attention on Somerset West, about 25 miles from Cape Town, where the ruling party is being challenged by a defector in the whites-only election. 1 Britain's first toad tunnel opened under the lethal Henley roadway in Hambleden, just in time for the mating season. The miniature tunnel is designed to help shepherd toads across a busy road to the mating ponds. 1 A trial on the Chernobyl disaster will begin ''soon'' in Kiev, said aSoviet official who said he did not know how many people would be prosecuted over the events at the nuclear power plant. 6 Debate about damage to a ferry that capsized off Belgium a week ago is now focusing on whether the propellers of the Herald of Free Enterprise were harmed and if she hit the harbor wall off Zeebrugge. 3 Declassification of the ABM treaty negotiating record was urged by Senator Sam Nunn so the public could evaluate the Administration's assertion that the agreement would allow ''Star Wars'' testing. 2 Greece's satirical tradition persists in language that is sometimes vulgar and often lacerating that spoofs political leaders and policies. ''Greeks,'' said one comedian, ''can laugh at themselves.'' 4 Six VW executives were suspended in a management shake-up following disclosures of a major foreign exchange swindle, Volkswagen A.G. said. Currency dealers said the action affected virtually all of the company's foreign exchange trading department. 37 Paris vows fight against terrorism 5 Prague group honors founder 6 NATIONAL 7-9, 34, 54 The Washington Post did not libel the former president of the Mobil Oil Corporation, a Federal appeals court ruled. The court reversed a $2 million judgment against the newspaper. 1 Payments for conserving farmland are more popular among American farmers than expected. Under a new Government program, nearly 19.5 million acres of highly erodible land have been removed from crop production. 7 The end of an era in Houston is how many residents describe the recent loss of local control over two of the city's most powerful home-grown institutions, The Houston Chronicle and Texas Commerce Bancshares. 7 Stanford University has a prototype electronic device made out of a new class of superconducting materials, scientists reported, indicating progress in superconductivity may come sooner than expected. 7 Japan will study superconducting materials in a government-coordinated effort to find commercial applications, said Japan's Ministry of Trade and Industry, which organized a successful push into microelectronics. 7 Transplanting brain tissue from aborted fetuses in an effort to aid people suffering from Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's disease has won support from a panel of medical, ethical and legal experts. 54 Richard Secord sent an angry letter to a book publisher last week touching on some issues that have been raised in the Iran-contra affair. The retired general has refused to testify about his role in the affair. 8 Criticism of the pace of an inquiry into the Iran-contra affair has come from the leaders of the Senate committee investigating the case, who say they are impatient with the work of Lawrence Walsh, the independent counsel. 8 The President has not backed away from his view that his Iran policy initiative had deteriorated into a trade of arms for hostages, the White House spokesman said, responding to the White House counsel's statement that Mr. Reagan still believed in his Iran policy. 8 Hope for Arab-U.S. relations was voiced by Senator Bob Dole in an overture to Arab-Americans in the United States. His statements appeared part of an effort to portray himself as a consensus politician. 9 Industrial production rose five-tenths of 1 percent in February, the fifth straight monthly increase, the Federal Reserve Board estimated. Many analysts said the rise, though less than expected, showed that the economy continued to grow. 37 Georgia Power Co. may proceed with full power operation of the Unit 1 reactor at the Vogtle Nuclear Power plant in east Georgia, following a Nuclear Regulatory Commission vote. 34 Teen-ager expelled for modeling 9 Public hospitals ask help with poor 28 REGIONAL 29-32 John Gotti was acquitted, as were his six co-defendants, of Federal racketeering and conspiracy charges in the Government's first major setback in its recent assault on organized crime. 1 A weakness in the prosecution's case was its reliance on turncoat career criminals as key witnesses against Mr. Gotti and 6 co-defendants, many lawyers and prosecutors who followed the seven-month trial said. 1 Mr. Gotti is said to be ruthless, according to prosecutors, who believe he is the boss of the Gambino family, the power behind an empire of loan-sharking, extortion, hijacking, robbery and murder. 32 A Farmingdale, L.I., plant will close by the end of the year as a result of the Air Force and Fairchild Industries' announcement that their contract for the T-46A training plane has been canceled. More than 2,500 jobs will be eliminated. 1 Lawyers in the Howard Beach case say they will make an issue at trial of the finding that the victim had cocaine in his system when he was killed. The lawyers represent two of the youths charged with murder. 29 3 state rent examiners testified that their superiors at the New York Division of Housing and Community Renewal ordered them to close outstanding landlord-tenant disputes improperly to disguise the agency's inefficiency. 29 12th casino changes Atlantic City 29 Ex-officer in drug treatment 29 Suicide-prevention efforts added 30 Youths' mourners vent anguish 30 Panel would raise Koch's pay 31 Grand Central arrests criticized 31

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
'THE NIGHT OF THE PENCILS,' BY OLIVERA
description: One of the sad recognitions to come from ''The Night of the Pencils'' is that its subject no longer shocks. Based on actual events, the film -about six Argentine high school students who disappeared in 1976, and a seventh who survived torture and imprisonment to tell their story - could easily have relied on ideological anger or sentimentality. But with harrowing accomplishment, Hector Olivera confronts the grim dailiness of the teen-agers' prison existence.

description: Throughout the trial, he was the focus of attention, dapper in the expensive suits and silk ties, a sleekness in the trim steel-gray hair, intensity in the dark eyes, a commanding presence. Other defendants and even lawyers were deferential. The crowds made way.

SUCCESS IN PREVENTING TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY
description: Every day more than 3,000 teen-age girls become pregnant, and 1,300 babies are born to adolescents. Five hundred teen-agers have abortions, 26 girls age 13 and 14 have their first child, and 13 others who are 16 have their second child. Over the course of a year, one of every 10 teen-age girls becomes pregnant.

title: SKYLINE CHILI reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 15
CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on Thursday about differences over trade policy between Democratic candidates for the 1988 Presidential nomination reported a comment by former Senator Gary Hart of Colorado incorrectly. He said it would be a mistake for any dark-horse candidate to try to run on a single issue, not that Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri was ''a one-issue candidate.''

title: WISE AND WRITTY
description: Legal columnist Billable Auer answers his readers' mail: Dear Mr. Auer: Since leaving my White House job to make a mint in the public relations business, I have been victimized by rumors. People said I broke some silly law against converting my White House career into heavy dough. I demanded and got the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate and squelch this slander, but recently this prosecutor said he was going to have me indicted. Naturally, I asked the judge to declare special prosecutors unconstitutional so the whole business could be dropped, but the judge refused. Should I appeal to a higher court? (Signed) Michael Deaver * * * Dear Deaver: The precedent for your plea is the case of People v. Chutzpa, in which Myron Chutzpa, having murdered his mother and father, asked the court for mercy on ground that he was an orphan.

description: Someone asked Bill Giles, the Philadelphia Phillies' president, if he had heard from the Detroit Tigers. Giles shook his head, smiled and said, ''I don't think I'm going to Lakeland.''

description: Lou Reycroft, who led Cornell to a fifth-place finish in the N.C.A.A. Division I hockey tournament during the 1985-86 season, has resigned as coach after posting a five-year record of 74-58-9. Reycroft, 38 years old, a graduate of Brown, made no announcement of his plans. . . . Five months after suffering a broken leg in a spill at Santa Anita, Chris McCarron returned to the race track on Thursday and finished out of the money on two mounts.

description: ''No!'' the writer yelled, leaping from his folding chair in the rehearsal hall. ''We have to give the jury a moment to deliberate. We can't just jump from argument to verdict in this scene.''

title: IF ONLY STALIN KNEW: VAIN HOPES IN THE TERROR
description: Following is an excerpt from a section of ''Children of the Arbat'' that the author, Anatoly Rybakov, selected for publication in the magazine Ogonyok. The scene is the Arbat, the intelligentsia's quarter in central Moscow that is now largely demolished. The year is 1934, the beginning of Stalin's terror, when even relatives of the victims could still believe that the unexplained disappearance of their loved ones was some kind of mistake that would soon be set right, if only they could get word to Stalin. The excerpt begins shortly after the arrest of the novel's protagonist, Sasha Pankratov, a student. It is printed by permission of Anatoly Rybakov and Ogonyok, and was translated by Kate Cook for The New York Times.

title: Postseason Proposal
description: Acting after complaints by Coach Denny Crum, the University of Louisville Athletic Association will ask the Metro Conference at the league's annual meetings to bar basketball teams not eligible for national championship competition from the league's postseason tournament.

title: Airborne Wins I.B.M. Contract
description: The Airborne Freight Corporation, No. 2 in the overnight delivery business, has won a major contract to handle most packages shipped from the International Business Machines Corporation's huge Information Systems division.

title: Cyclops Opposes Investor Group
description: The Cyclops Corporation gave a cold shoulder to an investor group's conditional plans to raise its takeover bid for the specialty steel and retailing concern. Cyclops said it did not consider the proposal, announced in a news release Thursday, an actual offer. Cyclops has already agreed to be acquired by British retailer Dixons Group P.L.C. for $90.25 a share, or nearly $400 million. Shareholders of Dixons approved the deal today.

title: CHARLES A. PETERSON
description: Charles A. Peterson, a former president of the New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, died of cancer on Tuesday at Misericordia Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 60 years old and lived in Middle Village, Queens.

title: OLDHAM IS INJURED IN LOSS TO THE NETS
description: As the Knicks moved closer to official elimination from the playoffs last night, all the problems that have haunted them during this losing season appeared to surface at various stages of the 126-121 loss to the Nets at Madison Square Garden.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
IN BERGEN COUNTY, CRISIS CENTERS INCREASE EFFORTS
description: Leslie Manning, a senior crisis specialist at the Mid-Bergen Community Mental Health Center here, slowly paced the hall outside her office, glancing occasionally at her watch. She was waiting for a high school student to come in for evaluation, and he was late.

title: Treasury Prices Move Higher
description: Prices of Treasury coupon securities posted moderate gains yesterday, as the latest flow of economic data dashed hopes for a strong recovery - and eased fears of a resurgence of inflation in the foreseeable future.

title: DEVILS' EARLY SURGE DOWNS ISLANDERS
description: Kelly Hrudey, the Islander goalie, landed on the seat of his pants as the Devils scored their fourth goal, and he stayed there for several moments, as if glued to the ice, as if there was little point in getting back up.

title: 2 SENATORS EXPRESS CONCERN OVER PACE OF WALSH INQUIRY
description: The leaders of the Senate committee investigating the Iran arms affair expressed impatience today with the pace of the inquiry being conducted by the special prosecutor.

title: Sweet Deal for Moscow
description: As Congress solemnly debates the supposed ''Soviet penetration'' of Central America -though there is little or no evidence that Nicaragua is a Soviet puppet -Moscow actually has made a bold new move into the Caribbean, thanks to that same Congress.

title: 12TH CASINO SHIFTS ATLANTIC CITY'S OUTLOOK
description: When the Showboat casino opens on the Boardwalk this month, it will be the 12th casino in the nine-year history of the gambling industry here. And there may be no more than 12 for years to come.

title: Surgery for Lendl
description: Ivan Lendl injured his left knee last week in a second-round match of the Lipton International Players Championships, but did not miss any of the of the tournament, making it to the final before losing. Now, however, he will miss several tournaments.

description: Three boys, ages 7, 8 and 10, were taken into custody today in the death of a 2-year-old girl who the police said was punched, jumped on and hit with a board.

description: About 30 prominent members of the Charter 77 human-rights organization were allowed to gather publicly today without police interference as they marked the 10th anniversary of the death of Jan Potocka, one of their founding leaders.

St. Lawrence Gains Final
description: St. Lawrence and Harvard, the two best teams in the league, brushed aside their opponents tonight in the Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey tournament.

title: HOYAS CRUISE AND SYRACUSE STRUGGLES
description: Bucknell, which has no trouble matching up with Georgetown academically, readily acknowledged its athletic deficiencies tonight against the top-seeded team in the Southeast Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. What the Bisons hoped to accomplish was to ''get into a mental contest and beat them that way,'' as one of their players stated.

description: All 1986 figures include the results of operations of Parmed Pharmaceuticals Inc., acquired May 29, 1986.

title: FOULS LIMIT MARIST IN A ROMP FOR PITT
description: The most successful basketball season in the six-year Division I history of Marist College tonight ended the way it began - in frustration.
