description: In a management shake-up following disclosures of a major currency swindle, Volkswagen A.G. said today that it had suspended six foreign exchange executives.

title: SIS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
France, Disney Progress
description: France and the Walt Disney Company expect to sign a contract to create a huge Disneyland amusement park, Europe's first, by the end of April, a French official said today. Michel Giraud, president of a Parisian district council in whose region the park would be situated, said talks were nearly over after lasting 15 months.

title: A CBS Issue Of $400 Million
description: CBS Inc. is issuing $400 million of convertible debt, the proceeds of which are to be used as working capital and for acquisitions in television. The issue, which is due April 7, 2002, has a coupon of 5 percent and is priced at par, according to Morgan Stanley Ltd., the lead manager.

title: YE GODS! HOOTS ARE HEARD ON SOCIALIST OLYMPUS
description: On a recent night when the chill turned rain to snow, 200 Athenians packed a frigid theater to watch a show that depicted their leaders as demigods and themselves as scavenging mongrels.

title: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TISCH IS HOLDING A HOT POTATO
description: CBS is not General Motors or any other industrial company. Whatever the usual recipe for dealing with hard times in business, many people contend that Laurence A. Tisch, CBS's chief executive, was chopping at the heart of his company when he decided to lop off more than 200 people at CBS News. They say that at CBS the most prized assets are the highly celebrated, hard-to-replace television personalities responsible for the network's news coverage.

title: OPERA: MET'S 'TURANDOT'
description: Two decades have elapsed since the Metropolitan Opera opened its new house at Lincoln Center with a production of Samuel Barber's ''Antony and Cleopatra'' so ornately designed and overbearingly directed by Franco Zeffirelli that the night went down as an unforgettable fiasco. Since then, Mr. Zeffirelli has gone from excess to excess, most recently giving the Met such glittering shows as his inflated ''Boheme'' and his elephantine ''Tosca,'' both of which seem to delight Met audiences with their extravagance. In fact, Mr. Zeffirelli's is one of the great excess stories of our time.

title: Six Are Killed in Crash Of an Air Force Tanker
description: An Air Force tanker plane practicing maneuvers with a B-52 for an aerial demonstation crashed and burst into flames today, killing six people, including one on the ground, officials said.

title: CHOCK FULL O'NUTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $1,028,000 for the quarter and $1,076,000 for the 6 months. The latest figures include results of Greenwich Mills Co. from Dec. 30, 1986, the date of acquisition. The losses from discontinued operations include a litigation settlement of $891,000.

title: D H HOLMES CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included an after-tax gain on the sale of real estate of $1,549,000. The share earnings for all periods have been adjusted for a 3 percent stock dividend issued January 1987.

title: Dow Off 8.68, to 2,258.66; Loss for Week Is 21.57
description: Stock prices fell yesterday in lighter trading volume, as Wall Street seemed to become nervous about the ''triple witching hour'' a week in advance.

title: Controversy Doesn't Make Tenure Decisions
description: To the Editor:

title: Magical Music
description: Amy Kaiser will conduct the Dessoff Choirs in a concert called ''Music of Magic and Mystery,'' featuring works by Rossini, Verdi, Lassus and Bruce Adolphe, tomorrow night at 8 at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. Tickets are $10; information: 362-8719.

title: HARSH CRITICISM OF PINOCHET SOFTENED BY CHILEAN BISHOP
description: The Roman Catholic hierarchy backed away this week from a confrontation with the Government over a bishop's charge that the regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet was ''marked by an immense immorality.''

title: Olmsted and Vaux, Central Park Has Need of You at This Hour
description: To the Editor:

title: LIPOSOME CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INSITUFORM OF NORTH AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $131,000.

title: LIFESTYLE RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
description: The loss for the first quarter fiscal 1986 included a gain of $870,000 and $70,000 from the sale of restaurant leases.

title: Dissident Soviet Priest Free From Siberia Exile
description: Gleb Yakunin, a dissident Russian Orthodox priest, has been released from exile in Siberia under a Government decree, Yelena G. Bonner, a dissident, said today.

title: A SOVIET AIDE SAYS CHERNOBYL OFFICIALS WILL BE PUT ON TRIAL
description: A Soviet official said today that those reponsible for the Chernobyl nuclear disaster would go on trial soon.

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $341,145 and $480,412 from land sales in Puerto Rico for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Major U.S. Witnesses Viewed as Unreliable
description: Many lawyers and prosecutors who followed events in the seven-month trial of John Gotti said the underlying weakness of the prosecution's case was its apparent reliance on turncoat career criminals as key witnesses against Mr. Gotti and six co-defendants.

title: Public Hospitals Ask Congress for Help With Poor
description: Public hospitals in large cities and isolated rural hospitals report they are providing a disproportionate share of the medical care of the poor, a financial burden that has grown to about $7.4 billion a year.

title: 'POSITIVE I.D.,' A METHODICAL MASQUERADE
description: Unlike almost any other story of switched identities, Andy Anderson's ''Positive I.D.'' pays no attention to the underpinnings of such an act. It concentrates on the mechanics, which, as Mr. Anderson sees them, can take on a life of their own.

title: Light and the Afghan Tunnel
description: In Moscow a few weeks ago, Henry Kissinger heard a senior Russian say something unexpected about Afghanistan - that the Soviet-backed regime in Kabul wasn't really Communist or even technically Socialist.

title: Trouble Spots Listed For Weekend Traffic
description: The city's Department of Transportation said these will be among the most severe traffic trouble spots in the region this weekend:

title: Oiler Wing Suspended
description: The long arm of professional hockey finally caught up with Marty McSorley, a right wing for the Edmonton Oilers. The National Hockey League suspended McSorley for eight games yesterday for deliberately injuring an opponent in an American Hockey League game earlier this season.

title: TV: 'SILAS MARNER,' TIMELY VICTORIAN CLASSIC
description: George Eliot's ''Silas Marner'' used to be the kind of Victorian novel that kept popping up on high school reading lists. I remember first approaching it reluctantly, having heard that it was merely a dreary tale about a miser. I also remember being very much surprised, having discovered a complex, sympathetic portrait of a good man who was forced by his tightly circumscribed society into being a loner, an embittered outsider. Love and kindness, of course, would be his redemption. The formula still works, at least for fiction, as can be seen in the BBC's new two-hour adaptation of ''Silas Marner,'' being broadcast in its entirety as a ''Masterpiece Theater'' presentation on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. tomorrow.

title: ARGUING THE CASE FOR HAIR
description: On Monday the Upjohn Company is to give the Food and Drug Administration the results of its tests on Rogaine, a product the company wants to sell as a baldness remedy. But the application for approval by the F.D.A. has prompted sharp criticism from the Public Citizen Health Research Group, a consumer organization that has accused Upjohn of trying to ''make bald people feel insecure.''

title: ANTI-EROSION PROGRAM FOR FARMS ACCELERATES
description: More than 10.5 million acres was added today to a national reserve of highly erodible farmland being taken out of production under a new Federal conservation program.

title: A 'NONPERSON' NAMED BORIS PASTERNAK
description: LEAD: The Soviet Government's rehabilitation of Boris Pasternak recalls an event involving the great Russian writer that turned out to be a dramatic and deeply moving moment for those who witnessed it in Moscow in September 1959.

title: Don't Serve Half-Baked Sentences
description: After getting off to a late start and having had its reporting deadline extended once, a commission created by Congress to rationalize sentencing for Federal crimes resists yet another extension. But its product, a complicated new sentencing process, remains half baked. More delay might be embarrassing, but blundering ahead would be dangerous.

title: FAIRCHILD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $67,588,000 for the quarter and $62,510,000 for the year, and gains from effects of an accounting change of $22,933,000 for the quarter and $44,949,000 for the year; the quarter also includes an extraordinary charge of $25,830,000. c-Net income d-After net of $1,812,000 for the quarter and a loss of $166,812,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: Telling Tall Tales
description: TALKATIVE MAN. By R. K. Narayan. 123 pages. Viking. $15.95.

title: PATENTS
description: LEAD: Crystals described as extremely sensitive to heat and infrared radiation were patented this week by two staff members at Pennsylvania State University and three visiting scientists from China. Patent 4,648,991 was assigned to the Research Corporation, a foundation offering rights to industry. The crystals are expected to be useful in surveillance, military applications, fire and burglar alarms, and robots.

title: 4-Year-old Virginia Girl Dies After Two Liver Transplants
description: A 4-year-old girl whose need for a liver transplant resulted in a court ruling providing her with Medicaid funds has died of liver failure, hospital officials said today.

title: CAR SALES 2.2% IN EARLY MARCH
description: Despite a new round of buyer incentives by the General Motors Corporation, sales of new cars fell 2.2 percent, to 181,820, in the first 10 days of March, compared with the 1986 period, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: NATIONAL PATENT DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $5,400,000 from an arbitration claim. c-Includes a settlement of an arbitration claim and litigation of $659,000.

title: Leak in Booster Seal Delays Test of Space Shuttle Rocket
description: A glued rubber seal leaked hot gases recently in an interim test of segments of a space shuttle booster rocket, causing engineers to postpone the first firing of a booster since the Challenger disaster in January 1986.

title: AEP INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $706,000. c-Net income

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Frost Takes One-Shot Lead: David Frost, a South African who hasn't won in two years on the PGA Tour, dropped a 20-foot birdie putt on the 16th green yesterday in Orlando, Fla., to take the second-round lead by one shot in the $600,000 Hertz Bay Hill Classic. The 27-year-old Frost posted a three-under-par 68 for a 36-hole total of 135, seven under par. Frost leads Tim Simpson and Payne Stewart, who are at 136. SKIING Austrian Wins Downhill: Sigrid Wolf of Austria charged out of the 16th starting position and overtook Pam Fletcher of the United States yesterday to win a women's World Cup downhill ski race in Vail, Colo. Wolf, registering the first World Cup triumph of her six-year career, took advantage of a momentary change in the weather and was timed in 1 minute 49.79 seconds.

title: COMTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $32,000 for the quarter and $45,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: 2 ILLINOIS YOUTHS COMMIT SUICIDE
description: Two young women apparently killed themselves in a garage full of auto exhaust, and the police said today that they were probably influenced by the news of the joint suicides of four New Jersey teen-agers.

title: BOITANO ISN'T UPSET BY LOSS OF HIS TITLE
description: Brian Boitano reigned for a year as the world figure-skating champion with honesty and humility and openness. On Thursday night, when he lost the title to Brian Orser, he was the same. It was difficult to tell whether he had won or lost.

title: EPITOPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Officials in Bronx To Meet on Leader
description: The Bronx City Council delegation, which declined to meet yesterday with Mayor Koch to discuss the procedures in electing an interim Borough President, is to meet this morning to work out the details in choosing a successor to Stanley Simon.

title: U.S. Output Rose 0.5% Last Month
description: Output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose five-tenths of 1 percent in February, the fifth straight monthly increase, the Federal Reserve Board estimated today.

title: NU-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HOUSING CASES RUSHED ALONG, WITNESSES SAY
description: Three state rent examiners testified under oath yesterday that their superiors at the New York Division of Housing and Community Renewal ordered them to close outstanding landlord-tenant disputes improperly in order to disguise the agency's inefficiency.

title: In Defense of Mary Beth Whitehead
description: LEAD: It's time someone came to the defense of Mary Beth Whitehead. She's the woman who agreed to deliver a baby for another couple for $10,000, changed her mind, turned her back on the money, fled with the baby and wound up in court in a custody fight in New Jersey.

title: INVACARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: INDEPENDENT BOOKSTORES: HOW SURVIVORS MANAGE
description: The Remarkable Book Shop in Westport, Conn., often gets calls from frantic customers: ''The Yankee pot roast is on the stove; what do I do now?'' The independent store, housed in a colonial landmark building on the town's Main Street, has half-a-dozen rooms, one of them devoted just to cookbooks.

title: PANEL TO SUGGEST $20,000 RAISE IN MAYOR'S PAY
description: Mayor Koch's annual salary would rise $20,000, to $130,000, and other elected city officials would get raises of up to 19 percent under a salary commission's recommendations to be announced Monday.

title:
PATENTS;
A MONITOR OF REACTOR COOLANT PATENTS
description: LEAD: A MONITORING system for liquid-cooled nuclear reactors, patented this week for the Department of Energy, will enable operators to determine the water level in each section of the reactor.

title: With or Without Gravy
description: LEAD: In 1959, the year I moved from New York to Cambridge, there were four cafeterias in Harvard Square - all with wonderfully evocative names: Albiani's (as if it were the summer house of a Venetian aristocrat), Hayes-Bickford (the second son of the Earl of Bickford?), the Waldorf (self-evident) and Cardell's (it could be a jewelry store).

title: CALIFORNIA PRIEST ENTERS PRIME-TIME TV WHIRL
description: When he meets with television executives, the Roman Catholic priest wears a sports coat. ''Basically I'm being a salesman, and the collar makes them nervous,'' says Father Ellwood (Bud) Kieser, a Paulist.

title: ST. JOHN'S WINS ON BALDI'S SHOT WITH 2 SECONDS LEFT
description: Marco Baldi found himself in an unusual position tonight. The basketball game was on the line and he was the shooting the ball.

title: Outside Pressures
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOL IS ORDERED TO READMIT GIRL WHO MODELED SWIMSUITS
description: A judge ordered a church-operated school today to readmit a 17-year-old girl expelled on Wednesday, two months before graduation, for modeling swimsuits in a department store's fashion show.

title: THE DANCE: 'GISELLE'
description: What a wonderful ballet. Audiences have said that about ''Giselle'' ever since its premiere in 1841. The heartfelt performance that Dance Theater of Harlem gave of ''Giselle'' on Thursday night could easily have made the audience at Davis Hall of the City University of New York say it all over again. This work about a young village woman who discovers that her mysterious lover is really betrothed to a woman of a higher social class is both a fine example of the choreography of the Romantic era and an emotionally powerful drama that can still move dancegoers to tears. What a wonderful ballet.

title: HEALTHCO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $1,205,000 for restructuring of the company's distributor system for the quarter and year; the year also includes a gain of $440,000 from repayment of debt and a gain of $12,761,000 from the sale of HPSC Inc. common stock. The company also said the fourth quarter was reduced by about $768,000 because of the retraactive repeal of the investment tax credit.

title: Article 210787 -- No Title
description: A Federal appeals court today reversed a $2 million judgment against The Washington Post, ruling that a 1979 article in The Post did not libel William P. Tavoulareas, former president of the Mobil Oil Corporation.

title: ROBERT T. ELSON
description: Robert T. Elson, a writer and former editor and executive for Time Inc., died Wednesday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital of complications following a stroke. He was 80 years old and lived in East Hampton, L.I.

title: STANFORD REPORTS ADVANCE IN USE OF A SUPERCONDUCTOR
description: Scientists at Stanford University, in what could lead to rapid advances in superfast computers, reported today that they had succeeded in making a prototype electronic device out of a new class of superconducting materials.

title: CHICAGO RIVET & MACHINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOYAS CRUISE AND SYRACUSE STRUGGLES
description: At one end of the court workmen struggled to fix a rim bent by the dunk that provided the final points in Michigan's convincing 97-82 victory over Navy in the first round of the East Regionals tonight. At the other end the star of the game, indeed of the college season, took his final bows after scoring 50 points in a losing effort.

title: Insider Case Guilty Plea
description: Darius N. Keaton, a former director of the Santa Fe International Corporation, pleaded guilty yesterday to two felony charges related to his trading on inside information about the takeover of Santa Fe five years ago.

title: Albany Moves Ahead on Ethics
description: New York's Legislature did some heavy housecleaning this week on two embarrassments: ''no show'' jobs and extravagant ''member items'' spending.

title: ELECTRONIC TELE-COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DOLE URGES CONTINUED CONTACTS WITH ARAB WORLD
description: Senator Bob Dole, addressing an increasingly active Arab-American political group, took steps today to open communication with members of the ethnic group, despite the possible risk of alienating the powerful pro-Israel faction in the United States.

title: A British Bank Ends Market Role
description: One of Britain's biggest banks, the Midland, said that it would pull out of its market-making role on the London Stock Exchange because the operation was losing money. A market maker has the responsibility to provide an orderly market in certain stocks. It said its market-making activity had encountered greater competition than expected since the ''Big Bang'' last year, when the exchange was deregulated.

title: Marvin A. Asnes Dies at 58; Executive at Bowery Savings
description: Marvin A. Asnes, a vice chairman of the Bowery Savings Bank, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 58 years old.

title: Airbus Decision Delayed
description: Western Europe's Airbus consortium today postponed a formal decision to start construction of two new airliners, apparently because of a lack of governmental financial backing.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I first have to reconstruct my country before I start paying debts.'' - President Leon Febres Cordero of Ecuador. [ 1:1. ]

title: FIRST FARWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,603,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: NEW G.O.P. CHIEF: 'UNITY IS ACHIEVABLE'
description: CONNECTICUT Republicans, seeking to put their 1986 election losses and a spirited leadership fight behind them, embarked last week toward a goal that has eluded them in the past: party unity.

title: Prague
description: To the Editor: As a concert pianist, just returned from my second tour of Czechoslovakia, I enjoyed your features on Prague. Rollene W. Saal's poignant article, ''Listening to Voices That Are Muted,'' captures the complex panoply of a tempered society, where tacit meaning may convey more than the conversation itself. These days in Prague, individuality is quiescent but canny, somehow knowing that blending into the general design is safer than varying it.

title: NINE SHOWS COMBINED IN ONE
description: LEAD: FOR the third consecutive year, the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art's annual invitational exhibition features artists from all of Long Island. What was once a show open only to Nassau County residents has now been expanded to encompass Suffolk, where five of this year's nine participants live and work.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: BLOWN AWAY. By Ronald Sukenick. (Sun & Moon, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $10.95.) The familiar backdrop is Los Angeles and environs - the biomorphic pools, the sepia smog, the fake architecture. Against this surreal painted flat, the two-dimensional actors in Ronald Sukenick's latest metanovel mix and merge.

title: VIETNAMESE CUISINE IN GREENWICH
description: ON entering the white-walled, high-ceilinged upstairs dining room of La Maison Indochine in Greenwich, one has the illusion of stepping into a cool oasis from the steamy heat of Vietnam. Mother-of-pearl inlaid wood screens and Indochinese paintings continue the Southeast Asian motif.

title: THE PERILS OF PROLONGING THE MIDEAST STATUS QUO
description: LEAD: Israel has the largest stake in United States' policy in the Middle East, but it keeps sending Washington conflicting signals.

title: THOMS TOPPLED BY WITT IN SHOWDOWN
description: In a dramatic showdown tonight, Katarina Witt of East Germany regained the world figure-skating championship for women. It was her third title in four years and, she said, ''maybe my best performance ever.''

title: Question Of the Week; Are There Too Many Teams in the N.C.A.A. Tourney?
description: No. It gives a lot of smaller unknown schools a chance for a day or two of glory, playing their first game and (if they are lucky) their second against the powerhouses of basketball. I never heard of many of the schools in this year's tournament, but I like to root for the underdog. BARRY G. SHOEMAKER Norwich, N.Y.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Fabrics in Pleasantville In the Old Village Old Village Fabrics is at the junction of Routes 141 and 117 and, as the name indicates, is in the historic-village area in Pleasantville. The shop has a St. Patrick's Day special linked solely to the date of celebration Tuesday: a 17-percent reduction in the price of any fabric containing the color green.

title: FOR AN ADOPTED CHILD, CLOSED RECORDS VS. OPEN LOVING
description: THE struggle to find myself has been a battle of heart and soul. I am adopted. The search for who I am could not start with my ancestors or blood relatives; I know little of them. The search had to start from within. People used to ask me how it felt to be adopted and it was always somewhat difficult to put my feelings into perspective. When I was younger, I understood adoption only in the simplest of terms. I did not have the depth to delve into my soul and understand what it really meant.

title: HOW TO GET THE MOST FOR YOUR DOLLAR
description: There is no way to compile a sure-fire survival guide to Tokyo, for its definition of ''inexpensive'' is out of kilter with the rest of the universe.

title: Charges in Mail Dumping
description: A former letter carrier, suspected of dumping more than 70 bags of mail behind a house he had recently sold, has been charged with delay or destruction of mail by a United States Postal Service employee. The former letter carrier, Richard Brindle, pleaded not guilty before a Federal magistrate. The charge carries penalties of up to five years in prison and a $500 fine. Postal inspectors said they found scores of canvas bags stuffed with mail behind a house in Lincoln that Mr. Brindle sold in January.

title: FROM ARMS SELLING TO ENVIRONMENT, PANEL CONSIDERS THE ROLE OF CONGRESS
description: Throughout 1987, public officials, scholars and other experts are gathering in forums around New York City and the nation to discuss the Constitution on the 200th anniversary of its signing.

title: WELCOMING THE SUN
description: IN CALIFORNIA, WHERE I LIVE, THE ONE SEASON we really don't have is spring. You know when it's summer, and you know when it's autumn - believe it or not, the leaves of the maples and sycamores do turn - and you know when it's winter -it rains then. But there's no such thing as spring. It just gets gradually a little dryer and a little warmer every day from February to June. And yet, somewhere around the last week in March an odd feeling grips you - something atavistic, something northern and primordial that makes you want to leap with joy, or kill yourself, or fall in love, or write a poem. And that's the vernal equinox.

title:
DINING OUT;
AN OASIS OF CHARM IN TRENTON
description: LEAD: NO, George Washington did not sleep there, but, according to The Eagle Tavern's modest claim, he did at least pass by. Built in 1765, the handsome, galleried brick structure is one of the few pre-Revolutionary buildings still standing in the state capital. Rescued by the city from the brink of demolition and then restored by the Trenton Historical Society, it now stands as an oasis of Colonial charm in a nondescript downtown block.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: HOUSE

title: CUPIDS AND CUSPIDS
description: THE BOND STREET BURLESQUE An Historical Novel of Murder. By Raymond Paul. 363 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: STILL AS SLICK AS SUGAR
description: AS soon as Sugar Ray Leonard hopped into the ring to shadow-box, his thighs appeared to be thicker and stronger than in earlier years. ''His body is different, he's bigger all over,'' one of his trainers, Angelo Dundee, was saying. ''He's a middleweight now, he'll weigh 158, but he's still smooth.'' And still slick.

title: Travel Advisory; New England Seacoast, Oregon Wine Country
description: Whales, Birds And the Story Of Seafaring

title: Catherine Mann Weds
description: Catherine Marie Mann, a daughter of Barbara Mann of Clifton Springs, N.Y., and Charles A. Mann of Webster, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jacob Nielsen-Kolding, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jorgen Nielsen-Kolding of Reigate, Surrey, England. The Rev. David Bonin performed the ceremony at St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church in Palmyra, N.Y.

title: IN SEARCH OF AMERICA
description: In 1978, when Joel Sternfeld received a Guggenheim Fellowship, a new world opened up to the photographer. ''All at once,'' says Sternfeld, who had previously portrayed the streets of his native New York, ''it seemed as if the entire continent, every region, every season and every photographic means were within reach.'' He set out with an old-fashioned Wista large-format camera, a 1972 Volkswagen camper, and the desire to find beauty in the contemporary landscape. Eight years' work is contained in his ''American Prospects,'' to be published by Times Books in April in association with the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston, where an exhibition of the work opens on April 5.

title: What Art Is
description: To the Editor:

title: DOCUMENTARY
description: CRUSADE IN THE PACIFIC At War with Japan: Philippine Independence to New Guinea. March of Time Television. Embassy Home Entertainment. 130 minutes. $24.95.

title: PRINCETON REVIEWS POLICIES ON WOMEN
description: LEAD: JUST when Princeton University thought it was finally improving its ratio of male to female undergraduate students, female enrollment dropped last fall, prompting the university to review its strategies.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
PLAYWRIGHT WITH A PENCIL
description: LEAD: In 1936, when he was in his late 30's, the Spanish poet and playwright Federico Garcia Lorca was executed by a fascist firing squad. Now, 50 years later, his work is experiencing something of a revival. Forgotten plays are being translated by young, talented writers, the theater is showing new interest in performing them and his work is being reissued.

title: Richard Pastorino Weds Colette Moylan in Jersey
description: Colette Moylan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Moylan of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Pastorino, the son of Mrs. Edward Pastorino of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Pastorino. The Rev. Bernard Fisher performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Ridgewood.

title: TAKE ME TO THE BEACH: Permanent Spring Break in the Middle East
description: My favorite beach in Israel may not be in Israel for long: Taba, the disputed 700-yard-long stretch of Red Sea shoreline about two miles south of Eilat is claimed by Egypt, and an international panel is spending the next two years deciding its fate.

title: TEEN-AGE GROUP'S GUIDE: GREENWICH IS NOT BORING
description: LEAD: A GROUP of Greenwich teen-agers has uncovered a wealth of services available to teen-agers in the town, and has published its findings. The group, which calls itself Greenwich Teen Voice, has put out a directory, ''Greenwich - What's in It for You? - A Directory Written for Teens, by Teens.'' The directory cost the group $700, which was funded by the Greenwich Council on Youth and

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IF anything drives Marjorie Anne Reed crazy, it's people who ask her what she does all day. Ms. Reed organizes corporate events and lectures on how to plan these events under the new tax law. She also has her fingers in other business pies. She is asked the question that drives her crazy for only one reason - she works at home.

title: A NEW EXPERIENCE IN SIMPLICITY
description: The newly introduced Canon EOS 650 and I went off to the Caribbean last week, a new experience for both of us. The camera didn't seem to have any trouble adjusting, auto-focusing its way through a gamut of crystal-clear beaches and char-broiled sunbathers with unnerving aplomb. I, on the other hand, took a few days to get relaxed with my high-tech companion.

title: SHOREHAM FOES LOOK TO LONG STRUGGLE
description: LEAD: THREE Federal administrative judges opened a hearing last week to consider the adequacy of a Long Island Lighting Company emergency evacuation plan for its Shoreham plant. But as the formal proceeding began, state and Suffolk County officials already seem to be looking ahead to Federal court fights, where they say the

title: IN QUOTES
description: The trade bill is a ''toughening of our trade policy, but it does it in a way that opens markets without the frightening word of protectionism.'' Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois

title: DATA BANK: March 15, 1987
HARVARD TAKES TITLE WITH ITS POWER PLAY
description: Harvard fired 13 shots at Scott Yearwood, the St. Lawrence goalie, in the second period tonight and the four that went by him earned the Eastern College Athletic Conference tournament championship with a 6-3 victory in Boston Garden. Three goals came on power plays at which Harvard had excelled all season.

title: A New Finding On Antarctica's Polar Ozone Hole
description: Scientists generally agree that chlorofluorocarbons and other chlorine-containing chemicals can destroy the ozone that shields the earth from the sun's harmful ultraviolet rays. Thus they find it perturbing that every September and October a ''hole'' appears in the ozone layer over Antarctica.

title: INDIA'S PRESIDENT CONFRONTS GANDHI
description: A long-simmering dispute between Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and President Zail Singh of India erupted in public this week, creating an embarrassing new political crisis for Mr. Gandhi's Government.

title: Garbage-Conversion Site Gains in Allure
description: A BARREN, wind-swept spit of land that juts into the Hudson River at Peekskill has lain fallow for a decade. Now, however, because a garbage-conversion plant there has become an asset, it is being fought over by developers.

title: Guilty in Boy's Pepper Death
description: A woman was been found guilty Thursday of involuntary manslaughter in the death of her 5-month-old son, who choked on pepper she was said to have poured into his mouth. The 26-year-old woman, Elizabeth R. Jewell, of Webster Groves, faces up to seven years in prison. She is to be sentenced April 14.

title: WOOD STOVES FAULTED IN POLLUTION
description: LEAD: JUNE SHAW, a member of this Bergen County town's Environmental Commission, never thought she would attack one of the environmental movement's sacred cows, but her neighbor's wood stove, she said, is the bane of her existence.

title: VIDEO RESUMES FOR JOB INTRODUCTION
description: DOUG MACKEOWN, an out-of-work mechanical engineer from Middle Haddam, said he plans to make a video resume to complement his written one in hopes it will increase his chances for employment.

title: NORA KAYE - THE INIMITABLE DRAMATIC BALLERINA
description: NORA KAYE WAS ONE OF THE rare dancers in history who defied all imitation. A charter member in 1940 of American Ballet Theater, where she soon became an international star, Ms. Kaye extended an established art form; she took ballet dancing into a new dimension of performance and meaning. Mention the term ''dramatic ballerina'' when discussing contemporary ballet and her name - and none other -springs to mind. Her impact was so strong that she seemed a natural model for dancers who would succeed her.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: 'Olympics of the Mind'

title: BOSTON AIMS FOR EXTENSIVE WATER TRANSIT BY '88
description: This began as a maritime city, but for years Boston turned away from its waterfront, treating its harbor, unused and largely inaccessible at the center of a bustling, crowded metropolis, like the hole in the doughnut.

title: Toy Boats and Pony Rides In the Heart of Paris
description: As the great parks and gardens of Europe come into bloom, three writers offer a nosegay of favorites.

title: Benefits in Three States
description: For Fans of the Bard March 18 - The 8 P.M. performance of Les Miserables at the Broadway Theater, followed by a Champagne party with the cast, will benefit the American Friends of the Royal Shakespeare Theater. Tickets are $100. Call 212-308-1399 or 212-799-7944. Local Craftsmen March 19 - The six-year-old Empire State Crafts Alliance is a network of artists who work in glass, clay, fiber, wood and metal. It includes established artists with works in major museums. The producer Joseph Papp will help auction 100 works as various as a handblown martini pitcher, jewelry, furniture and sculptures. Prices will range from $250 to more than $2,000. Tickets for the auction and cocktail party from 6:30 to 9 P.M. at Steuben Glass on Fifth Avenue at 56th Street are $50 at the door, or call 914-471-8188. For Those Who Fled March 19 - Founded in 1942 by refugees from Nazi-held France, the International League for Human Rights has gone on to aid other victims of persecution. The apt setting for a benefit for the League will be the 8 P.M. performance of Les Miserables, the musical adaption of Victor Hugo's novel of social injustice in France. A reception will follow at Gallagher's restaurant on West 52d Street. Tickets are $150. Call 212-684-1221. Parties in Connecticut March 19 - In its 76th year as one of Connecticut's leading philanthropic organizations, the Woman's Club of Greenwich will hold a cocktail-buffet and preview of its eighth annual antiques show, at which 54 dealers from 12 states will have displays. The show will be open to the public Friday from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M., and Saturday and Sunday from noon to 6 P.M. Admission is $4 at the Civic Center on Harding Road in Old Greenwich off exit 5 of Interstate 95. Tickets for the preview from 7 to 9 P.M. are $25 or $35 and include admission to the show. For $100, a Champagne reception is included. Call 203-869-2046 or 203-637-4583. March 20 - Billed as one of the largest art shows ever held in Connecticut, Silvermine Collection '87 will have works by more than 300 artists of the Silvermine Guild Arts Center in New Canaan, Conn. It is a 65-year-old nonprofit organization that includes a guild of artists, three galleries, a school of art and educational programs. The show, at the headquarters of Pitney Bowes in Stamford, off exit 7 of Interstate 95, will be open to the public March 21, 22, 28 and 29 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $5. A benefit preview of the show with cocktails and a buffet will be held from 7 to 11 P.M. Tickets are $50. Call 212-966-5618. Mardi Gras Cruise March 20 - A four-hour cruise aboard the yacht Princess will benefit the Flushing Council on Culture and the Arts and its programs of free summer park concerts. The theme of the cruise down the Hudson and up the East River will be Mardi Gras, with a Cajun dinner and dancing to the Bourbon Street Jazz Band. Boarding is at 7:30 P.M. at Pier 62 on West 23d Street. Tickets are $125. Call 718-463-7700. Kips Bay Youth March 21 - It started in 1915, when residents of the Kips Bay area in Manhattan got together to see what could be done about roving gangs of young vandals. The solution was the creation of the Kips Bay Boys' Club, where some 3,200 boys and girls ages 6 to 18 participate annually in educational, recreational and sports programs. To raise funds for the club's junior committee, there will be hors d'oeuvres, an open bar and dancing from 9 P.M. to 2 A.M. at the Park Avenue Atrium, Lexington Avenue at 46th Street. Tickets are $50. Call 212-893-8600. New Jersey Opera Ball March 21 - The New Jersey State Opera is planning a full evening at its annual black-tie benefit. It will be an ''Evening of Medieval Merriment'' at the Sheraton Tara Hotel in Parsippany, at the intersection of Routes 287 and 80, starting with cocktails at 7. Dinner, entertainment and dancing follow. Tickets are $175. Call 201-623-5757. Midtown Hoedown March 22 - Traditional and new country music will be featured at the West Bank Cafe Downstairs Theater Bar, 407 West 42d Street, at an 8 P.M. benefit for the homeless. Tickets are $10, with proceeds going to Volunteers of America. Call 212-695-6909. Avant-Garde Event March 23 - One of the newer theatrical arrivals in town is En Garde Arts, which transforms nontheatrical settings like an unused automobile showroom into stage space, a sort of reinvention of the earliest street theater. The historic Friends Meeting House at 15 Rutherford Place opposite Stuyvesant Park is the setting for its new work in progress called ''Public City.'' A reception follows the 8 P.M. performance. Tickets are $25; $100 for performance and reception. Call 212-945-3270. For Anglophiles March 23 - The educational programs of the English-Speaking Union will benefit from a 6 P.M. cocktail party and dinner in the Tower Suite of the Time and Life Building, followed by the 8 P.M. performance of Les Miserables. Transportation up Park Avenue to 96th Street will be provided afterward for those living in that area. Tickets are $250; for performance and transportation alone, $120 and $150. Call 212-879-6800, extension 217.

title: Prague
description: To the Editor: The articles on Prague brought attention to an extraordinary city. But you've touched only a bit more than the surface. The ghetto area by itself is worthy of a detailed article. My husband and I, on our recent visit, stumbled upon a find. The Military History Museum on Hradcany Square is a work of Renaissance architecture standing in good condition. It is the collection that merits attention since here is history rewritten. From the World War II exhibits one could not learn that any country besides the Soviet Union participated. The museum is open from May 1 to Nov. 1.

title: LOVE AMONG THE ORANGE ROOFS
description: THE PROPHETEERS By Max Apple. 306 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Cloth, $16.95. Perennial Library. Paper, $7.95.

title: Review; RECITAL: KONRAD WOLF
description: KONRAD WOLFF put on his own 80th-birthday party at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night. Generously, he also provided the entertainment. The eminent pianist, teacher and scholar played a full evening of music for a gathering of family, friends, colleagues, disciples - and the general public. The audience in itself was a tribute to Mr. Wolff's impact on the country in which he has lived since 1941. One noted in it not only distinguished pianists but many young people as well.

title: DATA UPDATE: March 15, 1987
A YEAR OF EDISON CENTENNIAL EVENTS
description: LEAD: THE chemistry laboratory overflows with test tubes, encyclopedias and dusty stacks of turn-of-the-century trade magazines. In the crowded stockroom are exotica such as rare walnuts and rhinoceros tusks, and in the machine shop an obsolete grinder still churns and whirs - a symbol of Thomas Alva Edison's endless energy.

title: Rediscovering Medical Leeches
description: LEECHES, widely used by doctors in the 18th and 19th centuries to draw blood from patients - usually for the wrong reasons - were reported to be coming into use again in American surgery.

title:
DINING OUT;
CLUB-LIKE SERENITY IN RYE BROOK
description: LEAD: SET far afield from civilization, Arrowwood was designed as the Compleat Environment, providing all to all. The contrast between the two main dining areas illustrates that conscious planning: one an aerie, with stars beyond soaring glass walls and twinklers in the ficus trees promising an evening of magic.

title: By Paul Scott. Edited by Shelley C. Reece. 226 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.  AFTER THE RAJ  British Novels of India Since 1947. By David Rubin. 197 pp. Hanover, N.H.: University Press of New England. $19.95.    THE main outlines of Paul Scott's literary life are clear but much about the man and his achievement remains shadowy. Born in London in 1920 and educated at Winchmore Hill Collegiate School, Scott served in the army in India during the Second World War and then until 1960 worked in publishing and as director of the David Higham Agency, literary agents, writing plays and half a dozen novels after hours. Success came gradually between 1966 and 1975, as each of the volumes that would become the panoramic ''Raj Quartet'' appeared. A related novel, the splendid ''Staying On,'' won the prestigious Booker Prize in 1977. Scott died a year later, achieving extraordinary fame posthumously when millions of people watched ''The Raj Quartet'' on television during 1984-85 as ''The Jewel in the Crown,'' the first title in the series, and have bought the ''Raj'' novels ever since.   As yet though, there is no biography and only a handful of critical studies, the most useful of which have been those by Patrick Swinden, a senior lecturer at the University of Manchester. In this context, readers might well look to the 11 essays in ''On Writing and the Novel'' to learn more about Scott as a man and writer. But, with the notable exception of a fine piece called ''Method: The Mystery and the Mechanics'' and a subtle reflection on Britain and India after E. M. Forster, they are likely to be disappointed.   Scott was a reluctant essayist and nearly all the selections printed here were given as invitational talks at literary luncheons, summer school writers' conferences and dozens of stops on government-sponsored speaking tours of India. More often than not, his tone for the occasion is a kind of genial ''we're all in this together and good luck to us.'' Gentle jests about food and the weather mix with agreeable but platitudinous comments on the craft of fiction: ''Writing is a discovery . . . a vitamin, not a drug''; ''Imagination is not enough. Knowledge is necessary. And an experience of the oddity of life''; ''Literature must always be alive - to the past, to the present, to the opportunities of the future''; authors, rather like Tennessee Williams's ''poor Blanche Dubois,'' ''depend a great deal for well-being and peace of mind on the unconscious courtesy of strangers.''   About fiction in general and about other people's work, Scott is almost never illuminating; the same favorite quotations from Hazlitt, James or Lionel Trilling appear frequently with no glosses, and jovial anecdotes about Tolstoy and Turgenev, Shaw and Conrad stand in for analysis. Yet happily, Scott's concrete observations about his own work are always absorbing and revelatory. Every admirer of ''The Raj Quartet'' will treasure his explanation of how from glimpses of a girl in Calcutta, from reading about a criminal assault in Amritsar and the 1919 riots in the Punjab and from a long process of culling and reflecting, he ''discovered'' Daphne Manners and wrote the unforgettable description of the running girl that opens ''The Jewel in the Crown.''   Scott (in the essay on ''The Mystery and the Mechanics'') formulates his esthetic of the novel as a kind of dramatic poem built on expanding images and multiple points of view, and at the same time reveals one of his cardinal principles of characterization: that individual human action is often subject to the processes of an ienflamed collective conscience. Unlike so many of his bland observations about other writers and fiction in general, Scott's description of his own procedures has a contagious excitement and an interest that comes of a justified pride in obliged creation.   ''The image of the girl running didn't peter out -the veins of possible exploration became intensely complex. When you feel this happening you are at the heart of your mystery. Extracting the ore is the mechanical side of the operation, and to extract it you stand away from the image and subject it to a kind of bombardment, as if you're trying to split an atom. You bombard it with your knowledge, your experience, and your imagination, your creative impulse. If you're lucky you have a beautiful explosion.''   Something of the same purposive tension comes across in Scott's essay ''After Marabar: Britain and India, a Post-Fosterian View.'' Here the source of energy comes from his having been challenged by two vital and pointed questions about his work. ''Why,'' an Englishwoman asked, ''does he have to revive all that old bitterness?'' ''Tell me,'' queried an Indian, ''what you think you have to offer the world today that might be of value?'' The two blunt questions seemed inevitably to lead to a third: Didn't Forster in ''A Passage to India'' cover the subject satisfactorily enough?   Scott's answer comes out not in serial and conclusive form but as a textured meditation on some of the issues pertaining to all the questions. By reviving the old bitterness he hopes to combat present ignorance and prejudice and to forge a new understanding. But modesty requires him to admit that perhaps the most valuable thing he has to offer is the uncertainty of having anything of value to offer at all. In Scott's view, this mix of skepticism and idealism can best be expressed in that most valuable of dialectical forms, the novel. Fiction is a moral dialogue between writer and reader that invites not acquiescence but a ''creative and critical response to the life it depicts.'' Forster created such a dialogue, and so - Scott hopes - did he. In his opinion, however, ''The Raj Quartet'' is hardly a grand philosophical and prophetic set of novels, but rather a kind of elegiac saga that tries to capture ''the melancholy arising from too long an exile, from too far a removal from the source of dynamic native experience.''   For these views, and many others, Scott is the hero of David Rubin's study, ''After the Raj: British Novels of India Since 1947.'' Mr. Rubin, a novelist and visiting professor of modern Indian languages at Columbia University, begins with a brief survey of British fiction set in India before independence and skillfully identifies its dominant modes and myths. Then, following a chapter on Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, he turns to Scott, who in his judgment produced by far the best novels about the relations between the British and the Indians ''not only since Independence but since the very beginning of such fiction.''   Mr. Rubin's case for Scott's predominance in the tradition rests on a sure-footed, informative account of the narrative thrust, varied characterization and thematic coherence of ''The Raj Quartet.'' In Mr. Rubin's view, Scott's immense spectacle of the last years of the British in India is unified by the dramatic and complex working out of a metaphor that joins and illuminates public and private history.   What Scott has done is to make sexual excess, deviation and aberration a near-inevitable correlative of the imperial process; the greed, and the moral and ethical blindness that inspire and sustain colonialism in the sphere of public action are accompanied by a parallel degeneration in the private sphere, where sexual problems, violence and confusion reveal and symbolize the same moral failure. MR. RUBIN'S account of ''The Raj Quartet'' is often eloquent and insightful, but in his eagerness to support the case for Scott's supremacy, he continually finds it necessary to make claims for the importance of the four novels that are likely to strike many readers as strained to the point of implausibility. Because of the prominence of ''A Passage to India'' in the history of his subject, Mr. Rubin keeps whittling away at Forster's stature. While admitting his genius for physical and emotional evocation and for caricature, he finds his perceptions of India and the Indians only narrow and stereotypical, and too easily dismisses Forster's expansive mysteries as mere mystifications. Mr. Rubin (unlike Scott) resists the imaginative sweep of Forster's vision in which mysticism and comedy are inseparable; and he has virtually nothing to say about the brilliant originality and suppleness of Forster's style.   Then, too, in order to elevate Scott as both a chronicler of modern history and a psychological realist, Mr. Rubin unconvincingly compares him with Tolstoy and Proust. But the more persuasive comparison - mutatis mutandis - would be with Trollope, whose Barchester and Palliser novels offer some of the same pleasures of vivid storytelling, memorable characterization and shrewd social analysis that can make Scott's bleak panorama so engrossing. As Webster Schott once put it in these pages, ''The Raj Quartet'' is one of the longest, most successfully rendered works of 19th-century fiction written in the 20th century. Scott was probably pleased by that, and so should we be.

title: PROSPECTS
description: LEAD: Merger Game: Still Playing

title: A SOPRANO AND 2 FOREIGN PIANISTS
description: ENA FREEMAN

title: EDUCATORS ALARMED BY GROWING RATE OF DROPOUTS AMONG HISPANIC YOUTH
description: As concern rises over the high rate of dropouts from the nation's schools, educators are looking with increasing alarm at what many consider the most worrisome aspect of the problem: the soaring dropout rate among Hispanic students.

title: VINTAGE DANNY KAYE
description: THE KID FROM BROOKLYN Starring Danny Kaye, Virginia Mayo, Vera-Ellen. Directed by Norman Z. McLeod. 1946. Embassy Home Entertainment. 96 minutes. $24.95.

title: Frailties of Mountain Climbers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Care Of a Leafy Amenity
description: AMONG the more appealing features of a single-family house are the trees that shade and decorate it. They can add value to the property by increasing the attractiveness of the setting, sheltering the house from icy winds, screening neighbors' yards and cooling the house in summer.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Resort Fraud Brings Action
description: LEAD: TIME-SHARE resorts with shaky finances and suspect marketing practices have taken more than their share of Vermont's consumer-protection efforts, according to Jeffrey L. Amestoy, the state's Attorney General.

title: Europe's Austerity
description: To the Editor:

title: MEASURE OF A MAN IN A BOTTLE OF BEER
description: WITH John Madden as the high priest and malt liquor the libation, our male culture's common prayer has become the loud belch.

title: A Reporter's Odyssey In Unseen China
description: If John F. Burns's stay in a Chinese prison was unpleasant, what about the grave consequences that faced his Chinese companion, Zhang Daxing (''A Reporter's Odyssey in Unseen China,'' Feb. 8)? Mr. Zhang spent more than two months in jail, with his whereabouts kept from his family for much of that time.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CONFRONTING THE COLOR LINE: The Broken Promise of the Civil Rights Movement in Chicago. By Alan B. Anderson and George W. Pickering. (University of Georgia, Cloth, $40; Paper, $17.95.) One of the biggest disappointments in the career of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. took place in Chicago in 1966 when he brought the civil rights movement north.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: I KNOW that this is a foolish notion. Logically, I admit that there is no cause or effect. But sometimes I get the feeling that I am bad karma for uncut woodlands, an unwitting John the Baptist for development.

title: Crack Murder: A Detective Story
description: I was intrigued by the observations of Detectives Cachie and Weidenbaum that ''guilty suspects'' often go to sleep ''as soon as detectives let them know they know the facts.'' This behavior is remarkably similar to a phenomenon known by sleep researchers as ''stress sleep.'' It is especially well documented in infants, who go into a rather tense, quiet (non-rapid-eye-movement) sleep when exposed to certain forms of averse stimulation, such as persistent loud noise, physical restraint or rocking in a mechanical rocker.

title: Police Force Quits in Vermont
description: Milton's The town's six full-time police officers resigned Thursday in a dispute with their chief, leaving the town without a regular police force.

title: WHAT'S HZ? XYLEM? THOR? (THIS IS ONLY A TEST)
description: What do literate Americans know, and why do they need to know it? E. D. Hirsch Jr. is a man who has tried to find out. Mr. Hirsch is a professor of English at the University of Virginia. He and two colleagues -- Joseh Kett, a historian, and James Trefil, a scientist --have identified nearly 5.000 names, images, concepts, proverbs (from absence makes the heart grow fonder to youth will have its fling), idioms, historical characters and events, technical terms and other entities most of which tend to appear regularly in serious newspapers, grown-up magazines and popular books of a thoughtful kind. These expressions are the tokens of communication between writers and readers in our society, Mr. Hirsch believes, the tools of the culturally literate, and people who can't use these tools are laboring under a handicap. He thinks a high school graduate ought to command them.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
Autumn in Paris
description: LEAD: PARIS DESIGNERS consistently use a single word to describe this year's fall and winter collections: wearable. Given the demands that some French clothes have made on women in recent seasons, this is good news. But more than merely wearable, the designs, which will be shown beginning Wednesday, are desirable in a fashion sense, from the very new-looking short coats with flared skirts to the welcome injections of pretty colors.

title: VERMONT'S SEASON OF STEAM AND SUGAR
description: Along about mid-March, when the nights are cold and the days are relatively warm, Everett Palmer knows he will get a feeling in his bones - the urge, he calls it -that tells him maple-sugaring time has come. It's been that way every year since 1917, when Mr. Palmer, then 10 years old, began sugaring with his team of steer calves, Star and Bright.

title: PUBLIC ROLE IN TOXIC CLEANUP
description: CITIZENS throughout our country can now play a crucial role in the ongoing effort to clean up toxic-waste sites across America.

title: Prague
description: To the Editor: Re: Prague (Travel, Jan. 25) you were right. One fears the place may be discovered, but we can't help letting on about its little pleasures.

title: SILKY MYRTLEWOOD OF OREGON'S COAST
description: The driver heading north on Highway 101 through California's forests and along the Oregon coast is bombarded with invitations to stop along the way and buy various objects made of wood. In California, the roadside merchants are offering redwood; cross the state line into Oregon, and you're in myrtlewood country.

title: BUSINESS
description: WINNING AT WORK, VOL. I Karl Lorimar Home Video. 60 Minutes. $29.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: WABASH. By Robert Olen Butler. (Knopf, $15.95.) The struggles of a young working-class couple for individual fulfillment are explored in this uneven but eventually engaging novel set in the steel town of Wabash, Ill., in 1932. Jeremy Cole, a steelworker, grapples with a growing awareness of social inequities in the shadow of the mill, and wonders whether to throw in his lot with the Communist agitators.

title: Rally Protesting Civil Rights Draws 250 in Georgia Town
description: About 250 people cheered calls for racial segregation and for the repeal of Federal civil rights laws at a white supremacy rally today in Forsyth County, the scene of a huge civil rights march in January.

title: FOR ISRAEL AND U.S., A GROWING MILITARY PARTNERSHIP
description: WATCHING foreign affairs is sometimes like watching a magician; the eye is drawn to the hand performing the dramatic flourishes, leaving the other hand - the one doing the important job - unnoticed. So it seemed last week as the

title: Lynn Ackerman Planning to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Ackerman of Oceanside, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Lynn Ann Ackerman to Daniel Marc Berger, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Philmore Berger of Oceanside.

title: Settling Estates
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop Music
description: In the early stages of her career, Rosemary Clooney had some lively, exuberant hits, notably ''Come On-a My House.'' But she has always basically been a ballad singer, catching the subtle flavors of a song and projecting them meaningfully. In recent years, she has been turning more and more to the golden age of pop music - the decades between the 1920's and the 1950's.

title: CLAIMING CREDIT FOR A VITAL IMPROVEMENT
description: There are five claimants: the United States, Panama, France, England and India. Who should get the credit for the start of contract bridge?

title: MAJORCAN RITUAL
description: WHO DOES NOT HAVE a paradise to which he would retreat if liberated from the quotidian burdens of what we call real life? There is a Gauguin streak in all of us - that impulse to throw off the responsibilities of citified existence and find a place of simplicity and repose. And it is not by chance that islands are central to such imaginings. An island, by definition, is cut off from the rest of the world; it is a limited space, defined by nature, where one explores intensively rather than extensively, where one's roamings become, over time, ritualized, liturgical. Gauguin had Tahiti. I have the village of Deya on the island of Majorca.

title: Catherine Tulis Plans To Wed C. F. Stimmel
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Mott Walbridge of Short Hills, N.J., have announced that their daughter, Catherine W. Tulis, plans to marry Chandler F. Stimmel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Stimmel of Slingerlands, N.Y., on May 30.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POP
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT RULING MAY OPEN WAY FOR MORE POLITICAL REFUGEES
description: THE Supreme Court decides relatively few cases involving immigration, and in even fewer does it uphold the rights of aliens. But last week, aliens won a big victory as the High Court ruled that the Government must relax its standard for deciding if they are eligible for asylum.

title: Louise R. Merritt Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Louise Rose Merritt to John Devlin Keogh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Keogh of Larchmont, N.Y., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William R. Merritt of Scituate, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. A September wedding is planned.

title: GAMES MEN PLAY- ON FILM AND STAGE
description: EARLY IN ''DINER,'' HIS autobiographical first film, the writer-director Barry Levinson showed a booth full of Baltimore buddies arguing the relative merits of Frank Sinatra and Johnny Mathis songs as aphrodisiacs. Then he swung briefly to the other side of the restaurant, and a table of older men, all aluminum-siding salesmen. They told a story about conning the owner of a brick house into buying siding, disparaged lawyers for not making ''an honest buck'' and then virtually disappeared from the movie, for ''Diner'' belonged to the younger generation.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE PRINCETON SHOW: PERENNIAL SUCCESS
description: LEAD: LOCATION, selectivity, impeccable presentation and outstanding volunteer support contribute to the perennial success of the Princeton Antiques Show, long recognized as one of the state's most attractive presentations and one of the best.

title: FOOD
description: GOURMET MENUS VOLS. 1 AND 2 Featuring Etta Sawyer. Video La Cuisine. Best Film & Video. 30 minutes each. $14.95 each.

title: Polarization in Chicago
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Honest
description: ARE YOU A MARRIED HOMOSEXUAL with two children?''

title: A BLEAK PICTURE OF POLAND IN 'A WOMAN ALONE'
description: THE life depicted in the Polish film ''A Woman Alone'' is unrelievedly grim. It is the life of Irena (Maria Chwalibog), an unwed working mother whose energies are being taxed to their limit. She lives in a small room with her young son Bob (Pawel Witczak), and must share a bed with him; mother and son are also harassed by their landlord. Her job as a letter carrier is so physically draining that she sometimes collapses under the weight of her sack. Her life seems to hold no satisfactions, not even small ones. Even when she bathes at home (where there is no indoor plumbing), she must do it with Bob's used bathwater.

title: WHAT IT TAKES TO UNRAVEL TANGLED IRAN-ARMS WEB
description: THE parallels between the Iran-contra affair and Watergate are inexact. No evidence has been found that implicates Cabinet-level officials, much less the President himself, in common crimes like burglary or perjury. What is more, from all appearances, this White House is cooperating with the investigators, not stonewalling them.

title: Why Suburbs Beat the Boroughs in Gaining Tenants
description: DESPITE a smorgasbord of subsidies, the boroughs outside of Manhattan rarely beat the New Jersey competition for back-office tenants, dollar for dollar.

title: FINE FRENCH FARE: SEARCH NO MORE
description: LE SOIR in Bayport is the dream everyone hopes to find: an attractive little French restaurant serving good food at reasonable prices. It is not a secret, though, for Le Soir has been in business for 10 years and has a large following.

title: TEACHERS' SALARIES RISING SHARPLY AMID PUSH TO IMPROVE EDUCATION
description: Teachers are winning significant salary increases as local and state governments around the nation move to improve the quality of public education, according to education experts.

title: IRISH SQUEAK BY; NORTH CAROLINA BEATS MICHIGAN
description: North Carolina and Notre Dame play dramatically different styles of basketball. But today each relied on this year's newest offensive wrinkle, the 3-point field goal, to subdue a stubborn foe and advance to an East Regional semifinal matchup Thursday night at the Meadowlands.

title: SON'S DANCE LESSONS TAKE SOME INTERESTING TURNS
description: SON No. 1 does not lie. So I believe him when he says he only stepped on her foot four times, and not the 11 times she maintains his size seven feet trod on her dainty little toes. Further, in protesting his innocence, he points out that three of those times were not his fault - he was pushed from behind. It was, admittedly, unclear if the fourth time was deliberate, but it seems to me that it might even have been justified.

title: LAWYER REACTS TO DRUG REPORT
description: A lawyer for the victims of the Howard Beach attack challenged the significance of findings by the New York City Medical Examiner's office that Michael Griffith had traces of cocaine in his system when he died.

title: Off Broadway
description: Some of the biggest names in New York real estate have been shuffling sites and assembling land north of Times Square. They are preparing for the future office buildings that are expected to tower over and illuminate the area known as Midtown West with blinking, colorful signs. Following in the wake are smaller players, who are also undertaking Class-A office space, but on a more modest scale.

title: Julie Hope Galton to Wed William Glenn Gale in June
description: Julie Hope Galton, a hydrologist for Philip Williams & Associates in San Francisco, and William Glenn Gale, a doctoral candidate in economics at Stanford University, plan to be married in June. Dr. and Mrs. Barry B. Galton of Wayne, N.J., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Manfred Gale of Annandale, Va.

title: 'TRACERS' AT PURCHSE
description: BECAUSE professional theater is in short supply in the county, it follows that when a production as potent as the much-acclaimed ''Tracers'' passes through - even if it is just for one night - attention must be paid.

title: BRIDGEPORT MUSEUM GETS GIFT OF WARHOL FLOWER PRINTS
description: LEAD: THE Museum of Art, Science and Industry of Bridgeport has been given two portfolios of silk-screen prints of flowers by the late Andy Warhol, and is trying to get at least one of them ready for an exhibition opening April 11.

title: INDIANA DEFEATS AUBURN
description: Steve Alford scored 31 points and his backcourt partner, Keith Smart, added 20 points and 15 assists as Indiana rallied from a 14-point deficit to beat Auburn, 107-90, today in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Midwest Regional.

title: Home Is Here, Not Russia
description: Alexander Altman, age 15, stayed in America last month when his parents and 4-year-old brother went home to Russia. Their separation was as anguished, but not as angry, as the Polovchak family's seven years ago. Then, 12-year-old Walter Polovchak ran away and sought asylum to avoid going back to the Ukraine.

title: Eve Ohringer Is Bride Of Stephen E. Milstein
description: At Temple Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday Eve Irene Ohringer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon J. Ohringer of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., and New York, was married to Stephen Eric Milstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Monroe G. Milstein of Mount Holly, N.J. Rabbi Gilbert Klepperman, assisted by Rabbi Stanley Platek and Cantor Marcus Ehrlich, performed the ceremony.

title: SUICIDE-PREVENTION EFFORTS GAIN ACCEPTANCE IN WESTCHESTER SCHOOLS
description: Two years after Westchester County experienced a rash of suicides by teen-agers, more than half the school districts in the county have suicide prevention programs, and officials report growing acceptance by students.

title: CLASSICAL AND JAZZ ARTISTS MEET HALFWAY
description: THE ''THIRD STREAM'' - a phrase the composer Gunther Schuller used in the 1950's to urge a confluence of jazz and classical music - is flowing wider and deeper than ever. Jazz musicians are playing straight classical pieces, writing for chamber ensembles and working on hybrids where structure meets improvisation. Classical musicians are revealing their fondness for jazz and marveling at virtuosity and individuality of jazz-trained soloists. Genre barriers haven't fallen, but they're more permeable than ever; in 1980's terms, there's a crossover.

title: Q&A
description: Merged Co-ops' Tax Status Question: My husband and I own a cooperative apartment in Manhattan as well as a vacation condominium. The apartment next door to ours in the city recently became available and we would like to buy it and join it with ours to make one larger apartment. If we joined the city apartments, would they be considered one residence for tax purposes, or would we be considered the owners of three residences - making the mortgage interest for the new purchase nondeductible according to the revised tax rules? . . . S. B., Manhattan Answer: According to Neil O'Keefe, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service, the new apartment you would create by joining two units would be counted as your primary residence. You would still be allowed to deduct all of the interest on the mortgage payments for the apartment as long as the loan did not exceed the cost basis of the home plus the value of improvements.

title: TOUGH DECISIONS ALONG A NEW ETHICAL FRONTIER
description: AMERICANS are notoriously skeptical of busybodies and of government telling them what to do. The notion that ''you can do what you want as long as you don't hurt anyone else'' is etched deeply in the national character, and the burden of proof usually falls on those who would meddle.

title: Donna Marie Albani to Wed
description: The engagement of Donna Marie Albani, a lawyer in the Philadelphia firm Dilworth, Paxson, Kalish & Kauffman, and John Edward Hoch, an account executive in the Philadelphia office of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dolores M. Albani of Havertown, Pa., and Francis J. Albani of Ardmore, Pa. Mr. Hoch is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Hoch of Bethlehem, Pa. The wedding is to be in September.

title: Spring's Arrival Dictates Patience
description: Spring will arrive quietly on Friday night at 10:52. Even though the seasons change, it is a time for gardeners to be patient. The ground may not be ready. Plants are slow in stirring. They have spent a long winter under snow cover and they cannot be rushed. Let the crocus and snowdrops bloom as they may to be followed by forsythia.

title: MOVIES
description: WHEN COMEDY WAS KING VidAmerica. 95 minutes. $39.95.

title: A LOOK AT DIVORCE IN JAPAN AND U.S.
description: LEAD: ''WHILE it is nowhere near the rate we have in America, the divorce rate is rising in Japan and the Japanese are very alert to the problem,'' said Dr. Lois Leiderman Davitz, a researcher and lecturer on cross-cultural issues, who with her husband recently completed a study entitled ''Marriage, Divorce - Japan-United States.

title: MAKING RULES TO UNMAKE RULES
description: IN HIS State of the State Message, Governor Kean called for the creation of a ''Regulatory Czar,'' a government official empowered to cut through the ensnarling red tape turned out each day by unaccountable state bureaucrats.

title: GREEK BILL WOULD TAKE CHURCH LAND
description: The Socialist Government here has submitted draft legislation to Parliament as a first step toward assuming control of vast estates held by the Greek Orthodox Church.

title: The 'Inclusionary-Zoning' Experiment
description: PLANNERS have long been intrigued by the notion of using land-use controls to benefit society at no direct cost to the public. An inventive application of that philosophy has been proposed by the Department of City Planning, which has submitted a plan to encourage the construction or improvement of housing for lower-income people in Manhattan. A second hearing on the plan is scheduled for Wednesday before the City Planning Commission.

title: ROY JENKINS ELECTED OXFORD'S CHANCELLOR, BEATING TWO TORIES
description: Roy Jenkins, a founder of the Social Democratic Party of Britain, was elected Chancellor of Oxford University Friday, defeating two leading Conservative candidates for the 763-year-old post.

title: LATEST CORPORATE TAKEOVERS INVOLVE MORE THAN JUST PAPER
description: WALL Street was bristling with announcements of corporate mergers last week as, after a pause, the brisk business expected for 1987 began to materialize. But, as a result of the insider-trading scandals, tax law changes and a record-setting stock market, the nature of the deals is changing. Gone, at least for now, are the raiders who plundered the corporate landscape with billions in junk bond financing. Instead, a new conservatism is taking hold.

title: HIS TOUGHEST CHALLENGE YET
description: WHEN Sumner M. Redstone made his regular trip to Los Angeles late last year, he ran into his old pal Larry Tisch in the lobby of the Beverly Hills Hotel. Mr. Redstone wondered what the new boss of CBS thought about his idea of putting together a group to make a bid for Viacom International, already the object of a management buyout.

title: HOW TO AVOID TUNNEL VISION
description: A LAMENTABLE byproduct of today's information glut is a narrowing of vision. At first glance, such a consequence seems quite the opposite of what one would expect. More information should presumably present more opportunities for broader vision and understanding. Yet the sheer volume of the data amassed makes almost inevitable the reduction of our focus to what is in the end a very narrow endeavor.

title: Backstairs
description: Once upon a time - from 1974 to 1977, to be precise - Sunday night went like this: After you washed the dishes and put the kids to bed and made sure you had enough cigarettes (lots of us were smoking then, remember?) and maybe poured yourself a little something, you sat down in front of the television set and thought of England.

title: WHO SHOULD PROFIT FORM CIGARETTES?
description: THE Congressional debate on the Federal cigarette excise tax is heating up again.

title: JUTLAND OF THE VIKINGS
description: MY HOME IS Jutland, and when a stranger notes my unusual accent and asks me what part of Denmark I come from, I have a stock answer. I am a West Jute, I say - from a little farther west than most. That, of course, requires elaboration. I am English, I explain, but from the ancient Danelaw, the northern half of England that was settled by the Danes about 850, where the Danish language and Danish laws held sway for over 200 years, and still, to this day, are more in evidence than its inhabitants know. I am a returned emigrant, I say, come back after a thousand years.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS RAISING FEES TO INCREASE TEACHER PAY
description: FOR the past four years, 8-year-old Andrew Cox has attended St. Thomas's Day School in New Haven. He will not be returning this September, however, because he will be going to the Worthington Hooker Elementary School, a public school.

title: U.S. Grand Jury Indicts 2 Men On Smuggling to South Africa
description: Two California men have been charged with trying to smuggle sensitive military manuals to South Africa in an indictment that asserts they were given their orders by the naval attache at the South African Embassy in Washington, officials said Friday.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: HAVE VOICES, WILL TRAVEL If you've got them - voices, that is - there's apparently no reason not to show them off, and see a little bit of the world at the same time. So the Choral Society of the Hamptons will mark its 44th year with a two-week European tour next month that will take the singers and their music to the Netherlands, Germany and Belgium, where they'll perform at festivals, with other amateur choruses, in churches and convents and at an American army base.

title: KEEPING HEALTHY ON THE TRIP
description: Yellow fever has broken out in the extreme northwestern forested areas of Kenya and Tanzania.

title: THE GREATEST OF EASE
description: WEARING A PLUSH QUILTED robe and pajamas, the New York decorator Mario Buatta says that he is ready to face the world.

title: A NASTY, EMPTY, DANGEROUS WORD
description: MODERN literature grew up with nationalism and with assorted epochal quackeries in which it participated deeply. We like to imagine literature as the still, small voice of human conscience. It is that only rarely, however. Actively and passively, it has always borne along pernicious ideas. Our laws protecting expression are meant to disperse power, to hedge in the potency of enthusiasms and hypotheses by assuring them critics and competitors. All expression is good because some ideas can be terribly bad.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE PILTDOWN INQUEST. By Charles Blinderman. (Prometheus, $22.95.) After three-quarters of a century, the perpetrator of the greatest hoax in scientific history remains unidentified. Piltdown Man, represented by a human skull and apelike jaw found in an English gravel pit, stood tall in the halls of science as a missing link in human evolution for decades after the finds were announced in 1912. The fossils were not exposed as unequivocally fraudulent until 1953. Ever since, scientists have wondered how such crude fakery could have escaped detection, while countless sleuths have tried to finger the culprit who doctored and planted the bones. Was his motive a practical joke gone out of control, sweet revenge against gullible enemies, the impatient act of a theorist who believed such a fossil had to exist? Charles Blinderman, who teaches English and biology at Clark University, here conducts a witty, erudite investigation. He rounds up the usual suspects, a colorful lot that includes the theologian Teilhard de Chardin and Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. Mr. Blinderman has his own nominee as culprit but admits he could find no smoking bones. May the mystery live on, as well as the more frightening moral of the tale - not just to beware of hoaxes, but to remember how easily leading minds can fool themselves when a forgery tells them what they want to believe.

title: Rhoda Jaffin To Be a Bride
description: The engagement of Rhoda Eleanor Jaffin to Michael Ray Murphy has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Jaffin of Princeton, N.J., and Greensboro, Vt. Mr. Murphy is the son of Mrs. James Raymond Murphy Jr. of Des Moines and the late Mr. Murphy. A September wedding is planned. Miss Jaffin, an account executive for Ruder, Finn & Rotman, a public relations concern in Chicago, graduated from the Princeton Day School and Princeton University and received a master's degree from the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University. Her father is a partner in the New York law firm Battle, Fowler, Jaffin & Kheel.

title: POLICE CITE NETWORK OF DRUGS IN COUTNY
description: LEAD: COCAINE trafficking in the county is a thriving industry, controlled by a shadowy, diffuse network of suppliers, according to law-enforcement authorities.

title: OASIS ON KANSAS PRAIRIE AWAITS CORPORATE FLIERS
description: It looks like an airport: the familiar runways, the noise, the planes of all sizes moving awkwardly about on broad stretches of concrete.
