title: Headliners; Well Warned
description: Former First Daughter Amy Carter took a trip to Brown University's woodshed last week, along with 20 other students who participated in a campus protest last month. Ms. Carter and 18 of the others were essentially let off with a warning. Brown's Disciplinary Review Board put them on limited probation, the lightest penalty possible, for engaging in a protest that ''disrupts or materially interferes with'' the rights of others. The students admitted disrupting a meeting of the University Corporation, demanding that the school sell its stock in companies with ties to South Africa. They were admonished not to do it again for the rest of the academic year and their parents, including former President Jimmy Carter, were notified about the disciplinary action.

title: AFRIKANER OF THE OLD SCHOOL
description: JAN CHRISTIAN SMUTS The Conscience of a South African. By Kenneth Ingham. Illustrated. 284 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $29.95.

title: SCHOOL DAYS AND PRIOM NIGHTS
description: NIGHT LIGHTS Bedtime Stories for Parents in the Dark. By Phyllis Theroux. 179 pp. New York: Viking. $14.95.

title: COUPLE GIVES FOREIGN AID, $100 AT A TIME
description: With a $100 contribution, a group of impoverished women opened a bakery on the outskirts of Nairobi, Kenya. Another $100 helped five young women in Nepal turn out cloth dolls for sale to tourists. And a similar donation put unemployed workers into business marketing rice fritters in Tanzania.

title: TERRORIST IN THE FAMILY
description: THE AMERICAN AMBASSADOR By Ward Just. 326 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: School's Needs Collide With New Zoning
description: DURING a tour of the Nightingale-Bamford School, where she has presided as headmistress for 16 years, Joan McMenamin does not try to gild the facilities. Rather, she emphasizes overcrowding. She notes the computers forced out into the hallways, the cafeteria where lunch must begin at 10:30 A.M. to accommodate all 13 grades, the coats sliding off the racks onto the floor, the auditorium that doubles as a gym. Even the sorry state of the cherubic pupils themselves. ''Did you see that little girl crying in the hallway?'' she asked. ''It's terrible. There's just no place for her to go.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in some copies last Sunday with an article about the New York Knicks' game against the Los Angeles Clippers misidentified the player at the left. He was Michael Cage, not Mike Woodson.

title: RUTGERS-CAMDEN GETS $1 MILLION CAMPBELL GIFT
description: LEAD: THE Rutgers University campus here has received the first $1 million contribution in its 36-year history. It came from the Camden-based Campbell Soup Company.

title: WHEN A HOUSE NO LONGER FITS
description: LIKE anyone getting ready to sell a house, I have been taking note of the many places where the woodwork is smudged, the paint needs to be touched up and the carpet begs for spot remover. I am excited about where we are headed. The new house offers more space, a better location and a vastly reduced commute for my husband. It is unquestionably a move up in the suburban world.

title:
IN THE REGION: LONG ISLAND;
A Mix of Projects To Rise on Last 3 Available Parcels
description: LEAD: DEVELOPMENT is about to begin in Glen Cove on the three remaining vacant parcels in an ambitious 25-acre downtown urban-renewal program started more than 15 years ago.

title: M. A. Braun Wed To Ms. Silverman
description: Susan Silverman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Silverman of Great Neck, L.I., was married in New York last night to Michael A. Braun, the son of David Braun of Lattingtown, L.I., and the late Irene Braun. Rabbi Jerome Davidson and Cantor Eleazer Shulman officiated at the Hotel Pierre.

title: ZONING IS VITAL TO QUALITY OF LIFE
description: BISHOP John R. McGann reminds us in his recent pastoral letter [ ''Affordable Housing Is a Basic Human Right,'' Opinion Page ] that the problem of affordable housing on Long Island has a moral dimension. However, his suggestion to solve it by downzoning the one-family districts to two-family indicates that he misunderstands the role of zoning.

title: Tricia Bernard To Wed May 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Axford Bernard of Skillman, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Lovelace Bernard to Craig Seiler Hevey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Donald Hevey of Sarasota, Fla., and Milton, Wis. A May 9 wedding is planned.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
A Headquarters Goes on Sale
description: LEAD: BETHLEHEM Steel's 21-story headquarters complex, the tallest building in the Lehigh Valley, has been put on the market for $55 million.

title: CALM: KEY TO A STORMY ACTOR
description: WHEN ANTHONY HOPKINS went to work in Hollywood in the mid-1970's, he was wryly amused to discover that when it came to party-going, one was either on the Alist or the Blist. One's social status depended entirely on one's box-office standing or one's hit ratio.

title: Pamela Harris Weds Andrew Heffner
description: Pamela Gwen Harris, an account executive specializing in fixed-income securities at W. J. Nolan & Company, a New York investment concern, and Charles Andrew Heffner, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, were married yesterday at the Plaza in New York by Rabbi Marshall T. Meyer.

title: Susan J. Lundeen To Marry in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Victor G. Lundeen Jr. of Fergus Falls, Minn., of the engagement of their daughter Susan Jane Lundeen to Jonathan Trowbridge Leo, a son of the Very Rev. and Mrs. James Richard Leo of Paris. The wedding is to be in May.

title: The Contras and the Drain
description: Where now in Nicaragua? The President's crusade for the contras has suffered another, perhaps mortal blow. He has to be wondering what policy to pursue if the rebel forces collapse.

title: THE SHIITAKE MUSHROOM IS AT HOME IN MANY DISHES
description: AMONG the foods that have been added to the culinary vocabulary in recent years are shiitake mushrooms. Of all the varieties of exotic mushrooms, these are the easiest to obtain.

title: GARY WARD PRIME EXAMPLE OF HOW TO LAST IN MAJORS
description: At various times in his baseball career, Gary Ward has had to push through roadblocks and avoid potholes. He had to play in the minor leagues, for example, for eight years before winning a permanent job in the majors. Then when he reached the majors to stay, he had to prove he could be an everyday player. And finally, after he registered his best batting average in six major-league seasons last year, the Texas Rangers let him go as a free agent.

title: COAST GUARD RESCUES 37 RUSSIANS FROM A STRICKEN VESSEL OFF JERSEY
description: Coast Guard helicopters fighting a howling Atlantic gale plucked 37 Russians, including an infant, from the heaving deck of a stricken Soviet freighter 210 miles off the coast of New Jersey yesterday and flew them to Atlantic City Airport.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Madison Home Opens to Public home of James and Dolley Madison, opens to the public tomorrow, the anniversary of James Madison's birth.

title: Well, Then, Cuomo for the Supreme Court
description: To the Editor:

title: The chances of becoming a victim
description: One in every 133 Americans, on average, will become a murder victim, and one in every 12 women will be the victim of rape or attempted rape, a Justice Department study concluded last week. Using figures compiled by the Government's National Crime Survey from 1975 through 1984, the department has calculated for the first time an individual's chance of someday becoming a victim of violent crime. Researchers conducted twice-yearly interviews with 101,000 people aged 12 and over in 49,000 households, and included crimes that were not reported to the police. PERCENT OF PEOPLE WHO WILL BE VICTIMIZED BY CRIME ONE OR MORE TIMES DURING THEIR LIFETIME STARTING AT AGE 12

title: Beirut Terrorists Vow To Execute Frenchman
description: A terrorist group said today that it would ''hand down the just sentence to execute'' a French hostage ''within 48 hours.''

title: TAKING THE TODDLERS TO AUSTRALIA
description: From the moment they walked into Toronto's Lester B. Pearson International Airport, one wearing a red sweatshirt with a choo-choo train emblem on the front, the other wearing an identical outfit in blue, it was obvious that Sarah and Stephen were not your typical travelers bound for Australia. Neither weighed more than the three pieces of luggage we were taking with us on our three-week vacation. Our twins were, in fact, just two months shy of their second birthdays.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: STOLEN SPRING. By Hans Scherfig. Translated by Frank Hugus. (Fjord Press, Box 16501, Seattle, Wash. 98116, Cloth, $15.95; Paper, $7.95.) ''A number of years ago an elderly man died in the Osterbro district of Copenhagen after eating a malt drop [on] a beautiful, mild evening at the beginning of June .

title: CENTER FOR VISUAL ARTS: LANDSCAPE AS 'REFLECTIONS OF SOCIAL CHANGE'
description: LANDSCAPE takes the floor again, this time at the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts, formerly the Summit Art Center.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor: I object to the tenor and substance of the description of the holocaust at Izmir (Smyrna) in 1922 in ''Where History's Sweep Conquers the Visitor'' by Frederic Raphael (Travel, Jan. 18). Greece entered Izmir at the behest and with the approval of the Great Powers. By the Treaty of Sevres in 1920, which restored peace between the Sultan and the Allies after World War I, Izmir and its environs, which contained a Christian, mostly Greek population, were placed under Greek administration.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As we now know, it turned out they were right and I was wrong.'' - President Reagan, on dealing with Iran. [ 1:6. ]

title: FOR 48 STUDENTS, KITCHEN IS CLASSROOM
description: LEAD: RON LUNGE, chef, teacher and a man given to frequent bouts of mock exasperation, stares unbelievingly into the pot of melted butter he grasps.

title: IN 'THE DEPOT,' POLITICS IS THE POINT
description: FOR Joanne Woodward, the director of ''The Depot,'' and Shirley Knight, who is starring in it, the play is not the thing. The political message is.

title: Lynne Scheurer Plans to Be Wed To Dr. C. M. Rish
description: The engagement of Lynne Norma Scheurer to Dr. Carlos Meyer Rish, a son of Dr. Lorenzo Rish of Mexico City and Helen Rish of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Charles Scheurer of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: NEWSPAPER RECYCLING CATCHES ON IN WEST VILLAGE EXPERIMENT
description: New Yorkers can be persuaded to wrap up their newspapers in neat bundles with twine. Or at least those who live in the West Village area can, according to Sanitation Department workers.

title: Kevin Keady Married To Barbara Connolly
description: Barbara Anne Connolly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome E. Connolly of Garden City, L.I., was married there yesterday to Kevin Kennedy Keady, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J.Walter Keady Jr. of Ramsey, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Mulvanerty performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Rutgers Women Sink Duke, 78-64
description: Sue Wicks scored 23 points to lead Rutgers to a 78-64 victory over Duke in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball championship today at the Louis Brown Athletic Center. Wicks hit for 8 points early in the second half as Rutgers outscored the Blue Devils, 17-9.

title: SHORTCUTS TO SUMMER
description: As soon as the temperature climbs above 55 degrees, the rush to peel off overcoats and gloves and pack away the heavy woolens begins. For more and more men, the urge to cast off the trappings of winter extends to the hair as well.

title: Prague
description: To the Editor: In regard to the museums in Prague, there is one that was left out: that of the Jewish museum that Hitler arranged to have established, after winning World War II, of a people who no longer existed. He did manage to kill six million. He confiscated from the Jewish people in the conquered countries of Europe, art, sculpture, tapestries, religious articles and hundreds of musical instruments, which now hang in this museum. One man, whose name I do not know, tried for 15 years to have part of this collection brought to the United States. Through his efforts and that of the Smithsonian Institution this was finally accomplished. Thousands of people viewed this exhibit in many cities, with deep-felt emotion. These treasures rightfully belong to the Jewish people.

title: Review; DANCE: 2D BENEFIT GALA IN 'THE SPINAL SERIES'
description: GOOD causes occasionally make dull benefits. But that was not the case on Thursday at Alice Tully Hall, where the Manhattan Performing Ensemble presented its second ''Spinal Series'' gala to raise money for several organizations involved in research and care for people with spinal cord injuries. The range of dance styles was wide. There were several top-notch pieces on the program, and there was urbane commentary from the master of ceremonies, Jack Hofsiss, the Tony Award-winning director, who himself suffered a severe back injury in 1985.

title: SUBWOOFERS BOLSTER THE BASS
description: GROWING INTEREST among audio fans in the lower depths of the tonal range has given rise to new loudspeaker designs with extended bass response. Owners of older and possibly somewhat bass-deficient speakers may wonder whether to replace their speakers with models having a deeper reach.

title: THE HEROES OF 1787
description: A MORE PERFECT UNION By William Peters. Illustrated. 294 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $22.50. THE GENIUS OF THE PEOPLE By Charles L. Mee Jr. Illustrated. 348 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: Brooklyn Graced By Green

title: Prague
description: To the Editor: Re Prague: Franz Kafka is not quite so dead in Czechoslovakia as some may say. A few of his books are creeping into bookstores, and a bust was erected on the street where he was born.

title: Katharine Place Plans To Marry Garry Clark
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. Curtis Place of Millbrook, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katharine Patricia Place to Garry Richard Clark, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Clark of Glen Rock, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: CD PRICES HEAD FOR A DIP
description: THE LONG-AWAITED PRICE break in compact disks hasn't quite arrived yet, but a major development in that direction will take place in the next few weeks and months, when all of the major record companies and some of the smaller ones introduce what they call budget or mid-priced lines of classical CD's, designed to carry retail prices of about $10.

title: Purdue Works Hard To Gain Recognition
description: Purdue, in a league with Indiana, Ohio State and Michigan, has captured more Big Ten Conference basketball championships than any other school. The Boilermakers have had 21 consecutive campaigns with a winning record and they are in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament for the fifth straight year.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: FLUTIST AND GUITARIST The flutist James Galway and the guitarist Kazuhito Yamashita, who first toured together last year in Britain, will perform in Montclair next Sunday in a program sponsored by Unity Concerts at Montclair High School, Park and Chestnut Streets, at 3:30 P.M.

title:
GARDENING;
BASIC QUESTIONS ARE ANSWERED FOR ORCHID GROWERS
description: LEAD: As an orchid grower, lecturer and author, I am frequently asked the same questions about raising these beautiful plants. Here are some of the basic queries, with my answers:

title: U.S. CLASH LOOMS ON AID TO PAKISTAN
description: The Reagan Administration and Congress are poised for a fight over aid to Pakistan because of its work on developing a nuclear bomb, Administration and Congressional sources said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last week on the Suffolk County Vanderbilt Museum incorrectly reported that G. Carroll Lindsay was appointed executive director by the museum's new board of trustees. Mr. Lindsay's appointment was approved by the outgoing board on Sept. 27, 1986. The new board of trustees took over in October of 1986.

title: Move to Block Election Fails
description: Federal District Judge Michael Mihm has declined to block the April 7 municipal election here despite allegations that Peoria's electoral process discriminates against blacks. He denied a request Friday by Timothy J. Cassidy, a candidate for the Park Board, for an injunction postponing the election.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 15, 1987
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. (Bantam, $4.95.) A plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 2 7 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Bantam, $4.95.) A rich, beautiful young woman conquers the world of magazine publishing. 3 8 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. (Fawcett, $4.95.) In the Republic of Gilead, men and women perform the services assigned them. 4 2 PRIVATE AFFAIRS, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $4.95.) A couple's marriage is seriously strained. 5 2 JOANNA'S HUSBAND AND DAVID'S WIFE, by Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey. (Dell, $4.50.) Two sides of a marriage revealed in diary entries. 6 52 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 7 15 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. (Signet/ NAL, $4.95.) An Englishwoman in Afghanistan. 8 1 THE GAMBLE, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Jove, $3.95.) The stormy romance of a saloonkeeper and a temperance crusader in a small Kansas town. 9 2 TO TASTE THE WINE, by Fern Michaels. (Ballantine, $4.50.) An English beauty's passionate affair with a handsome Australian. 10 7 SEASONS OF THE HEART, by Cynthia Freeman. (Berkley, $4.50.) A businesswoman is torn between devotion to her husband and her mentor. 11 7 THE IMMIGRANT'S DAUGHTER, by Howard Fast. (Dell, $4.50.) A woman involved in politics. 12 2 THE LEBARON SECRET, by Stephen Birmingham. (Berkley, $4.50.) Love and conflict among a wealthy family of California vintners. 13 1 WORD OF HONOR, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $4.50.) A former officer is falsely held responsible for an atrocity committed by his men in Vietnam. 14* 10 THE STORYTELLER, by Harold Robbins. (Pocket, $4.50.) A poor boy from Brooklyn sets out to make it big in the world of glamour as a writer. 15 16 THE TWO MRS. GRENVILLES, by Dominick Dunne. (Bantam, $4.50.) Scandal in high society. 16* 16 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. (Bantam, $4.95.) Life in the prehistoric world. Weeks This On Week List NONFICTION: General 1 3 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 2 5 WISEGUY, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Pocket, $4.50.) Life in a Mafia family. 3* 50 OUT ON A LIMB, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $4.50.) The actress's midlife ''journey to find her true self.'' 4 177 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 5 10 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) Strange neurological disabilities. 6 16 DANCING IN THE LIGHT, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $4.50.) The entertainer wins an Oscar, survives a stormy romance and has new visions. 7 19 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's experiences flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. Weeks This On Week List NONFICTION: Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 41 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. (Pocket, $4.50.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 2 7 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $4.95.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 3 6 THE FRUGAL GOURMET, by Jeff Smith. (Ballantine, $4.95.) A television chef's inexpensive dishes. 4 18 RAND MCNALLY ROAD ATLAS: United States, Canada, Mexico. (Rand McNally, $5.95.) For 1987. 5 41 ADULT CHILDREN OF ALCOHOLICS, by Janet Geringer Woititz. (Health Communications, $6.95.) Advice about a family problem. 6 8 J. K. LASSER'S YOUR INCOME TAX. (Prentice Hall, $8.95.) The 1987 edition. 7* 8 THE ARTHUR YOUNG TAX GUIDE 1987. (Ballantine, $10.95.) Aid from an accounting firm. 8* 1 GARFIELD FOOD FOR THOUGHT, by Jim Davis. (Ballantine, $5.95.) Comic strips. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. The number of titles within the two subdivisions of nonfiction can change from week to week, reflecting changes in book buying. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the bookselling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: STORYTELLER PUTS POW! INTO PASSIVITY
description: LOU DelBianco flaps his arms like a bird and rolls his 6-foot-4-inch frame on the floor. He makes funny faces and speaks in many voices as he tells about the big bragging bird, the too-tall elf or the five Chinese brothers.

title: A STATELY AVENUE STIRS ZONING FIGHT
description: LEAD: MERRICK homeowners, religious and civic institutions are fighting a proposal to rezone property on the west side of Merrick Avenue for a 10-unit, two-story condominium. Residents said they would be hard pressed to find a more elegant street than Merrick Avenue between Sunrise Highway and Merrick Road.

title:
GARDENING;
AT THE MARKET, BEAUTY OR THE BEAST
description: LEAD: WHILE consumers have become increasingly vocal in their opposition to pesticide use in food production, they are reluctant to purchase the blemished produce of organic farmers. They are so far removed from their agricultural ancestors that they see no contradiction in this stand, and therein lies the problem encountered by organic growers when marketing their produce.

title: NEITHER SCANDALS NOR JAIL TERMS DERAIL THE DEMOCRATS
description: RARELY has a political party in New York been engulfed in scandals of the depth and breadth of those that have swamped the Democratic-controlled New York City government and the Democratic Party organizations in Queens and the Bronx.

title: NORHTEAST JOURNAL
description: A Tight Fit In Maryland

title: ETHIOPIA: REBELLION BEHIND A MASK OF CONFORMITY
description: Ethiopia's Marxist Government, long a target of guerrillas financed by the Reagan Administration, appears to be more firmly entrenched but more widely resented than ever.

title: EXPLORING SURVIVAL STRATEGIES
description: CAN craft schools survive the rise of ''yuppiedom'' and its value system built around corporate careers and conservatism?

title: A BOOM OVER, CALGARY CASTS EYE TO FUTURE
description: Albertans have long suspected that they rated low in the esteem of other Canadians.

title: LOVE TRIANGLE IN 'WITCHBOARD'
description: THE one time I tried to use a Ouija board, the marker refused to move, and I tossed it aside after a few seconds. ''Witchboard'' convinces me I was right. Any movie that features a Ouija - or ''witchboard,'' as we're told it's sometimes called - as a way for spirits to enter this world ought to offer the audience some guesswork. But the first feature written and directed by Kevin S. Tenney is as moribund as any Ouija I've ever seen.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 300 YEARS OF FILES

title: TAMING UNRULY REALITY
description: JAN GROOVER'S ARTISTIC career has been a barometer of the recent fortunes of photography within the art world. In the mid-1970's her poetically condensed, visually syncopated triptychs of truck traffic and suburban houses caught the precise note of seriousness just when photography was itself beginning to attract attention in art precincts. In 1978 an exhibition of her dramatic still-life photographs of objects in her kitchen sink caused a sensation. When one appeared on the cover of Artforum magazine, it was a signal that photography had arrived in the art world -complete with a marketplace to support it. Her still-life photographs looked smashing on the wall, and their voluptuous colors were as impressive as their prices.

title: Haughey Back as Leader of Ireland
description: The Irish Parliament had barely chosen Charles J. Haughey as Prime Minister last week when speculation began that his minority Government might not last more than a few months. Garret FitzGerald, the former Prime Minister who had just been defeated by Mr. Haughey, quit as leader of his party, Fine Gael, presumably to give someone else a chance to challenge the new Prime Minister in the next election.

title: RAW MEAT FOR THE ACCOUNTANT
description: I WENT TO SEE MY FIRST accountant a few months ago, carrying my life in two tall garbage bags. ''Bring me everything,'' she had said over the telephone in a voice clearly the product of several generations of Manhattan living. ''If you're gonna throw out, it's better you should throw out here. I want to know everything about you -everything, things you don't even tell your therapist.'' And so I obliged, bringing years of bills, receipts, canceled checks, bank statements and papers only remotely financial in nature.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
IF THE NEST IS EMPTY, WHAT'S ALL THIS STUFF DOING IN IT?
description: LEAD: I'M UNIQUE among my circle of friends in that all of my children have left home. Some wonder what I do with myself all day and how I cope, and I reply that I can fill lots of time by writing letters to the absent ones and forwarding their mail and messages.

title: 'OTHER PEOPLE'S SMOKE': ROUND TWO
description: On January 4, Business Forum ran a debate over the ills of passive - or, as it is more formally called, ''involuntary'' - smoking. In his argument, Scott Edward Stapf of the Tobacco Institute questioned both Surgeon General C. Everett Koop's motivations, and his interpretation of data. Moreover, he said that the recent Surgeon General's report on the subject is ''at odds'' with one released by the National Academy of Sciences in November.

title: COALITION ON EDUCATION CALLS FOR MORE DIAOGUE
description: LEAD: REPRESENTATIVES of the county's school boards, school superintendents, teachers and parents -groups whose divergent interests often put them at odds - met last week to discuss how to bring about educational reforms in Westchester public schools.

title: BAHAIS FROM IRAN TEACH OTHERS AND KEEP THE FAITH
description: LEAD: THE early morning telephone call wasn't a surprise to Farzad Azizi of Great Neck, but that didn't lessen the pain he felt when he heard the news.

title: GREAT NECK'S YOUTH: READERS RESPOND
description: ''The Affliction of Affluence,'' an Opinion Page article on Feb. 15 by Linda B. Martin, drew a number of letters from readers, including the following responses.

title: CATHOLIC TEACHINGS AR CHALLENGED IN DUTCH COURT
description: The teachings of the Dutch Roman Catholic hierarchy on homosexuality and the status of women were put to court tests here recently that raised issues of discrimination and of freedom of religion.

title: CREDIT WHERE DUE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GREAT CAMCORDER BATTLE
description: A POPULAR FORM OF MEN-tal exercise is jumping from a valid premise to the wrong conclusion.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
GROWING PAINS
description: LEAD: SOMEONE called the disability ''insidious,'' a subtle thing, and it was easy to see why.

title: COMMUNITY BOARDS ARE FEELING UNLOVED AND POWERLESS
description: LAST month, Mayor Koch announced that his administration had selected a team of developers to build a $636 million apartment and hotel complex on the Hudson River waterfront west of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan. Even before the selection had been made public, however, the local planning board, Community Board 4, said it would oppose any development at the site because it would exacerbate traffic congestion in the Chelsea-Clinton neighborhood.

title: CONTRAS ON THE DEFENSIVE IN THE WASHINGTON WARS
description: IN the more than five years that the United States has been sending secret shipments of uniforms, guns and ammunition to fight the Sandinista Government, last week was one of the bleakest times for the Nicaraguan contra rebels .

title: AMID SCANDALS, WALL ST. SEEKS ADVICE ON ETHICS
description: As the insider-trading scandal on Wall Street has deepened, companies and executives find themselves at the center of a complex set of ethical questions, and some of them are looking to religious counseling for answers.

title: Professional Office Space
description: Ending a search of several years for a lot in Westchester County, the Homart Development Company has settled on a 1.2-acre site in downtown White Plains for a 12-story professional office building. Construction is scheduled to begin this summer on the property, which is at the southeast corner of Martine Avenue and Bank Street, directly across from the Metro-North Commuter Railroad station.

title: NEEDLEWORK, $100,000 AND UP
description: AMERICAN NEEDLEWORK - quilts, samplers and embroidered pictures -has been pursued seriously for decades by collectors, every few of whom could have foreseen that prices for such stitchery would equal what is paid these days for Tiffany lamps and Philadelphia furniture.

title: ONE STEP AHEAD OF THE ZEITGEIST
description: OVERHEAD IN A BALLOON Twelve Stories of Paris. By Mavis Gallant. 196 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: Walking Away From $2 Million
description: HE checked into Los Angeles International Airport, and he struck a clerk as suspicious. He was trying to exchange an airline ticket to Turkey for one to Switzerland.

title: Over-the-Hill Game
description: THE score, a 6-5 Team Canada victory, was the same, and so were many of the players, but there were a few differences between the National Hockey League's 1972 series showdown against the Soviet national team and the meeting Friday night.

title: RASKOLNIKOV COULD COP A PLEA
description: LEAD: INSANITY The Idea and Its Consequences. By Thomas Szasz. 414 pp. New York: John Wiley & Sons. $17.95.

title: A VOICE FROM THE STREETS
description: DURING THE EARLY 1960's, as August Wilson was reaching manhood, the church of St. Benedict the Moor took up a collection for a statue atop its steeple. The church straddled the border between the Hill, the black Pittsburgh slum where Wilson grew up, and the city's downtown district. And when the statue was unveiled, Wilson remembers, Saint Benedict was opening his arms to the skyscrapers and department stores, and turning his back on the Hill.

title: REAL ESTATE LATCHES ON TO 'ZEROS'
description: GREEN ACRES MALL, in Valley Stream, L.I., is as popular with investors as it is with shoppers. Last August, the Equitable Life Assurance Society sold its 90 percent interest in the mall to the public. At a time when tax changes and overbuilding were depressing the real estate market, the EQK Green Acres limited partnership raised nearly $93 million for a complete sellout. (EQ stands for Equitable, which retains an advisory role; K is for Kravco Inc., the property manager.) What attracted investors to Green Acres was its record as an established property with reputable management. But a creative financing technique, called the zero-coupon mortgage, also helped propel the buying surge.

title: IN REAGAN'S DRUG WAR, CONGRESS HAS THE BIG GUNS
description: IT was to be, in President Reagan's words, ''a national crusade against drugs, a sustained, relentless effort to rid America of this scourge by mobilizing every segment of our society against drug abuse.'' Now Congress is threatening to take Mr. Reagan at his word.

title: HOSPITAL AND UTILITY MAKE DEAL ON RATES
description: UNITED Illuminating has promised a New Haven hospital savings of $19 million over 20 years if it does not build a generator of its own.

title: NEW HAVEN CONCERT FOR THE HOLOCAUST
description: WHEN the New Haven Symphony began planning a concert to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the conductor, Murry Sidlin, said he saw an opportunity to present other concerts that would ''illuminate and perpetuate human dignity.''

title: A 'MATURE' WAY TO PLAY CABLE
description: Cable television is a maturing industry, but that may actually be good news for the its profitability - and for investors.

title: The Old Days At '21'
description: The fact that an article about the ''21'' Club appeared in The New York Times Magazine indicates that it is no mere restaurant (''Making Old '21' Young,'' Feb. 15). It had its own special ambiance, a wonderful bar, fantastic clientele, professional staff, not just the Kriendlers, Jerry Berns and Walter, but also Fred (who led you up the stairs) and Tino and Terry Guinan, and, no, upstairs was not Siberia. There were many who preferred it to the busy downstairs bar. Eating meant the best steaks and fish, just broiled, never order a sauce - leave that to La Cote Basque.

title: Betsy Donley Becomes Bride of Albert P. Hand 3d
description: Betsy Jordan Donley, public-affairs director of the South Street Seaport Museum in New York, and Albert P. Hand 3d, a partner in the New York law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, were married yesterday at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Richard F. Van Wely, the rector, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Dedee Z. Rigg, a Congregational minister.

title: IN A CITY THAT LOVES A DEBATE, STORMS SWIRL OVER ITS NEWEST MUSEUM AND CULTURAL FUNDS
description: LE MONDE THE OTHER DAY ran one of those backward glances designed, apparently, to make long-dead controversies look a little retroactively foolish. The paper reprinted an article, dated 1887, written by some 300 French writers and artists protesting - ''in the name of art and the threatened history of France'' -the plans to construct ''the useless and monstrous Eiffel Tower,'' which, the artists said, would ''crush with its barbaric, factory-chimney weight'' the ''pristine beauty of Paris.''

title: THEY'RE ONLY HUMANOIDS
description: COMMUNION A True Story. By Whitley Strieber. 299 pp. New York: Beech Tree Books/ William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: CHILD-ABUSE AID TO EXPAND
description: IN response to an increase in the number and severity of child-abuse cases, a monitoring agency is expanding. The agency, Children in Placement of Hartford, has opened an office in the Montville Juvenile Court. Before the end of the year, it expects to open offices in Willimantic and Rockville.

title: Bookshelf; BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: THE MAGIC SCHOOL BUS AT THE WATERWORKS. By Joanna Cole. Illustrated by Bruce Degen. Scholastic. $12.95. (Ages 8 to 12) Ms. Frizzle may be the strangest teacher in the school, but her class trip to the waterworks is a model of surprising, inventive, accurate and very funny science writing. Facts are cleverly introduced as science reports by the children on a trip that takes them into the waterworks, the reservoir and its filter system - all the way back to school. The illustrations are hilarious. WINTER BARN. Written and illustrated by Peter Parnall. Macmillan. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) A meditation, in words and evocative line drawings, on life inside a barn in Maine. A number of surprising creatures take shelter there, including a tightly coiled snake, two woodchucks, insects, and even a fugitive coon. Enthralling. BARN DANCE! By Bill Martin Jr. and John Archambault. Illustrated by Ted Rand. Holt. $11.95. (Ages 4 to 9) If you read it out loud, the text has the rhythm of a square dance, as a little boy is lured out to the barn one moonlit night. The fiddler is a scarecrow, the animals are dancing, the skinny boy goes home at dawn.

title: Stage Is Set for A State Tax Cut
description: It looks as if New Yorkers will get a real tax cut this year. In addition to the adjustment that everyone has agreed on to keep state taxes from rising because of the change in the Federal tax code, Governor Cuomo last week agreed with the contention of state legislators that an outright reduction is possible in 1987 because of unexpectedly higher revenues.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE INTELLECTUAL FOLLIES: A Memoir of the Literary Venture in New York and Paris, by Lionel Abel. (Norton, $7.95.) In 12 essays surveying American culture and politics across four decades, the author describes the conditions that drove the educated classes leftward in the prewar years and examines the effect of those conditions on artists. The pieces are ''replete with marvelous vignettes of major creative personalities,'' Vivien Raynor said in The Book Review in 1984. ''Mr. Abel was part of the New York scene at the time when American art was making its debut as an international force and his account of it is engrossing.'' HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE: The Making of the British Intelligence Community, by Christopher Andrew. (Elisabeth Sifton/Penguin, $8.95.) Christopher Andrew's narrative history of the British intelligence and security services, Michael Howard said here in 1986, ''illuminates a murky area with care, compassion, good humor and common sense.'' His portrait of this small, discreet and close-knit society assembles in a ''scholarly and lively . . . fashion all the information relevant to [ the ] profession and, without sparing well-deserved criticism, gives honor where honor is due.'' IRISH FOLKTALES, edited by Henry Glassie. (Pantheon, $11.95.) Most of these 125 tales were gathered from other authors or collectors, but some were tape-recorded from tellers in Ireland in the 1970's. In 1985 our reviewer, David H. Greene, praised the interesting introduction, which recounts how the collecting of folk tales began in Ireland in the early 19th century and intrigued the founders of the Irish literary revival. A FAMILY MADNESS, by Thomas Keneally. (Penguin, $6.95.) A young working-class Australian falls in love with the daughter of an obsessive Byelorussian immigrant - a madman whose own father was a Nazi collaborator. Thomas Keneally's novel, which moves between contemporary Sydney and the European past, achieves more documentary than literary success, our reviewer, Robert Towers, said in 1986. But the work is ''bold in its scope and its choice of subject,'' and its elements are assembled ''with an old pro's dexterity.'' THE PROTESTANT ESTABLISHMENT: Aristocracy & Caste in America, by E. Digby Baltzell. (Yale University, Paper, $12.95; Cloth, $35.) E. Digby Baltzell examines America's white Anglo-Saxon Protestant upper crust, and chronicles what he sees as the decline of the ''WASP'' establishment that for so long dominated the nation's politics and culture. The author discusses such phenomena as country clubs, patriotic societies, genealogy and anti-Semitism in ''a wide-ranging, intelligent and provocative book'' that is written ''lucidly, even stylishly,'' Alvin Toffler said in these pages in 1964. EVA'S MAN, by Gayl Jones. (Beacon, $7.95.) The story of Eva Medina, the narrator of Gayl Jones's novel, unfolds as she talks to a psychotherapist in the prison where she is being held for the killing and mutilation of her lover. This is a work of ''bedeviled compulsion,'' June Jordan said in The Book Review in 1976. ''Unerringly, [ the ] writing creates the tension of a problem unresolved.'' The same publisher has reissued the author's first novel, CORREGIDORA ($7.95), a portrait of a battered Kentucky blues singer. ''Gayl Jones has learned to write an interior monologue so naturally that it seems almost crude to say that she is using the stream-of-consciousness technique,'' Raymond Sokolov said here in 1975. ''The sexual writing,'' he said, ''is a model of grace and taste. And it is sexy. This is no mean achievement.'' POLITICAL MURDER: From Tyrannicide to Terrorism, by Franklin L. Ford. (Harvard University, $9.95.) The history of political murder - from antiquity to our own day - is treated here ''with encyclopedic scope,'' our reviewer, Eugen Weber, said in 1985. The author ''touches all major bases. . . . And his book is easy to read. If not used for reference, it may appeal as bedside reading for those who like a good murder.'' A BLUNT INSTRUMENT, by Georgette Heyer. (Berkley, $2.95.) A well-to-do English gentleman, Ernest Fletcher was easygoing and well liked - by everyone, presumably, but his murderer. In 1938 our reviewer, Kay Irvin, called this novel ''a brilliant mystery story, logical, well built, witty and original.'' The same publisher recently reissued two more Heyer mysteries (each $2.95). The victim in ENVIOUS CASCA is Nathaniel Herriard, a curmudgeonly bachelor who is dispatched at a Christmas party at his manor house. ''Rarely have we seen humor and mystery so perfectly blended,'' Isaac Anderson said here in 1941. The body in THEY FOUND HIM DEAD belongs to Silas Kane, whose departure during a walk in the fog seems to be part of a triple-murder plot. The author's mysteries may not have as many shudders as some others, ''but there is a lot more fun,'' Mr. Anderson said in 1937. HITLER AND THE FINAL SOLUTION, by Gerald Fleming. (University of California, $8.95.) Countering the arguments of some revisionist historians, Gerald Fleming sets out to demonstrate Hitler's personal responsibility for the extermination of the Jews. The author ''supplies the evidence that supports what reason suggests,'' Christoph M. Kimmich said in The Book Review in 1985. And he clearly shows ''Hitler's determination . . . to avoid a documented link to the policies he had initiated and sanctioned.'' ROOSEVELT TO REAGAN: A Reporter's Encounters With Nine Presidents, by Hedley Donovan. (Bessie/ Harper & Row, $8.95.) Most of Hedley Donovan's memoir is taken up with anecdotes and observations about the Presidents he has seen and met, but a large portion deals with his experience as an adviser to President Carter. His analysis of the Carter White House forms the heart of the book, Bernard Gwertzman said here in 1985, and is useful because ''he has no particular ax to grind and brings a veteran journalist's eye to the problems that infested the Carter Presidency.''

title: Question Of the Week; Are There Too Many Teams in the N.C.A.A. Tourney?
description: Since the Atlantic Coast Conference, the Big East and the Southeast Conference seem to allow all their members to play for the championship, why not have every Division I school compete in a massive tournament.

title: AT HOME IN DORDOGNE
description: LEAD: THE UNADVENTUROUS truth is, I have never been a compulsive traveler; I would sooner stay than go. If invited to hike unforgettably through the Himalayas, I find urgent reasons to escape the sublime. Why risk yourself, I wonder, on the roof of the world when there is perfectly good accommodation on the first floor?

title: Oldham Out For 4 Weeks
description: The Knicks announced yesterday that Jawann Oldham, their 7-foot-1-inch center-forward, suffered a sprained ligament in his left knee in Friday night's loss to the Nets and could be out for the remainder of the season.

title: Gotti and Friends Found Not Guilty
description: John Gotti, the man painted by Federal prosecutors as the most powerful criminal in the nation's most powerful organized crime family, walked out of Federal court in Brooklyn a free man last week.

title: TROUBLED ECUADOR LEADER FACES NEW ATTACKS
description: On a flight Friday to the northeastern region ravaged by earthquakes and flooding nine days ago, President Leon Febres Cordero described a country beset by unending tragedies in the last four years.

title: CORRECTION
description: An investing article on drug stocks last Sunday misstated Lovastatin's standing with the Food and Drug Administration. The drug was approved by an F.D.A. committee. The full agency is expected to rule shortly.

title: SHE INTERPRETS IN A SILENT WORLD
description: ''I AM a freelance interpreter,'' said Elizabeth G. Nagler of Valley Stream.

title: Agents' Woes Grow
description: AS a Southern Methodist booster who has been linked to a slush fund that paid 13 S.M.U. football players $61,000 over two seasons, Sherwood Blount, a Dallas real-estate developer, has had his troubles with the National Collegiate Athletic Association and S.M.U., which has banned him and eight other boosters for life from any association with the athletic department.

title: NEW IRAN MISSILES REPORTED AT GULF ENTRANCE
description: Iran has increased its threat to the flow of oil out of the Persian Gulf by installing large land-based anti-ship missiles near the Strait of Hormuz, according to American intelligence sources.

title: FEARS RISE OVER VERMONT LAND DEALS
description: Environmentalists are warning that land speculation in Vermont could have serious social and environmental consequences for the state if it is allowed to continue unchecked.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Arts and Leisure on Feb. 22 about the musical ''South Pacific'' misidentified the actor who played Emile de Becque in the 1958 film version. The role was performed by Rossano Brazzi, with the major singing sequences dubbed by Giorgio Tozzi.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Raleigh, N.C.; Getting Rentals For Migrants
description: IN a farm state that annually imports thousands of migrant workers - and is accustomed to stories of crowded and unsanitary conditions - a church group has found itself stymied in its effort to build the state's first rental housing for farm workers.

title: 10 HOTELS, 12 NIGHTS IN JAPAN
description: Our decision to spend 12 nights in 10 different hotels in Japan was made in a giddy moment - a whim, I suppose, intended to cram as much variety into a brief visit as we could manage. We planned our itinerary, with considerable help from friends in Tokyo, to include the modestly priced and the luxurious. They would range from what are known as love hotels to the Okura in Tokyo, judged by many to be among the best hotels in the world.

title: Esposito: Is He Good for Rangers?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: PRODUCER LAUDING IRISH MUSIC
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the woods of New Canaan are thousands of miles from Ireland, Turner Hill Road in this suburban town is closer to O'Connell Street in Dublin than you might expect.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: I CALL A SOURCE TO get some information. A secretary answers who has orders not to put a caller through without first learning my name and number (reasonable enough) and asking, ''What is this call in reference to?'' (Never the simple ''about''; always the highfalutin ''in reference to.'') I don't like to tell other people what I am calling about, nor do I like to let the targets on the other end of the line know in advance what I am going to ask them about, lest they prepare some innocuous response or shift me to some smooth-tongued aide trained to obfuscate.

title: BIRD LOVERS HEAR THE CALL OF THE WILD
description: COLORFUL, exotic birds have become increasingly popular among Americans in the 1980's, and bird sales accounted for about 20 percent of the $1.8 billion in pet store sales. But there is a supply crunch looming. Asia, Africa, Central and South America, the prime sources of such popular birds as African gray parrots, toucans and macaws, are curtailing exports out of fear that the species will become extinct. On top of that, New York has passed a law prohibiting the sale of wild-caught birds, and other states are expected to follow suit.

title: Ousted Soviet Official Faces Corruption Inquiry, Tass Says
description: An ousted Politburo member will be investigated by Communist leaders in Kazakhstan to determine possible links to corruption and other abuses in the republic, Tass, the official press agency reported today.

title: CONGRESS CAUTIONED AGAINST CHANGING TAX EXEMPTION LAWS
description: The Treasury Department has cautioned Congress against making wholesale changes in laws regulating political and lobbying activities of the more than 800,000 tax-exempt organizations.

title: Getting Down to Specifics on Missile Monitors
description: For a serious negotiation on arms control, the talking has been unusually public. Soviet officials have been voluble in promoting Mikhail S. Gorbachev's latest proposals. And last week, the Reagan Administration outlined its ideas for monitoring compliance with a treaty on removing medium-range missiles from Europe.

title: Anne C. Rudolph To Wed a Marine
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Rudolph of Ballston Lake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Cecelia Rudolph to Maj. Hugh Kenneth O'Donnell Jr., United States Marine Corps, the son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Donnell of Danville, Calif. The wedding is to be May 9.

title: Visions in Conflict
description: To the Editor:

title: Frances Rooney Engaged to Wed Michael S. Cifrino
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis C. Rooney Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Frances Elizabeth Rooney to Michael Stephen Cifrino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Cifrino of Cohasset, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: INSIDE
description: South Backs Front-Runners Southerners are giving strong early support to Vice President Bush and Gary Hart in the 1988 Presidential race, a newspaper poll says. Page 28.

title: SYRIANS REVIVE SENSE OF ORDER AT CAMPUS IN BEIRUT
description: Law and order have returned to the American University of Beirut, for years a target of violence by anti-American militants in Lebanon.

title: STATE INSURANCE AIDE DEFENDS DEPARTMENT
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the consumer activist Ralph Nader would like to see the state's Department of Insurance given additional staff, money and power to deal with the crisis in casualty liability insurance, Kenneth D. Merin, the Commissioner of Insurance, says the department is already experiencing reasonable growth.

title: Leslie Sara Carroll and Mark H. Gruber to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Philip Goldsmith of the Bronx and Sag Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leslie Sara Goldsmith to Mark Henry Gruber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gruber of Forest Hills, Queens, and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: A SYSTEM OVERLOADED: THE FOSTER-CARE CRISIS
description: New York City foster-care children are being bounced from home to home and institution to institution in far greater numbers and under more chaotic conditions than officials, caseworkers and other experts can recall.

title: Charles H. Tally, 72, Is Dead; An Expert in Real-Estate Law
description: Charles H. Tally, an expert in real-estate law and a senior partner in the New York law firm of Bachner, Tally, Polevoy, Misher & Brinberg, died of cancer Friday in United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 72 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: POLL FINDS SOUTHERNERS VARY LITTLE FROM OTHER VOTERS IN EARLY '88 CHOICES
description: Defying political stereotypes, Southerners are following national trends and giving strong early support to Gary Hart and Vice President Bush for the 1988 Presidential nominations, while rating such issues as school busing and aid to the Nicaraguan rebels as much less important than helping the homeless, according to a poll for The Atlanta Journal and Constitution.

title: A GUST OF BANKRUPTCY AND SCANDAL RATTLES ELEGANT HILTON HEAD ISLAND
description: LAST year was a bad one for this elegantly casual oceanfront retirement and vacation town.

title: HERZOG RATES 1977 YANKEES BETTER THAN 1986 METS
description: WHITEY HERZOG should know. He was, after all, in the perfect position to assess both teams, and he believes the 1977 Yankees were a better team than the 1986 Mets.

title: EDWARD P. CURTIS, EISENHOWER AVIATION AIDE
description: Edward P. Curtis, a retired vice president of the Eastman Kodak Company and a former aide to President Eisenhower who became the architect of the Federal Aviation Administration, died Friday in a nursing home in Rochester. He was 90 years old.

title: STREET-CORNER ORATOR'S DEATH MARKS END OF ERA IN HARLEM
description: For decades until the 1960's, street-corner orators were a daily part of life in Harlem and a primary source of news and information. They would preach messages to passers-by of racial pride, black nationalism and self-sufficiency.

title: Crack Murder: A Detective Story
description: One sidelight of Ron Rosenbaum's article deserves further comment: Records show that criminals are indeed switching from so-called Saturday night specials to 9-millimeter pistols. With a special magazine, certain 9-millimeter pistols can fire as many as 21 rounds in one loading, as opposed to the 5 or 6 shots of a revolver. Semi-automatic pistols, on the other hand, are more difficult to master than revolvers, which is one reason why the New York Police Department retains the safer revolver. HARRY KANE Editor Combat Handguns New York City

title: THE MURDER THAT PARTED THE CURTAINS
description: LEAD: THE PRIEST AND THE POLICEMAN The Courageous Life and Cruel Murder of Father Jerzy Popieluszko. By John Moody and Roger Boyes. 251 pp. New York: Summit Books. $17.95.

title: DOWN BY 4, ISLANDERS RALLY
description: Kelly Hrudey, who was yanked from his goal when the Islanders fell behind, 2-0, after five minutes, went to the bench and closely watched his team's unlikely revival.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE ANIMAL BUSINESS
description: THERE is no disputing that animals contribute a lot more to society than companionship and food. They sniff for bombs, gas leaks, and drugs; they catch criminals and serve as eyes for the blind and ears for the deaf; they rescue earthquake and avalanche victims.

title: PUTTING ONE LETTER AFTER ANOTHER
description: ''IT was pleasant to learn that you expect our correspondence to be read in the international salons and boudoirs of the future,'' Delmore Schwartz confided to his publisher, James Laughlin. ''Do you think they will be able to distinguish between the obfuscations, mystifications, efforts at humor, and plain statements of fact?'' That, of course, was the challenge, for it was in his letters that the poet's difficult and problematic character most vividly revealed itself. To be sure, there were other sources: interviews, memoirs, journals, autobiographical manuscripts. But it would have been hard to imagine his biography without the versions of himself he disseminated through the mail with such unflagging verve. ''These pieces of the self are with my friends,'' he noted in one of his verse-journals: ''They show me as I am, which never ends. / The word betrays the heart and mind.'' For Schwartz, letters belonged to the writer's vocation to which he had apprenticed himself; they were simply another mode of literary expression, like essays or poetry. But the sense of literature as a way of life has gone out of fashion, and so has the habit of writing letters. How many of us ever receive in the mail anything other than bills, magazines and the occasional perfunctory note? The telephone has made letters obsolete, and writers have not resisted its convenience. Even Robert Lowell, perhaps the Continued on page 25 last poet to know for certain that his life and work would merit a biography, was a less than assiduous correspondent; Ian Hamilton, his official biographer, relied as much on the recollections of friends as on the poet's letters.

title: KLEIN INTERCEDES IN RIFT
description: JOHN V. N. KLEIN, the former Suffolk County Executive and new chairman of the Long Island Association, is trying to make peace between the association and many Republican state legislators from Long Island.

title: FOR IDLERS AND ANGLERS
description: DESTIN HAS THE ADVANTAGE, for the troubled visitor, of being at the end of the world. Beyond the dunes of Destin is nothing but water. The surf melts into the eye-ring of the sky, and once you get here, there is nothing to do but stop and be still. At some point, even an American impelled in a car can go no farther.

title: Question Of the Week; Are There Too Many Teams in the N.C.A.A. Tourney?
description: Last weekend the A.C.C. and the Big East basketball conferences held their championships. What percentage of the eligible teams qualified for the tournaments? One hundred percent. Do people say that too many teams make the basketball playoffs? Nope.

title: SELLING THE GOOD LIFE FOR CATS AND DOGS
description: ON a recent spring-like afternoon, Linda, a woman in her late 20's who would not give her last name, was walking her Dalmatian on Manhattan's Columbus Avenue. All around her, heads turned. The reason: Her white cotton sweater with large, black spots perfectly matched her Dalmatian.

title: SHIFT IN WATER AIDES AROUSES ACTIVISTS
description: LEAD: THE recent decision by Assemblyman I. William Bianchi Jr., Democrat of Bellport, the new co-chairman of the State Legislative Commission on Water Resource Needs on Long Island, to dismiss all three Democratic staff members from the bipartisan panel, including its vocal co-executive director, Sarah

title: British Paper Adding Sting to Death Notices
description: Death's sting has a new meaning now that The Times of London is including candid descriptions of human peccadilloes in its obituaries.

title: LAWMAKERS PREDICT ACTION ON AIDS BILLS
description: LEAD: LEGISLATORS overseeing the progress of General Assembly bills dealing with AIDS expect most to be approved, but foresee some resistance to a measure prohibiting discrimination against people who suffer from the illness or who have been exposed to the AIDS virus.

title: DISMANTLING THE STALIN MYTH: NEW EFFORT UNDER GORBACHEV
description: After a silence of more than 20 years, Stalin's crimes and his legacy have once again become the subject of public debate in the Soviet Union.

title: NEW LAW LICENSES HOME CONTRACTORS
description: LEAD: IT soon will be illegal for a variety of types of home-improvement contractors to work in Westchester without a license from the county.

title: TAKE ME TO THE BEACH: Almost Perfect Privacy on Paros
description: It was a small beach, with only a couple of islands of soft sand to loll upon, encased by a rocky main. But it was perfectly shaped for defense of privacy - a crescent cove with low surrounding cliffs that sheltered us from the view of anyone not within its compass.

title: Mexico's Ruling Party Battles Founder's Son
description: His father is perhaps the most revered political figure in modern Mexican history, but Cuauhtemoc Cardenas has nevertheless found himself suddenly all but drummed out of the very party his father helped establish.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Francisco;
Old Mall Going Under Glass
description: LEAD: THE Stonestown Shopping Center, this city's oldest retail mall, is getting a face lift.

title: GIRL SCOUTS HONORED BY A COMMEMORATIVE
description: Precisely 75 years from the date on which Juliette Gordon Low established the Girl Scouts of the United States of America in Savannah, Ga., the United States Postal Service commemorated the anniversary with a 22-cent commemorative. It was released last Thursday in Washington.

title: HEALTH & MEDICINE
description: LEAD: WHEN Elizabeth Kelley was born with spina bifida eight years ago, her parents were told she would be ''dead from the waist down, and probably from the waist up.''

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: ASSAULTING THE BARRIERS TO LEGAL PRACTICE;
A BRAZEN SYSTEM OF SELF-ENRICHMENT
description: LEAD: LAWYERS usually protect their own, at least that's the way it has been traditionally. But W. Clark Durant 3d, the chairman of the Legal Services Corporation's board of governors, recently shocked the American Bar Association, the prime guardian of lawyers' economic interests for a century, by advocating elimination of ''the laws protecting our profession.

title: Amnesty Blames Syria for Deaths
description: Amnesty International has charged that Syrian troops and their Lebanese militia allies killed hundreds of civilians in Tripoli and that Syrian soldiers executed 23 Shiite Moslems in Beirut last month.

title: NO-ALCOHOL BAR FACING CLOSURE
description: LEAD: A TALL, dark-haired singer in spandex pants, T-shirt and leather vest takes a wide stance at the microphone and moves into his rendition of a rock ballad called ''All Alone.'' Clusters of fans and listeners sit at nearby tables, smoking cigarettes and sipping drinks. Music blares from the oversized speakers, and two attractive girls pay the cover charge and assume places at the bar.

title: Villanova Clears Massimino
description: The case of former Villanova basketball player Gary McLain's cocaine use is closed, as far as the university is concerned. The Rev. John Driscoll, university president, said a ''short but very intensive inquiry'' had concluded that Coach Rollie Massimino committed no wrongdoing in a scandal involving McLain.

title: DUSTING OFF THE OLD VALUES
description: INTERPRETATION AND SOCIAL CRITICISM By Michael Walzer. 96 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $12.50.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;
description: - Owners of the National Football League's 28 teams were notified today that their winter meetings would start Sunday, a day earlier than planned, so that Commissioner Pete Rozelle could review the terms of the new television contracts, and the owners could vote to approve them.

title: CONCERT: 2 FIFTH SYMPHONIES
description: VIOLENCE is the 20th century's particular contribution to music. The medium has always had the means to transport listeners, even anger or frighten them. But given the sheer mass of day-to-day sensory experience burdening human faculties these days, perhaps the kind of bone-shaking jolts that reverberated through Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night are necessary to get our attention.

title: Joseph Roth Reborn
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 SUICIDE VICTIMS BURIED IN JERSEY
description: Relatives and friends of three teen-agers who died in a suicide pact this week gathered at funeral services today, still struggling to come to terms with the deaths that have shaken this area and the nation.

title: GOING HOME AFTER A FAMILY QUARREL
description: ''DO you have power?'' That is what a friend of mine asked me in the library a while ago. I guess I looked at her sort of strangely, because the next thing she said was, ''I didn't mean in the large metaphysical sense. I meant: Do you have power -you know, the storm and all?''

title: PROVIDENCE RALLIES TO WIN IN OVERTIME
description: Ernie Lewis had 26 points and Billy Donovan added 25 today as Providence scored a 90-87 overtime victory over Austin Peay in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: 'CRISIS INTERVENNTION' USED TO REHABILITATE MARLBORO
description: LEAD: CRISIS intervention - a technique used to help the mentally or emotionally disturbed - was applied to an entire state psychiatric hospital last week.

title: Question Of the Week; Are There Too Many Teams in the N.C.A.A. Tourney?
description: Most major academic institutions already participate in three basketball seasons; the first or regular season (30 or so relatively meaningless contests), the conference playoff season (also known as the N.C.A.A. tryouts), and, lastly, the N.C.A.A. tournament itself, a significant television happening. As we get ready for this third season, I would like to make a constructive suggestion to the powers that be in the N.C.A.A. Why not open up next year's tournament to every basketball team in the country, regardless of won-lost record? Thus, while reaffirming collegiate dedication to the principle of equal opportunity, our educators could simultaneously fulfill the dreams of their big-time athletic departments - year-round revenue for alma mater and full-time employment for the student-athlete dribblers of America. ROBERT N. GOLDMAN New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: MY LIFE IN EXILE
description: ON MARCH 6, 1984, I WAS TAKEN OFF an airplane that had landed on the dirt airfield at the town of Sangar in Siberia, and my handcuffs were removed. Seven years of corrective labor camp were behind me. Five years of exile lay ahead.

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
Rail Link to Airport: Has Its Time Come?
description: LEAD: OVER the last five years, Newark and Elizabeth, two of the state's older urban centers, have experienced substantial revitalization. Nevertheless, they are struggling to keep pace with the rapidly expanding suburbs and the rest of the northern New Jersey market.

title: SEXISM IS THE LEAST OF IT
description: LEAD: BLOOD, BREAD, AND POETRY Selected Prose 1979-1985. By Adrienne Rich. 238 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $15.95. ADRIENNE RICH'S essays have always stressed revelation, the arduous probing of her feminism, her lesbianism, her Jewishness, her own white bourgeois ''privilege,'' her ambivalent emotions about mothers, both black and white.

title: Correction
description: A review Feb. 15 of the ''Frank Lloyd Wright Letters Trilogy'' misidentified one of the universities that purchased Wright's correspondence with his client Darwin Martin. The letters were bought by the State University of New York, Buffalo, and Stanford University.

title: ADDING A LITTLE LESS TO THE WHITNEY
description: IT IS SHRINKING MUSEUM TIME again. This month's entry, following close on the heels of the reduced addition proposed for the Guggenheim Museum in February, is a downsized version of an addition to the Whitney Museum that was originally proposed in larger form in 1985. That design, by the architect Michael Graves, unleashed a firestorm of controversy unmatched by anything in recent memory except, perhaps, the design for the A.T.&T. Building. The trustees of the Whitney, aware that the chances of winning approval from the city were scant, withdrew the project early in 1986.

title: TOKYO'S SURPRISING GARDENS
description: Tokyo is not the first city that leaps to most people's minds when Japanese gardens are discussed. That distinction belongs, deservedly, to Kyoto.

title: No Headline
description: THE Village of Babylon would not have summoned the owners of the John Anthony Water Cafe into court if it were not for the election scheduled for Wednesday, said John Anthony Albicocco, one of the owners of the recently opened restaurant-dance club built on the shores of the Great South Bay at a reported cost of $4.5 million.

title: MASSACHUSETTS LAWSUIT ASSAILS SEABROOK ADS
description: The Massachusetts Attorney General has filed suit to try to halt what he calls a ''deceptive'' advertising campaign in support of the Seabrook nuclear power plant in Seabrook, N.H.

title: CHINA SEES LONG WAR ON WESTERN IDEAS
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang said today that China's campaign against Western ideas and for a reassertion of rigid Communist orthodoxy could last for decades.

title: FENWICK RETURNS 'FOREVER' TO WHERE HER 'ROOTS ARE PLANTED'
description: PERIPATETIC, patrician Millicent Fenwick, now 77 years old, is home from the wars - for good, she says.

title: GREAT NECK'S YOUTH: READERS RESPOND
description: ''The Affliction of Affluence,'' an Opinion Page article on Feb. 15 by Linda B. Martin, drew a number of letters from readers, including the following responses.

title: 60-Victory Streak Falls for Potsdam
description: In Worcester, Mass., last night, the Potsdam State Bears had their 60-game winning streak - the second- longest in college basketball history -ended.

title: THEIR PROPER SEASONS: A Roman Spring Amid the Stones
description: Punctuality is seldom a priority in Rome. No one expects mail, employees, or dinner guests to show up on time. But everybody expects - no, they demand - that spring arrive weeks early, and in the first days of March they begin searching for subtle yet indisputable signs that the season has changed. As always in Italy, accurate observation requires keen peripheral vision and a heightened awareness of eccentric details.

title: MOVIES
description: THE NAME OF THE ROSE Starring Sean Connery, F. Murray Abraham, Christian Slater, William Hickey. Directed by Jean-Jacques Annaud.1986. Embassy Home Entertainment. 128 minutes. $79.95.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
FOREST HILLS
description: LEAD: IT is often easier, in Forest Hills, to stable a horse than it is to garage a car. Dixie Dew Stables on 70th Road boards horses and has several vacancies. Mets-Queens Parking on Queens Boulevard has 50 car owners on a waiting list for garage space, and a developer is planning to tear it down.

title: JACKSON AND BALDI ARE AILING
description: Mark Jackson, St. John's all-America guard, and Marco Baldi, the Redmen's 6-foot-11-inch center, became ill Friday night shortly after completing drug-testing. A team physician said the illnesses were probably caused by an excessive intake of soft drinks.

title: Lucy D. Jewett, a Magazine Executive, Will Marry Peter S. Lowenthal in May
description: The engagement of Lucy Dewitt Jewett to Peter Stern Lowenthal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lowenthal of Falls Church, Va., and Keene Valley, N.Y., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Freeborn Garrettson Jewett Jr. of McLean, Va., parents of the future bride. A May wedding is planned.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: RANGERS WIN IN OVERTIME
description: The Rangers had all kinds of gritty strategies in place tonight designed to stop Mario Lemieux. But in the end, their version of Lemieux, Tomas Sandstrom, prevailed.

title: CLIPPER RETURNS FROM WATERY EXILE
description: Remnants of what is believed to be the only surviving hull of a 19th-century American clipper ship arrived here this week from a muddy grave in the Falkland Islands, where the ship was abandoned 123 years ago.

title: WITH BRUCKNER THE ISSUE IS IMPACT
description: ANTON BRUCKNER ASKS OF LISTENERS what they are increasingly less able to give - time. Mahler's symphonies are just as long, but respond perhaps more easily to our lives. They are as restless as we have become. Mahlerian style is one of plurality, of constant change.

title: Review; MUSIC: THE KRONOS QUARTET AT WEILL HALL
description: DESPITE their Haight-Ashbury cum Jetsons fashions and punk-rock hairdos, the members of the Kronos Quartet have assembled an ensemble of exceptional seriousness and importance. They play all kinds of contemporary music - from Ornette Coleman to Terry Riley to John Cage and beyond - and play it with passion and style: their interpretations are alert, adaptive and altogether expert. And they have built an audience of unusual catholicity. At the Kronos Quartet's Friday night concert at Weill Recital Hall, Elliott Carter, the distinguished modernist composer, sat next to the unusually venturesome rock musician Sting. The two may or may not be aware of each other's work, but this listener would wager that many members of the audience have enjoyed music by both men.

title: IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA, A BLOW AGAINST CULTURE'S 'SPONTANEOUS MOMENTS'
description: ''I IMAGINE, for foreigners, the whole issue of an allegedly conspiratorial or insurrectionist group of jazz fans must seem ridiculous,'' said a member of the Jazz Section, a Czechoslovak group devoted to music and to artistic freedom, in November. ''But unlike Poland and Hungary and unlike even the Soviet Union under Mikhail Gorbachev, the main struggle in Czechoslovakia today is over the right to independent culture, to spontaneous moments.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WHAT IS FEMINISM? Edited by Juliet Mitchell and Ann Oakley. (Pantheon, Paper, $9.95.) One clear answer that emerges from reading this book is that feminism is not monolithic. Called ''feminisms'' by some of the 11 feminist thinkers in this collection, it took the form, in the 1960's, of movements for women's liberation, women's legal and health rights and women's studies.

title: DEATH TOLL IN FERRY DISASTER COULD BE 200, BELGIUM SAYS
description: More than 200 people may have died in the March 6 British ferry disaster, the Belgian Transport Minister said today. But the ship's owners said the toll was still 134.

title: Review; RECITAL: SIMON ESTES SINGS
description: SIMON ESTES' Monday night recital of works by Schubert, Mahler, Verdi and several American composers at the Metropolitan Museum was a disappointing affair.

title: GREAT NECK YOUTH: READERS RESPOND
description: ''The Affliction of Affluence,'' an Opinion Page article on Feb. 15 by Linda B. Martin, drew a number of letters from readers, including the following responses.

title: THE HIDDEN AGENDA OF THE RADICAL RIGHT
description: BADGERING lawyers is becoming a national pastime. In part, that is because advocating unpopular causes, defending individual rights, opposing demands of the sometimes-insistent, often-exasperated majority are lawyers' fundamental obligations.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
CANADA'S COINS PORTRAY WINTER SPORTS
description: LEAD: Continuing its program of Winter Olympic commemoratives, the Royal Canadian Mint has issued two silver coins which focus on figure skating and curling. The coins are the seventh and eighth in a series of 10 designed to mark and help finance the 1988 Winter Games in Calgary, Alberta.

title: ORDINARY IN AN EXTORDINARY WAY
description: ''I TOUCH THE FUTURE . . .'' The Story Of Christa McAuliffe. By Robert T. Hohler. Illustrated. 262 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: Boston U. Raises Tuition
description: Boston University's tuition and fees for room and board will rise 6.7 percent to $16,700 for the 1987-88 academic year, the school announced. The university's board of trustees set tuition at $11,800, up from $10,950 this academic year. Room and board fees, $4,700 this year, will be $4,900 next year. The school said today the increase was the smallest percentage rise in fees in a decade.

title: INDIAN HISTORY WOVEN THROUGH BASKETS
description: LEAD: A FACET of the lives and contributions of American Indians in Connecticut's past is the focus of an exhibition at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford.

title: A SENSE OF LIMITS GRIPS CONSUMERS
description: BONNIE WILCOX of Hampton, Va. recently decided not to buy a video camera.

title: Stress and The Immune System
description: It is becoming increasingly evident that the mind and emotions have a profound influence on immune-system function and that there is a continuing dialogue between these closely related structures (''New Clues to the Immune System,'' by Susan Squire, Feb. 1). They use the same chemical messengers to communicate, and both have the ability to remember. Further links are likely, because there are networks of nerve fibers in the thymus, spleen and lymph nodes, which indicate that these important mediators of immune activity may actually be hard-wired to the central nervous system.

title: LISBON'S NEW TAVARES
description: For many years, Lisbon's oldest restaurant, Tavares, withstood critics of its run-down appearance by maintaining its excellence in service and cuisine. During commemorations of its 200th anniversary, which have lasted two years, Tavares was awarded the City of Lisbon's gold and silver medals and was declared part of the national patrimony. Now it is looking to the future.

title: Recent Sales
description: Cornwall, Conn. $587,000 Flat Rock Road 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old farmhouse; vistas, high ceilings, pool with pool house, 24 acres; taxes $2,000. Farmington, Conn. $576,500 41 Mountain Road 6-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old colonial; private lane, 2 acres; taxes $3,355. West Hartford, Conn. $450,000 14 Wood Pond Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 43-year-old Dutch colonial; vistas, on large pond, 0.5 acre; taxes $5,029. Mount Kisco, N.Y. $241,000 2 Spencer Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 58-year-old frame/ stucco Dutch colonial; eat-in kitchen, wine cellar; taxes $2,844. Scarsdale, N.Y. $480,000 4 Greenville Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 32-year-old brick/ frame contemporary; eat-in kitchen, atrium, skylight, walk to station; taxes $7,982. White Plains, N.Y. $154,000 41 Westview Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 58-year-old masonry colonial; eat-in kitchen, den, walk to station and stores; taxes $1,480. OTHER AREAS Northport, L.I. $555,000 151 Asharoken Avenue 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 11-year-old contemporary; family room, fireplace, deck, 2-car garage, private beach; taxes $5,100. Rocky Point, L.I. $115,000 24 Tarpon Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $900. Short Hills, N.J. $300,000 192 White Oak Ridge Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, hardwood floors, patio, full basement; taxes $5,306.

title: A McCormick Moment
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ON BOXING By Joyce Carol Oates. Photographs by John Ranard. 118 pp. New York: Dolphin/Doubleday & Company. $14.95.

title: SCHOOLS ARE FOCUS OF SMOKING BANS
description: TO many students at Staples High School in Westport, it is known as ''Cancer Corner.''

title: JEWS IN AMERICA UPSET OVER ISRAEL
description: In the wake of the Pollard espionage case and the Iran-contra affair, American Jews are expressing greater anxiety about Israel's policies than at any time since the modern state was founded nearly 40 years ago, according to several American Jewish leaders.

title: U.S. IS DEVELOPING NEW GOTTI CHARGE
description: A new racketeering indictment against John Gotti is being developed by Federal prosecutors based largely on secret tape recordings of Mr. Gotti discussing the economic spoils he would get as the head of the Gambino crime family, according to law-enforcement officials.

title: SEANTE FIGHT SEEN OVER DRUG TESTING
description: A bill to require random testing of millions of airline, railroad and other transportation workers for drug and alcohol use appears headed for a prolonged fight on the Senate floor despite nearly unanimous approval by the Senate Commerce Committee.

title: 55-1 Shot Wins as Lady's Secret Fades
description: Lady's Secret, the reigning Horse of the Year, made a dismal and disheartening seasonal debut today at Gulfstream Park. The small, gray 5-year-old daughter of Secretariat tired badly to finish sixth, beaten 32 1/2 lengths by Little Bold John and Skip Trial, in the $147,600 Donn Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

title:
ART;
CREATIONS IN NEON: MOVING BEYOND A GAUDY ANCESTRY
description: LEAD: THE dance critic Edwin Denby once wrote that there is nothing as wonderful as neon in daylight. At the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, there are many varieties of neon, and even if the museum is darkened for their effulgent display, it is still wonderful having a show of technological wonder that all ages can delight in.

title: Review; JAZZ: GARRY DIAL ON PIANO
description: A new jazz piano room, the Judge's Chamber, has opened in the Sheraton Russell Hotel, 37th Street at Park Avenue, with a distinctive ambiance and a pianist who is not one of the regulars on the city's piano room circuit.

title: Hawaii Fire Controlled
