In the fine new Japanese film ''A Promise,'' the pain and humiliation of senility take a terrible toll, not only on the elderly but also on the younger relatives whose lives are affected. ''A Promise,'' about an elderly woman found dead in the house of her son and daughter-in-law, addresses the question of euthanasia, since the woman has almost certainly died at the hands of her loved ones. But it is even more disturbing as a study of ways in which the older generation's weakness and debility can affect the younger.

title: BRALORNE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes special charges of $44,100,000 for the latest year and $4,775,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said the special charges in 1986 include the writedown of the carrying costs of U.S. oil and gas interests; a writeoff of goodwill and patents; a provision against disposal of surplus inventory; losses on disposition of operating units and the writedown to net realizable value of assets held for disposal. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: TANDEM SHOWS NEW SYSTEM
description: Tandem Computers Inc. today introduced a new data base management system offering the ability to operate from multiple terminals in a distributed mode. Tandem said the new system, known as nonstop Structured Query Language, is both easy to use and faster than typical relational data base systems.

title: North Koreans Absent at Match
description: North Korea did not turn up for its pre-Olympic soccer match against Thailand today despite warnings that failure to appear would bring action by the Federation of International Football Associations.

title: OTHER INQUIRIES HAVE INVOLVED COASTAL'S CHIEF
description: The head of a Brooklyn ship-repair company at the center of the indictments of Representantive Mario Biaggi and Meade H. Esposito was involved in two previous corruption inquiries concerning military contracts.

title: INSIDE
description: L.I.R.R. Pact Announced

title: NEW 'PLAIN' UTILITY BILLS BEING MAILED TO PATRONS
description: Consumers across New York State are starting to receive redesigned utility bills that provide more information on energy use and cost.

title: PRICE ACQUIRES TSS-SEEDMAN
description: The Price Company, the nation's largest chain of warehouse stores, said it had acquired the TSS-Seedman department-store chain, and will open its first Price Club on Long Island in July. While the total purchase price was not disclosed, Price, which is based in San Diego, will make an initial payment of $50 million, with the full sum to be based on the results of the acquired company.

title: TOP ACCOMPANIST FOR SINGERS
description: Gerald Moore, an English pianist whose sensitive performances and articulate advocacy helped elevate accompaniment to a high level of musical endeavor, died in his sleep Friday at his home in Buckinghamshire, England. He was 87 years old.

title: ESTY ENJOYS AUTONOMY
description: THE best thing to have happened to the William Esty Company in recent years, according to Laurence M. Wassong, its president and chief operating officer, was losing its subsidiary status under Ted Bates Worldwide and getting to report directly to Saatchi & Saatchi, the British holding company that bought Bates last summer.

title: I.B.M.: NEW SUSPENSE
description: THE personal computer industry is in suspended animation these days as everyone awaits the announcement of a new family of I.B.M. PC's. The event is expected April 2, and many of the biggest corporate buyers of PC's have put their plans on hold until then.

title: NORWAY'S PRETORIA CURB
description: Norway's parliament approved a trade boycott of South Africa today. But it left a loophole for oil by excepting Norwegian-owned tankers whose destination is decided at sea. Oil cargoes are often resold after a voyage starts, making the final port uncertain.

title: AMCAST INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: b-Net loss and includes a $22.5 million pre-tax charge for restructuring of the company's iron castings business for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Blazers Sign Rowan
description: Ron Rowan, the former St. John's guard, has signed a 10-day contract with the Portland Trail Blazers. The 6-foot-5-inch Rowan was a third-round draft choice of the Philadelphia 76ers last spring, but was cut in training camp. He had been playing in the Continental Basketball Association.

title: THEY JUST KNOW IT WORKS
description: When Jan R. AufderHeide, a spokeswoman for the Upjohn Company, was asked today how Rogaine works to stimulate hair growth, she replied, ''No one knows.''

title: Destination Kiev, Too
description: At the invitation of the Supreme Soviet, the Soviet national legislature, the House of Representatives is dispatching a 20-legislator delegation for a visit next month. Headed by Speaker Jim Wright and including 10 members of the Geneva arms-talks observer team, the group will travel April 10-21, visiting Madrid, Moscow, Kiev and West Berlin. House officials believe this to be the highest-ranking House delegation ever to visit the Soviet Union. The 15 Democrats and 5 Republicans, seeking an ''improved environment between the United States and the Soviet Union,'' will arrive in Moscow April 13, at the same time that Secretary of State George P. Shultz begins negotiations there on a medium-range missile treaty.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Many of them are much bet-ter informed about AIDS than the average physician, and they are desperate.'' - Dr. Michael Lange of New York, speaking of AIDS patients. [ A1:1. ]

title: BRITAIN TO CONTINUE FIGHT TO BAN SPY'S BOOK
description: Britain's Attorney General, Sir Michael Havers, said today that the British Government would appeal a ruling by an Australian court last week that a former intelligence officer can publish his memoirs about M.I.5, the British intelligence service. Sir Michael brushed aside demands from opposition members of Parliament for a full judicial inquiry into contentions by the former spy, Peter Wright, that dissident M.I.5 agents tried to destablize the Government of former Prime Minister Harold Wilson. On Friday, a judge in New South Wales rejected Britain's claim that Mr. Wright's book, ''Spycatcher,'' would harm British security. In a 286-page ruling, the judge said the material in the book was either harmless or had already been disclosed because M.I.5 ''leaks like a sieve.''

title: ALBANY ACCORD HELPS PROPOSAL FOR ETHICS BILL
description: With expanding New York City corruption scandals fueling pressure for action, Republican and Democratic leaders of the State Legislature announced agreement today on a broad ethics measure intended to curb abuses by officeholders.

title: 'THE REALM OF FORTUNE'
description: DIONISIO PINZON seems the perfect hero for a dark comedy. A heavy, middle-aged peasant, he appears simple-minded, yet has enough dumb luck to leave behind his squalid shack - no running water but lots of religious gewgaws - and become wealthy by raising gamecocks. He happily marries a much-used woman who sings at sleazy carnivals, and finishes life as a crazed cardsharp, playing endless games in his near-empty mansion. But while Arturo Ripstein has been one of Mexico's more prominent directors for over 15 years, in ''The Realm of Fortune'' he gropes his way through Dionisio's mordantly promising history. The film, part of the New Directors/New Film Series, will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art today at 8:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 6 P.M.

title: Conner's Busy Docket
description: The solid silver America's Cup may become worth its weight many times over for Dennis Conner, whose attractiveness to commercial interests may not peak until the next battle for yachting's prestigious prize.

title: Rice Names Coach
description: Rice University named Scott Thompson, an assistant coach at Arizona for the last four years, as its head basketball coach. Thompson replaces Tommy Suitts, who resigned under pressure Jan. 30 after six years at Rice.

title: A.M.C. ABSORPTION BY CHRYSLER SEEN
description: The Chrysler Corporation plans to absorb and dismantle the American Motors Corporation by the end of the year if its proposed buyout of the ailing auto maker is completed on schedule, the trade journal Automotive News reported. Chrysler agreed last week to purchase Renault's 46.1 percent interest in A.M.C. and to buy all other outstanding A.M.C. shares.

title: EQK REALTY INVESTORS I reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company began operations on March 31, 1985; therefore, there are no comparable figures for the 1985 year.

title: ISRAEL REPORTEDLY PAID PART OF POLLARD'S LEGAL EXPENSES
description: The Israeli Government has helped to pay the legal bills of Jonathan Jay Pollard, the American intelligence analyst sentenced to life in prison last month for spying for Israel, Israel radio reported today.

title: Drug Challenges (Continued)
description: Simone LeVant's victory last week in winning a preliminary injunction against N.C.A.A. drug tests has cheered civil liberties lawyers pressing related cases across the country. LeVant, a senior on the Stanford diving team, got Judge Peter G. Stone of Santa Clara Superior Court to agree with her contention that the tests were an obtrusive, unreasonable invasion of privacy under the California constitution. As a result, she was freed from having to submit to urinalysis last weekend at Arizona State, where, in regional preliminaries to this week's N.C.A.A. championships, she failed to qualify in either one- or three-meter diving.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BOONE. By T. Boone Pickens Jr. Illustrated. 304 pages.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE BEATS MAINE
description: Boston College defeated Maine, 4-2, at the Boston Garden tonight for the Hockey East tournament championship, a prize that has eluded the Eagles in the past two seasons. The victory means that Boston College will receive an automatic bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tournament.

title: ZACCARO'S LAWYER URGES DISMISSAL OF BRIBERY AND EXTORTION CHARGES
description: Contending that the prosecution case was riddled with ''speculation, gaps and holes,'' a lawyer for John A. Zaccaro argued yesterday that bribe-seeking and attempted-extortion charges against his client should be thrown out.

title: AIRLINES WILL ALTER SCHEDULES TO REDUCE DELAYS AT NEWARK
description: Representatives of the major airlines serving Newark International Airport agreed today on summer schedule changes aimed at easing rush hour air traffic delays to and from the busy airport.

title: Mets Get Good Report Card
description: With three weeks to go to opening day, Dave Johnson issued a report card today that found the Mets ''above average'' and on schedule to defend their title.

title: U.S.-LATIN LOAN FIGHT INTENSIFIES
description: The Reagan Administration and the debtor nations of Latin America are embroiled in a bitter dispute over who should control billions of dollars of loans to the region from Western governments.

title: KODIAK OUTDOOR BOOTS TO MESSNER, VETERE
description: There was a minor celebration yesterday at Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey, which reached its six-month anniversary and got its sixth client.

title: INTENSITY OF EMOTION TIED TO PERCEPTION AND THINKING
description: EMOTIONAL intensity, a major, lifelong aspect of temperament, is emerging as a fruitful area of research that is yielding rich insights into how people experience themselves and others. Although the idea that people differ in emotional intensity is not new, the systematic new research is revealing important differences in the way that those with high and low intensity perceive, think about and react to events.

title: AIDS DRUGS OFFER HOPE BUT CURE REMAINS DISTANT
description: This year the AIDS epidemic is being transformed from an utterly hopeless situation to one in which many, perhaps most American victims of the disease will have access to drug treatments that may give precious extra months of life.

title: It's Detroit, by Default
description: The Detroit Red Wings, on top of the N.H.L.'s Norris Division with a record of only 31-30-10, are candidates to join this list of the poorest division winners in the history of major pro sports. W-L-T Pct.* 1976-77 Blues (NHL) 32-39-9 .456 '78-79 Black Hawks (NHL) 29-36-15 .456 '71-72 Bullets (NBA) 38-44 .463 '75-76 Bucks (NBA) 38-44 .463 '56-57 Hawks (NBA) 36-38d .486 '67-68 Flyers (NHL) 31-32-11 .493 '85 Browns (NFL) 8-8 .500 '73 Mets (NL) 82-79 .509 $'70-71 Bullets (NBA) 42-40 .512 '75-76 Black Hawks (NHL) 32-30-18 .513 *N.H.L. percentages are determined by dividing a team's points by the maximum number of points possible. dIncludes two games in tiebreaker playoffs with Fort Wayne and Minneapolis.

title: FEDERAL OFFERINGS
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks will announce interest rates today on three bond issues totaling $2.55 billion. The financing consists of $1.11 billion of bonds due in 1990, $1.07 billion in 1992 and $375 million in 1997.

title: Regan Plans to Write Book
description: Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff, will write a book about his experiences, his agent said today. Norman Brokaw, co-chairman of the board of the William Morris Agency, said he would represent Mr. Regan ''in the areas of literary, broadcast and lectures.'' He said his client would begin writing the book after a short vacation. ''It will certainly include his years as Secretary of the Treasury and chief of staff to the President of the United States,'' he said.

title: ISRAELIS VOICE NEW WEARINESS AT SCANDAL-RIDDEN LEADERS
description: Israel's largest newspaper, Yediot Aharonot, recently ran a photo spread of the country's top three leaders that summed up the prevailing mood toward politicians here.

title: Officials Sentenced in Jail Case
description: All five Santa Clara County supervisors were sentenced to jail terms today for violating a judge's order to provide more jail cells to ease overcrowding.

title: U.S. and Turkey Sign Accord to Keep Bases
description: An agreement was signed today allowing the United States to keep its military bases in Turkey through 1990 while providing millions of dollars in aid to the Ankara Government and promising to push Congress for more.

title: Aspin Opposes the Zero-Missile Option in Europe
description: The Democratic chairman of the House Armed Services Committee has asked President Reagan in a letter not to agree to the complete elimination of American and Soviet medium-range missiles from Europe.

title: U.S. TO DECIDE PHONE OF FUTURE
description: The future of American telecommunications is now on the drawing boards with a new state-of-the-art telephone network that the Federal Government plans to be using by 1990.

title: Parade Today
description: The St. Patrick's Day parade begins today at 11:30 A.M., moving up Fifth Avenue from 44th to 86th Street, then east to Third Avenue. Fifth Avenue between 42d and 90th Street will be closed from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Richard Britton and Michael Reingold have been promoted to executive vice presidents at HBM/Creamer, Boston.

title: JAPANESE PURCHASE OF CHIP MAKER CANCELED AFTER OBJECTIONS IN U.S.
description: Bowing to intense pressure from Reagan Administration officials, an American company said yesterday that it had called off the sale of a technology subsidiary to one of Japan's giant electronics companies.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing for pop clubs in The Guide on Sunday carried outdated information for the Ballroom. La Gran Scena Opera Company will perform tonight through Saturday, and Yma Sumac will appear tonight through Thursday.

title: Bonner Reports the Release Of 8 More Soviet Dissidents
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, said today that eight more dissidents had been released, three today and five last week.

title: MAY MISS A START
description: Roger Clemens, Boston's No. 1 pitcher, wasn't here today. Rick Rhoden, the Yankees' No. 1 pitcher, was here but not for long.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Three Hour Lark Wins at Aqueduct: Three Hour Lark withstood a stewards' inquiry and a jockey's claim of foul to register a one-length victory in the $27,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares 4-years-old and up at Aqueduct yesterday. Scissors was second to the wire but was placed third in the revised order of finish behind the original third finisher, Sharpening Up, whose rider, Chris Antley, charged interference at the half-mile pole by both Three Hour Lark and Scissors. For Three Hour Lark, who carried 117 pounds under Jose Santos, the victory was the first in two starts this year. The 5-year-old daughter of Super Concorde-Pink Larkspur covered seven furlongs in 1:27 1/5 on the fast track to earn $16,200 for Ken-Mort Stable. She paid $4 for $2 to win. N.B.A. Pistons 115, Pacers 95: Adrian Dantley scored 19 of his 31 points in the first half and Vinnie Johnson added 25 as Detroit beat Indiana at home for its seventh straight victory. The Pistons extended their lead in the Central Division to one game over Atlanta, which has a 10-game winning streak.(AP) Rockets 97, Bulls 96: In Houston, Rodney McCray's follow shot of Allen Leavell's miss with one second left gave Houston the victory. Michael Jordan, who hit two free throws with five seconds left after being fouled by Akeem Olajuwon, had 44 points for the Bulls, who lost their fifth straight game.(AP) FENCING Lofton Wins Saber Competition: Michael Lofton of New York University won the individual saber competition, 18-0, in the national collegiate men's championships at Notre Dame. Robert Cottingham of Columbia finished second with a 17-3 record and Christopher Reohr, also of Columbia, was third with a 16-3 mark.(AP)

title: N.F.L. FACES A NEW ECONOMY
description: While many National Football League owners today hailed the new three-year television contract announced Sunday, some nonetheless expressed concern that the slight decline from the television revenues of 1986 could force them to change how they do business.

title: TEXAS MUST ACT ON SALE OF CHRONICLE
description: The sale of The Houston Chronicle to the Hearst Corporation requires the approval of Attorney General Jim Mattox of Texas because the paper is owned by a charitable foundation, Houston Endowment Inc.

title: KING CALLS HILL, THEN WORKS OUT
description: When the telephone rang at Bob Hill's home yesterday morning, the Knicks' head coach was hopeful. After all, no news could be worse than the what had already befallen his team during this dismal season.

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $62,000 for the latest quarter and $358,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Tart Tark
description: Jerry Tarkanian, Nevada-Las Vegas basketball coach, on his suddenly cold-shooting forward, Gerald Paddio: ''He's due to go 10 for 10 any game now. I just hope it's not in the summer league.''

title: ACCORD LIFTS STRIKE PERIL ON L.I.R.R.
description: Long Island Rail Road commuters were apparently spared the prospect of another strike yesterday when negotiators succeeded in resolving a snag in a previously announced agreement with the electricians union.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed May 26, 1986.

title: CIRCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the sales increase in the latest year resulted from the inclusion of the sales of an endoscope producer acquired in August 1986 for $28.5 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MARCH 17, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-15

title: COLUMBIA U. PLANS MET GALA
description: Lest anyone forget that Columbia University is the Ivy League's outpost on Broadway, the institution is planning a gala tribute of show tunes at the Metropolitan Opera House April 12 to commemorate its 200th anniversary.

title: PREGNANCY WITH DONOR EGGS
description: SCIENTISTS at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey have used two innovative procedures to achieve pregnancy in a 38-year-old New Jersey woman whose ovaries had ceased to function.

title: OPEC CUT IN OUTPUT IS REPORTED
description: OPEC production this month has been around 14 million barrels a day, 1.8 million below the group's self-imposed ceiling, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today.

title: AIDS TESTS FOR TRANSFUSIONS BEFORE 1985?
description: THE United States Public Health Service is recommending that some of the tens of millions of Americans who received blood transfusions and other blood products between 1978 and April of 1985 be tested for infection by the AIDS virus.

title: TEXAS AIR SUIT
description: The Texas Air Corporation said that former minority shareholders of Continental Airlines Inc. would receive an additional $3.75 a share under a settlement of a class-action suit by the Mutual Shares Corporation. In February, Texas Air acquired the minority interest in Continental that it did not already own for $16.50 a share. Mutual, a New York investment firm, had said the price was inadequate.

title: HELEN LIGHTBODY
description: Helen Lightbody, the nanny who cared for Prince Charles and Princess Anne and was known as ''No Nonsense Lightbody,'' died in Hawick, Scotland, on Saturday, Buckingham Palace said today. She was 79 years old.

title: OIL RIG COUNT DROPS
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped by five this week to 761, officials of the Hughes Tool Company said today. The figure was down 33.1 percent from 1,137 a year ago. The Houston-based oil tool maker has kept track of working rigs, a yardstick of drilling activity, since 1940.

title: Regan at Treasury
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ATTORNEY IN MIAMI GUARDED AFTER DEATH THREATS ARE REPORTED
description: Leon B. Kellner, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, has been under heavy guard since Federal intelligence agencies reported more than two weeks ago that a South American narcotics ring planned to kill him, Federal law-enforcement officials said today.

title: DUKAKIS SAYS HE WILL RUN FOR PRESIDENT
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, declaring that he had ''the experience to manage'' and ''the values to lead,'' said today he was running for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: BRAZIL DEBT OPTIMISM
description: A.W. Clausen, the chairman and chief executive of the BankAmerica Corporation, said today that he does not believe Brazil will continue withholding interest payments on its debt.

title: FACING TRAGEDY: A FOSTER-CARE CASEWORKER'S BURDEN
description: The gray-blue light of a winter's dusk had settled over the tenement and the trash-filled vacant lot next door, when Allison Skeete, after a week of searching, finally caught up with the mother and two small children.

title: Paroling Prisoners with AIDS
description: Should a prisoner afflicted with AIDS be allowed a break from his parole board? Though the numbers involved are still small, the issue is sure to confront prison and parole officials around the country as the disease spreads. In New York the answer is yes. Of thousands released on parole in the last two years, 50 had AIDS. Many would not have been released had they not developed the disease. Their release is appropriate on humanitarian grounds - but only if they disclose their condition to those on the outside who might be imperilled.

title: Missile Passes 127th Test
description: A Minuteman 3 missile carried a cluster of dummy warheads to targets on a South Pacific atoll 4,200 miles away a half-hour after launching today from an underground silo, the Air Force said today. The missile was launched by an airborne crew in a test of a backup system to be used in the event ground crews were not operational. It was the 127th Minuteman launching in a series of tests.

title: 'MURDER BY THE BOOK,' ON CBS
description: ''MURDER BY THE BOOK,'' tonight's television movie on CBS at 9, is a promising idea that turns out to be only half as funny as it should be. Hank Mercer has been writing Biff Deegan mysteries (''The Dead Bimbo's Return'') for six years and is fed up. ''You don't know what it's like,'' he tells his publisher, ''to live day after day with a character you can't stand the sight of anymore.'' Hank wants to develop a new, more cerebral detective named Amos Frisbee, but Biff, all done up in a seedy brown suit, fedora and pencil mustache, has begun visiting the writer, arguing that his ways are still best and the most profitable in terms of book sales.

title: CARRINGTON LABORATORIES reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $968,763.

title: ICAHN CONFIRMS S.E.C. INVESTIGATION
description: Carl C. Icahn, the takeover specialist who is chairman of Trans World Airlines, acknowledged yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating whether he had violated securities laws.

title: ANGLICAN OFFERS TO SEEK IRANIAN
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury says he will try to find an Iranian who was kidnapped in Lebanon four years ago, and Iran has promised to seek information about the missing Anglican envoy Terry Waite, according to an Iranian radio broadcast today.

title: ADOBE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The year-ago period's share earnings restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Feb. 27, 1987.

title: CARUSO DENIES BIAS IN EJECTION MOVE
description: The head of the New York City police officers' union will issue a letter today denying that an effort by union leaders to expel 24 dissident members is motivated by racial or ethnic bias, union spokesmen said last night.

title: CAESARS WORLD SUES TO STOP BID
description: Caesars World Inc., the target of a $725.2 million bid by Martin T. Sosnoff, a New York investor, filed suit in Federal court to block the offer. Caesars World charged that the offer violates securities laws and margin regulations and that the offering materials contain false information. Caesars World said the $28-a-share offer was a maneuver by Mr. Sosnoff to manipulate the stock price and sell his 13.6 percent stake at a profit.

title: SHARING ACID RAIN'S COSTS
description: The extensive interstate sharing of coal-generated electric power strengthens the case for broad sharing of the costs of cleaning up acid rain, according to a new report.

title: THERE'S WESTWOOD, AND THERE'S THE REST
description: Vivienne Westwood is flying in the face of the prevailing fashion trend for next fall and winter. While most designers here are trying to make clothes that look grown-up and serious, the woman who is called the mother of punk fashions is regressing. This afternoon she showed clothes for the early adolescent crowd that included mini-length hoop skirts and jumpers. When the models flicked up their skirts to show their drawers and petticoats, they resembled bad little girls in a schoolyard.

title: 'BEST OF WILD AMERICA: THE BABIES'
description: ADORABILITY runs rampant; the cuddlesome quotient is high. ''The Best of Wild America: The Babies'' is full of small furry things. At 90 minutes, however - minus time for fund appeals - it's a little like drowning in teddy bears. On the other hand, Channel 13 may just think this is winsome. It is showing ''The Babies'' in its entirety at 8:30 tonight, and then in half-hour segments tomorrow night through Friday at 7 o'clock.

title: Candidates in Bronx Will Be Scrutinized
description: All candidates for Bronx Borough President will be required to fill out detailed disclosure forms for the city's Department of Investigation and to be interviewed at public hearings by the Bronx delegation of the City Council, under rules announced yesterday by Mayor Koch and Bronx Council members.

title: 'WITCHING' RULE ALTERED
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would cooperate with the Securities and Exchange Commission's request to modify a voluntary experiment for Friday's ''triple witching hour.''

title: W. STERLING COLE, 82, DIES OF CANCER
description: W. Sterling Cole, who represented an upstate New York district in the United States House of Representatives from 1935 to 1957 and was the first director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, died of cancer Sunday at the George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 82 years old and lived in Arlington, Va.

title: MARGARET CAMPBELL, DIRECTOR OF MUSIC FESTIVAL IN VILLAGE
description: Margaret Campbell, the chairwoman of the Washington Square Music Festival since 1956, died of a heart attack Sunday at University Hospital in Manhattan. She was 87 years old and had lived in lower Manhattan since 1922.

title: HYDROLOGICAL DECADE LEADER
description: Raymond L. Nace, a research hydrologist and former head of the United States scientific committee for the International Hydrological Decade, died of emphysema March 6 in Boise, Idaho, the United States Geological Survey said yesterday. He was 79 years old.

title: OSLO BANS SINATRA SHOW OVER SOUTH AFRICA ISSUE
description: The City Council has denied Frank Sinatra permission to hold a concert in Oslo because he has performed in South Africa, concert promoters said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT

title: DePau*
description: Some say DePaul, some say DePauw, but no matter how you pronounce it, having two basketball-minded universities with almost identical names spells confusion.

title: TV'S PITCH TO CHILDREN
description: TELEVISION and toy manufacturers have joined to get a firm grip on children. In the 1980's, the toy industry, whose sales already amount to $12 billion a year, has been growing by $1 billion a year. Its sales pitch is made mainly on Saturday mornings by all three major networks in the nonstop presentations of cartoons whose mayhem and firepower are striking to even the casual viewer.

title: Boy, 15, Held as Killer Of a Woman, 82
description: A 15-year-old boy was arrested last night and charged with fatally assaulting an 82-year-old woman Sunday morning on a Brooklyn street, the police said.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING MAY SELL LAND UNIT
description: The Pacific Lighting Corporation, parent of the Southern California Gas Company, said it is considering selling part or all of its land development business. The real estate group earned $24.2 million on operating revenues of $342 million in 1986 and employs 800 people. It deals mainly in residential and small commercial properties in California and Hawaii.

title: F.S.L.I.C. FUNDS SET FOR DALLAS
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas will receive close to $1 billion in cash on Wednesday from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, according to a source at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in Washington.

title: CUOMO CANCELS RADIO SHOW OVER STRIKE
description: Governor Cuomo has canceled his monthly call-in program on WCBS radio because he refused to cross the picket line of news writers outside CBS.

title: THE BATTLE OF THE BOOKSELLERS
description: To hear the San Francisco lawyer William R. Petrocelli tell it, a dispute that has divided the book-selling industry for six years started with some invoices sent by a publisher to the wrong bookstore. The invoices revealed that publishers were giving large chain bookstores a discount from the price paid by small independent stores.

title: POLISH ARTICLE GIVES DETAILS ON PLOTS AND A SECURITY UNIT
description: Attacks by assassins on Polish leaders in the 1950's and 60's came to light here for the first time last week with the publication of an article describing a top-secret security detail that protects party and Government officials as well as visiting foreign dignitaries.

title: DATAMAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Corrected from Saturday, March 14, editions.

title: ASTRONOMERS COME IN FROM THE COOL NIGHT AIR
description: ASTRONOMY is in the throes of a technological revolution that is imparting assembly-line efficiency to the art of observing the heavens, allowing astronomers to abandon observatories perched atop remote mountain peaks for comfortable office buildings thousands of miles away.

title: STAGE: BILL COSBY ON LIFE, FAMILY AND TURNING 49
description: IN his show last year at Radio City Music Hall, Bill Cosby talked about the pleasures of being 48 years old. He is far less sure about 49. In his new show, seen last weekend at the Music Hall, he fixes his gaze on those of his age in the audience, and says that once his body had ''definition.'' Now he has to remember to breathe in and to stand tall. Recently, he said, he stepped out of the shower and accidently walked past a mirror without preparing his body for the reflection. Seeing his once athletic form in its present, middle-aged shape, he wondered who the stranger was who had invaded his bathroom.

title: 'UPSTAIRS, DOWNSTAIRS' RETURNS TO TV
description: Reruns are common on public television. The program that runs on Thursday night may run the next Saturday morning and the following Tuesday afternoon to get the most mileage for the money.

title: CONTINENTAL HOMES HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
EUROPE URGES JAPAN TO BEND
description: The European Community today called on Japan to do more to open its markets to the community's products. It said it was worried about its widening trade deficit with that nation - $18.2 billion in 1986.

title: A Wise Reversal on Poland
description: Having belatedly reversed its policy toward post-Solidarity Poland only last month, the Administration seems to be making up for lost time by going out of it way to lend support. This policy change should be applauded as a constructive step in East-West relationships.

title: DISPLAYING GRAPHICS
description: THE personal computer industry is riddled with a multiplicity of standards. Probably in no area is this more evident than in graphics. It's not only that there is one set of criteria for color and another for monochrome. Among the I.B.M. PC's and compatibles alone there are a host of standards relating to color display and several relating to monochrome display. All of this adds nothing but problems for people who simply want to use their computers.

title: BOWERY SAVINGS BANK IS RESIGNED BY OGILVY
description: Ogilvy & Mather announced yesterday that it had resigned the Bowery Savings Bank account.

title: IN TRIBAL COUNTRY: STRAWBERRIES AND SUBDIVISIONS
description: For many Thais from the sweltering lowlands, and for those foreigners who try to find ways to settle here, ''the north'' is without qualification the best part of Thailand.

title: 11 Charged in Corruption Case
description: A former state senator, a former alderman and nine other people were accused in Federal indictments today of corruption in the city's licensing and inspection units.

title: Students Hold Protests On Ecuador Austerity
description: Students throwing rocks clashed with riot policemen today during protests against Government austerity measures imposed to deal with an economic crisis caused by earthquake damage.

title: ALPINE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $130,000 for the quarter and $490,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-Includes a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $69,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $52,000 for the 9 months.

title: OF DISCARDED TREATIES AND THE ABM
description: The treaty with Britain allowing for joint custody of the Oregon Territory proved to be a nuisance for President Polk. So in 1846 he arrived at a simple solution that has been repeated by many Presidents since then. He chucked the treaty. It was, historians say, one of the earliest instances of America renouncing a major treaty to escape its encumbrances. Bar to Star Wars Progress Seen

title: WHY BOOK PUBLISHERS ARE TARGETS FOR MERGER
description: From a secondhand press, a rented office and 200 book salesmen who canvassed the country on horseback, the four Harper brothers built their company into one of the largest publishing houses in the world by the mid-19th century. Over the years it has slipped from that lofty pedestal, but a combination of editorial talent and shrewd acquisitions has kept Harper's at or near the forefront of American book publishing for 170 years.

title: THE NEW ORLEANS MAN BEHIND 'STAGGERLEE' SOUND
description: Tall, dignified, moving deliberately, Allen Toussaint sits down at the piano just as the bandstand he's sitting on rolls out onto the stage for the beginning of ''Staggerlee,'' the rhythm-and-blues musical opening tomorrow at the Second Avenue Theater. The music that comes rolling out is pure New Orleans strut - sultry and syncopated, with a blues bedrock just beneath its gaudy carnival surface. ''I've been feeling like going back and recording a certain kind of music that's very familiar to me now,'' Mr. Toussaint said, ''music that doesn't call for any heavy scrutiny on trying to make a hit. This feeling has been rejuvenated lately; playing with the show every night is a blessing.''

title: HOUSTON PAPER'S HEAD PLEASED BY HEARST TIE
description: Richard J.V. Johnson will soon be getting a new set of bosses. He is president of The Houston Chronicle, which the Hearst Corporation plans to purchase for $400 million.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Halco Mining Inc., Pittsburgh, a supplier of bauxite, appointed John W.G. Gilby president and chief executive, succeeding Michael Jaoul, who is retiring.

title: BOESKY FUND PARTNERS TO WAIT YEAR FOR MONEY
description: Limited partners in the arbitrage fund of Ivan F. Boesky will have to wait for at least a year before getting any money back under a plan announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: U.S. URGES CUT IN DEPENDENCE ON FOREIGN OIL
description: Continued dependence on Mideast oil will pose a security threat for the rest of the century or longer and Government initiatives are needed to reduce this vulnerability, according to an Administration study to be published Tuesday.

title: Mr. Serrano for the Bronx
description: Economically, the Bronx shows signs of resurgence from a deep trough. Politically, Bronx leaders dig ever deeper holes for themselves and their constituents. In selecting a new Borough President, they will do so again unless a majority of the Bronx City Council members find the courage to vote for Jose Serrano, a candidate who is not a card-carrying member of the borough's Democratic clique.

title: Q&A
description: Q.How do scientists calculate the number of calories in a particular food and the number of calories the body burns in a particular exercise? A.A calorie is the amount of heat needed to raise the temperature of one gram of water by one degree Celsius. To calculate the number of calories in a certain food, scientists burn the food in a device called a bomb-calorimeter, according to Jean Himms-Hagen, chairwoman of the biochemistry department at the University of Ottawa, Ontario. The device uses an electric charge to cause the food to combust, measures the amount of heat produced by the food and expresses that heat in terms of calories. Dr. Himms-Hagen said that the body burns food and gives off heat in a similar fashion. To measure the number of calories consumed during exercise, scientists have built very large calorimeters in which people can live. One type measures the heat given off by the person exercising. Another, called an indirect calorimeter, measures the oxygen that is consumed. Oxygen is needed for a substance to burn. Dr. Himms-Hagen said that an average man who is not very active burns 2,800 calories a day. He can increase the number by about 10 percent by playing squash twice a week and by 15 percent by jogging two hours a week. Q.Why does it take seven human years to equal one dog year? A.Dogs mature about seven times as fast as humans, according to Dr. Lawrence Glickman, a professor at the School of Veterinary Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania. The equivalence is based on the amount of time it takes both species to undergo certain physiological changes, such as sprouting teeth and reaching sexual maturity. A dog develops much more rapidly in early life and then slows down: the first year for a dog is equal to 15 years for a human, but a 5-year-old dog is comparable to a 35-year-old human.

title: Costello Resigns
description: Following his school's decision last month to abandon Division I basketball and return to Division III, Larry Costello announced his decision to retire as coach at Utica (N.Y.) College.

title: Not Italian, but Puerto Rican
description: A recent item in this space under the headline ''An Italian Name'' described the crime-fighting achievement of Benito Romano, who works for United States Attorney Rudolph Giuliani and was named to the State Commission on Government Integrity, headed by Joseph Califano Jr. It said: ''How often have three Italian-Americans been thus juxtaposed, and in a report about fighting crime no less? The answer is, more and more often, as the melting pot increasingly obliterates the ugly stereotype that portrays Italian-Americans as mobsters.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jerry Vainisi, who was dismissed as general manager of the Chicago Bears in January, was named team counsel for the Detroit Lions.

title: TOBIA BROWN FRANKEL, TEACHER AND EDITOR, 52
description: Tobia Brown Frankel, a teacher, editor and most recently third-year law student at Columbia University, died at New York Hospital early yesterday from the effects of a brain tumor diagnosed in 1985. She was 52 years old.

title: INVESTMENT SOURS FOR A TIMES SQ. SHELTER
description: Covenant House has come a long way since it opened its pioneering storefront shelter for runaway and homeless youth in Times Square a decade ago. But now its progress may be halted because of New York City's law on single-room-occupancy hotels.

title: CON ED TAX-EXEMPTS OFFERED TO YIELD 7 1/8%
description: At a time when 7 percent yields on tax-exempt bonds are becoming hard to find, the New York State Energy Research and Development Corporation is offering $100.8 million of 7 1/8 percent bonds due in 2022 on behalf of the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: Police Need Such Means as Hogtying to Restrain Violent Felons
description: To the Editor:

title: CONRAIL ISSUE: PRICE RAISED
description: THE price tag has been raised on what shapes up as this country's largest new issue ever: the public sale of the Government's 85 percent stake in the Consolidated Rail Corporation.

title: AVANT-GARDE COMPUTING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ROBERT COLBY, POP COMPOSER AND THEATER PRODUCER, DIES
description: Robert Colby, a composer, producer and publisher of popular music and a theater producer, died of cancer last Tuesday at Memorial Sloane-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Rail Stop Is Planned Despite Opposition
description: Amtrak plans to move its Westchester stop from Rye to New Rochelle, despite some local opposition based on potential traffic problems.

title: E.P.A. PREDICTS ACID RAIN DAMAGE
description: About 300 lakes in the northeastern United States will become acidic in the next 50 years unless the pollutants that cause acid rain are reduced, according to a new study by scientists at the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: JAPANESE WARY ON TRADE
description: More Japanese have become wary of imports, the Government said today. Of 2,385 people it polled in October, 33.8 percent - up from 28.9 pecent a year earlier - said Japan should be cautious about opening its markets wider to foreign competitors because of problems caused by the yen's rise.

title: CHIEF MAPS FUTURE FOR CAESARS WORLD
description: Henry Gluck was new to the gambling industry in 1983 when he took over Caesars World Inc. But the industry knows him now as the man who put Caesars on a sound financial footing.

title: Bombing in Managua
description: Explosive charges damaged an electrical tower in Managua early today, and the Government said United States-backed contra rebels were responsible. It was believed to be the first time the Government had acknowledged a contra ground attack in the capital.

title: ASA LTD reports earnings for As of Feb 28
description: Assets represent net assets. The company said for the three months ended Feb. 28 it had net investment income of $13,607,867, or $1.42 a share, compared with $15,479,454, or $1.61 a share, in the year-ago period.

title: COOPER LASERSONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $1,082,000.

title: 4TH TEEN-AGER IN SUICIDE PACT BURIED IN JERSEY
description: Nineteen-year-old Thomas Rizzo of Bergenfield, who was asphyxiated last Wednesday with three other teen-agers in a suicide pact, was buried here today after a funeral mass that focused on forgiveness.

title: SHIFT TO NEUTRAL FOR EARLY SITES SOUGHT
description: The clock ticks down, and one of the two teams in the theoretically neutral arena faces elimination from the tournament. A shot is missed, and as the other team comes down the floor with the basketball and the chance for a score that would give them control of the game, the fans stand and cheer in a deafening display of one-sided passion.

title: Soviet Study of Abuse of Psychiatry Is Urged
description: A dissident psychiatrist who was recently freed from prison has called on the Soviet Government to establish a special commission to review the cases of people who are confined in mental hospitals under questionable circumstances.

title: Save the Wilderness
description: To the Editor:

title: Freedom to Criticize
description: The right to criticize ''public characters and measures,''

title: TRANSPLANTED, DIONNE FINDS A BETTER FIT
description: An hour had passed after the end of the game, and Marcel Dionne had still not gotten to the point of trading the towel around his waist for his clothes. He was talking about why he had wanted to leave Los Angeles and about how he managed to land in New York. He said that he had not come here to be everyone's favorite relic, and he added in his rich, French-Canadian accent, ''I have finally discovered what hockey really is.''

title: BRIDGE: TEAM OF WORLD CHAMPIONS IS VANDERBILT TITLE WINNER
description: After a swinging battle at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here Sunday, a six-man team of reigning world champions captured the Vanderbilt Knockout Team title.

title: Heaven in Asphalt
description: Mall:

title: Wedtech Jury Hears Ex-G.O.P. Chairman
description: George Clark, a former New York State Republican chairman, has been called to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the Wedtech Corporation.

title: DATA SHOW E.P.A. DELAYED WARNING ABOUT PCB PERIL
description: The Environmental Protection Agency knew about PCB contamination at specific sites along the Texas Eastern pipeline as early as the autumn of 1985 but took no immediate action to protect public health at the sites, according to internal agency documents.

title: HONORING FINN WHO DROVE OUT THE GRASSHOPPERS
description: It was a terrible time in Finland, so the story goes. Much of the nation's bountiful crop of wild grapes was being devoured by swarms of grasshoppers.

title: CONSERVATIVES GAIN IN FINNISH ELECTION
description: In a modest shift to the right in Finnish politics, the dominant Social Democratic Party lost support and the Conservatives gained in elections today.

title: U.S. SAYS ESPOSITO GAVE HIM PAYOFFS
description: Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx and Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader, were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of bribery, fraud and conspiracy involving attempts to help a financially troubled Brooklyn Navy Yard company.

title: INTENSE SCIENTIFIC EFFORTS FAIL TO REVERSE THE PANDA'S DECLINE
description: DESPITE conservation efforts by the Chinese Government and international scientists, the number of giant pandas is continuing to decline sharply, leaving the endearing black and white animals still on the road to extinction.

title: OWNED NEWSPAPERS AND WAS A CHEMIST
description: Paul Block Jr., a research chemist and co-publisher of The Blade of Toledo, Ohio, and of The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, died Sunday at Community Hospital . He was 75 years old.

title: SAMUEL H. SHAPIRO, 79, EX-GOVERNOR OF ILLINOIS
description: Samuel H. Shapiro, who served briefly as Governor in 1968, died today at home. He was 79 years old.

title: Rudolf Hess Back in Prison After 16-Day Hospital Stay
description: Rudolf Hess was taken back to his prison cell today after a 16-day stay at a British military hospital, a British diplomatic spokesman said.

title: KEY RATES
SUFFOLK COUNTY SETS OFFERING
description: Suffolk County, L.I., is tentatively offering $162.8 million of refunding bonds for the Southwest Sewer District through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: CAPACITY USE RISES TO 79.8%
description: A big increase in the production of automobiles and other durable goods helped push the operating rate in American industry to 79.8 percent of capacity last month, the highest level in a year, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: ISLANDERS COME UP EMPTY
description: The struggling, injury-prone Islanders' season-long weakness in front of the goal on both sides of the ice brought them down close to .500 again tonight as the opportunistic Canadiens produced a 3-0 victory.

title: U.S. Faltering in Davis Cup
description: The most recent chapter in the decline of American tennis was written in Asuncion, Paraguay, last weekend when Victor Pecci and Hugo Chapacu led that country's lightly regarded Davis Cup team to a 3-2 victory against the American clay court specialists, Jimmy Arias and Aaron Krickstein.

title: BALLY TO SELL STOCK IN ITS HEALTH CLUBS
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said today that it would make an initial public offering of 5.8 million shares, or 24 percent, of its health-club chain.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MARCH 17, 1987
description: Companies

title: JAMES WATT, NOW AN INDIAN LAWYER, LOSES A CLIENT
description: Montana's Crow Indians have dismissed James G. Watt, the former Interior Secretary, as the tribe's attorney in a boundary dispute.

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,667,000 and $2,123,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; and net gains on insurance recovery of $54,000 for the quarter and $1,289,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $42,000 and $1,334,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; and a net gain on insurance recovery of $91,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $885,000 for the 9 months. d-Net loss The company said the extraordinary charge in the year-ago 9 months includes a charge of $1,103,000 to account for change in accounting for inventories in the company's textile segment less a gain on insurance recovery of $218,000. The figures for the year-ago third quarter and 9-months were restated for the discontinued apparel segment and for the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle.

title: CLOSE CALL NO COMFORT TO REDMEN
description: For nearly half an hour after losing to DePaul on Sunday, the St. John's basketball team sat in its locker room wondering how a game that seemed so solidly in hand had slipped away.

title: TERRORIST'S CONFESSIONS HELPING ITALY
description: Italian officials say they have gained valuable insights into the workings of the Abu Nidal terrorist group through the confessions of one of its captured members.

title: FBX CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: The company went public on Dec. 17, 1986.

title: MULRONEY'S TRADE HOPES
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said today that Canada and the United States were making ''significant progress'' in their 11-month-old negotiations aimed at producing a trade pact that would eliminate tariff and nontariff barriers between the two nations.

title: The U.N. Today: March 17, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: AVIA SHAREHOLDERS FIGHT REEBOK BID
description: A group of shareholders in Avia Group International Inc. has filed suit to halt the planned $180 million acquisition of the athletic-shoe company by Reebok International Ltd. The suit contends that the price being offered for Avia is too low. The complaint was filed by Clem Eischen, a Portland-area resident who said he owns 500 shares of Avia, and Robert Withers, who said he owns 954 shares, court records showed.

title: NURSING HOME INSURERS RISE
description: INSURING the elderly against the frailties of old age is emerging as one of the fastest-growing and most hazardous segments of the insurance business, industry experts say. About 200,000 nursing home insurance policies have been sold to individuals, nearly half of them in 1986.

title: EX-UNIVERSITY CHIEF AND WIFE HELD IN FRAUD CASE
description: Dr. Robert A. Huttenback, who resigned last July as Chancellor of the University of California at Santa Barbara while under investigation for misuse of the university's funds, was arrested today with his wife, Freda, on charges of embezzlement, insurance fraud and tax fraud.

title: WHEN A STAFF IS CUT
description: CHANGE and transition are common enough words but they have special meaning for human resource experts. Last week William Bridges, president of Pontes Associates of Mill Valley, Calif., management consultants, spoke here on the topic before a meeting held by J.J. Gallagher Associates, an outplacement firm, for managers of some of its client companies.

title: Fuel From Plants
description: To the Editor:

title: BATTLE STARTING ON CONVERSIONS OF APARTMENTS
description: State lawmakers began bracing today for a major battle over attempts to keep an estimated 170,000 subsidized apartments from being transferred to the open market.

title: CLEVELAND ST. RALLY FALLS SHORT, 79-77
description: Derrick Sanders scored 20 of his 27 points in the second half tonight and Illinois State held off a late rally to defeat Cleveland State, 79-77, in a second-round National Invitation Tournament game.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $403,000 and $598,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and the 6 months also includes a gain of $571,000, or 6 cents a share, from the sale of land.

title: Children of Transients Are Denied Schooling
description: A survey of transient families suggests that at least two out of five homeless children do not attend school, and seeing that the children get an education and other help while they are on the road is almost impossible.

title: A EUROBOND NOTE SECTOR IS STILL SHAKY AFTER FALL
description: The floating-rate note market in London, a $160 billion sector of the Eurobond market featuring many large commercial banks as issuers and investors, remained in disarray yesterday following steep price declines late last week.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: For several seasons it has been fashionable to complain about British fashion. Retailers complained that London's designers couldn't deliver the goods and that what was delivered was often shoddily made. Designers blamed British manufacturers.

title: Fried Is Summoned
description: It happens rarely, but the House Judiciary Committee has summoned the Solicitor General, Charles Fried, who represents the Government before the Supreme Court, to testify before a subcommittee on Thursday. Committee sources said it was unusual to have an oversight hearing involving a Solicitor General and his office.

title: Yankee Loyalty
description: New Yorkers who might have worried that George Steinbrenner would take the Yankees to the New Jersey Meadowlands because of parking are about to learn that there's more than one way to leave your lover.

title: SPLIT-FINGER GIANTS WITH SF CAPS
description: For most members of the Giants, the intertwined orange ''SF'' on their black caps stands for San Francisco. But for the pitchers, it seems to stand instead for split-finger, as in the split-finger fastball taught by Roger Craig, the Giants' manager.

title: Selected Appearances
description: Donald T. Regan, who resigned as White House chief of staff last month, is undertaking what promises to be a lucrative sideline as a private citizen: public speaking. Mr. Regan, a Wall Street executive before he joined the Reagan Administration, has agreed to be represented by the Harry Walker Agency in New York and the William Morris Agency of Los Angeles for selected appearances around the country.

title: AGENCY FINANCING IN SOUTH CAROLINA
description: The South Carolina Public Service Authority is offering $193.8 million of bonds, with a maximum yield of 7 percent for bonds due in 2021, through underwriters led by the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

title: NETWORKS SAVE CASH, GAIN A COMPETITOR
description: While not quite a bombshell, the National Football League's decision to add cable to its television package is certain to bring some significant changes to both the TV industry and the sports leagues.

title: Baker Is Finding His Niche, As a Counselor-Compromiser
description: For two weeks Howard H. Baker Jr. has been trying to figure out his new job as White House chief of staff, in part by talking to other men who have held the post.

title: ADVANCE CIRCUITS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,737,000 from refinancing for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: INDICTED OFFICIALS WIELD BEHIND-THE-SCENE POWER
description: Two longtime friends from opposite ends of New York City, Representative Mario Biaggi and Meade H. Esposito, who were indicted yesterday, are among the most powerful behind-the-scenes politicians in New York.

title: The Obvious Cure for Air Delays
description: Sorry we're late. The 8:59 from LaGuardia left at 9:45. When it did arrive at O'Hare, we waited 20 minutes for a gate. . . .

title: It's Not Cheap to Keep a Hospital Competitive
description: To the Editor:

title: CHESS: 4 GRANDMASTERS END TIE IN THE HASTINGS INTERNATIONAL
description: The 62d running of the Hastings International Tournament in England saw four grandmasters tie for first place - Murray Chandler and Jonathan Speelman of Britain, Bent Larsen of Denmark and Smbat Lputian of the Soviet Union. Each finished with 8-5.

title: Our Towns; Romance Keep Your Hero Over 6 Feet Tall
description: Mildred Lubke had news. Her unpublished novel made it to the semifinals in the Romance Writers of America's Golden Hearts competition, traditional category - for books without sex before marriage.

title: LATIN PEACE PROPOSAL GAINS, BUT IS FACING STIFF HURDLES
description: A Costa Rican plan to bring peace to Central America appears to be getting increasingly serious consideration in the region. But several Central American officials say the plan faces difficult negotiations.

title: CJI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,069,000 from the termination of a pension plan for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss d-Includes the results of Rowe International Inc. since June 1, 1985, the effective date. The company said the preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in both periods.

title: GROUP OWNS 5.9% OF PUROLATOR
description: The Mutual Shares Corporation, a New York investment firm, and its affiliates said they had purchased a 5.9 percent stake in the Purolator Courier Corporation. The Purolator board has accepted a $268 million leveraged buyout proposal from a management group led by E.F. Hutton LBO Inc. But last week, a director of the air-freight concern, which is based in Basking Ridge, N.J., resigned to seek possible counter offers.

title: KEY ADVISER FOR DOLE EFFORT SAYS HE'S OUT AFTER DISPUTE
description: A struggle within the top ranks of Bob Dole's Presidential exploratory committee has resulted in defeat for a key campaign aide, David A. Keene, chairman of the American Conservative Union.

title: A Dream You Can't Refuse
description: LEAD: Mergers. Buyouts. Takeovers. I go home dizzy after regarding the day's events. Chrysler takes over American Motors, U.S. Air and Piedmont merge, Carl Icahn wants U.S. Air, somebody wants Harper & Row, my Pathmark supermarket may be sold, and if I need parts for my 40-year-old Sunbeam Mixmaster, I may have to write to an investment house for them.

title: MUSIC: STRAUSS ORIGINAL OF 'ARIADNE AUF NAXOS'
description: ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' counts now as a mainstream opera. But it achieved that status only after Richard Strauss and the librettist Hugo von Hofmannsthal subjected their 1912 original version to a radical revision, first performed in 1916. The Boston Symphony presented a concert version of the original in 1974, and the Juilliard School did a staging that same year. But the Long Beach Opera's production, seen in its fourth and final performance this afternoon, apparently counted as the professional American stage premiere.

title: FRUSTRATED AIDS PATIENTS DEVISE THEIR OWN THERAPIES
description: LEAD: People desperate to halt the progress of AIDS in their bodies, and frustrated with a medical establishment that cannot offer effective treatment, are seeking alternative therapies in the United States and abroad.

title: JERSEY'S SELLOFF STARTS MARKET'S FALL
description: With the State of New Jersey unloading shares in companies that do business with South Africa and some program traders trying to get out of the line of fire before Friday's ''triple witching hour,'' stock prices fell sharply at the opening yesterday and never fully recovered.

title: Weinberger, in Spain, Raises U.S. Base Issue
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger met with Spanish leaders today and discussed reducing the American military presence in Spain.

title: Detective in the Ulster 'Shoot to Kill' Inquiry Quits
description: The ranking British detective who tried to investigate charges of a ''shoot to kill'' policy among anti-terrorist policemen in Northern Ireland, Deputy Chief Constable John Stalker, quit the police force today, complaining that he was not permitted to finish his inquiry.

title: Barbara Walters Gave Reagan Papers on Iran
description: Barbara Walters provided the White House with documents reporting that an Iranian arms merchant believed that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North had diverted profits from the sale of arms to Iran to the Nicaraguan insurgents, a senior White House official said today.

title: THAIS REPORTEDLY FORCE EXILES BACK TO LAOS
description: Thailand has begun to forcibly repatriate dozens of Laotian exiles whom authorities have classified as illegal aliens living in the Ban Vinai refugee camp, according to reports reaching embassies and international orgnizations in Bangkok.

title: U.S. PLAN ISSUED ON AIDS EDUCATION
description: The Reagan Administration today issued an AIDS education plan that calls for specific information to be made available to Americans on how to prevent the spread of the disease, including the use of condoms for sexually active people.

title: BECOR WESTERN GETS HIGHER BID
description: Becor Western Inc., a diversified manufacturer of aerospace and mining components, said it had received a $255 million takeover bid that tops a previously announced leveraged buyout offer from company management. Investment Limited Partnership of Greenwich, Conn., and an investor, Randolph W. Lenz, are offering $15.50 a share in cash.

title: THE RETURN OF THE STOLE
description: The stole was the surprise accessory in the fall and winter fashion showings here, endorsed by all the heavy hitters of the Italian fashion world.

title: TEACHER-HIRING PRACTICES CRITICIZED IN STUDY
description: Most school districts deserve failing grades for the way they hire new teachers, the Rand Corporation said today.

title: What We Can Do to Limit Our Oil Dependency
description: To the Editor:

title: BALDNESS DRUG GAINS SUPPORT
description: An independent Federal advisory panel of medical experts recommended today that the Food and Drug Administration grant approval for the first time to a remedy for baldness.

title: Shakespeare Theories Are Twice-Told Tales
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dance listing and a picture caption on Sunday in The Guide misidentified a choreographer who opens tonight with her troupe at the CSC Theater. She is Risa Jaroslow.

title: DETAILS OF FREEMAN CHARGES
description: The Government has released a document in its investigation of Robert M. Freeman, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company, maintaining that Mr. Freeman had said he created research files to make stock buying appear legitimate when in fact it was based on insider trading.

title: DETECTIVE SLAIN IN BROOKLYN IS RECALLED AS ONE OF THE 'TRUE HEROES'
description: As thousands of his colleagues lined the streets of this South Shore community, Detective Louis Miller, believed to be the oldest member of the New York City Police Department ever killed in the line of duty, was mourned today.

title: STALIN IS FAULTED FOR WARTIME ROLE
description: A Soviet historian said today that Stalin took the Soviet Union to the brink of disaster in World War II in leading the Red Army against the invading German forces.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, picture captions yesterday with an article about the 236th anniversary of James Madison's birth misidentified two men shown. The man at Madison's grave was Ralph E. Grove; the commander of the First Virginia Regimental Color Guard was James R. Nash.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary Sunday of Edward P. Curtis, a former aide to President Eisenhower, misstated the date of a memorial service. It will be held next Monday at 11 A.M. at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Rochester.

title: TOKYO CRITICAL OF SEOUL PLAN
description: Japan has told the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that South Korea is violating GATT regulations by promoting a program to discriminate against Japanese goods, Government officials said today.

title: Spinks Arrested
description: Michael Spinks, the former International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, was charged with driving under the influence of alcohol early yesterday morning.

title: TEXAS FEUDS NOW FOUGHT OVER HOTELS
description: LEAD: FROM its historical status as Santa Anna's Alamo-era camp to its present-day stature as a bastion for bucks, luxe and tuxes, the site of the new Fairmount Hotel is a fitting monument to the recent revolution in the Texas hotel industry. Both a product and a victim of the oil boom, luxurious hotels were built throughout Texas in the late 1970's and early 80's by oil-rich, property-rich and cattle-rich Texas families that wanted to diversify.

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Oct. 31, 1986.

title: THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AMERICAN ISRAELI PAPER MILLS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said prior year results are for the 9-month fiscal year ended Dec. 31, 1985. The adjusted new Israeli shekels were converted into dollars at 1.4864 Shekels to $1.

title: Top Assembly Aide Resigns
description: Joseph F. Crangle, a top aide to five Assembly Speakers for the past 21 years, resigned today to devote more time to his family and his Buffalo law practice. Mr. Crangle, 54 years old, is the Erie County Democratic chairman and the senior Democratic county leader in the state.

title: T.C.U. Coach Retires
description: Fulfilling a pledge that this would be his last job unless he goes broke leading a life of leisure, Coach Jim Killingsworth of Texas Christian University yesterday announced his retirement after a 38-year career in coaching basketball, the last eight at T.C.U.

title: Australian Trade Deficit
description: Australia's Bureau of Statistics said today that the nation's trade deficit narrowed to $750 million (Australian), or about $514 million (American), in February, from $1.23 billion (Australian) the previous month. The Australian dollar jumped on the news, rising to nearly 68.6 cents in American currency, close to its highest level in eight months.

title: WESTERBEKE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Net income

title: Rydholm to Join Tatham-Laird
description: Ralph Rydholm, 50, will be going back to Chicago to take on the job of managing partner and chief creative officer at Tatham-Laird & Kudner Advertising. That's a new job title there.

title: Fairchild Plan for Buyout
description: The Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation announced a management-backed buyout proposal today that would create several ''alliances'' with Fujitsu Ltd., but skirt the political controversy that curtailed Fairchild's sale to the Japanese company.

title: The Reborn Zero Option
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's willingness finally to agree to the concept of eliminating intermediate-range missiles in Europe - the so-called zero option - has triggered a debate over whether such an agreement would serve Western interests. It would. As the Administration and allied governments concluded more than five years ago, an agreement to dismantle all the SS-20's targeted against Europe, as well as the American Pershing 2 and cruise missiles recently deployed there, would on balance strengthen the Atlantic alliance militarily and politically.

title: THE FUTURE OF FAIRCHILD
description: WITH the collapse of the plan by Fujitsu Ltd. to buy the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, Fairchild's management is now attempting likely to try a leveraged buyout. But Analysts said the plan poses difficulties such a move will ould be difficult and they suggest ed that other companies may come forward offering to buy Fairchild.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE ENTERPRISE reports earnings for 12mos Feb 28
description: Year-ago earnings are restated.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.I.T. Nebraska 78, Arkansas 71: Anthony Bailous scored 20 points as Nebraska, after building a 31-12 halftime lead on its home court, won the second-round game. Bernard Day scored 19 points and Derrick Vick 18 for the Cornhuskers (19-11). Nebraska's biggest lead was 21 points early in the second half. Two consecutive 3-point goals by Tim Scott capped an Arkansas rally that closed the margin to 53-50, but Arkansas (19-14) couldn't get closer.(AP) La Salle 89, Niagara 81: In Buffalo, Lionel Simmons, a freshman who missed more than four minutes in the first half after taking an elbow to the nose, scored 23 points to pace La Salle. Craig Conlin, a center, had 20 points and a game-high 10 rebounds for La Salle (18-12). Niagara's Joe Arlauckas, a forward, led all scorers with 27 points as the Purple Eagles finished at 21-10. (AP) N.A.I.A. Washburn 79, W. Virginia St. 77: Tom Meier scored 22 points and Bobby Sumler added 18 to help Washburn of Kansas (35-4) capture the men's championship in Kansas City, Mo.(AP) S.W. Oklahoma 60, North Georgia 58: Joyce Boudreaux scored with 6 seconds left to give Southwestern Oklahoma its fourth women's championship in six years. N.B.A. Bucks 123, Celtics 115: John Lucas scored 26 points and Jack Sikma had 8 key points in the fourth quarter as the Bucks held off the Celtics in Milwaukee. Leading by 92-90 early in the fourth period, the Bucks went on an 8-2 run. Kevin McHale led the Celtics with 31 points. (AP) Hawks Win 11th Straight: Dominique Wilkins scored 18 of his 43 points in the first quarter as the Hawks rolled to their 11th consecutive victory, defeating the Washington Bullets, 118-98, in Atlanta. Terry Catledge put Washington on the scoreboard first with a free throw but Atlanta then reeled off 17 straight points.(AP) N.H.L. Kings 5, Capitals 4: Bernie Nicholls recorded his ninth career hat trick and added two assists to lead Los Angeles past Washington in Landover, Md. Nicholls had 3 points in 50 seconds in the third period to rally the Kings from a 3-1 deficit.(AP) Red Wings 3, Bruins 1: Shawn Burr scored two goals in the third period to break a 1-1 tie as Detroit increased its home winning streak to eight games.(AP) SLED DOG RACING Butcher and Swenson Vie for Lead: Susan Butcher and Rick Swenson, both former winners, were only minutes apart when they reached Koyuk, 171 miles from the finish of the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race from Anchorage to Nome. Butcher checked into the tiny Eskimo village on Norton Bay at 6:50 A.M., local time, with a dozen dogs. Swenson, also with 12 dogs, followed her 15 minutes later. Tim Osmar of Clam Gulch arrived at 8:40 A.M., followed by Duane Halverson of Trapper Creek a minute later.(AP) INDOOR TRACK Bubka Breaks Mark: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union broke his indoor world record in the pole vault in Turin, Italy, clearing 19 feet 7 inches. Bubka surpassed his mark of 19-6 1/2. (AP) HORSE RACING The Cold Fact Is First: The Cold Fact dueled with favored French Express through the first mile and then edged away through the stretch to win by a 1 1/4 lengths in the $27,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. The Cold Fact paid $17.20 for $2 to win. (AP) FENCING Columbia's Mindel Takes Foil: William Mindel of Columbia defeated his teammate, Marc Kent, twice to win the foil competition of the N.C.A.A. fencing tournament in South Bend, Ind.(AP)

title: SOUTH KOREA REBUFFS A CALL FOR TALKS BY THE NORTH
description: South Korea today formally rebuffed a new North Korean bid for direct talks, saying the proposal smacked of insincerity.

title: The Lethal Dangers Of Carbon Monoxide
description: The effects of carbon monoxide exposure are similar to those of trying to breathe the ambient air at high altitudes, according to Dr. Peter M. Winter, anesthesiologist at the University Health Center of Pittsburgh.

description: To The Living Section:

description: Talk about your bulky inserts, Delco Electronics, through the good offices of Campbell-Ewald, Detroit, will be slipping an audio casette into the pages of Automotive Fleet magazine's April issue, attached to a four-color two-page spread.

title: N.F.L. OLD-TIMERS ARE AIDED By MICHAEL JANOFSKY
description: On the heels of signing a new television package that will bring them less money for the next three seasons than in 1986, the owners of the National Football League teams voted unanimously today to create a special benefit fund for players who played all or part of their careers before 1959.

DEFYING THE WIND WITH LESS STEEL
description: AS architects design taller, more elaborate skyscrapers, engineers are being pressed to find more economical ways to prevent these high-rise structures from drifting wildly in the wind.

German-Dutch 'Superchip' Set
description: West Germany and the Netherlands have developed Europe's first computer ''superchip'' prototype that they hope will beat industry leaders in the United States and Japan to the market, a West German official said today. The Technology Minister, Heinz Riesenhuber, told a news conference that production of the four-megabit chip should start by late 1988 or early 1989. Companies in the United

title: About New York; CALL MISS HALL: FICUS BENJAMINA IS LOSING LEAVES
description: ''The secret to retirement is to keep working.'' - Elizabeth Hall (not Yogi Berra), an 89-year-old horticulturalist, who has failed miserably in repeated attempts to retire.

title: REAL LIFE--AND GAMES
description: The subject comes up wherever Notre Dame goes. If the reporters don't bring it up first, then it emerges from the monologues of Digger Phelps, the coach, and also the responses of David Rivers himself.

title: Chinese TV and Radio
description: China has established a national radio and television corporation, a news report said. The China Communication and Broadcasting Electronics Corporation will handle television and radio research, development, manufacturing, marketing, maintenance and trade, the New China News Agency said today. The new corporation will work with research institutes to accelerate the development of China's radio and television industry, strengthen technological cooperation with foreign companies and help Chinese enterprises to import new technology, key equipment and component parts, the report said.

title: VERDICT IS AFFIRMED IN IUD SUIT
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld a verdict in favor of G.D. Searle & Company in a lawsuit brought by 17 women who said they suffered injuries from the use of the pharmaceutical company's Copper 7 intrauterine device.

title: Minister Quits In Brazil
description: Brazil's Planning Minister, Joao Sayad, a key figure in the Government's anti-inflation efforts, resigned today, a spokesman for President Jose Sarney said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: OUT IN THE MIDDAY SUN. My Kenya.

title: Winfield Smashes Homer and Single By MURRAY CHASS
description: Dave Winfield, the primary target of George Steinbrenner's sniping last year, wants to co-exist peacefully with the Yankees' owner this season. Probably the best way for him to achieve that aim is to start the season hitting and never stop. Until today, Winfield didn't appear to be following that strategy.

title: NEW I.B.M. STANDARDS ON LINKING
description: The International Business Machines Corporation released a new set of standards yesterday that will eventually make it possible for newly developed software to run on every I.B.M. machine from a personal computer to a mainframe.

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 14
DIANNE WIEST MAKES NEUROSIS A SUCCESS STORY
description: SHE is heard before she is even seen, but although the words are those of Lady Macbeth, the accent is a fractured Polish that immediately sends a wave of laughter rippling through the audience. When Anka does appear, backing onstage in sweatsocks and a voluminous nightgown, she is holding her hands out and moaning, ''Out, damned spot!'' Her husband is huddled in bed with a pillow over his head, trying in vain to sleep, but that doesn't stop Anka; when she finishes Lady Macbeth's soliloquy, she launches into the story of her own life.
