title: Role of Futures
description: To the Editor:

title: FANS HURL POSTERS AT KNICKS IN DEFEAT
description: The evening began amid renewed hope for the beleagured Knicks. In the morning Bernard King, their elusive captain, rejoined the team for his first public workout in almost two years since he suffered a knee injury that threatened to end his career. And last night they arrived at Madison Square Garden to face the reeling Denver Nuggets, a team that had lost seven consecutive games on the road and won only one of seven games against Eastern Conference competition.

title: CURB ASKED ON FOREIGN TAKEOVERS
description: The Reagan Administration will consider policies to block foreign takeovers of companies in security-sensitive industries, officials said today.

title: LATIN DRUG ENFORCEMENT EFFORT IS SAID TO LAG
description: The ranking Democratic and Republican members of the House narcotics committee, saying anti-drug efforts in Colombia have collapsed, urged President Reagan today to hold a meeting with South American leaders to deal with the issue.

title: SIDNEY COHEN
description: Sidney Cohen, founder and chairman of Andover Togs Inc., a manufacturer of children's sportswear, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: WINE TALK
description: FINE California wines came to New York last weekend in the form of two wine-tasting extravaganzas, but most of New York could not go to the wines. Ticket prices for the two events - one sponsored by a small group of California wineries, the other by a private food-and-wine society - were stratospheric. The prices alone almost hermetically sealed the public out of the events. Since both, held for the second year, promise to become annual showcases to promote some of California's best bottles, excluding the public is all the more unfortunate.

title: IN A CITY OF CALAMITIES, 300,000 LIVE ON THE STREETS
description: It was a typical scene in Calcutta. Over an open fire on a noisy traffic island a woman was cooking lunch while her children, naked or in rags, pushed each other waiting for something to eat.

title: WASHINGTONJames Reston; The New Collective
description: With the best of intentions, the President's friends are urging him to demonstrate that he's back in charge of the Administration, directing events, pushing his agenda with Congress, ready for televised news conferences and preparing for another summit meeting with Mikhail Gorbachev.

title: Survivor of Assault Prepares to Sue City
description: One of the men set upon in the Howard Beach racial attack, Cedric Sandiford, has filed a notice that would allow him to sue New York City for $25 million, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: Jews Who Killed Arabs to Get Reduced Sentences in Israel
description: President Chaim Herzog plans to commute the sentences - from life in prison to 25 years - of three Jews convicted of murdering Palestinians, a spokesman said today.

title: CATHOLIC HOSPITALS IN EUROPE DEFY VATICAN ON IN-VITRO FERTILIZATION
description: Defying the Vatican's doctrinal statement on human procreation last week, several Roman Catholic medical institutions in Europe said today that they would continue to help sterile couples conceive children through in-vitro fertilization.

title: Judge Rejects Suit Filed by Men's Clubs
description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a suit filed by two of New York City's most prestigious all-male clubs challenging a city law that could force them to admit women.

title: LANDMARKS PANEL MEMBER LEAVES AFTER 15 YEARS ON THE COMMISSION
description: Barbaralee Diamonstein, who has served on New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission for most of its existence, resigned last night, becoming the third commissioner on the 11-member panel to leave or lose their post in less than two months.

title: STEEL CLAWS AND VIDEO EYES: ROBOTS GIVE AN EDGE TO POLICE
description: The ranting man in the basement room of the Manhattan apartment building had fired half a dozen shots at police officers.

title: Japan Growth Sluggish in '86
description: Japan's economy grew 2.5 percent last year, down sharply from 4.7 percent in 1985, as the economy was battered by the strong yen.

title: Defending a Treaty From Star Warp
description: Without care for facts or credibility, the Reagan Administration startled the world more than a year ago by asserting a new interpretation of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972. With great attention to treaty text, negotiating history and testimony before Congress, Senator Nunn has now demolished these legal fantasies. President Reagan would do well to hear out the chairman of the Armed Services Committee.

title: EXPERTS' ADVICE ON DEPRESSION: OPEN DISCUSSIONS
description: For parents worried that their teen-age children might consider suicide, experts say the best advice is old advice: talk with the children often as possible.

description: At a time when much of the remaining landscape of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut is being rapidly plotted for development, government agencies and urban planners have undertaken a broad new campaign to preserve open space.

Austin, eliminated Monday night by Arkansas-Little Rock in the second round of the National Invitation Tournament, can trace its 54-48 defeat to 6-of-20 shooting from 3-point distance. The Lumberjacks' long-range lapse was notable because in the 3-point goal's inaugural season, they finished atop this list of the Division I schools that employed it with greatest accuracy. Att. title: A TRIBUTE, 'MINELLI ON MINNELLI'

There will be interruptions for wooing new subscribers. Like last Friday's tribute to James Stewart, this Minnelli package was made in association with M-G-M/ Universal, which clearly knows more than one way to market old film clips.

title: Buddy Rich Has Tumor Removed From Brain
description: Buddy Rich, the jazz drummer, was in good condition after surgeons removed a brain tumor during a four-hour operation, a spokesman for the University of California-Los Angeles Medical Center said Monday.

title: WEINBERGER, IN SPAIN, BACKS U.S. BASES' PRESENCE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, confronted with widespread opposition to the American troops in Spain, defended the United States military presence in a news conference here today as essential to Western security.

title: Speakes: So Near but So Far Away
description: It is late afternoon in Larry Speakes's 46th-floor office overlooking New York Harbor. Near the center of his desk rests a copy of the Tower Commission report on the Iran arms affair. The phone rings, and a White House official at the other end wants to gossip with him. Ten minutes later Dan Rather calls for a chat.

title: 11 Winners Selected in Met Auditions
description: Seven sopranos, a mezzo-soprano, two tenors and a baritone were named winners in the 1987 Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions on Sunday after two rounds of arias by 21 finalists. Each of the 11 winners will receive $5,000 and will perform in a concert at the Metropolitan Opera House on March 29 at 2:45 P.M.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
PURELY PANCAKES
description: LEAD: PANCAKES have been browning and puffing on griddles, pans and flat rocks since well before the word ''diet'' entered our vocabulary. Their venerability, together with their nutritional characteristics, have earned them a continuing place on our table.

title: Reed Tool Sale
description: The Baker International Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell substantially all of its subsidiary, the Reed Tool Company of Houston, to Camco Inc., also of Houston, for an undisclosed amount. Reed Tool is one of two units slated for sale as part of an agreement with the Justice Department. The agency warned it would seek to block a merger between Baker and the Hughes Tool Company if Reed and another unit, Baker Lift, were not divested.

description: IT'S not particularly easy for an advertising agency to come up with a corporate philosophy, since what each offers differs little in the fundamentals from its competitors.

description: Na-tional Public Radio announced today the selection of Renee Montagne and Robert Siegel as the new co-hosts of its evening news broadcast, ''All Things Considered.''

title: AT DON'S, PUTTING BEST FACES FORWARD
description: IT'S not easy to smile, chew and ''look pretty'' at the same time, as 183 customers of Don's restaurant in Livingston, N.J., have found. They were asked to munch hamburgers and french fries, slurp tomato sauce and bite into creamy eclairs - all while being photographed.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * First Capital Holdings Corp., Los Angeles, said it had entered a joint venture with Robert M. Bass Group to acquire and manage real estate investments. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Albany Agrees to Curb Corruption
description: Through the smog of indictments and convictions from New York's corruption scandal comes a ray of bright news: The state's legislative leaders, deadlocked last year over a major new ethics law, now have agreed to pass one. Senate Republicans, once content to do nothing on the theory that the scandal belonged only to New York City, acknowledge that Albany must participate in the cure. The bill makes a good start.

AIDS CHANGES SCRIPTS AND LIVES IN HOLLYWOOD
description: The effects of AIDS will not be reflected in movies for nearly two years, but the fatal disease is shaking up Hollywood lives right now.

description: President Reagan has been urged to propose a large tax break for oil companies, an Administration official said today.

title: A DAY FOR GREEN HAIR AND BLARNEY
description: Politicians worked the crowd, pipers droned and revelers in everything from green hats to green hair cheered lustily as more than 100,000 sons and daughters of Ireland strode up Fifth Avenue yesterday in the nation's oldest St. Patrick's Day parade.

title: NICARAGUA WARNS THE U.S. ON PEACE
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that no peace plan for Central America, including the one that the United States Senate backed by a 97-to-1 vote last week, could succeed without a fundamental change in the attitude of the Reagan Administration.

description: The Federal Government yesterday announced the indictment of Israel G. Grossman, a 34-year-old lawyer, on 24 felony counts related to an insider-trading scheme that it accused him of starting.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ''THESE are not my husband's!'' an irritated Mary Jacobson exclaimed, waving her laundry ticket and pointing to an open bundle of shirts. She was in a fancy Upper East Side laundry that she had never used before. The shirts she was looking for were her husband's best - shirts he was planning to take on a trip to Rome in a few days. To insure that nothing would go wrong, Mrs. Jacobson had taken them to what she had heard was the finest laundry in the neighborhood.

title: Thon in Puerto Rico

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Pollards and Rosenbergs
description: The espionage convictions of Jonathan Jay Pollard and his wife, Anne Henderson Pollard, raise inevitable comparisons with the Julius and Ethel Rosenberg case in 1951. The most striking comparison involves their sentences. Mr. Pollard and the Rosenbergs received the maximum sentences permitted by law. There were many protests over the Rosenbergs' death sentences. But few American voices are heard protesting Mr. Pollard's outrageously excessive life sentence.

title: HARLEY ASKS END TO TARIFF AID
description: Harley Davidson Inc., the sole surviving motorcycle manufacturer in the United States, roared into the international trade spotlight yesterday with a surprise request that the Government withdraw tariff protections granted four years ago to save it from Japanese competitors.

description: Faced with growing resistance from the Legislature, Governor Cuomo battled today to save the commission he appointed to investigate government ethics.

title: INSIDE
description: Stronger Magnets Predicted Scientists studying a new superconducting material say it can be made into magnets far more powerful than any now in existence. Page A14.

title: A Boatload Of Backing
description: The United States Rowing Association's membership rolls of college and club competitors have increased from fewer than 10,000 two years ago to more than 17,000, and three times that many recreational rowers are estimated to participate regularly. Perhaps the most telling index of the sport's growth, though, is the interest it has begun to draw from commercial sponsors. While local companies have long helped underwrite individual regattas, rowing has begun to attract national backers eager to make financial commitments that will identify them with an activity demanding both strenuous effort and intricate teamwork.

Results for the 26 weeks ended Feb. 1, 1986, include unusual charges of $21.4 million, primarily for the estimated cost of plant closings and restructuring and reduction in administrative salaried workforce.

title: GOODEN FIELDS ADVICE By JOSEPH DURSO
description: Stop cupping the ball. Quit squeezing it so hard with your fingers. Rock back on your right leg. Don't let your body get ahead of your arm. Hurry your motion. Slow down your motion. Do what you did in '85. Don't do what you did in '86. Do this, do that.

title: Brazil Trade Surplus Up
description: Brazil's trade surplus jumped to $261 million in February, from January's four-year low of $129 million, but was still down by more than half from a year earlier. Exports in February were $1.53 billion, down from $1.75 billion a year earlier. Imports totaled $1.27 billion, more than the $1.12 billion in February 1986, when the surplus totaled $628 million. Roberto Fendt, director of the Federal Trade Bureau, said January and February were traditionally weak months for trade and predicted the surplus would pick up in April. A dock workers' strike that ended last week will keep the March trade surplus low, he said.

title: 'Conscience Fund' at New High
description: It was, perhaps, the largest guilt trip in the history of the Republic.

title: 5 PALESTINE FACTIONS AGREE TO MEETING ON REUNIFICATION
description: Five Palestinian factions have agreed to hold a session of the Palestinian parliament in exile on April 20 in an effort to reunify the Palestine Liberation Organization, Palestinian officials contacted by telephone in Tunis said today.

title: FLYING TIGER
description: Baseball owners, wary of players who take up flying in their spare time, occasionally go so far as to demand that player-pilots swear off their hobby as the price of a new contract. One budding ace who slipped through the contractual net is Kirk Gibson, the Tiger outfielder, who a year ago bought a Cessna 206, a single-engine, piston-driven model, and says he plans to use it this season to commute from his home in Oakland County, Mich., to the Detroit airport.

title: Intermountain Power In a Debt Refinancing
description: The Intermountain Power Agency in Utah, which long ago borrowed the $4 billion or so needed to construct two coal-fired power plants, is maintaining a high profile in the bond market by refinancing its outstanding debt.

title: IRAN PANELS PLAN LIMITED IMMUNITY
description: Moving to obtain more information about the Reagan Administration's actions to help the rebel forces in Nicaragua, the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair plan to grant limited immunity from prosecution to a former White House official and to a key figure in the private supply network that aided the insurgents, people familiar with the committees' operations said today.

title: Criticisms of Veterans Agency Aired at a Hearing
description: Witnesses at a Congressional hearing today accused the Veterans Administration of abusing the trust of the wounded and retired Americans it was created to serve, by hastily and inaccurately processing pension and disability claims and then concealing the flaws.

title: U.S. PLANS TO SPIN OFF TECHNICAL DATA SERVICE
description: The Reagan Administration is planning to spin off the Commerce Department's National Technical Information Service, a clearinghouse for both United States Government and foreign government technical information, over the complaints of many of the agency's users.

title: KENYAN CRITICIZES REPORTS OF RIGHTS ABUSES
description: President Daniel arap Moi, returning today from official visits to the United States and Britain, strongly denied reports that his Government had committed human rights abuses.

title: Display Oswald's Rifle?
description: The forthcoming 25th anniversary of the assassination of John F. Kennedy has raised some suggestions that the National Archives put on public display various items related to his death - Lee Harvey Oswald's rifle and diary, the President's blood-stained shirt, the bullet that is believed to have killed him. But the Government remains highly solicitous of Kennedy's memory.

title: 7 BLACK YOUTHS KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The bodies of seven black youths who had been stabbed to death were discovered today in a ditch in a black township north of Durban.

title: Drug Treatment Facilities for Offenders Better Than Work Camps
description: To the Editor:

title: BROOKLYN NAVY YARD PROGRESS
description: DESPITE a departing tenant's financial troubles and involvement in a New York City corruption scandal, the Brooklyn Navy Yard is making strides in its effort to overcome the mismanagement that has kept many of the industrial park's buildings and docks empty, underutilized and in bad repair for years.

title: WAS MAJOR FASHION ILLUSTRATOR
description: Antonio Lopez, a fashion illustrator whose drawings appeared frequently in Vogue, Harper's Bazaar, Elle, Interview and The New York Times and whose works were exhibited in galleries all over the world, died of AIDS yesterday morning in the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 44 years old.

title: SCOTT MCKAY, ACTOR FEATURED IN WIDE RANGE OF STAGE ROLES
description: Scott McKay, an actor who played almost 30 featured roles on Broadway during a stage career that began in 1939 and spanned 36 years, died of kidney failure Monday at Cabrini Hospital in New York. He was 71 years old.

title: K Mart Talks End
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company of New York said it was no longer negotiating with the K Mart Corporation for the purchase of the retailer's S. S. Kresge stores. A Woolworth spokesman said, ''The conversations proved fruitless, and the subject matter has been dropped.'' Crain's Detroit Business, a weekly publication, reported Monday that Woolworth was negotiating the purchase of 116 Kresge stores.

title: U.S. DROPS EFFORTS ON SENSITIVE DATA
description: Under fire from a House committee, the Reagan Administration has rescinded a plan to tighten control over the release of potentially sensitive unclassified information stored in computers or transmitted electronically.

title: JAPAN DENIES 'DUMPING,' SAYS CHIP PACT IS INTACT
description: The day after Fujitsu Ltd.'s deal to buy the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation fell apart under intense pressure from Reagan Administration officials, Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry once again pleaded its case that Japan was doing its best to enforce the semiconductor agreement between the two nations.

title: TEST ON HUMANS NEAR IN AIDS VACCINE HUNT
description: Before the end of the year, medical experts say, up to a hundred Americans will roll up their sleeves for injections of experimental vaccines against AIDS.

title: Altschiller and S.A.S.
description: Altschiller, Reitzfeld, which for the last 18 months had been doing the vacation travel facet for the Scandinavian Airlines System, has been named to do all the advertising for the airline in the eastern region of the Uniged States. A while back Ally & Gargano had the business. Lately it's been done by a Swedish firm.

title: FAR FROM BROOKLYN AND YOUTH, THE 'DUX' HOLD COURT AGAIN
description: The game has changed and so have the men who played it.

title: CHINESE CAST TO PERFORM 'THE MUSIC MAN' IN BEIJING
description: Beijing may be a long way from River City, but on May 8 the members of an all-Chinese cast are to buckle their tap shoes, uncrate the trombones and mount a full-scale production of ''The Music Man.''

title: Grades and Sex Abuse
description: To The Living Section:

title: Bally Chairman Acting To Reduce Debt Load
description: Robert E. Mullane, chairman and chief executive of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, does not consider himself a betting man, although some contend that he has gambled the company's future on two sizable casino acquisitions.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS SHIFT PLANS ON STRATEGY TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: The House Democratic leadership, unable to assemble its own plan for cutting the budget deficit, shifted strategy today, partly in an effort to blame Republicans and the President for their problems.

title: EVEREST & JENNINGS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 28
description: b-Includes gains on sale of West Los Angeles real estate of $9,903,000, or $1.23 a share. c-Net loss d-Includes provisions for plant closure of $4,952,000, or 61 cents a share, and $4,952,000, or 62 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively; and gains on sale of West Los Angeles real estate of $650,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter, and for the year gains on sale of West Los Angeles real estate, including expired purchase options, of $1,471,000, or 18 cents a share.

title: JAZZ: ORNETTE COLEMAN AT WEILL HALL
description: ORNETTE COLEMAN is sometimes called the man who freed jazz. It was almost a generation ago that this eminent saxophonist-turned-composer let the boundaries of blues-based chordal formulas and rigid metric movement dissolve into a new kind of free association - one where melody, harmony and rhythm could wander off in search of their own destinations and meet together as they chose. Mr. Coleman has also been busy over the years applying his liberating principles to older European formats, and at two concerts over the weekend at Weill Recital Hall, at Carnegie Hall, listeners have had a chance to share in his thinking.

title: WILLIAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest periods' nets include the contribution of John F. Beasley Construction Co., which was acquired Aug. 1, 1986.

title: Power Out in Johannesburg
description: A power failure plunged Johannesburg and the black township of Soweto into darkness for two hours tonight. South African officials blamed human error. Police vehicles, sirens wailing, rushed through the streets but there were no reports of disturbances. Hennie Harmse, manager of the Johannesburg Electricity Supply Commission, said: ''It was an operating error. One of our chaps pulled the wrong switch, causing a short circuit.''

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: In 1986 the after-tax effect of LIFO was a charge of $441,000 and $539,000 for the fourth quarter and full year, respectively, as compared with a charge of $359,000 and $407,000 during the 1985 fourth quarter and full year, respectively.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They have them in Dublin, but this is great.'' - John Redmond of Dublin, at the St. Patrick's Day parade in New York City. [ B3:3. ]

title: Wheeling Names A New Chairman
description: Lloyd C. Lubensky was named chairman of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation late yesterday, succeeding George A. Ferris. Mr. Ferris, who was named chairman only two months ago, resigned not only that post but his positions as director, vice-chairman, and chief executive. The steel company is in bankruptcy preceedings.

title: Federal Abduction Story in Question
description: To the Editor:

title: '85 PLANE CRASH LAID TO FAILURE BY CONTROLLERS By RICHARD WITKIN
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, ending its inquiry into a fatal midair collision near Teterboro (N.J.) Airport in November 1985, said today that the probable causes were a breakdown in traffic control and the inability of the crew of a corporate jet to ''see and avoid'' the other plane.

title: WALTER BOTHE
description: Walter Bothe, a former Secret Service agent who guarded Henry A. Kissinger died of cancer Sunday. He was 46 years old.

title: 'Les Miserables' Team Plans Its Next Project
description: Now that their pop-opera adaptation of ''Les Miserables'' has successfully conquered the West End and Broadway, the composer-lyricist team of Claude-Michel Schonberg and Alain Boublil are turning to an almost equally familiar story for their next project.

title: CHICAGO DOCK & CANAL TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $7,666,000 from disposition of real estate.

title: Britain Cuts Income Tax, Lifting Thatcher's Hopes
description: In a move that both supporters and opponents see as one designed to strengthen Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's hand in a re-election campaign, the Government announced a 2 percent cut today in the income tax rate.

title: Nunn, Baker and '88
description: Last week, as neatly as Caspar Weinberger thinks a laser beam can nail an incoming missile, Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia shot down the Reagan Administration's ''broad interpretation'' of the ABM Treaty - and may have affected profoundly the 1988 Presidential election.

title: INVESTIGATORS SAY F.B.I. TAPED ESPOSITO WITH A CRIME FIGURE
description: Federal prosecutors who are investigating political corruption in Brooklyn have a tape of a telephone conversation in which Meade H. Esposito, the former Democratic leader, discussed political matters with a reputed organized-crime figure, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Taft Broadcasting Gets Sweetened Bid
description: A group headed by the Taft Broadcasting Company's vice chairman, Dudley S. Taft, today sweetened its offer to buy the company, which operates a nationwide array of broadcast stations and an entertainment division.

title: CELTICS ENCOURAGED BY WALTON'S RETURN
description: On March 8, Robert Parish played 45 minutes, shot 14 for 19 from the field and scored 32 points.

title: PETER F. CULVER
description: Peter F. Culver, a senior vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died last Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at a business meeting in Frankfurt. He was 42 years old and lived in Brussels.

title: INSTITUTE OF CLINICAL PHARACOLOGY PLC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CHINA AWAITS VERDICT ON ANCIENT WINE
description: Tucked along the back wall of a battered refrigerator on the third floor of the chemistry building at Beijing University are two beetle-brown laboratory bottles, their caps sealed with white tape. They contain what is very likely to be the oldest wine on earth. ''We believe it is about 3,000 years old,'' said Lin Zuming, an assistant professor of chemistry at the university. ''It is the oldest ever found here.''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Attractions of Leanness

title: S&K FAMOUS BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AMERTEK INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $910,487 gain on sale of real estate and a $423,273 tax credit. c-Includes a $294,859 special gain. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Home Loan Bank Offering
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks is offering $2.55 billion of bonds divided into maturities of three, five and ten years through various securities dealers and banks.

title: Addicted to Jazz
description: To The Living Section:

title: TRANS WORLD MUSIC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
EXPLORATION OF MARS IS ADVISED AS GOAL FOR NASA
description: The exploration of Mars by robots and eventually people should be the ''primary goal'' of the nation as a means of reasserting its leadership in space, an advisory council to the space agency recommended yesterday.

title: BROOKLYN FAMILY SAYS IT WAS BEATEN BY POLICE
description: A 44-year-old Brooklyn woman charged yesterday that she and members of her family, including two young grandchildren, were beaten and abused last week by police officers from the 73d Precinct in Brooklyn.

title: CLOTHESTIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: NEW FRUITS OF AN OLD CHINESE WINERY
description: LEAD: THE scene could easily be found in France, Italy or the Napa Valley in California: a gentle slope of land planted with rows of vines heavy with ripening grapes. But this is Yantai, a seacoast town in Shandong Province along the northeastern coast of China. The vineyard is the site of the Chang Yu Pioneer Winery, the oldest grape winery in

title: ENZO BIOCHEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PATTERN OF DEATH: COPYCAT SUICIDES AMONG YOUTHS
description: The suicide attempt yesterday morning by two young people in Bergenfield, N.J., which closely copied the death of four teen-agers last week, fits a pattern of imitation that often comes after well-publicized suicides, according to experts.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE various harmonies of foods are always fascinating, and sometimes inexplicable.

title: NUCLEAR TURNING POINT: PLANT CONVERSION PLAN A CHALLENGE TO U.S. PRINCIPLE
description: The Department of Energy is preparing to present Congress with a proposal that would chip away at a 30-year principle that the civilian and military sides of nuclear development should never mix.

title: Women's Colleges Value Student Independence
description: To the Editor:

title: Not for Women Only
description: To The Living Section:

title: IN THE SPIRIT OF THE SPRING SEASON
description: 1. Hand-Painted Fans This decorative fan, hand-painted with flowers and made of oiled paper on a sturdy wooden frame, comes from Shanghai. It opens to a width of 48 inches and stands 32 inches high. The fan can be a wall ornament or a handsome screen for a fireplace. Each is one of a kind; a variety of colors and patterns are available. The fans cost $65 each at Art Asia, 1086 Madison Avenue (81st Street). 2. Like a Wrist Corsage These cheerful rubber watches have the spirit of warm weather written all over them. Made in Milan, Italy, they are water-resistant and have a quartz movement. The watches cost $48 and are white with red, blue, yellow and green flowers. Other patterns and colors are also available. At Ylang-Ylang, 806 Madison Avenue (68th Street); 4 West 57th Street, and 324 Columbus Avenue (75th Street). 3. A Bold Belt Fashion accessories are getting bigger and bolder, and that includes belts. This one, designed by Elena Benarroch, is brown leather that has been pressed to look like crocodile. Wear it with just about anything, from coats and dresses to pants. It is $150 at Elena Benarroch, 733 Madison Avenue (64th Street). #4. Traveling in Style Here is a compact shoeshine kit that can be an elegant addition to a man's travel accessories. Made of English harness leather, it contains two brushes, a buffing cloth and black, brown and neutral polish. The kit closes with a stylish leather buckle. The price is $40 at Peter Elliot, 1383 Third Avenue (79th Street).

title: Last L.I.R.R. Unions Ratify Contracts
description: The Long Island Rail Road's last four labor unions have ratified new contracts, forestalling the possibility of another strike, officials of the commuter line announced yesterday.

title: Beta Carotene Ads By Smith/Greenland
description: Hoffmann-LaRoche has begun a multimillion-dollar ad campaign through Smith/Greenland to educate the public to the benefits of beta carotene, the food substance from green leafy vegetables and orange vegetables the consumption of which seems to cut down on the incidence of cancer.

title: HAYES IS EULOGIZED FOR PRIVATE IDEALS By PETER ALFANO
description: A baseball cap inscribed with the letter ''O'' lay on a table draped in purple at the altar of the First Community Church. An American flag was neatly folded behind it. They were framed by two white candles, burning slowly as former President Richard Nixon eulogized his friend Wayne Woodrow Hayes, better known during his tumultuous football coaching career at Ohio State University as Woody.

title: KERR OUTSCORES RANGERS By CRAIG WOLFF
description: Scoring a goal is not always the prettiest part of hockey. That is essentially what Phil Esposito and Tim Kerr communicated to one another in a few brief sentences tonight.

title: DeConcini as G-man?
description: Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona is emerging as a leading candidate to succeed William H. Webster as the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: HOWELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year loss includes a writedown of $20,382,000 on the company's investment in its oil and gas properties.

title: COALITION SHIFT SEEN
description: In Finnish politics, which has been dominated for decades by the Social Democratic Party, the Conservative gains in the national parliamentary elections on Monday were striking.

title: MACGREGOR SPORTING GOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits of $28,000 for the quarter and $453,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary tax benefits of $61,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The latest periods include for the entire period the operations of Sports Specialties, acquired as of Aug. 1, 1986.

title: MILLIONS FROM ARMS SALES TRACED TO IRAN GROUP AIDING KIDNAPPERS
description: Several million dollars in profits from Iran arms sales were paid to an Iranian group that financed the kidnappers of Americans in Lebanon, according to United States officials and associates of an Iranian middleman.

title: NORTHWEST'S BANK SHOWDOWN
description: When a branch of the Peoples Bank was robbed here a while back, investigators were given the license plate number of a man who had been lurking around, taking photographs, earlier in the day. The man, it turned out, was not a bank robber but an employee of Citicorp, doing a little market research.

title: BITTER CLASHES RESOUND IN DAILY NEWS BIAS TRIAL
description: Lawyers for four black journalists in a Federal race discrimination trial against The Daily News have concluded presenting their evidence with a flurry of statistics and bitter attacks on Daily News management.

title: GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter loss includes writedowns of obsolete inventories, loss on the sale of the C-21A to the Air Force and the writeoff of deferred taxes, all of which were also reflected in results of the third quarter. The year-ago quarter loss included a joint venture writeoff which increased the loss by $9,110,000.

title: POP: RAY DAVIES AND KINKS
description: FOR some 23 years, Ray Davies, the self-proclaimed ''misfit'' and longtime leader of the Kinks, has been doling out seriocomic topical whimsy, much of which has worn remarkably well. Taking trendy subjects like fashion, movie icons and the changing economic climate, Mr. Davies evokes a topsy-turvy world in which fragile souls like himself are buffeted about but manage to avoid despair through a quirky blend of humor and nostalgia.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $14,341,000 on early extinguishment of debt. The latest quarter's net included an after-tax expense of $15.7 from the merger of two divisions and the year- ago period's net included an after-tax expense of $23.9 million from the merger of various divisions and the reorganization of certain corporate and divisional functions.

title: Interest Rates Fall Slightly
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined slightly yesterday, but remained well within the range of the last few weeks.

title: MARKEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $185,011 and $287,077 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a capital loss of $17,187 for the quarter and a capital gain of $147,371 for the year.

title: CUISINE OF THAILAND: NEXT UP FOR STARDOM
description: BEFORE the sun is up in Bangkok, small flames flicker all over the city streets, marking the portable kitchens that dot the landscape and provide Bangkok residents with a never-ending supply of snacks.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After losses of $315,000 and $735,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from minority interest in net earnings of Commtron.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Old Troupers

title: EQUION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $897,925 for the quarter and $1,306,860 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $841,511 and $2,132,073 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; and the 6-month also includes a gain of $621,763 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said latest quarter and 6 months results reflect the operations of Tramco Manufacturing Corp. since its acquisition Dec. 8, 1986. The company said year-ago quarter and 6 months results reflect a change in accounting principle effective Aug. 1, 1985, and include the operations of Haydem Inc. since its acquisition Oct. 23, 1985.

title: CHIRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CURRENT ACCOUNT DEFICIT ROSE TO RECORDS IN '86
description: America's deficit in the broadest measure of foreign trade increased to a record $36.84 billion for the final three months of 1986, 4.4 percent higher than the previous record, set in the July-September quarter, of $35.30 billion.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a Miami dispatch yesterday about threats against the United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida misidentified John Russell, a Justice Department spokesman. He is based in Washington, not Miami.

title: NEW INSULIN INJECTOR MARKETED FOR DIABETICS
description: MARGUERITE WARD, a diabetic, remembers having to fill her insulin syringe while standing on a corner in downtown Toronto, her home city. With the needle in view, she was afraid of being mistaken for a drug addict. ''I felt certain I'd be arrested,'' she said. ''I had to have friends gather around me just so I could achieve the feat.''

title: WAKING UP TO DROPPING COFFEE PRICES
description: THE price of coffee, high for much of the last year because of a drought in Brazil, is going down nationwide. Zabar's, which sells 13,000 pounds of coffee a week, has cut the price by a dollar a pound in the last few weeks. Noah's Gourmet on Reade Street, which carries 51 kinds of beans, recently trimmed prices by at least 40 cents a pound. And at the Porto Rico Importing Company on Bleecker Street, the house blend that sold for $5.99 a year ago is now $3.99.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: LEAD: THE following is a message to every woman in America who is too fat or thinks she is too fat. For many of you, and that includes yours truly, the time may finally have come to learn to live normally with food and to accept the body that results. While fitness is a desirable goal regardless of your weight, fashion-model thinness is not, unless you happen to be among the small percentage of people who are genetically programmed to sport a lean and hungry look.

title: The U.N. Today: March 18, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Bayer Named In AIDS Suit
description: Bayer A.G., the giant West German chemical company, said today that it had been sued over its sale of hemophilia drugs that may have been infected with the AIDS virus.

title: HART ASSAILS U.S. POLICY ON THE LATIN DEBT CRISIS
description: Former Senator Gary Hart, visiting Brazil less than one month after this country suspended interest payments on its debts to foreign banks, today sharply criticized the Reagan Administration's response to the continuing Latin American debt crisis.

title: NETS' 29 TURNOVERS HELP CAVALIERS WIN By ALEX YANNIS
description: Just when it appeared the Nets would put together a string of decent games after winning four of five, they returned to their usual scenario tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: JUDGE FINDS GOTTI PROSECUTORS DID NOT ASK A WITNESS TO LIE
description: The judge in the trial of John Gotti has termed ''deliberately false'' the chief defense witness's allegation that Federal prosecutors tried to have him give perjured testimony.

title: DOW SURGES 36.36, TO RECORD 2,284.80
description: Stock prices rallied broadly to record levels yesterday as an explosive rise in technology and oil issues helped Wall Street get over the ''triple witching hour'' blues.

title: A Lifelong Love
description: To The Living Section:

title: China Technology Unit
description: A group of scientists has recommended that China establish a body to oversee technology imports and control the approval of key state projects involving imports, the official New China News Agency reported. The scientists made the proposal today to the science and technology section of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, an advisory body. Sometimes the same type of equipment has been imported by several plants simultaneously, the report said. It said the problems had occurred because of lack of overall state control and neglect of experts' opinions.

title: 49 CHARGED AS DRUG SMUGGLERS
description: A Federal indictment unsealed today accuses 49 people of participating in a drug ring that smuggled millions of counterfeit Quaaludes into the United States from Canada over a five-year period.

title: EAST AND WEST GERMANY STRIVE TO BUILD TIES
description: Contacts between East and West Germany have intensified in the last week amid indications that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is interested in winning West Germany's support for the Soviet proposal to withdraw all medium-range missiles from Europe.

title: Coopervision Stake
description: Siebel Capital Management Inc., an investment advising firm in Larkspur, Calif., said that it had purchased a 5.9 percent stake, or more than 1.3 million shares, of Coopervision Inc., an eye-care company in Palo Alto, Calif. Siebel's filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission indicated that it ''may attempt to influence management of the company to make major changes in the company's business or corporate structure.''

title: NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
LIFE IN THE 30's
description: WHEN he went home last year he realized for the first time that he would be buried there, in the small, gritty industrial town he had loathed for as long as he could remember. He looked out the window of his bedroom and saw the siding on the house next door and knew that he was trapped, as surely as if he had never left for the city.

title: Citicorp Auction
description: Interest rates rose slightly at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.219 percent, up from 6.218 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 6.1996 percent, up from 6.187 percent.

title: WHY MARKETS ARE CONFIDENT
description: WHILE there are some similarities today to the worldwide crisis that led to the Great Depression of the 1930's, especially those involving the international debt crisis, there are important differences that should enable us to avoid another economic holocaust. The most crucial of these differences is that there is widespread understanding of what caused the last depression and how to use that knowledge to prevent it from happening again.

title: JUDGE AMENDS RULING IN BOOK-BANNING CASE
description: A Federal judge today amended a March 4 order, allowing restricted use of some of the 44 textbooks he banned from Alabama classrooms for promoting ''secular humanism.''

title: TOP PANEL URGES CONGRESS TO WEIGH OUSTING OF JUDGE
description: The Federal judiciary's chief policy-making body told Congress today that ''consideration of impeachment may be warranted'' in the case of a Federal district judge in Miami.

title: BREAKTHROUGH SEEN IN MAGNET RESEARCH
description: Scientists analyzing a new superconducting material have discovered that it can be made into magnets far more powerful than any now in existence, according to unpublished data from a half-dozen laboratories in the United States and China.

title: DECORATOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-Net loss

title: POLICE FOIL SUICIDE ATTEMPT BY 2 JERSEY YOUTHS
description: Two young people tried to commit suicide early today in the same garage bay where four teen-agers asphyxiated themselves last Wednesday.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Aided by a boom in the single-family market, housing construction rose 2.6 percent in February to the highest level in 10 months.

title: AGREEMENT WILL CURB EXPORT AID
description: The major industrial countries have reached agreement on mechanisms to curb foreign assistance practices that governments use chiefly to help win business for exporters, the Treasury Department announced today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 18, 1987
description: The Economy

title: SUBDUED BUT STILL DAZZLING, KING TAKES ANOTHER STEP By ROY S. JOHNSON
description: The moves, remarkably, are still there. The drives, the deft shooting touch from 12 to 15 feet, the reckless abandon with which he completed the fastbreak are all still there. In fact, except for the large brace covering much of his right leg, it was not until he left the court that anything seemed different about Bernard King.

title: REAGAN SETS THURSDAY NEWS SESSION
description: As President Reagan stepped up his pace of public activity, the White House announced today that he would hold a nationally broadcast news conference Thursday night, his first in more than four months.

title: Rice Price Off 15% in ''86
description: Weak demand and large supplies in 1986 caused the largest decline in international rice prices since 1982, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said today in a report. Protectionism and increased competition among exporters also contributed to the worldwide fall in rice prices in 1986, the report said. Although prices have declined for five consecutive years, the reduction in 1986 was the largest, with prices averaging 15 percent below their 1985 level and 25 percent below the level in 1982-84, the report said.

title: FILM: HITLER'S HIGHWAYS
description: WHY did Hitler build the famed autobahn, Germany's thousands of kilometers of high-speed highway? To ease the unemployment that was afflicting the country in the 1930's? To provide fast transport to grease a sluggish economy? To make travel pleasanter for car owners? To serve military needs?

title: SANTA ANITA REALTY ENTERRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses of $761,000 and $875,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively, and a gain of $6,054,000 on the disposition of discontinued operations for both periods. c-Includes a gain of $31,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter, and for the year includes a loss of $2,000 from discontinued operations.

title: SIMMONS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Immunity Set On Dynamics
description: The Justice Department is reviving a stalled criminal investigation into the General Dynamics Corporation by granting immunity from prosecution to a company official and a retired executive, department sources confirmed today.

title: Transamerican Suit Advances Suit
description: A United States bankruptcy judge ruled today that the Transamerican Natural Gas Corporation could pursue a $2 billion lawsuit filed against the Coastal Corporation to ward off a hostile takeover attempt.

title: Investigation at Temple
description: Temple University officials said they were investigating the association of an all-America running back, Paul Palmer, with an agent who has admitted giving money to some players in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules. The Temple athletic director, Charlie Theokas, said he expected to finish his review of the situation regarding the agent, Norby Walters, and make an announcement today.

title: Clerics Plead for Hostage; Beirut Captors Respond
description: In a development that political observers said might help bring freedom to foreign hostages held in Lebanon, the country's most prominent Moslem clerics have publicly criticized the captors.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: 125 FLIGHT CHANGES IN ATLANTA FALL SHORT OF GOALS BY F.A.A.
description: Airlines serving Atlanta agreed to more than 125 changes in their proposed summer flight schedules today in the second day of discussions with Federal officials about how to ease serious delays at the country's major airports.

title: The Editorial Notebook; India's Slow-Growth Path By PETER PASSELL
description: An economist closely identified with the Indian Government winces at the memory. After Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi slashed tax rates, reduced import restrictions and promised new business freedoms, The Wall Street Journal dubbed him ''Rajiv Reagan.'' Mr. Gandhi, the economist protests, is misunderstood in America. Economic liberalization will be gradual. The Indian path to prosperity lies in better - not less - government.

title: VIDEO LIBRARY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss The company said the Tax Reform Act of 1986 contributed significantly to the fourth quarter loss.

title: Why Black Children Wait for Adoption
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET IS PRESSING FOR PROHIBITION ON PUTTING WEAPONS INTO SPACE
description: The Soviet Union urged the 40-nation Conference on Disarmament today to consider establishing an international agency that would make sure no weapons were put into space.

title: Time May Invest In Turner System
description: Time Inc. said it was interested in joining the investment group putting money into Turner Broadcasting System Inc. to help insure the survival of Cable News Network, the 24-hour television news service. No terms were disclosed and the negotiations were said to be under way.

title: BERGENFIELD ADULTS VIEW YOUTHS WHO LACK HOPE By JANE GROSS
description: From his barbershop in the Foster Village shopping mall here, Alfred D'Ambrosia has a bird's-eye view of the teen-agers who have lately given this suburban town a grim kind of celebrity.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 18, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13, B6

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 5
MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEMENT & INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Comings and Goings
description: Jeff Kunkel, a leading candidate for the second-base job with the Texas Rangers, suffered a shoulder separation diving for a fly ball in the outfield Monday and probably will be sidelined for three months. . . . Nick Esasky, first baseman for the Cincinnati Reds, is expected to miss four to six weeks because of a fractured right wrist suffered when he was hit by a pitch from Doug Sisk of the Mets Monday. . . . Buddy LeRoux, part owner of the Boston Red Sox, has withdrawn his offer to buy the New England Patriots from the Sullivan family, but both sides indicated a willingness to try and work out a deal. . . . Ron Jaworski, a pro for 14 years, has cleared waivers and now the former quarterback for the Philadelphia Eagles is free to market himself to all 28 National Football League teams. He'll be 36 next week. . . . Johnny Rodgers, winner of the Heisman Trophy in 1972 at Nebraska, was freed on $35,000 bail pending an appeal of his conviction of assault with a deadly weapon and of being an ex-felon in possession of a firearm. . . . A harness trainer, Larry Remmen, has been suspended for 60 days, starting March 22, because one of his horses, Pershing Square, twice raced with an illegal tranquilizer in his system, according to the New York State Racing and Wagering Board. The pacer won one race in March and finished second in the other, but has been disqualified in both and the purses have been redistributed.

title: 3 Penn Square Pleas Entered
description: A former Penn Square Bank vice president and two other men have pleaded not guilty to a new round of charges that they schemed to defraud the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company.

title: Gimme a W, gimme a 4
description: The story of the W-4 form is not over yet. The Internal Revenue Service is back at the drawing board once again, thinking about yet another redesign of the employee tax withholding form.

title: Bridge: Partner Gives High Marks To Young Atlanta Expert
description: For historians he is the exotic explorer of the Nile. For the entertainment world he is the late Welsh actor. But for many in the world of tournament bridge the name Richard Burton suggests a young expert from Atlanta who has been a steady winner in recent years.

title: B.C. AND HARVARD IN OPENING GAMES By WILLIAM N. WALLACE
description: Pairings for the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament, announced today, matched Boston College against Minnesota and Harvard against Bowling Green in games Friday and Saturday at Boston and Cambridge, Mass.

title: RECALLING SONNY CLARK
description: ON ''Voodoo'' (Black Saint/ Polygram), the Sonny Clark Memorial Quartet has something original to say about Sonny Clark, the modern jazz pianist and composer who died in 1963 at the age of 31. A cult following has build up around Sonny Clark's recorded work, much of it among fans of be-bop and the hard-bop sessions associated with Blue Note Records, the label that recorded Mr. Clark most frequently. But the Sonny Clark Memorial Quartet was assembled by Wayne Horvitz, a downtown keyboard player known for his partly-electronic solo albums and his work with ''deconstructionist'' ensembles like Curlew and John Zorn's performing groups. Mr. Zorn himself is on alto saxophone, and the drummer, Bobby Previte, is also associated with the downtown avant-garde. Only the bassist, Ray Drummond, has ''jazz credentials'' in the conventional sense.

title: Oilers Down Devils, 7-4
description: Kent Nilsson, Paul Coffey, Jari Kurri and Wayne Gretzky had 3 points each tonight as the Edmonton Oilers rolled to a 7-4 victory over the Devils.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $4,090,000 resulting from the exchange of the company's 11 percent subordinated notes for common stock. The results for the latest fourth quarter include a $15 million gain from the sale of real estate. The 1986 loss includes the previously announced non-recurring charges of $34 million related to the restructuring of the company's Bojangles' restaurant subsidiary. The 1985 results included a charge of $6.9 million related to the company's food service division. Additionally, the 1986 results include gains of $15 million from the sale of real estate, compared to $2.4 million in 1985 from the sale of marketable securities.

title: SANTO TRAFFICANTE, REPUTED MAFIA CHIEF, DIES AT 72
description: Santo Trafficante Jr., one of the last of the old-time reputed Mafia dons, who was reportedly enlisted in 1960 in a futile effort to kill Fidel Castro, has died at the age of 72.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MANHATTAN '45. By Jan Morris. Illustrated. 273 pages. Oxford University Press. $17.95.

title: HAZARDOUS REAR DOORS STILL PLAGUE CITY BUSES
description: Despite repairs, the Transit Authority has yet to resolve problems with bus door safety systems that have resulted in nine accidents and two passenger deaths since 1984.

title: PENWEST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: ARCHITECT FROM JAPAN WINS AWARD
description: Kenzo Tange, a 73-year-old Japanese architect who has designed dozens of major government, civic and private buildings throughout Japan, Europe and the Middle East, was awarded the $100,000 Pritzker Architecture Prize yesterday.

title: COLITIS RISK SEEN FOR EX-SMOKERS
description: Although the benefits of giving up smoking are well known, doctors believe they have found the first apparent hazard of kicking the habit, an increased risk of a rare but serious intestinal disease called ulcerative colitis.

title: TECHNODYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Includes tax credits of $312,000 and $490,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and also includes a $642,000 pretax gain on the sale of a building for both periods. c-Net loss and includes losses of $295,000 and $104,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations. The year-ago periods exclude the results for Action Drug Co., acquired in August.

title: Many School Buses Recalled By Navistar to Modify Brakes
description: The Navistar International Corporationsaid Monday that it had begun a recall of 19,000 school buses and 33,000 medium-size trucks equipped with power-assisted hydraulic brakes.

title: 2 UNIONS IN NEW YORK CONCRETE INDUSTRY AGREE TO COURT TRUSTEE
description: Two construction unions that the Government describes as ''tools of organized crime'' have agreed to replace many of their leaders and undergo supervision by a court-appointed trustee.

title: PIEDMONT AIR BEGINS TEST OF ANTI-COLLISION DEVICE
description: The 30-year effort by Government and industry to perfect an anti-collision device for airliners reached an often-postponed milestone today when Piedmont Airlines put a test system into regular operation on scheduled passenger service.

title: ANNA E.M. LEVY
description: Anna E.M. Levy, a charter founder of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, died Tuesday in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 96 years old and lived in Palm Beach and Manhattan.

title: 'BRONX ZOO' ON NBC
description: TAKE every high-school movie made since ''The Blackboard Jungle,'' mix with such television entertainments as the series ''Fame,'' throw in great gobs of inspiring-teacher uplift, as in the television movie ''The George McKenna Story,'' and you will begin to perceive the general outlines of NBC's ''Bronx Zoo,'' a new series being given a preview at 10 this evening. Its regular time period, beginning next week, will be Wednesdays at 10 P.M.

title: Boomerang Wins Offshore Racing
description: George Coumantaros's 80-foot Frers maxi yacht, Boomerang, needed just over 24 hours to complete the 172-mile Miami-to-Nassau course as she won International Offshore Rule Class 1 of the fifth race of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference series.

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax capital gain of $71.2 million from the sale of Horne's in Pittsburgh, a pre-tax charge of $62 million for costs related to combining certain operations and for store closings and department eliminations, and a pre-tax charge of $26 million for costs associated with several repurchase transactions.

title: G.I. JOE GOES HIGH-TECH
description: CAN Star Wars technology find success with the help of G.I. Joe? Makers of two of the hottest toys sold in America will find out later this year when they introduce the result of one of the more unusual tie-ups in product marketing.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $227,457,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $16,085,000 for the quarter and $42,735,000 for the 9 months. d-Net income

title: BITTERNESS MARKS TRIAL ON MAGAZINE
description: The lawyer for the real estate developer who bought The Atlantic traded bitter charges of fraud and breach of contract with the attorney for five of the magazine's former owners today as opening arguments were presented in Federal District Court here.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about Barbaralee Diamonstein's resignation from New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission referred erroneously to the head of the panel, Gene Norman. Mr. Norman, its chairman, has not resigned.

title: WENDY'S GOES BACK TO BASICS
description: WENDY'S INTERNATIONAL, threatened by the bigger burger boys above and an aggressive upstart below, has returned to the advertising basics with the man who was responsible for some of its past glory days.

title: LEGAL SNAG ON SWISS RECORDS
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra arms case said today that he had run into a legal snag that would delay efforts to get Swiss bank records for his investigation.

title: SHOPPING IN LONDON: SOHO SAVINGS
description: Remember Carnaby Street? It was once the heart of swinging England and the symbol, if not the best example, of London's first revolutionary burst onto the fashion scene. Nowadays Carnaby Street is filled with ticky-tacky tourist stands. Things have gotten so bad that Carnaby Street has disappeared from some tourist guidebooks.

title: EMBATTLED JUDGE SAYS HE WILL BE VINDICATED
description: As he came out of a meeting at the Marriott Pavilion Hotel here today, the embattled Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings was smiling like a seasoned politician, predicting that an attempt to impeach him ''will stop dead in the House Judiciary Committee.''

title: Reagan Session To Be Broadcast
description: President Reagan's news conference tonight will be broadcast live at 8 P.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks and will be carried on CNN, the Cable News Network. The networks will offer news analyses immediately after the news conference. In addition, some affiliates of PBS and SIN, the Spanish International Network, will carry the address, either live or delayed. In the New York area, for example, Channel 13 will broadcast it at midnight.

title: Tourney Wins A Friend at Court
description: Michael Garavente, a 35-year-old Merrill Lynch executive, started out having a few of the guys over on a March Saturday in 1983 to watch the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament on television. Then things began getting out of hand. By 1985, the annual gathering had grown to more than 30 friends, most of them buddies from Wall Street, who swarmed over Garavente's home, swilling Garavente beer and wolfing down Garavente snacks. Garavente, by now stuck with a tradition, had to find some way to get the hordes out of the house.

title: Robertson and Confidentiality
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson's skills as a communicator are an important part not only of his ministry but also of his budding quest for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: CAPTIVE SAUDI DIPLOMAT FREED IN BEIRUT
description: A Saudi diplomat kidnapped in West Beirut 66 days ago was freed today, 24 hours after a pro-Iranian organization said it would delay a death sentence for a French hostage for one week.

title: Roll-Call in Senate On Aid to Contras
description: Following is the roll-call vote today by which the Senate refused to kill $40 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels: FOR HALTING AID - 48 Democrats - 40 Adams, Wash. Baucus, Mont. Biden, Del. Bingaman, N.M. Bumpers, Ark. Burdick, N.D. Byrd, W.Va. Conrad, N.D. Cranston, Calif. Daschle, S.D. DeConcini, Ariz. Dodd, Conn. Exon, Neb. Ford, Ky. Fowler, Ga. Glenn, Ohio Gore, Tenn. Harkin, Iowa Inouye, Hawaii Kennedy, Mass. Kerry, Mass. Lautenberg, N.J. Leahy, Vt. Levin, Mich. Matsunaga, Hawaii Melcher, Mont. Metzenbaum, Ohio Mikulski, Md. Mitchell, Me. Moynihan, N.Y. Pell, R.I. Proxmire, Wis. Pryor, Ark. Reid, Nev. Riegle, Mich. Rockefeller, W.Va. Sarbanes, Md. Sasser, Tenn. Simon, Ill. Wirth, Colo. Republicans - 8 Chafee, R.I. Durenberger, Minn. Evans, Wash. Hatfield, Ore. Packwood, Ore. Specter, Pa. Stafford, Vt. Weicker, Conn. AGAINST HALTING AID - 52 Democrats - 14 Bentsen, Tex. Boren, Okla. Bradley, N.J. Breaux, La. Chiles, Fla. Dixon, Ill. Graham, Fla. Heflin, Ala. Hollings, S.C. Johnston, La. Nunn, Ga. Sanford, N.C. Shelby, Ala. Stennis, Miss. Republicans - 38 Armstrong, Colo. Bond, Mo. Boschwitz, Minn. Cochran, Miss. Cohen, Me. D'Amato, N.Y. Danforth, Mo. Dole, Kan. Domenici, N.M. Garn, Utah Gramm, Tex. Grassley, Iowa Hatch, Utah Hecht, Nev. Heinz, Pa. Helms, N.C. Humphrey, N.H. Karnes, Neb. Kassebaum, Kan. Kasten, Wis. Lugar, Ind. McCain, Ariz. McClure, Idaho McConnell, Ky. Murkowski, Alaska Nickles, Okla. Pressler, S.D. Quayle, Ind. Roth, Del. Rudman, N.H. Simpson, Wyo. Stevens, Alaska Symms, Idaho Thurmond, S.C. Trible, Va. Wallop, Wyo. Warner, Va. Wilson, Calif.

title: In South Korea, Democracy Is Mainly Illusion
description: To the Editor:

title: Warning to Democrats
description: For four years the House Democratic Caucus, which is made up of all 257 House members, has tried to limit its members to serving on no more than five House subcommittees. The theory is anyone who serves on more than five subcommittees is inevitably spread too thin, with scheduling conflicts and so much to do that he cannot master any one panel's agenda.

title: Bechtel Reports Work Reductions
description: Reflecting an extended downturn in heavy construction, the Bechtel Group reported that the volume of work it performed in 1986 declined to $6.5 billion, from $6.8 billion in 1985. The privately held engineering and construction company, which is based here, said it ''completed the year in the black, as it has always done in the past.''

title: THAILAND PRESSING OUSTER OF LAOTIANS
description: A year after shutting down several reception centers for Vietnamese boat people, and less than three months after closing the Cambodian refugee camp at Khao I Dang, the Thai authorities appear to have turned their attention to the 84,000 or more Laotians in crowded Mekong Valley and other Thai-Lao border camps.

title: ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said results reflect a change in accounting methods for oil and gas properties from full-cost to successful effort.

title: Boxing Notebook; SPINKS AWAITS JUDGE'S RULING
description: The confused circumstances of the heavyweight division are expected to clear soon.

title: Fruit of the Cactus
description: As American lawmen were moving in on the American hired to spy for Israel, Jonathan Pollard sent a message to Col. Aviem Sella, one of his handlers who was in Washington at the time. The key word was ''cactus''; it was a code word warning to run for cover.

title: BOMB KILLS 4 IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: A bomb exploded today at a military academy where President Corazon C. Aquino is scheduled to speak this weekend, and the military said four people were killed and 38 wounded.

title: LAST ROUNDUP FEARED AT TEXAS PRISON RODEO
description: Through the years it has featured an acrobatic horse named Henry The Flying Prince, a prison chorus called the Cotton Pickers Glee Club, and hundreds of felons risking life and limb as neophyte rodeo cowboys.

title: U.S. TO DISTRIBUTE $47 MILLION FOR SCHOOL ASBESTOS CLEANUP
description: President Reagan has signed a joint resolution that requires the Environmental Protection Agency to follow a rigid timetable for distributing funds for the removal of asbestos from schools, the White House announced today.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SPLIT OVER COSTA RICAN PEACE PLAN
description: Administration officials concerned with Central American policy are in disagreement over how much support to give a Costa Rican plan for a peace settlement in the region.

title: TRADING OF U.S. ISSUES THIN
description: Yields of Treasury securities vacillated in a narrow range yesterday in quiet trading that was again overshadowed by sharply higher prices in the British gilt, or government bond, market.

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''My testimony was truthful and correct on all of these subjects to the best of my recollection and beliefs. To the extent that there may have been inconsistencies between my testimony and the vast array of facts developed during Mr. Seymour's investigation, it was totally inadvertent.'' - Michael K. Deaver. [ D26:1. ]

title: NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
DAMON CREATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-Net loss The company said the substantial decrease in net loss is due to a reduction of selling, general and administrative expenses, a decrease of interest expense and a pension reversion of $1,131,000.

title: C.I.A. GIVES CONTRAS DETAILED PROFILES OF CIVIL TARGETS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is providing the Nicaraguan rebels with precise information on dams, bridges, electrical substations, port facilities and other targets that the rebels will try to destroy in guerrilla raids deep inside Nicaragua, according to Government officials.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, MARCH 19, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: SPRING CLEANING ADVICE
description: With the time for spring cleaning approaching, two new books seek to speed and simplify the process.

title: Allegheny Tells Of Rejected Bid
description: Allegheny International Inc. disclosed that it had turned down a higher takeover offer from an unnamed bidder before accepting a leveraged buyout led by a unit of the First Boston Corporation. It said the offer was rejected because the bidder had refused to pay a $7 million ''termination payment'' to First Boston.

title: Federated's Net Rises 11%; May's Is Up 9%
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 11 percent. The May Department Stores Company, meanwhile, reported a 9 percent profit increase.

title: Richardson Is Courted
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, banned from the National Basketball Association because of drug use, might sign a contract to play this summer with the United States Basketball League's Long Island Knights.

title: GRACE'S UNCERTAIN SUCCESSION
description: It is the stuff of business lore: the battle for the executive suite. At W. R. Grace & Company, three men are pitted against each other, fighting to be the next chief executive.

title: Merc Floor Trader Elected Chairman
description: Like most husbands, William R. Bradt from time to time likes to spring pleasant surprises on his wife. He was able to do it again yesterday, but not before he experienced a few anxious hours.

title: Bonding Among Women
description: To The Home Section:

title: NAVY REQUEST REPORTED ON 522 ADVANCED PLANES
description: The Navy has asked two competing teams of military contractors for proposals to build 522 modified versions of the advanced fighter jets the companies are developing for the Air Force, industry executives involved in the program said today.

title: DANCE: AILEY ENSEMBLE IN 'STREAMS'
description: THE Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble's performance on Sunday afternoon at the Theater of the Riverside Church demonstrated how valuable this company can be. Founded by Mr. Ailey in 1974 as a workshop group and now under the direction of Sylvia Waters, the ensemble gives young dancers professional experience performing old works and new and it encourages choreographers to try out ideas.

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a tax credit of $26 million. c-After tax credits of $5.3 million for the quarter and $32.2 million for the year. The results for the fiscal 1987 fourth quarter include operations of Shopwell Inc., acquired in August 1986 and Waldbaum Inc., a majority-owned subsidiary acquired in December 1986.

title: DR. EARLE H. BALLOU
description: The Rev. Dr. Earle H. Ballou, for many years a Congregational missionary in China, died Sunday at a nursing home in Townshend, Vt. He was 93 years old and lived in Brookline, Vt.

title: NL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $81.5 million from the reversion of surplus pension assets; a writeoff of goodwill of $20.7 million, previously classified with property, plant and equipment; a charge of $15.6 million related to adjustment of the carrying value of non-chemicals discontinued operations assets, all for the quarter and year; and gains of $2.4 million and $15.9 million for the quarter and year, respectively, related to adoption of provisions of SFAS No. 87. c-Net income The company said latest quarter results also reflect certain non-recurring charges associated with the change of control of the company.

title: Butcher Wins Iditarod Again
description: Susan Butcher outdueled Rick Swenson today to win the 15th annual Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race for the second straight year. Butcher's team trotted under a spruce log arch on Front Street in this historic gold rush community on the coast of Norton Sound at 11:05 A.M., local time.

title: 4th-QUARTER G.N.P. RISE IS PARED TO 1.1% RATE
description: Economic growth slowed in the closing months of 1986, inching upward at an annual rate of only 1.1 percent and resulting in the slowest growth for a full year - 2.5 percent - since the last recession, the Government said today.

title: CHAIRS THAT ROAR
description: FUNNY, it doesn't look like an armchair. It has two working headlights, a bumper, front fenders, blinkers, a windshield and an antenna, and it sits on wheels. But it is a chair, with good lower-back support and comfortable enough for a long visit with a Russian novel. Designed by Gary Schatmeyer, an East

title: EQUITY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Share earnings and shares outstanding for 1985 have been adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid Dec. 5, 1986.

title: THE DANCE: MURRAY LOUIS
description: THERE was a time when the director of a modern-dance company was not only its choreographer and main dancer but also its star. In an era when choreographers are dropping out from performing, Murray Louis - who formed his troupe in 1953 -remains indisputably the star of the Murray Louis Dance Company.

title: China Spending Curb
description: China said today that two or three more years of measures to curb excessive investment were needed to bring capital spending under control. The China Daily quoted Zhou Daojiong, president of the People's Construction Bank of China, as saying unauthorized spending by local governments or enterprises of more than 20 billion yuan, $5.4 billion at current exchange rates, was partly responsible for an overheated rate of investment.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: The share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend distributed March 11 to shareholders of record Feb. 20.

title: AUCTION PRECEDES START OF TROUT SEASON
description: With the opening of the trout season less than two weeks away, various organizations dedicated to the well-being of the species have scheduled special affairs calculated to stir their winter-weary members into action.

title: Opposing Coaches Downplay Chances
description: - The battle for position begins long before a basketball is tossed into the air.

title: Soviet Dissident Is Freed
description: Sergei Khodorovich, a well-known Soviet dissident, arrived here today after being freed from a work camp in the northern Siberian city of Norilsk. Mr. Khodorovich, who used to manage a fund for the families of political prisoners, was on a list of 14 prisoners on whose behalf Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist, had interceded with the Soviet authorities.

title: NUMBER OF DOCTORS SELLING PRESCRIPTION DRUGS GROWS
description: A growing number of physicians and dentists in the New York metropolitan region are selling prescription drugs to their patients.

title: Jackson Forms a Panel To Explore a 1988 Bid
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has joined a growing field of Democratic Presidential hopefuls by organizing an exploratory committee, the first official step toward a rerun of his unsuccessful campaign for his party's nomination in 1984, a Jackson spokesman said today.

title: HOUSE BACKS A SPEED LIMIT OF 65 FOR RURAL INTERSTATES
description: The House of Representatives, seeking to end the national speed limits imposed after the 1973 oil embargo, voted today to increase the limits from 55 miles per hour to 65 m.p.h. on rural Interstate highways.

title: Unionists Protes At University Club
description: Members of Local 6 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union protested outside the University Club yesterday, saying the club was threatening layoffs of union workers.

title: THE STAGE: 'STAGGERLEE'
description: FROM the New Orleans folk tale of ''Staggerlee,'' Vernel Bagneris and Allen Toussaint have created a mediocre rhythm-and-blues musical. Opening last night at the Second Avenue Theater, ''Staggerlee'' is overly casual in all departments except Mr. Toussaint's flavorful New Orleans-accented score and the performances of some of the women in the cast, especially Ruth Brown.

title: WINDSOR JEWELS DRAW BIDDERS AND BROWSERS
description: The storied jewels of the Duchess of Windsor, the commoner who beguiled a king, were glimpsed by the public for the first time yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anacomp Inc., Indianapolis, which provides computer services and specializes in software development, said it had acquired Datagraphix Inc. from General Dynamics Corp. for about $128 million.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. to Run 2 Unions

title: McReynolds Gets Into a Hitting Groove
description: The beanball war between the Mets and the Boston Red Sox was canceled today when the chief combatants were diverted to peaceful pursuits.

title: REAGAN SEES 2 BILLION ACID RAIN FUND
description: President Reagan, trying to pave the way for a harmonious meeting next month with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, said today that he would seek $2.5 billion over the next five years for projects to combat acid rain.

title: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring after-tax gain of $383,000, or 10 cents a share, from the sale of real estate for the quarter and year. The year also includes an after-tax charge of $558,000 related to a settlement of litigation.

title: TOYS 'R' US CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: Latest quarter and 1986 share earnings are restated for a 3-for-2 stock split effective June 27, 1986.

title: This Year's Gun Fight
description: No session of Congress is complete without a fight over gun control, and this year's legislative battle is already taking shape. At issue are ''invisible'' guns, which are made largely of plastic and can pass through metal detectors and other screening devices without notice.

title: A.T.&T. to Call In Most of Preferred
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would spend $775 million to redeem most of its outstanding preferred stock on May 1 as part of its efforts to reduce its outstanding debt.

title: Yields Unchanged
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds remained virtually flat for the week ended yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The obituary of the actress Joan Greenwood on March 3 misidentified the actor with whom she appeared in the movie ''Tight Little Island.'' He was Basil Radford, not Basil Rathbone.
