title: THOUGHTS ON MAXIMIZING AND MINIMIZING MUSIC
description: SERIOUS moviegoers are pretty angry about the coloring of old black and white films - a ploy to increase their marketability with television audiences. Music has had a similar problem for a long time - orchestra transcriptions - but no one seems much to mind. They should. In both cases, cosmetics have served to catch the eye but mislead the heart.

title: Continental's Brazil Loans
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation, reacting to the Brazilian Government's decision to suspend interest payments to creditor banks, said today that it might have to put $380 million in medium- and long-term loans to Brazil on a cash basis. The bank said it also might take similar action on its loans to Ecuador, which total $25 million.

title: BOOKBINDING WITH FLAIR
description: HERBERT WEITZ, bookbinder, was rubbing the spine of a clothbound book. Suddenly the lackluster binding began to glow. ''Do you know this trick?'' he asked, referring to the Vaseline on his fingers.

title: Eight Seized in Scheme To Bring Heroin to U.S.
description: An inmate at a Federal prison, a prison guard and six others were charged yesterday with operating a heroin smuggling organization that was preparing to bring hundreds of pounds of the drug into the United States from Thailand, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Sculptor Indicted for 3d Time in Wife's Death
description: A 52-year-old sculptor has been indicted a third time on a murder charge in his wife's 1985 death, after two previous indictments were dismissed by the trial judge, prosecutors in Manhattan announced yesterday.

title: Cuomo Indicates He's Willing To Limit Ethics Panel's Scope
description: Governor Cuomo, faced with bipartisan legislative opposition to the commission he named to investigate ethics in government, indicated today that he would be willing to restrict the scope of the panel's inquiry.

title: Metro Matters; THE WATERFRONT IS REDISCOVERED WITH A PASSION
description: A century ago, Herman Melville captured New York's fascination with the waterfront. ''There now is the insular city of the Manhattoes,'' he wrote in ''Moby Dick,'' an island teeming with inlanders whose goal was to ''get just as nigh the water as they possibly can without falling in.''

title: Airlines Cited in Europe
description: The commission of the European Community threatened today to bring legal action against three European airlines for price and route fixing. It gave the companies - Lufthansa of West Germany, Alitalia of Italy and Olympic Airways of Greece - three weeks to modify their methods of fixing fares, pooling revenues and dividing routes.

title: Second Success for Trident
description: A Trident 2 submarine missile was launched Tuesday, scoring a second consecutive test success for the Navy's newest, most powerful rocket. Officials said the 44-foot, three-stage missile, launched from the land, hurled an instrument-laden dummy warhead to an Atlantic Ocean target area several thousand miles to the southeast. ''The Navy has classified it as a successful test,'' said a Navy spokesman, Lieut. Max Allen.

title: McFARLANE SAID TO HAVE TOLD OF SAUDI OFFER TO AID CONTRAS
description: In separate letters written to his lawyer and three members of Congress before his suicide attempt last month, Robert C. McFarlane disclosed that Saudi Arabia's ambassador to Washington had offered secret contributions in 1984 for the Nicaraguan rebels, his lawyer said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 19, 1987
description: Companies

title: Leader Holding Edge In Race for a 3d Term
description: With the release of a budget tailored for maximum political appeal, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher now holds the high ground on the major economic and foreign policy issues upon which her advisers say she will base her campaign for a third term.

title: SUICIDES IN JERSEY STRAIN MENTAL HEALTH RESOURCES
description: In the week since four teen-agers asphyxiated themselves in a garage here, local officials have scrambled to start hot lines and set up counseling services for others who might be suicidal.

title: 'LAWRENCE WELK,' ON 13
description: CORNY, yes; old-fashioned, of course. But who else could star on television for 27 years? From 1955 to 1982, first on ABC and then in syndication, Lawrence Welk appeared every Saturday night. Come revisit now with ''Lawrence Welk: Television's Music Man'' on Channel 13 at 8:30 P.M. It is like opening a time capsule.

title: RUTGERS DEVELOPS IN IMAGE OF A NATIONAL CHAMPION
description: Their coach considers herself a grand manipulator, and the members of the Rutgers' women's basketball team, now in pursuit of the national championship, are playing right into her hands.

title: DEAVER IS INDICTED BY U.S. GRAND JURY ON PERJURY COUNTS
description: Michael K. Deaver, who left the White House to form a multimillion-dollar lobbying business, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges that he lied to the panel and to Congress about his lobbying activities.

title: OPPOSITION PAPER LAUNCHED IN CHILE
description: For the first time since the military took power 13 years ago, a daily newspaper identified with the opposition to President Augusto Pinochet went on sale today in the kiosks of the Chilean capital.

title: WOOLRIDGE FOUL SHOT ENDS PISTON STRING
description: Orlando Woolridge made a free throw with five seconds left in the game tonight to lead the Nets to a 113-112 victory over Detroit and end the Pistons' seven-game winning streak.

title: TRAINING OF SCHOOL OFFICIALS FAULTED IN EDUCATION REPORT
description: Calling for better professional training of school administrators, a national commission said yesterday that more than half of the nation's colleges and universities that train school administrators should stop because they lacked the necessary ''resources and commitment.''

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 22
Seeds of a Knick Revolt
description: For centuries, the great revolutions have usually been ignited by an isolated incident minimized by the reigning monarchs. Rifle shots at Lexington and Concord, angry French peasants storming the Bastille, a small plane above Giants Stadium towing a sign that read ''15 Years of Lousy Football, We've Had Enough.'' And at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night rolled-up Patrick Ewing posters were flung onto the court by Knick followers fed up with watching another dreary defeat, a 133-111 loss to the Denver Nuggets, hardly a contender for the National Basketball Association championship.

title: More Than Mere Luck
description: To The Home Section:

title: Bridge: A Respected Publication Is Going Out of Business
description: A recent announcement is a sad blow for students of the game: Popular Bridge, which has been published bimonthly in Ventura, Calif., for two decades, has announced that it will cease publication.

title: U.S. Aviation Administrator Quits Amid Battle in Congress for Funds
description: The chief of the Federal Aviation Administration, Donald D. Engen, announced his resignation today, effective in July.

title: QUEST FOR A CURTAIN FOR A HISTORIC HALL
description: THE great golden curtain that for decades draped in majestic folds above the Rockettes at Radio City Music Hall was lowered for the last time in mid-January and ripped to pieces. The next day a new one went up, every thread of the four-ton, 330-by-78-foot replacement looking precisely like the original - but cleaner. No changes could be made in the curtain's style or color because the building is a National Historic Landmark.

title: FOR NOW, LONE WEAPON ON AIDS IS PREVENTION
description: As the death toll from AIDS continues to mount and hopes recede for developing a vaccine or cure any time soon, the nation is turning more vigorously and more desperately to the only available defenses against the epidemic: prevention.

title: WILKINSON: QUIET MAN AS VALJEAN
description: On stage in ''Les Miserables,'' Colm Wilkinson has a powerful dramatic presence. One believes that his Jean Valjean is a man who could lead armies and revolutions. Sitting in his dressing room before a performance, the actor seemed the antithesis of his role - congenial, mild-mannered, hesitant about making pronouncements.

title: MUSIC: AMADEUS QUARTET AND GUEST
description: GIVEN enough time, string quartets develop their own easily recognizable personalities, and the Amadeus Quartet has certainly had enough time. When the British-based group appeared last evening at Carnegie Hall, its members were the same musicians who founded it 40 years ago, a remarkable length of time for any alliance to endure and probably an unprecedented one for a major quartet.

title: CURTAIN UP ON THE 12TH CENTURY
description: A musical drama that has gone unperformed for eight centuries is going back before audiences this week, after some international detective work turned up at least some of its music.

title: SCHOOLS INQUIRY SAYS A DISTRICT FELL INTO CHAOS
description: A two-month investigation found that Community School Board 6 in upper Manhattan allowed its schools to deteriorate into chaos, Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday.

title: 'Social Security' to Close
description: ''Social Security,'' a comedy by Andrew Bergman about a married couple who are art dealers, will close after the Sunday matinee at the Barrymore Theater. Directed by Mike Nichols, the play will have run for 385 regular performances and 26 previews.

title: Melcher's Cowboys
description: It is common to hear Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and other major players in the Iran-Nicaragua affair referred to as ''cowboys.'' But one Senator stood up the other day to protest, not on behalf of Colonel North and the others, but on behalf of the legislator's good friends the cowboys.

title: WINNEBAGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: HAWKER SIDDELEY CANADA LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $7.7 million provision for planned divestiture of Trenton Works operation in Trenton, Nova Scotia. c-After a $1,930,000 special charge. The results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: RANGERS FLOUNDER AGAINST WHALERS
description: The Whalers start down the ice, and the Rangers scurry back. Dean Evason crosses the blue line and winds up. A defenseman, Pat Price, appears in front of him. Price puts the blade of his stick down, and the puck deflects not into the stands, where Price wanted it to go, but toward the net and through the legs of Bob Froese.

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Revenue represents contract revenue and the latest fiscal year results include a one-time writeoff announced during the third quarter of certain costs and investments in the Dawn Enterprises ethanol refinery project and that without the writeoff, the company said net income would have been $7,926,000, or $1 a share.

title: Brubeck Group to Play 13 Concerts in Soviet
description: The Dave Brubeck Quartet will give a series of 13 jazz concerts in the Soviet Union under the 1985 United States-Soviet cultural exchange agreement, the United States Information Agency announced today.

title: RADIATION IS LEAKED IN AUSTRALIA
description: A fire at a nuclear reactor complex south of Sydney released radiation into the atmosphere today and contaminated two workers, the authorities said.

title: CENTRAL ILLINOIS PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for 12mos Feb 28
Dow Rises Only 2.13 but Sets Record
description: What seemed destined to be a historic day on Wall Street turned into only a slightly memorable one as the Dow Jones industrial average rose above 2,300 for the first time but did not stay there.

title: AUSTRALIANS COOL TO VATICAN PAPER
description: As a pioneer in fertility research and home to more than 1,000 so-called test tube babies, Australia has reacted sharply to the Vatican's condemnation last week of artificial means of procreation.

title: 2 Issues Marketed By Ryder System
description: Ryder System Inc., a diversified truck leasing concern, is offering 30-year bonds and seven-year notes totaling $175 million through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
JUDGE BLOCKS A P.B.A. EXPLUSION
description: A judge in Manhattan signed an order yesterday temporarily preventing the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association from expelling one of 24 police officers that the union's leaders are seeking to eject.

title: CONGRESS PANELS MERGE INQUIRIES INTO IRAN AFFAIR
description: The special Senate and House committees investigating the Iran-contra affair decided today to hold joint hearings, and set a timetable for granting limited immunity from prosecution to the two central witnesses.

title: 12 LYNDON LAROUCHE SUPPORTERS ARE ARRESTED ON FRAUD CHARGES
description: Twelve followers of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the political extremist, have been arrested on charges of fraudulently obtaining money from donors to LaRouche causes, the New York State Attorney General announced yesterday.

title: 'TURANDOT' CURTAIN CALL A RIDDLE
description: Was it a curtain call or a wrestling match? The question arose at the Metropolitan Opera Tuesday night after the second act of ''Turandot,'' when audience members tittered at some apparent jostling between the two high-powered stars of the evening - Eva Marton and Placido Domingo.

title: NEW PLOY: 'TIN PARACHUTES'
description: After three corporate takeovers shuttered plants and eliminated many jobs in their area, the 3,300 employees of Herman Miller Inc. in Zeeland, Mich., might be just a bit worried. But they show few signs of it.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Earlier Suicidal Sign Cited in Jersey Deaths
description: Thomas Olton, one of four Bergenfield teen-agers who died in a suicide pact on March 11, cut his wrists in an apparent suicide attempt five days earlier, according to the Bergen County Prosecutor, Larry J. McClure.

title: The U.N. Today: March 19, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MOST people don't even think about casters until it is time to move a heavy piece of furniture. If it is equipped with casters of good quality and correct size, the moving job is easy. Good casters also help protect floors and carpets from damage, even when the piece is not being moved.

title: Microsoft Action Against Falcon
description: The Microsoft Corporation said that in response to its copyright infringement action, a Federal district judge here had issued a preliminary order blocking three Taiwan companies and a California company from copying, importing, disseminating or distributing a program, Falcon MS-DOS. Microsoft said Falcon was a copy of its MS-DOS operating system for the I.B.M. PC and compatible computers.

title: James Baker Denies Ordering Invasion Lie
description: James A. Baker 3rd today denied that, as White House chief of staff, he had ordered Vice Adm. John Poindexter to deny that an invasion of Grenada was imminent.

title: DANCE: GABRIELLE LANSNER
description: ATTRACTIVE kinetic images crystallized and melted away in the two works by Gabrielle Lansner that Gabrielle Lansner and Dancers offered Monday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center. But seldom was this imagery developed or explored.

title: BULLISH OMEN FOR STOCKS?
description: DURING most of last year, analysts kept reducing estimates of company earnings at least twice as fast as they made upward revisions. Lately, however, they have been less prone to trim profit forecasts for 1987.

title: GOOD DESIGN FOR UNDER $50
description: ONE definition of a good buy is a functional object at a bargain-basement price. A search through the city turned up some remarkable buys under $50. A cotton bedspread, above right, 90 by 108 inches, comes in different colored checkered patterns, and is $12.98 at Azuma, 251 East 86th Street. A secretary's chair in black, left, swivels, has an adjustable seat and back, and is $39.95 at Third Avenue Bazaar, 1145 Third Avenue near 67th Street. Three French wallpaper designs include a black and white design featuring images of movie stars; a gold and black leopard print, top left, and a gold and black tropical flower print. The rolls of wallpaper are 20 1/2 inches wide by 5 yards long, and are sold in double rolls for $1.98 at Janovic Plaza, 1150 Third Avenue at 67th Street. The stainless steel flatware, far left, comes in a 48-piece package, consisting of 8 6-piece place settings of a fork, salad fork, knife, teaspoon, dessertspoon, and soupspoon.The flatware costs $49.95 at Conran's, 160 East 54th Street. Lacquered wood chopsticks, top, have either a panda bear on a black and cream background, or black flowers on a terra cotta and cream background. A package of 10 pairs is $1.80 at Kam Man Food Products, 200 Canal Street. Glass ice-cream dishes, left, come six to a set and cost $4.49 at F. W. Woolworth, 761 Broadway near Eighth Street.

title: O'Rourke Son Face Intoxication Charge
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke Jr., the 31-year-old son of the Westchester County Executive, was charged with drunken driving after a collision Tuesday night on the Sprain Brook Parkway. The state police said he had refused to take a Breathalyzer test.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: ONE night when I was a teen-ager my friends and I turned on a television show about a beautiful woman with an ugly nose. A plastic surgeon fixed it but cautioned, ''This only changes your nose, not who you are.''

title: WESTERN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: STORES WHERE ECLECTICISM IS ENCOURAGED
description: It pleases Judy George when customers in her furniture stores choose strikingly different items to create an ensemble. ''Nothing here matches,'' she boasted. Customers are more likely to mix a red Italian marble dining table with a Victorian-style skirted linen chair than with a more traditional wooden dining seat.

title: Cotton's Choice for '88
description: Former Senator Norris Cotton of New Hampshire is the dean of the Republican Party in the state that holds the first Presidential primary. So what he has to say about the Republican Presidential nomination is taken seriously.

title: AT UNLICENSED JAZZ CLUBS, 3 IS A CROWD BUT 4 IS ILLEGAL
description: On Tuesday, Feb. 10 at about 5 P.M., police cars converged, lights flashing, on Mikell's, the jazz club at Columbus Avenue and 97th Street. ''It was like we were mass murderers,'' said Pat Mikell, the club's co-owner.

title: WEINBERGER TRYING TO REASSURE TURKS ON U.S. ARMS HELP
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger met Turkish leaders today to try to convince them that the Reagan Administration wanted to reverse major reductions in military and economic aid.

title: PROFITS SURGE 6.1%, BEST IN 3 YEARS
description: After-tax corporate profits rose 6.1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1986, the most in more than three years, the Government reported today.

title: When Good Deeds Become Credits in the Bank
description: To the Editor:

title: LENA HORNE IS HONORED AT GALA CAPTIAL DINNER
description: Representatives of the music industry, members of Congress and a number of well-known songwriters and performers gathered tonight in the nation's capital to salute one of the legends of American show business, Lena Horne.

title: Prescription for a Scalping
description: In the world of cosmetics, the currency is dreams and fantasy defeats hard truth. Now comes Minoxidil, a hair restorer that the Federal Food and Drug Administration seems about to approve as safe and effective. Is this another wishful illusion or does the chemical really resurrect hair? The answer seems just a smidgeon of both.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: ALLISON'S PLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
DALLAS DANCERS A HIT AS FUND-RAISERS
description: The Dallas Ballet danced last night in the opening performance of its spring season. Just two weeks ago, it looked as if the curtain would not rise on that performance.

title: THE BLACK FOREST? EVERYTHING'S COMING UP GREEN
description: A lovely medieval university city cradled between the Rhine and the Black Forest, Freiburg boasts of having the most hours of sunshine in the Federal Republic, making it very roughly a German Florida. A lot of older Germans come south to retire here.

title: Japanese and Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: President Signs Bill Setting Appliance Energy Standards
description: President Reagan signed legislation Tuesday that requires national energy conservation standards for large appliances, a measure he once vetoed.

title: Florida Utility Sets A Yield of 8.951%
description: The Florida Power and Light Company is offering $150 million of 8 7/8 percent debentures due in 2017 at 99.20 to yield 8.951 percent. Salomon Brothers heads the underwriters.

title: Florida Frees Two Men Found With 6 Children
description: Two men jailed six weeks ago when they were found in a park with six bedraggled children have been freed after charges of child neglect were dropped for lack of evidence.

title: Happy With Adoption
description: To The Home Section:

title: ERIK CLAUSEN'S 'DARK SIDE OF THE MOON,' A DRAMA
description: ERIK CLAUSEN'S ''Dark Side of the Moon'' is a Danish film about a man named John who's released from prison after serving 16 years for an awful crime, the nature of which the film treats as a mystery long after it actually is.

title: Article 334887 -- No Title
description: A $2.2 billion takeover bid for the Gencorp Corporation - the old General Tire and Rubber Company -sent the stock soaring yesterday.

title: Jimmy Carter in Cairo On a Middle East Visit
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that he might get new information about American and other foreign hostages held in Lebanon during a visit to Syria over the weekend.

title: FOSTER-CHILD'S NIGHTMARE: MOVING 10 TIMES IN 5 YEARS
description: Bill was 6 years old when his mother's boyfriend beat her so badly she had to be hospitalized. Because they needed care and safety, Bill, his two brothers and his sister soon found themselves in the city's vast foster-care system. Bill became No. 4783021.

title: Shearson-Japan Deal Reported
description: A Japanese newspaper has reported that the Nippon Life Insurance Company of Japan would buy 10 percent of Shearson Lehman Brothers from the American Express Company as part of a drive into the American financial markets. Nihon Keizai Shimbun said

title: CBS Executive Joins Broderbund Family
description: In acquiring a reputation as the most successful software company in the difficult home computer market over the last seven years, Broderbund Software Inc. became known as a family-run concern. Yesterday the company reached outside, naming Edmund Auer as senior vice president and chief operating officer in a move to add management strength.

title: Senator Biden's Bad Arms Idea
description: In the guise of reform, Senator Joseph Biden of Delaware would put Congress in control of major arms sales. Reversing current procedure, he would require Congressional approval rather than allowing disapproval of every transfer of advanced weapons to nations other than established friends and allies. Mr. Biden has half a point; some reforms are needed. But his Arms Export Reform Act looks more like a reckless invasion of executive authority.

title: High Stakes on News Conference Tonight
description: The stakes will be high Thursday night when President Reagan holds his first news conference in more than four months, a prime-time, nationally broadcast special. For the public will be judging a lot more than the accuracy and adroitness of his answers to reporters' questions, which are expected to focus mainly on the Iran arms scandal.

title: Buying Reading Glasses Without a Prescription
description: To the Editor:

title: Visa Move Questioned
description: Four members of Congress asked the Justice Department today to investigate whether antitrust laws were violated when Visa suggested last week that banks re-examine their relationships with American Express.

title: PETROLEUM HELICOPTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: OWNERS OPPOSE FREE AGENCY
description: The National Football League's chief labor negotiator said that the club owners today ''gave a very strong 'no' '' to two of the players' highest priorities for the next collective-bargaining agreement - free agency and guaranteed contracts.

title: A Court Fails, an Old Woman Dies, and the Police Stand Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: SLOW PROGRESS IN AIRPORT TALKS
description: Little progress was reported today in airline scheduling talks being held here to reduce delays at the nation's two busiest airports.

title: BROWNSTONES AND TERRARIUMS
description: A Woman's Place Is in a Brownstone,

title: Avoiding a Hot Summer
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward first said it out loud earlier this month: ''I think that there are some groups . . . that have an agenda for this summer, in which I think we may see more taking to the streets and more demonstrations.''

title: Boeing Contract To Unit of LTV
description: The LTV Aircraft Products Group has been awarded a contract valued at more than $500 million with the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company. The agreement covers continuing production for sections of the Boeing 767, 757 and 747 airliners, including the new 747-400, through mid-1990.

title: Registration Site Barred
description: A ban by the United States Postal Service on voter registration by political parties and other partisan groups on post office property was upheld Tuesday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The court rejected a challenge to the ban by the Monterey County Democratic Central Committee, which wanted to register voters on a covered walkway leading to the Post Office in Carmel Valley.

title: Philippines Buying San Miguel Stake
description: The Philippines' social security system is planning to buy 8 million shares in the San Miguel Corporation, the company's chief financial officer, Ramon Del Rosario, said. He said the Government organization was preparing to invest $40 million.

title: BISHOPS MEET AT VATICAN TO PLAN POPE'S U.S. VISIT
description: A delegation of American bishops began four days of unusual meetings with Pope John Paul II and senior Vatican officials today, hoping that preparations for the papal visit to the United States in September will help ease tensions between Rome and American Catholics.

title: Smith Changes Sticks
description: Sharp-eyed viewers may notice that Billy Smith, the Islander goalie, has been using a blue Louisville Slugger stick instead of his old black Victoriaville stick. The factory that made the Victoriaville sticks has burned down, and Smith has used his last one. ''I've got to get someone to paint my new sticks black,'' he said. Smith took part in the Islanders' full practice yesterday at Nassau Coliseum after having left the ice in a huff on Tuesday during a practice that was optional for him. He said he was annoyed because the players were ''fooling around and that's when you get hurt.'' Tuesday's workout was conducted by Bobby Nystrom, the assistant coach, who said he was trying to have a meaningful practice, ''but Billy's got his own ideas.'' . . . Denis Potvin worked out lightly for the second straight day after being sidelined 24 days because of a sprained left knee. Potvin is 3 points short of becoming the first defenseman to score 1,000 points in a career.

title: Pretoria Foe Derides Election for Parliament
description: The president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, the Rev. Allan Boesak, said today that the May 6 election for the white chamber of the South African Parliament was ''a futile exercise.''

title: IRAN TRADE SHIFT SEEN
description: Two of the Federal agencies now willing to approve the sale of American computers to Iran's electric-power system had blocked a similar sale a year ago under pressure from the Defense Department, according to Government officials and computer industry executives.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A skins game for golf's senior players, featuring Arnold Palmer, Gary Player and Chi Chi Rodriguez, will be held early next year. The fourth player, as well as the site, for the two-day $360,000 event, which will be televised by NBC, have yet to be announced. . . . The St. Louis football Cardinals have traded Lionel Washington, the cornerback, to the Los Angeles Raiders for an undisclosed choice in this year's National Football League draft. . . . Mario Soto, the ace of the Cincinnati Reds' staff, threw about 60 pitches in a simulated game at the Reds' minor-league complex in Tampa, Fla. Soto, who had shoulder surgery last August, has not pitched in a game this spring, but Pete Rose, the Reds' manager, said Soto looked good and Rose hoped the left-hander could work two innings in a minor-league game Saturday.

title: Georgetown 'Specialist' Is Widening His Practice
description: When John Thompson speaks, his players do more than listen: They quake. It is within that context that Charles Smith's reaction to a rather loud order from his coach during a heated moment of Sunday's game between Georgetown and Ohio State must be characterized as a blatant act of defiance. It went like this: Late in the first half, with the Hoyas struggling, Thompson noticed Smith, a sophomore reserve guard, poised to launch one from deep in the corner, right in front of the Hoya bench.

title: Hoyas Settle Back In the Driver's Seat
description: Larry Brown and his Kansas team arrived at Freedom Hall this afternoon and were immediately struck by the magnitude of their competition in the N.C.A.A. tournament's Southeast Regional semifinal, the Georgetown Hoyas. ''We drove over in a station wagon,'' said the Jayhawks' coach. ''They just left in a limo.'' The disparity in vehicular accommodations not only speaks volumes about the Hoyas' status as one of the nation's most respected teams, but it could also be an analogy to the styles of the two teams, which meet for the first time ever Thursday night.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: College Basketball San Jacinto Stopped at 71: Lincoln Minor scored on a layup with seven seconds left as Midland, Tex., ended the 71-game winning streak of top-ranked San Jacinto, Tex., with a 98-93 victory last night in the second round of the National Junior College Athletic Association tournament. San Jacinto, whose streak stretched over two years, was vying for a record fifth national title and consecutive championships with perfect seasons.

title: Sallie Mae Security Tied to Currency Rates
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, one of the most innovative borrowers in the capital market, has added another variety of debt security. It offers investors a high interest rate, but it also involves the risk of fluctuations in a foreign currency.

title: Gordon Rogoff Wins Drama Criticism Award
description: Gordon Rogoff, a theater critic for The Village Voice and a professor of dramatic literature at Brooklyn College, has been named winner of the 1985-86 George Jean Nathan Award for Dramatic Criticism. The annual $5,000 award was established in 1958 by the late critic, who stipulated that submissions be judged by the heads of the English departments at Yale, Princeton and Cornell Universities.

title: KOHL, AFTER RE-ELECTION, STRESSES NEED FOR CLOSER TIES WITH SOVIET
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl called today for better relations with the Soviet Union and for an early accord eliminating Soviet and American medium-range missiles from Europe.

title: Another Hayes Tribute
description: The third memorial tribute to Woody Hayes in three days was held yesterday in Columbus, Ohio, this one at Ohio Stadium, where Hayes had coached football for 28 years. According to Roger Deerhake, Ohio State University's assistant ticket director, the crowd numbered 15,000 yesterday. They listened to tributes from Hayes's only son, Steven Hayes; his successor at Ohio State, Earle Bruce; his fiercest coaching rival, Bo Schembechler; former players and university officials. The speeches were made from a platform on the 30-yard line at the north end of the stadium. Steven Hayes, a municipal judge in Columbus, Ohio, said he never thought of his father as a celebrity. ''To me, he was just Dad,'' he said, adding that his father, a stern figure as a coach, was a doting grandparent who would wear a Darth Vader mask or play with dolls to entertain his grandchildren. Hayes, who won 205 games at Ohio State, died at age 74 of a heart attack last Thursday at his suburban Columbus home. A service for family and friends was held on Monday, and 1,400 invited guests attended a service Tuesday at First Community Church, near the university.

title: Control of Cyclops Passes to Dixons
description: Dixons Group P.L.C., the British retailer, has gained control of 56 percent of the Cyclops Corporation's stock after a tender offer, prevailing in its effort to win control despite a sweetened takeover bid by the Cyacq Corporation. The total acquisition price for Cyclops, a Pittsburgh-based specialty steelmaker that owns the Silo appliance store chain, will be $384 million.

title: RISE AND FALL OF U.S. DATA DIRECTIVE
description: The sudden cancellation of a five-month-old directive that tightened control over sensitive but unclassified information appears to mark a major setback to the Reagan Administration's effort to make sure strategic technologies developed by scientists and engineers in United States do not leave American shores.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $179,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes income from discontinued operations of $34,000.

title: British Banks Cut Rates
description: Two major British banks, National Westminster and Barclays, cut their base lending rates to 10 percent, from 10.5 percent. Other banks were expected to follow. The reductions follow a big drop in the Government's borrowing target, announced in the annual budget Tuesday. It was not clear whether the building societies would cut mortgage rates.

title: CONCERT: DESSOFF CHOIRS
description: AMY KAISER'S work hereabout with choruses -among them the Dessoff Choirs, which returned to Merkin Concert Hall Sunday evening - can be counted on to produce alert, characterful singing. This time around she brought out the dramatic side of Orlandus Lassus, the startlingly Mozartean side of some of Monteverdi's madrigals, and the full-hearted quality that we have always known in Verdi.

title: TEH PRACTICAL GARDENER
description: I SOMETIMES envy gardeners who live where the climate is comparatively predictable.

title: FLEET TO BUY NORSTAR FOR $1.3 BILLION
description: In another large merger in the banking industry, the Fleet Financial Group of Providence, R.I., said yesterday that it would acquire the Norstar Bancorporation of Albany.

title: THE OUTLOOK: AUTUMN IN NEW YORK
description: History suggests that the Mets, having finished farther in front last year than all but one other team in modern major league history, are a virtual cinch for October play again. Here are the clubs that have finished the greatest number of games ahead, and how they fared the following season. $ NEXT YEAR GA Pos. GA/B 1902 Pirates 27 1/2 1SY6 1/2 1986 Mets 21 1/2 - - 1906 Cubs 20 1 17 1975 Reds 20 1 10 1983 White Sox 20 5 10 1936 Yankees 19 1/2 1 13 1927 Yankees 19 1 2 1/2 1969 Orioles 19 1 15 1929 Athletics 18 1 8 1943 Cardinals 18 1 14 1/2 1907 Cubs 17 1 1 1939 Yankees 17 3 2 1941 Yankees 17 1 9

title: Q&A
description: Q.The sliding glass door leading out to my patio has suddenly become hard to slide open or closed; it sounds as if it is running on gravel. Can you tell me what the problem is? A.It sounds as if the wheels on which the door rides need replacing. Most sliding patio doors have grooved wheels riding on tracks below. If the wheels are badly worn, or if the bearings are giving out, the wheels make the noise you describe and the door becomes hard to move.

title: ZENITH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: 2D GENETIC DEFECT LINKED TO ILLNESS
description: Scientists have found strong evidence that manic-depressive illness is a group of disorders rather than a single entity and that either of at least two different genetic defects may produce the illness.

title: Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific Corporation said it had agreed to sell a 50 percent interest in its Japan Security Pacific Finance Company. Mitsui & Company will buy the unit for an undisclosed price. The new joint venture, with assets of $200 million, would offer consumer and commmercial loans and sell financial services.

title: SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The U.S. dollar amounts have been translated from yen at the rate of 153 yen equals U.S. $1, the Tokyo foreign exchange market rate as of Jan. 30, 1987. Share earnings represent depositary share and each depositary share represents one share of common stock.

title: SENATE VOTES, 52-48 NOT TO BLOCK AID TO CONTRAS
description: The Senate today narrowly defeated an effort to cut off the final installment of military aid this year to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Kennedy School Sets Loan Aid
description: The John F. Kennedy School of Government, a graduate school of Harvard University, announced today a plan to help its graduates who take low-paying public service jobs to pay off student loans.

title: Britain Selling B.P. Stake
description: The British Government said today that it planned to sell its remaining 31.7 percent stake in the British Petroleum Company, the second-largest oil company outside the United States. At current market value, the shares would be worth about $7.6 billion.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Prolific Dubliner In 1888 George Bernard Shaw, lecturer, playwright and novelist, became a music critic. In 1895 he was a drama critic and in 1898 he published a collection, ''Plays Pleasant and Unpleasant.'' His plays were published between 1900 and 1915, and he won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1925.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for 13wks to Jan 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $250,000 and $2,910,000 for the 13 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $1,200,000 for the 12 weeks and $2,380,000 for the 52 weeks. The company said income before federal income taxes and extraordinary tax credit includes a LIFO inventory credit of $186,000 in 1987 and a charge of 414,000 in 1986 for the quarter and charges of $564,000 in 1987 and $675,000 in 1986 for the year.

title: RUMOR FUELS EGYPT FUROR OVER RELIGION
description: A series of clashes between young Moslem fundamentalists and minority Coptic Christians, some spurred by a rumor that Christians had a secret spray that made crosses appear on Moslem women's veils, has prompted an unusual display of official concern here.

title: MUSIC: ECLECTIC GAGEEGO
description: A CONTEMPORARY music group with the euphonious name of Gageego played an engaging concert at the Fashion Institute of Technology Saturday night.

title: Navy Warns of Crisis in Anti-Submarine Warfare
description: The Navy has completed a sweeping revision of its programs for hunting enemy submarines in an effort to overcome what the service says is a crisis in its undersea competition against the Soviet Union.

title: AIR ATLANTA IN CRISIS MEETING
description: Executives of Air Atlanta, a small, three-year-old airline catering to business travelers, met today with its investors in New York in an attempt to stave off bankruptcy.

title: Chase to Offer Account Tied to S.&P. 500 Index
description: A bank account that pays interest based on the performance of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was introduced yesterday by the Chase Manhattan Corporation. But the new account is likely to face strong opposition from the securities industry and some legislators.

title: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,678,000 from the settlement of litigation against Belcher Oil Co., offset by a provision of $375,000 in connection with the resignation in March 1986 of the company's former president, legal settlements and costs of $1,074,000 and expenses of about $552,000 due to operating inefficiencies and costs relating to the closing of its contract packaging division.

title: ZZZZ BEST reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Corrections
description: A television article on Tuesday about the rebroadcast of the series ''Upstairs, Downstairs'' misidentified the actress who played Elizabeth Bellamy. She was Nicola Pagett, not Lesley-Anne Down.

title: The Blood and Stone Principle
description: A venerable banking principle holds that stones rarely yield blood. This simple notion is sometimes overlooked by John Reed, chairman of Citicorp and leader of the spartan school now dealing with third world debtors - nations on whom multibillion dollar loans were urged in the 1970's when recycling surplus oil dollars was a sacred and profitable calling.

title: Kelly Award Winner Named
description: Michael Winslow, a senior vice president of McKinney Silver & Rockett of Raleigh, N.C., whisked a $100,000 creative advertising award out from under the noses of some high-powered New York agencies yesterday.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
PSA Deal Accepted
description: Shareholders of PS Group Inc., the parent of Pacific Southwest Airlines, have approved the company's $400 million takeover by USAir Group Inc., the company said. PS Group said shareholders voted 91.1 percent Tuesday in favor of the deal, which already has been approved by the Transportation Department. The only remaining hurdle is negotiations between PS Group and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents about 3,000 of the company's 3,800 unionized employees.

title: 8 Die in Djibouti Cafe Blast; 'Criminal' Origins Explored
description: An explosion ripped through a cafe here today, killing 8 people and wounding 27, the President's office said.

title: Fed Allows Chase to Underwrite Some Paper
description: In a move that appeared to allow banks to take another step into the securities business, the Federal Reserve Board authorized a unit of the Chase Manhattan Corporation today to underwrite - as well as deal in - commercial paper.

title: Palmer Issues Denial
description: Paul Palmer, the all-America running back from Temple University, said at a news conference in Philadelphia that he had never signed a contract or accepted money from an agent before his football eligibility expired. The news conference was held to announce the findings of a two-day review of Palmer's relationship with Norby Walters, an agent. Palmer, runner-up to Vinny Testaverde in the Heisman Trophy balloting last season, acknowledged he signed a contract with Walters on Jan. 2 and had since been given some cash advances pending an agreement with a National Football League team after next month's draft of college players. Charles Theokas, the athletic director at Temple who oversaw the review, said he had spoken to both Palmer and the Temple coach, Bruce Arians. ''I felt comfortable after talking with Paul and Bruce, who gave me 105 percent cooperation, that nothing was done improper,'' said Theokas. ''There were no violations whatsoever.'' According to a report in The Atlanta Constitution last week, Walters admitted giving cash to some players in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules. The story said Palmer was among the players whom attorneys and agents identified as having had past or present dealings with Walters. Theokas said part of his investigation included contacting Walters, who heads a New York firm that represents many sports figures, ''and he told me that he never stated Paul Palmer was given any money while playing for the Temple football team.'' Palmer said he intended to honor his contract with Walters and told reporters, ''I feel comfortable with him.''

title: ISRAEL WILL CURB ARMS FOR PRETORIA
description: The Israeli Cabinet decided today not to sign new military sales contracts with South Africa, Cabinet officials said. They said it had acted in response to pressure from Congress and American Jews to curtail Israel's relations with Pretoria.

title: COOPERVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an estimated net gain of $118 million on the sale of the company's ophthalmic pharmaceutical business to Johnson & Johnson,, and also includes an extraodinary charge of $17.9 million representing a provision for the proposed repurchase of all of the company's 10 7/8 percent senior subordinated debentures due 1998. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $120,000. The company said the latest results include the operations of Cilco Inc., which was acquired Feb. 28, 1986. The company said operating results for the first and subsequent quarters in 1987 will not be directly comparable with those of a year-ago, since sales of the company's former pharmaceutical business will still be included with year-ago results until Dec. 31, 1986. Also the year-ago first quarter results did not begin to reflect sales of the acquisition of Cilco until March 1, 1986.

title: Support for Buyout Is Seen at Fairchild
description: The Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation has received a handful of proposals from financial companies interested in backing a management buyout, Fairchild's president and chief executive said today.

title: President Is Pre-empted
description: Only one of Florida's seven CBS television affiliates will carry President Reagan's news conference live on Thursday night because it conflicts with the Florida-Syracuse National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament game.

title: Nicaragua's Peace Aims
description: As the Reagan Administration prepares to escalate its military assault against Nicaragua by asking Congress to release $40 million in aid for the contras, the American people should be aware that the Administration has repeatedly rejected peace proposals put forth by Nicaragua to avoid unnecessary bloodshed in Central America.

title: VICTORIAN WITH A TWIST: NOT VENERABLE, BUT BRAND-NEW
description: WHEN Penny Strong was a little girl growing up on the South Shore of Long Island, she would fantasize about the large old Victorian houses in the more expensive parts of town.

title: CHINA'S 'WILD MOUNTAINS'
description: THE Chinese film ''Wild Mountains'' takes place in a rustic paradise fraught with problems that might be found anywhere: troubles about money, ambition, get-rich-quick schemes, idle gossip and marital discord. It concerns two married couples, the younger of them separated. Hehe (Du Yuan) has come to live with his brother Huihui (Xin Ming) and sister-in-law in a hut that is within clear view of the place where his beautiful wife Quirong (Xu Shouli) lives with their baby. Hehe and Quirong have quarreled about his dissatisfaction with simple peasant life and his eagerness to see the wider world.

title: Man Is Slain in Front of Wife In the Theft of Their '78 Car
description: A 37-year-old Queens man was shot and killed last night as he attempted to stop an unidentfied man from stealing his car on a street in Hollis.

title: CERADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: 'Star Wars' Deal For 2 Groups
description: The Pentagon office overseeing the Strategic Defense Initiative selected two competing teams of aerospace companies to develop a satellite that could closely track nuclear missiles fired at the United States immediately after they are launched.

title: Letter: On Soviet Reforms; Let Moscow 'Risk' Jewish Emigration
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
2 Doctors Suspended In Sex-Abuse Cases
description: Two New York City physicians face charges of sexually abusing teen-age patients and have been suspended from practicing medicine, the State Health Commissioner said yesterday.

title: 3 Told to Shun Pollard Panel
description: A lawyer for three Israelis in the Jonathan Jay Pollard spy case said today that he had advised them not to testify before a Government commission examining the affair. David Libai, the lawyer, said he told Yosef Yagur, former science counsel at the Israeli Embassy in Washington, Ilan Ravid, former science attache at the embassy, and Irit Erb, a secretary, not to appear because anything they said could be used against them later.

title: No Rush to Fill Wheeling Post
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, which is struggling to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings, has set no timetable for the selection of a new chief executive, the company said yesterday.

title: If Anything, Pay Student Athletes More
description: To the Editor:

title: RESEARCHER DESCRIBES A PROMISING AIDS THERAPY
description: Dr. Daniel Zagury, the first researcher known to test an experimental AIDS vaccine on human beings, today disclosed details of the vaccine's trials and described what he said were promising experiments with a new kind of therapy against the deadly disease.

title: FOR BERGENFIELD POLICE OFFICERS, A TIME OF STRESS AND ANGUISH
description: By mid-morning today, five more calls had come into the suicide-watch hot line at police headquarters. And five officers had been sent out to look for the five young adults whose friends were worried about them. All five, it turned out, were at home or work and were fine.

title: Yeutter Warns of Trade Veto
description: The United States Trade Representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, warned lawmakers today that the Administration has ''major problems'' with sweeping trade legislation they are drafting. He raised the possibility of a veto if the measure reaches President Reagan's desk unchanged.

title: AT P.S. 128, THE CRITICAL REPORT IS NOT SURPRISING TO PARENTS
description: Few of the parents waiting outside P.S. 128 in Washington Heights yesterday afternoon seemed surprised by an official finding that the schools under Community Board 6 were ''in a mess,'' in the words of Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones.

title: The Very First Secretary
description: Here is a question for Messrs. Dole, Bush, Hart, Bumpers, Kemp, Gephardt, Du Pont, Dukakis and all others who are dreaming the big dream:

title: Rhoden Will Miss a Start
description: Rick Rhoden, the Yankees' projected No. 1 starting pitcher, underwent a second examination for his aching left side today, and the doctor said the injury was not serious. Rhoden nevertheless will miss his scheduled turn Saturday, meaning he will miss at least nine days.

title: Japan Bond Plan
description: The Japanese Ministry of Finance has approved a plan to increase the participation of foreign banks and securities firms in 10-year government bond sales. In Japan, the 10-year bonds are allocated among banks and securities firms rather than sold through competitive bidding. Although the foreign allocation remains small, it was a step to placate American Government officials and securities dealers who have complained that they are denied access to the Japanese market while Japanese firms compete freely in the American market. Local and foreign securities houses may now underwrite 26.2 percent of the 10-year issue. Of that total, 5.7 percent is divided among 23 foreign firms. In the past, local and foreign houses were allocated 26 percent, of which 1.19 percent was divided among 17 foreign firms.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: CATHERINE DENEUVE came to 14th Street and created the biggest stir since S. Klein opened in 1910. The reason was a benefit party Wednesday night at Nell's for Very Special Artists, an organization founded by Jean Kennedy Smith that provides opportunities in the arts for people with disabilities. Parfums Phenix, a subsidiary of Avon, underwrote the evening, which raised $100,000 for the organization, but the fact that the company happens to make the film star's fragrance, Deneuve, was played down.

title: First Financial In Comdata Bid
description: The First Financial Management Corporation, a data-processing company for financial institutions, said today that it had made a $343 million takeover offer for Comdata Network Inc., the money transfer service.

title: HALLWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax credits of $164,000 for the quarter and $365,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income d-After tax credits of $551,000 for the quarter and $1,016,000 for the 6 months.

title: The Bosworth Shuffle
description: Oklahoma's spring football guide came out this week and among the names missing was that of Brian Bosworth. ''Bosworth has been gone since the Orange Bowl,'' Coach Barry Switzer told The Norman (Okla.) Transcript yesterday about his all-America linebacker who was barred from playing in the bowl because he tested positive for steroid use. ''It humors me to see the attention he gets. He's gone. He's history.'' But how far gone? Last night Switzer told The Associated Press that he would be willing to talk with Bosworth ''if he came in and was sincere that he really wants to come back next year.'' ''It would have to be structured how I want it,'' Switzer said of a possible return by the linebacker. ''I'll play Brian Bosworth; I won't play the Boz.'' Bosworth's publicist, Herb Machol, said the linebacker had not decided whether to return for his final year of eligibility with the Sooners or make himself available for the National Football League supplemental draft. He has until April 13 to make that decision.

title: SIGMA DESIGNS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid March 10, 1987.

title: Medical Facilities Bond Sale
description: In a first-of-its-kind bond sale yesterday, New York State is lending its reputation to help finance reconstruction of two financially distressed New York City hospitals.

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Youth Guilty in Deaths Of TV Actor's Parents
description: A 19-year-old janitor was convicted here today in the deaths of the parents of Patrick Duffy, a television actor.

title: NEW YORK ATHLETIC CLUB CHARGED WITH SEX BIAS
description: The New York City Human Rights Commission formally charged the New York Athletic Club yesterday with illegally discriminating against women by barring them from membership.

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BLOCKBUSTER ENTERTAINENT reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $625,000.

title: A YEAR AFTER THE HOMOSEXUAL RIGHTS LAW, 2 SIDES STILL DEBATE ITS RESULTS
description: It has been a year since the City Council passed a law protecting the civil rights of homosexuals, and, in words reflective of Mayor Koch's assessment on that night last March, proponents point out that ''the sky has not fallen.''

title: Chemlawn Bid Of $33 a Share
description: Waste Management Inc. said today that it was prepared to sweeten its offer for the Chemlawn Corporation to $33 a share, or a total of about $330 million.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Includes a loss of $2,396,000 from the early redemption of debt.

title: Worker Discontent at Airline Affecting Travelers
description: Worker dissatisfaction since Northwest Airlines took over Republic Airlines six months ago has not only left travelers fuming about chronic flight delays and lost baggage but has also led to suspicions that a disgruntled employee may have sabotaged one of the carrier's jets.

title: JUMPING-JACKS SHOES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Madison Avenue Editor Returns to Advertising
description: John V. Chervokas, who finally turned 50, is joining Sudler & Hennessey, the health-care advertising subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, as executive vice president and chief creative officer. It is a new job title at the agency.

title: Executive Leaving CBS For Job at Multimedia
description: Peter A. Lund, president of the television stations division of CBS Inc., said yesterday that he had resigned to direct the entertainment division of Multimedia Inc.

title: Moody's Lowers 2 Merrill Ratings
description: Merrill Lynch & Company's long-term debt ratings were reduced yesterday, Moody's Investors Service announced.

title: SHUBERT SIGNS 'PHANTOM OF THE OPERA'
description: The Shubert Organization this week captured one of the few prizes left in a boom-or-bust industry when a British producer, Cameron Mackintosh, agreed to bring ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' the biggest hit of the London season, to the Majestic Theater, a Shubert-owned house, in November.

title: BARS A RECURRENCE
description: President Reagan repudiated his Iran policy initiative tonight, saying ''I would not go down that road again.''

title: NOTRE DAME: BACK ON THE ROAD
description: Coaches are finally complaining about the annual Long Trek of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, and not a moment too soon.

title: GLOBAL ISSUES: BAKER'S VIEWS
description: THE United States ran a record deficit in merchandise trade of $170 billion last year. And the broadest measure of the trade deficit, the balance of payments on current account, hit an all-time high of $140 billion. Many economists, who consider the dollar still overvalued in these circumstances, are asking why the United States agreed at the Paris ''Group of Six'' meeting to help stabilize the dollar at about its present level.

title: JAPANESE PARTNER FOR SHEARSON
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 13 percent stake in its Shearson Lehman Brothers brokerage subsidiary to Japan's largest life insurance company for $530 million.

title: AGENCY RENT-A-CAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Israeli Spy 'Permission' Reported
description: An Israeli official who helped direct the espionage activities of Jonathan Jay Pollard in the United States told a Government commission investigating the affair that he acted with ''permission and authority,'' the newspaper Haaretz reported today.

title: CONVENIENT FOOD MART INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $657,000 on the sale of Conna Corp. stock.

title: Record for Gibson
description: Kirk Gibson, a Detroit Tigers outfielder, flew a Cessna 206 airplane to 25,200 feet and into the record books Gibson, a student pilot, has been flying for about five years. The flight took 1 hour 32 minutes. ''I guess I had some butterflies, if that's what you want to call it,'' said Gibson, who is in his ninth season with Detroit. ''You never know what might happen.'' A Cessna 206 has reached 22,000 feet before, but not with the same specifications as Gibson's plane, said Milton Brown, a retired Air Force colonel and spokesman for the National Aeronautics Association. Gibson flew out of Lakeland, Fla., where the Tigers are in spring training.

title: Tourney Talk
description: * Coach Tom Chapman, whose Gannon University basketball team includes a 30-year-old former steelworker and two Army veterans in their mid-20's: ''They're so old we use Geritol instead of Gatorade.''

title: ENGLISH SPOKEN HERE, FOR THE WOULD-BE DOCTORS
description: In the search for a coveted place in a medical school, few young Americans have gone farther afield than the 30 who have come to this southern Hungarian town near the Yugoslav border.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 379 money market mutual funds increased $43.4 million, to $237.34 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were up $465.7 million, to $66.06 billion. Assets of the 196 general purpose funds decreased $245.6 million, to $62.49 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds declined $176.7 million, to $108.79 billion.

title: Housing Is Built Over a Brooklyn Store
description: As the idea of living over the store gains acceptance, developers have been able to turn the upper floors of small, dilapidated retail buildings into housing.

title: JEANNETTE M. GINSBURG, 83, AUTHOR AND EDITOR
description: Jeannette Mirsky Ginsburg, who wrote acclaimed books on explorers, travelers and inventors, died March 10 at the Medical Center at Princeton, N.J. She was 83 years old and had lived in Princeton for 37 years.

title: Steel Cuts Endorsed
description: European Community industry ministers agreed today on the need for mass closings of steel plants throughout Western Europe to bring production capacity more in line with demand. The ministers were meeting to discuss a plan for voluntary plant closings, which it is estimated would cut about 22,000 jobs.

title: N.F.L. REPLAY PLAN EXTENDED ONE YEAR
description: After an unexpectedly long and emotional discussion today, National Football League owners voted by the narrowest of margins to continue using the instant-replay system for another season. A year from now, the system will be reviewed again.

title: STAGE: 'LADY MOONSONG,' FAIRY TALE FOR GROWN-UPS
description: WHEN we first meet Lady Moonsong (Mia Dillon) and her fisherman husband, Mr. Monsoon (Reed Birney), in Alice Eve Cohen's theatrical collage of mythology, poetry and music, they are exchanging alliterative exclamations while making love wrapped in a blanket. The scene is the happiest moment in a cautionary fable that augments the Grimm fairy tale ''The Three Wishes'' with plot elements borrowed from ''Macbeth'' and the Adam and Eve myth.

title: ART: EDWARD HOPPER, BIOGRAPHY IN DRAWINGS
description: THE Hoppers were by all accounts a peculiar pair -Josephine an ''indefatigable tug,'' Edward the ''somnolent gray cruiser'' that she was forever ''piping around.'' The metaphor is the biographer James Mellow's, and it comes to mind whenever the artist berths, as it were. Few outputs hint so strongly at autobiography while at the same time denying it, so that with each Hopper manifestation there is always the hope a Rosetta stone will somehow emerge to settle the contradiction, once and for all.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: OLIVER STONE'S ''Platoon,'' which won the second prize at the Berlin Film Festival a few weeks ago, has been stirring controversy at home and abroad. By trying to re-create the Vietnam War from the perspective of the American soldiers who fought and died in it, the film seems to have rekindled - a decade and a half after the war's end - the passions, moral conflicts and deep divisions that tore at American society during the war years.

title: A FARE-BEATING ARREST LEADS TO SEIZURE OF $1 MILLIION IN BOGUS BILLS
description: When the Transit Authority police arrested Simon DeLeon on fare-evasion charges in a Bronx subway station Tuesday night, they found two $50 bills in his pocket. But Officer Daniel Rodriguez noticed something odd: The serial numbers were identical.

title: DISCOVERIES BRING A 'WOODSTOCK' FOR PHYSICS
description: No sooner was a breakthrough announced than it was obsolete, and only the coming of dawn yesterday ended what participants called the most extraordinary scientific meeting in memory.

title: British Jobless Decline
description: The number of Britons unemployed registered the biggest fall on record in February, raising Government hopes that it would drop below the symbolic three million mark in time for a summer or autumn election.

title: LOS ANGELES BROKER, KEY BOESKY FIGURE, ADMITS STOCK FRAUD
description: The Government, pursuing its investigations of Wall Street, yesterday accused an important West Coast broker of manipulating the price of a stock and helping Ivan F. Boesky break securities laws.

title: Penal Reformer Of Another Sort
description: On occasion, something happens that reminds Coach Bob Timmons of 1972, when all 57 members of his University of Kansas track team were initially barred from the N.C.A.A. championships because of infractions he had supposedly committed several years earlier. When such a reminder comes along, Timmons does what he did back then: He swings into action in behalf of what he calls student-athlete rights and the proposition that the innocent should not be punished for the transgressions of others.

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes losses of $546,613 and $706,246 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: DIGITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $113,000 and $562,000 for the latest quarter and the year-ago period, respectively; and the year-ago quarter also includes net from discontinued operations of $481,000.

title: REPUBLICANS ASSAIL CONTRACTS FOR CUOMO AIDE'S HUSBAND
description: Senate Republicans have called for an investigation into the awarding of almost $5 million in state contracts to the husband of a top Cuomo administration official.

title: Senate to Start Contempt Action Against Secord on Iran Accounts
description: The Senate decided today to begin contempt proceedings against Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force major general who is a principal figure in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Plush Prep
description: Call it trickle-down finance, if you will, but those luxury sky boxes that are a standard feature of pro stadiums have now reached the high school level. Not surprisingly, the scene is trend-setting California, where Village Christian High in Sun Valley, north of Los Angeles, has become what is believed to be the first high school in the nation to play copy the fat cat.

title: New York Police and Commissioner Ward Need Encouragement
description: To the Editor:

title: GATEWAY MEDICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-After a reversal of a tax credit of $24,198 for the quarter and a tax credit of $351,953 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-After an extraordinary tax credit of $558,629 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: FIBRONICS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The prior year results restated to reflect the acquisition of Spartacus Inc. in February 1986.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report on Wednesday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page, about speculation on Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona as Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, misstated Arizona's means of filling any Congressional vacancy. The seat is always filled by election, never by gubernatorial appointment.

title: MAGNETIC TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Shell Sells Hawaii Unit
description: The Shell Oil Company has agreed to sell its Hawaii operations to Pacific Resources Inc. for $32 million, Pacific Resources said. The sale, expected to be completed by Sept. 1, includes Shell's interest in 39 retail gasoline stations and four petroleum product terminals along with its marketing and distribution business.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: Benjamin Charny is a Soviet mathematician, 49 years old, who is desperately ill with cancer. He wants to join his brother, Leon, in the United States. Soviet officials have denied him permission to leave.

title: UNMASKED, HE MOVES TO STAGE AND TO SHELLEY
description: WHEN Eric Stoltz appeared on movie screens around the nation in John Hughes's new film, ''Some Kind of Wonderful,'' his sensitive, mobile face seemed perfect for Hughes-style teen-age dreams: wide, searching blue eyes, chiseled features, a handsomely cleft chin that made the lead female character's infatuation with him readily understandable.

title: SEARCHING FOR SIGNS OF SPRING'S PALETTE IN A WHITE-WALLED WORLD OF GALLERIES
description: TO the immigrant observer, the New York art scene is a matter of continuous, never-staling astonishment.

title: RHODEN UNCERTAIN FOR START IN OPENER
description: In the past, there was only the mere suggestion that Rick Rhoden was going to be the Yankees' starting pitcher on opening day April 6 in Detroit. But today, in comments that were almost off-handed, Manager Lou Piniella made it official.

title: TOXIC WASTE LAW FACING A HURDLE
description: When Californians approved a sweeping measure last fall restricting the disposal of toxic chemicals, proponents predicted that it would be the first shot in a new national environmental battle aimed at assuring the safety of drinking water.

title: Japanese Excitement in Paris
description: It is a great time for Japanese designers. Kenzo kicked off the week of fall and winter fashion openings Wednesday night with a colorful show that was lively without being crazy. Rei Kawakubo of Comme des Garcons showed the best collection of her career this morning, offering exciting, pure clothes in a low-keyed manner. Yohji Yamamoto followed with clothes that were also toned-down but had some jazzier details. Compared with Thierry Mugler's femme fatale collection shown later, the Japanese clothes looked modern and strong.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MARCH 20, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: CRAMER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After an extraordinary credit of $54,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: At the Finish, Ambassadors With 4 Legs
description: If there is some magical creature that can bring the Irish and English closer together, it was running here today on four legs.

title: Highway Bill Passes as Reagan Threatens a Veto
description: The victory that proponents of higher speed limits on Interstate highways have won in the House of Representatives was thrown into doubt today by President Reagan's announcement that he planned to veto the $87.9 billion highway bill to which the speed amendment is attached.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: Among themselves, European businessmen and financiers are quaking at the implications of the Wall Street financial scandals. For one thing, they are worried about a sudden loss of investor confidence if the scandals turn out to be even more widespread than it appears. The stock markets are high still, but prices are considered to represent a speculative bubble due in large part to what is now called the ''oil bonus,'' not to real growth.

title: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $161,000 and $464,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $66,000 and $226,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split declared in December 1986 and distributed in February 1987.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Fortress-America Myth
description: In the third century B.C., the Emperor Shih Huang Ti began building a wall along China's northwest border to seal off the Middle Kingdom from marauding nomads, and 500 years later Hadrian tried the same approach in England. A thousand years later, the same solution was invoked by the lords of medieval Europe to keep out bandits and armies. In this century, France built the Maginot Line along its border with Germany.

title: INTERDYNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: The year-ago first quarter loss is restated to include the September 1986 acquisition of Anthem Systems on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: In Memory of Dad
description: Payne Stewart, the knickered golfer who won last week's Bay Hill Classic in Orlando, Fla., has donated his $108,000 first prize to establish a house on the grounds of Florida Hospital for the relatives of cancer patients. Stewart said yesterday that he wanted to honor the memory of his father, William Louis, who died of cancer two years ago. ''He was an important part of my life,'' Stewart said. ''He introduced me to the game at 4, and for the next 24 years, he was my coach. But more importantly, he was my friend and inspiration.''

title: Showing Sensitivity to Pakistan
description: LEAD: Pretend you're a Pakistani official observing the battle developing in Congress over continuing military and economic aid to your country because Congress believes it is developing a nuclear device. What lesson would you have learned from recent American attitudes toward nuclear proliferation?

title: A BROKER WHO WENT TOO FAR
description: For years, Boyd L. Jefferies has stretched the boundaries of securities trading.

title: MODULAIRE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said that fourth-quarter results were reduced by the effect of the repeal of the investment tax credit.

title: TAX LAW USED TO DISCOURAGE WAREHOUSING
description: A coalition of tenants and city and state legislators yesterday proposed a new campaign to prevent landlords in New York City from intentionally keeping apartments vacant.

title: AT RIVERSIDE, EUPHONY OF BELLS
description: On Sunday afternoon at the Riverside Church, one of Manhattan's highest points, hundreds of bells will peal - some weighing tons, others only ounces.

title: SEMIFINALISTS REFLECT A SEASON
description: While the Midwest Regional is no tougher or weaker than any of the other three, it certainly is a puzzling bracket to figure. In a sense, this semifinal field of Indiana, Duke, Louisiana State and DePaul could be called a microcosm of the entire college basketball season itself: no dominant team, a predominance of outstanding guards and small forwards, and no one player who can singlehandedly carry his team to New Orleans.

title: N.H.L.
description: Bruins 6, North Stars 2: Charlie Simmer scored twice in a five-minute span of the second period as Boston prevented the visiting North Stars from jumping from fourth to second place in the Norris Division. Keith Crowder broke a 1-1 tie at 2 minutes 1 second of the second period with his 20th goal of the season before Simmer scored his 26th and 27th goals from close range, making the score 4-1 going into the third period. (AP) Kings 5, Flyers 2: In Philadelphia, Jean-Luc Robitaille scored twice in a four-goal second period to lead Los Angeles. Robitaille, who leads all N.H.L. rookies in goals with 39, gave the Kings a 3-1 lead when he fired a 30-foot wrist shot past Ron Hextall's left shoulder at 11:08.(AP) N.B.A. Bullets 110, Sonics 106: Terry Catledge had 25 points and 14 rebounds, and Jay Vincent added a season-high 29 points to lead Washington at home. Catledge had 12 points in the first quarter, as the Bullets opened a 37-7 lead.(AP) Golf Stephenson Overcomes Wind: Jan Stephenson fired a four-under-par 67 to take a two-stroke lead yesterday despite winds gusting to 35 miles an hour during the first round of the $200,000 L.P.G.A. Tucson Open. Deedee Roberts and Lauri Peterson shot three-under-par 69's and a seven-way tie developed for third. (AP) Mast Leads: Dick Mast, who has won more than 25 times on mini-tours but never finished higher than fifth in a PGA event, one-putted 10 times yesterday on the way to a 64 that gave him a one-shot lead in the first round of the $500,000 USF&G Classic in New Orleans. (AP) Barber Ahead: Miller Barber survived an up-and-down first round to fire a one-under-par 71, giving him a one-shot lead after 18 holes of a $300,000 seniors tournament in Indian Wells, Calif. Barber, 55, had five birdies and four bogeys on a windy day over the 6,240-yard Vintage Club Desert Course. One shot off the pace were Bobby Nichols, Bob Charles and Gary Player.(AP) Horse Racing Alioth Wins Again: Alioth took the lead after entering the stretch and went on to a 3 1/4-length victory in the $40,000 Greek Ship Handicap for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old son of Vigors-Bright Reflection carried 110 pounds under E. T. Baird while covering seven furlongs on the fast track in 1 minute 24 seconds. Feeling Gallant was a neck ahead of Royal Doulton. Alioth returned $9.80 for $2 as the second choice in the field of seven. Tennis Lloyd Trounces Bassett: Top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd needed only an hour and six minutes to blitz unseeded Carling Bassett, 6-0, 6-1 yesterday in the second round of the Virginia Slims of Dallas. Lloyd will meet unseeded Stephanie Rehe of Highland, Calif., today in the quarterfinals.(AP) McEnroe Wins: John McEnroe defeated Michiel Schapers, 6-4, 6-0, in a heated second-round match yesterday at the $315,000 A.B.N. World Tennis Tournament in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Afterward, Schapers threatened to punch McEnroe. McEnroe and Schapers exchanged words in the early part of the match when McEnroe said that the Dutch player was taking too much time between points. Chip Hooper, ranked No. 223 in the world, upset the defending champion, Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, 6-4, 6-4. (AP) Connors Edges Holmes: Top-seeded Jimmy Connors used a strong tiebreaker performance to finish off unseeded Greg Holmes, 6-2, 7-6 (7-2), in a second-round match at a $315,000 tennis tournament in Orlando, Fla. Connors raced to a 3-0 lead in the tie-breaker, taking advantage of three consecutive backhand errors by Holmes. (AP) Swimming Texas Women Lead: Betsy Mitchell was part of three first-place finishes to lead Texas in its bid for a fourth consecutive N.C.A.A. Division I women's swimming and diving championship. Mitchell finished first in the 200-yard individual medley, started the Texas 200-yard medley relay team toward an N.C.A.A. record, and anchored the winning 800-yard freestyle relay team in competition at the Indiana University Natatorium in Indianapolis.(AP)

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss The latest periods' results include a gain of about $1.8 million from the sale of investment property. The year-ago periods' results include a $1,217,000 charge from equity in the net loss of National Beverage Corp.

title: MAUNA LOA MACADAMIA PARTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings are in units and the partnership was formed last April.

title: Guinness Action Against Directors
description: Guinness P.L.C., the British-Irish brewing company, said it had begun legal action against its former chairman, Ernest Saunders, and another director to recover $:5.2 million, or $8.3 million, paid out during a takeover battle last year. A company statement also said Guinness intended to seek the dismissal of Mr. Saunders and the director, Thomas Ward, an American lawyer, at the company's annual meeting May 27.

title: House Gets Bill to Overhaul Welfare
description: The Democratic leadership of the House of Representatives today offered legislation to overhaul the nation's main cash welfare program by increasing benefits and creating new incentives for poor people to take jobs.

title: 10,000 Jews Expected To Leave Soviet in '87
description: A senior Soviet official said today that he expected 10,000 to 12,000 Jews to emigrate this year, more than 10 times the number of those allowed to emigrate in 1986.

title: COMEDY AT NEW MUSEUM
