description: Danitra Vance, Ethyl Eichelberger and Pat Oleszko are among those to take part in a comedy showcase tonight at 8:45 at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, between Prince and Houston Streets. Also appearing will be Danny Mydlack, an accordion player, and the duo called Dancenoise, which features Anne Iobst and Lucy Sexton. Admission is $4. Information: 219-1222.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: UP 'TIL NOW: A Memoir. By Eugene McCarthy. 273 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

title: BEAUX ARTS TRIO
description: The Beaux Arts Trio will play works by Haydn, Ravel and Brahms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tonight and tomorrow night at 8 o'clock. Admission is $15; information: 570-3949.

title: Few Sparks Fly at Conference as President Keeps His Balance
description: All the panoply of a great event was there in the beginning - the sense of anticipation, the sparkling chandeliers, the President striding briskly out of the shadows and into the spotlight. Cameras clicked like a batch of crickets on a summer night.

title: 2 Join to Make Magnets
description: The TDK Corporation, the leading Japanese producer of magnetic recording tape, and the Allen-Bradley Company announced a joint venture today for the production, marketing and sale of magnets for electronic goods.

title: Official Upheld At Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation announced yesterday that a Defense Department appeals board had unanimously ruled that Lester Crown, executive vice president of the company and a member of its board, could keep his top-level security clearance.

title: FEDERAL HOME LOAN MORTAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $10 million.

title: Coach Is Dismissed
description: Mike Hanks, who refused to resign as South Alabama's basketball coach with two years remaining in his contract and refused other options offered by the school, was dismissed by Joe Gottfried, the school's athletic director. Hanks, 34 years old, was in the third year of a five-year contract. In Hanks's three seasons at South Alabama his teams finished 15-13, 16-16 and 14-14. The former Maryland basketball coach, Lefty Driesell, told The Mobile Register that he would ''investigate'' any offer from the school, but George Smith, a spokesman for South Alabama, said neither Driesell nor any other coach had been contacted.

title: Justice Dept. Voicing Doubt Over Prosecutor Law
description: A senior Justice Department official testified at a Senate hearing today that the department had ''grave doubts'' about the constitutionality of the law on special prosecutors and that he believed that the law was unconstitutional.

title: GUITARISTS' TRIOS
description: John Abercrombie and Jack Wilkins, guitarists, are each leading trios in a double bill through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight today and tomorrow, 8 and 10 P.M. Sunday; there is a $12.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: BIAGGI SAYS HE ACCEPTED VACATION FROM ESPOSITO OUT OF FRIENDSHIP
description: Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx, indicted on charges of bribery, fraud and conspiracy, acknowledged today that he had accepted a paid vacation from Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader. But he stressed that there was ''no quid pro quo.''

title: FLEET FACES CONNECTICUT DIVESTITURE
description: One day after announcing a $1.3 billion merger with the Norstar Bancorporation of Albany, the Fleet Financial Group said yesterday that it might have to sell its banking operation in Connecticut because of that state's banking law.

title: KEY CHANGES ARE SEEN FOR LANDMARKS PANEL
description: The composition of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, which oversees nearly 15,000 properties in New York City, will undergo a dramatic change because 6 of its 11 members must be replaced by Mayor Koch.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Carmen McRae, Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street (758-2272). The veteran jazz singer's formidable intelligence is matched by an impeccable taste in songs and a way of bending phrases and shading notes that makes whatever she touches a penetrating exploration of life's more bitter truths. Full of autobiographical overtones, her tough-tender ''Sophisticated Lady'' is a dried-eyed, moving reflection on the pleasures and perils of the jazz life. Her trio - Earl Gunnison on piano, Mark Pulice on drums and Scott Colley on bass - offers sturdy, fluent support. Shows are tonight and tomorrow at 9 and 11. There is a $25 cover charge and a two-drink minimum.

title: NEW TRADE CHARGES AGAINST JAPAN
description: The Reagan Administration's top trade officials have accused Japan of backing away from commitments in telecommunications and charged that the actions undercut the process for resolving trade issues.

title: San Francisco Agrees to Pay Rise for Women
description: This city has agreed to pay $35.4 million in special raises to women and members of minority groups who have been paid less than men in jobs of comparable worth. These men are predominantly white, although some are members of minority groups.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: The year-ago quarter and year results include a gain on the disposal of assets of $1,317,000.

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $29,253,000 on early retirement of debt for both the quarter and year; and a charge of $14,148,000 in connection with an accounting change for the year; and both the quarter and year is also after a pre-tax loss of $2.2 million on the sale of John Wanamaker and a charge of $25 million in connection with Carter Hawley's recapitalization program. c-Net income d-After a pre-tax loss of $2,450,000 on the sale of Holt Renfrew & Co. for both the quarter and year.

title: Japan Seeks Chip-Output Cut
description: Japanese chip makers will be asked to cut output further in an effort to save a semiconductor pact with the United States, officials of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

description: b-Includes $147,100 and $262,000 in gains on the sale of securities for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes $437,800 and $450,600 in gains on the sale of securities for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Syria Promises 'Punishment' if Hostages Are Killed
description: Syria has served notice that its 7,000 soldiers deployed here will mete out ''the severest punishment'' if any of the 25 foreigners held hostage in Lebanon are killed, a police official said today.

title: Who Says Old People Have to Move Over; Laws Against It
description: To the Editor:

title: MERITS OF FAIRNESS DOCTRINE DEBATED BY BROADCASTERS
description: The chairman of a Senate communications subcommittee wants to put the force of law behind the Fairness Doctrine, which requires radio and television broadcasters to cover all sides of a controversy.

title: Emerson Gets Thom McAn
description: Emerson Lane Fortuna, a six-year-old Boston firm, has stepped up to the Thom McAn Shoe Company account. The agency said the budget is $10 million.

title: READING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $2,319,000 and $2,284,000 from equity in the loss of El Paso Refining Co. for both periods, and for the quarter includes a special dividend from Trailer Train of $4.7 million, and for the year includes income from the sale of its investment in Trailer Train Co. back to that company for $3.5 million. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,054,000.

title: CAROLINA PREVAILS: GEORGETOWN GAINS
description: They believed, and they worked, and they pushed the North Carolina Tar Heels to the point where the smallest mistake could create the opportunity for Notre Dame to steal the East Regional semifinal game of the national collegiate basketball tournament.

title: PRISCILLA HERDMAN
description: Priscilla Herdman, a folk singer, will perform tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Peoples' Voice Cafe, 133 West Fourth Street. Tickets are $5. Information: (718)-426-2183.

title: S.M.U. Alumnus Sues Group
description: A Southern Methodist University alumnus filed a lawsuit against the N.C.A.A. today, charging that the association had violated civil rights of the scandal-plagued school's present and former students.

title: INTERACTIVE TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
LAYOFFS DISRUPT STABLE LIVES OF L.I. FAMILIES
description: Gerard Mennona was on the telephone, giving a visitor directions to his family's large Colonial-style house here. ''We're the house at the end of the corner, the one with the 'For Sale' sign on the lawn,'' he said.

title: BACH ORGAN WORKS
description: Joan Lippincott, the head of the organ department at Westminster Choir College, will play works by Bach, Durufle, Liszt and others at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and 50th Street, Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock. Admission is free. Information: 751-1616.

title: PRETORIA BLAMES U.S. FOR ISRAELI MOVE
description: South Africa's Foreign Minister blamed the United States today for Israel's decision to ban new military contracts with Pretoria and investigate severing other links.

title: The President, Chastened but Unrepentant, Offers Little New in His News Conference
description: President Reagan broke little new ground tonight in his first news conference since before Thanksgiving, and he showed himself still unable to give anything approaching a clear and complete account of how the Iran-contra affair developed.

title: MONY REAL ESTATE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Senate Democrat May Seek to Curb 1988 ABM Research Spending
description: A Democratic Senator who opposes early deployment of missile defenses in space said today that he might try to prohibit any spending in 1988 on research that would violate a strict interpretation of the 1972 ABM treaty limiting tests of such technologies.

title: TELEQUEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $144,000 and $258,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively. c-Net income

title: Long Pretoria Emergency Is Seen
description: A pro-Government newspaper here reported today that the national state of emergency, now nine months old, might continue for two or three years more.

title: WEEKEND OF SECOND CHANCE FOR HOPEFULS
description: A round of important preps for the Kentucky Derby begins Saturday, and it will be a weekend of searching for redemption. Gulch, Temperate Sil, Alysheba, Bet Twice and Conquistarose, all star 2-year-olds from flashy outfits but all recent losers as 3-year-olds, will be trying to get their campaigns back on track in New York, Florida and California.

title: TIE-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $312,000 and $1,179,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; a pretax loss of $45,009,000 and $55,470,000, for the quarter and year, respectively, which included a writedown of inventory and restructuring charges amounting to $37,097,000 and $37,997,000, and a tax provision of $940,000 and $3,094,000 for the same periods, respectively; the year also includes net of $1,543,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes a pretax loss of $23,994,000 and $102,322,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, which included a writedown of inventory, restructuring charges and loss on the sale of a division amounting to $13,000,000 and $61,000,000 and a tax benefit of $3,036,000 and $28,513,000 for the same periods, respectively; the quarter also includes losses from discontinued operations of $3,354,000 and the year includes a loss of $2,859,000 from discontinued operations.

title: For More - and Better - Teachers
description: The education reform movement began with efforts to increase school budgets and set stricter standards for students. Now it is sharpening its focus on teachers. The basic problem is to find a million teachers to meet the shortage projected over the next five years. Recruiting superior people will require more than higher salaries and better health insurance plans. In fact the recruiting crisis presents an unusual opportunity to redefine teaching and make it a more rewarding pursuit.

title: U.S. Ships in Strike Distance Of Iranian Missiles in the Gulf
description: The United States has moved warships led by the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk into the Arabian Sea, where they are within striking range of newly emplaced Iranian missiles that threaten the entrance to the Persian Gulf, Pentagon officials said today.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: THE influence of Anthony Solomon, which once ranged over such territory as the nation's money supply and interest rates, has spread to the art world of New York.

title: HERRINGTON URGES LIMIT IN OIL DEPLETION PLAN
description: Energy Secretary John S. Herrington said today that the restoration of the oil depletion allowance to major companies should be confined to new production, a restriction that would make it relatively inexpensive to the Treasury.

title: Jackson Condemns 'Economic Violence' as He Opens Headquarters in Iowa
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, calling for aid to farmers and other victims of what he termed ''economic violence,'' today began his effort to explore a possible second race for the Presidency in the friendly embrace of this small town in rural Iowa.

title: FLEXWATT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
5 VIEWS OF IMMIGRANT LIVES
description: The American experience is the immigrant experience, of course; we know that already. Nonetheless, ''The American Promise: Wanting It All,'' on Channel 4 at 9:30 P.M. tomorrow, still has something to say. It makes up an attractive 30 minutes. The program, one of a series, as the host, John Chancellor, says, about ''you and me and our country,'' looks at members of five immigrant families - Russian, Mexican, Japanese, Vietnamese and Armenian. They all have points in common.

title: Thai Officials Deny Violating the Rights Of Laos Tribesmen
description: Thai officials denied today that they violated the rights of Hmong tribesmen by forcing them to return to Communist-ruled Laos, as the United States has asserted.

title: DINING OUT GUIDE: 3-STAR MULTINATIONAL
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. The original date of publication is given. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. THE FOUR SEASONS, 99 East 52d Street (754-9494) - (Nov. 22, 1985) Even more impressive than its longevity (more than 25 years) is how this grand vessel of luxury has managed to maintain its high standards of food quality and service over the years. The palatial scale affords privacy at well-spaced tables - the glittering Pool Room is romantic and plush with a lavish menu, while the Grill Room has a masculine tone and a lean and spirited menu. In the Pool Room, for an appetizer, the terrines are consistently superior; or you might try the Scottish smoked salmon, or crisped shrimp filled with mustard fruits. Entree options are duck au poivre, which is two legs and a breast with crisp skin, apple and red cabbage; medallions of lamb with an eggplant timbale, and fillet of salmon with wild mushrooms. You may want to save room for the chocolate velvet, a flourless Swiss-chocolate cake. Entrees $35 to $40. Pool Room:

title: Women See Rise in Job Bias
description: Women's perception of job discrimination has grown despite recent improvements in their prospects for employment but men's opinions of the problem have not changed significantly, according to a recent Gallup Poll.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday gave an incorrect location for a concert at 8 tonight by Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonic. The concert, in the Meet the Moderns series, will take place at Cooper Union, not at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Gencorp's Bidders Plan RKO Selloffs
description: An investor group attempting a hostile $2.2 billion takeover of Gencorp Inc. said yesterday that, if it won, it would sell all broadcasting properties owned by Gencorp's subsidiary RKO General Inc.

title: Why Cuomo Convention Draft Is Unlikely
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Includes loss from an extraordinary item of $6,900,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes a gain of an extraordinary item of $9,861,000, which includes utilization of tax credits. c-Net income d-Includes extraordinary items of $7,587,000 and $35,482,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, which include utilization of tax credits; also includes income from discontinued operations, net of income taxes, of $6,572,000 and $12,572,000 for the same periods, respectively. Latest quarter and year periods are equal to 14 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively.

description: b-Includes a gain of $9.7 million, or 11 cents a share, and $16.1 million, or 18 cents a share, from the sale of assets for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively, which in the year- ago period is offset partially by a restructuring provision of $22.5 million pretax. Fiscal 1986 results have been restated to include the effect of adopting SFAS No. 87 relating to pension costs. Share earnings for fiscal 1986 have been restated to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split, effective Nov. 30, 1986.

title: FEMINISM CONFERENCE
description: Princeton University's Program in Women's Studies will present a day-long conference, ''Feminism and Its Translations,'' on March 28 at the university's Woodrow Wilson School in Princeton, N.J. The program, which begins at 9 A.M. and ends at 6 P.M., includes workshops and panels on such themes as women and political movements, motherhood and reproductive technology, feminist research outside the academy, and men, feminism and women's studies. Admission to the conference, which is open to the public, is $5 to $15 in advance and $10 to $20 at the door. Information: (609) 452-5430.

title: BRIDGEPORT ACTS TO KEEP GUNS OUT OF SCHOOLS
description: City officials here met today with a Justice Department official to try to deal with what they said was a growing problem of guns in the schools. The meeting came two days after two seventh graders were charged in separate incidents with carrying loaded handguns to school.

title: WHAT'S GOOD FOR PARTY CIRCUIT IS GOOD FOR CORPORATIONS
description: If all the shrimp consumed each month at Washington parties were laid on line, head to tail, they probably would stretch from the Capitol to the White House. And maybe farther.

title: GOODMARK FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 22
FAST FORWARD PROVIDES EDGE
description: The Boston College hockey team has so many good forwards that if the names and numbers came off their jerseys, it might be hard to distinguish Craig Janney from Ken Hodge, Dan Shea, Kevin Stevens or Tim Sweeney.

description: b-After gains from sale of investments of $887,000 for the latest year and $304,000 for 1985.

LOUIS DEBROGLIE, FRENCH PHYSICIST, WON '29 NOBEL FOR WAVE THEORY
description: Louis de Broglie, a French physicist who won the 1929 Nobel Prize for work in wave mechanics, died Thursday at a hospital in Paris, his relatives announced. He was 94 years old.

MAINE PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $1,617,192 and $2,560,866 for the quarter and year, respectively, which reflects a loss on the partial writeoff of Seabrook units 1 and 2 and also includes a tax credit for both periods. c-Net losses and includes extraordinary charges of $9,299,350 and $10,105,936 for the quarter and year, respectively. The year-ago results are restated to recognize additional tax benefits applicable to the company's extraordinary loss arising from the partial writeoff of its investment in Seabrook unit 1.

title: ON THE STREETS: HELPING ADDICTS COMBAT AIDS
description: One day this week, Barry Peterson, a heroin addict with a $100-a-day habit, went looking for Greg Howard in Military Park. A friend had said: ''Come to the park. Ask for Greg Howard. You can get a coupon.''

title: TWO STATES IN OFFERING
description: Texas and Massachusetts offered tax-exempt general obligation bonds yesterday totaling $300 million after Salomon Brothers won both issues in competitive bidding as sole or lead underwriter.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 20, 1987
description: The Scandal on Wall Street Boyd L. Jefferies agreed to plead guilty to two felony counts that could send him to prison for 10 years. The prominent broker, the latest Wall Street executive snared by a Federal investigation, resigned as chief executive of Jefferies & Company of Los Angeles and will be barred from the securities business for five years. According to S.E.C. charges, Mr. Jefferies artificially lifted the price of a stock by making heavy purchases just before a large new offering was sold to the public. In a second instance, the Government said he created bogus stock transactions that allowed Ivan F. Boesky's securities firm to operate with less capital on hand than required. [ Page A1. ]

title: BOBBY PREVITE
description: Bobby Previte, a drummer and composer, will lead a quintet tomorrow at Roulette, at 228 West Broadway, at White Street (219-8242) in TriBeCa. On Sunday, Tom Johnson, a minimalist composer, will play ''Chord Catalogue,'' the 8,178 chords possible in one octave. Concerts begin at 9 P.M.; admission is $5.

title: HOSPITAL STAFFING SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a tax credit of $33,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I would not go down that same road again.'' - President Reagan. [ A1:6. ]

title: Mexico Equity To Build Hotels
description: The American Express Bank Ltd., a unit of the American Express Company, has reached an agreement with Mexico and certain Mexican companies to convert $100 million of existing debt into equity. The equity will be used to finance the construction of 3,000 hotel rooms.

title: REALTY SOUTH INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split Feb. 23. The company commenced operations in May 1985. The company said that for the eight months ended Dec. 31, 1985, it reported net of $1,359,273, or 82 cents a share, on revenue of $1,494,304.

title: DANCE: AILEY'S 'STREAMS' AND 'BASIC STRATEGIES IV'
description: THE Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble offered an interesting mix of dances Tuesday at the Theater of the Riverside Church. There was the pure-dance choreography of Mr. Ailey's ''Streams.'' Keith Lee provided an impassioned response to apartheid in South Africa. And Blondell Cummings offered a stylish and touching dance about living and remembering.

title: BROKERAGE STOCKS VIEWED
description: STOCK MARKET volume may be running at record levels, but the numbers and rising revenues are not being fully reflected by the share prices of the larger retail brokerage houses. While the stocks of the big brokerage houses have been doing well this year, many analysts regard them as undervalued and underperforming the market as a whole.

title: MEESE SAYS U.S. WILL SUPPORT DRUG TESTS FOR NEW TEACHERS
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that the Justice Department supported mandatory drug testing for teachers being considered for employment.

title: New Phase To Trading Inquiry
description: A few defense lawyers - mostly with clients facing similar charges -worried yesterday that the guilty pleas by Boyd L. Jefferies mark a new phase in the investigation into stock-trading practices. For as Mr. Jefferies himself emphasized, he was not part of the insider-trading schemes that have been the main focus of the Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry.

title: Private Clubs Offer Something Distinct
description: To the Editor:

title: SYRACUSE ROLLS; PROVIDENCE SHOCKS ALABAMA, 103-82
description: In and around central New York State, the play will be known as The Block. Perhaps it will forever be known that way, should Derrick Coleman's moment eventually open the way for Syracuse to return to the Final Four of the national collegiate basketball tournament for the first time since 1975.

title: BRIDGE: LEAGUE IN JERSEY TO OFFER INTRODUCTION TO DUPLICATE
description: A nonswimmer who is considering taking the plunge is rather like a rubber-bridge player thinking about trying duplicate: he is slightly nervous and in need of guidance.

title: RUTGERS AND TEXAS GAIN EAST FINAL
description: Sue Wicks scored 33 points and grabbed 13 rebound to lead sixth-ranked Rutgers to a 75-60 victory over No. 13 North Carolina State tonight in the semifinals of the women's National Collegiate Athletic Association East Regional tournament.

title: TRUSTEE TO OVERSEE 2 UNIONS
description: A former Federal prosecutor was named yesterday as the trustee to supervise two construction unions that the Government accused of falling under the influence of the Mafia. The trustee, Eugene Anderson, is empowered to oversee the affairs of the two unions, Local 6A and the District Council of Cement and Concrete Workers in New York City. Mr. Anderson was appointed by Judge Vincent L. Broderick in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
KMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $398,000 for the latest year and $455,000 for the prior year. The prior year net also includes $29,000 from minority interest in earnings of consolidated subsidiaries.

title: WARREN CHIASSON
description: Warren Chiasson, a vibraphonist, will lead a group tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M., midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: ACADEMY INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $1,231,000 and $3,338,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and the year also includes a loss from discontinued operations of $921,000. c-Net loss d-After capital gains of $2,066,000 and $2,145,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and losses from discontinued operations of $473,000 for the quarter and $1,137,000 for the year.

title: Official To Leave A.T.&T.
description: James D. Edwards, a central figure in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's push into the computer business, said yesterday that he was leaving A.T.&T. to run a small company called Telwatch Inc.

title: HANOVER COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $596,000 for the quarter and $2,173,000 for the 9 months. The losses in the latest quarter and 9 months are attributable to the use of the equity method of accounting of a real estate transaction. The 9 months' loss also includes charges from the sale of marketable securities at a loss, from legal charges, and other non- recurring charges.

title: Short Interest on Big Board Up by 2.5% in Month
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 11.2 million shares, or 2.5 percent, in the month ended March 13, to 459.4 million shares. The record of 469.1 million shares was set on Nov. 14, 1986. The short interest for the period a year earlier was 318.6 million shares.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: UPON entering East, the handsome, countrified Japanese restaurant on the Upper East Side, you are stopped at an alcove of little wooden lockers and asked to remove your shoes. You are then ushered into the dining room, which has two sections of low-slung tables separated by a center aisle that is as shiny as a new bowling lane from constant sock buffing. Under each communal table is a knee-deep pit for those who consider sitting in a lotus position for two hours about as relaxing as doing one-arm pushups.

title: BIL BAIRD, CREATOR OF PUPPETS, IS DEAD
description: Bil Baird, the puppeteer who enchanted millions of all ages with his ''little wooden ones'' and trained a generation of other gifted puppeteers, particularly the Muppets' creator, Jim Henson, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: United Press International Names Ben Cason as Editor
description: Ben Cason, who joined United Press International two months ago, was named editor of the news agency Monday by the agency's president, Milton R. Benjamin.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: IT will never make anybody's list of Manhattan's 10 chicquest restaurants, nor will you see it mentioned in the society columns accompanied by photographs of insouciant celebrities clinking glasses and pecking cheeks. La Mediterranee, on Second Avenue at 50th Street, is about as voguish as spats - but considerably more comfortable. Quite simply, it is a wonderfully homey and neighborly spot that gives you a warm feeling upon entering - all timber and stucco with faux wooden shutters, colorful murals of France and comfortable banquettes.

title: RISKING ONE'S JOB
description: Concern seems to be mounting for employees in Government or private industry who risk their careers to publicize health and safety hazards, fraud or other misconduct.

title: TWO CLASSICS BY GERSHWIN IN BROOKLYN
description: ECSTATIC is the only word to describe Michael Tilson Thomas's enthusiasm for ''Of Thee I Sing'' and ''Let 'Em Eat Cake,'' the early 30's Gershwin musicals he is conducting in concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this weekend.

title: ROCKWOOD HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $900,000 and $7,099,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and also includes tax credits of $896,000 and $1,431,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Net loss and includes capital gains of $127,000 and $1,030,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Emergency Relief
description: Four members of the Mets assisted paramedics in St. Petersburg, Fla., last night in an attempt to save a heart attack victim in a helicopter airlift from the infield just before the Mets played the Chicago White Sox. As the teams were taking the field for the exhibition game, a spectator identified as Walter Roskosky of St. Petersburg, 46 years old, sitting next to the Mets' dugout in Al Lang Stadium, suffered cardiac arrest. City paramedics tried to revive him, then decided to take him to the hospital. But they believed it would be too difficult to carry him by stretcher through the grandstand, so they called for a helicopter from the nearby Bayfront Medical Center. It landed a few minutes later on the infield grass near the pitcher's mound. ''We needed help to lift the stretcher over the dugout roof to the ground,'' said Steve LeCroy, one of the paramedics. ''So we asked for the taller Mets to help.'' The appeal got an immediate response from Darryl Strawberry, Gary Carter, Ed Hearn and Terry Blocker. Roskosky was listed in critical condition.

title: DEP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
For Big Sizes, a Little Glitter
description: Lane Bryant will return to Fifth Avenue next Thursday after a year's absence, with a sleek new shape and jazzy clothes to match.

title: DOW NEARS 2,300 WITH 12.64 RISE
description: The ''triple witching hour'' loomed large over the stock market yesterday, but the pressure eased enough to permit the Dow Jones industrial average to close within a point of 2,300.

title: Guru, Focus of Inquiry, Takes Case to White House
description: A West Virginia Hare Krishna leader who is the focus of investigations into murder, child abuse and drug smuggling was expelled from the Krishna movement Wednesday, hours after meeting with a White House official to complain that he was being persecuted by the authorities.

title: BELVEDERE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After net realized investment gains of $2,274,000 for the latest year and $1,468,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TIMBERLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EWING IS INJURED IN KNICKS' VICTORY
description: Injuries that have plagued the Knicks for the last three seasons struck home again last night. This time they lost Patrick Ewing, the $30-million center, who suffered a sprained left knee, the severity of which will be determined today, following X-rays at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: INERTIA DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $87,449 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: People
description: * James Handloser has been promoted to senior vice president and group creative head at Ally Gargano/ MCA Advertising Ltd.

title: U.N. TO KEEP ITS FILES ON NAZI WAR CRIMES CLOSED
description: The former members of the United Nations War Crimes Commission have rejected an Israeli request that the commission's files on Nazi war criminals be opened to the public, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: THE DANCE: 'BUGAKU' BY HARLEM COMPANY
description: THE Dance Theater of Harlem has revived George Balanchine's ''Bugaku'' for its current season at Aaron Davis Hall of City College, at 134th Street and Convent Avenue. Like the other ballets on its latest program, it is a work that shows off the company to brilliant advantage.

title: Democrats on House Panel Vote Savings of $8 Billion on Military
description: The Democrats on the House Budget Committee, with Republican members refusing to participate, today approved $8 billion in savings in the 1988 military budget, leaving it only $6 billion over this year's level.

title: ISRAEL PARLAIMENT HEARS PLAN ON PRETORIA
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres formally presented to Parliament today the Cabinet's decision to bar any new military sales contracts with South Africa and generally to reduce ties with Pretoria.

title: Who Says Old People Have to Move Over; 'Don't Save Me Again'
description: To the Editor:

title: Farm Exports in Black
description: To the Editor:

title: A FIGHT ON REDUCING THE OFFICER CORPS
description: To save money, Congress decreed last year that the military officer corps would be reduced. To foster unity, it decreed that officers aspiring to be generals or admirals should first serve on a joint staff with officers of other services.

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes other income of $2,041,000 from the reversal of a tax liability, due to the termination of a pension plan related to the acquisition of Struthers-Dunn Inc.

title: JAPAN PLAN FOR 3D WORLD DEBT
description: In a new approach to handling third world loans, 28 Japanese banks announced today that they had formed a company to buy their outstanding loans to Latin American countries.

title: Transcript of President's News Conference
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Executive at Gap Named President
description: Millard S. Drexler, who started his career as a teen-ager working part-time in New York's garment district, has been named president of The Gap Inc., the fast-growing California-based retailer of jeans and casual clothing.

title: SYRACUSE ROLLS; PROVIDENCE SHOCKS ALABAMA, 103-82
description: No one can dispute the impact of the 3-point shot on college basketball this season. But perhaps no team has taken advantage of the new stripe on the floor more than the Providence Friars. Tonight they used it to achieve one of the most stunning upsets of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Comings and Goings
description: William Andrews, the running back who returned to the Atlanta Falcons last season after surgery on his left knee, underwent arthroscopic surgery to remove a bone chip from his right knee, and the team said he was not expected to miss the team's mini-camp in May. . . . Randy White, the Dallas Cowboys' linebacker who was arrested Wednesday night in North Dallas on a charge of driving while intoxicated, refused to take a breath test and was released early yesterday morning after posting a $200 bond, according to the police. . . . With Al Trautwig as commentator, ABC-TV will begin broadcasting a weekly late-night sports show on June 1 that will air every Monday night from midnight to 1 A.M.

title: Salvadoran Official's Home Raided by Unknown Gunmen
description: Unknown assailants using machine guns and rockets attacked the house of the head of the Salvadoran congress, officials said today.

title: MAN WOUNDS 2 AND KILLS A HOSTAGE AND HIMSELF
description: A man wrested a gun from a police officer and took several people hostage yesterday afternoon in a Brick Township, N.J., furniture store, where he killed a salesman and wounded a former girlfriend before shooting himself to death, the authorities said.

title: AUCTIONS
description: FROM now through Easter, while New York auction houses are relatively quiet, auctiongoers have a choice of traveling, telephoning or sending letters in order to place bids at sales elsewhere. Several galleries in San Francisco, London and Hyannis, Mass., report that auctions scheduled over the next few weeks are attracting an unusually strong response from collectors and dealers.

title: COORS BEER TAKES ON NEW YORK
description: THE Adolph Coors Company of Golden, Colo., in a move that must have been long awaited by someone, will be bringing its beer to New York market and New Jersey at the end of the month - to the accompaniment of $25 million worth of promotion.

title: MAGADAN'S AILMENT PERSISTS
description: Dave Magadan, the rookie third baseman who is rated perhaps the best prospect on the Mets, flew to New York today for hospital treatment of a persistent infection of the lymph nodes under his right arm.

title: INFORMATION SOLUTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CAROLINA PREVAILS; GEORGETOWN GAINS
description: There were days when the Hoyas played the kind of basketball that made them the nation's most feared team. These days, they are more subtle. They simply drain the opposition of its will to win.

title: Riding Lesson
description: One recent morning, as the Eighth Avenue bus waddled uptown, the scene inside was more or less what it always is at 9 o'clock. The passengers, swaddled in coats and scarves, were staring moodily out the window. Or at a newspaper. Or at their fingernails.

title: The U.N. Today: March 20, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: TRUMP PLANS HOUSING FOR ATLANTIC CITY LAND
description: Donald J. Trump made a strong commitment today to the development of much-needed housing here, including homes for families of low and moderate incomes.

title: AMRE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
No Mandate, No Legitimate Power
description: To appreciate the economic and political crisis afflicting Brazil, recall recent history, and the folly of compromising on democracy. The exercise perhaps also offers lessons for South Korea, now planning its own transition from military to democratic rule. As both states negotiate that rare and difficult passage, their leaders require the strengths that derive only from democratic mandates.

title: Iowa Wrestlers Set Back
description: Iowa, trying for a record 10th consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championship, suffered two second-round setbacks tonight before an unseeded 158-pounder, John Heffernan, pulled off the upset of the day.

title: Swissair Orders 6 MD-11's
description: Swissair dealt a blow to Europe's Airbus consortium today by announcing a $780 million order for six MD-11 long-haul passenger aircraft made by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

title: 'PYGMALION' AT MARYMOUNT
description: Concert Royal and the New York Baroque Dance Company will present two one-act opera-ballets, Handel's ''Terpsicore'' and Rameau's ''Pygmalion'' at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street tonight and tomorrow night at 8. James Richman is the music director and Catherine Turocy the choreographer; the performance is based on mid-18th-century sources. The cast includes Ann Monoyios, Frank Kelley, Stephen Rickards, Camille King and Julia Davidson. Tickets are $15 and $20. The number for information is 279-4200.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $7,042,000 and includes a pretax charge of $19,475,000 related to a recapitalization program. c-Net income and includes a loss of $1,350,000 from discontinued operations, an extraordinary gain of $6,734,000 and pretax gain of $7,167,000 on sales of land and a product line.

title: BROADWAY
description: THE Roundabout Theater Company is celebrating its coming-of-age 21st birthday this year with a nice coup: the 20th-anniversary production of ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead.'' And the Tony Award-winning play by Tom Stoppard is only part of the news. The rest is in the cast, with a trio of stars named John Wood and John Rubinstein, both Tony winners, and Stephen Lang, who was featured in the recent Broadway production of ''Death of a Salesman.''

title: U.S. Priest, Freed From Transkei, Tells of Torture
description: A Roman Catholic priest from the United States who was detained in South Africa's so-called homeland of Transkei for nearly three months without trial, and who said he was tortured, was released last week.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about the Environmental Protection Agency's program for financing asbestos removal in schools omitted a reason some funds will not be distributed until mid-June. The E.P.A. began the lengthy application process only after March 15, when a deadline expired without Congressional action on an Adminstration attempt to rescind the funds.

title: 'SLEEPWALK,' FAIRY TALES IN REAL LIFE
description: WHEN Chinese fairy tales impinge on the life of Nicole, a young woman in downtown New York, several things happen: her sexy French roommate becomes bald; her finger begins to bleed; an Oriental woman about to unravel these mysteries is killed. Nicole's half-Chinese son, a wise child, thinks the whole thing smells like almonds. Sara Driver's lyrical, witty ''Sleepwalk'' has the illogical sense of a dream, backed by the texture of everyday life. In her first feature, Ms. Driver blithely absorbs influences - from chiaroscuro to Surrealism to performance art - and spins them into her own vibrant, original style.

title: RETIRED REYNOLDS CHIEF TO HEAD RJR NABISCO
description: In a surprise move, J. Paul Sticht, a former top executive at R.J. Reynolds Industries, was brought out of retirement yesterday and nominated to be chairman of RJR Nabisco.

title: AERO SERVICES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest first quarter loss includes $9,325,000 in revenue from the nine Beckett aviation fixed-based operations acquired in September 1985, but year-ago first quarter net does not include about $8.3 million in revenue from Beckett because reporting procedures required Beckett operations to be accounted for on an equity basis.

title: AMERICAN PHYSICIANS SERVICE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: FILM: WHOOPI GOLDBERG IN 'BURGLAR'
description: THE further the screen version of ''The Color Purple'' recedes into history, the better it looks, especially Steven Spielberg's presentation of Whoopi Goldberg, the star of her first film in what became an Oscar-nominated performance.

title: In Salvador Village, Can There Be Peace of Mind?
description: There are places in countries such as this one where war, state terror and fragile recovery have withered the public will to remember, places that stand apart and touch a nerve in the national character.

title: ADMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: ANIMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
OPERA: 'I DUE LITIGANTI,' AN 18TH-CENTURY STORY
description: MOZART'S great operatic decade fell 200 years ago, and though hardly any operas but Mozart's own survived it, a handful of others are known to us by name either because Mozart wrote arias to be inserted into them or because of a little inside joke in ''Don Giovanni.'' At the Don's party, the orchestra strikes up bits from rival operas popular in Vienna. One is ''Una Cosa Rara,'' which was exhumed for a fuller look by the Vineyard Opera last year. Last weekend, in its tiny theater on 26th Street, the company turned to the other, Giuseppe Sarti's ''Fra i Due Litiganti il Terzo Gode'' (''Between Two Contestants, the Third Wins'').

title: Texaco Requests New Pennzoil Trial
description: Texaco Inc. is asking an appeals court to order a new trial in its litigation with the Pennzoil Company, contending that Pennzoil did not comply with the court's order involving a multibillion-dollar judgment against Texaco. A motion filed by Texaco contends Pennzoil did not properly file a reply to the First Texas Court of Appeals ruling that reduced damages in the suit. Pennzoil's lead attorney, Joseph Jamail Jr., said the filing had been proper.

title: FOUR DIVAS SHARE THE MET SPOTLIGHT IN 'CARMELITES'
description: ''DIALOGUES OF THE CARMELITES'' contains love in its purest sense, fear, sin, redemption, one of the more harrowing death scenes in musical literature, the French Revolution and a finale in which most of the main characters get their heads lopped off on the guillotine. What more can one ask of an opera?

title: UNCERTIFIED TEACHERS REQUIRED TO BE INTERNS
description: The Board of Regents voted today to require one-year, part-time internships for all working uncertified teachers. The rules are to take effect in September.

title: OFFICELAND INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary credit of $23,719. Results for the latest year include the operations of Metropolitan Collection Service Inc. from Aug. 1, 1986, and for Tel-Ex'perts Inc. from June 1, 1986, which were acquired by the company in October 1986. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: GRAHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $2,250,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-After a loss of $1,327,000 for the quarter and a loss of $1,903,000 from discontinued operations for the year. The latest quarter and year results include unusual gains of $2,105,000 and $1,140,000, respectively. The year-ago periods' results include unusual losses of $935,000.

title: NIPPON WIELDS POWER AT HOME AND ABROAD
description: Wall Street is no stranger to the Nippon Life Insurance Company, the latest Japanese financial institution to show a taste for investing in a big-name American securities firm. Nippon, Japan's largest life insurance company, has been investing heavily in United States Treasury bonds, equities and real estate in recent years.

title: Space for Chagall
description: Few great painters have been as shabbily ignored in their homeland as Marc Chagall. ''A magnificent artist,'' declared a Soviet Minister of Culture defensively in 1968, but ''unfortunately there is not enough space in Soviet museums to show his work.'' Until Chagall's death two years ago, those museums somehow never managed to find space for this master who memorably portrayed his native city, Vitebsk, where he once served briefly as Commissar of Art.

title: FILM: 'HOLLYWOOD SHUFFLE,' SATIRE BY TOWNSEND
description: HAVING appeared in ''A Soldier's Story,'' ''Streets of Fire,'' ''Ratboy'' and ''American Flyers,'' Robert Townsend had established himself as a not bad, not terribly memorable black actor best suited to supporting roles. He might have remained one indefinitely, had he not had the temerity to challenge fate. Mr. Townsend raised $100,000, some of it as cash advances against his own credit cards, and used the money to co-write, produce, direct and star in a comedy about the very troubles he had encountered. Even if ''Hollywood Shuffle'' had been a dismal failure, the tale of its origins would have made a great story.

title: SEA CONTAINERS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in 1986 was largely attributable to non-recurring events and provisions; it said 15 container lessees and ship charterers had defaulted, costing the company about $25 million. The company also said that in October, its Sealink British Ferry subsidiary decided to withdraw two loss- making services from Britain's south coast to the Channel Islands and that severance pay and other costs incidental to a strike which occurred as a result of the closure totaled about $23 million.

title: NOVAR ELECTRONICS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
MABOU MINES REVIVALS IN A BRIEF CHELSEA RUN
description: Consider Ulysses S. Grant in a glass-walled museum showcase, holding forth on annihilation as an acceptable military tactic, on one hand, and the brutality of bullfighting, on the other. And consider, too, a sometimes frenetic, sometimes droll duologue between a man and his dummy at a pay phone on a night-drenched California highway, talking with his mother, among other mysterious characters, all performed by the same actor.

title: PANEL PROPOSES CODE OF ETHICS FOR DEMOCRATS
description: After months of deliberation and dispute, a New York State Democratic committee completed work yesterday on what it called a model code of ethics for party officials.

title: Accounts
description: * J. Bildner & Sons, a Boston-based food marketer, to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article about a Victorian-style house in The Home Section yesterday appeared with a passage misplaced in the last three columns. The passage, beginning ''unusual home'' and ending '' 'I really wanted,' '' should have appeared at the end of the article.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: George Coleman Quartet, the Village Vanguard, Seventh Avenue South at 11th Street (255-4037). George Coleman's career has been an epic, from early blues playing in the Deep South through the Max Roach quintet of the late 50's, the Miles Davis quintet of the mid-60's, landmark albums for Blue Note and other labels, and his own fondly remembered octet of the 70's. Surely he has forgotten more about playing the tenor than most musicians will ever learn? Not at all. Mr. Coleman's style is inclusive, encyclopedic. The postmodern extended techniques, lightning-fast be-bop variations, and the cry of the blues reinforce and enrich one other. And his quartet knows where he's going every step of the way. Shows are around 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. through Sunday; admission is $12, with a $6 minimum.

title: First City Bancorp
description: The First City Bancorporation, a banking company based in Houston, said that two of its subsidiaries had sold a package of energy-related loans and loan participations to Prudential-Bache Energy Growth Fund L.P. G-1, for $54 million. The company said it was the first time a package of solely energy-related loans had been sold in this way.

title: Personal Income Rise Lifts Consumer Spending
description: Spurred by an increase in personal income, consumer spending rose 1.7 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: JUDGE IN BRIBERY CASE WARNS AGAINST LEAKS
description: A Federal judge yesterday warned Government prosecutors and lawyers for Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx and Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader, against leaks to reporters about secretly taped telephone conversations that figured in the indictment of the two men on bribery and other charges.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Share earnings reflect a 2 percent stock dividend payable April 17.

title: THEATER: FOUR ONE-ACTS AT JEWISH REPERTORY By Richard F. Shepard
description: THE bill of short plays, ''Our Own Family,'' currently at the Jewish Repertory Theater, might better be proclaimed as four one-acts in search of a resolution.

title: Reagan Is Faulted on Mideast
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that peace efforts by America's friends in the Middle East were almost doomed to failure because Washington had failed to exert leadership.

title: Rebels Can't Run From Their Image
description: Jerry Tarkanian is not one to call this a crusade, a chance to show he belongs in the company of North Carolina's Dean Smith, Georgetown's John Thompson and Indiana's Bob Knight. Tarkanian already has the impressive won-lost record to prove he has been one of the better coaches in college basketball in the past 20 years. What he does not have is the national championships the other three have earned, or their reputations.

title: Reagan Orders Assets of the Duvaliers Frozen
description: President Reagan has signed an executive order freezing the assets in the United States of Haiti's former President, Jean-Claude Duvalier, and his family.

title: B.J.K.& E. Picks Up Vigoro Industries
description: Vigoro Industries, which has been fertilizing gardens for the last century, has shifted its $4 million account to Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt/Chicago from Adamson Advertising, St. Louis, which had been handling it for the last year.

title: COUNTRY BANDS
description: Two New York country bands, Kristi Rose and the Dying Breed, and the Surreal McCoys, perform tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with double bills at 9:30 P.M. and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: MCRAE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MICROBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Talks by Airlines on Changes In Flight Times Are Recessed
description: Airline industry talks aimed at easing flight delays this summer were recessed today after the airlines failed to reach agreement on schedule revisions for three major airports, including the nation's two busiest.

title: SIERRA SPRING WATER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: QUARTET AT SWEET BASIL
description: Michel Petrucciani, a pianist, will lead a quartet - with Jim Hall on guitar, Ron Carter on bass, Al Foster on drums - tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $7 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $10 cover and a $6 minimum Sunday.

title: MSA REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $85,000 for the quarter, and for the year includes an extraordinary gain of $250,000. c-Net loss

title: April Trial for School Sex Cas
description: A mother and son accused of molesting children at a nearby preschool institution will go on trial next month, Judge William R. Pounders said Wednesday. He said jury selection would begin April 20.

title: SEEING THE EVOLUTION OF NEW YORK CITY THROUGH ARTISTS' EYES
description: The city of New York, a collection of islands weighted with concrete in a broad bay, has never been a place where the artist could get away from it all. Quite the contrary, it is a place where the artist comes, looks and depicts. Each artist views the metropolis with different eyes, and lucky New Yorkers have abundant opportunities to see these perceptions and match them with their own in the city's museums and galleries.

title: MICROPRO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Spinks-Cooney Nearer
description: A New York State Supreme Court judge yesterday cleared the way for a heavyweight fight between Michael Spinks and Gerry Cooney by lifting an injunction on the bout, which might be June 15 or 26 in Atlantic City or Las Vegas, Nev. Home Box Office had tried to stop the fight, claiming it would interfere with the cable network's heavyweight unification series. But Supreme Court Judge Elliott Wilk said the argument was no longer valid because the International Boxing Federation recently stripped Spinks of his heavyweight title. ''Since there is no I.B.F. champion, I can't see any reason to continue the injunction,'' Wilk said. Spinks forfeited his title for refusing to sign for a mandatory defense against the top contender, Tony Tucker, who will fight second-ranked James (Buster) Douglas May 30 for the vacant title.

title: SERIOUS CRIMES IN NEW YORK CITY RISE 5%, FIRST INCREASE IN 5 YEARS
description: Led by a 14 percent increase in murders, the number of serious crimes reported in New York City rose more than 5 percent last year, the first yearly increase since 1981, according to Police Department figures released yesterday.

title: Backstop Forefront
description: If catching is the most arduous job in baseball, then let's hear it for 39-year-old Bob Boone. Should he find the right home - he's still an unsigned free agent - Boone will advance late in the coming season to the No. 1 spot on this list of players who have caught the most games in major league history.

title: GENZYME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a charge of $2 million in connection with settlement of a lawsuit for the quarter and year.

title: FITNESS TEST FOR BABY M'S MOTHER UNFAIR, FEMINISTS SAY
description: When two dozen women met recently in a Manhattan apartment to discuss the Baby M trial, they quickly found one issue on which they could agree. None would want her skills as a mother put to the scrutiny that Mary Beth Whitehead was being subjected to in a Hackensack, N.J., courtroom.

title: INSIDE
description: Reagan Threatens a Veto

title: 'JAWS OF LIFE,' A COMEDY
description: ''IN THE JAWS OF LIFE,''

title: JIM WALTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a $4 million gain from the sale of land for the quarter and 6 months, and gains of $645,000 and $1,290,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, for reduced pension expenses.

title: COMPETITION IN MILK SALES IS DEBATED
description: A proposal to revise New York State's milk licensing law to allow more competition among dairies will bring ''predatory practices'' that could cripple the milk industry, a group of New York dairies told a State Assembly public hearing in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Who Says Old People Have to Move Over
description: To the Editor:

title: A MUSICAL PASTICHE IN TRIBUTE TO JULE STYNE
description: THIS being a pledge period for public television, the normal schedule is largely pre-empted for a slew of ''golden oldies'' offerings that presumably inspire viewers to rush to their mailboxes with support dollars. We have had clips from old movies in tributes to James Stewart and Vincente Minnelli. This Sunday, we will be getting the evergreen top hits from opera and operetta in ''A Musical Toast,'' with Itzhak Perlman as host. And tonight at 9 on Channel 13, we have a 2 1/2-hour collection (with pledge interruptions) of popular songs in ''Broadway Sings: The Music of Jule Styne.''

title: UPDATING A SURVEY
description: Speaking of Federal employees, in 1980 the Merit Systems Protection Board, an independent agency that protects the rights of Government workers, studied sexual harassment on the job. It concluded that 42 percent of all women who work for the Government and 15 percent of the men had been so harassed. Now it wants to update its findings. So this week it sent questionnaires to 13,000 randomly selected Federal workers.

title: Reagan Vows Veto of Any Tax Hike
description: President Reagan declared tonight that he would veto any tax increase that Congress might pass, and he warned lawmakers not to relax the statutory goals for reducing the Federal deficit.

title: Kenya's Police Begin Seizing Illegal Aliens for Expulsion
description: The Kenyan police have started a nationwide roundup of illegal aliens after President Daniel arap Moi's statement that the aliens were troublemakers who should be expelled.

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After reserves for nonrecurring items of $1,140,000. c-Includes a $2,556,000 pretax gain from the sale and leaseback of the company's headquarters building.

title: Who Says Old People Have to Move Over; Permission Not Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC OFFERS 'WAR REQUIEM'
description: A QUARTER of a century has passed since Benjamin Britten's ''War Requiem'' had it first performance in Coventry's rebuilt cathedral, which Nazi fire bombs had destroyed in 1940. In a time when so few new scores survive much beyond birth, Britten's solemn and deeply grieving work is still with us. There are good reasons why, of course. It is certainly true that in a world where wars, large or small, are always going on somewhere or other, the elegiac theme of this piece does not go out of fashion. Perhaps one day our descendants will wonder what a ''War Requiem'' could possibly have been about, but we seem to be far from that paradisiacal time.

title: Rolls Jet Engine Net Up
description: Rolls-Royce Ltd., the state-owned British jet engine maker, which is scheduled to be sold to the public in the next two months, today announced a rise of almost 50 percent in its pretax profits for 1986. The Rolls-Royce chairman, Sir Francis Tombs, said pretax profits in 1986 climbed to a record $:120 million, from $:81 million the previous year, marking the third successive year of improved results. Sir Francis said the civil-air sector of the market provided the biggest part of the 12.5 percent jump in sales, which reached $:1.8 billion.

title: Democracy's Antibodies
description: The American political system has been sorely tested in recent months. Charges of high-level influence peddling and suspicions of lawbreaking in the White House have strained confidence both in the Reagan Administration and democracy itself. However, for a nation so injured by greed and abuse of power, there is fresh evidence of democratic vitality.

title: PHOTOGRAPHIC SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses of $548,000 and $696,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and includes a loss of $14,000 from discontinued operations. The company changed from a fiscal year to a calendar year reporting basis; prior year results are not available. The acquisitions late in the year of Optel Systems Inc. and Techtran Inc. contributed substantially to the rise in its sales.

title: KEY RATES
Soviet Plane Skids at Gander
description: A Soviet airliner en route from Moscow to Havana skidded off a runway into a snowbank today as it was landing here. No injuries were reported and the pilot managed to steer the jetliner back onto the runway and taxi to the terminal.

title: SATELLITE MUSIC NETWORK INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $252,160 and $152,717 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: U.S. Seeking to Allay Fears Over a Call for AIDS Tests
description: Clarifying confusion over Federal policy, the Federal Centers for Disease Control said yesterday that physicians should consider recommending the blood test for AIDS virus infection for some people who received transfusions of blood and blood products from 1978 to the spring of 1985.

title: UNION DISPUTE CANCELS 'DIVORCE' PERFORMANCE
description: A performance last night of ''Gay Divorce'' at the Kaufman Theater, 534 West 42d Street, was canceled when members of the musicians' union threatened to picket the 97-seat theater.

title: TECH DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
LATE SHOT SAVES ISLANDERS
description: There have been few times this season when the Islanders have gained respect for themselves, winning the sort of game a contending team is supposed to win. Tonight was one of those times. They rallied to topple the Detroit Red Wings, 3-2, when Pat LaFontaine scored with 4 seconds remaining, 11 seconds after Kelly Hrudey made a big save in goal.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: INTRODUCTION AND CODA

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: ART: NEW OIL PAINTINGS BY BRICE MARDEN AT BOONE
description: BRICE MARDEN'S new work, at the Mary Boone Gallery (417 West Broadway, near Spring Street), forms a somberly beautiful show that is at once impressive and somewhat disappointing - and disappointing in a way that is difficult to put a finger on. With these new canvases, which are on view through March 28, Mr. Marden has moved beyond the work for which he is best known: the monochrome panel paintings that reduced painting to an austere yet voluptuous essence. Like the young Frank Stella of the ''Black Paintings,'' Mr. Marden started his career in a corner, making works so minimal they seemed to signal the end of painting. While he spent much more time than Mr. Stella in fruitful production in that corner, he has also spent the last few years cautiously working his way out of it.

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Includes equity in unremitted earnings of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. amounting to $169,057,000 for the latest year, compared with $75,694,000 in the prior year; and for the latest fiscal year also includes non-recurring charges of $35 million associated with the sale of several wine operations and a planned reorganization of spirits operations in the U.S. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: SPARTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
N.H.L. Honors Ziegler
description: John Ziegler Jr., president of the National Hockey League, will be inducted into the builder's section of the Hockey Hall of Fame this summer, Brian O'Neill, the Hall of Fame chairman, announced yesterday. Ziegler, who is in his 10th season as league president, will be inducted June 15 in Detroit. The builder's section is reserved for nonplayers who have made significant contributions to the sport.

title: WHITE HOUSE KNEW OF A SHIFT ON IRAN, C.I.A. OFFICIALS SAY
description: Central Intelligence Agency officials say that, in revised intelligence estimates in 1985, they told the White House that there was little prospect for improving relations with Iran, even as the Reagan Administration began a covert initiative to accomplish that purpose.

title: FILM AT FOGGY BOTTOM
description: The Justice Department has had some unaccustomed excitement lately: the filming of a murder mystery on the fifth floor, not far from Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's office.

title: WEISFIELD'S reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BOEHEIM TAKES ON CRITICS
description: Yes, Jim Boeheim revealed yesterday, he is sensitive to criticism. And maybe the tall figure that stalks the sideline in front of the Syracuse bench - arms out, palms up, staying after the officials, eyes squinting behind his glasses, looking for an edge - maybe that character is not the same person that goes home to his wife and daughter when his work is done. ''Just because Clint Eastwood shoots people in the movies,'' said the coach of the Orange, ''doesn't mean he walks down the street in Carmel shooting people. That's my style. A lot of it is an act.'' Boeheim was an experienced chair thrower nearly a full year before Indiana's Bob Knight began to develop his style. He has been known to become argumentative with officials, reporters, and former coaches who are now paid to criticize his work on television. ''Former coaches,'' Boeheim said. His eyebrows started upward. ''Fired coaches.''

title: BUDGETARY RHYTHMS
description: As flawed as the Congressional budget process is, it does have its annual rhythms. So if it's spring, it's time for partisan discord.

title: VIRCO MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $309,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $253,000 for the quarter and $1,559,000 for the year.

title: DRYCLEAN-U.S.A.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company, which went public in December 1986, said the results are on a pro forma basis.

title: IOWA ST. THREATENS IOWA'S BID FOR 10TH
description: Iowa State, trying to deny state-rival Iowa a record 10th consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championship, built a comfortable 14 1/2-point lead tonight over the Hawkeyes by winning all five of its semifinal matches.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES reports earnings for 3mo Feb 28
DEMBO BASKING IN ROLE
description: Standing off to the side, Fennis Dembo was soaking in the atmosphere of the West Regional in the Kingdome, watching the Oklahoma players milling after practice, the Iowa players loosening up on the court.

title: MARXISM EMBRACES CAPITALISM IN AN INDIAN STATE MARKED BY SQUALOR
description: Countless posters bearing a bright red hammer and sickle are plastered on the lampposts, doorways and walls of this squalid city. It is election season, and the Communists are preparing for another huge victory.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary of Santo Trafficante Jr. by The Associated Press on Thursday described the 1957 killing of Albert Anastasia incorrectly. He was shot to death as he sat in a barber chair at a New York hotel.

title: BRAE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $190,000 and $731,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $185,000 for the quarter and $815,000 for the 9 months. The company said for the latest periods it provided additional reserves and writedowns of appoximately $6.4 million.

title: WHAT WORKS IN CALCUTTA? A SUBWAY
description: A gleaming subway train rumbles up to a spotless underground platform and lets out hundreds of commuters. They exit past potted plants and chandeliers while a Hindu hymn plays on the loudspeaker.

title: OPPENHEIMER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Nicaragua Protests U.S. Aid To Contras in Finding Targets
description: The Sandinista Government sent a formal protest today to the United States, accusing the Central Intelligence Agency of giving Nicaraguan rebels information about targets.

title: Highway Robbery and Necessity
description: Suddenly, lifting the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit is the least of the obstacles to a new Federal highway bill. The long-overdue speed limit revision - approved this week by Congress - is now tangled up with lesser matters of legislative pork and larger questions of mass transit and raising taxes.

title: DEMOCRATS MAINTAIN HOLD ON SOUTH
description: In Washington, among those who formulate political strategy, the two-party South is considered a reality.

title: REAGAN REVISES STATEMENT ON BUSH
description: President Reagan today revised the characterization of Vice President Bush's role in the Iran arms affair that he gave in Thursday night's news conference. Both leaders appeared eager to prevent the matter from becoming a political embarrassment for Mr. Bush.

title: Ewing Out for Rest of Season
description: Patrick Ewing's latest injury, a sprained ligament in his left knee, will force him to miss the remainder of the season, the Knicks announced yesterday.

title: U.S. WILL CUT POWER AT BOMB FUEL REACTORS AMID CONCERNS ABOUT SAFETY
description: The Department of Energy said yesterday that it would cut power sharply at its three operating plutonium-producing reactors because of concern that the reactors' emergency cooling systems could not handle an accident.

title: DEMOCRATIC FUND-RAISERS DELAY DECISION TO BACK SINGLE CANDIDATE
description: About 40 leading Democratic fund-raisers, meeting here today, temporarily abandoned plans to back a single candidate for their party's Presidential nomination in 1988.

title: A Crowded Neighborhood for This Housing Plan
description: To the Editor: Phyllis Goodman's letter (March 4) on the proposed 1,105 units of condominium housing for New York City at West 230th Street and Tibbett Avenue in the Bronx is right to the point. Both your news story and accompanying photo (Feb. 18) ignore the existence of John F. Kennedy High School abutting the site's southern boundary. Kennedy High, whose more than 5,000 students, plus faculty members and staff, will each school day compete with the construction crews and then the condominium residents for access, has only one, narrow access road, from West 230th Street on the site's eastern boundary.

title: MAJOR MAFIA LEADER TURNS INFORMER, SECRETLY RECORDING MEETINGS OF MOB
description: A major Mafia leader has turned informer, secretly recording mob meetings since last October, Federal prosecutors disclosed yesterday in court documents in Manhattan.

title: Back to School
description: The American League's 1986 Cy Young Award winner and most valuable player is throwing batting practice for his former high school team in Houston these days. ''My feelings are still the same, nothing has changed,'' Roger Clemens said, declining to elaborate on his contract squabble with the Boston Red Sox. Clemens walked out of the Red Sox training camp in Florida March 6 and is being fined $1,000 a day. He wants a contract of $2.4 million over two years. Boston is offering $500,000 plus $350,000 in incentives for this year. ''I'm here for a week to see my wife and kids,'' Clemens said. He has been working out at Spring Woods High School, which he left seven years ago. . . . The Philadelphia Phillies are expected to announce today whether Steve Carlton will be allowed to continue his effort to win a job with the club. Carlton pitched five innings yesterday in an 8-3 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals. He gave up four runs, three earned, on four hits, struck out two and walked three.

title: ROBERT WHITE RECITAL
description: Robert White, a tenor, will present a recital devoted entirelyto the music of Beethoven at Alice Tully hall this afternoon at 3 o'clock. The program will include some of Beethoven's rarely heard Irish, Welsh and Scottish folk song settings. Mr White will be accompanied by the pianist Samuel Sanders. Admission is $15; information: 362-1911.

title: JAZZ: ROSEMARY CLOONEY
description: Rosemary Clooney's recent recordings for Concord Records have put her in what has proved to be an ideal setting - backed by a small jazz group that includes Scott Hamilton on tenor saxophone, Warren Vache on cornet and her arranger, John Oddo, at the piano. Billie Holiday made some of her finest records with this kind of accompaniment in the 1930's, and Miss Clooney responds to it equally well.

title: SENATOR IS QUOTED AS SAYING U.S. RECRUITED ISRAELI OFFICER AS A SPY
description: A former chairman of the Senate intelligence committee told two Jewish political gatherings last Sunday that American intelligence agents had used an Israeli military officer as a spy in the early 1980's, according to three people who were at the meetings.

title: JAPAN IN PACT TO INCREASE FISH IMPORTS FROM U.S.
description: The United States would eventually sell $300 million more fresh and processed fish to Japan under an accord just reached by the two Governments, Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today.

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said non-recurring expenses relating to continued cost savings reorganization efforts during the latest third quarter caused the net loss to widen slightly from the second quarter loss of $381,000.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Scouting column in Sports Pages on Thursday misstated the name and age of the organizer of the Wall Street Charity Classic basketball tournament. He is Chris Garavente, 31 years old.

title: AIDS TEST SHUNNED FOR RECIPIENTS OF TRANSFUSIONS
description: Deluged in recent days with calls from worried patients, many physicians are reluctant to urge tests to detect infection with the AIDS virus among those who received blood transfusions from 1978 to the spring of 1985.

title: THE PULL OF PARIS, STILL FASHIONS'S FORUM
description: Late Wednesday night, at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts on the Left Bank, Helmut Lang showed a starkly beautiful fashion collection. Mr. Lang's clingy jersey dresses made his models look like pre-Raphaelite waifs. But his pointy-collar loden coats, skirts worn over stiff, pleated slips, and groups named ''Costumes for Expatriates'' and ''Good News From the Ziller Valley'' hinted that Mr. Lang hails from Vienna, not Paris.

title: CAPITAL GAINS AND NEW LAW
description: MANY individuals are changing their attitude about investing for capital gains this year as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. But not Gertrude Friedman, a New York City teacher.

title: PROFESSOR LOSES EYE IN SHOOTING ON BROADWAY
description: A biochemist at Columbia University lost his left eye after it was struck by a bullet that pierced the window of his car late Thursday as he was driving south on upper Broadway, the police said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 21, 1987
description: The Scandal on Wall Street

title: SPI PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a gain of $821,000 from the sales of certain marketable securities.

title: Thon Examined
description: Dickie Thon, the Houston Astros shortstop who left the club's training camp last weekend, underwent a 2 1/2-hour eye examination in Houston yesterday that found no change from last year's check, officials said. Dr. Dan Jones, an eye specialist who has worked with Thon since the player was hit in the left eye by a pitch from Mike Torrez in April 1984, checked Thon's eyes after the 28-year-old had complained of vision problems. ''There is reduced vision, problems which cannot be corrected with eyeglasses or surgery,'' said Chuck Pool, a team spokesman. No further treatment or tests were planned at the moment, Pool said. Thon left the club's training camp in Kissimmee, Fla., last Saturday, frustrated with his performance and his trouble seeing the ball during exhibition games. He was hitless in eight times at bat, struck out twice and committed three errors in the three spring games he started. The Astros asked Thon to undergo the examination and expect him to make a decision concerning his status: either return to camp or retire by this weekend. ''We're anticipating his return to Kissimmee,'' Pool said.

title: AN OFFICIAL OF NICARAGUAN REBELS ADMITS TAKING FUNDS FROM NORTH
description: Alfonso Robelo, a top Nicaraguan rebel leader, said tonight that his political party and an affiliated group together received at least $100,000 in contributions in 1985 and 1986 from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the former National Security Council aide.

title: Memorial Mass for Warhol
description: A memorial mass will be offered for the artist Andy Warhol on April 1 at 10:15 A.M. at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and 50th Street. The public is invited. Mr. Warhol died last month; he was believed to be 58 years old.

title: For Taxes, Britain Gets Oil by Constable
description: One of John Constable's most famous paintings, ''Stratford Mill,'' has been given anonymously to the nation in partial payment of inheritance taxes, Britain's Minister of Arts, Richard Luce, said. The painting, which Constable completed in 1820, shows boys fishing on a river beside a water mill; it is valued at $16 million.

title: Johan von Spreckelsen, Danish Architect, Dies
