description: Johan Otto von Spreckelsen, the Danish architect who designed a 24-story arch in a business and residential complex, La Defense, outside Paris, died Wednesday in a Copenhagen hospital. He was 57 years old. The cause of death was withheld at the request of the family.

title: Soviet Swords and Plowshares
description: LEAD: Directors of institutes of the Soviet Academy of Science, officials of the State Planning Commission and a deputy foreign minister have assured me that it is now the policy of the Government and of Mikhail S. Gorbachev to support planning for conversion from a military to a civilian economy.

title: Monet Is Stolen In Iowa At Community Center
description: While a theater group was rehearsing, a thief entered the community center here and cut a painting by Claude Monet out of its frame, the police said today.

title: COLLAPSE OF AIRPORT SCHEDULING TALKS TRIED TO ABSENCE FEDERAL AUTHORITY
description: The collapse Thursday of airline industry talks over easing flight delays at major airports this summer offers an example of how ''voluntarism'' works in the Federal Government's post-regulation era.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Dining Out Guide in Weekend on March 13 gave an incorrect address for Montrachet. The restaurant is at 239 West Broadway, between White and Walker Streets.

title: State Dept.'s Legal Adviser Agrees to Testify at Hearing
description: Under threat of subpoena, the State Department's legal adviser has agreed to testify next week at a joint session of the Senate Foreign Relations and Judiciary committees, Congressional officials said today.

title: Tax on Commuters Passed by Committee
description: A bill that would impose an income tax averaging $134 a year on about 50,000 out-of-state residents who work in Connecticut was approved yesterday by the Finance Committee of the Connecticut General Assembly.

title: 6 ARE INDICTED IN A CRACKDOWN AGAINST WESTIES
description: Three members of the Westies, a notorious Manhattan gang, were indicted yesterday for the murder of a construction worker, and three others were accused of plotting a contract killing with an undercover police detective.

title: Bridge: New York and L.I. Entries To Meet in Grand Nationals
description: Knockout play in the Grand National Team Championship begins today at the Adria Motor Inn, 220-33 Northern Boulevard, Bayside, Queens, with 32 teams from New York City and Long Island in contention.

title: Bond Prices Slightly Lower
description: Bond prices continued to meander in a narrow range yesterday before closing slightly lower on selling linked to the expiration of the spot March Treasury bond futures contract. Intermediate Treasury issues were basically unchanged, and the discount rates on bills were up three basis points on all maturities.

title: BILL HOLMAN
description: Bill Holman, the cartoonist who drew the comic strip ''Smokey Stover,'' died Feb. 27 in New York. He was 84 years old and lived in the city.

title: DANCE: 'AGON' OFFERED BY TROUPE IN HARLEM
description: Dance Theater of Harlem was born within recent memory. It is calling its current season at City College's handsome Aaron Davis Hall a ''Harlem Homecoming.'' And so it is easy to feel a little proprietary and imagine that while it may be an internationally acclaimed ballet troupe, the company is family to us. But programs like the one Dance Theater presented on Thursday - with an astonishingly varied and complete repertory, a high standard of performing and that good old-fashioned element called entertainment - are something of a jolt. Not only is the company now a glittering and independent adult, but its proper ''home'' is in that select pantheon reserved for first-rate artistry.

title: IN HOLLYWOOD, SOVIET PEACE TALKS
description: A delegation of nine Soviet film makers arrived in Los Angeles on Thursday for what is being called an Entertainment Summit with the Hollywood film industry.

title: Gain for Dixons In Cyclops Bid
description: Dixons Group P.L.C. said late yesterday that a Federal judge in Ohio had denied a motion filed by Audio/Video Affiliates Inc., an Ohio-based electronics retailer defeated by Dixons in a bid to take over the Cyclops Corporation.

title: Trident Protester Sentenced
description: The first of 186 activists to be convicted of trespassing while protesting the test launching of a Trident 2 missle was sentenced Thursday to six months in jail. The defendant, Willa Elam, 43 years old, of Cocoa, was convicted by a jury March 11.

title: NORTH-WEST TELECOMM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $130,784 and $32,030 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $171,381 and $590,030 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: MISSING FINAL 4 IS CONSOLATION
description: The adage that anyone still coaching at this juncture of the season has no preference concerning his next opponent did not wash with Providence's Rick Pitino. He sat in the stands at Freedom Hall late Thursday evening, following his team's upset of second-seeded Alabama in the Southeast Regional semifinal, and cheered for a team that had soundly beaten the Friars twice in three meetings tthis season. And the motive wasn't revenge.

title: ICN PHAMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After gains of $3,686,000 for the latest first quarter and $975,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Kampelman Is Hospitalized
description: The chief United States negotiator in arms-control talks with the Soviet Union, Max M. Kampelman, was hospitalized today after what an assistant described as ''a minor heart attack.''

title: FRANCE CURBS SEX MAGAZINES, STIRRING NEW POLITICL DISPUTE
description: France's conservative Government stirred a new political storm today by effectively banning several sexually oriented magazines, including the French edition of Penthouse and a magazine aimed at male homosexuals.

title: Icahn Drops Fight To Acquire USAir
description: Carl C. Icahn has decided to give up his quest for USAir Group Inc., for the time being at least. The airline said yesterday that Mr. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., had agreed not to buy more USAir shares without notifying it first and not to interfere with USAir's acquisition of Piedmont Airlines.

title: Shelter Animals Make Poor Research Subjects; Worsening the Problem
description: To the Editor: Douglas Hess misses the point on why humane societies are against pound seizure laws.

title: TRIANGLE HOME PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHARTER-CRELLIN INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MYERSON PLANS TO RESUME CITY POST
description: Bess Myerson said yesterday that she expected to resume her post in the Koch administration within three weeks, despite the legal problems she and her companion, the city contractor Carl A. Capasso, are facing.

title: Nebraska Governor Named
description: Gov. Kay Orr of Nebraska will head the platform committee for the 1988 Republican National Convention in New Orleans, Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., the Republican national chairman, announced today. Mrs. Orr, who was elected Governor last November, will be responsible for supervising the writing of the party's platform, a statement of its goals, programs and hopes for the 1988 general election.

title: Catherine Kurland Marries John Serkin
description: Catherine Kurland and John Serkin were married in New York yesterday at the home of Lori Zabar and Mark Mariscal. Justice Israel Rubin of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: C.B.A. Awards
description: Two current members of the Portland Trail Blazers of the National Basketball Association have been honored for efforts this season in the Continental Basketball Association. Joe Binion, who played for Topeka before being signed by Portland on Feb. 14 for the remainder of the season, was voted the C.B.A. most valuable player award after he finished as the league's leading rebounder, averaging 13.9 per game, and third-leading scorer, with a 26.3-point average. Ron Rowan, a teammate of Binion at Topeka and now at Portland, was selected as the league's rookie of the year. The former St. John's guard finished with an 18.8 scoring average, shooting 53.4 percent from the field.

title:
PATENTS;
Computerized Scanning Of Tiny Circuit Wires
description: LEAD: An optical scanning system for computerized inspection of tiny circuit wires on printed circuit devices was patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation. Printed circuit devices are used in many electrical products.

title: ENTEX ENERGY DEVELOPMENT LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $21 million from writedowns of the capitalized cost of oil and gas properties, and a $10.4 million loss from a reduction in the carrying basis of a geothermal property.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID TARGET IN LEBANON
description: Israeli aircraft attacked Palestinian targets today in southern Lebanon, the first raid in more than a month. A Palestinian spokesman said there were no casualties in the attack.

title: HARDVARD WINS, 7-1, IN OPENER
description: The Harvard skaters flew around their rink tonight and did what their coach, Bill Cleary, likes best. ''Attack, always attack,'' said Cleary, and the Crimson did just that.

title: Lendl Withdraws
description: Ivan Lendl, recuperating from knee surgery, has withdrawn from the upcoming Volvo Tennis-Chicago tournament, his agent said yesterday. ''He's been working on special exercises for the knee and we can only monitor his progress on a weekly basis,'' said Jerry Solomon. ''Ivan hopes to be back on tour in a few weeks, but for the time being he has had to withdraw from both the Volvo Tennis-Chicago and WCT-Dallas tournaments.'' Lendl's departure means Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe move into the top-seeded and second-seeded spots, respectively. The $315,000 tournament is set for March 30-April 5 at the University of Illinois-Chicago Pavilion.

title: NORRIS OIL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an $11,814,900 writedown of oil and gas properties which was necessitated by a severe decline in the price of crude oil and natural gas in 1986.

title: PARISIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
THE 'WITCHING HOUR' TURNS BENIGN
description: To Wall Street's immense relief, the predictions about the ''triple witching hour'' came true yesterday: It was a shadow of its former self.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS AND 2 BROKERS SUPOENAED IN U.S. STOCK INQUIRY
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has subpoenaed the American Express Company, Shearson Lehman Brothers and Salomon Brothers as part of the inquiry into last year's illegal stock manipulation scheme involving Boyd L. Jefferies.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Looking for Distinction

title: WARD FEARS FEW BLACKS WILL BE READY TO LEAD POLICE
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that the slow progress in recruiting and promoting blacks would leave few ready for promotion to top jobs when senior black officers left the department.

title: Casey Is Hospitalized Again
description: William J. Casey, former Director of Central Intelligence, was readmitted to Georgetown University Hospital March 13 for medical reevaluation, a hospital spokeswoman said today. Robin Payes, the spokeswoman, said Mr. Casey was in stable condition. Mr. Casey, 73 years old, underwent surgery Dec. 18 for removal of a cancerous brain tumor. He resigned in late January after six years as head of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: MICRON TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 5
A Chance to Simplify New York Taxes
description: LEAD: New York State has a rare opportunity to serve as a national model of tax simplification. But it must move quickly.

title: BIOSEARCH MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nobody's Home to Solicitors
description: LEAD: It happened again last night - the phone call in the middle of dinner. But it could have been at the high point of my favorite television show, during the Hallelujah Chorus of ''The Messiah'' or while I was washing my hair. A cheery voice announced: ''Hi! I'm Joe Brown, a junior at Eastwest U.'' (a pseudonym for my son's alma mater).

title: Can There Be Too Much Free Speech Sometimes?
description: To the Editor: It was most heartening to read the story of Beulah Mae Donald's determination to bring the Ku Klux Klan to justice for murdering her 19-year-old son, Michael, in 1981 and of her ultimate victory when a white jury in Mobile, Ala., returned a $7 million verdict against the United Klans of America (news story, March 8).

title: CITY PARKING AIDE IS SHOT TO DEATH IN QUEENS LAUNDRY
description: George M. Aronwald, a 78-year-old hearing officer for the Parking Violations Bureau in Queens, was killed yesterday afternoon in a gangland-style shooting in a Long Island City, Queens, laundry.

title: GREENPOINT SCARRED BY SHARP RISE IN ILLEGAL DUMPING
description: Robert D. Schwartz arrived at his job last week in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn - an area of warehouses and small, neatly kept houses - and found six feet of cement and dirt outside his door.

title: AMERICAN HOME SHIELD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from tax loss carryforwards of $501,000 and $1,040,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $10,000 for the quarter and $67,000 for the year. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect application of preferred stock dividends.

title: PHOTRONIC LABS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Devil Demoted
description: The New Jersey Devils yesterday returned Doug Brown, a right wing, to Maine of the American Hockey League. Brown had one assist in four games after being called up March 13 under emergency conditions due to a back injury to Peter McNab. The Devils said McNab, a forward, was expected to returned to the lineup tonight for a game in St. Louis against the Blues. . . . The Islanders are sending Derek King back to his junior team as Ari Haanpaa, a left wing, returns for tonight's game against the Rangers at Nassau Coliseum. King played two games as Haanpaa's emergency replacement.

title: SHAD PLANS TO LEAVE S.E.C. POST
description: The head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, John S. R. Shad, will leave his post to become Ambassador to the Netherlands, the White House announced today.

title: Alcoa to Sell Unit
description: The Aluminum Company of America said it had agreed to sell the American Powdered Metals Company of Cheshire, Conn., to R.W. Technology Inc. of Cheshire. The terms of the sale were not disclosed. American Powdered Metals, which has about 100 employees, operates plants in Cheshire and Conover, N.C., to manufacture small, complex metal parts for the automotive, appliance, business machine, hardware and military industries.

title: Japan Rejects Fake Reeboks
description: Japanese customs authorities, faced with a flood of counterfeit Reebok sneakers from South Korea, have turned away 100,000 pairs since last summer, company and Government officials said.

title: INDIANA HOLDS OFF BLUE DEVILS' RALLY
description: Duke was willing and, for spots in the game, the Blue Devils were able. But Indiana, relying on superior strength and quickness inside, was simply too powerful and defeated Duke, 88-82, in a Midwest Regional semifinal tonight.

title: Not All Shiites of Persian Gulf Look to Khomeini
description: To the Editor: Michael Rosenblum (letter, March 4) argues that grounding in the history of the Persian Gulf and its culture are necessary to understand the Iran-Iraq war. However, he seems himself to oversimplify when he charges that ''there exists in the gulf the seeds of Shiite discontent under oppressive Sunni rule,'' and says it is no surprise if the Shiites of the Arab littoral look to Iran's Ayatollah Khomeini for ''inspiration and hope.''

title: Say It Ain't So, Larry
description: People in the news business tend to forget it's a business, so when something like the firings at CBS News jolts them back to reality, they respond with shock and rage.

title: SCHOLASTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,213,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-After a tax credit of $155,000 for the quarter and 9 months. The latest periods' results include a non-recurring pre-tax gain of $720,000 from the buyout of a royalty arrangement entered into by Scholastic Inc. in conjunction with its 1984 sale of certain assets of children's choice hardcover home book club.

title:
PATENT;
An Enzyme Advance In Genetic Engineering
description: LEAD: An improved version of an enzyme widely used in genetic engineering has been patented by staff members at Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond. Known as alkaline phosphatase, the enzyme serves as a biocatalyst to manipulate DNA and other molecules.

title: PARCHED SUMMER IS FEARED IN WEST
description: As it tumbles out of the red mountains in Yellowstone National Park, the Snake River becomes a watery lifeline for thousands of farmers and scores of cities in Wyoming and Idaho.

title: CANADA'S 'LOYALTIES' LOOKS AT 2 WOMEN
description: ''Loyalties,'' set in the small community of Lac la Biche in northwestern Canada, is a technically adequate Canadian film about the sustaining friendship that grows up between two very different kinds of women. The film will be shown in the New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art today at 6 P.M. and tomorrow at 3:30 P.M.

title: ITALIAN GENERAL IS SHOT DEAD AND TERRORSTS ARE BLAMED
description: Two attackers on a motorcycle shot dead a senior Italian Air Force general as he was being driven home tonight, and the Italian authorities said terrorists were to blame.

title: Ray Knight in the Spring
description: In the deceiving languor that is baseball spring training, Ray Knight in his new white-and-orange Baltimore Orioles uniform stood sentry the other afternoon in the cutoff position between third and home at Miami Stadium. He intercepted or let pass to the catcher an assortment of heaves from a gaggle of left fielders.

title: INCREASE IN PRICES FAULTED IN POLAND
description: The Government-sponsored labor federation that replaced the outlawed Solidarity movement has declared that expected increases in the price of food and fuel are unacceptable to Polish workers.

title: Lieut. Gov. Ruth Meiers Of North Dakota Dies
description: Lieut. Gov. Ruth Meiers, the first woman to serve in that post in North Dakota, died Thursday. She was 61 years old.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: CUTS URGED IN SPACE STATION PROGRAM
description: Administration officials, seeking to head off growing opposition in Congress, are urging President Reagan to scale down his plans for an orbiting space station so as to reduce the costs and make the project more politically acceptable, Government sources said today.

title: HALL, FRANK B & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $15,216,000 for the quarter and $17,761,000 for the year, and loss on disposal from discontinued operations of $8,985,000 for the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $60,000 for the quarter and $7,341,000 for the year, and losses on disposal from discontinued operations of $85 million and $192 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: GREAT COUNTRY BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company converted to a stock from a mutual savings bank Jan. 14, 1986.

title: PAN AM HAS BIG LOSS FOR QUARTER AND YEAR
description: The Pan American Corporation yesterday reported substantial losses in the fourth quarter and all of 1986 but securities analysts found hopeful signs.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: Treasury Statement
description: Selected data on the United States Government's spending and debt contained in the Treasury Department's monthly statement, which was released yesterday. Amounts are in millions of dollars; fiscal years run from Oct. 1 through Sept. 30.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MARCH 21, 1987
description: International 2-5, 28 Labor unrest in Yugoslavia has erupted recently. Since the beginning of March, workers have been walking off their jobs to protest stern new wage restraints at a time when prices of most necessities are being raised. Page 1 Poland's labor federation protested expected price increases, declaring them unacceptable to Polish workers, and calling for an end to policies of continuously raising prices of food, services and consumer goods. 5

title: Venezuela Brew Kills 9
description: Nine elderly people died and 126 were hospitalized after they drank a home brew tainted with a poisonous pesticide during a party at a home for the aged, Health Ministry officials said today. It has not been determined how the pesticide got into the brew, which was consumed Thursday at the home in San Cristobal.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: Surgery for Howser
description: Dick Howser, the former Kansas City Royals manager, was said to be alert after a third brain operation in which part of a growing tumor was removed, the Royals said. The surgery was performed at Huntington Memorial Hospital in Pasadena, Calif., by a team headed by Dr. Skip Jacques. It was the second time the experimental surgery had been performed on Howser, who resigned as manager of the Royals March 22 after deciding he was not strong enough to run the club. Howser, who was said to be alert and talking with his wife, was expected to remain in the hospital about a week.

title: BID FOR PRESIDENT IN 1988 IS SHUNNED BY BUMPERS
description: Senator Dale Bumpers of Arkansas took himself out of the 1988 Presidential race today, eliminating the last question mark about the shape of the early Democratic field.

title: CITING DISARRAY, QUINONES OUSTS A SCHOOL BOARD
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones suspended a community school board in upper Manhattan yesterday, saying he could no longer permit students to be ''victims'' of the board's mismanagement.

title: U.S. Judge Orders Rezoning in Yonkers
description: The Federal judge presiding over the Yonkers desegregation case ordered the city yesterday to rezone two former school sites for public housing.

title: France, Germany Agree on Copter
description: Defense Ministers Andre Giraud of France and Manfred Worner of West Germany have agreed to establish guidelines for French-West German joint production of a new antitank helicopter, officials said.

title: Washburn Ready
description: Chris Washburn, the rookie center who entered a drug-treatment center in late January, will begin practicing with Golden State next week and is expected to play again soon, the Warriors announced yesterday. ''We are pleased with Chris's response to the treatment and look forward to his return,'' said Dan Finnane, the club president. Washburn is entering the after-care phase of his treatment program. He has been in a treatment center in Van Nuys, Calif., since coming forward on Jan. 28 and seeking help under the league's drug program. He played in 27 games with the Warriors, averaging 10 minutes of playing time and 3.5 points.

title: Deciphering the Book of Man
description: The information in the human chromosomes, if printed out in full, would stretch through some 75 Manhattan phone directories or, more conveniently, across four compact disks. Deciphering the three billion units of DNA that compose this genetic data bank has long seemed a distant dream. Machines can now analyze up to 1,000 DNA units an hour, thus bringing the cost of that enterprise down to a mere $3 billion. That's still too big a stake for the Federal Government to risk, but maybe biologists can find other patrons.

title: 4 CHANCELLORS NAMED BY CALIFORNIA REGENTS
description: The University of California's Board of Regents today approved appointments of four new chancellors for the nine-campus system, including the first women in the university's history.

title: Dispute Imperils S.A.S. Jet Order
description: The Scandinavian Airlines System threatened to cancel a planned $1.5 billion order for American-made jets and buy European Airbus planes unless the United States gave it freer access to the American market. S.A.S.'s board said it had received an aggressive counterbid from Airbus Industrie.

title: Shelter Animals Make Poor Research Subjects
description: To the Editor: Douglas Hess (letter, Feb. 27) objects to your Feb. 1 editorial Topics item ''Laboratory Pets,'' which opposed the use of shelter animals for experimentation (commonly referred to as pound seizure). Mr. Hess states, ''It is irrational at best and hypocritical at worst so to limit the pool of experimental animals and thereby increase the cost of biomedical research.'' He also points out that euthanasia is performed on most strays in shelters, and that they die a ''purposeless death.'' It is not that simple. Although the initial cost of pound animals is low, their use is not economical, except perhaps for nonsurvival surgery. Because of their unknown genetic and medical backgrounds, the use of pound animals can yield misleading results, paid for not only in the unnecessary suffering of the animals used, but also in the wasted time and salaries of the investigators, and in all the other costs of conducting research, and sometimes even in delays in scientific progress. (The National Institutes of Health, which supports most of the research in this country, does not use shelter animals in its own laboratories.) There are other reasons why pound seizure is objectionable.

title: IOWA WINS IN OVERTIME RALLY; L.S.U. TOPS DEPAUL
description: Duke was willing and, for spots in the game, the Blue Devils were able. But Indiana, relying on superior strength and quickness inside, was simply too powerful and defeated Duke, 88-82, in a Midwest Regional semifinal tonight.

title:
PATENTS;
Easing the Examination Of Very Small Data
description: LEAD: A microscopic display system invented by Prof. Robert S. Ledley of Georgetown University in Washington should simplify the examination of minutely recorded medical and other data. Both a low-power scanning and a high-power magnified image can be viewed simultaneously. Professor Ledley, who serves with the National Biomedical Research

title: A.M.C. Delays Chrysler Action
description: The American Motors Corporation said today its board had reviewed the Chrysler Corporation's merger proposal but had taken no action on it.

title: COLONIAL COMMERCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $49,044. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $132,990 for the quarter, and net from discontinued operations of $23,518 for the year. The company said share earnings have not been presented since earnings subsequent to Dec. 31, 1982, benefit the preferred shareholders until preferred shareholders' equity equals or exceeds the liquidating and mandatory redemption values.

title: DOLE SEES AIDS ISSUE AS KEY ONE IN '88 RACE
description: Senator Robert Dole said today that the AIDS issue would be a major one in the 1988 Presidential race and that the Government should consider spending several billion dollars to deal with preventing the spread of the disease.

title: LIBERTY HOMES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Clean, At a Price
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's college basketball tournament is providing great sports television, exciting games leading to a national championship - but a sad refusal to defend individual rights.

title: Mets Notebook; Magadan Illness Called Viral
description: The Mets were forced to make the first change in their master plan for opening the season today when Dave Magadan was found to be suffering from a viral infection of the lymph nodes, and he was not expected to return for at least three weeks.

title: SALE OF SHEARSON STAKE LIKENED TO RIVAL'S DEAL
description: The American Express Company's proposed sale of a minority stake in its Shearson Lehman Brothers subsidiary appears likely to resemble another Japanese investment in a leading American brokerage.

title: FREED DISSIDENTS, IN MOSCOW, URGE MORE RELEASES
description: Six Soviet dissidents recently freed from prison said today that fewer than 100 similar prisoners had been released since the Soviet Government announced decrees pardoning many of those sentenced for various political activities.

title: U.S. APPROVES DRUG TO PROLONG LIVES OF AIDS PATIENTS
description: The first drug proved to prolong the lives of AIDS patients was given Federal approval today. Both Government and drug company officials emphasized, however, that the drug was not a cure for the fatal disorder of the immune system, which has struck 33,000 Americans.

title: RIVERSIDE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,834,000 and $2,898,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the quarter also includes a tax charge of $52,000, and the income from discontinued operations in the prior year includes a $2,747,000 gain on the disposal of discontinued operations. The company said that latest-year results do not include results from the Dependable Insurance Group Inc. of America, an insurance holding company Riverside acquired in December.

title: S.M.U. Abolishes Board of Governors
description: Southern Methodist University's board of trustees voted today to abolish the board of governors and replace it with an interim executive committee. The action was taken to protect against the possibility of another damaging football scandal.

title: Awards to U.S. Artists Given to Aid Creativity
description: Six artists will receive $5,000 each as recipients of this year's art awards given by the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters.

title: REGENTS URGE A NEW EXAM FOR AID GRANTS
description: Finding that women consistently score lower than men on the Scholastic Aptitude Test and the American College Test, the State Board of Regents took steps today to begin devising an examination to replace those tests as the basis for awarding state scholarships.

title: 3 Feared Lost in Barge Blast
description: Searchers today recovered the body of one of three men missing after oil storage tanks exploded on a petroleum production barge in a remote corner of a lake. Three people were injured and four escaped unhurt in the explosion and fire Thursday evening in Lake Maurepas, 40 miles north of New Orleans. No names of victims were released. The production barge is owned by the Stone Petroleum Company of Lafayette. The cause of the explosion was not known.

title: CONCERT: 'LINCOLN PORTRAIT,' BY MIKEL ROUSE
description: The plinking of one note, repeated and syncopated, opened ''A Lincoln Portrait,'' by the Mikel Rouse Broken Consort, a group of nine short pieces by Mr. Rouse performed Monday and Tuesday at the Dance Theater Workshop. In true minimalist form, that note evolved into clockwork patterns played by what looked and occasionally sounded like a jazz-rock quartet - Mr. Rouse on keyboard, Ellery Eskelin on soprano saxophone, James Bergman on electric bass and Bill Tesar on drums - but that didn't improvise or play one unconsidered note. The concert was a rare chance to hear one of the city's finest under-discovered composers.

title: NEW YORK ADDS CENTERS TO REDUCE 4-WEEK WAIT FOR AIDS TESTING
description: The wait to take a blood test for infection by the AIDS virus has grown to four weeks in New York, and state health officials said yesterday they were expanding their hours and opening four new testing centers in New York City to reduce delays.

title: Transit Projects May Be Threatened
description: The New York City Transit Authority will run out of money to pay for capital projects as early as late May unless the state acts on its five-year capital budget plan, the authority's president, David L. Gunn, said yesterday.

title: SENATE SETS STAGE FOR REAGAN CLASH OVER HIGHWAY BILL
description: The Senate set the stage today for a major battle with the White House by sending President Reagan a highway bill that he has promised to veto despite its bipartisan popularity in both houses of Congress.

title:
PATENTS;
NEW SAFETY DESIGN FOR REACTORS
description: LEAD: A HEAT-DISSIPATING nuclear reactor, designed to protect the public in case of a meltdown and breach of the reactor vessel, was patented this week for the Department of Energy. The invention was made under contract with the General Electric Company.

title: Colombia Rebels Burn Trucks
description: Rebels dressed in army uniforms burned three trucks loaded with chemicals destined for an Exxon subsidiary, causing $250,000 in damage, the police said today. About 20 guerrillas of the National Liberation Army detained five trucks belonging to the Exxon subsidiary Intercol in northeastern Arauca Province on Thursday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Weekend on March 6 about the merger of two literary agencies - Sterling Lord and Literistic Inc. - omitted the name of a founding partner of a third agency, the Intercontinental Literary Agency in London. He was Harold Matson of the Harold Matson Agency.

title: IOWA WINS IN OVERTIME RALLY; L.S.U. TOPS DEPAUL
description: With the seconds and game slipping away, Kevin Gamble did not have time to get any closer to the basket. The Iowa senior shot a jumper from 3-point range that barely disturbed the net, giving the Hawkeyes a 93-91 overtime victory against Oklahoma in a Midwest Regional semifinal tonight.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is an area that needs attention from the very top. It's a moral question. It's a health question. A lot of people are scared. And whether it takes $100 million or $1 billion or $2 billion we need to address it.'' - Senator Robert Dole, on AIDS.

title: Steinbrenner Reins
description: A $275,000 filly driven by George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, escaped injury after falling following a training session at Pompano Park harness racing track in Florida. When the filly fell while leaving the track, Steinbrenner was not unseated from the training cart and he was able to get the horse up without incident. Steinbrenner was scheduled to drive in the opening of the Plimpton Celebrity Challenge Cup along with Oleg Cassini, the designer; Steve Miserak, the pocket billiards champion; Ken Stabler, the former quarterback, and George Plimpton, the author.

title: BILLBOARD PUBLICATIONS IS PURCHASED
description: Affiliated Publications, the parent of The Boston Globe, said yesterday that it was paying $100 million to acquire Billboard Publications Inc., which owns Billboard magazine, the leading trade publication for the recorded music industry.

title: Brokerage Stake In Allegheny
description: The New York brokerage Spear, Leeds & Kellogg has purchased a 7.1 percent stake, or 136,000 preferred shares, in Allegheny International Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Spear, Leeds said it had bought the shares ''in the ordinary course of its trading activities.''

title: FIRECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: MUSIC: RICHARD STOLZMAN
description: The clarinetist Richard Stoltzman offered a little bit of everything in his Sunday evening concert at Carnegie Hall - a towering masterpiece by Mozart, the Quintet in A for Clarinet and Strings; dapper minimalism by Steve Reich (''New York Counterpoint'') and Jeremy Wall (''Spiral''); a showy display piece for solo clarinet by William Thomas McKinley; a jazzy tribute to Benny Goodman; Leonard Bernstein's distinctly American derivation from Paul Hindemith, the Sonota for Clarinet and Piano, and a selection from ''West Side Story.''

title: CELEBRATING 40 YEARS OF THE HOUSE OF DIOR
description: The House of Dior, a worldwide fashion empire with annual sales of more than $700 million, is celebrating its 40th anniversary here with a glittering whirl of receptions, a grand dinner and a museum exhibition.

title: INSIDE
description: Spying on Israel Reported

title: Wolfgang Zuelzer Dies at 77, Ex-Health Institutes Official
description: Wolfgang W. Zuelzer, former director of the division of blood diseases and resources at the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute of the National Institutes of Health, died today of acute leukemia. He was 77 years old.

title: STALKING THE RIGHT WINE
description: IT'S Saturday, and people everywhere are heading for, dallying in or returning home from a wine store. What Monday once was to laundry, Saturday now is to wine.

title: MORT SAHL, STILL BITING, ENDORSES HAIG
description: Mort Sahl thinks there is nothing strange about his helping Alexander M. Haig Jr. raise money. These are days when the edges of everyone's politics are a little blurred.

title: 4 JERSEY SUICIDE VICTIMS SHOW TRACES OF COCAINE
description: The four Bergenfield, N.J., teen-agers who asphyxiated themselves in a suicide pact last week had taken cocaine about two hours before their deaths, the Bergen County prosecutor said yesterday.

title: ROBERT-JEAN LONGUET
description: Robert-Jean Longuet, a lawyer and journalist who was a great-grandson of Karl Marx, has died in a Paris hospital, his family said today. He was 85 years old.

title: AIDS Strategies
description: To the Editor: Your March 1 editorial on acquired immune deficiency syndrome advocates wider counseling and testing, public education and treatment of intravenous drug abusers. This is no ''new strategy against AIDS.'' These were all part of the strategy devised last June at a meeting of senior U.S. Public Health Service officials and nongovernmental consultants at Berkeley Springs, W.Va., reported in Public Health Reports (July-August, 1986). DONALD R. HOPKINS, M.D. Assistant Surgeon General, Deputy Director, Centers for Disease Control Atlanta, March 5, 1987

title: TV CONTRACEPTIVE ADS BACKED IN POLL
description: A substantial majority of Americans say that television stations should be allowed to show advertising for contraceptives and that they would not be offended by such ads, according to a recent poll by Louis Harris and Associates Inc.

title: LICENSING BOARD DISCIPLINES A DEPUTY MEDICAL EXAMINER
description: The Board of Regents voted unanimously today to censure and reprimand one of New York City's deputy chief medical examiners for professional misconduct.

title: Trouble Spots Listed For Weekend Traffic
description: The New York City Department of Transportation listed the following trouble spots for traffic this weekend:

title: Ecolab to Buy Chemlawn
description: The Chemlawn Corporation agreed today to be acquired by Ecolab Inc. of St. Paul, apparently thwarting an unsolicited takeover bid from Waste Management Inc.

title: A SKATER ON FIRE: SPRING RETURNS TO CENTRAL PARK
description: The arrival of spring is traditionally heralded across the country with the return of the famous swallows, the crowning of forsythia queens and crop fertility rites. In New York, it was celebrated by setting an ice skater on fire in Central Park .

title: SAND TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: DRUG SMUGGLERS: NEW BREED OF ETHNIC GANGS
description: As the Mafia's role declines, the multibillion-dollar heroin trade in New York is increasingly being conducted by criminal organizations that together sound like a United Nations of drug smugglers, including Chinese, Thais, Pakistanis, Indians, Iranians, Afghans, Nigerians and Israelis.

title: POPULAR ESOP'S GET TAX AID
description: The Reflexite Corporation, a manufacturer of reflective materials with 126 workers, started an employee stock ownership plan in 1985 - and the results have been dramatic.

title: FRANCE ACCUSES 6 OF ROCKET SPYING
description: The French counterintelligence service has charged two Eastern bloc nationals and four Frenchmen with trying to pass secret information on European rocket technology to a foreign country.

title: NETS SHOT DOWN BY BAGLEY'S JUMPER
description: John Bagley's jump shot from the top of the key with three seconds to play tonight gave the Cleveland Cavaliers a 106-105 victory over the New Jersey Nets.

title: DIODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: KITTLE CHANCES ARE NO LAUGHING MATTER
description: In the warm solitude of the early afternoon earlier this week, Dave Righetti searched for answers to a spring of discontent. He stood alone on a pitcher's mound in the bullpen at Fort Lauderdale Stadium, not far from the watchful observance of his pitching coach, Mark Connor, and several thousand empty seats. He tried not to allow his problems to burden him.

title: Shelter Animals Make Poor Research Subjects; Appropriate Models
description: To the Editor: Your Feb. 1 editorial Topics item about the use of pound animals in research contained errors that should be corrected. Since this is clearly an issue fraught with emotion, it is important that decisions about it be based on facts.

title: GOODY PRODUCTS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,332,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a gain of $319,000 from discontinued operations. The latest year results include a credit of $345,000, which reflects the adoption of pension accounting standard 87. The prior year results are adjusted to reflect J.&P.B. Myers as a discontinued operation.

title: CAVALIER HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $30,000.

title: PSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 112, SuperSonics 108: Larry Bird scored 19 of his 42 points in the fourth quarter as the Celtics extended their Boston Garden winning streak to 21 games last night. Bird's 16-foot jumper with 1 minute 15 seconds left in the third quarter put the Celtics ahead to stay, 79-78. Bird, whose season high is 43 points, scored from the corner with 7:15 left, giving him 10 points in the fourth period and the Celtics a 97-86 lead. He scored the Celtics' last 9 points.(AP) 76ers 116, Nuggets 106: In Philadelphia, Charles Barkley had 26 points and 25 rebounds for the 76ers. Barkley equaled his season high of 16 offensive rebounds and had 9 assists. Maurice Cheeks, with a dislocated middle finger on his left hand, suffered a torn tendon in the little finger on his right hand with 8:10 left in the first quarter and did not return to the game. (AP) Hawks 114, Bucks 97: Dominique Wilkins had 41 points and a season-high 16 rebounds as Atlanta moved into a virtual tie for first place in the Central Division with a 114-97 home victory over Milwaukee. Atlanta, which entered the game trailing the division-leading Detroit by one-half game, has a 45-22 record and trails the Pistons by .005 percentage points. The Pistons (44-21) were idle. After Randy Wittman hit a jumper to put the Hawks ahead, 24-23, late in the first period, Atlanta never trailed. (AP) Rockets 126, Clippers 98: In Houston, Akeem Olajuwon had 28 points and eight rebounds in less than three periods of play, for the Rockets. Rodney McCray followed with 17 points in only three periods as five Rockets scored in double figures for Houston, which won its third straight game. (AP) N.H.L. Nordiques 5, Maple Leafs 4: Anton Stasny scored the decisive goal early in the second period and the Nordiques survived a Toronto rally to defeat the visiting Maple Leafs and take a 4-point lead over Buffalo in the race for the last playoff berth in the Adams Division. Quebec and Buffalo each have eight games remaining. Toronto is last in the Norris Division, five points behind Minnesota.(AP) Canadiens 3, Sabres 2: Ryan Walter scored the tying and winning goals as the Canadiens defeated their hosts and further dampened the Sabres' N.H.L. playoff hopes. Mike McPhee scored the other goal for Montreal, which moved 3 points ahead of idle Boston in the battle for second place in the Adams Division. (AP) Golf Stephenson Maintains Lead: Jan Stephenson held on to her two-stroke lead yesterday despite problems with her drives during the second round of the $200,000 L.P.G.A Tucson Open. Stephenson scattered birdies and several par-saving putts for a 36-hole total of 137 over the 6,214-year par-72 municipal Randolph North Golf Course. Sally Quinlan shot the day's low round, a 68, to take second place at 139.(AP) Mast Fires 68 to Lead: In New Orleans, Dick Mast birdied the final hole to finish off a 68 that left him one stroke in front of the field yesterday in the second round of the $500,000 USF&G Classic. Mast reached the tournament halfway point at 132, 12 under par. But Jim Thorpe led the wholesale assault on par with a 9-under-par 63 in which he one-putted 13 times. Bob Gilder, a non-winner for four years, retained his second-place standing with a 68 that left him at 133. Ben Crenshaw, with a 68, Thorpe and Ronnie Black, who had a 67, were another stroke behind at 134.(AP) Douglass Moves Up: The defending champion, Dale Douglass, fired a five-under-par 67 to move into a three-way tie for first place with Bobby Nichols and Bob Charles halfway through the $300,000 Vintage Chrysler Invitational seniors' tournament at Indian Wells, Calif.(AP) Horse Racing Saucey Missy First: Saucey Missy raced to an 8 1/2-length victory in the $29,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares 4 and up at Aqueduct. The 4-year-old daughter of Sauce Boat-Bed Shy rushed to the lead entering the stretch and widened her advantage through the lane under David Nuesch. Saucey Missy went seven furlongs on the fast track in 1:24 3/5 for her first victory in three starts this year. Flantasia was a nose ahead of Just Gorgeous. Saucey Missy earned $17,400 for Morris Bailey and returned $4.60 for $2 as the favorite in the field of eight. Swimming Big Finish for Meagher: Mary T. Meagher, an Olympic gold medalist wound up her college career by winning the 100-yard butterfly in the 6th N.C.A.A. Division I swimming and diving championships in Indianapolis. Meagher outraced the defending champion, Jenna Johnson, to establish an N.C.A.A. and U.S. Open record of 52.46 seconds in the event. Texas, seeking its fourth consecutive championship and leading in point standings since the opening event, had 438 points heading into Saturday's final day of competition. Stanford was second at 395 1/2 and Florida, the runner-up the last two years, was a distant third at 218. (AP) Squash Cogswell, Nimick Winners: John Nimick of Philadelphia and Sue Cogswell of New York City were the winners in the $13,500 Mutual Benefit United States Pro Squash Racquets tournament that ended March 12 at the Uptown Racquet Club. Nimick, seeded second, defeated Juan Mendez of Mexico City, seeded sixth, 18-16, 15-8, 15-12, in the men's final. The women's final was won by the top-seeded Cogswell, who defeated second-seeded Alicia McConnell, the defending champion, 13-15, 15-7, 16-15, 12-15, 15-9.

title: Article 907487 -- No Title
description: The Federal Government deficit surged to $28.37 billion in February, the biggest imbalance in nine months, the Treasury Department said today.

title: DANCE: TIBETAN OPERA AT ASIA SOCIETY
description: The program called ''Tibetan Opera, Music and Dance from Lhasa,'' presented by the Asia Society today at 2 and 8 P.M., is certainly worth a visit for anyone interested in Asian theatrical forms.

title: AT THE AUTOMAT, MEMORIES ARE FREE
description: ''Extraordinary how potent cheap music is,'' says a character in Noel Coward's ''Private Lives.'' The macaroni and cheese at the Automat is equally potent.

title:
Patent;
Electric Cable Container
description: LEAD: David J. Young, an electrician in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., has invented a container from which several hundred feet of electric cable can be conveniently dispensed in a home or office building. Flexible material such as nylon is used instead of the customary cardboard, which is likely to break. Patent 4,650,073 was granted this week to Mr.

title: RUSSIAN FAULTS AFGHAN INVASION
description: A deputy Soviet delegate to the United Nations said in New York yesterday that the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan was ''a mistake.''

title: Israel Stumbles Into Virtue
description: Even when Israel's coalition leaders do right, it seems to come out wrong. It's been an open secret for years that Israel has been a covert arms supplier to South Africa. All that has been hidden is the size of the trade; estimates vary from $40 million to $800 million a year. Now Israel is finally moving to halt what it has never acknowledged - but it won't say when, and its leaders imply that their welcome decision is somehow a favor to the United States. Perversely, the effect is to deny Israel the credit it deserves.

title: Fencing Title To Notre Dame
description: Notre Dame, led by Molly Sullivan's 10-0 sweep, won its first National Collegiate Athletic Association women's fencing title with victories today over Columbia and Temple.

title: DOW SURGES 33.95, TO RECORD 2,333.52
description: It was the good witch who paid a visit to Wall Street yesterday, sending stock prices sharply higher to record levels and lifting the Dow Jones industrial average over the 2,300 level for the first time ever.

title: BAKKER, EVANGELIST, RESIGNS HIS MINSTRY OVER SEXUAL INCIDENT
description: The Rev. Jim Bakker, a leading television evangelist, has resigned his ministry, asserting that he was maneuvered into a sexual encounter six years ago and subsequently blackmailed.

title: Books of The Times; White House Beat
description: HOLD ON, MR. PRESIDENT. By Sam Donaldson. Illustrated. 260 pages. Random House. $17.95.

title: AARON BROTHERS ART MARTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said for comparative purposes, certain of the prior-year data has been presented on a pro forma basis to give retroactive effect to the September 1985 acquisition of the predecessor operating subsidiary, Aaron Brothers Inc.

title: KEY RATES
UNION VALLEY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary item of $281,000. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a reorganization and issuance of 600,000 additional shares in August 1986.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
WIDE WALKOUTS IN YUGOSLAVIA PROTEST AUSTERITY WAGE PLAN
description: Throughout Yugoslavia since the beginning of this month, thousands of workers have walked off their jobs to protest severe wage restraints when the prices of most necessities are being raised.

title: Drug Expected to Spur Growth and Profit of Its Maker
description: The Burroughs Wellcome Company and its parent, the Wellcome Foundation Ltd. of Britain, are expected to grow rapidly and reap substantial profits from the sale of Retrovir, the drug approved yesterday by the Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of patients with acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: 30-Year Sentence for Arson
description: An Englewood man was sentenced today to 30 years in prison for setting a boarding-house fire that killed seven people, including his pregnant girlfriend. The man, Walter Lee Craig, 20 years old, was found guilty Jan. 29 of seven counts of manslaughter and one count of arson for setting the fire at the boarding house in Englewood in May 1985 after his 17-year-old girlfriend told him she wanted to have an abortion. He was acquitted of felony murder. Superior Court Judge James S. Madden sentenced Mr. Craig to three consecutive 10-year terms for three of the manslaughter counts.

title: 4% Inflation in Canada
description: Higher prices in Canada for housing, clothing and recreation last month pushed the annual rate of inflation to 4 percent, from 3.9 percent in January, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. Five of the seven major components of the consumer price index rose, led by increases of five-tenths of 1 percent for housing, 1.8 percent for clothing and 1.4 percent for recreation. Moderating those advances were an unchanged food index and a small decline in transportation.

title: ART'S WAY MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $372,000 and $643,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: GULF WAR THREATENING THE GOOD LIFE
description: It is 9 o'clock on a Saturday night at the Sultan Center, and Kuwaitis are doing one of the things they do best: consuming.

title: McCarran-Walter Strikes Again
description: No, the Immigration and Naturalization Service insisted, it is not persecuting eight immigrants it seeks to deport. Evidence that the immigrants are dangerous troublemakers would be revealed at a court hearing, officials promised.

title: Science Isn't Supposed to Be Entertaining
description: To the Editor: By presenting science as entertainment, museums that try to increase science literacy (news story, March 8) are not encouraging public interest in science, but rather in entertainment. Such an approach is misleading, and it does nothing to redress the true calamity of the widespread lack of appreciation for science in our society.

title: CHINESE ARE FLOCKING TO 'LOVE STORY'
description: ''Love Story,'' the tale of a doomed love affair that soaked handkerchiefs in the United States 17 years ago, opened to packed movie houses here on Thursday. Tickets for the film, the latest in a sporadic series of American movie releases in China, went on sale days ago and sold out almost immediately. At some theaters, crowds dallied around the entrances hoping to buy a spare 8-cent ticket, but they were hard to come by.

title: REAGAN MOVES TO SHIFT PUBLIC ATTENTION FROM IRAN
description: The White House, seeking to shift public attention away from the Iran arms controversy, made plans today for President Reagan to be more visible to the public and more available to the press.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BLAMES U.S. FOR ISRAELI DECISION
description: South Africa's Foreign Minister has blamed the United States for Israel's decision to ban new military contracts with Pretoria.

title: CONCERT: TOKYO KONSEI
description: Tokyo Konsei presented a fascinating program of contemporary Japanese choral music at the La Mama Annex Monday night, under the direction of Nobuaki Tanaka. The chorus, some 25 voices strong, sang mostly a cappella, producing a pure, even, slightly reedy tone with a minimum of vibrato. The sound seemed distilled, and had a very different timbre from the typical Western chorus.

title: Xerox Divesting In South Africa
description: The Xerox Corporation's London affiliate, Rank Xerox Ltd., said it would sell its South African subsidiary to a South African electrical and electronics company for an undisclosed sum. Rank Xerox South Africa Ltd. will be sold to Fintech, a member of the Altron Group, Xerox said.

title: MONFORT OF COLORADO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
COMMONWEALTH EDISON reports earnings for 12mos Feb 28
description: b-Includes revenue subject to a refund of $371,654,000 under the May 16 order of the Cook County Circuit Court.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A photograph illustrating an article last Sunday about the restoration of a trout stream misidentified one of the fishermen restoring the Cross River Inlet. The man pictured with Clement Fullerton was Mark Ruza.

title: IN BUSINESS, LUNCH IS ON THE RUN
description: ON a recent, unseasonably mild afternoon, groups of executives settled down at Brock's restaurant on Route 7 in Norwalk to begin what for some of them would be a two- and, in some cases, three-martini lunch, replete with heavy entrees and rich desserts. About a quarter of a mile away, Ben Savino of Danbury, an executive at the Perkin-Elmer Corporation headquarters in Norwalk, and a colleague, Ray Garcia of Shelton, were spending a much shorter time away from work in a markedly different fashion - running 3 1/2 miles in 27 minutes.

title: POSTINGS: ABC's of Conversion; 21 Loft Condos
description: Gentrification continues its inexorable march across ''Alphabet City,'' the blighted but improving area between the East Village and the East River named for the lettered avenues.

title: Pamela Brown Marries Stanley Crock
description: The marriage of Pamela J. Brown, an associate in the Washington office of the law firm Nixon, Hargrave, Devans & Doyle, to Stanley M. Crock, news editor of Business Week's Washington bureau, took place last night at B'nai Israel Synagogue in Rockville, Md. Rabbi Matthew Simon, assisted by Cantor Robert Kievel, performed the ceremony.

title: ENGLAND BECAME HER
description: VICTORIA An Intimate Biography. By Stanley Weintraub. Illustrated. 700 pp. New York: Truman Talley Books/ E. P. Dutton. $26.95.

title: BEHIND THE ACCORD ON AID TO CITIIES
description: AFTER months of lobbying by municipal officials and political soul-searching by the Legislature, an urban-aid package has been enacted that will let some hard-pressed cities balance their budgets until next year.

title: WITH SPRING COME THE FIRST BUDS OF BLIGHT
description: THESE are among those times that can really try your soul: what little snow that's left on the roadside is filthy with exhaust and sand, and spring is not yet enough in the air to have tempted even a hint of green up from the still-sleeping earth. If the daylight lasts longer and the air is not so bitingly cold, you are yet faced with the sludge and detritus of contemporary life: the beer bottles, filtered cigarette butts, plastic fast-food containers and styrofoam coffee cups that somehow never find their way to a proper garbage can.

title: BATTLE SCENES ON CANVAS AT FAIRFIELD U.
description: THE Forbes Magazine collection that bestowed ''Victorian Childhood'' on the Yale Center for British Art earlier this season now brings ''Valor and Vainglory'' to Fairfield University. And no doubt to just as warm a reception since, being a show of 19th-century military painting, it is yet another example of popular art reclaimed for serious use. Not that there is an alternative, now that there are more art scholars than there is new territory for them to investigate.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: PAPER BAG PLAYERS After 29 exhuberant seasons, surely there is nobody who doesn't like The Paper Bag Players, the imaginative children's-theater ensemble performing this week and next at the Music Hall in Tarrytown. ''Fell Off a Truck - What Luck!'' is the title of a new production of skits, music and dance, performed on a stageful of props and sets constructed out of brown paper, paper bags, cardboard and paper boxes.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Baltimore: Preserving Horse Country
description: LEAD: EFFORTS to preserve the three rustic and wealthy residential valleys north of Baltimore have been given a lift with the sale of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's 575-acre horse farm to James J. Ward 3d for about $4.5 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: Some copies of Sports Pages yesterday contained a headline about Louisiana State's 63-58 basketball victory over DePaul in Cincinnati Friday night but omitted an article on the game. A report appears today in Section 5.

title: YOUNG DANNY KAYE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BATTLE TO BUILD THE NAVY'S BLIMP
description: SPRING is here, and the Navy is buying balloons.

title: THERE IS A TIME OPTIONS ARE LOST
description: MY mother died on a cold February day, blessedly in her sleep.

title: MERITS AND DEMERITS OF DOUBLED PAWNS
description: THERE is no disputing Savielly Tartakover's old saying,''An isolated pawn spreads gloom all over the chessboard,'' but it would have been equally appropriate if he had made doubled pawns his subject.

title: Concrete Workers Wary of U.S. as Union Boss
description: At a 50-story apartment building under construction at 200 East 65th Street, an anonymous concrete worker has spray-painted a tribute to his union: ''To all employees: A new incentive policy - work or get fired.''

title: Father of French Hostage Asks for Mercy on Beirut TV
description: The father of the French hostage Jean-Louis Normandin came to Beirut today and pleaded on television for his son's life.

title: ART AND THE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: CITYSCAPE: Gimbels; A 'Big Store' Designed to Educate Bargain Hunters
description: IN an era of boutiques and mixed-use buildings, of luxury goods and marketing for the affluent, the basic, unadorned department store is something of a dinosaur - and the Gimbels building, on Avenue of the Americas just south of Herald Square, is on the verge of being fossilized.

title: Headliners; An Exclusive
description: What did Barbara Walters know about the Iran-contra affair, and when did she know it? In one instance, it seems, the White House could answer that. An official there said last week that in December and January, after interviewing an Iranian arms merchant, the ABC News correspondent had informed the President that the weapons dealer believed Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North had diverted profits from the Iranian arms sale to the contras. ABC said Ms. Walters violated ''a literal interpretation of news policy,'' which ''expressly limits journalists cooperating with Government agencies'' unless lives are threatened.

title: THE GOVERNMENT GOES TO WORK ON 'CORRUPT' UNIONS
description: PROSECUTORS claimed another victory last week in a new phase of a campaign against organized crime in the metropolitan region. This time it concerned labor racketeering.

title: A Luminous Portrait
description: REFLECTIONS OF A DANCER: ALEXANDRA DANILOVA Seahorse Films, New York 52 minutes. $69.95.

title: SCANDAL ENSNARES ANOTHER BIG NAME
description: Boyd L. Jefferies pleaded guilty to criminal fraud charges and agreed to settle civil charges in a new angle to the Wall Street scandals. Mr. Jefferies, the heart and soul of Jefferies & Company, which pioneered off-exchange trading, admitted that he helped Ivan F. Boesky break securities laws by allowing Mr. Boesky to ''park'' stock in Jefferies' name until he had enough capital to buy it. Mr. Jefferies also admitted to illegal manipulation of the stock price of an unnamed company just before a new offering. Mr. Jefferies was barred from securities trading for five years and faces a prison term, but most analysts said he would get off relatively lightly because the information he will give the Government is expected to assist the inquiry.

title: Miss Rollins Has Wedding
description: Elizabeth Rollins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Rollins of York Harbor, Me., was married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Portsmouth, N.H., to Frank Mauran 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mauran of Providence, R.I. Bishop Charles F. Hall, who is retired from the Episcopal Diocese of New Hampshire, and the Rev. Gordon Allen, rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Camilla Kuhn Is Wed
description: Camilla Reid Kuhn and William A. Quinn, both of Westfield, N.J., were married yesterday at Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church in Mountainside, N.J. Msgr. Raymond Pollard, assisted by the Rev. John R. Willis, performed the ceremony. The bride is New Jersey district manager for Doncaster Inc. Mr. Quinn is president and chief executive officer of Frank B. Hall & Company, an insurance brokerage in New York. The bride was a widow; the bridegroom, a widower.

title: Catherine Elizabeth Ryen To Wed John Simmonds
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Rollin Ryen of Oradell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Elizabeth Ryen to John Harding Simmonds, a son of Barbara Smith Simmonds of Chevy Chase, Md., and Albert Carleton Simmonds 3d of Washington.

title: PRESIDENT IN QUARREL WITH THE DEMOCRATS OVER FEDERAL BUDGET
description: President Reagan and Congressional Democrats quarreled about the budget today, each accusing the other of using ''smoke and mirrors'' to distort the truth about Federal spending.

title: STEAMING TO MOMBASA
description: LEAD: OUT IN THE MIDDAY SUN My Kenya. By Elspeth Huxley. Illustrated. 262 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Library Data Bases
description: When it comes to research, says the New Jersey Library Association in Trenton, there is no greater source of information than one's own hometown library - especially in these changing times, when computer data bases are replacing traditional reference volumes.

title: F.D.A. MAY ISSUE A HAIR-RAISING DECISION
description: SINCE the days of the Roman Empire, bald men have yearned for the trappings of youth and have paid dearly to recover the semblance of hair. Plutarch, the renowned observer of Greek and Roman life, quoted a contemporary view that long hair makes ''good-looking men more beautiful, and ill-looking men more terrible.'' The Roman biographer Suetonius reported that when bald men failed to grow hair with potions and were too poor to buy wigs, they painted their bare scalps with images of hair.

title: Review; MUSIC: NEW YORK WOODWIND QUINTET
description: COMMISSIONING new works is one important function of our well-established chamber ensembles, but a certain first-performance syndrome sometimes keeps the new pieces, even the good ones, from being taken up by groups who didn't commission them. The New York Woodwind Quintet therefore earns double credit for bringing to Merkin Hall Monday night a quarter-hour piece called ''Just Time,'' composed by Martin Bresnick for the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival, where the Taft Quintet played it two years ago.

title: RUTGERS BOARD TO HEAR TUITION-RISE PROPOSAL
description: LEAD: DESPITE the opposition of a student organization and some faculty members and the reservations of at least one state legislator, Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, the president of Rutgers University, is expected to put before the university's board of governors on April 10 a proposal for a two-year, 22 percent tuition increase.

title: Fire on Oil Tanker in Jersey
description: A fire that broke out tonight on a docked tanker unloading 26 million gallons of crude oil sent flames 20 feet in the air before it was extinguished, the Coast Guard said. Coast Guard officials said no injuries were reported and the British tanker, which was docked at the Eagle Point Coastal Refinery across the Delaware River from Philadelphia, suffered little damage in the blaze.

title: NATURAL GAS WELL IS BELIEVED FOUND
description: The bottom has, in effect, dropped out of a hole drilled 19,950 feet into the floor of a meteorite crater in Sweden, allowing 900 barrels of drilling lubricant to vanish into the earth's interior, and Dr. Thomas Gold of Cornell University believes the lubricant fell into a large reservoir of natural gas.

title: STATUE GETS HELP OFFER
description: FOR THE last 76 years, Abraham Lincoln has sat in front of the old Essex County Courthouse, silently greeting passers-by.

title: EXCUSE ME PLEASE, WHICH WAY?
description: LEAD: Some travelers can pack two bags in 30 minutes, forgetting nothing and producing no creases. Others conjure up cabs on deserted streets, or whisk through the boarding process with ease five minutes before takeoff, while I arrive the statutory one hour early only to be alternately bullied and ignored.

title: Beth Schelling to Wed James T. Robinson Jr.
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis Schelling of Newton, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Beth Katherine Schelling, to James Thomas Robinson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robinson of Key West, Fla. An August wedding is planned.

title: LIBERTY PARK MARINA
description: IT'S NOT that Morris Pesin of Jersey City doesn't like water sports. The former City Councilman showed that back in 1958, when he and a companion canoed to the Statue of Liberty to prove a point: that the Statue is a lot closer to Jersey City than most people realize.

title: FATHERS AND DAUGHTERS AND MOTHERS AND POETS
description: THE NEARNESS OF YOU By Carolyn Kizer. 97 pp. Port Townsend, Wash.: Copper Canyon Press. Cloth, $15. Paper, $9. THE GOLD CELL By Sharon Olds. 91 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $8.95. THE JOURNEY And Other Poems. By Eavan Boland. 60 pp. New York: Carcanet. Paper, $7.50.

title: TALKING: Brownstones; Special Aspects of Co-op Life
description: AT first glance, a co-operative apartment in a town house - in New York City often called a brownstone no matter what its facade is made of - may look like an attractive alternative to one in a conventional elevator building.

title: MELTING IS SLOW IN S.E. ASIAN POT
description: IN an effort to blend in with the predominantly Moslem society in which he lives, Henry Chandra, an ethnic Chinese, has changed his name and his religion. Still, he is prepared for the problems he knows will arise because a Malay, Linda Hakimin, is his wife.

title: DON'T MANGLE CLASSICS
description: To the Editor:

title: IMPROVING ON PERFECTION
description: WHEN THE FIRST CD players were sounding off back in '83, their promoters proclaimed that perfection had been achieved. Now it turns out that it was possible to improve on perfection. That's lucky; for perfection is a final state, inherently static and terribly boring. Imperfection is more fun. It allows things to go on. To prove it, those supposedly unsurpassable CD players are being surpassed.

title: Martha A. Jeffery Becomes a Bride
description: At the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield, Conn., Martha Ann Jeffery, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Jeffery Jr. of Southport, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter James Hart Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hart of Altoona, Pa. The Rev. George Coxe Bland Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Office Smoke
description: To the Editor:

title: TUTU HAS MEETING WITH REBEL GROUP
description: South Africa's Anglican Archbishop, Desmond M. Tutu, held four hours of talks today with leaders of the African National Congress at the group's headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia.

title: 7 CHINESE EMOTIONS AND AMERICA'S PASTIME
description: THE Chinese divide human emotions into seven different kinds: happiness, anger, sorrow, fear, love, hatred and desire. To baseball fans, the sport is a human drama. What is drama? Drama is an expression of human emotions, so let's connect this national pastime of the Americans with human emotions as defined by the Chinese.

title: Maureen P. McEnroe Weds Brian J. Harkins
description: Maureen Patricia McEnroe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. McEnroe of Summit and Stone Harbor, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian Joseph Harkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Harkins of Montvale, N.J. The Rev. Gregory C. LeStrange performed the ceremony at St. Theresa of Avila Roman Catholic Church in Summit.

title: WHEN MORE MANHATTAN IS NEEDED, NEW YORK JUST CREATES IT
description: IF Peter Minuit had stood on what is now the southern tip of Manhattan when he negotiated the island's purchase from the Indians in 1626, he would have been under water. Generation by generation over the last 350 years, the island has nudged itself farther out into the harbor, gradually adding more than 75 square blocks to the land area of lower Manhattan.

title: Shifting Gears at an Old Plant
description: By JAMES WENSITS

title: CLUB IS RESTORING LUSTER TO NOTED ACTOR'S ROOMS
description: Nearly 100 years ago, the celebrated Shakespearean actor Edwin Booth bought a Gramercy Park town house and, seeking to elevate the social status of actors, had it converted into a club.

title: REPLACING A FAUCET CAN BE EASIER THAN REPAIRING ONE
description: ALTHOUGH most homeowners think of it as a job that is beyond their scope, replacing a kitchen or bathroom faucet is a fairly simple plumbing project that is sometimes easier than trying to repair the old one.

title: FRESH FROM THE SEA
description: WHEN JEAN-LOUIS PALLADIN RETURNED TO Paris last fall to demonstrate what French chefs have done for America, he brought with him Maryland crabmeat, Maine lobster coral and Tennessee caviar. ''I wanted to show chefs in France how good American seafood ingredients are to cook with,'' says Palladin, who in 1974, at the age of 28, was the youngest chef in France to receive two of Michelin's coveted stars.

title: TEMPORARY WORKERS ARE GOING UPSCALE
description: CATHERINE OWENS, a graduate of Stanford Medical School, has practiced in four different states and a variety of different clinics and hospitals as a temporary physician. ''I call myself a Kelly Doc,'' she said. Andrew Jarett is an attorney for hire, and manages to keep busy and ''make a decent living'' in Chicago with temporary assignments from more than 60 law firms.

title: Three Bodies on Dutch Coast Are Linked to Capsized Ferry
description: The bodies of three women believed to have died in the March 6 sinking of the British ferry Herald of Free Enterprise washed ashore today on the southern Dutch coast, the police said.

title: Laurie Ostroff to Wed Roger Landau in June
description: Herbert Ostroff of Verona, N.J., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Laurie Jill Ostroff, to Roger Landau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Landau of Teaneck, N.J. The wedding is to be in June.

title: WHAT'S HAPPENED SINCE ACT I
description: THERE have been many changes of scenery in the production she has watched for so long. Oddly enough, the stage manager has handled the changes so deftly and precisely that they never seemed unnecessary or lacking in coordination.

title: Nancy J. Bregstein, a Lawyer, Marries
description: Nancy Jane Bregstein, a partner in the Washington law firm Shea & Gardner, and Dr. Gary Victor Gordon, a rheumatologist at the Lankenau Hospital in Philadelphia, were married last night at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie performed the ceremony.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: March 22, 1987
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 8 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. (Bantam, $4.95.) title: Melinda Miller Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley T. Miller of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melinda Miller, to David E. Friedman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Friedman of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Miss Miller is a senior at Newcomb College of Tulane University. Mr. Friedman, who graduated cum laude from Tulane, is a member of the class of 1988 at the Duke University School of Law. The wedding is to be in May.

title: COUNTRIES MOVING IN BATTLE ON AIDS
description: As the number of AIDS cases grows around the world, scores of nations outside the already highly infected areas of North America and Western Europe are beginning to gear up for a battle against what is increasingly being described as a modern-day plague, according to World Health Organization officials.

title: OUTFITS TO BIKE BY
description: IT used to be that when you wanted to go for a bicycle ride, you just hopped on your bicycle and started pedaling. But these days the right stuff for a bike ride includes not only a two-wheeler but an appropriate outfit.

title: Soviet Discloses 1977 Survey of Narcotics Use
description: A Soviet survey of narcotics users has found that most of them are city dwellers in their 20's and early 30's, affluent and well educated.

title: Headliners; A Dismissal
description: As Interior Secretary from 1981 to 1983, James Watt, among other things, represented the Government in its dealings with Indians. Mr. Watt, a lawyer, has since turned to representing Indians in their dealings with the Government. It has not been the smoothest of transitions. One client, the Crow Indians of Montana, dismissed Mr. Watt last week, saying he appeared not to be on their side. Crow leaders, who maintain that their reservation ends not at the bank of the Yellowstone River but in mid-channel, giving them water rights, said Mr. Watt filed papers saying the opposite in a boundary dispute now before a Federal court. Mr. Watt had no comment.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: REINDEER MOON. By Elizabeth Marshall Thomas. (Peter Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) The author of ''The Harmless People,'' a study of Kalahari bushmen, and ''Warrior Herdsmen'' has combined her solid background in anthropology and animal behavior with powerful writing to give us this entrancing first novel.

title: Through Jungle and Ice by Armchair
description: When winter is supposed to be over and isn't, and spring is supposed to be here and is laggard (a slower word than late), and every sunny day has to be paid for with a week of grayness or rain, you see what Eliot meant by calling April the cruelest month.

title:
GARDENING;
CONSIDERING THE OVERLOOKED PERENNIALS
description: LEAD: EVERYWHERE one looks there is evidence that perennials are the ''in'' plant of the decade. Mail-order catalogues feature them, garden centers build displays of potted perennials in bloom, small nurseries have sprung up specializing in perennials, gardening periodicals are filled with articles about them and botanical gardens sponsor highly successful symposiums on their virtues.

title: Hi-Tech Music
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: INSIDE INSOMNIA: HOW TO SLEEP BETTER TONIGHT by Dr. Bernard Dryer and Ellen S. Kaplan. Villard Books. 198 pages. Paperback, $8.95.

title: WIDELY ACCLAIMED PIANOS SYMBOLIZE OLD MASSACHUSETTS CITY'S RESURGENCE
description: In this city near the New Hampshire border, where fortunes sank with the decline of the New England shoe industry, the Falcone Piano Company is now turning out some of the most acclaimed pianos in the field.

title: 2 PIANISTS A CELLIST, ORGANIST AND OBOIST
description: Louis Lortie Louis Lortie's impressive recital at the 92d Street Y Wednesday night introduced New York to a Canadian pianist with musical and technical gifts out of the ordinary. Mr. Lortie's program also had a certain honesty - discarding the usual historical survey of styles and concentrating on the bravura extravagance that suits his talents so well. The three Liszt ''Etudes de Concert'' that began the evening were not simply technically at ease; they had the kind of tone that emanates from an attentive and discriminating ear. The use of rubato, moreover, was never capricious or for effect alone, but always fit the curves of harmonic tensions developing beneath melodic lines. Liszt's extravagance must always be believable to the heart, and Mr. Lortie made us believe. He also played two of Chopin's familiar Scherzos and then gave over the second half of his program to Ravel - with ''Gaspard de la Nuit'' and the composer's piano version of ''La Valse.'' ''Ondine'' enjoyed its customary shimmer, but ''Le Gibet'' was even more communicative. Mr. Lortie's tempo was quite slow but the quiet control and subtle chiaroscuro created an arresting bleakness. Seldom will one hear the cold horror of this curious piece so well evoked. The ''Scarbo'' movement, of course, offers a different set of horrors -Ravel's conscious efforts to create piano music that outstrips even Balakirev's ''Islamey'' in difficulty. One could only admire Mr. Lortie's conquest of this fearsome material, but the stretches of hardness and angularity seemed to slip away from ''Scarbo'' as musical character piece and into ''Scarbo'' the pianistic obstacle.
