Mr. Lortie's best playing came in ''La Valse,'' never for an instant sacrificing beauty of timbre and inviting inner detail for right notes. It is perhaps beside the point to wonder how well this young man might meet the very different challenges of a Beethoven or a Schubert. What he accomplished on Wednesday should, for the moment, be satisfaction enough. The Gagnepains A brother and sister duo from France also gave pleasure at their Town Hall debut on Monday night. They were Xavier and Martine Gagnepain, playing the cello and piano respectively. The Brahms E-minor Sonata, in particular, struck that excellent balance between graceful coherence and the darker emotional needs of this music. Indeed, throughout this evening, one felt a musicianship that ceded to the ardor of the moment but always with eyes wide open. Such an approach, of course, suited the great Debussy Sonata admirably, and in Falla's ''Suite Populaire Espagnol,'' each section became a finely drawn, vividly acted vignette. Mr. Gagnepain offered a transcription of his own from Schubert's Introduction and Variations on an Original Theme. Its premise was correct - that Schubert's original flute is not a satisfactory medium. The music's florid detail, however, sat awkwardly for the cello as did its range, which rarely descended below the instrument's upper registers. The communication and coherence between these two players was witness to their lifetime musical association, though one wished at times for a little more aggressiveness from Miss Gagnepain, who too often chose the role of accompanist in music that demands full partnership. Mark Hill Mark Hill, an oboist with the chamber group Sylvan Winds, joined a small group of string players in various combinations for an evening of music at Weill Recital Hall. Tom Flaherty's Scherzo for oboe and three strings and the Arnold Bax Quintet gave an Irish touch to this St. Patrick's Day event, though the first, with it busy post-Hindemith contrapuntal style, had little of the Gaelic in it. The other, newer piece was an Adagio in E flat by Tison Street, which in its ascending major scale at the beginning announced a nostalgic harmonic idiom from a previous age. The Adagio owes much to the spirit of ''Verklarte Nacht,'' but I think even young Schoenberg at the turn of the 20th century would have found it reactionary. Mr. Hill played with a forthright competence, though one heard little arresting in matters of sharp rhythmic profile or distinctive phrasing. He would seem to belong exactly in the position toward which his career seems to be taking him -as an honorable contributor to chamber-music life. Alex Mendez Alex Mendez's organ recital at St. John the Evangelist Church last Sunday seemed a little less sure. In a program that ran from Bach to Alain, Mr. Mendez showed a penchant for bright registrations, but also a tendency to accelerate tempos past the point where either he or the music could manage them effectively. The result was a feeling of marginal competence often threatened by stress. Mr. Mendez also played his own Fantasia and Fugue in E minor, which merged the syntax of early Romanticism with a format from the Baroque.

title: HOW DID I EVER GET ALONG ALONE?
description: WHILE the business reporters of the nation have had a field day reporting the belt-tightening processes of major corporations, a few thousand Westchester residents have been caught in the squeeze. These are the major and minor executives and their wives who suddenly find themselves among the retired. This was an occurrence they thought would take place when they were old, weary and prepared. But ready or not, here it is.

title: Cheeks Sidelined
description: IT was one of those costly victories, and for the Philadelphia 76ers the price was paid early Friday night.

title: GEORGE AND NINA, POWERLESS TO BE HATCHED
description: THE OBJECT OF MY AFFECTION By Stephen McCauley. 316 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: STAGE: POLITICAL SATIRE IN GERSHWIN DOUBLE BILL
description: After more than half a century, the barbs of political satire might be expected to seem blunted or obscure to present-day audiences. But ''Of Thee I Sing,'' which opened in 1931, ran for 441 performances and won a Pulitzer Prize, and its less successful 1933 sequel, ''Let 'Em Eat Cake,'' which closed after 90 performances, are dotted with satirical jabs that could be quite contemporary.

title:
THE JOB PICTURE ACROSS THE NATION;
Reports From Eight Regions: Far West
description: LEAD: Despite the seasonal ups and downs of the job market in the West, California, Arizona and Nevada all report fairly stable conditions in their traditionally strong service-oriented economies. State economists say that while the migration of workers from depressed oil and manufacturing regions has begun to taper off, the

title: CAN A LOW-PRICED DOLLAR KILL A HIGH-PRICED SHOE?
description: THE sliding dollar is finally changing the economics of the high-fashion shoe trade. Take the case of Joan Helpern, proprietor of one of the powerhouses of an industry that designs and makes elegant, avant-garde shoes mostly in Italy and sells huge quantities of them in America.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: FROM HISTORY Before celebrations marking the bicentenary of the United States Constitution begin in earnest, the Northport Historical Society gets first licks in with an exhibition of historic flags. Donated to the society by Harold Maybeck of Setauket, whose father founded a flag and awning company in Queens in 1906, the 10 replicas include such exotica as the St.

title: 'GRAND AND INTIMATE' SETTING FOR ART
description: VISITING Silvermine Collection '87 at Pitney Bowes's world headquarters in Stamford is like visiting a contemporary art museum. Works by major artists catch the eye - here a Motherwell, there a Dubuffet or a Lichenstein. The most beautiful part is that you can take home any canvas or sculpture you fancy. And feel virtuous besides. Fifty percent of the purchase price, as well as the $5 per person admission fee, goes to the nonprofit Silvermine Guild Arts Center of New Canaan, which is presenting the multi-media show this weekend and next.

title: Q and A
description: Hollywood Tours Question: Were Hollywood bus tours to stars' homes outlawed because residents complained they were an invasion of privacy? Also, where can I write for information on a new tour to sites of Hollywood's murders and other scandals? -C. E. S., New York Answer: In 1984, following complaints by residents, the city of Beverly Hills banned the use of tour buses weighing more than 6,000 pounds on residential streets. Since then, bus-tour operators in Los Angeles have been using minivans for three-hour sightseeing trips that go by the homes of stars. One of those companies, Hollywood Fantasy Tours, also runs an excursion it calls Hidden Hollywood that goes to places that have been marked by crimes and scandals involving celebrities. The tour does not have a regular schedule but is held, according to Rory O'Boyle, a tour guide who designed it, on demand, usually on two or three evenings a month. The three-hour trip - by van - costs $35 a person.

title: FUNDS ASKED FOR CANCER DATA
description: LEAD: SEVERAL Hartford-area hospitals are awaiting word about whether financing will be renewed for their participation in a coast-to-coast cancer treatment project.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE Commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, Dr. Richard T. Dewling, has decided not to use the chemical insecticide Dimilin against the gypsy moth, even on a test basis. The department, he said, will not use any chemical pesticides unless safer methods of controlling the insect are proved ineffective.

title: One Killed, 8 Injured As Balloon Hits Wire
description: A hot air balloon carrying tourists over a scenic mountain area collided with electrical wires today and its gondola plunged 50 feet to the ground, killing one person and injuring eight.

title: GETAWAY CLOTHES
description: By the Friday of Memorial Day weekend, the symptoms are usually in full evidence. Suits are replaced by blazers and slacks, shoes are more likely to be slip-on than laced and, as the afternoon wears on, tie knots tend to slide farther and farther down shirt fronts.

title: COLLEGES IN SOVIET OVERHAULED TO SPUR GORBACHEV CHANGES
description: The Soviet leadership published a detailed blueprint today for fundamental change in higher education, saying present standards did not meet the demands of the Kremlin's economic and social initiatives.

title: ESPOSITO: IS HE GOOD FOR RANGERS?
description: Yes, Phil Esposito is good for the Rangers! Esposito is good for the entire sport of hockey. His go-for-it-all attitude has sent waves through the N.H.L. and has lifted the Rangers. No longer do Ranger fans need to wait until the playoffs to see good Ranger hockey.

title: GEORGETOWN STUNNED, 88-73
description: With about 20 seconds remaining in the most glorious afternoon of his young coaching career, Rick Pitino of Providence was confronted by one of the school's heralded alumni, John Thompson, in front of the Friars' bench. The Georgetown coach extended his hand, whispered a few congratulatory words and then turned to rejoin his team. It was a journey and gesture that Thompson could have made long before then.

title: HARVARD SHUTS OUT BOWLING GREEN
description: After outskating Bowling Green Friday night in a 7-1 rout, Harvard played defensively tonight and won, 3-0, in their National Collegiate Athletic Association regional playoff series.

title: The Palme Obsession
description: In his article ''The Palme Obsession: The Murder Sweden Can't Forget or Solve'' (March 1), Richard Reeves argues that the Swedish Government has deliberately withheld important facts about the investigation of the assassination of Sweden's Prime Minister, Olof Palme.

title: SMILE WHEN YOU CALL ME ALTRUISTIC
description: TALES OF A NEW AMERICA By Robert B. Reich. 290 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95.

title: SUITS: BEHIND THOSE HIGH PRICES
description: Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States Trade Representative, once boasted at a State Department lunch about the bargain he had found last May in a tailor's shop in Seoul, South Korea. The two suits he bought there cost only $150 each, he said, adding, ''They would be $500 apiece here.''

title: Jersey Becomes A Job Factory
description: JUST OVER a decade ago, New Jersey had become synonymous in many people's minds with trouble. Its school systems were running out of money, its biggest cities were embroiled in racial and political distress, and the factories that had long given the state an identity as a manufacturing powerhouse were closing down at an alarming rate, throwing thousands of men and women out of work.

title: NICARAGUA RELIVES ITS YANKEE PAST
description: THIS GRACEFUL AND DIGNI-fied city, founded in 1524, is the only place in Nicaragua where one feels in touch with Latin America's colonial past. Sculpted iron balconies protrude from whitewashed buildings, and strong cedar beams support elegant churches. The Spanish-style central plaza is as stately as any in the hemisphere. Dominating the plaza is the enormous building that once housed the Granada Social Club, which in bygone days was the gathering place for Nicaragua's highest society.

title: L.I. DEVELOPER CHARGED IN SLAYING OF HIS EX-CONSTRUCTION SUPERVISOR
description: A wealthy Long Island real-estate developer and philanthropist was charged yesterday in the murder of one of his former construction supervisors last November, the Nassau County police said.

title: DROPOUTS BECOME 'BUSINESS INTERNS'
description: FROM all appearances, the class being held in the engineering and technology building at Westchester Community College in Valhalla on a recent morning looked like any other college class. Eleven students, ranging in age from 16 to 21, sat in comfortable swivel chairs at long tables and took part in a spirited discussion.

title: TEN MYTHS ABOUT THE REAGAN DEBACLE
description: WE ARE AT THE INTERMISSION FOLLOWING Act I of a three-act drama entitled ''The Iranian Arms Affair.'' Not a catchy title - not Irangate, or Iranscam, or Iranamok - just a simple label for a wild and worrisome plot.

title: PRIVATE CENTER TREATS SICK AND WOUNDED BIRDS OF PREY
description: LEAD: THE red-tailed hawk was lifted gently from a small holding pen and, despite an eye damaged in an accident, managed to glare fiercely. Mark Payne, wearing heavy gloves, carried the bird to an operating table in the intensive-care building at the Raptor Trust center here as Jean Stamey prepared an ophthalmic solution to treat the wound.

title: TOURNAMENT, AND MEMORIES, RETURN
description: THE cheerleaders hugged and kissed him, the fans stormed out of their seats and paraded him round the court on their shoulders. For Joe Lapchick, at the age of 65, it was the sweetest day, and the last day, of a 50-year career of playing and coaching basketball.

title: ARAB ARMS SALES DRAW LESS PROTEST
description: The Reagan Administration's proposed arms sales to Saudi Arabia and other Arab nations this year are meeting less opposition than usual from supporters of Israel, partly because of the cloud cast over Israeli-American relations by the Pollard spy case and the Israeli role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: LONG BEACH RESTRICTS USE OF WATER
description: LEAD: THE City of Long Beach is the first government in Nassau County to pass laws to conserve water, including limiting lawn watering to every other day.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
BASSIST FOLLOWS ARMSTRONG TRAIL
description: LEAD: ARVELL SHAW, the veteran jazz bassist, has no real quarrel with modern jazz, progressive jazz or any other kind of jazz that's come down the pike since those initial, explosive days in New Orleans in the 1920's when traditional, or Dixieland, jazz was born.

title: ARNOLD BAX: DOWDY, YES, BUT DAZZLING
description: SOME COMPOSERS ARE OUT OF fashion, like Hindemith, and some composers are really out of fashion. Take Arnold Bax. Bax is a name known to lovers of classical music in this country, of course, but just barely. Even in his native England, which so dotes on its dowdy old late Romantics, there is apparently considerable resistance to programming his scores in concerts - or so claims the Scottish conductor Bryden Thomson in the February issue of the English record magazine Gramophone.

title: HAVING A MINIMALIST TIME, WISH YOU WERE HERE
description: ''I DO not expect to see many travel books in the near future,'' Evelyn Waugh wrote in 1946. Like Claude Levi-Strauss, he saw the world turning into a ''monoculture.'' The sense of place would give way to placelessness, and when every country had been contaminated by every other one, the whole world would be ''Westernized.''

title: HOME VIDEO: HOW TO
description: Complete Guide to Home Security Ray Johnson 1986. Available by mail order 1-800-692-4000. Winning Visions. Inc. 55 minutes. $29.95.

title: Sports of The Times; Pitino Wins the Rematch With Thompson
description: IN the small world of college basketball, Rick Pitino and John Thompson keep bumping into each other. They held a shouting match on the sideline nearly three months ago, but yesterday the loudest thing was the score: Providence 88, Georgetown 73.

title: ARCH OBOLER, WROTE THRILLERS FOR RADIO IN 1930'S AND 40'S
description: Arch Oboler, who enthralled listeners with his tales of suspense and horror in the golden age of radio in the 1930's and 40's, died Thursday of heart failure at the Westlake Community Hospital in Westlake, Calif. He was 79 years old and lived in Malibu.

title: TRAUMA CENTERS DESIGNATED
description: LEAD: LATE last fall, at 3:45 A.M. on Interstate 95 in New Rochelle, a car headed north in the left lane hit a steel plate covering a drainage grate. The plate was hurled into the center lane where it hit a tractor trailer. The truck's fuel tanks were ruptured and spread an estimated 250 gallons of diesel fuel across three lanes of the highway.

title: BOOK BY AIDE TO MITTERRAND CAUSING A STIR
description: When Jacques Attali, who is widely known in this country as President Francois Mitterrand's closest adviser, published an admiring biography of Siegmund Warburg, the head of the German-British Warburg banking dynasty, many in this country detected a paradox.

title: Route 1's Missing Riders: Office Workers
description: THE SPRAWL of office parks, research centers, convention hotels and the like along U.S. Route 1 between Trenton and

title: ITALY' HERALDS OF THE BAROQUE
description: ''WHAT'S IN A NAME?'' poor innocent Romeo asked. ''Everything'' is the worldling's answer. A rose by any other name may smell as sweet, but it sure isn't going to get corporate sponsorship. Anyone who doubts that has only to consider the fact that not one cent of corporate money could be raised for the major exhibition of 16th- and 17th-century Italian Old Master painting that opens to the public at the Metropolitan Museum next Thursday and can be seen there through May 24.

title: TUTORS AID THE DEAF IN LITERACY
description: AT A recent session here of a literacy project for deaf adults, Joseph Linfante of East Brunswick, a volunteer tutor, used sign language, finger spelling and lip movements to read a job memorandum that Carlos Ortiz of Somerset had received from his employer.

title: INCREASINGLY, PRO CASH BEATS PRO BONO
description: JOHN S. R. SHAD, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, startled a Congressional subcommittee recently by saying that his $82,500-a-year salary, the highest at the S.E.C., was less than his daughter, admitted to the bar only last year, earned at her New York law firm.

title: Lingering in An Irish Hamlet
description: Nearly every tour bus traveling between Limerick and Killarney stops in Adare.

title: LOUISIANA STATE GOES TO THE BODY
description: Moments after DePaul had been eliminated by L.S.U., 63-58, Joey Meyer, the Blue Demons' head coach, made a complaint, in the way of an observation on something that has followed Louisiana State throughout the tournament.

title: A MAGNET FOR LOST STRANGERS
description: AN UNFINISHED JOURNEY By Shiva Naipaul. 136 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: Skiing
description: To the Editor: As someone who has spent six years looking for the perfect skiing arrangement for children, I really appreciated ''The A B C's of Skiing With the Kids'' (Travel, Feb. 22). We have recently found two excellent programs for little skiers (up to ages 6 or 7) - Okemo in Vermont and the Vesle Barnes program in Alta, Utah, the best in the West. Children are welcome from before the lifts open until well after closing. The ski instruction is excellent, and the combination of creative play and quiet time in a large space for different age groups rivals the best nursery experience.

title:
ART;
WHEN PAINTERS TURN TO PRINTS
description: LEAD: CONE EDITIONS of Port Chester, N.Y., was established in 1981 by Jon Cone, who describes the enterprise as ''a collaborative print-making workshop.'' During the last six years, he has encouraged the participation of painters who are not also printmakers, much as Universal Limited Art Editions in West Islip stimulated the practice of lithography among the painters of the New York School 25 years earlier.

title: MODELS OF SUCCESS OF NEWARK
description: LEAD: SOMETIME in the fall, this city will play host to a gathering of men and women who were born or grew up here and who have made their mark in the world.

title: RELIGIOUS TENSIONS IN EGYPT CLAIM A LIFE
description: A woman was killed and scores of people have been arrested in renewed fighting between Moslems and Coptic Christians, the police said today.

title:
GARDENING;
A PLEA FOR THE RETURN OF FRAGRANT MOCK ORANGE
description: LEAD: FASHION is as much a fact in gardening as it is in dress. Plants are in and out of fashion for a bewildering number of reasons or sometimes for no reason at all. Dwarf conifers were all the rage just a few years ago. Lately, ornamental grasses have enjoyed similar popularity. Herbaceous borders, the mainstay of gardens 80 years ago, are coming back.

title: Reports From Eight Regions: Southwest
description: The slump in the energy industry remains the overriding factor holding the region's unemployment level at nearly 9 percent, and calls are still heard for diversification of the economic base. But restoring vigor to the once-soaring economy of the Southwest through expansion of non-energy-related businesses could take three years, economists warn. Meantime, the woes in the oil patch caused by collapsed energy prices are spreading to other industries.

title: TWO CULTURES FACE THE UNIVERSAL THEMES OF RENOUNCING LIFE AND EMBRACING GOD
description: RELIGION - REAL RELI-gion - may offer its comforts, but it is not a comfortable thing. It finds the world wanting; it makes inexorable demands, and there are times, as a new stage production and a new movie in New York both set out to demonstrate, when it will settle for nothing less than life itself.

title: INSIDE
description: Few Oppose Arms for Arabs Proposed arms sales to Arab nations are meeting less opposition than usual in Washington, partly because of strains in Israeli relations. Page 15.

title: COMMITMENT BILL CONSIDERED
description: LEAD: A BILL being reviewed by Governor Kean could help resolve questions of which patients should be committed to a state psychiatric hospital and which should be treated in a community facility.

title: Attacking Problems Money Can't Solve
description: LEAD: The promise of the Great Society some 20 years ago was that since the free market could not rapidly enough raise up the neglected poor, a major government program -- indeed, a governmental "war" on poverty -- was thought to be necessary. Much progress was achieved thereby, certainly for the elderly.

title: Ditto Westchester
description: WESTCHESTER'S development as a major economic center for the region continued unabated in the last half of 1986.

title: California
description: To the Editor: I would like to suggest to anyone who enjoyed ''From Half Moon Bay to Santa Cruz'' and ''California on a Cozy Scale'' (Travel, Feb. 22) and who plans to visit our lovely beaches (including those in Southern California), to write letters to the California Coastal Commission (631 Howard Street, Fourth Floor, San Francisco, Calif., 94105), referring to Appeal A5-86-687, CDP 85-016 and urging the commission to protect and preserve the beaches and Santa Monica Bay by voting against oil drilling in Pacific Palisades.

title:
CONNICTICUT OPINION;
THE BOOKS OF OLIVER ELLSWORTH
description: LEAD: IN this bicentennial year of the Constitutional Convention, a happy chance has brought me the books of Oliver Ellsworth, the Connecticut delegate who insisted on ''United States'' as the country's proper name. Ellsworth was also one of our first senators and the second Chief Justice of the United States.

title: DRIVER INJURED BY A SHOTGUN BLAST
description: A man fired a shotgun blast last night at two motorists who had stopped along a busy thoroughfare in Queens, the police said. The motorists said they had stopped to pick up a woman who was hitchhiking.

title: AIDS AND INSURERS
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE JOB PICTURE ACROSS THE NATION;
Reports From Eight Regions: New England
description: LEAD: The ''Help Wanted'' signs that clutter storefront windows in towns across New England are not the only proof that the region has a significant labor shortage. Unemployment figures for each of the six New England states and together as a region are the lowest in the nation, and the demand for able bodies is driving up the area's traditionally low wages.

title: WHY I.R.A.'S MAYU NO LONGER PAY OFF
description: Below are answers to recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column. Q.

title: POSTINGS: Saving the Views; Quarry Low-Rise
description: Over the years, village officials in South Orange, N.J., had considered many proposals for the development of a former stone quarry. All were rejected because the buildings would have risen above a ridgeline on the sloping, six-acre site, obstructing the views of homes above. Now, however, a plan has been approved and construction of a six-story condominium complex will begin late this spring.

title: The Drive To Excel
description: As Bronx Science graduates, we were excited to read about the continuing academic success of its students, such as that demonstrated by David Kuo. During the 1960's, we were part of the unexciting group that Milton Kopelman dismisses as suffering from ''. . . the sameness. . . .''

title: THE SNARLS IN WASHINGTON WON'T SLOW THE PACE ON EMPTY INTERSTATES
description: DENNIS Laird, a Texas produce hauler, said he would like a 65-mile-per-hour speed limit, but not so that he could drive faster. ''I run 62 to 64 miles an hour,'' Mr. Laird said. ''If the speed limit was 65, I'd be legal all the time. Not only do I consider other people's bones, I consider my own.''

title: How Novels and Software Are the Same (and Not the Same)
description: To the Editor:

title: FRONTONS ASK LOWER AGE LIMIT
description: CONCERNED over steadily declining attendance, the state's three jai alai frontons are pushing for legislation that would lower the minimum age for patrons to 14 to 18.

title: NOAH'S ARK SAILS ONTO THE STAGE
description: ''WHY is the theater nowadays in such a mess?'' asks Volodya, a guide. Intending to set it all straight, he offers to lead the audience ''to the wild, wonderful, wacky and wide, wide world of total spectacle.''

title: DEADLY TRAFFIC
description: AT KUALA LUMPUR'S SUBANG INTERNA-tional Airport, a stark poster greets all visitors.

title: A NEW INTEREST IN RETARDATION INSTITUTE
description: THE uncertainty that has characterized relations between the county's Mental Retardation Institute and its state financial sources may soon be eased, according to the State Commissioner of the Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
WHERE DOES THE BUCK STOP ON ILLITERACY?
description: LEAD: ON U.S. 1, just south of the Pulaski Skyway, is a billboard that reads: ''Illiteracy Kills Opportunity.''

title: NEW YORK PURSUES TAXPAYERS WITH RECORDED PHONE CALLS
description: A recorded telephone message is the State Tax Department's latest weapon against laggard taxpayers.

title: Development and Jobs Speed Along Route 1
description: NEW JERSEY'S Route 1 corridor, a rapidly developing nine-mile stretch of highway between New Brunswick and the Princeton-Trenton region, has become a magnet for corporate and technological concerns - and for jobs to make them run - as the state's economy continues its boom.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LEAD: THE AFFAIR: The Case of Alfred Dreyfus, by Jean-Denis Bredin. Translated by Jeffrey Mehlman. (Braziller, $12.95.) Nearly a century later, ''the Affair,'' as the French call the Dreyfus espionage scandal, one of the great causes celebres of modern times, continues to fascinate, and some mysteries persist to this day.

title: JAPANESE: DELUXE, NOT AUSTERE
description: THE stereotype of the austere, spartan Japanese restaurant is shattered by the Kokura II restaurant in Woodbury. Valet parking is the first indication that this is a Japanese restaurant in the deluxe style.

title: HOME VIDEO: DANCE
description: LEAD: Bujones In Class Starring Fernando Bujones Kultur. 31 minutes. $39.95. Bujones in His Image Starring Fernando Bujones Kultur. 62 minutes. $39.95.

title: Miss Tavis Weds P. L. M. Beckwith
description: Therese Marie Tavis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Arthur Tavis of Granger, Ind., was married yesterday to Paul Laurence Marshall Beckwith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Athelstan Laurence Johnson Beckwith of Canberra, Australia. The Rev. David Schlever performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Sacred Heart Church at the University of Notre Dame, where the bride's father is the C. R. Smith Professor of Business Administration.

title: Miss Sheridan Marries Wayne Giuffrida
description: Suzanne Carol Sheridan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas I. Sheridan Jr. of New York and Windham, N.Y., was married yesterday to Wayne C. Giuffrida, a son of Mr. and Mrs. I.Cosimo Giuffrida of Middletown, Conn. The Rev. Frederick Hoesli performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan. He was assisted by the Rev. D.Bradley Murray, an uncle of the bride.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: Androcles and the Lion Starring Alan Young, Jean Simmons, Victor Mature, Maurice Evans, Alan Mowbray. Directed by Chester Erskine. Embassy Home Entertainment. 98 minutes. $39.95.

title: Connecticut Thrives
description: THE job picture in Connecticut is the brightest it's been in more than a decade, state officials believe.

title: FLORAL DESIGNERS ADD SOME ORGANIZATION TO NATURE'S PALETTE
description: THEY are artists working with live color. Nature is their medium as well as their message. Their creations are at once painterly and sculptural - and smell good, too. The five women arranging party baskets in a blossoms-strewn room in Scarsdale once worked at professions as diverse as nursing and computer technology. Now they are freelance commercial floral designers, doing work one describes as ''peaceful and happy.''

title: COPENHAGEN
description: What do they do in Copenhagen when the Tivoli gardens are closed? In fact, quite a lot. The Danish capital, while eagerly anticipating the reopening of the gardens on May 1, bustles with life. The cultural season is in full swing, and the streets are alive with shoppers and strollers.

title: FEDERAL REGULATORS SPLIT ON SHOREHAM
description: LEAD: IN the 20 years since the Long Island Lighting Company proposed to construct the Shoreham nuclear power plant, opposition to the facility, which began among community groups, has spread to include much of the public and most Long Island elected officials.

title: SLASHED MODEL ACCUSED OF RACE BIAS BY DEFENSE
description: The defense attorney for one of the two men accused of slashing a model's face with a razor told a Manhattan jury last week that the defendants, both of whom are black, were victims of ''racial stereotyping.''

title: BRITAIN LEADS WITH SEVERAL NEW ISSUES
description: THE British Post Office began its 1987 program with two divergent looks at our world. On Jan. 20, four stamps were released picturing unusual aspects and angles of plant life found in Britain. Next Tuesday, the British will release four stamps to mark the 300th anniversary of the publication of Sir Isaac Newton's work in which he established the law of gravity.

title: Betsy Malcolm to Wed A Columbia Professor
description: Betsy Malcolm, a second-year student at the Fordham University Law School, and Michael Lebowitz, an associate professor of computer science at Columbia University, plan to be married in May.

title: Gwen I. Cohen Plans To Wed James Brown
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul S. Cohen of New York and Sherman, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gwen Iona Cohen, to James S. Brown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry P. Brown of Lindenhurst, L.I.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Productivity Gains; Appetizing Street
description: West 46th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, known as Restaurant Row for its variety of high-class bistros and cafes lining both sides, has long been one of New York City's better blocks. Now it's better still, thanks to a handsome street renovation that earns an apple for the city's Department of Transportation.

title: FANCY FOOTWORK OFF THE FIELD, TOO
description: GARBED in a T-shirt and navy-blue sweatpants, Mike Daly put one sock-clad foot in front of the other and concentrated. ''Right, left, right,'' he said, panting, as he lumbered across the polished wood floor. Then, his feet got tangled. ''Missed it,'' he murmured, and started over again. ''Right, left, right.'' This time, the lumber was more of a leap, and a triumphant Mike smiled. ''Got it,'' he said.

title: Electronics Field Shows Renewed Signs of Life
description: WHEN Tandem Computers Inc. held an open house recently for prospective employees, 3,000 people applied for jobs. ''We had people waiting in the rain for one hour to get in our doors,'' recalled Gregory J. Dougherty, director of human resources for the fast-growing company in California's ''Silicon Valley.'' Out of those applicants, Mr. Dougherty said, the company might hire 50.

title: The Nursing Profession Is in Need of Care
description: THE nursing profession promises to be a wide open job field in the coming decade. The problem will be in making it attractive enough to entice young people and to keep experienced nurses, seeking better job opportunities and working conditions, from leaving.

title: BARNACLE REPELLANT FACES BAN AS MARINE HAZARD
description: A paint that has delivered mariners from the scourge of barnacles and other marine growths may soon be banned as one of the most hazardous aquatic poisons, driving up the cost of maintaining and operating recreational and commercial vessels.

title: PACT NEAR ON EDUCATION OFFICIALS' PAY DISPUTE
description: New York State legislative leaders have reached a tentative agreement that would end a two-year dispute over who should set the salaries for the top education officials in the state.

title: MX Hits Its Target in Test
description: An unarmed MX missile was launched from an underground silo here today and successfully delivered six mock warheads to targets 4,200 miles away on a Pacific atoll, military officials said. The launching and flight to the Army test range at Kwajalein Atoll was the 17th of 20 planned tests of the MX.

title: Kids on Safari
description: To the Editor: We liked Martha Eliott's article on ''Taking a Safari With Kids in Kenya'' (Travel, Jan. 4), but we disagree with her statement that group travel is the best way to travel with kids in Africa. She also says that siblings would have fought if they had not had other children around. This was not our experience.

title: COOKING CLASSES GAINING INTEREST
description: LEAD: WHILE more people are dining out or bringing home takeout food, a new interest has grown along with it: specialized cooking classes.

title: Challenge Grant
description: Late last year, William Paterson College in Wayne received word from Trenton that it had been named recipient of a $4.5 million challenge grant to expand and improve its telecommunications and applied-sciences curriculums.

title: Robots Right at Home In This Region
description: THE Westchester-Connecticut region, rarely identified as a center for high-technology manufacturing companies, has within its boundaries two of the world's major producers of industrial robots. One of them, Unimation Inc., was the first company in the world to produce an industrial robot - not in Japan but in Danbury, Conn., in 1961 -and is today one of the world's leading manufacturers of industrial robots.

title: A HILL OF WOODED WILDERNESS JUST BEHIND THE BACKYARD
description: UNTIL a few years ago, the only occupation I had ever had was that of guide on white-water and wilderness rivers, a career that took me to the wildest West, from Alaska down to Mexico.

title: Berlin at Age 750: Unusual Political Prospects
description: It is in the realm of the imaginable that next month the East German leader, Erich Honecker, will cross the Berlin wall in a black limousine and attend a festive occasion on this side of the divided city in the company of Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany.

title: The Locked Files
description: There are news stories that simply will not go away. The press can forget about them, bureaucrats can try to hide them, governments can try to wipe them from national memories. Every now and then somebody insists they be remembered. Suddenly they are alive again, demanding attention again.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ECLECTIC MUSICAL MIX FROM the Chipmunks to the Beasty Boys, Miss Piggy to Bon Jovi, it was an interesting mix of vocalists heard on the Sag Harbor radio station WLNG-AM/FM last Sunday night. A guest disk jockey, Lutha Leahy-Miller of Southampton, was spinning the platters, and since Lutha just turned 11, his choice of music and the call-in requests he received were not always in harmony.

title: COSTA RICA'S RETURN TO NEUTRALITY STRAINS ITS TIES WITH WASHINGTON
description: HISTORICALLY the best of friends with the United States, Costa Rica has been sharply at odds with the Reagan Administration of late. Determined to reassert his country's cherished neutrality, President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica appears to have rubbed powerful hard-liners the wrong way.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: TIME CAPSULE By Mitch Berman. 295 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: FOR THE KNICKS, THE WRONG WILKINS IS THE STAR
description: The Knick game plan last night was to slow down the Atlanta Hawks' running game and force Dominique Wilkins into taking shots he did not want to take.

title: LEARNING DIGNITY FROM THE 'SELTZER MAN'
description: MY FATHER, who recently turned 65, has retired after working hard all his life. He saw combat as a Marine in World War II and after his discharged he married my mother, found a job and really never let up.

title: A CHILD'S GARDEN OF TERRORS
description: LEAD: THE STRANGELOVE LEGACY Children, Parents, and Teachers in the Nuclear Age. By Phyllis La Farge. Illustrated. 242 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: Texas Women Capture 4th Straight Title
description: Betsy Mitchell defended her National Collegiate Athletic Assocation title in the 200-yard backstroke event today to help Texas win its fourth consecutive Division I women's swimming and diving championship.

title: 4 CANDIDATES PLEDGE TO SHUN RACE ISSUE IN PHILADELPHIA BIDS
description: The four major candidates for Mayor have pledged to keep race out of the campaign.

title: FOUNTAIN OF YOUTH TO TEST COLTS' STAMINA
description: With just six weeks until the Kentucky Derby on May 2, the time has come for the trainers of some leading 3-year-olds to find out if their colts can handle two turns and a distance that approaches the mile and a quarter of the Derby.

title: PENALIZED PLAYERS LEARN THROUGH SERVICE
description: SOME of the two dozen teen-agers, Mona Riscoe recalled, ''knew his name and some knew who he was after he began to talk. Some didn't know about him as a baseball player but were aware of the cocaine trials and who he was because of that.''

title: AIDS Treatment Wins the Approval Of Federal Agency
description: Deciding that the promise of prolonging the lives of some AIDS patients outweighs serious side effects, the Food and Drug Administration last week approved the use of the drug azidothymidine, or AZT. A cure for acquired immune deficiency syndrome is not in sight, but AZT may offer many victims a shred of hope.

title: THE INVOICE IS IN THE ETHER
description: PERSONAL computers have been touted as the linchpins of the paperless office, still presumed, against all the evidence, to be imminent. The catalogues I receive, however, are resplendent with paper products to feed these hungry machines. Mountains of press releases are still deposited in my mail, and the tractor feed strips torn off my reams of manuscripts are recycled by my son Revell in the production of incredible quantities of everything from papier-mache to ersatz soggy woggies -modern-day, supersized spitballs so much a part of the current educational scene. It seems to me that, rather than diminishing the paper flood, personal computers have added a major tributary to the deluge unleashed by its predecessor in the high-tech office, the copier.

title: A POLISH 'WOMAN FROM THE PROVINCES'
description: ''A WOMAN FROM THE PROVINCES'' finally works almost in spite of itself. The Polish movie, which will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art tonight at 9 and tomorrow at 6 P.M., creates a mosaic of a woman who did nothing more special than live out an arduous existence in a village. It takes a while, but the director, Andrzej Baranski, finds the truth in the truism that every closely observed life is extraordinary.

title: SCHOLARS WHO SHAPED MODERNISM
description: WITH THE DEATH IN JANU-ary of Arthur Drexler, longtime director of the department of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, and the death last month of Henry-Russell Hitchcock, the dean of American architectural historians, it has been a grim winter indeed for architectural scholarship. These two men could not have been more different in temperament, in outlook and in accomplishment, yet they shared a profound commitment not only to the pleasure of architecture, but to the idea of architecture as the central esthetic framework for our lives. Both men, the curator and the historian, saw architecture with rigorous clarity. They were not social critics or general cultural commentators so much as passionate connoisseurs.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: TOUR OF VALLEY FORGE

title: A Carefully Timed Plan on Acid Rain
description: President Reagan, who has been accused of dragging his feet on the most serious conflict between Canada and the United States, declared last week that he would seek $2.5 billion over the next five years to combat acid rain.

title: Michelle Levi to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Levi of Kendall, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter Michelle Anne Levi to Scott Michael Sarason, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Sarason of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Henry Ogilby to Wed Anne Phillips in May
description: Anne Crocker Phillips, an associate in the Boston law firm Ropes & Gray, and Henry McFarlan Ogilby, an office information systems marketing manager with the Digital Equipment Corporation in Merrimack, N.H., plan to be married in May.

title: HENDERSON'S LONG-BALL SWING DEBATED
description: THE change in Rickey Henderson's style of hitting was obvious to people he played against last season. ''He was really cranking,'' Sparky Anderson, manager of the Detroit Tigers, said. One of Anderson's pitchers, Frank Tanana, said, ''He's shown me he's trying to hit with power.''

title: Dorothy Kindred Wed in Scarsdale
description: St. James Episcopal Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Dorothy Estabrook Kindred, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G.Estabrook Kindred of Scarsdale and Skytop, Pa., to David Edward Yewer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Yewer of Chenequa, Wis. The Rev. William Jerry Winterrowd performed the ceremony.

title: Skiers Blaze a Rugged Trail Across Vermont
description: IT would be difficult to pick a better time to cross-country ski 280 miles up the length of the state of Vermont. The weather is warm, the snow deep and the days long. From Feb. 27 to March 21, groups have been skiing consecutive sections of the proposed Catamount Trail. In some places the trail is well-marked and groomed; in others it can be found only with compass bearing through the woods.

title: Managerial Class Gets Roughed Up
description: ANNA H. JONES lost her job as vice president for information systems when the Gilman Paper Company consolidated its staff and moved its headquarters from Manhattan to St. Mary's, Ga., to cut costs.

title: AMIS BEHAVIN'
description: THE OLD DEVILS By Kingsley Amis. 294 pp. New York: Summit Books. $16.95.

title: Weapons Race Coverage Cited
description: The Los Angeles Times, The Washington Post, CBS-TV News and CNN-TV have been named winners of Olive Branch Awards for outstanding coverage of the nuclear weapons race. Robert S. McNamara, former Secretary of Defense, earned an award for his book ''Blundering Into Disaster.''

title: FLORIDA RACE HAS LIGHT MODE
description: The limelight of world yacht racing has shifted to the United States in the aftermath of the America's Cup series in Australia. Some of the key players are the same, but little else is.

title: Juror Is Wrongly Jailed For His Father's Crime
description: A man arrested while serving on a jury turned out to be the wrong man, the authorities discovered Friday after he spent a night in jail. The man they really wanted was his father.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: Don't Look Back A film by D. A. Pennebaker with Bob Dylan and Joan Baez. Paramount Home Video. VHS/Beta. 95 minutes. $39.95.

title: IF WISHES WERE JAZZ CD'S . . .
description: WHEN THE COMPACT DISK was introduced, the policy makers and engineers at record companies were less than sanguine about the prospects of converting material from the 78 r.p.m. era to the new technology, and lovers of classic jazz resigned themselves to sticking with the good old LP.

title: SHIITE RADICALS: RISING WRATH JARS THE MIDEAST
description: From the bleak, stony hills of southern Lebanon to the oilfields of the Persian Gulf, Shiite Moslems inspired by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Iranian Revolution have emerged as a formidable, if unstable, political force.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Baltimore;
Preserving Horse Country
description: LEAD: EFFORTS to preserve the three rustic and wealthy residential valleys north of Baltimore have been given a lift with the sale of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's 575-acre horse farm to James J. Ward 3d for about $4.5 million.

title: UConn Building Research Park in Storrs
description: IN a major effort to attract a premier faculty while sharing the profits of product development, the University of Connecticut in Storrs joined a private developer early this month in breaking ground for a $120 million research park.

title: LA SALLE ROUTS ILLINOIS STATE TO REACH SEMIFINALS
description: Lionel Simmons scored 18 points and Tim Legler added 17 tonight as La Salle defeated Illinois State, 70-50, to advance to the semifinals of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: THE WOMAN WITHOUT A FIRST NAME
description: I MET Jim's wife at a picnic. She had a college degree, a big house, a diamond wedding ring and two little pigtailed daughters. What she didn't have was a first name. ''Hi, I'm Jim's wife,'' she said as an introduction. ''Hi, I didn't catch your first name.'' ''Just call me Jim's wife - everybody does,'' she said with a dismissing wave of her hand. ''I'm used to it. You'll just forget my first name anyway. They all do.''

title: Israel Loosens Ties With Pretoria
description: In common with more than a few countries, Israel has long been ambivalent about South Africa. It has condemned the South Africans' racial policies while quietly selling them weapons and military technology. Taking a step back from that position last week, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said no new military contracts would be signed with South Africa. Cultural, official and tourist relations will also be curtailed, and possible economic sanctions will be studied. Israeli critics asserted, however, that despite the ban on new contracts, the Government might continue its current military dealings with Pretoria indefinitely.

title: Gardener's Dream: No Cloudy Days
description: WHAT gardener hasn't been frustrated at times by a scarcity of sunshine to make things grow or ripen? Lawrence E. Stanhope of Lakeland, Fla., came up with a solution.

title: Carlton Loses Job
description: IT'S hard to get back your old stuff when you're 42 years old, especially if your old stuff was the stuff of legends. Now after trying for a comeback as an unpaid, nonroster pitcher at the Phillies' training camp, Steve Carlton has been dropped from the squad. For Carlton, a four-time Cy Young Award winner who spent 15 of his 22 major-league seasons with the Philadelphia Phillies before his release last June, the anticlimactic end came after the left-hander, knowing his job was on the line, allowed four runs on four hits Friday in the Phillies' 8-3 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals. That brought his exhibition totals to 13 hits and 7 earned runs in 14 innings and prompted a decision by the Phillies' front office. John Felske, the Phillies' manager, Bill Giles, the club president, and other team executives marked their votes on slips of yellow paper and when they were read out, some said ''let him go,'' some said ''another start,'' but none said, ''give him a contract.''

title: GLUM ROCK: MOPE AROUND THE CLOCK
description: ''I CAN'T HELP THE WAY I feel,'' Morrissey of the Smiths sings on the band's new double album, ''Louder Than Bombs.'' Guitar chords ring, the drummer knocks out an easy shuffle, and Morrissey elaborates, ''You can kick me, and you can punch me, and you can break my face, but you won't change the way I feel.'' That's a boast.

title: GOOD RUNNERS NEED GOOD SHOES
description: LEAD: In those vernal seasons of the year, when the air is calm and pleasant, it were an injury and sullenness against Nature not to go out and see her riches, and partake in her rejoicing with heaven and earth. - John Milton ''Tractate of Education''

title: Departing U.S. Envoy Optimistic on Manila
description: The United States Ambassador, completing a three-year posting here, says he has seen the Philippines ''trade certainty for uncertainty'' in its transition from the Marcos to the Aquino eras.

title: NEVER MIND THE CROCUS. BATTER UP!
description: THE first sign of spring is not the date on the calendar or the budding of a crocus, but the opening of the baseball training camps.

title: FEDERAL AGENCY REPORT RENEWS DEBATE ON VALUE OF A DOLLAR IN EDUCATION
description: PARENTS who have scrimped to send their children to private schools or voted for higher taxes to improve their public school systems may be confused by the Education Department's recent statements discounting the value of the dollar in promoting student achievement.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: LITURGICAL DANCE One of the few liturgical dance groups in the United States will perform at 10 A.M. today in the Stratford United Methodist Church at 2600 Main Street. The program, produced and directed by the Rev. Kathleen LaCamera, is ''In Defense of Creation.''

title: KEEPING THEIR WIT ABOUT THEM
description: ALTHOUGH THERE WILL ALWAYS be actresses who make audiences laugh by poking fun at themselves and their characters, the preferred path to comedy is that of wit and intelligence, as demonstrated by a number of women currently performing on the New York stage. Giving droll performances of the most serious intentions and the most pleasurable results are Lisa Banes, Laura Hicks and Patricia Hodges as a time-trekking trio in ''On the Verge or the Geography of Yearning'' and Dianne Wiest in ''Hunting Cockroaches.'' Recently there was also Anna Levine in ''The Maderati.'' One key to the combined success is that the actresses do not try to be funny - and they are not primarily comedy performers.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESIDENTS MUST SPEAK OUT
description: LEAD: AN open letter to my former colleagues on the N.C.A.A. Presidents' Commission:

title: Target Qaddafi
description: Seymour Hersh's article raises questions which the Congress should have been asking long ago:

title: Data Bank: March 22, 1987
STOPPING THE HIGH-TECH GIVEAWAY
description: WHEN Reagan Administration opposition forced Fujitsu Ltd. to drop its plans to buy control of the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation last week, Fujitsu and Fairchild executives immediately made it clear that their relationship was not dead. The two companies now plan to enter into a series of technology-exchange and development programs and joint manufacturing projects that will enable the companies to make and sell each other's products.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: MAN'S WORK. By John Connelly. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $14.95.) John Connelly's first collection of short stories is set in a drab middle America familiar to readers of Frederick Barthelme and Raymond Carver. Written in a vigorous prose, the 10 stories focus on disengaged workers -waitresses, clerks and salesmen whose lives peaked early and are now in decline; they are all about contained anger and unacknowledged depression.

title:
GARDENING;
CONSIDERING THE OVERLOOKED PERENNIALS
description: LEAD: EVERYWHERE one looks there is evidence that perennials are the ''in'' plant of the decade. Mail-order catalogues feature them, garden centers build displays of potted perennials in bloom, small nurseries have sprung up specializing in perennials, gardening periodicals are filled with articles about them and botanical gardens sponsor highly successful symposiums on their virtues.

title: The Drive To Excel
description: In her article ''The Drive to Excel'' (Feb. 22), Anna Quindlen systematically refuses to take seriously the view that excellence in mathematics and science are significantly related to genetic factors. She credits only social scientists who insist that family environment is the major factor in explaining the pre-eminence of so many Asian-American students in these fields.

title: KISSING OFF SNOW WHITE
description: THE new fairy tales rising out of the social and political struggles of the late 1960's and 1970's excite me both as a literary critic and as the father of a 2 1/2-year-old daughter. Cinderella, Snow White, Sleeping Beauty and the other chaste heroines have been radically transformed. Comatose princesses no longer wait for their dream princes or venerable fathers to rescue them. The princes tend to stumble over their own feet rather than perform valiant deeds. Fierce dragons and giants turn out to be friendly, while mysterious witches, once seen as evil, often possess the healing power of wise women. War and violence are not portrayed as viable means for resolving problems and disputes.

title: Art
description: With her exhibition at the Gruenebaum Gallery (415 West Broadway, through April 4), Susan Rodgers has established herself as one of the best steel sculptors around. She works with scraps that she finds mainly in junkyards. She lengthens or shortens, twists or bends the steel, but leaves it fundamentally unaltered. Some scraps are welded together, others left unjoined: this fluent, confident, seemingly harmonious vision is filled with absence.

title: INCINERATOR STANDARDS PROPOSED
description: LEAD: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency would have to establish air-emissions standards for solid-waste incinerators under legislation being proposed by Representative James J. Florio, Democrat of the First District (Gloucester County and parts of Camden County).

title: DEFENDER OF FRENCH STYLE
description: FRENCH MUSICAL STYLE - always elusive - has become even more so in recent years. Indeed, many fear it is vanishing altogether. In somewhat of a coup, the Metropolitan Opera now has within its walls three eminent conservators of an esteemed tradition. Manuel Rosenthal has been conducting the Met's new ''Manon,'' Hugues Cuenod, the tenor, is appearing as the Emperor in the house's even newer ''Turandot,'' and, making his Met debut in next Saturday's ''Samson et Dalila'' is the conductor Jean Fournet.

title: Virginia Dailey Is Planning to Marry August Belmont 3d, Banker, on Aug. 8
description: The engagement of Virginia Dailey to August Belmont 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William T. Dailey Jr. of Hillsborough, Calif., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. Belmont Jr. of Pasadena, Calif., and Anne Marie Wilson of Carmel, Calif., and a great-great-great-grandson of the original August Belmont of New York, the banker and president of the American Jockey Club. The wedding is to be Aug. 8. Miss Dailey, an account services representative at the Eric Sommer advertising agency in Washington, graduated from Georgetown University. Her father is a partner in Montgomery Securities, an investment bank in San Francisco. The future bride is a granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dailey of Manhasset, L.I., and of the late Mr. and Mrs. Victor L. Ridder of Pelham Manor, N.Y. Mr. Dailey, now retired, was a senior vice president of the Interstate Container and Paper Corporation in New York. Mr. Ridder was publisher of Catholic News, a weekly newspaper in New York.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: The lavish pictorial display in Mary C. Henderson's THEATER IN AMERICA: 200 Years of Plays, Players, and Productions (foreword by Joseph Papp; Abrams, $45) should not deter one from reading the text, for this is both a book for browsers and a valuable and relatively concise history. Ms. Henderson, formerly the curator of the Theater Collection at the Museum of the City of New York, has the curiosity of a bibliophile as well as the enthusiasm of someone who loves the stage. Her book is divided according to profession, with chapters on producers, playwrights, actors and so on. Each story is told chronologically, which means there is a certain amount of repetition. At the same time, each chapter is independent and useful for reference. Enter anywhere and one is immediately immersed in tales about prominent theatrical personalities, from the Booth brothers (Edwin, Junius Brutus Jr. and John Wilkes) to R. H. Burnside, who cast elephants as well as actors in his spectacles at the Hippodrome Theater. The book is as up to date as La Mama and Mabou Mines and it is adorned with visual curios, including a colorful page of cameo portraits -cards depicting old theaters - that the tobacco company P. Lorillard inserted in cigar boxes in the early part of the century.

title: Impeachment of a Judge Suggested
description: ''Be assured that I'm going to be a judge for life,'' Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings told reporters in 1983, after a Miami jury acquitted him of conspiring to solicit a $150,000 bribe from two racketeers. Now he is facing an attempt to remove him from the bench under a 1980 law providing self-policing procedures for Federal judges.

title: AIDS PATIENTS GRASPING AT HOPE WITH NEW DRUG
description: Although he has been told he is dying of AIDS, Nick Pippin - a 32-year-old actor - considers himself on a lucky roll.

title: 4 IN FAMILY SHARE ART AFFINITY
description: LEAD: AT first glance, the four artists now exhibiting at Canio's Books in Sag Harbor would seem to have little in common - artistically, at least. They've hung gentle watercolor landscapes; subdued abstract lithographs and mixed-media canvases; detailed, finely made drawings, and candid photographs of children and places.

title: POSTINGS: 5,700 Sq. Ft.; Modular Mansion
description: Most modular houses are simple, predesigned stuctures kept under 2,500 square feet for easy shipment and assembly. But a modular home planned for Mamaroneck, N.Y. is shattering that stereotype with an elaborate French-provincial design and 5,700 square feet of space.

title: INDIANS IN NEW YORK SEARCH FOR A BETTER LIFE
description: Lavonne Hill, a Seneca Indian from upstate New York, spoke of a Mohawk friend who wanted to return to the reservation and her roots. But the friend's parents had moved to Brooklyn before she was born.

title: LETTING GRANDPA DELIVER THE NEWS
description: TO Brian J. Kelly, using children to deliver the weekly Greenwood (Ind.) Gazette to 19,000 geographically dispersed customers made no sense. So he went to the other extreme - he contracted the delivery work out to a local senior citizen center.

title:
GARDENING;
CONSIDERING THE OVERLOOKED PERENNIALS
description: LEAD: EVERYWHERE one looks there is evidence that perennials are the ''in'' plant of the decade. Mail-order catalogues feature them, garden centers build displays of potted perennials in bloom, small nurseries have sprung up specializing in perennials, gardening periodicals are filled with articles about them and botanical gardens sponsor highly successful symposiums on their virtues.

title: Correction
description: A report on March 15, about bills before the General Assembly's Public Health Committee dealing with acquired immune deficiency syndrome, misidentified State Senator Cynthia Matthews of Wethersfield, the committee's co-chairwoman. She is a Democrat.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE PATHOLOGY OF POWER. By Norman Cousins. (Norton, $15.95.) According to Norman Cousins, the world is mad. ''The Pathology of Power'' traces the etiology of its illness, from Hiroshima, where the decision to drop what Harry Truman called ''the terrible bomb'' had, Mr. Cousins shows, more to do with keeping the Russians out of the Far East than with defeating the enemy there, to General Dynamics, whose manipulation of ''the Revolving Door strategy, the 'perks and good fellowship' gambit, and the Blackmail ploy'' brought the company immense profits and the country lousy weapons systems. With nation-states threatening rather than protecting their citizens through their ''false reliance on unworkable power'' - that is, on nuclear force - Mr. Cousins, the author of ''Anatomy of an Illness'' and numerous other books, asks the question: Is it ''within the reach of the present generation of Americans to create global sanity''? His answer: Perhaps not, but it is our duty to try. Drawing on Gen. Douglas MacArthur's call for an ''integrated world society'' and Dwight Eisenhower's insistence on an ''alert and knowledgeable citizenry,'' Mr. Cousins, who knew both generals in their time, honors Congressmen, whistleblowers and muckrakers of our day who ''dare to speak truth to power,'' and ''everyone who has taken pains to communicate with public officials urging better policies than are routinely offered.'' Would that the problem he so passionately delineates were amenable to a progressive gentleman's solution.

title: Boxing's Order Curbs Violence
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL;
Pool Champion
description: LEAD: When she was 15 years old, Loree Jon Ogonowski won the women's straight pool title in a world championship tournament held in New York City. Last year, at 21, she won it again, in Philadelphia, and also the Motor City Open in Lovonia, Mich.

title: A Male Secretary
description: After reading Joseph Finder's article, my respect for my profession grew.

title: Minds, Molecules and Monsters
description: To the Editor: In reviewing Jon Franklin's ''Molecules of the Mind'' (Feb. 8), Barry L. Jacobs writes: ''Indeed, as Mary Shelley tells us in 'Frankenstein,' it would be easy to mistake the brain of a beggar or thief for that of a nobleman or genius.'' Frankenstein's monster must have had quite a brain; he was reading ''Paradise Lost'' within a year or so after he was assembled. But nowhere in the novel did Mary Shelley discuss the monster's brain or anyone else's. The business of putting the wrong brain into the monster's head began over a hundred years later, with James Whale's classic 1931 film. ALAN C. ELMS Davis, Calif.

title: WHAT CHARLES KNEW: HOMAGE TO AN ENGLISH TEACHER
description: HE was a tobacco brown, soft-eyed, angular man. He had transformed himself from a poor Bluefield, W.Va., mountain boy into an American intellectual. He had crafted an Oxonian mask behind which one could only surmise black beginnings. I caught glimpses of that ethnic past in the twinkle - the almost break-loose and ''signifying'' laughter - of his eyes when he told us of his dissertation. The title of that work in progress, according to him, was: ''Some Ontological and Eschatological Aspects of the Petrarchan Conceit.'' He never dreamed of writing such a work, but he enjoyed using philosophical words that he knew would send the curious among us scurrying to the dictionary. I believe he actually wrote on the ''Canterbury Tales.'' He intrigued us. Slowly puffing on the obligatory pipe, he would chide us for the routineness of our analyses of revered works in the British and American literary canons. He wore - always - a tie and tweed of Ivy provenance, and at the end of the first session of his World Literature course at Howard University in the fall of 1963, I had but one response - I wanted to be exactly like him.

title: SPRINGFIELD CAPTURES P.S.A.L. TITLE
description: Using height and muscle, Springfield Gardens of Queens won the Public Schools Athletic League boys' championship yesterday at Alumni Hall at St. John's by upsetting Stevenson of the Bronx, 66-59.

title: A Medieval Preserve
description: LEAD: The road to Albarracin twists through a mountain landscape of scrub growth and massive striated rocks of a rosy hue. Quite suddenly Albarracin and its hanging houses appear, rising dramatically over the rocks and blending in color and construction with the natural surroundings in a most perfect harmony.

title: Target Qaddafi
description: Seymour Hersh charges that the principal purpose of the Libya air raid was to assassinate Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his family. Perhaps he's right, perhaps not, but his article fails to make his case. Why? Virtually every ''fact'' Mr. Hersh adduces is attributed to a nameless ''source.''

title: H.M.O.'S: AS FIELD FILLS, STRUGGLE GROWS
description: COMPETITION is heating up among the providers of managed health care as they struggle to carve out markets in what is becoming an increasingly crowded field.

title: Crafts Carve a Niche in Rome
description: Although many people value Rome more for its historic monuments than its shopping posibilities, many shops have recently opened in the Eternal City and are changing this opinion.

title: EXPLORING THE BYWAYS OF HARPSICHRD REPERTORY
description: ''I FEEL IT'S IMPORTANT TO show a greater range of the literature than the 30 or 50 years' worth of music people normally play,'' explains Ton Koopman, the Dutch harpsichordist, when asked about the unusually broad scope of the program he will perform at the Metropolitan Museum of Art this evening at 8 o'clock.

title: PARKLAND REPRIEVE: PROBLEMS REMAIN
description: LEAD: THIRTY acres of parkland that residents in South Farmingdale and North Massapequa feared would be sold to developers has been given a new lease. Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta has pledged that it will remain a recreational area under the county's jurisdiction.

title: Data Update: March 22, 1987
DEAVER CHARGED WITH PERJURY
description: MICHAEL K. DEAVER, the longtime friend of President and Mrs. Reagan who left a $72,000 White House job to build a multimillion-dollar lobbying business, last week became the first person to be indicted under the post-Watergate law providing for special prosecutors to investigate allegations of wrongdoing against senior Government officials.

title: RECORD BURNING PLANNED
description: LEAD: PLANS to hold a rock-record burning - one scheduled for earlier this month was called off four hours before it was to have begun - have been revived here. This time, says the minister in charge of the event, the date will not be announced.

title: CAN FED COUNT ON A VOLCKER 3D TERM?
description: IF it is true that political success ultimately rests on pocketbook issues, the last two years of Ronald Reagan's Presidency may be judged by what the new White House team decides to do about Paul A. Volcker, whose four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve expires Aug. 6.

title: Miss Hendler to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Leo Hendler of Spring Valley, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Karen Lynn Hendler, to Barry Edward Goldberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Goldberg of Brooklyn. Miss Hendler and her fiance expect to receive M. D. degrees from the Stritch School of Medicine at Loyola University in Chicago next year. The future bride graduated cum laude from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Goldberg is a graduate of New York University. An August wedding is planned.

title: North Koreans Opening Doors to Australians
description: In an apparent experiment at more open relations with the West, North Korea is cautiously opening its doors to Australians.

title: Hearings set on TV News
description: The House telecommunications subcommittee has asked the chief executives and news division presidents of the three major television networks to testify on the quality of network news.

title: How You Can Survive A Corporate Upheaval
description: LEAD: DESPITE a corporate takeover, merger or downsizing, most employees can take steps to improve their chances of survival inside their company or in the job market. The important thing, said David Smith, managing director of the New York office of Korn/Ferry International, an executive-search firm, is ''to heed warnings and come up with options to a number of 'what if' scenarios.

title: A CASE FOR USING LIGHTER EQUIPTMENT
description: A friend of mine recently developed a bad case of photographer's back. This occupation-specific malady is brought on by lugging pounds of camera gear over hills, dales and city sidewalks. It strikes especially hard at view camera users, whose minimum equipment includes heavyweight lenses, holders and tripods. Being an 8-by-10 buff myself, I know well the dissonant growl of vertebrae under pressure.

title: Satellite for Indonesia Is Launched by NASA
description: A $43 million communications satellite originally delayed because of the Challenger disaster has become the space agency's seventh straight successful launching.

title: RUNNING GUNS TO ARCADIA
description: THE AMERICAN CONNECTION U.S. Guns, Money, and Influence in Northern Ireland. By Jack Holland. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: THE URGE TO MERGE
description: BOONE By T. Boone Pickens Jr. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95. THE story T. Boone Pickens Jr. tells has all the elements of high drama.

title: CASINOS WIDEN RECRUITING DRIVE
description: TRUMP'S CASTLE Hotel-Casino opened in June 1985, and the following August employment in the casino industry here hit a peak of 41,000. Since then, it has hovered between 41,000 and 37,000, depending on the season.

title: One More Year
description: HIS college coach says he is good enough to go into the pros and make an impact now, but Danny Manning, who broke the Kansas career-scoring record as a junior this year, has another year of collegiate eligibility remaining and apparently plans to put it to good use. ''I think if I stay in college the N.B.A. will still be there next year,'' said Manning, whose coach, Larry Brown, thinks Manning will be around next year, too. ''I don't think staying at Kansas another year will hurt him,'' he said. Another Kansas coach offered another reason for Manning to stick with the Jayhawks. ''His mother and I want him to enjoy his four years,'' said the assistant, Ed Manning, Danny's father.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: LOYALTIES. By Raymond Williams. (Chatto & Windus/ Salem House, $16.95.) There is a changing fashion in spies, as Janet Flanner pointed out to us after World War II. There are also different styles in radical politics. Raymond Williams explores both in a panoramic novel that spans the period from the 1930's to the 80's.

title: 7 TOWNS NEAR DECISION ON WASTE-TRANSFER SITE
description: IN a move to ease their garbage- removal problems, the seven towns of Bedford, Lewisboro, New Castle, North Castle, North Salem, Pound Ridge and Somers have banded together to establish a transfer installation to handle their solid waste. The choice of a nearby building site, now narrowed to three locations, is expected to be announced April 15, with construction to be completed by fall 1988.

title: Softball Immortality
description: THE EMPIRE STATE Building pokes up, a mile or so behind my right shoulder, as I walk through the spring wind along 11th Avenue toward De Witt Clinton Park. The rank green smell of the Hudson blows lightly up 49th Street. Soon the winter mudhole at home plate will dry into dust, the outfield crabgrass turn green and the softball games begin again, with the shouts of young men certain of their immortality.

title: AS PESTICIDES FADE, EAGLES RETURN TO ST. LAWRENCE
description: Bald eagles, recovering from the effects of pesticide contamination and human predators, are reclaiming the St. Lawrence River as an important winter habitat.

title: THE COMIC BAD MEN OF ENGLISH LETTERS
description: THE British have rarely produced the philosophical novel, the serious political novel or the novel of esthetic exactitude.

title: VICTIM'S SON: EX-PROSECUTOR OF THE MAFIA
description: William I. Aronwald, the son of the slain Parking Violations Bureau hearing officer, George M. Aronwald, earned a reputation as an aggressive prosecutor and a successful defense lawyer. Both careers enveloped the son in stormy controversies over the last 20 years.

title: POLICE ASSOCIATION'S VIEWS ON STATE INQUIRY
description: The Suffolk County Police Superior Officers Association would like to respond to the Feb. 8 article ''Head of Suffolk Police Investigation Stresses Professionalism.''

title: A Stew in Maine Over the Lobster
description: WHEN the Maine legislature followed the advice of schoolchildren in Saco and voted last year to put a lobster on motor vehicle license plates issued after July 1987, it wasn't looking for a fight.

title: FROM ATOMIC PROJECT TO THE BOARDROOM
description: ''I WAS never an empire builder,'' said Albert Nerken of Brookville. ''I always put one foot in front of the other and said: What seems the reasonable thing to do next?''

title: 'Intimate Partners'
description: To the Editor: It's a shame that Carol Tavris could not be more enthusiastic in her review of Maggie Scarf's ''Intimate Partners'' (March 1), because it's an important book that should have had a front-page review and lots of praise.

title: Ms. McCormack Planning to Wed Stephen Traugott
description: Katherine Mary McCormack, an international tax analyst for the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation in New York, plans to be married May 2 to Stephen L. H. Traugott, a partner in Supply Side, a home improvement and general contractor in New York.

title: Dance; HOW CUNNING HAM BUILDS DRAMA
description: WHEN CHOREOGRAPHERS are called poetic, it is frequently because their work looks pure and pretty. This is a romantic view of both poetry and dance, but it does not fit as far as Merce Cunningham is concerned.

title: Where Deadly Force Became Rare
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSTRALIA FOUND GUILTY
description: EVIL ANGELS By John Bryson. 560 pp. New York: Summit Books. $18.95.

title: DON'T MANGLE CLASSICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Easter Celebrations Of Coptic Egyptians
description: LEAD: Coptic Easter is the most important event in the calendar of the six million Egyptians who follow the Christian tradition established in Egypt around A.D. 60. A sect that believes in the Monophysite tenet that Jesus had one nature, a composite of divinity and humanity, it also maintains traditions related to beliefs that predate

title: Alice Cary Brown To Wed Beck Lee
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Lee Lyons Brown Jr. of Louisville, Ky., and Fishers Island, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Alice Cary Brown, to Warren Beckwith Lee Jr., the son of Frances Parillo Lee of New York and the late Mr. Lee. The wedding is to be June 13.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Gelardin
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Hugo J. Gelardin of New York and Quogue, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Nicole Gelardin to A.Mark Berlin Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Berlin of Winnetka, Ill. A May wedding is planned.

title: ESPOSITO: IS HE GOOD FOR RANGERS?
description: Only time will tell. JAY KREISBERG New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: ALIVE WITH ALL THE OLD SINS
description: A TIME TO KEEP And Other Stories. By George Mackay Brown. 306 pp. New York: Vanguard Press. $19.50.

title:
DINING OUT;
NEAR THE 'SMALL HOTEL' IN STOCKTON
description: LEAD: STOCKTON is known for Colligan's Inn, made famous by Rodgers and Hart as the subject of their 1936 song ''There's a Small Hotel.'' The Hunterdon County town was just as well known among food people for a small restaurant down the road called Le Bistro. The quality of food there alternated almost from year to year between very good and average.

title: One-Room School Expands
description: New Hampshire soon will lose one of its three one-room schoolhouses. Voters in the Newfound School District on Wednesday approved adding a second room to the Village School in Alexandria. Built in the 1850's and used by 20 first graders and second graders, the school has run out of room. The other two one-room schoolhouses are the Hebron Village School, also in the Newfound district, and the Blue School in Landaff.

title:
SOCIAL EVENTS;
Wine With the Muses
description: LEAD: Musical Benefit March 23 - Founded four years ago, the Musical Theater Works provides its theater on Lafayette Street for American musicals that are being developed or revised. Three of the 78 musicals it has assisted will be presented at the C.S.C. Rep Theater, 136 East 13th Street, starting April 3.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN:;
Montclair
description: LEAD: ON an unusually warm Sunday afternoon early this month, residents of Montclair were out making the most of a sunny spring preview. Young couples strolled through the open-air mall along Church Street, owners of Victorians and colonials broke out paint brushes and tools, and families packed picnic baskets and headed for the New Jersey township's 17 parks and playgrounds.

title: Internment in Hindsight
description: To the Editor: Patrick S. Washburn's review of Richard Drinnon's ''Keeper of Concentration Camps'' (Feb. 22) is fair in one sense, that Mr. Drinnon studies Dillon S. Myer, director of the War Relocation Authority, and his actions from our contemporary viewpoint. But Mr. Washburn's admonition to beware of ''hindsight'' is self-defeating. One must ask today's questions of yesterday's actions. It is today's questions that make history interesting. If we leave Myer and the internment of Japanese-Americans where history left them in 1946 we are looking at Myer's own view (stated in his book, ''Uprooted Americans''): a record of a selfless administrative wartime effort in difficult circumstances. The actions of F.D.R. and the War Relocation Authority were in fact unconstitutional (now admitted), and therefore illegal throughout.

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
Staving Off Rural Hunterdon Developers
description: LEAD: FOR more than two centuries, farming has been the way of life in Rosemont Valley with its 1,500 acres of green fields extending to the hills in the heart of rural Delaware Township.

title:
BUSINESS FOUM: RENEWING THE WAR ON POVERTY;
TARGET SUPPORT AT CHILDREN AND FAMILIES
description: LEAD: THE paradox of continuing high poverty during a prolonged recovery has contributed to a bipartisan consensus, evident in the recent Senate hearings presided over by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, that welfare must be reformed. We concur with this consensus. However, only a broader antipoverty effort that goes beyond welfare reform can significantly lower poverty.

title: PARAGUAY POLITICS IS TURNING BITTER
description: Marked by a bitter power struggle within Paraguay's governing party and in-fighting among opposition leaders, the noisy campaigning for the next presidential elections here could almost pass muster for a genuine competition were the result not already known.

title: DON'T MANGLE CLASSICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Passport Restrictions In a Free Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Claudette Fisher Becomes a Bride In Massachusetts
description: Claudette Marie Fisher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald M.
