He was 68 years old and lived in Montecito, Calif.

title: MUSIC: BAROQUE OPERA
description: SMALL opera in New York usually means a troupe of worthy amateurs and semi-professionals banded together to present a work that might not otherwise be heard, and one is willing to overlook certain flaws of execution for this spirit of adventure. Concert Royal and the New York Baroque Dance Company, who presented Handel's ''Terpsicore'' and Rameau's ''Pygmalion'' at the Marymount Manhattan Theater Wednesday night, demand no such trade-off from the spectator; indeed, this was one of the most satisfying evenings of musical theater it has ever been my pleasure to attend.

title: Educated in New York
description: Many a visitor to Paris is amazed by the variety of ways to order coffee. There's un cafe, of course, and un grand and un demi. But then there's au lait and creme, nature and express. It all seems incomparably foreign. And that, a newcomer to New York tells us, is exactly how she felt for weeks in the local deli at breakfast time.

title: Leading Greek Junta Member Is Found Hanged in His Cell
description: A leading member of the military junta that ruled Greece from 1967 to 1974 was found hanged in his prison cell today, police officials said.

title: ASSEMBLY CHIEF'S FIRMNESS CAUSES STRAINS WITH CUOMO
description: In his first 10 weeks as Speaker of the State Assembly, Mel Miller has significantly altered the dynamics of power here, splitting the Democratic Assembly from the Democratic Governor on several key issues and focusing attention on the strains between the administration and the Legislature.

title: SOVIET FAULTS U.S. ON MISSILES
description: A Soviet arms control expert accused the United States today of opposing the removal of all Soviet and American medium-range missiles from Europe and said he had doubts that an accord on the issue could be signed.

title: Paul Plishka New Lead In 'Boris Godunov'
description: It is easy to point out flaws in Mussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov,'' in much the same manner that one can find structural defects in the Himalayas, but there are few more majestic, epical, proud and terrible works in the repertory. The Metropolitan Opera's current production of ''Boris'' has undergone several cast changes since its revival earlier this season.

title: Lehman's Sea-War Strategy Is Alive, but for How Long?
description: Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. unveiled a daring maritime strategy a few years ago.

title: Government at Work, Dept. of Trinkets
description: Doling out trinkets and memorabilia is a longstanding practice at the White House and throughout the Government. And rare is the recipient who does not like to show off his or her gift.

title: ARCHITECTURE: LE CORBUSIER EXHIBITION IN LONDON
description: Le Corbusier never built a building in England. Yet his influence in this country far exceeded that in France, where he lived for most of his adult life. Far more than any English architect, Le Corbusier shaped postwar English architecture. So it is fitting, if more than a little surprising, that in this centennial year of his birth it is here and not in France that the most impressive celebration of his 100th birthday is being mounted.

title: Torture in Salvador
description: To the Editor:

title: MAGAZINE ON COUNTRY INNS READY
description: JUST because the last of Gail Kent's four children went off to college this year does not mean that the big house in South Orange, N.J., is now an empty nest. She has filled it with a magazine publishing enterprise.

title: OSTROW LEAVING Y.&R. TO JOIN FOOTE, CONE
description: After 32 years with Young & Rubicam, Joseph W. Ostrow, one of America's best-known agency media executives, has resigned to join Foote, Cone & Belding Communications as executive vice president and worldwide media director, a new position. He will be responsible for all media activities at FCB/Leber Katz Partners in New York.

title: War on Vaccination
description: To the Editor:

title: Buffaloed Bisons
description: You can say this for Jim Valvano: Even in the face of season-ending defeat, the North Carolina State basketball coach loses neither his perspective nor his humor. Right after the Wolfpack was eliminated by Florida from this year's national tournament, Valvano allowed that things could have been worse, and indeed had been. He recalled that in 1972, during a trying rookie season as coach at Bucknell, he once watched his Bisons struggle to a 56-point deficit at intermission. They lost by 71. ''Yeah,'' Coach V remembered, ''we had a good second half.''

title: The Lupercalia's Connection With Fertility
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH-STAKES BINGO COMES TO EVERGLADES
description: The building, two and a half acres of it, rises out of the Florida swamp like a misplaced aircraft hangar.

title: REAGAN ASKED TO NAME VIGOROUS CHIEF AT S.E.C.
description: Members of Congress and the securities industry today urged President Reagan to nominate a Securities and Exchange Commission chairman who would continue to take a tough line on law enforcement and help restore investor confidence at a time when Wall Street is reeling from its biggest scandals since the 1920's.

title: Tutu Appeals for Halt To the Guerrilla War
description: Archbishop Desmond Tutu said tonight that he had made a personal appeal to black guerrilla leaders to halt their armed struggle in South Africa but held out little hope of a cease-fire.

title: Designated White House Savior
description: Some Presidencies, like Lyndon Johnson's in Vietnam, failed through tragedies too deep for any individual to avert. Others have gone awry through such egregious blunders that it seems an ounce of common sense in the President's ear would surely have saved him. What if Presidents were to install not just a biographer, as Mr. Reagan has done with Edmund Morris, but a designated savior in the White House, charged to speak only in the presence of what he deemed a historic goof.

title: A WINTER OF CROWDS AT MOVIES
description: Led by ''Platoon,'' ''Outrageous Fortune,'' and such unstoppable 1986 movies as ''Crocodile Dundee'' and ''Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home,'' the 1987 winter box office has been remarkable. For six weeks in a row, ticket sales have set records for this time of year.

title: MET OPERA: 'DIALOGUES OF THE CARMELITES'
description: THE newest work in the Metropolitan Opera's repertory is Poulenc's solemn 30-year-old ''Dialogues of the Carmelites,'' and the production, by John Dexter, is one of its strongest - perhaps the strongest surviving emblem of the direction the house once seemed intent on taking, a direction far removed from the Zeffirelli-Ponnelle circus of recent months. Mr. Dexter has returned to prepare the work for its run of eight performances, which began Saturday night, and for its first telecast. He has an earnest and capable cast. Though the drama did not grip as tightly as it sometimes has, one felt the possibility that, with further performances, it might. In any case it emerges as one of the only two fully recommendable offerings of the house's spring calendar (the other being the not-yet-unveiled ''Samson et Dalila'').

title: DANCE: ROBERT KOVICH
description: ACCORDING to the program note, Robert Kovich's ''Multiple/Choice Crimes,'' which the Danspace Project presented Friday night at St. Mark's Church, concerned three people who went into a trance, relived myths, returned to reality and revealed their peccadillos. Although that note may indeed have summarized Mr. Kovich's intentions, his piece turned out to be a grab bag of miscellaneous choreographic ideas.

title: AQUINO DEMANDS MILITARY VICTORY OVER INSURGENTS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that her peace initiatives had failed and that the time had come for military victory over Communist insurgents and right-wing terrorists.

title: The U.N. Today: March 23, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: THE NEW SOUND OF SPRING IN LENINGRAD: SECOND FIDDLE
description: Spring in Leningrad might well have been designed by the city fathers as a deliberate affront to the city's centuries-old rival, Moscow.

title: POLICE UNION ENDS PLAN TO EXPEL 24 DISSIDENTS
description: New York City's police labor union has agreed to abandon its efforts to expel 24 dissident officers, citing the ''divisive impact'' the dispute was having on police morale, Mayor Koch and union leaders said yesterday.

title: ACCOUNTING IN FACTORIES IS CRITICIZED AS OUTDATED
description: Outmoded accounting systems may be responsible for the failure of many American manufacturing companies to update their factories to compete with the Japanese and other international competitors, according to a study commissioned by an accountants' group and an organization of people involved in high-technology manufacturing.

title: 1 WOMAN, 2 ROLES AND STRESS
description: During the day, Kathryn Niebuhr considers herself a dynamic, decisive executive. She is personnel manager of the History Book Club, a division of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. She is also vice president of the southern Connecticut chapter of the International Association of Personnel Women.

title: 3 JUMP TO DEATH AND 4 OTHERS DIE IN HARLEM APARTMENT TOWER BLAZE
description: Three young people, trapped by flames in their 33d-floor apartment, jumped to their deaths and four other people were killed yesterday morning when a smoky blaze - at first thought to be contained in the basement -raced up a garbage chute and raged through the top floors of a building at the northeast edge of Central Park.

title: IF ANGRY WITH ANTIGUA, THEY CAN ALWAYS PHONE
description: The telephone arrived on this out-of-the-way Caribbean island 10 months ago and already some people are discussing the virtues of push button over rotary dial.

title: A CHANGE IN BOND PORTFOLIOS
description: The lack of volatility in bond prices and the uncertain outlook for interest rates have limited speculative trading in recent weeks, but they have not inhibited officials at many large corporations, who are proceeding with major adjustments in the bond investments of their pension funds.

title: ROSTENKOWSKI BARS TAX ON SECURITIES TRANSFERS
description: The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said Saturday that his committee would not consider this year a proposal for a transfer tax on the purchase and sale of securities.

title: What's in a Zoo?
description: To the Editor:

title: PAUL A. FREILICH WED TO HANNAH B. HOLMES
description: Temple Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Hannah Babette Holmes, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, and Paul Allen Freilich, a tax associate at Coopers & Lybrand in Manhattan. Rabbi Sol Roth performed the ceremony.

title: TOUGHER PENALTIES GET RESULTS IN LOCAL STATES
description: In line with the national trends, all three states in the metropolitan area have revised their laws to discourage drunken driving.

title: APRIL READER'S DIGEST INCLUDES CLAIROL INSERT
description: Reader's Digest, a pioneer in publishing advertorial inserts, has an eight-page one for Clairol in the April issue.

title: Gipper 1, Gators 0
description: It's been a better season for the University of Florida basketball team than for Ronald Reagan, of course, but the President won in a blowout last Thursday night when six of the seven CBS affiliates in Florida and four in upstate New York declined to televise his news conference live, in favor of the Florida-Syracuse regional semifinal. Of the 10 TV markets involved, only Miami was covered by the overnight ratings, and there the game drew an average of 7.0, compared with an 11.6 for the news conference on ABC and a mammoth 24.2 on NBC. The question of the President's ability at both rebounding and scoring points has been a hot topic in Washington lately, but against the Gators, at least, he sure put up the numbers.

title: 5 Seized in Paris Arms Raid
description: Security agents arrested five people of Tunisian origin and seized arms, explosives and ammunition in a raid Saturday night, the Interior Ministry said today. It was not known if the arrests were connected to terrorist activities. A ministry statement said two machine guns, ammunition and ''a large stock of explosives'' were seized. Those arrested were not identified. It was not clear if they were French citizens. they were French citizens.

title: CABARET: NANCY LAMOTT
description: CABARET singers who combine contemporary pop songs with vintage standards often find themselves on one or the other side of the fence. Either they connect emotionally to the older material and are uncomfortable with the new or vice versa. Nancy LaMott, who is appearing at Don't Tell Mama, 343 West 46th Street, on Friday and Saturday nights through April 11, seems equally at home in both camps. She has an attractive, middle-sized voice; a smooth, understated delivery; excellent diction; very good taste in material, and a versatile director in her pianist, Rick Jensen.

title: INVOKING HARRIMAN, WESTCHESTER DEMOCRATS FORM A GROUP
description: Nearly 200 Westchester Democrats and some of the party's nationally known figures gathered Saturday night under a new banner, the Harriman Society, to revitalize the party's local political fortunes.

title: AMBACH JOINS SCHOOL GROUP
description: Gordon M. Ambach, who resigned last July as New York State Commissioner of Education, has accepted a post as executive director of the Council of Chief State School Officers, the professional organization of state education commissioners and superintendents. The council, which is based in Washington, develops positions on major education issues and lobbies for them with Congress and Federal agencies.

title: U.S. WILL STRESS FARM-AID ISSUES IN GLOBAL TALKS
description: Senior officials of the Reagan Administration say the cost of aiding farmers has become such a burden to so many countries that the United States wants to push the problem to the top of the list of international economic issues to be negotiated this year.

title: Education, Not Politics, in District 6
description: New York City's public schools are in trouble partly because the central Board of Education tolerates too much patronage and politics by community school boards. Welcome, therefore, Chancellor Nathan Quinones's suspension of a local board's powers following a report of its educational and administrative failures.

title: Bet Twice Is First in Florida
description: Bet Twice confirmed his best form of last year and stamped himself as a Kentucky Derby contender by cruising to a 2 1/2-length victory over No More Flowers and Gone West in the $153,970 Fountain of Youth Stakes today at Gulfstream Park.

title: CAPOTE, AT AGE 3, TRIES TO BEAT ODDS AGAINST A JINX
description: VISITORS to the D. Wayne Lukas Stable at Santa Anita Park this winter have been coming to call with all the enthusiasm of mourners.

title: BANK BOARD SETS 3 CLOSINGS
description: The Government on Friday closed three savings and loan associations, including one in Texas that it said wasted its assets on a fleet of airplanes and a beach house.

title: 'FIGHT FOR LIFE,' ON ABC
description: ''FIGHT FOR LIFE'' ponders a moral question: What does God want us to do? It doesn't answer, of course -how could it? - although Jerry Lewis soliliquizes just like Tevye. Mostly, though, the two-hour movie, on ABC at 9 o'clock tonight, wants to be heart-warming. Intermittently, it is.

title: Swiss Bank Measures Set
description: Swiss bankers announced long-awaited measures today aimed at preventing abuses of their country's tight banking secrecy laws.

title: U.S. IS OFFERING KUWAIT'S SHIPS A NAVAL SHIELD
description: The United States has offered to extend military protection to Kuwaiti vessels traveling through the Persian Gulf to meet possible threats from Iran, Administration officials said today.

title: BRANDT RESIGNS AS WEST GERMAN SOCIALIST PARTY CHIEF
description: Amid mounting criticism of his leadership, Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor and Nobel Peace Prize laureate, resigned today as chairman of the opposition Social Democratic Party. He had held the post for more than two decades.

title: Limits Imposed in B-1 Tests
description: The Air Force is limiting flight maneuvers for crews training in the new B-1B bomber, because of problems with critical equipment, officials said today.

title: US SHELTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter loss includes a charge of $10.2 million from writedowns of certain real estate projects and costs of discontinued partnership offerings.

title: WITNESS SAYS CLUB FOUNDER DIRECTED MURDER OF BEVERLY HILLS MAN
description: A top lieutenant in a former business and social club, the Billionaire Boys Club, has told a jury that Joe Hunt, the club's founder, planned, carried out and covered up the murder of a Beverly Hills man.

title: Correction
description: The obituary of Andy Warhol on Feb. 23 listed his earliest major successes incompletely. His first one-man show in New York, important to his early renown as a Pop artist, took place in November 1962 at the Stable Gallery.

title: Our Towns; A TAle of Video: Nose for News, Eye for Fortune
description: Last year Tom Voorhees, building superintedent for the Van Dyke Apartments, bought himself a Panasonic video camera. It took a year to save the $2,000 for the entire unit. His girlfriend, Karen LePore, a nurse, said, ''Why don't you wait until we're married and have kids?'' but he wanted this now. He felt it would be a good hobby that might lead to something.

title: DOLLAR DROPS TO 148.40 YEN IN TOKYO
description: The dollar plunged to an all-time postwar low against the Japanese yen this morning, trading at 148.40 yen in the morning session. As the afternoon session opened at 2 P.M., the dollar was being traded at 149.10 yen.

title:
PLAYERS;
BATTLE OF SWORDS AND MINDS
description: LEAD: D'Artagnan did it for the love of France, Douglas Fairbanks for the love of Saturday afternoon matinees, Musashi, the legendary 16th-century Japanese warrior, for the mystical Way of the Sword. Last week, a band of swordsmen and women from Columbia University traveled to South Bend, Ind., and did to the National Collegiate Athletic

title: KEY RATES
MEM CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $62,216. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $96,327 and $281,367 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: More Therapy for Casey
description: William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence who had surgery for brain cancer in December, is being fed through a tube in his stomach and undergoing continued therapy. Mr. Casey is in stable condition, aides at Georgetown University Hospital said today.

title: 51 REPORTED DEAD AS AFGHAN JETS ATTACK PAKISTANI BORDER VILLAGE
description: Afghan Air Force jets rocketed and bombed a Pakistani border village today, killing at least 51 people and wounding 105, the Government said.

title: TRITON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $1,423,000 for the quarter and $5,437,000 for the year, and the year also includes a loss from discontinued operations of $293,000. c-Net loss d-After net from discontinued operations of $196,000 for the quarter and $407,000 for the year, and an extraordinary charge of $625,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $7,261,000 for the year. The latest fourth quarter results include the operations of U.S. Press Inc., which was acquired Nov. 3 from Intermark Inc.

title: QUALITY-CARE REVIEWS HURTING RURAL DOCTORS
description: For two decades now, Dr. Claude W. Betty, son of a local farmer, has ministered almost single-handedly to the people of Perryton. He delivered the babies at all hours, took out the gall bladders, sewed up the victims of tractor and oil-rig mishaps.

title: SONICS TURN BACK KNICKS IN OVERTIME
description: Seattle's Xavier McDaniel scored a career-high 40 points last night, in part because the 6-foot-7-inch forward was guarded for much of the game by Trent Tucker, two inches shorter and normally a guard. Tom Chambers, 6-10, had 33 points. He, too, benefited because the injury-riddled Knicks had no one with his size and experience to guard him.

title: EUGENE SEAMAN
description: Eugene Seaman, a pianist, composer, educator and musical entrepreneur, died of lung cancer Saturday. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Sought to Bypass Rules For Company Aiding Contras
description: State Department officials, citing White House concern, asked to bypass normal procedures in 1985 to help a financially strapped company that was aiding the Nicaraguan rebels, a department memo shows.

title: STRAWBERRY SHARP IN RETURN TO LINEUP
description: Darryl Strawberry lashed out today at Philadelphia pitching, instead of at his manager.

title: BRIDGE: 4 TEAMS REACH SEMIFINALS FOR NATIONAL PLAYOFF SPOT
description: Three top-ranked teams and one unexpected group reached the semi-final stage of the district Grand National Teams competition on Sunday at the Beverly Club, at 130 East 57th Street in Manhattan. They will continue play on April 4 for the right to compete in national playoffs in July.

title: BAKER GETS LATIN REBUFF ON BANK CONTROL PLAN
description: The debtor countries of Latin America rebuffed a compromise offered today by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d to end the battle for control of the Inter-American Development Bank, which lends billions of dollars a year throughout the continent and the Caribbean.

title: Remainder Royalties
description: To the Editor:

title: A CHEERY ATMOSPHERE
description: In the exhilarating moments after Providence upstaged Georgetown in Louisville, Ky., Saturday, the Friars' fans at Freedom Hall went wild over their team's unexpected victory. But nowhere was the moment headier than on the small campus where the late bloomers of the Big East learned to play ball.

title: Recall of Walkers Ordered
description: Certain Kidde Kare baby walkers are being recalled because a buckle on the seat may slip and allow the baby to fall, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today. The recall involves 49,000 high-back Kidde Kare infant walkers, Model 106 FLP, sold by Service Merchandise stores between 1984 and 1985, the agency said. Parents who have the recalled walkers should contact the company at (800) 251-1389, or in Tennessee, (800) 251-1212.

title: Johnson's Tax Trouble
description: Curtis Johnson, a former cornerback for the Miami Dolphins, was charged yesterday with failing to file Federal income tax returns on $100,073 in income that had been deferred while he was with the team. Johnson, 38 years old, of Toledo, Ohio, played for the Dolphins from 1970 to 1978. Some of his salary was deferred during that time, and the Government charges that he failed to file tax returns on football money he didn't receive until 1980 and 1981. He faces fines of up to $20,000 and a maximum of two years in prison if convicted, according to Leon Kellner, the United States Attorney in Miami.

title: Confession in Djibouti Blast
description: A Tunisian who said he was recruited in Syria has confessed to planting the bomb that killed 11 people and wounded 40 in a cafe in this northeast African country, President Hassan Gouled Aptidon said today. The Tunisian, identified as Adouani Hamouda Hassan, 27 years old, was arrested Thursday, the day after the explosion at the Historil cafe.

title: Israeli Jets in New Raid On Targets in Lebanon
description: For the second time in four days, Israeli fighter jets today attacked areas in southern Lebanon that Israel suspects of harboring Palestinian guerrillas.

title: SOMETIMES HEAVIER OBJECTS GO TO THE TOP: HERE'S WHY
description: PHYSICS - the same enterprise that regularly predicts the emergence of bosons and mesons from high-energy particle collisions - has been unable until now to explain why the brazil nuts rise to the top of a jar of mixed nuts. But that barrier seems finally to have fallen.

title: DOES CIVILIZATION OWE A DEBT TO BEER?
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 23 -

title: Baker's Declaration
description: When Howard H. Baker Jr. was considering a bid for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination, his deliberations evoked more skepticism than interest on the part of political professionals and reporters, many of whom considered him either too much of a Hamlet to enter the race or a long shot if he did. But when Mr. Baker shelved his Presidential plans to become White House chief of staff, his future suddenly became the object of intense political speculation.

title: THE ALLURE OF MARS GROWS AS U.S. SEARCHES FOR NEW NATIONAL GOAL
description: MOMENTUM is building in the space agency and among science and aerospace leaders to make Mars the next major goal of the American civilian space program. Proponents hope to explore Mars extensively with robots and then send astronauts on the first human visit to another planet.

title: Storms Sweep Mongolia
description: Storms cut a swath of destruction across Mongolia last week, killing people and livestock, the official press agency Tass reported today. Tass, which did not give casualty figures, said the storms hit hardest in the steppes of the vast, thinly populated nation.

title: No Merger Talks At Financial Corp.
description: The Financial Corporation of America said that it was not holding discussions about selling or merging the company. But the company repeated its interest in any transaction that would help it overcome its lingering financial problems.

title: CITY'S PRISON BOAT IS LATE AND COSTLY
description: The Koch administration's plan to convert a surplus Staten Island ferryboat into a floating jail is nearly three months behind schedule and millions of dollars over budget.

title: ALC COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes charges of $35.6 million from consolidation of switching centers and equipment writedowns and $14.3 million from office consolidation. The company said the latest year results reflect fourth quarter actions resulting from the business combinations of Allnet and Lexitel Corp. in December 1985.

title: Auditors Question A.M.C. '86 Report
description: The American Motors Corporation said that its auditors had questioned its 1986 financial report because of a dispute with the Emerson Electric Company over work performed under a $1.2 billion military contract. Analysts said the award was unlikely to pose an obstacle to the Chrysler Corporation's acquisition of A.M.C., although adjustments in the $1.5 billion price are possible.

title: SURVEILLANCE TAPES CITED IN BIAGGI-ESPOSITO CASE
description: A Federal prosecutor said yesterday that the Government had more than 1,500 electronic surveillance tapes that could figure in the bribery and fraud trial of Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx and Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader.

title: FILM HISTORY BEING LOST BY OVERSIGHT AND PLAN
description: When thousands of blueprints for sets of old M-G-M movies were destroyed a few weeks ago, it was by accident. Through carelessness and sometimes by design, the movie industry is being robbed of much of its history each year.

title: Please! Not an Art Form!
description: In the Wish-They-Wouldn't Department, how about that expensive Manhattan apartment house that elevates living to an art form? Yes, that is its threat. ''From its mansard roof to its wood-and-leather lobby,'' reads its ad in The New Yorker, it ''elevates living to an art form.''

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Shares outstanding for the latest quarter reflects the pro rata effect of the insurance of 1.35 million shares in public offering in August 1986.

title: JERSEY DAM: THREATENING AND COSTLY
description: When state officials recommended a decade ago that New Jersey buy land for a park on Union Lake in Cumberland County, they knew the 118-year-old dam holding back the artificial lake needed repair.

title: 5 Are Killed in Blaze In a Dallas Apartment
description: A fire that began in an apartment living room trapped three children and two adults upstairs, and all five died in the blaze as neighbors climbed to a second-story window and tried to reach the victims.

title: DESPITE ARMS BUILDUP, EXPERTS SAY U.S. IS NOT READY FOR WAR
description: Day after day, admirals and generals and senior civilians have been trooping up to Capitol Hill to testify that American military forces are still not ready for sustained combat despite the expenditure of $1.5 trillion in the last six years.

title: Dole's Tactics
description: Iowa voters will get an advance look at some campaign tactics of Senator Bob Dole tomorrow when his Presidential exploratory campaign opens a headquarters in Des Moines. Because he will be on duty in Washington as Senate minority leader, Mr. Dole will be represented at the ceremony by his wife, Transportation Secretary Elizabeth H. Dole.

title: MUSIC: FRENCH ORCHESTRA PLAYS WORKS BY DVORAK
description: IN a country already teeming with virtuoso orchestras, visitors from abroad hold out perhaps one great expectation - a distinctive point of view born of a different culture and a different sense of place. This is what made Sunday afternoon's visit by the Orchestre National de France to Avery Fisher Hall, for this listener at least, a disappointment.

title: Man Who Killed Priest Is Indicted in Robbery
description: A 19-year-old Brooklyn man who was acquitted last month in the killing of a Roman Catholic priest has been indicted in Manhattan for an armed robbery in midtown.

title: TERRORISTS' VICTIM IS BURIED IN ITALY
description: Sitting in a cold and dimly lighted church today, Italy's political leaders put aside their quarrels for a few hours while Gen. Licio Giorgieri, who was killed Friday by terrorists, was given a hero's funeral.

title: HAIG TO SEEK REPUBLICAN NOMINATION FOR PRESIDENCY
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr., who called himself the ''vicar of American foreign policy'' as Secretary of State in the first 18 months of the Reagan Presidency, said last night that he would be a candidate for the Republican nomination for President.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have had a long summer holiday, but the holiday is fin-ished. Everything will change.'' -The Rev. Domingos Lam, Roman Catholic Vicar General of Macao, on accord returning the colony to China. (A1:6)

title: Fruit of the Loom
description: Fruit of the Loom Inc. said that it had agreed to sell its General Battery subsidiary to the Exide Corporation for $145 million. General Battery produces replacement auto batteries. Exide, which is based in Horsham, Pa., produces auto and industrial batteries.

title: BAKKER ASSERTS HE RESIGNED TO THWART TAKEOVER OF PTL
description: The Rev. Jim Bakker and his wife, Tammy Faye, said today they resigned as heads of the 500,000-member PTL television ministry to thwart the first step of a hostile takeover of PTL, and not because of Mr. Bakker's admission that he was blackmailed over a sexual encounter.

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
HERALD CENTER: MORE TROUBLES
description: The problems at Herald Center, the vertical shopping mall at Herald Square in Manhattan, are continuing to mount.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Variety Every year, the Third World Institute of Theater Art Studies produces a festival that includes theater, dance, poetry, performance art and cabaret at La Mama E.T.C. This year's theme is ''New Directions: A Celebration of Human Culture.'' Starting today and running nightly through Saturday, La Mama will present a variety of ensembles and performers from such places as Japan, Nigeria, Peru and Morocco.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MARCH 24, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: The Right Track
description: While many baseball players spend their hours off the field in hotel lounges or even at race tracks, Rob Murphy of the Cincinnati Reds elects to play the horses in the comfort of his own room.

title: BOSSY'S STOICISM IS SHOWING CRACKS
description: Performing in his sport has become such an ordeal that the premier right wing in hockey is again pondering the wisdom of surrendering his starring role with the Islanders.

title: Citicorp Offer On Cyclops Bid
description: A Citicorp unit said today that it would drop its bid to buy the Cyclops Corporation if a rival bidder, Dixons Group P.L.C., would sell it Cyclops's industrial division for $124.4 million. Citicorp Capital Investors

title: IRAN RADIO SAYS WAITE IS BEING HELD IN BEIRUT
description: Iran said today that Terry Waite, the missing Anglican envoy, was being held here by a group believed to be pro-Iranian.

title: ANALYSTS FAVOR RYDER SYSTEM
description: MOST people know Ryder System Inc., which joined the Dow Jones transportation average in December, for its distinctive yellow rental trucks. But M. Anthony Burns, the chairman and chief executive, likes to clarify that impression. ''Actually, we own 135,000 trucks,'' he said. ''But only about 50,000 are painted yellow.'' Many others are leased to such customers as Wal-Mart Stores, Xerox, McDonald's and Sears, Roebuck, all of which specify their own colors and designs. After all, whatever it carries inside, a truck's panels are a natural for corporate embellishments.

title: Gencorp Accuses Its Bidders
description: The Gencorp Corporation accused two Texas oil millionaires yesterday of a ''false and illusory'' plan to take over the company. It maintained that the ''true purpose'' of the plan was to ''put Gencorp into play.''

title: DUCOMMUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $279,000 and $555,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and losses on the sale of discontinued operations of $14,636,000 for the quarter and $15,867,000 for the year. The company said the largest portion of the losses for the latest fourth quarter and year were incurred by it Kierulff unit and included a combination of operating losses and inventory writedowns.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Rexham Corporation, a maker of packaging materials and machinery, said it had received an unsolicited offer of $43 a share in cash and preferred stock from Nortek Inc., a Providence, R.I., manufacturer of building materials.

title: DOUBT CAST ON TOWER PANEL FINDING
description: The Tower Commission's general counsel, elaborating on the report's findings on the financing of the Iran arms sales, said today that the commission had no evidence that Adnan M. Khashoggi, a Saudi businessman, received duplicate payments.

title: PARAGUAY REGIME VILIFIES U.S. ENVOY
description: The United States Ambassador to Paraguay has come under an unusually fierce attack from the long-ruling regime of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner for speaking out on human rights issues and identifying with democratic forces in Latin America's oldest dictatorship.

title: Send Out for Ice! It's Been Broken
description: Ice skating, even the world figure-skating championships, is the kind of thing that the television networks routinely relegate to taped delay on weekend afternoons. Indeed, until this year no figure-skating competition outside the Olympics had ever been televised in prime time, live or otherwise.

title: RELIABLE LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,578,887 from a change in accounting methods for pensions. The prior year results have been restated for a 100 percent stock dividend paid in August 1986.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: The weary fashion army crossed the English Channel last week, all wearing the latest in de rigueur accessories: little black bags beneath the eyes.

title: SPECTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes restructuring costs of $6,704,000. c-Net income

title: CAPITALISM LIFTS CHINA BANK
description: As recently as eight years ago, the Bank of China here was a stodgy outpost of the Beijing Government that barely mattered on the local banking scene.

title: U.S. COASTAL PLAN SEEKS TO EXPAND PROTECTED AREAS
description: The Interior Department today proposed expanding the network of fragile coastal areas in which the Federal Government discourages development.

title: THE DEMOCRATS NARROW HUNT
description: WHOSE ox is likely to be gored as the Democrats search for new revenues to reduce the Federal deficit? One target after another is being eliminated, until all that's left are motorists and smokers, but no one expects them to lie down and be rolled over.

title: I.B.M. to Ship Computers Early
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would begin shipping its new midrange computers, the system 9370, two months earlier than planned. Two models of the new computers - known in the industry as ''VAX killers'' because they are aimed at the Digital Equipment Corporation's VAX line - will be available in July. Another will be available in October.

title: MORGENTHAU INVESTIGATES HIRING BY SENATE DEMOCRATIC LEADER
description: The Manhattan District Attorney said today that he was investigating the employment practices of the State Senate minority leader, Manfred Ohrenstein, of Manhattan, who controls the payrolls of Democratic Senators.

title: LASSE HALLSTROM'S 'MY LIFE AS A DOG,' A BOY'S YEAR
description: WHEN left to his own devices, Ingemar Johansson is a most winning adolescent - skeptical, introspective, curious, trying earnestly to bring order out of nature's chaos. As played by 11-year-old Anton Glanzelius in Lasse Hallstrom's 1958 Swedish film ''My Life as a Dog,'' Ingemar even looks unfinished. His forehead's too high for the rest of his face, and his eyes too small. Physically as well as emotionally, he's still in transit.

title: 2 Exchanges Plan Merger
description: The New York Merc and the Commodity Exchange have stepped up efforts to merge, the chairmen of the two exchanges said yesterday.

title: REV. RICHARD E. DOYLE
description: The Rev. Richard E. Doyle, a classics scholar and vice president for academic affairs at Fordham University, died of cancer Saturday at Murray-Weigal Hall, a residence hall on Fordham's Rose Hill campus in the Bronx. He was 57 years old. Father Doyle, of the Society of Jesus, was dean of the Fordham Graduate School of Arts and Sciences before he became vice president in 1985. He was chairman of the classics department from 1970 to 1977, and since 1972 was editor of Traditio, an annual journal of classical and medieval studies published by the Fordham University Press.

title: Ex-Studio Official Gets Reebok Post
description: C. Joseph LaBonte, a former president of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, was named president and chief operating officer yesterday of Reebok International Ltd.

title: SCIENTISTS MAKE A SURGICAL 'GLUE' FROM BLOOD
description: RESEARCHERS at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania have used blood clotting agents to develop a ''glue'' to repair damaged bone and tissue. The glue, known as autologous fibrinogen adhesive, is a combination of the two agents, thrombin and fibrinogen.

title: Grand Jury Does Not Indict Officers in Chokehold Case
description: A grand jury today did not indict two white police officers involved in a scuffle that led to the death of a black man and prompted charges of racism against the authorities.

title: Players Lose in Court
description: Major league baseball players lost a Supreme Court appeal today over the legal right to millions of dollars in revenue from televised games.

title: Reagan's Mighty Effort to Condemn Cuba
description: For months, until it was narrowly defeated the other day, what seemed like an obscure, United States-sponsored resolution in the United Nations to condemn Cuba for human rights abuses consumed much of the time and attention of top Reagan Administration officials.

title: Hewlett Shipping Its New Computer
description: Capping weeks of rumors and industry speculation, the Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it had begun limited shipments of the first customer test units of its HP 3000 Series 930 business computer. The machines use the company's new internal architecture, code-named Spectrum.

title: 2 G.O.P. Congressmen Move to Impeach Judge
description: Two conservative Republican Congressmen introduced an impeachment resolution today against Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings of Miami, who was acquitted in 1983 of charges of conspiring to solicit a $150,000 bribe from two convicted racketeers.

title: INLAND, NIPPON SIGN PACT
description: The Inland Steel Company said yesterday that it had signed a long-awaited agreement with the Nippon Steel Corporation to establish a $400 million joint venture in the United States to make sheet steel for use in automobiles and other consumer products.

title: STANWOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods' results include a loss of $911,000 from a provision for inventory losses and related expenses because of the company's mutual agreement to terminate its licensing agreement with Pony Sports & Leisure Inc. The latest quarter and year results also included a loss of $319,000 related to the company's termination of its women's wear operations.

title: Marques Johnson Facing Surgery
description: Marques Johnson, the Los Angeles Clippers' forward who was injured in a game against Dallas Nov. 20, will undergo surgery on Friday to repair a ruptured disk in his neck, the team announced today.

title: 2 Jockeys Injured
description: Two jockeys, Declan Murphy and E.T. Baird, were injured in a spill in the sixth race at Aqueduct yesterday. Both were removed from the track on stretchers and taken to Long Island Jewish Hospital.

title: IN POLICE CLASS, BIASES STAY IN LOCKERS
description: The recruits, intent on improving the image of police officers, are wrestling with prejudices - those they already have, those they may develop and those they may encounter from a suspicious public.

title: THOMPSON EX-CHIEF JOINS ESTY
description: AS rumored in the advertising trade press for a week, Joseph W. O'Donnell, the ousted chairman and chief executive of the J. Walter Thompson Company, is joining the William Esty Company, a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi, with the same titles.

title: A Lesson From Japanese Banks
description: LEAD: The decision by 28 Japanese banks to create a mechanism for clearing their books of ossified loans to Latin America should force the debate over the third-world debt problem into a new and more creative phase, especially in the United States.

title: LAST OF A BURLESQUE DYNASTY
description: Morton Minsky, the last of four brothers who made burlesque a New York institution, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: Devil in the Computer
description: A friend on a new job had to learn to operate a computer terminal, about which he knew nothing. One lives and dies by the computer, he was cheerfully advised. ''It's the tool of our trade.'' His associates were whizzes at signing in, entering passwords, storing and retrieving data, accessing information from the outside world.

title: THE BULLDOZER'S PROGRESS: CAN HE REACH THE TOP?
description: The Mayor of Athens, Miltiadis Evert, is a man whose ebullient self-confidence seems undaunted by the seeming anomalies on which his office appears to rest.

title: Israel's Envoy in U.S. Expects to Leave Soon
description: Meir Rosenne, Israel's Ambassador to the United States since July 1983, has said he expects to end his term by this summer.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * First Interstate Bancorp has filed a shelf offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $1.5 billion of debt securities, which may be offered from time to time. * Guilford Mills Inc. is offering $75 million of 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2012 at 100 through Bear, Stearns. Noncallable for two years and rated Ba-1 by Moody's, the debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at $44.25 a share. * Hechinger Co. is offering $125 million of 5 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2012 at 100 through Morgan Stanley. The debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at $27.84 a share. * Holiday Rambler Corp. has filed for $70 million of subordinated notes due 1997 through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. as sole underwriter. * LSI Logic Corp. plans to issue $100 million of convertible Eurobonds due 2002, with an indicated coupon of 5 3/4 percent to 6 1/4 percent, through Morgan Stanley International. * Merrill Lynch & Co. is offering in the U.S. capital market $75 million (New Zealand currency) of 20 percent notes due 1989 at 100, or 1 1/2 percentage points less than comparable New Zealand rates. Interest on the notes, rated A-1 by Moody's and AA by S.& P., is paid annually instead of semiannually. * Reynolds Metals Co. has filed for $200 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2012 through Goldman, Sachs. * Southern Natural Gas Co. has filed for $100 million of 12-year debentures through Goldman, Sachs. * Western Financial Auto Loans 2 is offering $125 million of 6 3/4 percent bonds due 1990 at a price of 99.938 to yield 6.86 percent, or 6/10 of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity, through Drexel Burnham Lambert as sole underwriter. The bonds are collateralized by auto loans. Common Stock * Amax Inc. has filed for 15.8 million common shares, 12.6 million to be offered in the U.S. through First Boston and the remainder overseas through Credit Suisse First Boston. * Amplicon Inc. has filed for an initial public offering of 1.65 million common shares through Kidder, Peabody. * Calton Inc. has filed for 2.5 million common shares through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. * Meridian Insurance Group is making an initial offering of 1.5 million common shares at $12 a share through Prescott, Ball & Turben * Weyerhaeuser Co. has filed for 4 million shares of convertible exchangeable preference shares through Morgan Stanley.

title: The U.N. Today: March 24, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Cold Conception
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED ILLUMINATING CO reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
INSIDE
description: Dollar Falls in Tokyo

title: WHITHER FASHION? IN PARIS, PATH'S UNCLEAR
description: There was plenty of action on the runways as the spring and summer fashion openings continued over the weekend, but it was not clear where it was all heading. After the triumph of the Japanese last week, the collections have been lively and full of fashion jokes, but they have not been exactly epochal. Rubber and stretch fabrics make up tight clothes that fit like corsets. Nobody is using the word, but a miniskirt revival is clearly under way. Furs, real and fake, turn up repeatedly and the chief ethnic influence so far is Tyrolean.

title: Levels of Vulnerability
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Company Interests Davis
description: Marvin Davis, who made his fortune in the oil business and then bought and sold the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation is now interested in acquiring Lexington Broadcasting Services, a barter syndication company, according to an executive at Grey Advertising, which controls a large block of Lexington's stock.

title: Semiconductor Shows Deficit
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation today reported a deficit of $25.6 million for its third quarter ended March 8, compared with a $39.4 million loss a year ago. The third-quarter 1987 results include a charge of $15 million related to the restructuring of certain Datachecker Systems and semiconductor group operations announced in January.

title: Connecticut Murder Trial Begins After 3 Years
description: After nearly three years of legal maneuvering, jury selection began here today for the trial of Michael B. Ross, who is accused of killing four young women in eastern Connecticut in 1983 and 1984.

title: STAGE: 'ROOSTERS' AT INTAR
description: THE atmosphere is hot and bone-dry in Milcha Sanchez-Scott's ''Roosters'' (at Intar), and soon the temperature begins to rise among the members of the family under the playwright's scrutiny - a patient mother, a searching son and a daughter enveloped by her own seraphic fantasy world. The father of the house, a breeder of fighting roosters, is about to return home after serving a term in prison for manslaughter.

title: CREATING ONE'S OWN ENTERPRISE
description: AT age 22, not long out of Hampshire College, Sharon Graff started a child-care company in St. Louis. Now called In-Home Care, it provides help not just to working mothers but to the elderly and the disabled as well.

title: MACAO WILL REPORT TO CHINA IN 1999 UNDER PORTUGAL PACT
description: China and Portugal reached agreement today on returning this small gambling haven, a Portuguese colony for 430 years, to China in 1999.

title: Judge Won't Lift Ban On Texts in Alabama
description: A Federal district judge today rejected the state's request that he temporarily set aside his order banning from public schools 44 textbooks that he had ruled promoted a humanist faith.

title: CHESS: GRABBING A PAWN PAYS OFF FOR RIBLI AT REGGIO EMILIA
description: In a competition where everyone played everything close to the vest, Zoltan Ribli, a 35-year-old Hungarian grandmaster, won the Reggio Emilia International Tournament in Italy by scoring two victories and nine draws.

title: Blacks at Columbia U. File Charges in Brawl
description: One day after a fight involving several black and white students at Columbia University, a black student group said yesterday that complaints had been filed with the Police Department against the white students.

title: Unocal Note Yields Are Set
description: The Unocal Corporation is offering seven-year and ten-year notes totaling $450 million through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as lead underwriter.

title: SLAYER MARRIED IN PRISON
description: Angelo Buomo Jr., convicted of the sexual torture and murders of nine young women, was married last year at Folsom Prison, a prison official said today. Mr. Buomo, 52, married Christine Klzuka, 35, a mother of three who is a supervisor at the Los Angeles office of the state Employment Development . The Los Angeles Herald Examiner reported the wedding in today's issue after reviewing records in Sacramento.

title: Allegations on Rebels
description: Nevada-Las Vegas apparently committed at least seven violations of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules while recruiting Lloyd Daniels, the New York City high school basketball star, according to a published report. The 6-foot-8-inch Daniels received cash, clothing, a car, a motorcycle and free housing from U.N.L.V. coaches, boosters and other representatives of the school, Newsday reported in its Sunday issue. Coach Jerry Tarkanian denied the charges Sunday night, shortly after the Rebels had defeated Iowa to earn a berth in the Final Four. ''It's just not true,'' Tarkanian said. ''We would never do anything like that - no way.'' The newspaper based its charges on several interviews and official documents. It said Daniels declined to be interviewed. The school's athletic director, Brad Rothermel, said last week he knew of no irregularities in his school's dealing with Daniels. Regarding the charges, Rothermel said he would ''guarantee we didn't do one thing.'' After dropping out of Andrew Jackson High School in Queens in February 1986, Daniels signed a letter of intent with Nevada-Las Vegas in April and spent the summer in Las Vegas before enrolling at Mount San Antonio College in Walnut, Calif., in the fall. Daniels, who never received a high school diploma, enrolled at Nevada-Las Vegas as a full-time student in January, planning to play there as a junior-college transfer starting next December. But Daniels's future as a college player was clouded after his arrest Feb. 9 on a charge of attempting to possess a controlled substance, crack. Tarkanian has said Daniels would not play for the Runnin' Rebels because of the arrest.

title: PROBLEMS OF TARIFFS ON JAPAN GOODS
description: Imposing tariffs on Japanese products - such as video-cassette recorders and personal computers - that contain ''dumped'' computer chips could raise prices to American consumers and hurt American companies that compete abroad, economists and trade analysts said yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Report On Dow Fall
description: A report released today by the Securities and Exchange Commission said that program trading was not to blame for the rapid fall of the stock market on Sept. 11 and 12, 1986, though it might have accelerated it.

title: State-Sponsored Child Abuse
description: Recent reports of death and abuse in foster care programs in New York, Illinois, California and the District of Columbia are not isolated incidents. Just six years after Federal reform legislation was passed, mismanagement and scandal are once again rampant.

title: DOW CLIMBS 30.26, TO RECORD 2,363.78
description: With its fears of the ''witching hour'' only a memory, Wall Street scored another big gain yesterday as the stock market resumed its relentless quest for new records.

title: Triple Threat
description: When asked about Doug Flutie the other day, Coach Mike Ditka of the Chicago Bears continued to forecast a bright future for his undersize quarterback but noted that Flutie had difficulty last year with audibles. Said the coach: ''He'd call our audibles half the time, Boston College's half the time and New Jersey's half the time.'' Same old Ditka, still insisting on 150 percent.

title: ALLIED PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain on the prepayment of debt of $1,119,000 and a tax credit of $5,841,000.

title: U.S. SAYS MOSCOW IS QUIETLY CUTTING ITS STAFF AT U.N.
description: The Soviet Union has assured the United States that it has complied with an order to further cut the size of its United Nations missions by April 1, an American official said today.

title: Aegean Dispute Worsens Turkish-Greek Ties
description: Relations between Greece and Turkey seem to have deteriorated sharply in the last week because of their dispute over sovereignty in the Aegean Sea.

title: Nazi Trial Judges in Israel Refuse to Withdraw
description: The judges presiding over the trial of John Demjanjuk, who is accused of being a Nazi war criminal, today rejected a request from the defense that they withdraw from the case.

title: JEFFERIES ACCOUNTING DISPUTE ENDED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has dropped an accounting dispute with the Jefferies Group that could have reduced its fourth-quarter profit, the company said today.

title: OUTMANEUVERING A PARASITE
description: Schistosomiasis, a parasitic disease that afflicts at least 200 million people around the world, has been a difficult target for vaccination. Natural immunity to the parasite develops slowly and is not very effective.

title: 'BOLD AND BEAUTIFUL,' NEW CBS SOAP
description: THOSE resourceful and indefatigable folks who have been bringing you ''The Young and the Restless'' for years have now devised a new half-hour soap called ''The Bold and the Beautiful,'' and CBS is urging viewers to ''be in on the beginning of the boldest daytime drama ever.'' In its own endearingly dopey way, the beginning of a new soap opera is an event worth watching. The sheer mechanics of getting five different plotlines moving simultaneously are staggering, and the shorthand methods of characterization are positively dizzying. Little wonder that the commercial breaks, taking up about nine minutes of each half-hour, are so top-heavy with products promising to relieve headaches.

title: COURT UPHOLDS G.O.P. CHOICE OF SUFFOLK CHIEF
description: A four-justice appellate panel, reversing a lower-court decision, declared unanimously today that Michael A. LoGrande was ''lawfully occupying the office of acting County Executive'' in Suffolk County.

title: NEOAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes charges in lieu of income taxes (which is not accruable or payable because of pre-reorganiation tax loss carryforwards) of $257,000 for the latest quarter and $4,635,000 for 1986, compared to $472,000 and $2,941,000 for the year-ago quarter and year, respectively. Both latest periods include a pre-tax charge of approximately $1 million related to the previously announced discontinuance of the company's convertible automobile manufacturing business. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest year.

title: A FILIPINO OFFICER IS HELD IN BOMBING
description: An army captain was arrested today in connection with a bombing last Wednesday at a military academy a few days before an address there by President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: SHEARSON TO SELL OFF 40% SHARE
description: The board of the American Express Company yesterday approved the sale of 40 percent of its Shearson Lehman Brothers brokerage subsidiary, giving both companies a significant international link.

title: HOSPITAL ADMITS FAULT IN PATIENT'S DEATH
description: New York Hospital admitted yesterday that it failed to provide adequate care to a young woman who died there three years ago as a result of what a Manhattan grand jury said were repeated medical mistakes.

title: NEBRASKA'S COACH COMES BACK HOME
description: Nebraska played before three capacity crowds in the early rounds of the National Invitation Tournament, but Madison Square Garden won't be sold out when the Cornhuskers appear in the semifinals tonight. Danny Nee, the Nebraska coach, isn't upset, however. He's happy his squad is still playing ball.

title: TELESCOPE SITE CHOSEN
description: The dormant Mauna Kea volcano in Hawaii will be the site for the National New Technology Telescope, scientists announced today. The $125 million, 600-inch device will be the most powerful optical telescope in the world.

title: Tokyo Acts To Prevent Chip Curbs
description: Japanese trade officials today announced measures aimed at warding off American sanctions against Japanese semiconductor manufacturers. The officials also hinted that Japan would retaliate if sanctions were imposed anyway.

title: JUSTICES STRIKE DOWN CURBS ON 'INDECENT' CABLE TV PROGRAMS
description: The Supreme Court today struck down a Utah law that restricted cable telecasts of nudity and sex acts that the state deemed ''indecent'' but that did not meet the Court's definition of obscenity.

title: SUNBELT NURSERY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The year-ago periods' results have been restated.

title: Foster Care Undone By Contracting Out
description: To the Editor:

title: CLUB MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
JUDGE ORDERS REPORTER TO DISCLOSE SOURCES FOR ARTICLE IN LAXALT SUIT
description: A Federal magistrate in Reno has ordered a newspaper reporter to disclose his confidential sources for an article about possible legal violations at a Nevada gambling casino owned in part by former Senator Paul Laxalt.

title: Case for Baby M's Biological Mother Is Weak
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET HISTORIANS TOLD TO CITE THE NEGATIVE AND THE POSITIVE
description: Yegor K. Ligachev, the second ranking Soviet party leader, said today that a review of Soviet history should not focus solely on mistakes and disappointments.

title: Q&A
description: Q.People usually cut off the brown spots on fruits such as bananas and apples because they don't look very pretty. Is there actually any harm in eating them? A.The bruised or overripe parts of fruits and vegetables probably contain some type of fungus, mold, or fermented material that could upset the digestive system, according to Dr. Gerald Dull of the Georgia Agricultural Research Service in Athens. Dr. Dull recommended that such spots be removed and if the spots are large that the area surrounding them be tasted before eating to make sure the fruit is not spoiled. ''Just use common sense, if it doesn't smell and taste good don't eat it,'' he said. There are some fruits that are exceptions, however. For example, when pineapples are stored for long periods of time they develop small brown spots within. These indigenous brown spots, as they are called, are esthetically unpleasant, but the pineapple is just as good as one without the spots, Dr. Dull said. Q.Is it true that sharks never sleep? A.Because sharks are very difficult to keep and observe in captivity, very little is known about their behavior. Scientists have little knowledge as to whether sharks engage in a sleeping activity similar to ours, according to Dr. Samuel Gruber, a biologist at the Rosen Steil Marine School at the University of Miami. Sharks do not lie down for long periods and respire deeply. Nor do they exhibit rapid eye movement. But some sharks such as the nurse shark appear to rest regularly on the sea bottom or in underwater caves. However, most sharks do not rest like that because they must continue to move about in order to run water over their gills for oxygen. To rest on the ocean floor would mean death, Dr. Gruber said. Still, the shark may be resting in its own way. Experiments have shown that a shark maintains swimming movements even when its spinal chord to its brain has been severed. The shark seems to go on automatic pilot.

title: POET REBUILDS LIFE IN U.S. AFTER SOVIET PRISON TERM
description: Irina Ratushinskaya, a poet who was released from a Soviet prison last October amid demonstrations of support by such groups as PEN, the international writers' association, says she is surprised how many people have asked her since her arrival in the West about one of her prison-camp methods of composition.

title: On Television
description: Television coverage of Congress has enabled many Americans to identify members, including their own, by sight for the first time. The lawmakers, with re-election campaigns never far from their minds, tend to regard this as a political plus. But Jack Russ, the Sergeant-at-Arms of the House, who is in charge of maintaining security, has a a different viewpoint.

title: AMBRIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes pretax gains from the sale of investment in Sheraton Securities International PLC of $8,068,000 for the latest year and $928,000 for the prior year; and losses of $1,891,000 and $845,000 for the latest year and prior year, respectively, from Ambrit's oil and gas operations, which are conducted through Ambrit International PLC, for which no tax benefits can be recorded. The company said the latest year revenue includes a gain of $87,169,000 from Wilbur Chocolate Co., acquired March 10, 1986. The company said the prior year operatings results include non-recurring charges of $942,000 incurred in connection with the company's acquisition of Sheraton and Ambrit International.

title: WESTWORLD COMMUNITY HEALTHCARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The 1986 results include substantial charges in connection with the closing or divestiture of a large number of Westworld's facilities and certain other assets. Revenue is from patient services.

title: WHEN THINGS GO WRONG
description: WHY blame the schools whenever something goes wrong with young people or society? What are the limits of the schools' responsibility?

title: Forest Service Saws While Grizzlies Die
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. MARIAN BALICKI
description: Dr. Marian Balicki, a former professor at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn and research director in the New York office of the Atomic Energy Commission, died Friday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: STUDENTS HONE SKILLS IN VIDEO COURTROOM
description: IN his first courtroom appearance as counsel, Wayne E. Anderson objected when the opposing counsel presented a financial ledger as evidence.

title: 7 Skiers Killed in Avalanche In Wilds of British Columbia
description: Seven members of a ski party were killed by an avalanche today in the remote mountains near here, authorities said.

title: An Arthurian Vignette For the Marine Corps
description: J. Walter Thompson has created a replacement for that award-winning Marine Corps recruiting television commercial featuring an officer and his sword and called, simply, ''Sword.'' The new entry is much more of a production number, entailing a trip to a castle in England that is used for a King Arthur-like tableau in which an armored knight rides in on horseback and is dubbed by the king with a sword that crackles with blue lightning.

title: CAR BOMB BLASTS BRITISH BASE
description: A car bomb exploded Monday night outside a British military mess hall where officers and their wives were holding a going-away party, and officials said at least 31 people were injured.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BERNARD BERENSON. The Making of a Legend. By Ernest Samuels with the collaboration of Jayne Newcomer Samuels. Illustrated. 680 pages. Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $25. ARTFUL PARTNERS. Bernard Berenson and Joseph Duveen. By Colin Simpson.

title: WINGS WEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,556,000 from the sale of aircraft. c-Net income

title: 2 RIVALS FOR BRONX POST QUESTIONED ON INTEGRITY
description: Two of three major contenders for Bronx borough president were sharply questioned on matters of integrity yesterday as six City Council members began the process of selecting a new borough leader.

title: Schools Outlay Stirs Bitter California Debate
description: School officials say California high school seniors scored their largest one-year gain ever on academic achievement tests last year. In Sacramento these days, that is political news, not merely good news for parents and teachers.

title: Sierra Leone Reports Quelling of a Rebellion
description: The Government said today that it was in full control and had seized a large quantity of arms after an apparent attempt was made this morning to overthrow President Joseph Momoh.

title: Wagner/English Gains On Shifts to Freelance
description: McCaffrey & McCall recently dismissed five of its in-house TV producers because, David B. McCall, chairman, said, by going to freelance people the agency hopes to avail itself of producers in all of the various advertising categories.

title: Ashford and Simpson To Pitch for Champale
description: Meanwhile, Valerie Simpson and Nickolas Ashford, singers and songwriters, are going to do their thing for Champale Malt Liquors and Coolers.

title: COOPER DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a charge of $4,711,000 from the expensing of a portion of unamortized debt issuance costs. c-Net loss The company said the latest quarter figures also includes a gain of $11,419,000 from the sale of a product line. The company said that an accounting change in its acquisition of the company's Cooperbiomedical business unit necessitated a revision of its financial results for the fiscal year ended Oct 31, 1986. The company also said it had a net loss of $61.7 million for fiscal 1986, primarily as a result of $53.5 million of Cooperbiomedical restructuring costs that previously had been capitalized, versus a loss of $12.1 million previously reported. The accounting change treatment means the company will not have to charge the $53.5 million of restructuring costs against the results of future operations.

title: MOSCOW TO OFFER ARMS DRAFT SOON
description: Soviet officials have told the United States that they will soon offer their draft of a proposed treaty on reducing medium-range nuclear missiles, Administration officials said today.

title: ROCK: LOS LOBOS AT THE RITZ
description: LOS LOBOS could easily make a career as one of America's top blues bands. Or rockabilly bands. Or country-rock bands. Or norteno polka bands. But like other ethnic minority members breaking into the mainstream, the Mexican-American band from East Los Angeles overachieves; on its albums, as at the Ritz on Friday night, Los Lobos lays claim to music from across the South, the Southwest and Mexico. Its members know exactly what they're doing. While their lyrics speak to the 1980's, their music has its heart, voice and fingers in the directness of 1950's rock.

title: RUOTSALAINEN HAS HOMECOMING PARTY
description: Reijo Ruotsalainen, the former defenseman for the Rangers, made a triumphant return to the metropolitan area tonight after joining the Edmonton Oilers nine games ago.

title: Yugoslavia Refinancing
description: Yugoslavia's Deputy Prime Minister, Janez Zemljaric, said today that his nation wants to refinance $2 billion of its total debt of $19.7 billion, the official Tanjug news agency reported. Mr. Zemljaric was quoted as saying Yugoslavia expected a ''definite measure of understanding'' from 16 Western creditor countries it will meet on March 30. But the country, whose economic crisis is under scrutiny by foreign creditors, will not follow Brazil in suspending repayments of its debt, the Prime Minister, Branko Mikulic, said.

title: Coca-Cola Enterprises In $600 Million Offering
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises is offering $600 million of notes and bonds evenly divided between 10-year notes and 30-year debentures, according to underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Wickes Wants A Reverse Split
description: The Wickes Companies said today that it would ask shareholders to approve a reverse stock split of its 239 million common shares outstanding on a 1-for-5 basis.

title: STUDY TIES NICOTINE TO CANCER SPREAD
description: Nicotine seems to promote the spread of cancer throughout the body, and people with cancer should avoid tobacco to improve their odds of surviving, new research suggests.

title: MURDERS SOAR IN 21 PRECINCTS IN NEW YORK
description: The number of reported murders soared by 50 percent or more in 21 of New York City's 75 police precincts last year, reflecting the pervasive impact of drug-related crime on neighborhoods, officials said yesterday.

title: Atlantic County Utilities Bonds
description: The Atlantic County Utilities Authority of New Jersey is tentatively offering $57.2 million of refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 6.868 percent for an issue due in 2006 through underwriters led by the First Fidelity Bank, Newark.

title: 'A DIFFERENT AFFAIR,' ON TALK-SHOW HOST
description: FOR whatever tactical scheduling reasons, the commercial networks are suddenly dumping a lot of wretched made-for-television movies on viewers these days. Still another prize specimen can be found tonight at 9 on CBS under the apparently arbitrary title ''A Different Affair.'' Written by Jodi Rothe and directed by Noel Nosseck, this Rogers-Samuels Production is the kind of pointless exercise that leaves generally competent actors conveying the impression that if only they can get through the next few lines of dialogue, they can pick up their checks and go home and maybe nobody will watch the bloody thing.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Airship Industries, a British company that makes airships, said its American depository receipts would begin trading over the counter on the Nasdaq system tomorrow. * Allied Supermarkets Inc., Detroit, said it had agreed to sell its Michigan operations for about $46 million in cash and debt to Meadowdale Foods Inc., a corporation formed by existing management. * Energy Factors Inc., San Diego, said it had signed an agreement to acquire GWF Power Systems Co. and Combustion Power Co. from Garrett Corp., a unit of Allied-Signal Inc. Terms were not disclosed. * Mark IV Industries said it would begin a tender offer for all outstanding stock of the Conrac Corp., a Stamford, Conn., maker of control instruments and telecommunications products, for $25 a share. * Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America Inc., Fountain Valley, Calif., said it would raise retail prices on trucks by as much as 1.9 percent, or $190 each. * Tandon Corp., Chatsworth, Calif., a maker of computer peripherals and disk drives, said it had agreed in principle to sell during 1987 about $50 million worth of 3.5-inch, 20-megabyte Winchester disk drives to Amstrad P.L.C., a British computer company.

title: 50-Millionth V.W.
description: Volkswagen A.G.'s 50-millionth vehicle rolled off the assembly line to a subdued welcome, dampened by the disclosure earlier this month of a loss of $260 million in a currency exchange scandal. VW's chairman, Carl Hahn, drove the milestone car, a white Golf model, off the assembly line. Of the 50 million vehicles produced since 1945, nearly 21 million were low-budget Beetles, the best-selling car of all time.

title: REPORTS CONFLICT ON HARLEM BLAZE
description: Investigators at a high-rise building in Harlem where a fire killed seven people Sunday heard conflicting reports yesterday on whether water to a sprinkler system was shut off when the fire began.

title: STATE'S NEW EDUCATION CHIEF IS SAID TO BE SCARSDALE OFFICIAL
description: The New York State Board of Regents has tentatively selected the Superintendent of Schools in Scarsdale to be the new State Education Commissioner, according to educational and legislative aides in Albany.

title: 22% RISE IN NEW YORK CAB FARES RECOMMENDED BY TAXI PANEL STAFF
description: Taxicab fares in New York City would rise 22 percent under recommendations issued yesterday by the staff of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: With All Deliberate Impropriety
description: Imagine the outcry if a Supreme Court Justice were caught feeding inside information from the Court to the Justice Department lawyer in an explosive case, something like abortion. Talk about outrage. There'd be instant demands for resignation and threats of impeachment for impropriety. Loftiness of purpose or concern for national interest would be no defense.

title: Reverse Play
description: Charles Barkley of the Philadelphia 76ers, who in the past has exchanged words with courtside spectators at Milwaukee, acknowledges a ''love-hate relationship'' with the Bucks' fans: ''I love to hate them.''

title: 'WATER TUNNEL' FOR FISH
description: Just as scientists generate high-velocity winds in cavernous tunnels to study the performance of aircraft, they have long used tunnels filled with flowing water to study the physiology and behavior of fish. But in the past, these tunnels could only accommodate small fish.

title: Actor's Son Is Missing As Fighter Goes Down
description: Dean Paul Martin, an actor, rock star and Air National Guard captain who is the son of the entertainer Dean Martin, was pilot of a fighter jet believed to have crashed on a snowy mountain, officials said today.

title: The Gift of Sight, Squandered
description: This year, corneal transplant operations will restore the vision of 1,300 sightless New Yorkers. Three times that many more will have to wait because New York City residents lag when it comes to authorizing the donation of corneas after death. Better training of city hospital staffs might do much to relieve the shortage.

title: Keep Cheap Hydropower in Western New York
description: To the Editor:

title: With New Curb on Life After Government, More Officials Leave
description: A new regulation prohibiting Pentagon officials from taking jobs in the defense industry for two years after they leave Government has nudged some toward the door earlier than they might have been as the Reagan Administration draws to a close.

title: VERNITRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,441,000 for the quarter and $3,509,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,078,000 for the quarter and $5,278,000 for the year.

title: POSSIBLE THEFT OF U.S. AFGHAN AID BEING INVESTIGATED BY THE G.A.O.
description: The General Accounting Office has started an investigation into allegations that millions of dollars in covert American military aid intended for the Afghan insurgents never reached them, agency officials said today.

title: Ex-Princeton Student Held In Cyanide-Tampering Case
description: A Yugoslavian national and former Princeton University graduate student confessed today to putting a cyanide-laced tea bag in a Princeton Township supermarket last month, the authorities said.

title: FULLER, H B CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
TIPS, REVIEWS AND GOSSIP
description: USERS' groups are a wonderful resource for beginning and experienced computer users alike. Although they have been around since the first home-made computers appeared, recently they have become a significant force in the personal computer industry. The larger groups exert a great deal of influence on the way computer companies design, market and support software and hardware.

title: LONG ISLAND LIGHTING CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said it revised its preliminary earnings for 1986 to reflect the settlement agreement reached this month with the staff of the Public Service Commission regarding the costs of the Jamesport Nuclear units. The company said the revision reflects a provision for a loss relating to its investment in the units amounting to $16 million after an estimated tax effect of $3 million. The company also said the settlement agreement is subject to the approval of the Public Serrvice Commission.

title: REAGAN SET TO VETO HIGHWAY BILL
description: President Reagan opened a campaign today to sustain his expected veto of an $87.9 billion highway and mass transit bill. Supporters said the fight would show whether the President has been able to regain some of the political leverage he has lost in recent months.

title: Conspiracy to Defraud
description: What criminal charges might result from the special prosecutor's investigation of the Iran-contra affair? Among many possibilities one stands out. That would be a broad charge of conspiracy in the supply of arms to the Nicaraguan contras at a time when Congress had barred official military support.

title: Fast and Healthy
description: Fast food chains justify the heavy doses of sodium and cholesterol in their standardized menus on grounds of market research. The public, they assert, wants them instead of good nutrition. Jim and Ken Raffel, operators of four Arby's fast food outlets in southern Maine, have had different experience.

title: Recommitment to Indochinese Refugees
description: Thailand, seeing no end to providing asylum for Indochinese refugees, has turned against them with acts of extortion, brutality and now life-endangering forced repatriation. The Thais have committed the acts, yet the United States must share the blame; its declining role in this long-playing refugee story has contributed to the Thai frustration. A humane ending requires a recommitment to these helpless people from both Bangkok and Washington.

title: YELLOWSTONE AND STAFF ARE STRAINED AS RANKS OF WINTER VISITORS SWELL
description: When Gerald Mernin began working here in 1964, winter was a season of snowy silence, a time when traffic and tourists were scarce and rangers skied through the back country, studying the park's geysers, forests and wildlife.

title: 'MY FRIEND IVAN LAPSHIN'
description: ONE'S sympathies are all with Aleksei German. The Soviet director has had his troubles with his country's authorities; movies that he made 10 and 20 years ago have only recently been released in the West.
