His fourth and latest effort, ''My Friend Ivan Lapshin,'' which will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art as part of the New Directors/New Films series tonight at 8:30 and tomorrow at 6 P.M., is one of the first proscribed films to benefit from glasnost. Scheduled to open next month at the Cinema Studio, it is evidence that not every movie that has displeased the cultural commissars is a masterpiece.

title: DEFENDANT PLEADS GUILTY IN AIDS MURDER CASE
description: The trial of a homeless man who said he killed a male friend after the two had sex and the friend revealed that he had AIDS ended today when the defendant pleaded guilty to manslaughter.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Fall
description: Weaker prices for the American dollar quickly spread to the Treasury market yesterday, as traders worried that foreigners would be reluctant buyers of government issues until the dollar stabilized.

title: SANFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The latest quarter net does not include results from Sanford's Mexican subsidiary since the company has agreed to sell a controlling interest in the unit.

title: KNIGHT, TARKANIAN: A CLASH OF STYLES
description: Even the shrewdest matchmaker could not have designed a more striking Final Four semifinal matchup than Indiana versus Nevada-Las Vegas.

title: Reaction in Washington
description: An American trade official said today that he did not expect the production cutbacks announced by Japan to have much effect on the coming White House decision on whether to impose sanctions against the Japanese.

title: Texas Under Scrutiny
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has sent a letter to the University of Texas charging rules violations in 19 categories in the Longhorns' football program from 1980 through 1986, Knox Nunnally, a lawyer hired by the university, said today.

title: DIOR CELEBRATION: FETE THAT FIZZLED
description: Everything went wrong at the party Friday night to celebrate Dior's 40th anniversary. Guests, including Jerome Zipkin and Anne Slater, who flew over from New York for the event, could not find seats. No scissors were available when Princess Caroline of Monaco was ready to cut the ribbon at the newly renovated boutique on the Avenue Montaigne, and a crush developed as the 550 guests, who had gathered in an adjoining tent, tried to file in for dinner. Marc Bohan, the Dior designer, finally located some kitchen shears so that the ribbon could be cut and so that guests like Bernadette Chirac, Morgan Fairchild and Sophia Loren could sit down to their lobster and lamb.

title: BLUE-CHIP FORMULA FAVORS INDIANA
description: Syracuse is the only Final Four team with a ''legitimate center'' - Rony Seikaly. Providence is ''on a roll.'' Nevada-Las Vegas ''is one of the best college basketball teams'' in recent decades. But Indiana has ''four immediate or eventual'' first-round National Basketball Association draft choices - Steve Alford, Dean Garrett, Rick Calloway and Keith Smart.

title: U.S. Judge Stays Execution, Overruling Tribunal in Texas
description: A Federal district judge today stayed the execution of a prisoner who had been scheduled to die by lethal injection early Tuesday.

title: Ellsworth Howell, 71, Dies; Publisher of Books on Dogs
description: Ellsworth S. Howell, a publisher of books on dogs as well as a writer and dog show judge, died Thursday in Darien, Conn. He was 71 years old.

title: UMPIRES' STRIKE IS A POSSIBILITY
description: With the opening of the baseball season only two weeks away, the presidents of the American and National Leagues have notified clubs to have umpires available for their home games in the event that major league umpires strike at the start of the season.

title: JOB OPPORTUNITIES SEEN RISING FOR YOUTHS IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Young people in the New York region are facing greater opportunities than ever as they prepare for careers and look for jobs, according to economists and business executives.

title: RANDOLPH B. SMITH
description: Dr. Randolph B. Smith, an educator and former director of the Little Red School House, a private school in Greenwich Village, died Sunday at Rutland (Vt.) Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Belmont, Vt.

title: RESEARCH LIFTS BLAME FROM MANY OF THE OBESE
description: RECENT findings on the causes of obesity and the metabolic consequences of ''yo-yo'' dieting are forcing weight-reduction specialists to reconsider both their methods and the goals of treatment.

title: WD-40 CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $432,000 from payment of a legal settlement which may later be reimbursed.

title: Mariners Want Raines
description: The Seattle Mariners' owner, George Argyros, said yesterday he was prepared to make a contract offer to Tim Raines and hoped an accord could be reached ''within 48 hours.'' Argyros added, ''We think we could realistically meet the figures we've been hearing about and make him happy.'' Raines, last year's National League batting champion, had recently talked with the Padres, but the discussions collapsed. He has said he would like to get a contract that would at least equal the $1.5 million pact he had in Montreal last season before becoming a free agent.

title: THEATER: 'SHOEMAKERS'
description: IN his prescient 1934 play ''The Shoemakers,'' Stanislaw I. Witkiewicz, Poland's greatest modern playwright, wittily demonstrates that Communist and fascist dictatorships are the same. That kept it off the stage in Poland until 1965, when it was presented by Wlodzimierz Herman, who also directs its first English-language performance by the Jean Cocteau Repertory company at the Bouwerie Lane Theater, at 300 Bowery.

title: A Woman's Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 648787 -- No Title
description: In agreeing to sell its South African holdings, the Xerox Corporation would get less than half the amount at which local industry officials had valued the properties, a merchant bank representing both companies said today.

title: Budget Chief Cancels Speech at Men's Club
description: James C. Miller 3d, the Reagan Administration's budget chief, canceled a speaking engagement tonight at the Cosmos Club after learning his appearance at the male-only club would violate Federal regulations.

title: SOVIET ECONOMIC IMPROVEMENT BELOW EXPECTATIONS
description: Two years after Mikhail S. Gorbachev took power promising a new prosperity, the Soviet economy is sputtering and political pressure for better fiscal and industrial results is building, according to Soviet officials and Western experts.

title: Iba to Coach T.C.U.
description: Moe Iba was named as Texas Christian basketball coach, succeeding Jim Killingsworth, who resigned earlier in the month. Iba, 47 years old, had a 106-71 record in five seasons at Nebraska before he resigned a year ago. He was an assistant coach at Drake this season. Killingsworth retired after eight years at T.C.U.

title: Murray Goes for Pros
description: Kevin Murray, the quarterback who led Texas A&M to Southwest Conference championships and Cotton Bowl appearances the last two seasons, announced he would forgo his final year of eligibility and make himself available for this spring's National Football League draft. Murray, twice a consensus all-conference player, had indicated earlier in the year he would return for his final season of eligibility. That would have been his fifth year, since he was granted an extra year to compensate for a season-ending injury in an early non-conference game in 1984.

title: CHILD WORLD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Texaco Offers New Evidence
description: Texaco Inc. said today that it had given a Texas appellate court ''new evidence'' indicating that a trial judge was biased against the company during the 1985 jury trial that led to a $10.53 billion judgment for the Pennzoil Company.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MARCH 24, 1987
description: Companies

title: Assistant to Volcker Is Joining Peat Marwick
description: Steven M. Roberts is leaving his post as assistant to the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, to join Peat Marwick & Co., the accounting firm. He will work in the firm's Washington office as partner responsible for a consulting practice advising financial institutions on Government regulatory policy.

title: MACHINE-AIDED ART
description: FROM a technological point of view, the advances made in personal computer graphics have been quite amazing. Less than a decade ago, the machines were limited to straight lines and saw-toothed curves. Today they can produce reasonably recognizable computer-drawn figures and landscapes as well as three-dimensional diagrams intricate enough to serve as blueprints.

title: 'WILL THE WORLD STARVE?' ON 'NOVA'
description: ''WILL THE WORLD STARVE?'' is a curiously flat documentary. Its title may suggest cosmic urgency, but its mood is more like lassitude. Soil erosion, the ''Nova'' episode says, may force a worldwide crisis; on the other hand, it may not. The program, on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, is so stately in its presentation we're not sure what it's about. The only certainty is that China is grand.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on March 12 with an article about an American art exhibition in Leningrad misidentified the United States consul general there. He is Edward Hurwitz, not Gurvich.

title: Esposito Answers Second-Guessers
description: He has given vibrance to an organization that for too long sat and waited and then waited some more, as if the Stanley Cup would come walking through the front door. The Rangers had become a staid, cautious organization in the pre-Phil Esposito days. But in the eight months Esposito has been in charge, he has made the Rangers interesting, mainly by putting them through one change after another.

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SENATE PANEL TO GET A PLAN FOR BUDGET SAVINGS
description: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee is preparing a 1988 budget that would save $36 billion, half of it in tax increases, according to Congressional aides.

title: MUSIC: BENNETT LERNER IN A PIANO MARATHON
description: BENNETT LERNER, a pianist with a mission (to say the least), started playing 20th-century music mostly by American composers at about 2 P.M. Sunday at the 92d Street Y, and kept it up, with short breaks, for about four hours. By the end, counting separate movements, it amounted to 75 pieces played end to end. This is, of course, an unconventional way to listen to music. For this listener, it is also an uncongenial one. Reactions to such marathons are inevitably personal; many in the enthusiastic audience could still be observed at the end in the same seats they had taken at the beginning. Fortunately for those who preferred to drop in and out, a great deal of the music Mr. Lerner played Sunday has also been recorded by him on the Etcetera label (distributed in America by Qualiton Imports). One could supplement visits by listening to the records at one's own convenience.

title: IF A COMPUTER ANSWERS, GET TICKETS
description: By pushing a few buttons on a Touch-Tone telephone, callers anywhere in the country can now find out what's going on in New York City theater, dance and music and can buy tickets to performances.

title: Channel 13 Exceeds Goal for Memberships
description: Channel 13, one of New York City's public television stations, exceeded its membership goal for the first time in three years, station officials said yesterday.

title: SHIFT IN '63 CASE MAY HELP AVERT A DEATH PENALTY
description: New York's highest court overturned today a 24-year-old assault conviction against a man awaiting execution in Mississippi. The ruling cleared the way for new legal efforts to block the execution.

title: VALLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $756,000.

title: IOWA PARENTS SYMBOLS OF DEFIANCE ON SCHOOLS
description: Trailed by a bobbing stream of umbrellas and 200 hymn-singing supporters, Sharon Taylor went off to jail here this morning.

title: Monthly Video Cassette Will Be Given Away
description: A dozen years ago, there were quite a few skeptics around when Judy Price introduced her give-away magazine called Avenue that was delivered to homes on the fashionable East Side. Common wisdom at the time was that free magazines were neither valued by the recipients nor trusted by advertisers.

title: THE DANCE: MARTHA BOWERS
description: MARTHA BOWERS is not afraid to think. Nor is she afraid to be unabashedly emotional. She revealed both her thoughts and her feelings in the works that Martha Bowers Dance/Theater/Etcetera presented Sunday night at the Field, at the Pineapple Dance Center.

title: Hogtying Was Banned as Barbaric, Offensive and Unnecessary
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Operating Post Is Filled by GF Corp.
description: The GF Corporation, a maker of steel and wood office furniture said yesterday that it had named Richard D. Major as president and chief operating officer.

title: 'BETTER CLASS OF PERSON' BY JOHN OSBORNE, ON 13
description: SOME 30 years ago, the British theater was rocked out of its drawing-room complacency by ''Look Back in Anger.'' The play was written by John Osborne, the most prominent of a group dubbed the ''angry young men.'' Not too many commentators at the time considered that Mr. Osborne might be less interested in demolishing the aristocracy than in getting a firm foothold for himself on the social ladder. Behind much of the anger, it seemed, was simple resentment and envy.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET FILM MAKERS DEBATE STEREOTYPES
description: The film clips traded insults.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Home Section March 12 about the designer Sam Lopata omitted the name of his co-designer for the restaurants Coastal, Anabelle's, Home on the Range and Extra! Extra! She is Denise Hall.

title: COOPER DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a charge of $4,711,000 for costs of a portion of unamortized debt issuance. c-Net loss The company said the latest quarter results also include a pre-tax gain of $11,400,000 from the sale of a product line. The company said that an accounting change in its acquisition of the company's Cooperbiomedical business unit necessitated a revision of its financial results for the fiscal year ended Oct 31, 1986. The company also said it had a net loss of $61.7 million for fiscal 1986, primarily as a result of $53.5 million of Cooperbiomedical restructuring costs that previously had been capitalized, versus a loss of $12.1 million previously reported. The accounting change treatment means the company will not have to charge the $53.5 million of restructuring costs against the results of future operations. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Thon Wants to Rest
description: Dickie Thon, the Houston Astros' shorstop, said yesterday he does not want to retire from baseball but would like some time off to undergo eye exercises. Thon, whose career was nearly ended after he was hit above the left eye on a pitch early in the 1984 season, left camp in Kissimmee, Fla., March 14 after being frustrated with his performance and having trouble seeing the ball during exhibition games. Thon, 28 years old, underwent a two-and-a-half-hour eye examination in Houston by a team specialist last Friday with results showing no change in his vision from last year.

title: Hafts Increase Bid for Supermarkets
description: The Haft family of Washington said yesterday that it was raising its offer for the Supermarkets General Corporation, the operators of Pathmark stores and Rickel home-improvement centers.

title: Playing All 8,178 Chords In 'Chord Catalogue'
description: In his own quiet, pleasant and slightly quizzical style, Tom Johnson has for years been questioning the way most of us look at music. In the ''Chord Catalogue'' - as played on the piano by the composer at Roulette on Sunday night - the processes of nature, for example, are not so much reinvented by a creative ego as simply noticed and identified.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about 1986 crime statistics for New York City's police precincts misstated the number of murders reported citywide in 1985. There were 1,392.

title: Texas Port Bonds Taxable, Insured
description: The Port of Houston yesterday offered nearly $31 million of taxable bonds through Masterson & Company in the first taxable municipal bond issue to be insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation. The bonds, which are rated triple-A, were issued in taxable form because more than 10 percent of the issue is to finance private business facilities at the port.

title: Finally, the End Of the Rainbow
description: A rare kind of pension arrangement offering a pot-of-gold payoff led several veteran players in the National Hockey League to postpone retirement after last season. It's not that they didn't want the pot of gold, but that they did. Under preliminary rules, a player qualifying for it needed minimum service of 400 N.H.L. games, at least 40 of which had to be played this season.

title: Cutbacks at Avco Aerostructures
description: Avco Aerostructures Textron said that it would be forced to lay off about 3,000 employees of its work force by year's end as it completes a Government contract for B-1 bomber wings. John S. Kleban, president of the company, said it ''will be reducing employment by an average of 400 per month starting in April and continuing through 1987'' as the contract for 100 sets of wings draws to an end.

title: SOME FIRMS SAID TO AVOID DREXEL
description: Several of Wall Street's biggest firms have been limiting the amount of business they do with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in the commodities markets, according to Drexel and other sources.

title: SOMEBODY UP HERE LIKES HIM
description: While many of his football teammates at Southern Methodist University sift through offers from perennial bowl candidates, at least one player is relatively confident that he will not be playing on a championship team next season.

title: Bridge; Scientific Player Runs Risk Of Giving Guidance to Rival
description: The desirability of giving information is a central problem of bridge theory, in both bidding and defense. Any information you may give your partner is liable to help the opposition.

title: Bucks' Torrid Start Trounces Knicks
description: Craig Hodges scored 27 points and the Milwaukee Bucks erupted for 44 first-quarter points en route to a 135-96 victory over the injury-riddled Knicks tonight.

title: 12 SCIENTISTS WIN 1987 WOLF PRIZES
description: The 1987 Wolf Prizes, among the most prestigious and lucrative in science, have been awarded to 12 leaders in six areas of endeavor. Seven of them are Americans, all but one of whom were born abroad.

title: ELGIN NATIONAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge from restructuring the consumer products operations of $1,700,000 for both the quarter and year; and the year also includes a charge of $4,500,000 from restructuring of the engineering, manufacturing and construction group. c-Net income

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: U.S. Condemns Air Raids
description: The United States today condemned the bombing raids against Pakistani villages, calling them ''the worst single cross-border attack since the war began.''

title: CYNTHIA OZICK'S RABBINICAL APPROACH TO LITERATURE
description: Cynthia Ozick is at a turning point, a crucial moment in her writing career that is mirrored in her new critically acclaimed short novel, ''The Messiah of Stockholm.'' A deeply religious person, Ms. Ozick has long been concerned about, and has written on, what she sees as the danger of literature violating the Second Commandment - literature as idol worship.

title: CHEZ GAULTIER, OFFSTAGE AND ON
description: Basha Cohen's eyes swept the crowd of fashion groupies trying to dress their way into Jean-Paul Gaultier's show at the Halle de la Villette in the slaughterhouse district on the outskirts of Paris. ''This is the best place to find the incoming looks,'' said Ms. Cohen, director of fashion merchandising for the Associated Merchandising Corporation in New York.

title: Chip Concerns Form Alliance
description: Texas Instruments Inc. and the Linear Technology Corporation said today that they had formed a strategic alliance for the production of analog integrated circuits. In return for specified fees, Texas Instruments will gain access to 60 circuits made by Linear, a company based in Milpitas, Calif., that specializes in analog, or linear, chips, rather than digital chips.

title: Schofer and Gold Leave Classical Artists Agency
description: The reshuffling in the world of classical-music management under way since the death of Sheldon Gold of ICM Artists in 1985 has taken a new turn with the departure, announced Monday, of Marvin Schofer and Michaela Deren Gold, Mr. Gold's wife, from the new agency they had formed last September, Classical Artists International.

title: Disney in France
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, as expected, signed a contract for a $2 billion Disney theme park outside Paris. The world's fourth Disney park is to open in 1992 on a 4,400-acre site in rural Marne-la-Vallee, 20 miles east of Paris. French officials said it would create 30,000 new jobs and should draw about 10 million visitors a year.

title: Atari, Commodore Settle
description: The Atari Corporation and Commodore International Ltd. said that all pending litigation between the two personal computer companies had been settled. Atari had sued the Amiga Corporation, which was later acquired by Commodore, for breach of contract in a deal to develop a new computer. It subsequently sued Commodore in Federal court for patent infringement. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed.

title: Haig Makes It Official: His 'Helmet' Is in the Ring
description: Formally beginning his Presidential campaign, Alexander M. Haig Jr. outlined his positions yesterday on some key issues.

title: Some Second Thoughts on 'Super Tuesday'
description: Democrats, having organized a regional primary in the South, are now trying to figure out how to make the event live up to their expectations.

title: John Alden Sale
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation said it had agreed to sell the John Alden Life Insurance Company and affiliated operations to a group of the unit's managers for $280 million. The management group, led by Glendon E. Johnson, John Alden's president, has obtained a commitment letter from the General Electric Credit Corporation to finance the deal. Great Western, which put the insurance company up for sale in November, will post a pretax gain of about $65 million and an after-tax gain of $15 million on the sale.

title: Gencorp Measures
description: Gencorp Inc.'s directors withdrew from its annual meeting agenda three proposed anti-takeover measures that had become an issue in the pending $2.3 billion tender offer for the company. A. William Reynolds, Gencorp's chairman, said in a statement the proposals were withdrawn so the company could concentrate on responding to the unsolicited tender offer by a partnership led by AFG Industries Inc. and Wagner & Brown. The three shareholder measures would have authorized an increase in the number of common shares from 35 million to 100 million, staggered the terms of Gencorp directors and eliminated cumulative voting.

title: TEJON RANCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net for 1985 includes a non- recurring tax benefit of $2,465,000 from the settlement of litigation with the I.R.S. relating to prior years' tax returns.

title: PRESS IS BARRED FROM A HEARING FOR ARMS DEALER
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday barred reporters from most of a bail hearing for a New York arms dealer who is charged with plotting to ship military equipment to the Soviet Union, Poland, Iraq and Argentina.

title: NEW U.S. RULE FOR AIR SAFETY TO TAKE EFFECT
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday put into effect a new rule on crash recorders that will speed many investigations and should improve chances of pinpointing causes and averting similar accidents.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 8
description: b-After a charge of $15 million related to restructuring of certain operations as announced in January for the quarter and 9 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $1.1 million for the quarter and $3.3 million for the 9 months; the 9 months also includes a gain of $51.2 million from cumulative effect of change in method of recognizing revenue on distributor shipments.

title: A KISSING COUSIN OF BELGIAN ENDIVE ON LONG ISLAND
description: Week after week, a forklift pulls into a refrigerated room in a small factorylike building here, reaches toward the ceiling and pulls down crates containing about 3,000 chicory roots each.

title: Corrections
description: An Athens dispatch in some copies yesterday incorrectly characterized the political prospects of Miltiadis Evert, the Mayor of Athens. Some Greek analysts have called him the heir apparent to the leadership of the New Democracy Party, not necessarily to the post of prime minister.

title: Federal Express Moves To Fallon, McElligott
description: One of the most creative partnerships in the history of advertising has ended. Federal Express of Memphis has switched the domestic portion of its account from Ally Gargano/MCA Advertising to Fallon, McElligott of Minneapolis. The billings are estimated at more than $20 million.

title: Who Needs This 'Glasnost' Anyhow?
description: LEAD: I liked the old Soviet Union better before all this foolishness about ''glasnost.'' The Russian word being trumpeted by General Secretary Mikhail S. Gorbachev means ''openness, candor and publicity.'' The energetic leader is using this word like a hammer to pound some life into his country's stagnating, low-tech economy.

title: SOVIET EMIGRATION OF JEWS IS HIGHEST IN LAST FIVE YEARS
description: More than 400 Soviet Jews have so far received permission to emigrate in March, the highest monthly figure since the end of 1981, Western diplomats and Soviet officials said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 25, 1987
description: Markets

title: About New York; Falling Behind On the Latest List Of Urban Plagues
description: After recently placing a lowly 14th in the latest ''serious crime'' ranking by the F.B.I. of the country's 25 biggest cities, New York suffered yet another damaging blow to its image yesterday, showing up a measly 12th on a list of America's most roach-infested cities.

title: Philadelphia Electric Issue
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company is offering $250 million of bonds due in 2017 at a price of 99 3/4 to yield 9.40 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & company. Rated Baa-3 by Moody's and

title: Georgians Act to Curb Racism After Marches
description: A biracial committee formed to deal with racial turmoil in Forsyth County, an all-white area north of here, issued its first report today and cited progress on several fronts.

title: DATA ON MANHATTAN LEGISLATORS' STAFF SUBPOENAED
description: The Manhattan District Attorney subpoenaed the personnel records of all 18 members of the State Legislature from Manhattan today.

title: AIDS TEST FOR WOMEN URGED BEFORE PREGNANCY
description: Any woman who wants to have a baby should voluntarily be tested for AIDS infection before becoming pregnant, Surgeon General C. Everett Koop said today.

title: The Democrats' Dilemma
description: Speaker Jim Wright, among other Democrats, has been chastised in this space for a ''political death wish'' - wanting to raise taxes to reduce the Federal deficit. More in sorrow than in anger, Mr. Wright recently insisted over lunch that he has a problem only a tax increase can ease.

title: ORDERS FOR DURABLES RISE 6%
description: Orders for ''big ticket'' durable goods, bolstered by heavy demand for military hardware, shot up 6 percent in February, the biggest gain in five months, the Government reported today.

title: GENERAL NUTRITION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest quarter and year results both include a $1 million increase to 1985 provision from expected store closing costs and a pretax loss of $3.9 million in connection with discontinuance of Canadian operations.

title: Music Award to Harrison Birtwistle
description: Harrison Birtwistle, a British composer who has written for orchestra, ballet, small ensemble, voice and film, won a $150,000 award Monday for his modern opera ''The Mask of Orpheus.''

title: Philip Rhinelander, 79, Dies; Former Dean at Stanford U.
description: Philip Rhinelander, former head of general education at Harvard University and a former Stanford University dean, died of cancer last Friday at his campus home. He was 79 years old.

title: MUSIC: SONGS BY BEETHOVEN
description: Robert White has made charming records of Beethoven's folk song arrangements, but his Beethoven Society concert of them Saturday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall was only a partial success. The tenor has a fresh, attractive way with words; under the right conditions, the same can be said of his voice, but the voice is very light, and the conditions do not seem to include competition with a sonorous violin-cello-piano trio in a large room. Mr. White tightened up as he approached his higher notes, and tended to phrase in choppy bursts when the dynamic level was at all high.

title: BENJAMIN S. HORNSTEIN
description: Benjamin S. Hornstein, a philanthropist and retired retail executive, died Friday at St. Mary's Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 96 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter and 9 months results include gains on disposition of investments of $5,000 and $7,052,00, respectively; and the year-ago quarter and 9 months results include similar gains of $2,454,000 for the quarter and $5,306,000 for the 9 months.

title: NEW BRUNSWICK SCIENTIFIC CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said an adjustment in the estimated annual effective income tax rates used during its first three quarters of each year to the actual rate realized each year increased net income by $207,000, or 6 cents a share, for the latest fourth quarter, and by $57,000, or 2 cents a share, for the year-ago period.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on March 17 about the disposition of assets of a limited partnership run by Ivan F. Boesky misstated Lewis Lehrman's role at the Rite Aid Corporation. He was president of the company but not the founder.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
NEW-SELF SAUCE
description: LEAD: YOU have left the Old Self, that butter-spreading, cruller-inhaling wretch, forever. The New Self turns back supermarket snack cakes at the border and revokes heavy cream's visa. What foods can the two selves possibly have in common?

title: Token Stalking
description: New York City's subways and buses consume tokens wholesale. Therefore it stands to reason that tokens are easily available, doesn't it? Forget reason. To buy tokens, New Yorkers must head for the nearest subway booth. They have to hope it's open. They have to hope the line's not long, and that the other token seller isn't about to seal off his window.

title: 5 Artists to Get Greenburger Awards
description: Five artists have been chosen to receive the Francis J. Greenburger Foundation Awards. The foundation was established last year by Mr. Greenburger, a real-estate developer, to help artists whose work deserves wider public recognition. Each artist will receive $5,000 and a small bronze by Isaac Witkin, a sculptor.

title: The Ames Quartet In New York Debut
description: The Ames Quartet, in residence at Iowa State University, consists of William David, a pianist; Mahlon Darlington, a violinist; Laurence Burkhalter, a violist, and George Work, a cellist. Their first New York appearance, which took place Sunday afternoon at the Merkin Concert Hall, included a spirited romp, the Quartet in E flat (Op. 16), by the young Beethoven; an ambitious Quartet (1976) by the American composer William Bolcom, and the first of two essays in this medium by Gabriel Faure, the Quartet in C minor (Op. 15).

title: MANHATTAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net gains from investments of $74,000 for the quarter and $642,000 for the year. c-Includes net gains from investments of $644,000 and $1,979,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net loss The company said the latest fourth quarter results were effected by an expense provision for terminated employees and refinements to the methodology for allocating operating expenses among the consolidated group.

title: S.M.U. Acts On Sex Report
description: Southern Methodist University has hired a private investigator to look into reports that boosters paid sorority women to have sex with football recruits and hired other students to take tests for athletes.

title: 'A TRIBUTE TO AMERICAN MUSIC' AT WHITE HOUSE
description: THE East Room of the White House may not be the right place for Rodgers and Hart.

title: Rasmussen to Open Instead of Rhoden
description: So far, the concern within the Yankee camp is still minimal. But now that Rick Rhoden has been scratched from his opening-day assignment in Detroit, the feelings of uncertainty may be rising.

title: Wynton Marsalis Plays Cornet Showpieces
description: Wynton Marsalis's latest demonstration of classical virtuosity is a revival of showpieces written by, and for, the cornetists who led bands at the turn of the century. The conductor of the Eastman Wind Ensemble, Donald Hunsberger, researched and arranged that music for Mr. Marsalis's latest album, ''Carnaval,'' and Mr. Marsalis, playing cornet, rejoined Mr. Hunsberger and the band Sunday at Carnegie Hall for a solemn sort of pops concert.

title: AD FIRMS FIND LOWER WEST SIDE
description: GEER DUBOIS INC., an advertising agency, was considered a daring pioneer when it left midtown in 1981 in search of moderate rents on lower Fifth Avenue. But within five years it had been joined by more than two dozen other advertising agencies.

title: X's, O's and A's
description: When Coach Pat Kennedy of Florida State filled in his ballot for the Metro Conference's all-freshman basketball team, he left two of the five lines blank and then, with a nod to Proposition 48, wrote at the bottom of the page, ''The rest of them are in study hall.''

title: Wyoming Coach Exits
description: Jim Brandenburg, the 51-year-old basketball coach who took Wyoming to the round of 16 in the N.C.A.A. tournament before losing to Nevada-Las Vegas, has jumped to San Diego State. ''It's an opportunity I just couldn't afford to turn down,'' Brandenberg said at a news conference yesterday in San Diego, where he replaced David (Smokey) Gaines, who resigned. San Diego State and Wyoming are both members of the Western Athletic Conference, and Brandenburg's defection is likely to heat up the schools' rivalry. Paul Roach, the Wyoming athletic director, said he offered to raise Brandenburg's annual salary but could not convince the coach to stay.

title: PRETORIA REACHES PACT ON DEBT IT FROZE IN '85
description: South Africa and its creditor banks have reached agreement on the repayment of the $13 billion in debt on which Pretoria halted payments in 1985, the Government announced today.

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $70,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $372,000 for the year; and the quarter and year also include minority interest expenses of $973,000 and $3,717,000, respectively. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary gain of $214,000 for both the quarter and year; and the quarter and year also include benefits from minority interest of $110,000 for the quarter and $90,000 for the year. The company said the latest fourth quarter net includes pretax gains of about $5 million from the disposition of a portion of its 86 percent-owned Ambrit units interest in Sheraton Securities International PLC; and the latest year net is after non-cash charges of more than $18 million.

title: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: The Business of TV News Is Show Business
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAEL CITES NEW DATA IN U.N. NAZI FILES
description: United Nations war-crimes files that have been examined by Israel hold a ''treasure trove of new information'' on the Nazis that ''could change our understanding of that era,'' Israel's chief delegate to the world body said today.

title: MAKEUP OF A NEW AFGHAN REGIME IS SEEN AS BARRIER TO PEACE EFFORTS
description: Despite a narrowing of differences in the Geneva talks on the Afghan war, officials said a disagreement over who should run the Afghan Government continued to block a resolution of the conflict.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
S.I. CHIEF AGREES TO A NEW 4,000-INMATE CITY JAIL
description: The Koch administration announced plans yesterday to build a jail on Staten Island for as many as 4,000 inmates, after striking a deal with the Borough President to reduce the proposed number of shelters for the homeless there.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jim Covert, the all-pro offensive tackle, has signed a series of one-year contracts with the Chicago Bears. The 27-year-old player underwent arthroscopic surgery to correct elbow and knee problems last month. . . . Dennis Scott, 6-foot-7-inch swingman who led Flint Hill Prep in Falls Church, Va., to consecutive 23-0 seasons and was named the Naismith High School Player of the Year, announced he has accepted a scholarship to attend Georgia Tech.

title: PLENUM PUBLISHING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All share earnings reflect the previously announced 5-for-2 stock split.

title: JAPANESE THRUST IN WALL ST.
description: Wall Street has long been home to brokers and investors from all nations. But no single country is moving faster to add to its presence in America's financial capital than Japan.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IN the beginning there was Jell-O. Then Bab-O and SpaghettiOs. There's a song called ''Peg O' My Heart'' and O! so many others. Everyone knows that. But Richard Szabo and Richard Crater, lifelong pals in Livingston, N.J., have done something about names or titles that feature the letter O set off by dashes (as in Protect-O-Hood hairnets) or followed by an apostophe replacing the letter f (as in Land O' Lakes butter) or some variation thereon. What they've done is documented more than 900 of these products and collected them in an underground warehouse (actually the Crater family's 1950's bomb shelter) in Livingston. What's more, they've given their collection a name. They call it, not surprisingly, Shrine O' Stuff.

title: TCBY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
U.S. MODIFIES RULES ON WORKER STATUS OF ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that it had proposed, in effect, to allow illegal aliens to work in this country through Sept. 1.

title: TIFFANY'S NEXT SALE: ITS STOCK
description: Not since Holly Golightly has Tiffany's seemed so special.

title: CASEY IS TERMED THE MASTERMIND OF EFFORTS TO SUPPLY THE CONTRAS
description: Congressional investigators have clear indications that William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, masterminded the Reagan Administration's efforts to help the Nicaraguan rebels get military supplies, according to two Senators and a Representative.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: For Cooks and Foragers

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
Going Mad For Things Australian
description: LEAD: IT used to be that when Americans thought of Australia - if they thought of Australia -they conjured up the image of a koala bear, a kangaroo or a tennis player. Not anymore.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 25, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: MILLIONAIRE AND LABOR LAWYER
description: Edward Lamb, a millionaire businessman, broadcaster and lawyer long active in labor union and civil rights causes, died Monday at his home in Maumee, Ohio. He was 84 years old.

title: OPERA: 'ABIGAIL ADAMS'
description: THOSE who have jocularly praised Judge Richard Owen of Federal District Court in Manhattan for bravery in sentencing the eight defendants in the Mafia ''commission'' trial despite history's warnings of underworld retribution may not be aware that the good judge has tested his fortitude in an arena still less forgiving: with no oath of office to bind him, Mr. Owen has repeatedly presented operas of his composition for public and critical scrutiny. The latest is ''Abigail Adams,'' whose short run at the Harkness Center concluded Friday evening.

title: Foreign Aid Fight Heats Up
description: Every year the foreign aid bill runs into trouble on Capitol Hill, with critics contending that the funds it provides are too often squandered or misdirected and would be better spent on needs at home. But this year the bill seems to be in more trouble than ever.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Smoother Streets, Shorter Lines; Pothole Half-Life
description: New York City's Bureau of Highway Operations has earned worm after worm for failing to keep up with the potholes that pock city streets each spring. Now, remarkably, the bureau deserves an apple.

title: OFFICIAL DEFENDS VOLUNTEER ARMY AGAINST A POSSIBLE PLEA FOR DRAFT
description: A senior Defense Department official today gave Congress what Pentagon officials characterized as a Republican defense of a volunteer military force against an expected call by some Democrats for a return to the draft.

title: MUSIC: BROOKLYN ORCHESTRA PLAYS MODERN WORKS
description: THE Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra opened its Friday night ''Meet the Moderns'' program at Cooper Union, entitled ''Music From the West Coast,'' with a work by Ralph Shapey, who has spent most of his career in Chicago and recently moved to New York. This seeming incongruity was easily explained, however. The Shapey work, entitled ''Discourse for Four Instruments'' (1961), had been scheduled for an earlier concert this year but canceled. Rather than drop it from the season, Lukas Foss, the Brooklyn Philharmonic's music director, added it as a ''prelude'' to the current concert.

title: Delicate Tax Issue
description: The Internal Revenue Service, fresh from its scrap with Congress over the design of a new W-4 wage withholding form, appears headed for another messy confrontation with Congress, Washington tax experts and homeowners. This time the issue is the deductibility of ''points'' paid on the refinancing of mortgages, an especially delicate area given the hundreds of thousands of homeowners who refinanced last year to take advantage of lower interest rates.

title: Comdata Takes Bid
description: Comdata Network Inc., a money transfer service, said it would accept a sweetened takeover offer of $313 million from a New York investment group. Comdata said it would merge into a company formed by Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe IV, in return for either $16.50 a share in cash or $10 in cash as well as stock and debt in the new company.

title: Top Dogs
description: The most popular canine breeds in the United States, according to American Kennel Club registrations for 1986: FOR 1985 Pos. Breed Total Pos. Total 1 cocker spaniel 98,330 1 96,396 2 poodle 85,500 2 87,250r 3 Labrador retriever 77,371 3 74,271 4 golden retriever 59,057 5 56,131 5 German shepherd 55,958 4 57,598 6 chow chow 43,026 8 39,167 7 beagle 39,849 7 40,803 8 min.schnauzer 38,961 9 38,134 9 dachshund 35,537 11 33,903 10 Sh'tland sheepdog 35,064 10 34,350 The underdog? That's the harrier, which looks like a cross between a big beagle and a small foxhound. It ranks 129th and last on the A.K.C. list, with only 15 registrations last year.

title: VIOLATIONS CITED IN UTAH MINE FIRE THAT KILLED 27
description: The operators of a Utah coal mine where 27 miners died in an underground fire in December 1984 were cited today by a Federal agency for 34 safety violations, including nine linked directly to the ignition and rapid spread of the fire.

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER ENSEMBLE
description: THE members of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center seemed to be going about their duties with a new sense of purpose, and the group's Sunday afternoon concert at Alice Tully Hall was rewarding.

title: Salomon Handling Ford Unit's Notes
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $200 million of 8 percent notes due in 1997 at 99.125 to yield 8.13 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: REGIONAL tastes seem to change in the subtlest ways. A few years ago, as I was traveling in the Midwest, I noticed an abundance of fresh pork tenderloin in the meat markets, notably in Chicago. Returning to New York, I was surprised to find that this cut of pork was not at all easy to come by. Stores that sold it were few, and their stock was generally limited.

title: NEW HUSKER DU ALBUM POSES HARD QUESTIONS
description: WITH six albums in less than six years, the Minneapolis band Husker Du has churned out a soundtrack for frantic lives filled with tough questions. On the new ''Warehouse: Songs and Stories,'' the band asks: ''How much misery can one soul take?'' ''Is love another way to count the things you haven't got?'' ''What have you done to yourself in this instance?'' ''Is it only happiness you want?'' Bob Mould's guitar supplies a furious drone and buzz; below it, Greg Norton's bass and Grant Hart's drums are likely to double the tempo. It's music that doesn't allow the thought of repose.

title: BAKER, VOLCKER AND THE DOLLAR
description: THE dollar has been falling again against the yen and the mark despite the Paris agreement among the ''Group of Six'' of Feb. 22 to stabilize the dollar about where it was then.

title: Washburn Returns
description: ''I had the life of a dope addict, and it's nothing I want to go back to,'' said Chris Washburn, who returned to practice Monday with the Golden State Warriors after seven weeks of rehabilitation at a drug-treatment center. ''It more or less started in the San Francisco Bay area. It was cocaine addiction. I didn't have the experience at North Carolina State. I didn't dabble in drugs there.'' George Karl, the Warriors' coach, would not say when his rookie 6-foot-11-inch center, a No. 1 draft choice, would be activated. The Warriors, with a 34-34 record, have 14 games remaining in the regular season. Under the drug agreement between the National Basketball Association and the union representing the players, Washburn did not lose any of his $700,000 yearly salary during his treatment because he stepped forward to ask for help. In another development, Dan Finnane, the team president, said that a kidney problem that had been bothering Washburn has been solved. Finnane said the problem was a reaction to an anti-inflammatory medicine Washburn had been taking to alleviate tendinitis in his left knee before he went to the rehabilitation center.

title: Running in Future
description: When Joan Benoit Samuelson steps up to the starting line in the Boston Marathon April 20, she will not be running for herself alone. Samuelson, the Boston winner in 1979 and in 1983, is pregnant and expects her first child in October. ''After careful consideration, we decided that I should attempt Boston this year,'' she said of discussions with her husband, Scott. ''I feel very competitive, and my only concern is the weather. If it's a very hot, humid day, I will have to make adjustments.'' In 1983, she set the Boston course record of 2 hours 22 minutes 43 seconds for women, which was a world best until surpassed by Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway at the 1985 London Marathon. Samuelson was the gold-medal winner in the first Olympic Marathon for women, in 1984 in Los Angeles, and she pointed to Kristiansen, last year's Boston winner, as a role model.

title: Scramble for Canada Brokers
description: Three months before the Canadian securities industry is to be opened wider to foreign ownership, brokers in the Bay Street financial district are reporting a rush of merger and acquisition talks involving some of the largest American and Canadian financial firms and a number of Canada's biggest banks.

title: CITY COUNCIL BACKS INCREASE IN NUMBER OF TAXI MEDALLIONS
description: A bill that could create as many as 1,800 new medallions for yellow taxicabs and that is expected to lead to the approval today of the first significant taxi fare increase in seven years was approved unanimously yesterday by the City Council.

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Vegetarianism: Green-Plate Specials Abound
description: NEW YORK CITY boasts a healthy crop of strictly vegetarian restaurants, not-so-strict ones and every kind of hybrid. Moreover, conventional restaurants now offer enticing vegetable dishes as the demand grows for light and healthful fare, particularly among the younger generation of executive lunchers. It could be charcoal-grilled carrots or fennel and wild mushrooms at a smart new Italian trattoria, a mosaic of baby vegetables drizzled with a herb vinaigrette at a California-style bistro or a stunning palette of plant life created by a master sushi chef.

title: TECHNITROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ex-Im Bank's Emphasis
description: The president of the United States Export-Import Bank said today that the institution was focusing on smaller businesses to reflect changing conditions in export financing.

title: Beirut Kidnappers Say They Weigh Execution
description: Moslem kidnappers announced today that they were still considering the execution of a French hostage, a day after the captive said his abductors had suspended a decision to kill him.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE MISALLIANCE. By Anita Brookner. 191 pages. Pantheon Books. $14.95.

title: Robinson Top Player
description: David Robinson, the 7-foot-1-inch center who helped to lead Navy to a 26-6 record, has been named winner of the Eastman Award as the top player in college basketball this season. Robinson, a senior who averaged 28.2 points and 11.8 rebounds this season, faces two years of active duty before he can play pro basketball on a full-time basis.

title: Neil Finn Leads Band, Crowded House
description: Neil Finn, a New Zealander who leads Crowded House, knows just how much he can get away with in a tuneful little pop song. Mr. Finn, the band's drummer, Paul Hester, and its new keyboardist, Eddie Rayner, were members of the Melbourne-based Split Enz, whose elaborately Beatlesque albums never quite found an American audience. Crowded House is a more straightforward, more focused and much bouncier band, and at the Bottom Line on Sunday it knocked out Mr. Finn's newer songs as if they were casual ditties about love.

title: QUICK & REILLY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The share earnings do not reflect stock split to be paid April 1. The latest year figures are unaudited.

title: Four of a Kind
description: Growing up in Freeport, L.I., Michael Lofton had a fantasy that was honed to a bright gleam while watching ''Zorro'' and Errol Flynn on television. Last week the boyhood dreams of swashbuckling glory led to a real athletic record. Lofton, now a 23-year-old fencer for New York University, won his fourth consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association saber championship, making him the first swordsman, and only the 10th Division I athlete in any sport, to win individual N.C.A.A. titles in four consecutive years.

title: Reagan 'Advance Men' Warned
description: Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said today that people working on Presidential trips would not pose as journalists, as one consultant did recently.

title: CONCERT: MONTREAL SYMPHONY
description: THE Orchestre Symphonique de Montreal - the Montreal Symphony Orchestra -played only two works Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, but both were substantial. Anne-Sophie Mutter joined forces with the orchestra to play the Violin Concerto of Johannes Brahms and the program concluded with the Symphony No. 8 by Dmitri Shostakovich, both under the direction of Charles Dutoit.

title: 68 Dead Cows Found Hidden
description: The State Agricuulture Department has suspended a dairy farm's milk-production license after 68 dead cattle were found hidden. The farm, owned by Richard Akowchek, was investigated Monday after a complaint had been received. The cause of death appeared to be malnutrition, according to a state veterinarian, Dr. Jean Kucia. She said that 75 surviving animals were in varying states of health and that they were quarantined, relocated and isolated.

title: NETS FALL AS AGUIRRE GETS 43
description: Mark Aguirre had a point to prove to his Dallas Maverick teammates, and he came through for them tonight, scoring 43 points in a 119-107 victory over the Nets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: SENATE FILIBUSTER CONTINUES OVER BILL TO BLOCK AID TO CONTRAS
description: The Senate Democratic leadership failed today in a second effort to cut off a Republican filibuster that is preventing debate on a bill to block further military aid to the rebels in Nicaragua.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Can infants grow and develop normally on a diet devoid of all animal products except mother's milk? Can teen-agers and young adults mature properly and meet the physical, intellectual and emotional demands of their lives if they eat no meat, chicken or fish? Can you tell if your children are getting enough of the needed nutrients from a vegetarian diet, and what the risks are if they don't?

title: PREWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year loss reflects high interest payments and non-recurring expenses connected with the closing of a distribution center in Memphis and a plant in Killeen, Tex., as well as professional fees relating to two debenture exchanges and on-going litigation. The prior year results include operations of a foreign subsidiary and a furnace product line, both subsequently sold, and a $3 million inventory reserve writedown.

title: Higher Cab Fares? For Better Service
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission will vote today to increase cab fares, by 22 percent for the average ride. The rationale - that there has been no rate hike in seven years - remains fallacious but it's worth going along with on two conditions: more cabs and better cabs.

title: NICARAGUAN COFFEE AVAILABLE
description: In church basements and food cooperatives across the country, people are dodging the United States trade embargo on Nicaraguan products by selling a relatively rare commodity: Nicaraguan coffee.

title: Monoclonal Order
description: Monoclonal Antibodies Inc., a biotechnology company based in Mountain View, Calif., said a district court judge had granted a preliminary motion blocking the sale of the company's pregnancy test. The order was in response to a 1984 patent-infringement lawsuit filed by Hybritech Inc., a subsidiary of Eli Lilly & Company based in San Diego. Products involved include Ovustick Self-Test and Advance, a pregnancy test produced by Monoclonal and marketed by the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation.

title: Iran Warns of Danger If U.S. Attacks in Gulf
description: The Speaker of Iran's Parliament said today that Americans around the world would be in danger if the United States launched an attack in the Persian Gulf, where American Navy forces have been strengthened.

title: ANTI-STALIN POEM OF 30'S APPEARS
description: The Soviet literary establishment, which long ago restored Anna Akhmatova to its pantheon of 20th-century Russian poets, has just permitted publication of her poem ''Requiem,'' for years the underground anthem of those who suffered under Stalin.

title: TAYLOR IS NOW RESTING ON HIS HANDS
description: A few weeks ago Lawrence Taylor had enough of four, five and six well-paying appearances a week. He needed a break even from his beloved golf.

title: WINE TALK
description: QUESTION: Since 80 percent of the wine produced in Washington is white, and one of the state's most successful whites is Johannisberg riesling, what varietal did the state send to New York last week for a judging?

title: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $45,571,000 and $53,607,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and extraordinary credits of $10,906,000 for the quarter and $13,459,000 for the year. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,743,000 for the quarter and $15,237,000 for the year; and extraordinary credits of $644,000 and $2,837,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan. 6, 1987.

title: Oddly, Israelis Misunderstand Us
description: LEAD: The prospect of hanging, they say, concentrates the mind. Let us hope that the life sentence given to Jonathan Jay Pollard will serve the same purpose. We need less moralizing about the Israeli-American mess and more inquiry into what went wrong.

title: Article 835887 -- No Title
description: The MacArthur Foundation of Chicago has awarded $9.3 million in grants in the United States and abroad to promote activities aimed at keeping international peace.

title: AIDS OVERTAKES DISEASE OF HEART AS NO. 2 WORRY
description: Blood bank officials reported yesterday that AIDS had replaced heart disease in the public mind as the second most serious health problem in the country, ranking behind cancer.

title: SPEEDING TRAVEL THROUGH THE TERMINAL
description: AIR travelers have for years maligned this city's O'Hare International Airport for its long delays, crowded terminals and exhausting hikes to connecting flights at faraway gates.

title: METS' $1,500 FINE PAID BY STRAWBERRY
description: In the words of Davey Johnson, ''We kissed and made up.''

title: THE FINAL FOUR: SYRACUSE L>ORANGEMEN HAVING A BALL IN THE DOME
description: When the big field house opened in 1962, Syracuse University was ahead of its time. Two decades before the indoor practice facility would become the plaything of major universities, a commitment to attract nationally known coaches and a selling point in the bidding for talented teen-agers, Syracuse erected one.

title: Borg-Jacobs Talks Collapse
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said today that it had held talks with Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, who has made a takeover attempt, but that those discussions broke down.

title: CHARTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains of $28,612,000 and $28,479,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively; and a gain of $90,500,000 from settlement of claims for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $114,780,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $41,217,000 and $36,312,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and a gain of $25,625,000 from tax loss carryforwards and settlement of claims for the quarter, and a loss of $6,921,000 from the cumulative effect on prior years of a change in accounting principle. The company said the year-ago share earnings are not available; share earnings were adjusted for dividends on preferred stock which were not declared or paid.

title: TESTS RAISE HOPE ON BRAIN CANCER
description: A new form of therapy is providing ''some hope'' for the first time for victims of the most common form of brain cancer, which until now has been quickly and relentlessly fatal, a researcher says.

title: For Many, the Health Plan Is Catastrophic
description: The Reagan Administration's ''catastrophic'' health care plan may provide some political help to a wounded Presidency. But despite the hype that describes it as ''that last full measure of security,'' the plan offers little economic help to most victims of catastrophic illness.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Bouquet, Et Cetera

title: Reason for Concern in Japanese Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 7
DINKINS PROPOSES REPAIRING 40,000 UNITS FOR THE HOMELESS
description: Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins proposed yesterday a vast expansion of city housing programs for the poor that he said would essentially end the problem of homelessness among families in New York in five years.

title: Export Rules Eased to Help U.S. Suppliers
description: The Commerce Department announced new regulations today that will ease controls on the export of foreign-made products incorporating American high-technology components.

title: Joint Satellite Effort Planned
description: The United States and France agreed Monday to launch a satellite into space in 1991 to watch how water flows in the oceans and how the tropical seas affect the weather. It will mark the first time that the Ariane launching vehicle of the European Space Agency will send up a satellite supplied by the United States Government.

title: CHICAGO FACES URBAN CLASS PROBLEM AS SCHOOL IS CONSTRUCTED
description: A decade after young urban pioneers began settling in the lifeless, abandoned industrial area just south of the Loop here, the neighborhood now boasts thriving shops, pubs, bookstores, delicatessens - and enough children to warrant a new school.

title: INSIDE
description: Dollar Is Propped Up The Federal Reserve and other central banks took action to support the dollar, traders said, though the currency stayed below 150 yen. Page D1.

title: Air Traffic Controllers to Vote On Forming Another Union
description: Air traffic controllers, whose union was disbanded after a 1981 illegal strike in which 11,400 controllers were dismissed, will decide this June whether once again to embrace unionism, according to an agreement reached today with the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: LA SALLE IN N.I.T. FINAL
description: With the game 13 seconds old, Larry Koretz hit a 3-point shot from the right side of the circle. The next three baskets La Salle attempted were also 3-pointers, and they swished through.

title: Camper Makes the Final Four
description: Rick Pitino is an overnight sensation, and it only took him 20 years. He still looks like an earnest graduate assistant, but he is making the kind of moves that one of his mentors will be praising all summer long at camps and clinics.

title: Leftists Set Back Gandhi in Elections in Two States
description: Leftist political coalitions led by India's main Communist Party scored victories in two state legislative elections on Monday, dealing a setback to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, election returns tonight show.

title: CAPTIALS GAIN ON ISLANDERS
description: The Washington Capitals came to town tonight and took away the Islanders' skating game. The absence of the ailing Mike Bossy left the Islanders without their most experienced sniper, and they were stifled, 3-1.

title: Giuliani Tea Leaves
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, has been mentioned as a candidate to head the Federal Bureau of Investigation. And the rumors grew stronger yesterday, when, according to a White House official, Mr. Giuliani met at the White House with the chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr. The White House official would not disclose the topic but denied that it was the F.B.I. A spokeswoman for Mr. Giuliani's office had no comment.

title: Soviet Said to Shift Air Defenses on Missiles
description: The Soviet Union has begun a major reorganization of its air force to improve defense against attack by low-flying American cruise missiles and aircraft, the Pentagon said in a report issued today.

title: Nasdaq's Architect To Join Hambrecht
description: Gordon S. Macklin, architect of Nasdaq, the computerized share price information system for over-the-counter stocks, said yesterday that he would become chairman and co-chief executive of Hambrecht & Quist, the San Francisco-based investment firm.

title: A Bond Refunding For Ohio Hospital
description: Ohio's Hamilton County, on behalf of the Jewish Hospital of Cincinnati, is tentatively offering $112.3 million of refunding bonds with a top yield of 7.094 percent for ones due in 2008.

title: CATS, CUPS AND CURIOS
description: 1. Cat at the Door

title: An AIDS Drug, at a Cost
description: The first drug to prolong the lives of AIDS patients received Federal approval last week. That's an encouraging victory in the long campaign against the AIDS epidemic. But the drug comes with a high price - $10,000 per patient for a year's supply - and has bred frustration among AIDS patients unable to get it sooner.

title: The U.N. Today: March 25, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 2 RECENT EXPLOSIONS REFLECT INCREASE IN COCAINE LABS
description: Two illegal cocaine-processing laboratories have exploded in residential neighborhoods in New York City recently, providing the authorities with new evidence that more of the highly explosive drug-production plants are operating in the city.

title: RJR Nabisco View On Pretoria Link
description: The board of RJR Nabisco Inc. said it was not convinced a policy of blanket divestment would lead to social progress in South Africa. RJR Nabisco, in a proxy statement to shareholders, urged them to vote against a stockholder's proposal for the company to stop doing business in South Africa by the end of May. Shareholders will vote on the proposal at the company's annual meeting April 22 in Wilmington, Del.

title: Le Deluge
description: The I.R.S. is also bracing for a bigger than usual deluge of income tax returns as the April 15 filing deadline approaches. So far, the I.R.S. says processing of returns has run smoothly, with none of the computer problems, backlogs or other snarls that marked the tax filing season two years ago. ''Everything's running fine,'' a spokesman said.

title: Bottles of Castor Oil Recalled Over Mislabeling of Poison
description: The Food and Drug Administration warned today that three brands of castor oil distributed in 21 states and the District of Columbia might contain a poisonous liniment.

title: KEY RATES
Digital Introduces Computer Series
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, seeking to extend its recent successes over I.B.M. to the factory floor, introduced a series of industrial computers yesterday based on its VAX minicomputer designs.

title: ALBANY REGENTS APPOINT A CHIEF FOR EDUCATION
description: The New York State Board of Regents yesterday elected Dr. Thomas Sobol, the Superintendent of Schools in Scarsdale, N.Y., as the new State Commissioner of Education.

title: Memories Fade, But Judgment Remains
description: To the Editor:

title: PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Vegetarianism: More Popular, if Less Pure
description: VEGETARIANS no longer need to defend their diets at parties. While some unrepentant carnivores may sneer at their victuals as assorted seaweed with an occasional foray into nuts and berries, there is clearly a growing interest in the vegetarian way of eating.

title: MAN FOUND HANGED IN CENTRAL PARK IS IDENTIFIED AS ETHIOPIAN
description: A man found hanging from a tree in Central Park in Manhattan two weeks ago has been identified as a 33-year-old Ethiopian national studying at the State University at Stony Brook.

title: PIONEER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 29
description: b-After losses on discontinued operations of $3,431,000 for the latest year and $5,910,000 for 1985. The company said the losses on discontinued operations for both years was from discontinuance of the fabric finishing operations of its Putnam- Gellman subsidiary.

title: WALTER L. GORDON, EX-CANADIAN AIDE
description: Walter Lockhart Gordon, a former Finance Minister and one of the foremost advocates of Canadian economic independence from the United States, died after suffering a heart attack here on Saturday. He was 81 years old.

title: 'Starlight' Sets Record
description: The new Andrew Lloyd Webber musical, ''Starlight Express,'' broke a Broadway record last week for the highest gross for a single week's performances, taking in $560,618.99, according to the head of research for the League of American Theaters and Producers, George Wachtel. The previous record, $532,000, was set in April 1985 during the final week of the revival of ''The King and I.'' ''Starlight'' opened last week at the 1,933-seat Gershwin Theater, Broadway's largest.

title: QUESTIONS IN THE DEATH OF A HARLEM VENDOR
description: Nothing about the last morning of Nicholas A. Bartlett's life would seem to have been anything but routine.

title: GOLD ISSUES OUTPACE DOW
description: PRICES of gold and gold mining stocks usually travel along parallel tracks, but so far in 1987 they have diverged sharply. A Kidder, Peabody index of North American gold mining shares, as of last Friday's market close, was ahead 40 percent for the year. This compared with a gain of 3 percent for bullion.

title: INQUIRY BOARD SET UP IN FIRE THAT KILLED 7
description: The New York City Fire Department yesterday established a special board of inquiry to investigate the garbage-chute fire that killed seven people in a Harlem high-rise building Sunday, and fire officials will also start reinspecting the hundreds of buildings in the city with similar chutes and sprinkler systems.

title: SPANISH PREMIER DEFENDS POLICIES
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, at his first news conference in several months, defended his social and economic policies tonight, saying ''no other government dares to do more, and I am talking about all political systems, not just in the West.''

title: People
description: * Anne MacDonald has been elected senior vice president at N.W. Ayer.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for 16wks to Feb 7
description: b-Includes a credit of $1,408,000 from an accounting change. Sales includes leased departments.

title: DOLLAR ENDS FALL AS FED INTERVENES
description: The Federal Reserve and other central banks intervened in the currency markets yesterday to shore up the dollar and halted its slide, although the dollar remained below the important 150-yen level, currency traders said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A jail is preferable to a shelter because it's self-contained.

title: Mrs. Aquino Plans to Fight
description: For more than a year, President Corazon Aquino has tried to find non-military ways to end two insurgencies in the Philippines. To the leftist New People's Army she offered amnesties, opened the jail cells of guerrilla leaders and agreed to a 60-day cease-fire. To stop a war with Moslem insurgents she made offers of qualified autonomy.

title: GUILTY PLEA IN KILLING OF FATHER
description: A 17-year-old girl and the classmate she hired to kill her father because, she said, he sexually abused her pleaded guilty today to manslaughter.

title: The Open Door Policy
description: One of the first things Howard Baker did as White House chief of staff was to have former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger around for a talk.

title: A PRACTICAL ADMINISTRATOR: DR. THOMAS SOBOL
description: Dr. Thomas Sobol, the new State Education Commissioner, was described by colleagues yesterday as a consummate educator who can take ideas and put them to work.

title: BOROUGH CHIEF CONTEST SPLITS HISPANIC POLITICIANS IN BRONX
description: The struggle for the Bronx borough presidency has reopened divisions in the ranks of Hispanic politicians that badly handicapped a Hispanic candidate for borough president two years ago.

title: HIGH COURT SUPPORTS STATES ON REGULATING MINES ON U.S. LAND
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that states may prevent companies from conducting federally approved mining activities on federally owned forestland unless the companies comply with reasonable state environmental regulations.

title: Support of Arab Boycott
description: To the Editor:

title: Workers Flee Mercury Vapors
description: About 30 workers at a Government nuclear weapon plant here escaped injury after a release of mercury vapors that had built up in walls of the buildings, a plant spokesman said today. The vapors were accidentally released Monday after construction workers knocked out a concrete wall, Bob Wesley said. The employees returned to work today, he said. Residual mercury from work in the 1950's and 1960's at the plant has been trapped in parts of the buildings, he said.

title: THE DANCE: KAJA GAM TROUPE
description: KAJA GAM takes on the sprawling life of a great urban railroad station in ''Grand Central,'' performed by Ms. Gam and her Awkward Dance company on Saturday at Performance Space 122. Set to a whirring, clanking, lazily rollicking score by Chris Cunningham, ''Grand Central'' is an agreeable dance full of meetings too transitory for farewells. Two businessmen talk of deals, aiming sly kicks at each other to signal noncompliance. Men with briefcases trot by, and we see the wives they have left at home. A man and a woman attempt a lethally casual pickup. Another man and woman pass agonizingly close but never meet. A trembling derelict mops his body and laughs compulsively. A businessman standing nearby tries not to notice, in a small moment played with powerful control by Christian Juul Jessen. And throughout people crawl across the stage, as reduced in scale and importance as the antlike people scurrying through the films and slides of Grand Central projected on a backdrop and on side panels.

title: '42d Street' Will Change Theaters
description: The David Merrick production of ''42d Street'' will close April 5 at the Majestic Theater and will reopen on or around April 7 at the St. James Theater, the musical's general manager, Leo Cohen, said Monday. The move was necessitated when the Shubert Organization, which owns the Majestic, exercised its option to terminate the booking of ''42d Street'' in order to bring the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical ''Phantom of the Opera'' to the theater next fall.

title: WEAN UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,237,000. c-Net income

title: JAZZ: DAVE HOLLAND
description: DAVE HOLLAND, a bassist, made his first foray into big-band writing for Monday's concert at the Public Theater, which commissioned the program. The music was more conventional than his suite-like sets for quintet; with the big band, there was a clearer division between written and improvised material. But since Mr. Holland's 12-piece group brought together many of New York's best young jazz musicians - and because he'd written in plenty of room to maneuver - the music was rambunctious, far-reaching and full of life.

title: Fannie Mae Adds 2 New Maturities
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association said it would begin regular purchases of home mortgages with maturities of 10 and 20 years. The new program will supplement its buying of 15-year and 30-year mortgages.

title: Article 971487 -- No Title
description: Marvin Davis, the Denver oil billionaire, made a complex and unexpected $200 million proposal yesterday to purchase Resorts International Inc., the casino and real estate company.

title: Widow of Ira Gershwin Endows Literacy Center
description: Leonore Gershwin, the 86-year-old widow of Ira Gershwin, has provided $10,000 to establish a literacy center at University Settlement, a century-old institution at 185 Eldridge Street on the Lower East Side, where the Pulitzer Prize-winning lyricist and his younger brother George, the composer, spent many after-school hours.

title: MOTT'S SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for 14wks to Dec 31
description: The company said there were 14 weeks and 53 weeks in the latest fourth quarter and year, respectively; compared with 13 weeks and 52 weeks in the year-earlier fourth quarter and year, respectively.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $308,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $1,536,000 from disposal of discontinued operations. c-After net from discontinued operations of $2,815,000 for the quarter and $1,880,000 for the year. The share earnings for all periods have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split, effective Aug. 1, 1986. Results have been restated to reflect the discontinuance of the department store segment which was sold during the second quarter of 1986. The increase in the company's 1986 effective tax rate is primarily due to the Tax Reform Act of 1986, which repealed the investment tax credit retroactive to Jan. 1, 1986.

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $10,395,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary loss of $10,510,000 from early extinguishment of subordinated debentures. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,570,000 and $6,330,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Preferred dividends exceeded net income in the latest year. The company said the year-earlier figures are restated to give effect to the consolidation of the company's previously unconsolidated subsidiaries and the discontinuance of the operations of the company's energy division.

title: Dow Advances by 5.40 As Prices End Mixed
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose a bit yesterday but stock prices over all ended mixed in fairly heavy trading.

title: FAST ACTION SOUGHT IN SENATE ON $400 MILLION FOR HOMELESS
description: Citing ''serious, emergency needs of the homeless across America,'' the Senate Democratic and Republican leadership moved today to seek rapid endorsement of a $400 million measure to provide aid for them.

title: CLAREMONT GROUP
description: A group led by the investment banking firm Claremont Group Ltd. has dropped its $85 million takeover offer for Champion Products Inc. But the group, which includes the New York brokerage firm of Walsh, Greenwood & Company, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it intended to increase its stake in the sportswear concern to 15 percent, from 10 percent.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Preventing Storewide Paralysis
description: DEPARTMENT stores and supermarkets are increasingly switching to computer-based cash registers, which let customers pay for merchandise more quickly, allow the store to check credit cards more easily, and keep better records of sales and inventory. But in the past these retail wonders have occasionally caused wholesale nightmares for some stores, because, like a string of Christmas tree lights, if one goes out all the others along the same wire also go out.

title: CANADA ALLOWS RESUMPTION OF SEAL HUNTING FROM SHIPS
description: The Canadian Government has approved resuming large-scale seal hunting from ships off the country's east coast, prompting an outcry from animal welfare groups whose protests virtually ended seal hunting as a major industry in the region four years ago.
