title: PSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: REAGAN SAID TO BE ADAMANT ON VETOING HIGHWAY AID BILL
description: Several Republican senators tried in vain today to dissuade President Reagan from his plan to veto an $87.9 billion highway and mass transit bill that passed both houses of Congress by large margins.

title: Oscar Wilde Had an Idea About Identity of 'W.H.'
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW DIRECTION IN SKIRTS FOR FALL: IT'S UP, UP, UP
description: Even the staid designers here are beginning to swing. Hemlines are going up, up, up, while leather is as popular as cloth. Emanuel Ungaro has literally gilded his rounded leather skirts by giving them a metallic finish. The style by Hubert de Givenchy that bared the most leg was a billowing pair of taffeta bloomers attached to a black velvet strapless top. Mario Valentino's clothes exuded sex appeal and luxury with their skinny or flared skirts, tiny waistlines and bare shoulders.

title: HUNDREDS ORDERED TO LEAVE BY KENYA
description: Kenyan courts have ordered the expulsion of hundreds of illegal aliens after President Daniel arap Moi blamed them for causing unrest.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing Bruno Stops Tillis: Frank Bruno, the British heavyweight, pummeled James (Quick) Tillis of the United States into submission in the fifth round last night in Wembley, England, to set up a possible challenge to Mike Tyson. Tyson, the 20-year-old World Boxing Council and World Boxing Association champion, was at ringside. Tillis went the distance with Tyson last May. The fight was Bruno's first since he lost to Tim Witherspoon in a W.B.A. title fight last July. Bruno, 25 years old, scored his 29th victory in 31 pro fights, showing power and mobility. He bloodied Tillis, 29, midway through the fifth round. When Tillis indicated he could not go on, John Coyle, the referee, stopped the bout after 1 minute 50 seconds. Tillis's record slipped to 35-11-1.(AP) Tennis Jarryd and Bloom Advance: Anders Jarryd of Sweden beat Libor Pimek of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-3, and Gilad Bloom of Israel defeated Christophe Geukens of Belgium, 6-3, 6-2, to reach the second round of the Belgian Indoor championships yesterday. The 25-year-old Jarryd dominated Pimek throughout the match that lasted less than 90 minutes. Bloom, playing in his first Grand Prix event outside his native country this year, had less trouble in disposing of Geukens, a local qualifier. The 20-year-old Israeli, in his second year as a professional, took less than an hour to win. In one of the bigger upsets so far, Jan Gunnarsson of Sweden beat Emilio Sanchez of Spain, the tournament's No. 4-seeded player, 6-1, 7-6.(AP) Shriver Upset: Marianne Werdel stunned second-seeded Pam Shriver, 7-6, 3-6, 7-6, in opening round of the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Washington tournament last night. Werdel, of Bakersfield, Calif., fought back from a 5-4 deficit in the final set, then won the tiebreaker, 7-3. Shriver, the fifth-ranked player in the world, could not contend with the power-hitting of Werdel, 19, who refused to fold when Shriver served for the match at 5-4 moments after breaking serve. After Shriver, of Lutherville, Md., easily won the second set, Werdel never quit banging the ball and rarely had a mishit. Earlier, Czechoslovakia's Hana Mandlikova, the top seed, advanced with a 6-3, 6-4 triumph over Gigi Fernandez. Mandlikova, ranked No. 4 in the world, trailed 0-2 and 15-40 at the outset of the match before winning 20 of the next 23 points to take control. (AP) N.B.A. Celtics 111, Cavaliers 88: Larry Bird scored 32 points and Kevin McHale had 22 last night as the Celtics rolled to their fourth consecutive victory, playing in Hartford. McHale had all his points and Bird had all except 2 of his in the first three quarters as the Celtics built a 20-point lead. It was the second straight loss and second straight low-scoring performance for the Central Division's last-place Cavaliers, who were coming off a season-low 76 points in a weekend loss to the Indiana Pacers. Bird made 13 of 16 shots and had 9 assists and 8 rebounds. Boston held Ron Harper, the high-scoring rookie who leads Cleveland with 23 points a game, to only 8 on 3-of-12 shooting. (AP) Hawks 96, Bullets 87: Dominique Wilkins took six stitches above the left eye in the first quarter but scored 31 points to lead Atlanta in Landover, Md. Kevin Willis had 22 points for the Hawks, who won their third straight to move a game ahead of the idle Pistons in the Central Division. Jeff Malone, the Bullets' guard who was averaging 22.3 points a game, missed his first 13 shots and finished with only 6 points. His only field goal came with five seconds remaining. (AP) N.H.L. Penguins 3, Flyers 3: Warren Young scored at 8:45 of the third period to give the Penguins the tie on their ice. Young put a rebound past Glenn Resch for his seventh goal of the season as the Penguins rallied from a 3-0 second-period deficit. Philadelphia is 0-0-8 in overtime, the only N.H.L. team that has not won or lost a game in overtime this year. (AP) Canadiens 4, Nordiques 3: Bobby Smith's goal with 26 seconds to play was the game-winner. The goaltender, Clint Malarchuk, stopped Claude Lemieux at the lip of the crease but the rebound rolled to Smith, who sent the puck into the net. The victory was Montreal's first at the Colisee in two years and gave the Canadiens a 5-3 won-lost record against Quebec this season.(AP) Maple Leafs 6, Sabres 5: Rick Vaive and Dan Daoust had a goal and an assist each as the Maple Leafs blunted a third-period rally. The Leafs entered the third period with a 5-2 lead, but the Sabres, at home, then outscored Toronto, 3-1. Peter Ihnacak scored Toronto's only goal in the third period, and it was the winner.(AP) Swimming Evans and Podkoscielny Win: Janet Evans, a 15-year-old from Placentia, Calif., and Mariusz Podkoscielny of Poland won the grueling 1,000-yard freestyle events yesterday on the opening day of the United States Swimming Short Course National Championships in Boca Raton, Fla. The two distance events were the only ones scheduled on the first day of the five-day competition at the Mission Bay Aquatics Center. Evans, who is only 5-foot-3-inch and weighs 90 pounds, is perhaps the smallest United States swimming champion ever. She covered the distance in 9:32.59 to easily beat Kim Brown of Irvine, Calif., who was second in 9:36.55. Debbie Babashoff of Mission Viejo, Calif., was third in 9:39.43. Podkoscielny finished in 8:54.93 to beat Alex Kostich of Bellmont, Mass., in the men's event. Kostich was timed in 8:56.18. (AP)

title: Vegetarianism: Cook's Tour Tests Chefs
description: LEAD: Contrary to what most vegetarians think, the best meatless meal is prepared by the best chef you can find, not necessarily by a vegetarian chef. I learned this firsthand.

title: 2D MARINE CONFINED IN INQUIRY ON SPYING AT A U.S. EMBASSY
description: The Marine Corps has arrested a second former embassy guard on suspicion of espionage as a result of a continuing investigation of Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree, the service disclosed late today.

title: Jordan Scores 56
description: Michael Jordan, the league's leading scorer, finished with 56 points tonight as the Chicago Bulls defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 93-91.

title: THE RAIN FALLS, THE BAMBOO BLOOMS, HOPES WILT
description: March was not an auspicious month for the farmer U Chit Maung and his family.

title: Notes and Bonds in Late Spurt
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell slightly yesterday, but ended the day on a strong note as they recovered most of their early morning losses.

title: Life in the 30's
description: Anna Quindlen is on vacation. Her column will resume April 8.

title: NEW EFFORT FOR HOUSE BEAUTIFUL
description: MARCIA MILLER, for a year the publisher of Hearst Magazines' House Beautiful, is out to create excitement around the 90-year-old publication that she hopes advertisers will find catching.

title: Mid-March Auto Sales Showed a Decline of 4%
description: Sales of new American-made cars fell 4 percent in the middle of March, compared with the the 1986 period, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: North Carolina Utility Offering 7 1/2% Top Yield
description: The North Carolina Eastern Municipal Power Agency is tentatively offering $1.025 billion of power system refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7 1/2 percent for bonds due in 2015 and 2021.

title: HERSHEY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After writedowns of oil and gas properties of $800,000 for the quarter and $2,600,000 for the year. c-Includes a writedown of $13,400,000 of oil and gas properties for both the quarter and year.

title: Woodson Is Accused
description: Purdue University and the Big Ten have started an investigation into reports that the all-America cornerback, Rod Woodson, was being sued after reportedly accepting $21,606 in payments from an agent in violation of N.C.A.A. rules. Woodson, a projected first-round N.F.L. draft pick, is still attending Purdue and is scheduled to compete in a track meet in Florida this weekend. He is a hurdler and sprinter. A report in yesterday's Daily News said Woodson was named in a lawsuit filed in New York State Supreme Court by Norby Walters, a New York-based sports and entertainment agent. Walters is suing for $500,000 in damages, alleging that Woodson broke a representation contract he signed on Jan. 2, 1987.

title: INSIDE
description: Tax Fraud Charged Three men were charged with operating a conspiracy that produced $350 million in fraudulent tax deductions for wealthy investors. Page D1.

title: BATTLING DRUG USE ON THE JOB
description: With companies scrambling to cope with drug problems among their employees, a mini-industry of consulting and health-care concerns has sprouted up.

title: VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for 16wks to Feb 15
description: b-Includes a $9.5 million gain ($17.5 million pretax) from the sale of the company's specialty restaurants subsidiary. Results of operations for 1987 do not include those of the specialty restaurants. Also included were extraordinary charges of $660,000, net of taxes, related to the repayment of debt and an extraordinary credit of $4.6 million resulting from recognition of the tax benefit of net operating loss carryforwards. c-Net loss

title: Report Questions Casino's Finances
description: A state report has raised questions about the financial stability of the Atlantis Hotel and Casino and its ability to compete in Atlantic City's casino industry, Attorney General W. Cary Edwards said yesterday.

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Lear Siegler Division Is Up for Sale
description: Forstmann Little & Company put up for sale today the aerospace operations of Lear Siegler Inc., which generate a third of that company's sales.

title: LAWYER ASSERTS DAVIS SHOT SIX IN SELF-DEFENSE
description: A lawyer for Larry Davis, the 21-year-old man accused of wounding six police officers in a shootout in a Bronx apartment last November, asserted yesterday that Mr. Davis had acted in self-defense.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Orlando Pizzolato, winner of New York City Marathons in 1985 and 1985, yesterday entered the Trevira Twosome 10-mile race for couples, scheduled for April 25, with no partner. . . . Ray Knight, the Baltimore Oriole third baseman, has completed shock therapy treatment on his right kidney for kidney stones, but is expected to miss the chance to play against his former team, the Mets, tomorrow night in Miami. . . . The Los Angeles Laker leader in scoring and assists, Earvin (Magic) Johnson, who suffered a bruised left calf in a collision with Jay Humphries of Phoenix Tuesday night was examined by a team physician Wednesday and listed as questionable for tonight's game against Detroit.

title: U.S. FOR REASSURE NATIONS IN GULF
description: President Reagan and his top advisers have decided to intensify efforts to reassure Arab countries in the Persian Gulf region that the United States is committed to protecting their security, Administration officials said today.

title: Rolls-Boeing Deal
description: Rolls-Royce, one of the world's largest jet engine makers, said it had agreed to install engines in a new generation of the Boeing Company's civilian aircraft. Rolls-Royce said it would put its RB 211-524 D4D engine in the Boeing B-767 family of aircraft, a successor to the B-747's that have been powered by Rolls engines. A company spokesman declined to say how many engines had been ordered or how much the deal was worth. The engine, currently under development, will be ready for service by early 1990, the company said.

title: Corrections
description: A Bonn dispatch on Tuesday about the resignation of Willy Brandt as leader of the Social Democratic Party misstated the background of Margarita Mathiopoulos, who was offered a post as party spokeswoman.

title: GREENS BETTER IN T.P.C.
description: The best players on the PGA Tour and from foreign lands seem more content with their surroundings than they have in many years as they gather for Thursday's start of the 14th annual Tournament Players Championship.

title: '20/20' STUDIES HOLLYWOOD-PENTAGON RELATIONSHIP
description: HOW do Hollywood and the Pentagon get along? Often to their mutual advantage, ABC's ''20/20'' finds; movie makers get planes, tanks and explosions at bargain prices, while the military receives favorable publicity. Is this good or bad? ''20/20,'' on Channel 7 at 10 o'clock tonight, doesn't definitively answer, but it suggests it's not so hot. The program could be more explicit.

title: ABC NEWS TRIES FORMAT THAT MAY BE THE FUTURE
description: On two nights this week, long after the regular version of ABC's ''World News Tonight'' program had aired and most of its staff had gone home, another, secret version of the program was screened. The second newscast, which never left the ABC building, may be the network's broadcast of the future.

title: Farm Credit Unit Short-Term Bonds
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering $540 million of 6.35 percent bonds due on July 1 and $1.16 billion of 6 1/2 percent bonds due on Oct. 1.

title: LIBYANS SAID TO BEGIN RETREATING FROM LAST MAJOR FOOTHOLD IN CHAD
description: Libyan forces were starting to evacuate their last major stronghold in northern Chad today after a recent series of spectacular losses to Chadian troops, French military sources said.

title: INDIANS SUE OVER DISPUTED MINNESOTA LAND
description: A group of Chippewa Indians filed suit in Federal District Court Tuesday contending that a Federal law enacted last year to settle land disputes in Minnesota would make it nearly impossible for Indians to regain land unfairly taken from them.

title: Malawi Doing Better Than Was Expected
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOLS CHIEF URGES A RESTRUCTURING
description: The newly appointed New York State Education Commissioner, Dr. Thomas Sobol, said yesterday that the schools needed to be restructured because so many students felt alienated from them.

title: E.P.A. Backing Away From Acid Lake View
description: A review by outside experts has led scientists at the Environmental Protection Agency to back away from their recent prediction that 300 more lakes in the Northeast could become acidified in the next 50 years. The agency cited the great uncertainty surrounding the estimates.

title: JAZZ: VLADIMIR SHAFRANOV
description: THE 20th anniversary of the death of John Coltrane seemed to be on the mind of the pianist Vladimir Shafranov as he led a quartet at the Blue Note on Monday evening. His first set included two Coltrane compositions - ''Naima,'' and a tribute to his bassist Paul Chambers, ''Mr. P. C.'' - as well as Duke Ellington's rarely heard composition ''Take the Coltrane.''

title: Clemens Holds Position
description: Roger Clemens said today that he remained resolute about his 19-day contract holdout and said that the Red Sox management was trying to use him as an example for the rest of the league.

title: Unmentionable Fever
description: Do not dare to say that s----- has arrived. In New York City, the current new season has a way of making one superstitious. The first week of April 1982 brought snow. So did the last week of April 1986. It is not, in any case, necessary to mention the vernal equinox or the last two days' temperature. One need only observe that all over the city, New Yorkers were taking off their clothes.

title: GREECE AND TURKEY, THE LOCAL WAR
description: Turkey may finally be gaining some ground on Greece in the battle for influence in the United States government.

title: JAZZ: MIKE LEDONNE, PIANIST
description: MIKE LEDONNE, who divides his time between playing piano with the Widespread Jazz Orchestra and performing as a soloist, is wearing his solo hat this week, through Saturday at Zinno, 128 West 13th Street.

title: AMERICAN NETWORK INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $9 million gain from American Network's successful lawsuit against Intercom Inc., a manufacturer of telecommunications switching equipment. c-Net loss The company said the year-end revenue includes four months of revenue from the acquisition of Starnet Corp., but does not include about $42 million in revenue from the ATE acquisition in the last two months of the year. The latest year results included the anticipated operating loss of $6 million, attributable to newly acquired Starnet Corp. operations.

title: Chinese Mastercard
description: The Bank of China plans to merge its Great Wall credit card operations with Mastercard International, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: Hiker and Son Die in Flood
description: A flash flood roared through a mountain valley after heavy rain, killing a hiker and her 2-year-old son and stranding dozens of other people, the authorities said Tuesday. The victims were identified by relatives as Patricia A. Kalakau, 22, of Kailau, and son Kainoa, the police said. They were among 58 hikers caught by surprise when water swelledover a waterfall into a pool of water where many hikers were resting and swimming after reaching the end of the one-mile Sacred Falls trail.

title: IN CLASSROOM'S NEW ALPHABET LESSON, 'A' IS FOR AIDS
description: Between lessons in mathematics and reading, the sixth graders at the Chancellor Avenue School here turned their attention to the blackboard and the words ''drugs,'' ''needles'' and ''homosexuals.''

title: CBS AND ABC INTRODUCE PRIME-TIME SITCOMS
description: THE commercial networks are busy making schedule adjustments these days and, with NBC comfortably ahead in the ratings race, most of the changes are being made on ABC, the poor third, and on CBS. During the first prime-time hour of Fridays alone, for instance, there are two new sitcoms pleading for attention: ''The Charmings,'' on ABC at 8 o'clock, and, most promisingly, ''The Popcorn Kid,'' on CBS at 8:30.

title: RULING: WHAT COURT SAID
description: Following are summaries of the Supreme Court's previous decisions on the legality of affirmative action plans in the workplace:

title: Sarah G. Power, 52, Dies in 8-Story Fall; Michigan U. Regent
description: Sarah Goddard Power, New York City's deputy assistant secretary of state for human rights and social affairs in 1980 and 1981, died in a fall Tuesday from Burton Tower on the campus of the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. She was 52 years old and lived in Ann Arbor.

title: The Sputnik Syndrome (Cont'd.)
description: LEAD: There's a lot of hand-wringing about America's competitiveness these days, and once again it has occurred to policy makers that our success in the marketplace is connected to the way we educate young people. So once again education is being asked to solve a national problem.

title: Greek Bishops Boycott Fete In Conflict With Government
description: Greek Orthodox bishops boycotted National Day celebrations today in protest against a threatened takeover of church lands.

title: SALVADOR TROOPS SEIZE TWO IN HOSTAGE DRAMA AT SCHOOL
description: A man and a woman seized about 900 elementary school pupils at gunpoint here this morning, all but 30 of whom they later let go, then surrendered after long negotiations with Government and army officials.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
S.E.C. ASSAILS MAIN HURDMAN
description: In an unusual wrist-slapping of a major public accounting firm, the Securities and Exchange Commission censured KMG Main Hurdman yesterday for ''improper professional conduct'' during two audits in Texas.

title: Woman Dies in Subway Leap
description: A 30-year-old woman who was six months pregnant was killed early yesterday when she leaped in front of a subway train at Herald Square, the police said. The woman, Felisa Cowart, who lived with her two children in the Hotel Martinique, jumped into the path of a train at 1:15 A.M. at the 34th Street station of the IND line, according to Sgt. Edward Burns of the police.

title: DRIVER-HARRIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a charge of $1,042,000 for expenses related to the restructuring of the company's domestic alloy business.

title: ARMS AND THE DEBTOR
description: General John Galvin, the head of the Army's Southern Command, testified before a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee Wednesday and offered the senators an object lesson in bureaucratic excess. He said the United States had sold Ecuador ammunition for recoiless rifles. After some of the ammunition exploded, killing three soldiers, Ecuador asked the U.S. to examine the rest of the supply. A team sent to study the situation concluded that 400 rounds were dangerously defective. The United States then billed Ecuador $180,000 for the examination, and also asked the Ecuadorians to pay for the replacement ammunition. He did not indicae whether payment had been received.

title: Hopes Rise for Chilean Trial in Letelier Case
description: A former Chilean Army officer's confession of his role in the 1976 assassination of a Chilean exile in Washington has improved the prospects that others will face trial, according to a lawyer for the victim's family and others familiar with the case.

title: Plane in Emergency Landing
description: An American Airlines jetliner was evacuated today at O'Hare International Airport after it made an emergency landing shortly after smoke was detected in the cockpit, the authorities said. The spokesman said 164 passengers and a crew of 10 were on the airliner, Flight 333.

title: New York Nix
description: Is a 39-point loss - in which the opponents are allowed 78 points before halftime - as bad as things can get for a basketball team? Perhaps not, especially if the team is the Knicks. After their 135-96 defeat at Milwaukee on Tuesday night, Coach Bob Hill called the game ''the worst we've played in the last three or four.''

title: 'Tampopo,' A Comedy from Japan
description: ''Tampopo,'' Juzo Itami's new Japanese film, is a satiric comedy about noodles - about their making, cooking, serving and consumption. It's about people who take noodles seriously, who read self-help books that, among other things, instruct the eater to regard the pork ''affectionately'' while ''slurping'' the noodles that have been ''activated'' by the soup.

title: Ford Executives To Get $167 Million
description: The Ford Motor Company, which this month split some of its industry-leading profits with its rank-and-file employees, said it would hand out $167 million in executive bonuses. Ford's 1986 profits rose 31 percent over the previous year to $3.3 billion, surpassing those of the General Motors Corporation, which earned $2.9 billion.

title: INDIANA DELAYING TRIP TO FINAL FOUR
description: French Quarter bars and persistent reporters have nothing to do with why Indiana will be arriving later than the other three teams for the Final Four, said Coach Bobby Knight. He said the reason was that school work came first.

title: Hostage Ceremony at U.N.
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and other United Nations officials, diplomats and correspondents today marked the second anniversary of the kidnapping of Alec Collett in Lebanon by appealing to his captors to ''show respect for the values of humanity'' and release him. Mr. Collett, a British journalist, was on assignment for the world body when he was abducted by a pro-Libyan group.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Oilers 5, Whalers 3: Paul Coffey scored the game-winning goal on an end-to-end rush in the second period to lead the visiting Oilers. It was the second straight victory for the Oilers on their five-game Eastern trip, moving them closer to their sixth consecutive Smythe Division title. The Oilers also stopped a three-game winning streak by the Whalers, who were unable to score on eight power-play opportunities. Glenn Anderson, Craig Muni and Craig MacTavish also scored for the Oilers during the second period and Jari Kurri added a goal in the final period. Kevin Dineen scored two goals and John Anderson the other for the Whalers.(AP) North Stars 6, Maple Leafs 2: Mark Pavelich and Bob Brooke scored two goals each as the visiting North Stars broke a three-game losing streak. Brad Maxwell and Larry DePalma also scored for the North Stars. Wendel Clark and Dan Daoust scored for Toronto, which was eliminated from playoff contention.(AP) Kings 6, Red Wings 1: Jimmy Carson and Luc Robitaille, the league's highest scoring rookies, each scored goals to lead the Kings. Detroit, which scored its only goal on a penalty shot by Mel Bridgman, was able to clinch a playoff spot when Minnesota beat Toronto. Sean McKenna and Steve Duchesne each scored their 12th goals of the season in the first period to give the visiting Kings the lead.(AP) N.B.A. Pacers 125, Bucks 108: Steve Stipanovich scored 9 of his 24 points in the fourth quarter and Wayman Tisdale added 24 more to lead Indiana at home. With the Pacers leading, 90-81, at the start of the fourth quarter, Stipanovich scored his 9 points in the first 2:20, including an 18-foot jumper that capped an 11-2 Indiana run and pushed the lead to 101-83. Tisdale, who had been in a recent scoring slump, scored 9 of the Pacers' first 18 points in the second period.(AP) Tennis McEnroe Breezes: John McEnroe overwhelmed his opponent and top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany struggled to reach the second round of the $315,000 Belgian indoor championships yesterday at Brussels. McEnroe beat Paolo Cane of Italy, 6-3, 6-1, in less than an hour, but Becker had to rely on the jittery nerves of Peter Lindgren of Sweden to win by 7-6, 6-3. McEnroe, who is trying to regain the status of the world's best player, combined deep groundstrokes with quick rushes to the net and never let Cane into the match. Becker, who has had a checkered early season, survived a big scare when he was 2 set points down in the first-set tiebreaker, but capitalized on errors by a jittery Lindgren.(AP) Swimming Record Set in Breast-Stroke: Hiroko Nagasaki, a member of the 1984 Japanese Olympic swimming team and now a Berkeley, Calif., resident, set a United States record of 2 minutes 9.76 seconds in the women's 200-yard breast-stroke yesterday at the United States Swimming Short Course National Championships at Boca Raton, Fla. Nagasaki, 18, broke Tracy Caulkins's 1980 record of 2:11.46 - the third-oldest swimming record. Tom Jager, the former American record-holder in the 50-yard freestyle, won the men's 100-yard freestyle in 43.44 seconds. The former U.C.L.A. swimmer squeaked into the championship final in eighth place and had to win the race in an outside lane. Melvin Stewart won the 200-yard butterfly in 1:44.32. The top qualifier in the 200-yard butterfly, Bobby Patten, a Denver swimmer who has overcome cancer, was disqualified.(AP) Horse Racing Fine Day for Long Shot: That's Fine, a 10-1 shot, staged a strong late rally to score a 2 1/2-length victory in Aqueduct's $27,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares. The 4-year-old daughter of Mr. Leader-Done Good carried 117 pounds under Robbie Davis a mile on the fast track in 1:37 1/5. May Be Bold was the runner-up, three-quarters of a length ahead of the favorite, Sweet Sound. The victory was the first in four starts this year for That's Fine, who paid $23.

title: Treasury Issues Slide Again
description: Treasury note and bond prices continued to slide yesterday, as securities dealers digested a heavy supply of new issues and worried that the potential for further declines in the dollar would discourage heavy foreign buying.

title: RANGERS ROUTED BY DEVILS, 8-2
description: These are the last days of the long, long regular season, when a team should be holding in its palm a master plan. The plan should tell the players who will fill this role, who will get that assignment, and optimally, should outline a strategy. But here are the Rangers, with five games to go and playoff-bound - they hope - without a plan and in disarray.

title: EAST GERMANY WON'T BOYCOTT
description: The president of East Germany's legislature said today that his nation would compete in the 1988 Olympics in South Korea, regardless of whether North Korea boycotts the Games.

title: DANCE: 4 YOUNG ARTISTS
description: FLEDGLING artists do need to be encouraged. And one way of encouraging new choreographers is to provide them with space to work in and audience to play to. The 92d Street Y and American Dance Festival aimed to do that with Dance Preludes, a new project whose first program was presented on Tuesday at the Y. But it was a dispiriting and troubling evening.

title: Barris Industries
description: Chuck Barris, who produced such television programs as ''The Gong Show'' and ''The Dating Game,'' has agreed to sell back to Barris Industries his remaining 763,546 shares for $12.50 a share. He will also resign from the board and end an agreement to submit projects to the company, which produces, licenses and distributes television programs and sells advertising time. Burt Sugarman, the company's chairman and chief executive, said it now controlled about 25 percent of the 8.87 million common shares outstanding. Mr. Sugarman said Mr. Barris's actions were not the result of any dispute.

title: CLUB'S PLAN FOR HIGH-RISE IS CRITICIZED
description: In the usually hushed precincts of Fifth Avenue, a major fight has begun over a plan to build a 37-story apartment tower over the Metropolitan Club, a plan opposed by the Pierre Hotel to the north, the Harmonie Club to the south and preservationists all over town.

title: For Moran Towing, A Presidential First
description: The Moran Towing Corporation, operators of 80 tugboats from Maine to Texas, announced yesterday that Malcolm W. MacLeod had been named president and chief operating officer - the first president to be chosen outside the Moran family.

title: 80 ARE KILLED, SCORES WOUNDED
description: Afghan planes raided guerrilla camps in Afghanistan near the borders with Pakistan and Iran today, killing at least 80 guerrillas and civilians, guerrilla officials said.

title: Fire Damages 4 Stores
description: Four stores at the southwest corner of Eighth Avenue and 44th Street were severely damaged by a fire of undetermined origin last night, the authorities said. The blaze, which started in a novelty shop shortly before 9 P.M., also damaged second-floor rooms in the Globe Hotel above the stores. The single-room-occupancy hotel was evacuated, and no injuries were reported among the residents or firefighters.

title: Reining Supreme
description: John Campbell's victory in the final race at the Meadowlands last Saturday night pushed earnings for Campbell-driven horses above $50 million, a milestone previously reached by only one other harness reinsman, Herve Filion. And while Filion, who has a shade over $52 million to his credit, is 47 years old and has won some 10,000 of his 47,000 races, Campbell is only 31, has been driving just 15 years and has won just 3,290 of 18,556.

title: EQUITY LIBRARY THEATER GETS FOUNDATION GRANT
description: The Rodgers and Hammerstein Foundation has given $25,000 to the Equity Library Theater to go toward the renovation of the company's theater at 103d Street and Riverside Drive.

title: BTR REALTY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUNSTAR FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After net of $2,000 for the quarter and a loss of $26,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $49,000 for the quarter and $74,000 for the 6 months.

title: CROWLEY, MILNER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The results have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: Editors' Note
description: A picture caption yesterday described arrests during a protest rally in lower Manhattan against delays in Government approval of drugs that might combat AIDS. The heading said, ''Homosexuals Arrested at AIDS Drug Protest.''

title: NO. 2 BUSCH OFFICIAL QUITS AMID TURMOIL
description: Dennis P. Long, the No. 2 man at the Anheuser-Busch Companies, resigned today as the nation's largest brewer confronted accusations of improper payments to some of its executives.

title: DEMOCRATS ON HOUSE PANEL AGREE ON DEFICIT PLAN
description: Democrats on the House Budget Committee reached a tentative agreement tonight on a deficit reduction package of at least $36 billion, with half that amount proposed to come from tax increases.

title: PIANO: KAZUKO HAYAMI
description: KAZUKO HAYAMI is not atypical among young pianists in her preference for vigorous blocks of sound over flowing legato, but in the Weber, Brahms and Berg on her Merkin Concert Hall recital Sunday, that aspect predominated in this listener's perception of her playing. She is a capable, energetic and committed player, and - as she showed in quite another context at the end of the program - possessed of considerable stamina in the face of strenuously demanding keyboard writing. But Berg's sonata lacked in sensuous ebb and flow and the Brahms fantasies of Opus 116 lacked singing line and variety of texture.

title: When Engines Wear
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 ARE CHAINED IN HOUSE
description: Three nude women were found chained to a sewer pipe today in the basement of a row house, and the police said they found body parts elsewhere in the house. A man who lived in the house was charged with murder after the nude body of a woman was found buried in New Jersey.

title: 106 in Boston Area Accused of Auto Theft Fraud
description: Soon after two police undercover agents set themselves up as tow truck operators, the word on the street was that if you wanted to collect on your auto theft insurance, Empire Auto Service would make the car disappear quickly and cheaply, no questions asked.

title: ROSS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The latest periods' results include a non-recurring pre-tax charge of $39.4 million related to store closings.

title: Elmer Gantry Lives
description: ''The gospel of Jesus Christ has never sunk to such a low level,'' says Jimmy Swaggart, president of Jimmy Swaggart Ministries of Baton Rouge, La. He is expressing his disgust at other televangelists who channel funds into peripheral businesses, conduct ''soap-opera'' liaisons or add do-or-die urgency to the passing of their plates by threatening their own demise.

title: And What About Baby M's Ruined Life?
description: LEAD: The Baby M case, which is to be decided in a few days, spotlights the potentially disastrous results of the surrogate-mother phenomenon. All parties are in pain and will suffer, no matter what Judge Harvey R. Sorkow decides. But no one will suffer in years to come as much as Baby M, whose ''best interests'' cannot be served by any outcome.

title: GOTTSCHALKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said share earnings and shares outstanding reflect the 2-for-1 stock split to be paid later this month.

title: Talking Deals; Brokers Trade Themselves
description: TRADING on one's fate is the ultimate form of deal-making, and there has been a lot of it in the current Wall Street scandal. Such cooperation with the Government has never taken place with such regularity in a case of white-collar crime and it has led to a rash of guilty pleas, subpoenas and a sense of unease in the financial community.

title: Speed Limit and the Trade Balance
description: To the Editor:

title: Fleet Chairman's Urge To Diversify Leads . . . to a Strategic Merger With Norstar's Leader
description: It may have been because J. Terrence Murray was running the largest bank in the smallest state that made him, at an early stage, eager to diversify. He took the Rhode Island banking company - the Fleet Financial Group - and put it into non-banking activities in other states.

title: PEP BOYS, MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest year results include a 3 cents a share gain from the sale of assets.

title: HERS
description: LEAD: THE book sits on the kitchen table, surrounded by crayons and slips of homework. For days now the children have returned to it, asked questions, stared at the pictures.

title: Verbatim's Choice
description: Altschiller Reitzfeld has won the four-month competition for the $5 million Verbatim floppy disk account. Verbatim, situated in Charlotte, N.C., is a subsidiary of the Eastman Kodak Company. Verbatim was formerly at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, San Francisco.

title: Romero Rides No. 3,000
description: Randy Romero rode the 3,000th winner of his career in the eighth race at Gulfstream Park yesterday, then returned half an hour later to score an upset victory aboard Life at the Top in the featured Shirley Jones Handicap. Romero, a 35-year-old native of Erath, La., was thwarted in his first four attempts on the card to win his 3,000th race, then rode Full Courage to an easy victory in a $19,000 allowance race. ''I knew it was just a matter of time,'' Romero said. ''I remember a time when I didn't think I'd ever see a horse again.'' Four years ago, Romero suffered serious burns in a jockey-room fire at Oaklawn Park and was sidelined for a year.

title: TAXI PANEL, SEEKING TO BROADEN SERVICE, VOTES 22% FARE RISE
description: A 22 percent fare increase approved yesterday by the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission is weighted to encourage drivers to better serve areas outside central Manhattan, commission members said.

title: STATE SENATE CONDEMNS 'BRONX ZOO' SHOW TITLE
description: The State Senate passed a resolution Wednesday condemning the title ''The Bronx Zoo'' for an NBC television series.

title: BUDDHIST RELIGIOUS ARTIFACTS IN SHOW
description: More than 100 examples of Buddhist religious artifacts, the earliest dating from the eighth century, will go on view April 9 at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 71st Street. The exhibition, is believed to be the first major show of such pieces; they will be drawn from more than 30 museums and private collections around the country.

title: TREES TO FOOL THE SENSES
description: GEORGE BROWN, the owner of Rhinelander Florists, once received a frantic call from a customer's housekeeper.

title: Serving America, and Paraguay
description: When Clyde Taylor, United States Ambassador to Paraguay, protests the barbarities of South America's oldest dictatorship and defends its beleaguered democrats, he faithfully expresses the best values and the most sensible interests of the American people.

title: PUBLISHING OBSESSION: MEGABOOKS
description: Book publishers have always looked for titles that would keep check-out registers whirring, but their preoccupation with big books now borders on the obsessive. Even some industry executives who publicly defend the practice say they are worried about where it will lead.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: First Interstate Bancorp is offering $200 million of 8 5/8 percent subordinated capital notes due in 1999 at a price of par through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: ALBANY LEGISLATORS BYPASS CUOMO TO AGREE ON FINANCING FOR TRANSIT
description: The leaders of the New York State Legislature - in an unusual alliance that bypassed Governor Cuomo - announced agreement today on financing for mass transit, one of the major issues dividing their two houses.

title: Securities Group Seeks Disclosure Rule Change
description: The trade association for the securities industry conceded today that new legislation was needed to curb insider trading abuses on Wall Street.

title: CLEMENTS FITTING INTO MIDDLE-RELIEF ROLE
description: Anonymity in New York? Pat Clements speaks of it almost fondly, as if he wishes nothing more than to disappear quietly into the background and become a nameless face in pinstripes this season.

title: ENTERTAINMENT MARKETING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes the reversal of about $500,000 of investment tax credits recognized in fiscal year 1986. The company said the latest second quarter and 6 months earnings reflect the negative impact of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and of the introduction of new operations.

title: THE DOLLAR FIRMS; FED MOVE SEEN
description: The Federal Reserve and other central banks reportedly intervened in the foreign exchange markets again yesterday to prevent the dollar from sliding against the Japanese yen. The activity had the desired effect, and the dollar firmed.

title: BLATNICK EYES SEOUL OLYMPICS
description: ''I've always felt a little guilty because I was famous for having cancer,'' said Jeff Blatnick. The Olympic Greco-Roman gold medalist has had two bouts with Hodgkin's disease, one before and one after the 1984 Los Angeles Games. He is now pointing toward wrestling again in the 1988 Games in Seoul, South Korea.

title: What Koch Might Learn From La Guardia
description: To the Editor:

title: TAR HEELS REMAIN THE TEAM TO BEAT
description: Seven consecutive goals, three by Jeff Reh, against mighty Syracuse, turned a recent game around and led to a 19-9 victory for Adelphi at Garden City, L.I. The challenge is to name the sport in which an Adelphi team can beat Syracuse.

title: MUSIC: DAVID LINTON
description: WHEN a musician relies as heavily on technology as David Linton, the composer and one-man percussive band who appeared at Dance Theater Workshop on Monday and Tuesday, the tiniest mechanical failure can disrupt the proceedings. That is what happened near the end of Mr. Linton's premiere performance on Monday of a new work, ''Drum Midi Evil (Songs for Drum-Triggered Tape and Digital Instruments).'' Sound engineers scurried around with flashlights examining Mr. Linton's drum kit while the composer waited helplessly for severed electrical connections to be re-established.

title: Miranda Rule Gets In Way of Coercion
description: To the Editor:

title: MANHOLE BLAST ON WEST SIDE INJURES 9
description: An explosion in an underground vault for electrical equipment blew off a manhole cover on the Upper West Side of Manhattan yesterday, injuring nine schoolchildren who were returning from a field trip.

title: FIGHT ERUPTS ON BABY M BOOK AND FILM RIGHTS
description: All sides in the custody fight over Baby M have joined in a fight over a new issue - money from book and movie deals.

title: Gore, Tennessee Democrat, Rules Out Presidential Race
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee, mentioned as a possible candidate for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination, says he will not be in the race.

title: S.&P. Reduces Ratings Of 6 Banking Concerns
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that primarily because of the continuing debt crisis in developing nations, it had lowered its debt ratings of several major bank holding companies - the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the Chemical New York Corporation, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Irving Bank Corporation.

title: A THREAT IS SEEN TO TWO MAYA SITES
description: Mexico and Guatemala are planning to build a series of dams along their border that would destroy two of the most historically important archeological sites of the Mayan civilization, a group of Mexican ecologists and cultural figures said today.

title: CHAPMAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in 1985. The latest fourth quarter results include a writedown of $16,089,000 on the value of the company's oil and gas properties and the assets of its interests in the natural gas transmission partnership. The company said the primary factor contributing to the 1986 loss was $36,574,345 of asset impairments, including a $26,993,519 writedown of oil and gas properties and a $8,449,111 writedown of the assets of Phenix Transmission Co., its 60 percent owned gas gathering and transmission partnership.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Last summer I added a railing to my porch, using pressure-treated lumber. I want to paint the railing white, but have gotten conflicting advice on when to paint. The carpenter said to wait a year and the lumberyard said eight months; the hardware store said the wood could be painted any time. When is best to paint pressure-treated outdoor wood?

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD HOME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Hospital Decisions Not Made by Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINESE PREMIER, IN MAJOR SPEECH, ADOPTS HARD LINE
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang told the Chinese people today that his Government's economic initiatives would continue. But he denounced ''pernicious'' Western ideas and demanded a tight rein on intellectual and artistic expression.

title: U.S.-SOVIET PARLEY ON MID-RANGE ARMS ADJOURNING TODAY
description: Soviet-American negotiations in Geneva on reducing medium-range nuclear missiles will adjourn Thursday with the two sides still far apart on several issues, Western diplomats said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, MARCH 26, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: One Among Four Strives for Three
description: Should Indiana make it through the Final Four and capture the championship next Monday night, Bobby Knight will have become only the third major-college basketball coach to win three N.C.A.A. titles. Those who have won at least two: John Wooden, U.C.L.A. 10 Adolph Rupp, Kentucky 4 Bobby Knight, Indiana 2 Hank Iba, Oklahoma A&M 2 Branch McCracken, Indiana 2 Phil Woolpert, San Francisco 2 Ed Jucker, Cincinnati 2 Denny Crum, Louisville 2

title: IN NIGERIA, TOUCHES OF BRAZILIAN STYLE
description: IN this century Lagos has become a grimy metropolis of five million people, but pockets of what are known here as Brazilian houses still exist in quirky contrast to later local building styles, including colonial-issue British homes with deep verandas and overhanging eaves and oil-boom skyscrapers, faithful imitations of their Manhattan models.

title: DEAN MARTIN'S SON DEAD IN JET
description: The remains of Dean Paul Martin, the oldest son of the entertainer Dean Martin, and another flier were found today by rescue workers in the San Bernardino Mountains where their fighter plane was lost five days ago, the Air National Guard said late today.

title: AUTO MAKERS GET EXTENSION OF AIR BAG RULE
description: The Department of Transportation, in a trade- off it said would spur the use of air bags in automobiles, today granted the industry four additional years to install automatic restraint systems for drivers and passengers in the right front seat.

title: Aid on Bounced Checks
description: The Federal Reserve Board unanimously approved a proposal today to allow Federal Reserve banks to offer a redeposit service for bounced checks. The service would allow a commercial bank that sends checks for collection to a reserve bank to instruct it to redeposit a bounced check rather than return it. The reserve bank would be required to charge a fee for the redeposit service. Industry studies showed that nearly two-thirds of bounced checks cleared the second time around.

title: CBS Wasn't There
description: To the Editor:

title: EXCERPTS FROM OPINIONS IN RULING ON AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court decision today upholding an affirmative action plan of the Santa Clara County, Calif., Transportation Agency against a suit by a man passed over for a promotion in favor of a woman. Justice William J. Brennan Jr. presented the majority opinion, joined by Justices Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun, Lewis F. Powell Jr. and John Paul Stevens. Justice Stevens wrote a separate concurrence. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor concurred in the result but did not join Justice Brennan's opinion. Justice Byron R. White dissented. Justice Antonin Scalia wrote a separate dissent, joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice White. F ROM THE OPINION By Justice Brennan

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We therefore hold that the agency appropriately took into account as one factor the sex of Diane Joyce in determining that she should be promoted to the road dispatcher position.'' - Justice William J. Brennan Jr., for the majority of the Supreme Court. [ B10:2. ]

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Coming-Out Party

title: ADDICTS' AIDS DEATHS MAY BE HIGHER THAN REPORTED, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: The number of AIDS-related illnesses and deaths among intravenous drug addicts in New York City may be 50 percent higher than reported, Dr. Stephen C. Joseph, the City Health Commissioner, said yesterday.

title: Edelman Takeover Of Morse Hinted
description: The New York investor Asher B. Edelman said Morse Shoe Inc. had agreed to give him and a group of investors confidential company information that could lead to a takeover. But the group said it would attempt to buy the shoe retailer, which is based in Canton, Mass., only in a friendly, negotiated deal.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Bell Is Reinstated
description: The Kansas City Chiefs' defensive lineman, Mike Bell, who served a four-month prison sentence on a drug conviction, was reinstated Wednesday by the N.F.L., the Chiefs said. Bell was ordered to pay $10,000 to a drug abuse clinic in Kansas as a condition of being reinstated. The reinstatement was also conditional on his avoiding any further drug trouble and avoiding any conduct detrimental to the N.F.L. or its public image. The N.F.L. also said Mark Bell, Mike Bell's twin brother, who was convicted with him, could play in the N.F.L. Mark Bell, a former player with the Seattle Seahawks, is a free agent.

title: NOW OPEN TO THE PUBLIC: THE SOCIABLE KITCHEN
description: LEAD: PEOPLE have always socialized in the kitchen. The difference now is that the kitchen is being designed specifically as a place for gathering. Instead of being ushered into more formal rooms, guests increasingly congregate in the kitchen, or in a room that is open to it.

title: AFFAIR WITH LAW AIDE CITED
description: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct has recommended that Bronx Surrogate Bertram R. Gelfand be removed from the bench for his ''repeated abuse of judicial authority'' during an eight-year affair with a female law assistant.

title: State Labor Chief Quits With a Jab at Cuomo
description: New York State's Labor Commissioner has resigned after accusing the Cuomo administration of ''character assassination'' and saying that she was asked to leave the post.

title: HAZARDS EXISTED BEFORE BIG FIRE, TENANTS ASSERT
description: Tenants of the Schomburg Plaza in Harlem assailed the apartment building's managers last night for failing to correct hazardous conditions that several residents said existed before last Sunday's fire, in which seven people died.

title: ON MY MIND
description: The movie at the local 14-screen cinema enclave ended just in time to get home and catch the last half of ''60 Minutes.''

title: Canada to Aid Oil Concerns
description: Canada's federal Government will provide $267 million (United States) in aid a year to the oil industry, mostly to help small and medium-sized companies hard hit by last year's collapse of oil prices, Energy Minister Marcel Masse said today.

title: JAZZ: MARLENA SHAW SINGS
description: AMONG the scores of jazz singers who can claim to be the stylistic descendants of Dinah Washington and Nancy Wilson, none is more exuberantly iconoclastic than Marlena Shaw.

title: Europe Inflation Up
description: Inflation in the European Community, which fell in the fourth quarter to its lowest rate in 25 years, rose in February, figures from the community's statistics office, Eurostat, showed today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Living Section yesterday about fashion collections in Paris misidentified a designer. A cross-reference caption about the article, on the front of the section, also carried the error. The designer is Valentino Garavani (known professionally as Valentino), not Mario Valentino, whose collections are shown in Milan.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: REAGAN, IN HOUSE, PUSHES HIS AGENDA
description: President Reagan went to Capitol Hill today to promote his legislative agenda, but the Republican leader in the House, Robert H. Michel, said he would oppose the President's veto of the $87.9 billion highway bill because it contained money for an important project in his district in central Illinois.

title: REPLACING THE SEATS IN CANE CHAIRS
description: LEAD: A high standard of hand-caning has been maintained over the years. Occasionally, though, one may come across uneven spacing of the strands along the rails, crooked lines in diagonal weaving or stray strands that have found their ways into the wrong holes, which disturbs the overall rhythm of the work.

title: 'BACKLASH,' AUSTRALIAN CRIME STORY
description: THE Australian film ''Backlash'' begins with a brief, crude sequence in which a young aboriginal woman is attacked by her employer, an older white man whom she proceeds to murder and emasculate (we are later told) with a garden shears. How will the film, which is the second dramatic feature by Bill Bennett, make use of this episode? As it turns out, the focus shifts quickly from the murder to the man-and-woman police team assigned to escort the accused woman to her trial. Once these three begin their journey together, the film shifts gears entirely and becomes an odd hybrid, a whimsical, eccentric road movie with an element of mystery.

title: President Is Retiring At Publishers Group
description: William F. Gorog, 61 years old, announced that he would retire as president of the Magazine Publishers Association at the end of the year. Mr. Gorog, who has held the job for the last five years, said that his plans were indefinite, but he was not ruling out entrepreneurial projects.

title: School Van Flips, Putting 4 in Hospital
description: A school van carrying 11 teen-agers overturned on the Saw Mill River Parkway yesterday, injuring at least three students and the driver. The use of seat belts may have prevented more injuries, the police said.

title: ENTERRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $34,774,000, after tax benefit, which included a writedown for property, plant and equipment; and a writeoff for goodwill associated with these assets for both the quarter and year.

title: Home Resales In Rebound
description: Sales of existing homes rebounded in February after a sharp drop in January that was attributed to people rushing to close deals in 1986 before new tax laws took effect, a real estate trade association said today. The National Association of Realtors said that February sales were up 6 percent, to an annual pace of 3.69 million units, compared with 3.48 million in January.

title: Allegis Stock Up On Trump Rports
description: The stock of the Allegis Corporation, formerly known as UAL Inc., rose sharply yesterday amid continuing rumors that Donald J. Trump, the New York developer who owns a large block of the company's stock, might attempt a takeover. The stock of Allegis climbed in recent weeks on such rumors, and Wall Street has also speculated that Allegis might decide to undertake a corporate restructuring should Mr. Trump or another investor threaten its independence.

title: Peer Pressure vs. Pregnancy
description: Any adult with children or a long memory knows that young people steer by peer pressure. Sometimes that produces nothing more than an odd haircut and odder wardrobe. Sometimes, though, it has serious consequences. Like babies.

title: 'SPITTING IMAGE: 1987 MOVIE AWARDS,' ON NBC
description: NBC and Britain's ''Spitting Image'' organization have been trying eagerly to develop a mutually satisfying format for the commercial market in this country. The life-size puppets, ingenious caricatures created by Peter Fluck and Roger Law, popped up on British television a couple of years ago with some of the most outrageous satire since ''That Was the Week That Was.'' Not just fooling around, they selected as their primary targets the royal family, Margaret Thatcher and the Pope, just to mention the more prominent. The style was gloriously nasty.

title: Riding Shotgun in the Persian Gulf
description: The Reagan Administration and Kuwait play a clever but misleading game when they propose using American warships to protect oil tankers in the Persian Gulf from attack by Iran.

title: Soviet-Israeli Contacts Reported Continuing
description: Israeli and Soviet diplomats have continued diplomatic contacts for the last four months in Washington, New York and Europe on ways to improve relations, Israeli officials said today.

title: TV Cable Penetration 41.6% in New York City
description: New York City ranks about 135th among American cities in the percentage of its homes wired for cable television, with 41.6 percent. However, it is No. 1 in number of households wired: more than 2.8 million.

title: ARCHITECTURE: MIES MASTERPIECE'S NEW INCARNATION
description: For lovers of modern architecture, walking through the newest architectural wonder in this city is something like being in Shangri-La - for this building is not supposed to exist. It is the pavilion Mies van der Rohe designed in 1929 as the German exhibition at the Barcelona World's Fair, and although photographs made it one of the most celebrated and influential buildings of the 20th century, it was torn down after only six months. A few years ago a movement began to reconstruct the pavilion as a permanent structure, and in the middle of last year, just in time to be part of the celebrations marking the centennial of Mies van der Rohe's birth in 1886, the brand-new pavilion opened.

title: No Headline
description: Several seasons ago at the Humana Festival of New American Plays, the Actors Theater of Louisville went on location to a field house, which was turned into an immense dumping ground as an environment for Gary Leon Hill's ''Food From Trash.'' It is that play that served as the prototype for this year's festival, which culminated in a three-day marathon that ended Sunday.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,120,000 and a loss on disposal of $922,000.

title: SUPREME COURT, 6-3, EXTENDS PREFERENCES IN EMPLOYMENT FOR WOMEN AND MINORITIES
description: In a broad extension of its decisions on affirmative action, the Supreme Court ruled today that employers may sometimes favor women and members of minorities over better-qualified men and whites in hiring and promoting to achieve better balance in their work forces.

title: PREACHERS' BATTLE TANSFIXING THE SOUTH
description: This is the eastern front in what has become a battle of evangelists, waged on airwaves around the country but concentrated here in the South.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morris Township, N.J., said it had reached an agreement to sell its linotype group to Commerce Bank A.G. of West Germany.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: An underwriting syndicate today expects to offer the country's largest new issue - a public sale totaling $1.65 billion of the Government's 85 percent stake in the Consolidated Rail Corporation.

title: CORK GALLERY TO SHOW WORKS OF 16 ARTISTS
description: The works of 16 artists are to go on display today at the Cork Gallery at Lincoln Center as part of a multi-gallery exhibition run by the League of Exhibitors, Galleries, Exhibit Rooms, Dealers and Markers of Art in Neighborhoods. The league was founded three years ago by Ernest Acker, an artist.

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ISRAEL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $647,000, or 3 cents a share. Share earnings represents Class A shares. The 1985 results have been restated due to an acquisition by an affiliated company which is accounted for by the equity method.

title: AS SOVIET JEWS AWAIT WORD, DESPERATION SETS IN
description: ''When are you leaving?''

title: West Point Off Limits To Soviet Astronaut
description: The Army has forbidden the Military Academy at West Point to invite a Soviet astronaut, Maj. Gen. Vladimir A. Dzhanibekov, to speak there.

title: NANCY BRYAN LUCE
description: Nancy Bryan Luce, who was active in philanthropy, died of cancer Monday at her home in Millbrook, L.I. She was 58 years old.

title: EMIGRES' LETTER PRINTED IN SOVIET, DRAWS HARSH REPLY FROM PRAVDA
description: A weekly Moscow newspaper published the text of a letter by prominent Soviet emigres today challenging Mikhail S. Gorbachev to withdraw Soviet forces from Afghanistan and declare a general amnesty for all imprisoned dissidents.

title: AIRLINE WORKERS GET PROTECTION DESPITE VOIDED PART OF LAW
description: The Supreme Court today upheld provisions of a 1978 law that protect laid-off airline employees, even though a related part of the statute had been ruled unconstitutional.

title: Filibuster by Senators On Contras Succeeds
description: Senate Republicans thwarted a third and final attempt by the Democratic leadership today to end a filibuster and force a vote on cutting off further aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: AVATAR HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $1,405,000 for the latest year and $3,538,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Slow Start For Global Venture
description: THE joint venture that partly united the fortunes of America's Interpublic Group of Companies and Britain's Lowe Howard-Spink & Bell P.L.C. in December 1985 has had little effect so far on the former Marschalk Company, which was made the United States anchor of the venture.

title: A CARPENTER WHO RECONSTRUCTS THE PAST
description: ON the second floor of the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a sawdust-covered workroom with Ezra Mills's name on it. ''I'm the prop department,'' said the 62-year-old carpenter from Goshen, N.Y., surrounded by stray columns, tools and a dusty calendar from Walters Mobil Service Center in Middletown, N.Y.

title: Begin Won't Meet Carter
description: Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin today turned down a request by former President Jimmy Carter to meet in Jerusalem on the anniversary of the signing of the Israel-Egypt peace treaty, Yechiel Kadishai, a spokesman for Mr. Begin, said. He said Mr. Begin did not give a reason for declining.

title: What's 'Behind' Strawberry?
description: Even before the thrill of last year's World Series, the Mets' motto across the outside of Shea Stadium was ''Baseball Like It Oughta Be,'' although the Red Sox wouldn't agree. In other years, it was ''The Magic Is Back,'' long before the magic really returned. And now, as drivers on the Grand Central Parkway can attest, it's simply ''1986 World Champs.'' But for opening day on April 7 the Mets should update their Shea Stadium sign to read: ''We've Put That Behind Us.''

title: 2 MARINES SAID TO ALLOW SOVIET EMBASSY ACCESS
description: American intelligence officials strongly suspect that two marines assigned to guard the United States Embassy in Moscow allowed Soviet agents to enter sensitive areas of the compound, Administration officials said today.

title: THE JEANS SHOOPE ADN BUSY BUTIKS OF VACI STREET
description: Janos Kadar, for 30 years the leader of the Communist Party, is so proud of Vaci Street that last year he took his guest, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, for a walk along it to show him the smiling face of Hungarian consumerism.

title: ENFORCING CHIP PACT WITH JAPAN
description: When the United States and Japan reached an agreement on the semiconductor trade last summer, it was hailed by political and industry leaders. President Reagan called it ''an important step toward freer and more equitable world trade.''

title: TAIWAN'S U.S. STAKE UP
description: New Taiwanese investment in the United States is likely to almost double to $80 million this year and reach $400 million a year by 1991, the Taiwanese Economic Ministry said in a forecase published today.

title: BLACKS IN A MISSISSIPPI TOWN APPROVE A NEW WARD SYSTEM
description: The all-black municipal government in this town of 1,515 people, responding to complaints by whites who said they were not being fairly represented, agreed Tuesday to create a majority-white district in a new ward system.

title: OLSON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $330,000 for the quarter and $485,000 for the year, and an extraordinary tax credit of $1,042,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $1,603,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $385,000 for the quarter and $2,692,000 for the year. d-Net loss

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: Congress is not the only forum debating whether to preseve or abandon the 55 mile-an-hour speed limit. If Congress manages to override President Regan's expected veto of the highway bill, which contains language repealing the national speed limit, the debate will shift to the states. The bill gives the states discretion to raise the speed limit to 65 miles an hour on rural portions of the Interstate highway system, or about 75 percent of the system.

title: Italian Coalition Effort Fails
description: Giulio Andreotti announced tonight that he had abandoned his attempt to form a government. Mr. Andreotti's hopes of restoring the five-party coalition had rested on a plan for settling a dispute between his party, the Christian Democrats, and the Socialists, led by the departing Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, about three referendums on nuclear energy. The Socialists wanted to hold the referendums, but the Christian Democrats were opposed.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MANY amateurs do not realize that a sharp blade not only cuts faster and with less effort than a dull blade, but is also much safer to use.

title: PCP Is Found in Brakeman in Amtrak Crash
description: New drug tests on the Conrail train crewmen involved in January's collision with an Amtrak passenger train near Baltimore showed that one of them had used the hallucinogenic drug PCP as well as marijuana, officials said today.

title: US SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the LIFO inventory method lowered earnings by 6 cents a share in the latest fiscal year, compared with a reduction of 2 cents a share in the prior year.

title: Chemlawn Offer
description: Waste Management Inc. said it had ended its $35-a-share tender offer to buy the outstanding shares of the Chemlawn Corporation. Chemlawn, a lawn-care company based in Columbus, Ohio, announced last Friday that Ecolab Inc., which makes cleaning products, had signed a definitive agreement to buy it for about $370 million, or $36.50 a share. Herbert A. Getz, a spokesman at Waste Management's headquarters here, would say only that his company's offer had been withdrawn and would not comment on whether his company still hoped to acquire Chemlawn.

title: VALIDITY OF QUASAR 'YARDSTICK' IS QUESTIONED
description: New findings support the theory that the method used to measure distances in the heavens may be less accurate when it is applied to quasars, the most remote objects in the universe, according to the proponent of that theory.

title: JOHNSTOWN-CONSOLIDATED REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GREATER RISK FROM RADIUM CITED IN JERSEY
description: Federal environmental officials said today that radium contamination in three Essex County communities was far more extensive than originally believed, adding that more than 700 homes may have some degree of risk.

title: POPE CALLS VIRGIN MARY SPUR TO CHRISTIAN UNITY
description: Pope John Paul II issued an encyclical on the Virgin Mary today, proclaiming her a ''model'' for the Roman Catholic Church and calling on all Christians to accept her as a source of unity because she is their ''common mother.''

title: GRAY MARKET FOR CHIPS SHRINKING BUT STILL BIG
description: The Southeast Asia gray market for Japanese chips, which is at the center of a bitter trade dispute, is shrinking but remains significant, participants in the market say.

title: TRADE BILL PASSED BY HOUSE UNIT
description: The House Ways and Means Committee overwhelmingly approved a trade bill today that both Democrats and Republicans said significantly enhanced the chances of eventual agreement with the White House.

title: Anthem Antipathy
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. ALLAN A GUTSTEIN
description: Dr. Allan A. Gutstein, a dentist who was among the first to establish group dental-care centers in suburban shopping malls, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 43 years old, lived in Manhattan and suffered from hypertension.

title: G.M. Plant Closing
description: The General Motors Corporation will close its foundry in Pontiac, Mich., in May, eliminating more than 1,600 jobs and forcing some layoffs, the company announced. The foundry's last pour is scheduled for May 22, and the last day for 1,000 workers there will be May 25. Most remaining workers, who will help clean the plant and remove equipment, will work until June 1, a G.M. spokesman, Tom Spencer, said. The closing had been planned since April 1985, but a date had not been set. G.M. said it had not determined how many workers would be transferred, how many would retire early or how many would be laid off. The foundry is one of three G.M. Central Foundry operations to be closed.

title: Navy Ordered to Halt Work at Arms Depot
description: The Navy was barred yesterday from building more than 500 housing units at its Colts Neck munitions depot until it studies whether the housing would hurt the environment in a ruling by Chief Judge Clarkson S. Fisher of Federal District Court.

title: U.S. NEARS A MARK IN NEW HOUSING
description: IF big, round numbers are the stuff of milestones, then the United States will achieve one by the end of March with the completion of the country's 100 millionth housing unit, according to the Census Bureau.

title: Belgium Fights Insiders
description: Belgium plans to outlaw insider trading, the practice of buying or selling stocks using non-public information. Insider trading, illegal in a number of countries including the United States and Britain, has not been illegal in Belgium.

title: NEW ENGLAND SKI SEASON NOT OVER
description: Judging by the number and variety of competitions to be held over the next few weekends, the ski season is far from over. In fact, New England ski areas report solid snow cover and even brief March storms that brought fresh snow.

title: Brooklyn Group Serves Up Hope With Fast Food
description: The Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation has invested in a fast-food franchise, which might cause some people to ask whether going into the hamburger business is a local development organization's proper role. The answer is a tentative yes. In the 20 years since it was founded by Senators Robert F. Kennedy and Jacob K. Javits, Restoration has evolved from a shaky experiment in social engineering into a nationally recognized model for local revival. Recently, however, the virtual elimination of Federal administrative funds has forced the corporation into a struggle toward self-sufficiency.

title: A Main Event: Manic Sunday
description: Don't be surprised that the Pontiac Silverdome, with some 90,000 seats, is a sellout Sunday for Wrestlemania III, an annual 12-match tribute to mayhem that serves as pro wrestling's Super Bowl. Or that there are no more seats available for the closed-circuit telecast at either Madison Square Garden's main arena or the Felt Forum.

title: FOR COOKING EASE, THERE'S NO PLACE LIKE AN ISLAND
description: LEAD: ''ISLANDS are for cooks who don't like to work behind closed doors,'' said Freya Block, a New York interior designer. The elaborate island she designed for her weekend home in Lime Rock, Conn., is ''the focal point of the house,'' Mrs. Block said.

title: PROTESTANTS WEIGH DOCUMENT'S EFFECT
description: The two major Protestant groups involved in ecumenical discussions with the Roman Catholic Church said yesterday that although they did not agree with all the essential doctrines of the encyclical on the Virgin Mary, they generally welcomed Pope John Paul II's message.

title: 3 INDICTED IN HUGE TAX FRAUD
description: Three financiers were indicted yesterday on charges of operating a tax shelter conspiracy that produced more than $350 million in fraudulent tax deductions for wealthy investors.

title: RISE IS PROPOSED IN MINIMUM WAGE 8C1>
description: A proposal to raise the national minimum wage to roughly $4.65 an hour from $3.35 an hour over the next three years was introduced in Congress today.

title: Lofton on Trade Block
description: The Green Bay Packers are trying to trade their former all-pro wide receiver, James Lofton, before the April 28 National Football League draft, according to Tom Braatz, the team's new director of football operations. Saying that the idea was Coach Forrest Gregg's, Braatz indicated that Lofton, who is scheduled to go on trial May 18 on a charge of second-degree sexual assault, would not play for the Packers again. ''I think it was pretty much agreed upon before I ever got there that it would be better for the state of Wisconsin, for James Lofton and for the Green Bay Packers if we mutually separated,'' Braatz said in a report in yesterday's Green Bay Press Gazette. Braatz added that the Packers had been talking to the San Francisco 49ers regarding the 30-year-old Lofton, who played under Coach Bill Walsh at Stanford. The Packers suspended Lofton for the final game last season after he was arrested Dec. 18. If Lofton is found guilty, he could face up to 10 years in prison. Braatz wouldn't say what compensation he was seeking for Lofton, a Pro Bowl player from 1980-85. ''He's like an old gun -he's worth whatever somebody will pay,'' he said.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF THE COUNSEL: WHAT HE DOES AND WHEN HE DOES IT
description: President Reagan's legal staff operates in an up and down world these days.

title: UKRAINIAN LEADER IS AFFIRMED
description: Vladimir V. Shcherbitsky, the Ukrainian leader, apparently thwarting an effort by Mikhail S. Gorbachev to unseat him, retained his post in a meeting of the Ukrainian Central Committee ending today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 26, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Accounts
description: * Singer Co. to Paul Kaufman Associates for the Kearfott Guidance and Navigation division and the Electronic Systems division.

title: NEW YORK CITY PLANS TO STOP BOARDING BABIES ON HOSPITALS
description: New York City officials announced a plan yesterday that they said would end the practice of leaving abandoned babies in hospitals for months while foster homes are sought for them.

title: PLANTS THAT ANSWER CHILDHOOD'S CALL
description: IT'S only a hunch based on anecdotal evidence, not sober research using questionnaires and carefully constructed polls of people with horticultural inclinations, but I suspect that there are some notable differences between those of us who started gardening when we were children and those who came to the pursuit later in life - the late bloomers, so to speak.

title: U.S. EXPANDING USE OF PRIVATE GROUPS TO COLLECT DEBTS
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would greatly expand its use of private collection agencies to track down and dun 1.4 million people who have defaulted on Federal loans worth $7 billion.

title: A WARNING ON PACIFIERS
description: The only safe pacifier is the simple one-piece type, according to a consumer group. The group called for tougher Federal standards and urged parents to avoid fancy pacifiers that could be dangerous.

title: No Headline
description: PARIS, March 25 - Yves Saint Laurent said his fashion message for fall could be summed up in two words, ''short'' and ''young.'' This was perfectly true, and it made everybody happy. He received a standing ovation after his show this morning, and then practically everybody filed backstage to congratulate him personally.

title: NO. 434 GOES THE WAY OF ALL WOOD HOUSES
description: SUSANNA MOORE, who lives across the street, remembers the way the club members would put on their lederhosen and stand outside their wood-framed clubhouse at 434 East 84th Street during Oktoberfest. They would play ''Lilli Marlene'' over and over again, Miss Moore recalled: '' 'Always I'll remember how you used to wait, every summer evening, close by the barrack gate.' ''

title: Giuliani May Have Been Offered S.E.C. Job
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, met with the White House chief of staff this week to discuss the search for a chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission and may have been asked to take the job, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: EVENTS: 1804 MANSION AND CRAFTS GALORE
description: Spring Tours of Boscobel Restoration, Route 9D at Garrison-on-Hudson, N.Y.; 914-265-3638.

title: FUNCTION AND WHIMSY IN METAL
description: IN an era when faux finishes and elaborately patterned plastic laminate surfaces are popular, metal, an ancient and durable material, is looking particularly fresh again. Designers admire its raw strength. Around the city there are home accessories made of metal that are both streamlined and fanciful. In the 1920's and 30's, metal was a material that lent itself to mass production; it could be stamped out by machine. On the other hand, some artisans have always treated metal as a material to be sculptured, sometimes into whimsical shapes.

title: A REPORT FAULTS TRANSIT AGENCY ON DOOR WOES
description: Efforts to modify subway car doors to reduce the chances of their flying open were hindered by ''constant delays and a lack of firm management direction,'' according to the Inspector General of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Joy Simpson, Soprano, On South African Tour
description: Joy Simpson, an American soprano, died early today after suffering a brain hemorrhage during a performance last week, a hospital spokeswoman said. Ms. Simpson was 40 years old. The soprano, who was from Philadelphia, went into a coma Saturday and never recovered, the spokeswoman said.

title: Coke, Wendy's And Big Mac
