description: WALL STREET'S rumor mills conjured up a tantalizing menu early this week: The Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest producer of soft drinks, might acquire Wendy's International, the nation's third-largest fast-food chain. Burgers and Coke - what could go better?

title: PANEL WARNS CONGRESS ON RESEARCH GRANT SYSTEM
description: A special panel representing universities has warned that the nation's research capacity faces ''serious and lasting damage'' if Congress continues to give funds directly to institutions for research facilities, bypassing reviews on their scientific merit.

title: RULING CALLED SPUR TO ADOPTION OF PREFERENTIAL HIRING PROGRAMS
description: Women's groups and civil rights organizations predicted today that the Supreme Court's latest decision on preferential hiring programs would encourage public and private employers to adopt plans that favor women over men in hiring, promotions and layoffs. But opponents of affirmative action assailed the Court's ruling, saying it would prompt employers to disregard merit as the basis for hiring and promotions.

title: N.F.L. Players Take an 8-Point Stance
description: With free agency and guaranteed contracts among their prime objectives in a new labor agreement, leaders of the National Football League Players Association finished preparations today for a three-day convention designed to enlighten players on the issues and remind them that negotiations starting next month could be difficult.

title: NEW STUDY SEES LAG IN LAWS ON THE USE OF HUMAN TISSUE
description: The sale of human tissue and cells that could be sources of valuable biomedical products is generally permissible, but laws do not establish standards on compensation for such materials or their ownership, the Office of Technology Assessment said today.

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of assets of $7,719,000 for the quarter and $7,975,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: RED WINGS AND SPARTANS PROMOTING A HOCKEY RENAISSACE
description: The wisecrack that Detroit is really ''suburban Canada'' is at least figuratively accurate in terms of geography, and hockey.

title: 52 Implicated In Oil Schemes
description: Kickbacks, phony invoice schemes and illegal tax shelters may have inflated Oklahoma oil prices by up to 40 percent between 1979 and 1983, according to charges being brought against 52 Oklahoma oilmen, Assistant United States Attorney Michael Ringer said Wednesday. So far, 12 men have pleaded guilty to charges ranging from accepting kickbacks to mail fraud, he said.

title: Some Rises In Yields
description: Yields on bank money market accounts were unchanged for the week ended yesterday, while the yields on certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds moved slightly higher.

title: Inventions
description: If necessity is the mother of invention, discomfort is its father. A recent ski trip suggests two inventions that need inventing.

title: WATCH KEMP RUN
description: As Presidential campaigns get ever longer and more elaborate, so does the process by which politicians let the world know that they are running. The record in this department is surely about to be set by Representative Jack F. Kemp, the New York Republican who will make his long-expected declaration next month.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co. named Steven D. Goldstein executive vice president and general manager of the new service establishment division of the Consumer Card Group USA.

title: VARITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The results for the latest full year included reorganization charges of $15.2 million, compared with $17.6 for the year-ago period. Preferred dividends exceeded net income for both year-ago periods. All figures are in U.S. funds.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE RUG MERCHANT. By Phillip Lopate. 218 pages. Viking. $16.95. FADING, MY PARMACHEENE BELLE. By Joanna Scott. 262 pages. Ticknor & Fields. $17.95.

title: Poisoning in Cuban Prison
description: Seven prisoners died and another 17 were in critical condition after more than 300 of them drank methyl alcohol at the Combinado del Este penitentiary east of Havana, the official newspaper Granma reported today.

title: A SCHOOL TRIES TO BEAT ODDS AGAINST ITS IMAGE
description: Whenever possible, Robert Maxson visits the student union and walks across the Nevada-Las Vegas campus, greeting students, determined to make his presence felt as president of the university. On Tuesday, he spoke briefly at a rally proclaiming ''Animal Rights Week,'' telling a handful of activists that he was pleased they were taking an interest in worthwhile causes.

title: Matilda W. Salpeter, Founder Of After-Class Day-Care Plan
description: Matilda W. Salpeter, a retired New York City elementary school teacher and principal who established the child-care All-Day Neighborhood School Program, died Tuesday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. She was 96 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: ENTRANCE FEE DELAYED AT INDEPENDENCE PARK
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel said today that in deference to the Constitution's 200th anniversary the Government would delay until next year the imposition of admission fees at Philadelphia's Independence National Historical Park.

title: Bid on Gencorp May Be Raised
description: A group offering to buy the Gencorp Corporation for $100 a share, or $2.2 billion, said yesterday that it might be willing to raise the offer. Wagner & Brown, a Midland, Tex., oil company, is seeking Gencorp together with AFG Industries, a glass company in Irvine, Calif. Joel L. Reed, chief financial officer for Wagner & Brown, said, ''We'd be prepared to consider raising the price if they are willing to let us take a look at the books and give us an opportunity to find additional value.'' He said that Cyril Wagner

title: BRIDGE: AT TIMES, GOOD THOUGHT CAN OVERCOME BAD BREAK
description: In bridge, as in life, careful thought can sometimes enable one to overcome bad breaks.

title: The Jets Music Group Will Sing for Kool-Aid
description: General Foods, through Grey Advertising, has retained the Jets, a pop music group, to sing the praises of Kool-Aid Koolers Juice Drink.

title: Soviet Is Seeking Reciprocity In Monitoring of Atom Tests
description: The Soviet Union has told an American group that it may have to shut down monitoring stations near the Semipalatinsk nuclear test site unless Washington allows monitoring by Russians.

title: NEIGHBORS IN QUEENS DEPICT SUSPECT AS A 'LOVABLE' PATRIOT
description: In the working-class project where he grew up in Woodside, Queens, Cpl. Arnold Bracy of the Marine Corps was remembered yesterday as a lovable, patriotic minister's son from a hard-working, upright family.

title: FOR POLITICIANS, SCRUTINY INTO THE MURKY AREA OF PUBLIC WORKERS AND MONEY
description: Nearly all elected officials, in both the legislative and executive branches of government, use public workers and public funds to run election campaigns and further their political goals, politicians in New York, Albany and Washington said yesterday.

title: KEY RATES
Return to Alma Mater
description: Boyd Grant, whose Fresno State team won the National Invitation Tournament in 1983, has confirmed that he will become the new head basketball coach of his alma mater, Colorado State University. Grant, who stepped down from the Fresno State job after the 1985-86 season, will replace Tony McAndrews, who resigned March 8 after compiling an 80-120 record in seven years. In nine years at Fresno State, Grant built a 194-74 mark. . . . Lefty Driesell, who resigned as Maryland coach last fall, has been interviewed for the basketball coaching job at South Alabama, according to The Mobile Press Register.

title: COMPREHENSIVE CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
American Being Tried In a West Bank Court
description: An Israeli Army officer testified in a military court today that he saw Roger L. Heacock, an American professor accused of incitement, at a protest here on Feb. 16.

title: DANCE: NAI-NI CHEN TROUPE SHOWS ASIAN MOTIFS
description: NAI-NI CHEN, a choreographer from Taipei, Taiwan who lives in New York and teaches at New York University, combines aspects of Asian and Western modern dance in her works. The performance by Nai-Ni Chen and Dancers on Tuesday night at La Mama also revealed that her choreography possesses strong sculptural qualities.

title: Bleak Forecast
description: Dick Williams, manager of the Seattle Mariners, on the team's slim chances of landing one especially prominent free agent: ''I think it'll snow before it Raines.''

title: Stocks Fall Broadly; Dow Slips 5.69
description: The stock market retreated broadly yesterday, ending a string of six consecutive record highs for the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: DANCE: HARLEM'S 'PHOENIX RISING'
description: ''PHOENIX RISING,'' which Dance Theater of Harlem presented as a premiere Tuesday night, is listed as ''a work in progress'' on the program. Judging by its enthusiastic reception, this jointly choreographed effort by Arthur Mitchell and Billy Wilson can also be called a winner in progress.

title: No Headline
description: India's ambitious space program suffered a setback Tuesday when the first of a new generation of big rockets failed within a minute after takeoff and crashed into the Bay of Bengal with its payload.

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''Ever so subtly, without even alluding to the last obstacles preserved by earlier opinions that we now push out of our path, we effectively replace the goal of a discrimination-free society with the quite incompatible goal of proportionate representation by race and by sex in the workplace.'' - Justice Antonin Scalia, dissenting. [ B10:5. ]

title: To Speak Against Evil
description: The hero of Orwell's ''Nineteen Eighty-four,'' Winston Smith, is finally broken when threatened with the horror he fears most: rats. A cage of rats is clamped to his face, and he betrays the woman he loves to keep his torturer from lifting the gate and letting the rats at him.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about regulatory approval of an acquisition by the Chemical New York Corporation misstated one of the payment terms. Among other considerations, Chemical is offering nine-hundredths of a Chemical common share, not nine-tenths, for each share of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc.

title: Article 546787 -- No Title
description: An Atlas-Centaur rocket carrying a military communications satellite went out of control and was destroyed shortly after liftoff yesterday at Cape Canaveral, Fla.

title: KEY RATES
The System They Know
description: To the Editor:

title: KIDDIE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Contra Debate Is Over, For Now, but It May Be Really Over Next Fall
description: The latest Congressional debate over aid to the Nicaraguan rebels was a puzzling exercise, a kind of shadow play of signs and symbols.

title: WILLIAM M. CREASY
description: Maj. Gen. William M. Creasy, former chief chemical weapons officer for the Army, died Sunday. He was 81 years old.

title:
COLLEGE ROWING;
HARVARD EMERGES AS EARLY FAVORITE
description: LEAD: The 1987 opening races of the collegiate crew season get under way tomorrow. But even before the first strokes have been taken, Harvard's heavyweight varsity has emerged as the consensus favorite among Eastern coaches as the crew to beat.

title: MED-MOBILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company went public in September 1986.

title: IRISH TRADITIONAL MUSIC
description: The Egan Family, featuring Seamus Egan on flute, tin whistle, mandolin and uilean pipes, will play traditional Irish music tomorrow at 9 and 10:30 P.M. at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Tickets are $5. Information, 581-7773.

title: Seabrook Plant Gains On Low-Power Testing
description: The Seabrook nuclear reactor today moved a step closer to gaining permission for low-power testing when a licensing board of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission approved a license to operate at 5 percent power.

title: Jersey Chief Justice Changing Residence
description: Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of the State Supreme Court, who was questioned in the Legislature last year about whether he was a New Jersey resident, said yesterday that he would make his summer home in Deal, N.J., his permanent residence.

title: FALWELL TO PRESS INQUIRY ON PREACHER'S RESIGNATION
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell today promised an inquiry into the controversy surrounding the Rev. Jim Bakker and urged his fellow Christians not to ''let Satan win the day.''

title: MACNEAL-SCHWENDLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After equity in loss from discontinued operations of $263,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $2,073,000. Share earnings reflect the 100 percent stock dividend paid.

title: U.S. READY TO ACT AGAINST JAPANESE ON TRADE IN CHIPS
description: President Reagan is expected to announce on Friday that the United States will act against Japan for its failure to comply with a semiconductor agreement between the two Governments.

title: GULL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The 1986 results are restated and fiscal 1986 net income included receipt of a $250,000 insurance claim payment.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Saro Liotta, Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street. Saro Liotta, born in Palermo, Sicily, is known in Italy for albums and soundtrack scores; he has also been a globe-trotting guitarist, living and studying music in India and Peru as well as his native Sicily. In his New York debut tonight, he'll play traditional and traditionalist music with roots on four continents - tarantellas, raga, blues and ''triste'' Peruvian street music - along with his own compositions, perhaps drawing on all of those styles. Tonight at 8; tickets are $10. Information: 242-3374. $ ? * * *

title: Former Omaha Police Chief Ordered Reinstated by Judge
description: A former Omaha Police Chief who was dismissed for insubordination was ordered reinstated to his job yesterday by a Douglas County district judge.

title: Ecolab Chairman Turns His Attention to Lawns
description: The name Ecolab may not mean much to the average consumer, but many consumers use Ecolab products, which include Electrasol and Finish dishwasher detergents. Now Ecolab, under Pierson M. Grieve, chairman and chief executive, plans to stress the yard as well as the kitchen with the proposed acquisition of Chemlawn, a lawn-care company.

title: 'WITHNAIL AND I,' A COMEDY
description: THE place is London, where the swinging 1960's are coming to an end. Nearly gone is the decade of ''The Yellow Submarine,'' ''Hair,'' dropping out and turning on (preferably with money from home or an idependent income), of ''Oh! Calcutta!'' Mary Quant, free love, public sex, booze, ''Blow-Up,'' pills to soar on and pills for the descent.

title: The U.N. Today: March 27, 1987
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: STAGE: 'STEEL MAGNOLIAS,' A LOUISIANA STORY
description: SEVERAL months ago, the stage at the WPA Theater was converted into a frozen fish processing plant in Gloucester, Mass., the setting for Israel Horovitz's ''North Shore Fish.'' The environment was so redolent of its time and place that one could almost smell the sea breeze. Now, the WPA has - temperamentally and geographically - traveled in the opposite direction, to Chinquapin, La., the setting for Robert Harling's ''Steel Magnolias,'' at the theater through April 12. The scene is a tranquil beauty salon, complete with lotions, perfumes, sinks and hair dryers. At the end of the run of the play, the stage could easily be opened for neighborhood business. In the case of both plays, there was a wizard at work: the set designer, Edward T. Gianfrancesco.

title: Postseason Play
description: Just when you thought that the Super Bowl silly season was over and that all those tiresome bets between prominent Giant and Bronco fans had been paid, along comes word that one remains unsettled. It turns out that the New York Philharmonic made a Super Bowl wager with the Denver Symphony, and at a performance on April 3 the Denver musicians will pay off - by playing the John Kander-Fred Ebb standard, ''New York, New York.'' That may not be of much benefit to the members of the Philharmonic, but their reward will come during their park concerts this summer. They won't have to play ''Rocky Mountain High.''

title: WESTON, ROY F INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MANLY FLEISCHMANN, LAWYER WHO LED PANEL ON EDUCATION
description: Manly Fleischmann, a lawyer and government official who headed a controversial commission assigned to find out how New York State might get better public education for less money, died of a heart attack Wednesday. He was 78 years old and lived in Buffalo.

title: Man Held in Holdups At Automatic Tellers
description: A 21-year-old man, carrying a loaded automatic pistol, was arrested in Greenwich Village in connection with 24 holdups at automatic-teller machines since September, the police said yesterday.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday MINI-OPERAS

title: Nigeria Seeking to Curb Population Growth
description: Spinning computer models into the future, population experts here forecast that in 30 years there will be more Nigerians on the globe than Western Europeans.

title: Schoolboy Twist
description: The 3-point shot will be coming to high school basketball next season. The basketball rules committee of the National Federation of High School Athletic Associations has voted to put the new rule into effect in the 1987-88 season. Billy Wise, the executive assistant commissioner of the Kentucky Athletic Association and a committee member, said the distance would be the same as it is in college: 19 feet 9 inches. ''The states that experimented with the 3-point shot found out that attendance was up at their games, that the rule created more interest in the game, and that the fans stayed for the entire game instead of leaving early,'' Wise said.

title: Advertising; Cold Water At Florida Gathering
description: So you spend the cold winter months in the freezing North turning out advertising with great care, so that the messages are properly honed, then come spring and you head South for a meeting of your peers and the first thing you find out is that a lot of folks out there haven't been understanding your messages. What a way to make a living! But the advertising crowd is a resilient bunch, and by the time the cocktail hour rolled around today with an afternoon of golf, tennis and swimming added to the memory bank, the knowledge that 37 percent of the people exposed to magazine ads and articles don't understand or comprehend them became a bit easier to take.

title: Why No One Laughs at Gorbachev's High-Wire Act
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSPECTS IN PARIS REPORT TIE TO IRAN
description: Eight people suspected of planning terrorist bombings in France have told investigators that they have links to Iran's secret service and to Moslem fundamentalist groups in Lebanon, French officials said today.

title: U.S. TO PURSUE PROPOSAL TO BAR ALIENS WITH AIDS
description: The Reagan Administration intends to proceed with its plan to bar AIDS victims from immigrating to the United States, despite objections raised when the proposal was announced last year, Federal Health officials said today.

title: THATCHER OFF ON A SOVIET VISIT TOMORROW
description: A struggle over the mantle of British statesmanship is being joined this week as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Neil Kinnock, her rival from the Labor Party, prepare for meetings with leaders of the superpowers.

title: Rivers Hospitalized
description: David Rivers, who came back after a van accident in August to average 15.7 points and lead Notre Dame's basketball team to the final 16 in this year's National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, underwent surgery yesterday for a complication related to the injury. Surgeons at St. Joseph's Medical Center in South Bend, Ind., removed scar tissue that was twisting a portion of Rivers's bowel, according to John Heisler, an athletic department spokesman. Heisler said Rivers would be hospitalized for another five days.

title: Film Career Seminar
description: A one-day seminar for people interested in a career in film production will be held from 8:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. tomorrow at the Fashion Institute of Technology, Fred Pomerantz Art and Design Building, Seventh Avenue and 27th Street. Professionals will lead workshops on such topics as ''Casting and Extras Casting,'' ''Production Design,'' ''Costume Design'' and ''Associate Director.'' It costs $40 ($35 for students) and is sponsored by New York Women in Film. Information: 512-8022.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bullets 106, Celtics 103: Jay Vincent paced a 10-point run at the start of the third period to establish an 11-point Washington lead, and the Bullets held on to defeat the visiting Celtics last night, breaking a three-game losing streak. Vincent, who finished with 28 points, scored 8 of 10 points at the start of the second half. The Bullets moved to a 67-56 lead as the Celtics went nearly four minutes without scoring. The loss snapped Boston's four-game winning streak and extended to five its road losing streak. The Celtics got no closer than 5 points until Danny Ainge made a 3-point shot to trim the lead to 100-97 with 40 seconds left in the game.(AP) Hawks 120, Mavericks 112: In Atlanta, Dominique Wilkins scored 35 points and led the Hawks with 12 rebounds. The victory was the fourth straight and 15th in 16 games for Atlanta, the leader in the Central Division. The loss snapped a six-game winning streak for the Midwest-leading Dallas. Dallas led by 58-57 at halftime, but the Hawks scored the first 8 points of the second half to take the lead for good.(AP) N.H.L. Bruins 4, Oilers 1: Boston took a 4-0 lead and Bill Ranford shut out Edmonton, the league's highest-scoring team, 12 minutes 8 seconds into the third period. Boston got goals in the first period by Ray Bourque and Steve Kasper, in the second by Rick Middleton and in the third by Keith Crowder. Less than a minute after Crowder's 21st goal of the season at 11:33, Glenn Anderson ruined Ranford's bid for his fourth shutout by scoring his 33d goal. The Bruins improved their home unbeaten streak to five victories and a tie. Edmonton entered the game with 350 goals, an average of 4.7 per game. Wayne Gretzky had an 11-game scoring streak stopped.(AP) Kings 5, Sabres 3: Luc Robitaille and Jimmy Carson, Los Angeles rookies, each scored during a four-goal second period. Robitaille scored his 43d goal and Carson his 34th as the Kings ended a six-game road trip with their fourth victory against two losses. Roland Melanson was instrumental in goal, turning aside 38 shots. Steve Duchesne, Joe Paterson and Bob Bourne also scored for Los Angeles, while Buffalo got goals from Phil Housley, Mike Foligno and former King, Doug Smith. After spotting the Sabres a 2-0 lead in the first period, Los Angeles scored four unanswered goals in the second period.(AP) Flyers 3, Nordiques 2: Dave Poulin scored at 3:22 of overtime to give Philadelphia the victory at home. Poulin took a pass from Brian Propp behind the goal and slid a low shot past the Quebec goalie, Clint Malarchuk. Michel Goulet scored two power-play goals, including one in the third period, to bring Quebec into a tie with the Flyers. Goulet tied the score at 2-2 in the third period when he intercepted Propp's pass at center ice, broke into the Flyers' zone and fired a 15-foot wrist shot past Ron Hextall's glove at 8:58.(AP) Horse Racing Forest Fair Wins: Forest Fair ran past Irish Bear and then moved away to a 2 3/4-length victory yesterday in Aqueduct's $28,000 allowance feature for 3-year-olds. The Son of Naskra-Fairest Forest raced a mile on the fast track in 1:37 1/5 carrying 117 pounds under Jose Santos to register his second victory of the year in four starts. Forest Fair earned $16,800 for Gary Marano and returned $4.20 for $2 to win as the favorite in the field of six. Track Dance was runner-up, a neck ahead of Irish Bear. Tennis Becker Rallies to Win: Boris Becker of West Germany came from behind to overpower Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia, 3-6, 6-4, 6-4 and John McEnroe beat Thomas Hogstedt of Sweden, 7-6, 6-1 yesterday to reach the quarterfinals of the $315,000 Belgian Indoor Championships of tennis in Brussels. Becker produced powerful winning shots to gain a quarterfinal berth against Anders Jarryd of Sweden. Jarryd beat Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-2, 6-3. Earlier yesterday, Mats Wilander of Sweden swept past Mark Kratzmann of Australia, 6-0, 6-2, and will next play Gilad Bloom of Israel. Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland came from behind to defeat Mike Leach 2-6, 7-5, 6-3, and will face McEnroe. Jonas B. Svensson and Jan Gunnarsson, who qualified Wednesday, make up the fourth quarterfinal pairing.(AP) Golf Foyer Ties for Lead: Martha Foyer, playing in only her seventh tournament as a professional, birdied the final hole yesterday for a 69 to tie Penny Pulz for the lead in the opening round of $300,000 L.P.G.A. Turquoise Classic golf tournament in Phoenix. Foyer, 22 years old, who joined the tour a few weeks before her December graduation from Southern Methodist University, sank a 16-foot birdie putt on the par-4 18th hole of the 6,419-yard, par-73 Moon Valley Country Club course. Patti Rizzo, twice a winner since joining the tour five years ago, headlined a group a shot back at 70. Among the others were Marta Figueras-Dotti, Deb Richard, Lisa Young and Colleen Walker.(AP)

title: Butch Morris on Cornet
description: Butch Morris, a cornetist, and his trio will perform at 10:30, followed by the Bosho Trio at midnight, in the new-music series tonight at Tin Pan Alley, 220 West 49th Street (582-9376). Admission is free.

title: PIANO: MAURIZIO POLLINI AT CARNEGIE
description: ANY recital by Maurizio Pollini is enough to turn his fellow pianists green and last evening's performance at Carnegie Hall was no exception. There must have been faces in all shades from pale jade to emerald in the audience, especially after intermission when the Italian virtuoso turned his attention to Debussy's horrendously difficult 12 Etudes. Here, Mr. Pollini - with the composer's help, of course - seemed determined to show precisely all that can be accomplished at a keyboard by 10 fingers, two feet and one brain. The overflow audience, most of them apparently subscribers to what Shaw once referred to as the religion of the pianoforte, existed all night in a state of astonished delight.

title: Article 699587 -- No Title
description: A computer check of health-care providers has led to the recovery of $774,000 in previously unpaid New York City taxes, City Finance Commissioner Abraham Biderman said yesterday.

title: SLAIN VENDOR HAD A HISTORY OF MENTAL ILLS
description: Nicholas A. Bartlett, a street vendor who was shot and killed Feb. 28 by the police, after he was said to have attacked a police officer with a pipe, had a history of cocaine use and had been admitted to hospitals three times in 1983 for what a police report described as extremely violent behavior, senior law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: FILM: 'BLIND DATE,' A COMEDY BY BLAKE EDWARDS
description: THE perfect gag, as orchestrated with supreme professionalism by Blake Edwards, is something that proceeds in stages. It has a beginning, a middle, an end, and maybe even a postscript or two. The beginning is the anticipatory stage, as when Bruce Willis, playing the man in ''Blind Date'' who falls in love with a woman who should never drink, is seen with a hypodermic syringe, some whisky and a box of chocolates. The middle comes when the chocolates are delivered, and the young woman's mother soon remarks that her daughter seems to have eaten them all.

title: A PERSONALITY CHANGE SEEN FOR 14TH ST.
description: If impressionistic histories are to be trusted, Union Square and 14th Street to the west still bear a marked resemblance to the same area 50 years ago.

title: AUCTIONS
description: AFTER a visit to Pompeii in 1920, Armand-Albert Rateau, a French interior decorator, drew inspiration from the ancient Roman chairs and tables in iron he had seen, and he designed some extraordinary Art Deco bronze furniture, an example of which wil be auctioned tomorrow at Christie's.

title: How Labor Would Defend Britain
description: LEAD: Britain must choose between effective conventional defense and its own nuclear weapons, and we in the Labor Party hope that it will choose conventional defense, even if Britain has to take unilateral action to renounce the nuclear program.

title: Rescind Fee to Visit Statue, Bradley Urges
description: Senator Bill Bradley is sponsoring a bill to rescind the $1 admission fee imposed earlier this year on visitors to the Statue of Liberty.

title: 2 GROUPS, 2 DIVERGENT MUSIC VIEWS
description: THE newest jazz faces a terminology crisis. It's not ''mainstream jazz,'' since the mainstream has split more ways than the lower Mississippi; it's not ''free jazz,'' because the current generation of musicians has reclaimed and revamped all sorts of structures. To call it ''postmodern jazz'' makes it seem like some theoretical proposition rather than the songful, raucous, ambitious, heartfelt music it is. When pressed, some call it ''avant-gutbucket'' - but that still slights its melodic grace and large-scale forms. Terminology aside, though, there's no crisis in creativity - and this weekend brings two groups that are well worth hearing.

title: MUSTANG RECRUIT VISITING THE LIONS' DEN
description: Larry McElreavy looked at the future of Columbia football yesterday and told the big linebacker from Texas, ''We'll throw a lot of propaganda at you about this city.''

PINIELLA PONDERS: 10 OR 11 PITCHERS
description: The injuries have become small but annoying hurdles for Lou Piniella, who has overseen a training camp full of instability and uncertainty. Today, the Yankee manager thickened the plot even more when he said there was ''a good possibility'' he might take 11 pitchers to Detroit for the season opener that is less than two weeks away.

description: In provincial towns all over Vietnam, the Communist Party has been criticizing, purging and punishing errant party workers, according to frank and unusually detailed reports in the Vietnamese press.

description: b-After a loss of $375,000 for the quarter and a gain of $260,000 for the year from the sale of discontinued operations; and the year also includes net of $286,000 from discontinued operations.

title: GLITZ, FUNK AND VICTORIANA ENLIVEN NEW YORK'S DISCOS
description: IT is midnight on a recent Saturday. Outside the unmarked black entrance at 246 West 14th Street are about 100 people standing in silence, eyes fixed ahead on the cadre of bouncers who hold their fate.

title: SOUTHERN MISSISSIPPI WINS N.I.T. TITLE
description: The 3-point basket, which helped La Salle reach the final round of the National Invitation Tournament, deserted the Explorers last night, but not the Southern Mississippi long-range shooters.

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $29,000 and $1,761,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; and the 9 month also includes a gain of $3,820,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: First Interstate Seeks Acquisition
description: Less than two months after First Interstate Bancorp ended its bold attempt to buy the BankAmerica Corporation, its chairman, Joseph Pinola, is still looking for a good buy. He is also trying to prevent his company from being bought. Mr. Pinola said Wednesday that he is looking for ways to improve profitability and capital between now and 1991, when changes in Federal regulations will allow East Coast banks to buy banks in the lucrative California market.

title: COMMUNICATIONS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ORACLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The latest periods' results of $1,295,000 for the quarter and $3,701,000 for the 9 months of software production costs have been capitalized in accordance with Financial Accounting Standard No. 86. The share earnings reflect the 2-for- 1 stock split paid March 24.

title: OPERA: STUDENTS OFFER MASSENET'S 'CHERUBIN'
description: SQUELS were not unknown to art, even before ''Jaws'' and ''Rocky.'' Several characters in ''The Marriage of Figaro'' live on, for instance, though few except students of French literature know it. In Beaumarchais's third and final ''Figaro'' play, ''La Mere Coupable,'' Cherubino runs away with the Countess Almaviva and they have a baby, an outcome that should not really surprise anyone who hears the lovesick youngster pour out his heart to the Countess in Mozart's opera.

title: TRANSFORMING P.S. 332 INTO BROWNSVILLE'S STAR
description: When Anthony Amato took charge of an unruly public school in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn six years ago, he established a daily ritual. It was a military-style morning lineup of all the students in the schoolyard, followed by a silent procession to class.

title: NATIONWIDE CELLULAR SERVCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN NURSERY PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
STANDARD OIL REAPS PRAISE FOR CHANGES
description: In recent years, the Standard Oil Company came to be considered a stodgy giant, an especially cruel blow for the company founded by John D. Rockefeller in the early days of the oil industry.

title: Piedmont Shares Cleared for USAir
description: USAir Group Inc. said the Department of Transportation had allowed it to purchase and hold in a voting trust the 9.3 million Piedmont Aviation Inc. shares USAir is seeking in its $69-a-share tender offer.

title: 2 U.S. INTELLIGENCE UNITS ASSERT GORBACHEV IS REVIVING ECONOMY
description: United States intelligence agencies said in a report today that Soviet economic growth had accelerated under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but that his goals might be too ambitious.

title: Some Perils In Trade Bill
description: THE trade bill approved by the House Ways and Means Committee this week is a get-tough-but-not-too-tough measure. Its supporters hope it has enough teeth to scare other countries into opening their markets wider to American goods but is not so threatening as to provoke a retaliation and downward spiral in world trade.

title: New York Teen-Agers Face a Short Slide From Truant to Dropout
description: To the Editor:

title: Argyros Buying Padres
description: Joan Kroc, owner of the San Diego Padres, has agreed to sell the team to George Argyros, owner of the Mariners, who put the Seattle team on the market today as a step toward winning approval of the Padres transaction.

title: FROM SPAIN, A SCHEDULE OF DOUBLE FEATURES
description: The Third Festival of Films From Spain in New York will run through April 9 at the Guild 50th Street Theater, between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas. All of the films have English subtitles. Admission to each double bill is $6. Information: 757-2406. TODAY ''La Mitad del Cielo'' (''Half of Heaven,'' 1986), directed by Manuel Gutierrez Aragon. A young girl from northern Spain becomes a successful restaurateur in Madrid. At 12:35, 4:20 and 8:05 P.M. (Also April 3, same times.) ''27 Horas'' (''27 Hours,'' 1986), directed by Montxo Armendariz.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A STRIKING addition to the lower Fifth Avenue dining orbit is Sofi, formerly the Fifth Avenue Grill. Richard Lavin, owner of Lavin's on West 39th Street, has taken the soaring yet austere space and imparted an air of warmth and sophistication befitting the alluring new menu. Hand-rubbed blended pastel walls mimic Impressionistic painting, and everything in the room plays off them, from the oversize artwork to the flower-patterned table settings.

title: BROADWAY
description: ALMOST 20 years ago it was a film and before that it was a book, and now it's a musical. It's called ''No Way to Treat a Lady'' and the adaptation of the William Goldman novel will mark the return to the New York stage of Jack Hofsiss, the possessor of all kinds of awards - including a Tony - for his directing, and who was seriously injured in a swimming-pool accident in 1985.

title: AMERICAN SHARED HOSPITAL SERVICES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 3 MORE INQUIRIES ON STATE PAYROLL START
description: District Attorneys in Queens, Brooklyn and Rochester have begun inquiries into possible abuses of the New York State legislative payroll. That puts the number of district attorneys who have announced inquiries at six.

title: Dow Gains 9.10, to a Record 2,372.59
description: Stock prices took off again yesterday as a continued influx of foreign cash and optimism over the profits picture helped propel blue-chip issues into record territory.

title: SCRIPT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mining Merger
description: The Foote Mineral Company said it had signed a letter of intent to merge into the Rio Tinto-Zinc Corporation, a London-based mining and industrial-operations concern. The company said that at the time of the acquisition its assets will include only its lithium and ferrosilicon operations. Foote, which is 83 percent owned by the Newmont Mining Corporation, said it was in talks with several companies on the sale of is manganese operations. Foote said that Newmont had informally indicated that it would approve of the Rio Tinto proposal.

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Harvard Theatrical
description: ''Bye Bye Verdi,'' this year's offering by the Hasty Pudding Theatricals of Harvard University, will be performed this weekend at Norman Thomas High School, 111 East 33d Street. The musical comedy, featuring the ''Opera Winfrey Company'' and the ''Bland Ole Opry,'' will show ''what happens when country and classical culture collide,'' according to the producers. Sixteen undergraduates will appear in the annual production, the 139th since the student shows began. Shows are today at 8 P.M., tomorrow at 9 P.M. and Sunday at 5 P.M. Tickets range from $14.50 to $17.50. Information: 512-0115.

title: Weinberger in Wonderland
description: Congress has pumped close to $2 trillion into the military budget in the last six years, yet military commanders in the field continue to complain that they do not have enough resources to carry out a wartime mission. What's going on?

title: Americans in Bologna
description: Meanwhile in Bologna, another former N.B.A. scoring leader, Bob McAdoo, scored 29 points to lead Tracer of Milan to a 95-93 victory over Scavolini of Pesaro in the Cup of Italy tournament final. Charles Davis, another American, was the game's high scorer with 34 points for Scavolini.

title: VOGART CRAFTS CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 29
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE KILLJOY. By Anne Fine. 189 pages.

title: Court Overturns Police Directive On Drug Tests
description: An appeals court panel struck down today a Newark police directive requiring all members of the narcotics squad to submit to drug tests, saying it was an unreasonable search under the State Constitution and a ''significant interference with personal privacy and autonomy.''

title: NOW, SAY IT WITH NUMBERS
description: What's in a number? For thousands of telephone owners it might be a special word, as they sign up for the latest in self-expression: a vanity telephone number.

title: 'English Disease' And a Novel Cure
description: Soccer authorities in London have adopted a plan they hope will be a further palliative for what has become known as the ''English disease.'' Beginning with the new season this summer, in the most radical move yet to curb the fan hooliganism that has brought disgrace to the nation, each of the 92 professional English soccer clubs will be required to set aside at least half of its stadium for home-team supporters, who must show special club-issued membership cards in order to enter the segregated section. Visiting fans, believed to be the instigators of most soccer violence, will be relegated to other areas, where they can be watched closely by the police.

title: LANCER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ONE JUSTICE SETS A TACK OF HER OWN
description: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the Supreme Court's first woman Justice, continued to steer her own, very independent course in her opinion on the Court's first decision involving affirmative action for women.

title: N.F.L. UNION OPENS MEETING
description: The National Football League Players Association opened its first convention in five years today with four past union presidents discussing their experiences.

title: Kodak Buying Biotech Stake
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it would acquire a 16 percent equity interest in Genencor Inc., a biotechnology company based here that specializes in industrial products. Genencor, formed in 1982 as a joint venture between Genentech Inc. and Corning Glass Works, was spun off in 1983 and has been owned equally by the founding companies and Staley Continental Inc. since 1984.

title: NORTH'S SECRETARY TESTIFIES BEFORE GRAND JURY
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North's former secretary testified twice in recent weeks before a Federal grand jury that is nearing a decision on whether to seek charges of obstruction of justice against the colonel, according to people with knowledge of the investigation.

title: 18 ARE SEIZED IN ILLEGAL USE OF MOBILE PHONES
description: In a Federal attack on a crime made possible by the latest technology, 18 New Yorkers were arrested yesterday on charges of using illegally altered memory chips in their mobile telephones so they could make calls without being charged for them.

title: A NEW PLAY'S CHARACTERS TRAVERSE TIME AND LINGO
description: In Eric Overmyer's fanciful comedy ''On the Verge or the Geography of Yearning,'' three Victorian women set out with pith helmets, butterfly nets, lemon drops, shepherd's pie and other quaint gear to explore unknown territory.

title: FOR YANKEES' FANS IN BRONX, TV SCHEDULE IS BUSH LEAGUE
description: Opening day is a couple of weeks off, but already fans in the Bronx, home to the Yankees, have been shut out of most of the team's season.

title: P&F INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $571,000 for the quarter and $1,347,000 for the year. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $496,000 for the quarter and $1,107,000 for the year. The 1985 shares adjusted to 1-for-5 reverse stock split, Oct. 1, 1986.

title: Going the Route
description: The Indiana University basketball team has a lot of devoted fans in the Hoosier State, but few are quite as devoted as Michael Wilson. In order to attend the Final Four in New Orleans, where Indiana plays Nevada-Las Vegas tomorrow, he's giving up his job.

title: SECOND PLACE IS PRIZE IN BITTER CHICAGO RACE
description: On the surface, it might seem that this city's current mayoral campaign is simply about electing a chief executive.

title: 2 INDICTMENTS SPUR INQUIRY ON JAIL STRIFE
description: A correction officer and an inmate at Rikers Island were indicted yesterday in the beating death of another inmate, prompting the city Department of Investigation to open an inquiry into violence in city jails.

title: CENTRAL PARK RACE
description: The annual 10-kilometer race in Central Park sponsored by Perrier and the New York Road Runner Club is to begin at 11 A.M. tomorrow at 69th Street and East Drive. It ends, 6.2 miles later, at Tavern on the Green, West 67th Street and Central Park West. The entry fee is $6. Information: 860-4455.

title: SCHOLARS TACKLE U.S. BUSINESS
description: American business is coming under unprecedented scholarly scrutiny.

title: GATT Critical Of U.S. Goals
description: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said in a report prepared for release today that Washington's obsession with its huge foreign trade deficit was misplaced because the real economic threat lay in the big Federal budget deficit.

title: Soviet Grain Imports
description: The International Wheat Council said today that it had increased its estimate for Soviet grain imports for the year ending June 30 by 3 million metric tons, to a total of 29 million tons. The forecast that the Soviet Union will import 29 million tons of grain, up from a previous estimate of 26 million, is still down from last year's total of 30 million. The United States Department of Agriculture has forecast the Soviet Union's 1986-87 imports at 26 million tons.

title: SANDUSKY PLASTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $179,000 from prepayment of certain debt. The company went public in April 1986.

title: PLAINS RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $230,000.

title: No Headline
description: Ray Floyd and Seve Ballesteros, two of the world's premier golfers, were assessed a total of seven penalty strokes today during a fiasco of mental mistakes in the first round of the Tournament Players Championship.

title: SOME POLES WARY OF SOVIET POLICIES
description: While some Poles in and out of Government are privately flirting with the notion that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is leading this part of the world to a new consciousness, the most pervasive public attitude aroused by the Soviet leaders' policies has been a hesitant wariness.

title: Plea of Not Guilty Filed In Wife's Death
description: An airline pilot accused of murdering his wife and chopping her body to pieces pleaded not guilty in Superior Court yesterday and requested a jury trial.

title: MONEY FUND ASSETS FALL
description: Assets of the nation's 379 money market mutual funds decreased $1.19 billion, to $236.16 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 91 institutional funds were down $549.7 million, to $65.51 billion. Assets of the 196 general purpose funds were down $496.2 million, to $62 billion. The 92 broker-dealer funds fell $142.7 million, to $108.65 billion.

title: Macao's Way of Life Gets a Grace Period
description: Residents of this Portuguese colony on the south China coast will be able to travel freely, elect local leaders, and continue their way of life for 50 years after Macao returns to Chinese control in 1999, according to the text of the agreement between Portugal and China on the enclave's future.

title: A Kenny Rogers Pastiche On CBS Tonight
description: Kenny Rogers likes people who work for a living; he tells us so in ''Kenny Rogers: Working America,'' a kind of video-travelogue, interview program and concert performance on CBS at 9 o'clock tonight. It's a slender program, and although Mr. Rogers will never be confused with Bruce Springsteen, who also mines working-class territory, he is as amiable as can be. If his singing voice doesn't enthrall you - talk about vocal mannerisms - his personality may.

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICAN COS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
U.S. EXAMINES PROSTITUTES AND AIDS VIRUS
description: The widest study yet of AIDS virus infection among prostitutes in the United States has found that 98 of 835 female prostitutes tested in seven cities were virus carriers, according to a Federal report released at a scientific meeting here today.

title: SHOE-TOWN INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $785,000 for the latest year and $59,000 for 1985.

title: COMSTOCK GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $623,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $1,910,000 for the year.

title: NEW AFFIRMATIVE ACTION RULING CULMINATES BROAD REJECTION OF ADMINISTRATION'S STANCE
description: The Supreme Court's broad approval Wednesday of affirmative action in the workplace was the fifth in a series of rulings that have shredded legal objections raised by the Reagan Administration and by white men.

title: New Chief Named At Acme-Cleveland
description: The Acme-Cleveland Corporation, a maker of industrial tools, said yesterday that it had named David L. Swift president, chief executive and director.

title: SPANISH 'LAW OF DESIRE'
description: PEDRO ALMODOVAR'S ''Law of Desire'' begins with a scene in which a film maker directs another man to perform a very graphic sexual act before the camera, a sequence in which the film maker's reactions are monitored as closely as the actor's. The film, it develops, will turn into a big hit for the film maker, who is already something of a celebrity. ''Law of Desire'' graduates from that sensationalized opening to a breezy study of the famous director Pablo Quintero (Eusebio Poncela), who lives quite the high life in modern Madrid. Casual drug use and casual homosexual encounters are all in a day's work for Pablo, who exists quite happily in a film devoid of moral opprobrium.

title: Advertising; MAGAZINE ADS UP 2.7%
description: In February, the Publishers Information Bureau reports, its member magazines carried 12,028 pages of advertising, an increase of 2.7 percent from the same period last year. Revenues were up 5.1 percent, to $401.5 million.

title: Magazine Editor Quits Post
description: The editor of Manhattan,inc., Jane Amsterdam, resigned yesterday along with the magazine's managing editor and art director, according to writers and editors at the publication.

title: QUANTECH ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $99,209 for the quarter and $202,097 for the 9 months.

title: PATIENT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $764,000 for the latest year and $5,152,000 for 1985.

title: FILM: 'TASIO,' A LOOK AT VILLAGE LIFE IN SPAIN'S BASQUE COUNTY
description: THE small Spanish village at the foot of the hills of Urbasa is in Basque country. It is psychologically as far from the Basque industrial center of Bilbao as it is from the trendy night life of fast-moving Madrid. Here Tasio, the hero of the first feature written and directed by the Basque film maker Montxo Armendariz, is born, matures, comes of age, takes a wife, raises his child.

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The year-ago quarter results include a gain of more than 5 cents a share from the sale of land.

title: DEAVER PLEADS NOT GUILTY TO U.S. PERJURY CHARGES
description: Michael K. Deaver, who left the White House to form a lobbying concern, pleaded not guilty to perjury charges today at his arraignment in Federal District Court.

title: Spinks-Cooney June 15
description: Butch Lewis, the promoter, announced last night that the Michael Spinks-Gerry Cooney heavyweight fight would take place June 15 at the Atlantic City Convention Center, adjacent to Trump Plaza. Earlier this week, Lewis was considering the Atlantic City site and Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., for the bout. Wednesday, Lewis said, Steve Hyde and Mark Etess, executives at Trump Plaza, phoned him with a site-fee offer of $5 million from Donald Trump, owner of Trump Plaza.

title: THEATER: FAMILY TIES IN WILSON'S 'FENCES
description: TO hear his wife tell it, Troy Maxson, the middle-aged Pittsburgh sanitation worker at the center of ''Fences,'' is ''so big'' that he fills up his tenement house just by walking through it. Needless to say, that description could also apply to James Earl Jones, the actor who has found what may be the best role of his career in August Wilson's new play, at the 46th Street Theater.

title: EX-TREASURY CHIEF ADMITS TAX FRAUD AND BANKING CRIME
description: A former Secretary of the Treasury, Robert B. Anderson, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of illegally operating a Caribbean bank and evading taxes on personal income, including $79,000 he received as a consultant to the Unification Church.

title: WOMAN IN LIAISON IS FEARFUL OF FALSE IMPACT ON RELIGIOUS
description: The former church secretary who had a sexual tryst with the Rev. Jim Bakker seven years ago said today that she did not want believers to think that sort of thing was commonplace.

title: 2d Putnam Youth Commits Suicide
description: A teen-age girl committed suicide yesterday, the second suicide by a teen-ager in this small Putnam County town in as many days, the police said.

title: Final 4 Coaches Clash in Style
description: The Runnin' Rebels of Nevada-Las Vegas, who could not be more aptly named, and the conservative yet efficient Indiana Hoosiers are at opposite ends of the Final Four. In the middle is one team finally playing to its potential -Syracuse - and another, Providence, enjoying a success beyond anyone's fantasies.

title: Some Calcium Supplements Are Found to Be Ineffective
description: About one out of three calcium supplements, which many women take to strengthen their bones, pass through the stomach before they can take effect, a university study has concluded.

title: 50 Trapped in Ecuador Mine
description: A cave-in at a remote gold mine in southern Ecuador buried 50 miners today, the police said. There were no confirmed casualty figures, but the prefect of the province estimated the number of dead at 30. The disaster occurred at the Nambija mine, on a mountainside four hours by foot from Zamora, about 435 miles south of Quito.

title: Advertising; BOSTON CHARITY FUND
description: Claiming a first, the Advertising Club of Greater Boston has established a charitable fund to be used to help minorities enter the communications field, support the fight against illiteracy and promote other community projects. It will be administered by the Boston Foundation, which has assets of $137 million.

title: MAN FOUND HANGED IN A TRANSVAAL POLICE CELL
description: A young man jailed under South Africa's emergency laws was found hanged in a police cell in the Transvaal early today, the police said.

title: MARTIN LAWRENCE LIMITED EDITIONS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
PROSECUTORS TO ASK DEATH PENALTY IN TORTURE CASE
description: Prosecutors said today that they would seek the death penalty against a man charged with kidnapping, raping and torturing four young women and killing one in a dungeon-like basement of a house whose walls were partly papered with $1 and $5 bills.

title: CUOMO BACKING A COMPROMISE ON TRANSIT AID
description: Governor Cuomo today endorsed a compromise financing plan for more than $8.6 billion in mass-transit improvements, ending a two-month political impasse that has delayed several key transit spending projects.

title: The Espo League
description: Here is the points-per-game standing of N.H.L. forwards since they were either obtained or dealt by Phil Esposito in a trading spree he undertook soon after being named Ranger general manager last July. (Players in capital letters are those Esposito acquired, in regular print those he shipped).

title: WEATHER SERVICE TO DROP NASA FOR SATELLITES
description: The National Weather Service is going to use private companies to launch its satellites, ending more than 25 years of dependence on the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IN other parts of the country, the signs of spring have to do with the great outdoors. Birds sing, lawns turn green, crocuses bloom and animals fall in love.

title: ALLIED RESEARCH ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Prospect of Sanctions Worries the Japanese
description: Japanese officials and semiconductor industry representatives expressed concern today over reports that the United States would announce sanctions against Japan for failing to comply with a semiconductor agreement. But they said they had received no official word of the decision.

title: GREEK PARADE
description: Floats, bands and marchers in ethnic costume will be heading up Fifth Avenue on Sunday during the annual Greek Independence Day Parade. It begins at 1 P.M. at 61st Street and travels up the avenue to 79th Street. The parade is sponsored by the Federation of Hellenic Societies of Greater New York. Information: (718)335-2468.

title: ISLANDERS SUCCUMB TO LOWLY CANUCKS
description: With Bryan Trottier scoring his team's goals in another game without his favorite linemate, Mike Bossy, the Islanders lost by 5-2 tonight to the Vancouver Canucks, the team with the worst record in the National Hockey League. And a team that had not beaten the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum in nearly seven years.

title: FILM: 'PRETTYKILL,' A CRIME STORY
description: WHAT'S showing at the U.A. Twin and other theaters beginning today? Prostitutes with diction of gold: ''My clients expect a certain level of style.'' A black-white cop team. Drug busts, kinky sex, mother love, murder and mayhem. You say you've seen it all before? Sure, but perhaps not so foolishly put together as in ''Prettykill.''

title: HOOSIER FANS START AT AN EARLY AGE
description: The Hoosier corner of the global village will find it difficult to stock enough AA batteries to power all the miniature televisions to satisfy all the hysteria that will take place this weekend.

title: CANADIAND ASK U.S. TO HONOR THEIR VIETNAM WAR VETERANS
description: While American veterans of the Vietnam War say they are gradually gaining respect for their service, a small group of Canadian veterans of that war assembled here today said they have continued to feel rejected.

title: OFFICIAL POLISH UNIONS IN DEAL ON FOOD PRICES
description: Poland's official labor unions struck a deal today with the Government, pledging support for greater work discipline in exchange for assurances that food price rises would be lower than planned.

title: The Chiefs Retreat
description: Does the Soviet Union really have a lead in the technology needed to make nuclear warheads?

title: 'Ozawa,' on 13, Shows Conductor in Action
description: TONIGHT'S ''Great Performances'' presentation on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock is ''Ozawa,'' one of the last joint ventures of the sibling film makers Albert and David Maysles (''Gimme Shelter,'' ''Grey Gardens''). David Maysles died last January. The trademarks are all here: the hand-held camera, tight close-ups, an uncanny ability for getting subjects to relax, and an underlying sense of restraint. The documentary conveys a good idea of how any internationally renowned conductor might have to cope with a grueling schedule and the more obvious demands of private life. It is less successful, however, in penetrating the professionally polished shell of Seiji Ozawa himself. Maestro Ozawa, who seems to spend a good deal of time cultivating the public image of a Far Eastern Peter Pan, remains elusive.

title: PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in June 1986.

title: ALBANY ACCORD REACHED ON TAX CUT
description: With the deadline for enacting a new state budget only five days away, Governor Cuomo announced today that his administration and the Legislature had reached agreement on the overall amount of a state tax cut but not on specific rates or deductions.

title: YOUTHS LANGUISH IN DIAGNOSTIC CENTERS
description: Teen-agers with nowhere left to go have been languishing for months or even years in city-run foster care centers that were intended for stays of no more than 90 days.

title: Boston Edison In Shake-Up
description: Two of the Boston Edison Company's senior officers will take early retirement, the utility announced yesterday, in what analysts called an effort to improve relations with Massachusetts regulators and focus more attention on energy conservation.

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $13,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $258,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes an extraordinary charge of $85,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $235,000 for the 9 months.

title: Playoff Payments Raised by N.H.L.
description: The National Hockey League announced yesterday that each member of this year's Stanley Cup-winning team would receive $25,000, an increase of $5,000 from last year, A player on a team finishing first in its division and compiling the most points among all teams during the regular season could earn up to $35,000.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: ''RESTAURANT X has a new look and a new menu! Come and try us,'' crows the typical publicity release that arrives on a food writer's desk. Often this sort of invitation is an 11th-hour effort by a restaurant Titanic to attract help, hoping that by rearranging the silverware it can regain ballast.

title: 3 Killed on Charity Walk
description: A truck struck a car trailing a group of University of Mississippi sorority sisters taking part in a charity walk today, killing three students and injuring 13, the authorities said. A one-ton truck hauling a hay baler crashed into the car behind the walkers, pushing it into the crowd, Ed Meek, a university spokesman said. Two students were in critical condition with head injuries at the Regional Medical Center in Memphis and nine others were admitted to the Oxford-Lafayette Medical Center. The students, members of Chi Omega, were participating in the walk-a-thon for the Mississippi Kidney Foundation.

title: FILM: CHRISTOPHER REEVE STARS IN 'STREET SMART'
description: ''STREET SMART'' tells of a facile, blowhard journalist who's corrupt enough to fictionalize an entire feature story. But it is not the predictable tale of this man's lapse and subsequent redemption - and that's what makes it interesting. Instead, ''Street Smart'' follows Jonathan Fisher (Christopher Reeve) from his first misstep into the web of trouble spun out of his initial set of lies. It grows into an engrossing study of loose talk, weakness and seduction, played out in both the world of high-powered journalism and the seediest corners of Times Square.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
UNIVERSAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Universal said the latest year loss was primarily attributable to a one- time charge of $716,000 in the first quarter of 1986 related to a contractual obligation to the recently deceased former chairman of the company.

title: COMCOA INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 25
A TINY 'UTOPIA' ON L.I. FIGHTS OVER GROWTH
description: Two years ago, while campaigning to become the first mayor of this tiny, mostly industrial, community, Warren A. Raymond became fond of telling how the village received its lyrical name.

title: TREASURY MAY REVISE ITS BORROWING
description: Faced with the possibility of a smaller budget deficit and reduced financing needs, the Treasury plans to re-evaluate the maturity, size and frequency of Government borrowings.

title: Women's Final 4 Tonight
description: The Texas Longhorns are the defending national champions playing on their home court, but their coach said that another women's basketball championship is not a sure thing.

title: Bonds Regain Part of Losses
description: Treasury note and bond prices yesterday recovered some of their losses of earlier in the week, as the Government completed a three-part, $25 billion note financing.

title: British Trade Surplus Grows
description: Britain registered a balance-of-payments surplus equivalent to $601.6 million in February, the biggest current account surplus in 14 months, the Trade and Industry Department announced today.

title: OBOE AND PIANO
description: Heinz Holliger, an oboist, and Andras Schiff, a pianist, will play a joint recital of works by Mozart, Debussy and others Sunday night at 8 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Admission is $12. Information: 570-3949.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It sort of settled down to just trading arms for hostages, and that's a little like paying ransom to a kidnapper. If you do it, then the kidnapper's just encouraged to go kidnap someone else.'' - President Reagan. [ A12:3. ]

title: BRENNER COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
ART: MICHAEL LEKAKIS
description: MICHAEL LEKAKIS'S work was most recently seen in ''The Third Dimension: Sculpture of the New York School,'' an exhibition organized in late 1984 by Lisa Philips at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Now the Kouros Gallery (23 East 73d Street) has organized a good-sized retrospective spanning from the 1930's to 1984, when Mr. Lekakis had a stroke. At Kouros the sculpture is installed, not always to its best advantage, throughout the foyer and several floors of an old town house. But it is there to be seen (through April 4), along with numerous drawings, and it sums up a lifelong dedication to an organic-based abstraction and to wood carving.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $6,548,000 and $150,897,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $235,313,000 for the quarter and $342,867,000 for the year.

title: LACROIX: HIGH FASHION, CORPORATE INTRIGUE
description: As a boy, Christian Lacroix dreamed of becoming Christian Dior. This week the young designer, who modernized couture with a sense of humor and returned it to pre-eminence in Paris fashion, took an important step toward realizing that dream.

title: Advertising; PEOPLE
description: Kenneth A. Glaser has been appointed senior vice president, director of business development at Muller Jordan Weiss.

title: Brazil Exchanges Struck
description: A nationwide strike by bank workers shut down the stock exchanges in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo, and organizers said participation in the walkout was growing.

title: Sampson Returns
description: The Houston Rockets, losers in six games to the Boston Celtics in last season's National Basketball Association championship series, are looking for help for this year's playoffs, which begin in a couple of weeks. On Wednesday, Ralph Sampson, the 7-foot-4-inch forward who has missed 25 games, participated in his first workout since undergoing arthroscopic knee surgery. He is expected to start playing full-time next week. The Rockets are also trying to lure George Gervin, the four-time N.B.A. scoring champion with San Antonio, back from the Italian League, where he has been playing this season for Banco di Roma. ''It's a unique case where we could help him and he could help us over the short haul,'' said Ray Patterson, the Rockets' general manager. ''Here's a guy who can roll out of bed and score 20 points. He would give us a tremendous lift at the big guard spot.'' Robert Reid, the Rockets' big guard, is shooting only 40.7 percent from the field, and the Rockets lost two other players, Lewis Lloyd and Mitchell Wiggins, who were banned from the N.B.A. in January because of drug use. Contacted in Rome by The San Antonio Express-News, Gervin said he was happy playing in Italy but left room for negotiation. ''I'm a businessman first, and I have to consider an offer like that,'' he said.

title: ALTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a non-recurring loss of $788,000 which includes the closure of facilities, inventory writeoffs and a gain from the sale of real estate. c-Net income

title: MUSIC FOR A BRIDGE
description: A chamber arrangement of Tobias Picker's ''Keys to the City,'' originally written for piano and full orchestra to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Brooklyn Bridge in 1983, will have its world premiere Sunday afternoon at 5 at Alice Tully Hall. It will be played by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center; also on the program are works by Handel, Brahms, and Beethoven. Admission is $17.50. Information: 362-1911.

title: SYRIA SAID TO WARN PARTY OF GOD ON CAPTIVES
description: Arab diplomats here said today that Syria had told a pro-Iranian group that it must release its foreign hostages or Syrian troops would take measures necessary to free them.

title: Lawmakers Protesting E.P.A. Asbestos Action
description: A bipartisan group of legislators contends that the Environmental Protection Agency's schedule for distributing funds to schools for the cleanup of asbestos does not comply with a law signed by President Reagan last week.

title: On Giving Women a Break
description: Imagine that you are an employer who wants to promote more women. Maybe you think that would be good for business; or that lots of able women are available; or that it would be the decent thing to do. Until Wednesday, the law made things hard for you. If you promoted a woman over a man, you opened yourself to being sued for discrimination by the man. Or you could promote women as correctives for prior discrimination. But by thus pleading guilty to past bias, you would open yourself to discrimination suits from women.

title: SENATE DUE TO VOTE ON BANK BILL
description: The Senate tonight headed toward passage of wide-ranging bank legislation, and is expected to take final action on Friday.

title: First Amendment Rights Are Not for Everybody
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Are the Suggested Names for F.B.I. Chief
description: In helping choose the next Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is bound to hurt a lot of feelings.

title: A.T.&T. IS VACATING MUCH OF ITS TOWER
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company plans to move most of its headquarters staff from its signature office building on Madison Avenue to a suburban complex it owns in Basking Ridge, N.J., the company said yesterday.

title: MILASTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NETS DEFEAT BULLS
description: Michael Jordan, the leading scorer in professional basketball, performed typically tonight with 40 points, but the Nets played inspiringly and edged the Chicago Bulls, 109-107, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: INSIDE
description: Satellite Launching Fails

title: CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split effective Feb. 16, 1987.

title: Smoking in Parks Is Out, Too
description: Smokers looking for a breath of fresh air along with their cigarette will not find it in community parks in Waterford Township. Officials unanimously banned smoking in the southeastern Minnesota township's two parks, its parking lot and inside the township hall. ''Smoking is a killer,'' John Dudley, the township Supervisor said Wednesday. ''Whether it's done inside a building or outside, it's a killer. You might as well call a spade a spade.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: BankAmerica's Rating Is Cut
description: Moody's Investor Services Inc. said today that it had downgraded debt ratings of the BankAmerica Corporation and its Overseas Finance Corporation, citing concerns about the company's prospects for profits in the medium term and its exposure to Latin American debt.

title: DEMOCRATS IN CONGRESS MOLD DEFICIT PLANS WITH TAX RISES
description: Despite the continued opposition of President Reagan, Congressional Democrats moved cautiously ahead today with plans for reducing the budget deficit that include tax increases.

title: DEAN MARTIN'S SON IS DEAD IN JET
description: The remains of Dean Paul Martin, the oldest son of the entertainer Dean Martin, and another flier were found Wednesday by rescue workers in the San Bernardino Mountains where their fighter plane was lost six days ago, the Air National Guard said.

title: A Homeless Man Is Remembered With Dignity
description: It was an ordinary paid newspaper notice but behind it lay an extraordinary sentiment.

title: Market Place; Big Comeback For Big Blue
description: THE stock action of the International Business Machines Corporation was one of the market's big disappointments in 1986. The shares fell 22.8 percent and finished the year at $120. In January, after the company issued a lackluster earning report, the stock traded at $115.75 - its lowest price since August 1984.

title: Soviet Reservoir Is Polluted
description: The newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda said today that the Rybinsk Reservoir on the Volga River was polluted last winter by a chemical spill. The paper said oil products and other chemicals had spilled into the reservoir from a coke-chemical plant producing ammonia, phenol and benzene. Residents of the steel center of Cherepovets said the city's water had turned into a ''muddy, dark-brown liquid with the smell of oil.

title: Soviet Psychiatrist Says Son Has Been Released
description: The International Association for Human Rights said here today that Ivan Koryagin, the son of a dissident Soviet psychiatrist, had been freed from labor camp, and the family had been told to apply for emigration.

title: Hope, at Last, for the Boarder Babies
description: Finally, New York City has announced a humane plan to keep abandoned or abused infants who are otherwise healthy from languishing in city hospitals. City and state officials, though pressed by a lawsuit, nevertheless deserve credit for this important step. They will deserve even more when the plan is carried out.

title: Party Leader in South Korea Given Broad Political Powers
description: President Chun Doo Hwan has given Roh Tae Woo, the head of his governing party, broad powers to seek a resolution of stalled political talks on constitutional revisions. The move was seen here as an indication that Mr. Chun wants Mr. Roh to succeed him when his presidential term ends in 1988.

title: B.P. SEEKS BALANCE OF STANDARD
description: The British Petroleum Company announced today that it would offer $7.4 billion for the 45 percent of the Standard Oil Company it does not already own.

title: VANGUARD TECHNOLOGIES INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FALCON CABLE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges which related to the early retirement of debentures. The company said the results for 1986 were not comparable, since they reflected high depreciation, amortization and interest expenses as well as extraordinary charges.

title: JOHN C. GRISWOLD
description: John C. Griswold, a retired executive vice president of W. R. Grace & Company, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: Phils Get Cowley
description: Troubled by a nagging injury to Kevin Gross, the Philadelphia Phillies yesterday obtained another right-handed starting pitcher by sending Gary Redus, an outfielder, to the Chicago White Sox for Joe Cowley. Gross suffered a herniated disc early in spring training, and although he was making his regular exhibition game appearances, the team physican, Dr. Phillip Marone, said Gross could be bothered by the injury all season. Cowley, 28, topped the White Sox staff last season with 11 victories, including a no-hitter against the California Angels. He had an 11-11 record with a 3.88 earned run average after starting the season in the minors.

title: FILM FESTIVAL FOR 3 VANTAGE POINTS
description: Three very different sorts of film festivals open this weekend in different parts of town.

title: STARS OF '86 HAVE YET TO GLITTER
description: The 10 horses who won Eclipse Awards as last year's champions and the seven who won Breeders' Cup races on Nov. 1 have accounted for the grand total of one victory in the last four months.

title: Afghan Jets Resume Raids On Town at Pakistan Border
description: Afghan jets bombed and rocketed this town near the Afghan border and Moslem guerrilla bases just across the frontier today, killing at least five people and wounding eight, Pakistani military officers said.

title: POLL FINDS DOLE GAINS ON BUSH IN G.O.P. BID
description: Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader has gained increasing support for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination and now trails Vice President Bush by 14 percentage points, according to the latest Gallup poll.

title: 85% U.S. STAKE IN CONRAIL SOLD FOR $1.6 BILLION
description: After a decade of Federal stewardship, the Consolidated Rail Corporation, made up of the bankrupt ruins of several of the Northeast's largest freight railroads, was sold to private investors yesterday.

title: More Expected To Quit Busch
description: More departures are expected soon at the Anheuser-Busch Companies, industry officials and analysts said today.

title: Judge Keeps Alive Hunt Family's Suits
description: A Federal judge today denied motions by several banks to dismiss two lawsuits brought against them by the wealthy Hunt brothers.

title: Illiteracy Fund Use Is Faulted
description: More than half the money that the Education Department says is available to fight adult illiteracy is earmarked for vocational education and grants for disabled citizens, a Congressional study says.

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $21,680,000 from the sale of the Virginia Service Territory.

title: REAGAN LIKENS IRAN POLICY TO 'RANSOM'
description: President Reagan said today that his policy of selling arms to Iran had become ''a little like paying ransom to a kidnapper.''

title: TELEVISION UNIONS VIEW WRITERS' STRIKE AS PORTENT
description: The strike by the Writers Guild of America against the ABC and CBS television networks is small as strikes go - only 525 people. It is unobtrusive as well, failing to shut down the networks or even make a discernible difference on their nightly news programs.

title: DANCE FARE MIXES THE FRESH AND FAMILIAR
description: IT was once assumed with some frequency that dancers just traipsed out onto the stage and moved as the spirit drove them.

title: Slashed Model Cross-Examined In Attack Trial
description: A Manhattan model whose face was slashed with a razor blade last summer was portrayed by a defense lawyer yesterday as an ambitious woman who used men, and she was reminded on the stand of a graphic sexual vulgarity used to describe her minutes before the attack.

title: QUESTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges for discontinued operations of $594,347 for the quarter and $1,060,848 for the year. c-Net income

title: Dance Career Topics
description: Careers, economic survival and work after performing will be discussed in ''Career Opportunities and Concerns for Dancers,'' a free conference from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Sunday at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center, 1515 Broadway, at 44th Street. After the conference, which is open to the public, a studio performance will be presented. Among those participating in the conference are Carmen de Lavallade, Gail Conrad, Jennifer Muller, George Faison, Suki Schorer and Charles Reinhart, director of the American Dance Festival. Information: 997-1950.

title: HEALTHMATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Let Ruling on Foreign Ships in U.S. Ports Stand
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTOMATED LANGUAGE PROESSING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. LETS INDIA BUY COMPUTER
description: The United States has formally notified the Indian Government that it will be permitted to buy an American-made supercomputer, but only a model of relatively limited power, according to Government and industry officials.
