The supercomputer would be the first shipped to a nation with strong ties to the Soviet Union.

title: Debt Offering By Time Inc.
description: Time Inc. is offering $250 million of 8 3/4 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2017 at a price of 99.055 to yield 8.84 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a tax credit of $142,000. c-Net loss

title: Comings and Goings
description: After reviewing tapes showing the Philadelphia Flyers' Dave Brown high-sticking Tomas Sandstrom of the Rangers in the closing seconds of a game March 17, the National Hockey League has suspended Brown for five games, all the Flyers have left in the regular season. . . . Chris Washburn, the Golden State Warriors' rookie who entered a drug abuse treatment center on Jan. 28 and has missed 25 games since then, will be re-activated for Saturday's game against Utah. Purvis Short, a forward, was placed on the disabled list because of a pulled thigh muscle, creating the roster opening for Washburn. . . . Chuck Swenson, an assistant coach at Duke the last seven years after having been Bobby Knight's assistant at Indiana, has been selected to become head basketball coach at William & Mary, replacing Barry Parkhill, whose contract was not renewed after four years, the last two with 5-22 and 8-20 records. . . . Dan Devine, former head football coach at Arizona State, Missouri, Notre Dame and Green Bay, will rejoin Arizona State as director of a new campus program to combat substance abuse. For the last five years, Devine has been chief executive officer for the Sun Angel Foundation, the school's main booster club.

title: DATA ARCHITECTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Home Court Handicap
description: To the Editor:

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: James Williams Ensemble Celebrates Wynton Kelly, Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street, third floor (505-5660). The Jazz Center's ''Celebrating Late Great Black Composers and Artists'' series is now in its fourth season and, after paying tribute to such superstars as Duke Ellington, Count Basie and Charles Mingus, it is now getting to some of those who are not often the subject of such acclaim. The pianist Wynton Kelly, who died in 1971 and had been a member of the Miles Davis and Wes Montgomery groups, is one who particularly deserves such treatment before his memory fades. For James Williams, Wynton Kelly was one of his prime influences. Mr. Williams's schooling as a pianist has included the Berklee College of Music and Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers, with whom he played for four years. Leading a trio, a quartet and a quintet, Mr. Williams will play such Wynton Kelly compositions as ''Sassy,'' ''Temperance'' and ''Action'' as well as pop standards that Kelly played. Performances tonight and tomorrow are at 9 and 11. There is a $10 admission for which one can stay for both sets. $ ? * * *

title: TWO CENTURIES OF ITALIAN PAINTING IN MET EXHIBITION
description: EMILIA-ROMAGNA bridges northern and central Italy.

title: HARVARD TROUNCED BY NORTH DAKOTA
description: Another chance to win its first national title in hockey escaped Harvard tonight when North Dakota defeated the Crimson, 5-2, in a National Collegiate Athletic Association semifinal.

title: ANGOLA REBELS ON OFFER ON RAIL LINK
description: Anti-Communist rebels in Angola said today that they would allow the Angolan Government to reopen the Benguela railroad, a move that would help the black countries of southern Africa reduce their economic dependence on South Africa.

title: ADVANCED COMPUTER TECHIQUES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
A RADIO CALL-IN SHOW BRINGS PERES AND ARABS A BIT CLOSER
description: It was not your usual radio talk show, but with the Israeli Foreign Minister, Shimon Peres, as the telephone host and the Arab world as his call-in audience, how could it have been?

title: ANTIQUES MARTS
description: Three piers along the Hudson River will be transformed into antiques marts this weekend at the Triple Pier Expo, 12th Avenue, from West 48th to 55th Streets. The event, sponsored by Stella shows, will feature items ranging from designer clothers to Art Deco posters. In addition, there will be entertinment, lectures, appraisals and a fashion show. Hours are 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow and 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Sunday. Admission is $5, or $8 for a two-day pass. Information: (201)262-3063.

title: Bridge; Reading Opponents' Cards, Literally and by Deduction
description: Among the many bad habits indulged in by partners and opponents is sloppy holding of the cards. What should an ethical player do about an opponent who regularly thrusts his cards across the table at a 45-degree angle?

title: Pryor 'Born Yesterday'
description: At black-tie ceremonies at the Kennedy Center this week honoring the director Robert Ellis Miller and his movie ''The Heart is a Lonely Hunter,'' Senator David H. Pryor, a Democrat from Arkansas, spun a yarn about movies and personal determination that many have come to expect from a more famous personality in the Republican Party.

title: SUNSHINE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter loss includes accruals, writedowns, and non-recurring charges aggregating $13.9 million. These include various costs anticipated in 1987, including charges to cover the anticipated cost of reopening the Sunshine Mine, and a writedown of the capitalized costs at the Sixteen-to-One Mine by $4.2 million. The latest year loss includes a total of $83 million in non-cash charges for depreciation, depletion, amortization, lease impairment and writedowns of property values. In addition, the loss for the year includes $17 million in non-recurring charges and accruals representing, among other things, the cost of release from non-economic drilling contracts and costs associated with restructuring the company's credit arrangements, as well as the fourth quarter accruals referred to above.

title: FILM: 'THE HANOI HILTON'
description: ''THE HANOI HILTON,'' written and directed by Lionel Chetwynd, is an earnest but clumsy tribute to the heroism of the American servicemen - mostly officers - who were captured and held prisoner by North Vietnam during the long, desperate undeclared war we now refer to simply as Vietnam.

title: Conference on Writing
description: ''For Love and Money: The Business of Writing,'' a conference, is scheduled tomorrow from 8:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. at the Columbia School of Journalism, Broadway and West 116th Street. Among the editors, writers and agents who will be taking part will be Gloria Naylor, author of ''Linden Hills'' and ''The Women of Brewster Place,'' and Andrea Eagen, president of the National Writers Union. Admission is $55. Information: (718) 797-2333.

title: BMW Shipping Move
description: BMW of North America Inc. will begin shipping luxury cars to another port after industrial pollution here ruined the paint on some of its expensive automobiles. Thomas McGurn, a company spokesman, said Wednesday that BMW was unhappy about pollution that resulted in dozens of cars having to be repainted, but said the fallout was not the sole reason for the move. BMW plans to build its own $4.5 million auto-import processing center on a 25-acre site available near the Brunswick, Ga., docks, Mr. McGurn said.

title: CONTINENTAL HEALTH AFFILITES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Cole Porter Tribute Planned at St. Bart's
description: A musical tribute to Cole Porter will be presented this weekend at the St. Bart Playhouse, Park Avenue at 50th Street. A cast of nine and a pianist will be featured in the work, directed and choreographed by Louis Mattioli; the musical director is Ken Dake, who will also play the piano.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a loss from debt extinguishment of $2,600,000. c-Net income

title: F.B.I. IS REPORTED TO BE INVESTIGATING THREATS BY AGENTS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun investigating alleged incidents of threats and violence involving sports agents and players. According to a number of sources familiar with the investigation, Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, two New York agents, are among the subjects of this inquiry.

title: TAKERU HIGUCHI
description: Takeru Higuchi, a pharmaceutical chemist who developed pills that release medicine slowly into the bloodstream, died Tuesday at the University of Missouri-Columbia Hospital and Clinics. He was 69 years old.

title: ALLIES FACE DECISION ON SHORTER RANGES
description: As the medium-range arms talks between the Soviet Union and the United States adjourned here today, difficult choices loomed for the Western alliance on how to tie in the issue of shorter-range missiles with a medium-range accord. Although the outlines of an agreement have been accepted by the two superpowers, the Soviet Union is well ahead in the deployment of shorter-range missiles.

title: The Arms Control Choices
description: Controversy is still raging among officials and defense experts on whether to remove medium-range missiles from Europe. This is after the U.S. has formally offered a draft treaty at the Geneva talks and not long before Secretary of State George Shultz goes to Moscow to see if a deal can be completed in time for a Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting this year.

title: INTERVIEW WITH TOP DISSIDENT PRINTED IN YUGOSLAV MAGAZINE
description: For the first time in more than 30 years, a Yugoslav magazine has published an interview with the country's leading dissident.

title: COMMUNICATIONS & CABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $65,000 for the latest quarter and $75,000 for the year- earlier period; and the latest quarter also includes a gain of $1,025,000, or 7 cents a share, from the sale of the remainder of the company's cellular telephone investment. The company said the results for the year-ago quarter were reclassified for the real estate partnership interests and other net assets to be sold.

title: Jewish Book Fair
description: Old and new Judaica, including books, music cassettes and theatrical arrangements, will be on sale Sunday at the Jewish Book Fair at the Workmen's Circle, 45 East 33d Street. Hours are 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Admission is free. Information: 889-6800.

title: RECOTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: IN MAYA COUNTRY, REFUGEES WHO STAY AND STAY
description: More than five years after fleeing military repression in their homeland, nearly 100,000 Guatemalans are languishing in refugee camps and squatter settlements scattered across southeastern Mexico, with little expectation of returning home anytime soon.

title: For Irvings, performing is a tradition.
description: WHEN Amy Irving arrived in Israel to start shooting Cannon's ''Rumpelstiltskin,'' she had traveled a long distance to a foreign land to do something that was as familiar as coming home: work with her family. ''Rumpelstiltskin,'' the first in a series of 16 musical fairy tales that Cannon plans to produce, is the directorial debut of David Irving, the actress's brother, who also wrote the film. Priscilla Pointer, their mother, plays Queen Grizelda, and their stepfather, Robert Symonds, plays Victor, the father of Ms. Irving's character. A release date for the film has not yet been set.

title: LIABILITY INSURANCE REPORTED EASIER TO GET THAN YEAR AGO
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it is much easier to obtain liability insurance than it was last year at this time.

title: Waiting for the Word
description: The door to the manager's office was closed, and every now and then Clint Hurdle glanced out of the corner of his eye to see if anyone was coming out, anyone who would walk over to him and perhaps lay a hand on his shoulder and say quietly, ''Davey wants to see you.''

title: Q: New Soviet Wine or Old? A: Yes.
description: The March figure for Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union is the highest in five years, about 400. The news evokes pleasure - and recurrent questions. How significant are these reforms of Mikhail Gorbachev's? How should the West respond to them? Such questions split Soviet dissidents and emigres. The dissidents speak largely to Mr. Gorbachev and address what could be done. The emigres talk mostly to the West and focus on what should be. Consider these two different views: ''It's not right to say that it's only propaganda or window-dressing. Objectively, something real is happening. How far it's going to go is a complicated question. But I myself have decided that the situation has changed.'' ''For the West to take the new policies at face value is to deal with symptoms and ignore the disease. . . . What Westerners fail to understand is that if the Soviet leaders were really intent on radical change, they would have to begin by discarding the ruling ideology.''

title: INTELLIGENT BUSINESS COMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $190,000 for the latest quarter and $2,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 27, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Stocks Decline Sharply; Dow Off 36.79, to 2,335.80
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday on a wave of profit taking touched off by a steep drop in the dollar's value.

title: GREECE AND TURKEY ALERT FORCES AS TENSION BUILDS ON OIL SEARCH
description: Greece said today that it would use force to block a Turkish ship from exploring for oil in the Aegean.

title: Interest Rates Move Higher
description: Interest rates climbed yesterday as prices of all Treasury debt issues dropped in reaction to another steep decline in the dollar's value against major foreign currencies.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A music review in some editions yesterday, on a recital by Maurizio Pollini at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening, misstated the date of Debussy's 12 Etudes. He wrote them during World War I.

title: DOLLAR PLUNGES VERSUS YEN
description: The dollar plunged against the yen yesterday, overwhelming the persistent efforts of several central banks to prop it up.

title: Lecture on Gershwins
description: A lecture on the effects of Jewish immigrant life in Manhattan on the music of George and Ira Gershwin will be given by Deena Rosenberg at 4 P.M. tomorrow at Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street. Ms. Rosenberg is the author of ''The Gershwins, 1930 and Girl Crazy,'' a musical piece, and other works based on the lives of the composers. Admission is $5. Information: 362-8719.

title: PHILIPPINES AND BANKS IN $13.2 BILLION DEBT PACT
description: In a move that appears to mark a turning point in Manila's debt crisis, creditor banks yesterday announced a restructuring agreement on $13.2 billion in Philippine debt.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES HIGHWAY MEASURE AS 'PORK BARREL'
description: President Reagan today vetoed an $88 billion highway and mass transit bill that also allowed states to raise the speed limit to 65 miles an hour on rural Interstate highways. He thus set the stage for a major showdown with Congress.

title: Bronx Judge Asserts Judicial Panel Erred
description: Bronx Surrogate Bertram R. Gelfand said yesterday that the State Commission on Judicial Conduct was wrong when it recommended his removal from office because of ''an abuse of judicial authority'' during his eight-year affair with a female law assistant.

title: TV: TWO NEW SERIES TO START ON CHANNEL 13
description: Two new series, both courtesy of Mobil underwriting, get under way this weekend on public television. The new tenant on ''Mystery!,'' beginning tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, is ''Cover Her Face,'' still another adaptation of a P. D. James novel. And starting tomorrow at 9 o'clock, ''Masterpiece Theater'' breaks with its normal mini-series routine to offer adaptations of five short stories by Noel Coward. The title of the series and the first story is ''Star Quality.''

title: Texas Upset, 79-75
description: Louisiana Tech upset top-ranked Texas, 79-75, tonight in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament. The Lady Techsters will meet Tennessee for the championship Sunday.

title: Bring Back Orphanages as Homes for Children
description: To the Editor:

title: DISPUTE WITH LOUVRE ENDS
description: Resolving a six-year old dispute with the Louvre and other art museums of France, the Cleveland Museum of Art announced yesterday that it had agreed to lend a painting by Nicolas Poussin to the Louvre for periodic exhibitions over the next 25 years.

title: Green Light, Red Ink for the M.T.A.
description: At last, Albany has found a way to fund in full the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. With Governor Cuomo's concurrence, legislators now promise enough revenue to freeze fares until 1990 and continue the capital enhancement program that will cost $8.4 billion over the next five years.

title: SENATE PASSES BANK BILL THAT HALTS NEW POWERS
description: After nearly three days of debate, the Senate approved important legislation today that includes a moratorium on new powers for banks until a Presidential commission conducts a fundamental review of competition in financial services.

title: Translating the Bible
description: To the Editor:

title: WALTER ABEL, 88, ACTOR IN THEATER AND FILMS
description: Walter Abel, an actor who appeared in the earliest plays of Eugene O'Neill in the 1920's and who continued to work on stage and in films for more than 50 years, died Thursday at Chesterfields Nursing home in Essex, Conn. He was 88 years old.

title: THE SWEET 64
description: If they still went by the old rules in the national college basketball tournament, we would not have Syracuse against Providence this afternoon, would not have Sherman Douglas against Billy Donovan, two slick guards from the land of schoolyards and the give-and-go.

title: VATICAN SEEKS HELP ON DEFICIT
description: The Vatican announced Thursday that it was turning to local churches worldwide for financial help because it faced a record deficit of about $63 million this year.

title:
Patents;
AIDS Virus Production
description: LEAD: A broadened process for the production of AIDS virus, which is useful in research, was patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services. Dr. Robert C. Gallo and Dr. Mikulas Popovic of the National Cancer Institute were granted patent 4,652,599, which provides the use of more cell lines, with different characteristics, than they had previously patented.

title: ERVING STIFLES NETS
description: Julius Erving, playing his first game since Feb. 16, scored 29 points to lead the 76ers to a 110-99 victory over the New Jersey Nets tonight. The victory clinched a National Basketball Association playoff berth for Philadelphia.

title: COMMUNIST PICKED TO MEDIATE ITALY CRISIS
description: President Francesco Cossiga appointed Nilde Iotti, a longtime Communist legislator, tonight to mediate Italy's government crisis. It was the first time either a Communist or a woman had been given a mandate to help form a government here.

title: Storm Kills 6 in Britain
description: Strong winds and heavy rain killed at least six people in Britain today. Three men were killed and three injured when a tree fell on a van near Banstead, south of London.

title: VIOLENCE IN THE CITY'S JAILS: 30 INCIDENTS A DAY
description: A total of 1,831 violent incidents -more than 30 assaults, fights, stabbings and slashings every day - erupted in New York City's jails in January and February, leading to hundreds of injuries that hospitalized an average of two inmates daily, correction officials said yesterday.

title: Tulane Report
description: Men's college basketball will probably return to Tulane University in New Orleans in time for the 1990-1991 season, according to a report in yesterday's issue of The Times-Picayune/The States-Item. The Tulane president, Eamon Kelly, disbanded the program in the midst of a burgeoning point-shaving and payoff scandal in 1985. At the time, Kelly said the demise of the basketball program was permanent. He later softened his stand. On April 16, Tulane's Board of Administrators is scheduled to meet to consider a recommendation from its athletic committee that essentially calls for basketball to be reinstated and a timetable established to bring the team back, the newspaper reported.

title: RANGER NEWCOMERS FITTING IN
description: On Wednesday night, the Rangers played so badly that many of the players wondered if they could ever play as a unit, considering how unfamiliar they were with one another.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MARCH 28, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5 A trade retaliation against Japan came when President Reagan doubled the import price on a wide range of Japanese electronic products. The action could affect up to $300 million worth of consumer products. Page 1 Greece would block a Turkish effort to explore for oil in the Aegean by using force, it said. Both countries' forces were said to be on alert as a Turkish seismic research vessel prepared to sail for disputed waters. 1 U.S.-Greece diplomatic negotiations are focusing on Greece's request that the United States suspend operations at a major communications base on the Greek mainland near Marathon Bay, the Administration said. 4 For many Turks, a scandal involving a Saudi-financed foundation that paid the salaries of a group of Government-employed Moslem clerics bore omens of sovereignty diminished by foreign handouts. 4 Chad has recaptured Faya-Largeau, the most important town in the north and a Libyan stronghold for four years, according to an official statement from the Chadian capital, Ndjamena. 3 Malaysia's leaders face a crisis caused by a revolt in Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's party, which comes as the party, the United Malays National Organization, prepares for a leadership vote on April 24. 5 In Rome, a mediator was appointed in Italy's Government crisis, a Communist legislator named Nilde Iotti. It was the first time that either a Communist or a woman had been given a mandate to help form a government. 3 Mr. Reagan met with Neil Kinnock, the head of Britain's Labor Party, about their differences on nuclear arms policy and the Administration's preference for the Thatcher Government's policies. 2 Creditor banks of the Philippines announced an accord that restructures $13.2 billion of that nation's loans, a move that appears to mark a turning point in Philippines debt crisis. 33 Vatican faces record deficit 3 U.S. details Israel-Pretoria arms trade 3 Tough terms for ending P.L.O. rift 5 NATIONAL 6-9, 28 Mr. Reagan vetoed a highway bill, thus setting the stage for a major confrontation with Congress. The $88 billion bill also allows states to raise their speed limits to 65 miles an hour in certain rural areas. 1 Soviet spies toured the U.S. embassy in Moscow and they were allowed access ''on numerous occasions'' to sensitive sections of the embassy by two Marine guards, the Marine Corps charged. 1 Criticism of the Justice Department came from Solicitor General Charles Fried, who said the Justice Department's top spokesman's comment about the Supreme Court and affirmative action was ''deeply troubling.'' 1 TV evangelists are deeply divided in both style and theology and the divisions have become all the more complex given the unlikely alliances that have emerged in the wake of Jim Bakker's resignation as president of the PTL Network. 6 Four likely Republican candidates for President provided their visions of the future and answered questions from about 125 Republican members of the House of Representatives, their families and staff members. 9 Harassment of rural physicians was charged by some members of Congress, who criticized the Reagan Ad-ministration for excluding such doctors from the Federal Medicare program because they provided care deemed to be substandard. 6 In Philadelphia, a portrait emerged of the man accused of enslaving and torturing young women in a basement dungeon. The police and others said he was a psychotic who between bouts of mental illness seemed to function normally. 8 A new advance in superconductors was announced by scientists at Wayne State University, who have identified a material that becomes a superconductor at a temperature much warmer than previously reported. 6 Lightning may have harmed a rocket which failed at the Kennedy Space Center on Thursday, space agency engineers said. The Atlas-Centaur rocket's mishap was the space program's fourth failure in little more than a year. 28 The dollar plunged against the yen, overwhelming the persistent efforts of central bank efforts to prop it up. By late in the day in New York, the dollar was bid at 147.15 yen, its lowest level in more than 35 years. 33 Spying remarks prompt inquiry 6 Court stays Alabama book ban 6 Gore reconsiders Presidential bid 9 REGIONAL 29-31, 50 Abuses of the legislative payroll are being broadly investigated, the Manhattan District Attorney said, including allegations of kickbacks to local party leaders and state salaries being paid to private lobbyists. 1 Some reductions in violence in jails in New York City appear to be the result of measures adopted in recent months, correction officers said, who noted that last year a small fraction of the 100,000 inmates were involved in violent incidents. 1 Mayor Koch warned A.T.& T. that the city would ''sue the hell out of you'' if the company carried out plans to move much of its staff from its Manhattan headquarters to Basking Ridge, N.J. 29 Mark Rudd, back at Columbia after 19 years, reflected on the 60's after witnessing more recent demonstrations at the school. After decades of avoiding publicity, the former student leader has decided to become an activist again. 31 No departmental charges will be made against 10 transit police officers involved in the 1983 arrest and death in police custody of Michael Stewart, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board decided. 31 Staff shortages at a shelter for men, the Shelter Care Center for Men on East Third Street, result in a daily tug-of-war between an overworked and sometimes ill-equipped security staff and the people who visit there. 29 The big job of cleaning up Local 560 of the United Brotherhood of Teamsters keeps Joel Jacobson busy. Nine months ago, a Federal judge appointed him trustee of the union, which has been called one of the most corrupt in the nation. 29 Racquet club rejects woman 29 Beefeaters end years of guilt 29 Battle lines over Newark ark 30 City acts on bus-shelter pact 50

title: KEEPING LUNCH COOL
description: Riki Kane, an owner of Metro-Kane Imports, wanted something to keep her lunch salad cool at work. ''We decided that a good-looking lunch box for adults that had the added feature of being able to keep things cold would be a boon to working women and men as well,'' Ms. Kane said. Using the metal lunch box used by construction workers as a starting point because ''it was so readily identifiable and sort of nice and old-fashioned looking,'' Ms. Kane said, she developed the ''Ice Man.'' The neat plastic lunch box comes with a cold pouch that snaps into its lid and also an adjustable shoulder strap. It is $25 and comes in white, black, red, blue and gray at the Museum Store, 11 West 53d Street, and Roberts & Company, 182 East 86th Street.

title: CHURCH TERMS: DEFINITIONS
description: Pentecostal - A type of Christianity that stresses personal religious experience rather than doctrine. It is manifested in glossolalia, or speaking in ''tongues,'' as well as faith healing, prophecy, performance of miracles and other ''gifts of the spirit.'' The term refers to the experience of the Apostles in the New Testament on the Jewish feast of Shabuoth, or Pentecost, after the resurrection of Jesus.

title: Rep. Oakar Is to Repay Aide's $47,000 Salary
description: Representative Mary Rose Oakar of Ohio said today that, in an effort to ''clear the air,'' she had begun paying the United States Treasury an amount equal to the more than $47,000 an aide on her payroll received while working for her in New York.

title: Coghlan Mark Rejected
description: Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland yesterday lost credit for what he and everyone else in the world of track and field believed was an indoor world mark that he set more than six years ago. On Feb. 20, 1981, at San Diego, he was was clocked at 3 minutes 35.60 seconds for 1,500 meters while on his way to a 3:50.60 victory in the mile. But the 1,500-meter time, which has since been widely recognized as a world best, yesterday was rejected by the International Amateur Athletic Federation as a record because it was timed by only one stopwatch instead of the three required to make a world record legitimate. Thus The Athletic Congress, the governing body for track and field in the United States, informed the I.A.A.F. that it was unable to confirm the record and it was rejected. ''It was the only one where we did not get confirmation by the member federation that all requirements for a world record as we stipulate were met,'' said Mike Gee, the technical secretary of the I.A.A.F. Gee has been reviewing world indoor bests turned in before Jan. 1 for the purpose of giving them world record status. With Coghlan's time rejected, the record recognition went to Jose-Luis Gonzalez of Spain, who ran 3:36.03 for 1,500 meters last year at Osviedo, Spain.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: .B.A. Celtics 111, Bulls 106: Larry Bird scored 41 points and Kevin McHale had 21 as Boston ended a streak of five losses on the road. It was the Celtics' ninth consecutive victory over the Bulls this season. Michael Jordan, the league scoring leader, was held to 22 points, including three baskets in the second half; his teammates John Paxson and Brad Sellers led the Bulls with 23 points each. Jordan and Paxson combined for 38 first-half points. Jordan scored only two third-quarter baskets and Paxson was held to 5 points in that period. Paced by Jerry Sichting and Bird, with 6 points apiece, the Celtics sparked Boston to a 91-82 lead entering the final quarter.(AP) Cavaliers 116, Bucks 113: Ron Harper scored 31 points and Brad Daugherty had 27 points, 12 rebounds and 9 assists as Cleveland withstood several charges by visiting Milwuwaukee. Cleveland led by as many as 13 points in the third quarter and took a 94-85 lead into the final period.(AP) High School Archbishop Molloy Gains Final: Archbishop Molloy of Queens, the top-ranked team in the state, beat Shenendahowa, the only unbeaten team in the state, 54-49, last night to advance to tonight's State Federation championship game. The Stanners, champions of the Catholic bracket, led by as many as 17 points, but let the Clifton Park school, near Albany, back into the game when they made just 4 of 17 shots in the second half. With the majority of the 6,449 fans at the Civic Center in Glens Falls, N.Y., behind them, Shenendahowa (27-1), which won the New York State Public School bracket, drew as close as 3 points in the waning minutes. Molloy, however, was accurate from the foul line, making 10 of 16 free throws in the second half. The Stanners (26-2), who have won 17 in a row, were led by a sophomore guard, Kenny Anderson, who had 21 points. Greg Koubek, a Shenendahowa senior who has signed to play at Duke next season, led all scorers with 25. In last night's second game, Our Savior Lutheran of the Bronx defeated Springfield Gardens, 60-58. Lutheran, champion of the Independent school bracket, will face Molloy in tonight's final. Springfield Gardens was the P.S.A.L. champion. Tennis Becker Upset: Anders Jarryd of Sweden upset top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, to gain the semifinals of the $315,000 Belgian indoor championships in Brussels. John McEnroe, troubled by a tender hip, defeated Jakop Hlasek of Switzerland, 6-3, 7-5, and will face Jarryd next. Mats Wilander of Sweden, ranked No. 6 in the world, needed three sets to defeat Gilad Bloom of Israel, ranked No. 146, while Jonas Svensson of Sweden defeated his countryman, Jan Gunnarsson, in straight sets.(AP) Mandlikova Gains: In Fairfax, Va., top-seeded Hana Mandlikova defeated Kathy Rinaldi, 7-5, 6-0, to gain the semifinals of the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Washington tournament. Mandlikova will play next against Helena Sukova, who beat Lori McNeil, 6-4, 2-6, 6-1. In the other semifinal match, Barbara Potter will face Zina Garrison.(AP) Golf Pulz Leads by 2: Penny Pulz led by two strokes with 141 after the second round of the $300,000 L.P.G.A. Turquoise Classic in Phoenix as late scores ballooned under winds gusting to 45 m.p.h. Pulz, who shared the first-round lead with Martha Foyer, a rookie, with 69, shot a one-under-par 72. Cindy Ferro was in second place on the 6,419-yard Moon Valley Country Club course. Foyer faded with a 78 yesterday.(AP) Charles Shoots 67: Bob Charles, looking for his second straight victory on the P.G.A. Seniors Tour, fired a five-under-par 67 to take a two-shot lead over Tommy Aaron after the opening round of the $275,000 GTE Senior Classic in Simi Valley, Calif.(AP) Swimming Three-Time Winners: Tamas Darnyi of Hungary and Marius Podkoscielny of Poland each won his third title of the week at the United States Short-Course National Championships. Darnyi won the 200-yard individual medley by three body lengths over Ron Karnaugh. Podkoscielny, who trains with the Mission Viejo Swim Club in California, took the 500 freestyle in 4:16.60. Tom Jager won the 50 freestyle in a meet-record 19.52 seconds. Two Virginia swimmers took women's titles: Whitney Hedgepeth of Colonial Heights won the 500 freestyle in 4:41.03 and Katy Arris of Virgina Beach took the 200 individual medley in 2:00.86.(AP)

title: About New York; Hail, Cholesterol: Beefeaters End Years of Guilt
description: There are issues that continue to divide this nation and fish for dinner is one of them.

title: SENATOR'S ACCOUNT OF SPYING ON ISRAEL SETS OFF AN INQUIRY
description: The Senate ethics committee has begun a preliminary investigation into the propriety of Senator Dave Durenberger's assertion that American intelligence agents used an Israeli military officer as a spy in the early 1980's, according to Senators and Congressional aides.

title: U.S. COURT RUNS A JERSEY UNION IN TEST
description: Joel Jacobson gets up early these days, usually between 4:30 and 5 A.M. By 6 he has had breakfast in a diner, and by 7 he is outside a truck terminal somewhere in New Jersey preaching the gospel of honest trade unionism.

title: CHAD TAKES ANOTHER KEY LIBYA BASE
description: Chad announced today that its troops had recaptured Faya-Largeau, the most important town in the country's north and a Libyan stronghold for four years.

title: STRANGE PORTRAIT OF TORTURE SUSPECT
description: As the police searched two former homes of the man accused of enslaving and torturing young women in a basement dungeon here, a portrait emerged today of a psychotic who seemed to function normally between bouts of mental illness.

title: Trade Shocks, Protectionist Fevers
description: Momentous decisions being made in Washington now rock the world economy. Yesterday President Reagan announced the most sweeping trade sanctions against Japan since World War II, in retaliation against alleged dumping of computer chips. Meanwhile, new and restrictive trade legislation wends its way through Congress. Unmistakably, the danger signals flash. Unquestionably, world leaders have to put free and fair trade back at the top of their agenda, and quickly.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about AIDS virus infection misstated results of a study of male customers of female prostitutes in New York. The study, by Dr. Joyce I. Wallace, found that 2 of 175 customers who volunteered to be tested were carriers of the AIDS virus and admitted to no other risk factors, an indication that they might have been infected through intercourse with prostitutes.

title: Taken for a Ride by the Taxi Fare Hike
description: LEAD: The Taxi and Limousine Commission's decision to raise fares in May demonstrates that the public once again takes a back seat to the industry's demands. Despite pronouncements by the Koch administration that a fare rise is a necessary trade-off to get more taxis on the streets, it's really nothing more than a pay-now get-nothing-later scheme.

title: FILING BY RESORTS
description: Resorts International Inc. said it might sell its 9.2 percent stake in the Pan Am corporation in order to raise funds for its new hotel/casino project. In filing with the Securties and Exchange Commission, resorts said it might sell its Pan Am stake ''if it obtains the prior written approval of Donald J. Trump, the New york real estate developer.

title: REAGAN AND KINNOCK HOLD TALK ON NUCLEAR WEAPONS AND BRITAIN
description: Neil Kinnock, the head of Britain's Labor Party, met with President Reagan today about their differences on nuclear arms policy.

title: No Stigma in Adoption
description: To the Editor:

title: TO '68 LEADER, COLUMBIA IS STILL LIVELY
description: It was, said Mark Rudd, a complete coincidence. He had not set foot on campus in years. But here he was at Columbia University, a few hours early for a longstanding speaking engagement, and the students were demonstrating.

title: U.S. IS RETALIATING WITH 100% DUTIES IN JAPAN DISPUTE
description: President Reagan decided today to double the import price of some Japanese electronic products, in the first American trade retaliation against Japan in the postwar period.

title: South Africa Prohibits Rally By Black Trade-Union Group
description: The South African Government has banned a rally by the Congress of South African Trade Unions planned for Sunday in Soweto to start a campaign for higher wages.

title: BIG STAKES IN BORG ARE SHIFTED
description: The GAF Corporation yesterday replaced the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs in posing a takeover threat to the Borg-Warner Corporation.

title: GORE AGREES TO RECONSIDER 1988 PRESIDENTIAL BID
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee told a group of Democratic fund-raisers today that he would consider becoming a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988.

title: BUS-SHELTER PACT IN JEOPARDY
description: The Board of Estimate moved yesterday to end New York City's contract with a company that builds and maintains shelters at bus stops.

title: Comings and Goings
description: David Robinson of Navy accepted the Adolph Rupp Trophy in New Orleans yesterday as The Associated Press college basketball player of the year. Robinson, a 7-foot-1-inch senior center who averaged 28.2 points a game and led the nation in blocked shots, received 206 of 419 votes in a nationwide poll of sports writers and broadcasters. Steve Alford of Indiana received 63, followed by Danny Manning of Kansas with 56. . . . Tom Davis, who received 89 of 419 votes, was named The Associated Press coach of the year for guiding Iowa to 30 victories in his first year there, the most in the school's history. Joey Meyer of DePaul was second with 81. . . . Mel Gray, a 12-year wide receiver in the National Football League with the St. Louis Cardinals, has been arrested in California on a Missouri charge of failing to make child support payments of more than $27,000 to his 14-year-old daughter, according to Mike Shortridge, an assistant prosecuting attorney in Jackson County in Missouri.

title: Stuttgart Orchestra
description: The Stuttgart Chamber Orchestra will play works by Handel, Shostakovich, Mendelssohn and Grieg at 3 P.M. tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall. The 22-member ensemble will be directed by Patrick Strub, who has replaced the ailing Karl Munchinger. Tickets are $15, $10 and $8. Information: 874-2424.

title: BAD TIMES FOR BULLPEN AND STARTING STAFF
description: If anyone is keeping count, the continued succession of injuries to Yankee pitchers is now at five. Add Tim Stoddard to the list, and don't scratch Charles Hudson yet. He's hurting again. There seems to be no relief for Lou Piniella, the Yankee manager, who has endured a spring of unsettling injuries to his pitching staff. And today he had to watch his opening-day starter, Dennis Rasmussen, struggle through another disappointing afternoon.

title: Another Knick Injury
description: The injury situation has gotten so bad for the Knicks that they had to receive a dispensation from the National Basketball Association yesterday to place a fourth player - Bob Thornton - on the disabled list. Ordinarily, no more than three are allowed. Thornton, whose sprained right ankle will sideline him the rest of the season joins three other injured Knick forwards: Bernard King (knee), Pat Cummings (finger) and Patrick Ewing (knee). Nine players dressed for last night's game in Indiana, and the team will sign another forward this weekend.

title: North Koreans Are Penalized
description: The international soccer federation has formally barred North Korea from the soccer tournament for the 1988 Olympics and imposed financial sanctions after the North Korean national team failed to show up for a qualifying round.

title: Dixons Offer Wins Cyclops
description: Dixons Group P.L.C., the British retailer, said today it had acquired more than half of the Cyclops Corporation's common stock for $95 a share, after its failure to attract a majority of shares with an offer of $90.25 a share.

title: COMMERCIAL TV OFFICIAL TO HEAD CHANNEL 13
description: A search committee at Channel 13 has chosen William F. Baker, a commercial television executive, to be president of the public television station, ending a five-month effort to fill the post, members of the Channel 13 board said yesterday.

title: MICHIGAN STATE ADVANCES TO FINAL
description: Michigan State, the defending champion, defeated Minnesota, 5-3, tonight to advance to the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament.

title: METS TRADE HEARN, ANDERSON TO ROYALS
description: The Mets sent Ed Hearn and Rick Anderson to Kansas City today for David Cone, a 24-year-old right-handed pitcher.

title: KENNEDY CENTER SALUTE FOR ROSTROPOVICH'S 60TH
description: Today was the 60th birthday of Mstislav Rostropovich, and he was honored in Kennedy Center. But at the very end of a concert in which many brilliant musicians participated, the show was almost stolen from him when Mrs. Nancy Reagan made her debut as a conductor.

title: Screen Foster Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: DONALD F. O'DONNELL
description: Donald F. O'Donnell, who headed up Senate investigations of organized crime and labor racketeering in the 1950's and 1960's, died Wednesday. He was 70 year old.

title: Fournier and Powell
description: Vernel Fournier, on drums, and Benny Powell, on trombone, will lead a jazz group tonight at the Angry Squire, 216 Seventh Avenue, at 23d Street (242-9066). There are three sets from 9:30 P.M.; $7 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Deere and G.M. Cancel Diesel Unit
description: Deere & Company and the General Motors Corporation said that they had canceled plans to form a joint venture company to build diesel engines. ''The parent companies have been studying the proposed venture for quite some time, and they determined that they could gain the benefits by continuing with the arrangement they have,'' said Judy Kangas, a G. M. spokeswoman in Detroit.

title: BASTION OF COURT TENNIS KEEPS WOMAN ON SIDELINE
description: On Fridays, after she finishes work as a French teacher in Manhattan, Evelyn David boards a bus to Tuxedo, N.Y., where she spends the weekend practicing court tennis, a sport in which she ranks among the nation's top female athletes.

title:
Patents;
Horse Run By Remote Control
description: LEAD: A HORSE can be driven by remote control with apparatus patented this week by David R. Kime, vice president of Super-Jock Inc. in Memphis. He received patent 4,651,678.

title: Red Sox, Nipper Fined
description: Both Al Nipper, who hit Darryl Strawberry of the Mets with a pitch during an exhibition game two weeks ago, and the Boston Red Sox have been fined by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth, who was a spectator at the game. In the first meeting between the teams since the Mets defeated the Red Sox in the World Series, Boston's pitcher struck Strawberry in the back with a second-inning pitch and players from both teams raced onto the field. Nipper gave up a lead-padding home run to Strawberry in the seventh game of the World Series and was angered when the Met right fielder took an unusually long time to circle the bases. He reportedly said afterward that he would throw at Strawberry in their next confrontation, although he denied after hitting him that it was done intentionally. ''The ball just got away,'' he said after the game. ''It wasn't anything personal.'' Murray, a baseball administrator, said in announcing the fine, ''Our conclusion upon investigation was that the incident would not have occurred had proper and reasonable care been practiced.'' No amounts were disclosed, but sources said Nipper's fine was $300 and the team's at least $1,000.

title: A SCANDAL RUBS NATION'S RAW NERVES
description: When word of the scandal seeped out, some said it might rock the republic. Others, more ponderously, mused on its implications for Turkey's long and unresolved quest for modernity.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 9.

title: INQUIRY ON THE LEGISLATIVE PAYROLL HAS EXPANDED, MORGENTHAU SAYS
description: The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday that his office was investigating a wide range of abuses of the legislative payroll, including allegations of kickbacks to local party leaders, of state salaries being paid to lobbyists and of employees being paid by both the State Senate and the State Assembly.

title: Japanese Export Inquiry
description: A Japanese trading company and four businessmen were reported to the prosecutor's office for allegedly exporting to China high-technology items that could be used to build advanced weaponry, the police said. The Tomei Boeki Company and the businessmen were suspected of exporting about 18 million yen ($120,000) worth of items used in the manufacture of televisions without the permission of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, the police said.

title: Parade Tomorrow
description: A parade marking Greek Independence Day will begin at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow at 62d Street and Fifth Avenue. The three-hour parade will proceed to 79th Street, turning east to Third Avenue for dispersal.

title: Turner Cites Large Losses
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc., the debt-laden cable television concern, today reported large losses for the fourth quarter and for all of 1986, due mainly to increases in costs relating to its $1.5 billion acquisition of the MGM/ UA Entertainment Company.

title: Taft to Negotiate With Group on Bid
description: The Taft Broadcasting Company said it would negotiate with an investor group led by its vice chairman, Dudley S. Taft, which recently raised the price of its offer to buy the company to $1.38 billion. The television and cable system operator based here also said it had authorized Goldman, Sachs & Company, its financial adviser, to explore other acquisition bids.

title: HARRIS J. KLEIN
description: Harris J. Klein, a former member of the New York City Transit and Human Rights Commissions, died of Alzheimer's disease Thursday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 80 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Review; CONCERT: THOMAS LORANGO
description: WHEN a young pianist still building a career comes to New York with an all-standard program like the Schumann-Brahms bill Thomas Lorango offered at Alice Tully Hall Tuesday evening, the reflexive response is to question his musical curiosity or perhaps his presumption in offering yet another traversal of the ''Symphonic Etudes'' or Brahms's Third Sonata to a city that regularly hears them played by renowned artists.

title: AT BANK OF BOSTON, A DIFFERENT PATH
description: For most of the emerging breed of large regional banks, the strategy these days is to focus on doing business with small companies in a single region. The Bank of Boston, which has a long Yankee tradition of going its own way, is showing that there is more than one route to becoming a powerful regional bank.

title: CONTRASTING MOODS FOR PROVIDENCE AND SYRACUSE
description: The Providence Friars appear to be taking this unlikely weekend in stride, as if there is nothing unusual about the school's first appearance in the Final Four in 14 years. No Bourbon Street. And no pressure. They have an 11 P.M. curfew and no one has complained.

title:
Patents;
Compositions for Care Of Alzheimer's Disease
description: LEAD: Preparations described as providing treatment for patients with Alzheimer's disease and enhancing their memory were patented this week for a New Jersey pharmaceutical company.

title: SPECTACLES: LEGISLATIVE FINE PRINT
description: READING the fine print is almost always a problem for people older than 45, ophthalmologists say. The condition is presbyopia and the best solution is spectacles.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 28, 1987
description: The Economy

title: TWO MASTER LYRICISTS TALK SHOP AT THE Y
description: As John Guare told a packed house Thursday evening at the 92d Street Y, he first encountered Stephen Sondheim in the summer of 1966, when the young playwright went to hear the journeyman composer-lyricist give a talk at the Goodspeed Opera House. Mr. Guare's first play, ''The House of Blue Leaves,'' was being given a staged reading nearby at the nascent O'Neill Playwrights Center in Waterford, Conn., and Mr. Guare, being himself a lyricist with a knowledge of American song, was interested in what Mr. Sondheim had to say.

title: Court Stays Alabama Book Ban
description: A Federal appellate court today temporarily suspended a Federal district judge's order removing 44 textbooks from the Alabama schools on the ground that they promoted what the judge described as the religion of secular humanism.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 32.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. AIDE UNDER FIRE FOR COMMENT ON HIGH COURT By STUART TAYLOR Jr.
description: A public dispute erupted within the Justice Department today when Solicitor General Charles Fried criticized as ''deeply troubling'' a comment the department's top spokesman made about the Supreme Court and affirmative action.

title: Sale and Lease Set by McLean
description: McLean Industries, the financially troubled owner of one of the biggest American-flag shipping lines, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell part of its shipping unit and to lease the assets of another unit.

title: MARINES SAY TWO GUARDS ALLOWED RUSSIANS TO ROAM U.S. EMBASSY By STEPHEN ENGELBERG
description: The Marine Corps charged today that two Marine guards at the United States Embassy in Moscow allowed Soviet agents to spend hours roaming through highly sensitive sections of the embassy on ''numerous occasions'' last year.

title: INSIDE
description: Consumer Price Index Up Consumer prices climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in February. The rise intensified worries about the outlook for inflation. Page 33.

title: U.S. MOVE A DEPARTURE FROM THE NORM
description: By announcing sanctions on Japanese companies today, the United States acted toward a key ally as it has seldom done in the four decades since the end of World War II.

title: MALAYSIA LEADER FACING MAJOR REVOLT IN HIS PARTY
description: The coalition Government of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, re-elected by a record majority in August, is facing an unexpected crisis caused by a revolt in his own party.

title: Couple Shot to Death In High-Rise Home
description: A Manhattan couple were found shot to death in their 14th-story West Side apartment yesterday morning in what the police said was apparently a homicide-suicide.

title: Chicago Merc Proposals
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange has proposed imposing fines of up to $50,000 and banning dual trading by some floor brokers in an effort to combat purported abuses in the trading of stock index futures.

title: PITINO SETS RECORD STRAIGHT
description: As long as there is going to be a legend, the facts really ought to be straight.

title: Trouble Spots Listed For Weekend Traffic
description: The New York City Department of Transportation has listed these trouble spots for weekend traffic:

title: J. VICTOR HERD, FORMER CHIEF OF CONTINENTAL INSURANCE COS.
description: J. Victor Herd, retired chairman and chief executive officer of the Continental Corporation in Manhattan, holding company of the Continental Insurance Companies, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 85 years old.

title: THE RIFT AT MANHATTAN, INC.
description: By all accounts, Manhattan,inc. got off to a fast start. Born only three years ago, the magazine picked up readers and advertisers at a rapid clip, and its splashy mix of articles won an award for general excellence from the National Magazine Association.

title: Raymond Johnson, 40; Dancer-Choreographer
description: Raymond Johnson, a dancer and choreographer, died Thursday at Caledonian Hospital in Brooklyn of complications after a stroke. He was 40 years old.

title: Lost Illusions
description: THAT NIGHT. By Alice McDermott. 184 pages. Farrar, Straus Giroux. $14.95.

title: Iranscambashamokgate
description: It's the season to scam, gate, bash and amokize every noun around Washington. Contra-scam, Olliegate, President-bashing, Iranamok - place any person or group in Column A, and the drearisome foursome in Column B. Then generate headlines to your heart's content. Rich undiscovered possibilities remain. Nancyamok, as Donald Regan might agree, has a nice ring to it.

title: Robber Shoots Clerk
description: A robber wearing a bulletproof vest and carrying a submachine gun wounded an employee in a Washington Heights grocery store early yesterday. But he was captured as he and two accomplices fled into a subway, the transit police said. A transit officer arrested the main suspect, Alberto Martinez, 22 years old, of Rahway, N.J., and recovered $2,325 stolen from the store, according to a Transit Authority spokesman, Albert O'Leary. Mr. O'Leary said that three men robbed the store, at 2017 Amsterdam Avenue, at 163d Street, at 2:20 A.M. and that the other two suspects fled at the IND station at 163d Street.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''The air force, navy and army are in a state of alert.'' - Gen. Guven Ergenc, secretary general of Turkey's general staff.

title: LLOYD GOODRICH, ART EXPERT, DIES: EX-DIRECTOR OF WHITNEY MUSEUM
description: Lloyd Goodrich, a former director of the Whitney Museum of American art and a leading author and advocate of American art for more than a half century, died yesterday of cancer at his home in New York City. He was 89 years old.

title: THE FORGOTTEN CAMEL
description: Having decreed as recently as December that it was time for journalism to abandon the tired old -gate suffix in the naming of scandals, I am now given a humbling lesson in the error of dogmatism. Its source is the scandal of the warring television preachers, for which there is only one possible name: Pearlygate.

title:
Patents;
Image Analysis System
description: LEAD: Jerome H. Lemelson of Princeton, N.J., believes that the image analysis system for which he and Christian Grund were granted patent 4,653,109 this week will be useful in watching and regulating chemical production and other manufacturing operations. Work under way is scanned by television and studied by computer.

title: DEVILS CONTINUE MASTERY
description: After their 8-2 trouncing of the Rangers two nights ago, the Devils came up with another inspiring performance in a 5-2 triumph over the Minnesota North Stars tonight.

title: Big Japanese Trade Surplus
description: Japan posted another large monthly trade surplus in February, the Government said today, and economists said the news was certain to intensify international pressure on Tokyo to reduce the imbalance.

title: ADMINISTRATION ASSAILED OVER EXCLUDING DOCTORS
description: Members of Congress charged today that the Reagan Administration was harassing rural physicians by excluding them from the Medicare program because they provided care that was deemed substandard.

title: COUNTRY-ROCK BILL
description: Two New York country-rock bands, Tijuana Bible and Tall Lonesome Pines, will perform tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with double bills a 9:30P.M., and midnight. There is a $5 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: U.S. IN TALKS WITH GREECE OVER CALL TO CLOSE BASE
description: Reagan Administration officials said tonight that they were in intense diplomatic negotiations with Greece over its request that the United States suspend operations at a major communications base on the Greek mainland near Marathon Bay.

title: NEW GAIN CITED IN CONDUCTIVITY OF TEST MATERIAL
description: Scientists at Wayne State University, using an unconventional testing technique, say they have identified a material that conducts electrcity without any loss of energy at a temperature much warmer than previously reported.

title: IN PARIS, POLKA DOTS AND PLAIDS
description: The stylish women of Paris are fending off the cold and rain of a lingering winter with a profusion of spring suits and coats. Many of them are cheerfully patterned in polka dots, houndstooth checks, gingham checks and Prince of Wale plaids.

title: CHIRAC TO ASK CONDITIONS ON U.S.-SOVIET MEDIUM-RANGE PACT
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, who is going to Washington next week, will ask the United States to attach stiff conditions to any accord with the Soviet Union that will remove medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe, French officials said Thursday.

title: 4 G.O.P. HOPEFULS QUESTIONED GENTLY
description: Four prospective Republican Presidential candidates offered their visions of the future yesterday and answered gentle questions from a partisan audience, about 125 Republican members of the House of Representatives, their families and staff members.

title: Doctors Shouldn't Be Pharmacists
description: Should doctors sell drugs to patients as well as prescribe them? The American Medical Association says no, not as a general rule. But more and more physicians are doing so, raising questions of medical ethics and of the need for law. Without question, it's time to legislate.

title: Four Nuclear Reactors In Tennessee Are Shut
description: Four nuclear reactors here were shut by the Federal Energy Department because of management deficiencies that could lead to safety problems, officials said today.

title: Rain Causes a Second Delay
description: After playing 31 holes today to complete the remainder of his first round and the entire second round of the Tournament Players Championship, Scott Simpson said, ''Most of our round yesterday was today.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Art, Mostly Abstract

title: Working Women's Unworkable World
description: Most people have accepted the big change: women have taken jobs. The problem is that society hasn't yet accepted the other, consequent changes needed if women's work is going to work.

title: CORRECTION
description: The 60-Minute Gourmet in Living last Wednesday gave an incorrect amount for an ingredient in roast tenderloin of pork with sweet peppers and paprika sauce. One-half teaspoon of finely chopped garlic should be used.

title: Eugene V. Debs and the L.I.R.R.
description: In common with many American radicals dead a half-century or more, Eugene Victor Debs currently enjoys a vastly greater degree of public respect and acclaim than was accorded to him by the Government, academe or the Establishment when he was leading the Pullman strike in 1894 and being jailed in 1918 for denouncing official persecution of pacifists accused of sedition under the Espionage Act in World War I. Unfortunately for commuters on the Long Island Rail Road, however, these latter-day tributes to the saintly qualities of the warmhearted Hoosier who five times ran for President on the Socialist ticket still have not been translated into adoption of the thoroughly hard-headed reform for which Debs crusaded in his early career as a challenger of craft union elitism in railway labor.

title: Two Sad Stories
description: In the eye of the storm that disturbs and threatens the nation's highly profitable ''television ministries,'' the Rev. Jerry Falwell urges their devoted followers not to ''let Satan win the day.''

title: 5 HARD-LINE P.L.O. FACTIONS SET TOUGH CONDITIONS FOR ENDING RIFT
description: Representatives of five hard-line guerrilla factions have set tough conditions for closing ranks within the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: EVANGELISTS DIVIDED OVER THEOLOGY
description: The Jim Bakker episode has brought to the surface longstanding but latent doctrinal and stylistic divisions within the closely related but sometimes fiercely competitive family of television preachers.

title: John W. Hinckley Jr. Seeks Unescorted Call on Parents
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., who attempted to assassinate President Reagan in 1981, is seeking permission from a Federal court to leave a mental hospital for an unescorted visit with his parents, the Secret Service said today.

title: At Least 4 Are Killed In West Beirut Blast
description: An explosion rocked west Beirut today and the police said at least four people were killed.

title: M.T.A. WON'T CHARGE 10 IN MICHAEL STEWART CASE
description: Ten transit police officers will not face departmental charges in connection with the 1983 arrest and death of Michael Stewart, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board decided yesterday.

title: Plea in Constitution Attack
description: A Colorado man pleaded guilty today to a charge of destroying Government property when he tried to attack the United States Constitution with a hammer last Oct. 10. The man, Randall Husar, 37 years old, broke the glass display case that holds the Constitution at the National Archives. Guards seized him before the document was damaged.

title: Lighting Bolt May Have Caused Rocket's Failure
description: A lightning bolt that struck shortly after the launching is considered a ''possible cause'' of the mishap that led to the destruction of the Atlas-Centaur rocket Thursday, space agency engineers said yesterday.

title: KOCH TO URGE COURT TO BAR A.T.& T. MOVE
description: Mayor Koch warned the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday that the city would ''sue the hell out of you'' if the company carried out plans to move much of its staff from its Manhattan headquarters to New Jersey.

title: Review; CONCERT: JANET AND ST. LUKE'S GROUP
description: Dame Janet Baker shared slightly less than half of Wednesday night's Carnegie Hall concert with the Orchestra of St. Luke's, but she obviously filled the hearts of her listeners.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary and its headline in some editions on Thursday about Sarah Goddard Power misidentified a position she held. She was deputy assistant secretary for human rights and social affairs in the United States Department of State.

title: February Consumer Prices Up 0.4%
description: Consumer prices climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Government reported today, intensifying the concerns of economists about inflation.

title: Review; JAZZ: ALL-STAR BENEFIT FOR TRUMPETER
description: The totally all-star band that played a program made up largely of arrangements from the repertory of Howard McGhee's big band of the 1960's on Thursday in the auditorium of Parsons School of Design gave an exceptionally vivid display of the jazz world's admiration and affection for the 69-year-old trumpeter. Proceeds from the concert will help pay medical expenses for Mr. McGhee, who has been seriously ill.

title:
Patents;
Nominations Asked For the Hall of Fame
description: LEAD: A call has been issued for nominations to the National Inventors Hall of Fame for 1988. They must be submitted by July 1. Induction ceremonies will be held next February, with selection based on American patents.

title: Europe's Prices Rise
description: Consumer prices in the 12 European Community nations rose three-tenths of 1 percent in February, the community's statistics agency, Eurostat, said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A brief article in Weekend yesterday about a cornet performance by Butch Morris gave an incorrect date.

title: ISLANDERS RALLY TO TIE CAPITALS
description: They left the game just as they had entered it, a single point ahead of the Washington Capitals, the team that poses the gravest challenge to the Islanders' grasp on second place in the Patrick Division, a spot that yields home-ice advantage in the playoffs and the chance to avoid meeting the Flyers in the opening round.

title: Your Money; Universal Life: Some Caveats
description: UNIVERSAL life insurance, trumpeted by many companies and brokers in recent years as the ''answer'' for an individual's insurance needs, has indeed been a useful product for thousands of policyholders. But there also may be drawbacks in this kind of insurance.

title: Verdi Medal Awarded
description: Robert Sherman, executive producer of WQXR-FM and AM, has been awarded this year's Verdi Medal for ''outstanding service to the world of music.'' The award dinner, is given annually by the Metropolitan Opera National Council, was last night.

title: THE OSCARS, A CAVALCADE OF CAPPED TEETH
description: If this year's Academy Awards are anything like last year's, 65 million Americans and millions more people in half the planet's countries, from Britain to Bangladesh and beyond, will spend part of Monday night - or their time zone's equivalent - watching what some Hollywood insiders call the cavalcade of capped teeth.

title: EUGEN JOCHUM, CONDUCTOR OF GERMAN CLASSICS
description: Eugen Jochum, one of the last representatives of the traditional German school of conducting and the founder of the Bavarian Radio Symphony, died Thursday at his home in Munich after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Mystery Writers' Group Has Officers' Election
description: Mary Higgins Clark has been elected president of the Mystery Writers of America, the organization announced this week.

title: TENSION LIVES AT BIG SHELTER NEAR BOWERY
description: ''Chicken Day'' always draws a crowd to the Shelter Care Center for Men on East Third Street, near the Bowery. But one recent day, wet and windy weather, as well as chicken dinners, drove between 800 and 1,000 homeless men into the first floor and basement levels by 4 P.M.

title: Carmen McRae
description: Carmen McRae will sing, backed by a trio, tonight at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street (758-2272). There is a $25 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: QUARK: IT'S RARE AND DELICIOUS
description: The unheralded arrival of quark in New York City has not exactly set the food community on its ear. Quark will never replace cream cheese or sour cream in the American diet. In fact, perhaps the only people who care about this cheese are those who ate it as children in Germany, France or the Netherlands.

title: KNICKS HIT LOTTO NUMBER
description: Chuck Person scored 22 points and grabbed 18 rebounds, and Vern Fleming hit 5 straight points late in the game to lead the Pacers to a 100-91 victory over the Knicks tonight. The loss eliminated the Knicks from playoff contention.

title: Still Time for Negotiation in South Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Erasmus Hall and the Constitution Are 200 Together This Year
description: To the Editor:

title: A Double by a Weary Bidder Brought Confusion to Table
description: If there were a prize for the funniest deal of 1986, the one shown in the diagram would be a strong candidate.

title: A BATTLE OVER NEWARK ARK'S FUTURE
description: The ark, standing three stories tall in a church parking lot, is a sight to behold.

title: Garvey Speaks Out
description: Ed Garvey, the former executive director of the National Football League Players Association, said in Los Angeles yesterday that he didn't think the 1987 season would be interrupted by a strike. After a 30-minute speech to current and former players attending the union's convention, Garvey said that the ''successful'' strike in 1982, which he helped lead, and the current strength of the union should persuade league owners to negotiate a new collective bargaining agreement in good faith. The current agreement expires in August. ''This is a mature union, one that knows its strength,'' Garvey said at an informal news conference. ''Prior to 1982, the union never had a successful strike. Now, we have had one, and management knows that without the players there can be no football.'' Later, Gene Upshaw, Garvey's successor, announced that team representatives to the union had voted earlier in the week, by 27-1, to hold a strike authorization vote in May.

title: Initial Talks on Sale By Financial Corp.
description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that it had held preliminary discussions about being acquired by several separate companies or groups.

title: STATE DEPT. DETAILS ISRAELI ARMS TRADE TO PRETORIA
description: The State Department will detail to Congress next week the extensive arms trade between Israel and South Africa in a report that could cause problems for Israel in Congress, Government officials said today.

title: OFFICIAL SEES RETALIATION
description: In a strongly worded protest, the Japanese Government called on the United States to reverse its decision to impose tariffs on selected Japanese products.

title: Girl Said 'Iran,' Reagan Insists
description: President Reagan today found himself disagreeing with an 11-year-old girl about a question she asked him.

title: KEY RATES
Eritrea Also Seeks Self-Sufficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: INQUIRY FROM F.B.I. REPORTED BY AGENT
description: Norby Walters, the sports agent, said that he was interviewed by two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents in his New York office today regarding alleged threats made by him and an associate against various football players and agents. Walters denied having made threats or having any knowledge about threats.

title: Florida Shooting Plea
description: The man who fatally shot Pablo Lopez, a Florida State football player, last Sept. 13 outside a student dance hall in Tallahasee, Fla., has pleaded no contest to a reduced manslaughter charge, maintaining the shooting was a case of self-defense. Byron C. Johnson, 21 years old, who was released from prison on a $20,000 bond in November, had been initially charged with first-degree murder, then had the charge reduced to second-degree murder and finally to manslaughter. In pleading no contest, Johnson gave up his right to a jury trial and a future appeal. He faces a maximum of 10 years in the state prison system.

title: Data Interchange Gets a Test Spin
description: AS each new step toward the computerization of our world is taken, the one just ventured is accepted as long-given. For example, the Universal Product Code was but a gleam in the eyes of computer visionaries a decade ago. Soon, no doubt, bar codes will be incorporated into haute couture, and the U.P.C. will perch proudly on shirt pockets, a high-tech alligator rampant.

title: HOW WILL THE METS AND YANKS DO IN 1987?
description: Don't bet on a Subway Series in 1987. Although the Mets and Yankees will win their share of games, I don't expect either to win their division. The Mets won't win because of complacency and inconsistency; the Yankees because of lack of depth (especially pitching) and Righetti's burnout. JUDY GOLDBERG Kew Gardens, Queens

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''They brought an old dog back to life, and the market was glad to have it back.'' - Brian Hunter, Dritz Goldring floor broker, on Conrail's public offering.

title: MILLIONS OF BOOKS ARE TURNING TO DUST - CAN THEY BE SAVED?
description: LEAD: IMAGINE the New York Public Library's 88 miles of bookshelves, and then imagine 35 miles' worth of those books crumbling between their covers. Library of Congress officials estimate that 77,000 books among their 13 million enter the endangered category each year. At least 40 percent of the books in major research collections in the United

title: Beijing Reports Its Aide Met an Israeli at U.N.
description: China announced today that its representative had met with a senior Israeli official at the United Nations amid increased Israeli efforts to establish diplomatic relations with Beijing.

title: SNOW CHIEF READIES FOR GULFSTREAM HANDICAP
description: The horses were late being saddled for the fifth race at Gulfstream Park today, so most of the horseplayers were running to the windows by the time a dark colt stepped into the walking ring a minute after the runners for the fifth had left. A few fans waited to see him, though, clicking their cameras and smiling.

title: WATERFRONT PROJECT DEBATED
description: A FAMILY of developers in Port Jefferson is proposing a waterfront complex that, critics say, would transform the once-serene village into a bustling tourist town.

title: Photo of John W. Matthews (NYT)POLITICS; NASSAU DEMOCRATS SET GOALS
description: NASSAU COUNTY regularly produces the largest vote of any county in the state, but while its Republican Party is considered very strong, its Democratic Party is viewed by politicians as one of the weakest in the state.

title: Anne T. Robbins Engaged to Wed J. F. Mandeville
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Spalding Robbins of Fairfield, Conn., and Onancock, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Tiffany Robbins to Jonathan Fisk Mandeville, a son of Ann Mandeville, also of Fairfield, and Hubert Turner Mandeville of New York. The wedding will be in August.

title: Lawsuit Settled in Dismissal Over Coke-Pepsi Love Match
description: A settlement has been reached in a damage suit filed by a Coca-Cola bottling company worker who said she was dismissed after falling in love with a Pepsi employee.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN ANNUAL REPORTS
description: THE annual report we have come to know and hate is dead,'' proclaimed Edward Kulkosky, publisher of an investor-relations newsletter, in an article in The Wall Street Journal earlier this year.

title: PLAY, PHOTOGRAPHS OF THE BLACKLIST ERA
description: LEAD: IN an unusual tie-in of an exhibition with a dramatic production, the play ''Are You Now or Have You Ever Been'' by the writer and drama critic Eric Bentley will be presented in April by the Hudson River Museum Theater. The accompanying museum exhibition, ''The Photo League, 1936-1951,'' is of 60 documentary photographs taken by members of the league.

title: PANAMA MILITARY HOLDING TO POWER
description: Despite new pressures from the United States Congress intended to push Panama toward civilian rule, the military has shown no disposition to withdraw from its dominant position here.

title: Women Get 3-Point Shot
description: The N.C.A.A. Women's Basketball Rules Committee has adopted the 3-point field-goal shot from the same 19-feet-9-inch distance the men use.

title: SPRINGTIME CHORES FILL THE SCHEDULE
description: CONTINUE spring cleanup, especially on lawns, walks, patios and decks. Strawberries: If winter mulches are covering plants, remove them carefully but allow some to remain near crowns to prevent weed growth and keep summer fruits clean. Plant: If the ground is workable, seed another half row of spinach, peas and lettuce and set out onion sets for scallions; make tunnel ''covers'' of polyethylene to protect seedlings when frost threatens. Peaches: Since these fruit trees are subject to leaf curl, protect the young limbs and twigs with fungicide. Nursery Orders: It is getting late to mail orders to nurseries for first choices on rarer plants; be prompt. Plans: Finalize designs for the summer garden to be sure seed and plants will be available; coordinate color schemes with exterior decor. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS TRUE VIOLETS

title: 11 INFANTS ENROLLED IN CHICAGO CHILD-AID PROGRAM
description: Since January, 11 special babies have been born in Robert Taylor Homes, a high-rise public housing development on Chicago's South Side where births customarily get no special recognition.

title: PICKING UP THAT GLASS
description: LEAD: GARBAGE is a problem for all of Long Island's towns, and Huntington is no exception.

title: NEW YORK RACE TENSION IS RISING DESPITE GAINS
description: Despite some significant progress in race relations, most New Yorkers say important divisions between blacks and whites are now as wide as they were a decade ago, or wider.

title: PIANISTS, FLUTISTS, VIOLINIST, HORNIST AND GUITARIST
description: Mirian Conti

title: A SAMPLING OF HOUSE TOURS ACROSS NATION
description: Home is sweet indeed when marble mantels, gingerbread-trimmed turrets or stained-glass windows are among its charms. Showing off such architectural details has become a national pastime, particularly in spring when house-proud owners from Albany, Ore., to Zoar, Ohio, open their doors to the public in a myriad of historic home tours.

title: Susan Jean Martin Is Bride of Mark David Godvin
description: Susan Jean Martin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Martin of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark David Godvin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Godvin of Rumson, N.J. Msgr. Andrew T. Cusack, Episcopal Vicar of Clergy and Religious for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport, Conn., performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Church in Riverside, Conn., where he is the pastor.

title: HOW WILL THE METS AND YANKS DO IN 1987?
description: I think the Mets can do as well in '87 as they did in '86. The big question is the pitching: Will it be as consistent? If it is, then the Mets will be on top again. They have their same great players plus Dave Magadan and Kevin McReynolds.

title: HOSICE HELPS ON THE LAST VOYAGE
description: LEAD: A SILHOUETTE drawing of a lone person in a sailboat, tacking in the breeze, adorns the literature of the newly established hospice in Southold, a narrow strip of land where no one is more than five minutes from water. The solitary sailor is on a journey - to death, in the view of members of SHIP, the Southold Hospice in

title: Athletes and the Pressure to Perform
description: The behavior of Red Sox fans to visiting ball players can be atrocious, but I witnessed a touching episode at Fenway Park. I was seated next to the visitors' dugout for the last game of the Twins' series and saw Jim Eisenreich, who sat there during the game. The bleacher fans had placed a large poster on the back wall in right center field which read: ''Eisenreich Has Courage.''

title: NEW YORK SHELTERS MEET SPECIAL NEEDS OF ELDERLY
description: Leosh Horsky, who is in his 70's, spends much of his time in libraries, studying botany, Rembrandt and dentistry, which he practiced in his native Czechoslovakia. At the end of the day, he goes home - to a shelter for the homeless.

title: F. EDGAR DAVIS
description: F. Edgar Davis, a former senior vice president of Newsweek, died of pneumonia Wednesday at a Branford, Conn., hospice. He was 70 years old and lived in Plainfield, N.J.

title:
MUSIC;
BRITISH QUARTET
