title: THATCHER, IN SOVIET, LINKS ARMS PACT TO RIGHTS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher arrived in Moscow today with a message that progress on East-West arms control depended on Soviet observance of human rights.

title: 'Free TV' Still a Fantasy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Award for Killer of Husband
description: Constance Y. Moorehead, 34 years old, who shot her husband to death in 1984, has been awarded $31,000 by a jury based on the accidental death provision of his insurance policy. Her lawyer, F. Kirk Kolodner, said in Circuit Court Thursday that the husband, Nelson Moorehead, 24, probably did not believe she would shoot him because he had beaten her often without reprisal. Manslaughter charges were dropped by State's Attorney Warren Duckett, who concluded that she acted in self-defense. The jury awarded her $25,000 plus $6,335 in interest.

title: Elizabeth Musser To Become Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James G. Musser Jr. of Birmingham, Mich., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Anne Musser to Jeffrey Holmes Spurr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gregory W. Spurr Jr. of Short Hills, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: Comings and Goings
description: HE'S the newest head of the senior league, so it's only appropriate that Bart Giamatti should begin his first season as president of the National League by throwing out the first pitch for baseball's oldest team. He'll do that April 6 when the Cincinnati Reds open at home against the Montreal Expos. . . . Brad Benson, the Giants' Pro Bowl tackle, will be saluted April 8 at the Meadowlands Hilton Hotel in Secaucus, N.J., by a roaster roster that will include teammates Harry Carson, Joe Morris, George Martin and Jim Burt. Proceeds from the $100-a-plate dinner will go to the Colleen Giblin Foundation for pediatric neurological research. . . . Marques Johnson, the Los Angeles Clipper forward who was to undergo surgery Friday to repair a cervical disk injured last November, decided to postpone the operation indefinitely, the team announced. . . . Francie Larrieu-Smith, the 1985 winner, has entered the L'eggs Mini Marathon in Central Park May 30.

title: HER CANDLE BURNS AT ONE END
description: IN THE CITY By Joan Silber. 246 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: REMEMBER, WHERE THERE'S A TAG SALE, THERE'S A WAY
description: THERE are Westchester residents who diligently scan the weekly classifieds for moving, tag, garage and church sales. For the poor and rich alike, it is their weekend happy hunting ground. Let the less adventurous go to their golf clubs or stay home raking leaves. I am off early on Saturday mornings, for the bargains are snapped up by us eager beavers before lunch. Yet we keep in mind that on Sundays whatever picked-over goods are left, often go for absurdly low prices.

title: Steven J. Ford Marries Patricia Lynn, Lawyer
description: Patricia A. Lynn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Lynn of Skaneateles, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Steven J. Ford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Ford of New City, N.Y. The Rev. John J. Morse performed the ceremony at St. Mary's of the Lake Roman Catholic Church.

title: PROVIDENCE STRIVING TO JOIN THE BOOM BY LURING BUSINESS FROM ELSEWHERE
description: If you put up a new building in Providence, the Mayor will name a street after you.

title: S.M.U. May Cancel
description: ROSTER players and prospects are looking for other colleges, and some school officials are wondering if football should be resumed at all. Now, in the wake of the play-for-pay scandal that has cost Southern Methodist its 1987 season, the school is expected to announce this week that it will not return to the field in 1988 for the abbreviated season of seven road games allowed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. William B. Stallcup, the interim S.M.U. president, told The Dallas Morning News that ''several of the university's communities'' had urged him to cancel the 1988 season, and for a couple of persuasive reasons. ''One is that we wouldn't have enough kids to play. We don't want to put anyone in a position of being hurt. Secondly, it would give the university more time to make the decision about its future.'' Asked whether S.M.U. would play in 1988, he replied: ''Right now, I can't think of any strong arguments in attempting to do so.''

title: Jane Riley to Wed
description: The engagement of Jane Wilson Riley to Lieut. John P. Appleton, U.S.A., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Appleton Jr. of Stoneham, Mass., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Edward D. Riley of Larchmont, N.Y. Miss Riley, a senior at Villanova University, attended the United States Military Academy, of which her fiance is a graduate. The wedding to be June 14.

title: Ms. Strickler Plans to Wed
description: A September wedding is planned by Elizabeth Bolton Strickler and Mark Timothy Gallogly, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Strickler Jr. of New York and Colebrook, Conn., have announced. Mr. Gallogly is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Gallogly of Snug Harbor, R.I.

title: NATO NATIONS CONDUCTING WINTER MANEUVERS IN NORTHERN NORWAY
description: Four NATO countries are conducting maneuvers this week in northern Norway within the Arctic Circle to test the alliance's ability to defend its northern flank in the event of a Soviet attack.

title: CRIME IN THE CITY
description: In 21 of New York City's 75 police precincts, the number of reported murders jumped by 50 percent or more last year, the Police Department reported last week. The 34th Precinct in the Washington Heights section of Upper Manhattan, where street dealing in crack has become widespread, had the most murders of any precinct. By contrast, the 83rd Precinct in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn had a sharp decline in the number of murders. The total number of murders in the city rose 14.8 percent.

title:
PRO BASKETBALL;
WALTON PERSEVERES AMID THE PAIN
description: LEAD: Recently, Bill Walton resumed his super-sub role for the Boston Celtics after an ankle injury had sidelined him for the first 61 games of the season. Tuesday night, when the Celtics play at Madison Square Garden against the Knicks, Walton will be sitting again. Only days and a few games into his return, his right ankle is hurting once more.

title: RENOVATED THEATER FOSTERS HOPE
description: LEAD: LESS than two years ago, the Strand Theater in Seymour was so deteriorated that Tony Smith, the theater's newest proprietor, called it the ''temple of doom.''

title: Don't Poke Fun At Graduates
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Scrubbing Down 'Filthydelphia'

title: THE PRICE INDEX AS THE KEY TO STABILIZATION
description: Would the rent stabilization system be better off if landlords had to open their books? And would it make sense to require owners to submit audited statements of their cots beore they are granted stablized rent increases?

title: LAW LIMITING SMOKING CREATING FEW PROBLEMS
description: LEAD: BY MOST accounts, the new state law limiting smoking in the workplace has created little hue and cry.

title: Debate Resumes on Libel Protection for Dead
description: A new set of legislative hearings began this week on a proposal to allow the families of dead people to sue for libel, a controversial measure that would break with centuries of legal tradition.

title:
ABOUT CARS;
Sleek Range Rover Passes Rugged Test
description: LEAD: THE town is called Tuxedo, but there is not much formality there. Certainly, there is nothing formal about this ''road.'' The woods close in, and there is barely room for the Range Rover's boxy bulk. Branches gouge its silver paint. There are large rocks, tree stumps. And this is just the beginning, the easy part.

title: Of Koch's Power To Sway Cities
description: SOME 1,500 municipal officials at a convention of the National League of Cities in San Antonio gave Mayor Koch a standing ovation in November after he urged the group to declare war on narcotics.

title: PARKS PROGRAM SEEKS EDUCATORS
description: LEAD: IF you love working with children, are 18 years old or older and have some experience in ecology, agriculture or American history, the county's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation may have a summer job for you.

title: DELICATE FLAVOR OF MAPLE ENHANCES THE DESSERT MENU
description: AMONG the annual rites of spring is the flow of sap in the sugar maples. Although it is not an important event in this immediate locality, maple-sugaring represents a substantial industry in upstate New York, New England and Canada. A few weeks ago the Canadians in the province of Quebec were concerned that an extended spell of unseasonably cold weather might hinder or delay the maple-sugaring season.

title: NICOTINE: HARDER TO KICK...THAN HEROIN
description: DESPITE OVERWHELMING EVIDENCE that tobacco is destroying their health and shortening their lives, 53 million Americans continue to smoke. Increasingly aware that their addiction is also harmful to their children and co-workers, they continue to puff away on 570 billion cigarettes a year.

title: August Wedding Planned By Kimberli Kay Walliser
description: Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Walliser of Denver have announced the engagement of their daughter Kimberli Kay Walliser to David Neil Sonnenblick, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur I. Sonnenblick of Larchmont, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: MOUNTAIN RAIL PLANS STIR FEAR FOR UNSKILLED SKIERS
description: Among seasoned skiers, the run at Tuckerman Ravine on Mount Washington is considered so dangerous that only the foremost experts should risk it.

title: Haitians Voting Today on a New Way of Life
description: In the most decrepit slums of this impoverished country and in the cool hills where the rich live in luxurious villas, there was a rare mood of ebullience today as people prepared to vote Sunday on a constitution that defines a new way of life in Haiti.

title:
THE WORLD;
By 1999 Portugal Will Leave China
description: LEAD: For 430 years, Macao, a gambling haven on the South China Sea, has been a colony of Portugal. Last week, Portugal and China agreed that China will take back the colony in 1999, two years after Britain is to give back Hong Kong, 40 miles to the northeast. Prime Ministers Zhao Ziyang of China and Mario Soares of Portugal are to sign the agreement next month, making Portugal, the first European country to establish itself on the Asian mainland, the last to give up its colony in

title: SLEEK AND SUITED FOR ACTION
description: BATHING SUITS COULD ONCE be easily classified as either athletic or chic. The racing styles sold in sporting goods stores came in decidedly functional cuts and only a few colors. Bikinis and strapless one-piece suits were fine for reclining on the chaise longue but often fell off during a brisk swim.

title: No Headline
description: AFTER a day's work as an investment banker in Manhattan, Gene Bedell left work earlier than usual, taking the 5:10 express and arriving in Greenwich 41 minutes later. In another hour, Mr. Bedell was skipping rope, shadow-boxing and pounding away at the speed and heavy bags in a small area near the suspended track at the Greenwich Y.M.C.A.

title: Andrea Zukaukas To Marry in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles L. Zukaukas of Long Branch, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Andrea J. Zukaukas to Mark R. Aikins, a son of Ellen K. Aikins of West Long Branch, N.J., and the late Judge Louis R. Aikins of New Jersey Superior Court. A May wedding is planned.

title: DESPITE STUCK ELEVATOR 2 ADVANCE AT NATIONALS
description: OPERATION overload, with which the bridge organizers grappled earlier this month at the Spring Nationals in St. Louis, has only a nominal connection with Operation Overlord, which carried the Allies into Western Europe in 1944. Both involved physical danger and adaptable staff work.

title: A MOTHER'S CRUELTY IN 'THE SILVER CORD'
description: WHO are the real, the irredeemable contemporary villains in theater -those destructive, mean-spirited characters who thrive on wrecking lives?

title: CRIME
description: It is nice to encounter talent, and most of the debutnovels in this batch manage to grab one's interest thanks to smooth writing, deft characterizations and able storytelling.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
NEXT TO DIAMONDS, SHOULDER PADS ARE A GIRL'S BEST FRIEND
description: LEAD: DIAMONDS may be a girl's best friend, but shoulder pads are a woman's. And so are elastic waistbands and the floppy sweater look, all of which were hot this year.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Owings Mills, Md.: A 'New Town' Still Growing
description: LEAD: A SIX-MILE, $178 million rapid-transit line extension to this suburban ''new town'' in northwest Baltimore County is expected to bring on a surge in its development.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Tyson's Corner, Va.; Innovations To Ease Traffic
description: FIFTEEN years ago, Tyson's Corner was little more than pastureland, but it now has a reputation for some of the worst traffic problems in the Washington area. Sixty thousand cars stream every day into this cluster of corporate headquarters and retail shopping.

title: Laurie Roth Married To a University Aide
description: Laurie Roth, assistant director of admissions counseling at the Bernard N. Baruch College of the City University of New York, was married last night to Roddy G. Austin, assistant director of information systems at Polytechnic University in Brooklyn. Rabbi Nathaniel H. Schwartz and the Rev. James R. Corgee, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Linda Marcovici to Wed
description: Linda Anne Marcovici, a financial and planning associate at National Westminster Bank USA in New York, and Seth Phillip Plattus, an associate at the New York law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, plan to be married June 14. The future bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Marcovici of Dix Hills and Westhampton Beach, L.I., who have announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Plattus of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: THE ARTS -- REAL OR VISIONARY? STUDENTS EXPLORE THE ANSWERS
description: LEAD: AT the Summer Arts Institute here, impressionism is served for lunch and Mozart after dinner. Between meals, students can sample Goya and gouache, ballet and bel canto.

title: On the Look-Out For No-Shows In Albany
description: Guess who's coming to work? The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, would rather know for certain, so he subpoenaed personnel records of all 18 State Legislators from Manhattan last week in a rapidly widening investigation of legislative payroll abuses.

title: Stock Strategies
description: To the Editor:

title: Celeste Gallagher Is Engaged to Douglas W. Tulin
description: Dr. and Mrs. Philip G. Gallagher of Weston, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Celeste Elizabeth Marie Gallagher to Douglas Wise Tulin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Wise Tulin of Larchmont, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: HUNTINGTON VOTE TO TEST OPINION OF LANDFILL LAW
description: LEAD: AS property owners in much of Huntington Town go to the polls this Tuesday, their ballots on a referendum requesting approval of a new garbage district may serve as one of Long Island's first tests of voter reaction to the growing costs of meeting the mandate imposed by the Long Island Landfill Closure

title: POIGNANCY PRESIDES AT TOWN MEETING
description: It took the town almost an hour to decide between the big $54,000 six-wheel dump truck that Roland E. Bergeron said his Road Department needed to plow and maintain the roads, and the smaller $25,000 model with automatic transmission and power steering that Warren Adams, the chairman of the Planning Board, said would do most of the same work and could be shared with the Recreation Commission in summer.

title: Capitalizing On a Name
description: Manuel Scharf, a Brooklyn developer, knows that home buyers like Park Slope. But he concedes that his new town-house development, called the Villas at Park Slope, is actually situated in a fringe area that some call Park Slope South and others call Greenwood Heights.

title: The New Flirt
description: Maureen Dowd's irony makes abundantly clear why modern woman isn't being treated as she would like by modern man.

title: SURMOUNTING A DEVELOPMENT DILEMMA
description: TO Manhattan's already unlikely mixture of sliver towers and lollipop condominiums, another unusual architectural style may be added. Buildings Commissioner Charles M. Smith Jr. called it ''early Robinson Crusoe.''

title: INVESTING;
description: LEAD: Many investors assume that mutual funds specializing in over-the-counter stocks are full of risky, volatile ''penny'' stocks that may evaporate overnight. But, in fact, the typical company in the Over-the-Counter Securities Fund is a stable, profitable nuts-and-bolts concern with a solid balance sheet.

title: HIGH SCHOOL PRINCIPAL'S SUSPENSION UPSETS CONNECTICUT TOWN
description: The suspension of a high school principal here after he disciplined a student has riled this quiet, affluent Fairfield County town.

title: Sheryl Leff and K. S. Ring, Physicians, Wed in Queens
description: At Temple Shalom of the Electchester Jewish Center in Fresh Meadows, Queens, last night Dr. Sheryl L. Leff, a resident in radiology at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, and Dr. Kenneth S. Ring, a resident in surgery at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan, were married by Rabbi Steven M. Graber.

title: ARTIST'S PATH TOWARD DREAM
description: LEAD: THE calendar said March, but this Saturday was as glorious as any in May. Mid-70 degree temperatures and a sunny, bright blue sky beckoned nearly everyone to postpone indoor chores and frolic outdoors.

title: Carlotta A. Fendig To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Carlotta Anne Fendig to Wendell Lewis Willkie 2d, has been announced by the mother of the future bride, Mrs. Philip Franklin Fendig of Washington. Miss Fendig is the daughter also of the late Mr. Fendig. Her fiance is a son of Mrs. Edward M. Hall of Minneapolis and the late Philip H. Willkie. A June wedding is planned. Miss Fendig, a graduate of the University of Vermont, is a media specialist at the National Endowment for the Humanities in Washington, of which her fiance was formerly general counsel.

title: Broch and 'The Spell'
description: To the Editor:

title: HARVARD'S GIFTS TO GAG WRITING
description: SPORTING TWISTED TURRETS and mock cathedral windows, the castle-like home of the Harvard Lampoon stands on an island in the center of Cambridge's Mt. Auburn Street. The front facade resembles a winking face, with the eyes, nose and mouth formed by windows and doors. It has a flagpole out front and a statue of an ibis on the roof. What it doesn't have is a sign outside pointing ''This way to Hollywood'' or ''This way to a job on 'The David Letterman Show.' '' But there might as well be such a sign.

title: EAST END ACTS TO SPUR HOUSING
description: LEAD: WITH real-estate values continuing to escalate rapidly on the East End, area officials are stepping up efforts to provide housing for year-round residents of modest incomes.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DINNIEABBIESISTER-R-R! By Riki Levinson. Illustrated by Helen Cogancherry. 90 pp. New York: Bradbury Press. $11.95. (Ages 6 to 9)

title: Ex-Rep. Tim L. Carter, Kentucky Republican
description: Former Representative Tim Lee Carter, a Republican who called for the withdrawal of United States troops from Vietnam in 1967, died of anemia Friday, his doctor said. He was 76 years old.

title: No Headline
description: ON THE SATURDAY BEFORE THE final week of the Baby M trial in New Jersey, I went to visit Noel Keane, the lawyer who had arranged the contested contract in that case. He was doing business as usual, which meant that his comfortable two-story offices in Dearborn, Mich., were full of prospective surrogate mothers, often with husbands and babies in tow, and infertile couples who had come to check out the candidates for surrogacy. The well-groomed couples, who had come from as far away as New York and Texas, were each assigned a private office, through which the surrogates were rotated, to proffer their fertility and show off the living, gurgling proof thereof.

title:
DINING OUT;
JAPANESE FARE ALONG THE PALISADES
description: LEAD: TRIM and spare little storefronts are the usual setting for Japanese fare in New Jersey, so to pull up to Shinwa - a luxurious restaurant inside a California Grandiose building complete with valet parking - causes some double-takes.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BIRD CARVING Janet Somoroff and Dr. Sam Weinstock will give their third bird-carving workshop at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich beginning Tuesday from 7 to 10 P.M.

title: Brazilian Bishop Planning a 'Pilgrimage' to Israel
description: In a major step toward stimulating Roman Catholic-Jewish cooperation here, the president of Brazil's Bishops' Conference is to make an ''ecumenical pilgrimage'' to Israel next week at the invitation of Brazilian Jews.

title: For Philanthropists of Modest Means: Potholes
description: To the Editor:

title: Greek Junta Backers March
description: More than 4,000 backers of Greece's military dictatorship of 1967-74 marched through Athens today demanding the immediate release of 17 former officers serving prison terms. The protest followed a memorial service at Athens Cathedral for a junta leader, Gen. Odysseas Angelis, 75 years old, who committed suicide by hanging himself in his jail cell last week.

title: Time to Be Serious About the War on Drugs; Coercion Won't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Edith G. Brand Is Engaged to Lyman Townsend Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abel Lineberger Brand of Middletown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Edith Gingrich Brand to Lyman Bass Townsend Jr., a son of Mrs. Louis Busch Hager of New York and Cooperstown, N.Y., and Mr. Townsend of Pittsford, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Ellen Adrienne Gold Wed in Philadelphia
description: Ellen Adrienne Gold, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney A. Gold of Cheltenham, Pa., was married yesterday to Daniel Softness, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Softness of New York. Rabbi Elliott Holin officiated at the College of Physicians of Philadelphia.

title: Exotic Abundance From the Amazon
description: When Ana Maria Martins decided to open a restaurant that serves the best of Amazon cooking, she began her search for recipes in the heart of the Brazilian rain forest, not far from Belem. She traveled upstream to the family farm in Alenquer, on the bank of the mighty river. There, in the large, traditional kitchen, cut off from processed foods and condiments, she learned to work with the produce of the world's largest collection of forest and river life.

title:
POLAND;
ILLEGAL DRAMA IN LIVING ROOMS - AND A BIT OF CULTURAL BREATHING SPACE
description: LEAD: THE STAGE WAS THE living room of an apartment, the actors were some of the leading professionals from Warsaw's best theaters, and the play was a work by Pavel Kohout, the emigre Czechoslovak playwright now living in Vienna.

title: Aquino Goes for Military Victory
description: The olive branch did not work, Corazon C. Aquino said, so she is taking up the sword against leftist insurgents and rightist terrorists. Speaking at graduation ceremonies last week at the Philippine Military Academy, President Aquino said her offers of peace and reconciliation had been met ''with the most bloody and insolent rejections.'' She vowed to ''smite the foe'' and go for military victories in both quarters.

title: WHAT REFORM WROUGHT
description: UP 'TIL NOW A Memoir. By Eugene McCarthy. 273 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

title: A Fulfillment
description: MY OLDEST SON is 39 years old, my youngest barely 1. The nearly four decades that separate them include my entire professional career, from graduate school into retirement. They include, too, the births of my grandchildren, two failed marriages and then marriage, once again, to someone too young to remember the Beatles. I, at 67, remember silent movies.

title:
DINING OUT;
IN STORMVILLE, ELEGANCE, COMFORT
description: LEAD: OVER the last 16 years, Harralds has acquired something of a name for itself not only in this area but across the country.

title: Editor to Wed Dr. Matthews
description: The engagement of Dr. Lisa Gordon Matthews to Michael G. Molyneux has been announced by Lydia Matthews and Mortimer J. Matthews, both of Pasadena, Calif., parents of the bride-to-be. Mr. Molyneux is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Molyneux of Richmond Hill, Queens.

title: GREEKS AND TURKS EASE AEGEAN CRISIS
description: The crisis between Greece and Turkey over oil-drilling rights in the Aegean appeared to ease today, and Greece withdrew its demand for the temporary closing of a major United States naval installation.

title: THE HIT MAN WITH A HEART
description: PARADISE MAN By Jerome Charyn. 240 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $17.95.

title: Elizabeth Henderson to Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Warwick Peter Henderson of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Warwick Henderson to Robert John Andrew Coleman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Coleman of New York and Fishers Island, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title:
TAKING CARE;
PLAQUE CONTROL
description: LEAD: A FEW YEARS AGO, PLAQUE WAS JUST a technical term that dentists used and their patients ignored. Today, it is the rallying cry of pharmaceutical companies and their advertising agencies throughout the United States. Picking up on what dental journals have been reporting for years, marketing strategists have finally targeted plaque - the almost invisible film that builds up on teeth - as the nation's primary deterrent to oral health.

title: BAKKER'S TROUBLES TEST FAITH AT RELIGIOUS RESORT
description: A few miles outside the Heritage USA complex, the faces of Jim and Tammy Bakker suddenly appear, offering a huge, smiling welcome from a billboard along the highway. From that moment on, a visitor to this Christian resort is entering a different realm, one rocked in recent days by the unfolding controversy around Mr. Bakker.

title: Taxis Scratch A 7-Year Itch
description: New York City's taxi drivers got their first significant fare increase in seven years last week - and Taxi and Limousine Commission Chairman Gorman Gilbert said there just might also be a benefit or two for the rider.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
SPECIAL TIMES
description: LEAD: ANTOINE BOBEN misses his father. ''He passed away,''

title: Landmark at Risk
description: City and Suburban Homes, turn-of-the-century tenements on the Upper East Side, represented, at the time they were built, a more humane way of housing the poor. Still home to hundreds of working people, the 14-building complex with 1,254 units is threatened by the plan of the owner, Peter S. Kalikow, to erect a 65-story tower on the eastern third of the site. It would mean razing four of the buildings and the loss of 400 units.

title: NAVY VARSITY TOPS PRINCETON
description: The Navy varsity heavyweight crew prevented Princeton from dominating the Lake Carnegie races today by winning the varsity contest.

title: FIGHTING DRUGS IN A BRONX SCHOOL, BY THE BOOK
description: When Beryl Dorsett took over as interim principal of Public School 73 last September, the building was surrounded by the flourishing drug trade of the South Bronx. So she turned to the Federal Government for help in protecting her students.

title: Amherst to Shut Road To Save Salamanders
description: Two weeks after Hambleden, England, opened a tunnel under a road for its toads' mating season, Amherst has approved closing a street to save the lives of salamanders.

title: STILL 'TOUGH' CARPENTER HOPES FOR GOOD DYS AGAIN
description: THERE has always been a special aura around Bobby Carpenter, but lately - as he's been shipped around the National Hockey League like so much excess baggage - it has been tinged with unpleasantness instead of promise.

title: PROVIDENCE DINER, 97, VS. CITY HALL, '87
description: Every afternoon at 5 a truck tows a small trailer-diner to a corner outside City Hall. The diner, in one form or another, has been selling hamburgers, hot dogs and other snacks there for 97 years.

title: Verbatim; Homeless Generation
description: 'When I read in your report that there are 11,000 children in hotels and shelters, half of whom are under age five, my feeling was confirmed that unless we do something to change their living conditions soon, we will have created an entire generation of disaffected and angry young people.' - David N. Dinkins Manhattan Borough President, commenting on a report produced by his office's Task Force on Housing for Homeless Families.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; New Strategies for Affordable Housing
description: WESTCHESTER COUNTY has little affordable housing for the family in the $29,000- to $50,000-a-year bracket, and several housing experts say the problem has reached crisis proportions.

title: Miss Speyer to Wed M. M. Schieffelin
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. Joseph Frederick Speyer of Willington, Conn., and Anne Mattison Speyer of Middletown Springs, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter Katherine Elsa Speyer to Michael Markoe Schieffelin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin 3d of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The wedding is to be in July.

title: CLEANING THE HOUSE: SO MUCH WORK FOR SO LITTLE RESPECT
description: LAST summer my 20-year-old daughter gave me an unsolicited discount when I hired her to clean my Fire Island house on a weekly basis. When she announced that housecleaning was the perfect way to earn enough money to tide her over the winter while she was in college, I fired (with no ill feelings) a very likable young man, set the ground rules that I was to be treated like any other client, and sat back to watch her amass her fortune.

title: OUR SAVIOR TOPS MOLLOY FOR TITLE
description: Our Saviour Lutheran, a Bronx private school with 145 students, won the Class A state federation championship by upsetting Molloy, the state's top-ranked team, 71-61, tonight at the Civic Center.

title: MOYNIHAN SEEKING NOFZIGER TESTIMONY
description: LEAD: A FORMER adviser to President Reagan is being asked to testify at a Senate subcommittee hearing expected later this spring to tell what he did to help the Long Island Lighting Company advance toward a Federal license for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: A CLEAN CLOSET IS A CLEANSED SOUL
description: I SPENT an afternoon throwing things out with my mom today, and tonight I am faced with the results - a mound of postcards, autographs and travelogues from my teen-age days. There are even two diaries that my mother, when telling of the find to me on the phone two weeks ago, was wise enough to say, ''Don't worry. I didn't read them. I don't want to get ulcers over what you did 20 years ago.''

title: GRIEF AND ANGER FOR HARLEM FIRE VICTIMS
description: More than 700 people, grieving and angry, packed a Harlem church yesterday afternoon to mourn four victims of the high-rise blaze that took seven lives in Harlem last week.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: EASTER DAY, 1941. By G. F. Borden. (Beech Tree/ Morrow, $16.95.) The recent spate of books and movies about the ''Vietnam experience'' may cause a younger generation of readers to overlook the terrible fighting that occurred in World War II - ''the big one,'' as its veterans call it. A nasty reminder of that war is the convincing first novel by G.

title: SURPRISING MATCHUP FOR FINAL
description: The championship game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament between Louisiana Tech and Tennessee Sunday ''could be a backstreet brawl,'' the Louisiana Tech coach said today.

title: FINALLY, AL GIACCO RETIRES -- MAYBE
description: IF YOU want to see Al Giacco's eyes twinkle, ask him about the time Hercules Inc. developed a silent candy wrapper just because he heard Gene Shalit, the film critic, complain about the sound of candy being opened at the movies. Or about the time he took a tip from the bottled water craze and started to sell bottled methanol.

title: SCULPTURE AS A HIGH-WIRE PERFORMANCE
description: THE SCULPTURE OF NANCY Graves has for some years divided opinion the way Moses divided the Red Sea. There are those who prize it as a source of endless and rewarding astonishment, and there are those who find it contrived, inept, affected, flimsy and arguably not sculpture at all. Between the two camps, lines are clearly drawn and never crossed. Now is the best possible time to see what the fuss is about.

title: HOW WILL THE METS AND YANKS DO IN 1987?
description: Behind the bats of Mattingly, Henderson, Winfield, Pagliarulo, Pasqua, and newcomer Gary Ward, the Yankees will have no problem outscoring their opponents this season. Of course they'll have to because pitching is a sore spot.

title: In Defense Of the Black Market
description: It is hardly by chance that Mario Vargas Llosa described the life of Hernando de Soto, the theoretician of the market, and not the life of the practitioners, the street vendors of Peru. If he had done the latter, readers would have to reflect on what it means to get up at 3 every morning, drag heavy bags of merchandise across town on an inadequate bus system, bribe middlemen and compete for street-corner space, hold wet, dirty babies in a shawl throughout the day, live on a diet of fried potatoes and see one's children drop out of school in the second or third grade to help in selling. Of course, human beings will do anything to survive and support their children, but desperation is hardly a moral basis for an economic system.

title: THE 34TH: MURDERS SURGE AS CRACK SPREADS
description: IN the desolate early-morning hours or during the midday rush, in seemingly respectable apartments or in abandoned buildings, the drug trade in Washington Heights flourishes with the dependability of a 24-hour supermarket. And it is at least partly for that reason, the police say, that this pastiche of middle- and working-class neighborhoods in northern Manhattan has turned into the city's murder capital. The 34th Precinct, which includes all of Washington Heights and some of Inwood, reported 72 murders last year, up 50 percent from the year before and more than in any other precinct in the city. The precinct has a population estimated at up to 250,000.

title: A.T.&T.'s Move Angers Koch
description: The pink granite headquarters of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is more than just another Manhattan skyscraper. The monumental building represented the turnaround of the mid-1970's depression in real estate and reflected the strength of the Bell empire in the days before deregulation.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: STORIES WE LISTENED TO. By John Haines. (Bench Press, 408 Haverford Place, Swarthmore, Pa., 19081, Cloth, $16; Paper, $8.) To the question ''Why on earth would anyone want to live in the wilderness?'' John Haines provides a lyrical answer in this short book of essays about life in Alaska. His is not the ooh-and-ah prose of travel writing, or the macho rhythm of outdoor magazines or even the Linnaean detail of nature books. Rather, Mr. Haines, a poet-homesteader who worked and wrote for 15 years in the bush, sets his scenes and tells his stories from the point of view of someone who loves his demanding environment deeply but still is somewhat in awe of what it can do. He has the eye of an Audubon and the style of a Thoreau. He describes an encounter with a grizzly bear in terms that graphically communicate his barely controlled fear. In ''Death Is a Meadowlark,'' he finds the perfect carcass of a frozen bird, a ''tiny, quenched image of vitality.'' But, as if fearful that we will think him sentimental, he goes on to describe the killing and dressing-out of a moose, and in so doing gives us a peep into the ecological cycles of death and rebirth. His people are rawhide men, ''bent to the cordwood and the trap''; but, as Mr. Haines says of one of them, ''as long as he can walk or stand he will stay with this life of snow, of fur, of solitude and dogs.'' In Mr. Haines's wilderness, the seeker will find ''a freshness denied him in the place he came from.'' This wondrous land is lighted by a major talent telling his stories in a haunting minor key.

title: AN IDEA THAT CAME FROM OUTER SPACE
description: JOSH SIMPSON'S work in glass reflects his view of what the universe looks like.

title: Spain Trial Opening in Toxic Cooking-Oil Scandal
description: A six-year-old Spanish scandal involving tainted cooking oil, in which more than 600 people have died, goes to court Monday with the opening of the trial of 40 importers accused in the case.

title: U.S. MARINE GUARDS LEADING LONELY, ISOLATED LIFE IN SOVIET
description: A United States Embassy guard, shaken by reports that two of his fellow marines helped Soviet agents infiltrate the embassy last year, turned to a diplomat on Friday and said, ''Everyone is going to think we are a bunch of Communists.''

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: DOUBTS ABOUT 'CAUSE-RELATED' MARKETING;
A Dangerous Trend in Corporate Giving
description: LEAD: AS THE 200th anniversary of the Constitution draws near, we can be reasonably sure that deals will be struck between non-profit institutions involved in the celebration and corporations looking to market their products. On the surface, the deals will seem a boon to both, with the corporations building their sales and burnishing their images, and the nonprofits pocketing some much-needed cash.

title: REGION SCORES WELL ON BUSINESS GROWTH
description: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have received high marks in comparison with other states on a ''development report card'' issued by a Washington-based economic research organization.

title: B.P. Sets Its Sights On All of Standard
description: British Petroleum is seeking the rest of Standard Oil at $70 a share, or $7.4 billion, which would be the third-largest acquisition in the United States. But analysts say B.P., which already owns 55 percent of Standard, may have to come up with more money to prevail. The move would allow B.P. a greater foothold for development of American oil and gas resources, but analysts note it also would further concentrate B.P.'s dependence on Alaskan and North Sea oil. However, most analysts say the move, which was not unexepected, is smart now, while oil and gas properties are cheaper and the market appears poised for a rebound.

title: A NAZI PAST AND THE PRESENT
description: FOR more than 30 years, Karl Linnas, who is now 67 years old, lived quietly on Long Island, supporting himself as a draftsman. Before that, according to the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations, Mr. Linnas was commandant of a Nazi concentration camp in Estonia where 12,000 people perished.

title: Resolving Contractor Disputes
description: WATER is dripping from the skylight, the tiles are the wrong shade of blue and, although the job was supposed to be completed by November, it is almost April and the work still is not done.

title: WHEN THE PAST IMPROVES THE PRESENT
description: SATCHEL PAIGE, whose baseball career stretched over many, many years, once advised, ''Don't look back. Something may be gaining on you.'' I have always appreciated the sly humor of his remark and accepted the wisdom of his advice. I have never bothered to attend any of my high-school reunions. I do not pine for my old hometown. For me there has been no going back. The town where I grew up has changed. My classmates have changed. Certainly I know that I have changed. I live happily in the present. Life today is full enough on its own. I have felt no need to try to cram the past into it as well.

title: Peaceful Pursuits
description: When he was President, the quest for peace in the Middle East ''was almost an obsession with me,'' Jimmy Carter said. It evidently remains high up on his list of concerns. In a five-nation tour of the region, which ended last week, Mr. Carter talked with a host of national leaders in hopes of getting them to talk to each other. Afterward, he called for bilateral negotiations between Israel and Syria. Mr. Carter, whose arrival in Israel March 26 coincided with the eighth anniversary of the Egypt-Israel peace treaty that he helped negotiate, criticized President Reagan's policies, saying Mr. Reagan had not made Middle East peace ''nearly as high a priority as it was with me.'' The White House has disputed this, saying Mr. Reagan ''has demonstated a continuing diplomatic effort'' in the region.

title: SUMPREME COURT REAFFIRMS REJECTION OF A REAGAN TENET
description: ITrrxh was not only the Supreme Court's most sweeping endorsement of affirmative action after nine years of agonizing, splintering and seesawing on the issue. It was also a stunning setback to the Reagan Administration's last-ditch effort to turn back the kinds of preferences for women and minorities that thousands of employers already have in place.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Austin, Tex.;
A Bonanza For Students
description: LEAD: THE tide of new-home construction here that accompanied an influx of high-tech industries and an oil boom in the early 1980's has ebbed, leaving the flotsam of bankruptcies and foreclosures in its wake.

title: SEPARATING FATS FROM FICTION
description: REDUCING FAT and cholesterol consumption is fast emerging as the primary dietary concern of the late 1980's - with confusion as its hallmark. And it is not only the consumer who is confused. Many doctors are just learning the up-to-date facts about fats and cholesterol in the diets and bloodstreams of average Americans.

title: DANCE: A TRIBUTE TO FOUNDER OF JULLIARD DIVISION
description: Martha Hill, who founded the Juilliard School Dance Division in 1951, was honored Thursday night with a testimonial dinner. But perhaps the best tribute took place immediately afterward at a 35th-anniversary gala at the Juilliard Theater - a showcase of dance works by the division's faculty and alumni, danced by the students Miss Hill has nurtured.

title: INCINERATION VS. RECYLCING?
description: LEAD: THE Town of North Hempstead's plan to build a resource recovery plant in the Port Washington sand pits to handle up to 990 tons of garbage a day has caused a strident reaction against it.

title: FROM SCARSDALE TO ALBANY
description: Amid charges that it was being insensitive to the needs of inner-city children, the New York State Board of Regents last week elected Dr. Thomas Sobol, the Scarsdale Superintendent of Schools, as State Commissioner of Education.

title: Israeli Salt in the Pollard Wound
description: Spying is a deadly business.

title: THE STRUGGLE TO BELONG
description: SONG IN A WEARY THROAT An American Pilgrimage. By Pauli Murray. Illustrated. 451 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $23.95.

title: HOSPITAL PROFITS ON MEDICARE RISE UNDER A SYSTEM TO CONTROL COSTS
description: Profits earned by hospitals on the treatment of Medicare patients have been substantially higher than expected under a payment system established three years ago to control the costs of the Federal health program for the elderly, Government officials say.

title: PANEL TO EXAMINE PRISON CROWDING
description: FOR the second time in six years, a county task force has been appointed to examine the persistent problem of prison overcrowding, which in the last year has reached unprecedented levels at the Westchester Correctional Complex in Valhalla.

title: JIMMY ERNST MURAL MOVED FROM HOUSE
description: LEAD: WHEN Owen A. Perla, a Hewlett insurance agent, and his fiancee, Susan Campbell, purchased their summer house in the Hamptons last year, they got more than an ordinary beach cottage.

title: TECHNOLOGY STEALS THE THUNDER
description: MARSHALL McLuhan's famous description of television, ''the medium is the message,'' could be applied as easily to popular music. In the last 50 years - and especially since the mid-1960's - changing technology has altered the form, shape, scale and even the meaning of popular music. Increasingly, its subject has become the ambiguous relationship between people and machines.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
BRITAIN INTRODUCES A NEW ROUND POUND
description: LEAD: THIS year's version of Britain's ''round pound'' portrays a majestic English oak piercing the center of the royal diadem worn by the British monarch to Parliament's state opening. It is the fourth and final design in a special series which has featured botanical themes. Although the first one-pound coin, issued in 1983, depicted the royal coat of arms, each annual issue since then has had a plant theme.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: 3-Day Sale Offers Designer Knits A three-day sale Friday, Saturday and next Sunday in Crugers from noon to 5 P.M. features designer knits by Bonnie Case in natural fibers -cotton and wool - and in rayon alone or rayon blended with metallics. Yarn in balls, skeins or on cones is also part of the sale, plus square wooden beads at 50 cents a string for knitting into clothing designs, or re-stringing into bracelets, necklaces or earrings.

title: Air Today, Gone Tomorrow
description: LEAD: CLEVELAND Not long ago, I presented myself to an agent at the New York Air counter. This was hardly surprising since my plane ticket was tucked snugly inside a bright red folder marked ''New York Air.'' But I was in a tentative mood, so I asked, ''Is this New York Air?''

title: AN OPERA? NO, IT'S A (GASP!) SET
description: THE ''BAYREUTH HUSH,'' THE REVERENTIAL, all but palpable silence that prevails during performances in the Wagnerian shrine known as the Festspielhaus, is part of operatic legend. Well, don't be jealous, New York. You are developing your own legend: the ''Metropolitan gasp.'' The latest manifestation of the phenomenon - the sudden, communal drawing-in of breath, followed by fervent hand clapping - comes during Franco Zeffirelli's (sometimes known as Puccini's) ''Turandot.'' The Act II, Scene 2 curtain rises on a dazzlingly bright throne room so grandiosely proportioned that the poor old Emperor of China becomes a fly on a distant wall. Does it matter that the set is so deep that people in balcony and family circle seats complain that they cannot see the Emperor or, in fact, much of whatever it is that goads the main floor to stunned applause? Apparently not to those who control the destinies of the Metropolitan, where every new production evidently must now offer at least one show-stopping visual coup rivaling Broadway's ''Starlight Express.'' What does all this current fascination with empty spectacle mean, and where can it lead? A Spenglerian pessimist might point out, for a start, that Rome in decline specialized in circuses.

title: Photo of sign for Lakeview Motels; HOMELESS IN CORTLANDS ASK FOR RETURN OF STOVES
description: ''VERYBODY is afraid of us,'' said Martha Frye, who has been homeless for three years and was making a plea to the Cortlandt Zoning Board of Appeals to let her continue to live at the Lakeview Motel on Route 6.

title: A NEW STREETLIGHT BRINGS DARKNESS
description: A STREETLIGHT appeared on the telephone pole in front of my house this evening. Last night it was not there nor was it there on any other evening for the last five years. My dedicated and disciplined street-watching can attest to that.

title: TWO OTHER ERRATICS CAN EASILY BE SEEN
description: I enjoyed Mr. [ Lincoln ] Diamant's notes on erratics. [ ''Travels of a Rock,'' Opinion Page, Feb. 15. ] May I offer a brief supplement?

title: June Bingham Marries Robert B. Birge
description: June Rossbach Bingham and Robert Bowen Birge were married yesterday in the Edgehill Church at Spuyten Duyvil in the Bronx. The Rev. William N. Lovell, a Congregational minister who graduated in 1936 from Yale College with the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: CHAIN THAT YOUNG man to a computer,'' said John Tower, ''and feed him baloney sandwiches.'' Thus did the chairman of the Reagan-appointed board to investigate Iran-contra arms dealings assign the task of writing ''Appendix B'' to Nicholas Rostow, a staff member borrowed from the State Department who had academic training in diplomatic history.

title: ANGER AMD ELATION AT RULING ON AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: THOSE on both sides of the issue agree that the Supreme Court's decision in Johnson v.

title: C.I.A.'S REPORT REVIVES SOVIET-GROWTH DEBATES
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that the Soviet economy significantly improved last year, putting the agency at odds with some Western specialists who say the Soviet Union has modified statistical procedures to conceal economic problems.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE BOYS OF BENSONHURST. By Salvatore La Puma. (University of Georgia, $13.95.) In Salvatore La Puma's Brooklyn of the 1940's, Italian-American kids are pulled between the rigors of Roman Catholicism and the lure of the mob. Winner of this year's Flannery O'Connor Award for Short Fiction, ''The Boys of Bensonhurst,'' Mr.

title: MIDDLE-INCOME HOMES SET FOR INWOOD LOTTERY
description: LEAD: THE Town of Hempstead says it wants to keep middle-income people from fleeing the town because of the lack of affordable housing, and to this end it plans to sell three acres of its land in southwestern Inwood to a developer to construct 19 single-family homes that will cost from $75,000 to $80,000.

title: A SPY DIVIDED
description: JERICHO MOSAIC By Edward Whittemore. 374 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: OLD GAMES FOR NEW PLAYERS
description: LEAD: FIVE years ago, Constance Karkowski became frustrated at being unable to find the kinds of games she wanted her children to play.

title: Munich
description: To the Editor: I read with interest ''What's Doing in Munich'' (Travel, March 1) and would like to add a museum to it.

title: OF RESEARCH AND REPUTATION
description: In what has been described as a battle between the haves and the have nots, the academic community is debating how Federal money should be awarded for building and renovating university research facilities. Should Congress continue its current practice of giving the money directly to universities, without a review of the scientific merit of the proposals, or should schools compete for the money on the basis of their reputations as research institutions?

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
THE STRUGGLE TO CONTROL NOMINATIONS
description: LEAD: IF there ever existed such creatures as casual observers of the Connecticut General Assembly, they might be startled at the nature of this year's bitterest issue. No, it isn't teen-age pregnancy, increasing homelessness, jammed highways or school funding. It is who controls the nomination for governor.

title: Politics of Nuclear Burial Breeds Distrust
description: To the Editor:

title: OFF YUCATAN, AN ISOLATED PRESERVE
description: Last Thanksgiving my midday meal included grilled sea mackerel, thick chunks of papaya and a nibble from a ceviche made with conch harvested that morning. Not a traditional combination, but it wasn't supposed to be anything special. It was just the normal luncheon menu on the Lucky Hooker's regular Thursday run from Cancun, Mexico, to the wildlife preserve island of Contoy.

title: In Today's Issue: Good Health
description: Part 2 of The Times Magazine today is The Good Health Magazine, including these special reports: * Doctor and patient: striving for a better relationship. * Clearing up the confusion over fats and cholesterol. * Why nicotine may be the most potent of addictive drugs. * The father of aerobics, on the future of the fitness movement.

title: VIEWS OF 19th-CENTURY LIFE FROM THE LENSES OF WOMEN
description: LEAD: THE leisure time of well-to-do Victorian women was as circumscribed as every other aspect of their lives. They were encouraged to fill their days with needlework, music, literature and the decorative arts, all activities that kept them in the home. When development in photography made the new art form acceptable to the amateur, adventurous ladies took to it with enthusiasm.

title: A GUIDE TO STRESS TESTS
description: LEAD: IF YOU ARE IN A HIGH-RISK CATE-gory for developing coronary artery disease or have recently suffered a heart attack, you are clearly a candidate for a stress test. But agreement among most physicians as to who should take the test ends there. Increasingly debated is whether middle-aged adults with no significant risk factors for heart disease need a stress test as part of a routine physical.

title: Kohl and Mitterrand Consult On Terms of Mid-Range Pact
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that they were in accord on the terms of a Soviet-American deal to withdraw medium-range missiles from Europe.

title: Farewell, First Ladies
description: Right at the start, perhaps on Inauguration Day, the next First Lady of the United States will ask Government officials, press, television, diplomats and the whole blessed country never to call her the First Lady.

title: India Won't Help Stop Pakistan Bomb Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES HOT OFF THE TUBE
description: VIEWERS WHO CAN'T wait to see the latest hit movies from their favorite armchair now have a cable service intended just for them. It's called PPV - short for Pay-Per-View. By showing popular feature films about half a year ahead of their presentation on regular pay channels (and about a month before their release on cassettes) PPV also gives avid video fans a chance to be the first to tape these features while they're hot.

title: PASTOR TELLS OF GUILT OVER INTRODUCING PAIR
description: The evangelist who brought the Rev. Jim Bakker together with a young woman for what became a sexual encounter says he has been been tortured with guilt.

title: TANNING SALONS MAY FACE LICENSING
description: WHen Jennifer Tyree and her friend Aida Sabato went to an Upper East Side health club a few weeks ago in search of tans, they came away temporarily blinded.

title: A DOZEN DIE AS ULSTER'S REBELS FEUD
description: Gangs of Irish nationalist gunmen have turned on each other in the West Belfast ghetto, slaying a dozen of their own people in street violence that echoes more with underworld vendetta than traditional anti-British fighting.

title: CACHE OF MAYAN ARTIFACTS FOUND AT ANCIENT SITE IN HONDURAS
description: An unusually well-preserved cache of artifacts, including exquisite jade carvings and a shell that may contain the blood of a Mayan king, has been uncovered in the ancient city of Copan in Honduras, according to a team of archeologists.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: A BILL that would ease restrictions on the disposal of construction debris has stalled, at least temporarily, in the Assembly, with both supporters and opponents claiming the environmentalist mantle.

title:
GARDENING;
IGNORED PERENNIALS FOR A NEW LOOK
description: LEAD: GARDENERS tend to get into a rut when it comes to selecting plants for their gardens. Too frequently, they plant the same old things, ignoring others that are just as good if not better. Perennials are no exception. Certain plants are overused, while others are overlooked. As a result, many gardens lack diversity and interest.

title: The Misalliance
description: AS a novelist, Anita Brookner is frequently compared with Jean Rhys, the author, most famously, of ''Wide Sargasso Sea.'' The comparison of the two Englishwomen is irresistible. In their slim, precisely composed novels, both depict the extreme isolation of a type of heroine one might describe as a female dandy, a deracinated woman who has been abandoned, often by a married man. Yet whereas Rhys's work bristles with an electrifyingly savage rage against all mankind - and especially the well protected - Anita Brookner's fiction is safer and more life-affirming. Ms. Brookner's Blanches and Fannys and Kittys and Ediths don't want to scratch other women's eyes out or to lie in a darkened bedroom all day with a bottle of absinthe and a handful of sleeping pills: they simply want husbands to cook for.

title: No Deficiencies At Bucknell
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN THE SANDS OF SINAI, AN ANCIENT MONASTERY
description: Believed to be the oldest Christian monastery in uninterrupted existence, it is the only Christian religious edifice with a mosque within its walls and possibly the sole Christian shrine granted protection and freedom from taxation in a letter from the Prophet Mohammed. The monastery is St. Catherine's, a massive fort-like structure created by the Roman Emperor Justinian at the foot of the traditional site of Mt. Sinai 1,456 years ago.

title: MORRISTOWN RESTAGES THE REVOLUTION
description: THE opening round of a season of re-enactments has been fired at Morristown National Historical Park. The fusillade - by 100 musketeers in Colonial Army garb - was discharged earlier this month at a ''grand encampment'' of volunteers from New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Maryland.

title: Data Update
description: BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED (Housing units) Jan. 87 c. 86 Jan. 86 New York 3,040 4,961 3,223 New Jersey 3,047 5,338 3,146 Connecticut 1,232 1,784 1,227 *3*Source: U.S. Department of Commerce, Census Bureau *2*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES(Averages) New York Last Week Previous Week Year Ago Conventional (30-yr) 9.24 9.28 10.36 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 7.39 7.40 8.36 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 9.15 9.16 10.19 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 7.45 7.50 8.82 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 9.21 9.24 10.28 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 7.51 7.53 8.85 Co-ops (N.Y.) ?Conventional (30 yr) 9.89 9.91 10.93 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 7.51 7.53 9.38 *2*Indexes for Adjustable-Rate Mortgages* 1-yr. Treasury security 5.99 6.06 7.01 National Mortgage 8.89 8.89 10.46 Contract Rate Source: HSH Associates * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: Singles
description: To the Editor: I have been widowed about a year and a half. I have the time and inclination to travel. I cannot get into a hotel unless I am willing to spend for two. All rooms are double occupancy. A room will rent for anywhere from $75 to $100 per night, but I can't get a single room.

title: HOME VIDEO: MOVIES
description: KID GALAHAD Starring Elvis Presley. MGM/UA Home Video. 1962. 96 minutes. $69.95.

title: MARKETING WEST GERMAN ARMS
description: THE issue was illicit arms shipments to an embargoed country, and a legislative commission held hearings. Some witnesses -Government employees and industry executives - simply could not remember key events; the head of Government said he was unaware of any wrongdoing, and his senior foreign policy aide said he had not bothered to read a key contract that lay on his desk for months before he fed it into a shredder.

title: Anne C. Harleman to Wed Peter S. Krieger on June 27
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Robert Ferguson Harleman of Cambridge and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Curry Harleman to Peter Small Krieger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Weston Krieger of Summit and Monmouth Beach, N.J. The wedding is to be June 27.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
South Hadley, Mass.: Store's Odyssey Is Near an End
description: LEAD: A NEW building for Romeo Grenier's Odyssey Book Shop, which was burned out of two business locations over a five-month period, will be a cornerstone of a $7 million development program planned by Mount Holyoke College.

title: Time to Be Serious About the War on Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: BEST SELLERS: MARCH 29, 1987
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List FICTION 1 2 2 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 1 8 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment as Ambassador to Rumania. 3 3 9 THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, two princes, an evil wizard and a mouse. 4 4 3 BOLT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) The jockey-hero of ''Break In'' has to contend with a romantic crisis, a family feud and an international arms-selling intrigue. 5 5 35 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 6 1 DESTINY, by Sally Beauman. (Bantam, $19.95.) (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) From the Boston slums of Irish immigrants to the White House: three generations of a family. 4 4 47 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.)
