description: FUNDAMENTAL CHANGES IN THE WAY fresh seafood is prepared, sparked in part by a rising tide of interest in Japanese and other Eastern cuisines, have added a bright new stripe to America's culinary spinnaker. Happily, the benefits go beyond matters of taste. The new style of seafood cooking, which minimizes cooking time and shuns heavy sauces, is good for you.

title: ITALY ASKS VATICAN EXTRADITION
description: Italy has asked the Vatican to extradite an American Archbishop and two colleagues charged with being accessories to fraudulent bankruptcy.

title: IN HER PLAYBILL COLLECTION, 60 YEARS OF THEATRICAL MEMORIES
description: ''I DON'T go buying them. I don't swap them. I don't beg them,'' said Estelle Oldak of Port Washington.

title: FOOD
description: LEAD: I STILL REMEMBER THE JOY of going to the local bakery on New York's West Side for layered buttercream cakes that cost only 25 cents and served 12. Sadly, I saw the neighborhood family-owned bake shop -pork store and corner grocer, too - disappear. Immigrant families matured and moved to the suburbs, and giant supermarkets crushed the small, independent shopkeeper.

title: THE DANCE: DANA REITZ
description: SHE was no ordinary mortal dancing. Instead, she was an apparition born of the darkness and to the darkness returning. That was the impression Dana Reitz gave in ''Circumstantial Evidence,'' the new solo she performed Thursday night at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
BALL TO AID RETARDED
description: LEAD: CHARLES and Emily Kingsley helped their 12-year-old son, Jason, write the little speech he gave at the Rye Town Hilton Inn last weekend, but the ideas, they said, were all their boy's:

title: ROAD WORK AT RISK IF VETO IS UPHELD
description: President Reagan's veto of a Federal highway and mass transit bill, coming at the start of the prime road construction season in New York and New Jersey, could delay many projects and threatens thousands of workers with layoffs, according to officials in the two states.

title: TOWNS REBUFF GREENWICH
description: LEAD: SUPERVISOR John A. Lombardi of North Castle has a long memory. He recalls that 20 years ago, adjacent Greenwich, Conn., was not as neighborly as he would have liked it to be. So now when Greenwich officials are looking for across-the-border relationships, he is skeptical and not planning to get involved.

title: SACRED ANDROGYNY
description: LEAD: THE SPIRIT AND THE FLESH Sexual Diversity in American Indian Culture. By Walter L. Williams. Illustrated. 344 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $21.95.

title: N.Y. TOWNS REBUFF GREENWICH
description: LEAD: JOHN A. LOMBARDI, the Supervisor of the Westchester town of North Castle, recalls that 20 years ago adjacent Greenwich was not as neighborly as he would have liked in a zoning case that affected his town. So now, as Greenwich is resisting a zoning plan in North Castle and is seeking an across-the-border accommodation, Mr.

title: Billion-Dollar Tax Fraud Is Charged
description: The money was big, and so were the names. Three financiers, one of whom was once known as the boy wonder of tax shelters, were indicted on charges of creating fictitious losses of over $1 billion so that more than 100 wealthy investors could improperly deduct $350 million on their tax returns.

title: MINOR U.S. IMPACT SEEN FROM TARIFFS
description: The stiff tariffs that the Reagan Administration plans to impose on Japanese imports could lead to some price increases for American consumers, but the overall impact should not be dramatic, according to executives in the electronics industry and to figures released by the Government.

title: THE 83RD: STABILITY RISE, MURDERS DECLINE
description: A DECADE ago, despair was everywhere on the rubble-strewn streets of Bushwick, a northeast Brooklyn neighborhood abutting Queens.

title: A NEW LIGHT IN THE SKY
description: ON A DINGY BASEMENT office of the California Institute of Technology's astronomy department in Pasadena, Christine Wilson has surrounded herself with symbols of her earthly passions: a volleyball schedule is taped on a wall near her desk; next to it, a cartoon about how falling in love is like having cooties. Tacked onto a bulletin board is a reminder that ''Life Is Too Short to Drink Cheap Beer,'' and hanging from a bookshelf is the red-and-white uniform of her Sweet Adeline quartet.

title: Profits Have a Place in Philanthropy
description: AS THE 200th birthday of the Constitution approaches, questions are being raised about a marketing technique - cause-related marketing - that increasingly is becoming a major means of bankrolling such public celebrations. There are fears that this marketing approach could co-opt nonprofit institutions and dilute corporations' traditional philanthropic commitment. But these fears, while understandable, are not supported by the facts.

title: HOME VIDEO: MUSIC
description: WHITNEY HOUSTON: THE No. 1 VIDEO HITS RCA/Columbia Home Video. 18 minutes. $14.95.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MARCH 29, 1987
description: REGIONAL 26-32, 38-42 Divisions between whites and blacks are now as wide or wider than they were a decade ago, most New Yorkers say. Many also say that racial tension in the New York area has increased markedly in the last several months. 1 Inquiries into 6 local school boards are being conducted by the New York City Board of Education's Inspector General, the president of the central board said. 26 Letting families of dead people sue for libel was the subject of legislative hearings begun last week in Albany on a bill that would break with centuries of legal tradition. 32 Local effects of the President's veto of a Federal highway and mass transit bill will include many delayed projects in New York and New Jersey. 29 Weston, Conn., has been riled by the suspension of its high school principal after he disciplined a student. Most of the students and many of the parents at Weston High School have supported the principal. 26 Focus in Baby M case narrowed 26 Talk-show host accuses caller of harrassment 31 Shelters meet needs of elderly 38 NATIONAl 20-25, 34-37 How Marine guards are trained and deployed will be investigated in wake of reports that 2 security guards at the American Embassy in Moscow had cooperated with Soviet spies, the Deputy Defense Secretary said. 1 The Marine contingent in Moscow is in the spotlight because of reports that two former colleagues were involved in a Soviet spy operation. The affair has raised questions about the marines' vulnerability to Soviet influence. 14 Hospitals' profits from Medicare patients' treatment have been substantially higher than expected under a payment system established in 1984 to control costs of Federal health program for the elderly, Government officials say. 1 A dispute over airline delays has deepened between Administration and Congress because of a 25 percent increase in airline delays and cancelled flights in 1986 and predictions that the situation will worsen. 20 In New England, the town meeting is still the dominant form of government in small towns, but some experts in government are concerned that the tradition is suffering from apathy and alienation. 20 In Chicago, a child development plan is under way that begins wide-ranging care before children are born and continues until the children enter elementary school. The 3-year project receives Federal funds. 20 Pat Robertson tried to stay out of the battle among television evangelists as he pressed his crusade for the Presidency in New Hampshire. 24 The mood at Heritage USA, a Christian resort complex in South Carolina, has been one of shocked acceptance since the Rev. Jim Bakker's admissions of adultery. Among many of the faithful, it has all been viewed as part of God's plan. 24 A proposed rule to protect sea turtles has drawn protests from hundreds of Vietnamese-American and native Gulf Coast shrimp fishermen, who have put aside disputes of the past to ''fight this thing together,'' one shrimper said. 22 REGIONAL 26-32, 38-42 Divisions between whites and blacks are now as wide or wider than they were a decade ago, most New Yorkers say. Many also say that racial tension in the New York area has increased markedly in the last several months. 1 Inquiries into 6 local school boards are being conducted by the New York City Board of Education's Inspector General, the president of the central board said. 26 Letting families of dead people sue for libel was the subject of legislative hearings begun last week in Albany on a bill that would break with centuries of legal tradition. 32 Local effects of the President's veto of a Federal highway and mass transit bill will include many delayed projects in New York and New Jersey. 29 Weston, Conn., has been riled by the suspension of its high school principal after he disciplined a student. Most of the students and many of the parents at Weston High School have supported the principal. 26 Regan assails housing program 21 Focus in Baby M case narrowed 26 Talk-show host accuses caller of harrassment 31

title: TAKING THE PLUNGE IN KYOTO
description: LEAD: The landlord showing me a flat in an old quarter of Kyoto assured me many Japanese apartments and houses have no bath or shower -awfully difficult to believe, I thought, in a land where jammed commuter trains smell as fresh as a pine forest. But when a tidy looking tenant corroborated the landlord's claim I slapped down a month's rent.

title: Now Playing on 42d Street: Mr. Nobody
description: To the world, 42d Street has long symbolized action, throngs, entertainment, urbanity. A nexus of subways and buses, international neon marketplace, heart of the theater district and home of the New Year - Times Square and 42d Street are a part of the New York legend that all visitors want to see for themselves.

title: PRESERVING THE PAST IN MERRICK
description: Re ''A Stately Avenue Stirs Zoning Fight'': As a Merrick resident, real-estate broker and mortgage banker, I feel the past needs to be preserved. Since moving to Merrick, I have seen a townhouse development take away a wooded area on Sunrise Highway, a strip shopping center replace the Lannick House on Merrick Road, and the Merrick Gables Theater turned into office space. There is also a proposal for part of the preserve on Merrick Road to be turned into a shopping center. The Gables Area in which I live has a Spanish style, and new spot construction of single-family homes is not in similar style.

title: AIDS, Sex and Needles
description: Some 33,000 AIDS cases have been diagnosed so far, and an estimated 1.5 million Americans are already infected with the virus, half a million of them in New York City. In the shadow of the grim disease stalks another - an epidemic of fear. The task is to contain both.

title: BLACKS BEFORE THE CAMERA
description: Most early black photographers - a majority of whom photography periodicals overlook - worked in studios making individual and group portraits. In Columbia, S.C., such a photographer was Richard Samuel Roberts, who operated a studio for about 15 years - until his death in 1936. His customers were the proud, the patient and the pathetic - hewers of wood and those whom W. E. B. Du Bois called ''the talented tenth.'' The nearly 200 pictures in A TRUE LIKENESS: The Black South of Richard Samuel Roberts 1920-1936 (Bruccoli Clark/Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, Cloth, $34.50; Paper, $19.95) were selected from 3,000 glass plates stored in a crawl space under the Roberts home. They have been cleaned and restored by Phillip C. Dunn, an associate professor in the art department at the University of South Carolina. About 125 Columbians identified the subjects, among whom are George A. Elmore, who challenged South Carolina's all-white voting in a 1947 primary and won; Annie E. Plunkett, better known as Annie Greene Nelson, one of the state's first black woman novelists; Malinda Bolden, a schoolteacher whose grandson Charles became an astronaut; and future doctors and teachers who went North to college and returned to work and establish institutions to help others. One unidentified woman is pictured twice - once in her maid's apron, once with her jewelry and no apron. Roberts's pictures and the text by Mr. Dunn and his co-editor, Thomas L. Johnson, the assistant director of the South Caroliniana Library at the University of South Carolina, constitute a rich source for the history of a 1920's and 1930's Southern black urban community.

title: LONG ISLANDERS
description: In Full Swing THE Patty Kakes Rhythm Band was in full swing. And the audience at the Little Flower Residence, an adult home in Babylon, was clapping, stomping its feet, even dancing the Peabody.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE PERILS OF PAUL PURSUING ACADEME: AN EPISTOLARY ODYSSEY
description: LEAD: IN THIS season of college applications, student anxiety and parental pressure, it is good to remember that the race does not always belong to the swift.

title: HOME VIDEO: POETRY
description: POETRY IN MOTION With William Burroughs, Amiri Baraka, Allen Ginsberg, Charles Bukowski, Tom Waits and others. A film by Ron Mann. Voyager Press. 90 minutes. $39.95.

title: Jill Stanley-Brown Plans June Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward Garfield Stanley-Brown of Ridgewood, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jeanne Drake Stanley-Brown to Paul Robert Driscoll Jr., a son of Mr. Driscoll of Needham, Mass., and the late Genevieve Drisoll. The wedding will be June 20. Miss Stanley-Brown, who is known as Jill, is a registered nurse at the Children's Hospital in Boston and a candidate for a master's degree in nursing at Boston University. She graduated from Manhattanville College and the University of Pennsylvania School of Nursing. She made her debut at the St. Nicholas Society Ball in New York. Her father, who retired as associate director of surgery at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York, is an associate clinical professor of surgery at the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. The future bride is a great-great-granddaughter of President James A. Garfield.

title: CLASSES IN VERMONT: SCIENCE AND TALKING ABOUT IT
description: Dressed in patched jeans and a chamois shirt, his wool cap set at a rakish angle, Mark Gershman muscles an earth auger into a hole in the ice on a beaver pond. Clustered around him on the melting ice are a handful of colleagues who shout their approval as he hauls up the auger. Mr. Gershman has struck dirt.

title: Social Events; Helping Art and Research
description: Women and Art March 31 - A cocktail party and preview of a new exhibition, ''The Genius of the Fair Muse: Painting and Sculpture Celebrating American Women Artists, 1875-1945'' will be held at the Grand Central Art Galleries Educational Association, 24 West 57th Street. The event, from 6 to 9 P.M., will benefit the association's programs for students as well as other projects. The exhibition will be open to the public from April 1 through May 16. Preview tickets are $25. Call 212-757-6580. For the Newborn April 2 - The division of perinatal research at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, not quite a year old, is holding a benefit for its many projects in the Bruno Walter Auditorium at the Library of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. Carol Wincenc, a flutist, and Heidi Lehwalder, a harpist, will perform. Following the 7:30 P.M. concert, there will be a tasting of wines from the Capezzana Vineyard in the Tuscany region of Italy. Tickets are $125. Call 212-554-6361. A Healthier America April 2 - The National Center for Health Education is a private, nonprofit organization created in 1975 to improve the health of all Americans. The group is sponsoring a black-tie dinner-dance at the Pierre, at which James E. Burke, chairman of Johnson & Johnson, will accept an award on behalf of the company. The reception starts at 6:30 P.M.; dinner and dancing will follow. Tickets are $350. Call 212-755-1190. For the City's Homeless April 2 - The Child Development Center of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services operates day care centers for children of families living in welfare hotels and other temporary quarters. A cocktail party and fashion show to benefit the program at the Great Northern/ Regent Children's Center will be held at Le Cafe at Barneys New York. Tickets are $75. Call 212-582-6300, ext. 266. Of Art and Music April 3 - Billed as ''the world's largest international art fair,'' ArtExpo NY '87, will be at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center through April 6. There will be a preview of the show and a performance by the Ambassadors of Opera and Concert Worldwide, a group of singers and musicians from the Metropolitan Opera, from 3 to 8 P.M. Tickets are $20 at the door. Call 718-236-7779. A Whodunit Benefit April 3, 4 - The venerable Universalist Church on Central Park West at 76th Street will be the scene of numerous crimes in a dozen specially constructed ''crime scenes'' on Friday and Saturday night, including a stable, a graveyard (flashlights required) and ''the most menacing medical establishment since Dr. Frankenstein's.'' Celebrities will be there, along with some bona fide crime experts. The festive mayhem will occur from 8 to 11 P.M., with Sherry to steady the nerves. The benefit is for Landmark West, a preservation group on the Upper West Side. Tickets are $50. Call 212-496-8110. Hampton in New Jersey April 4 - Lionel Hampton will perform at a buffet dinner-dance in the newly designed A.T.&T. headquarters in Berkeley Heights, N.J. The black-tie evening that starts at 7:30 will benefit the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts in Summit. Tickets are $100, or $75 for those 35 years old and under. Call 201-273-9121. Williamstown Cabaret April 5 - For the last 32 summers, the Williamstown (Mass.) Theater Festival has presented 275 performances of almost 80 different productions. Once a year, actors present a fund-raising cabaret in New York. Treat Williams, Geraldine Fitzgerald, Celeste Holm, Blythe Danner, Lynn Redgrave, Richard Thomas, Ann Reinking and Mary Tyler Moore are scheduled to perform at the Manhattan Center, 311 West 34th Street. A 6 P.M. buffet opens the evening. Tickets are $175, or $25 for the show alone, which starts at 8. Call 212-599-4240. Aid for Mental Health April 6 - The Postgraduate Center for Mental Health is one of the largest nonprofit treatment facilities in the nation. The Performing Artists Counseling Service was formed as a division of the center in 1979 by Gwen Verdon for specialized treatment of those in the unstable field of acting. Marvin Hamlisch, Peter Allen and Patti LuPone will be among the performers at a benefit for the center starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. at the Broadway Ballroom in the Marriott Marquis Hotel. Dinner, dancing and entertainment by members of the cast of ''A Chorus Line'' will follow. Tickets are $350 and $500. Call 212-755-1190. A Museum Party April 6 - The associates division of younger professional people of the American Friends of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem is holding a black-tie benefit at Doubles in the Sherry Netherland. Cocktails are at 8 P.M., followed by a buffet supper and dancing. Tickets are $120, or $95 for museum members. Call 212-683-5190.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: DEAR FLOYD: I'M SORRY this letter is late. I had planned on coming to visit you Monday afternoon, but I got the call from your son, Bob, that morning. He told me the news.

title: THE LOOK OF SPRING: VERY SHORT
description: THE signs of spring are here. Crocuses are starting to bloom, robins have come out of hiding and all over town, young women are parading about in shorter skirts.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: TRADE VS. NATIONAL SECURITY;
Managing the Flow of Vital Technology
description: LEAD: THE Reagan Administration, like each of the eight previous administrations, professes a free-trade and open investment philosophy that it often must violate in practice. Most recently, concerns about national security have motivated several exceptions in high-technology industries. For example, both the Commerce Department and the Defense Department cited national security as the basis of their informal opposition to Japan Fujitsu Ltd.

title: 'OVER A DARK AND QUIET EMPIRE'
description: AN ARROW IN THE WALL Selected Poetry and Prose. By Andrei Voznesensky. Edited by William Jay Smith and F. D. Reeve. 344 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $22.95.

title: AMBITION VS. ART: ETERNAL TUG OF WAR
description: THAT MERCURIAL AND MUCH admired performer Martha Argerich once said that she loved playing the piano but hated being a pianist. Having a career in music, unfortunately, means both.

title: Catching Shrimp, Saving Turtles
description: Busloads of angry Louisiana shrimpers came to Washington last week to continue their battle with environmentalists over turtles. Every year more than 10,000 sea turtles become entangled and die in the nets of American shrimp fishermen. Without some protection, environmentalists fear four of the five species native to U.S. waters could dwindle to extinction.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If a country persists in putting people into prison because of their political and religious views, that's something you have to take into account when you gauge whether they are going to keep any agreements you reach on arms control.'' - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, en route to Moscow. [ 14:2. ]

title: REBEL'S RALLY IS THWARTED
description: They had no choice but to run with the Rebels. Long ago, before the birth of the 3-point basket, before the Final Four could fill a giant domed stadium and deliver a million-dollar check to each of the schools, the basketball team at Indiana was known as the Hurryin' Hoosiers.

title: Sale of Conrail Sets a Record
description: More than a decade ago, fearing a collapse of freight service in the Northeast, Congress voted to take several bankrupt railroads out of private hands. They became the Consolidated Rail Corporation and, given $7 billion of Federal money, became profitable. Last week the Government sold the corporation back to private investors, in a $1.65 billion stock offering, the largest in Wall Street history.

title: Paterno's Rose Fever
description: SPENDING the winter celebrating a national football championship can apparently take its toll on a coach and his players. Last Tuesday Joe Paterno canceled the first day of Penn State's spring practice because many of his players were suffering from pulled muscles and other assorted minor injuries. Before getting the drills under way yesterday with 116 players on hand, Paterno indicated that he, too, was suffering from a post-bowl malady, a sort of limelight burnout, since the Fiesta Bowl victory over Miami. ''You can only smell the roses so long,'' he said. ''After that you get sick of them, and that's about where I am.''

title: In Praise of New York
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: JOYCE LINDORFF, HARPSICHORD
description: THE revival of the harpsichord early in this century, by Wanda Landowska and others, was naturally most important for the performance of 18th-century music. But a fascinating side effect was the cultivation of new repertory for the instrument. This is not a tendency that petered out as French neo-Classicism ebbed. It has continued well into our own time, with contributions by composers of most every stylistic stripe.

title: BANGOR CHURCH REGAINS HOPE IT LOST IN SCANDAL
description: Since the Rev. Herman C. Frankland resigned as pastor of the Bangor Baptist Church 18 months ago, after admitting a sexual relationship with a church schoolteacher, the church members he left behind have struggled to regain financial and moral credibility.

title: TOO MANY LAWS, NOT ENOUGH NEED
description: IN a recent article on the proliferation of senseless, useless and meaningless bills that impede the legislative process in Hartford and impose heavy costs on the taxpayers, one word leaped out at me. The word ''only.'' The sentence: Lieut. Gov. Joseph J. Fauliso ''noted that 4,844 bills had been introduced in the 1981 session and only 547 became law.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the March 15 Noted With Pleasure column incorrectly listed ''In Trouble Again,'' a collection of travel essays. Granta is the publisher, Penguin the distributor.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CAITLIN: Life With Dylan Thomas. By Caitlin Thomas with George Tremlett. (Holt, $17.95.) Caitlin Macnamara, daughter of a ''great exhibitionist and show-off'' father and an intellectual, lesbian mother, wanted to be another Isadora Duncan.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
A MODEL SEDER
description: LEAD: Passover does not begin until sundown, April 13, but a group of youngsters will be getting a head start on this festival that commemorates the liberation of the ancient Jews from slavery in Egypt. Next Sunday at 9:30 A.M., they will gather at the Student Center at Pace University in Pleasantville for a model seder, a scaled-down version of the ritual Passover meal.

title: EFFORT ON TRUCK SAFETY INTENSIFIES
description: LEAD: MORE trucks than ever have been using the state's highways, transportation and police officials say, and last year, 31,966 trucks, 18 percent of those inspected at weigh stations by the state police, were cited for violations ranging from faulty equipment to overweight loads to improper licenses.

title: ROBERTSON SHIFTS POLITICAL TACK IN BID TO STEER CLEAR OF EVANGELISTS' BATTLE
description: Pressing his crusade for the Presidency in New Hampshire, the Rev. Pat Robertson worked hard this week to keep a distance from the battle enveloping his fellow television evangelists.

title: FREEDOM NOURISHES ARGENTINE MOVIES
description: Dormant for decades under a succession of authoritarian regimes, Argentina's film industry - heartened by the nation's return to democracy four years ago - is enjoying an artistic renaissance.

title: INSIDE
description: Maria von Trapp Is Dead Maria von Trapp, whose escape from the Nazis with her husband and children inspired the ''Sound of Music,'' has died at the age of 82. Page 30.

title: STAGE: 'LOVER YOU NOT,' A HOLOCAUST ALLEGORY
description: DAISY (Daria Maazel), the troubled teen-ager who storms through Wendy Kesselman's two-character one-act drama ''I Love You, I Love You Not,'' is a sullen problem child whose best friend is her kindly grandmother, Nana (Rita Karin). A gentle, nurturing woman of indomitable patience and solicitude, Nana tends a simple country cottage to which Daisy periodically repairs when the stresses of life overwhelm her.

title: BRIDGING THE YEARS THROUGH FRIENDSHIP
description: LEAD: BEE KARTON, 82 years old, has friends who were born if not yesterday, not too far from it. ''I have two ''adopted'' grandchildren named Adam and Beth, both nursery school age and too little to talk,'' Mrs. Karton said. ''When I go to their nursery school in Bridgeport, I play whatever they want - firehouse, fire drill, all kinds of games.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: RETURN OF ROOF URNS

title: Was Sartre a Stalinist?
description: To the Editor:

title: Athletes and the Pressure to Perform
description: It is unfortunate that a group of diseases that are as common and debilitating as the anxiety disorders are still so widely misunderstood. The anxiety disorders include panic disorder (which may progress to agoraphobia) and social phobia (which, in a discrete form, manifests as performance anxiety).

title: REAGAN'S TARIFF MAY DAMAGE NAKASONE, A FRIEND, AT HOME
description: By approving retaliatory trade measures against Japan on Friday, President Reagan may have harmed not only Japanese exporters but also his close ally, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: ROSEMARY KENT has three huge address books, labeled Texas, New York and Elsewhere, each loaded with names. She says that almost everyone in them is a friend of hers.

title: JUDICIAL PANEL STUDIES ALTERNATIVES TO SUING
description: LEAD: THREE years ago, saying that the judicial system was ''reaching the breaking point,'' Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz appointed a 20-member State Supreme Court committee to look into alternatives - such as mediation, arbitration, negotiation and conciliation - to the traditional adversary process.

title: Next Week; Who Will Win, Hagler Or Leonard, And Why?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: HOME VIDEO: NATURE
description: ATTRACTING BIRDS TO YOUR BACKYARD Written, directed and narrated by Michael Godfrey. With Roger Tory Peterson. Avi-Video 1-800-342-3825. 60 minutes. $59.95.

title: WRITING CONTEST: WHEN BAD IS GOOD
description: IT is once again the season of the Bulwer-Lytton Fiction Contest, an event in which Connecticut residents have regularly achieved considerable, although dubious, distinction.

title: Static and Discord In the World Of TV Evangelism
description: In the book of Matthew, Jesus tells his disciples of the prophecies that must be fulfilled before he returns to save the planet. Among the events that are to precede a Second Coming are earthquakes, famines, nation rising against nation, and the preaching of the gospel to each of the world's inhabitants.

title: CONCISION, PERCEPTION, AWARENESS - HAIKU
description: LEAD: RECENT writers on the phenomenon of postmodern literary minimalism, including John Barth in an article in these pages, rarely mention one of its most extreme examples: contemporary English-language haiku. Yet the radically experimental works being created by poets in the English-language haiku movement constitute one of today's most exciting literary developments.

title: Sawdust Spectacle
description: RINGLING BROS. AND BARNUM & BAILEY CIRCUS, 115TH EDITION Executive producer, Kenneth Feld. Family Home Entertainment. 110 minutes. $89.95.

title: Oral Roberts Bucks Eternity
description: Oral Roberts and God have settled their accounts. The television evangelist's loyal audience contributed close to $5 million after Mr. Roberts warned that unless he collected the money he needed for medical missionary work, God would ''call him home.''

title: ROASTING REAGAN: GUESS WHO LAUGHED LAST
description: He was, after all, the only real pro in the hall.

title: HUDSON HAPPY TO GET CHANCE
description: There are small scars of bitterness, even though Charles Hudson insists they are gone forever. He will tell you that he holds no grudges against the Phillies, his former employers, but he will also tell you that he cannot forget the injustices that developed in the past.

title: Peru Gold Discovery
description: President Alan Garcia said today that Peru has found gold deposits worth an estimated $1.3 billion in a jungle region near the Ecuadorean border about 610 miles north of here. He said the Government soon would install a $2 million treatment plant at Tomaque that would extract enough ore to provide an estimated $25 million profit by the end of the year.

title: FOR MILL TOWN'S COMEBACK, THE PLAY'S THE THING
description: ''Brush up your Shakespeare,'' two singing gangsters advised the other night on center stage in this careworn northern city. ''Just declaim a few lines from O-thel-la and they'll think you're a helluva fella.''

title: B.P. Head Sees Bid As a Housecleaning
description: Sir Peter Walters, the 56-year-old chairman of the British Petroleum Company, described his company's $7.4 billion offer last Thursday for the 45 percent of the Cleveland-based Standard Oil Company it does not already own almost as a bit of corporate housecleaning.

title: N.Y.U. TO RECEIVE $15 MILLION FOR HELLENIC STUDIES
description: A foundation created by Aristotle S. Onassis is giving New York University $15 million - the largest gift in the school's 156-year history - to establish a center for Hellenic studies.

title: QUEENS CONGRESSMAN BALANCES DUTIES IN CHURCH AND THE CAPITOL
description: Every Sunday morning, an old-time preacher ascends to the pulpit of the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Counting Sales
description: And speaking of books, former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has a book contract that is the envy of most American authors. It prohibits Little, Brown & Company, which has published four of his books, from selling them at cut-rate prices once sales begin to taper off. Publishers usually do not pay royalties on such ''remaindered'' books.

title: Geri Shapiro Weds Dr. Aaron Gindea
description: At Temple Beth-El in Cedarhurst, L.I., Geri Shapiro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Shapiro of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Dr. Aaron Gindea, a son of Mildred Gindea of Margate, Fla., and the late Abraham Gindea. Rabbi Abraham Wahrhaftig performed the ceremony.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MARCH 30, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9 An Israeli will give up a promotion because of the problems it had caused between Israel and the United States. The Israeli, an air force officer, is accused of recruiting an American intelligence analyst as a spy. Page A1 Israel's Herut Party elected a chairman, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who urged the 2,000 Herut convention delegates to fight any attempt to force Israel to relinquish the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. A9 In Siberia, remains of labor camps were shown to Western reporters. The Kolyma camps were where prisoners of the Stalin era were housed between their shifts at hard labor. A1 Margaret Thatcher's Soviet visit is a ''historic mission'' for peace, she said. But the British Prime Minister's first full day in the country had the tone and trappings of an election campaign at home. A8 An emigration plan for Soviet Jews will send emigres to Israel by way of Rumania, making it more difficult for them to settle in Europe or the United States instead, said an American rabbi who said he had negotiated the new procedure. A8 The Pope beatified five people in a move that could revive old disputes in Spain. Three of the five were Carmelite nuns who were executed in one of the most vicious phases of the Spanish Civil War. A7 News analysis: Andreas Papandreou faced down what was depicted in Greece as an American-backed threat from Turkey. But he traded short-term domestic political gains for long-term economic and diplomatic liabilities. A2 In Haiti, voter turnout was huge and political leaders and American observers said the voting seemed overwhelmingly in favor of a new constitution that promises freedom from past tyrannies. A3 P. W. Botha has begun his campaign for election with charges about the source of his opponents' funds and an excursion into the territory of his far-right rivals. A whites-only election is on May 6. A3 Japan is seen as an unfair trader by many in Washington, who resent that the world's second-largest economy exports everywhere but is reluctant to open its own markets. D1 News analysis: Chip dispute D11 NATIONAL A10-17, B6 The U.S. dollar plunged further against the yen today, at one point hitting a record low of 144.70 yen in the Tokyo foreign exchange market. This was the lowest since modern exchange rates were set in the late 1940's. A1 The President lobbied vigorously over the weekend to sustain his veto of an $88 billion highway and mass transit bill that would also allow states to raise the speed limit to 65 miles per hour on rural Interstates. A1 A Marine guard's conflicting stories about how he became entangled with a Soviet agent at the American Embassy in Moscow were told to investigators in three seperate interviews last year. The guard is accused of espionage. A1 Electrical power during nuclear war could be generated by several hundred small nuclear reactors that the Air Force is considering building, say Air Force, Department of Energy, Congressional and industry officials. A13 Protecting Nebraska's Platte River is the aim of an Audubon Society campaign. Conservationists say sandhill cranes are threatened by plans to divert the river for municipal and agricultural use. A10 The Supreme Court's senior liberal, William J. Brennan Jr., has written or assigned the majority opinions in all five of this term's most important decisions. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist has consistently dissented. A10 The move off welfare and into a job is being made easier for people who live in Massachusetts, Michigan and about 22 other states that have been experimenting with intensive counseling, education and training programs. A14 Was a snowwoman obscene, art or just a pile of snow? Milwaukee's Chief Prosecutor will consider the question as he decides whether to try a woman for taking her ax to a snow sculpture of a woman in a bikini. A11 WASHINGTON TALK A16 The N.S.C. under Carlucci Reagan laughs last at a roasting REGIONAL B1-5 A look at 2 New York high schools, John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx and suburban New Rochelle High School, reveals that racial and ethnic divisions remain. New Rochelle's schools superintendent says the high school is desegregated, ''but I'm not sure if it fulfills the ideal of an integrated school. I'm not sure the ideal of an integrated school exists in our country today.'' A1 An Arturo Toscanini collection of scores, letters, recordings and memorabilia that has been inaccessible since 1970 has been acquired by the New York Public Library under an agreement concluded last December. A1 Foster-care will not be withdrawn this summer, John Cardinal O'Connor said, setting aside his threat to stop Roman Catholic group services because a Federal court has requires that teen-agers be given birth control and abortion services. The Cardinal plans a court appeal. B1 Tuberculosis among homeless men in New York City is a rapidly growing problem, health officials say. The outbreak is so serious that last summer the city began sending health workers into the shelters to deliver medication. B1 A trash-energy plant was destroyed in Westbury, L.I. It had stood unused for seven years. A new, $350 million incineration plant is to be built on the site on Meadowbrook Parkway. B2 Some S.I. landowners protested a move by the State Department of Environmental Conservation to designate their property as wetlands. The landowners fear the action will block their rights to build there. B2 Briefs in Rubin Carter case filed B3

title: 4 ARE SLAIN IN BEIRUT IN PROTEST OVER FOOD, PALESTINIANS ASSERT
description: Four Palestinians were killed today just outside their Shatila refugee district when Shiite Amal militiamen opened fire on demonstrators protesting food shortages, Palestinian sources said.

title: SOURCES OF HELP
description: Those who have questions about the test for AIDS virus infection, or who need information to help determine if they are at risk of AIDS infection, can call the New York City Health Department at 718-485-8111 or the Gay Men's Health Crisis at 212-807-6655, or they can ask for the counseling service of the Greater New York Blood Program at 212-570-3400.

title: SNOWWOMAN CLAD IN A BIKINI STIRS LIVE WOMAN TO USE AX
description: When Bill Hackbarth created a snow sculpture of a woman in a bikini in his front yard recently, he thought passers-by would consider it cute. Kathleen A. Zanio, a former nun, had stronger feelings. She chopped the snowwoman to pieces with an ax.

title: ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL
description: Allegheny International Inc. said Friday that it had agreed to sell its Pacific appliance group to an Australian company for an undisclosed price. Reil Corp. Ltd. of North Sydney, Australia, is buying the Sunbeam Corporation of Australia, Sunbeam of New Zealand Ltd. and Victa Ltd. of Basingstoke, England. Sunbeam Australia produces lawn mowers, small appliances and sheep-shearing equipment. Sunbeam New Zealand produces electric blankets and small appliances. Victa distributes lawn mowers and related equipment.

title: A WALL ST. REALTOR LURES FOREIGN CASH
description: Simon J. Milde came to the United States from England in 1976 with a few hundred thousand dollars, not much of it his. In the following decade, he made himself, his partners and his real estate company, Jones Lang Wootton, very rich by brokering and managing billions of dollars worth of New York property.

title: Mussorgsky's 'Boris' At Philadelphia Opera
description: Mussorgsky's original 1869 version of his opera ''Boris Godunov'' is to be presented by the Opera Company of Philadelphia tonight and Friday night at the Academy of Music, with Paata Burchuladze, a bass from Soviet Georgia, making his United States opera debut in the title role.

title: Metro Matters; Things to Come: As Society Rots, Crime Will Rise
description: Burglars rested on weekends, while murderers worked overtime. About $911 million worth of merchandise and money was reported stolen; $200 million was recovered.

title: MANY OF THE WORLD'S STOCK MARKETS HAD A STUNNING QUARTER
description: Stock markets around the world were fantasylands during the first quarter of 1987, as the dream of wealth that began more than four years ago was extended beyond the imagination of even the most optimistic investor.

title: Italian Extremist Held By Venezuelan Police
description: The Venezuelan police said today that they had captured Stefano delle Chiaie, a right-wing Italian extremist sought most recently in the bombing of the Bologna, Italy, train station that left 85 people dead and more than 200 wounded in 1980.

title: Howard Trivers Dies; Was Career Diplomat
description: Howard Trivers, a retired career diplomat who helped develop United States policy during the Berlin blockade, Hungarian uprising and Cuban missile crisis, died Friday. He was 77 years old.

title: L.I. Woman Dies In a House Fire
description: A 49-year-old woman died early yesterday in a fire that swept through her two-story home, the authorities said.

title: Couple Held in Kidnapping
description: A 23-year-old woman was arrested today and charged with kidnapping a week-old baby and killing the child's mother. The woman, Wendy Lee Zabel, was arrested along with her companion, 26-year-old Robert H. Ryan, at their apartment after a sheriff's deputy found the murder weapon by a roadside and traced the pistol to Ms. Zabel. She was charged with murder and kidnapping, and Mr. Ryan with kidnapping, the sheriff's office here said. The baby, Heather Marie Witt, appeared to be unharmed, the authorities said. The infant was abducted Thursday and her mother stabbed and shot to death. The baby's grandmother, Marie Barrett, was also shot in the attack. She was listed in serious but stable condition today.

title: RATES SAID TO HINGE ON DOLLAR
description: The foreign exchange market is calling the shots for interest rates, with weakness in the dollar leading to higher yields on short and long-term debt securities.

title: U.S. SECRETS HINDER INVESTORS
description: The Pentagon's penchant for secrecy is hampering investors who are denied basic details about the business prospects of aerospace companies, according to financial experts in industry and Government.

title: 'Can You Imagine?'
description: In 1984, when Senator Jesse Helms, a North Carolina Republican whose committee assignments include the Foreign Relations Committee, was seeking re-election, he appealed to the diplomatic corps for support. Twenty-two ambassadors, all political appointees, endorsed him, much to the dismay of professional Foreign Service officers, who protested that ambassadors are appointed to represent their country, not their party.

title: South Africa Cabinet Member Is Discovered Shot to Death
description: A member of the South African Cabinet was found shot to death today with a pistol at his side.

title: No Rush for Seats
description: In the past, when President Reagan traveled around the country, members of Congress elbowed one another for the chance to fly with him on Air Force One and bask in his popularity. But with the Iran arms scandal driving down the President's approval ratings in public opinion polls, the rush for seats on Mr. Reagan's plane has dwindled considerably.

title: Police Seize Drugs From 2 Men on I-295
description: The state police arrested two men and seized about $288,000 worth of hashish oil that was hidden in door panels of a rental car, officials said yesterday.

title: Love, Again, in China
description: ''Love Story'' is packing the movie houses in China. Tickets sell out immediately. But it is not popularity but politics that determines which American movies may come and when they must go in China.

title: HURRICANE CARTER CASE IS BACK IN COURT
description: After 20 years of trials, retrials and reversals, the case of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter is back in court.

title: Guatemala Asks the U.S. for Trouble
description: The Guatemalan Interior Minister, Juan Jose Rodil Peralta, recently visited Washington for a flurry of meetings with members of Congress. His mission was to lobby for training and assistance for Guatemala's police forces. He is genuinely committed to a professionalization of the police, who have long been involved in killings, torture, disappearances, corruption and theft. Assistance from the United States, however, is the last thing he should seek to accomplish this end.

title: CLOSENESS OF THE OLD AND YOUNG
description: ARVILLE and Ida Schaleben of Milwaukee are devoted grandparents. They discuss theater with their 17-year-old granddaughter Erin, keep up with 10-year-old Gina's achievements in soccer and have introduced 16-year-old Lemisa to Mrs. Schaleben's Italian relatives.

title: 'LEY BYGONES' BUY A BOOK
description: DURING the nightly news conferences at the America's Cup final in Australia a few weeks ago, Dennis Conner sat stiffly and smiled stiffly. He also spoke stiffly, in platitudes and puffs. Only once did the Stars & Stripes skipper react spontaneously, and revealingly.

title: OBSTACLES SEEN IN MANILA DEBT PLAN
description: The innovative plan by the Philippines to service its foreign debt in the form of notes that are essentially i.o.u.'s has raised a host of issues -accounting, economic, and political -that threaten to doom the plan even before it gets started, financial experts said over the weekend.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 30, 1987: MONDAY Ameron Inc Unocal TUESDAY Carolina Freight Cascade Nat Gas WEDNESDAY Amer Water Wks Nevada Power Houston Indus THURSDAY General Dynamics Orange & Rockland Utils Mercantile Stores Phillips-Van Heusen FRIDAY Flowers Indus Sterling Drug

title: Link to Iran Arms Deal and Nugan Bank Denied
description: To the Editor:

title: Seattle News Union Contract
description: Union members at the two major daily newspapers here voted overwhelmingly today to accept a contract after being told that newspaper truck drivers were unlikely to honor their picket lines.

title: CHIP DISPUTE: READING BETWEEN THE LINES
description: In the trade dispute with Japan over computer chips, the real issues have rarely been what they seemed.

title: SKIP TRIAL SAILS BY 3-TO-5 SNOW CHIEF
description: Skip Trial collared heavily favored Snow Chief turning for home and drew off to a 4 1/2-length victory over Creme Fraiche today in the $242,500 Gulfstream Park Handicap, marking the third time this month that one of last year's champions has been badly beaten in a major race at this track.

title: Addendum
description: * East/West Network, a publisher of in-flight magazines, has created a new Midwest edition of TWA Ambassador magazine, to begin in May.

title: HARD YEAR IS EXPECTED
description: New orders for American-made machine tools slipped 1.1 percent in February from the improved level of January, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: An Open Book

title: TUBERCULOSIS CASES SPREADING IN NEW YORK CITY'S SHELTERS
description: Tuberculosis, a disease many people associate with a bygone era, is a rapidly growing problem among the homeless in New York City, according to city and health officials.

title: Paper Piles Up In Insider Case
description: The crackdown on insider trading abuses and the resulting subpoenas for documents, memos, letters, phone records and papers of all kinds have set dozens of copying machines in motion. Tons of paper have been crammed into hundreds of cardboard boxes and shipped to Government offices in New York and Washington.

title: DR. JAMES HUGH KIDDER
description: Dr. James Hugh Kidder, a retired surgeon, Army medical officer and dean emeritus of the Fordham University School of Pharmacy, died Friday at the Kingsbridge Veterans Hospital in the Bronx. He was 85 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, having returned there from Washington last July.

title: The U.N. Today: March 30, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Outer Space Legal Subcommittee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: RANGERS STILL UNDECIDED ON NO. 1 GOALIE
description: At one point Friday night when Bob Froese had grabbed a shot from point-blank range, it seemed as if the Rangers had found their man. Froese was in the middle of a sharp performance, the crowd at Madison Square Garden was with him on every save, and it seemed that the Rangers finally had themselves a hot goalie.

title: DYNASTY IS NOT LIKELY
description: The North Dakota team, the new National Collegiate Athletic Association champion, belied its nickname, Fighting Sioux, in its easy tournament victories here over Harvard and Michigan State. The Sioux were skaters, not fighters, and they never let up.

title: WILANDER OUTWITS McENROE
description: Mats Wilander of Sweden outwitted John McEnroe today in the final of the $315,000 Belgian Indoor Tennis Championships for a 6-3, 6-4 triumph.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: STARING AT THE SUN. By Julian Barnes. 197 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Saudi Minister Plans U.S. Visit
description: Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister, Hisham Nazer, will fly to Washington Monday for talks with United States Government officials, the official Saudi Press Agency reported today.

title: Shubert Event to Aid Ensemble Company
description: An event to benefit the Negro Ensemble Company, featuring performances by a number of noted black entertainers, is planned on April 26 at 8 P.M. at the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street. Those appearing are to include Charles (Honi) Coles, Roz Ryan, Jackee Harry and the Abyssinian Baptist Church Sanctuary Choir.

title: THEATER: 'CONSEQUENCE
description: WHILE watching Kat Smith's ''Consequence'' at the South Street Theater, one remembers those World War II Japanese prison camp movies in which a sadistic guard tries to pit one captive against another, thereby breaking a united democratic front. Many of those movies were far more provocative than anything that occurs on stage in this American Place Theater Women's Project production.

title: FINANCIAL CORP. BACK IN SPOTLIGHT
description: The Financial Corporation of America, whose near-collapse three years ago sent shock waves through the nation's financial system, is again at the center of controversy and speculation in the savings and loan industry.

title: Special Short-Term Issue Expected
description: The Treasury is expected to borrow actively in the short-term bill market this week, leaving securities dealers time to distribute last week's heavy supply of medium-term notes.

title: Darwin, Too, Saw the Ocean in the Andes
description: To the Editor:

title: LOTS OF SAVVY AND BALANCE, TOO
description: IN the short amount of time available, Syracuse and Indiana have devised and practiced their game plans. They have evaluated each other's strengths and weaknesses and, as they always do, will attempt to take away the strengths of their rivals while playing to their own.

title: Bronx Babies
description: James VI, who was born on March 5 in the Bronx, had his first outing this week - and outclassed every other baby in the borough. In all the boroughs, actually: Show us another kid who weighed in at 150 pounds and sports a pair of brown eyes that'd make a stone weep.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Science Times on March 10 about autism incorrectly characterized the circumstances surrounding the death of a student at a treatment facility in Providence, R.I.

title: Advertising; Four-A's Gets to the Bad News
description: After two days that had attendees grumbling about the low quality of the program, the annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies finally got down to the nitty-gritty this morning - and the news was mostly bad.

title: S.I. RESIDENTS PROTEST STATE'S ACTION ON WETLANDS
description: One woman waved an American flag and sang, ''My Country 'tis of Thee, It's Taking My Land for Free.'' Another hoisted a sign that read, ''No Condemnation without Compensation - An American Tradition.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MARCH 30, 1987
description: International Report

title: INSIDE
description: Huge Turnout in Haiti Voting was reported heavy in Haiti, with the ballots overwhelmingly in favor of a new constitution with democratic safeguards. Page A3. Cardinal in Foster-Care Shift John Cardinal O'Connor dropped his plan to end the church's foster-care services this summer for 2,500 youngsters in New York City. Page B1.

title: How Publishers Can Help TV
description: For all the years I've been in television - 39 of them - newspapers have been taking it upon themselves to be TV's conscience. That's not necessarily a bad thing. Everybody needs a conscience. So I'll take a small stab at being theirs.

title: IDLE TRASH PLANT BLOWN UP TO CLEAR SITE FOR INCINERATOR
description: After seven years as a silent, rusting monument to failed technology, a garbage-to-energy plant was dynamited into tons of rubble here today in seven seconds.

title: ALFORD COMMENTS: CAUTION'S THE WORD
description: He has grown to understand that eyes follow him wherever he goes, particularly within the State of Indiana and most especially whenever he is on a basketball court. Steve Alford, the latest living representation of the Indiana basketball dream, realizes that since so many people scrutinize the sometimes volatile atmosphere that surrounds the Indiana University basketball team, a sense of diplomacy can be as essential as a free throw in the final seconds of a game.

title: METS LOSE McDOWELL UNTIL JUNE
description: Roger McDowell, who won 14 games and saved 22 others as the ace of the Mets' bullpen last year, will undergo surgery for a hernia Monday morning and will be lost to the team for two months.

title: HAITIANS VOTE ON PROPOSED CONSTITUTION
description: Tens of thousands of Haitians voted today for a new constitution that promises freedom from the tyrannies that have prevailed in this Caribbean country through most of its history.

title: A SPECIAL CAMP FOR SOME VERY SPECIAL CHILDREN
description: The snow lay deep and cold on a gentle hill in Chappaqua, N.Y., making it difficult for a small boy in a wheelchair to reach the top.

title: Miss Gross Becomes Bride Of Wayne David Kurzner
description: Elana Gross, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David A. Gross of Jerusalem, was married at the St. Moritz in New York yesterday to Wayne David Kurzner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. R. Raymond Kurzner of New York. Rabbi Joseph Sungolowsky, the bride's uncle, officiated.

title: BAKKER IS HERO AT L.I. CHURCH
description: With their preachers under siege but their faith unshaken, members of the Full Gospel Tabernacle gathered here today for a rousing service in which many pledged to forgive two of their own.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In certain circumstances in baseball, why is a batter permitted to attempt to reach first base when a third strike gets away from a catcher or is mishandled by the catcher? Hasn't the batter been struck out?

title: Claudia F. Schiff and Thomas Eff Exchange Vows
description: The marriage of Claudia Faith Schiff, a senior vice president of the North American Precis Syndicate, a public-relations agency in New York, to Thomas Allan Eff, an associate at the New York law firm Debevoise & Plimpton, took place yesterday. Rabbi Bernhard Cohn performed the ceremony at the Harkness House in New York.

title: Empire Buys Thrift Offices
description: Empire of America-California Federal Savings Bank has acquired the $79 million in deposits at five branches of the Equitable Savings and Loan Association of San Mateo, Calif.

title: SOVIET SAID TO PLAN EMIGRATION SHIFT FAVORED BY ISRAEL
description: The Soviet Union has agreed that future Jewish emigres will be sent to Israel by way of Rumania, making it more difficult for them to settle in Europe or the United States instead, according to an American rabbi who said he had negotiated the new procedure.

title: See No Evil in Albany
description: Manfred Ohrenstein, the Democratic minority leader of the New York State Senate, says he sees nothing wrong in padding the legislative payroll with ''no show'' staff members who work exclusively on political campaigns. It's possible that public prosecutors will soon enlighten him. In any case, public outrage should enlighten the whole Legislature and move it to halt such practices, fast.

title: Carr's Introduction To Venet Advertising
description: Venet Advertising has been assigned the domestic introduction of Carr's Home Wheat Cookies made by Britain's Shaffer Clarke & Company.

title: JOB TRAINING EFFORTS IN MASSACHUSETTS AND MICHIGAN MOVE POOR OFF WELFARE
description: Michigan has a high unemployment rate and large concentrations of poverty. Massachusetts has a booming economy and relatively few jobless people. Both say they are moving substantial numbers of chronically poor people off welfare and into relatively well-paying private jobs.

title: 'MONEY WORLD' ON 1990
description: LOOK ahead now: soup kitchens and bread lines, condominiums and general affluence, or, just possibly, a muddling through between extremes? ''Adam Smith's Money World'' raises the questions. If you expect final answers, don't watch; there are none. Nonetheless, there is some intelligent, interesting discussion. The program will be seen on Channel 13 at 8:30 tonight.

title: FOR MARY ALICE, 'FENCES' HAS A UNIVERSAL THEME
description: For 18 years she has built her life around him, loving him, serving him, making a home for him, raising their sons. Now he has told her that another woman is about to bear him a child. Defensive, blustering, he tries to explain, saying that the other woman made him laugh, that with her he didn't have to worry about paying the bills or getting the roof fixed - that despite his wife's devotion, he had wanted more.

title: Mindy L. Kallus Bride Of Merrill Evan Weber
description: The marriage of Mindy Lee Kallus, a daughter of the late Rabbi and Mrs. Samuel B. Kallus of Far Rockaway, Queens, to Merrill Evan Weber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Weber of Highland Park, Ill., took place yesterday at the Jewish Center in New York. Rabbi Jacob J. Schacter performed the ceremony.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: OPERA: VICKERS IN 'SAMSON ET DALILA'
description: CAMILLE SAINT-SAENS'S ''Samson et Dalila'' is an opera of earnest purpose and drastically uneven inspiration, plausible in the hands of an extraordinary tenor whose identification with the hero can transcend the ordinariness of his music and a mezzo-soprano who can seize the opportunities of three great arias that stand out like oases in the score. A sensitive conductor who has faith in the idiom is a great help, and the Metropolitan Opera's current revival introduces one in the person of Jean Fournet, making a welcome house debut late in his career. At the opening performance Saturday night he set the somber mood of the introduction simply and surely. Jon Vickers as Samson sustained it magnificently. Marilyn Horne as his nemesis brought every resource of intelligence, technique and subtle knowledge of her voice to make a limited success in a role neither vocally nor temperamentally ideal for her.

title: WALL STREET'S DEFENSIVE LINE
description: The Government's widening investigation into corruption on Wall Street has pitted Federal prosecutors and Securities and Exchange Commission lawyers against the largest brigade of white-collar criminal lawyers ever assembled.

title: MARINE GAVE CONFLICTING STORIES OF SOVIET INTRIGUE, RECORDS SHOW
description: Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree, a Marine Corps guard accused of espionage, told investigators conflicting stories about how he became entangled with a Soviet agent in Moscow, according to records of his interrogation.

title: Fisher-Price Toys Shifts Ad Assignments
description: Fisher-Price Toys, a division of Quaker Oats, announced last week that it had realigned the advertising assignments among its three agencies - Waring & LaRosa, Backer & Spielvogel and J. Walter Thompson, Chicago - to reflect the restructuring of its own marketing operation.

title: PLUTO FACING INDENTITY CRISIS: IS IT A PLANET OR AN ASTEROID?
description: Pluto is the smallest planet in the solar system, a careless wanderer that is usually the farthest planet from the Sun, a heavenly body that many people think was named after a Walt Disney character.

title: FINAL FOCUS SHIFTS TO DEFENSE
description: At first glance, the national championship game between Indiana and Syracuse Monday night seems to lack the ingredients for a classic basketball confrontation.

title: ISRAELI INDICTED IN POLLARD CASE GIVES UP HIS POST
description: The Israeli Air Force officer accused of recruiting an American intelligence analyst as a spy announced tonight that he was giving up his recent military promotion because of the problems it had caused between Israel and the United States.

title: TO REAGAN'S CONSTERNATION, BRENNAN LEADS COURT IN BIG CASES
description: William H. Rehnquist is Chief Justice, but the man President Reagan appointed to lead the Supreme Court to the right has been in dissent in all five of this term's most important decisions on ideologically charged issues.

title: Vatican Wages a Costly War Against Women; A Need for Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Citrus Shuffle
description: In the Grapefruit League, there are squeeze plays that have nothing to do with a bunt. They're maneuvers of major league clubs wanting to wrest new spring homes for themselves. Either the team fakes the hit-and-run and gets its host community to spiff up or replace its training complex, or it does run and scores a new complex in another town, which can expect to pay upward of $5 million for construction.

title: Alisa Roslin, a Nurse, Wed To Neil Forrest, a Lawyer
description: The marriage of Alisa Michele Roslin, a registered nurse in the operating room at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, to Neil P. Forrest, an associate at the New York law firm Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, took place yesterday at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I. Cantor David Hiesiger officiated.

title: BANK ACTION FAILS
description: The dollar plunged in the Tokyo currency markets this morning in hectic trading, at one point falling as low as 144.70 yen before closing the morning session at 145.35 yen. In early trading in the afternoon session, the dollar recovered to 145.70 yen.

title: 2 Top Officers Named At New Honeywell Bull
description: The new information systems company formed by Honeywell, Bull of France and NEC of Japan, will be an American company with American management, according to Jacques Stern, who heads Compagnie des Machines Bull.

title: ROD-AND-REEL ROUNDUP
description: FOR one who began fishing in the early 1930's, going after trout with a metal telescoping rod and bluefish in the surf with a handline and a heavy metal jig, the variety of rods and reels being manufactured today is astonishing.

title: DEVILS YIELD TO 3 EARLY GOALS, LOSE TO BLUES
description: The bad memory of starting slowly in their previous game disappeared quickly this afternoon for the St. Louis Blues against the Devils.

title: 'The Chronology'
description: Speaking of the Iran-contra affair, Warner Books is rushing to print 75,000 copies of ''The Chronology,'' a day-to-day account of the Reagan Administration's secret program to sell military equipment to Iran and the subsequent diversion of profits to Nicaraguan insurgents.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Capitals 4, North Stars 2: Alan Haworth and Dave Christian scored third-period power-play goals yesterday as Washington moved into second place in the Patrick Division. Washington, which was playing at home, is unbeaten in its last five games and moved 1 point ahead of the idle Islanders. Each team has four games left.(AP) Whalers 7, Canucks 4: Ron Francis had two goals and two assists and John Anderson reached the 30-goal mark for the sixth straight season for Hartford. The victory put the Whalers within 1 point of clinching first place in the Adams Division. Vancouver was eliminated from playoff contention.(AP) Oilers 3, Sabres 2: Reijo Ruotsalainen scored once and assisted on Glenn Anderson's game-winning goal as Edmonton clinched first place in the Smythe Division. (AP) Canadiens 4, Penguins 1: Petr Svoboda scored two goals and assisted on another as Montreal won and kept Pittsburgh out of the playoffs for a fifth consecutive season. The Penguins have missed the playoffs 11 times in their 20-year history.(AP) Bruins 8, Blackhawks 6: Ray Bourque wristed in an eight-foot shot midway through the final period to break a 5-5 tie, then added an empty net goal with 18 seconds left to clinch Boston's victory in Chicago. (AP) N.B.A. Trail Blazers 135, Spurs 113: Clyde Drexler scored 31 points and Jerome Kersey scored 11 of his 28 in the fourth quarter to lead Portland yesterday. Walter Berry and Jon Sundvold scored 24 points each for San Antonio. (AP) Mavericks 101, Cavaliers 98: At Richfield, Ohio, Rolando Blackman scored 38 points, and Roy Tarpley's basket with 59 seconds remaining put Dallas ahead to stay. The Mavericks got their eighth victory in the last nine games.(AP) Pistons 108, SuperSonics 107: Adrian Dantley scored 33 points, including 22 in the second half, and Isiah Thomas added 26 as Detroit rallied to win and tighten the Central Division race. The victory left Detroit one game behind idle first-place Atlanta. Xavier McDaniel scored 27 points for Seattle.(AP) Auto Racing Victory for Earnhardt: Bill Elliott ran out of gas on the last lap and Dale Earnhardt, who took a calculated risk by making a pit stop 11 laps from the end, charged past to win the TranSouth 500 at Darlington International Raceway in Darlington, S.C. Elliot finished second. (AP) Boxing Muguruma Captures Title: Takuya Muguruma of Japan knocked out Azael Moran of Panama at 2:50 of the fifth round of a scheduled 15-round bout in Moriguchi, Japan, to win the vacant World Boxing Association bantamweight title. Muruguma's record is now 26-1-1, including 19 knockouts. Moran is 16-2 with 7 knockouts.(AP) Horse Racing Omar Khayyam Wins: Omar Khayyam came from off the pace to score a 4 3/4-length victory in the $67,900 DeWitt Clinton Stakes for New York-bred 3-year-olds at Aqueduct. Hot Amber beat Lone Quadrant for second. Omar Khayyam, with Jean-Luc Samyn riding, covered seven furlongs on the fast track in 1:23 1/5 for his third victory in five starts this year. He returned $2.80 for $2 to win as the favorite in the field of six. Grass Debut for Ferdinand: In Arcadia, Calif., Zoffany withstood the challenge of Louis Le Grand to win the $211,200 San Luis Rey Stakes at Santa Anita by a neck. Ferdinand, the 1986 Kentucky Derby winner, finished fourth in his first race over a grass course. Ridden by Eddie Delahoussaye, the 7-year-old Zoffany covered the mile and a half in 2:25 1/5. Long Mick, bred in France, finished third, another neck behind.(AP) Show Jumping Jacquin Takes Invitational: Lisa Jacquin of Phoenix, the only woman among six riders in the jumpoff, won the $100,000 Michelob American Invitational Saturday night at Tampa Stadium in Tampa, Fla. In the jumpoff, Jacquin rode second on For The Moment, a 12-year-old American thoroughbred. She turned in a fault-free ride in 45.078 seconds.(AP) Golf Bradley's Drought Ends: In Phoenix, a struggling Pat Bradley birdied the 17th hole to close the door on Chris Johnson and capture her 22d career tour victory in the $300,000 L.P.G.A. Turquoise Classic yesterday. The triumph was the first this season for Bradley, last year's L.P.G.A. player of the year. Bradley played erratically compared with her normal precision, but still managed a three-under-par round of 70 on the 6,419-yard Moon Valley Country Club course. She finished 72 holes at six-under 286, two shots ahead of Johnson, who finished with a 67 and a four-day total of 288.(AP)

title: DANCE: AT ST. MARK'S CHURCH, DEJA VU THEATER
description: BARRY MARTIN is a choreographer with a pleasant habit of looking to everyday life for his themes. He has good taste in guest choreographers, too, and a clear sense of the assets and capabilities of his new young company, Deja Vu Dance Theater, which performed on Thursday at St. Mark's Church. It all made for an enjoyable evening of dance.

title: Old Hawk on the Hill
description: A recent Scouting column in The Times carried an account about Thomasina Robinson, a 46-year-old guard on the women's junior-varsity basketball team at Hunter College. Robinson has been called the oldest female intercollegiate athlete in America, and she may well be. But she raises few eyebrows at Hunter, where 43-year-old Don Larkin was a varsity fencer until his eligibility expired last spring and where Jaime Negroni, 30, plays j.v. basketball, varsity tennis and baseball, which the school has now resumed on the club level after a six-year hiatus.

title: Debra Kling Is Bride Of Jeffrey N. Shaffer
description: Debra Shelley Kling, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Kling of Congers, N.Y., and Montauk, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeffrey N. Shaffer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Shaffer of Sherman Oaks, Calif. Cantor George Weinflash officiated at the Hotel Westbury in Manhattan.

title: To the Brink in Athens
description: Greek Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has been edging up to the brink for years. He has been stirring nationalist feeling against Turkey, an easy task, and against the U.S., which is a little harder but popular on the left, to bolster his internal political position.

title: Panel Named to Study City's Teaching Staff
description: The New York City Board of Education named a special 12-member task force yesterday to study ways to enhance the professionalism of the city's public school teaching staff.

title: BRAZIL OFFICIAL'S OUSTER URGED
description: A month after Brazil suspended interest payments on $67 billion in foreign bank debt, leading bankers, businessmen and politicians here are pressing President Jose Sarney to replace his powerful Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro.

title: THATCHER GREETED BY SOVIET CROWDS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today called her visit to the Soviet Union a ''historic mission'' for peace, but her first full day in the country had the tone and trappings of an election campaign in her own country.

title: BUDDY EBSEN AND JOEY CRAMER STAR IN 'STONE FOX'
description: LAST week on NBC, Britain's cheeky ''Spitting Image'' puppets did a spoof of the Academy Awards. When the ceremonies began, most of the audience promptly decided to take a nap until the action really started, around the time the presenters got to the Best Actress nominations. With tonight's Oscar ceremonies in Los Angeles getting under way on ABC at 9, NBC is offering a pleasant alternative to a snooze between 8:30 and 10:30. It's a family-entertainment movie called ''Stone Fox,'' all about an orphaned 12-year-old boy, his dog and his loving grandfather. As an antidote to Hollywood extravagance, the film has its distinctive charms.

title: Cincy Sees Red
description: Last year the Detroit Tigers got their opener under way 25 minutes before the season's first pitch in Cincinnati, and there went tradition, apparently for good. Next Monday, while the National League continues to reserve for the Reds an honor befitting the oldest team in baseball, Detroit (playing host to the Yankees) will again be getting a jump of about a half-hour on Cincinnati, whose 2:05 start will be matched by Baltimore. Then there's Toronto, where the game is scheduled to begin a whopping - and egregious - 90 minutes before the Reds, so enraging a Cincinnati City Councilman, David Mann, that he has sent protests to both Commissioner Peter Ueberroth and, because of what he called the ''international implications'' of the Canadian initiative, Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: Euphoria in Mexico
description: After the Mexican Bolsa de Valores registered an average return on investment of 104 percent, in dollar terms, in 1986, shareholders here could scarcely believe their good fortune.

title: DAVID MODEL MYSTERY: WHO IS THE OWNER?
description: Though a recently discovered plaster model of the famed David by Michelangelo has been proclaimed by a leading art historian to be a long lost and highly valuable original work by the great Renaissance artist, the identity of the object's owner has remained a carefully guarded secret.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions Saturday about an investigation into New York State legislative payrolls misidentified State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein.

title: BOTHA CAMPAIGNS IN CRITICS' BASTION
description: President P. W. Botha has embarked on an election campaign with an excursion into enemy territory and a flurry of charges about the source of his opponents' funds.

title: Karen R. Schwalb Becomes a Bride
description: Karen Robin Schwalb, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Robert Schwalb of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Joel Daniel Hollander, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Bernard Hollander, also of Stamford. Rabbi Joseph Ehrenkranz performed the ceremony at Congregation Agudath Sholom.

title: 3 EX-PRO FOOTBALL PLAYERS REINSTATED
description: The International Amateur Athletics Federation, the world governing body of track and field, voted today to reinstate three former pro football players, Stanley Floyd, Mel Lattany and Mark McNeil, all of them sprinters.

title: Vatican Wages a Costly War Against Women; Jews Lack Consensus
description: To the Editor:

title: Vatican Wages a Costly War Against Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: INNER CITY PROMOTING A REVIVAL
description: Hardly anyone regarded it as a sure thing, but a lot of people turned out the other day to celebrate their hope that a new retail center here would help awaken the city's long-slumbering downtown section and turn it into a shopping mecca.

title: REAGAN IN DRIVE TO SUSTAIN VETO OF HIGHWAY BILL
description: Facing a critical legislative test, President Reagan lobbied vigorously over the weekend to sustain his veto of an $88 billion highway and mass transit bill that would also allow states to raise the Federal speed limit to 65 miles per hour on rural Interstates.

title: U.S. RESENTMENT GROWS ON JAPAN TRADE BARRIERS
description: Japan is seen by many in Washington as the archetypal unfair trader.

title: Israeli Meets Secretly With Iran Arms Dealer
description: Amiram Nir, one of the key Israeli figures in the Iran arms affair, met secretly with the Iranian arms dealer Manucher Ghorbanifar in Switzerland 10 days ago, an Israeli newspaper reported today.

title: Pitino's Future Is His Secret
description: Even in the wake of his team's disappointing season-ending defeat, Rick Pitino was a captive of his success and of talk concerning his future.

title: SPECIALIST IN CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Martin Provensen, an award-winning illustrator of children's books, died of a heart attack at his home in Clinton Corners, N.Y., Friday. He was 70 years old.

title: How Knight Got Smart
description: OF all the players in the Final Four, only one has talked openly about going out for some crawfish etouffee. His name is Keith Smart, as fitting a last name as you'll ever find in the Final Four.

title: GREEK LEADER'S GAMBIT
description: Lost amid the frenzies of perilous brinksmanship as Greece and Turkey edged toward war last week, a small but telling announcement was made.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch Saturday on President Reagan's meeting with Neil Kinnock, the British Labor Party leader, described the session incorrectly. The talks were almost entirely about nuclear policy; they referred only briefly to British politics.

title: A YEAR AFTER CHAOS, SHAMIR IS VOTED PARTY CHIEF
description: A year after its convention broke up in chaos and fistfights, the right-wing Herut Party reconvened today and elected Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir as its chairman.

title: JORDAN LIFTS BULLS OVER KNICKS, 115-96
description: Michael Jordan scored 11 of his 33 points during a decisive 35-point third quarter to lift the Chicago Bulls to a 115-96 victory over the Knicks today.

title: Rise in Prices in Poland Denounced by Walesa
description: Sharp increases in food and energy prices were denounced today by Lech Walesa, who said he favored the economic initiatives of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, but not those being introduced in Poland.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The deterioration in United States-Israel relations and my concern for the future of those relations and the ties with United States Jewry have brought me to ask you to relieve me of my post as commander of Tel Nof base.'' Col. Aviem Sella [ A9:1. ]

title: Davis Extends Resorts Offer
description: The KSZ Company, which is backed by Marvin Davis, the Denver billionaire, has extended its surprise $200 million offer for Resorts International Inc., the casino and real estate company, a KSZ spokesman said yesterday.

title: MUSIC: KEITH JARRETT
description: NEAR the close of his solo piano concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening, Keith Jarrett somewhat patronizingly congratulated the audience for being attentive to music that was so ''difficult.'' Miles Davis, he explained, once contended that the reason he didn't play many ballads was that he loved to play ballads too much.

title: LYLE WINS T.P.C. IN PLAYOFF
description: Sandy Lyle, the Scot who won the British Open in 1985 to silence many of his critics, sank a 7-foot putt for par on the third hole of a sudden-death playoff today to beat Jeff Sluman for the $180,000 top prize in the $1 million Tournament Players Championship.

title: CARDINAL EASES THREAT TO CURB FOSTER SERVICES
description: John Cardinal O'Connor yesterday set aside his threat to withdraw Roman Catholic foster-care services this summer from 2,500 New York City youngsters.

title: HAGLER VS. LEONARD: THE STAGE IS SET
description: For those who revel in the gaudy excess of Las Vegas, Nev., the Hagler-Sugar Ray Leonard match April 6 promises to be a good show.

title: SEIKALY COMES OF AGE
