description: It has come to this now. When most young potential basketball players - particularly the very tall ones - are introduced to the sport, their first lessons aren't about dribbling or shooting or rebounding. Someone simply takes the basketball and slams it through the hoop.

title: Pollard Strikes Again
description: Senator David Durenberger of Minnesota, until recently the Republican chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, called to set up a breakfast date last week.

title: SOME IN JAPAN FEEL U.S. IS USING IT AS SCAPEGOAT
description: The Reagan Administration's threats of trade retaliation may fuel a Japanese sense of frustration and resentment toward the United States that is already on the rise in some circles here.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on the front page Saturday misidentified the official with Nilde Iotti, a Communist legislator and president of the lower house of the Italian parliament. He was Sergio Berlinguer, a senior aide to the president.

title: WORKERS APPROVE G.M. PACT
description: Workers at three General Motors plants voted overwhelmingly today to end a four-day strike that had halted production of some trucks and buses.

title: USE OF SMALL REACTORS FOR POWER IN WIDE NUCLEAR WAR IS EXPLORED
description: The Air Force is exploring the possibility of building several hundred small nuclear reactors that would generate electrical power in a protracted nuclear war, according to Air Force, Department of Energy, Congressional and industry officials.

title: Ruling Delay on First Jersey
description: A Federal judge in Philadelphia reserved final judgment Friday on a $10 million settlement offered by First Jersey Securities to end a class-action suit that accused the brokerage firm of defrauding customers by charging excessive markups in a number of stocks.

title: DR. KEVIN SULLIVAN
description: Dr. Kevin Sullivan, a former associate dean of graduate studies at Columbia University, died of lung cancer yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: SAVING THE SUBWAY'S LAST MOSAICS
description: Long before paint came in aerosol cans, the Transit Authority's founding fathers believed subways should be colorful.

title: Bridge: Marty Bergen, Just Married, Cites Sharp Play by His Wife
description: A player-writer who is a constant center of attention in both capacities is Marty Bergen of White Plains.

title: GRAND JURORS SAID TO EXPLORE WIDE U.S. ROLE IN NICARAGUA
description: A Federal grand jury exploring the Iran-contra affair has begun to reconstruct the complete history of American involvement with Nicaraguan rebel groups and is studying several key incidents, including the mining of Nicaraguan harbors in 1984, according to people with knowledge of the investigation.

title: SOUND AND FURY MAY SIGNIFY LITTLE
description: It may get noisy over the next five months. Most of it won't mean a thing because that's the nature of collective bargaining in professional football. The players union will insist, ''We want this and that.'' The owners will respond, ''No way.'' Only when the pressures are brought to bear - i.e., when the season is threatened by a strike - will negotiations between the National Football League Players Association and the owners grow more serious and substantive.

title: CONCERT: BRUCKNER BY PHILHARMONIC
description: THE New York Philharmonic was at its best Saturday night at Avery Fisher Hall, when Stanislaw Skrowaczewski conducted a program of Boccherini and Bruckner.

title: TENNESSEE WINNER IN FINAL
description: The Tennessee Lady Volunteers gave Coach Pat Head Summitt her first National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball title after 11 years of trying.

title: Business and the Law; New Company Vs. 'Old' Union
description: THE United States Supreme Court is expected to issue a ruling soon in a case that pits the A.F.L.-C.I.O. against the Chamber of Commerce and also has broad implications for corporate acquisitions. The case presents the question of what happens to the old union when a new company buys a failed business.

title: Save New York From a Merger of Street and Subway Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Arm Afghans, Balance the Rest
description: It's not hard to guess why Soviet planes flown by Afghan pilots are striking across the border at Pakistan. The aim is intimidation. By raising the stakes in its eight-year war in Afghanistan, Moscow hopes to impel Pakistan to accept its peace terms. That would mean cutting off all outside aid to Afghan insurgents and giving 115,000 Soviet troops 18 months to mop up an abandoned resistance.

title: DANCE: MISSOURI BALLET
description: THE STATE BALLET OF MISSOURI, which used to be called the Kansas City Ballet, made its New York debut Saturday night under the auspices of the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts.

title: ARTWORKS MIRROR CHINA: GAINING POST-MAO VIEW
description: In 1984, with the natural gas market deep in the doldrums, Robert A. Hefner, the chairman of a natural gas exploration company in Oklahoma City, went to China in search of new business.

title: AUDUBON SOCIETY IN DRIVE TO PROTECT WAY STATION FOR CRANES
description: Announcing their approach with a hoarse, tremolo cry, the sandhill cranes return to the river as evening falls. At first they descend in small clusters of half a dozen or so. But as the twilight deepens, the stately birds arrive in waves of 20, then 100, then 1,000, until the world seems to be filled with their wings and their wild calls.

title: OPERA: ONE-ACT BY SULLIVAN
description: ''TOMORROW and Tomorrow,'' as played by the Center for Contemporary Opera at the Henry Street Settlement Saturday night, returns to the original intentions of opera's creators more than 300 years ago. Thus, this one-character, one-act stage work by the young Canadian Timothy Sullivan put words first and then created music to serve them.

title: Market Place; The Pricing of Standard Oil
description: IS the ''intrinsic value'' of the Standard Oil Company ''materially in excess'' of $70 a share?

title: People
description: * Jay Schoenfeld has been appointed group senior vice president, media services, at Backer & Spielvogal.

title: AIDS TESTING: A DILEMMA FOR THOSE AT RISK
description: To test or not to test: that is the agonizing question. Some people who wonder if they are at risk of AIDS infection are saying, no, they are not going to undergo the blood test for antibodies to the AIDS virus. Their response is raising new concerns, not only about the emotional and practical consequences of such testing, but also about the ethical responsibilities of people who may be infected with the virus.

title: Pay College Athletes Openly
description: Provoked by the football scandal at Southern Methodist University, his alma mater, Representative John Bryant of Texas has introduced legislation to cut off all Federal funds to colleges that make under-the-table payments to athletes.

title: IN SUBURB: SOME SUCCESS
description: Each day at lunch, the same 8 or 10 young men, half of them white, half of them black, share one long table in the downstairs cafeteria at New Rochelle High School.

title: HUSSEIN IS SAID TO REBUFF U.S.
description: King Hussein, reportedly frustrated over coolness by the United States toward convening an international peace conference to negotiate a settlement of the Palestinian question, has decided to send his Prime Minister to Washington on April 6 rather than personally accept an invitation to Washington, sources among Jordanian officials and Western diplomats said today.

title: Under Carlucci, The Word Is 'Process'
description: If Frank C. Carlucci has a favorite word, it has to be ''process.''

title: PORTRAYED IN 'SOUND OF MUSIC'
description: Maria Augusta von Trapp, the guiding force behind a family of singers who won world renown when their story was portrayed in the play and film ''The Sound of Music,'' died of heart failure Saturday in Morrisville, Vt., three days after undergoing surgery. She was 82 years old, and had lived in Stowe, Vt., for more than 40 years.

title: British Ponder Some Curbs
description: The British Government may revoke the licenses of selected Japanese banks and securities companies to operate in London if progress is not made toward opening Japan's markets to foreigners, according to Government sources.

title: ROCK FANS OVERTURN AND BURN TWO CARS AT CONCERT IN JERSEY
description: A group of fans leaving a rock concert in the Brendan T. Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., overturned and burned two cars in a parking lot and pelted firefighters with bottles and cans before being dispersed early yesterday, the state police said. Thirty-three people were arrested before order was restored. The incident began Saturday shortly after 11 P.M., when a few thousand youths gathered in a lot after a concert by the British heavy-metal group Iron Maiden, according to Sgt. Richard Ryan of the state police. He said the number of people who overturned and burned the cars was not known.

title: Champion to Sell Stake
description: The Champion International Corporation, a newsprint manufacturer based in Stamford, Conn., said Friday that it planned to sell its interest in the Stone Container Corporation, which makes packaging materials, in a public offering. Champion received more than 1.6 million shares of stock and 300,000 warrants for Stone Container when it sold Stone its packaging business last year. A spokeswoman for Champion said yesterday that the company's cost basis in Stone was $42.25 a share and that the warrants were exercisable at $32.50 a share. Champion's stake in Stone is estimated to have a value of $77 million.

title: He Graded Out Well
description: George Young, the Giants' general manager, has a knack for spotting top talent early, but few youths ever impressed him as much as Kurt Schmoke, a quarterback who led Baltimore City College high school to two consecutive city championships when Young was coach there in the 1960's. It was less his football than his leadership that marked Schmoke as a champion in Young's eyes. He was a top scholar and president of the student body, and Young urged him to give up his dream of athletic stardom and concentrate on academics.

title: SPLIT PERSISTS AMONG STUDENTS AT BRONX SCHOOL
description: The senior portraits in the John F. Kennedy High School yearbook suggest a success story of racial and ethnic unity: hundreds of young adults, black and white, Hispanic and Asian - smiling and confident, side by side.

title: SOVIET LIFTING VEIL ON CAMPS OF STALIN ERA
description: Passengers who scan the snow-covered foothills on their descent into the Magadan airport can see abandoned clearings sketched in the larch and poplar forests. They are quite probably relics of the Kolyma labor camps, where prisoners of the Stalin era were housed between their shifts at hard labor.

title: 2 Warehouses Suffer Damage in Blaze
description: A fire gutted a record warehouse in the Ironbound section yesterday and damaged an electronics warehouse, officials said.

title: SETTLEMENT WITH JAPAN IS EXPECTED
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige predicted today that the United States and Japan would soon reach a settlement in their semiconductor trade dispute.

title: NEW YORK LIBRARY OBTAINS TOSCANINI ARCHIVE
description: A vast collection of scores, letters, recordings and memorabilia of Arturo Toscanini, which has lain inaccessible in a New York Public Library basement since 1970 while extensive negotiations were conducted with the heirs of the Italian conductor, has been acquired by the library.

title: POPE BEATIFIES 3 NUNS KILLED IN SPANISH WAR
description: In a move that could revive old disputes in Spain, Pope John Paul II beatified five people today, three of them Carmelite nuns who were executed in one of the most vicious phases of the Spanish Civil War.

title: Vatican Wages a Costly War Against Women; No Infallibility Claimed
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE IN WORKS BY BALANCHINE
description: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM offered a look through the company's history when it performed the final new program of its ''Harlem Homecoming'' season on Friday evening at City College's Davis Hall, 134th Street and Convent Avenue, where the company performs through Sunday.

title: Censorship Threat Reported Against Journalists in Kenya
description: A senior official of Kenya's sole political party was quoted today as saying the party might soon begin censoring foreign journalists' reports.

title: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $297,000 for the quarter and $474,000 for the 6 months. c-After a loss of $12,000 for the quarter and income of $37,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. The share earnings reflect 5-for-4 stock split paid March 1, 1987.

title: GEMCO NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $104,000 for the quarter and a loss of $3,430,000 for the year, both from disposal of discontinued operations and tax benefits of $17,000 and $515,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,087,000 and $4,187,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and a loss of $1,366,000 from disposal of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year. The company said the latest year loss on disposal of discontinued operations includes costs related to settlement of claims on discontinued operations, net of income tax benefit, of about $363,000.

title: 21 GO ON TRIAL IN NEW JERSEY AS MOB FIGURES
description: Twenty-one men accused as the hierarchy of an organized crime family went on trial here today in Federal District Court on charges of operating drug, gambling and other illegal activities out of a Newark luncheonette.

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
WOMAN WHO SEDUCED MARINE: A STYLISH PRESENCE
description: The Soviet woman who lured a Marine Corps guard into a spying scheme left some indelible memories at the United States Embassy.

title: New-Home Sales Drop By 2.7%
description: Sales of new homes, hurt by a slump in the Northeast, fell for the second consecutive month in February, declining by 2.7 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: PARNASSUS-ON-POTOMAC: POETS CELEBRATE ENGLISH
description: James Dickey called it ''a Parnassus of poets.''

title: FDP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: KEEPING UP WITH THE I.R.S.
description: SPECIAL care must be taken when using a personal computer to prepare Federal, state and local income taxes as the deadline draws near.

title: Judge Orders Release of Man Convicted in Guyana Death
description: Larry Layton, a former member of the People's Temple cult, is to be released on $250,000 bail pending an appeal of his conviction last December for aiding and abetting the murder of Representative Leo J. Ryan in Guyana in November 1978.

title: Kansas Mayor Recovering
description: Mayor Jack Reardon's recovery from a heart transplant has been above average, Dr. Jon Moran said, adding that he has a 70 percent chance of surviving five years or more. Dr. Moran led the transplant team in the Feb. 18 operation on the 43-year-old Mayor.

title: Retarded Patient Dies After Being Restrained
description: A 20-year-old patient who lived at a home for the retarded in Brooklyn, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, as he was being taken to a hospital after a struggle with attendants and policemen, the authorities said.

title: Allegheny Stake
description: The New York money manager Mario J. Gabelli and a group of companies he controls have purchased a 7.23 percent stake in Allegheny International Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Gabelli said he had no plans to seek control of the Pittsburgh-based appliance manufacturer. Allegheny has agreed to a $500 million leveraged buyout by the Sunter Acquisition Corporation, a unit of the First Boston Corporation. A class-action suit seeking to block the merger has been filed on behalf of Allegheny shareholders contending that the price is inadequate.

title: STOCKS AND BONDS PLUNGE AS DOLLAR CONTINUES TO DROP
description: An unrelenting decline in the dollar's value set off a violent reaction yesterday in the stock and bond markets, where prices plunged in tumultuous selling.

title: SURVEY FINDS MANY SKEPTICS AMONG EVANGELISTS' VIEWERS
description: Three-fourths of the people who watch evangelical television programs say most ministers who appear on them are too concerned with raising money, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. About three-fourths also expect more accusations against other ministers to follow the adultery scandal that arose over the Rev. Jim Bakker.

title: U.S. HEARS GERMANS MAY BAR EXTRADITION OF LEBANESE SUSPECT

title: Coach Halas

But in Worcester, Mass., the name Halas means Cougars, not Bears, hoops, not hulks: Wally Halas, hired 13 years ago at age 22 to coach basketball at his alma mater, Clark University, has won 79 percent of his games since 1977 and has taken Clark into the N.C.A.A.'s Division III tournament 10 straight seasons. This season's team reached the national final in Grand Rapids, Mich., before losing, 106-100, to North Park College of Chicago, which had led by 30 points with 14 minutes to play. Halas figures the Cougars suffered a letdown after their quarterfinal victory over Potsdam (N.Y.) State, which had won 60 straight.

title: Custody of Girl, 4, In Sale Case Is Shifted

The judge, who held a two-hour private hearing, gave the uncle, Gary Stern of Sunrise, Fla., until Monday to bring the girl, Rachel Rauser, here from Florida, where she had been in Mr. Stern's custody.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: OUT OF STEP. An Unquiet Life in the 20th Century. By Sidney Hook. 628 pages. Harper & Row. $29.95. SIDNEY HOOK has been a powerful presence in American intellectual life for something like 60 years. A former pupil of John Dewey, he is a professional philosopher - for most of his career he taught at New York University - who has also been deeply involved in politics and public debate. Having established his reputation early on as an interpreter of Marx, he subsequently became even better known as a tenacious critic of Soviet Communism and its apologists; but he has taken a stand on many other controversial issues as well.

title: BLACKS IN NEW YORK: THE ANGUISH OF POLITICAL FAILURE
description: Despite New York City's reputation for political pluralism and openness, blacks here have failed to achieve the political power that they have in other American cities.

He was flanked by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the guest preacher, and the Rev. T. J. Jemison, the church's pastor, who declared, ''This is Edwards country.''

description: Carl H. Lindner, the Cincinnati financier, took charge yesterday at the Penn Central Corporation in a management shake-up designed to move the company into what he called ''the next phase of its growth.''

title: POLL SHOWS A SLIGHT RISE IN APPROVAL FOR REAGAN SINCE IRAN REPORT

title: Gephardt, Hart and Issues

Gephardt of Missouri, one of the Democratic dark horses running for President, says he will use the trade issue to underscore a key difference between him and Gary Hart. Mr. Gephardt is promoting trade legislation that is favored by organized labor and opposed by Mr. Hart and others who view it as protectionist.

title: A COUNTERSPY SAYS HE GOT FEW REWARDS

description: In the last three months Time Inc. has trimmed an estimated 200 jobs from the editorial and business operations of its magazine division. By the end of October another 200 jobs may be eliminated, according to Time officials.

description: Representative Fred Grandy was married Saturday to Catherine Mann, a television reporter he met during an interview while he was playing Gopher Smith in the ''Love Boat'' television series.

title: Q & A
description: Q.What is meant by first, second, and third degree burns? A.The degree of a burn refers to the extento which heat has destroyed layers of skin, according to Dr. Bruce Aschauer of the University of California at Irvine. A first degree burn such as a sunburn results in some redness and swelling. These burns heal fairly quickly in a few days without any scarring. A second degree burn is much deeper and actually destroys some layers of skin, resulting in the formation of blisters. No scarring results and the skin regenerates after a few weeks. In a third degree burn, the heat completely destroys the upper layers of skin including accessory skin structures like hair and sweat glands. The burned area takes on a white leather-like appearance and normal skin does not regenerate. Third-degree burns are treated with skin grafts, in which thin layers of skin are removed from an unburned part of the body and grafted onto the burned portions. One way to minimize the severity of any burn is to cool it by applying an ice pack or cold water. Q.Is the bite of a black widow spider deadly? A.Except in the elderly or very young, death does not normally occur from the bite of a black widow spider, according to the Pennsylvania State University Extension Service. However, the neurotoxic venom that a black widow releases when it bites makes the victim very sick. It can cause a number of reactions such as nausea, chills, slight fever, rise in blood pressure, retention of urine, burning sensations of the skin, fatigue, motor disturbances, breathing difficulty, constipation and muscle aches, particularly in the abdomen. Pain does not occur until one to two hours after the bite. The symptoms usually end after four days.

title: STAGE: REVIVAL OF 'THE APPLE TREE'
description: IN ''The Diary of Adam and Eve,'' the drollest of the three stories set to music that make up the 1966 Sheldon Harnick-Jerry Bock show ''The Apple Tree,'' the world's first man doesn't realize that his offspring are his own flesh and blood. His first boy, he reasons, is probably a very noisy fish. But once the creature begins sprouting teeth, he decides that it must be a bear. The fall from grace that has driven the couple from Eden to a new home in a place called Tonawanda, is depicted not as a punishment for their disobedience but a sequence of blunders orchestrated by the serpent who persuades a credulous Eve that chestnuts, not apples, are the forbidden fruit.

title: Magnifying the Eyewear Problem
description: Question: Why should New Yorkers pay as much as $75 to buy reading glasses that retail for about $12 in Connecticut and New Jersey? Answer: Because New York is one of only three states that still require a prescription to buy reading glasses. Reason: New York lawmakers, with the full backing of the Optical Retailers Association, say it's for their constituents' own good. Proposed Action: Repeal this costly rip-off.

title: Wilkinson Sale At $230 Million
description: Swedish Match A.B., a major match producer, said today that it had agreed to acquire its chief rival, Allegheny International Inc.'s Wilkinson Sword Group Ltd., for $230 million.

The show, starring Kenneth Walsh and Ray Leslee, with music by Mr. Leslee, comprises lyrics from various Shakespeare works, is directed by Mike Nichols and produced by the Shubert Organization. Mr. Evans said the postponement was allowing time for work on the production to continue.

Three weeks earlier Smile had finished fourth in the Gulfstream Breeders' Cup Handicap, and a week after that Lady's Secret was sixth of seven in the Donn Handicap.

title: Red Sox Owner Sells

He said he decided reluctantly to sell to Haywood Sullivan and Jean R. Yawkey because they wouldn't sell their shares to him. LeRoux has questioned the Red Sox's handling of negotiations with their holdout pitcher, Roger Clemens. He also reportedly had been interested in buying the New England Patriots. His two partners consistently sided with each other to form a majority against LeRoux in club decisions. Negotiations have reportedly gone on for several months, and the sale price has been reported at about $7 million.

title: Suicide Among Elderly
description: Recent reports of teen-agers taking their own lives have obscured the fact that, in the United States, people 65 years old and older commit suicide more frequently than do younger people. Past studies have shown that 17 percent of all suicides are committed by the 11 percent of the population 65 or older; now new research has found that suicide is increasing among the elderly.

title: Deport Karl Linnas To the Soviet Union
description: Karl Linnas, onetime commandant of a Nazi concentration camp, is alive and well in America. By all rights, he should be in the Soviet Union, where he has been tried and sentenced to death in absentia as a war criminal. However, because of efforts on his behalf by an improbable coalition that includes his ultraliberal lawyer - the former Attorney General Ramsey Clark - and the conservative former White House director of communications, Patrick J. Buchanan, Mr. Linnas may live out his days in freedom.

description: b-Net loss

title: VALLEY FORGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net of $61,060 for the quarter and a loss of $240,018 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and extraordinary credits of $323,181 and $1,008,297 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After loss of $86,287 for the quarter and net of $15,362 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and extraordinary credits of $153,152 and $836,512 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Acquit Demjanjuk: The Case Is Weak
description: The trial in Jerusalem of John Demjanjuk, who is accused of being Ivan the Terrible, has riveted the nation of Israel - understandably so. Treblinka is one of the horrific events of history, for which there is no defense. But for Mr. Demjanjuk, an American, there is a defense few of his adopted countrymen will ever hear.

title: RULING IN BABY M CASE IS DUE TODAY
description: When the decision in the Baby M custody case is announced today by a judge in Hackensack, N.J., legal scholars across the country will be watching for answers to fundamental questions raised by the dispute over a baby girl born one year ago.

title: FRENCH DOMINATE FALL FASHION
description: In the last days of the fall and winter ready-to-wear openings in Paris, everything began to jell. The change that had been hinted at earlier in Milan and in London crystallized. Fashion was undergoing a major change.

title: Japanese Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: OXOCO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,887,405, a loss on disposal of $9,020,565 and an extraordinary gain from extinguishment of debt of $98,657,162. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $14,890,413. The latest results include the additional downward adjustment of writedowns of the full cost pool of $30,958,472, the abandonment of certain foreign assets of $2,718,853 and asset revaluations of $6,616,396.

title: BIOGEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Roberts Seeks More Pledges
description: Oral Roberts, one day away from the end of his 10-day prayer vigil, appealed today for more donations to his missionary scholarship program.

title: Endotronics In Chapter 11
description: The founder of Endotronics Inc., once a fast-growing biotechnology company that sought cures for cancer and AIDS, resigned today after the company filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: JUDGE, CRITICIZING METHODS, DROPS 3 DOZEN DRUG CASES
description: A Brooklyn judge has dismissed about three dozen drug cases in the last two weeks, contending that the undercover police officers making the complaints were not qualified to determine whether the substances sold were drugs.

title: ANNIVERSARY OF A REVOLUTION: NEWTON'S PRINCIPIA TURNS 300
description: FEWER than 700 copies of the book are sold each year, and even specialists in the subjects it covers rarely read more than exerpts from the 600-page work. But on the the 300th anniversary of its publication, scientists on both sides of the Atlantic are gathering to acclaim it anew as the greatest and most influential scientific book ever written.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MARCH 31, 1987
description: Markets Stock and bond prices plunged in tumultuous selling set off by the unrelenting decline in the dollar. Pressure on both markets was intense from the start of trading as investors feared that an unchecked drop in the dollar would strengthen inflation and force interest rates higher; the currency has fallen decisively since Washington announced trade retaliation against Japan on Friday. The Dow Jones industrial average, off a stunning 79 points after a half-hour of trading, finished at 2,278.41, for a 57.39-point loss - its third-worst one-day drop. [ Page A1. ] Treasury bond prices fell sharply, hitting their lowest levels since last fall, as weakness in the dollar caused a modest amount of selling by foreign investors and cast a pall over the domestic market. [ D1. ] Stock index futures closed lower, partly recovering from a sharp drop in early trading. [ D26. ] Money managers predicted that stock prices would climb after a correction runs its course. [ D1. ] Stock traders contended that the Big Board's specialist system could have done a better job of stabilizing the market by placing its own capital at risk. [ D5. ] The dollar steadied against the Japanese yen in Western markets after an early flurry of selling in Tokyo and other overseas markets, but the dollar still finished below Friday's close. For the first time in more than a week, there was an absence of coordinated intervention by central banks to shore up the dollar. On the Comex, gold fell $1.60, to $421.10. [ D5. ] A new setup to stabilize exchange rates while maintaining them at ''present parities'' was advocated by Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France. [ D23. ] Companies Rupert Murdoch agreed to buy Harper & Row for $300 million, in a move to expand his global empire of publishing, film and broadcasting interests. The $65-a-share offer far exceeded two other bids made for the 170-year-old publishing house. [ A1. ] John S. R. Shad is donating most of a $30 million gift to the Harvard Business School to support a program on ethics. The departing S.E.C. chairman cited concern about the involvement of graduates from leading business schools in insider-trading abuses. [ D1. ] Time Inc. has trimmed about 200 magazine employees, both editorial and business, in the last three months, and may trim 200 more by November as part of a belt-tightening process. [ D1. ] The former owner of Home State Savings Bank was sentenced to three and a half years in prison and ordered to pay $22 million in restitution for his role in the thrift unit's collapse. [ D1. ] The Shearson stock sale has been designed to keep important executives and employees at the brokerage. The prospectus filed by American Express includes lucrative stock purchase plans. [ D14. ] Carl H. Lindner took charge of Penn Central in a management shake-up designed to move the company into ''the next phase of its growth.'' The possible spinoff of Penn Central's electronics subsidiaries will also be studied. [ D2. ] The Henley Group disclosed it owns a large stake in Santa Fe Southern Pacific, touching off takeover speculation. [ D10. ] The Economy President Reagan has entered a U.S.-Japan dispute on telecommunications. In a letter to Japan's Prime Minister, Mr. Reagan reasserted American requests that Japan honor a commitment to allow 33 percent foreign participation in a new telecommunication venture, according to Congressional aides. [ D6. ] The Federal ethics office has requested an inquiry by the Justice Department on whether Lee H. Henkel Jr. of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board violated criminal laws. The move relates to a proposal made by Mr. Henkel that would have aided a thrift unit with which he has had extensive business dealings. [ D13. ] New-home sales fell for a second consecutive month in February, declining by 2.7 percent. The drop was led by a 19.4 percent plunge in sales in the Northeast. [ D2. ] Today's Columns Corporate renewal is the latest concern of Robert Waterman, a co-author of ''In Search of Excellence.'' He has addressed those concerns by studying resurrected corporate giants, such as Ford, and ''masters of renewal,'' such as I.B.M. Talking Business. [ D2. ] The buyers of stock index put options won a rare victory in their battle with the call buyers. This contest has meant extraordinary growth for the four-year-old market. Market Place. [ D14. ]

title: John Kloss Dies at Age 49; Designed Women's Fashions
description: John Kloss, a versatile fashion designer whose clothes included the sexy, the sporting and some sensible, go-everywhere designs, died of carbon monoxide poisoning Wednesday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 49 years old.

title: SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
HUSTLER-FALWELL CASE WILL BE HEARD
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear Hustler magazine's appeal of a $200,000 award to the Rev. Jerry Falwell for his ''emotional distress'' over publication of a parody depicting the evangelist as an incestuous drunk.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The latest quarter includes the results of William M. Wilson, acquired in the third quarter of 1986.

title: DESIGNS SOUGHT FOR NEW WOMEN'S PARK
description: One hundred thirty-nine years ago, in a small village in upstate New York, a convention was held to demand equality for women. Today, on that site, known as the ''birthplace of the women's rights movement,'' a coin laundry stands.

title: LIBYAN JETS BOMB CHADIAN UNITS
description: Libyan jets bombed Chadian forces in northern Chad today and the Chadians consolidated positions won last week, the Government radio said.

title: SOVIET ATTACHE IN FRANCE IS LINKED TO SPY SUSPECTS
description: The French Government was reported today to be considering expelling a Soviet diplomat after newspaper disclosures that six people, arrested for spying two weeks ago, were supervised by a member of the Soviet Embassy here.

title: SHAMIR, SHARON AND ARENS GAIN SOLID CONTROL OF THE HERUT PARTY
description: The Herut Party convention ended relatively peacefully early today, with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, Ariel Sharon and Moshe Arens having won solid control of the party leadership from David Levy and his allies.

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $147,000 for the latest quarter and $137,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: European Farm Talks
description: Farm ministers of the European Community opened their first substantial debate today on a proposed freeze of guaranteed farm product prices for 1987. The bloc's executive commission is seeking to hold down prices to reduce the community's large farm surpluses.

title: Override or Ride With the President
description: The last acts of the highway bill drama draw to a close in Washington. President Reagan and Congress walk through the final paces of a legislative process marked as much by procrastination and politics as concern for the national interest. It took Congress more than a year to pass the bill and Mr. Reagan days to veto it. Now it rests once again on the Capitol Hill stage.

title: COMPUTER NETWORK TECHOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year was its initial year of product revenue.

title: ADVANCED SEMICONDUCTOR MAERIALS INTERNATIONAL NV reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax benefit of $836,000 for both the quarter and year. Results are in Netherlands guilders.

title: DEPARTING U.S. ENVOY CRITICIZES USE OF YOUNG MARINE GUARDS IN MOSCOW
description: Arthur A. Hartman, the departing Ambassador to the Soviet Union, said today that he believed the young, single Marine guards at the embassy in Moscow should be replaced by a more mature force less susceptible to temptation.

title: GORBACHEV FIRM ON ARMS PACT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev accused the Western allies tonight of introducing ''additional conditions and demands'' to block an agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union to remove their medium-range missiles from Europe.

title: PANEL URGES PROGRAM TO ARREST LOSS OF SPECIES
description: A Congressional advisory group today called for a coordinated program to arrest the decline in animal, plant, insect and microbe species it said are disappearing at a rate perhaps not seen since the loss of the dinosaurs 65 million years ago., The recommendation came in a 334-page report prepared over the last two years by the Office of Technology Assessment, an agency chartered by Congress to advise on scientific and technological issues.

title: U.S. AGENCY HEARS FIRST WITNESSES TELL OF AMTRAK COLLISION
description: The Conrail engines that collided with an Amtrak train north of here in early January had stopped, backed up a few feet and stopped again before being struck by the Amtrak train, a man who says he saw the accident told Federal investigators today.

title: TRADERS' GRIM READING OF A LARGELY SYMBOLIC ACT
description: The rout in the financial markets touched off by President Reagan's Friday announcement of trade sanctions against Japan suggests a grim reading by the world's traders of a largely symbolic act.

title: PRESENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Anchor Shares Are in Demand
description: Demand for stock in Anchor Savings Bank has been strong enough among customers, employees and residents of its market area that the bank will not need to make a public stock offering through securities dealers.

title: COURT HEARS PLEAS ON HINCKLEY'S GUN
description: On the sixth anniversary of John W. Hinckley Jr.'s attempt to assassinate President Reagan, which left Mr. Reagan's press secretary permanently disabled, a Federal appeals court heard arguments today in a suit for negligence and liability against the manufacturer of Mr. Hinckley's gun.

title: Terry Waite and Iranian Aides Said to Figure in Discussions
description: Asian diplomats here say talks have been under way in West Germany to determine the whereabouts of four Iranian diplomats who have been missing in Lebanon since 1982 and whose fate has been linked to that of the Anglican envoy Terry Waite.

title: Captains in Black Sea Sinking Are Given 15-Year Jail Terms
description: The captains of two ships that collided in the Black Sea in August with the loss of 400 lives were sentenced today to the maximum jail term of 15 years, the Tass press agency said.

title: LEGISLATORS IN BOTH PARTIES CRITICAL OF ETHICS PANEL
description: While opposition to Governor Cuomo's new commission on government ethics has been voiced publicly by only a handful of officials here, interviews with more than 50 legislators show that legislative hostility toward the commission is pervasive, cutting across party lines.

title: FLASH! NEW OFFERINGS FROM I.B.M.
description: GOOD evening, Mr. and Mrs. America and all the chips at sea, as Walter Winchell would probably start his column were he writing today. The focus of glamorous gossip has, after all, shifted from the Mecca of Hollywood to the ticky-tacky industrial buildings of Silicon Valley. Just as years ago the comings and goings of movie moguls and stars created by publicists were constantly chronicled, so now the giants of the silicon screen are stalked by paparazzi perpetually on the alert for signs of who is dining with whom and what the nuances of those meetings might portend for the world of personal computing.

title: Chirac Asks New Currency Setup
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France called on the industrial nations yesterday to establish a new framework to stabilize exchange rates while maintaining them at ''present parities.''

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Includes contribution of $1,620,000 from Elisra Electronic Systems Ltd., which the company recently sold for the quarter; and the year includes an after-tax charge of $818,000 attributable to Elisra. c-Includes a charge of $114,000 attributable to Elisra for the quarter; and the year includes a provision for claim settlements with the U.S. government in the amount of $867,000 and a contribution to income from Elisra of $711,000, or 15 cents a share.

title: MILTOPE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HAWAIIAN PEAK OFFERS CELESTIAL VANTAGE POINT
description: THE selection of Mauna Kea, the highest summit in Hawaii, as site for the gigantic National New Technology Telescope has insured that the dormant volcano will continue to be the world's chief center of astronomical observations far into the next century.

title: AIR CARGO EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August.

title: A Small Victory Against the Tide Of Condominiums
description: Oh boy, there is big money to be made in real estate these days. President Reagan has virtually ended Federal low- and moderate-income housing programs, so there is a terrific housing shortage. In a boom state such as New Jersey, where tenants have limited protection, it can be a field day for landlord investors. ''Condo conversion!'' they cry. In the first three months of the year, landlords filed to convert 4,114 rental units - as many as all the conversions in the state in 1985.

title: HYPNOSIS STILL PROVOKES SOME SKEPTICS
description: A fierce scientific debate is focusing on whether hypnosis involves a special state of awareness or, as challengers claim, is simply one person seeking to please another by cooperating with suggestions made to him.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
description: The 1986 results are restated as if the change in accounting had been in effect throughout this period, but does not include the cumulative effect of the change in accounting, and additional 48 cents a share. The company believes that, if included, it would not result in a meaningful comparison of earnings.

title: 'UGLY' STICKERS ARE TRIED TO CLEAR PATH FOR SWEEPER
description: Subtle it is not.

title: MURDOCH TO BUY HARPER & ROW IN SURPRISE DEAL
description: In a dramatic move to enter the American book publishing business, Rupert Murdoch has agreed to acquire Harper & Row Publishers for about $300 million, the two parties announced yesterday.

title: WOLF, HOWARD B INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
'WALTER CRONKITE AT LARGE' ON CBS
description: ''WALTER CRONKITE AT LARGE'' is just that; the dean of television correspondents reports on what interests him - a social issue, an underwater treasure and another dean. The other dean is George F. Kennan, and when Mr. Cronkite talks to him it is like a meeting on Mount Olympus; two Titans look from above. The CBS-TV News program can be seen on Channel 2 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: Consider Lotto 48 a Shot At the American Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: PANEL ASSAILS AIR FORCE ON B-1B BOMBER PROGRAM
description: The House Armed Services Committee today accused the Air Force of mismanaging the B-1B strategic bomber program, and committee leaders said they would examine the B-1B's successor, the advanced Stealth bomber, to determine whether it was susceptible to similar flaws.

title: 2 SAY SOVIET PLANS TO LET JEWS LEAVE IN LARGER NUMBERS
description: Two Western Jewish spokesmen said today that they had been told by senior Soviet officials that Moscow would soon permit a major increase in Jewish emigration, direct flights through Rumania to Israel and an improvement in the ability of Soviet Jews to study Hebrew and observe their religious traditions.

title: SEOUL MAKES IT EASY TO SAY GOODBYE
description: With the same singleminded drive that transformed South Korea's economy in little more than a generation, the Government here is pressing an ambitious program to groom aspiring emigrants for life overseas.

title: KNIGHT'S METHODS WIN ONCE MORE
description: Years before, on a basketball court in Philadelphia, another group in cream and crimson had passed this way. Soon after the thrilling climax of an evening in the Louisiana Superdome, Sharan Alford weaved through the mob to meet her son Steve in an embrace, just the way Mary Thomas had hugged her son Isiah six years ago.

title: WORLCO DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOPE AMID MARKET'S GLOOM
description: As stock prices plunged and rumors whipped through Wall Street yesterday, money managers scowled at the troubling numbers on their quotation machines. But despite a two-day drop that clipped a total of 94.18 points off the Dow Jones industrial average, they expressed confidence that prices would head higher after a correction runs its course.

title: NETTLES EARNS SPOT ON BRAVES
description: There is a little more gray around the temples, perhaps even a few more lines across the forehead. But Graig Nettles said today he could not allow himself to consider retirement. Five years after George Steinbrenner said he was in ''the twilight of his career,'' Nettles, now 42 years old, has won a job with the Atlanta Braves.

title: U.S. DOCUMENTS BACKDATED TO MEET JUDICIAL DEADLINE
description: Education Department officials have backdated documents to create the impression that they were complying with court-imposed deadlines for handling civil rights complaints, a top department administrator said today.

title: Procurement Wars
description: When Richard Godwin appeared before the House Armed Services Committee this month, some members expressed concern that bureaucratic infighting was thwarting his new job of imposing order on the military's immense weapons procurement system.

title: DOLLAR ENDS ON LOWER PLATEAU
description: The dollar steadied against the Japanese yen in Western currency markets late yesterday after an early flurry of selling in Tokyo and other Far Eastern markets, but the dollar still finished below Friday's close.

title: FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN LEADING RANKS OF HOMELESS, STUDY SAYS
description: The number of homeless people in American cities grew by a record number this winter, and for the first time families with children became the largest segment of the homeless population, according to a survey in 47 cities.

title: The Latest in New York City Tenant Harassment
description: To the Editor:

title: SYNALLOY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $33,829, a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $446,350 and the reversal of a tax credit of $460,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $202,973 and a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,300,168. d-After income from discontinued operations of $113,627 for the quarter and $520,387 for the year.

title: CUOMO SEEKS EMERGENCY BILL TO FINANCE STATE'S PAYROLL
description: Governor Cuomo acknowledged today that a new state budget would not be enacted by the midnight Tuesday deadline and called for emergency legislation to enable 144,000 state workers to be paid on Wednesday and Medicaid checks to be sent to hospitals and nursing homes.

title: British TV Deal in China
description: Scientific programs promoting Western industry will be shown on Chinese television starting this fall, the British publisher Robert Maxwell said today. The series is the result of an agreement by Mr. Maxwell's Pergamon GED International, China's national television service CCTV and the China International Trust Investment Corporation. Pergamon has asked companies to produce films describing their latest research.

title: Merrill Lynch Names Investment Strategist
description: Charles I. Clough Jr. is Merrill Lynch & Company's new chief investment strategist, a job in which he divines how the average client's account should be diversified in stocks, bonds and other investments, and what sectors of the stock market should be weighted most heavily.

title: AIDS VACCINE: RELENTLESS QUESTIONS
description: EVEN as scientific understanding of the AIDS virus advances, researchers working to develop an AIDS vaccine continue to be plagued by severe practical and ethical dilemmas.

title: PHONE ISSUE GIVEN PUSH BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan has personally intervened in a telecommunications dispute with Japan after its top communications official effectively rejected American demands for greater competition in the Japanese telecommunications market, Congressional aides said today.

title: And the Winner Is . . .
description: My 1986 movie year bore scant resemblance to the one celebrated by the Academy Awards. In my log, for instance, ''Platoon'' is a 1987 flick, since it didn't turn up at the Tally-Ho, our local cinema, until last month.

title: Illinois Capital Is Told To Hold a Referendum
description: A Federal judge today ordered this city to hold a referendum that would allow voters to choose a form of government that does not discriminate against blacks.

title: PREHISTORIC PORTRAIT OF A MARSUPIAL
description: THE first rock painting of an Ice Age animal to be found outside of Europe has been reported from a rock shelter north of Cairns in Queensland, Australia. It has been identified as a diprotodon, the largest marsupial that ever lived.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Norris Coleman, the Kansas State forward who was an all-Big Eight selection the last two seasons, has decided to give up his senior year of eligibility and apply for the N.B.A. draft. . . . The Milwaukee Bucks' Junior Bridgeman will be out for the rest of the season because of a torn cartilage in his right knee.

title: REAGAN NAMES DOMESTIC ADVISER
description: President Reagan today appointed T. Kenneth Cribb, a spokesman for the conservative movement, as his adviser for domestic affairs.

title: Haitians, Charter Approved, Look to Election
description: With the evident overwhelming endorsement of a new constitution, the focus of political activity in Haiti appeared today to be shifting from the widely criticized provisional Government to the job of electing a President.

title: JOSEPH S. MURPHY
description: Joseph S. Murphy, a former executive vice president of the American Arbitration Association and professor of Latin and Greek at Fordham University, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Northern Dutchess Hospital in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

title: 2 STATES DEFY U.S. OVER NUCLEAR ATTACK PLANNING
description: The Governors of Washington and Oregon are defying a Federal agency and refusing to take part in a ''game'' designed in part to test state civil defense responses after a nuclear attack.

title: Ex-U.S. Envoy to El Salvador May Get Post in Costa Rica
description: Deane R. Hinton has emerged as the leading candidate to become the new ambassador to Costa Rica, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: COMPETING FOR STUDENTS
description: RIVALRY between private vocational schools and publicly financed community colleges is becoming intense as both compete for the same shrinking pool of students. In the past, public institutions and independent colleges often accused the proprietary schools of objectionable, hard-sell marketing; but today nonprofit public and private colleges are often as aggressive as the profit-seeking vocational schools.

title: Careers; Electronic Servicing Managers
description: SERVICING computers, office automation systems, telecommunications equipment and other electronic wizardry is a fast-growing business.

title: Hambrecht Offers A Mutual Fund
description: Hambrecht & Quist Inc. said it had begun its first mutual fund, H&Q Healthcare Investors. The closed-end fund will focus on emerging-growth companies and will be at least 80 percent invested in industries such as biotechnology, diagnostics, health care services, pharmaceuticals and medical products. Hambrecht said up to 25 percent of the fund's investments could contain venture capital.

title: Data Plan for Securities Backed by Mortgages
description: Salomon Brothers and the First Boston Corporation, the leading distributors and traders of mortgage-backed securities, announced yesterday that they would jointly publish historical and projected prepayment rates for various kinds of mortgage-backed securities.

title: RANGERS BEAT STARS ON McPHEE'S GOAL
description: They were not up for an Oscar, and they certainly were not going for a national championship, but the Rangers went a long way toward winning back some of their peace of mind tonight. And they did it in a most improbable way.

title: No More Cigars
description: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is a powerful man. His every word and move is watched and analyzed by financial interests all over the world.

title: SMART SHOOTS BETTER CLOSE UP
description: One thing Keith Smart can't do, and that is throw the ball into the upper deck. He tried last night, oh, how he tried, a looping sidearm heave, but the ball never came close to reaching the cavernous heights of the Superdome.

title: NEW ALARM AS AFRICAN BEES HEAD THROUGH MEXICO
description: Africanized honeybees, feared for their tendency to sting with little provocation, are in Mexico and headed north, and that could mean trouble for United States agriculture, a bee specialist says.

title: Hart Is Endorsed by Texans
description: Lieut. Gov. William Hobby and other leading Texas Democrats today endorsed the Presidential candidacy of former Senator Gary Hart, Democrat of Colorado.

title: Don't Flood the Maya Vatican
description: Mexico and Guatemala are planning a series of dams along their border that would effectively destroy a thinly populated jungle paradise rich in Mayan ruins. If built, the dams would create a huge lake, as big as 500 square miles, flooding two major Maya sites, Piedras Negras and Yaxchilan. Fortunately, no bulldozers are moving yet. There's time to listen to the outraged protests of archeologists and environmentalists.

title: FOUL SHOOTING INDEED
description: The theories were as varied as one could imagine. From Steve Alford to Rony Seikaly, from zone defenses to the man-to-man, from Syracuse's Jim Boeheim to Indiana's Bobby Knight, each was supposed to play a significant role in determining this season's national collegiate champion.

title: Call Them Indispensable
description: Disappointing though Roger McDowell's loss is to the Mets, it's not quite the same, of course, as if Dave Righetti were to be on the Yanks' sideline a couple of months. The major leagues' 10 most important pitchers last season according to the percentage of team victories in which they figured, by either winning or saving games:

title: JUNO LIGHTING reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Tennis Umpire Banned
description: Jeremy Shales, the tennis umpire who has clashed with Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe, has been dismissed by the governing body of men's professional tennis. ''I am obviously shocked,'' Shales said in London. One of only five full-time professional umpires employed by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, he was dismissed after 18 months in his $25,000-a-year job.

title: NO WORK STOPPAGE EXPECTED
description: Labor contracts for 10,000 employees of the three largest newspapers in New York City expired at midnight last night. But representatives of unions and management said yesterday that negotiations would continue without interruption.

title: The Matter Of Finding Angels
description: AS you can tell by the television commercials for toilet tissue, the most sought-after consumer benefit is softness. As in ''Please don't squeeze the Charmin.''

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 7
description: The share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split which occurred in January 1987.

title: BROUGHER INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a capital loss of $40,456 for the quarter and a capital gain of $80,088 for the year. c-Net income d-Includes capital losses of $3,929 and $54,031 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: FOR 'MOONLIGHTING' COUPLE, A VERY PUBLIC PRIVATE AFFAIR
description: Maddie Hayes and David Addison will become lovers at 9 o'clock tonight, and ABC wants to make sure everyone knows it.

title: Harold Haskin Is Dead at 80; Ballet and Broadway Dancer
description: Harold Haskin, a ballet dancer and teacher, died on Sunday at South Nassau Hospital in Oceanside, L.I., after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: GAC LIQUIDATING TRUST reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said its net income increased substantially in 1986 as a result of substantially lower operating expenses, lower professional and consulting fees and as a result of a reduction of $2 million of the allowance for possible losses based on the results of new independent appraisals received by the Trust in 1986 with respect of certain of its undeveloped land. Share earnings represent units.

title: Market Place; Bearish Bettors Win a Big One
description: IF all markets consist of the struggle between hope and fear, the victors yesterday were those who had acted on fears of a steep market decline and, after record advances in the last year, bet on a downturn.

title: Acid Lakes in the Poconos
description: Much of the concern about acid rain has focussed on the vulnerable lakes of the Adirondack Mountains of upstate New York, where fish life has disappeared from some waters.But a new survey of available information on 160 lakes in the Pocono Mountain region of Pennsylvania has shown that many lakes there, too, are vulnerable. According to the survey, 7.5 percent of the lakes are already acidified and more than 70 percent are ''sensitive,'' to damage from acid rain.

title: Agency Approves AirCal Takeover
description: The Transportation Department gave its final approval to American Airlines' acquisition of AirCal Inc. for $225 million, saying there is no evidence the merger would harm competition. The department had given tentative approval to the deal in February.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing A Princely Effort: Prince Judex took over from the tiring pacesetters after entering the stretch and went on to a 1 1/2-length victory yesterday in the feature race at Aqueduct, a six-furlong allowance with a $26,000 purse. Nephrite outfinished the rest of the field of nine to be runner-up, four lengths ahead of Alert Paster. Prince Judex covered six furlongs on a fast track in 1:10 4/5 under Jerry Belmonte. The Maryland-bred 3-year-old son of Mr. Judex earned $15,600 for his owner, Edwin Wactel. It was the horse's third victory in seven starts this year. He paid $11.20 for $2 to win as the third choice. Tennis Mecir Gains in Italy: Second-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia beat Ugo Colombini of Italy, 6-2, 6-3, last night in the first round of the Fila Trophy indoor tennis tournament in Milan. The only other seeded player in action was fifth-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain, who beat Laurie Warder of Australia, 4-6, 6-2, 6-3. (AP) Turnbull First-Round Winner: Sixth-seeded Wendy Turnbull posted a 7-6, 6-2 victory over Leslie Allen yesterday in the opening round of the Lynda Carter-Maybelline United States Women's Indoor Tennis Championships at the Rutgers Athletic Center in Piscataway, N.J. Eighth-seeded Sylvia Hanika of West Germany edged Jo Durie of Britain, 3-6, 6-4, 6-3, in another first-round match.(AP) Kriek Struggles: Fifth-seeded Johan Kriek of South Africa was forced to go to a second-set tiebreaker last night before eliminating Marcel Freeman of Los Angeles, 6-3, 7-6, in the opening round of the Volvo-Chicago tennis tournament. Sixth-seeded Scott Davis of Bardmoor, Fla., took advantage of six double faults to eliminate Christo Steyn of South Africa, 6-3, 6-2. Earlier, seventh-seeded Christo van Rensburg of South Africa subdued Kelly Jones of San Diego, 6-3, 7-5, but not until an umpire's ruling cost Jones the 11th game of the second set. Also advancing were Eliot Telscher, Dan Goldie, Peter Fleming, Sammy Giammalva and Mel Purcell. In the Kriek-Freeman match, Kriek's superior court savvy helped break Freeman's service in each of the seventh and ninth games of the opening set. Kriek won the tiebreaker by 7-5. The Davis-Steyn match was marked by booming serves by both players. But in the eighth game of the opening set, Steyn could not hold his serve, hitting two returns out of bounds to go down by five games to three.(AP)

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
THE OLD WARLORD MEETS HIS MATCH: A WOMAN
description: At the end of a long lunch with his political supporters, Ramon Durano, the 81-year-old warlord of this seaside town, trotted from the veranda for a quick round of sparring with a punching bag.

title: PAKISTAN DOWNS AN AFGHAN INTRUDER
description: An Afghan warplane that intruded into a tense border area of Pakistan was shot down on Monday by Pakistani planes, the Defense Ministry announced.

title: ''PLATOON'' WINS OSCAR AS THE BEST MOVIE OF 1986
description: ''Platoon,'' a movie that was turned down by every major studio, was named best picture of the year tonight.

title: NASA Aide Cites Lightning In Failure of Atlas Rocket
description: There are strong indications that a lightning bolt sent a rocket tumbling out of control shortly after liftoff last week, forcing safety officers to destroy it, a top investigator with the space agency said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MARCH 31, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain on sale and exchange of assets of $165,028,000 and after an extraordinary charge of $22,529,000. c-Includes a gain on sale and exchange of assets of $13,034,000.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a loss of $5,377,000 from discontinued operations.

title: WAYWARD BUS REACHES DENVER AFTER ODYSSEY
description: A Trailways Bus finally arrived here after a three-and-a-half-day odyssey from Kansas City that included a holdup of passengers reminiscent of the Old West, a fierce spring blizzard and two breakdowns.

title: Defense Left Stars in Eclipse
description: They came into the game as the focal points of their respective teams, two players from backgrounds as diverse as their appearances.

title: FOX MAKING ITS DEBUT ON PRIME-TIME TV
description: About a year ago, Barry Diller, the chief executive officer of 20th Century-Fox, and Rupert Murdoch, the company's new owner, set out to find the youngest, most talented and least cynical minds in television and to make them an offer no one under 30 years old could refuse.

title: S.&P. INDEX PRICES FALL, THEN RECOVER IN PART
description: In a hectic session, stock index futures closed lower today for a second straight session on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, recovering partly from a sharp drop in early trading.

title: 12TH CASINO HOTEL OPENS, WITH 60-LANE ATTRACTION
description: The 12th casino hotel here opened today, with a difference that is spelled out in its name, the Showboat Hotel, Casino and Bowling Center.

title: Leonard Bout Irks Board
description: The head of Nevada's medical advisory board on boxing complained today that the board ''has been kept in the dark'' about Sugar Ray Leonard's once-damaged eye and said it would accept no responsibility if the fighter is injured in next week's middleweight championship fight against Marvelous Marvin Hagler.

title: OPERA: RIVERSIDE GROUP
description: ALTHOUGH ''The Threepenny Opera'' is, for the most part, the story of characters who aren't worth tuppence, Bertolt Brecht's book and lyrics inspired Kurt Weill to one of his most vivid and powerful scores. If one takes the play's ''message'' for the skewed and sour cynicism it is, this determinedly Germanic evocation of ''olde London'' can still provide an evening of good theater.

title: BRAMALEA LIMITED reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said effective in 1986, the results of Coseka Resources Ltd., Bramalea's energy subsidiary, are excluded from the consolidated financial statements. Consolidated results in 1985, including Coseka, were revenues of $460.8 million, earnings of $20.1 million, or 69 cents a share. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Borg-Warner's Stock Rises Again
description: The stock of the Borg-Warner Corporation remained active amid continued speculation the company might become a takeover target of the GAF Corporation, which last week increased its stake in Borg-Warner to 19.9 percent. Borg-Warner, the sixth most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, was up $2.875, closing at $47.125.

title: ESSEX COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $3,445,000 of certain Michigan systems sold in April 1985.

title: Jersey Authority's Refunding Bonds
description: The New Jersey Building Authority is tentatively offering $103.7 million of refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 7 1/8 percent for bonds due in 2013 and a variety of zero coupon issues through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain from sale of real estate of $409,000, or 5 cents a share, and includes the operating results of Development Corp. of America, which was acquired by Lennar in December 1986. The company said the year-ago quarter results include a loss of $90,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: 'MAX HEADROOM' SERIES PREMIERES ON ABC
description: ''MAX HEADROOM'' is back, this time as a weekly series, getting under way tonight at 10 o'clock on ABC. Created in Britain by Peter Wagg and Chrysalis Visual Programming, the computer-enhanced Max first came into view in this country on pay-cable's Cinemax as star of ''The Max Headroom Story: 20 Minutes Into the Future,'' a movie. Max then became the host of a series featuring rock videos and celebrity interviews. Before long, Max was publishing books and doing commercials for soft drinks. Max had become a marketing phenomenon, which is not terribly surprising inasmuch as Mr. Wagg has an extensive background in advertising and merchandising. Significantly, the first episode of this ABC series has been directed by Farhad Mann, described in a press release as the recipient of 58 international awards for his work in television commercials.

title: DEAN FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
NOVO CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $570,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $82,000 from tax credits. c-After a gain of $569,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $2.9 million from tax credits and an insurance settlement. The latest year net includes a charge of $600,000 from divestment of the company's investment in an unrelated business. Novo said other fourth quarter adjustments reduced earnings by approximately $300,000.

title: Shearson to Offer Stock Incentives to Employees
description: A prospectus filed yesterday by the American Express Company for the previously announced sale of stock in its Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. subsidiary includes lucrative stock purchase plans aimed at keeping key executives and employees in the fold.

title: Red and Blue
description: The House Democratic Caucus and the House Republican Conference will meet in a rare joint briefing session tomorrow to hear top Pentagon officials analyze Soviet military strength and the ability of the United States to respond to it.

title: I.B.M.'S 2-PRONGED OFFENSIVE
description: This is killer week at the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: TEXAS INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter loss includes a $2.6 million loss provision for the sale of domestic oil and gas properties concluded in March 1987. The results for the year of 1985 includes a credit of $6.7 million for previous overpayments of windfall profit tax expense. The latest results also include extraordinary gains of $247,000 for the quarter and $809,000 for the year. The year of 1985 includes an extraordinary gain of $425,000.

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $14,385,000 and $47,260,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and extraordinary losses of $1,126,000 for the quarter and $4,862,000 for the year. c-Includes investment gains of $20,894,000 for the quarter and $38,128,000 for the year.

title: Hungary Testing for AIDS
description: Hungary has introduced compulsory screening tests for citizens most likely to suffer from AIDS, according to a report by the official Hungarian press agency. It reported that 114 Hungarians had been found to be infected by the AIDS virus, but that the total was estimated at 6,000.

title: SORG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Sorg Inc. was formerly the Sorg Printing Co.

title: Head of U.S. Prison System To Step Down After 17 Years
description: Norman A. Carlson, director of the Federal prison system for the last 17 years, says he plans to announce in about a week that he is resigning to take a teaching position.

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,113,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Farr-Fetched
description: Steve Farr, Kansas City Royal reliever, to the suggestion that his shoulder problem might be more mental than physical: ''How can it be mental? I don't even have a college education.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bally Manufacturing Corp., Chicago, whose interests include casinos, said its executive vice president and chief financial officer, Donald B. Romans, had decided to take early retirement to pursue other interests but would remain as a financial consultant. Paul J. Johnson will succeed him as chief financial officer.

title: Generals, You're Kidding
description: Just what the Pentagon and the Federal budget need - mobile nuclear reactors to provide electricity for military bases in a protracted nuclear war. And for only between $65 million and $75 million each. Now, let's see, we'll need a few hundred. Over five years that would add up to a mere $20 billion, barring cost overruns. At that price, get them while they last.

title: TOP AIDES CHEER REAGAN'S PEP TALK
description: President Reagan today sounded a highly optimistic note on the prospects for the remainder of his term as he told several thousand senior Administration officials that ''we're going to have the greatest fourth quarter in Presidential history.''

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE taffeta was stained with tears at the fashion shows in Paris in the last two weeks. The sadness was understandable: upon their arrival, the style set learned that Antonio Lopez, a much-beloved and renowned fashion illustrator, had just died in Los Angeles of AIDS.

title: Texaco's Appeal
description: Texaco Inc., as expected, asked a Texas appeals court in Houston to reverse its decision last month upholding most of an $11.1 billion judgment against the company, or order a new trial in its three-year-old legal dispute with the Pennzoil Company. The appellate court is expected to make its final ruling by mid-May. Lawyers for Texaco have said they will take the case to the Texas Supreme Court and, if necessary, the United States Supreme Court, if the appellate court does not change its ruling.

title: Anglers Wading Forth
description: Although the unusually balmy weather of last year will not greet them, most of the anglers who have planned to go forth tomorrow for the opening of the trout season in New York State will remain on course. What else can they do, having waited all fall and winter? Any heavily populated state with an abundance of varied trout habitat and distinct climatic zones - and New York so qualifies - has many exceptions to its general angling regulations. These exceptions are all in the fishing, hunting and trapping guide one gets when one purchases a fishing license.

title: SENTIMENTAL APPEAL IN 'SUNFLOWERS'
description: THE price paid last night for Vincent van Gogh's ''Sunflowers'' is best regarded in the context of the even larger lunacies that arise when too many people suddenly have more money than they know how to get rid of. It bears no relation whatever to any rational scale of values, to the status of this particular painting within van Gogh's total output or to its present condition. It does, however, have the immediate-recognition factor that is now much prized, together with a sentimental appeal that should not be underestimated.

title: Don't Bail Out Semiconductor Industry's Losers
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTIGATION OF THRIFT REGULATOR SOUGHT
description: The Government ethics office has asked the Justice Department to investigate whether a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board violated criminal laws when he sought to aid a California thrift institution with which he has had extensive business dealings.

title: RJR Says Tobacco Spinoff Unlikely
description: RJR Nabisco Inc., which has considered spinning off its tobacco operations, said such a move was not likely in the near future. A company spokesman said RJR Nabisco would evaluate other options for its tobacco business, but he declined to give details.

title: 3Com Introduces New Work Station
description: The 3Com Corporation, a manufacturer of computer networks, introduced a computer work station designed specifically for use in a network. The 3Station, which will be available in May for $1,895, lacks a disk drive or expansion slots, so it requires a network and file server to function.

title: Haiti Speaks
description: Something remarkable happened in Haiti this week. A people long cheated of political liberty and still mired in unbelievable poverty turned out massively to approve a new democratic constitution. Drawing lessons from the unhappy past of this hemisphere's second oldest republic, the new charter restricts presidential power, increases civilian control over the military and enshrines basic human and economic rights. It also establishes procedures for November's presidential elections.

title: BEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
PALM BEACH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-Net income

title: Edson Beers Gould Jr. Dies; Influential Stock Forecaster
description: Edson Beers Gould Jr., an influential stock market forecaster who retired in 1983, died Sunday at a hospital in West Reading, Pa. He was 85 years old and lived in New Ringgold, Pa.
